<DATA>{"Bisharp": {"Abilities": {"defiant": 3.285887392723124, "innerfocus": 0.021785806424715393, "pressure": 4.078020766129509e-06}, "Items": {"eviolite": 0.9994377224213252}, "Spreads": {"Adamant:252/252/0/0/4/0": 0.18760250294065042, "Adamant:60/252/0/0/0/196": 0.6159906128124236}, "Moves": ["protect", "ironhead", "suckerpunch", "assurance"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.24584991234143147, "dark": 0.645348551090259}, "Teammates": ["Gothitelle", "Rillaboom", "Volcarona", "Primarina", "Gengar", "Kommo-o"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Bisharp is a niche but dangerous offensive presence in VGC, leveraging its pre-evolution item Eviolite to patch up its otherwise frail bulk while it dishes out powerful priority and STAB attacks. With an overwhelming preference for Defiant, it punhes Intimidate and stat-drops with an immediate +2 Attack boost, turning the most common support abilities into setup fodder. Its move set is hyper-focused on immediate damage—Protect for pivoting, Iron Head and Sucker Punch for reliable and priority Steel/Dark coverage, and Assurance to exploit spread or double-target situations—while Tera Ghost and Tera Dark let it dodge Fighting-type blows or further amplify its Dark STAB. Although its teammate pool is small, the Gothitelle pairing hints at a Trick Room–centric or control shell where Bisharp can operate under speed control or behind Follow Me support.</OUTPUT>

input:
Write the 'full_analysis' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Bisharp": {"Abilities": {"defiant": 3.285887392723124, "innerfocus": 0.021785806424715393, "pressure": 4.078020766129509e-06}, "Items": {"eviolite": 0.9994377224213252}, "Spreads": {"Adamant:252/252/0/0/4/0": 0.18760250294065042, "Adamant:60/252/0/0/0/196": 0.6159906128124236}, "Moves": ["protect", "ironhead", "suckerpunch", "assurance"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.24584991234143147, "dark": 0.645348551090259}, "Teammates": ["Gothitelle", "Rillaboom", "Volcarona", "Primarina", "Gengar", "Kommo-o"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Bisharp’s viability hinges on Defiant: in a metagame saturated with Incineroar, Landorus-T, and other Intimidate users, every attempted attack drop becomes a free Swords Dance. Eviolite is the item of choice on almost every set, effectively giving Bisharp the bulk of a fully-evolved physical tank and letting it survive neutral Earthquakes, Heat Waves, and Dazzling Gleams that would otherwise OHKO it. The two most common spreads illustrate two philosophies: the 252/252 Adamant set maximizes immediate power and guarantees KOs on frail threats like Flutter Mane or Tornadus after a Defiant boost, while the 60 HP / 252 Atk / 196 Spe spread hits 91 Speed—enough to outrun uninvested base 70s and most support Pokémon—while still preserving respectable bulk. Iron Head is the mandatory Steel STAB, flinching opposing Fairies and punishing Xerneas and Sylveon switch-ins. Sucker Punch gives Bisharp a +1 priority option that, after a Defiant boost, cleanly KOes Dragapult, Calyrex-S, and other faster threats. Assurance is the sleeper pick: under doubles field conditions it becomes a 120-Base Power Dark move that deletes Psychic- and Ghost-types expecting to survive a Sucker Punch. Protect is non-negotiable for scouting choice-locked moves, stalling Dynamax turns, and enabling partner set-up or speed control. Tera Ghost removes Bisharp’s sole Fighting weakness, letting it survive Close Combat from Iron Hands or Sacred Sword from Zamazenta, whereas Tera Dark boosts both Sucker Punch and Assurance into nuke-tier damage while preserving the Dark typing’s useful Psychic immunity.</OUTPUT>

input:
Write the 'matchup_overview' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Bisharp": {"Abilities": {"defiant": 3.285887392723124, "innerfocus": 0.021785806424715393, "pressure": 4.078020766129509e-06}, "Items": {"eviolite": 0.9994377224213252}, "Spreads": {"Adamant:252/252/0/0/4/0": 0.18760250294065042, "Adamant:60/252/0/0/0/196": 0.6159906128124236}, "Moves": ["protect", "ironhead", "suckerpunch", "assurance"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.24584991234143147, "dark": 0.645348551090259}, "Teammates": ["Gothitelle", "Rillaboom", "Volcarona", "Primarina", "Gengar", "Kommo-o"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Bisharp enjoys overwhelmingly positive matchups against Intimidate archetypes—Incineroar, Landorus-T, and Arcanine all grant it a free +2 Attack the moment they enter the field. It also pressures Fairy-types such as Sylveon, Primarina, and Xerneas with Iron Head, and deletes Ghost- and Psychic-types like Calyrex-S, Indeedee, and Gengar with boosted Sucker Punch or Assurance. Conversely, Bisharp struggles against faster Fighting-types such as Iron Hands, Zamazenta, and Iron Valiant, which can either tank a Sucker Punch and OHKO back or simply outspeed and KO before Eviolite can be leveraged. Fire-types like Heatran, Volcarona, and Torkoal roast it, while bulky Waters such as Toxapex and Rotom-W can burn or Volt-Switch around it. Electric Terrain teams featuring Pincurchin + Iron Hands or Iron Moth also give it trouble, as they negate Sucker Punch mind-games and bring faster special attackers that can break through Eviolite with Overheat or Sludge Bomb.</OUTPUT>

input:
Write a detailed 'role_description' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Bisharp": {"Abilities": {"defiant": 3.285887392723124, "innerfocus": 0.021785806424715393, "pressure": 4.078020766129509e-06}, "Items": {"eviolite": 0.9994377224213252}, "Spreads": {"Adamant:252/252/0/0/4/0": 0.18760250294065042, "Adamant:60/252/0/0/0/196": 0.6159906128124236}, "Moves": ["protect", "ironhead", "suckerpunch", "assurance"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.24584991234143147, "dark": 0.645348551090259}, "Teammates": ["Gothitelle", "Rillaboom", "Volcarona", "Primarina", "Gengar", "Kommo-o"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Bisharp functions as a mid-speed, high-reward offensive pivot that punishes the opponent for using support moves or Intimidate. Its primary role is to switch in on predicted Intimidate or Parting Shot users, immediately gain +2 Attack, and threaten a sweep with dual priority and strong STAB coverage. In Trick Room squads it can operate as a secondary attacker that still functions outside reverse speed control thanks to Sucker Punch, while in Gothitelle shells it appreciates Fake Out or Follow Me support to buy a free turn for Protect or Sucker Punch mind-games. Because it is not fully evolved, Bisharp is uniquely reliant on Eviolite to survive neutral or resisted hits; consequently it prefers to enter the field after a KO or via a slow pivot like Parting Shot Incineroar or U-turn Rillaboom rather than hard-switching into attacks. Dynamaxing is situational: Max Darkness sets the damage benchmark for end-game cleaning, while Max Steelspike can boost its Defense to ludicrous levels alongside Eviolite, but the loss of Sucker Punch priority is often too costly.</OUTPUT>

input:
Create the 'synergy_breakdown' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Bisharp": {"Abilities": {"defiant": 3.285887392723124, "innerfocus": 0.021785806424715393, "pressure": 4.078020766129509e-06}, "Items": {"eviolite": 0.9994377224213252}, "Spreads": {"Adamant:252/252/0/0/4/0": 0.18760250294065042, "Adamant:60/252/0/0/0/196": 0.6159906128124236}, "Moves": ["protect", "ironhead", "suckerpunch", "assurance"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.24584991234143147, "dark": 0.645348551090259}, "Teammates": ["Gothitelle", "Rillaboom", "Volcarona", "Primarina", "Gengar", "Kommo-o"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Gothitelle is Bisharp’s most common partner for good reason: Shadow Tag guarantees the opponent cannot escape a +2 Bisharp, and Fake Out or Follow Me lets it set up safely. Rillaboom provides Grassy Glide priority, breaks enemy Focus Sashes, and removes Psychic Terrain that would block Sucker Punch. Volcarona offers Tailwind or Rage Powder redirection, covers Bisharp’s Fire and Fighting weaknesses with Heat Wave and Air Slash, and appreciates Dark-type Pursuit-style pressure on Psychic-types. Primarina is a bulky Fairy that can tank Fighting-type hits and retaliate with Hyper Voice or Moonblast, while Bisharp scares away Steel-types that trouble Primarina. Gengar forms a Ghost-spam core: both appreciate Tera Ghost, and Gengar’s Sludge Bomb or Shadow Ball can weaken shared checks like Toxapex or Sylveon. Kommo-o gives a second Defiant user, stacks Clangorous Soul buffs, and provides Wide Guard to block Heat Wave or Dazzling Gleam that would otherwise KO Bisharp.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Bisharp": {"Abilities": {"defiant": 3.285887392723124, "innerfocus": 0.021785806424715393, "pressure": 4.078020766129509e-06}, "Items": {"eviolite": 0.9994377224213252}, "Spreads": {"Adamant:252/252/0/0/4/0": 0.18760250294065042, "Adamant:60/252/0/0/0/196": 0.6159906128124236}, "Moves": ["protect", "ironhead", "suckerpunch", "assurance"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.24584991234143147, "dark": 0.645348551090259}, "Teammates": ["Gothitelle", "Rillaboom", "Volcarona", "Primarina", "Gengar", "Kommo-o"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Faster Fighting-types are public enemy number one: Iron Hands, Zamazenta, and Iron Valiant all tank a Sucker Punch and OHKO with Close Combat or Sacred Sword. Special Fire-types such as Heatran, Volcarona, and Torkoal roast Bisharp through Eviolite, especially under Sun. Bulky Water-types like Toxapex and Rotom-W can burn with Scald or Volt-Switch for chip, while Milotic with Competitive flips the script by gaining +2 Special Attack when Bisharp’s partner uses Intimidate. Terrain control is crucial: Psychic Terrain from Indeedee or Electric Terrain from Pincurchin blocks Sucker Punch, leaving Bisharp prone to faster special attackers like Iron Moth or Dragapult. Finally, passive damage—burn, Rocky Helmet, or Iron Barbs from Ferrothorn—quickly wears down Eviolite Bisharp, so status and chip must be managed carefully with Protect and partner healing.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Bisharp": {"Abilities": {"defiant": 3.285887392723124, "innerfocus": 0.021785806424715393, "pressure": 4.078020766129509e-06}, "Items": {"eviolite": 0.9994377224213252}, "Spreads": {"Adamant:252/252/0/0/4/0": 0.18760250294065042, "Adamant:60/252/0/0/0/196": 0.6159906128124236}, "Moves": ["protect", "ironhead", "suckerpunch", "assurance"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.24584991234143147, "dark": 0.645348551090259}, "Teammates": ["Gothitelle", "Rillaboom", "Volcarona", "Primarina", "Gengar", "Kommo-o"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Gothitelle @ Focus Sash, Shadow Tag, Modest 252 HP / 252 SpA / 4 SpD – Fake Out, Shadow Ball, Ally Switch, Protect. Bisharp @ Eviolite, Defiant, Adamant 60 HP / 252 Atk / 196 Spe – Protect, Iron Head, Sucker Punch, Assurance, Tera Ghost. Rillaboom @ Assault Vest, Grassy Surge, Adamant 252 HP / 252 Atk / 4 Def – Grassy Glide, Wood Hammer, U-turn, Knock Off. Volcarona @ Charti Berry, Flame Body, Timid 252 HP / 252 SpA / 4 Spe – Heat Wave, Air Slash, Tailwind, Protect. Rotom-W @ Sitrus Berry, Levitate, Bold 252 HP / 252 Def / 4 SpA – Volt Switch, Hydro Pump, Will-O-Wisp, Protect. Landorus-T @ Choice Scarf, Intimidate, Jolly 252 Atk / 252 Spe / 4 HP – Earthquake, Rock Slide, U-turn, Crunch. The core idea is to lead Gothitelle + Bisharp: Fake Out or Ally Switch buys a free Defiant boost, after which Bisharp can snowball. Rillaboom and Volcarona cover Fire, Water, and Grass weaknesses, while Rotom-W and Scarf Lando give speed control and pivoting options for the late game.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Dugtrio": {"Abilities": {"arenatrap": 3.000500273487618, "sandveil": 0.0011905747270954392, "sandforce": 0.7668220609183074}, "Items": {"focussash": 0.7463549988661381, "lifeorb": 0.18087252163781378}, "Spreads": {"Jolly:4/252/0/0/0/252": 0.20705624876760254, "Jolly:0/252/4/0/0/252": 0.382992905840519, "Serious:0/252/4/0/0/252": 0.28902617079423554}, "Moves": ["suckerpunch", "earthquake", "endeavor", "stompingtantrum"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.47571596829973006, "fairy": 0.47067383444870226}, "Teammates": ["Tyranitar", "Indeedee-F", "Armarouge", "Tauros-Paldea-Aqua", "Gallade", "Golduck"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Dugtrio carves a unique niche in VGC as a hyper-offensive trapper that deletes slower foes with Arena Trap, turning 2v2 into temporary 2v1s. A Focus Sash set with Jolly 252/252 EVs guarantees it survives one hit, letting it fire off STAB Earthquakes, priority Sucker Punches, and the deadly combo of Endeavor + Sash to drop a full-HP target to 1 HP. Ghost Tera is preferred to block Extreme Speed and Fake Out while maintaining a Ground immunity, though Fairy Tera is equally common to dodge Grassy Glide and resist Dragon. Sand Force variants holding Life Orb trade reliability for extra power under Tyranitar’s sand, but the sheer utility of Sash + Arena Trap keeps it the dominant choice.</OUTPUT>

input:
Write the 'full_analysis' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Dugtrio": {"Abilities": {"arenatrap": 3.000500273487618, "sandveil": 0.0011905747270954392, "sandforce": 0.7668220609183074}, "Items": {"focussash": 0.7463549988661381, "lifeorb": 0.18087252163781378}, "Spreads": {"Jolly:4/252/0/0/0/252": 0.20705624876760254, "Jolly:0/252/4/0/0/252": 0.382992905840519, "Serious:0/252/4/0/0/252": 0.28902617079423554}, "Moves": ["suckerpunch", "earthquake", "endeavor", "stompingtantrum"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.47571596829973006, "fairy": 0.47067383444870226}, "Teammates": ["Tyranitar", "Indeedee-F", "Armarouge", "Tauros-Paldea-Aqua", "Gallade", "Golduck"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Dugtrio’s claim to fame is Arena Trap, an ability that removes the opponent’s ability to switch in doubles. In best-of-three VGC this is invaluable: lead Dugtiro next to a setup sweeper such as Calm Mind Armarouge or Swords Dance Gallade, trap the slower threat, KO or cripple it, and grant your partner a free turn to boost. 110 base Speed with a Jolly nature outpaces the crowded 100/95 tier (Garchomp, Lando-T, Meowscarada) and lets it underspeed its own partner for spread-move synergy. Earthquake is the obligatory STAB, 2HKOing most neutral targets and OHKOing Toxapex, Heatran and Gholdengo after chip. Sucker Punch patches up its mediocre Attack by giving it a 70 BP priority move that punishes faster threats like Flutter Mane and Chien-Pao. Stomping Tantrum offers a second Ground STAB that doesn’t hit your ally, crucial for doubles, while also doubling power if the previous move failed—ideal after a predicted Protect. Endeavor is the set’s ace: after Focus Sash pops, Dugtrio drops a 400-HP Kyogre to 1, letting any teammate finish it off. EV spreads are straightforward: max Speed to trap as much of the metagame as possible, max Attack to secure KOs, and the remaining 4 EVs are split between HP and Defense to slightly manipulate download and Gyro Ball damage. Ghost Tera removes Normal- and Fighting-type weaknesses, blocks priority, and turns Earthquake into a neutral hit against Corviknight and Skarmory. Fairy Tera instead offers a Dragon immunity and a valuable resistance to Dark and Bug, notably letting it survive Kingambit’s Sucker Punch and retaliate. Sand Force sets trade the safety net of Sash for 30% stronger Earthquakes under sand, but the omnipresence of spread moves, priority, and weather wars makes Focus Sash the far more consistent item.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Dugtrio": {"Abilities": {"arenatrap": 3.000500273487618, "sandveil": 0.0011905747270954392, "sandforce": 0.7668220609183074}, "Items": {"focussash": 0.7463549988661381, "lifeorb": 0.18087252163781378}, "Spreads": {"Jolly:4/252/0/0/0/252": 0.20705624876760254, "Jolly:0/252/4/0/0/252": 0.382992905840519, "Serious:0/252/4/0/0/252": 0.28902617079423554}, "Moves": ["suckerpunch", "earthquake", "endeavor", "stompingtantrum"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.47571596829973006, "fairy": 0.47067383444870226}, "Teammates": ["Tyranitar", "Indeedee-F", "Armarouge", "Tauros-Paldea-Aqua", "Gallade", "Golduck"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Dugtiro excels against bulky offense and balance cores that rely on a single slow pivot. It traps and eliminates Toxapex, Slowking-G, Clodsire and Heatran, dismantling defensive backbones and allowing partners like Volcarona or Iron Valiant to snowball. Against rain, it outspeeds and OHKOs Pelipper with Stone Edge (or 2HKOs with Earthquake) while Endeavor cripples a full-HP Kyogre. Sun teams hate losing Torkoal or Indeedee-F to Sucker Punch, breaking Psychic Terrain for the rest of the match. Stall and hard Trick Room are tougher: Dugtrio can’t trap Hatterene (Magic Bounce) or Indeedee-F (Psychic Terrain) and dies to Moonblast or expanding Force, so it must rely on prediction and partner support. Priority from Kingambit, Dragonite and Scizor bypasses its Speed and pops Sash, while Corviknight and Skarmory wall it completely unless it Terastallizes. Flutter Mane, Iron Bundle and Chien-Pao all outspeed and OHKO, forcing Dugtrio to either Sucker Punch on the switch or protect and pivot.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Dugtrio is a lead or mid-game trapper whose sole purpose is to remove one specific slow threat and tilt the 2v2 into a 2v1. It functions as a “delete button” versus defensive cores, weather setters, or setup sweepers that would otherwise check your win condition. After it has done its job, it becomes a fast pivot that can still pick off weakened foes with Sucker Punch or emergency Endeavor anything that survived. Its mere presence warps team preview: opponents must decide whether to lead their slow pivot (risking immediate trap) or their faster offensive pair (risking a bad matchup into your own sweepers).</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Tyranitar is the most common partner, setting sand to boost Sand Force variants while providing special bulk and a Dark-type to absorb Ghost- and Psychic-type moves aimed at Dugtrio. Indeedee-F is equally vital: Psychic Terrain blocks priority that would pop Sash, while Follow Me lets Dugtrio fire off free Earthquakes or Endeavors. Armarouge loves having Clodsire and Toxapex removed so it can spam Expanding Force and Armor Cannon; Dugtiro traps them, drops to 1 HP, and lets Armarouge finish the job and begin Calm Mind sweeping. Gallade shares the same Speed tier and appreciates Psychic Terrain to safely set up Swords Dance while Dugtrio eliminates Dragapult or Aegislash.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Priority users are public enemy #1: Kingambit’s Sucker Punch, Dragonite’s Extreme Speed and Scizor’s Bullet Punch all pop Sash and KO. Psychic Terrain from Indeedee-F or Tapu Lele blocks Endeavor strats and lets bulky Psychics retaliate. Flying-types with Roost—Corviknight, Skarmory, Togekiss—wall Dugtrio completely unless it Terastallizes to Ghost and even then can stall with Defense boosts. Faster offensive threats (Flutter Mane, Iron Bundle, Chien-Pao, Meowscarada) outspeed and OHKO, forcing Dugtrio to predict a Sucker Punch or protect. Intimidate and burn cripple its already modest Attack, while Rocky Helmet users like Garchomp and Toxapex punish contact and break Sash. Finally, best-of-one formats reduce Dugtrio’s effectiveness because opponents can bring an unexpected Flying-type or priority user and invalidate the trap.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>The spread data show two dominant Modest builds: a 196/92 bulk-focused set and a 188/116 physically-defensive one, both investing just enough Speed to creep other slow pivots while pouring the rest into HP and one defense. Parabolic Charge is the crux of the set, turning Bellibolt into a self-sustaining tank that punishes passive play; Thunderbolt is chosen for immediate power, VoltSwitch maintains momentum, and Protect is near-mandatory for double-target formats. Assault Vest is the most common item (≈37%), letting it stomach special hits from the likes of Flutter Mane or Tera-Iron Bundle while still firing back with boosted Electric moves. Weakness Policy (≈16%) turns Bellibolt into a win-condition if you can bait a super-effective hit, a game plan enabled by its 116+ Def EVs and natural 109/91/83 bulk. Magnet (≈28%) sits in between, giving a free Life-Orb boost to Electric moves without recoil, which synergises perfectly with Tera Electric for a 1.95× STAB multiplier. Tera Grass is the secondary option (≈35%) to flip the Ground weakness and punish Water/Ground staples such as Gastrodon and Swampert on the switch. Electromorphosis is the only viable ability, effectively giving a free Charge every time Bellibolt is attacked, turning uninvested Parabolic Charge into a 120 BP healing nuke after STAB and boost. The listed teammates—Rillaboom, Annihilape, Alolan Ninetales, Garchomp, Incineroar, and Dondozo—form a collection of slow, high-control Pokémon that appreciate Electric’s Flying/Water match-ups and can cover Bellibolt’s Ground vulnerability with priority or terrain.</OUTPUT>

Water Pulse becomes a pseudo-Hydro Pump with perfect accuracy, Dark Pulse grants reliable flinch chances against slower threats, Aura Sphere hits Steel and Normal types for clean damage, and Dragon Pulse rounds out coverage against opposing Dragons. The Modest 252/252 spread maximizes this damage output, but leaves Clawitzer at a mere base 59 Speed, meaning it will usually move after many common threats. Tera Grass is preferred to flip Rotom-Wash, Miraidon, and Rillaboom matchups, turning Clawitzer’s Water weakness into a resistance and allowing it to tank Grassy Glides or Thunderbolts that would otherwise KO. Life Orb is the dominant item, giving every attack a noticeable bump without locking Clawitzer into a choice, preserving flexibility in doubles where target selection is crucial. The Pokémon’s weaknesses are its middling bulk and low Speed; it needs either Tailwind or rain support to function optimally, and even then it must be positioned carefully to avoid taking heavy damage before it can attack.</OUTPUT>

Regenerator is the preferred ability on about 28% of teams, letting it pivot out to reset terrain and HP, but the vast majority run Oblivious to guarantee field control. Leftovers and Covert Cloak are the only common items, with Cloak chosen to ignore Fake Out flinches and secondary effects like Kingambit’s Defiant or Garganacl’s Salt Cure chip. EV spreads are almost exclusively Relaxed, either 76/180 bulk to survive Urshifu Wicked Blow or max physical bulk to stonewall Garchomp and Palafin. output: <OUTPUT>Slowbro’s base 110/80/80 defenses plus access to Regenerator and Oblivious give it a unique support profile: it can absorb Fake Out, ignore Taunt, and still fire off accurate spread Water moves or click Yawn to force switches. Muddy Water’s 85% accuracy and 30% accuracy drop chance is preferred over Scald on more offensive teams, but Scald’s 30% burn remains valuable into physical threats like Chien-Pao, Kingambit, and opposing Garchomp. Trick Room is the primary speed-control option, turning Slowbro itself into a 34-Speed setter that underspeeds most of the metagame after room is up. Yawn is a spammable disruption tool that punishes Protect stalling and forces double targets onto Slowbro, letting partners set up or reposition. The chosen EV spreads highlight two philosophies: 252 HP / 76 Def / 180 SpD Relaxed with a 0 Speed IV lets Slowbro survive Jolly Urshifu Wicked Blow into Close Combat, while 252 HP / 252 Def Relaxed maximizes physical bulk to check Garchomp, Palafin, and Dragonite. Tera Grass is the standout typing, removing the Electric weakness that plagues most Water-types and adding a crucial resistance to Rage Powder Spore from Amoonguss, while Tera Dark blocks Prankster Thunder Wave from Whimsicott and Grimmsnarl and makes Slowbro immune to Fake Tears. Covert Cloak usage (≈40%) is rising because it blanks not only Fake Out flinch but also Garganacl’s Salt Cure chip, Glimmora’s poison, and Kingambit’s Defiant boosts from Icy Wind or Snarl. Regenerator sets prefer Leftovers for incremental recovery, but the two items are often interchangeable depending on whether the team needs more pivoting or more status immunity.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Slowbro loves facing physical attackers that rely on contact effects—Garchomp’s Rough Skin, Palafin’s Jet Punch, and Dragonite’s Extreme Speed all lose value when Slowbro can simply click Yawn or Tera Grass to tank and force switches. It flips the Amoonguss matchup by ignoring Rage Powder and either firing Muddy Water drops or setting Trick Room while Amoonguss can only Spore into Covert Cloak. Against Kingambit, Slowbro can burn with Scald or drop accuracy with Muddy Water, but must watch for Supreme Overlord boosts; Tera Dark blocks Sucker Punch mind-games. Iron Hands is a mixed bag: Slowbro can tank Wild Charge and retaliate with burns, but a +1 Ice Punch still 2HKOs even through Tera Grass. Electric Terrain teams featuring Pincurchin + Iron Hands or Regieleki pressure Slowbro hard—Tera Grass helps, but Regieleki’s Thunder Cage plus chip can still wear it down. Sun teams with Torkoal and Venusaur outspeed and OHKO with Solar Beam unless Slowbro has already set Trick Room; even then, Torkoal’s Eruption under Sun does 60-70% through Tera Grass. Flutter Mane and Iron Valiant ignore Oblivious with their pure damage, and a Specs Moonblast or Booster Energy Spirit Break cleanly KO. Finally, Gholdengo’s Good as Gold blocks Yawn and Trick Room, forcing Slowbro to attack into a 4x resist or switch out to reset.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Slowbro operates as a semi-room setter and bulky pivot that compresses speed control, disruption, and Water-type offense into one slot. It leads when the opponent relies on Fake Out or Taunt to stop setup, thanks to Oblivious and Covert Cloak blanking both. Once Trick Room is up, Slowbro becomes one of the slowest viable setters, letting partners like Ursaluna, Metagross, or Dragalge move immediately after. Regenerator variants can switch out on predicted double targets, resetting terrain and regaining 33% HP, then return later to re-set room or fire off burns. Yawn forces 50-50s: either the opponent switches and gives a free turn, or stays and falls asleep, enabling setup sweepers like Swords Dance Garchomp or Dragon Dance Gyarados. Muddy Water’s accuracy drops synergize with teammates that dislike being targeted—dropping both foes’ accuracy effectively grants your side a free Protect on the following turn. Tera Grass is the glue that holds the set together, flipping the Electric weakness and granting a crucial Grass resistance so that Amoonguss and Rillaboom can’t simply click Spore or Glide through Slowbro. In endgames, Slowbro can stall with Recycle Leftovers or simply click Yawn to force a 1-v-1 sleep cycle, making it a surprisingly durable win condition in long games.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Ursaluna is Slowbro’s ideal partner: it underspeeds everything under Trick Room, appreciates Yawn forcing switches to set up Swords Dance, and removes Ghost-types that block Slowbro’s room. Garchomp provides a Ground-immune to Slowbro’s Electric weakness while also threatening opposing Toxapex and Garganacl with STAB Earthquake; in return, Slowbro burns physical threats that bother Chomp like Kingambit and Dragonite. Gyarados forms a Water-type core that can Tera Grass and Tera Flying respectively to flip weaknesses, and both appreciate Yawn support to buy Dragon Dance turns. Metagross loves Trick Room and covers Slowbro’s Fairy weakness with Bullet Punch while Slowbro burns the Dark-types that stalk Metagross. Dragalge is another room abuser that resists Grass and Electric for Slowbro, while Slowbro tanks Ground- and Ice-moves aimed at Dragalge. Scrafty rounds out the list by providing Fake Out and Intimidate to further pad Slowbro’s physical bulk, while Slowbro removes Psychic Terrain so Scrafty can safely click Parting Shot. The shared Fighting resistance across Metagross, Dragalge, and Scrafty means Slowbro can safely switch out against Iron Hands and regenerate, then return later to reset room. Tera Grass on Slowbro and Tera Dark or Steel on teammates create layered typing puzzles that make it hard for opponents to find clean super-effective hits.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Braviary in VGC functions as a high-risk, high-reward Choice Scarf lead or mid-game cleaner that leverages Defiant to punish Intimidate and stat-drops while firing off 135 BP STAB Brave Bird and Double-Edge off an Adamant 212+ Atk stat. The bird’s 212 EV Speed tier with Scarf hits 189, outspeeding the unboosted metagame up to +1 base 100s, while Ghost Tera turns its Normal/Flying self-damage into neutral Tera Ghost Brave Bird and grants invaluable Fighting- and Normal-immunity to dodge Fake Out and Close Combat. Stellar Tera is run almost as frequently to keep STAB on both Flying and Normal moves and break through Tera-Steel and Tera-Fairy targets that otherwise wall its coverage. The four-move set is non-negotiable—Brave Bird for raw power, Close Combat for Rock/Steel, Double-Edge for neutral spam versus Fire and Electric types, and Shadow Claw to nail Aegislash, Mimikyu, and opposing Ghosts—leaving Braviary with no protect, no priority, and no way to change moves, so every click must win the game on the spot.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Braviary": {"Abilities": {"defiant": 2.823617255895912, "sheerforce": 0.046486728729661475, "keeneye": 0.0}, "Items": {"choicescarf": 0.7422080309038606}, "Spreads": {"Adamant:76/212/4/0/4/212": 0.3182336111197298, "Adamant:12/252/4/0/4/236": 0.3519678036218255}, "Moves": ["bravebird", "closecombat", "doubleedge", "shadowclaw"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.3938698894481682, "stellar": 0.3386923911227376}, "Teammates": ["Ursaluna-Bloodmoon", "Rillaboom", "Archaludon", "Volcarona", "Gallade", "Zoroark-Hisui"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Braviary’s niche in the current Regulation G doubles environment is built on three pillars: immediate Speed control via Choice Scarf, Defiant punishes on Incineroar, Landorus-T, and Grimmsnarl, and a Tera Ghost typing that flips the script on Fake Out and Fighting spam. 74 % of successful Braviary hold Choice Scarf, and the two most common spreads—Adamant 76/212/4/0/4/212 and Adamant 12/252/4/0/4/236—both guarantee the bird outruns +1 neutral-nature base 100s such as Jolly Bloodmoon Ursaluna after a Dragon Dance, while still retaining enough bulk to survive -1 252 Atk Iron Head from Tera-Steel Archaludon. Defiant is taken on 96 % of sets, turning Intimidate and Parting Shot into +2 Attack boosts that can snowball through would-be checks; the remaining 4 % run Sheer Force to boost Shadow Claw and any future elemental coverage, but the opportunity cost is too high when Incineroar is on half of all teams. Brave Bird and Double-Edge are mandatory for neutral coverage and raw damage, while Close Combat dents Tyranitar, Heatran, and Kingambit, and Shadow Claw prevents Ghost types from switching in freely. Tera Ghost is preferred on 39 % of teams for the immunities and the ability to spam Double-Edge recoil-free; Tera Stellar (34 %) instead keeps STAB on both Flying and Normal, letting Braviary nuke Tera-Fairy walls like Sylveon and Clefable without dropping power on either STAB. Because Braviary is locked into one move and lacks Protect, partners must provide redirection, speed control, or emergency switches to absorb hits it cannot.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Braviary": {"Abilities": {"defiant": 2.823617255895912, "sheerforce": 0.046486728729661475, "keeneye": 0.0}, "Items": {"choicescarf": 0.7422080309038606}, "Spreads": {"Adamant:76/212/4/0/4/212": 0.3182336111197298, "Adamant:12/252/4/0/4/236": 0.3519678036218255}, "Moves": ["bravebird", "closecombat", "doubleedge", "shadowclaw"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.3938698894481682, "stellar": 0.3386923911227376}, "Teammates": ["Ursaluna-Bloodmoon", "Rillaboom", "Archaludon", "Volcarona", "Gallade", "Zoroark-Hisui"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Braviary’s matchup spread is polarized: it steamrolls offensive teams that rely on Intimidate or lack priority, but folds hard to faster Scarfers, bulky Gigaton-Steel types, and spread damage. Against Incineroar, Landorus-T, and Arcanine, Defiant turns their primary utility into +2 Attack, allowing Braviary to OHKO back with Brave Bird or Close Combat after chip. It outspeeds and 2HKOs most Dragapult, Iron Valiant, and Meowscarada sets, and Tera Ghost dodges Sucker Punch from Kingambit and Bloodmoon Ursaluna. Conversely, Choice Scarf Garchomp, Iron Boulder, and Tera-Dragon Roaring Moon all outspeed and OHKO with Stone Edge or Rock Slide, while Tera-Steel Archaludon and Corviknight shrug off even +2 Close Combat and retalify with Body Press or Iron Defense setups. Priority users like Bisharp, Dragonite, and Gale Wings Talonflame can pick off a chipped Braviary before it moves, and spread moves such as Rock Slide and Discharge from Rotom-Wash or Zapdos wear it down through Protect-less turns. Trick Room teams that drop below Braviary’s Speed tier still threaten it under room with hard-hitters like Stakataka and Torkoal, so Braviary must either be preserved until Trick Room expires or paired with its own room control.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Braviary is played as a lead or early-game breaker that immediately threatens opposing Intimidate users and forces either a Tera commitment or a double-target to KO it. With Scarf and Adamant power, it functions as both speed control and win-condition: versus hyper-offense it can trade one-for-one with a key threat, while versus balance or stall it accumulates Defiant boosts until it becomes unstoppable. The bird fits best on bulky-aggressive cores that can absorb the retaliation it invites—Rillaboom provides Grassy Glide priority and heals Brave Bird recoil, Archaludon sets Stealth Rock and baits Ground moves for Braviary to switch in on, and Volcarona forces Rock-slide users out with Quiver Dance pressure. Because Braviary cannot Protect, it appreciates Follow Me or Ally Switch support from Indeedee-F or Zoroark-Hisui to guarantee a free attack, and it loves Tailwind or Electroweb speed control to outpace opposing Scarfers later in the game. In the late game, once Rock and Steel types are weakened and priority users are removed, Braviary can clean entire teams with recoil-free Tera Ghost Double-Edge or Brave Bird.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Braviary": {"Abilities": {"defiant": 2.823617255895912, "sheerforce": 0.046486728729661475, "keeneye": 0.0}, "Items": {"choicescarf": 0.7422080309038606}, "Spreads": {"Adamant:76/212/4/0/4/212": 0.3182336111197298, "Adamant:12/252/4/0/4/236": 0.3519678036218255}, "Moves": ["bravebird", "closecombat", "doubleedge", "shadowclaw"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.3938698894481682, "stellar": 0.3386923911227376}, "Teammates": ["Ursaluna-Bloodmoon", "Rillaboom", "Archaludon", "Volcarona", "Gallade", "Zoroark-Hisui"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Top teammates center on removing Braviary’s checks while leveraging the pressure it exerts. Ursaluna-Bloodmoon shares an offensive typing that pressures Ghosts and Steels, while also benefiting from Braviary’s ability to eliminate Incineroar; in return Bloodmoon can tank Rock Slides and provide Trick Room control. Rillaboom is the most common partner: Grassy Terrain reduces Brave Bird recoil, Glide picks off faster threats that survive Braviary’s hits, and Wood Hammer breaks through Water and Rock types that wall the bird. Archaludon sets Stealth Rock to put Rock and Steel types in Brave Bird range, draws Ground moves that Braviary can switch into, and can go Tera-Steel to wall opposing Dragons. Volcarona offers Quiver Dance passivity that forces opposing Rock-slide users to target it instead, and after a boost it can KO Garchomp and Roaring Moon that trouble Braviary. Gallade provides Wide Guard to block Rock Slide and Discharge, and its own Close Combat breaks through special walls like Sylveon that can stomach Braviary’s moves. Finally, Zoroark-Hisui disguised as Braviary can draw Fighting and Fake Out attempts, then punish with Ghost-type attacks or Illusion-boosted Nasty Plot, while the real Braviary switches in safely on predicted Normal or Fighting moves.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Braviary": {"Abilities": {"defiant": 2.823617255895912, "sheerforce": 0.046486728729661475, "keeneye": 0.0}, "Items": {"choicescarf": 0.7422080309038606}, "Spreads": {"Adamant:76/212/4/0/4/212": 0.3182336111197298, "Adamant:12/252/4/0/4/236": 0.3519678036218255}, "Moves": ["bravebird", "closecombat", "doubleedge", "shadowclaw"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.3938698894481682, "stellar": 0.3386923911227376}, "Teammates": ["Ursaluna-Bloodmoon", "Rillaboom", "Archaludon", "Volcarona", "Gallade", "Zoroark-Hisui"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>The standard Choice Scarf set is non-negotiable: Adamant nature, 76 HP / 212 Atk / 4 Def / 4 SpD / 212 Spe (or 12 HP / 252 Atk / 4 Def / 4 SpD / 236 Spe) to outspeed +1 base 100s and guarantee the OHKO on 4 HP Incineroar with Brave Bird after Stealth Rock. Moves are Brave Bird, Close Combat, Double-Edge, Shadow Claw; item is Choice Scarf; ability is Defiant; Tera Type is Ghost (or Stellar if your team already packs Ghost immunity). An alternative Bulk-Up set with Sharp Beak exists—Adamant 252 HP / 252 Atk / 4 Def, moves Bulk Up / Brave Bird / Close Combat / Protect, ability Defiant, Tera Ghost—but it is far rarer and requires extensive redirection support. Never run Life Orb or non-Scarf variants outside of meme teams; the bird’s bulk is mediocre and its Speed tier is everything.</OUTPUT>

input:
Generate the 'weaknesses_and_counters' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Braviary": {"Abilities": {"defiant": 2.823617255895912, "sheerforce": 0.046486728729661475, "keeneye": 0.0}, "Items": {"choicescarf": 0.7422080309038606}, "Spreads": {"Adamant:76/212/4/0/4/212": 0.3182336111197298, "Adamant:12/252/4/0/4/236": 0.3519678036218255}, "Moves": ["bravebird", "closecombat", "doubleedge", "shadowclaw"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.3938698894481682, "stellar": 0.3386923911227376}, "Teammates": ["Ursaluna-Bloodmoon", "Rillaboom", "Archaludon", "Volcarona", "Gallade", "Zoroark-Hisui"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Braviary is hard-countered by any faster Rock-type move or bulky Steel that can stomach a hit: Choice Scarf Garchomp, Iron Boulder, and Roaring Moon outspeed and OHKO with Stone Edge; Tera-Steel Corviknight and Archaludon take +2 Close Combat and retalify with Iron Defense Body Press or Flash Cannon. Priority users—especially Bisharp’s Sucker Punch, Dragonite’s Extreme Speed, and Gale Wings Talonflame’s Brave Bird—can pick off a chipped Braviary before it moves. Spread moves like Rock Slide and Discharge wear it down through Protect-less turns, and Fake Out plus double-target from Incineroar and Rillaboom can KO before Defiant boosts matter. Trick Room reverses its Speed advantage, letting slow powerhouses like Stakataka, Torkoal, and Glastrier OHKO it first. Finally, because Braviary is locked into one move, any Protect user can waste its turn, and once the opponent identifies the set they can hard-switch to the appropriate resist every time. To beat Braviary, preserve a faster Scarfer or bulky Steel, keep Rocks up to accumulate recoil, and never trigger Defiant unless you can immediately KO.</OUTPUT>

Provide the 'sample_team_concept' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Braviary": {"Abilities": {"defiant": 2.823617255895912, "sheerforce": 0.046486728729661475, "keeneye": 0.0}, "Items": {"choicescarf": 0.7422080309038606}, "Spreads": {"Adamant:76/212/4/0/4/212": 0.3182336111197298, "Adamant:12/252/4/0/4/236": 0.3519678036218255}, "Moves": ["bravebird", "closecombat", "doubleedge", "shadowclaw"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.3938698894481682, "stellar": 0.3386923911227376}, "Teammates": ["Ursaluna-Bloodmoon", "Rillaboom", "Archaludon", "Volcarona", "Gallade", "Zoroark-Hisui"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>A proven Regulation G core is Braviary / Rillaboom / Archaludon / Volcarona / Rotom-Wash / Indeedee-F. Lead Braviary + Rillaboom to punish Incineroar: if they Intimidate, Defiant +2 Brave Bird OHKOes back while Rillaboom Glide picks off the partner. Archaludon sets Stealth Rock and baits Ground moves for Braviary to switch in; Volcarona forces Rock-slide users out and can clean late-game once Braviary has broken holes. Rotom-Wash provides Tailwind to outpace opposing Scarfers after Braviary has done its job, and Indeedee-F gives Follow Me and Helping Hand to guarantee Braviary gets a free hit or a boosted KO. The team packs two speed control modes—Scarf Braviary early, Tailwind Rotom late—and redundant answers to Rock and Steel types, ensuring Braviary’s weaknesses are covered while its power is maximized.</OUTPUT>

Create the 'short_summary' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Spiritomb": {"Abilities": {"pressure": 0.34052672703157694, "infiltrator": 2.537630229387459}, "Items": {"sitrusberry": 0.4364731903630426, "mentalherb": 0.2986060088372407}, "Spreads": {"Bold:252/0/76/0/180/0": 0.1697749669287311, "Sassy:244/0/12/0/252/0": 0.24093023287544088}, "Moves": ["trickroom", "snarl", "foulplay", "willowisp"], "Tera Types": {"fire": 0.25157729896718994, "poison": 0.20581659164889163}, "Teammates": ["Archaludon", "Ursaluna-Bloodmoon", "Dragonite", "Torkoal", "Ninetales-Alola", "Gastrodon"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Spiritomb carves a unique niche as a bulky, disruption-oriented support that compresses Trick Room control, consistent Snarl pressure, and emergency burn spreading into one slot. Its Ghost/Dark typing leaves it weak to only Fairy while granting invaluable immunities to Normal, Fighting, and Psychic, letting it safely switch in on common support staples like Indeedee-F or Amoonguss. With 108/108 defenses backed by Pressure or Infiltrator, it can repeatedly pivot in, tank neutral hits, and break opposing Focus Sashes or Substitutes while chipping offense with Foul Play. The set’s EV spreads prioritize physical bulk (Bold) or special bulk (Sassy) depending on the partner core, but both aim to survive two unboosted neutral hits so Spiritomb can fire off two Snarls or set Trick Room twice in a match. Tera Fire or Tera Poison remove the lone Fairy weakness and let it bait Moonblast or Play Rough while punishing Iron Valiant or Azumarill switch-ins. On full-room or hybrid-room squads, Spiritomb is the glue that slows the game to a crawl, letting powerhouses like Ursaluna-Bloodmoon or Archaludon move first under Trick Room and sweep.</OUTPUT>

input:
Write the 'full_analysis' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Spiritomb": {"Abilities": {"pressure": 0.34052672703157694, "infiltrator": 2.537630229387459}, "Items": {"sitrusberry": 0.4364731903630426, "mentalherb": 0.2986060088372407}, "Spreads": {"Bold:252/0/76/0/180/0": 0.1697749669287311, "Sassy:244/0/12/0/252/0": 0.24093023287544088}, "Moves": ["trickroom", "snarl", "foulplay", "willowisp"], "Tera Types": {"fire": 0.25157729896718994, "poison": 0.20581659164889163}, "Teammates": ["Archaludon", "Ursaluna-Bloodmoon", "Dragonite", "Torkoal", "Ninetales-Alola", "Gastrodon"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Spiritomb’s greatest asset is its typing: no STAB super-effective hits bar Fairy, yet it resists Dark and Ghost and is completely immune to Fake Out, Close Combat, and Expanding Force. This means it can enter the field against Incineroar, Kingambit, or Indeedee-F without fear, immediately threaten Trick Room or begin a Snarl cycle that neuters special setup sweepers like Flutter Mane or Iron Moth. Foul Play provides a reliable damage option that punishes physical attackers that try to set up on it—+1 Dragonite still loses roughly half its health to a Foul Play while burned. Will-O-Wisp patches the physical side even further, letting Spiritomb cripple Gholdengo, Kingambit, or opposing Ursaluna trying to break through. Pressure variants excel in long games, draining 2 PP per opposing move and quickly stalling out Precipice Blades or Moonblasts, while Infiltrator variants ignore Follow Me, Substitute, and screens, giving it an edge against Togekiss or Grimmsnarl teams. Both item choices—Sitrus Berry and Mental Herb—shore up different weaknesses: Sitrus guarantees it survives a double target into the mid-game, whereas Mental Herb guarantees Trick Room goes up against Taunt users like Whimsicott or opposing Murkrow. Tera Fire flips the script on Iron Valiant and allows Spiritomb to tank a Moonblast and burn back, while Tera Poison lets it absorb Toxic and punish Fairy switch-ins with poison chip. Overall, Spiritomb is less about raw power and more about incremental advantage: every Snarl drop, every burn, and every successful Trick Room is a step closer to a win condition for its slower, bulkier teammates.</OUTPUT>

input:
Write the 'matchup_overview' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Spiritomb": {"Abilities": {"pressure": 0.34052672703157694, "infiltrator": 2.537630229387459}, "Items": {"sitrusberry": 0.4364731903630426, "mentalherb": 0.2986060088372407}, "Spreads": {"Bold:252/0/76/0/180/0": 0.1697749669287311, "Sassy:244/0/12/0/252/0": 0.24093023287544088}, "Moves": ["trickroom", "snarl", "foulplay", "willowisp"], "Tera Types": {"fire": 0.25157729896718994, "poison": 0.20581659164889163}, "Teammates": ["Archaludon", "Ursaluna-Bloodmoon", "Dragonite", "Torkoal", "Ninetales-Alola", "Gastrodon"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Against hyper-offense, Spiritomb is a hard wall. It ignores Fake Out, shrugs off Dragon Darts, and Snarl plus burn neuters physical sweepers like Chien-Pao or Palafin. Versus sun or rain, it still tanks a Specs Heat Wave from Torkoal or a +1 Thunder from Pelipper, sets Trick Room, and forces the weather team to play at half speed. Fairy-types are the obvious hurdle: Iron Valiant outspeeds and OHKOs with Moonblast outside Trick Room, while Azumarill can Belly Drum through it if left unchecked. However, Spiritomb’s Tera options plus WoW mean it can trade favorably if it predicts the switch. Against other Trick Room teams, Spiritomb becomes a speed-control mirror: it can Taunt-proof its own Trick Room with Mental Herb or simply Snarl the opposing setter to break potential Focus Sash. Stall or semi-stall match-ups turn into PP wars where Pressure Spiritomb shines, draining recovery or hazard moves faster than foes expect. In best-of-three settings, bringing Spiritomb forces opponents to consider whether to drop their Fairy slot or tech a Taunt user, both of which can be exploited by Spiritomb’s partners.</OUTPUT>

input:
Produce the 'role_description' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Spiritomb": {"Abilities": {"pressure": 0.34052672703157694, "infiltrator": 2.537630229387459}, "Items": {"sitrusberry": 0.4364731903630426, "mentalherb": 0.2986060088372407}, "Spreads": {"Bold:252/0/76/0/180/0": 0.1697749669287311, "Sassy:244/0/12/0/252/0": 0.24093023287544088}, "Moves": ["trickroom", "snarl", "foulplay", "willowisp"], "Tera Types": {"fire": 0.25157729896718994, "poison": 0.20581659164889163}, "Teammates": ["Archaludon", "Ursaluna-Bloodmoon", "Dragonite", "Torkoal", "Ninetales-Alola", "Gastrodon"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Spiritomb is a primary Trick Room setter and special bulk debuffer that doubles as a physical deterrent. It leads when the team needs slow tempo, sits mid-game to reset Trick Room, or pivots late to burn and Snawl cleaning sweepers. Its EV spreads reflect two philosophies: Bold with 76 Def / 180 SpD survives Jolly Chien-Pao Ice Spinner plus Life Orb Dragonite Espeed, while Sassy 252 SpD avoids the 2HKO from Specs Torkoal Heat Wave and guarantees Trick Room versus Indeedee-F + Farigabro cores. The moveset is four-slot perfect: Trick Room for speed control, Snarl for special damage reduction, Foul Play for consistent chip that ignores burn or Intimidate, and Will-O-Wisp to punish physical setup. Because it lacks recovery outside Sitrus, Spiritomb must be played proactively—switching into resisted hits, firing off the first Snarl, then either setting room or burning on the second turn depending on partner positioning.</OUTPUT>

input:
Write the 'synergy_breakdown' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Spiritomb": {"Abilities": {"pressure": 0.34052672703157694, "infiltrator": 2.537630229387459}, "Items": {"sitrusberry": 0.4364731903630426, "mentalherb": 0.2986060088372407}, "Spreads": {"Bold:252/0/76/0/180/0": 0.1697749669287311, "Sassy:244/0/12/0/252/0": 0.24093023287544088}, "Moves": ["trickroom", "snarl", "foulplay", "willowisp"], "Tera Types": {"fire": 0.25157729896718994, "poison": 0.20581659164889163}, "Teammates": ["Archaludon", "Ursaluna-Bloodmoon", "Dragonite", "Torkoal", "Ninetales-Alola", "Gastrodon"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Archaludon loves Trick Room and hates special attackers; Spiritomb’s Snarl plus Flash Fire or Tera Fire bait turns special attackers into marshmallows while Archaludon sets up Stamina boosts. Ursaluna-Bloodmoon wants slow turns and appreciates burn support to offset its mediocre physical bulk—Spiritomb provides both and can even Tera Poison to lure and toxic-stall Fairies that trouble the bear. Dragonite benefits from Trick Room to move first with bulky Weakness Policy sets, and Spiritomb’s WoW punits Ice-type counters trying to break Dragonite’s Multiscale. Torkoal and Alolan-Ninetales form a sun or hail backbone: Spiritomb sets room so these weather setters can move immediately, while Eruption or Blizzard under Trick Room can devastate opposing teams before they adjust. Gastrodon covers Spiritomb’s Electric and Water weaknesses, while Spiritomb handles Grass and Freeze-Dry users with burn and Foul Play. The core idea is to stack incremental damage reduction: Snarl plus Intimidate or Will-O-Wisp means opposing attacks deal 40–50 % less damage, letting the naturally bulky teammates snowball out of control.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Spiritomb": {"Abilities": {"pressure": 0.34052672703157694, "infiltrator": 2.537630229387459}, "Items": {"sitrusberry": 0.4364731903630426, "mentalherb": 0.2986060088372407}, "Spreads": {"Bold:252/0/76/0/180/0": 0.1697749669287311, "Sassy:244/0/12/0/252/0": 0.24093023287544088}, "Moves": ["trickroom", "snarl", "foulplay", "willowisp"], "Tera Types": {"fire": 0.25157729896718994, "poison": 0.20581659164889163}, "Teammates": ["Archaludon", "Ursaluna-Bloodmoon", "Dragonite", "Torkoal", "Ninetales-Alola", "Gastrodon"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Bold Support: 252 HP / 76 Def / 180 SpD, Bold nature, Pressure, Sitrus Berry, with Trick Room / Snarl / Foul Play / Will-O-Wisp, Tera Fire. This set survives Life Orb Dragonite Espeed + Chien-Pao Ice Spinner and reliably sets Trick Room versus most leads. Sassy Mental Herb: 244 HP / 12 Def / 252 SpD, Sassy nature, Infiltrator, Mental Herb, same four moves, Tera Poison. This variant ignores Follow Me, guarantees room versus Taunt, and tanks Specs Torkoal or Sylveon Hyper Voice. Max special bulk plus Tera Poison lets it 1v1 Iron Valiant in Trick Room by burning on the switch and stalling with poison chip. Both spreads outspeed uninvested base 50s to fire the first Snarl before opposing Gastrodon or Amoonguss move.</OUTPUT>

input:
Provide the 'weaknesses_and_counters' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Spiritomb": {"Abilities": {"pressure": 0.34052672703157694, "infiltrator": 2.537630229387459}, "Items": {"sitrusberry": 0.4364731903630426, "mentalherb": 0.2986060088372407}, "Spreads": {"Bold:252/0/76/0/180/0": 0.1697749669287311, "Sassy:244/0/12/0/252/0": 0.24093023287544088}, "Moves": ["trickroom", "snarl", "foulplay", "willowisp"], "Tera Types": {"fire": 0.25157729896718994, "poison": 0.20581659164889163}, "Teammates": ["Archaludon", "Ursaluna-Bloodmoon", "Dragonite", "Torkoal", "Ninetales-Alola", "Gastrodon"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Iron Valiant is Spiritomb’s biggest nemesis: Moonblast OHKOs even bulky spreads, and outspeeds outside room. Choice Specs Flutter Mane can 2HKO with Moonblast but hates Snarl drops. Taunt users faster than Spiritomb—Whimsicott, Murkrow, or Grimmsnarl—shut off Trick Room, though Mental Herb variants beat single Taunt. Multi-hit users like Breloom or Kingambit with Stone Edge can break through Sitrus ranges and finish Spiritomb before it burns. Encore from Togekiss or Dondozo locks it into Trick Room or Snarl, forcing awkward switches. Finally, bulkier Fairies such as Azumarill or Sylveon can tank a burn and set up or retaliate; Spiritomb must Tera or receive Helping Hand chip to win these exchanges. Teams facing Spiritomb should pack at least one fast Fairy and one Taunt or Encore user, then play aggressively to deny Trick Room turns.</OUTPUT>

input:
Create the 'sample_team_concept' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Spiritomb": {"Abilities": {"pressure": 0.34052672703157694, "infiltrator": 2.537630229387459}, "Items": {"sitrusberry": 0.4364731903630426, "mentalherb": 0.2986060088372407}, "Spreads": {"Bold:252/0/76/0/180/0": 0.1697749669287311, "Sassy:244/0/12/0/252/0": 0.24093023287544088}, "Moves": ["trickroom", "snarl", "foulplay", "willowisp"], "Tera Types": {"fire": 0.25157729896718994, "poison": 0.20581659164889163}, "Teammates": ["Archaludon", "Ursaluna-Bloodmoon", "Dragonite", "Torkoal", "Ninetales-Alola", "Gastrodon"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Start with Spiritomb + Ursaluna-Bloodmoon: Spiritomb sets Trick Room while tanking hits, Ursaluna clicks Blood Moon under room. Add Torkoal for sun-boosted Eruption and to break opposing weather; Torkoal’s Drought also weakens Water moves aimed at Spiritomb. Archaludon provides a second slow powerhouse that abuses Stamina and Body Press; Snarl support lets it survive special hits and snowball. Alolan-Ninetales gives Aurora Veil and second weather option, and Blizzard under room punishes Grass-types that trouble both bears. Round out with Gastrodon as a Water-immune pivot that handles Rain and opposing Torkoal. The team functions as a hybrid-room squad: lead Spiritomb + powerhouses versus fast teams, or Torkoal + Archaludon versus other room squads, then bring Spiritomb mid-game to reset room and Snarl. EV spreads maximize bulk to abuse Veil and incremental damage reduction, creating a fortress that concedes the first two turns but grinds opponents down under Trick Room and stacked debuffs.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Eiscue": {"Abilities": {"iceface": 3.252283208162529}, "Items": {"sitrusberry": 0.868024227271414}, "Spreads": {"Adamant:108/252/4/0/4/140": 0.4210323642008661, "Adamant:12/252/4/0/4/236": 0.2983180166314145}, "Moves": ["bellydrum", "protect", "icespinner", "waterfall"], "Tera Types": {"water": 0.9219552043642492}, "Teammates": ["Ninetales-Alola", "Glaceon", "Rillaboom", "Glimmora", "Toxapex", "Mienshao"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Eiscue is a niche but explosive setup sweeper in VGC that leverages its unique Ice Face ability to guarantee a Belly Drum boost under hail, transforming into a blazing-fast +6 attacker that can rip through unprepared teams. Although its stats are unimpressive on paper, the combination of Ice Face, hail, and a Tera-Water typing gives it a one-turn window to set up, after which STAB Ice Spinner and Tera-boosted Waterfall achieve near-perfect neutral coverage. The most successful spreads run Adamant with 140–236 Speed EVs to outpace key threats after a Drum, while the remaining bulk and a Sitrus Berry let it survive the self-inflicted Belly Drum drop. Because it absolutely requires hail and a free turn, it is almost always paired with Alolan Ninetales for guaranteed hail and additional Speed control, and appreciates teammates like Rillaboom and Glimmora that can pressure Steel, Rock, and bulky Water-types that otherwise wall its dual STABs.</OUTPUT>

input:
Create the 'full_analysis' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Eiscue": {"Abilities": {"iceface": 3.252283208162529}, "Items": {"sitrusberry": 0.868024227271414}, "Spreads": {"Adamant:108/252/4/0/4/140": 0.4210323642008661, "Adamant:12/252/4/0/4/236": 0.2983180166314145}, "Moves": ["bellydrum", "protect", "icespinner", "waterfall"], "Tera Types": {"water": 0.9219552043642492}, "Teammates": ["Ninetales-Alola", "Glaceon", "Rillaboom", "Glimmora", "Toxapex", "Mienshao"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Eiscue’s entire competitive identity revolves around the interplay between its signature ability Ice Face and the move Belly Drum. Ice Face blocks the first physical hit Eiscue takes and converts it into a free substitute-like shield, while also doubling its Speed in hail. This means that, under hail, Eiscue can click Belly Drum against any physical attacker without fear of being KO’d, emerge at 50% health (restored immediately by Sitrus Berry) and at +6 Attack, and then outspeed every unboosted Pokémon in the metagame. Once set up, Ice Spinner and Waterfall become 120- and 130-base-power STAB moves respectively, with Tera Water further strengthening Waterfall and removing Ice-type’s crippling weaknesses to Rock and Steel. The chosen EV spreads reflect this game plan: 108 HP / 252 Atk / 4 Def / 4 SpD / 140 Spe Adamant hits 131 Speed, enough to outspeed +1 base 100s after Ice Face’s Speed boost, while the bulk guarantees that even after Belly Drum and hail damage, Sitrus activates and leaves Eiscue in a safe range to sweep. Protect is mandatory both to stall Dynamax turns and to scout choice-locked or priority moves that could pick off the penguin before it drums. Despite its terrifying damage output, Eiscue is a one-trick pony: if hail ends, if the opponent carries special attackers, or if Eiscue is forced to take a second hit before setting up, it folds immediately. Consequently, successful Eiscue teams invest heavily in redirection, speed control, and hazard removal to ensure the setup turn occurs, and they carry backup win conditions for matchups where Eiscue cannot function.</OUTPUT>

input:
Provide the 'matchup_overview' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Eiscue": {"Abilities": {"iceface": 3.252283208162529}, "Items": {"sitrusberry": 0.868024227271414}, "Spreads": {"Adamant:108/252/4/0/4/140": 0.4210323642008661, "Adamant:12/252/4/0/4/236": 0.2983180166314145}, "Moves": ["bellydrum", "protect", "icespinner", "waterfall"], "Tera Types": {"water": 0.9219552043642492}, "Teammates": ["Ninetales-Alola", "Glaceon", "Rillaboom", "Glimmora", "Toxapex", "Mienshao"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Eiscue dominates slow, physically oriented teams that rely on contact moves to deal damage, turning common staples like Rillaboom, Chien-Pao, and Kingambit into setup fodder. Against hyper-offense or special attackers such as Flutter Mane, Iron Valiant, or Chi-Yu, however, Ice Face is never triggered, meaning Eiscue must either switch out or risk being KO’d before it can drum. Steel- and Water-type walls like Corviknight, Toxapex, and Dondozo completely blank its STAB combination even at +6, so these Pokémon must be eliminated or lured prior to the sweep. Sun teams are problematic because they overwrite hail, removing Eiscue’s Speed boost and exposing it to the faster, powerful attackers that sun teams naturally carry. Conversely, rain teams present a double-edged sword: the rain boosts Waterfall, but it also means opposing Swift Swim Pokémon will outspeed and KO Eiscue before it can move. Trick Room is another nightmare, as Eiscue’s Speed advantage is nullified and it becomes vulnerable to bulky sweepers that can tank a +6 hit and retaliate. In dynamax formats, Max Quake and Max Steelspike users can break Ice Face, change the weather, and raise defensive stats, so timing the Dynamax window is crucial for both players.</OUTPUT>

input:
Write the 'role_description' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Eiscue": {"Abilities": {"iceface": 3.252283208162529}, "Items": {"sitrusberry": 0.868024227271414}, "Spreads": {"Adamant:108/252/4/0/4/140": 0.4210323642008661, "Adamant:12/252/4/0/4/236": 0.2983180166314145}, "Moves": ["bellydrum", "protect", "icespinner", "waterfall"], "Tera Types": {"water": 0.9219552043642492}, "Teammates": ["Ninetales-Alola", "Glaceon", "Rillaboom", "Glimmora", "Toxapex", "Mienshao"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Eiscue is a hyper-offensive setup win-condition that functions as the primary or secondary sweeper on hail-based teams. Its job is to enter the field under hail, force a physically attacking opponent into play, use that turn to set up Belly Drum, and then clean the opposing team with perfectly accurate, high-power STAB moves. Because it only needs a single turn of support to become unstoppable, it is often paired with redirection or Fake Out users to secure that turn. Once the sweep begins, Eiscue acts as a fast, mixed-attacking wallbreaker that can Dynamax if necessary to overwrite unfavorable weather or to gain additional bulk through Max Guard. Outside of the sweep, it provides little defensive utility and must be preserved until the conditions are perfect, making it a classic “late-game cleaner” rather than a pivot or support Pokémon.</OUTPUT>

input:
Write a detailed 'synergy_breakdown' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Eiscue": {"Abilities": {"iceface": 3.252283208162529}, "Items": {"sitrusberry": 0.868024227271414}, "Spreads": {"Adamant:108/252/4/0/4/140": 0.4210323642008661, "Adamant:12/252/4/0/4/236": 0.2983180166314145}, "Moves": ["bellydrum", "protect", "icespinner", "waterfall"], "Tera Types": {"water": 0.9219552043642492}, "Teammates": ["Ninetales-Alola", "Glaceon", "Rillaboom", "Glimmora", "Toxapex", "Mienshao"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Alolan Ninetales is the non-negotiable partner, providing permanent hail with Snow Warning, Speed control with Icy Wind or Blizzard chip, and Veil support to buffer Eiscue’s setup turn. Rillaboom is the second most common teammate, offering Grassy Terrain recovery, priority Fake Out to block status or final blows, and powerful Wood Hammers to crack bulky Waters and Grounds that Eiscue dislikes. Glimmora supplies Toxic Spikes and Mortal Spin, wearing down Toxapex and Corviknight while also threatening Fairy-types that resist Waterfall. Toxapex itself appears on more balanced variants, spreading poison and providing Wide Guard to block Rock Slides and Discharges that could break Ice Face. Mienshao rounds out the core with fast Fake Out, Wide Guard, and Close Combat pressure to remove opposing Steel-types. Finally, Glaceon acts as an alternative hail setter and special wallbreaker that appreciates Eiscue’s ability to eliminate special walls like Blissey and Clodsire. The overarching synergy is to stack chip damage, remove Steel- and Water-type obstacles, and ensure hail stays active so Eiscue can claim its single, decisive sweep.</OUTPUT>

Bulky Steel-types such as Corviknight, Gholdengo, and Kingambit can stomach a +6 Ice Spinner and retalively with Iron Head or Steel Beam, while Water-types like Dondozo and Toxapex simply wall both STABs and Recover stall until hail ends. Finally, Trick Room and Tailwind teams invert or double the speed tiers, forcing Eiscue to take a second hit before it can sweep. <DATA>{"Inteleon": {"Abilities": {"torrent": 0.4328051702950659, "sniper": 2.478613482360558}, "Items": {"focussash": 0.20370690746407394, "scopelens": 0.5366816333810598, "lifeorb": 0.18222207313474065}, "Spreads": {"Timid:4/0/0/252/0/252": 0.603062124203459}, "Moves": ["snipeshot", "icywind", "protect", "taunt"], "Tera Types": {"water": 0.5403540366583541, "ice": 0.23149522470754544}, "Teammates": ["Ninetales-Alola", "Dragapult", "Rillaboom", "Magmar", "Kingambit", "Sneasler"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Inteleon’s niche in VGC 2024 stems from its blazing base 120 Speed, which lets it outrun the crowded base 110–119 tier—most notably Dragapult, Iron Valiant, and the Lati twins—and its access to Sniper, which turns every critical hit into a 2.25× modifier. Snipe Shot’s innate high critical-hit ratio plus Scope Lens yields a 50 % crit chance, meaning roughly half of its attacks will ignore enemy boosts and screens and deal nuclear damage. Icy Wind provides immediate speed control that benefits slower sweepers such as Kingambit and Rillaboom, while Taunt shuts down Trick Room, Recover, and Tailwind attempts from the likes of Indeedee, Dondozo, and Murkrow. Focus Sash variants guarantee at least one attack or disruption move against faster leads or double-target scenarios, whereas Life Orb boosts every roll at the cost of chip. Terastallizing into Water turns Snipe Shot into a 120 BP critical nuke that can OHKO neutral targets like Gholdengo and Chien-Pao after minimal chip, while Ice Tera gives a 140 BP Max Hailstorm that deletes Amoonguss, Rillaboom, and Dragon-types at the cost of a more exploitable defensive typing. Inteleon’s main drawbacks are its mediocre bulk and reliance on critical variance; any team that can survive the first turn or redirect its attacks can punish it with priority or spread moves. Nonetheless, its ability to compress offensive pressure, speed control, and disruption into one slot makes it a premier lead or late-game cleaner on hyper-offensive and tempo squads.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Inteleon dominates slower, setup-reliant cores that cannot afford to eat a critical Snipe Shot or Icy Wind drop. It cleanly 2HKOes bulkier Waters like Dondozo and Toxapex and OHKOes frailer threats such as Chien-Pao and Gholdengo with a crit. Against Tailwind or Trick Room teams, turn-one Taunt plus Icy Wind can cripple their speed advantage, forcing manual speed control or Tera commits. Conversely, Inteleon struggles into bulkier Tailwind or priority-heavy offenses: Murkrow and Talonflame can tank a hit and retaliate with Brave Bird or Tailwind, while Scizor and Kingambit punish its low physical bulk with Bullet Punch or Sucker Punch. Wide Guard users like Araquanid and Garganacl blank Max Geyser, and Assault Vest Gholdengo can survive a non-crit and retaliate with Shadow Ball. Rain teams also reduce Snipe Shot’s potency while boosting opposing Surfs and Hurricanes. Finally, because Inteleon usually carries Focus Sash or Scope Lens, residual damage from Rocky Helmet, Iron Barbs, or sand can break Sash or put it in KO range before it moves.</OUTPUT>

In the back, Inteleon can clean weakened teams thanks to its Speed tier and 50 % crit chance, especially after Terastallizing. output: <OUTPUT>Prankster Doodle is the entire reason Grafaiai sees tournament play. By moving first, it guarantees the ability copy before the target can be KO’d, transforming Slaking into a 160 BP double-targeting nuke with Pure Power or giving Rillaboom instant Grassy Surge without wasting a turn on Max Overgrowth. Encore locks opponents into setup or Protect, creating free turns for partners, while Knock Off removes crucial items like Sitrus Berry or Assault Vest. The chosen Tera types—Dark, Poison, Flying—are purely defensive: Dark prevents Prankster from being blocked by Psychic Terrain and cushions Ghost hits, Poison absorbs Toxic Spikes and shrugs off Fairy attacks, and Flying grants Ground immunities to ease prediction versus Garchomp or Ting-Lu. EV spreads are binary: Adamant 248 HP guarantees survival with Sash while keeping an odd HP number for hazard math, whereas Timid 252 Spe maximises the mirror versus other Prankster users and speed-ties opposing base 110s after Unburden if seed-activated. Grassy Seed variants pair exclusively with Rillaboom to proc Unburden, skyrocketing Grafaiai to 550 effective Speed and letting it fire off a second disruptive move or emergency Protect before going down.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Arboliva is a niche support Grass-type that relies on Leech Seed stalling, Grassy Seed Harvest synergy, and Tera Water bulk to stay on the field; its most successful sets are either Quiet 252/0/0/252/4/0 with Sitrus Berry for immediate Leech Seed pressure or Calm 236/0/172/0/100/0 with Grassy Seed for long-term Harvest recycling, both emphasizing Protect, Giga Drain, and Pollen Puff to keep itself and its partner healthy while chipping the opposition.</OUTPUT>

input:
Create the 'full_analysis' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Arboliva": {"Abilities": {"seedsower": 1.5355978800951715, "harvest": 1.1465686189146465}, "Items": {"sitrusberry": 0.4498013430950829, "grassyseed": 0.48929008213684666}, "Spreads": {"Quiet:252/0/0/252/4/0": 0.320464588966051, "Calm:236/0/172/0/100/0": 0.43570739675583126}, "Moves": ["leechseed", "protect", "gigadrain", "pollenpuff"], "Tera Types": {"fairy": 0.30451166081311476, "water": 0.5233733465573585}, "Teammates": ["Annihilape", "Incineroar", "Ninetales-Alola", "Garchomp", "Weezing", "Ursaluna-Bloodmoon"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>The Grass/Normal typing gives Arboliva a unique niche as a Leech Seed user that is immune to Ghost-type Fake Out and Shadow Ball, while Seed Sower automatically turns the field into Grassy Terrain on hit, powering up its own Giga Drain and enabling Grassy Seed Harvest loops. Quiet max-SpA spreads prefer Sitrus Berry for a one-time 25 % heal that combines with Leech Seed to offset its middling 78/90/101 bulk, whereas the Calm spread banks on Grassy Seed’s +1 Defense under Harvest to repeatedly recycle the seed every turn, turning Arboliva into a surprisingly durable pivot. Pollen Puff lets it heal partners for 50 % in a metagame where spread damage is omnipresent, while Protect is mandatory to stall Leech Seed turns and scout Choice locks. Tera Water is the most common final typing, removing the Fire and Ice weaknesses that plague Grass-types and giving it a crucial resistance to Incineroar’s Flare Blitz and Heat Wave, while Tera Fairy is an alternative that flips the Dragon and Dark match-ups, notably dodging Crunch from Chi-Yu or Chien-Pao. The combination of terrain control, Leech Seed, and partner healing makes Arboliva a passive but surprisingly oppressive support that can single-handedly win long games if the opponent lacks immediate Grass answers.</OUTPUT>

input:
Write the 'matchup_overview' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Arboliva": {"Abilities": {"seedsower": 1.5355978800951715, "harvest": 1.1465686189146465}, "Items": {"sitrusberry": 0.4498013430950829, "grassyseed": 0.48929008213684666}, "Spreads": {"Quiet:252/0/0/252/4/0": 0.320464588966051, "Calm:236/0/172/0/100/0": 0.43570739675583126}, "Moves": ["leechseed", "protect", "gigadrain", "pollenpuff"], "Tera Types": {"fairy": 0.30451166081311476, "water": 0.5233733465573585}, "Teammates": ["Annihilape", "Incineroar", "Ninetales-Alola", "Garchomp", "Weezing", "Ursaluna-Bloodmoon"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Arboliva loves facing bulky Water-, Ground-, and Rock-types such as Gastrodon, Swampert, and Tyranitar that cannot break through Grassy Terrain-boosted Giga Drain and are slowly worn down by Leech Seed; it also pressures Rain teams that rely on Pelipper and Barraskewda, since Seed Sower removes their Psychic Terrain and Grassy Terrain weakens Water moves. Conversely, it struggles against fast Flying-types like Tornadus and Talonflame that can OHKO with Supersonic Skystrike or Brave Bird before it moves, and any Pokémon with Grass-neutral coverage plus Taunt—think Murkrow or Whimsicott—can shut down Leech Seed entirely. Fire-types such as Chi-Yu and Heatran are problematic unless Arboliva has already Terastallized into Water, and opposing Terrain setters like Indeedee-F can overwrite Grassy Terrain and deny Grassy Seed boosts. Finally, Rillaboom is a direct counter: it ignores Leech Seed thanks to Grassy Glide priority and immediately reclaims terrain priority, while its Wood Hammer is only barely mitigated by Tera Water.</OUTPUT>

input:
Provide the 'role_description' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Arboliva": {"Abilities": {"seedsower": 1.5355978800951715, "harvest": 1.1465686189146465}, "Items": {"sitrusberry": 0.4498013430950829, "grassyseed": 0.48929008213684666}, "Spreads": {"Quiet:252/0/0/252/4/0": 0.320464588966051, "Calm:236/0/172/0/100/0": 0.43570739675583126}, "Moves": ["leechseed", "protect", "gigadrain", "pollenpuff"], "Tera Types": {"fairy": 0.30451166081311476, "water": 0.5233733465573585}, "Teammates": ["Annihilape", "Incineroar", "Ninetales-Alola", "Garchomp", "Weezing", "Ursaluna-Bloodmoon"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Arboliva is a passive support pivot whose primary job is to set Leech Seed on the most threatening opposing attacker, toggle Protect to accumulate healing, and use Pollen Puff to keep its own partner healthy while the field’s residual damage racks up. Because Harvest can recycle Grassy Seed indefinitely under Grassy Terrain, it can stay on the field for ten or more turns if not directly targeted, making it one of the few Pokémon that can out-stall opposing Tailwind or Trick Room turns. Giga Drain is its only offensive move, but under terrain it reaches 108 base power and provides reliable self-healing that combines with Leech Seed to offset burn or poison chip. The Calm spread’s 172 HP / 100 SpD EVs let it survive Modest Flutter Mane’s Shadow Ball or Life Orb Heat Wave from Torkoal, while the Quiet spread simply maximizes immediate Giga Drain damage and two-hit-KOes bulky Waters like Tapu Fini after Stealth Rock-style chip. In short, Arboliva is neither a win-condition nor a speed controller; it is a resource engine that trades momentum for long-term board control.</OUTPUT>

input:
Generate the 'synergy_breakdown' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Arboliva": {"Abilities": {"seedsower": 1.5355978800951715, "harvest": 1.1465686189146465}, "Items": {"sitrusberry": 0.4498013430950829, "grassyseed": 0.48929008213684666}, "Spreads": {"Quiet:252/0/0/252/4/0": 0.320464588966051, "Calm:236/0/172/0/100/0": 0.43570739675583126}, "Moves": ["leechseed", "protect", "gigadrain", "pollenpuff"], "Tera Types": {"fairy": 0.30451166081311476, "water": 0.5233733465573585}, "Teammates": ["Annihilape", "Incineroar", "Ninetales-Alola", "Garchomp", "Weezing", "Ursaluna-Bloodmoon"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Annihilape is the perfect partner: it baits Ghost- and Dark-type attacks that Arboliva is immune to, appreciates Leech Seed + Pollen Puff healing to keep Drain Punch rolling, and can Taunt opposing status moves that would otherwise cripple Arboliva. Incineroar forms a classic Intimidate + Leech Seed core, knocking off Heavy-Duty Boots and Sitrus Berries so Leech Seed sticks, while Arboliva’s Grassy Terrain halves Flare Blitz recoil. Alolan Ninetales provides Aurora Veil to patch Arboliva’s merely okay bulk and can Blizzard away opposing Grass-types; in return Arboliva removes the Psychic Terrain that blocks Ninetales’s Fake Tears. Garchomp enjoys Grassy Terrain halving its Earthquake damage and can Dynamax to set Sand, which does not overwrite terrain, while pressuring opposing Fire- and Steel-types for Arboliva. Weezing neutralizes Rillaboom with Neutralizing Gas and clears status, letting Arboliva avoid Toxic and burn that would break its Harvest loop. Finally, Ursaluna-Bloodmoon loves Leech Seed + Pollen Puff support to offset its own Life Orb recoil and can click Blood Moon freely under Grassy Terrain without fearing priority Fake Out.</OUTPUT>

Write the 'weaknesses_and_counters' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Arboliva": {"Abilities": {"seedsower": 1.5355978800951715, "harvest": 1.1465686189146465}, "Items": {"sitrusberry": 0.4498013430950829, "grassyseed": 0.48929008213684666}, "Spreads": {"Quiet:252/0/0/252/4/0": 0.320464588966051, "Calm:236/0/172/0/100/0": 0.43570739675583126}, "Moves": ["leechseed", "protect", "gigadrain", "pollenpuff"], "Tera Types": {"fairy": 0.30451166081311476, "water": 0.5233733465573585}, "Teammates": ["Annihilape", "Incineroar", "Ninetales-Alola", "Garchomp", "Weezing", "Ursaluna-Bloodmoon"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Fast Flying-types such as Choice Scarf Tornadus and Talonflame OHKO with Brave Bird before Arboliva can move, and because Arboliva is slower than most support Pokémon it cannot afford to invest in Speed. Taunt users—Murkrow, Whimsicott, or even Grimmsnarl—shut down Leech Seed and render it passive, while Rillaboom claims terrain and removes Grassy Seed boosts with priority Glide. Fire-types like Chi-Yu, Heatran, and Torkoal can break through even Tera Water if they carry Choice Specs or Eruption sun boosts, and opposing Terrain setters such as Indeedee-F or Farigiraf overwrite Grassy Terrain and deny Harvest loops. Knock Off from Incineroar or Kingambit removes Sitrus or Grassy Seed permanently, and because Arboliva is reliant on item recycling it becomes dead weight once its item is gone. Finally, Grass-resistant sweepers that ignore Leech Seed via Substitute or Magic Guard—think Clefable or Iron Valiant—can set up in Arboliva’s face while taking negligible damage from Giga Drain.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Arboliva": {"Abilities": {"seedsower": 1.5355978800951715, "harvest": 1.1465686189146465}, "Items": {"sitrusberry": 0.4498013430950829, "grassyseed": 0.48929008213684666}, "Spreads": {"Quiet:252/0/0/252/4/0": 0.320464588966051, "Calm:236/0/172/0/100/0": 0.43570739675583126}, "Moves": ["leechseed", "protect", "gigadrain", "pollenpuff"], "Tera Types": {"fairy": 0.30451166081311476, "water": 0.5233733465573585}, "Teammates": ["Annihilape", "Incineroar", "Ninetales-Alola", "Garchomp", "Weezing", "Ursaluna-Bloodmoon"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Build a bulky balance core around Arboliva + Annihilape: lead Arboliva / Alolan Ninetales with Annihilape in the back. Ninetales sets Aurora Veil while Arboliva fires Leech Seed; if the opponent leads Rillaboom, switch Ninetales into Weezing on turn one to block Glide with Neutralizing Gas. Mid-game, bring Incineroar to Knock Off items and Intimidate, then cycle Annihilape behind Veil to stack Bulk Up while Leech Seed + Pollen Puff offsets Drain Punch recoil. Garchomp serves as the speed control and late-game cleaner, benefiting from Grassy Terrain-reduced Earthquake damage and removing opposing Fire-types. Ursaluna-Bloodmoon is the Dynamax win-condition: under Veil and Leech Seed it can safely click Blood Moon three times, while Arboliva’s Pollen Puff heals off Life Orb chip. The team struggles against fast Tailwind or Booster Energy offense, so keep Ninetales healthy to reset Veil and preserve Tera Water on Arboliva for the inevitable Heatran or Chi-Yu endgame.</OUTPUT>
