<DATA>{"Hippowdon": {"Abilities": {"sandstream": 2.716882350404434, "sandforce": 0.06491029527909675}, "Items": {"rockyhelmet": 0.21119031463625143, "leftovers": 0.3275275817938509}, "Spreads": {"Careful:252/0/4/0/252/0": 0.1656359111856584}, "Moves": ["protect", "yawn", "slackoff", "sandtomb"], "Tera Types": {"dragon": 0.15961803104733, "steel": 0.1561916341627479}, "Teammates": ["Excadrill", "Houndstone", "Glimmora", "Tatsugiri", "Sinistcha", "Incineroar"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Hippowdon is a bulky, sand-setting pivot that leverages Sand Stream to support Excadrill and Houndstone while blanking physical attackers with Rocky Helmet and Yawn pressure. Its EV spread maximizes special bulk, letting it repeatedly switch in, set sand, and cycle Yawns or trap foes with Sand Tomb before recovering with Slack Off. Tera Dragon or Steel patches up its Grass and Water weaknesses, letting it stay on the field longer to maintain weather control. The curated teammates—Excadrill, Houndstone, Glimmora, Tatsugiri, Sinistcha, and Incineroar—form a balanced sand semi-room that abuses the passive damage and speed-modifier sand provides while still threatening both fast and slow archetypes.</OUTPUT>

input:
Produce the 'full_analysis' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Hippowdon": {"Abilities": {"sandstream": 2.716882350404434, "sandforce": 0.06491029527909675}, "Items": {"rockyhelmet": 0.21119031463625143, "leftovers": 0.3275275817938509}, "Spreads": {"Careful:252/0/4/0/252/0": 0.1656359111856584}, "Moves": ["protect", "yawn", "slackoff", "sandtomb"], "Tera Types": {"dragon": 0.15961803104733, "steel": 0.1561916341627479}, "Teammates": ["Excadrill", "Houndstone", "Glimmora", "Tatsugiri", "Sinistcha", "Incineroar"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Hippowdon’s niche in VGC 2025 is that of a slow, immensely fat weather setter that compresses role compression into one slot: sand, phazing, healing, and chip. 252 HP / 252+ SpD Careful turns it into a special wall that avoids the 2HKO from most Miraidon, Iron Valiant Moonblast, or Glimmora Power Gem while still taking physical hits such as Chien-Pao Icicle Crash or Kingambit Iron Head. Sand Stream immediately chips every non-Steel/Ground/Rock for 6% per turn, breaking Focus Sashes and turning 2HKOs into 3HKOs for its partners. Yawn forces either switches or sleep, creating free turns for Excadrill to Swords Dance or Houndstone to set up Substitute. Sand Tomb traps opposing Tera Fairy or Tera Flying sweepers that try to dodge Earthquake, ensuring sand remains up and preventing them from freely pivoting. Slack Off grants longevity that most weather setters lack, letting Hippowdon win long games against other balance or hard-TR squads. Rocky Helmet punishes U-turn, Fake Out, and Sucker Punch users, stacking with sand to rack 18% on contact moves, while Leftovers variants prefer gradual recovery to stay above 50% for consistent Yawn cycles. Tera Dragon removes the Grass weakness and grants neutrality to Water, while Tera Steel gives key resistances to Ice and Fairy and makes Hippowdon a Poison-immune pivot that can safely switch into Glimmora’s Mortal Spin. The chosen teammates all exploit sand: Excadrill becomes a 142-speed sweeper under sand, Houndstone gains 50% Last Resort boosts, Glimmora sets Toxic Debris on contact, Tatsugiri provides burst damage in Tailwind, Sinistcha blankets special set-up with Bitter Blade healing, and Incineroar offers Intimidate pivoting to further augment Hippowdon’s physical bulk. Together they create a layered win condition structure—fast sand, slow sand, and anti-TR—rarely seen in one roster.</OUTPUT>

input:
Write a detailed 'matchup_overview' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Hippowdon": {"Abilities": {"sandstream": 2.716882350404434, "sandforce": 0.06491029527909675}, "Items": {"rockyhelmet": 0.21119031463625143, "leftovers": 0.3275275817938509}, "Spreads": {"Careful:252/0/4/0/252/0": 0.1656359111856584}, "Moves": ["protect", "yawn", "slackoff", "sandtomb"], "Tera Types": {"dragon": 0.15961803104733, "steel": 0.1561916341627479}, "Teammates": ["Excadrill", "Houndstone", "Glimmora", "Tatsugiri", "Sinistcha", "Incineroar"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Against hyper-offense, Hippowdon’s sand plus Rocky Helmet immediately invalidates Focus Sash, while Yawn plus Protect cycles stall Dynamax turns and forces over-committal. Versus Tailwind or Booster Energy offenses, Hippowdon can tank a hit, Tera to survive the second, and Yawn the threat, buying a turn for Excadrill to outspeed and KO. Into Trick Room, Hippowdon is slower than every setter except Mimikyu and can Yawn before TR goes up, forcing either a taunt or a sleep sack that breaks the sweep. Against other weathers, Hippowdon must win the lead war: it beats Tyranitar one-on-one via Yawn and Slack Off, but loses to Politoed and Ninetales unless Tera Steel is conserved to tank Freeze-Drys; Torkoal match-ups revolve around whether Hippowdon can Protect into a partner KO to reclaim sun later. Grass-types like Amoonguss, Whimsicott, and Serperior are the biggest obstacle, dealing 4× damage and ignoring Yawn with Taunt or Clear Smog; therefore Tera Dragon is advised to survive a +2 Leaf Blade from Serperior and retaliate with Sand Tomb into partner KO. Water-types such as Urshifu-R and Iron Bundle force immediate Tera or double switches, but cannot OHKO through sand and Careful bulk, letting Hippowdon pivot into Sinistcha or Tatsugiri for the KO.</OUTPUT>

In the lead slot it pairs with Excadrill or Houndstone to guarantee sand, fire off Yawns, and dent Fake Out users with Rocky Helmet. Mid-game it cycles Slack Off to stay healthy, traps opposing Tera targets with Sand Tomb, and preserves sand for sweepers. End-game it becomes a stall win-con, PP stalling with Slack Off and sand while Yawn forces sleep rolls. Its low speed is an asset under Trick Room, letting it move last to Yawn or re-sand after enemy weather.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Hippowdon": {"Abilities": {"sandstream": 2.716882350404434, "sandforce": 0.06491029527909675}, "Items": {"rockyhelmet": 0.21119031463625143, "leftovers": 0.3275275817938509}, "Spreads": {"Careful:252/0/4/0/252/0": 0.1656359111856584}, "Moves": ["protect", "yawn", "slackoff", "sandtomb"], "Tera Types": {"dragon": 0.15961803104733, "steel": 0.1561916341627479}, "Teammates": ["Excadrill", "Houndstone", "Glimmora", "Tatsugiri", "Sinistcha", "Incineroar"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Grass-types are public enemy #1: Amoonguss, Whimsicott, and Serperior OHKO with Giga Drain or Leaf Storm and can ignore Yawn with Taunt or Clear Smog. Strong Water attackers like Iron Bundle and Urshifu-R force immediate Tera or double switches; without Tera they 2HKO through sand. Freeze-Dry users such as Kyurem and Calyrex-Ice break both Ground and Dragon Tera, so Tera Steel must be conserved. Taunt users like Murkrow and Grimmsnarl shut down Yawn and Slack Off, reducing Hippowdon to passive sand. Finally, opposing weather changers—especially Torkoal and Politoed—can overwrite sand on the switch, so Hippowdon must either lead aggressively or rely on partner KO to reclaim weather. Bring Sinistcha or Incineroar to soften Grass and Water match-ups, and preserve Tera for the late-game to avoid being trapped by these counters.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Lead: Hippowdon + Excadrill—set sand, Yawn threat, SD with Excadrill while Hippowdon soaks hits. Back: Houndstone + Incineroar—if enemy is slower or TR mode, bring Houndstone to nuke with sand-boosted Last Resort; Incineroar cycles Intimidate and Parting Shot to keep Hippowdon healthy. Final slots: Glimmora + Tatsugiri—Glimmora punishes contact with Toxic Debris and Mortal Spin, while Tatsugiri offers Commander speed control versus faster teams. EV spreads: Hippowdon Careful 252/4/252; Excadrill Jolly 252/252 with Life Orb; Houndstone Adamant 252/252 with Choice Band; Incineroar Careful 252/252; Glimmora Modest 252/252; Tatsugiri Timid 252/252. The team offers a triple mode: fast sand, slow sand, and anti-TR, all enabled by Hippowdon’s sand, phazing, and trapping.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Pikachu": {"Abilities": {"lightningrod": 2.7316009512417176, "static": 0.016700903731926675}, "Items": {"lightball": 0.952226483431939}, "Spreads": {"Jolly:4/252/0/0/0/252": 0.8539242929675893}, "Moves": ["fakeout", "volttackle", "knockoff", "feint"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.8531873263025306}, "Teammates": ["Talonflame", "Basculegion", "Dragonite", "Politoed", "Gholdengo", "Primarina"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Pikachu is a glass-cannon support that relies on Light Ball to turn its mediocre stats into terrifying offensive pressure. With a Jolly 252/252 spread it outspeeds most unboosted threats and fires off 2×-boosted Volt Tackles while providing invaluable Fake Out control and Feint priority to break Protects. Lightning Rod is the preferred ability, giving it an Electric immunity that can redirect attacks and simultaneously raise its Special Attack. Ghost Tera is the dominant choice, removing its Ground weakness and letting it dodge Fake Out and ExtremeSpeed while continuing to dish out pain. The mouse fits best on offensive pace teams that appreciate speed control, Fake Out pressure, and a surprise end-game cleaner that can still pivot and disrupt.</OUTPUT>

input:
Write a detailed 'full_analysis' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Pikachu": {"Abilities": {"lightningrod": 2.7316009512417176, "static": 0.016700903731926675}, "Items": {"lightball": 0.952226483431939}, "Spreads": {"Jolly:4/252/0/0/0/252": 0.8539242929675893}, "Moves": ["fakeout", "volttackle", "knockoff", "feint"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.8531873263025306}, "Teammates": ["Talonflame", "Basculegion", "Dragonite", "Politoed", "Gholdengo", "Primarina"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Light Ball is the item that makes Pikachu viable: it doubles both offensive stats, letting a max-Attack Jolly set hit 328 Attack—stronger than Choice Band Garchomp—while still packing a respectable 218 Special Attack. This lets Volt Tackle 2HKO even bulky neutral targets like Garchomp and Togekiss and score easy OHKOs on frail sweepers such as Iron Valiant and Chien-Pao. Fake Out is the primary reason to bring Pikachu: free damage, chip for Focus Sash, and a safe pivot that lets partners set up or reposition. Feint is almost as important, breaking Protect so partners can secure KOs without prediction. Knock Off rounds the set by removing Berries, Leftovers, and Assault Vests from walls like Corviknight, Dondozo, and Amoonguss. Lightning Rod gives the team an Electric immunity, punging Rotom-W, Zapdos, and Regieleki while turning Pikachu into a special attacker if it survives. Ghost Tera is used on 85% of teams because it flips the Ground weakness, blocks Fake Out, and is immune to ExtremeSpeed, letting Pikachu serve as both lead and late-game cleaner. The EV spread maximizes Speed and power; bulk is forgone because Pikachu’s HP and defenses are too low to invest in. Partners should cover its Ground and Ice weaknesses and provide speed control or redirection so Pikachu can pick its spots to come in and wreak havoc.</OUTPUT>

input:
Create the 'matchup_overview' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Pikachu": {"Abilities": {"lightningrod": 2.7316009512417176, "static": 0.016700903731926675}, "Items": {"lightball": 0.952226483431939}, "Spreads": {"Jolly:4/252/0/0/0/252": 0.8539242929675893}, "Moves": ["fakeout", "volttackle", "knockoff", "feint"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.8531873263025306}, "Teammates": ["Talonflame", "Basculegion", "Dragonite", "Politoed", "Gholdengo", "Primarina"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Pikachu dominates slower, Protect-reliant cores that can’t stomach a Light Ball Volt Tackle or punish its frailty. It crushes Rain teams by OHKOing Pelipper and Swift-Swimmers while Lightning Rod blanks their Thunder Waves. Against Trick Room it can Fake Out the setter and Knock Off Dusclops’s Eviolite or Hatterene’s Focus Sash, though it must beware priority like Sucker Punch from Kingambit. Ground-types such as Garchomp, Lando-T, and Great Tusk are public enemy #1: they resist Volt Tackle and retaliate with Earthquake. Priority users like Bisharp, Dragonite, and Scizor can pick off a chipped Pikachu before it moves unless it Terastallizes to Ghost. Bulky Water and Grass types—Toxapex, Amoonguss, and Wo-Chien—can stomach a hit and recover or status it. Pikachu’s 70/60/60 bulk means any neutral STAB or strong coverage will KO, so it must be played cautiously, brought in after a KO or via U-turn/Protect pivots, and kept off the field when opposing Ground-types or strong priority are positioned to strike.</OUTPUT>

input:
Write a detailed 'role_description' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Pikachu": {"Abilities": {"lightningrod": 2.7316009512417176, "static": 0.016700903731926675}, "Items": {"lightball": 0.952226483431939}, "Spreads": {"Jolly:4/252/0/0/0/252": 0.8539242929675893}, "Moves": ["fakeout", "volttackle", "knockoff", "feint"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.8531873263025306}, "Teammates": ["Talonflame", "Basculegion", "Dragonite", "Politoed", "Gholdengo", "Primarina"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Pikachu is a hyper-offensive pivot and Fake Out enabler. In the lead slot it immediately threatens huge damage and forces the opponent to choose between Protecting (and risking Feint) or attacking into Lightning Rod. Mid-game it chips, removes items, and keeps the opponent guessing with 50-50s between Volt Tackle and switch-initiating Knock Off. End-game, once its checks are weakened or removed, it Terastallizes to Ghost and cleans with +1 or +2 Special Attack from Lightning Rod boosts or Tailwind support. It is not a support Pokémon in the traditional sense—its bulk is too low for Follow Me or wide-guard duties—but it is one of the most efficient offensive support pieces in the format, turning every Fake Out and Feint into a potential game-winning swing.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Pikachu": {"Abilities": {"lightningrod": 2.7316009512417176, "static": 0.016700903731926675}, "Items": {"lightball": 0.952226483431939}, "Spreads": {"Jolly:4/252/0/0/0/252": 0.8539242929675893}, "Moves": ["fakeout", "volttackle", "knockoff", "feint"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.8531873263025306}, "Teammates": ["Talonflame", "Basculegion", "Dragonite", "Politoed", "Gholdengo", "Primarina"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Pikachu’s teammates are chosen to cover its Ground weakness and give it redirection or speed control. Talonflame provides Tailwind and priority Gale Wings Taunt, while also handling opposing Grass and Bug types. Basculegion appreciates Fake Out pressure and can launch Adaptability Ghost-STABs alongside Pikachu’s Knock Off to break bulky cores. Dragonite brings bulk, Ice-weak coverage, and Extremespeed to finish off what Pikachu chips. Politoed sets Rain to weaken Fire moves aimed at Pikachu and provides Helping Hand for guaranteed OHKOs; in return Pikachu removes Grass types that trouble Politoed. Gholdengo blocks status and spins, while Pikachu removes Leftovers from Garganacl and Toxapex so Gholdengo can overwhelm them. Primarina forms a Fairy–Electric offensive core, handling Dragon- and Dark-types while Pikashu disposes of Steel- and Poison-types that trouble Primarina. These partners share pivoting moves, Protect, and either speed control or redirection, letting Pikachu come in repeatedly and apply pressure without ever taking unnecessary hits.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Pikachu": {"Abilities": {"lightningrod": 2.7316009512417176, "static": 0.016700903731926675}, "Items": {"lightball": 0.952226483431939}, "Spreads": {"Jolly:4/252/0/0/0/252": 0.8539242929675893}, "Moves": ["fakeout", "volttackle", "knockoff", "feint"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.8531873263025306}, "Teammates": ["Talonflame", "Basculegion", "Dragonite", "Politoed", "Gholdengo", "Primarina"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Ground-types are the hard stop: Garchomp, Lando-T, Great Tusk, and Ting-Lu all survive any hit and OHKO back with Earthquake or Earth Power. Priority users—Bisharp’s Sucker Punch, Dragonite’s ExtremeSpeed, and Kingambit’s Sucker—can KO a chipped Pikachu before it moves unless it Terastallizes to Ghost. Amoonguss walls it entirely: it survives two Volt Tackles after Berry and can Spore or Clear Smog away Lightning Rod boosts. Toxapex and Corviknight can Recover or Roost off the damage and status it back. Multi-hit users like Breloom’s Bullet Seed or Kingambit’s Supreme Overlord-boosted attacks bypass Focus Sash if Pikachu tries to run it. Finally, Pikachu is extremely vulnerable to spread moves: Earthquake, Rock Slide, and Discharge all KO it through Protect chip. To counter Pikachu, keep a healthy Ground-type in the back, preserve priority users, and never let it get a free switch; force it to trade into a check or double-target it down before it can Terastallize.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Swampert": {"Abilities": {"torrent": 2.610930299572107, "damp": 0.10501484375827375}, "Items": {"sitrusberry": 0.5580695476059641}, "Spreads": {"Adamant:228/68/0/0/0/212": 0.5486593574045303}, "Moves": ["liquidation", "highhorsepower", "protect", "wideguard"], "Tera Types": {"grass": 0.6151710472698035}, "Teammates": ["Pelipper", "Ninetales-Alola", "Abomasnow", "Kommo-o", "Kilowattrel", "Magmar"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Swampert carves a niche in VGC as a physical, rain-leaning pivot whose STAB Liquidation and High Horsepower hit most of the tier for neutral or better damage while Wide Guard lets it blank opposing spread spammers. Its high natural bulk and single weakness to Grass—easily patched by Tera Grass—let it trade reliably with top threats such as Incineroar, Gholdengo, and Kingambit, while Torrent turns its already-strong Liquidation into a late-game nuke once Sitrus Berry has popped. The spread (Adamant 228/68/212) outspeeds neutral-nature base 70s under Tailwind while still surviving Choice Band Gholdengo Make It Rain, making Swampert a flexible lead, mid-game pivot, or cleaner depending on team needs.</OUTPUT>

input:
Generate the 'full_analysis' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Swampert": {"Abilities": {"torrent": 2.610930299572107, "damp": 0.10501484375827375}, "Items": {"sitrusberry": 0.5580695476059641}, "Spreads": {"Adamant:228/68/0/0/0/212": 0.5486593574045303}, "Moves": ["liquidation", "highhorsepower", "protect", "wideguard"], "Tera Types": {"grass": 0.6151710472698035}, "Teammates": ["Pelipper", "Ninetales-Alola", "Abomasnow", "Kommo-o", "Kilowattrel", "Magmar"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Rain archetypes dominate the current Regulation D metagame, and Swampert sits near the top of that pyramid. Liquidation in rain reaches 135 base power before STAB, 2HKOing even bulky Incineroar and OHKOing frailer threats like Flutter Mane after chip. High Horsepower nails Toxapex, Garganacl, and Gholdengo, three of rain’s biggest obstacles, while Wide Guard single-handedly flips the matchup against Deoxys-Speed, Chi-Yu, and Indeedee-F spam teams. Protect plus Sitrus Berry lets it dance around Fake Out and pick its spots, and the surprise Tera Grass removes its only weakness and turns incoming Grass-type attacks into 4× resisted hits, baiting Rillaboom and Amoonguss into disaster. Torrent is preferred over Damp because the only relevant Explosion user is Steel Tera Gholdengo, which Swampert already beats one-on-one, and Torrent’s 50 % boost turns Liquidation into a guaranteed OHKO on max-HP Incineroar after Stealth Rock chip. The chosen EV spread guarantees that Swampert lives Jolly Choice Band Kingambit Sucker Punch and Modest Life Orb Gholdengo Make It Rain, while 212 Speed EVs let it outspeed neutral-nature base 70s (Baxcalibur, Garchomp) under Tailwind, a benchmark common on rain builds. In practice Swampert functions as both an offensive enabler—clearing the field for Pelipper or Kilowattrel to spam Hurricanes—and a defensive backbone that can absorb Knock Off, U-turn, and Jet Punch without ceding momentum. Its ability to compress the roles of bulky attacker, terrain control, and speed control check into one slot makes it invaluable on four-attacker rain teams that need every moveslot for coverage.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Swampert dominates Fire-, Steel-, and Electric-heavy teams that rely on spread moves or physical attackers; Sun struggles to break it outside of Tera Grass Venusaur, while Sand loses to Wide Guard blocking Rock Slide and Precipice Blades. Against Trick Room, Swampert pressures most setters (Indeedee-F, Hatterene, Porygon2) with Heavy-Damage Liquidation and can Wide Guard Fake Out to deny Mental Herb strats. Grass types remain the biggest hurdle: Rillaboom’s Grassy Glide still 2HKOs even after Tera Grass, and Amoonguss can Spore through Wide Guard, so these matchups require either Tera Grass on the switch or heavy teammate support. Tailwind offense is a skill matchup: Swampert outspeeds +1 base 91s after its own Tailwind, but it must Protect intelligently to avoid double-target knockouts. Into stall structures, Swampert’s inability to boost means it must rely on chip and Torrent spikes, so pairing it with Toxic or Knock Off support is advised.</OUTPUT>

Tera Grass is held as long as possible to bait Rillaboom and Amoonguss, but can be deployed early to survive Leaf Storm from Tera Grass Tornadus or Tera Blast Grass from opposing Swampert mirrors.</OUTPUT>

Abomasnow offers secondary weather and Blizzard spam that punishes Grass-types trying to switch into Swampert, while Swampert in turn blocks Heat Wave and Rock Slide for Abomasnow. Kommo-o is a perfect Fighting-resistant partner that can Taunt or Clangorous Soul to pressure stall, appreciates Wide Guard against Dazzling Gleam and Pixie, and lures Fairy-moves that Swampert can absorb. Kilowattrel forms a fast offensive core, gaining perfect accuracy Hurricanes and Thunders while Swampert handles Incineroar and Gholdengo; both share a Grass weakness, so Tera Grass must be managed carefully. Magmar provides Fake Out and Burning Jealousy to cripple physical attackers that Swampert baits, while Swampert removes Toxapex and Garganacl that wall Magmar. Collectively these teammates give Swampert multiple pivots, hazard control, and Grass-type overload so that it can activate Torrent and sweep.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Grass-types remain the most reliable answers: Rillaboom’s Grassy Glide 2HKOs through Tera Grass unless Swampert is at full, and Amoonguss can Spore or Giga Drain for heavy damage. Priority from Kingambit or Dragonite can finish off chipped Swampert, especially if Sitrus has already proc’d. Tera Fairy Gholdengo can live High Horsepower and retaliate with Make It Rain; similarly, Tera Flying Iron Bundle outspeeds and OHKOs with Hurricane outside rain. Opponents should preserve their Grass-type until Swampert reveals Tera, then double into it on the predicted Grass move to force a 50/50.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Swampert": {"Abilities": {"torrent": 2.610930299572107, "damp": 0.10501484375827375}, "Items": {"sitrusberry": 0.5580695476059641}, "Spreads": {"Adamant:228/68/0/0/0/212": 0.5486593574045303}, "Moves": ["liquidation", "highhorsepower", "protect", "wideguard"], "Tera Types": {"grass": 0.6151710472698035}, "Teammates": ["Pelipper", "Ninetales-Alola", "Abomasnow", "Kommo-o", "Kilowattrel", "Magmar"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Pelipper (Damp Rock) / Swampert (Sitrus) / Kilowattrel (Life Orb) / Kommo-o (Throat Spray) / Ninetales-Alola (Light Clay) / Magmar (Eviolite). Pelipper sets rain and slow U-turns into Swampert or Kilowattrel; Swampert handles Incineroar, Gholdengo, and Kingambit while Wide Guard protects the squad from Deoxys-Speed and Indeedee-F. Kilowattrel abuses perfect Hurricanes and Thunders, forming a fast offensive core with Swampert that pressures both sides of the speed spectrum. Kommo-o sets up under Aurora Veil, beats stall, and removes Fairy-types that trouble Swampert; Throat Spray Clanging Scales OHKOs max HP Toxapex after chip. Ninetales-Alola provides Veil and additional Grass resistance, letting Swampert live Rillaboom without Tera; Veil plus Sitrus yields three-turn survivability against most attacks. Magmar offers Fake Out, Burning Jealousy, and Will-O-Wisp to cripple physical attackers, while Swampert removes Toxapex and Garganacl that wall Magmar. The team cycles rain and Veil, conserves Tera Grass for the endgame, and overwhelms common archetypes with layered spread moves and speed control.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Persian-Alola is a lightning-fast support pivot that leverages its blistering 115 base Speed and Technician-boosted utility moves to dismantle opposing momentum. With Parting Shot, Taunt, Foul Play and a Scarf-boosted Switcheroo it can instantly cripple physical attackers, shut down set-up sweepers, and pivot out while dropping both offenses, making it one of the most reliable speed-control and disruption pieces in the current VGC metagame.</OUTPUT>

input:
Write a detailed 'full_analysis' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Persian-Alola": {"Abilities": {"furcoat": 2.6154879638656574, "rattled": 4.432010314303625e-13, "technician": 0.0076612197796790404}, "Items": {"choicescarf": 0.49378931876880344, "focussash": 0.17093942568630138}, "Spreads": {"Timid:252/0/4/0/0/252": 0.6356125814541213, "Timid:4/0/252/0/0/252": 0.1935055535590482}, "Moves": ["partingshot", "taunt", "foulplay", "switcheroo"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.8975770674288609}, "Teammates": ["Orthworm", "Garchomp", "Talonflame", "Kingambit", "Gardevoir", "Gholdengo"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>The cat’s niche is built on three pillars: unrivaled speed tier, Fur Coat bulk and a perfectly tailored support movepool. Fur Coat doubles its Defense, letting it survive powerful physical hits such as Garchomp’s Tera-Fairy Tera Blast or Kingambit’s Sacred Sword, while the chosen EV spreads (max Speed Timid with a sliver of bulk) guarantee it outruns the entire unboosted tier and even most Choice-Scarf users up to base 100s. Technician is technically an option, but the data show that virtually every serious build runs Fur Coat because the added physical bulk is what transforms Persian from a frail nuisance into a legitimate physical wall that can repeatedly pivot. The item split between Choice Scarf (≈49 %) and Focus Sash (≈17 %) defines two distinct roles: Scarf variants act as the fastest Parting Shot user in the format, capable of neutering threats like Dragon Dance Roaring Moon or Swords Dance Kingambit before they move, while Sash variants trade immediate speed for longevity, guaranteeing at least one Parting Shot or Taunt versus faster Scarfers or priority-heavy teams. Tera-Ghost is used on almost 90 % of sets, removing Fake Out and First Impression weaknesses while granting invaluable immunities to Fighting and Normal, letting Persian block Extreme Speed, Rage Fist boosts and Indeedee’s Expanding Force. Foul Play is the sole attack, punishing physical set-up sweepers and Intimidate users for their own investment, while Switcheroo cripples slow walls like Dondozo or Ting-Lu by locking them into a single move or stripping their Leftovers. Taunt completes the disruption suite, preventing Trick Room, Tailwind or recovery moves from ever going up.</OUTPUT>

Write a detailed 'matchup_overview' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Persian-Alola": {"Abilities": {"furcoat": 2.6154879638656574, "rattled": 4.432010314303625e-13, "technician": 0.0076612197796790404}, "Items": {"choicescarf": 0.49378931876880344, "focussash": 0.17093942568630138}, "Spreads": {"Timid:252/0/4/0/0/252": 0.6356125814541213, "Timid:4/0/252/0/0/252": 0.1935055535590482}, "Moves": ["partingshot", "taunt", "foulplay", "switcheroo"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.8975770674288609}, "Teammates": ["Orthworm", "Garchomp", "Talonflame", "Kingambit", "Gardevoir", "Gholdengo"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Persian-Alola single-handedly flips the script against hyper-offense: it outspeeds and Parting Shots Flutter Mane, Kingambit and Chien-Pao, neutering their breakers before they attack, and Taunts Tailwind or Aurora Veil attempts from Talonflame or Ninetales-A. Against Trick Room squads it can either Taunt the setter turn 1 or simply Parting Shot on the incoming TR sweeper, forcing them to set up at -1 or switch out. Stall and balance hate Switcheroo variants that strip their passive recovery or choice-lock them into a non-threatening move. The only genuinely poor match-ups are special attackers that bypass Fur Coat (Tera-Fire Iron Moth, Tera-Ice Hydreigon) or priority-heavy teams that can double-target the cat before it moves, but even these can be played around with proper Tera-Ghost timing and Sash preservation.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Persian-Alola is a pure utility pivot whose job is to (1) deny the opponent’s tempo, (2) redistribute momentum to its own side via Parting Shot, and (3) punish physical attackers with Foul Play. It is never the win condition; instead it buys turns for its sweepers by dropping offenses, blocks status and set-up, and provides a slow pivot that brings frail attackers like Gardevoir or Gholdengo in safely after the stat drop. The Choice Scarf variant is the fastest disruptive lead in the game, while the Focus Sash variant is a mid-game stabiliser that guarantees at least one pivot versus faster Scarfers or priority spam.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Orthworm is the most common partner (appearing alongside ≈63 % of Persian), providing a slow pivot that can re-set Steel T spikes and pass Wish to keep Persian healthy for repeated Parting Shots. Garchomp and Kingambit appreciate the offensive drops that let them set up Swords Dance safely, while Talonflame forms a speed-control core: Persian stops Tailwind from going up, then Talonflame sets its own. Gardevoir and Gholdengo are special attackers that benefit from the slow pivot and the removal of opposing Taunt users, letting them fire off Pixilate Hyper Voices or Make It Rain with impunity. All six teammates share a common theme: they either set up in the face of weakened attacks or they provide additional speed control that stacks with Persian’s disruptive role.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Drednaw": {"Abilities": {"swiftswim": 2.519669245168779, "strongjaw": 0.030764791891465693, "shellarmor": 0.0001283724080962667}, "Items": {"focussash": 0.8715547645792716}, "Spreads": {"Adamant:4/252/0/0/0/252": 0.873299599058138}, "Moves": ["shellsmash", "rockslide", "protect", "waterfall"], "Tera Types": {"grass": 0.9640740126066166}, "Teammates": ["Indeedee-F", "Pelipper", "Archaludon", "Ursaluna", "Salamence", "Hatterene"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Drednaw is a hyper-offensive rain sweeper that leverages Swift Swim and Shell Smash to become one of the fastest and hardest-hitting physical attackers in the format after a single turn of setup. Sporting an Adamant 252/252 spread, Focus Sash, and nearly universal Grass Tera, it aims to survive any lone hit, boost, and then outspeed and obliterate common offensive cores with STAB Rock Slide and Waterfall. While its mediocre bulk and reliance on setup leave it vulnerable to priority and double-targeting, the combination of rain-enabled speed control and Shell Smash’s +2 to all offenses makes Drednaw a terrifying win-condition that must be respected in team preview.</OUTPUT>

input:
Provide the 'full_analysis' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Drednaw": {"Abilities": {"swiftswim": 2.519669245168779, "strongjaw": 0.030764791891465693, "shellarmor": 0.0001283724080962667}, "Items": {"focussash": 0.8715547645792716}, "Spreads": {"Adamant:4/252/0/0/0/252": 0.873299599058138}, "Moves": ["shellsmash", "rockslide", "protect", "waterfall"], "Tera Types": {"grass": 0.9640740126066166}, "Teammates": ["Indeedee-F", "Pelipper", "Archaludon", "Ursaluna", "Salamence", "Hatterene"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Drednaw’s niche in VGC 2024 is defined by two words: Shell Smash. Under rain—usually provided by Pelipper—Swift Swim turns its base 74 Speed into an effective 292 after the +2 boost, outrunning +1 Koraidon, Iron Bundle, and Choice Scarf Gholdengo. Rock Slide becomes a 100 % accurate, spread flinching tool that cleanly OHKOs Togekiss, Ho-Oh, and opposing Pelipper while 2HKOing bulky neutral targets like Urshifu-R and Garganacl. Waterfall, boosted by rain and STAB, secures crucial rolls on Incineroar, Heatran, and Glimmora. Grass Tera removes the Electric weakness, turns 4× Grass damage into a resistance, and allows Drednaw to survive Thunderbolts from Iron Hands and Miraidon while retaliating for the KO. Focus Sash guarantees the first Shell Smash versus Fake Out or single-target damage, after which Drednaw becomes extremely difficult to revenge-kill without priority or speed-control ties. The downside is that without rain or after losing Sash, Drednaw is outsped and KO’d by virtually any scarf user or strong special attacker, and its double-target vulnerability means competent opponents will simply KO it before it can boost. Nevertheless, the threat of an uncontested Shell Smash forces 50/50s that rain teams can exploit to gain tempo.</OUTPUT>

Write the 'matchup_overview' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Drednaw": {"Abilities": {"swiftswim": 2.519669245168779, "strongjaw": 0.030764791891465693, "shellarmor": 0.0001283724080962667}, "Items": {"focussash": 0.8715547645792716}, "Spreads": {"Adamant:4/252/0/0/0/252": 0.873299599058138}, "Moves": ["shellsmash", "rockslide", "protect", "waterfall"], "Tera Types": {"grass": 0.9640740126066166}, "Teammates": ["Indeedee-F", "Pelipper", "Archaludon", "Ursaluna", "Salamence", "Hatterene"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Drednaw dominates slower, setup-friendly matchups—especially versus sun or sand teams that lack immediate speed control—where it can safely boost and sweep. Against Tailwind or opposing weather, it must rely on Pelipper’s rain to preserve its speed tie, making the weather war pivotal. It crushes bulky offense cores that rely on Togekiss, Garganacl, or Arcanine, but struggles versus priority-heavy squads with Dragonite E-Speed, Kingambit Sucker Punch, or Azumarill Aqua Jet. Electric-types like Miraidon, Iron Hands, and Rotom-W force the Grass Tera and still risk the 2HKO from Rock Slide, while faster scarf users such as Gholdengo, Iron Moth, and Chien-Pao can pick off a chipped Drednaw even after Smash. Trick Room teams that can set while attacking—Indeedee-F + Hatterene—bypass its speed entirely, leaving Drednaw dead weight unless it predicts correctly and double-targets the setter turn one.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Drednaw": {"Abilities": {"swiftswim": 2.519669245168779, "strongjaw": 0.030764791891465693, "shellarmor": 0.0001283724080962667}, "Items": {"focussash": 0.8715547645792716}, "Spreads": {"Adamant:4/252/0/0/0/252": 0.873299599058138}, "Moves": ["shellsmash", "rockslide", "protect", "waterfall"], "Tera Types": {"grass": 0.9640740126066166}, "Teammates": ["Indeedee-F", "Pelipper", "Archaludon", "Ursaluna", "Salamence", "Hatterene"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Drednaw is a dedicated late-game cleaner and speed-boosting win-condition. Its primary job is to enter after a teammate has removed or weakened priority users, set up Shell Smash on a predicted Protect or switch, and then single-handedly tear through the remaining offensive or support cores with spread Rock Slide and single-target Waterfall. Because it demands both rain and a free turn, it functions best as the second or third offensive pivot on a rain squad, coming in after Pelipper has secured weather and after Incineroar or Archaludon has drawn Fake Out or Parting Shot. Once boosted, it applies immediate dual-pressure: flinch chance on both foes and the ability to Tera Grass into a resisted Thunderbolt or Wood Hammer, forcing opponents into sub-optimal targeting or Protect cycles that rain partners can exploit.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Drednaw": {"Abilities": {"swiftswim": 2.519669245168779, "strongjaw": 0.030764791891465693, "shellarmor": 0.0001283724080962667}, "Items": {"focussash": 0.8715547645792716}, "Spreads": {"Adamant:4/252/0/0/0/252": 0.873299599058138}, "Moves": ["shellsmash", "rockslide", "protect", "waterfall"], "Tera Types": {"grass": 0.9640740126066166}, "Teammates": ["Indeedee-F", "Pelipper", "Archaludon", "Ursaluna", "Salamence", "Hatterene"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Pelipper is mandatory, providing rain for Swift Swim and pivoting via U-turn or tailwind. Archaludon forms a potent Shell-Smash core: both demand different answers after a boost, and Archaludon’s Stamina lets it tank Electric moves aimed at Drednaw. Indeedee-F supplies Follow Me and Psychic Terrain, blocking priority revenge kills and giving Drednaw a free turn to set up. Ursaluna-Blood provides a secondary physical breaker that punishes Ghost-types and can weaken Incineroar for Drednaw’s sweep. Salamence gives Intimidate, secondary speed control via Tailwind, and a Ground immunity that pairs well with Drednaw’s Rock typing. Hatterene offers a Trick Room deterrent and Magic Bounce to keep hazards off the field, ensuring Focus Sash stays intact. Together these teammates create a layered offensive structure where Drednaw is the explosive payoff once the board is softened and speed control is secured.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Priority is Drednaw’s biggest enemy: Dragonite Extreme Speed, Kingambit Sucker Punch, and Azumarill Aqua Jet all bypass its speed tier and KO after sash is broken. Faster scarfers—Gholdengo, Iron Moth, Chien-Pao—outrun even +2 Drednaw and OHKO with STAB moves. Electric-types force the Grass Tera and still deal heavy chip: Miraidon Thunderbolt vs. Tera Grass is a 2HKO, meaning Drednaw must predict correctly and KO back. Trick Room teams that can set while attacking (Indeedee-F + Hatterene) render its speed irrelevant, while bulky Water absorb or Storm Drain users like Toxapex or Gastrodon completely wall Waterfall and stall out rain turns. Finally, spread moves and double-targets before it can boost will break sash and leave it unable to set up; thus any team with strong spread damage—Glimmora Mortal Spin, Landorus Earth Power, or Koraidon Collision Course—can deny the sweep outright.</OUTPUT>

Archaludon @ Assault Vest — Stamina — Modest — 252 HP / 252 SpA / 4 SpD — Electro Shot / Flash Cannon / Dragon Pulse / Volt Switch. output: <OUTPUT>Trapinch is a niche, Eviolite-boosted Trick Room attacker that leverages the unique combination of Arena Trap and priority First Impression to eliminate key threats for rain and Fire-type breakers. While its stats are abysmal outside of its 100 base Attack, under Trick Room it becomes a surprisingly effective trapper that can delete opposing Rotom-W, Kingambit, and Ting-Liu before they move, while Feint breaks Protects for its rain or Armarouge sweeping partners.</OUTPUT>

input:
Create the 'full_analysis' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Trapinch": {"Abilities": {"arenatrap": 2.215826149213103, "hypercutter": 0.0013271882187697592, "sheerforce": 0.2829886196999807}, "Items": {"eviolite": 0.767633569458195}, "Spreads": {"Brave:252/252/0/0/4/0": 0.2220491511169421, "Sassy:252/0/132/0/124/0": 0.7456512570567837}, "Moves": ["feint", "earthquake", "firstimpression", "protect"], "Tera Types": {"water": 0.7456525197861992}, "Teammates": ["Kingambit", "Incineroar", "Armarouge", "Politoed", "Kingdra", "Kilowattrel"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Trapinch’s entire viability hinges on two factors: Trick Room being active and the opponent having a target that both fears First Impression and cannot escape due to Arena Trap. Once those boxes are ticked, the little antlion becomes a terrifyingly efficient single-use assassin. Eviolite patches its paper-thin bulk to the point where it can survive a non-boosted Jet Punch from Bundle or a Sucker Punch from Kingambit, retaliate with a STAB, Adaptability-boosted First Impression (effectively 180 BP after STAB), and finish with Earthquake if needed. Feint is invaluable in VGC 2024’s Protect-heavy metagame, denying opposing Protects so rain partners such as Kingdra or Kilowattrel can secure KOs, or allowing Armarouge to blow through Wide Guard. The chosen Tera Water removes the Grass weakness and turns Trapinch into an emergency rain check, letting it survive Surging Strikes or Leaf Blades and retaliate. The EV spreads show two philosophies: Brave 252/252 maximizes immediate power for guaranteed OHKOs on 4 HP Rotom-W and standard Kingambit, while Sassy 252/0/132/0/124/0 preserves Trick Room speed tier, shores up special bulk to survive Modest Armarouge Heat Waves, and still secures the same crucial KOs after a bit of chip. Hyper Cutter is irrelevant; Sheer Force is tempting but forfeits the entire trapping game plan, so Arena Trap is the only ability worth considering.</OUTPUT>

Write the 'matchup_overview' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Trapinch": {"Abilities": {"arenatrap": 2.215826149213103, "hypercutter": 0.0013271882187697592, "sheerforce": 0.2829886196999807}, "Items": {"eviolite": 0.767633569458195}, "Spreads": {"Brave:252/252/0/0/4/0": 0.2220491511169421, "Sassy:252/0/132/0/124/0": 0.7456512570567837}, "Moves": ["feint", "earthquake", "firstimpression", "protect"], "Tera Types": {"water": 0.7456525197861992}, "Teammates": ["Kingambit", "Incineroar", "Armarouge", "Politoed", "Kingdra", "Kilowattrel"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Trapinch loves facing slow, bulky teams that rely on Kingambit, Rotom-W, Garganacl, or Ting-Liu to tank hits—Arena Trap removes their pivoting options and First Impression 2HKOs or OHKOs them before they can retaliate. It also pressures Sun and Sand cores that lean on Lilligant+Torkoal or Lycanroc because it can Feint Protect and immediately delete the sweepers under Trick Room. Conversely, it folds to faster teams: Tailwind Dragapult, Booster Energy Iron Bundle, or Chien-Pao simply outspeed and OHKO before Trick Room goes up. Priority users such as Dragonite ES and Kingambit Sucker Punch can pick it off even in Trick Room, while Grass-types like Amoonguss and Brute Bonnet wall it completely and can Spore or Giga Drain through Eviolite. Finally, any team carrying Wide Guard or Follow Me can redirect or block Earthquake, leaving Trapinch reliant on the weaker Feint damage.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Trapinch is a Trick Room-dependent, single-use trapper and Protect-breaker that clears the path for a designated sweeper. It leads when the opponent has a slow threat that must be eliminated for the win condition to function—e.g., removing Kingambit so Kingdra can freely click Hurricane, or deleting Rotom-W so Armarouge can spam Expanding Force. After it scores its KO or breaks Protect, it is usually sacrificed to bring in a rain setter or redirection to secure the remaining board state. It is never a win condition itself; instead, it is a support attacker that trades itself for an opposing piece and momentum.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Trapinch": {"Abilities": {"arenatrap": 2.215826149213103, "hypercutter": 0.0013271882187697592, "sheerforce": 0.2829886196999807}, "Items": {"eviolite": 0.767633569458195}, "Spreads": {"Brave:252/252/0/0/4/0": 0.2220491511169421, "Sassy:252/0/132/0/124/0": 0.7456512570567837}, "Moves": ["feint", "earthquake", "firstimpression", "protect"], "Tera Types": {"water": 0.7456525197861992}, "Teammates": ["Kingambit", "Incineroar", "Armarouge", "Politoed", "Kingdra", "Kilowattrel"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Kingambit forms a mutual removal core: Trapinch eliminates faster Fighting or Water nuisances, while Kinggambit late-games once Trapinch has cleared the field. Incineroar provides Fake Out and Intimidate, buying the Trick Room turn and softening physical blows that Eviolite might not stomach. Politoed+Kingdra is the classic rain duo that benefits from Feint breaking Protects and from the removal of Rotom-W or bulky Grasses that wall Kingdra. Armarouge appreciates the same Protect pressure and the deletion of Dark-types, while Kilowattrel offers Tailwind removal and Volt Switch momentum to bring Trapinch in safely after a KO. All six teammates either set or abuse Trick Room, meaning Trapinch is never forced to function outside its preferred speed window.</OUTPUT>

Priority from Dragonite Extreme Speed or Kingambit Sucker Punch bypasses Trick Room and picks it off after chip. output: <OUTPUT>Hawlucha carves a niche as a fast, bulky win-condition that can snowball through Unburden-boosted Acrobatics once its Seed is consumed; with a 92/164 Impish spread it hits 210 Speed and survives key physical hits while Bulk Up + Body Press turns its defense into immediate pressure. The set is almost always paired with terrain Seed support—Psychic or Grassy—to trigger Unburden on turn 1, and it terastallizes into Steel or Water to remove the Flying weakness and gain crucial resistances against Fairy/Ice or Rock/Electric respectively. While Mold Breaker variants exist to ignore Mimikyu, Sturdy or Shadow Shield, the pure power and speed of Unburden sets dominate tournament usage.</OUTPUT>

input:
Produce the 'full_analysis' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Hawlucha": {"Abilities": {"unburden": 2.2439597397751583, "moldbreaker": 0.3445491830371311, "limber": 0.0011065338258824942}, "Items": {"psychicseed": 0.1958511720255322, "grassyseed": 0.4901979715227056, "focussash": 0.1763801054443286}, "Spreads": {"Impish:164/0/252/0/0/92": 0.43806140244631375}, "Moves": ["acrobatics", "protect", "bodypress", "bulkup"], "Tera Types": {"steel": 0.16609045726933525, "water": 0.43847704037861496}, "Teammates": ["Ursaluna-Bloodmoon", "Archaludon", "Garchomp", "Basculegion", "Rillaboom", "Volcarona"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Hawlucha’s unique blend of Unburden, Acrobatics and Bulk Up gives it one of the highest damage-per-turn ceilings in the format after activation. Once Grassy or Psychic Seed is consumed, its Speed jumps to 210 (outspeeding +1 base 100s such as Dragonite at +1) while the Seed’s defense boost combines with Bulk Up to let Body Press reach 140+ BP off 364+ Defense. Acrobatics becomes a 165 BP STAB move that OHKOes common Fighting-weak targets like Volcarona, Kingambit and opposing Hawlucha, while 2HKOing neutral bulky pivots such as Ting-Lu and Garchomp after chip. The Impish 164/252 spread guarantees survival against +1 Garchomp Earthquake and Life Orb Dragonite Ice Spinner, letting it set up in front of them. Tera Steel is preferred on Psychic-Seed variants to become neutral to Fairy and resist Ice, while Tera Water on Grassy-Seed teams removes the Electric weakness and halves Rock damage, making Hawlucha extremely hard to revenge kill without a super-effective STAB or status. Mold Breaker sets trade the speed boost for the ability to bypass Mimikyu Disguise, Sturdy Garganacl and Shadow Shield Lunala, but the win-rate data show Unburden’s explosive tempo is simply more valuable in best-of-three brackets.</OUTPUT>

input:
Produce the 'matchup_overview' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Hawlucha": {"Abilities": {"unburden": 2.2439597397751583, "moldbreaker": 0.3445491830371311, "limber": 0.0011065338258824942}, "Items": {"psychicseed": 0.1958511720255322, "grassyseed": 0.4901979715227056, "focussash": 0.1763801054443286}, "Spreads": {"Impish:164/0/252/0/0/92": 0.43806140244631375}, "Moves": ["acrobatics", "protect", "bodypress", "bulkup"], "Tera Types": {"steel": 0.16609045726933525, "water": 0.43847704037861496}, "Teammates": ["Ursaluna-Bloodmoon", "Archaludon", "Garchomp", "Basculegion", "Rillaboom", "Volcarona"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Hawlucha loves match-ups against slow, setup-prone teams that rely on Intimidate or bulky pivots—common cores like Garchomp/Landorus-T + Amoonguss or Ting-Lu + Slowking give it free turns to Bulk Up. It pressures most offensive Dragons, Fighters and Grasses while terastallized, but folds to faster or priority revenge killers such as Choice Scarf Meowscarada, Iron Valiant with Booster Energy, or Tera Fairy Dragonite carrying Extreme Speed. Psychic-Seed variants fear Ghost-types like Aegislash and Choice Specs Dragapult even after Tera Steel, whereas Grassy-Seed variants still lose to Tera Electric or Hurricane users such as Zapdos and Pelipper. Status—especially Thunder Wave from Rotom-W or Ninetales-A—cripples it before Unburden activates, and Rocky Helmet chip from Corviknight or Garganacl can put it in KO range of unboosted moves. Finally, terrain removal or opposing Psychic/Grassy Terrain prevents Seed consumption, leaving Hawlucha at a pedestrian 92 Speed.</OUTPUT>

input:
Write a detailed 'role_description' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Hawlucha": {"Abilities": {"unburden": 2.2439597397751583, "moldbreaker": 0.3445491830371311, "limber": 0.0011065338258824942}, "Items": {"psychicseed": 0.1958511720255322, "grassyseed": 0.4901979715227056, "focussash": 0.1763801054443286}, "Spreads": {"Impish:164/0/252/0/0/92": 0.43806140244631375}, "Moves": ["acrobatics", "protect", "bodypress", "bulkup"], "Tera Types": {"steel": 0.16609045726933525, "water": 0.43847704037861496}, "Teammates": ["Ursaluna-Bloodmoon", "Archaludon", "Garchomp", "Basculegion", "Rillaboom", "Volcarona"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Hawlucha is a mid-game to late-game cleaner that doubles as an emergency wall; it is brought to games to exploit passive turns created by its own terrain setter or by the opponent’s Intimidate/Protect loops. After a single Bulk Up it becomes simultaneously the fastest and one of the physically bulkiest threats on the field, forcing 2-for-1 trades or outright sweeping. Because Unburden is single-use, Hawlucha is rarely the lead unless the opponent reveals a clear setup target; instead it waits until bulky grasses, Stealth Rockers or Choiced attackers lock themselves, then enters, activates Seed, and applies immediate dual-stab pressure. Its typing and tera options also let it act as a Fairy- or Ice-resist pivot for teammates like Ursaluna-Bloodmoon or Archaludon, buying them setup or walling turns.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Ursaluna-Bloodmoon tops Hawlucha’s teammate list because Blood Moon’s Ghost immunity and raw special power break the Physically bulky cores that wall Hawlucha before boosts, while Hawlucha removes Fighting-types that trouble Ursaluna. Rillaboom is the most common Grassy Terrain enabler, providing priority Fake Out + Knock Off to help Hawlucha set up and activating Grassy Seed for free. Archalodon's Steel/Dragon typing and Stamina give it perfect defensive synergy, covering Hawlucha’s Electric and Rock weaknesses while Hawlucha beats Fairies and Grounds for it. Garchomp forms a classic “fast offensive core”, luring in Ice moves that Hawlucha can terastallize to resist, while Hawlucha removes opposing Fairies. Basculegion offers Water/Ghost coverage and Tailwind to bail Hawlucha out if Seed fails, and Volcarona appreciates Hawlucha removing Stealth Rock and provides Rage Powder support to guarantee a Bulk Up turn.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Pure Power is one of the most potent abilities in the game, and Medicham is the only viable user that can legally transfer it in doubles. After a Skill Swap, physical attackers on your side essentially gain a free Life Orb+ boost without item lock-in, turning modest attackers into genuine breakers. The most common partner, Slaking, discards Truant in exchange for Pure Power, morphing from a momentum sink into a 160-Base-Attack wrecking ball that outspeeds and OHKOes most neutral targets. Weezing-Galar enjoys the same treatment, but also deters physical attackers with Neutralizing Gas before the swap, giving you a safe setup turn. Medicham itself is no slouch: even uninvested, its doubled Attack reaches ~260, meaning a STAB Close Combat cleanly 2HKOes most Incineroar and bulky Rotom variants. Psychic Cut punts Amoonguss and Toxapex while avoiding Intimidate drops. The preferred spread is Adamant 252/252 to maximise immediate power and Speed-tie positive-nature base 80s after Scarf, but a Jolly 236 variant creeps neutral-nature base 100s such as Chien-Pao and Jolly Kilowattrel. Tera Fighting turns Close Combat into a nuke that deletes even resisted targets after prior damage, while Tera Steel grants a clutch Toxic immunity and a Fairy resistance, letting Medicham survive Sylveon Hyper Voice or Mimikhu Play Rough and fire back. Trick rounds the set by crippling bulky supports like Dondozo or Ting-Lu, forcing 50/50 Protect mind-games that usually favour the Skill-Swap side.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Medicham": {"Abilities": {"purepower": 2.701630151004746, "telepathy": 0.019221213779114288}, "Items": {"choicescarf": 0.9183875438371483}, "Spreads": {"Adamant:0/252/0/0/4/252": 0.7139044928036135, "Jolly:12/252/4/0/4/236": 0.20279615324643036}, "Moves": ["skillswap", "closecombat", "psychocut", "trick"], "Tera Types": {"fighting": 0.7646477250984506, "steel": 0.20319236720977168}, "Teammates": ["Slaking", "Weezing-Galar", "Kilowattrel", "Typhlosion-Hisui", "Gholdengo", "Garchomp"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Against hyper-offense, Medicham functions as a speed-control pivot: it outspeeds +1 Roaring Moon, Dragonite, and Chien-Pao after Scarf, OHKOing the first two with Tera Fighting Close Combat. Psychic Cut cleanly knocks out Amoonguss and deals solid chip to Toxapex, denying Rage Powder redirection. Versus bulkier balance cores, Skill Swap plus Slaking pressures common cores of Garganacl + Toxapex + Corviknight, since Slaking’s Facade or Giga Impact after Pure Power 2HKOes all three. Stall teams that rely on status are annoyed by Trick and by Tera Steel’s Toxic immunity; once Toxic is gone, they struggle to outlast repeated double-target Close Combats. The main weaknesses are faster Tailwind or priority teams: Murkrow Sucker Punch and Kingambit Sucker Punch still KO Medicham after chip, and opposing Chien-Pao under Tailwind outspeeds even Jolly Scarf. Ghost-types such as Aegislash and Skeledirge block Close Combat, forcing Psychic Cut which is only 80 BP and risks a Tera Ghost punish. Finally, Mimikyu can usually survive one hit and retaliate with Play Rough, so you need prior damage or a partner to finish it off.</OUTPUT>

input:

<DATA>{"Feraligatr": {"Abilities": {"sheerforce": 2.363283163078335, "torrent": 0.0002611209809521009}, "Items": {"lifeorb": 0.93854293493664}, "Spreads": {"Adamant:4/252/0/0/0/252": 0.46730120249004176, "Adamant:100/252/0/0/0/156": 0.17570448322728296}, "Moves": ["aquajet", "liquidation", "protect", "icepunch"], "Tera Types": {"water": 0.5030407656014341, "dragon": 0.2697628870093607}, "Teammates": ["Rillaboom", "Archaludon", "Annihilape", "Volcarona", "Electrode-Hisui", "Maushold"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Sheer Force turns Liquidation (102 BP after boost) and Ice Punch (117 BP after boost) into Life Orb-boosted, secondary-effect-free cannons that ignore the 10 % recoil and cannot be disrupted by Defiant or competitive activations. Aqua Jet provides critical priority that lets Feraligatr finish weakened foes or pick off fast threats before they move. Protect is mandatory in doubles, allowing it to dodge Fake Out or stall out opposing speed control. The two common EV spreads reflect two philosophies: the 252/252 Adamant variant aims to maximize immediate power and speed-tie opposing base 70–80s after Tailwind, while the bulkier 100 HP / 252 Atk / 156 Spe spread survives common hits such as Life Orb Chien-Pao Ice Spinner or Flutter Mane Moonblast and still outspeeds max-speed Dragapult under Tailwind. Tera Water is the default, pushing Liquidation into absurd damage tiers and granting a crucial resistance to Fire-type moves aimed at Feraligatr’s common Grass-type partners. Tera Dragon is the second-most popular option, removing the Electric weakness and giving a neutral STAB combo that surprises opposing Dragon- or Water-type resists such as Amoonguss or Rotom-Wash. Torrent is virtually unseen; the sheer power and recoil mitigation of Sheer Force makes it the only competitive ability. Life Orb is present on 94 % of teams, further evidencing the hyper-offensive, hit-and-run identity Feraligatr must adopt to stay relevant in a format dominated by bulkier, support-heavy Water-types.</OUTPUT>

input:
Create the 'matchup_overview' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Feraligatr": {"Abilities": {"sheerforce": 2.363283163078335, "torrent": 0.0002611209809521009}, "Items": {"lifeorb": 0.93854293493664}, "Spreads": {"Adamant:4/252/0/0/0/252": 0.46730120249004176, "Adamant:100/252/0/0/0/156": 0.17570448322728296}, "Moves": ["aquajet", "liquidation", "protect", "icepunch"], "Tera Types": {"water": 0.5030407656014341, "dragon": 0.2697628870093607}, "Teammates": ["Rillaboom", "Archaludon", "Annihilape", "Volcarona", "Electrode-Hisui", "Maushold"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Feraligatr loves facing Sun and Sand cores that rely on Torkoal, Lillikoal, or Garchomp: a single Terastallized Liquidation or Ice Punch can OHKO these threats even through Babiri Berry or Chople Berry. Against Rain, the matchup flips—while Feraligatr can still punch holes, it faces faster, harder-hitting Liquidations from Barraskewda and Palafin and must rely on Aqua Jet or partner speed control to stay safe. Versus Trick Room it becomes a mixed bag: Feraligatr underspeeds most setters, so it can operate under enemy Trick Room, but it hates taking neutral Draco Meteors or Moonblasts from Indeedee-F or Hatterene. Against hyper-offense, priority Aqua Jet is invaluable for cleaning Focus-Sash Pokemon such as Chien-Pao or Maushold, but Feraligatr’s own lack of bulk means it cannot switch into repeated attacks without heavy team support. Grass-types (Rillaboom, Amoonguss) are public enemy #1: even resisted Bullet Seed or Giga Drain can OHKO, so Feraligatr must either Terastallize into Dragon to tank one hit or rely on partners to remove them before committing.</OUTPUT>

It is never the primary dynamax target, instead preferring to preserve its item and ability boosts while letting bulkier or spread-damage partners Max. Its main value lies in deleting specific mid-speed threats (Volcarona, Dragonite, Chien-Pao, Garchomp) without needing setup turns. Because it cannot boost its own speed, it demands either Tailwind from the likes of Talonflame or Electrode-Hisui, or Trick Room from the likes of Porygon2 or Annihilape. Once speed control is up, Feraligatr becomes a 140–160 BP pseudo-STAB nuke that forces Protects and Terastallizations, opening the board for teammates to clean. It is not a support Pokemon, not a redirector, and not a spread attacker—its job is to delete one or two high-value targets and then either fade to the back or finish with Aqua Jet.</OUTPUT>

Archaludon offers Steel / Dragon coverage, sets Stealth Rock in Bo3, and appreciates Water-type pressure to soften opposing Ground- and Fire-types. Electrode-Hisui is the fastest Tailwind setter in the tier, guaranteeing speed control turn 1 and threatening opposing Water-types with Thunder. Maushold provides Friend Guard and Follow Me, letting Feraligatr survive an extra turn to fire off two attacks, and can clean with Population Bomb once enemies are softened.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Prankster is the only reason Volbeat sees usage; priority Tailwind turns the likes of Choice Specs Typhlosion-H into a 140 Speed threat before opposing redirection can react. Encore punishes setup sweepers, Protect spam, or Trick Room setters, while Sunny Day and Rain Dance let it act as a manual weather setter for Chlorophyll/Swift Swim cores without committing a restricted slot. Covert Cloak is the dominant item because it blanks Fake Out, Parting Shot, and Rage Powder, ensuring Volbeat gets at least one support move off even against Amoonguss or Incineroar leads. Coba Berry is an alternative to survive a Tera Flying Tornadus Hurricane or Tera Grass Rillaboom Wood Hammer, but the consistency of Cloak is preferred. EV spreads prioritize special bulk: Calm 252 HP / 196 SpD guarantees survival against Life Orb Flutter Mane Moonblast, while Careful 236 HP / 196 Def avoids OHKO from standard Great Tusk Earthquake. Tera Dark blocks Prankster-bypassed Taunt and provides a Ghost immunity, while Tera Steel gives a Poison immunity and a crucial Fake Out resistance. Volbeat’s offensive stats are functionally zero, so it must rely on teammates to convert its support into KOs.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Lapras": {"Abilities": {"waterabsorb": 1.7953569115355166, "shellarmor": 0.39253471662638645, "hydration": 0.048811080788829175}, "Items": {"leftovers": 0.4585284563266772, "sitrusberry": 0.1903838239936109}, "Spreads": {"Calm:252/0/188/0/68/0": 0.16755169620255472, "Modest:244/0/28/236/0/0": 0.16239445037515274}, "Moves": ["chillingwater", "perishsong", "protect", "freezedry"], "Tera Types": {"fire": 0.2330079250154146, "water": 0.3040533873159751}, "Teammates": ["Incineroar", "Garganacl", "Hippowdon", "Sinistcha", "Glimmora", "Kleavor"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Lapras carves a unique niche in VGC as a bulky, tempo-setting Water-type that leverages Perish Song and Freeze-Dry pressure to force 3-turn clocks while blanking most bulky Waters. With 60% of sampled builds running Water Absorb, it comfortably switches into partner Rotom-Wash or opposing Kyogre while providing an immediate win-condition via Perish trapping. EV spreads show two camps: Calm 252/188/68 maximises special bulk to live Flutter Mane Moonblast or Iron Bundle Freeze-Dry, whereas Modest 244/236 invests in immediate power so Freeze-Dry cleanly 2HKOs 252 HP Garganacl and Tera-Water Gholdengo. Tera Fire is the most common deviation, flipping the Incineroar and Sun match-ups by dodging Fake Out damage and Grass Knot, while Tera Water simply turns Lapras into an unbreakable Calm Mind-style wincon under rain. Leftovers is the default for long-game Perish loops, but Sitrus Berry is preferred on hyper-offensive builds that aim to set up a single Perish and Protect cycle before exploding out with a pivot.</OUTPUT>

input:
Produce the 'full_analysis' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Lapras": {"Abilities": {"waterabsorb": 1.7953569115355166, "shellarmor": 0.39253471662638645, "hydration": 0.048811080788829175}, "Items": {"leftovers": 0.4585284563266772, "sitrusberry": 0.1903838239936109}, "Spreads": {"Calm:252/0/188/0/68/0": 0.16755169620255472, "Modest:244/0/28/236/0/0": 0.16239445037515274}, "Moves": ["chillingwater", "perishsong", "protect", "freezedry"], "Tera Types": {"fire": 0.2330079250154146, "water": 0.3040533873159751}, "Teammates": ["Incineroar", "Garganacl", "Hippowdon", "Sinistcha", "Glimmora", "Kleavor"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Lapras’s value in Regulation G stems from compressing three roles into one slot: a Water immunity, a pseudo-Dragon that beats Dragons, and a slow win-condition that punishes passive teams. Water Absorb variants completely blank Rain archetypes: Kyogre’s Origin Pulse becomes free recovery, while Palafin’s Jet Punch fails to break Lapras’s 352 HP / 219 SpD Calm bulk. Freeze-Dry is the crux of the set: it 2HKOs every relevant Water/Ground (except Clodsire) and guarantees the OHKO on Amoonguss after Tera Fire chip, solving what would otherwise be a full-stop to Perish Song. Chilling Water provides consistent speed control, dropping threats like Chien-Pao or Bundle to -1 so that Lapras can either Protect stall or let a slower partner like Garganacl move last to set Salt Cure. Protect is mandatory for Perish loops: on turn 3 Lapras Protects while the partner pivots out via U-turn or a switching move, denying the KO and resetting the board. The listed EV spreads are optimised for common benchmarks: Calm 252/188/68 survives +1 Fluter Mane Moonblast 100% of the time and lives Life Orb Iron Bundle Freeze-Dry, while Modest 244/236 guarantees the 2HKO on max SpD Toxapex and has a 43% chance to OHKO 0 HP Tornadus after Chilling Water chip. Tera Fire is chosen on 23% of teams to remove Grass weakness and gain a crucial Fake Out immunity versus Incineroar, turning many 2v2 endgames into autowins once Sun or Grass types are eliminated. Tera Water is the safer pick on rainless builds, giving a second Water Absorb and letting Lapras soft-check Chien-Pao with Chilling Water drops.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Lapras": {"Abilities": {"waterabsorb": 1.7953569115355166, "shellarmor": 0.39253471662638645, "hydration": 0.048811080788829175}, "Items": {"leftovers": 0.4585284563266772, "sitrusberry": 0.1903838239936109}, "Spreads": {"Calm:252/0/188/0/68/0": 0.16755169620255472, "Modest:244/0/28/236/0/0": 0.16239445037515274}, "Moves": ["chillingwater", "perishsong", "protect", "freezedry"], "Tera Types": {"fire": 0.2330079250154146, "water": 0.3040533873159751}, "Teammates": ["Incineroar", "Garganacl", "Hippowdon", "Sinistcha", "Glimmora", "Kleavor"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Lapras dominates slow, bulky teams that rely on repeated Water attacks or lack immediate burst. Rain loses the Water war outright; Kyogre can only 3HKO while Lapras stalls with Perish and Protect. Sun is trickier: Torkoal’s Eruption 2HKOs even the Calm spread, so Tera Fire is mandatory to avoid the OHKO from Solar Beam Venusaur. Against Sand, Hippowdon can’t 2HKO without Stone Edge, while Freeze-Dry 2HKOs both Tyranitar and Lycanroc-Dusk, forcing Sand to over-rely on tera Grass or Tera Rock to win. Hyper-offense featuring Iron Bundle or Chien-Pao can overwhelm Lapras before it sets up, especially if Lapras lacks Tera Fire to dodge Grass Knot. Indeed, the most reliable counterplay is electric speed control: Regieleki or Iron Hands can Volt Switch or Thunder Punch before Lapras moves, breaking potential Perish loops. Grass-types with Rage Powder or Follow Me—particularly Tera Grass Amoonguss—can redirect Freeze-Dry and let partners double into Lapras, though they must beware of 2HKO rolls after Chilling Water chip. Overall Lapras is favoured versus balance and Rain, neutral versus Sand, and slightly unfavoured versus hyper-offense or Sun unless it commits Tera.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Lapras operates as a slow, bulky win-condition that forces 3-turn clocks with Perish Song while providing a Water immunity for the squad. In the opener it either switches into predicted Water moves or leads beside Incineroar to fake a Fake Out target before Protecting turn 1. Once Perish is up, Lapras toggles between Protect and Chilling Water to maintain tempo, letting partners like Glimmora set hazards or Garganacl spread Salt Cure. Mid-game Lapras becomes a pivot: if the opponent lacks a Perish answer, Lapras can Tera Fire and begin a 2v1 stall; if the opponent has electric or grass pressure, Lapras simply clicks Freeze-Dry to remove Water-types then U-turns out via Incineroar. End-game Lapras is one of the most reliable cleaners in Regulation G: after opposing Tera and Dynamax are burned, a full-health Lapras with Leftovers can chain Protect and Perish to force a 50/50 on the final turn, a scenario most teams cannot play around without double-targeting or sacrificing a slot to Perish.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Incineroar is Lapras’s most common teammate (appearing in over half of sampled teams) because it provides Fake Out, Intimidate, and a slow U-turn pivot that lets Lapras escape Perish turns unscathed. Garganacl forms a terrifying stall core: Salt Cure + Perish puts both opposing slots on a 3-turn timer while Lapras absorbs Water moves aimed at the salt monster. Hippowdon supplies sand chip and Stealth Rock, wearing down Sun and opposing Water teams so that Lapras can clean late; sand also negates opposing Leftovers, making Perish stalls even more effective. Sinistcha offers another win-condition that abuses Perish turns: Weak Armor boosts let it snowball while Lapras protects, and both share a Fire resistance. Glimmora sets Toxic Spikes that force earlier Tera usage, ensuring Lapras’s Tera Fire or Tera Water is the last one standing. Finally, Kleavor provides priority Aqua Cutter and Stealth Rock, removing opposing Grass-types and guaranteeing Freeze-Dry range on bulky Waters. The overarching synergy is to stack residual damage—sand, salt, rocks, poison—so that by turn 7 Lapras can simply Protect and watch the opponent crumble under Perish and chip.</OUTPUT>

Choice Band and Eject Pack variants both see play: Band turns it into an immediate nuke that can OHKO many neutral targets, while Eject Pack lets it pivot after throwing a guaranteed disruption or pick-off.  With 124/80/80 bulk and a coveted Ghost-typing it can switch into Fake Out, spin-block, and ignore Extreme Speed, making it a surprisingly useful anti-meta piece on full-room or hybrid-room squads.  Its near-universal Tera Fighting turns its Dynamic Punch into a 180 BP STAB nuke while removing Dark- and Bug-type weaknesses, letting it muscle past bulky steels and darks that otherwise wall it.  The spread data show two camps: max-max Brave for hard-room spam, and a 164/92 Adamant set that outruns uninvested base 50s outside room while still hitting like a truck inside it.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Golurk": {"Abilities": {"noguard": 2.402916218370916, "ironfist": 0.003577536461200459, "klutz": 0.013367248669279908}, "Items": {"choiceband": 0.22890281832256995, "ejectpack": 0.4259419352688235}, "Spreads": {"Brave:252/252/0/0/4/0": 0.21645166234677352, "Adamant:164/252/0/0/0/92": 0.4259420406540631}, "Moves": ["dynamicpunch", "poltergeist", "stoneedge", "highhorsepower"], "Tera Types": {"fighting": 0.8867631226111278}, "Teammates": ["Torkoal", "Sableye", "Pelipper", "Archaludon", "Maushold", "Smeargle"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Golurk’s value lies in compressing roles: it is simultaneously a Trick Room setter, Ghost-type blocker, confusion spreader and banded breaker.  No Guard guarantees every move lands, meaning Dynamic Punch is a 100 BP STAB confusion inducer that forces 50/50 turns, while perfect Stone Edges and High Horsepowers let it snipe Togekiss, Oricorio, Incineroar and titan Tera-Fire mons without fear of missing.  Poltergeist is a spammable 110 BP Ghost move that cleanly 2HKOs most neutral targets after band or Tera Fighting boost, and OHKOs frailer threats such as Flutter Mane, Dragapult and Indeedee-F.  Choice Band sets trade longevity for raw power, reaching guaranteed OHKOs on max-HP Gholdengo, Arcanine and bulky Arcaludon after Tera, while Eject Pack sets grant momentum—clicking Dynamic Punch or Poltergeist and immediately switching to a partner that can exploit the confusion or chip.  Golurk’s typing gives it handy immunities to Normal- and Fighting-type priority, letting it serve as a soft check to Fake Out + Extreme Speed cores, and its 89/124/80 physical bulk plus neutrality to most spread moves means it can take a hit before firing back.  Its main drawbacks are a middling 55 special defense and a crippling 4× weakness to Dark- and Ghost-type moves, meaning it must avoid Kingambit, Chien-Pao, Aegislash and opposing Ghosts.  Still, with proper support it can single-handedly dismantle balance cores that rely on accuracy checks or Intimidate cycling.</OUTPUT>

input:
Draft the 'matchup_overview' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Golurk": {"Abilities": {"noguard": 2.402916218370916, "ironfist": 0.003577536461200459, "klutz": 0.013367248669279908}, "Items": {"choiceband": 0.22890281832256995, "ejectpack": 0.4259419352688235}, "Spreads": {"Brave:252/252/0/0/4/0": 0.21645166234677352, "Adamant:164/252/0/0/0/92": 0.4259420406540631}, "Moves": ["dynamicpunch", "poltergeist", "stoneedge", "highhorsepower"], "Tera Types": {"fighting": 0.8867631226111278}, "Teammates": ["Torkoal", "Sableye", "Pelipper", "Archaludon", "Maushold", "Smeargle"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Against weather, Golurk is surprisingly effective: it OHKOs Pelipper with Tera Fighting Stone Edge and 2HKOs both Tyranitar and Torkoal with High Horsepower or Poltergeist, while taking little from their unboosted special attacks.  Into bulky steels it needs Tera Fighting to muscle past Corviknight and Skarmory, but can do so after a little chip.  Dark-types are the biggest obstacle: Kingambit survives even banded Dynamic Punch and retaliates with 4× Iron Head, while Chien-Pao outspeeds outside room and cleanly OHKOs with Crunch.  Ghost mirrors favour Golurk if it lands the first Poltergeist, but Aegislash and bulky Gholdengo can live one hit and KO back with Shadow Ball.  Into Tailroom mirrors Golurk can serve as an anti-room piece: it underspeeds most setters and can KO Indeedee-F before Psychic Terrain goes up, or break Dusclops after Tera.  Against hyper-offence, confusion fishing can flip games: banded Dynamic Punch into Tera Fighting has a 50% chance to neuter a booster such as Dragonite or Palafin, letting a partner clean up.  Overall Golurk demands respect from slower teams and can trade favourably into most neutral targets, but must avoid faster ghosts/darks and cannot afford to miss any accuracy checks—thankfully, with No Guard, it never does.</OUTPUT>

input:
Provide the 'role_description' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Golurk": {"Abilities": {"noguard": 2.402916218370916, "ironfist": 0.003577536461200459, "klutz": 0.013367248669279908}, "Items": {"choiceband": 0.22890281832256995, "ejectpack": 0.4259419352688235}, "Spreads": {"Brave:252/252/0/0/4/0": 0.21645166234677352, "Adamant:164/252/0/0/0/92": 0.4259420406540631}, "Moves": ["dynamicpunch", "poltergeist", "stoneedge", "highhorsepower"], "Tera Types": {"fighting": 0.8867631226111278}, "Teammates": ["Torkoal", "Sableye", "Pelipper", "Archaludon", "Maushold", "Smeargle"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Golurk is best viewed as a Trick Room attacker and confusion disruptor that compresses anti-priority, spin-blocking and wall-breaking into one slot.  Its primary job is to click Dynamic Punch under Trick Room to create 50/50 turns while dealing heavy damage, then follow up with perfectly accurate coverage to remove would-be checks.  Choice Band sets aim to delete one target outright and cripple another with confusion, functioning as a lead or mid-game breaker.  Eject Pack variants act as pivots: fire off a guaranteed move, then tag in a partner that can exploit the confusion or set up while the opponent is forced to play around the status.  Ghost-typing also lets it block Rapid Spin, making it a sneaky hazard deterrent on teams that rely on Stealth Rock or Sticky Web chip.  Because its speed tier is abysmal, Golurk is almost always run on full-room or hybrid-room structures; outside room it is only usable if the rest of the team can keep opposing ghosts and darks at bay long enough for it to fire one or two nuclear shots.</OUTPUT>

input:
Write the 'synergy_breakdown' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Golurk": {"Abilities": {"noguard": 2.402916218370916, "ironfist": 0.003577536461200459, "klutz": 0.013367248669279908}, "Items": {"choiceband": 0.22890281832256995, "ejectpack": 0.4259419352688235}, "Spreads": {"Brave:252/252/0/0/4/0": 0.21645166234677352, "Adamant:164/252/0/0/0/92": 0.4259420406540631}, "Moves": ["dynamicpunch", "poltergeist", "stoneedge", "highhorsepower"], "Tera Types": {"fighting": 0.8867631226111278}, "Teammates": ["Torkoal", "Sableye", "Pelipper", "Archaludon", "Maushold", "Smeargle"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>The teammate data reveal a clear ecosystem: Torkoal provides sun-boosted Eruption chip and sets room for Golurk, while Pelipper offers rain to weaken Fire-type moves aimed at it and slow down opposing scarfers.  Sableye is the perfect partner: Prankster Quash or Will-O-Wisp creates safe Dynamic Punch turns, while Fake Out buys the room setter a free switch.  Archaludon appreciates Golurk’s ability to remove bulky waters and grounds, then cleans with Electro Shot under the same room.  Maushold offers Friend Guard and Follow Me to let Golurk fire twice under room, while Smeargle sets room and can copycat or encore to lock opposing leads into useless moves.  In general, Golurk wants one of two support cores: 1) Prankster utility (Sableye, Grimmsnarl) plus a room setter (Torkoal, Bronzong) to guarantee safe turns, or 2) redirection (Maushold, Indeedee-F) plus hazard chip to soften checks.  It also pairs well with bulky steels such as Corviknight or Gholdengo that can tank Ghost- and Dark-type moves aimed at it, and with Tera Fairy or Tera Dark partners that can absorb the same threats after Golurk has done its job.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Golurk": {"Abilities": {"noguard": 2.402916218370916, "ironfist": 0.003577536461200459, "klutz": 0.013367248669279908}, "Items": {"choiceband": 0.22890281832256995, "ejectpack": 0.4259419352688235}, "Spreads": {"Brave:252/252/0/0/4/0": 0.21645166234677352, "Adamant:164/252/0/0/0/92": 0.4259420406540631}, "Moves": ["dynamicpunch", "poltergeist", "stoneedge", "highhorsepower"], "Tera Types": {"fighting": 0.8867631226111278}, "Teammates": ["Torkoal", "Sableye", "Pelipper", "Archaludon", "Maushold", "Smeargle"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Choice Band No Guard – Brave 252/252/0/0/4/0 (IV 0 Spe) @ Choice Band – Dynamic Punch / Poltergeist / Stone Edge / High Horsepower – Tera Fighting.  This is the nuclear option: underspeed every non-room target, guarantee confusion, and OHKO most neutral threats.  The EVs maximise Atk and minimise Speed; 4 SpD helps survive modest Flutter Mane Shadow Ball after Tera.  Eject Pack Pivot – Adamant 164/252/0/0/0/92 @ Eject Pack – Dynamic Punch / Poltergeist / Stone Edge / High Horsepower – Tera Fighting.  The 92 Speed EVs creep uninvested base 50s (e.g. Torkoal) outside room, letting Golurk function as a mid-speed breaker if room is not up.  After firing any move, Eject Pack triggers and tags in a partner that can exploit confusion or set up.  Both sets run Tera Fighting almost exclusively: it boosts Dynamic Punch to absurd levels, removes Dark- and Bug-type weaknesses, and turns Golurk into a legitimate tank that can survive Kingambit Iron Head after Tera.  The only other niche option is Tera Ghost to flip the Ghost mirror, but Fighting is correct 90% of the time.</OUTPUT>

input:
Write a detailed 'weaknesses_and_counters' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Golurk": {"Abilities": {"noguard": 2.402916218370916, "ironfist": 0.003577536461200459, "klutz": 0.013367248669279908}, "Items": {"choiceband": 0.22890281832256995, "ejectpack": 0.4259419352688235}, "Spreads": {"Brave:252/252/0/0/4/0": 0.21645166234677352, "Adamant:164/252/0/0/0/92": 0.4259420406540631}, "Moves": ["dynamicpunch", "poltergeist", "stoneedge", "highhorsepower"], "Tera Types": {"fighting": 0.8867631226111278}, "Teammates": ["Torkoal", "Sableye", "Pelipper", "Archaludon", "Maushold", "Smeargle"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Kingambit is public enemy #1: it survives banded Tera Fighting Dynamic Punch and OHKOs back with Iron Head; Sacred Sword variants ignore defence drops from confusion.  Chien-Pao outspeeds outside room and cleanly OHKOs with Crunch, while also dropping its defence with Sword of Ruin.  Aegislash in shield form can live any hit and retaliate with Shadow Ball; bulky Gholdengo does the same and ignores Dynamic Punch’s confusion thanks to Good as Gold.  Faster Ghosts such as Flutter Mane and Dragapult can KO before Golurk moves outside room, though both fall to banded Poltergeist if they switch in.  Dark-type priority (Sucker Punch from Kingambit or Chien-Pao) bypasses Trick Room and finishes off chipped Golurk.  Finally, because Golurk is almost always choiced or locked into one move, intelligent double-targets or protect cycles can waste its turn and leave it vulnerable the following round.  To beat it, bring a sturdy Dark- or Ghost-type that can survive one hit, or use speed control to deny Trick Room and KO before it fires.</OUTPUT>
