<DATA>{"Golurk": {"Abilities": {"noguard": 2.402916218370916, "ironfist": 0.003577536461200459, "klutz": 0.013367248669279908}, "Items": {"choiceband": 0.22890281832256995, "ejectpack": 0.4259419352688235}, "Spreads": {"Brave:252/252/0/0/4/0": 0.21645166234677352, "Adamant:164/252/0/0/0/92": 0.4259420406540631}, "Moves": ["dynamicpunch", "poltergeist", "stoneedge", "highhorsepower"], "Tera Types": {"fighting": 0.8867631226111278}, "Teammates": ["Torkoal", "Sableye", "Pelipper", "Archaludon", "Maushold", "Smeargle"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Trick Room Firestorm – Torkoal @ Heat Rock / Bronzong @ Mental Herb / Golurk @ Choice Band / Sableye @ Focus Sash / Archaludon @ Assault Vest / Maushold @ Wide Lens.  Lead Torkoal + Sableye: Sableye Quashes or WoWs while Torkoal sets sun and room; next turn Golurk comes in and deletes something with Tera Fighting Dynamic Punch.  Bronzong offers a second room setter and Gyro Ball to punish Fairies, while Archaludon cleans late-game under the same room with Electro Shot.  Maushold provides Follow Me and Population Bomb to break sashes and allow Golurk a second nuke.  The squad is weak to Kingambit, so pack Will-O-Wisp and consider Tera Fairy on Bronzong to tank Iron Head.  Overall the team aims to set room, fire off two guaranteed moves, then pivot into Archaludon or Torkoal to finish the job while the opponent is still confused or chipped.</OUTPUT>

Write a detailed 'short_summary' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Cinccino": {"Abilities": {"technician": 0.8431693495974335, "skilllink": 1.2868648328947252, "cutecharm": 0.0007897487430980066}, "Items": {"focussash": 0.5029720671353307, "widelens": 0.31850254461871685}, "Spreads": {"Jolly:0/252/0/0/4/252": 0.16688791036529507, "Jolly:4/252/0/0/0/252": 0.3282606637941746, "Jolly:0/252/0/0/0/252": 0.470067401063931}, "Moves": ["tripleaxel", "tailslap", "protect", "bulletseed"], "Tera Types": {"ice": 0.33073614680537183, "stellar": 0.508084680602296}, "Teammates": ["Amoonguss", "Gholdengo", "Indeedee-F", "Politoed", "Farigiraf", "Hariyama"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Cinccino is a hyper-offensive, multi-hit specialist that capitalizes on Skill Link to convert Triple Axel, Tail Slap, and Bullet Seed into 100 % accurate, 5-hit powerhouses. With base 115 Speed, a Jolly nature, and Focus Sash or Wide Lens for insurance, it functions as a fast, self-contained wallbreaker that can obliterate common pivots like Togekiss, Garchomp, and Kyogre while punishing Protect stalling. Ice Tera turns Triple Axel into a nuclear 180 BP Ice attack that cleanly OHKOes most Dragon- and Ground-type restricted Pokémon, while Stellar Tera grants a one-time neutral coverage boost that keeps Cinccino relevant late-game. The mouse fits best on Rain, Psychic Terrain, or Trick Room pivot squads that can redirect or control speed, letting Cinccino click multi-hit moves with near-impunity.</OUTPUT>

input:
Draft the 'full_analysis' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Cinccino": {"Abilities": {"technician": 0.8431693495974335, "skilllink": 1.2868648328947252, "cutecharm": 0.0007897487430980066}, "Items": {"focussash": 0.5029720671353307, "widelens": 0.31850254461871685}, "Spreads": {"Jolly:0/252/0/0/4/252": 0.16688791036529507, "Jolly:4/252/0/0/0/252": 0.3282606637941746, "Jolly:0/252/0/0/0/252": 0.470067401063931}, "Moves": ["tripleaxel", "tailslap", "protect", "bulletseed"], "Tera Types": {"ice": 0.33073614680537183, "stellar": 0.508084680602296}, "Teammates": ["Amoonguss", "Gholdengo", "Indeedee-F", "Politoed", "Farigiraf", "Hariyama"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Skill Link is the only ability that matters: every listed move becomes a perfectly reliable 5-hit sequence, meaning Cinccino ignores the usual accuracy woes of Triple Axel and the RNG of Tail Slap. Technician is legal but almost never used because Skill Link’s raw output is superior. EV spreads are uniform—max Attack and Speed with a Jolly nature—to ensure the fastest possible triple-hit pressure. Focus Sash (≈ 50 % usage) guarantees Cinccino survives any single hit to retaliate, while Wide Lens (≈ 32 %) patches the rare misses on Bullet Seed and provides consistency for teams that already carry redirection. Tera Ice is the dominant choice, turning Triple Axel into a 180 BP STAB Ice move that OHKOes most Dragon- and Ground-type titans such as Groudon, Lando-T, and Miraidon after minimal chip. Stellar Tera is gaining traction as a one-time neutral coverage boost that preserves Cinccino’s damage output after Terastallizing and allows it to muscle past neutral targets like bulky Fairy-types. The four-move set is mandatory: Triple Axel (Ice), Tail Slap (STAB), Bullet Seed (Grass), and Protect. No other coverage option provides the same raw power or synergy with Skill Link. Cinccino’s teammates reflect its need for redirection and speed control: Amoonguss and Indeedee-F offer Rage Powder / Follow Me, while Politoed sets Rain to weaken Fire-type hits and synergizes with the Ice typing. Gholdengo and Farigiraf are offensive partners that appreciate physical Ice- and Grass-type pressure, and Hariyama provides Fake Out and a slow pivot that can flip speed brackets.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Cinccino": {"Abilities": {"technician": 0.8431693495974335, "skilllink": 1.2868648328947252, "cutecharm": 0.0007897487430980066}, "Items": {"focussash": 0.5029720671353307, "widelens": 0.31850254461871685}, "Spreads": {"Jolly:0/252/0/0/4/252": 0.16688791036529507, "Jolly:4/252/0/0/0/252": 0.3282606637941746, "Jolly:0/252/0/0/0/252": 0.470067401063931}, "Moves": ["tripleaxel", "tailslap", "protect", "bulletseed"], "Tera Types": {"ice": 0.33073614680537183, "stellar": 0.508084680602296}, "Teammates": ["Amoonguss", "Gholdengo", "Indeedee-F", "Politoed", "Farigiraf", "Hariyama"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Cinccino demolishes most Dragon-, Ground-, and Water-type restricted Pokémon—Dialga, Kyogre, Groudon, Lando-T, and Garchomp all fall to a Tera Ice Triple Axel. It also shreds common support Pokémon like Amoonguss, Togekiss, and bulky Water-types that rely on multiscale or berry recovery. Conversely, Steel- and Fire-type restricted Pokémon such as Zacian-Crowned, Koraidon, and Sun-boosted Groudon can tank a hit and OHKO back with Behemoth Blade, Collision Course, or Precipice Blades. Priority users like Kingambit and Dragonite bypass Focus Sash, while bulky Intimidate users such as Incineroar and Arcanine force Cinccino to Tera early to maintain damage output. Wide Guard (e.g., from Aegislash or Hitmontop) completely blanks every move Cinccino carries, and Rocky Helmet chip plus Iron Barbs/Rough Skin punishes the multi-hit contact. Finally, Psychic Terrain teams can backfire if Indeedee-F sets terrain and blocks priority Fake Out from Hariyama, but Cinccino itself does not care about terrain because its moves are not priority.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Cinccino is a lead or mid-game wallbreaker whose sole purpose is to delete bulky restricted Pokémon and support cores with perfectly accurate, 5-hit attacks. It functions as a fast, self-sufficient damage engine that requires minimal setup—only redirection or speed control—to sweep. Thanks to Focus Sash it can trade 1-for-1 or better versus most offensive leads, while Terastallization turns it into a temporary Ice-type nuke that redefines end-game positioning. Cinccino is not a support Pokémon, nor does it offer utility beyond raw damage; instead, it compresses the roles of speed control answer, restricted Pokémon check, and late-game cleaner into one slot.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Cinccino": {"Abilities": {"technician": 0.8431693495974335, "skilllink": 1.2868648328947252, "cutecharm": 0.0007897487430980066}, "Items": {"focussash": 0.5029720671353307, "widelens": 0.31850254461871685}, "Spreads": {"Jolly:0/252/0/0/4/252": 0.16688791036529507, "Jolly:4/252/0/0/0/252": 0.3282606637941746, "Jolly:0/252/0/0/0/252": 0.470067401063931}, "Moves": ["tripleaxel", "tailslap", "protect", "bulletseed"], "Tera Types": {"ice": 0.33073614680537183, "stellar": 0.508084680602296}, "Teammates": ["Amoonguss", "Gholdengo", "Indeedee-F", "Politoed", "Farigiraf", "Hariyama"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Amoonguss and Indeedee-F are the premier partners, redirecting lethal single-target moves and allowing Cinccino to click multi-hit attacks freely. Politoed sets Rain, halves Fire-type damage, and activates Cinccino’s Ice-type Tera synergy by removing Sun’s harsh sunlight. Gholdengo blocks opposing Amoonguss spores and provides special offense that complements Cinccino’s physical focus. Farigiraf sets Psychic Terrain, blocks priority Fake Out against Cinccino, and offers Trick Room reversal options. Hariyama supplies Fake Out, a slow pivot, and Knock Off support that cripples opposing Incineroar or Corviknight before Cinccino sweeps. EV spreads on teammates are standard support sets—max HP and relevant defense with berries or Sitrus—because Cinccino already covers offensive pressure. The core concept is redirection plus weather/terrain control to guarantee Cinccino gets two or three turns of free multi-hit damage.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Cinccino": {"Abilities": {"technician": 0.8431693495974335, "skilllink": 1.2868648328947252, "cutecharm": 0.0007897487430980066}, "Items": {"focussash": 0.5029720671353307, "widelens": 0.31850254461871685}, "Spreads": {"Jolly:0/252/0/0/4/252": 0.16688791036529507, "Jolly:4/252/0/0/0/252": 0.3282606637941746, "Jolly:0/252/0/0/0/252": 0.470067401063931}, "Moves": ["tripleaxel", "tailslap", "protect", "bulletseed"], "Tera Types": {"ice": 0.33073614680537183, "stellar": 0.508084680602296}, "Teammates": ["Amoonguss", "Gholdengo", "Indeedee-F", "Politoed", "Farigiraf", "Hariyama"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Priority users that bypass Focus Sash—Kingambit’s Sucker Punch, Dragonite’s Extreme Speed, and Breloom’s Mach Punch—end Cinccino immediately. Intimidate + Parting Shot cores (Incineroar, Arcanine) force Tera early and reduce Tail Slap to pitiful damage. Wide Guard users such as Aegislash, Hitmontop, and Celesteela completely blank every move Cinccino carries, forcing awkward Protect cycles. Rocky Helmet / Iron Barbs (Garchomp, Ferrothorn, Skarmory) punish every hit with 30 % chip, meaning Cinccino KOes itself before finishing the target. Finally, bulky Steel-types like Zacian-Crowned and Corviknight survive even a Tera Ice Triple Axel and retaliate with KOes, while Sun-boosted Groudon lives and OHKOes back with Precipice Blades. Cinccino’s frailty also means any spread move or double-target into it breaks Focus Sash, so teams that cannot provide redirection will find it difficult to justify the mouse over sturdier breakers.</OUTPUT>

<OUTPUT>Cinccino / Amoonguss / Politoed / Gholdengo / Incineroar / Kingambit
A Rain-centric squad that leverages Cinccino as the primary restricted Pokémon killer. Politoed sets Rain to halve Fire damage and enable Gholdengo’s Thunder; Amoonguss provides Rage Powder and Spore pressure; Incineroar cycles Intimidate and Parting Shot to soften physical attackers for Cinccino; Gholdengo offers special offense and blocks enemy Amoonguss spores; Kingambit supplies priority Sucker Punch and late-game sweeping once Cinccino has removed Groudon and Lando-T. The team opens with Politoed + Cinccino to guarantee Rain and threaten immediate Triple Axel pressure, then pivots through Incineroar and Amoonguss to keep Cinccino healthy for mid-game Terastallization. After Cinccino deletes the opposing restricted Pokémon, Kingambit cleans with Supreme Overlord boosts.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Porygon-Z": {"Abilities": {"adaptability": 2.2107342842250626, "download": 0.03299646089368802, "analytic": 1.2469973942330626e-09}, "Items": {"lifeorb": 0.22316920535220136, "choicespecs": 0.1959301940923285, "choicescarf": 0.2886047251057853}, "Spreads": {"Modest:4/0/0/252/0/252": 0.2648593799948352, "Timid:4/0/0/252/0/252": 0.21451482362043217}, "Moves": ["terablast", "protect", "triattack", "hyperbeam"], "Tera Types": {"normal": 0.29252737298781706, "ice": 0.3125663398869613}, "Teammates": ["Incineroar", "Rillaboom", "Annihilape", "Whimsicott", "Farigiraf", "Ninetales-Alola"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Porygon-Z’s niche in VGC is that of a single-target nuke whose Adaptability-boosted Tri Attack and Tera-Normal Hyper Beam can OHKO virtually anything that doesn’t resist them. Its base 135 Special Attack is excellent for a format where 140+ offenses are rare, and its 90/70/75 bulk is just enough to survive one neutral hit when paired with a Focus Sash or behind Aurora Veil. The most common spread, Modest 252/252, hits 178/200 offensive stats, guaranteeing KOs on common threats like Tornadus, Amoonguss, and non-bulked Gholdengo. Timid variants trade roughly 10% damage for the ability to outspeed positive-natured base 100s and most opposing Flutter Mane. Life Orb is preferred when the team has redirection or speed control, turning every attack into a guaranteed KO; Choice Specs is used on more offensive structures to break walls like Dondozo or Corviknight; Choice Scarf turns Porygon-Z into a surprise cleaner that can outspeed and delete faster threats such as Chien-Pao or Iron Valiant. The move set is intentionally minimal—Tri Attack is the spammable STAB with 30% chance of status, Hyper Beam is the nuclear option that removes Dynamax targets, Tera Blast covers the rare Ghost match-up or becomes an Ice-type nuke post-Tera, and Protect is mandatory for doubles play. Tera Ice is gaining traction because it allows Porygon-Z to one-shot Dragonite, Tatsugiri, and Flying Tera Pokémon while still retaining Normal STAB thanks to Adaptability.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Porygon-Z": {"Abilities": {"adaptability": 2.2107342842250626, "download": 0.03299646089368802, "analytic": 1.2469973942330626e-09}, "Items": {"lifeorb": 0.22316920535220136, "choicespecs": 0.1959301940923285, "choicescarf": 0.2886047251057853}, "Spreads": {"Modest:4/0/0/252/0/252": 0.2648593799948352, "Timid:4/0/0/252/0/252": 0.21451482362043217}, "Moves": ["terablast", "protect", "triattack", "hyperbeam"], "Tera Types": {"normal": 0.29252737298781706, "ice": 0.3125663398869613}, "Teammates": ["Incineroar", "Rillaboom", "Annihilape", "Whimsicott", "Farigiraf", "Ninetales-Alola"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Porygon-Z dominates neutral and frail offensive teams that lack dedicated special walls; it can OHKO or 2HKO the majority of the metagame that doesn’t invest heavily in bulk or resist Normal. Against bulky Water- or Steel-types such as Dondozo, Garganacl, or Iron Hands, it needs either Specs or prior chip to secure the KO, making partners like Rillaboom’s Grassy Glide or Incineroar’s Parting Shot invaluable. Ghost-types completely wall its STAB, so it relies on Tera Ice Blast or teammate support to remove Aegislash, Annihilape, or Dragapult before committing. Priority users like Kingambit and Dragonite can finish off a chipped Porygon-Z, but Farigiraf’s armor and Alolan-Ninetales’s Veil blunt that avenue. Speed control is the biggest swing factor: under Tailwind or Scarf it outspeeds and deletes faster threats, but under opposing Trick Room it becomes food for slow powerhouses like Iron Hands or Glastrier. Opposing Tera Dark or Tera Steel can rob it of the Hyper Beam KO, forcing prediction wars. Overall, Porygon-Z is a matchup fish—it auto-wins against teams that lack bulk or Ghosts and auto-loses when those elements are present without proper support.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Porygon-Z": {"Abilities": {"adaptability": 2.2107342842250626, "download": 0.03299646089368802, "analytic": 1.2469973942330626e-09}, "Items": {"lifeorb": 0.22316920535220136, "choicespecs": 0.1959301940923285, "choicescarf": 0.2886047251057853}, "Spreads": {"Modest:4/0/0/252/0/252": 0.2648593799948352, "Timid:4/0/0/252/0/252": 0.21451482362043217}, "Moves": ["terablast", "protect", "triattack", "hyperbeam"], "Tera Types": {"normal": 0.29252737298781706, "ice": 0.3125663398869613}, "Teammates": ["Incineroar", "Rillaboom", "Annihilape", "Whimsicott", "Farigiraf", "Ninetales-Alola"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Porygon-Z is a glass-cannon special attacker whose sole job is to delete one or two opposing Pokémon before it faints. It is never a win-condition in the traditional sense; instead, it functions as a hole-puncher that trades itself for the opponent’s most dangerous offensive or defensive piece. Teams bring it when they need immediate, reliable damage that ignores Intimidate and bypasses most defensive abilities. It is equally effective as a lead, mid-game breaker, or late-game cleaner depending on item choice—Life Orb variants prefer to operate behind redirection or Veil, Specs variants break walls early, and Scarf variants sweep once faster threats are chipped or paralyzed. Its low bulk demands either speed control or passive protection, so it is never seen outside of dedicated cores that can provide Tailwind, Aurora Veil, Fake Out, or Follow Me. In short, Porygon-Z is a one-use cannon: point, click, and remove something from the field.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Incineroar is the ideal partner, providing Fake Out, Intimidate, and Parting Shot to create safe entry turns while also softening special walls with Knock Off. Rillaboom brings Grassy Glide priority and Grassy Terrain recovery, patching Porygon-Z’s mediocre bulk and finishing off weakened Water- or Ground-types. Whimsicott offers Tailwind and Taunt to shut down Trick Room and opposing speed control, letting Porygon-Z attack first without a Choice Scarf. Annihilape flips the script, setting Trick Room itself so that a Modest Porygon-Z can underspeed and nuke threats like Iron Valiant or Chien-Pao that normally outspeed. Farigiraf’s armor blocks opposing priority, ensuring that Porygon-Z is not picked off by Sucker Punch or Aqua Jet, while also providing Helping Hand to secure key KOs. Alolan-Ninetales rounds out the core with Aurora Veil, effectively doubling Porygon-Z’s bulk for five turns and giving it the freedom to run Life Orb over Focus Sash. Together these teammates cover Porygon-Z’s weaknesses to Ghost, Dark, and Fighting while providing the speed control or bulk augmentation it needs to fire off unimpeded attacks.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Porygon-Z": {"Abilities": {"adaptability": 2.2107342842250626, "download": 0.03299646089368802, "analytic": 1.2469973942330626e-09}, "Items": {"lifeorb": 0.22316920535220136, "choicespecs": 0.1959301940923285, "choicescarf": 0.2886047251057853}, "Spreads": {"Modest:4/0/0/252/0/252": 0.2648593799948352, "Timid:4/0/0/252/0/252": 0.21451482362043217}, "Moves": ["terablast", "protect", "triattack", "hyperbeam"], "Tera Types": {"normal": 0.29252737298781706, "ice": 0.3125663398869613}, "Teammates": ["Incineroar", "Rillaboom", "Annihilape", "Whimsicott", "Farigiraf", "Ninetales-Alola"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Ghost-types—Aegislash, Dragapult, Annihilape—completely wall Porygon-Z’s STAB and can retaliate with Shadow Ball or Rage Fist. Specially bulky Steel-types like Corviknight and Garganacl can tank a Specs Hyper Beam and heal or set up in its face. Priority users such as Kingambit’s Sucker Punch or Dragonite’s Extreme Speed pick off a chipped Porygon-Z before it moves. Opposing Tera Dark or Tera Steel on neutral targets can survive the nuke and KO back. Speed control wars are brutal: if the opponent sets Trick Room or maintains Tailwind, Porygon-Z either moves last and dies or is forced into awkward Protect loops. Finally, because it is almost always choice-locked or Life Orb recoil-stacked, residual damage from Stealth Rock, sand, or burn quickly puts it in range of any neutral attack. The safest answers are to bring a Ghost, to preserve a healthy Steel-type, or to deny its speed control with your own Tailwind or Trick Room.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Alcremie": {"Abilities": {"sweetveil": 1.4433615479469073, "aromaveil": 0.6737419319126623}, "Items": {"leftovers": 0.45359047262474533}, "Spreads": {"Bold:252/0/200/4/52/0": 0.35365247505012004}, "Moves": ["decorate", "protect", "dazzlinggleam", "lightscreen"], "Tera Types": {"steel": 0.2502400881999014, "fairy": 0.2280392192018058, "water": 0.3544668206528892}, "Teammates": ["Sneasler", "Rillaboom", "Sinistcha", "Hydreigon", "Volcarona", "Milotic"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Alcremie is a niche support Pokémon in VGC that leverages its signature move Decorate to turn any partner into an immediate offensive threat, functioning best on hyper-offensive teams that appreciate the +2 Attack and Special Attack boost. Its bulk, bolstered by a Bold EV spread and access to Aroma Veil, allows it to block priority Taunt and Encore, ensuring it can get off a Decorate or set up a Light Screen before going down. While its own offenses are mediocre, the sheer swing potential of turning a Sneasler, Hydreigon, or Volcarona into a +2 powerhouse can dismantle unprepared opponents. Tera Water is the most common Tera type, patching its Fire and Steel weaknesses while retaining a neutral hit into Steel-types that resist Fairy. Leftovers is the item of choice to squeeze extra longevity out of its 110/95/90 bulk, letting it Decorate more than once in longer games. Alcremie is not a win-condition itself; instead, it is a catalyst that turns already dangerous teammates into game-ending monsters.</OUTPUT>

input:
Provide the 'full_analysis' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Alcremie": {"Abilities": {"sweetveil": 1.4433615479469073, "aromaveil": 0.6737419319126623}, "Items": {"leftovers": 0.45359047262474533}, "Spreads": {"Bold:252/0/200/4/52/0": 0.35365247505012004}, "Moves": ["decorate", "protect", "dazzlinggleam", "lightscreen"], "Tera Types": {"steel": 0.2502400881999014, "fairy": 0.2280392192018058, "water": 0.3544668206528892}, "Teammates": ["Sneasler", "Rillaboom", "Sinistcha", "Hydreigon", "Volcarona", "Milotic"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Alcremie’s calling card is Decorate, a +2 boost to both offensive stats of any ally, making it the only Pokémon in the format that can instantly convert passive board states into lethal ones without requiring a turn of setup. The listed Bold spread (252 HP / 200 Def / 52 SpD) survives key physical rolls such as Choice Band Chien-Pao Ice Spinner and Iron Valiant Spirit Break while still tanking modest special hits like Specs Dragapult Shadow Ball. Aroma Veil is preferred on most teams because it shuts down Prankster Taunt from Whimsicott, Murkrow, and Grimmsnarl, as well as Encore from Dondozo and Toxapex, guaranteeing that Alcremie can execute its game plan. Sweet Veil is a niche option to block sleep from Amoonguss or Spore from Breloom, but the value of Aroma Veil against the dominant Prankster meta is usually higher. Light Screen is chosen over Reflect because most of Alcremie’s best partners (Sneasler, Volcarona, Hydreigon) are special attackers that appreciate the special bulk more than physical bulk, and the 5-turn screen lets them set up or rip through teams after a Decorate. Dazzling Gleam is a mandatory two-target STAB that prevents Alcremie from being complete Taunt bait and picks off weakened Dragons, Dark-types, and Fighting-types. Protect is obvious for pivoting and stalling out Dynamax turns or Tailwind timers. Tera Water is the standout Tera type: it removes the Fire weakness that plagues Steel-tera variants, keeps a neutral hit into Steel-types, and lets Alcremie survive Heat Wave from Tornadus or Volcarona and Iron Head from Garchomp. Tera Fairy is an alternative that strengthens Dazzling Gleam and grants a Dragon immunity, but the defensive value of Tera Water is generally preferred. Leftovers is the only item worth considering because Alcremie’s job is to stay on the field for multiple turns, either to Decorate twice or to Decorate and then screen; Sitrus Berry is too small a recovery and Babiri Berry is too matchup-specific. EV spreads can be tweaked: 252 HP / 140 Def / 116 SpD with a Calm nature lets Alcremie survive Specs Hydreigon Draco Meteor and +2 Espathra Tera Fighting Tera Blast, but the Bold spread is the most common on ladder because it handles the physical meta better. In best-of-three, Alcremie is usually brought in game-two or game-three when the opponent has revealed less Fake Out or Taunt pressure, and it pairs beautifully with Dynamax partners because the Decorate boost applies to Max Moves, turning Max Airstream or Max Ooze into even bigger snowballs.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Alcremie": {"Abilities": {"sweetveil": 1.4433615479469073, "aromaveil": 0.6737419319126623}, "Items": {"leftovers": 0.45359047262474533}, "Spreads": {"Bold:252/0/200/4/52/0": 0.35365247505012004}, "Moves": ["decorate", "protect", "dazzlinggleam", "lightscreen"], "Tera Types": {"steel": 0.2502400881999014, "fairy": 0.2280392192018058, "water": 0.3544668206528892}, "Teammates": ["Sneasler", "Rillaboom", "Sinistcha", "Hydreigon", "Volcarona", "Milotic"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Alcremie enjoys matchups against bulky, setup-oriented teams that lack immediate offensive pressure or Taunt users. It feasts on Dondozo + Tatsugiri cores that spend turns setting up, on Sun teams that rely on Venusaur sleep or Torkool support, and on Stall teams that try to win with status and Encore. Conversely, it struggles against hyper-offensive teams that carry double-target pressure or Fake Out + Taunt leads such as Incineroar + Whimsicott or Chien-Pao + Grimmsnarl. Priority users like Kingambit and Dragonite can bypass Aroma Veil with Sucker Punch or Extreme Speed to KO Alcremie before it Decorates, while Choice Band Iron Valiant can outspeed and KO with Spirit Break even through Light Screen. Steel-types that resist Dazzling Gleam—Corviknight, Gholdengo, and Tinkaton—can sit in front of Alcremie and either stall out turns or retaliate with super-effective Iron Heads or Flash Cannons. Amoonguss is a mixed bag: Aroma Veil blocks Spore, but Clear Smog removes the Decorate boosts, forcing Alcremie to either Tera or switch out. Terrain teams with Indeedee can block Fake Out but also block Alcremie’s own priority, so positioning is key. Overall, Alcremie wants to face slower, setup-heavy or balance teams and wants to avoid facing dual-speed control or double-Fake Out leads.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Alcremie": {"Abilities": {"sweetveil": 1.4433615479469073, "aromaveil": 0.6737419319126623}, "Items": {"leftovers": 0.45359047262474533}, "Spreads": {"Bold:252/0/200/4/52/0": 0.35365247505012004}, "Moves": ["decorate", "protect", "dazzlinggleam", "lightscreen"], "Tera Types": {"steel": 0.2502400881999014, "fairy": 0.2280392192018058, "water": 0.3544668206528892}, "Teammates": ["Sneasler", "Rillaboom", "Sinistcha", "Hydreigon", "Volcarona", "Milotic"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Alcremie is a pure support Pokémon whose only win condition is to make its partner unstoppable. It is almost never the Dynamax target; instead, it enters the field, uses Decorate on a threatening ally, and then either Protects to waste opposing Dynamax turns or sets Light Screen to blunt retaliation. It functions as both a speed-control bypass (because the boost is immediate) and a counter-play to Taunt/Encore-heavy teams thanks to Aroma Veil. In the mid-game it can come back in after a KO, Decorate a second ally, and effectively give a team two boosted sweepers. Its bulk and typing allow it to check opposing Fairy-types and Dragons in a pinch, but its primary role is to turn one or two teammates into win conditions rather than to trade itself for KOs.</OUTPUT>

In return, Alcremie covers their Dragon and Dark weaknesses with Fairy typing and Aroma Veil protection. The core of Alcremie + Sneasler + Volcarona is especially potent because it presents two completely different win conditions—physical and special—that both require different answers after a Decorate.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Alcremie": {"Abilities": {"sweetveil": 1.4433615479469073, "aromaveil": 0.6737419319126623}, "Items": {"leftovers": 0.45359047262474533}, "Spreads": {"Bold:252/0/200/4/52/0": 0.35365247505012004}, "Moves": ["decorate", "protect", "dazzlinggleam", "lightscreen"], "Tera Types": {"steel": 0.2502400881999014, "fairy": 0.2280392192018058, "water": 0.3544668206528892}, "Teammates": ["Sneasler", "Rillaboom", "Sinistcha", "Hydreigon", "Volcarona", "Milotic"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Alcremie is countered by anything that can KO it before it Decorates or that can ignore the boost afterward. Double-target pressure, Fake Out + Taunt leads, and priority users are the biggest obstacles. Incineroar + Whimsicott can Fake Out + Taunt to stop the first turn, while Chien-Pao + Grimmsnarl can Spirit Break + Fake Out to KO through Light Screen. Kingambit and Dragonite can Sucker Punch or Extreme Speed for the KO if Alcremie is below 80%. Gholdengo and Corviknight can wall Dazzling Gleam and retaliate with Make It Rain or Iron Head, forcing Alcremie to Tera or switch. Amoonguss with Clear Smog removes the boosts, and Toxapex with Haze does the same, though both must watch for Aroma Veil blocking Spore. Clear Body Metagross and Goodra can ignore the stat drop from Decorate partners’ Max Wyrmwind or Max Quake, but they still take the full +2 damage. Finally, opposing Tailwind or Chlorophyll sweepers can simply outspeed and KO before the boosted partner can move. The best counterplay is to identify Alcremie in team preview, lead aggressive Fake Out + Taunt or double-target pressure, and never let it get off a free Decorate.</OUTPUT>

input:
Create the 'sample_team_concept' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Alcremie": {"Abilities": {"sweetveil": 1.4433615479469073, "aromaveil": 0.6737419319126623}, "Items": {"leftovers": 0.45359047262474533}, "Spreads": {"Bold:252/0/200/4/52/0": 0.35365247505012004}, "Moves": ["decorate", "protect", "dazzlinggleam", "lightscreen"], "Tera Types": {"steel": 0.2502400881999014, "fairy": 0.2280392192018058, "water": 0.3544668206528892}, "Teammates": ["Sneasler", "Rillaboom", "Sinistcha", "Hydreigon", "Volcarona", "Milotic"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Alcremie / Sneasler / Volcarona / Rillaboom / Rotom-Wash / Gholdengo. This squad abuses both physical and special Decorate targets while maintaining solid speed control and defensive backbone. Lead Alcremie + Sneasler against slower teams: Decorate turn one, then Dynamax Sneasler and sweep with Max Poison + Max Knuckle boosts. Against faster teams, bring Volcarona + Alcremie and Tera Water to survive Heat Wave, then Max Ooze to snowball. Rillaboom gives priority Grassy Glide and terrain control, Rotom-Wash provides Intimidate immunity and Volt Switch momentum, and Gholdengo is the Steel-type that blocks opposing status and spins. The team is weak to opposing Tailwind Chien-Pao, so Rotom can run Thunder Wave and Gholdengo can run Trick Scarf to disrupt speed control. In best-of-three, game-one is often the Sneasler blitz; if the opponent adapts with double-target or Clear Body, switch to Volcarona or Rillaboom as the Decorate target. The core idea is to present two completely different boosted win conditions that require different answers, forcing the opponent to guess wrong and lose on turn two.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Lurantis": {"Abilities": {"contrary": 1.9750032369596453, "leafguard": 9.55881517994417e-07}, "Items": {"assaultvest": 0.7890894595779326, "aguavberry": 0.19179145564367406}, "Spreads": {"Sassy:248/0/8/0/252/0": 0.1878327730570254, "Brave:96/100/252/0/60/0": 0.19179145564367406, "Quiet:4/252/0/252/0/0": 0.17557411293582229}, "Moves": ["superpower", "knockoff", "leafstorm", "leechlife"], "Tera Types": {"poison": 0.18958751264778353, "fire": 0.20256489669472216, "fighting": 0.298850483511803}, "Teammates": ["Malamar", "Incineroar", "Ursaluna-Bloodmoon", "Indeedee-F", "Oranguru", "Ursaluna"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Lurantis carves a niche as a slow, specially bulky Contrary sweeper that flips stat drops into boosts. Superpower and Leaf Storm become escalating nukes while Knock Off and Leeech Life grant coverage and recovery. Assault Vest is the dominant item, letting it tank special hits while it sets up, and Poison Tera is the most common to erase its Fairy weakness and absorb Toxic. It fits best on dedicated Contrary or Psychic-spam teams alongside Malamar and Indeedee-F, leveraging Instruct or Psychic Terrain to snowball faster.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Lurantis": {"Abilities": {"contrary": 1.9750032369596453, "leafguard": 9.55881517994417e-07}, "Items": {"assaultvest": 0.7890894595779326, "aguavberry": 0.19179145564367406}, "Spreads": {"Sassy:248/0/8/0/252/0": 0.1878327730570254, "Brave:96/100/252/0/60/0": 0.19179145564367406, "Quiet:4/252/0/252/0/0": 0.17557411293582229}, "Moves": ["superpower", "knockoff", "leafstorm", "leechlife"], "Tera Types": {"poison": 0.18958751264778353, "fire": 0.20256489669472216, "fighting": 0.298850483511803}, "Teammates": ["Malamar", "Incineroar", "Ursaluna-Bloodmoon", "Indeedee-F", "Oranguru", "Ursaluna"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>With 70/105 physical bulk and 90/90 special bulk, Lurantis is deceptively tanky, especially under Assault Vest. Contrary turns its otherwise mediocre 105 Attack and 90 Special Attack into constantly rising threats after a single Leaf Storm or Superpower. The chosen EV spreads reinforce this: the most common Brave set invests heavily in bulk (252 HP / 100 Atk / 60 SpD) to survive hits while accumulating boosts, whereas the Quiet spread (4 HP / 252 SpA / 252 SpA) attempts a mixed wall-breaker role. Sassy with 252 SpD is the premier special pivot, comfortably surviving Indeedee-F Expanding Force or Sylveon Hyper Voice and retaliating with a +2 Leaf Storm or Knock Off. Tera Poison removes the 4× Fairy weakness and grants Toxic immunity, making it the safest long-term play; Tera Fighting boosts both STABs and turns Superpower into an even bigger nuke, while Tera Fire punishes predicted Ice or Steel moves but leaves Lurantis exposed to Stealth Rock-style chip. Leech Life provides recovery that Assault Vest sets otherwise lack, allowing incremental healing while pressuring Psychic- and Dark-types. Knock Off is invaluable in VGC for removing Berries and Heavy-Duty Boots from common switch-ins like Incineroar and Toxapex. Superpower’s defense drops become boosts, letting Lurantis tank physical hits better after each use, while Leaf Storm’s SpA drops similarly become Special Attack raises, forcing opponents to either KO immediately or watch Lurantis spiral out of control.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Lurantis loves facing passive special attackers such as Toxapex, Slowking-G, and opposing Indeedee-F that fail to 2HKO through Assault Vest while it accum boosts. It also pressures common Steel-types like Corviknight and Gholdengo that dislike repeated Superpowers or Knock Offs. Conversely, fast offensive Fairies—Iron Valiant, Choice Specs Sylveon, and Flutter Mane—OHKO before it can move, and priority users like Bisharp and Kingambit can finish it off after chip. Fire-types such as Heatran and Chi-Yu outspeed and vaporize it unless Lurantis has already acquired multiple boosts. Psychic Terrain teams can block priority revenge killing, but outside that support it remains vulnerable to Sucker Punch and Jet Punch. Tera Poison variants still fear strong Earthquakes from Great Tusk or Ursaluna, so partners that can redirect or intimidate physical attackers are mandatory.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Lurantis functions as a mid-game Contrary win-condition and special pivot. It switches in on predicted status or resisted moves, fires off a Leaf Storm or Superpower, and either continues boosting or pivots out once its speed becomes a liability. With Assault Vest it can repeatedly check special attackers while removing items, and late-game it can clean once faster threats are eliminated. On Psychic-spam builds it appreciates Indeedee-F’s Terrain blocking priority and Oranguru’s Instruct doubling its boosting turns. On more balanced squads it pairs with Incineroar for Intimidate and Parting Shot support, giving it free turns to set up.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Barraskewda": {"Abilities": {"swiftswim": 0.6991241394041026, "propellertail": 1.34997954407812}, "Items": {"choiceband": 0.3619145860309594, "focussash": 0.4172992963955215}, "Spreads": {"Jolly:4/252/0/0/0/252": 0.4465013267016726}, "Moves": ["liquidation", "flipturn", "closecombat", "protect"], "Tera Types": {"water": 0.3823190187060001, "ghost": 0.33789442550373155}, "Teammates": ["Incineroar", "Pelipper", "Ursaluna-Bloodmoon", "Dragapult", "Weezing", "Corviknight"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Barraskewda is a lightning-fast physical attacker that thrives on rain teams, leveraging Swift Swim to outpace nearly the entire metagame while firing off STAB Liquidations and coverage Close Combats; with a Choice Band it becomes an immediate breaker, while Focus Sash lets it trade or set up a Flip Turn pivot even under harsh conditions. Its default Jolly 252/252 spread maximizes both offenses and Speed, ensuring it outruns +1 base 100s in rain and still speed-ties opposing base 115s outside of it. Water Tera is the most common to push Liquidation into nuke territory, but Ghost Tera is rising to dodge Fake Out and Extreme Speed while maintaining offensive momentum. Teammates like Pelipper provide mandatory rain, Incineroar offers pivoting and Intimidate support, Ursaluna-Bloodmoon breaks shared checks, Dragapult provides a fast Ghost mode, and Weezing/Corviknight cover Fairy and Grass problems respectively.</OUTPUT>

input:
Draft the 'full_analysis' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Barraskewda": {"Abilities": {"swiftswim": 0.6991241394041026, "propellertail": 1.34997954407812}, "Items": {"choiceband": 0.3619145860309594, "focussash": 0.4172992963955215}, "Spreads": {"Jolly:4/252/0/0/0/252": 0.4465013267016726}, "Moves": ["liquidation", "flipturn", "closecombat", "protect"], "Tera Types": {"water": 0.3823190187060001, "ghost": 0.33789442550373155}, "Teammates": ["Incineroar", "Pelipper", "Ursaluna-Bloodmoon", "Dragapult", "Weezing", "Corviknight"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Barraskewda’s claim to fame is its astronomical 136 base Speed, which under Swift Swim and rain becomes effectively unmatched in the current Regulation G format. This allows it to function as both a late-game cleaner and a powerful mid-game wallbreaker depending on item choice. Choice Band sets are the most threatening, turning Liquidation into a 140 BP nuke that OHKOes most neutral targets and 2HKOes even bulky resists such as AV Incineroar and Corviknight after Stealth Rock-style chip. Close Combat nails Ferrothorn, Kingambit, and opposing Incineroar, while Flip Turn preserves momentum versus predicted switches or Protects. Protect occupies the fourth slot on virtually every set, letting it scout choice-locked foes and block Fake Out damage that would otherwise break its Focus Sash variant. The Sash variant trades immediate power for survivability, guaranteeing at least one attack or pivot versus faster scarfers or priority spam teams. Propeller Tail is a niche ability that ignores redirection, but the overwhelming dominance of rain archetypes means Swift Swim is chosen roughly 70 % of the time. Tera Water is the default for the extra Liquidation damage and a stronger Flip Turn, but Tera Ghost is gaining traction to blank Extreme Speed from Dragonite, ignore Fake Out, and block Prankster Twave from Grimmsnarl. The listed teammates form a cohesive rain core: Pelipper sets infinite rain and provides wide-gauge support via Tailwind and Wider Lens Hurricanes; Incineroar offers Fake Out, Intimidate, and Parting Shot to create free turns; Ursaluna-Bloodmoon appreciates the removal of Water-immune foes and breaks past special walls that Barraskewda baits; Dragapult forms a fast Ghost spam core, punishing opposing priority with its own Tera Ghost synergy; Weezing neutralises Fairy and Grass threats with Neutralizing Gas and Sludge Bomb poisons; Corviknight supplies Defog, slow U-turns, and a crucial Ground immunity that covers Pelipper. In practice Barraskewda functions as the speed control glue that lets rain teams apply immediate pressure without requiring setup turns, distinguishing it from more passive Swift Swim sweepers like Kingdra.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Barraskewda": {"Abilities": {"swiftswim": 0.6991241394041026, "propellertail": 1.34997954407812}, "Items": {"choiceband": 0.3619145860309594, "focussash": 0.4172992963955215}, "Spreads": {"Jolly:4/252/0/0/0/252": 0.4465013267016726}, "Moves": ["liquidation", "flipturn", "closecombat", "protect"], "Tera Types": {"water": 0.3823190187060001, "ghost": 0.33789442550373155}, "Teammates": ["Incineroar", "Pelipper", "Ursaluna-Bloodmoon", "Dragapult", "Weezing", "Corviknight"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Against hyper offense, Barraskewda is a menace: it outspeeds every unboosted threat outside of weather and KOes frail leads such as Chien-Pao, Iron Valiant, and opposing Dragapult. Rain mirrors come down to speed ties and Tera choices, but +2 Jolly Liquidation always OHKOes opposing Barraskewda after minor chip. Versus balance cores built around Amoonguss + Tornadus, it pressures Tornadus on the switch and 2HKOes Amoonguss with Tera Water Liquidation, forcing Protect or redirection. Stall teams lacking Unaware Clodsire are demolished by Band Liquidation, while Clodsire itself is 2HKOed by Close Combat on the switch. Priority-heavy teams—Dragonite, Kingambit, Breloom—hate Tera Ghost variants that blank Extreme Speed and Sucker Punch, forcing them into prediction wars. Sun teams can outspeed with Chlorophyll Venusaur or Torkoal under its own weather, but under rain Barraskewda wins the exchange; the key is preventing Torkoal from resetting weather, a task handled by Pelipper’s faster Drizzle or Weezing’s Neutralizing Gas stopping Orichalcum Pulse. Trick Room is the worst matchup: base 136 Speed is irrelevant, and Hatterene or Indeedee-F can set Room while surviving a Liquidation. Counterplay involves either denying Room with Taunt from Corviknight or Dragapult, or simply firing off Flip Turns to preserve board presence until Room expires. Electric Terrain teams featuring Iron Hands and Pincurchin can survive a Liquidation and retaliate with Thunder Punch or Zing Zap, so prediction and Protect scouting are essential.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Barraskewda is the quintessential Swift Swim cleaner and pivot. Its primary role is to enter after rain is active, delete something with a Choice Band Liquidation or secure a safe Flip Turn, and then either clean late-game or chip key targets so that Ursaluna-Bloodmoon or Dragapult can sweep later. On Focus Sash sets it doubles as a lead that can trade versus faster scarfers or absorb a double-target while dealing massive damage. The combination of blistering Speed and respectable 100 base Attack makes it one of the few offensive Water-types that does not require Tailwind or Dragon Dance to function, freeing up team slots for utility Pokémon like Weezing or Corviknight. In BO3 sets, opponents must respect both the immediate Band variant and the pivoting Sash variant, creating a 50/50 that can decide games on preview.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Pelipper is mandatory: Drizzle unlocks Swift Swim and guarantees Barraskewda’s speed tier. Incineroar provides Fake Out, Intimidate, and Parting Shot, creating free attacks or safe Flip Turns. Ursaluna-Bloodmoon shares checks (Ferrothorn, Clodsire) and breaks special walls that can stomach Liquidation, while Barraskewda removes opposing Water immunities and faster threats that revenge Bloodmoon. Dragapult forms a dual-Tera-Ghost core, punishing priority and blanking Fake Out; both Pokémon can Flip Turn back and forth to maintain momentum. Weezing’s Neutralizing Gas stops Contrary, Orichalcum Pulse, and Protosynthesis, ensuring rain stays active; it also poisons Grass and Fairy types that resist Water. Corviknight offers a slow pivot, Defog to remove opposing hazards that break Sash, and a crucial Ground immunity that protects Pelipper from Earthquake spam. The team compresses roles efficiently: rain setter, physical breaker, special breaker, speed control, redirection immunity, hazard removal, and Intimidate pivot all coexist without major overlap.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Choice Band: Jolly 252 Atk / 4 Def / 252 Spe with Liquidation / Close Combat / Flip Turn / Protect, Tera Water. Item locks you into one move but every attack is a nuke; aim to delete a target or force a Protect, then switch to Incineroar or Pelipper to maintain pressure. Focus Sash: identical EVs and moves but item guarantees survival; play as a lead or mid-game pivot, firing off strong attacks and pivoting out with Flip Turn to bring in Incineroar or Bloodmoon safely. input:
Create the 'weaknesses_and_counters' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Barraskewda": {"Abilities": {"swiftswim": 0.6991241394041026, "propellertail": 1.34997954407812}, "Items": {"choiceband": 0.3619145860309594, "focussash": 0.4172992963955215}, "Spreads": {"Jolly:4/252/0/0/0/252": 0.4465013267016726}, "Moves": ["liquidation", "flipturn", "closecombat", "protect"], "Tera Types": {"water": 0.3823190187060001, "ghost": 0.33789442550373155}, "Teammates": ["Incineroar", "Pelipper", "Ursaluna-Bloodmoon", "Dragapult", "Weezing", "Corviknight"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Clodsire is the single best switch-in: unaware ignores Swift Swim speed, and it survives two Close Combats from full; however, it fears Toxic from Weezing and cannot recover if Barraskewda Tera Ghosts to block Sucker Punch. Amoonguss can redirect once with Rage Powder, but Tera Water Liquidation 2HKOes through Sitrus; the real answer is to pair Amoonguss with a faster Tornadus that can Tailwind and KO back. Priority from Kingambit or Dragonite can break Sash and KO, but both lose to Tera Ghost variants. Trick Room abusers such as Hatterene and Indeedee-F ignore speed and OHKO with Dazzling Gleam or Expanding Force; stopping Room with Taunt or double-targeting is essential. Weather wars can flip the matchup: if Torkoal sets sun, Venusaur or Charizard outspeed and KO; keeping Pelipper alive and using Weezing to block Orichalcum Pulse is critical. Finally, bulky Water resists such as AV Incineroar and Corviknight can stomach a Liquidation and retaliate, but both are 2HKOed by Band Liquidation after Stealth Rock-style chip, so Protect scouting and prediction are required.</OUTPUT>

Write the 'short_summary' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Lilligant": {"Abilities": {"chlorophyll": 1.642817447910371, "owntempo": 0.4718275425445349, "leafguard": 7.807088309164101e-13}, "Items": {"focussash": 0.29599278190851186, "covertcloak": 0.2675652213869297, "leftovers": 0.28235640309958315}, "Spreads": {"Timid:252/0/0/4/0/252": 0.2639033457367054, "Timid:140/0/116/0/0/252": 0.19046394699208544}, "Moves": ["afteryou", "pollenpuff", "protect", "sleeppowder"], "Tera Types": {"grass": 0.19662645590032457, "fire": 0.26449496506628806, "water": 0.35520721554842843, "ghost": 0.15056253987843174}, "Teammates": ["Torkoal", "Indeedee-F", "Volcarona", "Incineroar", "Hatterene", "Corviknight"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Lilligant carves a unique niche in VGC as a Chlorophyll support that turbo-charges sun cores by letting slower partners move first with After You, while simultaneously spreading safe Pollen Puff recovery and clutch Sleep Powder pressure. Its blazing 252+ Speed under sun, combined with a Grass Tera or defensive Water/Fire Tera, lets it outrun the entire metagame, pick off or cripple threats, and remain alive long enough to enable heavy hitters like Torkoal or Volcarona to sweep. The most common spread (Timid 252/0/0/4/0/252) maximizes this speed and power, while a bulkier 140/0/116 variant survives key hits and keeps the utility flowing. Focus Sash is the default safety net, Covert Cloak blocks Fake Out and powder, and Leftovers pairs with Leaf Guard for residual stalling, giving Lilligant surprising flexibility within sun archetypes.</OUTPUT>

input:
Write the 'full_analysis' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Lilligant": {"Abilities": {"chlorophyll": 1.642817447910371, "owntempo": 0.4718275425445349, "leafguard": 7.807088309164101e-13}, "Items": {"focussash": 0.29599278190851186, "covertcloak": 0.2675652213869297, "leftovers": 0.28235640309958315}, "Spreads": {"Timid:252/0/0/4/0/252": 0.2639033457367054, "Timid:140/0/116/0/0/252": 0.19046394699208544}, "Moves": ["afteryou", "pollenpuff", "protect", "sleeppowder"], "Tera Types": {"grass": 0.19662645590032457, "fire": 0.26449496506628806, "water": 0.35520721554842843, "ghost": 0.15056253987843174}, "Teammates": ["Torkoal", "Indeedee-F", "Volcarona", "Incineroar", "Hatterene", "Corviknight"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Lilligant’s value lies in its ability to compress three roles—speed control, status, and team healing—into one slot while demanding almost no offensive investment. Chlorophyll turns it into a 398-Speed monster under sun, letting it fire un-missable Sleep Powders before most opposing support Pokémon can even click Protect, and its 90 base Special Attack is still enough to OHKO common threats like Gholdengo with +1 Tera Grass Leaf Storm or cleanly 2HKO bulky Waters with Pollen Puff into a partner. After You is the signature tech: it allows a sun partner—usually a -Speed Torkoal—to move immediately after Lilligant, effectively giving the sun setter a free turn to Eruption or set sun again, or lets Volcarona fire a +1 Heat Wave before opposing Tailwind or Trick Room can be completed. Protect is mandatory for double-target mind-games and to preserve Focus Sash, while Pollen Puff provides 50% healing to any ally, punishing spread-damage teams and offsetting Flare Blitz recoil or Life Orb chip. Tera choices are calculated: Water removes the Fire weakness and combos with sun to survive Heat Wave mirrors; Fire boosts Eruption synergy and flips the script on Corviknight and Amoonguss; Grass grants a reliable STAB Leaf Storm nuke; Ghost blocks Fake Out and ExtremeSpeed, giving Lilligant a one-time slot to survive and keep the support loop alive. Lilligant’s EV spreads reflect two philosophies: max/max Timid guarantees the speed tie against opposing Chlorophyll users and +1 Iron Bundle, while the 140 HP / 116 Def spread survives Jolly Chien-Pao Ice Spinner and Modest Torkoal Overheat in sun, letting it remain on the field as a long-term nuisance. The combination of speed, disruption, and team healing makes Lilligant one of the most efficient support Pokémon in sun structures, and its mere presence forces opponents to respect both the sleep and the After You threat every single turn.</OUTPUT>

input:
Create the 'matchup_overview' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Lilligant": {"Abilities": {"chlorophyll": 1.642817447910371, "owntempo": 0.4718275425445349, "leafguard": 7.807088309164101e-13}, "Items": {"focussash": 0.29599278190851186, "covertcloak": 0.2675652213869297, "leftovers": 0.28235640309958315}, "Spreads": {"Timid:252/0/0/4/0/252": 0.2639033457367054, "Timid:140/0/116/0/0/252": 0.19046394699208544}, "Moves": ["afteryou", "pollenpuff", "protect", "sleeppowder"], "Tera Types": {"grass": 0.19662645590032457, "fire": 0.26449496506628806, "water": 0.35520721554842843, "ghost": 0.15056253987843174}, "Teammates": ["Torkoal", "Indeedee-F", "Volcarona", "Incineroar", "Hatterene", "Corviknight"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Against hyper-offense, Lilligant is a nightmare: it outspeeds every non-priority attacker under sun, can put half the opposing board to sleep, and redirects kill pressure onto its Sash while Torkal or Volcarona blast away. Into Tailwind or Chlorophyll mirrors, speed ties decide games, so the bulkier spread and Water Tera are preferred to survive opposing Leaf Storms and Heat Waves. Versus Trick Room, Lilligant’s speed is irrelevant, but a well-timed Sleep Powder onto the setter or a Pollen Puff heal onto an ally can stall the turn of Trick Room, and After You lets Torkoal or Hatterene strike before the room goes up. Into bulky Water or Dragon cores, Grass Tera Leaf Storm secures 2HKOs on Toxapex and Dondozo, while Fire Tera punits Gholdengo and Corviknight. Amoonguss is a soft counter—Clear Smog removes stat changes and Spore goes through Sash—but Covert Cloak variants ignore both Rage Powder and Spore, letting Lilligant stay active. Opposing weather, especially Sand and Rain, strips away the speed advantage, so partners must either reset sun immediately or apply enough offensive pressure that Lilligant can still support from the back line.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Lilligant": {"Abilities": {"chlorophyll": 1.642817447910371, "owntempo": 0.4718275425445349, "leafguard": 7.807088309164101e-13}, "Items": {"focussash": 0.29599278190851186, "covertcloak": 0.2675652213869297, "leftovers": 0.28235640309958315}, "Spreads": {"Timid:252/0/0/4/0/252": 0.2639033457367054, "Timid:140/0/116/0/0/252": 0.19046394699208544}, "Moves": ["afteryou", "pollenpuff", "protect", "sleeppowder"], "Tera Types": {"grass": 0.19662645590032457, "fire": 0.26449496506628806, "water": 0.35520721554842843, "ghost": 0.15056253987843174}, "Teammates": ["Torkoal", "Indeedee-F", "Volcarona", "Incineroar", "Hatterene", "Corviknight"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Lilligant is a hyper-speed utility pivot whose primary job is to ensure that its slower, hard-hitting teammates move first. In sun it functions as a psuedo–speed control, a sleep inducer, and a cleric simultaneously. After You turns a 54-Speed Torkoal into a 398-Speed Eruption machine, or lets a 0-Speed Volcarona outspeed and KO a +1 Dragonite before it can attack. Sleep Powder provides the safest status in the format—75% accurate but with no immunities outside of Grass types and Overcoat—allowing Lilligant to neuter Dynamax sweepers or support Pokémon for the rest of the match. Pollen Puff is the glue that keeps sun cores healthy, healing 50% to any ally and punishing Wide-Guard or Protect stalling. Protect and Focus Sash give Lilligat a guaranteed two-turn lifespan, enough to fire off both support moves and still remain on the board as a speed threat. The set is EV’d to either maximize speed or to survive the most common spread moves (Heat Wave, Rock Slide, Ice Spinner) so that it can keep the support loop running into the late game.</OUTPUT>

input:
Provide the 'synergy_breakdown' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Lilligant": {"Abilities": {"chlorophyll": 1.642817447910371, "owntempo": 0.4718275425445349, "leafguard": 7.807088309164101e-13}, "Items": {"focussash": 0.29599278190851186, "covertcloak": 0.2675652213869297, "leftovers": 0.28235640309958315}, "Spreads": {"Timid:252/0/0/4/0/252": 0.2639033457367054, "Timid:140/0/116/0/0/252": 0.19046394699208544}, "Moves": ["afteryou", "pollenpuff", "protect", "sleeppowder"], "Tera Types": {"grass": 0.19662645590032457, "fire": 0.26449496506628806, "water": 0.35520721554842843, "ghost": 0.15056253987843174}, "Teammates": ["Torkoal", "Indeedee-F", "Volcarona", "Incineroar", "Hatterene", "Corviknight"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Torkoal is the non-negotiable partner: sun enables Chlorophyll and Eruption benefits from After You, while Torkoal’s bulk covers Lilligant’s physical frailty. Indeedee-F adds Psychic Terrain to block priority and provides Follow Me to draw attacks away from Lilligant, letting it fire off Sleep Powder or Pollen Puff safely; the two together form a redirect-plus-status core that controls most opening boards. Volcarona appreciates the speed boost from After You to fire +1 Heat Waves before opposing Tailwind or to KO Gholdengo, and in return its Flame Body punishes contact attackers that target Lilligant. Incineroar offers Intimidate, Fake Out, and Parting Shot to pivot Lilligant in safely, while Lilligant’s Water Tera removes Incineroar’s Fire weakness, allowing both to stand up to opposing sun mirrors. Hatterene blocks opposing status and can absorb Trick Room attempts, while Lilligant outspeeds and sleeps the setter; the two cover each other’s bad match-ups versus Dark and Steel types respectively. Corviknight provides Tailwind for non-sun match-ups and Defiant pressure against Intimidate cycles, while Lilligant’s Pollen Puff heals off Brave Bird recoil. The six form a balanced sun core with multiple win conditions: fast Eruption spam, Volcarona Quiver Dance, and Corviknight end-game sweeping.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Lilligant": {"Abilities": {"chlorophyll": 1.642817447910371, "owntempo": 0.4718275425445349, "leafguard": 7.807088309164101e-13}, "Items": {"focussash": 0.29599278190851186, "covertcloak": 0.2675652213869297, "leftovers": 0.28235640309958315}, "Spreads": {"Timid:252/0/0/4/0/252": 0.2639033457367054, "Timid:140/0/116/0/0/252": 0.19046394699208544}, "Moves": ["afteryou", "pollenpuff", "protect", "sleeppowder"], "Tera Types": {"grass": 0.19662645590032457, "fire": 0.26449496506628806, "water": 0.35520721554842843, "ghost": 0.15056253987843174}, "Teammates": ["Torkoal", "Indeedee-F", "Volcarona", "Incineroar", "Hatterene", "Corviknight"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Standard Sun Support: Timid nature, 252 HP / 4 SpA / 252 Spe, Chlorophyll, Focus Sash, Tera Water — Moves: After You, Sleep Powder, Pollen Puff, Protect. This set guarantees maximum speed outside Trick Room and gives a one-time survive-anything safety net. Bulky Pivot: Timid nature, 140 HP / 0 Def / 116 SpD / 252 Spe, Chlorophyll, Covert Cloak, Tera Fire — Moves: After You, Sleep Powder, Pollen Puff, Protect. The EVs survive Modest Torkoal Overheat in sun and Jolly Chien-Pao Ice Spinner; Covert Cloak ignores Fake Out and Spore, while Fire Tera flips the matchup versus Corviknight and Amoonguss. Leftovers Staller: Timid nature, 252 HP / 116 Def / 140 Spe, Chlorophyll, Leftovers, Tera Grass — Moves: After You, Sleep Powder, Pollen Puff, Protect. Designed for longer games: outspeeds neutral-nature base 100s in sun, heals 6% every turn, and threatens a +1 STAB Leaf Storm after Tera. Choice of set depends on whether the team needs a fast one-time playmaker (Sash), a safe pivot into status and spread moves (Cloak), or a durable support piece for end-game scenarios (Leftovers).</OUTPUT>

input:
Generate the 'weaknesses_and_counters' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Lilligant": {"Abilities": {"chlorophyll": 1.642817447910371, "owntempo": 0.4718275425445349, "leafguard": 7.807088309164101e-13}, "Items": {"focussash": 0.29599278190851186, "covertcloak": 0.2675652213869297, "leftovers": 0.28235640309958315}, "Spreads": {"Timid:252/0/0/4/0/252": 0.2639033457367054, "Timid:140/0/116/0/0/252": 0.19046394699208544}, "Moves": ["afteryou", "pollenpuff", "protect", "sleeppowder"], "Tera Types": {"grass": 0.19662645590032457, "fire": 0.26449496506628806, "water": 0.35520721554842843, "ghost": 0.15056253987843174}, "Teammates": ["Torkoal", "Indeedee-F", "Volcarona", "Incineroar", "Hatterene", "Corviknight"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Priority and weather removal are the most reliable ways to shut Lilligant down. Kingambit’s Sucker Punch bypasses speed and KOs through Sash if Lilligant has already used Sleep Powder; similarly, Dragonite’s Extreme Speed or Palafin’s Jet Punch ends it unless Tera Ghost is revealed. Opposing sun or rain teams that carry their own weather setter can flip the speed tier: a opposing Chlorophyll Venusaur or Swift Swim Barraskeweda will outspeed and OHKO with Sludge Bomb or Liquidation before Lilligant can respond. Trick Room turns its greatest asset into a liability; once room is up, Lilligat becomes the slowest Pokémon on the field and is easily picked off by Rhyperior or Hatterene. Clear Smog users—Amoonguss, Toxapex—remove any chance of Lilligant snowballing with Leaf Storm boosts and can retaliate with status or direct damage. Taunt from Murkrow or Grimmsnarl prevents both After You and Sleep Powder, forcing Lilligant to either Tera and attack or switch out. Finally, Grass-types such as Amoonguss, Wo-Chien, or fellow Lilligant are immune to Sleep Powder, reducing it to a passive Pollen Puff bot. To counter these threats, teams must either preserve sun control, pack their own priority to KO opposing speedsters, or bring a second mode (Tailwind or Trick Room) that functions when sun is lost.</OUTPUT>

input:
Write the 'sample_team_concept' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Lilligant": {"Abilities": {"chlorophyll": 1.642817447910371, "owntempo": 0.4718275425445349, "leafguard": 7.807088309164101e-13}, "Items": {"focussash": 0.29599278190851186, "covertcloak": 0.2675652213869297, "leftovers": 0.28235640309958315}, "Spreads": {"Timid:252/0/0/4/0/252": 0.2639033457367054, "Timid:140/0/116/0/0/252": 0.19046394699208544}, "Moves": ["afteryou", "pollenpuff", "protect", "sleeppowder"], "Tera Types": {"grass": 0.19662645590032457, "fire": 0.26449496506628806, "water": 0.35520721554842843, "ghost": 0.15056253987843174}, "Teammates": ["Torkoal", "Indeedee-F", "Volcarona", "Incineroar", "Hatterene", "Corviknight"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Torkoal @ Charcoal | Eruption / Heat Wave / Protect / Yawn | Quiet 252/0/0/252/4/0 | Drought — The sun setter and primary damage dealer; Yawn punishes Protect stalling and pairs with Lilligant sleep for dual-status pressure. Lilligant @ Focus Sash | After You / Sleep Powder / Pollen Puff / Protect | Timid 252/0/0/4/0/252 | Chlorophyll — The engine: outspeeds everything, lets Torkoal move first, and keeps the team healthy. Volcarona @ Life Orb | Heat Wave / Giga Drain / Quiver Dance / Protect | Modest 0/0/0/252/4/252 | Flame Body — Secondary win condition; After You allows instant +1 Heat Wave, while Giga Drain covers Water types and heals off Life Orb. Incineroar @ Assault Vest | Flare Blitz / Knock Off / Parting Shot / Fake Out | Careful 252/0/252/0/4/0 | Intimidate — Pivot that brings Lilligant in safely, weakens physical attackers, and breaks Focus Sashes for the sun sweepers. Indeedee-F @ Sitrus Berry | Psychic / Dazzling Gleam / Follow Me / Protect | Bold 252/0/252/0/4/0 | Psychic Surge — Redirector that blocks priority and draws attacks away from Lilligant, ensuring Sleep Powder goes off. Corviknight @ Leftovers | Brave Bird / Iron Head / Tailwind / Protect | Impish 252/252/0/0/4/0 | Mirror Armor — End-game cleaner and secondary speed control if sun is lost; Iron Defense variants can sweep after opponents are slept or weakened. The team operates on a simple flow: lead Torkoal + Lilligant in most match-ups, click After You plus Eruption for immediate pressure, bring Incineroar or Indeedee-F mid-game to maintain momentum, and close with Volcarona or Corviknight once opposing speed control and Grass resists are eliminated.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Illumise": {"Abilities": {"prankster": 2.024267884309248, "oblivious": 1.1372646768759154e-08}, "Items": {"covertcloak": 0.4520511501276607, "focussash": 0.24150862510303184, "safetygoggles": 0.16944338018772578}, "Spreads": {"Calm:244/0/148/0/116/0": 0.26288434688506573}, "Moves": ["tailwind", "faketears", "encore", "sunnyday"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.19377354634651428, "water": 0.26625593700558275, "dark": 0.42522598380075516}, "Teammates": ["Incineroar", "Gholdengo", "Ursaluna-Bloodmoon", "Sinistcha", "Ninetales-Alola", "Malamar"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Illumise is a niche support pick in VGC that leverages Prankster to fire off priority Tailwind, Fake Tears, Encore, and Sunny Day, enabling faster, harder-hitting teammates while hampering opponents. Its bulk is paper-thin, so it relies on Focus Sash, Covert Cloak, or Safety Goggles to survive a single hit or ignore Fake Out, Rage Powder, or residual hail. EV spreads trend Calm to bolster special bulk, and Tera Ghost is the most common to block Extreme Speed and Fake Out. It fits best on offensive cores that appreciate speed control and immediate damage amplification such as Ursaluna-Bloodmoon, Gholdengo, and Alolan Ninetales.</OUTPUT>

input:
Draft the 'full_analysis' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Illumise": {"Abilities": {"prankster": 2.024267884309248, "oblivious": 1.1372646768759154e-08}, "Items": {"covertcloak": 0.4520511501276607, "focussash": 0.24150862510303184, "safetygoggles": 0.16944338018772578}, "Spreads": {"Calm:244/0/148/0/116/0": 0.26288434688506573}, "Moves": ["tailwind", "faketears", "encore", "sunnyday"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.19377354634651428, "water": 0.26625593700558275, "dark": 0.42522598380075516}, "Teammates": ["Incineroar", "Gholdengo", "Ursaluna-Bloodmoon", "Sinistcha", "Ninetales-Alola", "Malamar"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Prankster is the only reason to consider Illumise: guaranteed priority Tailwind is rare outside of Murkrow and Tornadus, and Illumise offers a unique typing that resists Ground and Fighting while being neutral to Rock, letting it switch into common spread moves more comfortably than other support Pokémon. Fake Tears is a devastating tool when paired with special attackers like Gholdengo or Sinistcha, turning 2HKOs into OHKOs against bulky titans such as Dondozo and Ting-Lu. Encore locks setup sweepers or Protect spammers into a single move, creating free turns for partners, while Sunny Day can dismantle rain teams and boost allied Fire-type attacks. The chosen items each solve a different problem: Focus Sash guarantees at least one turn of utility, Covert Cloak ignores the ever-present Fake Out and Serene Grace flinches, and Safety Goggles blocks Spore, Rage Powder, and hail chip. Tera Ghost is the most popular because it grants immunity to Fake Out and Extreme Speed, the two most common ways to pick off a frail support, while Tera Dark beats opposing Prankster users and Tera Water offers a handy Fire resist for sun mirrors. Calm nature with 244 HP / 148 Def / 116 SpD is the most documented spread, letting Illumise survive modest versions of Landorus Earth Power and Chien-Pao Ice Spinner while keeping special bulk high enough to live Gholdengo Make It Rain. Offensive stats are ignored completely; its job is to enable teammates, not deal damage.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Illumise": {"Abilities": {"prankster": 2.024267884309248, "oblivious": 1.1372646768759154e-08}, "Items": {"covertcloak": 0.4520511501276607, "focussash": 0.24150862510303184, "safetygoggles": 0.16944338018772578}, "Spreads": {"Calm:244/0/148/0/116/0": 0.26288434688506573}, "Moves": ["tailwind", "faketears", "encore", "sunnyday"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.19377354634651428, "water": 0.26625593700558275, "dark": 0.42522598380075516}, "Teammates": ["Incineroar", "Gholdengo", "Ursaluna-Bloodmoon", "Sinistcha", "Ninetales-Alola", "Malamar"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Against hyper-offense, Illumise is a double-edged sword: it can instantly swing the speed war with Tailwind, but any faster Taunt user such as Murkrow or Flutter Mane shuts it down completely. Priority Encore can punish setup sweepers like Dragon Dance Dragonite or Swords Dance Chien-Pao, forcing them to repeat a non-damaging move and buy a free pivot. Into bulkier balance teams, Fake Tears cracks open slow walls, letting special attackers overwhelm Toxapex and Dondozo before they can recover. Rain teams hate Sunny Day because it halves the power of their Water moves and boosts allied Fire attacks, but Pelipper can simply reset weather the next turn, so Illumise must click Sunny Day only when it secures a KO. Trick Room matchups are poor; Illumise cannot stop the room from going up unless it lands an Encore on the setter, and Prankster moves fail against Dark-types like Kingambit and opposing Murkrow. Finally, opposing Covert Cloak or Good as Gold Gholdengo ignore Encore and Fake Tears, so Illumise has to pivot out in those scenarios.</OUTPUT>

It functions best as the fastest priority user on the field, so teams generally pair it with mid-speed powerhouses that jump key benchmarks after Tailwind: Ursaluna-Bloodmoon hits 134 Speed, outspeeding max-speed Chien-Pao and Gholdengo; Alolan Ninetales sits at 140, outspeeding Dragapult and tying Flutter Mane; Gholdengo reaches 148, beating Iron Valiant and opposing Rotom. Because Illumise rarely survives beyond two turns, it is played aggressively: click Tailwind immediately unless the opponent has a clear Taunt user, then Fake Tears the most threatening special wall or Encore a predicted Protect. output: <OUTPUT>Taunt is the most reliable answer: Murkrow, Flutter Mane, and Iron Valiant all outspeed and silence Illumise before it can fire off any Prankster move. Dark-types such as Kingambit, Chien-Pao, and opposing Murkrow are immune to Prankster, so they can ignore Encore and Fake Tears and KO with their STAB. output: <OUTPUT>Base 165 Attack is the second-highest in the format, and the Sheer Force + Life Orb interaction removes LO recoil on every listed move, effectively gifting Rampardos a free 1.3× boost with no drawback.  Rock Slide becomes a 120 BP spread move that cleanly KOs standard Gholdengo and 2HKOs bulky Arcanine through Intimidate, while the elemental punches let it pick off Amoonguss (Fire Punch) and Corviknight (Thunder Punch) without locking into a Choice move.  Mold Breaker variants are rare but guarantee the OHKO on Mimikyu and ignore Well-Bodied Dondozo, giving the fossil a small but real tech niche.  The EV spreads show two philosophies: Brave 252/252 with 4 SpD underspeeds most Trick Room setters and lets it operate inside or outside TR, whereas the Jolly 252 set attempts to outspeed positive-nature base 70s (Baxcalibur, Volcanion) at the cost of missing key KOs such as 252 HP Gholdengo.  Tera usage is split: Rock reinforces STAB and secures the OHKO on neutral targets, Ghost removes Fighting weakness and enables immunity to Fake Out/ExtremeSpeed, while Fire turns Fire Punch into a 140 BP Sheer Force nuke that erases bulky Amoonguss and Steel-types in sun.  The teammates listed—Incineroar, Indeedee-F, Torkoal, Armarouge, Gallade, Maushold—point toward a hybrid sun/Trick Room shell where Rampardos can function under either speed mode and appreciate redirection, speed control and wide-target support.</OUTPUT>

It is never a win-condition; instead it punches holes so cleaners such as Choice Specs Torkoal or Gallade can sweep later. <DATA>{"Dragalge": {"Abilities": {"adaptability": 1.9515403943903205, "poisonpoint": 0.0009236156610846757, "poisontouch": 9.686140778342178e-13}, "Items": {"lifeorb": 0.5791564269822519, "assaultvest": 0.20572247061772367}, "Spreads": {"Quiet:252/0/4/252/0/0": 0.5514242162831147}, "Moves": ["dracometeor", "protect", "sludgewave", "terablast"], "Tera Types": {"dark": 0.19536527047294575, "ground": 0.5536710612808443}, "Teammates": ["Metagross", "Scrafty", "Torkoal", "Garchomp", "Gyarados", "Slowbro"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Dragalge enjoys stellar matchups into Grass- and Fairy-centric cores such as Amoonguss + Tapu Fini and Venusaur + Sylveon, as Adaptability Sludge Wave OHKOes or 2HKOes all variants after minor chip. It also pressures Rotom-Wash and Slowbro lacking Psychic coverage, while Tera Ground variants flip the script on Toxapex and Gholdengo. Conversely, Dragalge struggles vs. faster Dragons like Dragapult and Chien-Cac, as well as vs. Steel-types that can stomach Draco Meteor—Corviknight and Skarmory wall non-Tera Blast sets, and Kingambit can tank a hit and KO back with Iron Head. Psychic Terrain teams also give it headaches, blocking priority like Sucker Punch from allies and letting faster threats like Indeedee-F and Hatterene outspeed and KO. Finally, spread attackers such as Landorus-T and Garchomp can wear it down through Protect, especially if it forgoes Assault Vest.</OUTPUT>

input:
Provide the 'role_description' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Dragalge": {"Abilities": {"adaptability": 1.9515403943903205, "poisonpoint": 0.0009236156610846757, "poisontouch": 9.686140778342178e-13}, "Items": {"lifeorb": 0.5791564269822519, "assaultvest": 0.20572247061772367}, "Spreads": {"Quiet:252/0/4/252/0/0": 0.5514242162831147}, "Moves": ["dracometeor", "protect", "sludgewave", "terablast"], "Tera Types": {"dark": 0.19536527047294575, "ground": 0.5536710612808443}, "Teammates": ["Metagross", "Scrafty", "Torkoal", "Garchomp", "Gyarados", "Slowbro"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Dragalge is a specialized special wallbreaker that compresses anti-Fairy, anti-Grass, and anti-Water roles into one slot. Its middling Speed tier is a deliberate trade-off: under Tailwind it outspeeds key threats, while in Trick Room it becomes one of the fastest attackers available. The combination of Adaptability, high-powered STABs, and Tera flexibility lets it delete bulky pivots that otherwise shrug off neutral hits. Protect plus respectable bulk (especially with Assault Vest) allows it to serve as a pivot itself, absorbing predicted attacks while partners reposition or set up. In short, Dragalge is neither a dedicated sweeper nor a support Pokémon; it is a calculated breaker that removes specific defensive pillars and enables teammates to run roughshod afterwards.</OUTPUT>

Draft the 'synergy_breakdown' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Dragalge": {"Abilities": {"adaptability": 1.9515403943903205, "poisonpoint": 0.0009236156610846757, "poisontouch": 9.686140778342178e-13}, "Items": {"lifeorb": 0.5791564269822519, "assaultvest": 0.20572247061772367}, "Spreads": {"Quiet:252/0/4/252/0/0": 0.5514242162831147}, "Moves": ["dracometeor", "protect", "sludgewave", "terablast"], "Tera Types": {"dark": 0.19536527047294575, "ground": 0.5536710612808443}, "Teammates": ["Metagross", "Scrafty", "Torkoal", "Garchomp", "Gyarados", "Slowbro"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Metagross pairs perfectly with Dragalge: the sea dragon lures Steel-types and weakens Landorus for Metagross to sweep, while Metagross baits Fire- and Ground-type moves that Dragalge can switch in on. Scrafty provides Intimidate and Fake Out support, covering Dragalge’s physical weakness and granting free turns to fire off Draco Meteor. Torkoal sets sun for potential Chlorophyll partners (though not listed, it also enables Eruption synergy) and pressures opposing Steel-types with STAB Fire moves. Garchomp shares Earthquake immunity and forms a Dragon-spam core, forcing opponents to guess which draco to respect. Gyarados offers Intimidate plus Water-type redundancy, and can pivot with Flip Turn to bring Dragalge in safely. Slowbro rounds out the FWG core, provides Future Sight to break shared checks, and can set Trick Room to maximize Dragalge’s Speed tier. Together these teammates create a bulky offensive web that masks Dragalge’s average speed and amplifies its wallbreaking potential.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Dragalge": {"Abilities": {"adaptability": 1.9515403943903205, "poisonpoint": 0.0009236156610846757, "poisontouch": 9.686140778342178e-13}, "Items": {"lifeorb": 0.5791564269822519, "assaultvest": 0.20572247061772367}, "Spreads": {"Quiet:252/0/4/252/0/0": 0.5514242162831147}, "Moves": ["dracometeor", "protect", "sludgewave", "terablast"], "Tera Types": {"dark": 0.19536527047294575, "ground": 0.5536710612808443}, "Teammates": ["Metagross", "Scrafty", "Torkoal", "Garchomp", "Gyarados", "Slowbro"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Quiet 252/0/4/252/0/0 with Adaptability is the only statistically significant spread. Item choice defines the set: Life Orb maximizes damage, turning Sludge Wave into a guaranteed OHKO on 252 HP Tapu Fini after one round of LO chip, while Assault Vest lets it survive Modest Kingambit Sacred Sword and retaliate with Tera Ground Tera Blast. Moves are locked as Draco Meteor, Sludge Wave, Protect, Tera Blast. Tera Dark is preferred on teams weak to Ghost/Dark and needing a Sucker Punch immunity; Tera Ground is optimal if Toxapex or Gholdengo are problematic. No other EV spreads showed meaningful usage, so stick to the Quiet 252/252 to preserve its breaking power.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Dragalge": {"Abilities": {"adaptability": 1.9515403943903205, "poisonpoint": 0.0009236156610846757, "poisontouch": 9.686140778342178e-13}, "Items": {"lifeorb": 0.5791564269822519, "assaultvest": 0.20572247061772367}, "Spreads": {"Quiet:252/0/4/252/0/0": 0.5514242162831147}, "Moves": ["dracometeor", "protect", "sludgewave", "terablast"], "Tera Types": {"dark": 0.19536527047294575, "ground": 0.5536710612808443}, "Teammates": ["Metagross", "Scrafty", "Torkoal", "Garchomp", "Gyarados", "Slowbro"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Dragalge’s biggest enemy is its own Speed tier: base 44 leaves it outsped by the entire metagame under Tailwind and only barely faster than Trick Room attackers. Powerful neutral hits from Choice Specs Dragapult or Chien-Cac Aura Sphere end it before it moves. Steel-types with recovery—Corviknight, Skarmory, and Gholdengo—can roost off Draco Meteor and wear it down with Brave Bird or Make It Rain. Priority in the form of Sucker Punch from Kingambit or Shadow Sneak from Aegislash can finish off weakened Dragalge, though Tera Dark variants flip the latter. Finally, heavy spread damage from Landorus-T Earthquake or Heatran Lava Plume plus ally chip quickly puts Life Orb variants in KO range. To counter it, bring fast offensive pressure, recovery Steel-types, or spread attackers that can hit around Protect.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>A balanced semi-room squad showcases Dragalge’s strengths: Dragalge @ Life Orb, Quiet 252/0/4/252/0/0, Adaptability, Tera Ground—Draco Meteor, Sludge Wave, Protect, Tera Blast. Metagross @ Clear Amulet, Jolly 252/252/4—Iron Head, Stomping Tantrum, Bullet Punch, Protect. Scrafty @ Eject Button, Careful 252/4/252/0/0/0—Fake Out, Knock Off, Close Combat, Detect.
