<DATA>{"Trevenant": {"Abilities": {"harvest": 1.623148996348649, "frisk": 0.05556184653426499, "naturalcure": 0.337360899311687}, "Items": {"sitrusberry": 0.9698044565928704}, "Spreads": {"Adamant:244/252/0/0/12/0": 0.15817842248407252, "Sassy:244/12/0/0/252/0": 0.22213135191300556, "Adamant:252/252/4/0/0/0": 0.17706443759963733, "Brave:244/196/0/0/68/0": 0.2296035681030877}, "Moves": ["hornleech", "poltergeist", "trickroom", "woodhammer"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.29190724533897544, "fire": 0.4206983407683512, "poison": 0.1580205941057688}, "Teammates": ["Ninetales-Alola", "Torkoal", "Lilligant-Hisui", "Ursaluna-Bloodmoon", "Incineroar", "Indeedee-F"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Trevenant is a niche Trick Room setter that leverages Harvest + Sitrus Berry for repeated recovery, enabling it to survive long enough to set Trick Room and fire off strong Grass- and Ghost-type attacks. Its unique typing gives it key resistances to Water-, Electric-, and Ground-type moves, but it remains fragile to common Fire-, Ice-, and Dark-type offense. While outclassed by bulkier setters like Hatterene or Indeedee-F, Trevenant’s ability to pressure bulky Waters and Ghost-immune targets with Poltergeist and Horn Leech gives it a small but real role on sun-based Trick Room squads that appreciate immediate woodhammer power and Harvest consistency.</OUTPUT>

input:
Write a detailed 'full_analysis' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Trevenant": {"Abilities": {"harvest": 1.623148996348649, "frisk": 0.05556184653426499, "naturalcure": 0.337360899311687}, "Items": {"sitrusberry": 0.9698044565928704}, "Spreads": {"Adamant:244/252/0/0/12/0": 0.15817842248407252, "Sassy:244/12/0/0/252/0": 0.22213135191300556, "Adamant:252/252/4/0/0/0": 0.17706443759963733, "Brave:244/196/0/0/68/0": 0.2296035681030877}, "Moves": ["hornleech", "poltergeist", "trickroom", "woodhammer"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.29190724533897544, "fire": 0.4206983407683512, "poison": 0.1580205941057688}, "Teammates": ["Ninetales-Alola", "Torkoal", "Lilligant-Hisui", "Ursaluna-Bloodmoon", "Incineroar", "Indeedee-F"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>With Harvest guaranteeing a Sitrus Berry recycle under sun, Trevenant becomes one of the few setters that can repeatedly recover to 50 % while still posing an offensive threat. 120 / 110 base Attack backed by STAB Horn Leech and Poltergeist gives it the strongest unboosted Grass/Ghost coverage in the format, 2HKOing neutral targets such as Kyogre, Groudon, and bulky Rotom forms. Trick Room is mandatory to support slower partners like Ursaluna-Bloodmoon and Torkoal, while Wood Hammer provides a recoil-heavy nuke that secures OHKOs on Rillaboom and Gastrodon after minor chip. Tera Ghost removes its Fighting weakness and turns Poltergeist into a 120 BP STAB nuke that can surprise KO Tera Normal Dragonite and Tera Flying Lando-T, whereas Tera Fire patches up the 4× Fire weakness and flips the Sun matchup by letting Trevenant survive Heat Wave from Torkoal and Charizard. Tera Poison is a rarer option that dodges Toxic and turns Rage Powder into a safe pivot versus Amoonguss. EV spreads focus on maximizing physical bulk (244 HP / 196+ Def) to survive Behemoth Blade from Adamant Zacian-C after Sitrus, while still keeping enough Attack to secure key rolls; alternate Adamant 252/252 sets trade bulk for immediate power, and Sassy 252 SpD sets let it survive Life Orb Moonblast from Calyrex-S after Sitrus. Frisk is occasionally run to scout items, but Harvest’s recursion is the primary draw, making sun support from Ninetales-A or Torkoal near-mandatory for consistency.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Trevenant": {"Abilities": {"harvest": 1.623148996348649, "frisk": 0.05556184653426499, "naturalcure": 0.337360899311687}, "Items": {"sitrusberry": 0.9698044565928704}, "Spreads": {"Adamant:244/252/0/0/12/0": 0.15817842248407252, "Sassy:244/12/0/0/252/0": 0.22213135191300556, "Adamant:252/252/4/0/0/0": 0.17706443759963733, "Brave:244/196/0/0/68/0": 0.2296035681030877}, "Moves": ["hornleech", "poltergeist", "trickroom", "woodhammer"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.29190724533897544, "fire": 0.4206983407683512, "poison": 0.1580205941057688}, "Teammates": ["Ninetales-Alola", "Torkoal", "Lilligant-Hisui", "Ursaluna-Bloodmoon", "Incineroar", "Indeedee-F"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Trevenant loves facing bulky Water teams that rely on Kyogre, Tapu Fini, or Slowbro, as Horn Leech cleanly 2HKOs all variants while recovering huge chunks of health. It also pressures Psychic-spam cores lacking Dark coverage, since Poltergeist OHKOs Indeedee-F and 2HKOs most Neutralizing-Gas Glimmora. Under sun, Harvest outpaces opposing residual damage, letting Trevenant win long wars of attrition versus Seismic-chansey or Toxic-stall P2. Conversely, it folds to any strong Fire-, Ice-, or Dark-type attacker: Choice Band Chien-Pao’s Ice Spinner OHKOs even through Sitrus, Tera Fire Chi-Yu’s Overheat does the same, and Kingambit’s Sucker Punch cleanly picks off weakened sets. Faster Taunt users such as Murkrow or Whimsicott can shut down Trick Room, and Mold Breaker users like Haxorus ignore Harvest, forcing a straight damage race that Trevenant usually loses. Finally, spread moves like Dazzling Gleam or Rock Slide that hit both slots can break Sitrus loops if both foes target Trevenant, so positioning is critical.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Trevenant": {"Abilities": {"harvest": 1.623148996348649, "frisk": 0.05556184653426499, "naturalcure": 0.337360899311687}, "Items": {"sitrusberry": 0.9698044565928704}, "Spreads": {"Adamant:244/252/0/0/12/0": 0.15817842248407252, "Sassy:244/12/0/0/252/0": 0.22213135191300556, "Adamant:252/252/4/0/0/0": 0.17706443759963733, "Brave:244/196/0/0/68/0": 0.2296035681030877}, "Moves": ["hornleech", "poltergeist", "trickroom", "woodhammer"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.29190724533897544, "fire": 0.4206983407683512, "poison": 0.1580205941057688}, "Teammates": ["Ninetales-Alola", "Torkoal", "Lilligant-Hisui", "Ursaluna-Bloodmoon", "Incineroar", "Indeedee-F"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Trevenant’s primary job is to survive the first two turns, click Trick Room, and remain healthy enough to fire off strong attacks or set a second Room later in the game. It functions as a semi-support, semi-offensive pivot: it is not as inherently bulky as Diancie or Stakataka, but Harvest gives it pseudo-status immunity and repeatable recovery that no other setter possesses. Once Room is up, it becomes a wallbreaking Grass-type that can self-heal with Horn Leech, allowing slower partners to sweep without sacrificing momentum. Because it carries only one support move, it demands teammates that can provide Fake Out, Follow Me, or Ally Switch to guarantee Room goes up versus faster disruption.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Trevenant": {"Abilities": {"harvest": 1.623148996348649, "frisk": 0.05556184653426499, "naturalcure": 0.337360899311687}, "Items": {"sitrusberry": 0.9698044565928704}, "Spreads": {"Adamant:244/252/0/0/12/0": 0.15817842248407252, "Sassy:244/12/0/0/252/0": 0.22213135191300556, "Adamant:252/252/4/0/0/0": 0.17706443759963733, "Brave:244/196/0/0/68/0": 0.2296035681030877}, "Moves": ["hornleech", "poltergeist", "trickroom", "woodhammer"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.29190724533897544, "fire": 0.4206983407683512, "poison": 0.1580205941057688}, "Teammates": ["Ninetales-Alola", "Torkoal", "Lilligant-Hisui", "Ursaluna-Bloodmoon", "Incineroar", "Indeedee-F"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Ninetales-Alola and Torkoal provide automatic sun, ensuring Harvest procs every turn; Ninetales also brings Aurora Veil to pad Trevenant’s average bulk, while Torkoal adds Eruption pressure to soften foes for woodhammer clean-up. Lilligant-Hisui forms a Grass-spam core, appreciates Room, and can After-You to let Trevenant move first under Trick Room to immediately threaten opposing setters. Ursaluna-Bloodmoon is the ideal slow breaker, loving Room and Ghost-type removal that Trevenant provides. Incineroar offers Fake Out, Intimidate, and Fire-type resistance, covering Trevenant’s biggest weakness while providing pivoting. Indeedee-F gives Follow Me and Psychic Terrain to block priority Sucker Punch, ensuring Room goes up versus Murkrow or Kingambit. Together these teammates create a sun-TR shell that can flip between fast mode (sun) and slow mode (Room) depending on the opponent’s composition.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Trevenant": {"Abilities": {"harvest": 1.623148996348649, "frisk": 0.05556184653426499, "naturalcure": 0.337360899311687}, "Items": {"sitrusberry": 0.9698044565928704}, "Spreads": {"Adamant:244/252/0/0/12/0": 0.15817842248407252, "Sassy:244/12/0/0/252/0": 0.22213135191300556, "Adamant:252/252/4/0/0/0": 0.17706443759963733, "Brave:244/196/0/0/68/0": 0.2296035681030877}, "Moves": ["hornleech", "poltergeist", "trickroom", "woodhammer"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.29190724533897544, "fire": 0.4206983407683512, "poison": 0.1580205941057688}, "Teammates": ["Ninetales-Alola", "Torkoal", "Lilligant-Hisui", "Ursaluna-Bloodmoon", "Incineroar", "Indeedee-F"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Fast Fire-types are the hardest stops: Chi-Yu, Charizard-Y, and Heatran all OHKO through Sitrus even after Tera Fire. Priority abusers such as Kingambit, Chien-Pao, and Bisharp can pick off weakened Trevenant before it recycles its berry. Taunt from Murkrow, Whimsicott, or Grimmsnarl prevents Room and forces a predictable attack. Mold Breaker users like Haxorus or Basculin ignore Harvest, turning the matchup into a straight damage race that Trevenant loses. Finally, Knock Off or Corrosive Gas from Amoonguss or Glimmora permanently removes the berry, neutering Harvest and leaving Trevenant frail for the rest of the game.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Trevenant": {"Abilities": {"harvest": 1.623148996348649, "frisk": 0.05556184653426499, "naturalcure": 0.337360899311687}, "Items": {"sitrusberry": 0.9698044565928704}, "Spreads": {"Adamant:244/252/0/0/12/0": 0.15817842248407252, "Sassy:244/12/0/0/252/0": 0.22213135191300556, "Adamant:252/252/4/0/0/0": 0.17706443759963733, "Brave:244/196/0/0/68/0": 0.2296035681030877}, "Moves": ["hornleech", "poltergeist", "trickroom", "woodhammer"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.29190724533897544, "fire": 0.4206983407683512, "poison": 0.1580205941057688}, "Teammates": ["Ninetales-Alola", "Torkoal", "Lilligant-Hisui", "Ursaluna-Bloodmoon", "Incineroar", "Indeedee-F"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Sun-Trick Room Hybrid: Ninetales-A (Veil + Snow Warning) / Torkoal (Eruption + Sun) / Trevenant (Room setter) / Ursaluna-Bloodmoon (Calm Mind breaker) / Incineroar (Fake Out pivot) / Indeedee-F (Follow Me). Lead Ninetales + Trevenant versus fast teams: Veil turn one, Room turn two, then swap to Torkoal + Ursaluna for Eruption + Moonburst devastation. Tera Fire on Trevenant and Tera Fairy on Ursaluna provide defensive answers to opposing Fire- and Dragon-type offense, while the sun-TR core can toggle between fast mode (Aurora Veil + Eruption) and slow mode (Room + Bloodmoon) to handle a wide range of archetypes.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Oricorio-Pom-Pom": {"Abilities": {"dancer": 1.8727418098134994}, "Items": {"focussash": 0.1844272010477888, "covertcloak": 0.1570374941034629, "sitrusberry": 0.2664808505841065, "lifeorb": 0.282230291339373}, "Spreads": {"Modest:252/0/0/132/0/124": 0.16516239876313812}, "Moves": ["airslash", "protect", "revelationdance", "icywind"], "Tera Types": {"fairy": 0.2571279740367594, "steel": 0.2685875226584121, "ice": 0.23375663838058391}, "Teammates": ["Volcarona", "Archaludon", "Quaquaval", "Golduck", "Murkrow", "Gholdengo"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Oricorio-Pom-Pom’s main draw is Dancer, an ability that copies any dance move used on the field, turning ally Swords Dances, Dragon Dances, or even opponent’s Quiver Dances into free boosts for itself. This creates explosive swing turns when paired with setup sweepers such as Volcarona or Quaquaval, letting Oricorio double-dip on momentum while still attacking. Revelation Dance becomes an Electric-type attack thanks to Pom-Pom’s form, giving it a reliable 90 BP STAB that never misses and bypasses abilities like Flash Fire or Volt Absorb. Air Slash supplies a secondary Flying STAB with a coveted 30 % flinch chance, letting it fish for extra utility against slower targets. Icy Wind offers both damage and speed control, allowing Oricorio to underspeed and then outpace threats after the drop, while Protect is mandatory in doubles to shield against double-targets and stall out opposing speed control or Dynamon turns. The EV spread maxes Special Attack, dumps 132 into offense, and outspeeds key benchmarks like neutral-nature base 100s at 124 EVs, while the remaining EVs bulk the HP for better Sitrus Berry or Focus Sash synergy. Tera Fairy is the most popular option, granting a Dragon immunity and a useful resistance to Dark and Fighting, though Tera Steel provides an omniresist slot against Rock and Ice, and Tera Ice amplifies Icy Wind damage while giving a strong offensive presence against Lando-T and Amoonguss. Items are split between Sitrus Berry for longevity, Life Orb for damage, Focus Sash for one-time survival, and Covert Cloak to shrug off spore or static, indicating a flexible role that can be tuned to the team’s needs.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Oricorio-Pom-Pom enjoys solid matchups against common Water and Flying archetypes like Tornadus, Pelipper, and offensive Rotom-Wash, outspeeding and KOing with Revelation Dance or Air Slash. It also pressures Corviknight and bulky Grass types such as Amoonguss and Breloom, especially when Terastallized into Fairy to avoid spore. Conversely, it struggles versus faster Rock or Ice attackers like Chien-Pao, Garchomp, and Tyranitar, which can OHKO through its modest defenses. Priority users such as Kingambit and Dragonite with Extreme Speed can pick off a chipped Oricorio before it moves, and spread attackers like Iron Moth or Heatran can break its Sash or bypass its bulk. Opposing weather teams that boost speed—like Swift Swim Kingdra or Slush Rush Sandslash—can also outpace even after an Icy Wind. Finally, because it relies on partner synergy for maximum impact, teams that can disrupt setup or redirect—via Follow Me, Fake Out, or Taunt—can blunt its momentum significantly.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Volcarona is the most natural partner: Quiver Dance on one turn gives Oricorio +1 SpA, SpD, and Spe, after which both Pokémon become immediate offensive monsters. Volcarona’s Flame Body punishes contact moves, while Oricorio’s Flying typing absorbs Ground attacks aimed at the moth. Archaludon supplies Stealth Rock chip and a slow Volt Switch to bring Oricorio in safely; its Steel/Dragon typing also covers Oricorio’s Ice and Rock weaknesses. Quaquaval appreciates Icy Wind speed control, can click Swords Dance to hand Oricorio a +2 Attack boost via Dancer, and its Water typing checks Fire and Rock threats. Goldengo provides a spinblocker role, sponges special hits, and spreads status that lets Oricorio clean late. Murkrow offers Tailwind and Taunt, accelerating Oricorio without requiring a dance move, while Golduck (likely on a rain concept) can set up with Calm Mind or simply fire Hydro Pumps under rain, again copying boosts via Dancer. The shared weakness to Rock is partially mitigated by Terastallization and the prevalence of Protect, but stacking Flying and Fire types does demand careful play versus Stone Edge or Rock Slide users.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Sceptile": {"Abilities": {"unburden": 1.7587471954633598, "overgrow": 0.03395813845851259}, "Items": {"focussash": 0.7816631297301332}, "Spreads": {"Hasty:0/4/0/252/0/252": 0.24956193824187597, "Timid:0/0/0/252/0/252": 0.48543049226915025}, "Moves": ["endeavor", "upperhand", "grasspledge", "helpinghand"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.7144489467451456}, "Teammates": ["Dragonite", "Archaludon", "Pelipper", "Primarina", "Basculegion", "Farigiraf"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Unburden Focus Sash Sceptile sits at a commanding 738 Speed after the item is consumed, outspeeding every unboosted threat and most Choice Scarf users. This lets it fire off Endeavor first, reliably dropping any full-HP target to 1 HP and turning bulky staples like Gholdengo, Iron Hands, or opposing support into easy pickings for partners. Upper Hand provides a 60 BP Fighting-type priority move that also removes the target’s move if it has already acted, giving Sceptile a rare form of momentum control that punishes speed-tiers just below it. Grass Pledge offers a 60 BP STAB that becomes 120 BP under rain or when combined with a Fire Pledge ally, and its side-effect of creating a damaging sea-of-fire tile can chip grounded foes for 1/8 HP per turn—useful against Trick Room or Tailwind teams that clump together. Helping Hand rounds out the set, letting Sceptile boost a partner’s damage by 50% on any given turn, which is especially potent with rain-boosted Surging Strikes from Basculegion or Archaludon’s Electro Shot. The overwhelmingly preferred Tera Ghost removes Sceptile’s Fighting weakness, grants a crucial Normal immunity (stopping Fake Out and Extreme Speed), and blocks Rapid Spin, while the 1.2× offensive boost turns its otherwise modest Sp.Atk into respectable damage. EV spreads favor max Speed and max Special Attack with either Timid or Hasty nature; the Hasty variant preserves Endeavor’s physical damage component while still outspeeding everything relevant after Unburden. Overgrow variants exist but are rare, offering a one-time nuke on Grass Pledge at 33% HP or less, yet they forfeit the speed tier that makes Sceptile so threatening.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Sceptile": {"Abilities": {"unburden": 1.7587471954633598, "overgrow": 0.03395813845851259}, "Items": {"focussash": 0.7816631297301332}, "Spreads": {"Hasty:0/4/0/252/0/252": 0.24956193824187597, "Timid:0/0/0/252/0/252": 0.48543049226915025}, "Moves": ["endeavor", "upperhand", "grasspledge", "helpinghand"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.7144489467451456}, "Teammates": ["Dragonite", "Archaludon", "Pelipper", "Primarina", "Basculegion", "Farigiraf"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Sceptile dominates slower, bulky teams that rely on single big threats—think Iron Hands, Garganacl, or Torkoal—because Endeavor instantly equalizes HP totals and partners clean up the 1 HP remainder. It pressures Trick Room setters that lack Mental Herb, as Upper Hand can flinch and strip their move, while its own speed keeps it ahead of most Trick Room attackers. Against hyper-offense, Sceptile’s sash guarantees one meaningful action, but it must choose between Endeavor (which does nothing to Focus Sash foes) or Helping Hand to boost a partner. Rain teams are a mixed bag: Pelipper’s rain doubles Hydro Pump damage but also empowers Sceptile’s Grass Pledge into 120 BP, letting it dent bulky Waters like Toxapex or Rotom-W. Sun teams are tougher, as Torkoal’s Eruption and Chandelure’s Heat Wave can break the sash before Sceptile acts, and Chlorophyll Venusaur outspeeds even Unburden Sceptile. Steel-types such as Corviknight and Gholdengo wall Grass Pledge, but they hate being reduced to 1 HP by Endeavor, so proper prediction is key. Priority users like Bisharp, Kingambit, or Dragonite’s Extreme Speed can finish Sceptile after sash is popped, so partners must deal with them first.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Toxicroak": {"Abilities": {"dryskin": 1.586561923810547, "poisontouch": 0.0004407110771110778, "anticipation": 0.1972547018716701}, "Items": {"clearamulet": 0.5434957867081898, "focussash": 0.16301110870983151, "safetygoggles": 0.17782097398443503}, "Spreads": {"Adamant:20/236/0/0/0/252": 0.2741601001992071, "Jolly:0/252/0/0/4/252": 0.2555994947349774, "Adamant:244/28/4/0/4/228": 0.1920543350629657}, "Moves": ["closecombat", "gunkshot", "protect", "fakeout"], "Tera Types": {"dark": 0.22895632181079373, "fire": 0.40687300451677233, "ghost": 0.1768132939562925}, "Teammates": ["Archaludon", "Pelipper", "Amoonguss", "Kingambit", "Rillaboom", "Cramorant"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Toxicroak’s standout traits are Dry Skin and Fake Out. In rain—often provided by Pelipper—it flips the Water matchup, recovering 25% while shrugging off Scalds and Jet Punches. This, combined with Fake Out, gives its partner a free turn to set up or reposition. Poison Touch adds a 30% poison chance on contact, punishing U-turns and Extreme Speed users. Clear Amulet is preferred on roughly 54% of teams, blanking Incineroar, Landorus-T, and Kingambit’s Intimidate cycles and letting Toxicroak maintain its Attack stage through Parting Shot or Electroweb. Tera Dark removes Psychic and Ghost weaknesses, eases prediction versus Indeedee and Hatterene, and boosts Knock Off or Sucker Punch damage; Tera Fire flips the matchup into Sun and Zacian, resisting Behemoth Blade and burning opposing Grass types. EV spreads are straightforward: Jolly or Adamant max Speed to outrun base 100s and opposing Croaks, with the remaining EVs poured into Attack; bulkier Adamant variants drop a handful of Speed to survive Rillaboom’s Grassy Glide or Kingambit’s Sucker Punch. Protect is mandatory for double-target baits and Dynamon mirrors, while Close Combat and Gunk Shot give perfect neutral coverage against the metagame’s most common cores. The combination of a pivoting movepool (Vacuum Wave, Helping Hand) and a high-damage output makes Toxicroak a flexible lead or mid-game cleaner that thrives under speed control or redirection.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Toxicroak": {"Abilities": {"dryskin": 1.586561923810547, "poisontouch": 0.0004407110771110778, "anticipation": 0.1972547018716701}, "Items": {"clearamulet": 0.5434957867081898, "focussash": 0.16301110870983151, "safetygoggles": 0.17782097398443503}, "Spreads": {"Adamant:20/236/0/0/0/252": 0.2741601001992071, "Jolly:0/252/0/0/4/252": 0.2555994947349774, "Adamant:244/28/4/0/4/228": 0.1920543350629657}, "Moves": ["closecombat", "gunkshot", "protect", "fakeout"], "Tera Types": {"dark": 0.22895632181079373, "fire": 0.40687300451677233, "ghost": 0.1768132939562925}, "Teammates": ["Archaludon", "Pelipper", "Amoonguss", "Kingambit", "Rillaboom", "Cramorant"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Toxicroak loves facing Water-spam and Fairy-centric teams. Dry Skin turns Rain’s strongest weapons—Hydro Pump, Jet Punch, and Surging Strikes—into healing, letting Croak switch in freely and retaliate with Gunk Shot for the OHKO on Azumarill, Tapu Fini, and Sylveon. Against Sun, Tera Fire variants wall Venusaur and Torkoal, OHKOing back with neutral Gunk Shot or super-effective Fire Punch. Psychic Terrain teams struggle if Croak Terastallizes into Dark, removing its Psychic weakness and allowing unimpeded Fake Outs. Conversely, Croak dislikes Landorus-T’s Earthquake, Dragapult’s Draco Meteor, and Iron Valiant’s Moonblast; all outspeed and KO before it can move unless Croak is already Terastallized or behind redirection. Ghost-types like Aegislash and Mimikyu can stomach a Knock Off and retaliate with super-effective STAB, while bulky Flying types such as Corviknight and Togekiss take little from unboosted attacks and wear Croak down with Brave Bird or Air Slash. Finally, priority from Rillaboom’s Grassy Glide or Kingambit’s Sucker Punch can finish off chipped Croak, so positioning and HP management are crucial.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Toxicroak": {"Abilities": {"dryskin": 1.586561923810547, "poisontouch": 0.0004407110771110778, "anticipation": 0.1972547018716701}, "Items": {"clearamulet": 0.5434957867081898, "focussash": 0.16301110870983151, "safetygoggles": 0.17782097398443503}, "Spreads": {"Adamant:20/236/0/0/0/252": 0.2741601001992071, "Jolly:0/252/0/0/4/252": 0.2555994947349774, "Adamant:244/28/4/0/4/228": 0.1920543350629657}, "Moves": ["closecombat", "gunkshot", "protect", "fakeout"], "Tera Types": {"dark": 0.22895632181079373, "fire": 0.40687300451677233, "ghost": 0.1768132939562925}, "Teammates": ["Archaludon", "Pelipper", "Amoonguss", "Kingambit", "Rillaboom", "Cramorant"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Toxicroak operates as a fast offensive support: it breaks early with Fake Out pressure, removes or weakens Fairies and bulky Waters, then pivots to a setup sweeper or second attacker. Clear Amulet variants are primary leads that deny Intimidate cycles, allowing partners like Archaludon or Kingambit to keep their Attack stages and snowball. Dry Skin gives it a secondary role as a rain check, switching into predicted Water moves to gain 25% recovery and force unfavorable trades. Its speed tier—outrunning base 100s—lets it act as a pseudo-scarfer under Tailwind or after an ally’s Electroweb drop. In the back, Croak can clean weakened teams with STAB moves or serve as a Dynamax option, gaining HP with Max Knuckle or Max Ooze while boosting Attack or poisoning multiple foes. The Poison Touch chance also means even resisted U-turns or Fake Outs can cripple walls like Porygon2 or Ting-Lu with poison, adding residual damage that complements teammates such as Kingambit or Rillaboom.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Pelipper is the most common partner, summoning rain to activate Dry Skin and powering up Croak’s neutral coverage. Amoonguss provides Rage Powder and Spore, redirecting deadly Moonblasts and Draco Meteors while Croak fires off attacks. Kingambit appreciates Fake Out and Intimorate immunity, grabbing Defiant boosts or setting up Swords Dance; in return, Kingambit’s Sucker Punch removes faster threats like Dragapult. Rillaboom forms a Grass-Fighting core, breaking opposing Waters and Grounds that trouble Croak while Grassy Terrain softens Earthquake damage. Archaludon offers a slow pivot with Sturdy and Steel typing, tanking Psychic and Flying moves for Croak and providing Stealth Rock chip. Cramorant—usually under rain—adds a second Water immunity and Tailwind speed control, letting Croak outspeed and KO opposing weather sweepers. Tera-wise, Croak prefers Dark or Fire to complement these partners: Dark removes Psychic weaknesses shared with Amoonguss, while Fire covers Sun matchups for Pelipper teams. EV spreads are shared to maximize Speed and power, ensuring Croak and its allies hit key KOs without overlapping weaknesses to Electric or Ground.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Toxicroak": {"Abilities": {"dryskin": 1.586561923810547, "poisontouch": 0.0004407110771110778, "anticipation": 0.1972547018716701}, "Items": {"clearamulet": 0.5434957867081898, "focussash": 0.16301110870983151, "safetygoggles": 0.17782097398443503}, "Spreads": {"Adamant:20/236/0/0/0/252": 0.2741601001992071, "Jolly:0/252/0/0/4/252": 0.2555994947349774, "Adamant:244/28/4/0/4/228": 0.1920543350629657}, "Moves": ["closecombat", "gunkshot", "protect", "fakeout"], "Tera Types": {"dark": 0.22895632181079373, "fire": 0.40687300451677233, "ghost": 0.1768132939562925}, "Teammates": ["Archaludon", "Pelipper", "Amoonguss", "Kingambit", "Rillaboom", "Cramorant"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Toxicroak’s mediocre 83/65/65 bulk leaves it vulnerable to any super-effective or strong neutral hit. Psychic-types like Indeedee, Hatterene, and Calyrex-I OHKO with Expanding Force or Psychic under terrain unless Croak Terastallizes into Dark. Flying-types—Togekiss, Corviknight, and Dragonite—resist both STABs and retaliate with Air Slash or Brave Bird; Togekiss’ 60% flinch chance can shut Croak down entirely. Ground-types such as Landorus-T and Garchomp outspeed non-Jolly variants and KO with Earthquake or Tera Ground-boosted moves. Priority users are another issue: Rillaboom’s Grassy Glide, Kingambit’s Sucker Punch, and Dragonite’s Extreme Speed all finish off chipped Croak, so keeping its HP above roughly 70% is mandatory. Status cripples it quickly: burn halves Attack, while paralysis drops its Speed and lets bulkier threats move first. Finally, Clear Amulet variants lose to Rocky Helmet or Static punishes, building up passive damage that priority can later exploit. To counter, bring bulky Flying or Psychic pivots, keep terrain control, and preserve priority until Croak is within KO range.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Cyclizar is a blazing-fast support Pokémon that abuses Shed Tail to safely pivot a teammate into battle while preserving momentum. Regenerator lets it repeatedly pivot in and out, restoring 33 % of its health every time it exits, while Covert Cloak blocks Fake Out and other secondary-effect harassment. With Taunt it can shut down Trick Room and other set-up, and Draco Meteor gives it a strong, immediate Dragon STAB that discourages Intimidate and keeps it from being complete Taunt bait. Tera Dragon turns Draco Meteor into a nuclear option and removes its Ice weakness, making it harder to revenge-kill.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Cyclizar": {"Abilities": {"regenerator": 1.6962613989447477, "shedskin": 0.006040535781872525}, "Items": {"covertcloak": 0.19589420710902986, "sitrusberry": 0.1502064975628636, "leftovers": 0.3498404469950261}, "Spreads": {"Timid:0/0/0/252/4/252": 0.5064206706444079}, "Moves": ["dracometeor", "shedtail", "taunt", "hypervoice"], "Tera Types": {"dragon": 0.6461949781088608}, "Teammates": ["Gholdengo", "Ninetales-Alola", "Indeedee-F", "Annihilape", "Dragonite", "Magmar"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Cyclizar’s niche in VGC 2023 is defined almost entirely by Shed Tail, a move that creates a Substitute and then immediately switches in a teammate of your choice while keeping the Substitute intact. This single mechanic lets you protect a fragile or set-up-heavy partner such as Gholdengo or Dragonite for a turn while still attacking, and because Cyclizar is base 121 Speed it will almost always get the Substitute off before the opponent can KO it. Regenerator is the icing on the cake: after Cyclizar has passed the Substitute it can simply switch out later in the match and regain a third of its health, letting it act multiple times per game. Covert Cloak is the preferred item because it nullifies Fake Out, Rock Slide flinches, and Nuzzle paralysis, ensuring Cyclizar can fire off Shed Tail even under heavy disruption; Leftovers and Sitrus Berry are workable alternatives if you value passive recovery or a one-time burst. Draco Meteor is the only attack you need: it 2HKOs most neutral targets and detours Landorus-T and Garchomp from trying to set up on you. Taunt prevents Trick Room, Grimmsnarl screens, and Amoonguss spore spam, while Hyper Voice is a spread option that bypasses Follow Me and breaks Focus Sashes. Tera Dragon is taken on roughly two-thirds of teams because it powers up Draco Meteor and removes Cyclizar’s Ice-type vulnerability, letting it survive a typical Ice Spinner or Ice Beam and still get off a second Shed Tail.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Cyclizar": {"Abilities": {"regenerator": 1.6962613989447477, "shedskin": 0.006040535781872525}, "Items": {"covertcloak": 0.19589420710902986, "sitrusberry": 0.1502064975628636, "leftovers": 0.3498404469950261}, "Spreads": {"Timid:0/0/0/252/4/252": 0.5064206706444079}, "Moves": ["dracometeor", "shedtail", "taunt", "hypervoice"], "Tera Types": {"dragon": 0.6461949781088608}, "Teammates": ["Gholdengo", "Ninetales-Alola", "Indeedee-F", "Annihilape", "Dragonite", "Magmar"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Cyclizar loves facing slow, set-up reliant teams that can’t break its Substitute quickly—Trick Room squads without a strong Ghost or Steel attacker struggle to stop the Shed Tail chain. It fares well against sun and rain teams that rely on spread moves like Heat Wave or Surf, since a single Substitute can absorb the hit while your win-condition sets up behind it. Conversely, Cyclizar hates priority that can break the Substitute before it moves: Shadow Sneak from Dragapult or Kingambit, Aqua Jet from Drednaw, or Sucker Punch from Ting-Lu can all pop the sub and leave the incoming Pokémon exposed. Opposing Fake Out + double-target scenarios can also KO Cyclizar before it acts, so you must position carefully. Ice-type Pokémon such as Chien-Pao and Alolan-Ninetales threaten an OHKO with Ice Shard or Blizzard, forcing you to Tera early or switch out. Finally, Cyclizar is dead weight against Tailwind offense that can outspeed and KO it before it gets value—opposing Cyclizar mirrors often come down to speed ties and who keeps their Cloak intact.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Cyclizar is a pivot-support that compresses three jobs into one slot: it sets up a 25 % HP Substitute, passes that Substitute to a sweeper, and then heals itself off the field with Regenerator. In most games you lead Cyclizar next to a partner that wants one free turn—Gholdengo to spam Make It Rain, Dragonite to Dragon Dance, or Annihilape to Bulk Up—fire Shed Tail on turn one, and immediately switch to your win-condition. If the opponent tries to stall with Protect or Follow Me, Cyclizar can Taunt on the follow-up turn before switching out. Later in the match it can return, fire off a fast Taunt or Draco Meteor, and then U-turn or simply switch out to regain health, acting as a regenerating pivot that keeps the tempo firmly in your favor.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Cyclizar": {"Abilities": {"regenerator": 1.6962613989447477, "shedskin": 0.006040535781872525}, "Items": {"covertcloak": 0.19589420710902986, "sitrusberry": 0.1502064975628636, "leftovers": 0.3498404469950261}, "Spreads": {"Timid:0/0/0/252/4/252": 0.5064206706444079}, "Moves": ["dracometeor", "shedtail", "taunt", "hypervoice"], "Tera Types": {"dragon": 0.6461949781088608}, "Teammates": ["Gholdengo", "Ninetales-Alola", "Indeedee-F", "Annihilape", "Dragonite", "Magmar"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>The simplest way to beat Cyclizar is to break its Substitute before it can pass it: Shadow Sneak from Kingambit or Basculegion, Ice Shard from Chien-Pao, or Aqua Jet from Drednaw all pop the sub and leave the incoming Pokémon open to a double-target KO. Faster Fake Out users such as Meowscarada or Iron Hands can flinch Cyclizar if it isn’t holding Covert Cloak, and Grimmsnarl can Taunt it first turn to prevent Shed Tail entirely. Once Cyclizar has used Shed Tail it becomes extremely predictable: you know exactly which Pokémon is coming in, so you can position your attacks and Protects accordingly. Cyclizar also hates Tailwind or Chlorophyll sweepers that can outspeed even after it has passed the sub, since it offers no speed control of its own. Finally, because Cyclizar is a one-time use slot if KO’d early, aggressive double-targets or priority spam can remove it before it ever gains Regenerator value, forcing the rest of the team to play a conventional 3v4.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Cetitan": {"Abilities": {"slushrush": 1.7243190476800403, "thickfat": 0.052689400231456074, "sheerforce": 0.08147420324238319}, "Items": {"sitrusberry": 0.45159708007828375, "assaultvest": 0.15656089201984288, "loadeddice": 0.17194852599841115}, "Spreads": {"Adamant:4/252/0/0/0/252": 0.166252377390296}, "Moves": ["highhorsepower", "bellydrum", "icespinner", "protect"], "Tera Types": {"water": 0.3201457004261251, "ground": 0.2944379483497052, "ice": 0.19113132110999118}, "Teammates": ["Ninetales-Alola", "Incineroar", "Garchomp", "Indeedee-F", "Kilowattrel", "Armarouge"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Cetitan carves a niche in Regulation G as a Slush Rush sweeper that turns Alolan Ninetales' hail into 502 Attack after a Belly Drum. High Horsepower and Ice Spinner give perfect neutral coverage outside of niche dual-typed Grass/Bug or Ice resists, while Tera Water removes the Fire weakness and flips Stealth Rock damage into recovery. The EV spread maximizes Speed under hail, letting it outrun +1 Kingambit and scarfed Dragapult while still retaining Sheer Force-boosted power. Assault Vest or Sitrus Berry variants add longevity, but the classic Drum set remains the most menacing win-condition in dedicated hail structures.</OUTPUT>

input:
Draft the 'full_analysis' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Cetitan": {"Abilities": {"slushrush": 1.7243190476800403, "thickfat": 0.052689400231456074, "sheerforce": 0.08147420324238319}, "Items": {"sitrusberry": 0.45159708007828375, "assaultvest": 0.15656089201984288, "loadeddice": 0.17194852599841115}, "Spreads": {"Adamant:4/252/0/0/0/252": 0.166252377390296}, "Moves": ["highhorsepower", "bellydrum", "icespinner", "protect"], "Tera Types": {"water": 0.3201457004261251, "ground": 0.2944379483497052, "ice": 0.19113132110999118}, "Teammates": ["Ninetales-Alola", "Incineroar", "Garchomp", "Indeedee-F", "Kilowattrel", "Armarouge"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>With access to Slush Rush and Belly Drum, Cetitan functions as a weather-specific cleaner that can rip through unprepared teams in a single turn. After a Drum it reaches an astronomical Attack stat of 1,004, letting High Horsepower KO even bulky neutral targets such as max-HP Incineroar 100% of the time. Ice Spinner provides a secondary STAB that destroys Garchomp, Landorus-T and Amoonguss while removing opposing Psychic Terrain that could block priority support. Tera Water is preferred on the sweeping set because it halves incoming Fire damage, removes the crippling Stealth Rock weakness, and synergizes with the ubiquitous rain teams that often accompany hail cores. Tera Ground is a solid alternative that grants an Electric immunity and makes High Horsepower even stronger, but the loss of Fire resistance is noticeable versus Incineroar or Heatran. Loaded Dice turns Icicle Spear into a 125 BP spread move that can devastate frail doubles leads, yet the opportunity cost of not carrying Protect or a healing item is high. Sheer Force is occasionally run to boost Ice Spinner and High Horsepower, but the speed granted by Slush Rush under hail is the primary reason to use Cetitan over other bulky breakers such as Azumarill or Iron Hands. Thick Fat deserves a brief mention on Assault Vest sets that aim to check Chien-Pao and Iron Valiant, but the drop in power is palpable. Overall, Cetitan's success hinges on hail permanence; without it the whale drops to a mediocre 251 Speed and becomes bait for every faster attacker in the format.</OUTPUT>

Generate the 'matchup_overview' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Cetitan": {"Abilities": {"slushrush": 1.7243190476800403, "thickfat": 0.052689400231456074, "sheerforce": 0.08147420324238319}, "Items": {"sitrusberry": 0.45159708007828375, "assaultvest": 0.15656089201984288, "loadeddice": 0.17194852599841115}, "Spreads": {"Adamant:4/252/0/0/0/252": 0.166252377390296}, "Moves": ["highhorsepower", "bellydrum", "icespinner", "protect"], "Tera Types": {"water": 0.3201457004261251, "ground": 0.2944379483497052, "ice": 0.19113132110999118}, "Teammates": ["Ninetales-Alola", "Incineroar", "Garchomp", "Indeedee-F", "Kilowattrel", "Armarouge"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Cetitan loves facing bulky offenses that rely on Garchomp, Dragonite or Landorus-T as their speed control, since Slush Rush lets it outspeed and KO all three after a boost. It also pressures common Tailwind teams built around Tornadus-I or Kilowattrel, as Ice Spinner removes the field effect and High Horsepower punishes opposing Electric or Fire types. On the flip side, priority users such as Kingambit, Dragonite with Extreme Speed or Scizor's Bullet Punch can pick off a chipped Cetitan before it moves, while scarfed Flutter Mane or Iron Valiant cleanly outspeed even under hail. Opposing weather—especially sun—cripples Cetitan's Speed tier and leaves it walled by Torkoal or Heatran. Finally, double-target focus fire plus Fake Out support can prevent the Belly Drum from ever happening, so dedicated redirection or Follow Me users can blunt the whale's sweep before it begins.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Cetitan": {"Abilities": {"slushrush": 1.7243190476800403, "thickfat": 0.052689400231456074, "sheerforce": 0.08147420324238319}, "Items": {"sitrusberry": 0.45159708007828375, "assaultvest": 0.15656089201984288, "loadeddice": 0.17194852599841115}, "Spreads": {"Adamant:4/252/0/0/0/252": 0.166252377390296}, "Moves": ["highhorsepower", "bellydrum", "icespinner", "protect"], "Tera Types": {"water": 0.3201457004261251, "ground": 0.2944379483497052, "ice": 0.19113132110999118}, "Teammates": ["Ninetales-Alola", "Incineroar", "Garchomp", "Indeedee-F", "Kilowattrel", "Armarouge"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Cetitan occupies the slot of a weather-dependent win-condition on hail-centric balance or hyper-offense squads. Its primary duty is to sit behind Ninetales' Aurora Veil until hail is active, then use a protected Belly Drum turn to reach +6 Attack. Once boosted, it functions as a late-game cleaner that can OHKO most neutral targets while shrugging off weaker priority thanks to its 170 base HP and potential Tera Water resistance. Secondary duties include breaking Focus Sash with multi-hit Icicle Spear and removing Psychic Terrain to enable partner priority moves such as Incineroar's Parting Shot or Kingambit's Sucker Punch. Because it demands both hail and a free turn to set up, Cetitan is rarely a lead; instead it is brought after opposing speed control or Fake Out users have been weakened or KOed.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Alolan Ninetales is mandatory, providing both hail and Aurora Veil to guarantee the Belly Drum setup. Incineroar forms the classic Fire-Dark-Grass core, softening physical attackers with Intimigate and handling opposing Steel types that resist Cetitan's STABs. Garchomp shares Earthquake immunity and covers the Electric weakness while pressuring opposing Fire and Poison types. Indeedee-F supplies Follow Me and Psychic Terrain to block priority, although Cetitan's Ice Spinner can overwrite the field when needed. Kilowattrel gives a fast Flying-type ally that can break opposing sashes and bring its own Tailwind should hail fade, while Armarouge spreads Wide Guard to block Rock Slide and Heat Wave that could otherwise KO both whales. Tera Water is encouraged on multiple teammates to stack Fire resistance and enable double-Tera turns that flip momentum versus sun or Heatran squads.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Priority is the most consistent answer: Kingambit's Sucker Punch, Dragonite's Extreme Speed and Scizor's Bullet Punch all KO a chipped Cetitan before it moves. Faster scarf users—Flutter Mane, Iron Valiant, Roaring Moon—ignore the Speed boost and OHKO with STAB moves. Sun teams deserve special mention, as Drought removes hail and leaves Cetitan walled by Torkoal or Protosynthesis Fire types. Fake Out plus double-target damage can prevent the Belly Drum entirely, so partners like Indeedee-F or Farigiraf must be dispatched first. Unaware walls such as Dondozo or Skeledirge can stomach even a +6 Ice Spinner and retaliterate with strong neutral moves. Finally, residual damage is punishing: without Leftovers or Sitrus Berry Cetitan is worn down quickly by Stealth Rock, hail, and partner spread moves, so keeping Veil active and bringing it in via slow U-turn or Parting Shot is crucial.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Ampharos carves a niche in VGC as a slow, hard-hitting Electric special attacker that can pivot or nuke with Thunder/Thunderbolt while leveraging Tera Electric for extra power or Tera Fairy for key resistances; its bulk and access to Dragon Tail let it disrupt Trick Room or redirect setups, making it a flexible choice for structured offensive squads.</OUTPUT>

input:
Produce the 'full_analysis' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Ampharos": {"Abilities": {"static": 1.6663040938727527, "plus": 0.04025082338907643}, "Items": {"powerherb": 0.3709709761169494, "lifeorb": 0.5525411731751244}, "Spreads": {"Quiet:252/4/0/252/0/0": 0.5524003587236777, "Modest:68/0/4/252/4/180": 0.16961445185424542}, "Moves": ["thunderbolt", "voltswitch", "thunder", "dragontail"], "Tera Types": {"fairy": 0.2678620265205116, "electric": 0.7023898790425571}, "Teammates": ["Indeedee-F", "Sneasler", "Torkoal", "Ursaluna-Bloodmoon", "Dragapult", "Armarouge"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>With a base 115 Special Attack and access to STAB Thunderbolt, Ampharos hits most neutral targets for respectable damage, while Quiet 252/252 spreads paired with Life Orb or Power Herb give it immediate breaking power. Tera Electric pushes its Electric moves into OHKO territory versus common Water- and Flying-types such as Pelipper, Tornadus-T, and Ogerpon-Wellspring, while Tera Fairy grants a crucial Dragon immunity and Fighting resistance, letting it check Dragapult and Sneasler that otherwise threaten its teammates. Static punishes contact attackers, generating occasional paralysis that can swing speed control. Dragon Tail offers phasing utility: it bypasses Follow Me, evades Taunt, and can eject a freshly set-up WP holder or a Trick Room setter before it activates. The prevalence of Volt Switch on 55% of sets means Ampharos can pivot out of bad matchups, preserving momentum for frail partners like Indeedee-F and Armarouge. Its middling 90/85/90 bulk is workable but not stellar, so it appreciates redirection or speed control to fire off attacks safely. Overall, Ampharos functions as a mid-speed breaker that can adapt to either offensive pivoting or disruptive phasing depending on team needs.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Ampharos": {"Abilities": {"static": 1.6663040938727527, "plus": 0.04025082338907643}, "Items": {"powerherb": 0.3709709761169494, "lifeorb": 0.5525411731751244}, "Spreads": {"Quiet:252/4/0/252/0/0": 0.5524003587236777, "Modest:68/0/4/252/4/180": 0.16961445185424542}, "Moves": ["thunderbolt", "voltswitch", "thunder", "dragontail"], "Tera Types": {"fairy": 0.2678620265205116, "electric": 0.7023898790425571}, "Teammates": ["Indeedee-F", "Sneasler", "Torkoal", "Ursaluna-Bloodmoon", "Dragapult", "Armarouge"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Ampharos enjoys strong matchups against Rain cores (Pelipper, Barraskewda, Tornadus) and common Water-types like Urshifu-R and Dondozo, OHKOing most with Tera Electric Thunder. It threatens Corviknight and Skarmory, which otherwise wall many special attackers. Against Trick Room, Dragon Tail can punt slow setters like Hatterene or Porygon2, delaying their turns. Conversely, it struggles versus faster Ground-types such as Great Tusk, Garchomp, and Lando-T, which outspeed and KO through its weaker physical bulk. Dragapult can win if it carries Tera Fairy, but risks Static and must fear Thunder into Shadow Ball wars. Priority users like Kingambit and Sneasler can finish off chipped Ampharos, though Static can punish Sneasler's Contact CC. Tera Grass Rillaboom ignores Electric and threatens with Wood Hammer, making it a hard counter. In tailwind matchups, opposing Flutter Mane and Iron Bundle can overpower Ampharos before it moves unless the player controls speed.</OUTPUT>

On bulkier teams it can act as a mid-speed control piece, spreading para with Static and punishing passive play. output: <OUTPUT>Pachirisu is a niche support Pokémon that leverages Follow Me, Super Fang, and Electroweb to enable its teammates in VGC. While its stats are low, its unique utility and immunity to Electric give it a small but meaningful role on select teams.</OUTPUT>

input:
Create the 'full_analysis' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Pachirisu": {"Abilities": {"voltabsorb": 1.718969033417679, "runaway": 2.5463176012152644e-10, "pickup": 0.00048541424052955806}, "Items": {"sitrusberry": 0.9374468766725872}, "Spreads": {"Impish:252/0/252/0/4/0": 0.39157374991359534, "Calm:252/0/252/0/4/0": 0.4173583617397033}, "Moves": ["followme", "protect", "superfang", "electroweb"], "Tera Types": {"fairy": 0.4094715438657446, "flying": 0.403533746838081}, "Teammates": ["Rillaboom", "Primarina", "Sneasler", "Garchomp", "Tyranitar", "Dragapult"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Pachirisu’s entire value lies in its support movepool and Volt Absorb. Follow Me is the centerpiece, forcing single-target attacks to hit Pachirisu instead of its partner, buying a free turn for setup or a double-up KO. Super Fang slices 50 % off any non-Ghost target, turning bulky Dynamax threats into 2HKO range for the partner. Electroweb provides speed control that stacks with Icy Wind or Scary Face, letting slower breakers like Rillaboom or Primarina move first the following turn. Protect is mandatory to preserve its modest 80 / 70 physical bulk and 90 / 70 special bulk. EV spreads are almost evenly split between Impish and Calm, both maxing HP and defenses to ensure it lives at least one super-effective hit or a Max Lightning from opposing Zapdos or Regieleki. Tera Fairy is the most common choice, removing its Electric weakness and granting a crucial Dragon immunity to survive Dragapult’s Draco Meteor or Garchomp’s Outrage; Tera Flying is nearly as popular, giving a Ground immunity and a handy Max Airstream option if it ever attacks. Sitrus Berry is on virtually every set, restoring 25 % and synergising with its bulk investment to let it Follow Me twice under average damage rolls. Volt Absorb is taken on 99.9 % of teams, turning predicted Thunderbolts into free healing and punishing the opponent for targeting it.</OUTPUT>

Produce the 'matchup_overview' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Pachirisu": {"Abilities": {"voltabsorb": 1.718969033417679, "runaway": 2.5463176012152644e-10, "pickup": 0.00048541424052955806}, "Items": {"sitrusberry": 0.9374468766725872}, "Spreads": {"Impish:252/0/252/0/4/0": 0.39157374991359534, "Calm:252/0/252/0/4/0": 0.4173583617397033}, "Moves": ["followme", "protect", "superfang", "electroweb"], "Tera Types": {"fairy": 0.4094715438657446, "flying": 0.403533746838081}, "Teammates": ["Rillaboom", "Primarina", "Sneasler", "Garchomp", "Tyranitar", "Dragapult"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Pachirisu loves facing Electric-weak or Electric-locked foes such as Corviknight, Togekiss, or opposing Tapu Fini, turning their Thunder Waves or Volt Switches into recovery. It struggles against spread attackers like Landorus-T, Incineroar, or Calyrex-S who ignore Follow Me and OHKO with Earthquake, Flare Blitz, or Astral Barrage. Ghost-types are immune to Super Fang, so Aegislash and Dragapult can wall its chip damage. Taunt users such as Whimsicott or Grimmsnarl shut down Follow Me and force it to become passive. Fake Out pressure from Indeedee-M or Raichu can break its Sitrus Berry before it moves, making it harder to stay on the field. Terrain wars also matter: Psychic Terrain blocks priority Follow Me, while Electric Terrain boosts opposing Electric moves and prevents Volt Absorb healing if Pachirisu is grounded.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Rillaboom is the most common partner, appreciating Follow Me while it sets up Grassy Terrain and fires Grassy Glides. Primarina benefits from Electroweb speed control and Super Fang chip to secure Hydro Pump KOs. Sneasler loves having status redirected away so it can Swords Dance or fire off Dire Claws. Garchomp and Dragapult both enjoy the removal of Ice- and Dragon-type checks via Super Fang and the speed drop from Electroweb, while Tyranitar forms a sturdy special wall core with Pachirisu under sand, chipping foes with Sand Stream and special bulk investment. In general, Pachirisu fits on balanced or bulky-offense teams that want one slot of redirection plus speed control without compromising bulk.</OUTPUT>

input:
Write a detailed 'short_summary' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Magnezone": {"Abilities": {"sturdy": 0.69516824447951, "analytic": 0.3734735454997486, "magnetpull": 0.5365987677046704}, "Items": {"choicespecs": 0.40004764647676005, "lightclay": 0.21918750365945158}, "Spreads": {"Modest:252/0/0/252/4/0": 0.1956739551135901, "Relaxed:4/0/252/0/252/0": 0.21918750365945172}, "Moves": ["flashcannon", "thunderbolt", "terablast", "voltswitch"], "Tera Types": {"flying": 0.543818689600786, "ground": 0.19068978238535042}, "Teammates": ["Ursaluna", "Rillaboom", "Ninetales-Alola", "Porygon2", "Torkoal", "Dusclops"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Magnezone is a specialized offensive pivot that leverages its high Special Attack and unique Steel/Electric typing to break common Fairy- and Flying-type cores while providing slow Volt Switch momentum. With a 40 % usage of Choice Specs, it functions best as a hard-hitting wallbreaker that can bluff other sets, while the 22 % Light Clay variant offers dual-screen support for hyper-offense teams. Tera Flying is preferred 54 % of the time to dodge Ground-type moves and stack weaknesses with Flying-type teammates, whereas Tera Ground (19 %) flips the script on Electric immunities and Volt-blockers. Modest 252/252 spreads maximize immediate damage, while Relaxed 4/0/252/0/252 sets exist for bulkier screen roles. The move pool is predictably limited to Flash Cannon, Thunderbolt, Tera Blast, and Volt Switch, emphasizing its role as a linear but powerful attacker that appreciates teammates like Ursaluna, Rillaboom, Alolan Ninetales, Porygon2, Torkoal, and Dusclops for speed control, terrain, weather, and Trick Room options.</OUTPUT>

input:
Write a detailed 'full_analysis' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Magnezone": {"Abilities": {"sturdy": 0.69516824447951, "analytic": 0.3734735454997486, "magnetpull": 0.5365987677046704}, "Items": {"choicespecs": 0.40004764647676005, "lightclay": 0.21918750365945158}, "Spreads": {"Modest:252/0/0/252/4/0": 0.1956739551135901, "Relaxed:4/0/252/0/252/0": 0.21918750365945172}, "Moves": ["flashcannon", "thunderbolt", "terablast", "voltswitch"], "Tera Types": {"flying": 0.543818689600786, "ground": 0.19068978238535042}, "Teammates": ["Ursaluna", "Rillaboom", "Ninetales-Alola", "Porygon2", "Torkoal", "Dusclops"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Magnezone’s niche in VGC 2025 is defined by its ability to compress offensive pressure and pivoting into one slot, something few other Steel-types can claim. Sturdy is the most common ability at 70 % usage, guaranteeing at least one hit or screen against faster leads, while Analytic (37 %) rewards slow Volt Switches and late-game cleanup, and Magnet Pull (54 %) can trap and remove opposing Corviknight or Togekiss if prediction is on point. Choice Specs variants are the default, turning Thunderbolt into a 120-base STAB nuke that OHKOes most neutral targets and 2HKOes even bulky resists like Rotom-Wash. Flash Cannon provides reliable Steel coverage that punishes Fairy- and Ice-type Dynamax targets, while Tera Blast becomes either a 100 % accurate Flying move post-Tera or a Ground move to snipe opposing Magnezone and Toxtricity. Volt Switch is the glue that lets Magnezone maintain offensive tempo, bringing in frail attackers like Ursaluna or Rillaboom safely after a KO or chip damage. Light Clay sets sacrifice immediate power for 8-turn dual screens, enabling hyper-offense teammates such as Swords Dance Rillaboom or Belly Drum Ursaluna to set up with impunity. The Modest nature and 252/252 spread are non-negotiable for Specs sets to secure benchmarks like OHKOing max-HP Togekiss with Thunderbolt and 2HKOing Assault Vest Gholdengo. Relaxed nature and 252 HP / 252 Def are used exclusively with Light Clay to survive Earthquakes from Landorus-T and Garchomp while setting Reflect first turn. Tera Flying is the dominant choice because it removes the Ground weakness, synergizes with Grassy Glide Rillaboom and Tailwind Togekiss, and allows Magnezone to spam Volt Switch without fear of Earth Power or Earthquake. Tera Ground is a tech option that flips the Electric immunity, letting Magnezone win mirror matchups and surprise KO opposing Toxtricity and opposing Magnezone. Teammates are chosen to cover Magnezone’s poor Speed tier and limited coverage: Ursaluna provides Fake Out and priority Ground damage, Rillaboom sets Grassy Terrain and breaks Water-types, Alolan Ninetales offers Aurora Veil and Freeze-Dry for Dragons, Porygon2 gives Trick Room control, Torkoal supplies sun-boosted Eruption and removes opposing weather, and Dusclops offers Trick Room and Ally Switch support for the bulky screen variant.</OUTPUT>

input:
Write a detailed 'matchup_overview' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Magnezone": {"Abilities": {"sturdy": 0.69516824447951, "analytic": 0.3734735454997486, "magnetpull": 0.5365987677046704}, "Items": {"choicespecs": 0.40004764647676005, "lightclay": 0.21918750365945158}, "Spreads": {"Modest:252/0/0/252/4/0": 0.1956739551135901, "Relaxed:4/0/252/0/252/0": 0.21918750365945172}, "Moves": ["flashcannon", "thunderbolt", "terablast", "voltswitch"], "Tera Types": {"flying": 0.543818689600786, "ground": 0.19068978238535042}, "Teammates": ["Ursaluna", "Rillaboom", "Ninetales-Alola", "Porygon2", "Torkoal", "Dusclops"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Magnezone’s matchups are polarized: it dominates Fairy-, Flying-, and Water-type cores such as Togekiss + Tapu Fini + Pelipper, but struggles against faster Ground-, Fire-, and opposing Steel-type offenses. Against Tailwind or Regieleki hyper-offense, Sturdy guarantees at least one screen or a heavy trade, while Specs Thunderbolt picks off non-Dynamax variants of Zapdos and Yveltal. Versus Trick Room, Magnezone must either drop a screen on turn 1 or Dynamax immediately to survive Rhyperior’s Earthquake or Torkoal’s Eruption; Tera Flying is essential here to avoid the OHKO. Against sun teams, Magnezone outslows Torkoal under Trick Room but risks a sun-boosted Heat Wave, so pairing it with Rillaboom to overwrite sun with Grassy Terrain is critical. Mirror matchups hinge on Tera type: Tera Ground variants beat Tera Flying variants one-on-one, but both lose if Sturdy has been broken. Rain teams present a mixed bag: Specs Thunderbolt 2HKOes Pelipper through Sitrus Berry, but Swampert under rain OHKOes back with Earthquake unless Magnezone has already Terastallized to Flying. Finally, vs. stall or Corviknight cores, Magnet Pull variants can trap and remove Corviknight with Volt Switch + Tera Blast Ground, but must watch for Dynamax and Shed Shell variants.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Magnezone": {"Abilities": {"sturdy": 0.69516824447951, "analytic": 0.3734735454997486, "magnetpull": 0.5365987677046704}, "Items": {"choicespecs": 0.40004764647676005, "lightclay": 0.21918750365945158}, "Spreads": {"Modest:252/0/0/252/4/0": 0.1956739551135901, "Relaxed:4/0/252/0/252/0": 0.21918750365945172}, "Moves": ["flashcannon", "thunderbolt", "terablast", "voltswitch"], "Tera Types": {"flying": 0.543818689600786, "ground": 0.19068978238535042}, "Teammates": ["Ursaluna", "Rillaboom", "Ninetales-Alola", "Porygon2", "Torkoal", "Dusclops"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Magnezone is primarily a wallbreaking pivot that compresses Special Attack, typing, and pivoting into one slot. Choice Specs sets function as lead or mid-game breakers that delete Fairy- and Flying-type Dynamax targets while maintaining Volt Switch momentum for teammates like Ursaluna and Rillaboom. Light Clay sets act as dual-screen enablers for hyper-offense, guaranteeing 8-turn Reflect and Light Screen so that setup sweepers can safely boost. Both sets appreciate Sturdy for guaranteed value against faster leads, and both leverage Tera Flying to dodge Earthquake and spam Volt Switch freely. The modest 252/252 spread ensures OHKOs on Togekiss and 2HKOs on Gholdengo, while the relaxed 252 HP / 252 Def spread survives Jolly Garchomp Earthquake and sets Reflect first turn. In short, Magnezone is either a nuke that trades itself for two opposing Pokémon or a support that buys eight turns of setup for its teammates.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Ursaluna offers Fake Out and priority Ground damage that removes opposing Heatran and Stakataka, freeing Magnezone to click Thunderbolt freely. Rillaboom sets Grassy Terrain to halve Earthquake damage and provides priority Glide that finishes off chipped Water-types. Alolan Ninetales supplies Aurora Veil for 5 turns, stacking with Light Clay screens for 13 effective turns of protection, and Freeze-Dry snipes Dragons that resist Magnezone’s STABs. Porygon2 gives Trick Room control, allowing Relaxed Magnezone to underspeed and set screens before opposing attacks. Torkoal removes opposing weather and provides sun-boosted Eruption that pressures Steel-types that wall Magnezone. Dusclops offers Trick Room and Ally Switch, redirecting Earthquakes away from Magnezone and guaranteeing dual-screen value. In return, Magnezone traps Corviknight and Skarmory for Rillaboom, breaks Fairy-types for Ursaluna, and provides slow Volt Switch to bring these partners in safely.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Magnezone": {"Abilities": {"sturdy": 0.69516824447951, "analytic": 0.3734735454997486, "magnetpull": 0.5365987677046704}, "Items": {"choicespecs": 0.40004764647676005, "lightclay": 0.21918750365945158}, "Spreads": {"Modest:252/0/0/252/4/0": 0.1956739551135901, "Relaxed:4/0/252/0/252/0": 0.21918750365945172}, "Moves": ["flashcannon", "thunderbolt", "terablast", "voltswitch"], "Tera Types": {"flying": 0.543818689600786, "ground": 0.19068978238535042}, "Teammates": ["Ursaluna", "Rillaboom", "Ninetales-Alola", "Porygon2", "Torkoal", "Dusclops"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Magnezone is hard-countered by faster Ground-types such as Landorus-T, Garchomp, and Great Tusk that can break Sturdy with Fake Out or priority and KO with Earthquake before it can Tera. Fire-types like Heatran and Torkoal under sun OHKO through Sturdy with Heat Wave or Eruption, and both resist Flash Cannon. Opposing Steel-types with Shed Shell, namely Corviknight and Skarmory, ignore Magnet Pull and can Roost stall or U-turn out. Dragapult and Iron Bundle outspeed and KO with Specs Draco or Hydro respectively, though they must watch for Sturdy + Tera Flying. Finally, Taunt users such as Roaring Moon or Grimmsnarl shut down dual-screen variants, forcing Magnezone to attack into immunities or switch out. To mitigate these weaknesses, pair Magnezone with Rillaboom for Grassy Terrain chip and priority, Alolan Ninetales for Aurora Veil, or Porygon2 for Trick Room control.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Ariados carves a hyper-specific niche as a Brave, Loaded-Dice support that spams multi-hit Pin Missile while spreading Attack drops via Lunge and special damage reduction via Struggle Bug; Insomnia keeps it awake against Amoonguss and other sleep users, while Rage Powder lets it redirect single-target moves. Provide the 'full_analysis' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Ariados": {"Abilities": {"insomnia": 1.5310037011100879, "sniper": 0.029095043852507996, "swarm": 0.009508467615475302}, "Items": {"loadeddice": 0.891323124496945}, "Spreads": {"Brave:252/156/0/0/100/0": 0.891323124496945}, "Moves": ["lunge", "ragepowder", "strugglebug", "pinmissile"], "Tera Types": {"dark": 0.9592513716541605}, "Teammates": ["Indeedee-F", "Reuniclus", "Gallade", "Torkoal", "Tsareena", "Lilligant-Hisui"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Loaded Dice turns Pin Missile into a 92% chance to hit 4–5 times, giving Ariados a spammable 4× base 25 Bug STAB that breaks sashes, deals respectable neutral damage, and pressures frail attackers. Lunge guarantees an Attack drop on anything that doesn’t resist Bug, neutering physical Dynamax and setup sweepers, while Struggle Bug provides a special side equivalent that punishes special attackers and synergises with redirection to let partners set up or fire off Z-moves. Rage Powder completes the support suite, forcing opponents to choose between targeting Ariados—bulky enough to survive most unboosted neutral hits—and the real win condition sitting next to it. Insomnia is the only ability worth considering; it flips the Amoonguss and Venusaur match-ups on their heads and denies Grimmsnarl/Yawn users their free turns. 252/156/100 Brave spreads maximise Attack and give enough bulk to survive -1 Iron Head from Life Orb G-Moltres or +1 Jet Punch from Palafin. Tera Dark is taken on virtually every set, removing the pesky Bug/Flying weakness to Rock and turning Ariados into a soft check to Indeedee-F and other Psychics while preserving its Bug STAB. The spider’s natural speed tier of 40 is abysmal, but under Trick Room it becomes a respectable 16-speed tier, outspeeding most dedicated Room sweepers and letting it fire off utility before dying. Outside Room it functions as a slow pivot that can still redirect and drop stats, then either perish or bring in a cleaner. The combination of multi-hit, stat-dropping utility, sleep immunity and redirection is unique to Ariados in the current SV meta, and while its stats are mediocre, the role compression can be invaluable on teams that want every slot to perform multiple jobs.</OUTPUT>

Write the 'matchup_overview' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Ariados": {"Abilities": {"insomnia": 1.5310037011100879, "sniper": 0.029095043852507996, "swarm": 0.009508467615475302}, "Items": {"loadeddice": 0.891323124496945}, "Spreads": {"Brave:252/156/0/0/100/0": 0.891323124496945}, "Moves": ["lunge", "ragepowder", "strugglebug", "pinmissile"], "Tera Types": {"dark": 0.9592513716541605}, "Teammates": ["Indeedee-F", "Reuniclus", "Gallade", "Torkoal", "Tsareena", "Lilligant-Hisui"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Ariados loves facing Grass-types and slower set-up cores. Amoonguss, Venusaur, and Liligant-H become liability match-ups thanks to Insomnia and Rage Powder, while physical set-up sweepers such as Dragonite, Kingambit, and Palafin hate the guaranteed Attack drop from Lunge. Special attackers like Indeedee-F, Gholdengo, and Iron Moth are chipped by Struggle Bug and multi-hit Pin Missile, making it harder for them to KO through redirection. Conversely, faster Flying-types—Talonflame, Iron Moth, and especially Gale Wings Talonflame—obliterate Ariados before it can move, while priority Brave Bird or Hurricane OHKO through bulk investment. Fire-types such as Heatran, G-Moltres, and Torkoal roast it, though Tera Dark mitigates the Rock weakness Torkoal often carries. Rock-types like Lycanroc-Dusk and Tyranitar crush it with Stone Edge, and faster Dragapult can ignore Rage Powder and nuke with Draco or Tera Ghost Tera Blast. Rain teams with Barraskewda or Floaty Palafin also outspeed and KO before utility goes up. Trick Room mirrors are a mixed bag: Ariados underspeeds most threats under Room, but strong spread attackers like Glastrier or Stakataka still flatten it. Overall, Ariados wants to face slower, status-reliant or set-up teams and hates faster offensive structures that can ignore redirection.</OUTPUT>

It leads to deny sleep, redirect threatening single-target moves, and drop offensive stats while chipping with Loaded-Dice Pin Missile. Its purpose is not to sweep but to enable partners—Indeedee-F, Reuniclus, Gallade, H-Liligant—to set up or fire off attacks unimpeded while crippling opposing offense stats.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Ariados": {"Abilities": {"insomnia": 1.5310037011100879, "sniper": 0.029095043852507996, "swarm": 0.009508467615475302}, "Items": {"loadeddice": 0.891323124496945}, "Spreads": {"Brave:252/156/0/0/100/0": 0.891323124496945}, "Moves": ["lunge", "ragepowder", "strugglebug", "pinmissile"], "Tera Types": {"dark": 0.9592513716541605}, "Teammates": ["Indeedee-F", "Reuniclus", "Gallade", "Torkoal", "Tsareena", "Lilligant-Hisui"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Indeedee-F is by far the most common partner: Psychic Terrain blocks priority that would otherwise pick off the spider, and Indeedee appreciates redirection to fire off Expanding Force or set up Calm Mind. Reuniclus and Gallade share the same Room synergy, benefiting from Ariados underspeeding them and dropping enemy Attack so they can Weakness Policy or Swords Dance safely. Torkoal provides sun-boosted Eruption and appreciates Ariados handling Grass-types that resist Fire, while Tsareena bounces back priority and removes hazards that would otherwise chip Ariados into KO range. Hisuian Liligant pairs for a double-Grass offensive core that punishes Water- and Ground-types while Ariados covers Bug and Flying threats. All six listed teammates either set or abuse Trick Room, meaning Ariados is almost always on full-Room squads that aim to play a short, brutal six-turn game. Tera Dark synergises with Dark-weak partners like Indeedee-F and Reuniclus, letting Ariados tank Knock Off or Sucker Punch and retaliate with Bug coverage. In short, Ariados fits on hyper-structured Room teams that need redirection, status immunity, and stat-dropping utility without sacrificing offensive pressure.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Typhlosion": {"Abilities": {"flashfire": 1.435081191426139, "blaze": 0.16224316467118993}, "Items": {"lifeorb": 0.2577676990846471, "choicescarf": 0.43591585408838757}, "Spreads": {"Modest:4/0/0/252/0/252": 0.16732664315603696, "Modest:0/0/0/252/4/252": 0.26276074889544815, "Timid:4/0/0/252/0/252": 0.15996727743743258, "Timid:0/0/0/252/0/252": 0.240066973217574}, "Moves": ["eruption", "flamethrower", "heatwave", "scorchingsands"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.3091557770128174, "fire": 0.557223958061351}, "Teammates": ["Whimsicott", "Dragapult", "Basculegion", "Rillaboom", "Zoroark-Hisui", "Corviknight"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Typhlosion is a pure Fire-type that leverages its signature max-power Eruption to function as a fast special wallbreaker and late-game cleaner. Choice Scarf is the most popular item, letting it outpace and OHKO much of the metagame, while Life Orb gives it the freedom to switch moves and bluff sets. Tera Fire boosts STAB to nuclear levels, whereas Tera Ghost grants a crucial immunity to Fake Out and Extreme Speed while blocking Rage Powder redirection. Flash Fire is the preferred ability, turning opposing Heat Waves and Incineroar’s Flare Blitz into free Sp. Atk boosts that can snowball games. Modest and Timid natures are almost equally common, trading a small amount of speed for a meaningful power jump. The most common partners—Whimsicott, Dragapult, Basculegion, Rillaboom, Zoroark-Hisui and Corviknight—form offensive cores that either set speed control, break shared checks, or cover Typhlosion’s Rock/Water weaknesses.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Typhlosion": {"Abilities": {"flashfire": 1.435081191426139, "blaze": 0.16224316467118993}, "Items": {"lifeorb": 0.2577676990846471, "choicescarf": 0.43591585408838757}, "Spreads": {"Modest:4/0/0/252/0/252": 0.16732664315603696, "Modest:0/0/0/252/4/252": 0.26276074889544815, "Timid:4/0/0/252/0/252": 0.15996727743743258, "Timid:0/0/0/252/0/252": 0.240066973217574}, "Moves": ["eruption", "flamethrower", "heatwave", "scorchingsands"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.3091557770128174, "fire": 0.557223958061351}, "Teammates": ["Whimsicott", "Dragapult", "Basculegion", "Rillaboom", "Zoroark-Hisui", "Corviknight"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Typhlosion’s niche in VGC 2025 rests almost entirely on Eruption: a 150 BP spread move that remains at full power if Typhlosion enters the field at full HP. With base 100 Speed and a 252 EV investment, Timid Scarf sets hit 187 Speed—outspeeding +1 Kingambit, Flutter Mane, and every unboosted non-Scarf threat in the format. Modest variants trade the ability to beat opposing base 100 Scarfers for a 10% damage bump, securing guaranteed OHKOs on bulky Rotom-W and 2HKOs on Assault Vest Garganacl. Life Orb sets forgo the speed tier but gain the ability to alternate between Eruption, Heat Wave, and Scorching Sands, the latter offering a 30% burn chance that punishes Garganacl, Gastrodon and Iron Treads switch-ins. Flash Fire is taken on 90% of teams because it flips the Incineroar matchup: a predicted Flare Blitz turns Typhlosion into a +1 monster that can OHKO the fox back with its own Fire move. Tera Fire is the safe option, pushing Eruption past 200 BP after STAB and guaranteeing KOs on neutral targets up to 140/140 bulk. Tera Ghost is the high-risk/high-reward pick: it blocks Fake Out from Meowscarada and Indeedee, ignores Extreme Speed revenge attempts, and turns Dragapult’s Shadow Ball into an immunity, but leaves Typhlosion weak to common Knock Off and Sucker Punch. EV spreads are binary—max Speed and max Special Attack—because every point of bulk sacrificed translates directly into Eruption damage lost. The only deviation is four EVs dropped into either HP or SpD to manipulate Download and opposing Gyro Ball damage.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Typhlosion": {"Abilities": {"flashfire": 1.435081191426139, "blaze": 0.16224316467118993}, "Items": {"lifeorb": 0.2577676990846471, "choicescarf": 0.43591585408838757}, "Spreads": {"Modest:4/0/0/252/0/252": 0.16732664315603696, "Modest:0/0/0/252/4/252": 0.26276074889544815, "Timid:4/0/0/252/0/252": 0.15996727743743258, "Timid:0/0/0/252/0/252": 0.240066973217574}, "Moves": ["eruption", "flamethrower", "heatwave", "scorchingsands"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.3091557770128174, "fire": 0.557223958061351}, "Teammates": ["Whimsicott", "Dragapult", "Basculegion", "Rillaboom", "Zoroark-Hisui", "Corviknight"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Typhlosion dominates matchups against Grass, Steel and Ice teams, blowing past Amoonguss, Toxapex, Gholdengo and bulky Armarouge cores with spread damage. It pressures Sun and Rain equally: Sun teams hate Scorching Sands burns on Torkoal and Tera Fire Overheat rolls, while Rain teams struggle to stomach a full-power Eruption even through Pelliper’s drizzle. Against Trick Room, Typhlosion is a mixed bag: it can OHKO most setters on the first turn, but if Trick Room goes up it becomes dead weight unless it Terastallizes to Ghost to block Fake Out and survive Rage Powder. Opposing Fire-types are skill-tests: Flash Fire rewards prediction, but losing the mind-game versus Heatran or opposing Typhlosion can backfire spectacularly. Rock and Water types—especially Chien-Pao, Barraskewda and Stone Edge Garchomp—are hard counters, forcing Typhlosion to either switch or Tera on the predicted attack. Priority is the biggest hurdle: Basculegion’s Aqua Jet, Kingambit’s Sucker Punch and Dragonite’s Extreme Speed all KO after meager chip, so preserving Typhlosion’s HP and speed control is paramount.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Typhlosion": {"Abilities": {"flashfire": 1.435081191426139, "blaze": 0.16224316467118993}, "Items": {"lifeorb": 0.2577676990846471, "choicescarf": 0.43591585408838757}, "Spreads": {"Modest:4/0/0/252/0/252": 0.16732664315603696, "Modest:0/0/0/252/4/252": 0.26276074889544815, "Timid:4/0/0/252/0/252": 0.15996727743743258, "Timid:0/0/0/252/0/252": 0.240066973217574}, "Moves": ["eruption", "flamethrower", "heatwave", "scorchingsands"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.3091557770128174, "fire": 0.557223958061351}, "Teammates": ["Whimsicott", "Dragapult", "Basculegion", "Rillaboom", "Zoroark-Hisui", "Corviknight"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Typhlosion is a lead, mid-game pivot or late-game cleaner depending on item choice and team composition. Choice Scarf variants are classic leads that threaten immediate spread damage and force Protects, creating 2-on-1 turns for partners such as Whimsicott or Dragapult. Life Orb three-attack sets act as wallbreakers that soften checks early and still retain the option to sweep once Water- and Rock-types are removed. Because Eruption’s damage scales directly with remaining HP, Typhlosion must be kept above 75% to maintain its strongest output; consequently it dislikes hazards, chip and priority. Its role is therefore not just to attack but to condition the opponent: every Fire move they use risks a Flash Fire boost, every Protect risks a partner’s spread move, and every switch grants momentum to teammates such as Rillaboom or Corviknight that can reset terrain or set Tailwind.</OUTPUT>
