<DATA>{"Typhlosion": {"Abilities": {"flashfire": 1.435081191426139, "blaze": 0.16224316467118993}, "Items": {"lifeorb": 0.2577676990846471, "choicescarf": 0.43591585408838757}, "Spreads": {"Modest:4/0/0/252/0/252": 0.16732664315603696, "Modest:0/0/0/252/4/252": 0.26276074889544815, "Timid:4/0/0/252/0/252": 0.15996727743743258, "Timid:0/0/0/252/0/252": 0.240066973217574}, "Moves": ["eruption", "flamethrower", "heatwave", "scorchingsands"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.3091557770128174, "fire": 0.557223958061351}, "Teammates": ["Whimsicott", "Dragapult", "Basculegion", "Rillaboom", "Zoroark-Hisui", "Corviknight"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Whimsicott @ Focus Sash, Timid, Tailwind / Moonblast / Endeavor / Protect. Typhlosion @ Choice Scarf, Timid, Eruption / Heat Wave / Scorching Sands / Protect. Dragapult @ Life Orb, Modest, Shadow Ball / Thunderbolt / Draco Meteor / Protect. Basculegion-M @ Choice Band, Adamant, Aqua Jet / Wave Crash / Shadow Claw / Protect. Rillaboom @ Assault Vest, Adamant, Grassy Glide / Wood Hammer / U-turn / Knock Off. Corviknight @ Leftovers, Impish, Tailwind / Iron Head / Body Press / U-turn. The idea is to lead Whimsicott + Typhlosion: Tailwind turn one, then Eruption plus spread pressure. If the opponent leads Rock or Water, swap to Basculegion or Rillaboom to absorb hits and retaliate. Mid-game, Dragapult and Corviknight reset Tailwind while Typhlosion cleans at >75% HP. Double Ghost Tera options punish Shadow Ball and Fake Out, while Rillaboom and Corviknight cover Water and Rock weaknesses. The team packs two Tailwind setters, priority, hazard removal and a FWG core, giving Typhlosion the support it needs to erupt the field.</OUTPUT>

input:
Produce the 'short_summary' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Rotom-Frost": {"Abilities": {"levitate": 1.4709659053401019}, "Items": {"choicespecs": 0.8042952860361906}, "Spreads": {"Modest:0/0/0/252/4/252": 0.7922647440597882}, "Moves": ["blizzard", "discharge", "voltswitch", "thunderbolt"], "Tera Types": {"electric": 0.8412488759670284}, "Teammates": ["Ninetales-Alola", "Incineroar", "Talonflame", "Garchomp", "Farigiraf", "Annihilape"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Rotom-Frost is a niche but dangerous offensive pivot in VGC 2025, leveraging its unique Ice/Electric typing, Levitate, and Choice Specs to fire off perfectly accurate Blizzards in hail while still pivoting with Volt Switch.  It is almost always seen Modest max SpA/Spe with Specs and Tera Electric, acting as a fast, hard-hitting special attacker that can break common Dragon/Ground cores and punish bulky Waters, but it absolutely requires hail (Ninetales-Alola) and Incineroar’s support to offset its fragility and awkward speed tier.</OUTPUT>

input:
Provide the 'full_analysis' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Rotom-Frost": {"Abilities": {"levitate": 1.4709659053401019}, "Items": {"choicespecs": 0.8042952860361906}, "Spreads": {"Modest:0/0/0/252/4/252": 0.7922647440597882}, "Moves": ["blizzard", "discharge", "voltswitch", "thunderbolt"], "Tera Types": {"electric": 0.8412488759670284}, "Teammates": ["Ninetales-Alola", "Incineroar", "Talonflame", "Garchomp", "Farigiraf", "Annihilape"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Rotom-Frost’s single biggest draw is 100% accurate Blizzard under hail, a spread move that OHKOs most non-tera’d Dragons, Landos, and Chomps while cleanly 2HKOing bulkier neutral targets like Incineroar and Annihilape.  STAB Thunderbolt and Discharge give it perfect neutral coverage alongside Blizzard; Discharge is preferred in doubles to fish for para-spread while still chunking Corviknight and bulky Waters.  Volt Switch lets it maintain offensive momentum and escape from the dangerous Dragons it baits in, while also forming a slow VoltTurn core with Incineroar.  Levitate is irreplaceable—turning the usual Rotom-Wash Ground weakness into an immunity—so it can safely switch into Earthquakes from Garchomp or Lando and immediately threaten back.  Tera Electric is the only realistic option: it boosts both STABs, makes Volt Switch hit harder, and removes the Ice typing’s Stealth Rock weakness in BO3.  The EV spread is pure max/max Modest because the extra power is essential to secure KOs on 252/0 Garchomp and 252/0 Dragonite after hail damage.  Rotom-Frost’s shortcomings are equally stark: 86 base Speed is a hair below the crowded 90-95 tier, meaning it loses the mirror to Rotom-Wash and is outsped by +1 Dragonite, while 50/107/107 bulk is merely okay, leaving it vulnerable to strong neutral hits such as Specs Dragapult’s Draco or Life Orb Chomp’s Tera Dragon Outrage.  It is also a four-moveslot mon: without Protect it hates Fake Out and priority, and without Will-O-Wisp it can’t cripple physical set-up sweepers.  Finally, it is completely dependent on hail; if Ninetales is KOed or if the opponent sets sun, Rotom-Frost’s accuracy and damage output plummet.  In practice it functions as a hit-and-run breaker that removes or heavily dents the opponent’s Grounds and Dragons so teammates such as Annihilape, Garchomp, or Talonflame can clean late-game.</OUTPUT>

input:
Provide the 'matchup_overview' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Rotom-Frost": {"Abilities": {"levitate": 1.4709659053401019}, "Items": {"choicespecs": 0.8042952860361906}, "Spreads": {"Modest:0/0/0/252/4/252": 0.7922647440597882}, "Moves": ["blizzard", "discharge", "voltswitch", "thunderbolt"], "Tera Types": {"electric": 0.8412488759670284}, "Teammates": ["Ninetales-Alola", "Incineroar", "Talonflame", "Garchomp", "Farigiraf", "Annihilape"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Rotom-Frost dominates most Dragon-, Ground-, and Water-heavy teams, ripping through Garchomp, Lando-T, Dragonite, Kingdra, and bulky Pelipper.  It also pressures common Steel birds (Corviknight, Skarmory) that rely on Ground immunities.  Conversely, it folds to faster special attackers—Dragapult, Iron Valiant, Meowscarada—and to sun or sand teams that remove its hail accuracy.  Priority users such as Dragonite ExtremeSpeed, Bisharp Sucker Punch, or Kingambit Sucker can finish it after chip.  Tera Fire Garchomp or Tera Steel Corviknight can stomach a Blizzard and retaliate, while Assault Vest Tyranitar lives two Thunderbolts and OHKOs back with Rock Slide.  Opposing Rotom-Wash is a nightmare: it ignores Levitate, tanks Blizzards, and KOs with Hydro Pump or Overheat.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Rotom-Frost": {"Abilities": {"levitate": 1.4709659053401019}, "Items": {"choicespecs": 0.8042952860361906}, "Spreads": {"Modest:0/0/0/252/4/252": 0.7922647440597882}, "Moves": ["blizzard", "discharge", "voltswitch", "thunderbolt"], "Tera Types": {"electric": 0.8412488759670284}, "Teammates": ["Ninetales-Alola", "Incineroar", "Talonflame", "Garchomp", "Farigiraf", "Annihilape"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Rotom-Frost is a fast special attacker and offensive pivot whose primary job is to delete opposing Ground and Dragon threats under hail, then pivot out with Volt Switch to bring in a teammate safely.  It doubles as a spread damage dealer (Blizzard/Discharge) and a momentum engine, forming the special half of a slow VoltTurn core with Incineroar.  Because it lacks Protect and is Choice-locked, it is best used as an early- to mid-game breaker rather than a win-condition, relying on hail chip and partner redirection (Farigiraf) or intimidate cycling (Incineroar/Talonflame) to stay on the field.</OUTPUT>

input:
Draft the 'synergy_breakdown' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Rotom-Frost": {"Abilities": {"levitate": 1.4709659053401019}, "Items": {"choicespecs": 0.8042952860361906}, "Spreads": {"Modest:0/0/0/252/4/252": 0.7922647440597882}, "Moves": ["blizzard", "discharge", "voltswitch", "thunderbolt"], "Tera Types": {"electric": 0.8412488759670284}, "Teammates": ["Ninetales-Alola", "Incineroar", "Talonflame", "Garchomp", "Farigiraf", "Annihilape"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Ninetales-Alola is mandatory: it sets hail for perfect Blizzard accuracy, provides Aurora Veil to patch Rotom’s bulk, and itself threatens opposing weather setters with Freeze-Dry.  Incineroar is equally critical—Intimidate + Parting Shot lets Rotom survive physical hits and gain free switch-ins, while Fake Out and U-turn complete the slow pivot loop.  Talonflame offers Tailwind to fix Rotom’s speed tier, and priority Brave Bird to pick off weakened Dragons.  Garchomp covers Rotom’s Electric weakness and punishes opposing Ice-types with STAB Earthquake, while Rotom removes bulky Waters for Garchomp.  Farigiraf supplies Indeedee-style redirection, blocking priority and giving Rotom free turns to click Blizzard.  Annihilape appreciates Rotom’s ability to KO Ghost-resistant Dragons and provides a win-condition once the opponent’s Flying-types are chipped.  In return Rotom pressures Psychic- and Ghost-types that trouble Annihilape.</OUTPUT>

Blizzard is the main button under hail, Thunderbolt is reliable single-target Electric STAB, Discharge is spread with para chance, and Volt Switch gains momentum. Tera Electric is mandatory for power and to keep STAB on both attacking types.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Rotom-Frost": {"Abilities": {"levitate": 1.4709659053401019}, "Items": {"choicespecs": 0.8042952860361906}, "Spreads": {"Modest:0/0/0/252/4/252": 0.7922647440597882}, "Moves": ["blizzard", "discharge", "voltswitch", "thunderbolt"], "Tera Types": {"electric": 0.8412488759670284}, "Teammates": ["Ninetales-Alola", "Incineroar", "Talonflame", "Garchomp", "Farigiraf", "Annihilape"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Rotom-Frost’s Ice typing leaves it 4× weak to Rock and 2× weak to Fire and Fighting—Talonflame Flare Blitz, Iron Valiant Close Combat, and Tyranitar Rock Slide all OHKO.  Its Levitate-boosted Ground immunity is nullified by Mold Breaker Excadrill or Iron Thorns, both of which outspeed and KO with Rock Slide.  Choice-locking means any healthy Fire- or Rock-type can come in for free once the move is revealed; sun teams (Torkoal + Lilligant) erase hail and force 70% Blizzards.  Priority is deadly: Dragonite ExtremeSpeed, Bisharp Sucker Punch, and Kingambit Sucker Punch all finish Rotom after slight chip.  Finally, Rotom-Frost hates residual damage—no Protect means it can’t stall hail turns, and Stealth Rock in BO3 strips 50% on switch-in if it ever Tera-blasts away the Ice typing.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Yanma is a niche but surprisingly effective support option in VGC, leveraging its blazing 95 base Speed, Compound Eyes, and a unique movepool to set Tailwind and fish for Hypnosis turns while holding Focus Sash or Eviolite; nearly every serious build runs Timid max Speed, Tera Ghost to block Fake Out and Extreme Speed, and slots into bulky offense or rain-style squads that already feature Garchomp, Dragonite, Kingambit, Gholdengo, Alolan-Ninetales, and Amoonguss.</OUTPUT>

input:
Provide the 'full_analysis' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Yanma": {"Abilities": {"compoundeyes": 1.3468322212032913, "speedboost": 0.0007585826818992669}, "Items": {"focussash": 0.7096622468537612, "eviolite": 0.28319937420863744}, "Spreads": {"Timid:4/0/0/252/0/252": 0.27905278780668263, "Timid:4/0/0/0/252/252": 0.2963439082391672, "Calm:244/0/0/12/252/0": 0.28263642116088494}, "Moves": ["tailwind", "hypnosis", "protect", "screech"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.990896421404003}, "Teammates": ["Garchomp", "Dragonite", "Kingambit", "Gholdengo", "Ninetales-Alola", "Amoonguss"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Although Yanma’s offensive stats are unimpressive, its 95 Speed tier outpaces the crowded base-90 metagame, letting it fire off a guaranteed Tailwind before most threats move. Compound Eyes pushes Hypnosis to 78 % accuracy, turning Yanma into a high-risk, high-reward disrupter that can neuter a Dynamax target or lock a restricteds slot for two turns. The prevalence of Focus Sash (≈71 %) shows players value the guaranteed one-time survival to get both Tailwind and a Hypnosis attempt; Eviolite (≈28 %) is preferred on bulkier variants that aim to pivot repeatedly with Protect and Screech, stripping 2 stages of Defense so partners such as Kingambit or Garchomp can secure OHKOs without committing Tera or Dynamax. Tera Ghost is virtually omnipresent (≈99 %) because it nullifies Fake Out, Extreme Speed, and Sucker Punch, the three most common forms of priority that would otherwise pick off the frail bug before it acts. EV spreads are almost evenly split between hyper-speed Timid 252/0/0/0/252/4 and a Calm 244/0/0/12/252/0 spread that survives modest Heat Wave or Moonblast while retaining enough Speed to outrun +1 Kingdra under Tailwind. The combination of Tailwind + Hypnosis is irreplaceable: no other Tailwind setter bar Whimsicott gets a 78 % accurate sleep move, and no other sleep inducer except maybe Butterfree also sets up speed control, giving Yanma a genuinely unique niche on teams that prize tempo over raw power. Its typing grants a handy resistance to Ground and Fighting, useful for pivoting against Garchomp or Iron Hands, while the 4x Flying weakness is largely academic because Yanma’s goal is to support rather than wall. In practice, Yanma functions as a lead on 70 % of games and as a mid-game pivot in the rest, using Protect to waste Dynamax turns once Tailwind is up and fishing for clutch Hypnosis hits to flip momentum.</OUTPUT>

input:
Write the 'matchup_overview' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Yanma": {"Abilities": {"compoundeyes": 1.3468322212032913, "speedboost": 0.0007585826818992669}, "Items": {"focussash": 0.7096622468537612, "eviolite": 0.28319937420863744}, "Spreads": {"Timid:4/0/0/252/0/252": 0.27905278780668263, "Timid:4/0/0/0/252/252": 0.2963439082391672, "Calm:244/0/0/12/252/0": 0.28263642116088494}, "Moves": ["tailwind", "hypnosis", "protect", "screech"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.990896421404003}, "Teammates": ["Garchomp", "Dragonite", "Kingambit", "Gholdengo", "Ninetales-Alola", "Amoonguss"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Yanma loves facing bulky offense and mid-speed cores that rely on single-target Dynamax sweepers such as Garchomp, Dragonite, or Iron Hands; a first-turn Tailwing immediately flips the speed war, while Hypnosis or Screech can cripple the opposing Dynamax before it snowballs. It struggles most against hyper-offense teams carrying two forms of priority or faster Taunt users like Meowscarada or Chien-Pao, which can KO or shut Yanma down before it moves. Opposing weather teams—especially rain with Pelipper’s Tailwind or sun with Torkoal’s Eruption—can also pressure Yanma because their speed control nullifies Yanma’s primary niche, forcing it to land an early Hypnosis or become dead weight. Electric and Rock coverage from Rotom-W, Tyranitar, or Iron Thorns is problematic: Yanma’s Flying typing invites Rock Slide flinches and Volt Switch chip, and even Eviolite variants fold to strong Electric STAB. Finally, Safety Goggles or Grass-types such as Amoonguss completely blank Hypnosis, turning Yanma into a one-move Tailwind bot that must rely on Screech and pivoting to stay relevant.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Yanma is a dedicated speed-control and disruption lead whose job is to (1) guarantee Tailwind for its powerful but merely above-average-speed teammates, (2) roll the dice with Compound-Eyes Hypnosis to remove a threat for two-to-four turns, and (3) use Screech or Protect to waste Dynamax turns or enable partner knock-outs. It never aims to sweep; instead, it compresses the roles of Tailwind setter, sleep inducer, and pivot into one slot, freeing teammates to run bulkier or more offensive sets without compromising momentum.</OUTPUT>

input:

<DATA>{"Yanma": {"Abilities": {"compoundeyes": 1.3468322212032913, "speedboost": 0.0007585826818992669}, "Items": {"focussash": 0.7096622468537612, "eviolite": 0.28319937420863744}, "Spreads": {"Timid:4/0/0/252/0/252": 0.27905278780668263, "Timid:4/0/0/0/252/252": 0.2963439082391672, "Calm:244/0/0/12/252/0": 0.28263642116088494}, "Moves": ["tailwind", "hypnosis", "protect", "screech"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.990896421404003}, "Teammates": ["Garchomp", "Dragonite", "Kingambit", "Gholdengo", "Ninetales-Alola", "Amoonguss"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Garchomp and Dragonite appreciate Tailwind immensely, turning their middling 102/80 Speed into guaranteed first strikes while also resisting Rock and Electric for Yanma. Kingambit benefits doubly: Tailwind lets it outrun and KO faster threats, while Screech guarantees OHKOs with Sucker Punch or Kowtow Cleave. Gholdengo blocks opposing status and spreads hazard chip, freeing Yanma from worrying about opposing screens or Spore, and it returns the favor by beating opposing Steel-types that threaten Yanma. Alolan-Ninetales sets Aurora Veil, compensating for Yanma’s frailty and giving it a second chance to click Hypnosis even after Sash is broken; in return, Yanma’s Tailwind lets Ninetales and its Blizzard partners move first outside of hail. Amoonguss forms a classic “Bug-Grass” core: Rage Powder redirects Rock Slides and Thunder Waves away from Yanma, while Yanma’s Hypnosis can sleep a threat that breaks through Amoonguss’s redirection, creating a layered status-disruption blanket that stalls opposing Dynamax turns.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Yanma": {"Abilities": {"compoundeyes": 1.3468322212032913, "speedboost": 0.0007585826818992669}, "Items": {"focussash": 0.7096622468537612, "eviolite": 0.28319937420863744}, "Spreads": {"Timid:4/0/0/252/0/252": 0.27905278780668263, "Timid:4/0/0/0/252/252": 0.2963439082391672, "Calm:244/0/0/12/252/0": 0.28263642116088494}, "Moves": ["tailwind", "hypnosis", "protect", "screech"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.990896421404003}, "Teammates": ["Garchomp", "Dragonite", "Kingambit", "Gholdengo", "Ninetales-Alola", "Amoonguss"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Faster Taunt users—Meowscarada, Chien-Pao, or Iron Jugulis—shut Yanma down entirely, leaving it a sitting duck. Priority from Kingambit’s Sucker Punch or Dragonite’s Extreme Speed will break Sash and KO if Yanma has already taken any chip; Tera Ghost helps, but opposing Tera Dark or Tera Normal can still punch through. Rock Slide flinch spam from Tyranitar, Lycanroc, or Iron Thorns punishes Yanma’s Flying typing and can bypass Protect via wide-target damage. Safety Goggles on common threats like Amoonguss, Iron Hands, or opposing Dragonite completely blanks Hypnosis, turning Yanma into a one-trick Tailwind setter. Finally, opposing weather speed control—Pelipper rain or Torkoal sun—negates Yanma’s primary niche, forcing it to gamble on a 78 % Hypnosis or become momentum deadweight. In short, if you deny Yanma’s first two turns—via Taunt, priority, flinch, or simply outspeeding under your own Tailwind—it folds and its teammates lose their speed advantage.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Build a bulky-offense core around Yanma’s Tailwind + Hypnosis: Yanma (Timid Focus Sash) + Garchomp (Life Orb Swords Dance) + Kingambit (Black Glasses Sucker) + Gholdengo (Choice Specs Make It Rain) + Alolan-Ninetales (Light Clay Aurora Veil) + Amoonguss (Black Sludge Rage Powder). <DATA>{"Pyroar": {"Abilities": {"rivalry": 0.021975240590847822, "unnerve": 1.3250538713864832, "moxie": 0.0022092310776912205}, "Items": {"choicespecs": 0.647801773514058, "lifeorb": 0.3332534398706316}, "Spreads": {"Timid:4/0/0/252/0/252": 0.9953835595925741}, "Moves": ["hypervoice", "heatwave", "overheat", "hyperbeam"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.3033590789888854, "normal": 0.6478956810040891}, "Teammates": ["Amoonguss", "Gholdengo", "Empoleon", "Indeedee", "Kommo-o", "Drifblim"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Pyroar’s attacking stat of 109 SpA is merely decent, but Choice Specs turns its perfectly accurate, spread-based STABs into legitimate breakers: Hyper Voice cleanly 2HKOs neutral targets like 252 HP Garganacl and has a 75% chance to OHKO 4 HP Gholdengo after spread reduction, while Heat Wave secures the KO on bulky Amoonguss and deals ~70% to Assault Vest Azumarill. Overheat is the emergency button to nuke Steel-types that try to switch in, though the SpA drop forces an immediate pivot. Hyper Beam is almost exclusively a Tera Normal nuke that deletes weakened Dynamax or Terra'd threats, but leaves Pyroar helpless next turn. Timid 252/252 spread is non-negotiable to speed-tie opposing base 100s and outrun Jolly Chien-Pao; the remaining 4 EVs are dumped in HP to slightly improve bulk. Unnerve is the preferred ability because denying Sitrus or Chesto Berry can flip mirror matchups versus Ting-Lu or Iron Hands, while Rivalry is a marginal damage increase only versus same-gendered foes. Tera Ghost is the most common option, granting immunity to Fake Out, Extreme Speed, and Shadow Ball—crucial for keeping Pyroar on the field after a KO so Moxie can trigger. Tera Normal boosts Hyper Voice to ludicrous levels, turning it into a 117 BP spread move that can OHKO neutral Dynamax targets after Intimidate or Reflect. Life Orb is a less popular but still viable item that trades raw power for the freedom to switch moves, useful on pivot-heavy teams that rely on Parting Shot or Tailwind cycling.</OUTPUT>

It pressures common support leads like Indeedee-F and weaker variants of Iron Hands, but folds to faster offensive threats such as Chien-Pao, Dragapult, and Iron Valiant, all of which OHKO with super-effective STAB. Priority users like Kingambit and Dragonite can pick off weakened Pyroar, so it appreciates partners that can block or redirect Sucker Punch and Extreme Speed. Terrain wars matter: Psychic Terrain from Indeedee blocks priority for both sides, letting Pyroar fire off Hyper Voice safely, while opposing Electric Terrain boosts opposing Thunderbolts that KO. Rain teams with Pelipper and Barraskewda are problematic because Swift Swim outspeeds and Hydro Steam or Wave crashes KO, whereas Sun teams can flip the script by weakening Pyroar's Heat Wave while boosting opposing Fire moves. Overall, Pyroar is at its best versus mid-speed balance squads that lack dedicated special walls or Tailwind, and at its worst versus hyper-offense or Tailwind HO that can pressure it before it moves.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Masquerain carves a niche in VGC as a frail but fast Intimidate pivot that compresses Tailwind speed control, STAB Air Slash flinches, and coverage Ice Beam into a single slot. While its offenses are modest, the combination of Intimidate, 252+ Speed EVs (outspeeding +1 Roaring Moon), and Tera Steel to dodge Rock- and Ice-type onslaughts lets it swing momentum early and set Tailwind for powerful teammates such as Coalossal and Volcarona. Focus Sash is the default to guarantee at least one turn of field control, but Choice Scarf variants trade longevity for immediate revenge-killing power and surprise factor.</OUTPUT>

input:
Write a detailed 'full_analysis' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Masquerain": {"Abilities": {"intimidate": 1.3625956632066776}, "Items": {"focussash": 0.47592330808198763, "choicescarf": 0.37968689463698074}, "Spreads": {"Timid:0/0/0/252/4/252": 0.31010630840076864, "Timid:4/0/0/252/0/252": 0.15091413444174573, "Modest:0/0/0/252/4/252": 0.15953119942446542}, "Moves": ["bugbuzz", "tailwind", "icebeam", "airslash"], "Tera Types": {"steel": 0.4775978673110212, "ghost": 0.1697166098481756}, "Teammates": ["Incineroar", "Coalossal", "Volcarona", "Basculegion-F", "Oricorio-Sensu", "Murkrow"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Masquerain’s stat line is unimpressive on paper, yet its unique movepool and ability give it a perfect storm of support traits. Intimidate immediately cripples physical attackers, buying turns against titans like Chien-Pao, Kingambit, and opposing Incineroar. From there it can click Tailwind, turning its average 80 base Speed into a team-wide 4-turn speed advantage that faster threats such as Iron Bundle or Choice Scarf Gholdengo cannot ignore. Bug Buzz and Air Slash provide reliable STAB, the latter’s 30% flinch chance punishing slower or paralyzed targets. Ice Beam is the obligatory coverage slot, nailing the omnipresent Dragon- and Flying-types—most notably Dragapult, Tatsugiri, and the mirror versus opposing Masquerain. Tera Steel is overwhelmingly preferred, removing the 4× Rock weakness, granting crucial resistances to Ice-, Fairy-, and Dragon-type moves, and allowing Masquerain to survive a leading Flutter Mane Moonblast or a Chien-Po Ice Spinner. Ghost Tera sees niche use to block Extreme Speed and Fake Out, but Steel’s defensive value is simply more consistent. EV spreads are polarized around maximum Speed and Special Attack: Timid guarantees the jump on neutral-nature base 110s, while Modest trades a slight speed tier for a tangible uptick in damage that secures the OHKO on 4 HP Tatsugiri with Ice Beam. Focus Sash usage sits just under 48%, giving Masquerain a guaranteed turn against hyper-offense leads; the 38% Choice Scarf share instead aims to speed-tie or outspeed +1 Roaring Moon and scarfed Gholdengo, functioning as a surprise revenge killer and late-game cleaner. The remainder run defensive items like Charti Berry or Safety Goggles, but these are statistically fringe.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Masquerain": {"Abilities": {"intimidate": 1.3625956632066776}, "Items": {"focussash": 0.47592330808198763, "choicescarf": 0.37968689463698074}, "Spreads": {"Timid:0/0/0/252/4/252": 0.31010630840076864, "Timid:4/0/0/252/0/252": 0.15091413444174573, "Modest:0/0/0/252/4/252": 0.15953119942446542}, "Moves": ["bugbuzz", "tailwind", "icebeam", "airslash"], "Tera Types": {"steel": 0.4775978673110212, "ghost": 0.1697166098481756}, "Teammates": ["Incineroar", "Coalossal", "Volcarona", "Basculegion-F", "Oricorio-Sensu", "Murkrow"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Masquerain enjoys positive momentum against physical-centric cores that rely on Intimidate-weak attackers—most Sun and Rain archetypes featuring Lilligant, Slither Wing, or Barraskewda appreciate the Speed control and Attack drops. It also pressures slower Tailwind setters like Murkrow and Tornadus by outrunning and KOing with STAB moves. Conversely, it struggles into priority-heavy teams: Sucker Punch from Kingambit or Chien-Pao bypasses both its sash and its Speed, while Fake Out from Meowscarada or Indeedee can deny Tailwind. Special attackers in general—particularly Iron Bundle, Flutter Mane, and Gholdengo—can OHKO through Focus Sash with Ice Beam/Shadow Ball/Make It Rain before Masquerain can retaliate. Rock Slide users such as Tyranitar and Lycanroc threaten the 4× weakness pre-Tera, and spread moves like Discharge or Dazzling Gleam can break sash and KO partner Pokémon simultaneously.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Masquerain": {"Abilities": {"intimidate": 1.3625956632066776}, "Items": {"focussash": 0.47592330808198763, "choicescarf": 0.37968689463698074}, "Spreads": {"Timid:0/0/0/252/4/252": 0.31010630840076864, "Timid:4/0/0/252/0/252": 0.15091413444174573, "Modest:0/0/0/252/4/252": 0.15953119942446542}, "Moves": ["bugbuzz", "tailwind", "icebeam", "airslash"], "Tera Types": {"steel": 0.4775978673110212, "ghost": 0.1697166098481756}, "Teammates": ["Incineroar", "Coalossal", "Volcarona", "Basculegion-F", "Oricorio-Sensu", "Murkrow"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Masquerain is a hybrid speed-control pivot: it enters, drops the opponent’s Attack, and immediately establishes Tailwind to enable faster sweepers. Once Tailwind is up, it pivots into a secondary role of chip damage and flinch pressure with Air Slash, while picking off weakened threats with Bug Buzz or Ice Beam. Because it is neither bulky nor overwhelmingly powerful, its ideal game plan is to trade itself for board positioning—either by forcing double-targets that free its partner to set up, or by surviving via Focus Sash to fire off two attacks. In the mid-game it can re-field Tailwind if protected, and in the late-game a Tera-Steel Air Slash can flinch slower foes to clinch games.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Ambipom carves a niche in VGC as a lightning-fast Fake Out support that abuses Technician-boosted multi-hit moves. With 115 base Speed it outspeeds the crowded base-110 tier, letting it fire priority Fake Out before most opposing Incineroar or Rillaboom can pivot. Nearly 70% of players run the max-speed Jolly spread, underscoring its role as a momentum grabber rather than a tank. Normal Gem or Silk Scarf amplify its STAB Double Hit and Triple Axel (which becomes a 3-hit 75 bp move with Technician), while Focus Sash guarantees it survives to click Fake Out at least twice in a match. Tera Normal provides a 2× STAB boost on its strongest attacks, while Tera Ghost removes its Fighting weakness and lets it spam unresisted Fake Outs on Ghost-types.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Ambipom’s value lies in compressing speed control, chip damage, and disruption into one slot. Technician turns Triple Axel into a 112.5 bp move that breaks Sashes and Substitutes, while Double Hit becomes a 105 bp spread option that ignores Disguise and Sturdy. Fake Out buys a free turn for setup sweepers like Archaludon or Annihilape, both of which appear on over 20% of Ambipom teams. The monkey’s 100/66/66 bulk is mediocre, so Focus Sash is the most common item (30%), followed by Silk Scarf (28%) for consistent damage and Normal Gem (17%) for a one-time nuke. Assault Vest sets (16%) sacrifice Fake Out re-use for surprise special bulk, letting it survive Moonblast from Flutter Mane and KO back. Tera Normal is the dominant choice (52%) because it strengthens every move in the moveset; the 31% who opt for Tera Ghost typically pair Ambipom with Ghost-weak teammates like Annihilape to flip a losing matchup. The listed moveset—Fake Out, Triple Axel, Protect, Double Hit—gives perfect neutral coverage, maximizes Technician abuse, and keeps Ambipom flexible between lead and rear positions.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Crabominable is a niche but explosive Trick Room attacker that leverages its unique Ice/Fighting typing and sky-high Attack to delete common threats in one shot. Life Orb sets with Brave nature are the clear standard, letting it outpace most stall cores under Trick Room while wielding dual 100% accurate, 100 BP STABs in Crabhammer and Ice Hammer. Tera Grass is the most popular option, flipping its Water and Grass matchups and giving it a pseudo-resistance to Rillaboom’s Grassy Glide, while Tera Water offers a safer route into Fire-types and Tera Fighting simply amplifies its already nuclear Close Combat. Hyper Cutter is the preferred ability to block Intimidate from Landorus-T and Arcanine, though Iron Fist enjoys a sizable usage share for the 1.2× boost to Ice Hammer and Upper Hand. The bear fits best on dedicated Trick Room squads that can keep the field up for two to three turns, and its four-moveslot syndrome means it almost always runs the same four attacks, making it predictable but brutally efficient.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Crabominable": {"Abilities": {"hypercutter": 0.6679446994594556, "ironfist": 0.4608373409729562, "angerpoint": 0.0008783572204247303}, "Items": {"lifeorb": 0.6568556705408295, "assaultvest": 0.23377663127746284}, "Spreads": {"Brave:252/252/0/0/4/0": 0.5302862674173121, "Adamant:116/252/140/0/0/0": 0.16199020416377014, "Adamant:228/252/0/0/28/0": 0.17887030513317717}, "Moves": ["crabhammer", "icehammer", "closecombat", "upperhand"], "Tera Types": {"water": 0.22873108468606437, "fighting": 0.18044406277864472, "grass": 0.48771011797007296}, "Teammates": ["Torkoal", "Annihilape", "Ursaluna-Bloodmoon", "Farigiraf", "Rillaboom", "Typhlosion-Hisui"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Crabominable’s stat-line is min-maxed for one purpose: deleting whatever is in front of it under Trick Room. 403 Attack (Brave + Life Orb) is enough to OHKO 252 HP Gholdengo through Tera Steel with Tera Fighting Close Combat, and 404 HP / 156 Def with Assault Vest lets it survive a Jolly Landorus-T Earth Power or a modest Iron Moth Heat Wave. The two most common spreads are max/max Brave for pure power and a bulkier Adamant 228/252/28 spread that lives Choice Band Chien-Pao Ice Spinner after Tera Grass. Ice/Fighting is historically an awkward defensive typing, but in the current meta it nails the omnipresent Dragon, Flying, Grass and Steel cores while only fearing the rare Psychic or Fairy move. Tera Grass is the standout Tera type, removing the Water weakness and giving Crabominable a crucial resistance to Rillish-Grassy Glide and Kingambit’s Sacred Sword. Tera Water is next, turning the Fire and Water matchups on their head and letting Crabominable stay in on Heatran or Volcanion and retaliate with Crabhammer. The choice of ability is surprisingly impactful: Hyper Cutter blocks Incineroar and Landorus-T intimidate cycles, preserving its two-shot damage tier, while Iron Fist pushes Ice Hammer into guaranteed OHKO territory on 252 HP Dragonite through Tera Normal. Anger Point is essentially a meme, but in best-of-one it can steal games if Crabominable survives a critical hit. Four attacks is non-negotiable—Crabhammer and Ice Hammer are the most powerful reliable STABs in the format, Close Combat is mandatory for Steels, and Upper Hand is the best way to finish off weakened faster threats while gaining priority under Trick Room. Assault Vest sets trade a chunk of power for the ability to survive two hits from special attackers like Iron Moth or Choice Specs Dragapult, but the 30% damage loss is usually not worth the drop in KOs.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Crabominable’s matchup spread is polarized: it bulldozes most of the offensive meta but folds hard to faster Fairy, Psychic and Flying types outside Trick Room. Under Trick Room it claims positive matchups against every relevant Steel (except Aegislash), Grass, Dragon and Ground archetype, OHKOing Garchomp, Lando-T, Amoonguss, Rillaboom, Kingambit and Gholdengo. It also flips the Chien-Pao interaction, surviving Tera Dark Crunch and retaliating with Iron Fist Ice Hammer for the KO. The bear is neutral to Fire and Water, but Tera Grass makes it resist both, letting it beat Heatran, Volcanion and bulky Water Rotom variants one-on-one. Where Crabominable struggles is versus priority users and faster special attackers: Choice Specs Dragapult Shadow Ball, Tera Fairy Iron Valiant Spirit Break, and Tera Psychic Indeedee Expanding Force all OHKO before it moves. Outside Trick Room, Talonflame, Togekiss and Tera Flying Dragonite can all revenge kill it with Flare Blitz, Dazzling Gleam or Extreme Speed. Finally, Psychic Terrain teams that rely on priority-blocking Indeedee can stall out Trick Room turns and leave Crabominable exposed.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Crabominable is a hyper-offensive Trick Room win condition that needs exactly one turn of setup to begin dismantling cores. It is never brought to games without a dedicated setter—usually Torkoal for sunroom or Farigiraf for Mental Room—and is almost always paired with a second restricted attacker that can clean if the bear falls. Its job is to trade one-for-one versus the opponent’s fastest or bulkiest threat, then snowball through the mid-game with 100% accurate STABs that nothing short of a Tera Fairy resist can stomach. Because it lacks spread moves, Crabominable prefers to target single targets, making Follow Me or Ally Switch support valuable. Once Trick Room expires, its 43 Speed means it will still move before most stall cores, letting it act as a late-game cleaner with Upper Hand priority. In best-of-three, Crabominable is usually a game-two or game-three pick when the opponent reveals a Landorus-T, Gholdengo or Dragonite dependency, and it is equally effective as a lead or back-line closer depending on whether the opposing team carries Tailwind or priority.</OUTPUT>

Annihilape forms a Fighting-spam core, appreciating the removal of Flying and Psychic types that Crabominable baits in, while反过来 handling Ghosts that wall the bear. Ursaluna-Bloodmoon covers the special side, breaking bulky Waters and Steels so Crabominable can conserve HP. output: <OUTPUT>Faster Fairy and Psychic types are the hard stop: Tera Fairy Iron Valiant outspeeds and OHKOs with Spirit Break, while Choice Specs Indeedee and Hatterene vaporize it with Expanding Force or Mystical Fire before it moves. Outside Trick Room, priority users like Chien-Pao and Dragonite can pick it off with Ice Shard or Extreme Speed, though both need prior chip. Finally, Fake Out plus double-target focus fire is the most reliable way to remove it before Trick Room goes up; indeed, most successful teams pack a lead that can either Taunt the setter or KO Crabominable turn one with Helping Hand-boosted super-effective moves.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>SunRoom Bulldoze: Torkoal @ Heat Rock | Eruption / Flamethrower / Trick Room / Protect, Crabominable @ Life Orb | standard set, Ursaluna-Bloodmoon @ Choice Specs | Blood Moon / Earth Power / Hyper Voice / Protect, Farigiraf @ Mental Herb | Psychic / Shadow Ball / Trick Room / Protect, Rillaboom @ Assault Vest | Grassy Glide / Wood Hammer / Knock Off / Fake Out, Kingambit @ Focus Sash / Black Glasses | Iron Head / Sucker Punch / Kowtow / Protect. Lead Torkoal + Farigiraf versus offensive teams: set sun, block Fake Out with Mental Room, then pivot to Crabominable + Ursaluna on turn two. Versus stall, lead Rillaboom + Kingambit to pressure early, bring Crabominable in the back for late-game Trick Room. The team has two modes—sun offense and hard Trick Room—so you can tailor game one to the preview and sideboard accordingly in best-of-three. EV spreads are 0 Speed on both setters, min speed Ursaluna, and standard spreads on the others. The core idea is to overload the opponent with two win conditions that require different answers, while Crabominable serves as the explosive breaker that removes the shared checks.</OUTPUT>

Its EV spreads emphasize mixed bulk while outspeeding key threats like Timid Iron Moth or opposing base-95s, turning Primeape into a durable pivot that punishes Intimidate and Snarl cycles with Defiant and repeated Rage Fist boosts. <DATA>{"Primeape": {"Abilities": {"defiant": 0.17616226743350216, "angerpoint": 0.926919899757151, "vitalspirit": 7.794670866201336e-06}, "Items": {"eviolite": 0.9988629517039748}, "Spreads": {"Jolly:236/4/44/0/4/220": 0.18004491311552695, "Jolly:252/4/124/0/44/84": 0.3914545747955673}, "Moves": ["drainpunch", "ragefist", "protect", "earthquake"], "Tera Types": {"steel": 0.3305863771752963, "water": 0.4294042998544969}, "Teammates": ["Annihilape", "Rillaboom", "Smeargle", "Incineroar", "Archaludon", "Amoonguss"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Primeape’s viability hinges on Eviolite and Defiant: the item pushes its average bulk past the 70/70/70 threshold into respectable territory, while Defiant flips Intimidate or Parting Shot pressure into +2 Attack, immediately threatening KOs with a now 140 bp Rage Fist after one trigger. Drain Punch provides reliable recovery and a strong Fighting STAB that 2HKOs common Incineroar and Kingambit spreads. Earthquake hits Toxapex, Gholdengo, and Tera Poison targets that resist both STAB options. Protect is mandatory for double-up control, scouting Choice locks, and stalling Tailwind turns. The two dominant spreads illustrate Primeape’s flexibility: the 252/124/44 set maximizes overall bulk while creeping positive-nature base-90s, whereas the 236/44/220 spread sacrifices some bulk for a jump to 185 Speed, letting it outpace Timid Iron Moth and Adamant Chien-Pao. Jolly nature is universal because outspeeding the crowded base-95 and base-100 tiers is more valuable than a slight power bump. Tera Steel is preferred for the key resistances to Fairy, Flying, and opposing Rage Fist while keeping the crucial neutrality to Ground, but Tera Water is equally common to flip Fire and Water match-ups and remove the Electric weakness, notably surviving Zapdos’ Thunderbolts or Rotom-W’s Hydro Pumps. Primeape fits best on balanced or bulky offensive teams that appreciate a pivot capable of swinging momentum with Defiant, stacking chip with Rage Fist, and softening checks for bigger breakers such as Annihilape or Archaludon.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Against Fairy-centric squads Primeape struggles without Tera Steel, taking heavy damage from Sylveon Hyper Voice or Azumarill Play Rough; however, a timely Tera into Steel turns 2HKOs into 3HKOs and lets Primeape retaliate with boosted Rage Fist. Versus Sun, Primeape can survive Torkoal Eruption under Sun with Tera Water and KO back with Earthquake, though it must be wary of Tera Fire boosts. Opposing Tailwind or Trick Room teams force 50/50 Protect reads: Primeape can stall Tailwind turns but dislikes taking neutral Driftblim Shadow Balls or Hatterene Expanding Forces. Into Grass cores led by Rillaboom, Primeape threatens an OHKO with Drain Punch while shrugging off Glide, but Grassy Terrain weakens Earthquake, encouraging the Tera Water route to remove Fire weakness and keep consistent damage output. Electric terrain teams such as Pincurchin + Iron Thorns dislike Earthquake but can paralyze Primeape, so partners like Incineroar or Amoonguss are essential to redirect or clear status. Overall Primeape’s match-ups are matchup-dependent rather than lopsided, rewarding aggressive Defiant punishes and careful Tera timing.</OUTPUT>

Rillaboom provides priority Glide, breaks opposing Water- and Ground-types, and summons Grassy Terrain to soften Earthquake damage Primeape dishes to its own side. Archaludon appreciates Primeape removing Fire- and Ground-types and in return supplies Sticky Web or breaking potential Tera Fairy answers with Flash Cannon. Amoonguss rounds out the defensive backbone, redirecting with Rage Powder, putting opponents to sleep, and providing passive recovery that compounds with Drain Punch, allowing Primeape multiple setup cycles. The team archetype is a bulky pressure core that trades early, gains incremental advantages, and finishes with boosted Rage Fist or a second sweeper.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Primeape": {"Abilities": {"defiant": 0.17616226743350216, "angerpoint": 0.926919899757151, "vitalspirit": 7.794670866201336e-06}, "Items": {"eviolite": 0.9988629517039748}, "Spreads": {"Jolly:236/4/44/0/4/220": 0.18004491311552695, "Jolly:252/4/124/0/44/84": 0.3914545747955673}, "Moves": ["drainpunch", "ragefist", "protect", "earthquake"], "Tera Types": {"steel": 0.3305863771752963, "water": 0.4294042998544969}, "Teammates": ["Annihilape", "Rillaboom", "Smeargle", "Incineroar", "Archaludon", "Amoonguss"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Primeape’s biggest flaw is its middling base stats: even with Eviolite it folds to strong super-effective special attacks such as Specs Flutter Mane Moonblast or Life Orb Iron Valiant Spirit Break. Priority users like Bisharp or Kingambit can finish off a chipped Primeape with Sucker Punch before it boosts or heals. Ghost-types such as Aegislash or Dragapult immune Rage Fist force Primeape into Earthquake, which can be mitigated by Wide Guard or simply doubled into. Status, especially burn or paralysis, cripples Primeape’s damage output and speed, nullifying its sweeping potential; partners must provide cleric support or redirection. Fairy-heavy teams force an early Tera commit, and if Primeape is caught without it, Play Rough or Dazzling Gleam will OHKO. Finally, Primeape is vulnerable to double-targeting: because it relies on Protect and incremental healing, coordinated attacks from two faster threats can break through before it gains momentum. Solid counters therefore include Tera Fairy Iron Valiant, Choice Specs Dragapult, and bulky intimidate cycles that deny Defiant triggers.</OUTPUT>

input:
Produce the 'sample_team_concept' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Primeape": {"Abilities": {"defiant": 0.17616226743350216, "angerpoint": 0.926919899757151, "vitalspirit": 7.794670866201336e-06}, "Items": {"eviolite": 0.9988629517039748}, "Spreads": {"Jolly:236/4/44/0/4/220": 0.18004491311552695, "Jolly:252/4/124/0/44/84": 0.3914545747955673}, "Moves": ["drainpunch", "ragefist", "protect", "earthquake"], "Tera Types": {"steel": 0.3305863771752963, "water": 0.4294042998544969}, "Teammates": ["Annihilape", "Rillaboom", "Smeargle", "Incineroar", "Archaludon", "Amoonguss"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Build a bulky mid-speed core around Primeape + Annihilape: lead Primeape + Incineroar to bait Intimidate, gain Defiant, and pivot into Annihilape for immediate pressure. Rillaboom sets Grassy Terrain and breaks Water/Grounds while Smeargle offers Dark Void or Tailwind control. Archaludon supplies Sticky Web or acts as a secondary breaker, and Amoonguss provides redirection plus passive recovery. EV spreads emphasize living Choice Specs Shadow Ball and +2 Sucker Punch while outspeeding positive base-90s. Tera Steel on Primeape handles Fairies; Tera Water on Annihilape covers Fire. The team wins by trading early with Defiant boosts, accumulating Rage Fist damage, and cleaning with whichever ape remains standing.</OUTPUT>

input:
Write a detailed 'short_summary' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Froslass": {"Abilities": {"cursedbody": 0.949126167251515, "snowcloak": 0.11872001593002374}, "Items": {"focussash": 0.8018209694207313}, "Spreads": {"Timid:4/0/0/252/0/252": 0.18000035049527743, "Timid:96/0/0/60/116/236": 0.3308304145955012}, "Moves": ["icywind", "destinybond", "protect", "shadowball"], "Tera Types": {"ice": 0.26836344280844304, "fairy": 0.33354294191900113, "normal": 0.16361940749941148}, "Teammates": ["Incineroar", "Archaludon", "Pelipper", "Amoonguss", "Whimsicott", "Basculegion"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Froslass carves a niche in VGC as a blazing-fast support that guarantees at least one meaningful action thanks to Focus Sash. Base 110 Speed lets it outpace the crowded 100-109 tier, so it can fire off Icy Wind for immediate speed control or trade itself with Destiny Bond to remove a dynamaxed threat. Cursed Body is the preferred ability, fishing for 30 % move-disabling luck that can swing momentum, while Snow Cloak variants are deliberately rare. Tera Ice is common to boost STAB Icy Wind and survive a neutral hit, but Tera Fairy and Normal appear to dodge Ghost- or Dark-type counters. EV spreads either max Speed and Special Attack for damage, or creep key bulk numbers (96 HP / 116 SpD) to live choice-banded Sucker Punch from Kingambit and KO back with Tera Ice-boosted Shadow Ball. Although its offenses are modest, the combination of speed control, self-sacrifice, and item-less pressure makes Froslass a glue piece on archetypes that value tempo over raw bulk.</OUTPUT>

input:
Draft the 'full_analysis' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Froslass": {"Abilities": {"cursedbody": 0.949126167251515, "snowcloak": 0.11872001593002374}, "Items": {"focussash": 0.8018209694207313}, "Spreads": {"Timid:4/0/0/252/0/252": 0.18000035049527743, "Timid:96/0/0/60/116/236": 0.3308304145955012}, "Moves": ["icywind", "destinybond", "protect", "shadowball"], "Tera Types": {"ice": 0.26836344280844304, "fairy": 0.33354294191900113, "normal": 0.16361940749941148}, "Teammates": ["Incineroar", "Archaludon", "Pelipper", "Amoonguss", "Whimsicott", "Basculegion"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Froslass’s greatest asset is its speed tier; Timid and 252 EVs hit 364 Speed, outspeeding +1 Roaring Moon, +1 Dragonite, and every unboosted support in the format. This allows Icy Wind to drop the opposing side’s Speed before they move, creating a two-stage swing that turns slower breakers like Archaludon or Basculegion into immediate threats. Shadow Ball provides a 120-base-power STAB option after Tera Ice, 2HKOing offensive Flutter Mane, Mimikyu, and opposing Froslass while also sniping 4 HP Tornadus. Destiny Bond is the terror factor: because Focus Sash guarantees survival of any one attack, Froslass can click Destiny Bond on the same turn a dynamaxed opponent attacks, forcing a double-down dilemma—either they KO Froslass and lose their Dynamax, or they switch and sacrifice momentum. Protect is mandatory for scouting, wasting Tailwind or Trick Room turns, and enabling partner set-up. Cursed Body adds a 30 % chance to disable the move that hit Froslass, occasionally stranding a restricted legendary with only one usable attack. Snow Cloaf variants exist to abuse hail, but hail is almost non-existent in current Regulation G, so Cursed Body’s utility outweighs the evasion gamble. Tera Ice is the most straightforward: it strengthens both STABs, turns Shadow Ball into a legitimate nuke, and grants a neutrality to common Steel-type moves. Tera Fairy removes the Dark weakness, letting Froslass survive Kingambit’s Sucker Punch and OHKO back with Tera Fairy Tera-boosted Shadow Ball. Tera Normal is a tech to become immune to Ghost-type Fake Out and to receive Indeedee’s Follow Me, but it is fringe. EV spreads fall into two camps: max/max for immediate power, or the bulky Timid 96 HP / 60 Def / 116 SpD / 236 Spe spread that survives Choice Band Kingambit Sucker Punch, Life Orb Chien-Pao Ice Spinner, and +1 Dragonite Extreme Speed after Sash, while still outspeeding positive-nature base 100s. Froslass is not a win-condition; it is a tempo piece that trades itself for a board state, and it performs that role better than any other Ghost-type in the format.</OUTPUT>

input:
Draft the 'matchup_overview' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Froslass": {"Abilities": {"cursedbody": 0.949126167251515, "snowcloak": 0.11872001593002374}, "Items": {"focussash": 0.8018209694207313}, "Spreads": {"Timid:4/0/0/252/0/252": 0.18000035049527743, "Timid:96/0/0/60/116/236": 0.3308304145955012}, "Moves": ["icywind", "destinybond", "protect", "shadowball"], "Tera Types": {"ice": 0.26836344280844304, "fairy": 0.33354294191900113, "normal": 0.16361940749941148}, "Teammates": ["Incineroar", "Archaludon", "Pelipper", "Amoonguss", "Whimsicott", "Basculegion"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Froslass dominates slower, set-up reliant teams that need Trick Room or Tailwind to function. Against hard Trick Room, Froslass can Icy Wind both foes on turn one, drop their Speed, and then Destiny Bond the setter to prevent Room from ever going up. Against Tailwind offenses, Froslass can Protect while a partner KO’s the Tailwind user, then Icy Wind the remaining threats to negate the speed advantage. Kingambit is theoretically a counter, but the bulky spread survives Sucker Punch and OHKOes back with Tera Fairy Shadow Ball. Chien-Pao hates eating a Will-o-Wisp—oh wait, Froslass doesn’t run Will-o-Wisp, so Chien-Pao actually forces mind-games: Icy Wind plus any partner damage puts Pao in Shadow Ball range, but Froslass must respect Ice Spinner into Sash break. Amoonguss is a pain because Spore ignores Sash and Clear Smog removes stat drops; Froslass usually Protects while a partner deals with the mushroom. Indeedee-F with Safety Goggles blanks Icy Wind and sets Psychic Terrain, but Froslass can still Destiny Bond the Indeedee to open the field for priority teammates. Sun teams with Torkoal can erase Froslass with Heat Wave, but Froslass outspeeds and Icy Winds before Eruption, allowing a partner to KO Torkoal. Rain teams featuring Pelipper and Basculegion are actually favorable: Froslass underspeeds Pelipper in rain, so it can Icy Wind the rain core and then Shadow Ball Pelipper for the 2HKO while dodging Basculegion’s Shadow Ball thanks to Focus Sash. Overall, Froslass’s matchups are binary: if the opponent has a faster Fake Out or multi-hit move, Froslass struggles; if they rely on single-target big hits, Froslass trades up.</OUTPUT>

input:
Draft the 'role_description' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Froslass": {"Abilities": {"cursedbody": 0.949126167251515, "snowcloak": 0.11872001593002374}, "Items": {"focussash": 0.8018209694207313}, "Spreads": {"Timid:4/0/0/252/0/252": 0.18000035049527743, "Timid:96/0/0/60/116/236": 0.3308304145955012}, "Moves": ["icywind", "destinybond", "protect", "shadowball"], "Tera Types": {"ice": 0.26836344280844304, "fairy": 0.33354294191900113, "normal": 0.16361940749941148}, "Teammates": ["Incineroar", "Archaludon", "Pelipper", "Amoonguss", "Whimsicott", "Basculegion"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Froslass is a lead-oriented speed-control and removal tool. It is almost always brought in slot one or two because its value depreciates once hazards, weather, or speed modifiers are already established. The primary game plan is to lead Froslass plus a breaker, Icy Wind on turn one to drop both enemies’ Speed, and then either Protect while the partner KO’s a threat, or Destiny Bond to trade with the remaining dynamaxed target. Mid-game, Froslass can be switched in on predicted Protects or support moves to fire off another Icy Wind, re-establishing speed control after Tailwind expires. Late-game, Froslass cleans with Shadow Ball once Focus Sash is still intact and the opponent’s priority users are removed. Because it carries no speed-boosting item, Froslass appreciates teammates that can overwrite Tailwind or paralyze foes so it remains the fastest entity. Its Ghost typing is also vital: it ignores Fake Out from Incineroar and can click Destiny Bond through Follow Me, making it one of the few supports that can punish both redirection and intimidate in one slot.</OUTPUT>

input:
Create the 'synergy_breakdown' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Froslass": {"Abilities": {"cursedbody": 0.949126167251515, "snowcloak": 0.11872001593002374}, "Items": {"focussash": 0.8018209694207313}, "Spreads": {"Timid:4/0/0/252/0/252": 0.18000035049527743, "Timid:96/0/0/60/116/236": 0.3308304145955012}, "Moves": ["icywind", "destinybond", "protect", "shadowball"], "Tera Types": {"ice": 0.26836344280844304, "fairy": 0.33354294191900113, "normal": 0.16361940749941148}, "Teammates": ["Incineroar", "Archaludon", "Pelipper", "Amoonguss", "Whimsicott", "Basculegion"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Incineroar is the most frequent partner, providing Fake Out to guarantee Froslass survives turn one, Intimidate to buffer physical attackers that might break Sash, and Flare Blitz to remove Steel-types that resist Shadow Ball. Archaludon loves the Speed drops from Icy Wind, turning its 60 base Speed into a threatening 112 after one drop, and it removes opposing Steel-types with Stomping Tantrum or Steel Beam. Pelipper sets rain to weaken Fire-type moves aimed at Froslass, while Froslass removes Grass-types that bother Pelipper. Amoonguss offers redirection and Spore to incapacitate faster threats, freeing Froslass to click Destiny Bond without fear of double-target. Whimsicott provides Tailwind insurance: if the opponent sets Tailwind, Whimsicott can Taunt it or set its own, while Froslass Icy Winds to ensure Whimsicott’s Moonblast outspeeds. Basculegion enjoys Ghost-spam cores: Froslass baits Indeedee and weakens it for Basculegion to sweep with Last Respects. These six teammates form a tempo shell: Incineroar + Froslass for Fake Out + speed control, Archaludon + Pelipper for rain-boosted Electro Shot, and Amoonguss + Whimsicott for redirection and terrain control.</OUTPUT>

Create the 'recommended_sets' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Froslass": {"Abilities": {"cursedbody": 0.949126167251515, "snowcloak": 0.11872001593002374}, "Items": {"focussash": 0.8018209694207313}, "Spreads": {"Timid:4/0/0/252/0/252": 0.18000035049527743, "Timid:96/0/0/60/116/236": 0.3308304145955012}, "Moves": ["icywind", "destinybond", "protect", "shadowball"], "Tera Types": {"ice": 0.26836344280844304, "fairy": 0.33354294191900113, "normal": 0.16361940749941148}, "Teammates": ["Incineroar", "Archaludon", "Pelipper", "Amoonguss", "Whimsicott", "Basculegion"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Standard Lead Froslass: Timid, 4 HP / 0 Atk / 0 Def / 252 SpA / 0 SpD / 252 Spe, Focus Sash, Cursed Body, Tera Ice — Icy Wind, Destiny Bond, Protect, Shadow Ball. This set maximizes Speed and power, guaranteeing the first move and 2HKOing most offensive threats. Bulky Trade Froslass: Timid, 96 HP / 0 Atk / 60 Def / 0 SpA / 116 SpD / 236 Spe, Focus Sash, Cursed Body, Tera Fairy — Icy Wind, Destiny Bond, Protect, Shadow Ball. This spread survives Choice Band Kingambit Sucker Punch, Life Orb Chien-Pao Ice Spinner, and +1 Dragonite Extreme Speed after Sash, while still outspeeding positive base 100s; Tera Fairy ensures the OHKO on Kingambit. Optional tech: swap Shadow Ball for Thunder Wave on teams that already have Ghost coverage, allowing Froslass to paralyze a target before going down, but this is niche because Destiny Bond is the main reason to use Froslass.</OUTPUT>

input:
Generate the 'weaknesses_and_counters' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Froslass": {"Abilities": {"cursedbody": 0.949126167251515, "snowcloak": 0.11872001593002374}, "Items": {"focussash": 0.8018209694207313}, "Spreads": {"Timid:4/0/0/252/0/252": 0.18000035049527743, "Timid:96/0/0/60/116/236": 0.3308304145955012}, "Moves": ["icywind", "destinybond", "protect", "shadowball"], "Tera Types": {"ice": 0.26836344280844304, "fairy": 0.33354294191900113, "normal": 0.16361940749941148}, "Teammates": ["Incineroar", "Archaludon", "Pelipper", "Amoonguss", "Whimsicott", "Basculegion"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Faster Fake Out users such as Meowscarada and Iron Valiant can break Focus Sash before Froslass acts, so predicting the Fake Out and Protecting is mandatory. Multi-hit moves from Kingambit’s Beat Up (under Tailwind) or Maushold’s Population Bomb ignore Sash and OHKO. Priority users like Chien-Pao’s Ice Shard or Dragonite’s Extreme Speed can finish Froslass after Sash is broken, so removing them before committing Froslass is key. Torkoal under sun or Chi-Yu under sun one-shot with Heat Wave or Overheat even through Sash if sun is up, so weather control is essential. Indeedee-F with Safety Goggles ignores Icy Wind and sets Psychic Terrain, while Clear Amulet variants ignore the Speed drop entirely; the answer is to Destiny Bond the Indeedee and force a 1-for-1. Wide Guard from Celesteela or Aegislash blanks Icy Wind, so Froslass must Shadow Ball on those turns. Finally, because Froslass is item-locked to Focus Sash, Knock Off users such as Incineroar and Hydreigon can remove the Sash indirectly by forcing Protects and then knocking the item later. Opposing teams that carry two of these elements—Fake Out plus sun, or Beat Up plus priority—tend to shut Froslass down entirely.</OUTPUT>

input:
Write a detailed 'sample_team_concept' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Froslass": {"Abilities": {"cursedbody": 0.949126167251515, "snowcloak": 0.11872001593002374}, "Items": {"focussash": 0.8018209694207313}, "Spreads": {"Timid:4/0/0/252/0/252": 0.18000035049527743, "Timid:96/0/0/60/116/236": 0.3308304145955012}, "Moves": ["icywind", "destinybond", "protect", "shadowball"], "Tera Types": {"ice": 0.26836344280844304, "fairy": 0.33354294191900113, "normal": 0.16361940749941148}, "Teammates": ["Incineroar", "Archaludon", "Pelipper", "Amoonguss", "Whimsicott", "Basculegion"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Regulation G Tailwind-Breaker: Froslass + Incineroar + Archaludon + Pelipper + Amoonguss + Whimsicott. Lead Froslass + Incineroar into most matchups: Fake Out the biggest threat, Icy Wind both foes, then follow with Flare Blitz or U-turn. If the opponent sets Tailwind, switch to Whimsicott on turn two, Taunt the Tailwind user, and reset speed with your own Tailwind while Froslass Protects. Against Trick Room, lead Froslass + Amoonguss: Icy Wind the setter, Spore the TR user, then Destiny Bond the remaining slot. Archaludon sits in the back to clean once Speed drops are in place; under rain, Electro Shot OHKOes most restricted legendaries. Pelipper provides rain to halve Fire damage on Froslass and Archaludon, while Hurricane removes Grass-types. The team’s win condition is to trade Froslass for a dynamaxed threat, set rain or Tailwind, and sweep with Archaludon or Basculegion. EV spreads: Froslass uses bulky Fairy set; Incineroar is standard support; Archaludon is Modest 252/252 with Assault Vest; Pelipper is Bold with Damp Rock; Amoonguss is Relaxed with Black Sludge; Whimsicott is Timid with Eject Pack. The core idea is to never lose the speed war: either Froslass drops Speed, or Whimsicott sets Tailwind, ensuring your breakers always move first.</OUTPUT>

Write a detailed 'short_summary' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Goodra": {"Abilities": {"hydration": 0.032816292947608405, "sapsipper": 1.0107155953883529, "gooey": 0.15221591476268975}, "Items": {"assaultvest": 0.3024474102401425, "leftovers": 0.3782554315797998, "covertcloak": 0.22996269577809128}, "Spreads": {"Modest:182/0/74/252/0/0": 0.34158354471835134, "Modest:132/0/200/132/40/4": 0.22981130453224066}, "Moves": ["protect", "dragonpulse", "sludgebomb", "surf"], "Tera Types": {"water": 0.49631184452826815, "poison": 0.2830315675493765}, "Teammates": ["Pelipper", "Dudunsparce", "Quaquaval", "Pawmot", "Lycanroc", "Orthworm"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Goodra is a bulky special attacker that leverages Assault Vest or Leftovers to act as a pivot and spread status or damage. Its most common sets run Modest with heavy HP and Special Attack investment, running Protect, Dragon Pulse, Sludge Bomb, and Surf, while Terastallizing into Water or Poison to flip matchups. Sap Sipper is the dominant ability, punishing Grass-type moves and providing free Attack boosts, while Gooey and Hydration remain niche. Goodra fits best on balanced or rain-leaning teams that appreciate a soft check to special attackers and a Dragon-type that can pressure common Fairy- and Grass-type restricted Pokémon.</OUTPUT>

input:
Create the 'full_analysis' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Goodra": {"Abilities": {"hydration": 0.032816292947608405, "sapsipper": 1.0107155953883529, "gooey": 0.15221591476268975}, "Items": {"assaultvest": 0.3024474102401425, "leftovers": 0.3782554315797998, "covertcloak": 0.22996269577809128}, "Spreads": {"Modest:182/0/74/252/0/0": 0.34158354471835134, "Modest:132/0/200/132/40/4": 0.22981130453224066}, "Moves": ["protect", "dragonpulse", "sludgebomb", "surf"], "Tera Types": {"water": 0.49631184452826815, "poison": 0.2830315675493765}, "Teammates": ["Pelipper", "Dudunsparce", "Quaquaval", "Pawmot", "Lycanroc", "Orthworm"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Goodra’s stat distribution and movepool make it one of the few pseudo-legendary dragons that prefers special offense to physical, and the VGC 2024 usage reflects that. Modest nature with 182 HP / 74 Def / 252 SpA (or the bulkier 132/200/132 variant) lets it survive powerful physical hits such as Life Orb Chien-Pao Ice Spinner while still OHKOing 4 HP Flutter Mane with Sludge Bomb after Tera Poison. Assault Vest variants reach 615 effective special bulk after the boost, allowing them to stomach Specs Tatsugiri Hydro Pump or Choice Specs Pelipper Hurricane and retaliate with Thunderbolt from a teammate or its own neutral Dragon Pulse. Leftovers sets trade immediate bulk for passive recovery, pairing well with Protect stalling and Covert Cloak to ignore fake-out or secondary effect spam. Sap Sipper is the clear ability of choice: switching into Rillaboom Grassy Glide or Amoonguss Spore nets a +1 Attack boost that turns Goodra into a surprise physical breaker, letting its uninvested Body Slam or Power Whip 2HKO common special walls such as Blissey. Hydration is usable only on dedicated rain teams, curing status at the end of each turn and letting Goodra run Resto-Chesto or Hydration-Rest loops, but such builds are rare. Gooey punishes U-turn and Fake Out users, but the speed drops rarely swing games compared to the immediate value of Sap Sipper. Tera Water removes the Ice and Fairy weaknesses, granting a crucial neutrality to Freeze-Dry and turning Goodra into a pseudo-water tank that can spam rain-boosted Surf or retaliate with Tera Blast Ice. Tera Poison grants a Fairy resistance and an invaluable Toxic immunity, letting Goodra beat Togekiss, Sylveon, and Hatterene one-on-one while also flipping the Iron Moth matchup. Goodra’s main niche is therefore as a flexible mid-speed pivot that compresses special bulk, Dragon-type offensive presence, and Sap Sipper utility into one slot.</OUTPUT>

input:
Generate the 'matchup_overview' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Goodra": {"Abilities": {"hydration": 0.032816292947608405, "sapsipper": 1.0107155953883529, "gooey": 0.15221591476268975}, "Items": {"assaultvest": 0.3024474102401425, "leftovers": 0.3782554315797998, "covertcloak": 0.22996269577809128}, "Spreads": {"Modest:182/0/74/252/0/0": 0.34158354471835134, "Modest:132/0/200/132/40/4": 0.22981130453224066}, "Moves": ["protect", "dragonpulse", "sludgebomb", "surf"], "Tera Types": {"water": 0.49631184452826815, "poison": 0.2830315675493765}, "Teammates": ["Pelipper", "Dudunsparce", "Quaquaval", "Pawmot", "Lycanroc", "Orthworm"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Goodra’s Dragon typing leaves it weak to Fairy, Ice, and Dragon, but its bulk and Tera options let it flip many of these. Against Fairy-types it must Tera Poison or Water to avoid being OHKOed by Moonblast or Dazzling Gleam; after Terastallization it can survive +1 Sylveon Hyper Voice and KO back with Sludge Bomb. Ice-types such as Chien-Pao and Baxcalibur outspeed and threaten with Ice Spinner or Icicle Crash, but the bulky spread survives Jolly Life Orb Ice Spinner from full and can retaliate with Tera Water Surf or Dragon Pulse. Dragon mirror matchups revolve around speed and Tera: Goodra loses to Specs Dialga or Modest Hydreigon but beats physically offensive Dragons like Roaring Moon after Tera Poison. Fire-types such as Chi-Yu and Torkoal dislike Surf and are outsped, while Steel-types like Corviknight and Gholdengo fear Tera Water Surf or Fire coverage from teammates. Grass-types are outright countered by Sap Sipper, turning their STAB into set-up fodder. Amoonguss is perhaps the most important matchup: Assault Vest Goodra avoids the 2HKO from Pollen Puff and can either Sludge Bomb for the KO or click Protect to waste Spore turns, while Sap Sipper variants gain +1 Attack every time they switch in. Overall, Goodra’s matchups are neutral to favorable against most special attackers and Grass-types, but it must Terastallize to escape the common Ice and Fairy killers.</OUTPUT>

input:
Create the 'role_description' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Goodra": {"Abilities": {"hydration": 0.032816292947608405, "sapsipper": 1.0107155953883529, "gooey": 0.15221591476268975}, "Items": {"assaultvest": 0.3024474102401425, "leftovers": 0.3782554315797998, "covertcloak": 0.22996269577809128}, "Spreads": {"Modest:182/0/74/252/0/0": 0.34158354471835134, "Modest:132/0/200/132/40/4": 0.22981130453224066}, "Moves": ["protect", "dragonpulse", "sludgebomb", "surf"], "Tera Types": {"water": 0.49631184452826815, "poison": 0.2830315675493765}, "Teammates": ["Pelipper", "Dudunsparce", "Quaquaval", "Pawmot", "Lycanroc", "Orthworm"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Goodra operates as a special tank and pivot that switches into resisted or ability-immune moves, threatens spread damage or poison, and Terastallizes to flip bad matchups. Its speed tier (80 base) sits just below the crowded 85–95 scarfers, so it functions best in tailwind or under speed control from teammates like Pelipper or Dudunsparce. Sap Sipper gives it a secondary role as a Grass-type deterrent, puniting Rillaboom, Amoonguss, and Lilligant while simultaneously boosting its otherwise unused Attack stat. Protect is mandatory to stall Dynamax turns, scout choice locks, and rack up Leftovers recovery. Dragon Pulse is the reliable STAB, 2HKOing most neutral targets and OHKOing other Dragons after Tera. Sludge Bomb hits Fairies and Grass-types for super-effective damage while also spreading poison to bulkier walls such as Dondozo and Toxapex. Surf provides spread damage that is boosted by rain and benefits from Tera Water, while also hitting Fire- and Rock-types that otherwise wall Goodra. Assault Vest sets sacrifice flexibility for raw special bulk, whereas Leftovers sets can run Protect and Covert Cloak to ignore fake-out and status, making them better long-term win conditions. Terastallization is central to Goodra’s role: Tera Water turns it into a rain abuser that can tank Ice moves and spam 1.5× Surfs, while Tera Poison grants a Fairy resistance and Toxic immunity, letting it serve as a status absorber and Fairy killer.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Goodra’s biggest weakness is its pre-Tera typing: Ice Shard from Chien-Pao or Baxcalibur deals 70–85 % to the bulky spread, and Moonblast from Specs Sylveon or Flutter Mane OHKOes before Terastallization. The most common spread (Bold 252/0/36/0/220/0) leverages Eviolite to reach 191 physical bulk and 188 special bulk, letting it survive Life Orb Garchomp Earthquake, Modest Dragapult Draco Meteor, or Choice Specs Hydreigon Dark Pulse. output: <OUTPUT>Electivire carves out a niche as a fast, disruptive pivot that leverages Motor Drive boosts and Follow Me support to enable its teammates. With Jolly max-speed investment it outspeeds the crowded base-100 tier, and its unique dual utility—drawing Electric attacks for free Speed boosts while redirecting single-target moves—makes it a glue piece for sun and Psychic-spam style squads. Tera Flying removes its Ground weakness and grants emergency Earthquake immunity, while Tera Psychic lets it sponge Indeedee-F’s Expanding Force and benefit from Psychic Terrain’s priority blocking. The given set is simple but effective: Follow Me protects partners while they set up or attack, Wild Charge is a strong, recoil-heavy STAB, Earthquake pressures Steel and Fire types, and Protect keeps it alive long enough to pass Motordrive boosts or Sitrus recovery. It is not a powerhouse sweeper; rather, it is a tempo pick that buys turns, absorbs momentum, and punishes passive play.</OUTPUT>

input:

<DATA>{"Electivire": {"Abilities": {"motordrive": 0.608856937146774, "vitalspirit": 0.7344641199696711}, "Items": {"sitrusberry": 0.4854918945236818}, "Spreads": {"Jolly:104/52/100/0/0/252": 0.45925020645782383}, "Moves": ["protect", "followme", "earthquake", "wildcharge"], "Tera Types": {"flying": 0.22079130385302914, "psychic": 0.45861093260036256}, "Teammates": ["Torkoal", "Indeedee-F", "Whimsicott", "Armarouge", "Bruxish", "Overqwil"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Electivire’s value in VGC 2024 Regulation G lies in its ability to compress redirection and speed control into one slot while offering a Motor Drive carrot that lures Thunder Waves and Volt Switches. Base 95 Speed with a Jolly nature and full EVs hits 317, outspeeding Lilligant, Armarouge under sun, and every neutral-natured base-100 such as Garchomp and Zapdos. 104 HP plus Sitrus gives it a 20% berry range that almost always activates after one Wild Charge recoil or a modest super-effective hit, letting it survive long enough to redirect twice. 52 Attack EVs guarantee the OHKO on standard Torkoal with Earthquake after spread damage, while the remaining EVs are dumped into bulk. Motor Drive is preferred on teams that already pack sun or Psychic Terrain, because the +1 Speed immediately turns Electivire into a fast Follow Me user that can still outspeed threats the following turn even if it switches out. Vital Spirit is a serviceable alternative against Amoonguss or sleep-centric teams, but the data show players overwhelmingly prefer the burst speed option. The move suite is intentionally narrow: Protect and Follow Me are mandatory for redirection pivoting, Wild Charge is the hardest-hitting physical STAB available, and Earthquake is the best coverage move that also exploits Torkoal’s weakness while not harming Flying- or Levitate partners. Tera Flying is the most common defensive option, removing the 4× Ground weakness and granting an emergency immunity to opposing Earthquakes while still resisting Fighting. Tera Psychic is chosen on teams that already run Indeedee-F or Armarouge, because the terrain boost turns Electivire into a passable special tank that can sponge opposing Expanding Forces and retaliate with its own neutral coverage. The EV spread maximizes speed and minimizes offensive investment because Electivire’s role is to enable teammates, not to sweep; the 52 Attack is merely a breakpoint for KOing Torkoal and for finishing off weakened Rotom-Wash or Heatran. Sitrus Berry is the only item of note, as Leftovers recovery is too slow for doubles and Assault Vest precludes Follow Me. Overall, Electivire is a glue mon that thrives in structured cores where it can turn the opponent’s Electric-type support moves into free speed while keeping frail sweepers safe.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Electivire": {"Abilities": {"motordrive": 0.608856937146774, "vitalspirit": 0.7344641199696711}, "Items": {"sitrusberry": 0.4854918945236818}, "Spreads": {"Jolly:104/52/100/0/0/252": 0.45925020645782383}, "Moves": ["protect", "followme", "earthquake", "wildcharge"], "Tera Types": {"flying": 0.22079130385302914, "psychic": 0.45861093260036256}, "Teammates": ["Torkoal", "Indeedee-F", "Whimsicott", "Armarouge", "Bruxish", "Overqwil"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Against sun, Electivire is a double-edged sword: it can redirect Eruption or absorb Thunder Wave from Torkoal, but it must avoid Overheat and cannot OHKO Torkoal without prior damage. Versus rain, it outspeeds most Swift Swimmers after a Motor Drive boost and KOes Pelipper with Wild Charge, yet it folds to Kingdra’s Draco Meteor or Ludicolo’s Hydro Pump. Into Trick Room, Electivire is naturally faster than most setters, so it can Taunt or Follow Me to stall turns, but if Trick Room goes up it becomes dead weight against Crawdaunt or Hatterene. Against Psychic Terrain spam, Electivire’s Tera Psychic lets it live Expanding Force and redirect follow-up attacks, but it must beware Shadow Ball from Indeedee-F or Armarouge. Opposing Electric types such as Zapdos or Rotom-Wash are gifts: Motor Drive activates on Discharge or Volt Switch, instantly flipping the speed tiers, though Zapdos can still punish with Hurricane. Ground types are the biggest hurdle: Garchomp, Gastrodon, and Excadrill all threaten OHKOs, so Tera Flying is essential; even then, Garchomp can click Rock Slide or Scale Shot to flinch. Steel types like Corviknight and Celesteela wall Wild Charge and can stall with Roost or Leech Seed, forcing Electivire to rely on Earthquake and teammate support. Finally, priority users such as Dragonite with Extreme Speed or Kingambit with Sucker Punch bypass Follow Me and easily finish off a chipped Electivire, so terrain or burn support is appreciated.</OUTPUT>

input:
Draft the 'role_description' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Electivire": {"Abilities": {"motordrive": 0.608856937146774, "vitalspirit": 0.7344641199696711}, "Items": {"sitrusberry": 0.4854918945236818}, "Spreads": {"Jolly:104/52/100/0/0/252": 0.45925020645782383}, "Moves": ["protect", "followme", "earthquake", "wildcharge"], "Tera Types": {"flying": 0.22079130385302914, "psychic": 0.45861093260036256}, "Teammates": ["Torkoal", "Indeedee-F", "Whimsicott", "Armarouge", "Bruxish", "Overqwil"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Electivire functions as a hybrid pivot: part redirection support, part speed-control absorber, part soft attacker. It leads when the opponent relies on single-target moves or Electric-type speed control, immediately establishing tempo by either drawing attacks with Follow Me or punishing Electric moves with Motor Drive. Mid-game it switches in on predicted Thunder Waves or Volt Switches, gains a free Speed boost, and then either protects a setup partner or fires off a coverage move to chip checks. Late-game it can clean weakened teams thanks to its newly acquired speed tier, but its power is modest; instead, it usually sacrifices itself to guarantee a win condition for a faster or bulkier teammate. The presence of Electivire on team preview forces opponents to second-guess clicking Thunder Wave or Discharge, effectively giving your side a pseudo-immunity to paralysis while simultaneously providing a redirection safety net for frail sweepers like Bruxish or Armarouge.</OUTPUT>

input:
Generate the 'synergy_breakdown' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Electivire": {"Abilities": {"motordrive": 0.608856937146774, "vitalspirit": 0.7344641199696711}, "Items": {"sitrusberry": 0.4854918945236818}, "Spreads": {"Jolly:104/52/100/0/0/252": 0.45925020645782383}, "Moves": ["protect", "followme", "earthquake", "wildcharge"], "Tera Types": {"flying": 0.22079130385302914, "psychic": 0.45861093260036256}, "Teammates": ["Torkoal", "Indeedee-F", "Whimsicott", "Armarouge", "Bruxish", "Overqwil"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Torkoal is the most frequent partner: sun-boosted Eruptions break shared checks such as Gastrodon while Electivire redirects Grass or Water moves aimed at Torkoal; in return, Torkoal’s Drought weakens opposing Water moves and can burn physical threats with Will-O-Wisp. Indeedee-F sets Psychic Terrain, which blocks priority that would otherwise pick off a weakened Electivire, while Electivire redirects Ghost or Dark moves meant for Indeedee-F; when both terastallize to Psychic, the core becomes extremely hard to break with special moves. Whimsicott provides Tailwind or Fake Tears support, letting Electivire outspeed even faster scarfers after a Motor Drive boost and letting partner special attackers dent bulky steels. Armarouge appreciates Follow Me while it sets up Weak Armor or clicks Expanding Force, and Electivire’s Earthquake hits Torkoal and Heatran for Armarouge. Bruxish is a frail but powerful attacker that needs redirection to set up Swords Dance or fire off Psychic Fangs, and Electivire’s speed control ensures Bruxish can sweep before it gets doubled. Overqwil shares a typing that deters Grass and Fairy moves, and can spam Barb Barrage safely behind Electivire’s Follow Me while the latter absorbs Thunder Waves aimed at the poison dartfish. Overall, Electivire fits best on balanced offensive cores that need a pivot to absorb momentum and redirect pressure away from setup sweepers or terrain setters.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Electivire": {"Abilities": {"motordrive": 0.608856937146774, "vitalspirit": 0.7344641199696711}, "Items": {"sitrusberry": 0.4854918945236818}, "Spreads": {"Jolly:104/52/100/0/0/252": 0.45925020645782383}, "Moves": ["protect", "followme", "earthquake", "wildcharge"], "Tera Types": {"flying": 0.22079130385302914, "psychic": 0.45861093260036256}, "Teammates": ["Torkoal", "Indeedee-F", "Whimsicott", "Armarouge", "Bruxish", "Overqwil"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>The tournament-proven spread is Jolly with 104 HP / 52 Atk / 100 Def / 0 SpA / 0 SpD / 252 Spe holding Sitrus Berry. This outspeeds positive-natured base-100s and survives a Life Orb Earthquake from Garchomp with Tera Flying. Moves are Protect, Follow Me, Wild Charge, and Earthquake. Tera Flying is the default for Ground immunity; Tera Psychic is chosen only if your team already runs Indeedee-F or Armarouge to exploit terrain. Motor Drive is mandatory unless your team is desperately weak to Spore or Lovely Kiss, in which case Vital Spirit can be used at the cost of speed control. No other item is worth the loss of Follow Me: Sitrus guarantees a 20% recovery at 50% HP, which after one Wild Charge recoil usually lands in berry range. Alternate spreads can shift 52 EVs from Attack to Special Defense to better stomach Indeedee-F’s Expanding Force, but the Tera Psychic variant already handles that. If you need more power, Life Orb can be used, but you forfeit redirection and become extremely frail; such a set should run Thunder Punch over Wild Charge to avoid recoil, but this is niche and not reflected in the usage stats.</OUTPUT>
