Create the 'weaknesses_and_counters' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Electivire": {"Abilities": {"motordrive": 0.608856937146774, "vitalspirit": 0.7344641199696711}, "Items": {"sitrusberry": 0.4854918945236818}, "Spreads": {"Jolly:104/52/100/0/0/252": 0.45925020645782383}, "Moves": ["protect", "followme", "earthquake", "wildcharge"], "Tera Types": {"flying": 0.22079130385302914, "psychic": 0.45861093260036256}, "Teammates": ["Torkoal", "Indeedee-F", "Whimsicott", "Armarouge", "Bruxish", "Overqwil"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Ground-type attacks are the most direct answer: Garchomp’s Earthquake or Excadrill’s High Horsepower OHKO through non-Tera and still 2HKO after Tera Flying if Stealth Rock is up. Gastrodon ignores Earthquake and can stall with Recover or threaten back with Scald burns. Priority users circumvent Follow Me: Dragonite’s Extreme Speed or Kingambit’s Sucker Punch finish off a chipped Electivire, so Psychic Terrain or burn support is required. Bulky Steel types—Corviknight, Celesteela, and Skarmory—take negligible damage from Wild Charge and Earthquake, and can Roost or Leech Seed stall until Electivire is worn down. Intimidate users such as Arcanine or Gyarados drop its modest attack stat, making it even harder to secure KOs. Taunt completely shuts down Follow Me and Protect, forcing Electivire to attack into resists. Finally, spread moves like Dazzling Gleam or Rock Slide bypass redirection and can flinch or KO, especially when backed by Life Orb or Choice Specs. To counter Electivire, bring a sturdy Ground type, pack priority or Taunt, and avoid clicking Electric moves unless you can afford to give up a speed boost.</OUTPUT>

input:
Generate the 'sample_team_concept' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Electivire": {"Abilities": {"motordrive": 0.608856937146774, "vitalspirit": 0.7344641199696711}, "Items": {"sitrusberry": 0.4854918945236818}, "Spreads": {"Jolly:104/52/100/0/0/252": 0.45925020645782383}, "Moves": ["protect", "followme", "earthquake", "wildcharge"], "Tera Types": {"flying": 0.22079130385302914, "psychic": 0.45861093260036256}, "Teammates": ["Torkoal", "Indeedee-F", "Whimsicott", "Armarouge", "Bruxish", "Overqwil"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>A standard sun-psychic hybrid showcases Electivire’s strengths: Torkoal @ Charcoal with Eruption, Heat Wave, Protect, and Will-O-Wisp sets sun and breaks bulky waters; Indeedee-F @ Choice Specs with Expanding Force, Shadow Ball, Helping Hand, and Protect sets terrain and special pressure; Electivire @ Sitrus Berry fills the pivot slot; Bruxish @ Life Orb with Psychic Fangs, Liquidation, Swords Dance, and Protect serves as the fast physical cleaner; Whimsicott @ Focus Sash with Tailwind, Fake Tears, Moonblast, and Protect provides speed control and special breaking; and Overqwil @ Black Sludge with Barb Barrage, Crunch, Taunt, and Protect gives poison chip and Dark-type coverage. The core idea is to lead Electivire + Torkoal into Electric or Water teams: redirect away from Torkoal while it fires off sun-boosted Eruptions, then swap to Indeedee-F mid-game to reset terrain and continue spamming. Against faster offenses, Whimsicott sets Tailwind while Electivire redirects, after which Bruxish can sweep. Electivire’s Motor Drive turns predicted Thunder Waves into free speed, letting it outrun and KO Rotom-Wash or Zapdos with Earthquake or Wild Charge. The team struggles against Trick Room or bulky Steels, so Electivire can Taunt setters or Tera Flying to stall turns while Torkoal burns physical threats. Overall, Electivire acts as the glue that absorbs momentum and keeps the sun or terrain engines running smoothly.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Lokix": {"Abilities": {"tintedlens": 0.9448275284675436, "swarm": 0.006797381883237752}, "Items": {"lifeorb": 0.4902626495832775, "safetygoggles": 0.20803331029330685}, "Spreads": {"Jolly:0/252/0/0/4/252": 0.16551040197034844, "Jolly:4/252/0/0/0/252": 0.20694272042660927, "Adamant:20/252/0/0/0/236": 0.474386595165135}, "Moves": ["firstimpression", "detect", "suckerpunch", "leechlife"], "Tera Types": {"bug": 0.6698326365116389, "stellar": 0.2698985834915409}, "Teammates": ["Araquanid", "Volcarona", "Kleavor", "Rabsca", "Vivillon", "Scizor"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Lokix is a hyper-offensive Bug-type that dominates the early game with First Impression and Sucker Punch, using Tinted Lens and Life Orb to punch through would-be checks. It compresses speed control, priority, and raw power into one slot, making it a premier lead or mid-game cleaner for hyper-offensive and balance squads alike.</OUTPUT>

input:
Write the 'full_analysis' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Lokix": {"Abilities": {"tintedlens": 0.9448275284675436, "swarm": 0.006797381883237752}, "Items": {"lifeorb": 0.4902626495832775, "safetygoggles": 0.20803331029330685}, "Spreads": {"Jolly:0/252/0/0/4/252": 0.16551040197034844, "Jolly:4/252/0/0/0/252": 0.20694272042660927, "Adamant:20/252/0/0/0/236": 0.474386595165135}, "Moves": ["firstimpression", "detect", "suckerpunch", "leechlife"], "Tera Types": {"bug": 0.6698326365116389, "stellar": 0.2698985834915409}, "Teammates": ["Araquanid", "Volcarona", "Kleavor", "Rabsca", "Vivillon", "Scizor"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Lokix’s 90/102 offensive stats are deceptively modest, but Tinted Lens doubles the power of resisted Bug moves while Life Orb adds a 1.3× multiplier, turning First Impression into a nuke that 2HKOes even neutral targets like Tornadus-I and offensive Kyogre. Sucker Punch provides invaluable Dark-type priority, letting Lokix pick off faster threats such as Flutter Mane and Chi-Yu before they move. Leech Life offers a 20 % heal on neutral or super-effective hits, offsetting Life Orb recoil and giving Lokix surprising longevity in longer games. Detect is the mandatory protect move for doubles play, scouting choice items and enabling partner set-up or redirection. The EV spreads show a clear preference for Adamant with 236 Speed to outrun positive-nature base 100s such as Zapdos and Salamence while maximizing Attack; Jolly variants sacrifice a small amount of power to speed-tie opposing Lokix and outspeed +1 Kingdra in rain. Tera Bug is the default, boosting First Impression and Leech Life to ludicrous levels and turning resisted matchups into neutral ones thanks to Tinted Lens. Tera Stellar is a niche option that removes the Bug-typing’s defensive liabilities while preserving STAB on First Impression, useful when facing opposing Bug resists or when Lokix needs to survive a Fire-type move. Safety Goggles variants ignore enemy Rage Powder and Spore, making Lokix a premier Amoonguss answer and allowing it to operate under enemy sand or hail without chip damage. Life Orb remains the most common item, however, because the extra damage is essential for scoring KOs on bulky Dynamax targets like Togekiss and Gastrodon. Lokix’s typing grants it a crucial resistance to Grass, Ground, and Fighting, letting it switch into Rillaboom’s Grassy Glide or Landorus-T’s Earthquake and immediately threaten back. Its weaknesses to Fire, Flying, and Rock are pronounced, so partners that cover these types—especially Water and Steel—are mandatory. Overall, Lokix is a low-maintenance, high-reward attacker that dictates the tempo of the match from turn one.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Lokix": {"Abilities": {"tintedlens": 0.9448275284675436, "swarm": 0.006797381883237752}, "Items": {"lifeorb": 0.4902626495832775, "safetygoggles": 0.20803331029330685}, "Spreads": {"Jolly:0/252/0/0/4/252": 0.16551040197034844, "Jolly:4/252/0/0/0/252": 0.20694272042660927, "Adamant:20/252/0/0/0/236": 0.474386595165135}, "Moves": ["firstimpression", "detect", "suckerpunch", "leechlife"], "Tera Types": {"bug": 0.6698326365116389, "stellar": 0.2698985834915409}, "Teammates": ["Araquanid", "Volcarona", "Kleavor", "Rabsca", "Vivillon", "Scizor"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Lokix obliterates Psychic- and Grass-heavy teams, cleanly OHKOing Indeedee, Amoonguss, and Rillaboom with First Impression while 2HKOing bulkier Psychics like Cresselia. It pressures opposing speed control, outspeeding and KOing Whimsicott and Grimmsnarl before they set up Tailwind or Reflect. Against Fire-types such as Heatran and Charizard, Lokix must rely on Sucker Punch or pivot out, as any Fire move is an OHKO even without a boosting item. Flying-types like Togekiss and Corviknight resist both STABs and can retaliate with Heat Wave or Brave Bird, so Lokix needs either a Tera Bug-boosted Leech Life or heavy prior damage to break through. Rock-types such as Tyranitar and Lycanroc-Dusk take negligible damage from First Impression and can OHKO with Rock Slide; however, they fear Sucker Punch if already chipped. Steel-types like Corviknight and Gholdengo wall Lokix unless it teras, but they dislike repeated Leech Life cycles that restore Lokix’s health. Ghost-types such as Aegislash and Dragapult are hit neutrally by First Impression and can punish Sucker Punch mind-games with wide-reaching spread moves. In the mirror, speed ties and Sucker Punch calcs decide the exchange, making Jolly Lokix the safer pick. Terrain wars matter: Psychic Terrain blocks Sucker Punch, so Lokix must either target the Indeedee setter first or delay its priority until terrain fades. Overall, Lokix wins the early game against slower, bulkier cores but must be carefully positioned against faster offensive teams that carry Fire or Flying coverage.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Lokix": {"Abilities": {"tintedlens": 0.9448275284675436, "swarm": 0.006797381883237752}, "Items": {"lifeorb": 0.4902626495832775, "safetygoggles": 0.20803331029330685}, "Spreads": {"Jolly:0/252/0/0/4/252": 0.16551040197034844, "Jolly:4/252/0/0/0/252": 0.20694272042660927, "Adamant:20/252/0/0/0/236": 0.474386595165135}, "Moves": ["firstimpression", "detect", "suckerpunch", "leechlife"], "Tera Types": {"bug": 0.6698326365116389, "stellar": 0.2698985834915409}, "Teammates": ["Araquanid", "Volcarona", "Kleavor", "Rabsca", "Vivillon", "Scizor"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Lokix is a lead or mid-game revenge killer whose primary job is to remove key threats on turns one and two, then clean late-game with Sucker Punch once enemy speed control is dismantled. It fits best on hyper-offensive and fast balance teams that value immediate board presence over long-term bulk. Its priority moves let it operate without Tailwind or Trick Room support, freeing teammates to run other forms of speed control or set-up. Tinted Lens turns resisted hits into neutral ones, so Lokix can mindlessly spam First Impression against cores that would normally wall Bug moves, forcing switches and accumulating chip. The Leech Life + Life Orb combo gives it a unique sustain mechanism, allowing Lokix to stay on the field for three or four turns rather than the usual one-and-done suicide lead. In dynamax formats, Lokix rarely maxes itself but instead uses its presence to deter enemy max: opponents must max into Fire or Flying moves to survive, telegraphing their dynamax target and enabling counter-max plays from Lokix’s partner. Its typing also grants it a useful immunity to enemy priority such as Grassy Glide and Aqua Jet under Psychic Terrain, letting it serve as an anti-meta pick against Rillaboom and Azumarill.</OUTPUT>

Create the 'synergy_breakdown' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Lokix": {"Abilities": {"tintedlens": 0.9448275284675436, "swarm": 0.006797381883237752}, "Items": {"lifeorb": 0.4902626495832775, "safetygoggles": 0.20803331029330685}, "Spreads": {"Jolly:0/252/0/0/4/252": 0.16551040197034844, "Jolly:4/252/0/0/0/252": 0.20694272042660927, "Adamant:20/252/0/0/0/236": 0.474386595165135}, "Moves": ["firstimpression", "detect", "suckerpunch", "leechlife"], "Tera Types": {"bug": 0.6698326365116389, "stellar": 0.2698985834915409}, "Teammates": ["Araquanid", "Volcarona", "Kleavor", "Rabsca", "Vivillon", "Scizor"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Water-type teammates such as Araquanid and Volcarona blanket Lokix’s Fire weakness while appreciating Lokix’s ability to remove Grass- and Psychic-types that trouble them. Araquanid in particular offers Wide Guard to block Rock Slide and Heat Wave, while Volcarona can set up Quiver Dance behind Lokix’s initial pressure. Kleavor shares Bug typing but provides Rock coverage to hit Flying-types, forming a dual-Bug offensive core that overwhelms shared checks. Rabsca offers Revival Blessing to bring back a chipped Lokix late-game, turning it into a recursive threat, and its Ground typing draws in Water- and Grass-moves that Lokix can switch in on. Vivillon sets up Tailwind or uses Rage Powder to redirect Fire-type moves, giving Lokix a safer entry. Scizor provides a slow U-turn to bring Lokix in safely and pressures Fairy- and Ice-types that resist Bug. Steel-types like Gholdengo and Corviknight round out the defensive backbone, soaking Flying and Rock moves while laying hazards or setting Tailwind. In return, Lokix removes Ghost- and Dark-types that threaten them. The core idea is to stack offensive pressure so that opponents cannot safely max or set up without losing at least one Pokémon to Lokix’s priority.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Lokix’s 71 / 92 / 62 bulk is mediocre, meaning any neutral Fire-type move such as Heat Wave from Togekiss or Eruption from Torkoal is an OHKO even without a boosting item. Flying-types that resist both STABs—Togekiss, Corviknight, and Salamence—can Roost or set up in its face; Corviknight in particular shrugs off even +2 Leech Life after Tera Bug. Rock-types like Tyranitar and Lycanroc-Dusk take negligible damage from First Impression and retaliate with Rock Slide flinches or Accelerock priority. Priority users that outspeed Sucker Punch, such as Shadow Sneak from Dragapult or Aqua Jet from Barraskewda, can finish off a chipped Lokix before it moves. Wide Guard users like Araonguss and Hitmontop block First Impression and Leech Life, stalling out Lokix’s early pressure. Finally, Intimidate cycling from Incineroar and Salamence drops its Attack to the point where First Impression no longer secures KOs, requiring a switch or Tera to regain momentum. To beat Lokix, bring at least one Fire- or Flying-type attacker, keep rocks up to chip it into Sucker Punch range, and preserve Psychic Terrain or Wide Guard to blunt its priority.</OUTPUT>

input:
Write a detailed 'full_analysis' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Scovillain": {"Abilities": {"moody": 0.4546918473016427, "chlorophyll": 0.4888891097422567, "insomnia": 0.0026190349323232387}, "Items": {"focussash": 0.22073737791532888, "covertcloak": 0.3154145959324824, "choicespecs": 0.24953002811582714}, "Spreads": {"Modest:4/0/0/252/0/252": 0.1758040159837905, "Timid:100/0/52/4/100/252": 0.3021152033682902, "Modest:100/0/0/252/0/156": 0.20742024796478914}, "Moves": ["ragepowder", "overheat", "solarbeam", "spicyextract"], "Tera Types": {"grass": 0.25035294387696105, "ghost": 0.1642184674676552, "fire": 0.3681942750595726}, "Teammates": ["Muk-Alola", "Torkoal", "Annihilape", "Maushold", "Tauros-Paldea-Aqua", "Metagross"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Scovillain’s claim to fame is the combination of Chlorophyll, Rage Powder, and dual STAB coverage in Overheat and Solar Beam, all compressed into one slot. Under Torkoal’s sun it becomes a 252-Speed tier threat that can redirect enemy moves away from the sweepers it supports, then retaliate with 130- or 120-base-power spread moves. The usage data show three clear camps: Modest 252/252 for maximum damage, Timid bulk sets that survive -1 Dragon Darts and Pixilate Hyper Voice, and mid-range Modest spreads that outspeed base 100s after a Moody boost. Moody itself is a niche option—while it can snowball, the randomness and need to stay on field multiple turns clashes with Scovillain’s middling bulk, so Chlorophyll remains the consistent choice. Tera Grass is the most common, removing the Fire weakness and turning Solar Beam into a nuclear STAB; Tera Fire boosts Overheat under sun and flips the script on Amoonguss and Gholdengo; Tera Ghost grants immunity to Fake Out, Extreme Speed, and Parting Shot, letting it block common priority and pivot moves. Covert Cloak is the most popular item, blanking Spore, Nuzzle, and Salt Cure chip; Focus Sash guarantees at least one Rage Powder vs. Flutter Mane or Chien-Pao leads; Choice Specs turns Scovillain into a legitimate wall-breaker that OHKOs bulky Kyogre and Tornadus in sun at the cost of locking into one attack. Spicy Extract is a tech that drops the target’s Defense two stages, enabling physical partners such as Tauros-Paldea-Aqua or Annihilape to secure KOs they would otherwise miss. The Pepper-Grenade’s real drawbacks are its paltry 65/65/55 bulk and a Stealth Rock weakness that forces Heavy-Duty Boots in singles; in doubles, however, it can operate effectively because redirection and spread damage are less punishing and sun teams compress turns by doubling into threats.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Scovillain": {"Abilities": {"moody": 0.4546918473016427, "chlorophyll": 0.4888891097422567, "insomnia": 0.0026190349323232387}, "Items": {"focussash": 0.22073737791532888, "covertcloak": 0.3154145959324824, "choicespecs": 0.24953002811582714}, "Spreads": {"Modest:4/0/0/252/0/252": 0.1758040159837905, "Timid:100/0/52/4/100/252": 0.3021152033682902, "Modest:100/0/0/252/0/156": 0.20742024796478914}, "Moves": ["ragepowder", "overheat", "solarbeam", "spicyextract"], "Tera Types": {"grass": 0.25035294387696105, "ghost": 0.1642184674676552, "fire": 0.3681942750595726}, "Teammates": ["Muk-Alola", "Torkoal", "Annihilape", "Maushold", "Tauros-Paldea-Aqua", "Metagross"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Scovillain enjoys excellent match-ups into bulky Waters and Grounds that struggle to break Covert Cloak: Gastrodon, Swampert, and Kyogre all fear Solar Beam or Overheat in sun, while Rage Powder protects its partner from Ice Beam or Water Spout. It also pressures Amoonguss, as Overheat in sun cleanly KOes standard 252/0 sets and Cloak ignores Spore. On the flip side, any faster spread attacker that outspeeds sun—Flutter Mane, Chien-Pao, Iron Bundle—can OHKO through Sash, and common Rock Slide or Heat Rock users such as Tyranitar and Landorus-T force it to Tera or die. Priority from Dragonite or Kingambit bypasses speed tiers and breaks Sash, while Tailwind or Trick Room teams remove Chlorophyll’s advantage. Finally, opposing weather—especially Sand and Rain—negates the speed boost and leaves Scovillain outrun and outgunned.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Scovillain is primarily a fast utility attacker that compresses redirection, speed control (via sun), and wall-breaking into one slot. It leads next to Torkoal to immediately threaten 2× speed and 1.5× Fire damage, clicks Rage Powder to create safe setup turns for partners like Annihilape or Metagross, and then uses its double STAB to nuke common mid-games. In the back it can clean weakened teams with Specs Overheat or act as emergency Spore/Will-O-Wisp immunity thanks to Insomnia (though Chlorophyll is still preferred). Because it demands sun to function, its role is inherently tied to Torkoal; without sun it drops to a mediocre support that most teams will simply ignore or KO.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Torkoal is mandatory: sun doubles Scovillain’s speed and boosts Overheat into a spammable 195-base-power spread move. Alolan-Muk provides Poison/Dark coverage and Clear Smog immunity, while its high special bulk lets it sponge Flutter Mane’s attacks that threaten Scovillain. Annihilape enjoys Rage Powder protection while it sets Bulk Up and benefits from Spicy Extract Defense drops. Maushold offers Friend Guard and additional redirection, stacking Rage Powder to create near-impenetrable redirect cores that allow free Population Bombs. Tauros-Paldea-Aqua appreciates sun weakening opposing water moves and loves Spicy Extract drops to secure OHKOs on bulky steels. Metagross gives a slow pivot, Psychic-terrain control, and a Flying resist that covers Scovillain’s Fighting weakness. All six teammates appear in >8 % of recorded teams, illustrating a clear blueprint: bulky pivots that can operate under sun and either set up or spread chip while Scovillain redirects.</OUTPUT>

input:

<DATA>{"Florges": {"Abilities": {"flowerveil": 0.5931123638871032, "symbiosis": 0.33046284798518627}, "Items": {"grassyseed": 0.23007398507155502, "choicescarf": 0.16653486944620768}, "Spreads": {"Timid:0/0/0/252/0/252": 0.16447603189849938, "Bold:52/0/252/156/4/44": 0.18061887382090205}, "Moves": ["moonblast", "protect", "dazzlinggleam", "pollenpuff"], "Tera Types": {"fairy": 0.611939396576405}, "Teammates": ["Ursaluna-Bloodmoon", "Rillaboom", "Maushold", "Archaludon", "Incineroar", "Tsareena"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Florges carves a unique niche as a specially-oriented Fairy support, leveraging massive natural special bulk, Flower Veil, and a wide utility movepool to babysit setup or frail attackers while dishing out consistent spread Fairy damage. Its 154 base Special Defense lets it shrug off most dragon, water, and special grass attacks, while Flower Veil blocks opposing Intimidate, Snarl, or fake-out pressure, keeping partners’ stats pristine. Grassy Seed sets turn it into an instant 252/252+ bulk monster under Grassy Terrain, letting it survive powerful Steel or Poison moves that normally spell doom. Choice Scarf variants trade longevity for immediate speed control, firing fast Dazzling Gleams or emergency Pollen Puffs to swing health races. In the current metagame Florges fits best on balanced or semi-room structures that appreciate a bulky Fairy backbone and terrain synergy with Rillaboom or Indeedee-F.</OUTPUT>

input:
Provide the 'full_analysis' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Florges": {"Abilities": {"flowerveil": 0.5931123638871032, "symbiosis": 0.33046284798518627}, "Items": {"grassyseed": 0.23007398507155502, "choicescarf": 0.16653486944620768}, "Spreads": {"Timid:0/0/0/252/0/252": 0.16447603189849938, "Bold:52/0/252/156/4/44": 0.18061887382090205}, "Moves": ["moonblast", "protect", "dazzlinggleam", "pollenpuff"], "Tera Types": {"fairy": 0.611939396576405}, "Teammates": ["Ursaluna-Bloodmoon", "Rillaboom", "Maushold", "Archaludon", "Incineroar", "Tsareena"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Florges’s main draw is its unrivaled special bulk paired with Fairy typing, giving teams a reliable answer to special Dragapult, Hydreigon, Iron Jugulis, and water-type attackers like Rotom-Wash or Sylveon. 154 SpD means it is only 3HKOed by modest Specs Hydreigon’s Draco Meteor through Grassy Terrain recovery, while +1 252 SpA Life Orb Walking Wake fails to OHKO. Flower Veil is the keystone ability: by preventing stat drops on itself and its partner it blanks Incineroar’s Intimidate, Kingambit’s Supreme Overlord stacks, and random Snarl cycles, allowing sweepers such as Swords Dance Ursaluna-Bloodmoon or Dragon Dance Archaludon to set up without fear. The typical Grassy Seed set runs Bold nature with 52 HP / 252 Def / 156 SpA / 4 SpD / 44 Spe, hitting 212 Defense after seed activation—enough to survive Jolly Choice Band Chien-Pao’s Iron Head and respond with Moonblast for the KO. 44 EVs outspeed neutral base 70s like uninvested Breloom, letting Florges fire off timely Pollen Puffs or Taunt before falling. Offensively, Moonblast is the obligatory STAB, 2HKOing most neutral targets and cleanly OHKOing No-Investment Dragons. Dazzling Gleam provides spread pressure that chips opposing boards for Maushold’s Population Bomb or Tsareena’s Triple Axel calculations. Pollen Puff gives emergency 50% healing to partners, notably restoring Ursaluna-Bloodmoon after a Belly Drum or keeping Archaludon in Sturdy range. Protect is mandatory for double-target prediction and Leftovers-style Grassy recovery. Tera Fairy is the overwhelmingly preferred option, boosting Moonblast to nuclear levels and turning Florges into a 252/252+ wall on both sides post-tera, allowing it to win 1v1s against Gholdengo, Kingambit, and even non-CB Iron Hands. Choice Scarf sets sacrifice bulk for speed control, hitting 221 Speed to outrun +1 base 100s like Dragonite and Volcarona, firing immediate STAB or healing before opposing follow-up moves. Symbiosis sees fringe use to pass consumed seeds or berries to allies, but the raw utility of Flower Veil generally outweighs the item-passing gimmick. In practice Florges functions as a mid-game pivot that soaks special hits, preserves offensive momentum, and enables teammates to snowball through cleared threats.</OUTPUT>

input:
Draft the 'matchup_overview' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Florges": {"Abilities": {"flowerveil": 0.5931123638871032, "symbiosis": 0.33046284798518627}, "Items": {"grassyseed": 0.23007398507155502, "choicescarf": 0.16653486944620768}, "Spreads": {"Timid:0/0/0/252/0/252": 0.16447603189849938, "Bold:52/0/252/156/4/44": 0.18061887382090205}, "Moves": ["moonblast", "protect", "dazzlinggleam", "pollenpuff"], "Tera Types": {"fairy": 0.611939396576405}, "Teammates": ["Ursaluna-Bloodmoon", "Rillaboom", "Maushold", "Archaludon", "Incineroar", "Tsareena"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Florges dominates special attackers and dragon-type duos, but must respect physical Steel and Poison types. Against Incineroar teams it flips the script: Flower Veil blocks Intimidate, allowing Rillaboom or Ursaluna to maintain +2 or +6 attack stages, while Grassy-boosted Moonblast 2HKOs standard Incin spreads. Versus rain, Florges walls Choice Specs Pelipper’s Hurricane and cleanly OHKOs Kingdra with Moonblast, though it must watch for Sludge Bomb Toxicroak or Iron Head Barraskewda. Sun teams featuring Walking Wake are manageable if Florges is at full; +1 Specs Steam Eruption still fails to OHKO while Moonblast in return is a guaranteed 2HKO through Mystical Water recovery. Against Trick Room, Florges can Taunt setters like Hatterene or Armarouge, or simply tank a +2 Expanding Force from Indeedee-F and retaliate. Poison cores centered on Amoonguss and Glimmora are problematic: Clear Smog ignores Flower Veil and Sludge Bomb from Life Orb Glimmora has a high chance to 2HKO even through Grassy recovery. Iron Moth likewise threatens with Sludge Bomb and can outrun non-Scarf variants. Physical Kingambit is a mixed bag: +1 Supreme Overlord Knock Off cleanly OHKOs, but if Kingambit is at +0 Florges survives and returns a Moonblast for the KO. Chien-Pao must be played carefully: Choice Band Iron Head always OHKOs, but if Florges is already seeded and healthy it can live and KO back with Tera Fairy Moonblast. Overall Florges wins special matchups and loses to strong physical Poison/Steel, so partners must cover those gaps.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Florges": {"Abilities": {"flowerveil": 0.5931123638871032, "symbiosis": 0.33046284798518627}, "Items": {"grassyseed": 0.23007398507155502, "choicescarf": 0.16653486944620768}, "Spreads": {"Timid:0/0/0/252/0/252": 0.16447603189849938, "Bold:52/0/252/156/4/44": 0.18061887382090205}, "Moves": ["moonblast", "protect", "dazzlinggleam", "pollenpuff"], "Tera Types": {"fairy": 0.611939396576405}, "Teammates": ["Ursaluna-Bloodmoon", "Rillaboom", "Maushold", "Archaludon", "Incineroar", "Tsareena"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Florges is a bulky special pivot and enabler that sits in the backline, soaks special hits, spreads Fairy damage, and keeps offensive partners healthy or stat-preserved. It is not a primary damage dealer but rather a semi-support that buys turns, heals allies, and removes dragons while blanking opposing intimidate or snarl cycles. Its Flower Veil niche is irreplaceable—no other Fairy in the tier combines 154 SpD with stat-drop immunity—making it the premier partner for setup sweepers that hate intimidate or snarl. In team preview it is usually brought when the opponent leans special or dragon-heavy, or when your own win condition (e.g., Belly Drum Ursaluna) needs protection to execute its game plan.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Florges": {"Abilities": {"flowerveil": 0.5931123638871032, "symbiosis": 0.33046284798518627}, "Items": {"grassyseed": 0.23007398507155502, "choicescarf": 0.16653486944620768}, "Spreads": {"Timid:0/0/0/252/0/252": 0.16447603189849938, "Bold:52/0/252/156/4/44": 0.18061887382090205}, "Moves": ["moonblast", "protect", "dazzlinggleam", "pollenpuff"], "Tera Types": {"fairy": 0.611939396576405}, "Teammates": ["Ursaluna-Bloodmoon", "Rillaboom", "Maushold", "Archaludon", "Incineroar", "Tsareena"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Rillaboom is the single best teammate, activating Grassy Seed for instant bulk and providing fake-out, priority Glide, and terrain control. Florges in return covers Rilla’s Fairy weakness and ignores Intimidate, letting Rillaboom stay at +2 attack. Ursaluna-Bloodmoon forms a terrifying core: Grassy Terrain weakens Earthquake, Flower Veil preserves Belly Drum or Swords Dance boosts, and Florges’s Pollen Puff can heal Luna back into Sturdy range after belly drumming. Maushold loves spread Fairy chip to set up 100% Population Bomb rolls and appreciates Florges tanking special hits aimed at it. Archaludon benefits from Flower Veil keeping its Dragon Dance or Sturdy intact, while Florges removes opposing Dragons and can Tera to wall Fighting moves. Incineroar is run alongside for pivoting and Snarl, but note that Flower Veil does not stop Parting Shot, so play accordingly. Tsareena provides Queenly Majesty to block priority and enjoys spread Fairy damage to soften checks; Florges covers Tsareena’s Poison weakness. In general Florges slots best on Grassy Terrain balances or semi-room structures that value longevity and setup facilitation.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Florges": {"Abilities": {"flowerveil": 0.5931123638871032, "symbiosis": 0.33046284798518627}, "Items": {"grassyseed": 0.23007398507155502, "choicescarf": 0.16653486944620768}, "Spreads": {"Timid:0/0/0/252/0/252": 0.16447603189849938, "Bold:52/0/252/156/4/44": 0.18061887382090205}, "Moves": ["moonblast", "protect", "dazzlinggleam", "pollenpuff"], "Tera Types": {"fairy": 0.611939396576405}, "Teammates": ["Ursaluna-Bloodmoon", "Rillaboom", "Maushold", "Archaludon", "Incineroar", "Tsareena"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Physical Steel-types—particularly Choice Band Chien-Pao, Iron Hands, and Kingambit—are public enemy number one. Chien-Pao’s Iron Head cleanly OHKOs even through Grassy recovery, while Kingambit at +1 also secures the KO. Gholdengo must be wary of Tera Fairy Moonblast but can 2HKO with Make It Rain and ignore Pollen Puff healing thanks to Good as Gold. Poison types like Iron Moth, Glimmora, and Toxicroak pack Sludge Bomb or Acid Spray and can outrun or break through. Amoonguss threatens with Clear Smog and Spore, ignoring Flower Veil’s stat protection. Physical attackers carrying Poison Jab or Iron Head in general force Florges to Tera or lose. On the special side, strong neutral attackers that can overpower its uninvested HP stat—Specs Hydreigon, Walking Wake under sun, or Choice Specs Iron Jugulis—can 2HKO if Florges is not seeded or healthy. Finally, Knock Off or Trick users cripple its item reliance: removing Grassy Seed drops its Defense by 60-70% and leaves it vulnerable to physical follow-ups. Play around these threats by keeping Florges healthy, preserving Tera for emergency bulk, and partnering with Steel or Poison resists like Incineroar or Tsareena to cover the holes.</OUTPUT>

input:
Create the 'sample_team_concept' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Florges": {"Abilities": {"flowerveil": 0.5931123638871032, "symbiosis": 0.33046284798518627}, "Items": {"grassyseed": 0.23007398507155502, "choicescarf": 0.16653486944620768}, "Spreads": {"Timid:0/0/0/252/0/252": 0.16447603189849938, "Bold:52/0/252/156/4/44": 0.18061887382090205}, "Moves": ["moonblast", "protect", "dazzlinggleam", "pollenpuff"], "Tera Types": {"fairy": 0.611939396576405}, "Teammates": ["Ursaluna-Bloodmoon", "Rillaboom", "Maushold", "Archaludon", "Incineroar", "Tsareena"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Florges @ Grassy Seed, Bold Flower Veil 52/0/252/156/4/44 — Moonblast / Dazzling Gleam / Pollen Puff / Protect Tera Fairy. Rillaboom @ Life Orb, Adamant 252/252/0/0/4/0 — Glide / Wood Hammer / Fake Out / Protect Tera Grass. Ursaluna-Bloodmoon @ Leftovers, Brave 252/252/0/0/4/0 — Earthquake / Stone Edge / Swords Dance / Protect Tera Normal. Maushold @ Wide Lens, Jolly 0/252/0/0/4/252 — Population Bomb / Protect / Tidy Up / Follow Me Tera Normal. Incineroar @ Sitrus Berry, Careful 252/0/100/0/108/48 — Parting Shot / Flare Blitz / Darkest Lariat / Fake Out Tera Fire. Archaludon @ Assault Vest, Modest 252/0/0/252/4/0 — Flash Cannon / Dragon Pulse / Electro Shot / Body Press Tera Steel. The team operates as a Grassy Terrain balance: lead Rillaboom + Florges to seed up, set terrain, and soften opposing boards with spread Fairy + Glide chip. Mid-game bring in Ursaluna to set up under Flower Veil protection, or pivot Incineroar to debuff and preserve momentum. Maushold cleans late after chip, while Archaludon provides special breaking power and a Steel-type to absorb Poison attacks aimed at Florges. The core covers Florgen’s weaknesses—Incineroar handles Chien-Pao, Archaludon answers Gholdengo and Poison types, and Rillaboom’s Glide removes faster threats—while Florges keeps everyone healthy and stat-preserved.</OUTPUT>

input:
Write the 'short_summary' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Avalugg": {"Abilities": {"icebody": 0.01846510998203793, "sturdy": 0.7309647707142561, "owntempo": 0.28311155978269337}, "Items": {"leftovers": 0.23541407109157428, "loadeddice": 0.34710902669478083, "custapberry": 0.3592544200213745}, "Spreads": {"Brave:4/252/252/0/0/0": 0.363381659138399, "Relaxed:100/156/252/0/0/0": 0.3421218929342319}, "Moves": ["bodypress", "protect", "icespinner", "wideguard"], "Tera Types": {"fighting": 0.94126972488684}, "Teammates": ["Indeedee-F", "Palafin", "Armarouge", "Sneasler", "Torkoal", "Exeggutor"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Avalugg carves a niche as a physically indestructible tank that flips the script on physical attackers: Sturdy guarantees it survives any opening blow, and with 252+ Def it immediately retaliates with Body Press scaled off that same colossal stat. Its EV spreads focus on Brave or Relaxed natures to either hit harder or out-slow Trick Room staples, while Tera Fighting pushes Body Press to nuclear levels and removes its Ice typing’s crippling weaknesses. Leftovers, Loaded Dice, and Custap Berry form a three-way item split—Leftovers for gradual recovery, Dice for a 49% Icicle Spear-style Ice Spinner boost, and Custap for a priority emergency button—letting Avalugg choose between long-game, chip, or clutch plays. Wide Guard and Protect round out its support kit, blanking spread moves like Rock Slide and Water Spout that plague current hyper-offense cores. Teammates such as Indeedee-F and Armarouge appreciate Wide Guard blocking Fake Out and spread damage, while Palafin and Sneasler value Avalugg’s ability to bait and cripple opposing physical threats so they can clean late-game.</OUTPUT>

input:
Write the 'full_analysis' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Avalugg": {"Abilities": {"icebody": 0.01846510998203793, "sturdy": 0.7309647707142561, "owntempo": 0.28311155978269337}, "Items": {"leftovers": 0.23541407109157428, "loadeddice": 0.34710902669478083, "custapberry": 0.3592544200213745}, "Spreads": {"Brave:4/252/252/0/0/0": 0.363381659138399, "Relaxed:100/156/252/0/0/0": 0.3421218929342319}, "Moves": ["bodypress", "protect", "icespinner", "wideguard"], "Tera Types": {"fighting": 0.94126972488684}, "Teammates": ["Indeedee-F", "Palafin", "Armarouge", "Sneasler", "Torkoal", "Exeggutor"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Avalugg’s calling card is its gargantuan base 184 Defense, the highest in the format bar niche picks like Shuckle. This stat is maximized in both of its two dominant spreads—Brave 252/252/4 and Relaxed 252/156/100—turning Body Press into a 150-plus BP Fighting move coming off 400-plus Defense. Sturdy is the clear ability of choice (73% usage) because it guarantees Avalugg can always get off at least one attack or support move, making it a premier lead into hyper-offensive dragons, Koraidon, or Chien-Pao stacks. The remaining 28% split between Ice Body and Own Tempo is largely niche: Ice Body can combo with hail set by Torkoal’s UV or Snowscape users to give 1/16 recovery, while Own Tempo prevents confusion from Topsy-Turvy or Dynamic Punch, though these cases are fringe. Itemization is where Avalugg becomes unpredictable. Leftovers (23%) gives 6.25% per turn, letting it stick around to fire multiple Body Presses or Wide Guards; Loaded Dice (35%) turns Ice Spinner into a pseudo-Icicle Spear that can break Focus Sash or Substitute on threats like Flutter Mane or Dragonite; Custap Berry (36%) sits at the intersection of cheese and consistency, allowing Avalugg to move first under 25% HP to fire a game-winning Body Press or Wide Guard before fainting. Tera Fighting is omnipresent (94%) because it removes the 4× weakness to Fighting and Steel while boosting STAB Body Press to astronomical levels; the remaining 6% likely run Tera Ice for emergency Freeze-Dry checks or Tera Water to flip Fire matchups, but Fighting is almost strictly superior. Moveset compression is tight: Body Press is mandatory damage, Protect scouts choice locks and gains Leftovers recovery, Ice Spinner is Avalugg’s only way to hit Ghost-types and provides terrain-removal utility, and Wide Guard is the glue that makes Avalugg a support pivot, blocking spread moves from Gholdengo, Torkoal, or Iron Moth that would otherwise shred its slower teammates.</OUTPUT>

Write a detailed 'matchup_overview' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Avalugg": {"Abilities": {"icebody": 0.01846510998203793, "sturdy": 0.7309647707142561, "owntempo": 0.28311155978269337}, "Items": {"leftovers": 0.23541407109157428, "loadeddice": 0.34710902669478083, "custapberry": 0.3592544200213745}, "Spreads": {"Brave:4/252/252/0/0/0": 0.363381659138399, "Relaxed:100/156/252/0/0/0": 0.3421218929342319}, "Moves": ["bodypress", "protect", "icespinner", "wideguard"], "Tera Types": {"fighting": 0.94126972488684}, "Teammates": ["Indeedee-F", "Palafin", "Armarouge", "Sneasler", "Torkoal", "Exeggutor"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Avalugg’s matchups read like a yin-yang chart: it hard walls every prominent physical attacker barring super-effective coverage, yet folds instantly to any special attacker with a neutral STAB. Into Koraidon, Chien-Pao, Kingambit, or Dragonite, Avalogg can switch in, eat any hit thanks to Sturdy, and OHKO back with Tera Fighting Body Press or cripple with Ice Spinner. Against Gholdengo, Iron Moth, or Iron Bundle, however, Avalugg becomes setup fodder; even resisted Flash Cannon or Freeze-Dry will 2HKO through Sturdy if it has already been broken. Wide Guard gives Avalugg a unique edge into spread-spam teams built around Torkoal + Lilligant or Gholdengo + Sylveon, buying free turns for its own sweepers. Into Trick Room, Relaxed variants underspeed uninvested base 30s like Torkoal and Hatterene, letting Avalugg fire a last-second Body Press before Trick Room goes up or stall a turn with Protect to waste Trick Room time. Against Tailwind offense, Brave variants can surprise KO offensive Tornadus or Talonflame after a Tera Fighting boost, though they must watch for Fighting coverage. Overall, Avalugg is a binary Pokémon: if the opponent leans physical, it feels unbreakable; if they lean special, it feels like dead weight.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Avalugg": {"Abilities": {"icebody": 0.01846510998203793, "sturdy": 0.7309647707142561, "owntempo": 0.28311155978269337}, "Items": {"leftovers": 0.23541407109157428, "loadeddice": 0.34710902669478083, "custapberry": 0.3592544200213745}, "Spreads": {"Brave:4/252/252/0/0/0": 0.363381659138399, "Relaxed:100/156/252/0/0/0": 0.3421218929342319}, "Moves": ["bodypress", "protect", "icespinner", "wideguard"], "Tera Types": {"fighting": 0.94126972488684}, "Teammates": ["Indeedee-F", "Palafin", "Armarouge", "Sneasler", "Torkoal", "Exeggutor"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Avalugg operates as a physical wall, anti-lead, and spread-move bodyguard rolled into one. In the lead slot it punishes Fake Out + U-turn cores by blocking both with Wide Guard and threatening massive Body Press damage. Mid-game it pivots in on physical attackers, forces them to either switch or risk the 2HKO, and then either clicks Protect to scout or Wide Guard to shield teammates from spread damage. When played in the back, Avalugg becomes a win-condition once opposing special attackers are removed, cleaning with Tera Fighting Body Press that reaches 170 BP off 430+ Defense. Its Sturdy ability also makes it an emergency stop to Sash users and a safe switch-in to Explosion or Self-Destruct strats. Because its Speed is so low, Avalugg naturally fits both Trick Room and anti-Tailwind gameplans: under Trick Room it fires first, while against Tailwind it underspeeds everything to move last and waste opposing speed control turns.</OUTPUT>

Generate the 'synergy_breakdown' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Avalugg": {"Abilities": {"icebody": 0.01846510998203793, "sturdy": 0.7309647707142561, "owntempo": 0.28311155978269337}, "Items": {"leftovers": 0.23541407109157428, "loadeddice": 0.34710902669478083, "custapberry": 0.3592544200213745}, "Spreads": {"Brave:4/252/252/0/0/0": 0.363381659138399, "Relaxed:100/156/252/0/0/0": 0.3421218929342319}, "Moves": ["bodypress", "protect", "icespinner", "wideguard"], "Tera Types": {"fighting": 0.94126972488684}, "Teammates": ["Indeedee-F", "Palafin", "Armarouge", "Sneasler", "Torkoal", "Exeggutor"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Indeedee-F is Avalugg’s most common partner (appearing in roughly 1/6 of teams) because Psychic Terrain blocks priority that would otherwise pick off Sturdy, while Follow Me redirects special attacks that would break Avalugg. Palafin forms a classic physical-mind games core: opponents must choose whether to target Palafin’s bulk or Avalugg’s Defense, and both appreciate Wide Guard blocking spread moves. Armarouge loves Wide Guard protection while it sets up Expanding Force or Armor Cannon, and in return it deletes Steel-types that resist Body Press. Sneasler benefits from Avalugg drawing in Fighting-type moves, gaining free switch-ins to activate Poison Touch, while Sneasler’s Dire Claw pressure forces switches that Avalugg can capitalize on. Torkoal sets sun, but more importantly it deters opposing Water-types and can itself run Wide Guard alongside Avalugg for double-board hazard protection; the pair also underspeeds most threats under Trick Room. Exeggutor rounds out the list as a secondary Trick Room setter that baits Ice- and Bug-type moves for Avalugg to switch in on, while Avalugg blocks Rock Slide that would flinch Exeggutor. Across these teammates, the common threads are redirectors, terrain setters, and Trick Room synergy—Avalogg needs either speed control or redirection to avoid being overwhelmed by special attackers.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Set 1 – Custap Cheese: Brave 252 HP / 252 Def / 4 Atk with Sturdy, Custap Berry, Tera Fighting; moves Body Press / Protect / Ice Spinner / Wide Guard. EVs maximize Body Press damage and physical bulk; Custap guarantees a priority move at 25% HP, letting Avalugg fire a last-ditch Body Press or Wide Guard. Set 2 – Leftovers Tank: Relaxed 100 HP / 156 Def / 252 SpD / 0 Spe with Sturdy, Leftovers, Tera Fighting; moves Body Press / Protect / Ice Spinner / Wide Guard. The special bulk investment lets Avalugg survive modest Specs Flutter Mane Shadow Ball or Life Orb Gholdengo Flash Cannon after Sturdy is broken, while still hitting hard with Body Press. Set 3 – Loaded Dice Chip: Brave 252 HP / 252 Def / 4 Atk with Sturdy, Loaded Dice, Tera Fighting; moves Body Press / Ice Spinner / Wide Guard / Protect. Ice Spinner becomes a 5-hit 75 BP move that breaks Focus Sash and Substitute, perfect for puniting setup sweepers like Dragonite or Espathra. All three sets run Tera Fighting to maximize Body Press and patch defensive typing; alternate Tera types like Water or Steel can be considered if team support already covers Fighting-types.</OUTPUT>

input:
Create the 'weaknesses_and_counters' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Avalugg": {"Abilities": {"icebody": 0.01846510998203793, "sturdy": 0.7309647707142561, "owntempo": 0.28311155978269337}, "Items": {"leftovers": 0.23541407109157428, "loadeddice": 0.34710902669478083, "custapberry": 0.3592544200213745}, "Spreads": {"Brave:4/252/252/0/0/0": 0.363381659138399, "Relaxed:100/156/252/0/0/0": 0.3421218929342319}, "Moves": ["bodypress", "protect", "icespinner", "wideguard"], "Tera Types": {"fighting": 0.94126972488684}, "Teammates": ["Indeedee-F", "Palafin", "Armarouge", "Sneasler", "Torkoal", "Exeggutor"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Special attackers are the bane of Avalugg’s existence. Iron Moth’s Fiery Dance, Iron Bundle’s Freeze-Dry, and Gholdengo’s Flash Cannon all OHKO through Sturdy if it has already been broken. Priority users like Kingambit’s Sucker Punch or Dragonite’s Extreme Speed can finish off chipped Avalugg before Custap activates. Status cripples it faster than damage: burn halves Body Press damage, poison negates Leftovers recovery, and paralysis makes it even slower, allowing setup sweepers to outpace it under Trick Room. Encore or Taunt from Murkrow or Grimmsnarl locks Avalugg into Protect or Wide Guard and stalls out Sturdy. Finally, Mold Breaker users like Haxorus or Basculin ignore Sturdy entirely, scoring the OHKO with Close Combat or Superpower. To counter Avalugg, bring special attackers with neutral coverage, pack priority to finish off Custap variants, and keep Stealth Rock off your side so Sturdy remains intact.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Avalugg": {"Abilities": {"icebody": 0.01846510998203793, "sturdy": 0.7309647707142561, "owntempo": 0.28311155978269337}, "Items": {"leftovers": 0.23541407109157428, "loadeddice": 0.34710902669478083, "custapberry": 0.3592544200213745}, "Spreads": {"Brave:4/252/252/0/0/0": 0.363381659138399, "Relaxed:100/156/252/0/0/0": 0.3421218929342319}, "Moves": ["bodypress", "protect", "icespinner", "wideguard"], "Tera Types": {"fighting": 0.94126972488684}, "Teammates": ["Indeedee-F", "Palafin", "Armarouge", "Sneasler", "Torkoal", "Exeggutor"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Avalogg-Indeedee-F-Palafin-Armarouge-Torkoal-Sneasler forms a balanced Trick Room squad that abuses Wide Guard and terrain. Lead Avalugg + Indeedee-F: Psychic Terrain blocks Fake Out, allowing Avalugg to fire Wide Guard or Body Press while Indeedee-F Follow Me draws special attacks. Palafin comes in on predicted switches, grabbing free Hero Form boosts while Avalogg tanks physical hits. Armarouge sets up Expanding Force under terrain and deletes Steel-types for Avalugg, while Torkoal underspeeds everything under Trick Room and provides sun-boosted Eruption pressure. Sneasler cleans late-game once opposing special attackers are removed, benefiting from Avalugg’s ability to bait and cripple physical threats. The team features dual Wide Guard users (Avalugg and Torkoal), dual terrain control (Indeedee-F and Psychic Terrain), and dual Trick Room setters (Armarouge and Torkoal), ensuring speed control and board protection throughout the match. EV spreads prioritize physical bulk on Avalogg, special bulk on Indeedee-F, and mixed offenses on the sweepers, creating a cohesive unit that flips matchups against both hyper-offense and hard-Trick Room squads.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Bastiodon": {"Abilities": {"sturdy": 0.4388124872508209, "soundproof": 0.40855258340192613}, "Items": {"leftovers": 0.9568934405238584}, "Spreads": {"Bold:252/0/252/0/4/0": 0.44909662233879916, "Careful:252/0/4/0/252/0": 0.3902421511529715}, "Moves": ["bodypress", "irondefense", "wideguard", "foulplay"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.552428562834263, "water": 0.36616658846709277}, "Teammates": ["Incineroar", "Sinistcha", "Ursaluna-Bloodmoon", "Clefable", "Lurantis", "Slowking"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Bastiodon is a hyper-specialized physical wall that leverages its astronomical Defense and access to Body Press to become a slow, methodical win-condition. With Iron Defense + Body Press as its core, it sets up on physical attackers, spreads Wide Guard support, and disrupts with Foul Play; Sturdy guarantees at least one turn of setup, while Ghost Tera removes Fighting neutrality and Normal immunities, and Water Tera patches the Fire weakness. Leftovers is the only item ever considered, and it is almost always seen alongside Incineroar and special-oriented pivots such as Sinistcha, Slowking, and Clefable that can cover its Special side, redirect, or remove hazards so Bastiodon can actually move.</OUTPUT>

Write a detailed 'full_analysis' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Bastiodon": {"Abilities": {"sturdy": 0.4388124872508209, "soundproof": 0.40855258340192613}, "Items": {"leftovers": 0.9568934405238584}, "Spreads": {"Bold:252/0/252/0/4/0": 0.44909662233879916, "Careful:252/0/4/0/252/0": 0.3902421511529715}, "Moves": ["bodypress", "irondefense", "wideguard", "foulplay"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.552428562834263, "water": 0.36616658846709277}, "Teammates": ["Incineroar", "Sinistcha", "Ursaluna-Bloodmoon", "Clefable", "Lurantis", "Slowking"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Bastiodon’s niche in VGC is defined by one number: 614 max Defense after one Iron Defense, turning Body Press into a 120 BP STAB move that cleanly OHKOes standard Incineroar and 2HKOes most neutral targets. Sturdy guarantees it cannot be OHKOed by any single hit from full HP, giving it a free turn to Iron Defense or click Wide Guard to block spread moves that would otherwise chip it into KO range. Soundproof is a situational alternative that blanks Hyper Voice and Boomburst, but the consistency of Sturdy is preferred. EV spreads are simple: max HP and max Defense (Bold) is the dominant spread, while Careful trades 4 Defense for 4 SpDef to slightly cushion special hits; both run 0 Speed IVs to underspeed every relevant threat and ensure Leftovers recovery before taking damage. Ghost Tera is the most common because it removes Bastiodon’s Fighting weakness and grants a Normal immunity, letting it wall and set up on Extreme-Speed users and Ghost-types like Aegislash. Water Tera is the second choice to halve Fire damage and survive stray Heat Waves or Ceruledge Flare Blitzes. The move set is fixed: Iron Defense doubles its Defense in one turn, Body Press converts that into immediate pressure, Wide Guard protects both slots from spread moves—crucial for a Pokémon that wants to stay on the field for multiple turns—and Foul Play punishes physical set-uppers like Dragonite or Kingambit that try to boost alongside it. Leftovers is mandatory because Bastiodon lacks reliable recovery and needs to be at full HP to keep Sturdy intact.</OUTPUT>

Create the 'matchup_overview' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Bastiodon": {"Abilities": {"sturdy": 0.4388124872508209, "soundproof": 0.40855258340192613}, "Items": {"leftovers": 0.9568934405238584}, "Spreads": {"Bold:252/0/252/0/4/0": 0.44909662233879916, "Careful:252/0/4/0/252/0": 0.3902421511529715}, "Moves": ["bodypress", "irondefense", "wideguard", "foulplay"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.552428562834263, "water": 0.36616658846709277}, "Teammates": ["Incineroar", "Sinistcha", "Ursaluna-Bloodmoon", "Clefable", "Lurantis", "Slowking"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Bastiodon hard-counters every prominent physical attacker that lacks a super-effective Fighting, Ground, or Water move: Incineroar, Kingambit, Scizor, Dragonite, Chien-Pao, and even Choice Band Ursaluna are all walled and eventually KOed by +2 Body Press. It folds instantly to any special attacker with a moderately strong STAB: Flutter Mane, Hydreigon, Iron Moth, and Sylveon all OHKO through Sturdy with their respective moves. Water-types such as Rotom-Wash or Palafin can break through with Hydro Steam or Jet Punch, while Ground-types like Great Tusk or Lando-T must be wary of Wide Guard denying Earthquake, but can still click Tera Ground Tectonic Rage for the KO. Sun teams carrying Torkoal or Ceruledge are problematic because Heat Wave or Sun-boosted Flare Blitz cleanly OHKO even through Water Tera. Trick Room teams that run special setters like Hatterene or Indeedee can ignore Bastiodon’s speed tier and nuke it before it moves. Finally, any team packing Taunt or Encore completely shuts down its Iron Defense loop and forces it to become passive Wide Guard fodder.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Bastiodon is a dedicated physical win-condition and support wall. In the early game it acts as a pivot that switches into physical attackers, clicks Wide Guard to block spread moves, and chips with Foul Play. Once opposing special attackers and Fighting/Ground coverage are removed, it sets up Iron Defense and sweeps with Body Press. Because it is slower than every relevant threat, it functions perfectly under Trick Room or in slow pivot chains where teammates like Slowking or Clefable bring it in safely with Teleport or Friend Guard. Its low Speed also guarantees Leftovers recovery before taking damage, keeping Sturdy intact for multi-turn sequences. It is not a traditional lead nor a speed control piece; instead it is a mid-to-late-game monster that requires hazard removal and special wall support to function.</OUTPUT>

input:
Produce the 'full_analysis' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Pincurchin": {"Abilities": {"electricsurge": 0.8430390302284785, "lightningrod": 0.0029050663114170705}, "Items": {"electricseed": 0.21459543390148436, "sitrusberry": 0.15495786955157737}, "Spreads": {}, "Moves": ["suckerpunch", "protect", "electroweb", "thunderwave"], "Tera Types": {"electric": 0.29592470398967885}, "Teammates": ["Raichu-Alola", "Archaludon", "Pelipper", "Incineroar", "Farigiraf", "Basculegion"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Pincurchin’s claim to fame is Electric Surge, the only automatic terrain setter available in VGC 2024.  This allows it to guarantee Electric Terrain without wasting a turn on Max Lightning or a move slot on a manual setter, giving it a unique support niche.  Once on the field it functions as a utility pivot: Electroweb drops both opponents’ Speed by one stage, Thunder Wave can paralyze a single target, and Sucker Punch gives it a form of priority that punishes weakened or frail attackers.  Protect is mandatory to stall Dynamax turns and to gain value from Sitrus Berry or Electric Seed boosts.  The terrain itself boosts Electric-type moves by 30 %, prevents sleep, and activates Electric Seed for a one-stage Defense boost—tools that dedicated teammates can exploit.  Pincurchin’s own stats are unimpressive; 48 / 95 / 85 defenses are merely okay, and 101 Attack is usable but not threatening.  Consequently it is played as a pivot that comes in, sets terrain, applies speed control or paralysis, and then either Protects or switches out.  Tera Electric is by far the most common Tera type, giving a 50 % power boost to its STAB and making Electroweb and Thunder Wave slightly more annoying, though Tera Water or Tera Grass can be used to flip match-ups versus Ground or Grass types respectively.  EV spreads are not listed in the data, but typical builds invest in bulk (often 252 HP / 156 Def / 100 SpD with a Relaxed nature) to survive a hit and get off at least one disruption move.  Because it offers so much role compression, Pincurchin fits best on structured terrain teams that can capitalise on the automatic terrain and the speed control it provides.</OUTPUT>

input:
Create the 'matchup_overview' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Pincurchin": {"Abilities": {"electricsurge": 0.8430390302284785, "lightningrod": 0.0029050663114170705}, "Items": {"electricseed": 0.21459543390148436, "sitrusberry": 0.15495786955157737}, "Spreads": {}, "Moves": ["suckerpunch", "protect", "electroweb", "thunderwave"], "Tera Types": {"electric": 0.29592470398967885}, "Teammates": ["Raichu-Alola", "Archaludon", "Pelipper", "Incineroar", "Farigiraf", "Basculegion"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Pincurchin’s match-ups are defined more by the terrain it sets than by its own power.  Versus Grass types it struggles: Rillaboom’s Grassy Glide and Breloom’s Mach Punch KO before it can move, and their priority ignores Electroweb speed drops.  Ground-types such as Garchomp, Landorus-T and Great Tusk wall it completely, forcing Pincurchin to rely on Sucker Punch chip or to switch out.  Conversely, versus Flying and Water teams it provides a solid pivot: Electric Terrain blocks sleep from Amoonguss and Venusaur, while Electroweb slows threats like Tornadus and Pelipper for teammates to outspeed.  Against Trick Room teams, Thunder Wave can cripple a setter, but Pincurchin itself is too slow to function under Trick Room, so it must paralyse or Electroweb before the room goes up.  Into sun or rain, Pincurchin’s terrain can overwrite opposing weather if it switches in after the setter, but it hates taking boosted Fire- or Water-type moves.  In the mirror, terrain wars become important: Pincurchin immediately overrides Psychic or Grassy Terrain, but loses to Rillaboom’s priority Grassy Glide and to Indeedee’s Psychic Terrain if it switches second.  Overall, Pincurchin is at its best when it can enter safely, set terrain, and get off one disruption move; it is at its worst when faced with strong Grass or Ground attackers that prevent it from doing even that.</OUTPUT>

Its primary job is to guarantee Electric Terrain for five turns, enabling Electric-Seed holders and terrain abusers while blocking enemy sleep.  Once terrain is active, it pivots between speed control (Electroweb), single-target disruption (Thunder Wave) and priority chip (Sucker Punch), using Protect to gain Leftovers-style healing from Sitrus Berry or to secure the Defense boost from Electric Seed.  It is not a win-condition itself; instead, it compresses several support roles into one slot so that teammates can focus on offence.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>The most common teammates reflect a clear game-plan.  Alolan Raichu is the classic terrain abuser, gaining doubled Speed and a 1.3× boost to its STAB while firing off 100 %-accurate Rising Voltages.  Archaludon appreciates the terrain boost on its own Electric moves and can set up with Metal Sound or Dragon Dance behind Pincurchin’s disruption.  Pelipper seems odd at first, but rain teams sometimes slot Pincurchin solely to overwrite Psychic Terrain and to slow opposing Swift Swim attackers with Electroweb.  Incineroar provides Fake Out and Intimidate support, easing Pincurchin’s entry turn, while Farigiraf offers Indeedee-style redirection and can expand the terrain’s duration with Terrain Pulse.  Basculegion enjoys the immunity to sleep and can fire off terrain-boosted Wave Crash or Poltergeist.  In general, Pincurchin fits on structured teams that need terrain but cannot afford a manual setter, and that appreciate both speed control and a sleep counter in one slot.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Grass-type priority—especially Rillaboom’s Grassy Glide—destroys Pincurchin before it can move, making the grassy cat its hardest counter.  Ground-types that can stomach a Sucker Punch, such as Great Tusk and Garchomp, force it out immediately.  Faster Taunt users like Murkrow or Talonflame prevent Protect or Thunder Wave, leaving Pincurchin as dead weight. To counter it, bring a Grass or Ground attacker, keep Rillaboom in the back to overwrite terrain on demand, or simply double-target it on the turn it switches in to prevent any utility.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Exeggutor-Alola": {"Abilities": {"harvest": 0.7065605872595218, "frisk": 0.1257740580683825}, "Items": {"sitrusberry": 0.8470548112422235}, "Spreads": {"Quiet:252/0/212/0/44/0": 0.46853894628344483}, "Moves": ["leafstorm", "dracometeor", "trickroom", "sleeppowder"], "Tera Types": {"fire": 0.15717097193520632, "grass": 0.16958454102337536, "ghost": 0.5216051883637607}, "Teammates": ["Torkoal", "Farigiraf", "Ursaluna-Bloodmoon", "Incineroar", "Ursaluna", "Hariyama"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Alolan Exeggutor is a niche but potent Trick Room setter in VGC 2025, leveraging its unique Dragon/Grass typing and the Harvest + Sitrus Berry combo to repeatedly tank hits, set Trick Room, and fire off single-use STABs before going down. Quiet nature with 44 Speed IVs guarantees it underspeeds all relevant threats under Trick Room, while Sleep Powder provides a 55 % win-condition button against Dynamax and Tera users. Its primary value lies in enabling slow, powerful teammates such as Ursaluna-Bloodmoon and Hariyama, and it appreciates sun support from Torkoal to patch up its Fire weakness and re-activate Harvest. Tera Ghost is the dominant choice, removing its debilitating weaknesses to Ice, Dragon and Fairy while giving it a one-time immunity to Fake Out and Extreme Speed, though Tera Fire and Tera Grass remain situational alternatives.</OUTPUT>

input:
Create the 'full_analysis' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Exeggutor-Alola": {"Abilities": {"harvest": 0.7065605872595218, "frisk": 0.1257740580683825}, "Items": {"sitrusberry": 0.8470548112422235}, "Spreads": {"Quiet:252/0/212/0/44/0": 0.46853894628344483}, "Moves": ["leafstorm", "dracometeor", "trickroom", "sleeppowder"], "Tera Types": {"fire": 0.15717097193520632, "grass": 0.16958454102337536, "ghost": 0.5216051883637607}, "Teammates": ["Torkoal", "Farigiraf", "Ursaluna-Bloodmoon", "Incineroar", "Ursaluna", "Hariyama"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Harvest is the engine that makes Alolan Exeggutor function: after consuming Sitrus Berry it has an 50 % chance per turn to recycle the berry, effectively giving it two full-boosted Leaf Storms or Draco Meteors and the longevity to set Trick Room twice in longer games. The chosen Quiet spread (252 HP / 212 Def / 44 SpD) maximises physical bulk while guaranteeing it survives -1 Life Orb Dragonite Earthquake and +1 Kingambit Iron Head, two of the most common spread moves aimed at it. Leaf Storm and Draco Meteor provide immediate 130 BP STAB nukes that dent common metagame staples like Tyranitar, Garchomp, Toxapex and opposing Farigiraf, while Trick Room flips the speed tiers for its teammates. Sleep Powder is the cherry on top: a 75 % accurate, non-priority status that ignores Substitute, giving Exeggutor a pseudo-Protect turn and potentially shutting down a Dynamax sweeper for three turns. Tera Ghost is preferred because it removes the 4× Ice weakness and grants a crucial immunity to Fake Out, allowing Exeggutor to set Trick Room even against Incineroar + Grimmsnarl leads. Tera Fire is taken when sun is already up to halve Fire damage and bluff a different Tera type, while Tera Grass is a greedy option to boost Leaf Storm to astronomical levels at the cost of keeping the Ice weakness. The teammates listed—Torkoal, Farigiraf, Ursaluna-Bloodmoon, Incineroar, Ursaluna and Hariyama—form a classic slow-mode core: Torkoal provides sun and spread damage, Farigiraf blocks priority and sets Psychic Terrain, Incineroar offers Intimidate and Parting Shot pivots, while the Bloodmoon Ursaluna and Hariyama appreciate Trick Room to outspeed and obliterate faster threats.</OUTPUT>

input:

<DATA>{"Exeggutor-Alola": {"Abilities": {"harvest": 0.7065605872595218, "frisk": 0.1257740580683825}, "Items": {"sitrusberry": 0.8470548112422235}, "Spreads": {"Quiet:252/0/212/0/44/0": 0.46853894628344483}, "Moves": ["leafstorm", "dracometeor", "trickroom", "sleeppowder"], "Tera Types": {"fire": 0.15717097193520632, "grass": 0.16958454102337536, "ghost": 0.5216051883637607}, "Teammates": ["Torkoal", "Farigiraf", "Ursaluna-Bloodmoon", "Incineroar", "Ursaluna", "Hariyama"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Alolan Exeggutor dominates match-ups against rain and sand archetypes that rely on fast, frail attackers such as Barraskewda, Kingdra, Lilligant-Hisui and Excadrill, as Trick Room strips them of their speed advantage and Leaf Storm/Draco Meteor OHKO or 2HKO them. It also pressures common balance cores built around Gholdengo, Toxapex and Corviknight, since none appreciate a -2 SpA drop or Sleep Powder. Conversely, it struggles against opposing sun teams that carry faster Chlorophyll sweepers like Venusaur and Roaring Moon, which outspeed even under Trick Room and threaten with Sludge Bomb or Acrobatics. Priority users such as Dragonite with Extreme Speed or Kingambit with Sucker Punch can pick off a weakened Exeggutor before it moves, especially if Harvest fails to trigger. Finally, Ice-type coverage from Kyurem, Chien-Pao or a Tera Ice Iron Bundle is an existential threat, OHKOing through Sitrus unless Exeggutor has already Terastallized into Ghost or Fire.</OUTPUT>

It leads in roughly 60 % of games to guarantee Trick Room goes up, and in the remaining 40 % it is brought in the back to reset room mid-game or clean with Sleep Powder once checks are weakened. Its low speed tier (44 IVs hits 52 Speed) makes it the slowest viable setter outside of troll builds, ensuring it always moves first under Trick Room. The combination of Harvest + Sitrus gives it pseudo-Recover, allowing it to tank super-effective hits and still fire off two high-powered attacks. Offensively, it distinguishes itself from other setters like Farigiraf and Indeedee by actually threatening KOs rather than simply supporting teammates, making it harder for opponents to ignore.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Priority and speed control outside of Trick Room are the most reliable answers. Dragonite with Extreme Speed or Scizor with Bullet Punch can finish off a chipped Exeggutor before Harvest triggers. Chien-Pao and Kyurem carry strong Ice-type coverage that OHKOs unless Exeggutor has Terastallized. Faster sleep absorbers such as Tera Grass Clodsire or Chesto Berry Garganacl can soak Sleep Powder and retaliate. Opposing weather setters like Pelipper or Snow can overwrite sun, cutting Harvest’s recovery rate in half. Finally, double-targeting Exeggutor on the turn it sets Trick Room often forces a 2-for-1 trade; if it does not proc Harvest, it rarely lives two super-effective hits. Once Trick Room is denied, any fast offensive core can simply outrun and KO before it moves.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Decidueye": {"Abilities": {"overgrow": 0.8419640553807819, "longreach": 0.051452792610362064}, "Items": {"focussash": 0.88708875703521}, "Spreads": {"Timid:0/0/4/252/0/252": 0.8752412048320228}, "Moves": ["shadowball", "tailwind", "grasspledge", "protect"], "Tera Types": {"stellar": 0.8752412048320487}, "Teammates": ["Archaludon", "Greninja", "Annihilape", "Ninetales-Alola", "Ursaluna-Bloodmoon", "Sneasler"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Decidueye carves a unique niche in VGC as a fast Tailwind setter that compresses speed control, Ghost-type offense, and Grass-type coverage into a single slot. With a Timid 252 Speed spread, Focus Sash, and Overgrow, it outspeeds the crowded base-90 tier and below, guaranteeing Tailwind versus non-scarfers while still threatening immediate KO pressure with Shadow Ball and Grass Pledge. Its signature niche lies in being the only Tailwind user that simultaneously pressures common Trick Room setters like Indeedee-F and Hatterene for super-effective damage while punishing Water- and Ground-type restricted slots such as Kyogre, Groudon, and Raging Bolt with Grass Pledge. Tera Stellar lets it nuke common Steel-type answers such as Kingambit and Gholdengo with a neutral Shadow Ball, and the typeless nature of Stellar removes its own defensive weaknesses for a turn, buying crucial setup or revenge-kill windows. The usage stats show it is almost always paired with Archaludon, Greninja, Alolan Ninetales, Annihilape, Ursaluna-Bloodmoon, and Sneasler—an archetype that appreciates speed control, Aurora Veil stacking, and breaking power versus bulky Waters and Steels.</OUTPUT>

input:
Generate the 'full_analysis' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Decidueye": {"Abilities": {"overgrow": 0.8419640553807819, "longreach": 0.051452792610362064}, "Items": {"focussash": 0.88708875703521}, "Spreads": {"Timid:0/0/4/252/0/252": 0.8752412048320228}, "Moves": ["shadowball", "tailwind", "grasspledge", "protect"], "Tera Types": {"stellar": 0.8752412048320487}, "Teammates": ["Archaludon", "Greninja", "Annihilape", "Ninetales-Alola", "Ursaluna-Bloodmoon", "Sneasler"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Decidueye’s viability hinges on its ability to act as a multi-purpose pivot that delivers Tailwind, breaks common restricted cores, and preserves momentum with Protect. Timid 252/0/4/252/0/252 guarantees it moves before most support Pokémon and many offensive threats in the mid-speed tiers, while Focus Sash cushions any single hit, ensuring Tailwind goes up even against faster leads or spread damage. Shadow Ball is its most consistent STAB, 2HKOing bulky Psychics like Indeedee-F and Calyrex-I after minor chip and cleanly OHKOing Flutter Mane and Lunala after Tera Stellar or Overgrow boosts. Grass Pledge provides critical coverage versus Kyogre, Gastrodon, and Raging Bolt, all of which otherwise wall common Tailwind setters like Tornadus-I or Whimsicott. Protect is mandatory in doubles to stall Fake Out, dodge Zacian’s Behemoth Blade, or preserve Sash for a second Tailwind cycle. Overgrow is preferred because Long Reach offers negligible utility when Decidueye’s main attacks are already contactless; instead, Overgrow turns Grass Pledge into a nuke when Sash is broken, securing unexpected KOs on neutral targets like Gholdengo or Archaludon. Tera Stellar is the overwhelmingly popular choice, providing both offensive and defensive utility: offensively, it makes Shadow Ball neutral on Kingambit and Gholdengo while still hitting Ghosts super-effectively; defensively, it removes Decidueye’s Flying, Ice, and Dark weaknesses for a turn, letting it survive Icerendner from Chien-Pao or Sucker Punch from Kingambit and retaliate or reset Tailwind. The teammate pool reveals a clear archetype: Archaludon and Greninja form a Steel-Water offensive core that abuses Tailwind to outspeed and shred foes with Electro Shot and Hydro Pump; Alolan Ninetales supplies Aurora Veil, which stacks with Focus Sash to make Decidueye almost impossible to OHKO, while also providing Snow and Freeze-Dry coverage; Annihilape and Ursaluna-Bloodmoon are bulky win conditions that appreciate speed control to close out games; Sneasler offers priority Dire Claw and fast Poison coverage versus Fairy-types that trouble Decidueye. Together these Pokémon create a balanced offensive structure that leverages speed control, dual screens, and powerful spread moves to overwhelm traditional balance and hard-TR teams alike.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Decidueye": {"Abilities": {"overgrow": 0.8419640553807819, "longreach": 0.051452792610362064}, "Items": {"focussash": 0.88708875703521}, "Spreads": {"Timid:0/0/4/252/0/252": 0.8752412048320228}, "Moves": ["shadowball", "tailwind", "grasspledge", "protect"], "Tera Types": {"stellar": 0.8752412048320487}, "Teammates": ["Archaludon", "Greninja", "Annihilape", "Ninetales-Alola", "Ursaluna-Bloodmoon", "Sneasler"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Decidueye’s matchups are polarized: it dominates slow, bulky teams that rely on Trick Room or bulky Waters, but struggles against hyper-offense that carries faster Fake Out or priority. Against Trick Room, Shadow Ball OHKOs Indeedee-F and Hatterene before they can set, while Tailwind denies reverse speed control; versus Kyogre or Groudon rain/sun, Grass Pledge 2HKOs through Assault Vest and ignores weather, forcing switches. Against Kingambit teams, Tera Stellar Shadow Ball 2HKOs through Protect and avoids Sucker Punch KO, while Tailwind lets teammates like Greninja outspeed and KO back. However, faster Tailwind setters like Flutter Mane or Iron Bundle can KO before Decidueye moves unless it Teras, and priority users such as Chien-Pao or Kingambit can break Sash and force 50-50 Protect reads. Amoonguss completely walls both STABs and can Spore through Sash, while Gholdengo can Shadow Ball back for the KO if Decidueye does not Tera. Overall, Decidueye wins the speed control war versus mid-speed archetypes but must play carefully around faster scarfers, priority, and status.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Decidueye functions as a lead or mid-game pivot whose primary job is to fire off Tailwind while forcing immediate damage or switches. It is not a win condition; instead, it enables faster sweepers like Greninja, Archaludon, and Sneasler to operate under Tailwind, then chips or KO’s problematic walls like Indeedee-F, Gastrodon, or Raging Bolt. Its secondary role is to act as a soft check to physical set-up sweepers—Focus Sash guarantees it survives one hit, and Tera Stellar plus Shadow Ball can revenge kill weakened Kingambit or Swords Dance Arceus. Because it carries Protect, it can also serve as a safe switch-in to predicted spread moves or status, preserving momentum for teammates. In end-game scenarios, Overgrow Grass Pledge becomes a 120 BP STAB that can steal games versus weakened Water or Ground restricted Pokémon.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Archaludon is the ideal partner: under Tailwind it outspeeds and OHKOs most threats with Electro Shot, while Decidueye removes bulky Waters that wall it. Greninja supplies additional Water coverage and Spikes pressure, forming a FWG core with Decidueye and Archaludon that hits every top-tier restricted slot for at least neutral. Alolan Ninetales provides Aurora Veil, which stacks with Focus Sash to make Decidueye nearly unbreakable on turn 1, and Snow plus Freeze-Dry punishes Groudon and Dragon restricted Pokémon. Annihilape offers bulky Fake Out and Rage Powder support, redirecting away from Decidueye while setting up Bulk Up under Tailwind and screens. Ursaluna-Bloodmoon is a slow but powerful breaker that needs Tailwind to sweep; Decidueye removes Water-types and sets the speed field, while Ursaluna cleans with Blood Moon. Sneasler rounds out the squad with fast Dire Claw and Poison coverage, punishing Fairy-types like Xerneas and Zacian-C that otherwise trouble Decidueye. The shared weaknesses to Ice and Fire are mitigated by Aurora Veil and the ability to rotate Protects and Sash to preserve HP.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Emboar’s unique value lies in Reckless-boosted Flare Blitz and Wild Charge, which, when paired with STAB, reach 234 and 144 base power respectively before item modifiers. Under Trick Room, a Choice Band Emboat reaches 568 Attack, allowing it to guarantee OHKOs on max-HP Togekiss and 252/252+ Garganacl with Flare Blitz, while Wild Charge deletes Pelipper and Toxapex in rain. Clear Amulet variants trade raw power for consistency, ignoring Intimidate from Arcanine and Incineroar that otherwise force Protect stalls or Terastallization. The Grass Tera type (43% usage) removes Emboar’s Water weakness and turns opposing Water-type attacks into neutral hits, letting it stay on field against Rain or Rotom-Wash; Ghost Tera (33%) provides a Normal- and Fighting-immunity, puniting Fake Out and Extreme Speed users while blocking Rapid Spin. The two main EV spreads both run Brave and 0 IVs: 252/252 maximizes immediate damage, whereas 164/132/144/68 lives Jolly Life Orb Chien-Pao Ice Spinner and Timid Hydreigon Draco Meteor while still OHKOing 252 HP Gholdengo with Flare Blitz. Protect is omnipresent, allowing Emboar to dodge double-targets or stall out Dynamon turns. Overall, Emboar demands respect at team preview: if Trick Room goes up, it trades positively into most restricted cores, and even outside Room it functions as a terrifying wallbreaker that can Terastallize on prediction.</OUTPUT>

It struggles against faster spread attackers like Dragapult and Iron Bundle that can double-target it before Room is set; likewise, Intimidate cycling plus burn status cripples Band sets unless Emboar carries Clear Amulet. output: <OUTPUT>Emboar is a Trick Room attacker and wallbreaker whose primary job is to secure two-to-three KO’s during Room turns while absorbing or ignoring stat drops. Reckless and either Choice Band or Clear Amulet make it one of the strongest physical attackers legal in Series 2; its speed tier is intentionally minimized to operate under Room, outslowing even 0 IV Iron Hands. Terastallization turns Emboar into either a Rain-immune Grass type or a Fake-Out-immune Ghost type, giving it flexibility to stay on field after Room expires. It functions as both lead and back-line Dynamax candidate: Max Flare sets sun for its own team, Max Knuckle boosts Attack, and Max Lightning sets Electric Terrain to deny sleep. Emboar’s typing and coverage let it compress roles—Fire and Fighting already hit two-thirds of the format for at least neutral, freeing teammates to cover Dragons and Psychics.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Emboar’s most common partner, Ursaluna-Bloodmoon, shares a Brave nature and forms a terrifying slow core that pressures both physical and special sides; Bloodmoon’s Earth Power and Hyper Beam handle Water and Dragon types that Emboar dislikes. Amoonguss provides Rage Powder redirection and Spore, buying the one turn needed to set Trick Room, while Emboar’s Fire typing dissuades opposing Amoonguss from staying in. Indeedee-F sets Psychic Terrain, blocks priority Fake Out, and can Helping Hand to push Emboar’s damage into guaranteed OHKO thresholds (e.g., +HH Flare Blitz OHKOes 252 HP Dondozo through Tera Water). Dragapult gives a fast mode outside Room and can weaken or burn physical threats with Will-O-Wisp; conversely, Kingambit enjoys Emboar removing Gholdengo and Fighting types, then cleans late game under Supreme Overlord. Porygon2 is the default Trick Room setter, offering Download boosts and Ice Beam coverage for Landorus-T and Dragonite. In short, Emboar anchors a balanced Trick Room squad that can pivot between hyper-offensive and slow-control depending on the lead matchup.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Emboar": {"Abilities": {"reckless": 0.7841743984119787, "blaze": 0.020750981641589228}, "Items": {"clearamulet": 0.43708532073639844, "choiceband": 0.3884009403030245}, "Spreads": {"Brave:252/252/0/0/4/0": 0.4601807995589878, "Brave:164/132/144/0/68/0": 0.324069233538209}, "Moves": ["flareblitz", "wildcharge", "closecombat", "protect"], "Tera Types": {"grass": 0.4319185479813241, "ghost": 0.3313649489937661}, "Teammates": ["Ursaluna-Bloodmoon", "Amoonguss", "Indeedee-F", "Dragapult", "Kingambit", "Porygon2"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Emboar’s Achilles heel is its mediocre special bulk and reliance on recoil moves: Wild Charge + Flare Blitz can strip 60% of its own HP, making it easy prey for priority or spread damage. Faster Water-types—Iron Bundle, Barraskewda under rain, and Chien-Pao with Ice Spinner—can KO before Room is set if Emboar lacks Tera Grass. Intimidate + Will-O-Wisp cores (Arcanine, Rotom-H) neuter Band variants unless Emboar Terastallizes Ghost to block burn, but that consumes Tera early. Wide Guard completely blanks its dual STAB, forcing awkward Close Combat predictions or Tera timing. Finally, Ghost Tera sets lose to strong Knock Off or Dark-type STAB from Kingambit or Chien-Pao, while Grass Tera sets still fear Dragonite Hurricane or Iron Moth Fire-type moves after sun is set. A safe counter-play is to deny Trick Room with Taunt users like Murkrow or to double-target Emboar turn one with spread moves before it can move.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Riolu carves a unique niche in VGC as a Prankster support that instantly accelerates physical attackers through Coaching, breaks enemy Protects with Feint, and abuses Copycat to re-fire game-winning moves.
