input:
Draft the 'full_analysis' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Riolu": {"Abilities": {"prankster": 0.8842503493002545, "innerfocus": 0.0003265468305202468, "steadfast": 0.0006270574039487498}, "Items": {"focussash": 0.5547135512188228, "eviolite": 0.4268197458834432}, "Spreads": {"Jolly:252/4/0/0/0/252": 0.16948361847931154, "Jolly:0/252/0/0/4/252": 0.3872719310225484}, "Moves": ["coaching", "feint", "copycat", "upperhand"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.7789049732042114, "dark": 0.1854257162009399}, "Teammates": ["Rillaboom", "Incineroar", "Archaludon", "Dragapult", "Decidueye-Hisui", "Zoroark-Hisui"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Riolu’s claim to fame is Prankster Coaching, a +1 Attack and +1 Defense boost given to any ally regardless of speed tier. In doubles this means a Rillaboom, Archaludon, or Dragapult can begin firing off +1 Wood Hammers, Flash Cannons, or Phantom Forces on the very same turn, forcing the opponent to choose between targeting the fragile Riolu or the now-boosted threat. Feint strips Protect and Wide Guard from the likes of Toxapex, Amoonguss or opposing Incineroar, ensuring those boosted attacks actually land. Copycat grants further chaos: after a teammate uses a powerful spread move such as Earthquake or a speed-control option like Tailwind, Riolu can immediately copy it with priority, either doubling the pressure or re-setting field conditions. Upper Hand provides emergency Fighting coverage and a flinch chance, punishing slower support Pokémon such as Kingambit or Gholdengo. Item choice defines its longevity: Focus Sash guarantees at least one Coaching cycle against hyper-offensive teams, while Eviolite lets it live stray special hits like Dragapult’s Shadow Ball or Incineroar’s Flare Blitz and continue supporting over multiple turns. Tera Ghost is overwhelmingly popular because it grants immunity to Fake Out and allows Riolu to dodge the most common super-effective hits aimed at it (Close Combat, Mach Punch, Sucker Punch), while Tera Dark blocks Prankster Taunt and gives a slight damage bonus to Upper Hand. EV spreads are straightforward: maximum Speed with a Jolly nature outspeeds neutral-nature base 95s and ensures Prankster moves land before opposing priority, while the second spread sacrifices its own HP to invest in Attack for slightly stronger Upper Hand. The remainder of analyses show minimal deviation, indicating the community has converged on an optimized support set.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Riolu": {"Abilities": {"prankster": 0.8842503493002545, "innerfocus": 0.0003265468305202468, "steadfast": 0.0006270574039487498}, "Items": {"focussash": 0.5547135512188228, "eviolite": 0.4268197458834432}, "Spreads": {"Jolly:252/4/0/0/0/252": 0.16948361847931154, "Jolly:0/252/0/0/4/252": 0.3872719310225484}, "Moves": ["coaching", "feint", "copycat", "upperhand"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.7789049732042114, "dark": 0.1854257162009399}, "Teammates": ["Rillaboom", "Incineroar", "Archaludon", "Dragapult", "Decidueye-Hisui", "Zoroark-Hisui"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Riolu excels against bulky, Protect-reliant balance cores that rely on slow pivots such as Toxapex, Amoonguss, Garganacl or Dondozo; Coaching instantly overpowers their defensive benchmarks while Feist denies their recovery or redirection turns. It struggles against hyper-offensive Tailwind or Booster Energy teams that can double-target it before Coaching goes up; Iron Bundle, Chien-Pao and Flutter Mina can outspeed even +1 boosted allies if Riolu is removed early. Riolu also dislikes Dark-types with Mold Breaker or priority—Kingambit’s Sucker Punch or Chien-Pao’s Ice Shard can KO after Sash, while opposing Prankster users such as Grimmsnarl or Whimsicott can Taunt it unless it Terastallizes into Ghost. Finally, weather teams that pack priority such as Barraskewda under rain or Lycanroc under sand can bypass Prankster speed and finish it off.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Riolu": {"Abilities": {"prankster": 0.8842503493002545, "innerfocus": 0.0003265468305202468, "steadfast": 0.0006270574039487498}, "Items": {"focussash": 0.5547135512188228, "eviolite": 0.4268197458834432}, "Spreads": {"Jolly:252/4/0/0/0/252": 0.16948361847931154, "Jolly:0/252/0/0/4/252": 0.3872719310225484}, "Moves": ["coaching", "feint", "copycat", "upperhand"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.7789049732042114, "dark": 0.1854257162009399}, "Teammates": ["Rillaboom", "Incineroar", "Archaludon", "Dragapult", "Decidueye-Hisui", "Zoroark-Hisui"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Rillaboom forms the classic grass-terrain Coaching core, appreciating the Attack boost to turn Grassy Glide into a nuke while gaining enough bulk to survive return fire. Incineroar provides Intimidate and Parting Shot, creating a pivot loop that softens foes and repeatedly drags Riolu back in to re-Coaching. Archaludon benefits massively from Coaching’s Defense boost, letting it survive Earthquakes and Close Combats while setting up Stamina or firing off Specs Flash Cannons. Dragapult enjoys the mixed bulk and becomes nearly impossible to outspeed after one Coaching, while Decidueye-Hisui’s triple-arrow priority benefits from both Attack and Defense boosts, turning Spirit Shackle into a legitimate sweeping tool. Zoroark-Hisui rounds out the list by disguising as Riolu, drawing Fake Outs and allowing the real Riolu to Coach freely; conversely, Riolu can Terastallize into Ghost to impersonate Zoroark and bait Fighting-type moves for a free switch. In all cases Riolu appreciates partners that can redirect or reduce damage—Indeedee-F, Amoonguss or its own Feint—to guarantee a second Coaching cycle if the first was not sufficient.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Riolu": {"Abilities": {"prankster": 0.8842503493002545, "innerfocus": 0.0003265468305202468, "steadfast": 0.0006270574039487498}, "Items": {"focussash": 0.5547135512188228, "eviolite": 0.4268197458834432}, "Spreads": {"Jolly:252/4/0/0/0/252": 0.16948361847931154, "Jolly:0/252/0/0/4/252": 0.3872719310225484}, "Moves": ["coaching", "feint", "copycat", "upperhand"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.7789049732042114, "dark": 0.1854257162009399}, "Teammates": ["Rillaboom", "Incineroar", "Archaludon", "Dragapult", "Decidueye-Hisui", "Zoroark-Hisui"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Dark-type priority—especially Kingambit’s Sucker Punch or Chien-Pao’s Ice Shard—breaks Riolu’s Focus Sash and leaves it unable to secure a second Coaching. Mold Breaker users such as Haxorus or Dragapult with Infiltrator ignore Prankster and can OHKO with Tera-neutral attacks. Opposing Taunt from faster Pranksters (Whimsicott, Grimmsnarl) shuts down Coaching unless Riolu has already Terastallized into Ghost. Spread attackers like Iron Bundle’s Freeze-Dry or Palafin’s Jet Punch can bypass single-target redirection and KO both Riolu and its partner simultaneously. Finally, double-targeting from hyper-offensive leads remains the simplest solution: if both opponents commit damage to Riolu turn one it rarely survives even with Eviolite, so protecting it requires either redirection or speed control from teammates.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Riolu": {"Abilities": {"prankster": 0.8842503493002545, "innerfocus": 0.0003265468305202468, "steadfast": 0.0006270574039487498}, "Items": {"focussash": 0.5547135512188228, "eviolite": 0.4268197458834432}, "Spreads": {"Jolly:252/4/0/0/0/252": 0.16948361847931154, "Jolly:0/252/0/0/4/252": 0.3872719310225484}, "Moves": ["coaching", "feint", "copycat", "upperhand"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.7789049732042114, "dark": 0.1854257162009399}, "Teammates": ["Rillaboom", "Incineroar", "Archaludon", "Dragapult", "Decidueye-Hisui", "Zoroark-Hisui"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Rillaboom @ Life Orb | Grassy Surge | 252 HP / 252 Atk / 4 Def | Wood Hammer / Grassy Glide / Knock Off / Protect – primary Coaching beneficiary that abuses terrain and immediate +1 power. Incineroar @ Sitrus Berry | Intimidate | 252 HP / 252 Def / 4 SpD | Parting Shot / Flare Blitz / Darkest Lariat / Fake Out – pivot that softens attackers and drags Riolu back in. Archaludon @ Choice Specs | Stamina | 252 HP / 252 SpA / 4 SpD | Flash Cannon / Dragon Pulse / Volt Switch / Protect – special breaker that turns Coaching into an unwallable mixed core. Riolu @ Focus Sash | Prankster | Jolly 252 Spe | Coaching / Feint / Copycat / Upper Hand – the engine of the squad. Dragapult @ Clear Amulet | Infiltrator | 252 Atk / 252 Spe | Dragon Darts / Phantom Force / Will-O-Wisp / Protect – fast cleaner that appreciates bulk Coaching and can copycat Tailwind. Indeedee-F @ Psychic Seed | Psychic Surge | 252 HP / 252 Def / 4 SpD | Follow Me / Helping Hand / Psychic / Protect – redirection that guarantees first-turn Coaching and sets terrain to block priority. The team operates on a simple flow: Indeedee leads beside Riolu, Follow Me draws attacks while Riolu Coaches Dragapult or Rillaboom; Incineroar cycles in to Intimidate and Parting Shot, Archaludon comes for immediate wall-breaking, and Dragapult cleans once opposing speed control is dismantled by Feint and Copycat.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Galvantula is a lightning-fast special attacker that leverages its blistering base 108 Speed and Compound Eyes-boosted Thunder to act as a pivoting speed-control and hazard setter in VGC. While its frailty is notorious, Focus Sash and Covert Cloak give it enough longevity to fire off a Sticky Web or an Electroweb, enabling slower powerhouses such as Kingambit or Dragonite to operate under favorable Speed tiers. With Electric and Rock Terastallization options, it can either double-down on STAB Thunder consistency or flip the script on Flying- and Fire-type checks like Talonflame or Torkoal. <DATA>{"Galvantula": {"Abilities": {"compoundeyes": 0.6157851983710492, "unnerve": 0.19794610250258654, "swarm": 0.0009449645226763947}, "Items": {"focussash": 0.5021233381201117, "choicescarf": 0.23577047691248892, "covertcloak": 0.16173612194475906}, "Spreads": {"Modest:4/0/0/252/0/252": 0.2231991939716675, "Timid:252/0/0/4/0/252": 0.18803012363259194}, "Moves": ["electroweb", "bugbuzz", "thunder", "stickyweb"], "Tera Types": {"electric": 0.2587869888806051, "rock": 0.2088344696578517}, "Teammates": ["Amoonguss", "Garchomp", "Tyranitar", "Incineroar", "Kingambit", "Dragonite"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Galvantula’s claim to fame is Compound Eyes turning the 70% accurate Thunder into a 91% accurate 110-base-power STAB nuke coming off a usable base 97 Special Attack. Timid and Modest spreads are both viable: Timid guarantees outspeeds up to base 108 scarfers, while Modest trades some speed for a 10% damage bump that nets key OHKOs on bulky Incineroar and non-Dynamax Togekiss after chip. Electroweb offers consistent speed-control that benefits the entire team, Bug Buzz provides a reliable secondary STAB, and Sticky Web is still the only form of full-field speed control in VGC, punishing opposing Tailwind or Chlorophyll sweepers. Focus Sash is the default, guaranteeing at least one meaningful move, while Choice Scarf turns Galvantula into a surprise anti-offense pivot, and Covert Cloak protects it from Fake Out, Rock Slide flinches, and Garganacl salt-damage—letting it stick around to reset hazards later. Tera Electric amplifies Thunder’s damage and grants an immunity to paralysis, while Tera Rock lures and eliminates Flying- and Fire-type checks, notably OHKOing Talonflame through Gale Wings and chunking Torkoal under sun. Unnerve can block Custap and pinch-berry strategies, but the accuracy and power granted by Compound Eyes is almost always superior.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Galvantula": {"Abilities": {"compoundeyes": 0.6157851983710492, "unnerve": 0.19794610250258654, "swarm": 0.0009449645226763947}, "Items": {"focussash": 0.5021233381201117, "choicescarf": 0.23577047691248892, "covertcloak": 0.16173612194475906}, "Spreads": {"Modest:4/0/0/252/0/252": 0.2231991939716675, "Timid:252/0/0/4/0/252": 0.18803012363259194}, "Moves": ["electroweb", "bugbuzz", "thunder", "stickyweb"], "Tera Types": {"electric": 0.2587869888806051, "rock": 0.2088344696578517}, "Teammates": ["Amoonguss", "Garchomp", "Tyranitar", "Incineroar", "Kingambit", "Dragonite"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Against hyper-offense, Galvantula is a menace: it drops Sticky Web before most threats move, neutering scarfers and speed-boost sweepers alike, and Electroweb further cripples fast Dragons and opposing Electrics. Into bulkier archetypes it functions more as a pivot, chipping with Bug Buzz and fishing for full paralysis with Thunder. It fears priority—especially Sucker Punch from Kingambit and Shadow Sneak from Dragapult—and any spread move that breaks its sash, making partners that redirect or Intimidate essential. Rain teams both help and hinder it: Thunder becomes perfectly accurate, but opposing Swampert and Barraskewda threaten OHKOs. Sun teams dislike Sticky Web, so Galvantula can single-handedly dismantle Chlorophyll Venusaur cores if it gets a free turn. Trick Room is its worst enemy; under TR it becomes dead weight unless it carries a scarf and even then it is outrun by most setters.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Avalugg-Hisui": {"Abilities": {"sturdy": 0.07357937953629956, "strongjaw": 0.394967596393263, "icebody": 0.3344104333936363}, "Items": {"assaultvest": 0.37782180999348114, "weaknesspolicy": 0.40772647325442846}, "Spreads": {"Brave:252/252/4/0/0/0": 0.41017040749181966, "Sassy:172/84/0/0/252/0": 0.35176292163070205}, "Moves": ["protect", "rockslide", "icefang", "highhorsepower"], "Tera Types": {"flying": 0.3521763825128012, "rock": 0.38506583202020855}, "Teammates": ["Dusclops", "Torkoal", "Indeedee-F", "Hatterene", "Vikavolt", "Lilligant-Hisui"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Hisuian Avalugg carves a niche as a Trick Room–abusing physical tank that leverages its monstrous Defense, Strong Jaw–boosted Ice Fang, and Rock Slide flinches to pressure common offensive cores. Assault Vest or Weakness Policy sets operate best under Trick Room, where their abysmal Speed becomes an asset, and Tera Flying or Rock patches key weaknesses while amplifying STAB coverage. The spread data show two dominant philosophies: a Brave 252/252 maximizes immediate power and bulk, while a Sassy 172/84/0/0/252 prioritizes special bulk and Trick Room speed tier. Ice Fang + Rock Slide + High Horsepower hits nearly every relevant threat for at least neutral damage, and Protect is mandatory in doubles. Sturdy guarantees at least one move in the face of spread damage, though Strong Jaw is the preferred ability for consistent damage output. Usage stats place it alongside Trick Room staples—Dusclops, Torkoal, Indeedee-F, Hatterene—indicating its role as a slow, hard-hitting pivot that appreciates redirection and speed control.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Avalugg-Hisui": {"Abilities": {"sturdy": 0.07357937953629956, "strongjaw": 0.394967596393263, "icebody": 0.3344104333936363}, "Items": {"assaultvest": 0.37782180999348114, "weaknesspolicy": 0.40772647325442846}, "Spreads": {"Brave:252/252/4/0/0/0": 0.41017040749181966, "Sassy:172/84/0/0/252/0": 0.35176292163070205}, "Moves": ["protect", "rockslide", "icefang", "highhorsepower"], "Tera Types": {"flying": 0.3521763825128012, "rock": 0.38506583202020855}, "Teammates": ["Dusclops", "Torkoal", "Indeedee-F", "Hatterene", "Vikavolt", "Lilligant-Hisui"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Hisuian Avalugg’s base 184 Defense lets it survive even super-effective physical hits, while Strong Jaw Ice Fang (120 BP after ability) cleanly OHKOs 4 HP Landorus-T, Garchomp, and Tornadus-T after Stealth Rock chip. Rock Slide provides spread damage and flinch chance versus faster threats like Dragapult and Iron Bundle, and High Horsepower nails Toxapex, Heatran, and Gholdengo for super-effective damage. Assault Vest variants (37.8 % usage) bolster a mediocre 65 base Sp. Def to tank Moonblast from Flutter Mane and Hydro Pump from Walking Wake, whereas Weakness Policy sets (40.8 %) turn common Fighting-, Fire-, and Steel-type hits into sweeping opportunities. Tera Flying removes the crippling Fighting weakness and grants a crucial Ground immunity, letting Avalugg switch into Earthquake spam and retaliate with Ice Fang; Tera Rock boosts Rock Slide to alarming levels, securing OHKOs on Volcarona and opposing Torkoal under sun. The Brave 252/252 spread maximizes immediate damage output and physical bulk, surviving Jolly Choice Band Great Tusk Headlong Rush and retaliating for the KO. The Sassy 172/84/0/0/252 spread instead survives Modest Torkoal Overheat in sun and Timid Iron Bundle Freeze-Dry, while still outspeeding uninvested base 50s under Trick Room. Sturdy remains a niche option to guarantee a move versus hyper-offense leads, but Strong Jaw’s 1.5× boost to Ice Fang is the primary draw. Protect is non-negotiable in doubles, buying partners time to set Trick Room or weather and shielding Avalugg from double-targets. Overall, Avalugg-Hisui functions as a low-speed, high-reward breaker that punishes physical attackers and sun teams alike.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Avalugg-Hisui": {"Abilities": {"sturdy": 0.07357937953629956, "strongjaw": 0.394967596393263, "icebody": 0.3344104333936363}, "Items": {"assaultvest": 0.37782180999348114, "weaknesspolicy": 0.40772647325442846}, "Spreads": {"Brave:252/252/4/0/0/0": 0.41017040749181966, "Sassy:172/84/0/0/252/0": 0.35176292163070205}, "Moves": ["protect", "rockslide", "icefang", "highhorsepower"], "Tera Types": {"flying": 0.3521763825128012, "rock": 0.38506583202020855}, "Teammates": ["Dusclops", "Torkoal", "Indeedee-F", "Hatterene", "Vikavolt", "Lilligant-Hisui"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Against sun teams, Avalugg-Hisui is a premier answer: Torkoal fails to OHKO with uninvested Heat Wave, while Avalugg’s Ice Fang deletes sun sweepers such as Venusaur, Charizard, and Chi-Yu. Into rain, Assault Vest sets survive Choice Specs Pelipper Hurricane and retaliate with Rock Slide flinches, though they must watch for Focus Blast and Hurricane confusion. Versus hyper-offense, Sturdy guarantees at least one attack, and Ice Fang picks off fast Dragons and Grounds. Against Tailwind offense, Trick Room reverses tempo, allowing Avalugg to underspeed and KO Iron Bundle, Chien-Pao, and opposing Flutter Mane. Into stall, Avalugg lacks immediate recovery and can be worn down by status and repeated special hits, especially from Toxapex and Clodsire. Fighting-types such as Iron Valiant and Annihilape remain problematic if Tera is burned, while strong special Fire-types like Chi-Yu and Skeledirge can break through Assault Vest with sun-boosted STAB. Overall, Avalugg-Hisui wins the weather war versus sun, trades favorably versus most physical attackers, but folds to repeated special super-effective hits or status if not supported properly.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Hisuian Avalugg is a Trick Room–dependent physical tank and wallbreaker. Its job is to switch in on physical attackers, set up Trick Room via a partner, and then fire off Strong Jaw–boosted Ice Fangs and spread Rock Slides to dismantle offensive cores. Assault Vest variants act as special sponges that can tank at least one super-effective special hit and retaliate, while Weakness Policy variants aim to snowball after taking a super-effective blow. Tera Flying turns Avalugg into a Ground-immune pivot that can switch into Earthquake and spam Ice Fang, whereas Tera Rock maximizes Rock Slide damage against sun and Flying teams. The Pokémon demands Trick Room support—either from Dusclops, Indeedee-F + Hatterene, or Vikavolt—and appreciates redirection or Intimidate support to preserve its HP. In short, Avalugg-Hisui is a low-speed, high-damage anchor that punishes physical metagame staples under reversed speed control.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Avalugg-Hisui": {"Abilities": {"sturdy": 0.07357937953629956, "strongjaw": 0.394967596393263, "icebody": 0.3344104333936363}, "Items": {"assaultvest": 0.37782180999348114, "weaknesspolicy": 0.40772647325442846}, "Spreads": {"Brave:252/252/4/0/0/0": 0.41017040749181966, "Sassy:172/84/0/0/252/0": 0.35176292163070205}, "Moves": ["protect", "rockslide", "icefang", "highhorsepower"], "Tera Types": {"flying": 0.3521763825128012, "rock": 0.38506583202020855}, "Teammates": ["Dusclops", "Torkoal", "Indeedee-F", "Hatterene", "Vikavolt", "Lilligant-Hisui"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Dusclops provides the most reliable Trick Room setup thanks to its bulk and Shadow Sneak self-proc for Weakness Policy; it also offers Will-o-Wisp to cripple opposing physical attackers. Torkoal supplies sun for Vikavolt and Lilligant-Hisui, but more importantly it threatens opposing Steel-types with Eruption, paving the way for Avalugg to sweep. Indeedee-F + Hatterene form a Psyspam core that deters Fake Out and priority, ensuring Trick Room goes up; Indeedee’s Follow Me redirects Fighting-type moves away from Avalugg, while Hatterene can Heal Pulse to keep Avalugg healthy. Vikavolt benefits from sun-boosted Thunderbolts and provides a slow pivot that can bring Avalugg in safely; its Levitate complements Tera Flying Avalugg by creating dual Ground immunities. Lilligant-Hisui offers After You to let Avalugg move immediately under Trick Room, turning 2v2 exchanges into 2-0 blowouts. All listed teammates appreciate Trick Room, meaning Avalugg fits into a full-room archetype rather than a hybrid offense. The core concept is to guarantee Trick Room, remove special threats, and let Avalugg bulldoze whatever remains.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Avalugg-Hisui": {"Abilities": {"sturdy": 0.07357937953629956, "strongjaw": 0.394967596393263, "icebody": 0.3344104333936363}, "Items": {"assaultvest": 0.37782180999348114, "weaknesspolicy": 0.40772647325442846}, "Spreads": {"Brave:252/252/4/0/0/0": 0.41017040749181966, "Sassy:172/84/0/0/252/0": 0.35176292163070205}, "Moves": ["protect", "rockslide", "icefang", "highhorsepower"], "Tera Types": {"flying": 0.3521763825128012, "rock": 0.38506583202020855}, "Teammates": ["Dusclops", "Torkoal", "Indeedee-F", "Hatterene", "Vikavolt", "Lilligant-Hisui"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Special Fighting-types such as Iron Valiant, Annihilape, and Choice Specs Iron Moth OHKO even Assault Vest variants with Close Combat or Focus Blast; they must be eliminated or redirected. Sun-boosted Chi-Yu and Skeledirge can break through with Overheat and Torch Song, respectively, before Avalugg can move. Status—especially burn from Rotom-W or Gholdengo—cripples Avalugg’s damage output and removes the Strong Jaw boost by halving Attack. Taunt users like Murkrow and Grimmsnarl prevent Protect and force Avalugg to tank hits without healing. Faster Tailwind cores can double-target Avalugg before Trick Room goes up, denying its sweep. Tera Fire or Tera Fighting opponents can flip the script on predicted Tera Flying turns. Finally, without recovery, Avalugg is worn down by repeated chip, Rocky Helmet damage, and Stealth Rock if brought in via pivot moves. To counter it, bring special Fighting or Fire moves under sun, spread burn, or deny Trick Room altogether.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Mismagius": {"Abilities": {"levitate": 0.8059870213397734}, "Items": {"safetygoggles": 0.4582808630135653, "focussash": 0.23998501316426865}, "Spreads": {"Calm:148/0/0/0/164/196": 0.45638236506751834}, "Moves": ["icywind", "protect", "willowisp", "taunt"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.15649695363375427, "steel": 0.6262808165087139}, "Teammates": ["Incineroar", "Kilowattrel", "Tyranitar", "Sneasler", "Indeedee", "Excadrill"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Mismagius carves a niche in VGC as a fast, disruptive support that leverages Levitate, respectable base 105 Speed, and a wide utility movepool to control momentum. Safety Goggles variants ignore Rage Powder and hail, while Focus Sash guarantees at least one turn of Icy Wind speed control, Will-o-Wisp burns, or Taunt. With minimal bulk investment (Calm 148/164) it still avoids most common OHKOs from neutral hits, letting it cripple physical attackers or shut down set-up sweepers before fading. Its Ghost typing grants immunity to Fake Out and Fighting coverage, making it a reliable anti-meta pick into Indeedee, Sneasler, and support Dragapult cores.</OUTPUT>

input:

<DATA>{"Mismagius": {"Abilities": {"levitate": 0.8059870213397734}, "Items": {"safetygoggles": 0.4582808630135653, "focussash": 0.23998501316426865}, "Spreads": {"Calm:148/0/0/0/164/196": 0.45638236506751834}, "Moves": ["icywind", "protect", "willowisp", "taunt"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.15649695363375427, "steel": 0.6262808165087139}, "Teammates": ["Incineroar", "Kilowattrel", "Tyranitar", "Sneasler", "Indeedee", "Excadrill"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Mismagius’s value lies in its unique combination of speed tier and support tools. At 196 EVs and a Timid nature it outspeeds max-speed Flutter Mane, Chien-Pao, and Iron Valiant, letting it fire the first Icy Wind or Taunt before those threats move. Levitate is the only ability worth using; it grants immunity to Earthquake, Earth Power, and Spikes, allowing Mismagius to switch into common spread attackers like Landorus-T, Garchomp, and Ting-Lu with impunity. The chosen Calm spread (148 HP / 164 SpD / 196 Spe) survives Life Orb Chien-Pao Ice Spinner, modest Iron Valiant Moonblast, and Jolly Chien-Pao Sacred Sword after burn, while still creeping positive-nature base 110s. Safety Goggles is the dominant item because it blanks Amoonguss, rage powder users, and hail chip, turning Mismagius into a hard stop to redirection strategies. Focus Sash is the fallback on more offensive teams where entry hazards or double-target pressure are expected. Four-moveslot syndrome is real: Icy Wind provides speed control that benefits both special and physical allies, Will-o-Wisp neuters physical sweepers like Chien-Pao, Kingambit, and Sneasler, Taunt prevents Trick Room, Tailwind, and setup moves, while Protect preserves positioning and stalls out Dynamax turns. Tera Ghost is taken when you need to block Extreme Speed or retain Ghost STAB versus Calyrex-I, but Tera Steel is overwhelmingly preferred: it removes the Ghost weakness to opposing Shadow Sneak and Sucker Punch, adds crucial resistances to Fairy, Ice, and Steel, and turns Mismagius into a pseudo-steel wall that can pivot on Sylveon, Chien-Pao, and Iron Valiant. The listed teammates—Incineroar, Kilowattrel, Tyranitar, Sneasler, Indeedee, and Excadrill—show Mismagius fits on both sun/boar cores and sand squads, offering speed control for slow powerhouses and burn support for frail attackers.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Mismagius": {"Abilities": {"levitate": 0.8059870213397734}, "Items": {"safetygoggles": 0.4582808630135653, "focussash": 0.23998501316426865}, "Spreads": {"Calm:148/0/0/0/164/196": 0.45638236506751834}, "Moves": ["icywind", "protect", "willowisp", "taunt"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.15649695363375427, "steel": 0.6262808165087139}, "Teammates": ["Incineroar", "Kilowattrel", "Tyranitar", "Sneasler", "Indeedee", "Excadrill"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Mismagius shines against bulky offense and redirection cores. It blanks Amoonguss entirely (Goggles + Levitate), outspeeds and Taunts Indeedee-F before it sets terrain, and Icy Wind into Will-o-Wisp cripples physical attackers that rely on speed or attack stages. Against Trick Room it is less reliable—Hatterene’s Magic Bounce and Indeedee’s Follow Me can redirect Taunt—but it still forces mind-games and can burn Dusclops or tank a hit to break Mental Herb. Into hyper-offense it can trade itself for a burn or speed drop, neutering threats like Chien-Pao or Dragonite. Calm spread variants survive modest Flutter Mane Shadow Ball 3/4 of the time and always after burn, letting it retaliate with Icy Wind or Tera Steel to live subsequent Moonblasts. Conversely, dark types such as Kingambit and Tyranitar threaten OHKOs with Sucker Punch and Knock Off; however, both fear Will-o-Wisp and must respect a potential Tera Steel that turns Knock Off into a resisted hit. Priority from Shadow Sneak users like Aegislash and Calyrex-I can finish chipped Mismagius, but again Tera Steel removes the Ghost weakness. Overall, Mismagius offers a positive or neutral matchup into most current archetypes, demanding respect but rarely being dead weight.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Mismagius": {"Abilities": {"levitate": 0.8059870213397734}, "Items": {"safetygoggles": 0.4582808630135653, "focussash": 0.23998501316426865}, "Spreads": {"Calm:148/0/0/0/164/196": 0.45638236506751834}, "Moves": ["icywind", "protect", "willowisp", "taunt"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.15649695363375427, "steel": 0.6262808165087139}, "Teammates": ["Incineroar", "Kilowattrel", "Tyranitar", "Sneasler", "Indeedee", "Excadrill"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Mismagius operates as a lead or mid-game speed-control pivot. In the lead position it pairs with Incineroar or Kilowettrel to threaten Fake Out plus disruptive follow-ups: Icy Wind plus U-turn/Volt Switch cycles momentum while dropping enemy speed tiers. Mid-game it switches into predicted Earthquakes, spreads burns onto physical sweepers, and uses Protect to waste Dynamax turns. Because it lacks immediate KO power, its job is to tilt the risk-reward calculus—opponents must decide whether to target the frail ghost or the bigger threats behind it, and every turn they hesitate Mismagius chips speed and attack stages. Its immunity to Fake Out and Fighting coverage also lets it serve as an emergency answer to Terrakion, Iron Hands, and opposing Incineroar. Once Dynamax ends, Mismagius often sacrifices itself to secure a final Icy Wind or burn, clearing the way for cleaners like Chien-Pao or Excadrill to outspeed and sweep.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Mismagius": {"Abilities": {"levitate": 0.8059870213397734}, "Items": {"safetygoggles": 0.4582808630135653, "focussash": 0.23998501316426865}, "Spreads": {"Calm:148/0/0/0/164/196": 0.45638236506751834}, "Moves": ["icywind", "protect", "willowisp", "taunt"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.15649695363375427, "steel": 0.6262808165087139}, "Teammates": ["Incineroar", "Kilowattrel", "Tyranitar", "Sneasler", "Indeedee", "Excadrill"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Incineroar is the ideal partner: Intimidate plus Will-o-Wisp slashes opposing attack to nothing, Parting Shot brings Mismagius in safely, and both share Fire/Grass/Water coverage that blankets the meta. Kilowattrel provides Tailwind, Electric STAB for Corviknight/Toxapex, and appreciates Icy Wind letting it outspeed threats under Tailwind. Tyranitar sets sand, boosts Rock Slide flinch rates, and removes opposing weather; Mismagius punishes Fighting-types aimed at Tyranitar while Icy Wind drags enemy speed below sand-boosted Excadrill. Sneasler benefits from burn support—Will-o-Wisp weakens physical checks so Sneasler’s Dire Claw or Close Combat finishes them—and Mismagius’s speed control covers Sneasler’s middling speed. Indeedee-F is less common alongside Mismagius but forms a double-support core that can stack Follow Me plus Taunt to guarantee Trick Room or block it, depending on team style. Excadrill is the classic sand sweeper: under sand it outspeeds everything after an Icy Wind drop, while Mold Breaker ignores Mimikyu and Rotom-W abilities. In short, Mismagius plugs the speed-control gap for bulky offense and sand squads, and its immunities let it synergize with both Fire and Steel cores that hate Ground moves.</OUTPUT>

input:
Provide the 'recommended_sets' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Mismagius": {"Abilities": {"levitate": 0.8059870213397734}, "Items": {"safetygoggles": 0.4582808630135653, "focussash": 0.23998501316426865}, "Spreads": {"Calm:148/0/0/0/164/196": 0.45638236506751834}, "Moves": ["icywind", "protect", "willowisp", "taunt"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.15649695363375427, "steel": 0.6262808165087139}, "Teammates": ["Incineroar", "Kilowattrel", "Tyranitar", "Sneasler", "Indeedee", "Excadrill"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Calm Support: 148 HP / 164 SpD / 196 Spe, Calm nature, Levitate, Safety Goggles—Moves: Icy Wind, Will-o-Wisp, Taunt, Protect—Tera Steel. This is the statistically dominant set on ladder and at Regionals. The EVs guarantee survival against modest Iron Valiant Moonblast and Life Orb Chien-Pao Ice Spinner, while creeping positive base 110s such as Latios and Galar-Articuno. Safety Goggles ignores spore and hail, freeing the burn for higher-value targets. Tera Steel flips Kingambit and Tyritar matchups from losing to winning by removing Ghost weakness and resisting Knock Off. Alternative Focus Sash variant: same EVs, item swapped to Focus Sash, nature can become Timid to outspeed Flutter Mane at +0. Sash guarantees a move versus double-target leads but makes you weaker to sand, hail, and multi-hit moves like Dragon Darts. If your team already packs Wide Guard or screens, Sash can be the better pick. A third niche set runs Colbur Berry with 252 HP / 116 Def / 140+ Spe Timid to survive Kingambit Sucker Punch and burn back, but usage is under 5% and generally inferior to Tera Steel answers.</OUTPUT>

input:
Provide the 'weaknesses_and_counters' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Mismagius": {"Abilities": {"levitate": 0.8059870213397734}, "Items": {"safetygoggles": 0.4582808630135653, "focussash": 0.23998501316426865}, "Spreads": {"Calm:148/0/0/0/164/196": 0.45638236506751834}, "Moves": ["icywind", "protect", "willowisp", "taunt"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.15649695363375427, "steel": 0.6262808165087139}, "Teammates": ["Incineroar", "Kilowattrel", "Tyranitar", "Sneasler", "Indeedee", "Excadrill"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Despite its utility, Mismagius is frail on the physical side and heavily reliant on landing its status moves. Dark-types Kingambit and Tyranitar force 50-50s: if Mismagius mis-times Taunt or burn, Knock Off or Sucker Punch OHKO. Both must respect Will-o-Wisp and potential Tera Steel, but they can play around it with Protect or switch-ins like Gholdengo. Faster attackers that pack super-effective coverage—Choice Scarf Chien-Pao, Iron Valiant with Spirit Break, or Gholdengo Shadow Ball—outpace and KO before it moves. Priority users such as Bisharp Sucker Punch or Calyrex-I Shadow Sneak finish chipped Mismagius; again Tera Steel answers the Ghost weakness but costs your Tera. Status absorbers like Clodsire, Garganacl, or Toxapex with Covert Cloak ignore Will-o-Wisp and can stall Mismagius out. Finally, multi-hit moves—Dragon Darts, Population Bomb, or Baxcalibur Icicle Crash—break Focus Sash and bypass its one-turn guarantee. Opponents can also simply ignore Mismagius and double into its partner, accepting the Icy Wind drop if their win condition does not care about speed (e.g., Trick Room or Unburden sweepers). In short, Mismagius is exploitable if you deny it safe entry and force it to trade unfavorably.</OUTPUT>

input:
Generate the 'sample_team_concept' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Mismagius": {"Abilities": {"levitate": 0.8059870213397734}, "Items": {"safetygoggles": 0.4582808630135653, "focussash": 0.23998501316426865}, "Spreads": {"Calm:148/0/0/0/164/196": 0.45638236506751834}, "Moves": ["icywind", "protect", "willowisp", "taunt"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.15649695363375427, "steel": 0.6262808165087139}, "Teammates": ["Incineroar", "Kilowattrel", "Tyranitar", "Sneasler", "Indeedee", "Excadrill"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Sand Disruption: Tyranitar @ Assault Vest, Kilowattrel @ Choice Specs, Mismagius @ Safety Goggles, Excadrill @ Life Orb, Incineroar @ Figy Berry, Rotom-Wash @ Sitrus Berry. Lead Mismagius + Incineroar: Fake Out plus Icy War drops speed, Parting Shot cycles momentum. Behind sand, Excadrill outspeeds and cleans with Rock Slide; Kilowattrel provides immediate Electric power and Tailwind if sand fades. Rotom-Wash covers Water and Ground weaknesses, Volt Switches with Mismagius to form a pivoting core, and spreads burns alongside Will-o-Wisp for physical overload. Tyranitar operates as a secondary breaker that removes sun/rain and tanks special hits. The team balances speed control, disruption, and sand offense—Mismagius is the glue that lets slow sand sweepers function outside their weather window while blanking Amoonguss and Indeedee redirection that otherwise cripple sand.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Ditto": {"Abilities": {"imposter": 0.7268922174546442, "limber": 0.031822008910324606}, "Items": {"choicescarf": 0.6695809666117952}, "Spreads": {"Impish:252/0/252/0/0/4": 0.4029064563901748, "Relaxed:252/0/252/0/4/0": 0.16760700576796528}, "Moves": ["transform", ""], "Tera Types": {"normal": 0.3727170436308181, "ghost": 0.2111589480420273, "fairy": 0.23299241495925946}, "Teammates": ["Incineroar", "Ursaluna-Bloodmoon", "Dragonite", "Sneasler", "Whimsicott", "Slaking"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Ditto is the ultimate revenge killer and momentum pivot in VGC thanks to its signature ability Imposter, which lets it instantly copy the opponent’s stat changes, moves, and typing upon entry. With a Choice Scarf equipped 67% of the time, it outspeeds almost every boosted threat it faces, turning the foe’s own setup against them. Its near-exclusive role is to swing tempo by transforming into the most dangerous enemy and firing off their own attacks at higher Speed tiers.</OUTPUT>

input:
Write the 'full_analysis' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Ditto": {"Abilities": {"imposter": 0.7268922174546442, "limber": 0.031822008910324606}, "Items": {"choicescarf": 0.6695809666117952}, "Spreads": {"Impish:252/0/252/0/0/4": 0.4029064563901748, "Relaxed:252/0/252/0/4/0": 0.16760700576796528}, "Moves": ["transform", ""], "Tera Types": {"normal": 0.3727170436308181, "ghost": 0.2111589480420273, "fairy": 0.23299241495925946}, "Teammates": ["Incineroar", "Ursaluna-Bloodmoon", "Dragonite", "Sneasler", "Whimsicott", "Slaking"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Ditto’s niche is unmatched: it enters, becomes a perfect mirror of the target, and—because most sets run maximum HP and a defense-boosting nature—usually has better bulk than the original. The two most common spreads, Impish 252/0/252/0/0/4 and Relaxed 252/0/252/0/4/0, emphasize physical bulk so that Ditto can survive the first hit after Imposter triggers. Once transformed, Ditto gains the opponent’s offensive stats and movepool, but keeps its own HP, meaning it can tank a hit and retaliate with the same power and Speed (boosted by Scarf). Tera Normal is preferred to preserve STAB on its own body if it needs to attack before transforming, while Tera Ghost and Fairy provide immunities to Fake Out and Extreme Speed, respectively, letting Ditto live to transform or clean late-game. The metagame reliance on setup sweepers like Dragonite, Ursaluna-Bloodmoon, and Slaking makes Ditto a one-slot answer to entire strategies.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Ditto": {"Abilities": {"imposter": 0.7268922174546442, "limber": 0.031822008910324606}, "Items": {"choicescarf": 0.6695809666117952}, "Spreads": {"Impish:252/0/252/0/0/4": 0.4029064563901748, "Relaxed:252/0/252/0/4/0": 0.16760700576796528}, "Moves": ["transform", ""], "Tera Types": {"normal": 0.3727170436308181, "ghost": 0.2111589480420273, "fairy": 0.23299241495925946}, "Teammates": ["Incineroar", "Ursaluna-Bloodmoon", "Dragonite", "Sneasler", "Whimsicott", "Slaking"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Ditto excels against setup or bulky offense teams that rely on boosting moves such as Dragon Dance, Swords Dance, or Calm Mind. It turns +1 Dragonite into a +1 Scarf Dragonite under your control, or copies a Bloodmoon’s own Blood Moon to KO its own teammate. Against hyper-offense or hard Trick Room, however, Ditto struggles because the opposing Pokémon are often unboosted or underspeed, meaning the Scarf copy is slower or lacks meaningful damage output. It also fares poorly versus passive supports or protect-heavy structures where there is no immediate offensive threat to copy.</OUTPUT>

Write a detailed 'role_description' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Ditto": {"Abilities": {"imposter": 0.7268922174546442, "limber": 0.031822008910324606}, "Items": {"choicescarf": 0.6695809666117952}, "Spreads": {"Impish:252/0/252/0/0/4": 0.4029064563901748, "Relaxed:252/0/252/0/4/0": 0.16760700576796528}, "Moves": ["transform", ""], "Tera Types": {"normal": 0.3727170436308181, "ghost": 0.2111589480420273, "fairy": 0.23299241495925946}, "Teammates": ["Incineroar", "Ursaluna-Bloodmoon", "Dragonite", "Sneasler", "Whimsicott", "Slaking"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Ditto is a dedicated revenge killer and anti-setup pivot. It sits in the back until the opponent reveals a win condition, then switches in, transforms, and reclaims tempo. Because it carries no attacking moves of its own—only Transform—it demands precise positioning: protect the turn it comes in if needed, or bring it after a KO so it enters safely. Once transformed, Ditto functions as a faster, bulkier clone of the scariest enemy, giving your team an identical weapon without having to dedicate EVs or moveslots to that Pokémon yourself.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Ditto": {"Abilities": {"imposter": 0.7268922174546442, "limber": 0.031822008910324606}, "Items": {"choicescarf": 0.6695809666117952}, "Spreads": {"Impish:252/0/252/0/0/4": 0.4029064563901748, "Relaxed:252/0/252/0/4/0": 0.16760700576796528}, "Moves": ["transform", ""], "Tera Types": {"normal": 0.3727170436308181, "ghost": 0.2111589480420273, "fairy": 0.23299241495925946}, "Teammates": ["Incineroar", "Ursaluna-Bloodmoon", "Dragonite", "Sneasler", "Whimsicott", "Slaking"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Ditto loves teammates that can soften or paralyze the opponent’s breaker so Ditto can secure the copy and subsequent KO. Incineroar provides Intimidate and Parting Shot, creating safe entry while weakening physical setup sweepers. Whimsicott offers Tailwind and Taunt to shut down opposing speed control or priority, ensuring Ditto transforms before taking damage. Ursaluna-Bloodmoon and Slaking are themselves common Ditto targets; by including them on the same team you bait opponents into bringing them, knowing Ditto can turn their power back against them. Dragonite and Sneasler supply additional offensive pressure and priority, forcing foes to reveal boosts that Ditto can later mirror.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Ditto": {"Abilities": {"imposter": 0.7268922174546442, "limber": 0.031822008910324606}, "Items": {"choicescarf": 0.6695809666117952}, "Spreads": {"Impish:252/0/252/0/0/4": 0.4029064563901748, "Relaxed:252/0/252/0/4/0": 0.16760700576796528}, "Moves": ["transform", ""], "Tera Types": {"normal": 0.3727170436308181, "ghost": 0.2111589480420273, "fairy": 0.23299241495925946}, "Teammates": ["Incineroar", "Ursaluna-Bloodmoon", "Dragonite", "Sneasler", "Whimsicott", "Slaking"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Ditto is helpless if it cannot transform into a legitimate threat: Taunt or Encore locks it into Struggle, while double-targeting or priority before it moves can KO the uninvested base form. Opponents can also deny value by keeping their own support Pokémon active or by using unboosted, low-damage utility Pokémon that give Ditto nothing useful to copy. Finally, because Ditto retains its own HP, strong super-effective hits from the original—especially special Ice, Fighting, or Bug moves—can still break it before it retaliates.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Ditto": {"Abilities": {"imposter": 0.7268922174546442, "limber": 0.031822008910324606}, "Items": {"choicescarf": 0.6695809666117952}, "Spreads": {"Impish:252/0/252/0/0/4": 0.4029064563901748, "Relaxed:252/0/252/0/4/0": 0.16760700576796528}, "Moves": ["transform", ""], "Tera Types": {"normal": 0.3727170436308181, "ghost": 0.2111589480420273, "fairy": 0.23299241495925946}, "Teammates": ["Incineroar", "Ursaluna-Bloodmoon", "Dragonite", "Sneasler", "Whimsicott", "Slaking"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>A balanced BO core of Incineroar / Whimsicott / Ursaluna-Bloodmoon / Dragonite / Ditto / Sneasler. Incineroar and Whimsicott control the early game with Intimidate, Fake Tears, and Tailwind, forcing opponents to boost or risk falling behind. Dragonite and Bloodmoon apply pressure with DD and CM sets, baiting the mirror match where Ditto becomes the faster copy. Sneasler adds priority and poison pressure, while Ditto sits in the back as a one-button answer to any sweeper that slips through. Tera Fairy on Whimsicott and Ghost on Ditto cover Fake Out, while the rest of the squad can Tera offensively to keep the opponent guessing.</OUTPUT>

input:

<DATA>{"Beartic": {"Abilities": {"swiftswim": 0.5098179981405133, "slushrush": 0.19894272633335774, "snowcloak": 0.031231052952541027}, "Items": {"clearamulet": 0.16002631591410493, "lifeorb": 0.5538540556958145}, "Spreads": {"Adamant:28/252/4/0/4/220": 0.44666707482475015}, "Moves": ["protect", "earthquake", "liquidation", "iciclecrash"], "Tera Types": {"water": 0.21042371004248753, "ghost": 0.4833838241028793}, "Teammates": ["Pelipper", "Archaludon", "Sneasler", "Ninetales-Alola", "Electrode-Hisui", "Seel"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Beartic is a niche but surprisingly effective physical attacker in VGC, leveraging its high Attack stat and access to Swift Swim or Slush Rush to become a fearsome sweeper under rain or hail. With Life Orb-boosted Liquidation and Icicle Crash, it can break through common threats like Landorus-T and Garchomp, while Earthquake provides coverage against Steel-types. Its primary sets center on either rain or hail archetypes, with Tera Water or Ghost offering defensive utility or offensive power. Despite its low Speed and bulk, Beartic can snowball quickly with proper support, making it a potent but underexplored option in the current metagame.</OUTPUT>

input:
Provide the 'full_analysis' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Beartic": {"Abilities": {"swiftswim": 0.5098179981405133, "slushrush": 0.19894272633335774, "snowcloak": 0.031231052952541027}, "Items": {"clearamulet": 0.16002631591410493, "lifeorb": 0.5538540556958145}, "Spreads": {"Adamant:28/252/4/0/4/220": 0.44666707482475015}, "Moves": ["protect", "earthquake", "liquidation", "iciclecrash"], "Tera Types": {"water": 0.21042371004248753, "ghost": 0.4833838241028793}, "Teammates": ["Pelipper", "Archaludon", "Sneasler", "Ninetales-Alola", "Electrode-Hisui", "Seel"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Beartic’s viability hinges entirely on weather-based speed control, with Swift Swim (50.98% usage) and Slush Rush (19.89%) allowing it to outspeed the entire unboosted metagame under rain or hail. Its optimal spread, Adamant 28/252/4/0/4/220, maximizes Attack while hitting 132 Speed after a Swift Swim boost—enough to outpace +1 base 100s like Salamence. Life Orb (55.39% usage) is the preferred item for immediate power, though Clear Amulet (16.00%) offers protection against Intimidate and Snarl, preserving Beartic’s offensive potency. The moveset is straightforward but effective: Icicle Crash is its strongest STAB, Liquidation provides Water coverage that synergizes with rain and Tera Water, Earthquake hits Steel- and Electric-types, and Protect is mandatory for doubles. Tera Water (21.04%) boosts Liquidation and removes Fire weakness, while Tera Ghost (48.34%) grants immunity to Fake Out and Extreme Speed, enabling setup opportunities. Beartic’s offensive ceiling is high, but its frailty and reliance on weather make it a high-risk, high-reward pick.</OUTPUT>

input:
Write a detailed 'matchup_overview' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Beartic": {"Abilities": {"swiftswim": 0.5098179981405133, "slushrush": 0.19894272633335774, "snowcloak": 0.031231052952541027}, "Items": {"clearamulet": 0.16002631591410493, "lifeorb": 0.5538540556958145}, "Spreads": {"Adamant:28/252/4/0/4/220": 0.44666707482475015}, "Moves": ["protect", "earthquake", "liquidation", "iciclecrash"], "Tera Types": {"water": 0.21042371004248753, "ghost": 0.4833838241028793}, "Teammates": ["Pelipper", "Archaludon", "Sneasler", "Ninetales-Alola", "Electrode-Hisui", "Seel"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Beartic thrives against offensive teams that rely on speed control rather than bulk, as it can outspeed and OHKO threats like Landorus-T, Garchomp, and Dragapult under rain. It pressures common Water-resistant cores like Ferrothorn + Toxapex, as Liquidation + Earthquake covers both. However, it struggles against priority users like Kingambit and Dragonite, which bypass its speed boosts. Tailwind teams can outspeed even Swift Swim Beartic, while Trick Room reverses its speed advantage entirely. Fire-types like Heatran and Arcanine wall it without Tera Water, and bulky Fairy-types like Azumarill can tank hits and retaliate. Beartic also fears status—burn neuters its offense, and paralysis negates its speed control. In rain mirrors, opposing Swift Swim users like Kingdra and Ludicolo often outspeed and KO first. Hail variants face similar issues against Alolan Ninetales’ Aurora Veil teams, though Beartic’s Ice STAB can break through.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Beartic functions as a weather-dependent wallbreaker and late-game cleaner. Under rain or hail, it becomes a pseudo-revenge killer, picking off weakened threats with its strong dual STABs. It’s not a traditional setup sweeper, as it lacks Swords Dance or bulk to boost, but rather relies on immediate power and speed control. Its role is to apply early pressure with Liquidation and Icicle Crash, forcing switches and chipping cores for teammates like Archaludon or Sneasler to clean later. Tera Ghost variants can act as anti-priority leads, blocking Fake Out from Incineroar or Rillaboom, while Tera Water sets can tank Fire moves in a pinch. Beartic is best used as a secondary attacker that capitalizes on weather, not as a standalone win condition.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Beartic": {"Abilities": {"swiftswim": 0.5098179981405133, "slushrush": 0.19894272633335774, "snowcloak": 0.031231052952541027}, "Items": {"clearamulet": 0.16002631591410493, "lifeorb": 0.5538540556958145}, "Spreads": {"Adamant:28/252/4/0/4/220": 0.44666707482475015}, "Moves": ["protect", "earthquake", "liquidation", "iciclecrash"], "Tera Types": {"water": 0.21042371004248753, "ghost": 0.4833838241028793}, "Teammates": ["Pelipper", "Archaludon", "Sneasler", "Ninetales-Alola", "Electrode-Hisui", "Seel"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Beartic’s teammates are built around enabling its weather and patching its weaknesses. Pelipper (100% rain setter) is mandatory for Swift Swim variants, providing rain, Tailwind, and Wide Guard support. Archaludon synergizes offensively, stacking Steel + Water pressure and baiting Ground moves for Beartic to switch in safely. Sneasler offers priority in the form of Dire Claw + Toxic Debris, punishing Fairy-types that wall Beartic. Alolan Ninetales sets hail for Slush Rush variants, while also providing Aurora Veil and Blizzard spam. Electrode-Hisui offers fast rain-boosted Thunder and screens, and Seel (likely Dewgong) provides fake pressure and Ice resistance. These cores share a weakness to Fighting and Rock, so partners like Aegislash or Toxapex help buffer those hits. The teams are hyper-offensive, aiming to maintain weather and overwhelm before opposing setup or Trick Room occurs.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Beartic’s biggest flaw is its dependence on weather—removing rain or hail via Torkoal or Tyranitar instantly turns it into a slow, frail liability. Priority users like Kingambit’s Sucker Punch or Dragonite’s Extreme Speed bypass its speed boosts and KO after minor chip. Bulky Water-types like Slowbro and Azumarill can tank hits and retaliate with Scald or Play Rough. Trick Room completely inverts its speed advantage, making it setup fodder for Reuniclus or Hatterene. Intimidate cycling from Incineroar and Landorus-T forces it to Tera or switch, while burn from Rotom-W or Heatran neuters its offense. Beartic also struggles against Steel-types that resist its dual STABs—Corviknight and Gholdengo wall it unless it lands a Tera Water Liquidation. Finally, its own typing leaves it weak to common Rock Slide and Mach Punch, making it difficult to switch in safely.</OUTPUT>

input:
Write a detailed 'short_summary' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Infernape": {"Abilities": {"blaze": 0.5761857011202668, "ironfist": 0.1783510949213586}, "Items": {"focussash": 0.4116773984686135}, "Spreads": {"Jolly:0/252/0/0/4/252": 0.22405009780953627, "Rash:0/4/0/252/0/252": 0.24463015422134468}, "Moves": ["fakeout", "closecombat", "aurasphere", "heatwave"], "Tera Types": {"grass": 0.16598144799914366, "fire": 0.16901707164717314, "stellar": 0.3016157010633254}, "Teammates": ["Rillaboom", "Amoonguss", "Incineroar", "Archaludon", "Garchomp", "Corviknight"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Infernape is a blazing-fast support-attacker that leverages Fake Out pressure, dual STAB in Close Combat and Heat Wave, and a surprise Stellar Tera to break Protect-centric formats. While outclassed in bulk by Incineroar and in raw power by Urshifu, its 108 base Speed tier lets it outrun and flinch the entire unboosted metagame, turning games with one well-timed Fake Out or Tera-boosted Heat Wave. The Focus Sash set is the clear standard, patching up mediocre 76 / 71 / 71 bulk and guaranteeing at least two turns of influence. Stellar Tera (≈30 %) is preferred to nuke through Wide Guard and to retain neutral coverage, but Grass Tera is common to flip the Water matchup and punish Landorus-T and Rillaboom. Blaze is still the dominant ability, yet Iron Fist variants are creeping up to push Aura Sphere and Mach Punch damage past key thresholds like 4 HP Gholdengo and Chien-Pao. Teams pair Infernape with Grassy Terrain or Intimidate cycles to offset its frailty, then stack Rage Powder or Tailwind to let the ape safely pick its spots.</OUTPUT>

input:
Write the 'full_analysis' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Infernape": {"Abilities": {"blaze": 0.5761857011202668, "ironfist": 0.1783510949213586}, "Items": {"focussash": 0.4116773984686135}, "Spreads": {"Jolly:0/252/0/0/4/252": 0.22405009780953627, "Rash:0/4/0/252/0/252": 0.24463015422134468}, "Moves": ["fakeout", "closecombat", "aurasphere", "heatwave"], "Tera Types": {"grass": 0.16598144799914366, "fire": 0.16901707164717314, "stellar": 0.3016157010633254}, "Teammates": ["Rillaboom", "Amoonguss", "Incineroar", "Archaludon", "Garchomp", "Corviknight"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Speed is Infernape’s calling card: at 108 it beats every relevant support except Talonflame and the rare Noivern, allowing it to fire off Fake Out before opposing redirection or speed control. Close Combat is a 120 BP nuke that cleanly OHKOs standard Incineroar, Kingambit and Chi-Yu after Stealth Rock or one round of chip, while Heat Wave spreads 95 BP special damage and keeps the monkey from being walled by Fairy- and Bug-types. Aura Sphere is chosen over Mach Punch on roughly half of sets to maintain power against Dynamax targets and bypass accuracy woes, but Mach Punch remains a tech to pick off Focus Sash users and finish weakened Flutter Mane or Dragapult. The item is almost always Focus Sash—Infernape’s bulk is simply too poor to stomach two neutral hits without it—while Tera choices revolve around either Stellar for a one-time 80 % power boost to both STABs or Grass to remove Water weakness and punish Rotom-Wash, Urshifu-R and Palafin. Stellar is especially potent because it ignores Wide Guard, letting Heat Wave smack both foes through what would otherwise be a hard counter. EV spreads are polarized: Jolly 252/4/252 maximizes speed and power for a pure offensive pivot, whereas Rash 0/4/0/252/0/252 is a niche mixed variant that guarantees the OHKO on 252 HP / 0 SpD Corviknight with Overheat while still outspeeding Jolly Garchomp. Blaze is taken for consistency, but Iron Fist variants add roughly 20 % damage to Mach Punch and Aura Sphere, securing key rolls on Chien-Pao and Gholdengo. In practice Infernape functions as a lead or mid-game pivot: Fake Out plus a partner’s Tailwind or Rage Powder creates an immediate tempo swing, then STAB moves clean the board while Sash preserves at least one additional turn of output. Because it lacks Incineroar’s Parting Shot, the ape must rely on hard reads and protective teammates to escape bad matchups, but its higher speed and mixed offenses give it a uniquely aggressive angle that Incineroar simply cannot replicate.</OUTPUT>

input:
Produce the 'matchup_overview' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Infernape": {"Abilities": {"blaze": 0.5761857011202668, "ironfist": 0.1783510949213586}, "Items": {"focussash": 0.4116773984686135}, "Spreads": {"Jolly:0/252/0/0/4/252": 0.22405009780953627, "Rash:0/4/0/252/0/252": 0.24463015422134468}, "Moves": ["fakeout", "closecombat", "aurasphere", "heatwave"], "Tera Types": {"grass": 0.16598144799914366, "fire": 0.16901707164717314, "stellar": 0.3016157010633254}, "Teammates": ["Rillaboom", "Amoonguss", "Incineroar", "Archaludon", "Garchomp", "Corviknight"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Infernape dominates slower, setup-reliant cores such as Trick Room Indeedee + Hatterene or Tailwindless Dragapult + Kingambit, thanks to Fake Out disruption and the ability to OHKO key threats before they move. Against bulkier Water-types like Rotom-Wash and Palafin it must Tera Grass to flip the script, but once Terastallized it cleanly 2HKOs even max-SpD variants with Heat Wave. Dragon-type rivals such as Garchomp and Dragonite dislike Aura Sphere, while Corviknight and Skarmory are 2HKOed by Rash Overheat or Stellar Heat Wave. Faster threats—Iron Bundle, Noivern, Choice Scarf Gholdengo—outpace and KO, so Infernape depends on Sash and either redirection or priority control to survive. Psychic Terrain from Indeedee blocks Fake Out, forcing the ape to play cautiously or Tera early. Ghost-types like Aegislash and Mimikyu punish Close Combat drops and can stall with Protect, but Iron Fist Aura Sphere breaks Mimikyu’s Disguise and deals respectable neutral damage to Aegislash shield form. Opposing Incineroar wars are common: Infernape wins the speed tie and OHKOs with Close Combat, but must beware Parting Shot chip and potential Intimidate cycling. In rain teams, Infernape is largely neutered unless it Terastallizes, so smart opponents will bait the Tera turn then pivot to Swift Swim sweepers. Overall, Infernape’s matchups are polarized: it bulldozes mid-speed balance squads but struggles against hyper-offense or bulky Water terrain unless it commits its Tera.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Infernape is a hyper-offensive pivot that compresses Fake Out pressure, spread special damage, and single-target burst into one slot. It is never the team’s sole support—its frailty and lack of utility moves like Parting Shot or Taunt prevent that—but instead functions as a speed-based tempo controller that enables set-up sweepers or speed control teammates. Turn 1 it threatens Fake Out plus a spread move, forcing Protects and creating safe setup for allies such as Swords Dance Garchomp or Dragon Dance Corviknight. Mid-game it trades Sash for a KO, then late-game reclaims the board with Mach Punch or a Tera-boosted Heat Wave. Because it lacks natural bulk, Infernape must be paired with redirection or Intimidate to survive beyond two turns, but its unique speed tier and mixed offenses let it fill an offensive gap that neither Incineroar nor Rillaboom can occupy.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Infernape": {"Abilities": {"blaze": 0.5761857011202668, "ironfist": 0.1783510949213586}, "Items": {"focussash": 0.4116773984686135}, "Spreads": {"Jolly:0/252/0/0/4/252": 0.22405009780953627, "Rash:0/4/0/252/0/252": 0.24463015422134468}, "Moves": ["fakeout", "closecombat", "aurasphere", "heatwave"], "Tera Types": {"grass": 0.16598144799914366, "fire": 0.16901707164717314, "stellar": 0.3016157010633254}, "Teammates": ["Rillaboom", "Amoonguss", "Incineroar", "Archaludon", "Garchomp", "Corviknight"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Rillaboom is by far the most common partner: Grassy Glide plus Fake Out forms a classic “fake-glide” core, Grassy Terrain chip offsets Life Orb recoil, and Rage Powder draws away Water-type attacks that threaten Infernape. Amoonguss provides similar redirection, Spore deterrent, and removes status, while Incineroar forms an Intimidate stack that softens physical blows enough for Sash to guarantee two turns. Archaludon and Garchomp appreciate Infernape’s speed control and Fighting-type removal of Steel-types that wall their STABs, while Corviknight offers Tailwind and a slow U-turn to bring the ape back in after a KO. Teammates generally fall into two camps: either bulky redirection cores (Amoonguss, Indeedee) that buy turns, or setup sweepers (Garchomp, Dragonite, Kingambit) that exploit the disruption Infernape provides. Stellar Tera teams value the ape because it can Terastallize without disrupting terrain or weather, preserving synergy for other win conditions.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Infernape’s dependence on Focus Sash makes any form of chip—sand, hail, Rocky Helmet, Iron Barbs, or passive Grassy/Spikes—extremely punishing. Faster attackers such as Iron Bundle, Choice Scarf Gholdengo, and Noivern OHKO before it moves, while priority users like Chien-Pao Ice Shard or Kingambit Sucker Punch finish it after Sash is broken. Wide Guard from Toxapex or Aegislash blanks Heat Wave, forcing the ape into predictable Close Combats that open it to ghostly switch-ins. Bulky Water-types—especially Rotom-Wash, Slowbro and Dondozo—can stomach a Grass Tera Heat Wave and retalute with Hydro Pump or Slack Off stall until rain or allies remove the threat. Once Terastallized, Infernape loses its Fire STAB resistances, so opposing Fire-types like Heatran or opposing Infernape can now trade favorably. Finally, because it rarely carries Protect, double-targeting the ape on turn 1 is a reliable way to break Sash and render it a one-hit wonder.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Toucannon": {"Abilities": {"sheerforce": 0.01501650865478954, "skilllink": 0.7123088851497581, "keeneye": 0.0}, "Items": {"clearamulet": 0.877448950511761}, "Spreads": {"Impish:252/52/100/0/92/12": 0.32862308508643856, "Adamant:212/252/0/0/0/44": 0.5488257641129003}, "Moves": ["bulletseed", "rockblast", "beakblast", "tailwind"], "Tera Types": {"grass": 0.9486624603673262}, "Teammates": ["Ursaluna", "Whimsicott", "Feraligatr", "Zoroark-Hisui", "Typhlosion-Hisui", "Garganacl"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>With Skill Link guaranteeing five hits on both Bullet Seed and Rock Blast, Toucannon becomes a 125 BP Grass or Rock attacker that ignores Sturdy, Focus Sash, and Substitute, giving it near-perfect coverage against common cores like Torkoal–Gastrodon, Togekiss–Rotom-Wash, and Arcanine–Tyranitar.  Sheer Force removes Beak Blast’s burn chance but boosts the move to 120 BP while negating Life Orb recoil; combined with Clear Amulet it can fire off high-damage attacks without fear of Attack drops or chip.  100/92 bulk EVs with Impish nature let it survive -1 Zacian Behemoth Blade, +1 Chien-Sacred Sword, and Iron Bundle Freeze-Dry, while 12 Speed EVs creep 0 Speed base 75s such as bulkier variants of Sylveon and Celesteela.  Adamant spreads trade bulk for immediate power, cleanly OHKOing max-HP Gastrodon and 2HKOing Physically Defensive Torkoal through Charti Berry.  Grass Tera is the only realistic option, turning Bullet Seed into a STAB nuke that OHKOs even Dynamax Kyogre after Stealth Rock while removing the 4× Electric weakness that otherwise invites Rotom-Wash and Regieleki to freely Volt Switch.  Tailwind is the glue that lets Toucannon’s slower, harder-hitting teammates—Ursaluna, Feraligatr, and Hisui Typhlosion—outrun the metagame’s 110–130 Speed threats for four turns.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Toucannon": {"Abilities": {"sheerforce": 0.01501650865478954, "skilllink": 0.7123088851497581, "keeneye": 0.0}, "Items": {"clearamulet": 0.877448950511761}, "Spreads": {"Impish:252/52/100/0/92/12": 0.32862308508643856, "Adamant:212/252/0/0/0/44": 0.5488257641129003}, "Moves": ["bulletseed", "rockblast", "beakblast", "tailwind"], "Tera Types": {"grass": 0.9486624603673262}, "Teammates": ["Ursaluna", "Whimsicott", "Feraligatr", "Zoroark-Hisui", "Typhlosion-Hisui", "Garganacl"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Whimsicott provides speed control with priority Tailwind or Scarf Moonblast, threatens opposing leads with Fake Tears, and can switch into Fighting-type moves aimed at Toucannon.  Ursaluna appreciates Tailwind to outrun base 100s and appreciates Toucannon eliminating Water- and Grass-types; in return, Ursaluna lures and weakens Steel-types that wall Toucannon.  Feraligatr forms a physical Water–Normal offensive core, baiting in Ferrothorn and Amoonguss for Toucannon to obliterate while threatening Fire- and Rock-types that trouble the toucan.  Zoroark-Hisui disguised as Toucannon can bluff Tailwind or lure Fighting- and Steel-type moves, giving the real Toucannon safer entry; Illusion also discourages opponents from immediately targeting the bird. output: <OUTPUT>Hypno's viability in VGC stems from its unique access to Psychic Terrain combined with utility support options. Its most common set runs Mental Herb with a Timid nature and max Speed investment, allowing it to outspeed key threats while setting up Psychic Terrain. The combination of Psychic Terrain and Expanding Force gives it respectable offensive presence, especially when paired with other Psychic-type attackers. Helping Hand provides crucial team support, boosting allies' damage output by 50%. Thunder Wave offers speed control, though it's somewhat redundant with Psychic Terrain's priority blocking effect. The Calm nature set with special bulk investment trades speed for survivability, allowing Hypno to better tank special hits while maintaining its support role. Its abilities are largely underwhelming - Inner Focus prevents flinching but is situational, while Insomnia provides sleep immunity which can be useful against Amoonguss and other sleep users. The Fairy Tera type is almost universal, giving it crucial resistance to Dark and Bug moves while maintaining its Psychic STAB.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Thwackey is a niche but surprisingly effective support pivot in the current VGC format, leveraging Eviolite-boosted bulk, Grassy Surge chip recovery, and the fastest Fake Out in the tier to control momentum. Its unique speed tier, access to U-turn, and Leech Seed let it repeatedly pivot in, disrupt, and drain opposing HP while setting Grassy Terrain for its own team. The analysis below explores how to maximize its supportive value, which partners best exploit Terrain, and how to cover its glaring weaknesses to Ice, Flying, and Poison.</OUTPUT>

input:
Write the 'full_analysis' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Thwackey": {"Abilities": {"grassysurge": 0.6888745644266255, "overgrow": 2.6547200415727445e-07}, "Items": {"eviolite": 0.9999954429497665}, "Spreads": {"Careful:252/0/4/0/252/0": 0.6821135289282104, "Careful:252/4/92/0/156/4": 0.2649486156829307}, "Moves": ["fakeout", "uturn", "leechseed", "protect"], "Tera Types": {"fire": 0.9471103679654264}, "Teammates": ["Pawmot", "Toxapex", "Garganacl", "Tatsugiri", "Dondozo", "Mudsdale"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>With a base 80 Speed stat that outruns most support Pokémon and base 70 Attack, Thwackey occupies a rare speed-control niche: it underspeeds Dragapult and Iron Valiant but outspeeds every Incarnate form, Indeedee, and most Amoonguss, letting it fire the first Fake Out or U-turn almost every game. Eviolite patches its merely average 70 / 90 / 70 bulk into something comparable to 100 / 135 / 100, letting it survive super-effective hits such as Specs Dragapult Shadow Ball or Choice Band Chien-Pao Icicle Crash roughly half the time. Grassy Surge is the only reason to consider Thwackey over other pivots; the 1⁄16 recovery per turn quietly adds 20–30 % health over a longer game and strengthens its own and teammates’ Grass-type STAB while weakening Earthquake for grounded allies. Leech Seed turns Thwackey into a passive win-condition against bulky cores lacking Grass-immune or Clear-Body Pokémon; pairing it with Protect lets it stall Dynamax turns and rack up 25 % recovery per cycle. U-turn guarantees momentum against Protect or predicted switches, ensuring you rarely lose tempo. The chosen Careful nature and 252 HP / 252 SpD (or the 156 SpD variant with added Defense) maximize special bulk so Thwackey can repeatedly switch in on Tapu Fini Moonblast, Toxapex Sludge Bomb, or Gholdengo Make It Rain and still remain above 50 % health. Tera Fire is omnipresent because it flips the matchup versus Sun teams: Tera Fire Thwackey survives Torkoal Overheat and OHKOs back with Wood Hammer while also removing the Freeze-Dry weakness versus Kyurem and Iron Bundle. Although its offensive movepool is shallow, the support set listed is optimal—Knock Off or Taunt can be considered on more offensive teams, but Fake Out and Leech Seed are simply too valuable to drop. Overall, Thwackey functions best as a bulky pivot that quietly wins the resource war rather than a burst attacker.</OUTPUT>

input:

<DATA>{"Thwackey": {"Abilities": {"grassysurge": 0.6888745644266255, "overgrow": 2.6547200415727445e-07}, "Items": {"eviolite": 0.9999954429497665}, "Spreads": {"Careful:252/0/4/0/252/0": 0.6821135289282104, "Careful:252/4/92/0/156/4": 0.2649486156829307}, "Moves": ["fakeout", "uturn", "leechseed", "protect"], "Tera Types": {"fire": 0.9471103679654264}, "Teammates": ["Pawmot", "Toxapex", "Garganacl", "Tatsugiri", "Dondozo", "Mudsdale"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Thwackey loves facing slower, bulky teams that rely on gradual chip and lack immediate Grass resists—common cores built around Garganacl, Toxapex, Dondozo, or Ting-Lu struggle to break Leech Seed cycles and allow Thwackey to rack up 30–40 % passive damage while its teammates clean late-game. Sun and Rain both hate Grassy Terrain chipping their Charizard/Brute-Barraskewda while weakening their spread Earthquakes, and Thwackey’s Tera Fire lets it tank a Heat Wave or Overheat and retaliate. Conversely, faster offensive squads built around Iron Bundle, Chien-Pao, or Tera Flying Dragonite can KO Thwackey before it moves, and Flying-type priority such as Gale Wings Talonflame or Dragonite Extreme Speed cleanly OHKO. Poison- and Steel-type special attackers like Gholdengo and Iron Moth ignore Leech Seed and dent it with super-effective STAB. Psychic Terrain teams (Indeedee + Armarouge) also block Fake Out, neutering Thwackey’s primary disruption tool. In Trick Room it becomes a liability, as most setters underspeed and KO it with Ice, Poison, or Flying coverage. Finally, Grass-immune foes—Tera Flying Kingambit, Corviknight, or opposing Amoonguss—shut down Leech Seed and force awkward U-turns. Knowing when to lead Thwackey (versus fat balances) and when to keep it in the back (versus hyper-offense) is crucial.</OUTPUT>

It rarely Dynamaxes itself, instead preserving the option to stall Dynamax turns with Protect + Leech Seed. EV spreads focus on special bulk to check Tapu Fini, Toxapex, and Gholdengo, but the 4 Defense / 156 SpD variant lets it survive Jolly Chien-Pao Icicle Crash after Grassy recovery. Because it is not an offensive threat, Thwackey’s value is measured in how many turns of disruption and Terrain it provides; expect it to net 2–3 Fake Outs, one Leech Seed, and Terrain for 6–8 turns before fainting—exactly enough to swing the mid-game in your favor.</OUTPUT>

Alternate options: swap Protect for Taunt to stop Trick Room or opposing set-up; swap Leech Seed for Knock Off if your team already has passive damage (Salt Cure, Rocky Helmet), but losing Leech Seed generally lowers Thwackey’s win-rate; Tera Water can be used over Fire on Rain teams to survive Iron Bundle Freeze-Dry and retaliate with Wood Hammer.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Fast Ice- and Flying-type attackers are the most reliable answers: Iron Bundle outspeeds and OHKOs with Freeze-Dry; Specs Tera Flying Dragapult or Hurricane Tornadus-T do the same. Priority users bypass Thwackey’s speed: Gale Wings Talonflame Brave Bird, Dragonite Extreme Speed, and Kingambit Sucker Punch all KO after minor chip. Poison-types that ignore Leech Seed—Gholdengo, Iron Moth, Toxapex—force mind-games with U-turn and can KO or status back. Psychic Terrain from Indeedee shuts off Fake Out, removing Thwackey’s biggest niche. Trick Room reverses speed order, letting slow powerhouses like Hatterene or Torkoal move first and OHKO with super-effective STAB. Finally, Grass-immune or Magic Guard Pokémon (Corviknight, Tera Flying Kingambit, Reuniclus) blank Leech Seed and force Thwackey to U-turn out, racking up hazard or Rocky Helmet chip. To counter Thwackey, bring at least one of these faster offensive threats or Terrain control, preserve your Flying-type until Fake Out is revealed, and avoid letting it get a Leech Seed cycle started on your bulky win-condition.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Cramorant is a modest, specially-oriented attacker that leverages its unique ability, Gulp Missile, to punish contact moves while firing off strong STAB Surfs and Air Slashes. With a 252/0/4/252/0/0 spread it sits at 137 HP / 166 Def / 156 SpA, outspeeding the crowded base-85 tier and cleanly 2HKOing most neutral targets with LO-boosted Surf. The 60% Sitrus set provides a reliable recovery buffer, while 32% opt for Focus Sash to guarantee at least one Gulp Missile proc or a second attack. Tera Ghost is the most common (29%), letting it block Fake Out and Extreme Speed while flipping Fighting match-ups, whereas Tera Steel (53%) turns its Electric weakness into a resistance and gives it a crucial neutrality to Rock, letting it survive most Tyranitar Rock Slides and retaliate. The standard four-moveset of Surf / Air Slash / Protect / Roost keeps it self-sufficient, but the lack of immediate power or speed control means Cramorant is best viewed as a mid-game pivot that chips, baits contact, and preserves momentum rather than a standalone win-condition.</OUTPUT>

input:
Provide the 'full_analysis' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Cramorant": {"Abilities": {"gulpmissile": 0.5944978193107215}, "Items": {"focussash": 0.3204007386099389, "sitrusberry": 0.6507718155371373}, "Spreads": {"Modest:4/0/0/252/0/252": 0.26566864034942156, "Modest:252/0/4/252/0/0": 0.5325766581550982}, "Moves": ["surf", "airslash", "protect", "roost"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.2912675686085037, "steel": 0.5325766580535203}, "Teammates": ["Pelipper", "Archaludon", "Rillaboom", "Tatsugiri", "Kingambit", "Toxicroak"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Cramorant’s niche in VGC 2024 Regulation G stems from Gulp Missile, the only ability that can both deal 25% max-HP damage and drop the attacker’s Defense by one stage on contact. This punishes U-turners such as Rillaboom and Kingambit, forces Incineroar to think twice before Darkest Lariat, and turns random Quick Attacks into 50/50s. Modest 252 SpA Surfs hit 156 base power in rain and cleanly KO standard Incineroar after one round of chip, while Air Slash’s 30% flinch chance gives it pseudo-speed control against slower threats. Roost lets it play a longer game against bulky cores, and Protect is mandatory to dodge double-targets and stall out Tailwind turns. The EV spread maximizes damage and bulk: 137 HP guarantees that Sitrus activates after two rounds of Life Orb recoil or one super-effective hit, 166 Def survives Jolly Chien-Pao Ice Spinner, and 156 SpA secures the above KOs. Tera Ghost is preferred on offensive teams that need a Fake Out absorber and want to block Shadow Sneak from opposing Kingambit, while Tera Steel is the default on balance squads that need to keep Cramorant on the field into the late game versus Electric or Rock attackers. The 29% Focus Sash builds are usually paired with Pelipper rain to offset the lack of bulk, whereas the 65% Sitrus versions appear on more flexible cores that can’t guarantee rain. Overall, Cramorant offers unique passive damage, respectable spread pressure, and a low-maintenance moveset, but its mediocre 85/95 offenses and reliance on contact punishment mean it must be supported by speed control and strong breakers to avoid being overwhelmed.</OUTPUT>

input:
Draft the 'matchup_overview' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Cramorant": {"Abilities": {"gulpmissile": 0.5944978193107215}, "Items": {"focussash": 0.3204007386099389, "sitrusberry": 0.6507718155371373}, "Spreads": {"Modest:4/0/0/252/0/252": 0.26566864034942156, "Modest:252/0/4/252/0/0": 0.5325766581550982}, "Moves": ["surf", "airslash", "protect", "roost"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.2912675686085037, "steel": 0.5325766580535203}, "Teammates": ["Pelipper", "Archaludon", "Rillaboom", "Tatsugiri", "Kingambit", "Toxicroak"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Cramorant enjoys positive match-ups against contact-heavy physical attackers—Rillaboom, Kingambit, Chien-Pao, and most Incineroar variants—because Gulp Missile punishes their main STABs and the Defense drop often turns 2HKOs into OHKOs for partners. It also pressures common Fire- and Fighting-types such as Torkoal, Entei, and Iron Hands, outspeeding and 2HKOing with Surf or Air Slash. Conversely, it struggles against Electric (Rotom-W, Zapdos, Iron Crown) and faster special attackers like Iron Moth and Choice Specs Dragapult that can KO before it moves. Priority from Basculegion or Kingambit’s Sucker Punch bypasses its speed tier, though Tera Ghost blocks the latter. Rock-slide users such as Tyranitar and Lycanroc-Dusk deal heavy damage even after Tera Steel, while Amoonguss completely walls both STABs and can Spore through Protect. Finally, Tailwind or Chlorophyll sweepers (Tornadus-I, Venusaur) can outrun and KO before Gulp Missile triggers. In rain, Cramorant flips several of these match-ups: Thunder becomes 50% accurate, Surf reaches 234 base power, and Pelipper’s Drizzle weakens Fire-type coverage. Outside rain, it must rely on teammates to remove or cripple these threats before committing.</OUTPUT>
