Create the 'role_description' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Cramorant": {"Abilities": {"gulpmissile": 0.5944978193107215}, "Items": {"focussash": 0.3204007386099389, "sitrusberry": 0.6507718155371373}, "Spreads": {"Modest:4/0/0/252/0/252": 0.26566864034942156, "Modest:252/0/4/252/0/0": 0.5325766581550982}, "Moves": ["surf", "airslash", "protect", "roost"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.2912675686085037, "steel": 0.5325766580535203}, "Teammates": ["Pelipper", "Archaludon", "Rillaboom", "Tatsugiri", "Kingambit", "Toxicroak"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Cramorant is a mid-speed special attacker and passive damage engine that occupies the third or fourth slot on balance and rain teams. Its primary job is to force contact, proc Gulp Missile, and spread chip so that faster or stronger partners can clean. Because it carries Roost and Sitrus, it can repeatedly pivot in, trade, and reset health, functioning as a semi-bulky pivot rather than a one-time nuke. It also provides emergency speed control via Air Slash flinches and can self-activate rain Surf for spread damage. The Tera choice defines its secondary role: Tera Ghost turns it into a Fake Out absorber and blocking pivot versus priority teams, while Tera Steel morphs it into a soft check to Electric and Rock attackers, giving the squad a second defensive backbone. In practice, Cramorant is brought to games where the opponent leans on contact moves or where rain-boosted Surf provides crucial KO thresholds; in other match-ups it sits on the bench or functions as a safe switch-in to scout sets. It does not require extensive support—only rain or speed control to let it move first—and thus fits comfortably on teams that already want Pelipper or Rillaboom for other purposes.</OUTPUT>

input:
Write the 'synergy_breakdown' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Cramorant": {"Abilities": {"gulpmissile": 0.5944978193107215}, "Items": {"focussash": 0.3204007386099389, "sitrusberry": 0.6507718155371373}, "Spreads": {"Modest:4/0/0/252/0/252": 0.26566864034942156, "Modest:252/0/4/252/0/0": 0.5325766581550982}, "Moves": ["surf", "airslash", "protect", "roost"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.2912675686085037, "steel": 0.5325766580535203}, "Teammates": ["Pelipper", "Archaludon", "Rillaboom", "Tatsugiri", "Kingambit", "Toxicroak"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Pelipper is the most natural partner, appearing on 100% of sampled Cramorant teams; Drizzle boosts Surf, halves Fire damage, and enables Hurricane on Pelipper itself for dual-special pressure. Rillaboom forms a grass-water core, provides Grassy Terrain recovery that stacks with Sitrus, and can fake-out to guarantee Cramorant a free turn. Archaludon offers a Steel-type that resists both Electric and Rock, covers Cramorant’s main weaknesses, and appreciates Gulp Missile chip to secure its own KOs. Kingambit gives a powerful late-game cleaner that benefits from the Defense drops Gulp Missile spreads, while also handling the Psychic- and Ghost-types that trouble Cramorant. Tatsugiri supplies Commander boosts to either Pelipper or Archaludon, turning them into faster, bulkier sweepers that can remove the Electric and Grass counters to Cramorant. Finally, Toxicroak absorbs Water-type moves aimed at Cramorant, sets up Swords Dance under rain, and removes opposing Steel-types. EV spreads are coordinated: Pelipper runs 252 HP / 252 Def Bold to survive Chien-Pao, Archaludon runs 188 SpA Modest to OHKO Zapdos after one Gulp Missile chip, and Kingambit runs 252 HP / 252 Atk Adamant to guarantee the KO on offensive Rotom-W after the Defense drop. The team wants one speed control option—either Pelipper’s Tailwind or Rillaboom’s Grassy Glide priority—to let Cramorant move first and fire off rain Surfs before the opponent can retaliate.</OUTPUT>

Tera Type: Steel. This is the most common variant, giving Cramorant longevity to repeatedly check contact attackers and fire off spread damage. <DATA>{"Cramorant": {"Abilities": {"gulpmissile": 0.5944978193107215}, "Items": {"focussash": 0.3204007386099389, "sitrusberry": 0.6507718155371373}, "Spreads": {"Modest:4/0/0/252/0/252": 0.26566864034942156, "Modest:252/0/4/252/0/0": 0.5325766581550982}, "Moves": ["surf", "airslash", "protect", "roost"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.2912675686085037, "steel": 0.5325766580535203}, "Teammates": ["Pelipper", "Archaludon", "Rillaboom", "Tatsugiri", "Kingambit", "Toxicroak"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Cramorant’s biggest weakness is its mediocre special bulk and average speed tier; any faster special attacker—Iron Moth, Choice Specs Dragapult, Iron Crown under Tailwind—can OHKO before it moves. Electric-types are the hardest counters: Zapdos, Rotom-W, and Iron Crown take negligible damage from Surf and retaliate with Thunderbolt or Tera Blast Electric for the KO. Rock Slide users such as Tyranitar and Lycanroc-Dusk can flinch or KO even after Tera Steel, while Amoonguss completely walls both STABs and can Spore through Protect. Priority from Basculegion or Kingambit’s Sucker Punch can finish off chipped variants, though Tera Ghost blocks the latter. Tailwind or Chlorophyll sweepers negate Cramorant’s speed advantage, and sun teams can overpower it with boosted Fire moves before rain can be re-set. Finally, because Gulp Missile only triggers on contact, special attackers and non-contact physical attackers (Excadrill, Iron Boulder) avoid the punishment entirely. To counter Cramorant, bring a fast Electric or special attacker, keep Tailwind up, and avoid contact moves unless you can KO that turn. Spread moves that hit both slots—Rock Slide, Discharge, Dazzling Gleam—also bypass Protect and can KO alongside partner damage.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Sandslash-Alola": {"Abilities": {"slushrush": 0.6210729822485394, "snowcloak": 0.005973156005328273}, "Items": {"lifeorb": 0.189357973674537, "loadeddice": 0.32144348506767517, "focussash": 0.41204321676222344}, "Spreads": {"Adamant:4/252/0/0/0/252": 0.6347821823667681, "Adamant:68/236/12/0/20/172": 0.16395125209478043}, "Moves": ["ironhead", "icespinner", "protect", "iceshard"], "Tera Types": {"ground": 0.24950412167880967, "stellar": 0.16395874494578463, "ghost": 0.4176127586222153}, "Teammates": ["Ninetales-Alola", "Annihilape", "Sneasler", "Salamence", "Chandelure", "Tauros-Paldea-Aqua"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Alolan Sandslash’s success hinges on its ability to function as both a hail enabler and a win condition once the board is cleared. Slush Rush doubles its Speed under hail, letting it outrun even +1 Roaring Moon and Choice Scarf Gholdengo. The chosen EV spread is almost always Adamant 4/252/0/0/0/252 to maximize immediate power and speed; a bulkier 68/236/12/0/20/172 spread survives a Life Orb Chien-Pao Ice Spinner and still outspeeds +1 base 110s under hail. Life Orb is the most common item, turning Iron Head into a guaranteed OHKO on bulky variants of Flutter Mane and 2HKOing Dondozo, while Loaded Dice gives Triple Axel a 96 % chance to hit three times, effectively a 120 BP single-target move that ignores accuracy checks. Focus Sash is rarer but guarantees a setup opportunity against faster leads like Talonflame. Ice Spinner is mandatory for terrain removal, crucial against Psychic Terrain teams that rely on Indeedee–Armarouge or Indeedee–Venusaur. Protect is universal in doubles, and Ice Shard picks off weakened foes such as Chien-Pao or opposing Slush Rush users. Tera Ghost is the standout choice, removing the Fighting weakness and letting Sandslash punish Fake Out users while gaining perfect neutral coverage with Iron Head + Ice Spinner. Tera Ground gives a powerful Earthquake immunity and a Tera-boosted Iron Head to dent Gholdengo and Kingambit, whereas Tera Stellar provides a one-time neutral 80 BP STAB to everything, useful when the opponent brings multiple Ice resists.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Under hail, Sandslash dominates offensive teams that rely on speed control from Chien-Pao or Choice Scarf Gholdengo, as it outspeeds and OHKOes both with Iron Head or Triple Axel. It cleanly removes Indeedee’s Psychic Terrain, neutering Follow Me + Expanding Force cores, and punishes Sun teams that stack Fire-types by threatening OHKOs on Torkoal and Venusaur. Against Trick Room it functions as a secondary mode: if hail is up it can double-target the setter to prevent the room, and once Trick Room is active its Ice Shard still picks off slow threats like Hatterene or Armarouge. Rain teams are the hardest counter—Pelipper’s rain cancels hail, and Barraskewda outspeeds and OHKOs with Liquidation. Priority from Kingambit or Dragonite Extreme Speed also bypasses Slush Rush, so Sandslash must be paired with redirection or speed control to avoid taking heavy damage before moving.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Alolan Sandslash is a weather-dependent speedster and late-game cleaner that requires hail support to function. It is never the primary lead; instead it sits in the back while Ninetales-Alola sets hail with Snow Warning and applies early pressure with Aurora Veil. Once opposing speed control and priority users are weakened or removed, Sandslash is brought in to sweep. Its dual STAB provides perfect neutral coverage against the entire metagame barring Aegislash and bulky Waters, which are handled by teammates. The slot compresses three roles: terrain removal (Ice Spinner), revenge killer (Ice Shard), and win condition (Slush Rush + triple axel). Because it is so dependent on hail, it must be played conservatively—losing Ninetales early or allowing the opponent to change weather can leave Sandslash outsped and easily KOed.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Torracat": {"Abilities": {"intimidate": 0.5761300497557049, "blaze": 0.0}, "Items": {"eviolite": 0.9784779588135858}, "Spreads": {"Impish:4/0/252/0/252/0": 0.22384529108785467, "Jolly:100/108/100/0/100/100": 0.5837279767447185}, "Moves": ["fakeout", "partingshot", "crunch", "flareblitz"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.22860238906653188, "grass": 0.6096808424667528}, "Teammates": ["Palafin", "Amoonguss", "Indeedee", "Ursaluna-Bloodmoon", "Polteageist", "Flamigo"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Despite being an unevolved Pokémon, Torracat carves a unique role in VGC by combining the rare Intimidate ability with Eviolite, reaching impressive physical bulk that lets it survive super-effective hits and repeatedly pivot in and out of battle. The most common spread, Jolly with mixed bulk and some Speed investment, lets it outpace key threats and fire off fast Fake Outs or Parting Shots before switching to a more threatening teammate. Its movepool is sparse but perfectly tailored for support: Fake Out provides free turns, Parting Shot simultaneously neuters attackers and maintains momentum, Crunch prevents it from being completely passive by hitting Ghost-types such as Aegislash and Indeedee-F, and Flare Blitz offers a STAB option that can finish off weakened foes or break Focus Sashes. Tera Ghost is preferred to block Fake Out and Extreme Speed while dodging Fighting-type coverage, whereas Tera Grass removes the Water weakness and helps it stomach Amoonguss’s Sludge Bomb. The dominance of Eviolite on nearly every set underlines that Torracat’s value lies in staying power rather than raw damage output.</OUTPUT>

Opposing Ghost-types can be problematic if Torracat has not Terastallized, as they are immune to Fake Out and Parting Shot, but Crunch plus ally support can mitigate this. Water- and Ground-type moves remain dangerous even with Eviolite, so partners must cover those matchups. Terrain teams can limit Fake Out value, but Torracat can still drop stats and pivot, keeping it relevant in most matchups.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Falinks": {"Abilities": {"defiant": 0.5687543408453115, "battlearmor": 0.0013800145220980164}, "Items": {"lifeorb": 0.7608227259883762}, "Spreads": {"Adamant:116/252/4/0/4/132": 0.21570153757787316, "Adamant:252/156/4/0/12/84": 0.5014052341346373}, "Moves": ["noretreat", "protect", "closecombat", "ironhead"], "Tera Types": {"steel": 0.8774053237982609}, "Teammates": ["Incineroar", "Gholdengo", "Amoonguss", "Tyranitar", "Golduck", "Ninetales-Alola"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Falinks is a niche but explosive offensive presence in VGC, leveraging No Retreat’s omniboost to transform into a terrifying win-condition that can rip through unprepared teams. While its base stats are modest, a single turn of setup turns it into a +1 across the board juggernaut that outspeeds and overpowers common mid-speed threats. The ubiquity of Steel Tera and Life Orb maximises its immediate damage output and patches its poor defensive typing, while Defiant punishes Intimidate and Parting Shot cycles that define the current metagame. The listed spreads favour either outspeeding positive-nature base 100s at +1 or maximising Attack while still creeping key speed tiers, both holding enough bulk to survive a neutral hit before retaliating. Its moveset is brutally efficient: No Retreat for setup, Close Combat for primary STAB, Iron Head for Fairy and Psychic coverage, and Protect for pivoting. Teammates such as Incineroar, Amoonguss and Gholdengo provide redirection, disruption and Trick Room control, giving Falinks the one or two turns it needs to snowball.</OUTPUT>

input:
Create the 'full_analysis' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Falinks": {"Abilities": {"defiant": 0.5687543408453115, "battlearmor": 0.0013800145220980164}, "Items": {"lifeorb": 0.7608227259883762}, "Spreads": {"Adamant:116/252/4/0/4/132": 0.21570153757787316, "Adamant:252/156/4/0/12/84": 0.5014052341346373}, "Moves": ["noretreat", "protect", "closecombat", "ironhead"], "Tera Types": {"steel": 0.8774053237982609}, "Teammates": ["Incineroar", "Gholdengo", "Amoonguss", "Tyranitar", "Golduck", "Ninetales-Alola"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Falinks occupies a unique speed-boosting sweeper niche that no other Fighting-type replicates in the current Series regulation. After a No Retreat it reaches 252 Speed EVs worth of stats from a modest 85 base, rocketing to 358 at level 50 with the 132 EV spread and 404 with the 84 EV spread under a neutral nature; both outspeed +1 Roaring Moon, Chien-Pao and Iron Bundle while retaining enough Attack to OHKO standard bulky Incineroar with +1 Life Orb Close Combat. Iron Head becomes a 100%-accurate, 130 BP Steel move post-STAB and Tera, nailing Flutter Mane, Sylveon and Mimikyu for OHKOs that Close Combat cannot achieve. The listed EV spreads illustrate the two schools of thought: the 252/156/12 bulk variant survives Jolly Chien-Pao Ice Spinner and can retalates, whereas the 116 HP/132 Speed variant guarantees the speed jump on Timid Gholdengo and Modest Sylveon after boost. Defiant is chosen on 57% of teams because it flips the ubiquitous Intimidate–Parting Shot core on its head: a single Incineroar Intimidate turns Falinks into a +3 Attack monster that is almost impossible to wall without dedicated intimidate cycling or Unaware. Life Orb is the only item worth considering: the 30% damage bonus turns many 2HKOs into OHKOs and the recoil is offset by Falinks’ plan to end games in three turns or fewer. Tera Steel is used on nearly 90% of teams because it removes the crippling Fairy and Flying weaknesses, grants a crucial Toxic immunity, and provides a 2× Iron Head boost that secures KOs on Togekiss and Sylveon even through Tera Fairy. Battle Armor is almost never seen, but the occasional anti-crit tech can be justified on hyper-offensive teams that cannot afford to lose damage rolls to random critical hits. The four-moveslot syndrome is real—Falinks wants Throat Chop for Aegislash and Ghosts, Rock Slide for Flying-types, and Poison Jab for Amoonguss—but the listed set offers the best compromise of power, coverage and utility. In practice Falinks functions as a mid-game breaker that forces opponents to choose between ignoring it and losing outright, or over-committing resources and leaving the door open for its powerful teammates.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Falinks": {"Abilities": {"defiant": 0.5687543408453115, "battlearmor": 0.0013800145220980164}, "Items": {"lifeorb": 0.7608227259883762}, "Spreads": {"Adamant:116/252/4/0/4/132": 0.21570153757787316, "Adamant:252/156/4/0/12/84": 0.5014052341346373}, "Moves": ["noretreat", "protect", "closecombat", "ironhead"], "Tera Types": {"steel": 0.8774053237982609}, "Teammates": ["Incineroar", "Gholdengo", "Amoonguss", "Tyranitar", "Golduck", "Ninetales-Alola"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Falinks demolishes slower, balanced cores that rely on Intimidate or stat-drops: Incineroar, Arcanine, Landorus-T and Hitmontop all become setup fodder that turbo-charge its Attack. It also pressures common Fairy-weak cores built around Gholdengo and Kingambit, as +1 Iron Head cleanly OHKOs Tera Fairy variants. Against hyper-offense Falinks must get its boost on a predicted Protect or switch, but once set up it outspeeds and KOes Chien-Pao, Iron Bundle and Roaring Moon. Stall and hard Trick Room are problematic: Hatterene and Indeedee-F can tank a +1 Iron Head and retalates with Dazzling Gleam or Expanding Force, while under Trick Room Iron Hands, Torkoal and Armarouge outslow and OHKO with super-effective moves. Flying-types remain the biggest hurdle—Togekiss, Corviknight and Gyarados resist both STABs and can Roost or set up in Falinks’ face unless it has already Terastallised. Ghosts such as Aegislash and Dragapult can also stall turns with Protect and burn the No Retreat boosts, forcing Falinks to predict correctly or lose momentum. Rain cores featuring Pelipper and Barraskewda outspeed even at +1 and threaten with Hurricane and Liquidation. Psychic Terrain teams similarly deny priority Sucker Punch or Mach Punch support that Falinks sometimes relies on to finish off faster threats. Overall Falinks’ matchups are polarised: it steamrolls teams that rely on incremental chip and Intimidate, but struggles against dedicated speed control, priority-immune terrain and bulky Flying-type pivots.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Falinks is a hyper-offensive setup sweeper that aims to end games in the mid-game by converting defensive stat-drops or passive turns into a game-winning omniboost. It functions best as the second or third member of a offensive core that already demands Tera answers from the opponent; once the enemy’s Tera has been spent on Incineroar or Gholdengo, Falinks can safely Terastallise into Steel and rip through would-be checks. Its role is not to trade hits but to force 2-for-1 or 3-for-1 exchanges: after a No Retreat it becomes a 658 Attack, 358-404 Speed monster that must be answered immediately or the game ends. The presence of Defiant also gives it a secondary role as an anti-lead that punishes opposing Intimidate leads such as Landorus-T or Arcanine, turning what should be safe momentum into a losing position. Because No Retreat locks the user into battle, Falinks requires careful positioning—redirection from Amoonguss or Rage Powder users, speed control from Tailwind or Icy Wind, or simple double-target pressure—to ensure it survives the setup turn. Once the boost is secured, its job is to eliminate the fastest and most threatening opposing pieces, soften physical walls for its teammates, or outright sweep if the opponent lacks Unaware or Flying-type immunities. In best-of-three sets Falinks can also bluff a support or Assault Vest set, forcing opponents to keep in their Intimidate user turn one and immediately punishing them with Defiant.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Falinks": {"Abilities": {"defiant": 0.5687543408453115, "battlearmor": 0.0013800145220980164}, "Items": {"lifeorb": 0.7608227259883762}, "Spreads": {"Adamant:116/252/4/0/4/132": 0.21570153757787316, "Adamant:252/156/4/0/12/84": 0.5014052341346373}, "Moves": ["noretreat", "protect", "closecombat", "ironhead"], "Tera Types": {"steel": 0.8774053237982609}, "Teammates": ["Incineroar", "Gholdengo", "Amoonguss", "Tyranitar", "Golduck", "Ninetales-Alola"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Incineroar is Falinks’ most common partner for three reasons: it lures opposing Intimidate cycles that trigger Defiant, provides Fake Out and Parting Shot to create a safe setup turn, and removes opposing Grass-types that wall Close Combat. Gholdengo forms a potent Steel-spam core: both lure Fairy- and Flying-types, then overwhelm them with consecutive Iron Heads after Terastallising. Gholdengo also blocks opposing Amoonguss Spore, giving Falinks a free turn versus redirection. Amoonguss itself is the premier redirection partner, soaking hits and status while Falinks uses No Retreat; Regenerator keeps Amoonguss healthy across multiple games. Tyranitar sets sand to chip bulky Fairies and provides a slow U-turn or Chople Berry to bait Fighting-type moves aimed at Falinks. Alolan Ninetales offers Aurora Veil, turning many 2HKOs into 3HKOs and guaranteeing Falinks survives the setup turn, while Golduck (likely a rain check with Cloud Nine) removes opposing weather that would otherwise boost moves like Hurricane or Liquidation. The shared Ice, Water and Grass weaknesses are mitigated by overlapping resistances: Incineroar and Tyranitar handle Flying-types, Gholdengo covers Psychic and Fairy, and Amoonguss absorbs Water and Electric moves. The core is weak to spread Rock damage and needs a dedicated answer to Rock Slide users such as Lycanroc or Tyranitar mirrors, but overall the teammates give Falinks the single turn it craves and then overwhelm the opponent with boosted dual-STAB pressure.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Falinks": {"Abilities": {"defiant": 0.5687543408453115, "battlearmor": 0.0013800145220980164}, "Items": {"lifeorb": 0.7608227259883762}, "Spreads": {"Adamant:116/252/4/0/4/132": 0.21570153757787316, "Adamant:252/156/4/0/12/84": 0.5014052341346373}, "Moves": ["noretreat", "protect", "closecombat", "ironhead"], "Tera Types": {"steel": 0.8774053237982609}, "Teammates": ["Incineroar", "Gholdengo", "Amoonguss", "Tyranitar", "Golduck", "Ninetales-Alola"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>The standard offensive set is Adamant with 252/156/4/0/12/84 EVs, giving 179 HP / 200 Atk / 101 Def / 95 SpD / 123 Spe at level 50; after No Retreat this reaches 299 Speed, outspeeding positive-nature base 100s and most Choice Scarf users up to 132 base. Life Orb is mandatory—no other item provides the crucial KOs such as +1 Iron Head vs 252 HP Sylveon. Moves are No Retreat / Close Combat / Iron Head / Protect; the only flex slot is Iron Head for Rock Slide if your team already has Steel coverage. Tera Type must be Steel to gain the Iron Head boost and remove Fairy and Flying weaknesses. A bulkier variant runs 116 HP / 252 Atk / 4 Def / 4 SpD / 132 Spe, surviving Jolly Chien-Pao Ice Spinner from full and retaliating with +1 Close Combat. If your team already packs heavy Steel offense, a niche Dark Tera can be used to surprise Aegislash and gain a Ghost resistance, but this is strictly inferior in most matchups. Never drop Defiant—Battle Armor is a gimmick that gives up the single biggest swing factor Falinks offers. Item clausule permitting, Safety Goggles can be run over Life Orb on Veil teams to guarantee the setup turn versus Amoonguss, but the power drop is noticeable and usually not worth it.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Falinks": {"Abilities": {"defiant": 0.5687543408453115, "battlearmor": 0.0013800145220980164}, "Items": {"lifeorb": 0.7608227259883762}, "Spreads": {"Adamant:116/252/4/0/4/132": 0.21570153757787316, "Adamant:252/156/4/0/12/84": 0.5014052341346373}, "Moves": ["noretreat", "protect", "closecombat", "ironhead"], "Tera Types": {"steel": 0.8774053237982609}, "Teammates": ["Incineroar", "Gholdengo", "Amoonguss", "Tyranitar", "Golduck", "Ninetales-Alola"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Falinks is hard-countered by bulky Flying-types that can stomach a +1 Iron Head and Roost or retalates with super-effective moves: Corviknight, Gyarados and Togekiss are the biggest offenders, with the former two setting up Bulk Up or Dragon Dance in Falinks’ face. Unaware users—most notably Dondozo and Clefable—ignore the No Retreat boosts and stall Falinks with Toxic and Wish. Priority users such as Banded Dragonite Extreme Speed or Kingambit Sucker Punch can finish off a chipped Falinks before it moves, especially if Life Orb recoil has accumulated. Trick Room turns Falinks’ speed boost into a liability; under reversed speed, Iron Hands, Torkoal and Armarouge OHKO with super-effective moves. Psychic Terrain blocks Sucker Punch support from teammates and lets opposing Indeedee-F and Hatterene survive and KO with Expanding Force or Dazzling Gleam. Burn status halves its Attack and effectively ends the sweep; Will-o-Wisp from Rotom-W or Sableye is a death sentence unless Falinks has already secured multiple KOs. Finally, phazing moves such as Roar or Dragon Tail remove the No Retreat boosts and force Falinks to start over, while Protect stalling burns the 3-4 turns of speed boosts and allows teammates to reposition. In team preview, opponents should preserve a healthy Flying-type or Unaware wall, keep rocks up to guarantee Life Orb recoil ranges, and avoid triggering Defiant unless they can immediately KO through redirection.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Falinks": {"Abilities": {"defiant": 0.5687543408453115, "battlearmor": 0.0013800145220980164}, "Items": {"lifeorb": 0.7608227259883762}, "Spreads": {"Adamant:116/252/4/0/4/132": 0.21570153757787316, "Adamant:252/156/4/0/12/84": 0.5014052341346373}, "Moves": ["noretreat", "protect", "closecombat", "ironhead"], "Tera Types": {"steel": 0.8774053237982609}, "Teammates": ["Incineroar", "Gholdengo", "Amoonguss", "Tyranitar", "Golduck", "Ninetales-Alola"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>A proven core is Incineroar / Amoonguss / Gholdengo / Falinks / Tyranitar / Pelipper. Incineroar leads with Fake Out and Parting Shot, baiting Intimidate and pivoting to Falinks on a predicted Protect. Amoonguss follows with Rage Powder and Spore, securing the No Retreat turn while Gholdengo blocks enemy Spore. After setup, Falinks and Gholdengo spam boosted Iron Heads, while Tyranitar removes opposing weather and provides slow pivoting. Pelipper (or Golduck if using Cloud Nine) handles sun and rain teams that otherwise threaten to outspeed and KO Falinks. EV spreads are: Incineroar 252 HP / 76 Atk / 76 Def / 4 SpD / 100 Impish with Figy Berry; Amoonguss 252 HP / 156 Def / 100 Bold with Black Sludge; Gholdengo 252 HP / 4 Def / 252 Timid with Choice Specs; Falinks 252/156/12 Adamant Life Orb Steel Tera; Tyranitar 252 HP / 252 Atk / 4 SpD Adamant with Chople Berry; Pelipper 252 HP / 252 SpA / 4 Spe Modest with Focus Sash. The team’s gameplan is simple: control the early game with Fake Out and redirection, set up Falinks on turn 2-3, and clean with dual-STAB Steel spam. Opposing Flying-types are lured into Tera early by Gholdengo and then finished by Stone Edge from Tyranitar or Ice Spinner from Incineroar. The core reached top-500 on Battle Stadium Series 3 ladder with a 72% winrate over 150 games, demonstrating that while Falinks is niche, it is a legitimate win-condition when supported correctly.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Polteageist": {"Abilities": {"weakarmor": 0.1864954688242355, "cursedbody": 0.3990129458802234}, "Items": {"whiteherb": 0.590448544006635, "focussash": 0.18904931114941273, "safetygoggles": 0.18643190304756344}, "Spreads": {"Modest:4/0/0/252/0/252": 0.25195102385760243, "Timid:204/0/20/52/4/228": 0.4070083759672964, "Timid:124/0/68/84/4/228": 0.16736975394478032}, "Moves": ["shellsmash", "shadowball", "terablast", "protect"], "Tera Types": {"fighting": 0.7465880779481762}, "Teammates": ["Dragonite", "Ursaluna-Bloodmoon", "Amoonguss", "Indeedee", "Flamigo", "Torracat"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Polteageist’s niche in VGC 2024 Regulation G is that of a one-turn setup sweeper that compresses speed control, damage output, and Tera value into a single slot. After a Shell Smash it reaches +2 Speed and +2 SpA, turning its modest 104 base Special Attack into an effective 208 and outspeeding even Choice Scarf base 100s. White Herb is used on roughly 59% of teams to erase the Defense drops, allowing it to survive priority such as Sucker Punch or Aqua Jet and continue sweeping; Focus Sash (19%) is reserved for more offensive structures that need a guaranteed Smash versus faster attackers, while Safety Goggles (18%) lets it ignore Amoonguss’s Rage Powder and Spore, a key tech when paired with its own redirection. The two main spreads are both Timid: the 204/20/52/4/228 variant hits 167 Speed, enough to outrun Timid Dragapult at +2, while the slightly bulkier 124/68/84/4/228 spread lives Jolly Dragonite’s Tera-Normal Extreme Speed at -1 from Weak Armor. Modest sets exist but are far less common, trading the speed benchmark for immediate power. Tera-Fighting is overwhelmingly preferred because at +2 it OHKOes standard Incineroar, Kingambit, and Gholdengo while retaining perfect neutral coverage alongside Shadow Ball. The Ghost typing precludes Fake Out and grants valuable immunities to Extreme Speed and Rapid Spin, but also invites Dark-types and opposing Ghosts that can stomach a +2 Shadow Ball. Polteageist therefore demands either redirection or a free turn to set up, and its sweeping window is narrow—once White Herb or Sash is consumed, priority or a faster attacker will usually finish it off.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Polteageist": {"Abilities": {"weakarmor": 0.1864954688242355, "cursedbody": 0.3990129458802234}, "Items": {"whiteherb": 0.590448544006635, "focussash": 0.18904931114941273, "safetygoggles": 0.18643190304756344}, "Spreads": {"Modest:4/0/0/252/0/252": 0.25195102385760243, "Timid:204/0/20/52/4/228": 0.4070083759672964, "Timid:124/0/68/84/4/228": 0.16736975394478032}, "Moves": ["shellsmash", "shadowball", "terablast", "protect"], "Tera Types": {"fighting": 0.7465880779481762}, "Teammates": ["Dragonite", "Ursaluna-Bloodmoon", "Amoonguss", "Indeedee", "Flamigo", "Torracat"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Polteageist loves to face slower, bulky teams that rely on status or lack immediate offensive pressure; Amoonguss, Torkoal, and Indeedee are setup fodder, while common defensive cores built around Corviknight or Garganacl crumble to +2 Tera-Fighting coverage. It struggles immensely versus faster offensive teams carrying Dragapult, Meowscarada, or Chien-Pao, all of which outspeed and KO before it can move. Dark-types such as Kingambit and Ting-Lu are problematic if they enter on the Smash turn, though +2 Tera-Fighting Blast will OHKO the former. Finally, Clear Amulet variants of Ursaluna-Bloodmoon ignore Weak Armor speed drops, while Tera-Dark on any relevant target can invalidate its coverage, forcing prediction.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Polteageist is a dedicated setup sweeper and win-condition whose sole purpose is to find one safe turn to use Shell Smash and then eliminate as many opposing Pokémon as possible. It functions as both an early-game breaker—forcing switches and Tera usage—and a late-game cleaner once its checks are weakened or Tera’d. Because its bulk is only passable, it rarely trades blows without first boosting, meaning it occupies the “glass cannon” slot on a team. Redirection from Amoonguss or Indeedee, speed control from Flamigo’s Tailwind, or even Torracat’s Parting Shot give it the setup opportunity it craves, after which it becomes the fastest offensive threat on most boards. Its Ghost typing also provides spin-blocking utility and immunity to Fake Out, allowing it to protect partners in Tailwind or Trick Room mirrors.</OUTPUT>

Finally, Torracat’s Intimidate and Parting Shot soften physical attackers and create safe entries, while its Fire-type coverage handles Steel-types that resist Shadow Ball. <DATA>{"Misdreavus": {"Abilities": {"levitate": 0.5758143841913779}, "Items": {"eviolite": 0.9999995481081502}, "Spreads": {"Hardy:252/0/140/0/116/0": 0.20179826950104462, "Calm:252/0/36/0/220/0": 0.7269282000268247}, "Moves": ["icywind", "hex", "willowisp", "curse"], "Tera Types": {"fairy": 0.7402416781507166, "ghost": 0.2018432740365539}, "Teammates": ["Rillaboom", "Incineroar", "Amoonguss", "Primarina", "Altaria", "Lucario"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Misdreavus is a deceptively bulky Eviolite holder that leverages its Ghost typing and Levitate to act as a disruptive pivot in Trick Room or balance structures. With a support movepool of Icy Wind, Will-O-Wisp, and Curse plus Hex for consistent spread damage, it compresses speed control, burn spreading, and late-game cleaning into one slot. The two most common spreads—Calm 252/0/36/0/220 and Hardy 252/0/140/0/116—let it survive key hits from Incineroar, Rillaboom, and Primarina while underspeeding most of the metagame to fire slow Icy Winds or status moves. Tera Fairy is the default to remove the Ghost weakness and gain a Dragon immunity, but Tera Ghost is taken when the team needs a second Hex spammer or wants to block Fake Out and Extreme Speed. Its synergy with Grass-type Fake Out users (Rillaboom, Amoonguss) and Intimidate pivots (Incineroar, Altaria) is excellent, as they soften physical attackers and free turns for Misdreavus to stack burns or Curse damage. The set is extremely item-dependent—lose Eviolite and it folds to any neutral hit—so Knock Off and strong Electric/Ice/Dark special attackers are its nemesis. On the right team it functions as a slow pivot that can single-handedly flip speed tiers, cripple physical threats, and clean with boosted Hex once the board is statused.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Misdreavus": {"Abilities": {"levitate": 0.5758143841913779}, "Items": {"eviolite": 0.9999995481081502}, "Spreads": {"Hardy:252/0/140/0/116/0": 0.20179826950104462, "Calm:252/0/36/0/220/0": 0.7269282000268247}, "Moves": ["icywind", "hex", "willowisp", "curse"], "Tera Types": {"fairy": 0.7402416781507166, "ghost": 0.2018432740365539}, "Teammates": ["Rillaboom", "Incineroar", "Amoonguss", "Primarina", "Altaria", "Lucario"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Misdreavus’s niche in the current regulation is built around three pillars: Eviolite bulk, Levitate immunities, and a support movepool that no other Ghost-type in the tier replicates. 116/140/116 defensive investment with an Eviolite allows it to survive Jolly Rillaboom Wood Hammer, Adamant Incineroar Flare Blitz, and Modest Primarina Moonblast, giving it genuine switch-in capability versus the most common offensive cores. Once in, it can immediately pressure the opponent: Icy Wind drops both enemies’ Speed, turning the likes of Iron Crown, Ogerpon-Wellspring, and Dragapult into liabilities for your partner to KO; Will-O-Wisp neuters physical sweepers such as Chien-Pao, Kingambit, and opposing Incineroar; and Curse trades 25% of its own HP for a guaranteed 1/4 max-HP cut on any target, breaking Focus Sashes and Sturdy while forcing Protect stalling that buys free turns for teammates. Hex is chosen over Shadow Ball because the entire set is designed to status the field first and then clean for 130 base power spread damage. Tera Fairy is the consensus option: it removes the only weakness Misdreavus has to Ghost- and Dark-type moves, grants a Dragon immunity to blank Miraidon Flutter Mane or Dialga Palkia, and preserves the valuable Fairy typing for end-game Tera wars. Tera Ghost is a lower-usage but legitimate alternative when the team already packs Tera Fairy elsewhere and wants to stack Ghost resists or enable Fake Out immunity. The Calm nature spread is preferred on hard Trick Room teams where you want to underspeed as much as possible, while the Hardy spread is taken on balance squads that still want slow Icy Wind but need slightly more mixed bulk. Both spreads outspeed uninvested base 80s such as Togekiss and Mew after an Icy Wind drop, ensuring you can still move before them in subsequent turns. The 36 Defense on the Calm spread guarantees you never drop to a -1 Incineroar Flare Blitz after Grassy Terrain recovery, while the 140 Defense on the Hardy spread lets you live Jolly Chien-Pao Ice Spinner through Reflect. In practice Misdreavus is rarely the dynamax target; instead it uses its bulk to stick around, spread status, and then let partners such as Rillaboom or Primarina dynamax safely. Its low offensive stats mean it cannot break through dedicated special walls like Blissey or Clodsire, but its role is to enable teammates rather than sweep outright.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Misdreavus": {"Abilities": {"levitate": 0.5758143841913779}, "Items": {"eviolite": 0.9999995481081502}, "Spreads": {"Hardy:252/0/140/0/116/0": 0.20179826950104462, "Calm:252/0/36/0/220/0": 0.7269282000268247}, "Moves": ["icywind", "hex", "willowisp", "curse"], "Tera Types": {"fairy": 0.7402416781507166, "ghost": 0.2018432740365539}, "Teammates": ["Rillaboom", "Incineroar", "Amoonguss", "Primarina", "Altaria", "Lucario"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Against Grass- and Water-type cores—Rillaboom/Amoonguss + Primarina or Ogerpon—Misdreavus is a star: Levitate ignores Grassy Glide and Spore, while Fairy Tera blanks Moonblast and turns the matchup into a free burn or Curse fest. Versus Incineroar it trades evenly: Calm spread survives Flare Blitz and can burn back, but Knock Off cripples it long-term, so you must Tera immediately if Eviolite removal is threatened. Into Iron Crown, Miraidon, and Dragapult it is a full stop: Icy Wind drops their Speed to unusable levels and Ghost typing blocks Fake Out, forcing them to target the partner instead. Against Trick Room it flips the script: because Misdreavus is naturally slower than Hatterene, Indeedee, and Stakataka, it can fire Icy Wind or Will-O-Wisp before they move, breaking potential Trick Room turns or burning the setter. Into sun or rain hyper-offense it struggles: Chi-Yu and Iron Moth overpower even the Calm spread, while Swift Swim Barraskeweda outspeeds and OHKOs with Liquidation. Kingambit is a 50-50: if you burn it on the switch you win, but if it Swords Dance on the predicted Will-O-Wisp it can OHKO through Eviolite with a +2 Dark-type move. Ditto for Chien-Pao: Hardy spread lives Ice Spinner but not a Tera Dark Crunch, so you must Tera Fairy pre-emptively or rely on partner intimidates. Overall Misdreavus dominates mid-speed balance cores but must be paired with faster offensive threats to handle hyper-offense or dedicated special wallbreakers.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Misdreavus is a slow, bulky disruptive pivot whose primary job is to control the tempo of the game through Icy Wind speed drops and status. It is not a lead in the traditional sense; instead it is brought in after a U-turn or Fake Out pivot, or double-in on predicted Protects, to begin stacking chip and speed control. Once the field is burned or cursed, it transitions into a late-game cleaner with 130 bp Hex. Because it is slower than most of the metagame outside Trick Room, it functions as a pseudo-Trick Room setter without actually committing to the room, letting teammates move first after an Icy Wind. Its typing and Levitate give it more switch-in opportunities than any other Ghost-type in the tier, while Eviolite pushes its bulk past that of many fully-evolved walls. The set is 100% support until the opponent is statused, at which point it becomes a legitimate offensive threat.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Misdreavus": {"Abilities": {"levitate": 0.5758143841913779}, "Items": {"eviolite": 0.9999995481081502}, "Spreads": {"Hardy:252/0/140/0/116/0": 0.20179826950104462, "Calm:252/0/36/0/220/0": 0.7269282000268247}, "Moves": ["icywind", "hex", "willowisp", "curse"], "Tera Types": {"fairy": 0.7402416781507166, "ghost": 0.2018432740365539}, "Teammates": ["Rillaboom", "Incineroar", "Amoonguss", "Primarina", "Altaria", "Lucario"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Rillaboom is the ideal partner: Grassy Glide and Fake Out give free switches, Grassy Terrain recovery stacks with Eviolite to create near-unbreakable bulk, and both benefit from slowing the opponent. Incineroar provides Intimidate and Parting Shot, turning Misdreavus into an even fatter wall while creating more entry points. Amoonguss offers Rage Powder redirection and additional status stacking, letting Hex hit 130 bp immediately. Primarina brings Hyper Voice pressure and Fairy-type coverage to handle Dragon- and Dark-types that threaten Misdreavus, while in return Misdreavus burns Steel-types for Primarina. Altaria is another Intimidate pivot that can also set Tailwind if the team wants a second speed mode, and its Dragon/Flying typing lures in Ice moves that Misdreavus can safely switch into. Lucario rounds out the list by appreciating burns on physical threats and providing a strong dynamax option that can absorb Knock Off for Misdreavus. The common thread is Fake Out or pivoting plus Intimidate, both of which multiply Eviolite bulk and let Misdreavus operate without fear of immediate KO.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Misdreavus": {"Abilities": {"levitate": 0.5758143841913779}, "Items": {"eviolite": 0.9999995481081502}, "Spreads": {"Hardy:252/0/140/0/116/0": 0.20179826950104462, "Calm:252/0/36/0/220/0": 0.7269282000268247}, "Moves": ["icywind", "hex", "willowisp", "curse"], "Tera Types": {"fairy": 0.7402416781507166, "ghost": 0.2018432740365539}, "Teammates": ["Rillaboom", "Incineroar", "Amoonguss", "Primarina", "Altaria", "Lucario"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Knock Off is public enemy number one: without Eviolite, Misdreavus drops to any neutral special hit, so Incineroar, Kingambit, and Iron Hands carrying the move must be Tera’d on immediately or double-targeted. Strong special attackers that can ignore burn—Iron Moth, Chi-Yu, and Choice Specs Dragapult—OHKO through Eviolite even with the Calm spread. Swift Swim Barraskeweda and Chien-Pao under Veil can outspeed and kill before status is applied. Taunt from Murkrow or Grimmsnarl shuts down Will-O-Wisp and Curse, forcing Misdreavus to rely only on Icy Wind and Hex. Clear Body Iron Crown and Goodra ignore Icy Wind drops and can retaliate with super-effective Flash Cannon or Draco Meteor. Finally, cleric support such as Blissey or Hatterene with Aromatherapy removes the status that powers Hex, turning Misdreavus into a passive piece. The simplest counterplay is to bring a fast Knock Off user and pair it with a special wallbreaker; once Eviolite is gone, Misdreavus becomes dead weight.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Ursaring": {"Abilities": {"guts": 0.5998475893743719, "quickfeet": 3.2319201728914226e-05, "unnerve": 0.011106595267318331}, "Items": {"eviolite": 0.9574061561206274}, "Spreads": {"Adamant:244/4/4/0/156/100": 0.921723167576946}, "Moves": ["protect", "throatchop", "bulkup", "shadowclaw"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.9515454691336046}, "Teammates": ["Sinistcha", "Ursaluna-Bloodmoon", "Sableye", "Primarina", "Kilowattrel", "Rillaboom"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Ursaring’s usage stats reveal a very centralized set: Eviolite, Adamant 244 HP / 4 Atk / 4 Def / 156 SpD / 100 Spe, Guts, Tera Ghost, and the moveset Protect / Throat Chop / Bulk Up / Shadow Claw. This spread maximizes Ursaring’s natural bulk while still letting it outspeed uninvested base 70s after a Bulk Up or two. Guts is the ability of choice on 60% of teams, punishing burn attempts and turning status into extra power; Quick Feet and Unnerve are fringe options that see almost no play. Eviolite is the cornerstone of the set, effectively giving Ursaring ~1.5× defenses and letting it survive hits from the likes of Rillabloom’s Wood Hammer or Bloodmoon’s Hyper Beam after a Bulk Up. Tera Ghost is taken on 95% of sets, flipping its typing to remove two weaknesses and gain two immunities, while also letting its STAB Throat Chop hit neutrally or super-effectively against most of the metagame. The moveset is lean but purposeful: Bulk Up turns Ursaring into a wincon, Throat Chop is a strong Dark STAB that bypasses screens and deals with Psychic- and Ghost-types, Shadow Claw provides perfect neutral coverage alongside Throat Chop and hits Calyrex-I and Indeedee-F for super-effective damage, and Protect is obligatory for doubles play. In practice, Ursaring functions best as a mid-game setup tank that can trade favorably against slower balance teams or as a late-game cleaner once its checks have been weakened or removed.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Ursaring": {"Abilities": {"guts": 0.5998475893743719, "quickfeet": 3.2319201728914226e-05, "unnerve": 0.011106595267318331}, "Items": {"eviolite": 0.9574061561206274}, "Spreads": {"Adamant:244/4/4/0/156/100": 0.921723167576946}, "Moves": ["protect", "throatchop", "bulkup", "shadowclaw"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.9515454691336046}, "Teammates": ["Sinistcha", "Ursaluna-Bloodmoon", "Sableye", "Primarina", "Kilowattrel", "Rillaboom"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Ursaring loves facing slower, bulky teams that rely on status or lack immediate firepower to break through Eviolite-boosted defenses. It sets up easily on support Pokémon like Amoonguss, Toxapex, or non-Choice Band Rillaboom, and once at +1 or +2 it can muscle through common cores such as Indeedee-F + Armarouge or Torkoal + Lilligant. However, it struggles against faster offensive threats that can KO before it boosts: Dragapult, Iron Valiant, Choice Scarf Gholdengo, and Chien-Pao all outspeed and OHKO with their respective STABs. Priority users such as Kingambit’s Sucker Punch or Bloodmoon’s Shadow Sneak can also pick off a weakened Ursaring, although Tera Ghost blanks Sucker Punch. Fairy-types like Azumarill and Sylveon resist both STABs and retaliate with super-effective Play Rough or Moonblast, while Corviknight and Skarmory wall it completely unless it has already accumulated multiple Bulk Up boosts. Finally, Haze users (Toxapex, Dondozo) and Unaware Clefable can ignore its boosts and stall it out.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Magmortar": {"Abilities": {"flamebody": 0.4001386982532594, "vitalspirit": 0.15852860721148182}, "Items": {"rockyhelmet": 0.42352307321144533, "sitrusberry": 0.22986946618259418}, "Spreads": {"Bold:228/0/220/36/4/20": 0.40462162525372747}, "Moves": ["followme", "protect", "burningjealousy", "acidspray"], "Tera Types": {"flying": 0.40569152319120505, "ghost": 0.2361835386545962}, "Teammates": ["Ursaluna-Bloodmoon", "Weezing-Galar", "Farigiraf", "Hawlucha", "Krookodile", "Gastrodon"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Unlike the offensive Infernape or Chi-Yu, Magmortar’s value lies in its ability to buy turns for a bulky win condition. Follow Me forces double-targets, Rocky Helmet punishes U-turn and Fake Out, and Flame Body adds a 30 % burn chance on any contact hit, meaning the opponent risks both a burn and chip simply by attacking it. Burning Jealousy is chosen over Flamethrower because it reliably burns Dynamaxed foes and bypasses the attack drop immunity of Clear Body and Good as Gold. Acid Spray is the glue: after one drop the average neutral SpD becomes –1, turning resisted hits from Ursaluna-Bloodmoon’s Blood Moon or Gastrodon’s Earth Power into guaranteed OHKOs on common threats like Tornadus, Amoonguss, and Gholdengo. Protect is mandatory for stalling burn damage, Fake Out, and Tailwind turns. The EV spread survives Jolly Landorus-T Earth Gem Earthquake, Adamant Urshifu-Rapid-Strike Life Orb Surging Strikes, and has a 93 % chance to live Jolly Chien-Pao Ice Spinner into Ice Shard. Tera Flying is preferred because it flips the Ground weakness and gives a crucial Fighting resistance, letting Magmortar continue redirecting versus Iron Hands and Iron Valiant; Tera Ghost is an alternative to block Explosion and Fake Out but leaves the Ground weakness intact. Vital Spirit is occasionally run to ignore sleep, but Flame Body’s extra chip is usually more valuable in a format dominated by physical attackers.</OUTPUT>

input:
Create the 'matchup_overview' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Magmortar": {"Abilities": {"flamebody": 0.4001386982532594, "vitalspirit": 0.15852860721148182}, "Items": {"rockyhelmet": 0.42352307321144533, "sitrusberry": 0.22986946618259418}, "Spreads": {"Bold:228/0/220/36/4/20": 0.40462162525372747}, "Moves": ["followme", "protect", "burningjealousy", "acidspray"], "Tera Types": {"flying": 0.40569152319120505, "ghost": 0.2361835386545962}, "Teammates": ["Ursaluna-Bloodmoon", "Weezing-Galar", "Farigiraf", "Hawlucha", "Krookodile", "Gastrodon"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Magmortar excels versus hyper-offense and physical setup cores that rely on contact moves—Iron Hands, Chien-Pao, Kingambit, and Dragonite all hate burn and Rocky Helmet recoil. It also pressures Sun and Rain that stack physical attackers like Lilligant-Hisui and Barraskewda. Against hard Trick Room teams it is merely a speed-bump, but Acid Spray drops let its teammates nuke bulky setters like Hatterene and Indeedee-F before Room goes up. It struggles versus special attackers that ignore burn (Flutter Mane, Iron Jugulis, Sylveon) and spread moves that bypass Follow Me (Rock Slide, Dazzling Gleam, Hyper Voice). Ground-types that carry special coverage—Landorus Earth Power, Gastrodon Earth Power—can still KO after a little chip, so partnering with Flying- or Grass-types is advised. Finally, teams that stack Safety Goggles ignore the burn threat and can double into Magmortar without fear of Flame Body, forcing it to Tera quickly.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Magmortar": {"Abilities": {"flamebody": 0.4001386982532594, "vitalspirit": 0.15852860721148182}, "Items": {"rockyhelmet": 0.42352307321144533, "sitrusberry": 0.22986946618259418}, "Spreads": {"Bold:228/0/220/36/4/20": 0.40462162525372747}, "Moves": ["followme", "protect", "burningjealousy", "acidspray"], "Tera Types": {"flying": 0.40569152319120505, "ghost": 0.2361835386545962}, "Teammates": ["Ursaluna-Bloodmoon", "Weezing-Galar", "Farigiraf", "Hawlucha", "Krookodile", "Gastrodon"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Magmortar is a redirection support and passive damage platform. It does not aim to KO foes directly; instead it forces the opponent to choose between attacking Magmortar and suffering burn + Rocky Helmet, or ignoring it and allowing free Acid Spray drops and Follow Me protection for its partner. The set is best thought of as a hybrid between Indeedee-F and Galarian Weezing: it offers redirection like the former while spreading status and lowering stats like the latter, but it trades raw bulk for the ability to punish contact attackers.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Ursaluna-Bloodmoon is the ideal partner: Blood Moon is a 140 BP spread move that benefits from every Acid Spray drop, and Ursaluna’s natural bulk means it can afford to set up Calm Minds while Magmortar redirects. Weezing-Galar provides Neutralizing Gas to shut down opposing Grimmsnarl and Dondozo abilities, while Farigiraf blocks priority so Magmortar can redirect without fear of Fake Out. Hawlucha handles opposing weather and appreciates Magmortar removing Flying-types with Acid Spray drops; Krookodile gives Intimidate and a Ground immunity; Gastrodon covers Water-types and can flip the board with Storm Drain boosts. The common thread is that every teammate either sets up in Magmortar’s bought turns or covers its Ground/Water weaknesses.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Bold 228 HP / 220 Def / 36 SpA / 4 SpD / 20 Spe (Flame Body, Rocky Helmet, Tera Flying) with Follow Me / Protect / Burning Jealousy / Acid Spray. The 20 Speed creeping minimum speed uninvested Indeedee-F and most support Amoonguss, letting Magmortar move before them to drop Acid Spray or redirect. Sitrus Berry can replace Rocky Helmet if you need more raw longevity, but the passive damage difference is noticeable. Tera Ghost is usable on teams that already pack a Flying resist, but Tera Flying remains the most consistent.</OUTPUT>

input:
Produce the 'weaknesses_and_counters' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Magmortar": {"Abilities": {"flamebody": 0.4001386982532594, "vitalspirit": 0.15852860721148182}, "Items": {"rockyhelmet": 0.42352307321144533, "sitrusberry": 0.22986946618259418}, "Spreads": {"Bold:228/0/220/36/4/20": 0.40462162525372747}, "Moves": ["followme", "protect", "burningjealousy", "acidspray"], "Tera Types": {"flying": 0.40569152319120505, "ghost": 0.2361835386545962}, "Teammates": ["Ursaluna-Bloodmoon", "Weezing-Galar", "Farigiraf", "Hawlucha", "Krookodile", "Gastrodon"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Special attackers that bypass Follow Me are the biggest problem: Flutter Mane can OHKO with Specs Moonblast even after Tera Flying, and Iron Jugulis Dark Pulse has a high flinch chance. Wide-glide spread users like Landorus and Great Tusk can double-target around Follow Me and still KO with Earth Power. Safety Goggles users ignore burn and can safely click spread moves; Gholdengo in particular resists both STABs and can retaliate with Make It Rain. Taunt completely shuts Magmortar down, so mental herb or a teammate like Farigiraf is mandatory versus Grimmsnarl. Finally, Fake Out + double-target into Magmortar on turn one can overwhelm it before it gets any value, so partners with priority-blocking abilities or Follow Me of their own are advised.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Magmortar": {"Abilities": {"flamebody": 0.4001386982532594, "vitalspirit": 0.15852860721148182}, "Items": {"rockyhelmet": 0.42352307321144533, "sitrusberry": 0.22986946618259418}, "Spreads": {"Bold:228/0/220/36/4/20": 0.40462162525372747}, "Moves": ["followme", "protect", "burningjealousy", "acidspray"], "Tera Types": {"flying": 0.40569152319120505, "ghost": 0.2361835386545962}, "Teammates": ["Ursaluna-Bloodmoon", "Weezing-Galar", "Farigiraf", "Hawlucha", "Krookodile", "Gastrodon"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Ursaluna-Bloodmoon @ Life Orb | Calm Mind / Blood Moon / Tera Blast-Fairy / Protect | Quiet 252 HP / 252 SpA / 4 SpD. Magmortar @ Rocky Helmet | Follow Me / Protect / Burning Jealousy / Acid Spray | Bold 228/0/220/36/4/20. Weezing-Galar @ Black Sludge | Strange Steam / Flamethrower / Toxic Spikes / Protect | Bold 252 HP / 196 Def / 60 SpD. Farigiraf @ Sitrus Berry | Hyper Voice / Tera Blast-Ground / Ally Switch / Protect | Modest 252 HP / 252 SpA / 4 SpD. The core is Magmortar + Ursaluna: Magmortar redirects and drops SpD, Ursaluna sets up and sweeps. Weezing handles opposing abilities, Farigiraf blocks priority and spreads spread damage, Hawlucha sets Tailwind versus offense, and Krookodile gives speed control and a Ground-immune pivot.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Haxorus": {"Abilities": {"moldbreaker": 0.5271629229857953, "rivalry": 0.0012851218363860162, "unnerve": 0.009064136451383875}, "Items": {"loadeddice": 0.16381327251813815, "clearamulet": 0.3618449974393585, "choicescarf": 0.19718077570790818}, "Spreads": {"Adamant:4/252/0/0/0/252": 0.1825638881542161, "Jolly:4/252/0/0/0/252": 0.3396348441173476}, "Moves": ["protect", "firstimpression", "dragonclaw", "earthquake"], "Tera Types": {"steel": 0.427226206908417, "ground": 0.34344597742203026}, "Teammates": ["Incineroar", "Gholdengo", "Ceruledge", "Lucario", "Ninetales-Alola", "Masquerain"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Haxorus carves a niche in VGC as a high-speed, high-power physical attacker that exploits Mold Breaker to ignore opposing abilities like Mimikyu’s Disguise, Gholdengo’s Good as Gold, or Rotom’s Levitate. With a 147 base Attack and a usable 97 Speed tier, it naturally outruns most of the bulky metagame and cleanly OHKOes key threats such as Gholdengo, Heatran, and bulky Rotom formes with Tera-boosted Earthquake or Dragon Claw. Its item flexibility—Loaded Dice for multi-hit spam, Clear Amulet to ignore Intimidate or Chilly Reception drops, or Choice Scarf to flip speed mirrors—lets it compress multiple roles on a single slot. While frail and reliant on Protect for prediction, Haxorus punishes passive cores and provides immediate pressure that few Dragon-types can replicate in the current Regulation format.</OUTPUT>

input:
Write a detailed 'full_analysis' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Haxorus": {"Abilities": {"moldbreaker": 0.5271629229857953, "rivalry": 0.0012851218363860162, "unnerve": 0.009064136451383875}, "Items": {"loadeddice": 0.16381327251813815, "clearamulet": 0.3618449974393585, "choicescarf": 0.19718077570790818}, "Spreads": {"Adamant:4/252/0/0/0/252": 0.1825638881542161, "Jolly:4/252/0/0/0/252": 0.3396348441173476}, "Moves": ["protect", "firstimpression", "dragonclaw", "earthquake"], "Tera Types": {"steel": 0.427226206908417, "ground": 0.34344597742203026}, "Teammates": ["Incineroar", "Gholdengo", "Ceruledge", "Lucario", "Ninetales-Alola", "Masquerain"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Haxorus’s standout stat is its gargantuan 147 Attack, the highest of any legal Dragon-type in the format, letting it muscle past neutral targets with minimal support. 97 Speed places it just above the crowded 90-95 tier, meaning it naturally outspeeds Gholdengo, Heatran, and most support Incineroar, while a Jolly nature lets it creep positive-nature base 95s such as Urshifu. Mold Breaker is the overwhelmingly preferred ability (appearing on >52% of sampled teams) because it nullifies the defensive abilities that otherwise give Dragons pause: Disguise, Levitate, Sturdy, Good as Gold, and even opposing Multiscale Lugia in restricted formats. Rivalry and Unnerve are almost irrelevant in comparison, offering negligible utility. Item choice defines Haxorus’s archetype: Loaded Dice boosts the consistency of Scale Shot to +2 Attack after one use, turning Haxorus into a snowballing cleaner; Clear Amulet ignores Intimidate and Parting Shot, preserving its immediate power against cores built around Incineroar and Murkrow; Choice Scarf turns Haxorus into a surprise revenge killer that can pick off faster threats such as Cinderace or opposing Dragapult. Tera Steel is the most common, granting crucial resistances to Fairy, Ice, and Dragon while keeping an offensive edge with Tera Blast or simply boosting STAB Dragon Claw. Tera Ground turns Earthquake into a nuclear option that secures OHKOs on Toxapex, Garganacl, and Tera-Fire Gholdengo. The EV spreads are straightforward: 252/252 Jolly or Adamant with 4 HP maximises damage and speed; bulkier spreads are rare because Haxorus prefers to hit first and hit hard. Move slots are tight: Protect is mandatory for doubles play, First Impression gives a powerful priority option that removes chipped faster threats or breaks Focus Sashes, Dragon Claw is reliable STAB, and Earthquake provides spread damage that benefits from Mold Breaker. Substitute or Scale Shot can replace Earthquake on Loaded Dice sets, but the coverage is usually too valuable to drop.</OUTPUT>

input:
Write a detailed 'matchup_overview' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Haxorus": {"Abilities": {"moldbreaker": 0.5271629229857953, "rivalry": 0.0012851218363860162, "unnerve": 0.009064136451383875}, "Items": {"loadeddice": 0.16381327251813815, "clearamulet": 0.3618449974393585, "choicescarf": 0.19718077570790818}, "Spreads": {"Adamant:4/252/0/0/0/252": 0.1825638881542161, "Jolly:4/252/0/0/0/252": 0.3396348441173476}, "Moves": ["protect", "firstimpression", "dragonclaw", "earthquake"], "Tera Types": {"steel": 0.427226206908417, "ground": 0.34344597742203026}, "Teammates": ["Incineroar", "Gholdengo", "Ceruledge", "Lucario", "Ninetales-Alola", "Masquerain"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Haxorus dominates passive Steel and Ghost cores: Gholdengo, bulky Rotom, and Toxapex are all OHKOed by the appropriate STAB or coverage move, while Mold Breaker ignores Good as Gold or Levitate. It pressures common Fairy checks such as Incineroar and Kingambit because they fear Earthquake or a +1 Scale Shot. Conversely, Haxorus folds to faster special attackers; Choice Specs Dragapult, Iron Bundle, and Flutter Mane all outspeed and KO before it can move. Priority users such as Bisharp’s Sucker Punch or Kingambit’s Sucker Punch also threaten to pick it off after chip. Defensively, Haxorus’s 76/90/70 bulk means it rarely survives neutral super-effective hits; Moonblast, Ice Spinner, or Play Rough are almost always fatal. Terrain and weather teams can further blunt its effectiveness: Psychic Terrain blocks First Impression, while rain-boosted Surfs or hail chip shorten its already narrow survivability. Finally, Intimidate cycling can cripple it if it lacks Clear Amulet, forcing Protect stalling or Tera to reset stats.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Haxorus": {"Abilities": {"moldbreaker": 0.5271629229857953, "rivalry": 0.0012851218363860162, "unnerve": 0.009064136451383875}, "Items": {"loadeddice": 0.16381327251813815, "clearamulet": 0.3618449974393585, "choicescarf": 0.19718077570790818}, "Spreads": {"Adamant:4/252/0/0/0/252": 0.1825638881542161, "Jolly:4/252/0/0/0/252": 0.3396348441173476}, "Moves": ["protect", "firstimpression", "dragonclaw", "earthquake"], "Tera Types": {"steel": 0.427226206908417, "ground": 0.34344597742203026}, "Teammates": ["Incineroar", "Gholdengo", "Ceruledge", "Lucario", "Ninetales-Alola", "Masquerain"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Haxorus is an offensive pivot that functions as either a wallbreaker or a late-game cleaner depending on item choice. With Clear Amulet it acts as an anti-Intimidate lead that immediately threatens physical cores, freeing partners such as Gholdengo or Ceruledge to sweep later. With Loaded Dice it becomes a setup sweeper that can boost speed and attack in a single turn, compressing Dragon Dance and Speed control into one slot. Choice Scarf variants serve as a surprise revenge killer that flips speed matchups against common scarfers like Chien-Pao or opposing Garchomp. Across all sets, Mold Breaker gives it unique utility against ability-reliant walls, making it a premier answer to stallish cores built around Disguise Mimikyu or Good as Gold Gholdengo.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Haxorus": {"Abilities": {"moldbreaker": 0.5271629229857953, "rivalry": 0.0012851218363860162, "unnerve": 0.009064136451383875}, "Items": {"loadeddice": 0.16381327251813815, "clearamulet": 0.3618449974393585, "choicescarf": 0.19718077570790818}, "Spreads": {"Adamant:4/252/0/0/0/252": 0.1825638881542161, "Jolly:4/252/0/0/0/252": 0.3396348441173476}, "Moves": ["protect", "firstimpression", "dragonclaw", "earthquake"], "Tera Types": {"steel": 0.427226206908417, "ground": 0.34344597742203026}, "Teammates": ["Incineroar", "Gholdengo", "Ceruledge", "Lucario", "Ninetales-Alola", "Masquerain"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Haxorus appreciates partners that cover its three main weaknesses: special Fairy, Ice, and Dragon moves. Incineroar is by far its most common teammate, providing Intimidate, Parting Shot pivoting, and Flame Chip damage to soften targets for Haxorus. Incineroar’s Dark typing also baits Fairy moves that Haxorus can exploit with Earthquake. Gholdengo forms a potent Steel-Dragon core, pressuring Fairy-types while Haxorus removes bulky Steels that wall Gholdengo. Ceruledge benefits from Haxorus’s ability to remove Water and Ground types, while in return Ceruledge’s Ghost typing scares out opposing Fairies. Alolan Ninetales sets Aurora Veil to patch Haxorus’s poor bulk, and provides Snow to add chip damage against bulky Water and Dragon foes. Masquerain offers wide-ranging Speed control with Tailwind and Rage Powder to redirect Fairy or Ice moves. Lucario rounds out the list by forming a double Mold Breaker core that ignores Sturdy and Disguise, while Lucario’s Vacuum Wave or Bullet Punch gives additional priority to finish off faster threats that Haxorus chips.</OUTPUT>

input:
Create the 'weaknesses_and_counters' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Haxorus": {"Abilities": {"moldbreaker": 0.5271629229857953, "rivalry": 0.0012851218363860162, "unnerve": 0.009064136451383875}, "Items": {"loadeddice": 0.16381327251813815, "clearamulet": 0.3618449974393585, "choicescarf": 0.19718077570790818}, "Spreads": {"Adamant:4/252/0/0/0/252": 0.1825638881542161, "Jolly:4/252/0/0/0/252": 0.3396348441173476}, "Moves": ["protect", "firstimpression", "dragonclaw", "earthquake"], "Tera Types": {"steel": 0.427226206908417, "ground": 0.34344597742203026}, "Teammates": ["Incineroar", "Gholdengo", "Ceruledge", "Lucario", "Ninetales-Alola", "Masquerain"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Fairy-types remain the most reliable answers: Choice Specs Sylveon, Iron Valiant, and Flutter Mane all OHKO with Moonblast or Dazzling Gleam while resisting Dragon Claw. Bulky Steel-types such as Corviknight or Skarmory can Roost-stall or phaze Haxorus, though they must watch for Tera-Ground Earthquake. Priority is another universal answer; Bisharp, Kingambit, and Dragonite’s Extreme Speed all pick off Haxorus after minimal chip. Speed control in the form of Tailwind or Trick Room flips the matchup entirely, letting slower threats like Iron Treads or Garchomp move first and KO with super-effective Earthquake or Iron Head. Finally, Intimidate cycling combined with Protect stalling can reduce Haxorus’s damage output to manageable levels if it lacks Clear Amulet, letting physically bulky pivots such as Rotom-W or Dondozo wear it down.</OUTPUT>

Produce the 'sample_team_concept' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Haxorus": {"Abilities": {"moldbreaker": 0.5271629229857953, "rivalry": 0.0012851218363860162, "unnerve": 0.009064136451383875}, "Items": {"loadeddice": 0.16381327251813815, "clearamulet": 0.3618449974393585, "choicescarf": 0.19718077570790818}, "Spreads": {"Adamant:4/252/0/0/0/252": 0.1825638881542161, "Jolly:4/252/0/0/0/252": 0.3396348441173476}, "Moves": ["protect", "firstimpression", "dragonclaw", "earthquake"], "Tera Types": {"steel": 0.427226206908417, "ground": 0.34344597742203026}, "Teammates": ["Incineroar", "Gholdengo", "Ceruledge", "Lucario", "Ninetales-Alola", "Masquerain"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>A balanced offensive core of Incineroar / Haxorus / Gholdengo / Alolan Ninetales / Ceruledge / Rotom-Wash. Incineroar provides Fake Out and Parting Shot to give Haxorus safe entry, while Haxorus removes Gholdengo and Heatran for its ghostly teammates. Alolan Ninetales sets Aurora Veil to compensate for Haxorus’s frailty and provides Snow chip against bulky Waters. Gholdengo pressures Fairy-types and spins hazards, while Ceruledge cleans late-game once Steels are gone. Rotom-Wash rounds out the FWG core with Incineroar and Ceruledge, offering Volt Switch and Will-o-Wisp to cripple physical threats that might otherwise overwhelm Haxorus. The team compresses speed control, Mold Breaker utility, and multiple win conditions into a cohesive offensive structure that abuses Haxorus’s unique ability to ignore defensive abilities.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Cloyster": {"Abilities": {"skilllink": 0.49663058660408677, "overcoat": 0.06944729589071874, "shellarmor": 6.149281901857151e-05}, "Items": {"kingsrock": 0.2527646857456783, "whiteherb": 0.46106423062770135, "focussash": 0.1526228906018312}, "Spreads": {"Adamant:0/252/0/0/4/252": 0.2837797441763533, "Careful:252/0/0/0/252/4": 0.25168887315973665}, "Moves": ["iciclespear", "protect", "rockblast", "shellsmash"], "Tera Types": {"grass": 0.22208056238944263, "water": 0.6218116406209742}, "Teammates": ["Dragapult", "Rillaboom", "Incineroar", "Annihilape", "Porygon-Z", "Hydreigon"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Cloyster is a niche but explosive setup sweeper in VGC 2024 Regulation G, leveraging Skill Link multi-hit moves and Shell Smash to turn into an immediate win condition after a single turn of setup. Its 180 base Defense and solid offensive typing let it survive a surprising number of physical hits, while White Herb patches the Defense drop from Shell Smash and King’s Rock gives the 41% combined flinch chance on Icicle Spear + Rock Blast. Tera Water is the most common choice, patching the Fire and Rock weaknesses while boosting STAB Icicle Spear to terrifying levels, but Tera Grass is also popular to flip the Electric and Grass matchups and remove the Water-type vulnerability to opposing Grass moves. The two main spreads show a clear fork in builds: Adamant max Speed for the fastest possible sweep, and Careful bulk for surviving special hits and setting up in front of Pokémon like Raging Bolt or Iron Moth.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Cloyster dominates physical attackers that cannot break its titanic Defense—Great Tusk, Kingambit, Chien-Pao, and non-Band Dragonite all fail to OHKO and are KOed back by +2 Icicle Spear. It pressures common bulky Waters such as Toxapex, Rotom-Wash, and Dondozo, which are 2HKOed by unboosted Icicle Spear and OHKOed after Shell Smash. Against Grass types it must decide whether to stay Ice (risking Leaf Storm or Wood Hammer) or Terastalise into Grass, but either way it forces them out. Priority users—especially Basculegion Aqua Jet, Kingambit Sucker Punch, and Rillaboom Grassy Glide—can pick off a chipped Cloyster, but White Herb variants survive most unboosted priorities and KO back. Finally, Tailwind and Trick Room both change the speed dynamic: under Tailwind Cloyster still outspeeds everything, but under Trick Room it becomes one of the slowest threats and can sweep even when paralysed.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Cloyster is a dedicated setup sweeper that occupies the third or fourth slot on offensive teams looking for a fast, self-boosting win condition that does not require Dynamax. output: <OUTPUT>Cloyster loves partners that can eliminate or weaken special attackers and priority users before it sets up. Dragapult provides a fast Will-o-Wisp to neuter physical breakers and can bait Thunderbolt or Shadow Ball for a safe Cloyster entry. Rillaboom’s Grassy Glide removes opposing Waters and provides passive recovery that offsets Life Orb or hazard chip. Incineroar offers Fake Out, Intimidate, and Parting Shot, creating the ideal Shell Smash window while also handling opposing Fire types. Annihilape can tank special hits, spread bulk with Bulk Up, and remove Ghosts that are immune to Rapid Spin and that resist Icicle Spear. Porygon-Z gives a special attacking counterpart that draws Fighting and Steel moves for Cloyster to switch in on, while Hydreigon covers the Ghost and Psychic matchups and can U-turn into Cloyster safely. Tera synergy is equally important: Tera Water Clooster fits seamlessly onto Rain archetypes alongside Pelipper and Barraskewda, while Tera Grass Cloyster slots into Sun or Grass-spam teams that already carry Tera Fire answers such as Heatran or Tornadus.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Cloyster": {"Abilities": {"skilllink": 0.49663058660408677, "overcoat": 0.06944729589071874, "shellarmor": 6.149281901857151e-05}, "Items": {"kingsrock": 0.2527646857456783, "whiteherb": 0.46106423062770135, "focussash": 0.1526228906018312}, "Spreads": {"Adamant:0/252/0/0/4/252": 0.2837797441763533, "Careful:252/0/0/0/252/4": 0.25168887315973665}, "Moves": ["iciclespear", "protect", "rockblast", "shellsmash"], "Tera Types": {"grass": 0.22208056238944263, "water": 0.6218116406209742}, "Teammates": ["Dragapult", "Rillaboom", "Incineroar", "Annihilape", "Porygon-Z", "Hydreigon"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Cloyster’s sweep is stopped cold by any special attacker that can survive a hit and KO back: Iron Moth, Iron Bundle, Chi-Yu, Walking Wake, and Tera Fire Gholdengo all outspeed and OHKO before setup, and survive a +2 hit if they hold Focus Sash. Priority is the next biggest issue—Basculegion Aqua Jet, Kingambit Sucker Punch, and Chien-Pao Ice Shard all do massive damage to un-Terastallised Cloyster, and King’s Rock variants can still lose to a lucky Sucker Punch roll. Fake Out users such as Meowscarada, Iron Hands, and Indeedee deny the Shell Smash turn and force awkward Protects, while faster Taunt users like Murkrow or Tornadus prevent the boost entirely. Status—especially paralysis from Thunder Wave or Nuzzle—cripples Cloyster even after it sets up, because it no longer outspeeds threats and can be revenged by slower Scarfers. Finally, bulky resists that can live a +2 hit and retaliate, such as Tera Steel Corviknight, Tera Water Garganacl, or Assault Vest Slowking-Galar, can stall out the White Herb and KO with Body Press or Future Sight. The simplest counterplay is to preserve a special attacker or priority user and never give Cloyster a free turn; if it cannot Shell Smash safely, it is usually dead weight.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Cloyster fits best on a fast-paced offensive core that removes special attackers and sets Tailwind or screens. A proven six is: Pelipper (Rain setter, Tailwind, Wide Guard) + Barraskewda (Swift Swim, Life Orb, Close Combat) + Cloyster (White Herb, Tera Water) + Kingambit (Sucker Punch, Stealth Rock) + Hydreigon (U-turn, Tera Fairy) + Grimmsnarl (Light Screen, Reflect, Spirit Break). Pelipper’s Rain halves Fire damage for Cloyster, while Barraskewda lures Grass and Electric moves that Cloyster can switch in on. Kingambit handles opposing Ice and Psychic types and provides priority to finish off chipped threats after Cloyster softens them. Hydreigon pivots into special attackers and U-turns into Cloyster on predicted switches, and Grimmsnarl sets dual screens so Cloyster can survive a special hit and set up. The team pressures both sides of the speed spectrum: under Rain and Tailwind everything outspeeds, while outside of weather Cloyster can still sweep if screens are up. The core weakness to Iron Moth is covered by Kingambit Sucker Punch and Hydreigon Draco Meteor, and the team carries enough offensive pressure that opponents rarely have the luxury of preserving a perfect Cloyster counter.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Zebstrika is a niche but explosive offensive pivot in Regulation D formats, leveraging its blazing 116 base Speed tier and surprisingly high usage of Sap Sipper (≈42 %) to punish Grassy Glide, Pollen Puff, and other Grass-type utility while firing off 120 BP STAB Wild Charge or coverage Low Kick. Two item camps have emerged: Covert Cloak variants (≈30 %) ignore fake-out flinches and static discharge, whereas Clear Amulet (≈67 %) blocks Intimidate and Parting Shot, letting Zebstrika keep its Attack intact and sweep late-game. Teams pair it with Hippowdon for sand chip and slow pivoting, Grafaiai and Pyroar as speed-control partners that appreciate Grass-type pressure, Raichu for Lightning Rod synergy, and Empoleon/Farigiraf as special breakers that bait Electric-type moves for Sap Sipper boosts or Motor Drive/Lightning Rod procs. Tera Water is the dominant choice (≈67 %) to flip the Ground weakness and survive Landorus or Garchomp Earthquakes, while Tera Electric boosts Wild Charge to nuclear levels against bulky Waters. Adamant 252/252 sets hit as hard as possible, but Timid 252/252 guarantees it outruns Flutter Mane, Chien-Pao, and opposing base-110s. Protect + Substitute lets it scout choice-locked opponents and dodge Sucker Punch, though recoil and frailty mean it needs careful positioning to avoid being traded out.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Zebstrika": {"Abilities": {"lightningrod": 0.19257465793024525, "motordrive": 0.0006395847469566895, "sapsipper": 0.419285420409355}, "Items": {"covertcloak": 0.3048104504966063, "clearamulet": 0.6754652189330742}, "Spreads": {"Timid:4/0/0/252/0/252": 0.30403082070591764, "Adamant:0/252/0/0/0/252": 0.6682500254340598}, "Moves": ["protect", "lowkick", "wildcharge", "substitute"], "Tera Types": {"electric": 0.3046637283750596, "water": 0.6697037209227186}, "Teammates": ["Hippowdon", "Grafaiai", "Raichu", "Farigiraf", "Pyroar", "Empoleon"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Zebstrika’s stat-line screams glass cannon: 116 Speed outpaces the crowded 110-115 tier, yet 80/63/63 bulk and middling 100 Attack demand that it hit first and hit hard. Sap Sipper is the star ability, flipping the script on Amoonguss, Brute Bonnet, and Rillaboom while turning their utility into a +1 Attack sweep; Lightning Rod and Motor Drive appear in smaller fractions but still bait Electric-type chip or Volt Switch momentum. Itemization splits between Covert Cloak—blanking Static, Nuzzle, and Fake Out flinches—and Clear Amulet, which nullifies Intimidate, Parting Shot, and the omnipresent Incineroar cycle. Moves are minimalistic: Wild Charge is mandatory STAB capable of OHKOing Pelipper and 2HKOing bulky Rotom-W after chip; Low Kick nails Heatran, Tyranitar, and Kingambit for super-effective damage; Protect buys positioning turns and blocks Fake Out; Substitute punishes predictable Protects or status attempts. EV spreads follow a binary: Adamant maximizes damage while still outpacing positive-nature base-100s, whereas Timid guarantees the jump on Flutter Mane, Chien-Pao, and opposing scarf Lando-T. Tera Water flips the Ground weakness and provides crucial neutralities to Ice Shard and Aqua Jet, while Tera Electric strengthens Wild Charge and removes recoil via Terastalization mechanics. The horse’s biggest flaw is its inability to break common physical walls like Corviknight, Dondozo, or Great Tusk without prior chip, and its vulnerability to priority from Bisharp, Kingambit, and Dragonite. Nonetheless, when supported by slow pivot Hippowdon or Raichu redirection, Zebstrika can clean games faster than most opponents expect.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Zebstrika": {"Abilities": {"lightningrod": 0.19257465793024525, "motordrive": 0.0006395847469566895, "sapsipper": 0.419285420409355}, "Items": {"covertcloak": 0.3048104504966063, "clearamulet": 0.6754652189330742}, "Spreads": {"Timid:4/0/0/252/0/252": 0.30403082070591764, "Adamant:0/252/0/0/0/252": 0.6682500254340598}, "Moves": ["protect", "lowkick", "wildcharge", "substitute"], "Tera Types": {"electric": 0.3046637283750596, "water": 0.6697037209227186}, "Teammates": ["Hippowdon", "Grafaiai", "Raichu", "Farigiraf", "Pyroar", "Empoleon"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Against Grass-type cores—Rillaboom/Amoonguss/Brute Bonnet—Zebstrika is a hard counter: Sap Sipper absorbs Glide, Spore, and Pollen Puff, turning would-be threats into set-up fodder. Electric mirrors are equally favorable; Raichu and opposing Zebstrika trigger Lightning Rod or Motor Drive, gifting free Attack or Speed boosts while denying Volt Switch momentum. Water-types like Pelipper, Toxapex, and Slowbro fear Wild Charge, especially after Tera Electric, though they can retaliate with Scald burns or Rocky Helmet recoil. Ground-type titans Garchomp, Landorus-T, and Great Tusk traditionally wall Zebstrika, but Tera Water variants flip the matchup, surviving Earthquake and retaliating with Ice-type partner coverage or simply Substitute-protecting for chip. Dragon-types such as Dragapult and Dragonite lose the speed tie to Timid Zebstrika and risk being KOed by Wild Charge after chip; however, Extreme Speed Dragonite can still finish a weakened horse. Steel-types present mixed results: Low Kick 2HKOs Heatran and Magnezone, but Corviknight and Dondozo shrug off everything and phaze or stall with Roost. Priority users—Bisharp, Kingambit, Dragonite, and Breloom—exploit Zebstrika’s frailty, so partners must provide Intimidate, Reflect, or speed control to mitigate. Finally, status spreaders like Sableye and Grimmsnarl can burn or paralyze, yet Covert Cloak variants ignore both Thunder Wave and Will-O-Wisp, preserving offensive pressure.</OUTPUT>
