<DATA>{"Zebstrika": {"Abilities": {"lightningrod": 0.19257465793024525, "motordrive": 0.0006395847469566895, "sapsipper": 0.419285420409355}, "Items": {"covertcloak": 0.3048104504966063, "clearamulet": 0.6754652189330742}, "Spreads": {"Timid:4/0/0/252/0/252": 0.30403082070591764, "Adamant:0/252/0/0/0/252": 0.6682500254340598}, "Moves": ["protect", "lowkick", "wildcharge", "substitute"], "Tera Types": {"electric": 0.3046637283750596, "water": 0.6697037209227186}, "Teammates": ["Hippowdon", "Grafaiai", "Raichu", "Farigiraf", "Pyroar", "Empoleon"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Zebstrika functions as a high-speed, high-risk wallbreaker and late-game cleaner that punishes Grass-type utility and Electric-type spam while flipping defensive expectations through Terastallization. With Sap Sipper it assumes the role of anti-Grass pivot, turning Rillaboom’s Grassy Glide into a +1 Attack boost that immediately threatens opposing backlines. Clear Amulet variants act as an anti-Intimidate attacker, keeping full offensive potency against Incineroar, Landorus-T, and Parting Shot cycles, thereby enabling it to maintain pressure throughout a match. Covert Cloak sets pivot into predicted Fake Out or Nuzzle, scout turn one safely with Protect, and fire off powerful Wild Charges without fear of static paralysis. Substitute + Protect lets it stall Dynamon and Tera turns, dodge Sucker Punch, and punish passive play. Timid spreads focus on outspeeding the metagame’s fastest threats—Flutter Mane, Chien-Pao, and scarf Lando-T—while Adamant spreads maximize damage rolls against bulkier neutral targets like Rotom-W and Toxapex. Tera Water is primarily defensive, removing the quad Ground weakness and granting crucial neutralities to Aqua Jet and Ice Shard, whereas Tera Electric is purely offensive, boosting Wild Charge to nuke Waters and removing recoil. In sum, Zebstrika is a momentum grabber that compresses speed control, Grass-type immunity, and Electric-type offense into one slot, demanding precise positioning but rewarding aggressive piloting.</OUTPUT>

Timid Speed Control: 252 SpA / 4 SpD / 252 Spe Timid Sap Sipper with the same moves but Tera Electric to boost Wild Charge and remove recoil; outspeeds +1 Chien-Pao and scarf Lando-T. Covert Cloak Pivot: 252 HP / 252 Atk / 4 Def Adamant Sap Sipper, Covert Cloak, Tera Water, Wild Charge / Low Kick / Protect / Substitute—bulkier spread to survive Nuzzle or Discharge and ignore static paralysis, useful against Rotom-W and Zapdos. Motor Drive Cleaner: 252 Atk / 4 Def / 252 Spe Jolly Motor Drive, Clear Amulet, Tera Electric, Wild Charge / Low Kick / Protect / Substitute—sacrifices Grass immunity for Speed boosts versus Tapu Koko or opposing Zebstrika, turning it into a terrifying late-game sweeper. Each variant should be paired with slow pivot Hippowdon or Raichu to guarantee safe entry and maximize Sap Sipper or Motor Drive triggers.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Zebstrika": {"Abilities": {"lightningrod": 0.19257465793024525, "motordrive": 0.0006395847469566895, "sapsipper": 0.419285420409355}, "Items": {"covertcloak": 0.3048104504966063, "clearamulet": 0.6754652189330742}, "Spreads": {"Timid:4/0/0/252/0/252": 0.30403082070591764, "Adamant:0/252/0/0/0/252": 0.6682500254340598}, "Moves": ["protect", "lowkick", "wildcharge", "substitute"], "Tera Types": {"electric": 0.3046637283750596, "water": 0.6697037209227186}, "Teammates": ["Hippowdon", "Grafaiai", "Raichu", "Farigiraf", "Pyroar", "Empoleon"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Priority is the most reliable answer: Bisharp’s Sucker Punch, Kingambit’s Sucker Punch, and Dragonite’s Extreme Speed all KO Zebstrika after minimal chip. Faster scarfers such as Garchomp, Landorus-T, and Meowscarada outspeed non-scarf variants and OHKO with Earthquake or Flower Trick. Bulky Ground-types that carry Rocky Helmet—Great Tusk, Garchomp, and Landorus-T—punish Wild Charge recoil and contact damage, forcing Zebstrika to Tera Water early or risk being worn down. Dondozo and Corviknight completely wall non-Tera Electric sets and can stall with Rest, Roost, or Whirlwind; they must be lured by Low Kick chip or special breaker partners. Status spreaders that bypass Covert Cloak—Toxic from Toxapex or Gliscor, burn from Sableye or Rotom-W—cripple Zebstrika’s longevity, though Clear Amulet variants still fear burn damage. Finally, prediction wars against Protect or Substitute can leave Zebstrika overcommitted; players who telegraph Wild Charge into Protect will lose momentum and take unnecessary recoil. To counter, bring priority, bulky Grounds, or status, and force early Tera usage to deny its defensive pivoting potential.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Zebstrika": {"Abilities": {"lightningrod": 0.19257465793024525, "motordrive": 0.0006395847469566895, "sapsipper": 0.419285420409355}, "Items": {"covertcloak": 0.3048104504966063, "clearamulet": 0.6754652189330742}, "Spreads": {"Timid:4/0/0/252/0/252": 0.30403082070591764, "Adamant:0/252/0/0/0/252": 0.6682500254340598}, "Moves": ["protect", "lowkick", "wildcharge", "substitute"], "Tera Types": {"electric": 0.3046637283750596, "water": 0.6697037209227186}, "Teammates": ["Hippowdon", "Grafaiai", "Raichu", "Farigiraf", "Pyroar", "Empoleon"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Hippowdon @ Smooth Rock | Sand Stream | Stealth Rock / Slack Off / Yawn / Earthquake—slow pivot and chip setter that drags foes into Wild Charge range. Zebstrika @ Clear Amulet | Sap Sipper | Wild Charge / Low Kick / Protect / Substitute | Adamant 252/252, Tera Water—core breaker that punishes Grass and Electric spam. Raichu @ Focus Sash | Lightning Rod | Fake Out / Volt Switch / Nuzzle / Encore—redirects Electric moves for boosts and provides speed control. Grafaiai @ Black Sludge | Unburden | Toxic Spikes / Parting Shot / Knock Off / Gunk Shot—softens teams and Parting Shot cycles to keep Zebstrika safe. Pyroar @ Choice Specs | Unnerve | Hyper Voice / Flamethrower / Tera Blast Water / Will-O-Wisp—special breaker that benefits from Grass pressure and removes Substitutes. Farigraff @ Leftovers | Armor Tail | Psychic / Hyper Voice / Protect / Trick Room—blocks priority and Fake Out while offering Trick Room reversal. The team operates as a balanced offense that leverages ability-based immunities to flip momentum: Sap Sipper, Lightning Rod, and Water Absorb punish common offensive types, while Terastallization patches defensive holes. Lead Hippowdon sets sand and Stealth Rock, pivots into Raichu or Zebstrika to absorb attacks and accumulate boosts, then cleans with speed control or Substitute stalling. The core is weak to strong priority and bulky setup sweepers, so play aggressively early to deny Dragonite or Kingambit setup, and preserve Tera Water for the Ground-type emergency.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Palossand’s base 100 Special Attack is merely decent, but its dual STABs hit the metagame for excellent coverage: Shadow Ball pressures Indeedee, Armarouge, and opposing Ghosts, while Earth Power nails Gholdengo, Kingambit, and the omnipresent Tera Steel targets. The 252 HP / 156 SpA / 100 SpD Quiet spread guarantees the OHKO on 252 HP Gholdengo with Earth Power after Weakness Policy, while the bulkier 252 HP / 252 SpD variant survives Choice Specs Tatsugiri Muddy Water and +1 Hydreigon Draco Meteor, ensuring policy activation. Once activated, Palossand’s Special Attack effectively doubles, turning modest uninvested Shadow Balls into 2HKOs on max-invested support Grimmsnarl and bulky Toxapex. Shore Up is mandatory for longevity, recovering 66 % in sand and 50 % outside it, letting Palossand repeatedly switch in and trade. Giga Drain rounds the coverage by punishing bulky Water-types like Dondozo and Gastrodon that otherwise wall its STABs. The ability split shows Water Compaction (≈51 %) is preferred over Sand Veil; the Defense jump after any Water hit makes Palossand almost physically unbreakable and further deters Aqua Step or Jet users from attempting to snipe it. Tera Grass removes the Water weakness entirely and turns Giga Drain into a spammable recovery option, while Tera Rock grants a crucial resistance to Flying and Bug, letting Palossand survive Brave Bird from offensive Flamigo or Tera Flying Dragonite and retaliate with Rock Slide or Earth Power. The presence of Tyranitar as a top teammate indicates sand cores are still viable; Tyranitar sets sand, chips with Rock Slide, and deters special attackers with Assault Vest sets, while Palossand covers Fighting-type weaknesses and absorbs Knock Off for the team. Smeargle provides Fake Out and Silk Trap support, ensuring Trick Room goes up, and can pivot into Palossand with Follow Me to guarantee a Weakness Policy trigger. Flamigo offers Tailwind removal via Court Change and a secondary Fighting resist, whereas Gholdengo blocks opposing hazards and spreads status, creating a hazard-stacking core with Palossand’s Shore Up stalling.</OUTPUT>

It checks Indeedee–Armarouge Trick Room mirrors by ignoring Follow Me and threatening both with super-effective moves. Against rain teams, Palossand must be played cautiously: Water Compaction variants can turn the tables on Pelipper and Barraskewda, but a mispredicted Tera Water or Choice Specs Hydro Pump from Pelipper still cleanly OHKOes non-Tera Grass sets. Sun teams featuring Torkoal and Lilligant outspeed under sun and can 2HKO with Leaf Storm or Tera Grass Giga Drain, so Palossand relies on Tyranitar’s sand reset or Flamigo’s Tailwind removal to regain tempo. Dragon-type cores led by Hydreigon or Roaring Moon dislike Earth Power but can overwhelm with Draco Meteor or Tera Flying Acrobatics before Palossand moves; hence, speed control or Follow Me support is mandatory. Opposing Ghost-types like Aegislash and bulky Spiritomb can stall with King’s Shield and Pressure, but Palossand’s ability to recover and gradually boost through Weakness Policy means it usually wins the long game unless burned or taunted.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Raichu-Alola": {"Abilities": {"surgesurfer": 0.4919424471578393}, "Items": {"focussash": 0.25595872629107136, "lifeorb": 0.5710771559972512}, "Spreads": {"Modest:4/0/0/252/0/252": 0.1743206632055195, "Hasty:0/4/0/252/0/252": 0.31397838402505696}, "Moves": ["psychic", "fakeout", "voltswitch", "expandingforce"], "Tera Types": {"electric": 0.8164121323906013}, "Teammates": ["Pincurchin", "Toxtricity", "Ursaluna", "Armarouge", "Hitmontop", "Oranguru"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Alolan Raichu’s unique niche in VGC 2025 lies in the combination of Surge Surfer and Expanding Force, turning it into a 160 base-power spread Psychic attacker that outruns almost the entire unboosted metagame under Electric Terrain. The terrain boost also strengthens its own Electric STAB, letting it muscle past bulky waters and Flying types with ease. Focus Sash variants guarantee at least one attack or support move, making Raichu a reliable Fake Out user and lead option, while Life Orb variants trade safety for immediate wall-breaking power. The choice of Modest versus Hasty natures reflects a trade-off between maximizing damage rolls on bulky threats like Ting-Lu and Ursaluna versus outspeeding opposing Scarfers and other Surge Surfers outside of terrain. Its movepool is sparse, but the combination of Fake Out pressure, Volt Switch momentum, and terrain-boosted STABs is enough to justify a slot on full-field control archetypes. Tera Electric not only amplifies Volt Switch and Thunderbolt damage, but also removes the Ground weakness, letting Raichu serve as a late-game cleaner once Quake users are eliminated. The mouse’s natural special attack stat of 95 is middling, but terrain, STAB, and item boosts patch the gap, allowing it to 2HKO even invested neutral targets. Its weaknesses are primarily physical—paltry 60/70/85 bulk and a mediocre defensive typing leave it vulnerable to priority and strong neutral hits—so partners must provide redirection, intimidate, or speed control to keep it alive.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Raichu-Alola": {"Abilities": {"surgesurfer": 0.4919424471578393}, "Items": {"focussash": 0.25595872629107136, "lifeorb": 0.5710771559972512}, "Spreads": {"Modest:4/0/0/252/0/252": 0.1743206632055195, "Hasty:0/4/0/252/0/252": 0.31397838402505696}, "Moves": ["psychic", "fakeout", "voltswitch", "expandingforce"], "Tera Types": {"electric": 0.8164121323906013}, "Teammates": ["Pincurchin", "Toxtricity", "Ursaluna", "Armarouge", "Hitmontop", "Oranguru"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Under Electric Terrain Alolan Raichy becomes one of the fastest threats in the format, outspeeding +1 Roaring Moon and tying with Regieleki, giving it an immediate advantage against most offense teams. Spread Expanding Force applies immense centralizing pressure to opposing doubles, forcing Protects or Terastallization while racking up 40-50% on neutral bulk. Against bulkier cores, Raichu can pivot with Volt Switch to maintain momentum or chip with Fake Out, breaking Focus Sashes and Sturdy. Ground types such as Great Tusk, Garchomp, and Ting-Lu blank its STABs, but they risk eating a Tera Electric Volt Switch or being worn down by repeated chip. Priority users like Kingambit and Dragonite can bypass its Speed tier, though Sash variants can still trade or cripple back with Tera Electric Thunderbolt. Rain teams featuring Pelipper and Barraskewda can overwrite terrain and threaten with Aqua Jet, so Raichu must either be preserved for late-game or paired with its own weather setter. Psychic Terrain teams from Indeedee negate Fake Out and can tank Expanding Force, forcing Raichu to rely on single-target Psychic or Electric coverage. Overall, Raichu’s matchup spread is polarizing: it dominates when terrain is up and struggles when it is not, making terrain control the axis around which games pivot.</OUTPUT>

Its low usage and awkward stat line leave it outclassed by Incineroar and Grimmsnarl in most cores, but the combination of Encore, Knock Off, and a 160 BP STAB that ignores Follow Me makes it a pocket pick for teams that need to punish Trick Room or Tailwind setters without committing to a pure support slot.</OUTPUT>

input:
Write the 'full_analysis' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Tinkaton": {"Abilities": {"pickpocket": 0.13287923844725325, "owntempo": 3.2785142943983403, "moldbreaker": 16.74673933611415}, "Items": {"clearamulet": 0.1524903094487672, "mentalherb": 0.5555629853827444}, "Spreads": {"Jolly:132/124/0/0/0/252": 0.5782278351375751}, "Moves": ["fakeout", "gigatonhammer", "knockoff", "encore"], "Tera Types": {"water": 0.15333376558964038, "ghost": 0.7232526406957404}, "Teammates": ["Ursaluna", "Tyranitar", "Dragonite", "Gholdengo", "Cinderace", "Tauros-Paldea-Aqua"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Mold Breaker is the only ability that matters: it lets Gigaton Hammer ignore Follow Me, Encore ignore Aroma Veil, and Knock Off ignore Purifying Salt, turning Tinkaton into a scalpel against stall and redirection cores. The chosen Jolly 252 EV spread guarantees it outspeeds positive-nature base 90s such as Dragonite and Gholdengo while the 124 Atk EVs secure key damage rolls: 2HKO on 252 HP Gholdengo, 2HKO on 252 HP Indeedee-F, and 75 % min vs. 252 HP Ting-Lu. Gigaton Hammer’s 160 BP is the hardest single-target Fairy STAB in the format, but the recharge clause forces Tinkaton to switch or protect the following turn, so it is played as a hit-and-run breaker rather than a sustained sweeper. Encore is the centerpiece move: because Mold Breaker ignores Mental Herb, Tinkaton can lock opposing support Pokémon into Protect, Trick Room, or Tailwind and then pivot to a faster partner such as Cinderace or Tauros-Paldea-Aqua to capitalise. Fake Out provides the classic tempo lead, while Knock Off removes problematic items like Clear Amulet, Sitrus Berry, or Eviolite from Dusclops and Murkrow. The listed Tera types—Ghost and Water—are defensive answers: Tera Ghost dodges Fighting-type Fake Out and grants a Normal immunity, letting Tinkaton Encore or Gigaton Hammer against Ursaluna or Iron Hands, while Tera Water removes the Fire and Ground weaknesses and turns incoming Fire Blast or Earthquake into resisted hits. The 16 % Mold Breaker usage rate shows that players who do bring Tinkaton understand its job; the remainder run Own Tempo or Pickpocket, which are largely wasted slots. Overall Tinkaton is a high-skill, low-reward pick that fills a very specific anti-meta role rather than a staple.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Tinkaton": {"Abilities": {"pickpocket": 0.13287923844725325, "owntempo": 3.2785142943983403, "moldbreaker": 16.74673933611415}, "Items": {"clearamulet": 0.1524903094487672, "mentalherb": 0.5555629853827444}, "Spreads": {"Jolly:132/124/0/0/0/252": 0.5782278351375751}, "Moves": ["fakeout", "gigatonhammer", "knockoff", "encore"], "Tera Types": {"water": 0.15333376558964038, "ghost": 0.7232526406957404}, "Teammates": ["Ursaluna", "Tyranitar", "Dragonite", "Gholdengo", "Cinderace", "Tauros-Paldea-Aqua"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Tinkaton loves to face slow set-up teams that rely on Follow Me, Aroma Veil, or Mental Herb—think Indeedee-F + Hatterene Trick Room, Ting-Lu + Grimmsnarl Tailwind, or Dondozo + Tatsugiri. Mold Breaker Encore instantly dismantles these cores by ignoring their protective abilities and locking them into non-attacking moves, after which a faster partner such as Choice Band Ursaluna or Dragonite can clean. Gigaton Hammer OHKOs most non-bulk Gholdengo spreads and 2HKOs even 252 HP variants, while Knock Off cripples Dusclops, Murkrow, and Armarouge. On the other hand, Tinkaton folds to any faster offensive threat: Iron Bundle, Chien-Pao, and Choice Scarf Gholdengo all OHKO with their respective STABs, and priority from Bisharp or Kingambit bypasses Tinkaton’s mediocre bulk. Fire-types such as Chi-Yu and Heatran force the Water Tera or an immediate switch, and opposing Incineroar not only tanks Gigaton Hammer but also Intimidates and U-turns out, leaving Tinkaton with no safe Encore target. Finally, because Tinkaton must recharge after Gigaton Hammer, opposing Protect users can stall the turn and punish with double-target plays.</OUTPUT>

It does not attempt to stick around; its job is to break a hole, remove an item, or lock an opponent into an unfavourable move, then yield the slot to bulkier win conditions such as Ursaluna or Dragonite. The Jolly nature and 252 Speed ensure it outpaces the crowded base 90 tier, while Mold Breaker gives it unique utility that no other Fairy or Steel type in the format replicates. Think of Tinkaton as a one-time hammer that must be used precisely—if the Encore target or Hammer KO does not swing the game immediately, its low bulk and recharge turn become major liabilities.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Tinkaton’s counters are anything faster that can OHKO or anything bulky that doesn’t care about Encore. Priority users such as Bisharp, Kingambit, and Dragonite with Extreme Speed bypass Tinkaton’s speed tier and dent it even after Tera Ghost. Incineroar is the single hardest counter: Intimidate drops Hammer damage to 3HKO range, it resists both STABs, and can U-turn out of Encore or threaten a KO with Flare Blitz. Fire-types in general—Chi-Yu, Heatran, and Torkoal—force the Tera or a switch, and if Tinkaton has already revealed Tera Water it becomes setup fodder for Gholdengo or Kingambit. Finally, because Gigaton Hammer forces a recharge, double Protect stalling or redirection from Amoonguss can waste Tinkaton’s offensive turn and leave it vulnerable to a double target KO.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Espathra is a hyper-offensive, Speed-Boosting Psychic sweeper that dominates mid- to late-game with Stored Power-style pressure, but in VGC it forgoes set-up to immediately rip holes with Expanding Force under Psychic Terrain. output: <OUTPUT>Espathra’s niche in VGC 2024 is defined by Speed Boost turning it into a win-condition in three turns or less. Because Protect is mandatory, every game becomes a calculation of whether Espathra can Protect twice, net two Speed boosts, and then sweep. The 43 % Life Orb rate trades bulk for power, guaranteeing OHKOs on standard Kingambit and Ogerpon-W after one round of chip while still surviving a non-boosted Dark-type attack from full. The 53 % Focus Sash rate instead forgives mis-predictions versus faster attackers such as Chien-Pao or opposing Flutter Mane, letting Espathra survive a double-target and retaliate at +1 Speed. Tera Psychic is the default, turning Expanding Force into a 120 BP spread move that cleanly 2HKOs most neutral targets and OHKOs frail resists after Stealth Rock-style chip from allies such as Stealth Rock Archaludon or Sneasler’s Ceaseless Edge. Tera Fairy is the second choice, flipping the script on Dark- and Dragon-types that assume a safe switch-in, while also granting an immunity to Dragon moves that lets Espathra set up on a predicted Roar or Scale Shot. Lumina Crash is the coverage star: a –2 SpD drop on the target means the follow-up Expanding Force is effectively a 180 BP neutral hit, allowing Espathra to muscle past special walls such as Ting-Lu or Umbreon. Dazzling Gleam is obligatory spread Fairy coverage that punishes Kingambit, Chien-Pao, and opposing Espathra mirrors. Protect is non-negotiable for Speed Boost accumulation and for baiting opposing Dynamax or Tera.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Into offense, Espathra is a coin-flip: it either Protects twice and outspeeds the entire board, or it eats a double-up and dies. Against Tailwind or priority teams it prefers Focus Sash so it can live a First Impression from Lokix or a Brave Bird from Gale Wings Talonflame and fire back. Into bulkier balance cores, Life Orb is king because the extra 30 % damage turns 2HKOs into OHKOs on Toxapex, Rotom-W, and Clodsire. Dark-type match-ups are paradoxically favourable: Lumina Crash drops their SpD, and Tera Fairy removes their STAB, so even Kingambit that carry Sucker Punch are forced to Tera themselves or risk a roll. Ghost-types such as Aegislash and Basculegion are problematic because Shadow Ball OHKOs through Sash and ignores Speed boosts; therefore Espathra must either Tera Fairy pre-emptively or rely on Indeedee-F’s Follow Me. Steel-types like Corviknight and Gholdengo are neutral: Gholdengo blocks Expanding Force in Psychic Terrain but still takes 70–80 % from neutral Dazzling Gleam, while Corviknight risks a –2 Lumina Crash that puts it in range of ally Sneasler’s Close Combat.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>**Indeedee-F @ Psychic Seed** – Follow Me / Psychic / Helping Hand / Protect – partners with Espathra to guarantee terrain and a free Protect. **Sneasler @ Focus Sash** – Ceaseless Edge / Close Combat / Poison Jab / Protect – lays hazards and baits Fairy moves. **Kingambit @ Black Glasses** – Sucker Punch / Iron Head / Kowtow / Protect – provides slow pivot and priority control. **Archaludon @ Leftovers** – Stealth Rock / Volt Switch / Flash Cannon / Protect – sets rocks and slow-pivots into Espathra. **Basculegion @ Choice Band** – Shadow Sneak / Liquidation / Wave Crash / Protect – cleans late-game after Espathra dents the board. output: <OUTPUT>Bruxish is a niche Trick Room attacker in VGC Series 2 that abuses Psychic Fangs and priority Aqua Jet under Dazzling to break common redirection and priority strats. A Brave 140/116/0/0/252/0 spread with Focus Sash and Tera Grass lets it survive key hits, nuke Amoonguss/Tornadus, and flip the Rain matchup while outspeeding nothing under Trick Room. It demands Rillaboom support to remove Grassy Terrain and supply Fake Out, and it fits best on semi-room squads alongside slow powerhouses like Annihilape, Ursaluna and Torkoal.</OUTPUT>

input:
Write the 'full_analysis' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Bruxish": {"Abilities": {"dazzling": 20.097486231546842, "strongjaw": 0.010012671398135331, "wonderskin": 1.1522065251901026e-07}, "Items": {"focussash": 0.8602012636789137}, "Spreads": {"Brave:140/116/0/0/252/0": 0.8018437615965904}, "Moves": ["psychicfangs", "aquajet", "protect", "trickroom"], "Tera Types": {"grass": 0.8753145783048292}, "Teammates": ["Rillaboom", "Maushold", "Annihilape", "Dusclops", "Torkoal", "Ursaluna"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Bruxish’s base 115 Attack and 92 Speed are awkward outside Trick Room, but under room its STAB combination is nearly unresisted and Psychic Fangs’ ability to shatter screens and Aurora Veil gives it immediate utility. Dazzling blanks every prevalent priority move—Fake Out, Aqua Jet from opposing Barraskewda, Sucker Punch from Kingambit—letting it click moves without fear. Strong Jaw is theoretically stronger for Aqua Jet, but Dazzling’s anti-priority value is so high that 95 % of registered sets run it. Focus Sash guarantees it survives at least one super-effective hit so it can trade or set up Trick Room itself in a pinch. The chosen spread maximizes Attack while dumping the remainder into HP to round its bulk vs. Rillaboom’s Grassy Glide and Torkoal’s Eruption; 0 Speed IV ensures it underspeeds every relevant threat under room. Tera Grass removes the Electric weakness and turns 4× Grass damage into a resistance, letting Bruxish bait Rotom-Wash, Miraidon and Iron Hands while also taking negligible damage from Rillaboom’s Glide. Psychic Fangs is the spammable STAB that also removes screens and breaks Tera Poison Garganacl’s Salt Cure, Aqua Jet supplies crucial priority to finish weakened Dragapult or Charizard before they move, Protect is mandatory for double-target prediction and Focus Sash preservation, and Trick Room turns Bruxish into an emergency room setter if Dusclops or Indeedee are dead or taunted.</OUTPUT>

Write the 'matchup_overview' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Bruxish": {"Abilities": {"dazzling": 20.097486231546842, "strongjaw": 0.010012671398135331, "wonderskin": 1.1522065251901026e-07}, "Items": {"focussash": 0.8602012636789137}, "Spreads": {"Brave:140/116/0/0/252/0": 0.8018437615965904}, "Moves": ["psychicfangs", "aquajet", "protect", "trickroom"], "Tera Types": {"grass": 0.8753145783048292}, "Teammates": ["Rillaboom", "Maushold", "Annihilape", "Dusclops", "Torkoal", "Ursaluna"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Bruxish loves facing priority-reliant teams: it blanks Fake Out from Indeedee, Maushold, or Murkrow, and it laughs at Kingambit’s Sucker Punch, turning those matchups into 6-5s from turn one. It crushes Poison-centric cores—Tera Grass Psychic Fangs OHKOs Tera Poison Garganacl and deals ~70 % to Amoonguss through Tera, while outspeeding both under room. Against Rain it flips the script: Tera Grass resays Thunder from Pelipper and Iron Head from Barraskewda, and Aqua Jet picks up KOs on weakened Barraskewda or Tornadus after Rillaboom’s Glide. Sun is more even—Torkoal’s Eruption does ~55 % through Sash, so Bruxish needs Rillaboom to knock Torkoal into Jet range or Dusclops to burn it. It struggles vs. bulky Steel types: Corviknight and Gholdengo survive a +0 Psychic Fangs and retaliate with Iron Head or Make It Rain; Gholdengo also blocks Trick Room with Good as Gold. Dragonite with Tera Normal Extreme Speed bypasses Dazzling and KOes through Sash, so partners must eliminate or paralyze it first. Finally, opposing Indeedee-F with Follow Me + Dazzling Gleam can stall turns until room ends, so Bruxish appreciates its own Indeedee or Maushold for redirection.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Bruxish": {"Abilities": {"dazzling": 20.097486231546842, "strongjaw": 0.010012671398135331, "wonderskin": 1.1522065251901026e-07}, "Items": {"focussash": 0.8602012636789137}, "Spreads": {"Brave:140/116/0/0/252/0": 0.8018437615965904}, "Moves": ["psychicfangs", "aquajet", "protect", "trickroom"], "Tera Types": {"grass": 0.8753145783048292}, "Teammates": ["Rillaboom", "Maushold", "Annihilape", "Dusclops", "Torkoal", "Ursaluna"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Bruxish is a hybrid lead and mid-game cleaner on semi-Trick Room squads. In the lead slot it pairs with Rillaboom: Grassy Glide removes Focus Sash from opposing leads while Bruxish either fires off Psychic Fangs or sets Trick Room, depending on whether the opponent threatens a KO or a Taunt. Mid-game it switches in after a KO or via slow U-turn from Corviknight/Landorus, immediately threatening Psychic Fangs on support Pokémon or clicking Trick Room to reverse speed control if the opponent has gone for Tailwind or Max Airstream. Its priority Aqua Jet cleans up weakened Dynamax or Terastallized threats that otherwise outspeed your slow breakers. Because it carries its own room, Bruxish is never dead weight if the opponent denies your primary setter, giving the team flexibility to play either hyper-offensive or attrition styles in the same set.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Bruxish": {"Abilities": {"dazzling": 20.097486231546842, "strongjaw": 0.010012671398135331, "wonderskin": 1.1522065251901026e-07}, "Items": {"focussash": 0.8602012636789137}, "Spreads": {"Brave:140/116/0/0/252/0": 0.8018437615965904}, "Moves": ["psychicfangs", "aquajet", "protect", "trickroom"], "Tera Types": {"grass": 0.8753145783048292}, "Teammates": ["Rillaboom", "Maushold", "Annihilape", "Dusclops", "Torkoal", "Ursaluna"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Rillaboom is the single most important teammate: Grassy Terrain weakens opposing Earthquakes and Glides while supplying a strong priority move that softens targets for Bruxish’s Aqua Jet; Wood Hammer also KOes Gastrodon and Quagsire that wall Bruxish. Maushold provides Friend Guard and Follow Me, letting Bruxish fire off attacks or set room safely while also spreading damage via Population Bomb for end-game Jet clean-up. Annihilape and Ursaluna share the same Brave nature and 0 Speed, forming a terrifying slow trio that forces the opponent to guess which threat to target; both appreciate Psychic Fangs removing screens so their Drain Punch or Headlong Rush hit harder. Dusclops is the primary Trick Room setter, freeing Bruxish to run Protect and attack; Will-O-Wisp cripples Kingambit and Gholdengo that otherwise threaten Bruxish. Torkoal supplies sun-boosted Eruption to break bulky Waters and Steels, while Bruxish removes opposing sun checks like Tornadus and Gastrodon. Together these six create a balanced semi-room core with Fake Out, redirection, multiple speed control options, and mixed offensive coverage.</OUTPUT>

Corviknight survives two Psychic Fangs outside Dynamax and stalls with Roost + Iron Defense; Tera Fire Corviknight is an outright counter. Iron Bundle outspeeds and OHKOs with Freeze-Dry even through Tera Grass, so Bruxish needs Rillaboom Glide or Annihilape Vacuum Wave to remove it. Amoonguss with Clear Smog removes stat changes and can redirect with Follow Me, though it risks death from Tera Grass Psychic Fangs. Finally, opposing Trick Room teams that run faster room setters like Hatterene or Bronzong can reverse room and leave Bruxish outsped and KOed; in these matchups Bruxish should stay in the back and come in only after room is confirmed.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Kleavor is a fast, physical attacker that thrives in the current metagame by combining the new STAB Stone Axe with strong coverage and a 135 base Attack stat. With over 93% of players choosing either Choice Scarf or Focus Sash, it functions as either a revenge killer or a one-time setup breaker, while Sharpness boosts its slicing moves such as Stone Axe and X-Scissor to frightening levels. Tera Water grants a crucial resistance to Fire and neutrality to Rock, letting it survive common counters like Heatran or opposing Rock Slide users, while Tera Fighting gives a reliable boost to Close Combat and removes the Flying weakness. Its most common teammates—Dondozo/Tatsugiri, Incineroar, Gholdengo, Porygon2 and Dragonite—showcase its fit on balanced and rain-style squads that appreciate Kleavor’s ability to force switches, break Sashes, and stack residual damage.</OUTPUT>

input:

<DATA>{"Kleavor": {"Abilities": {"sharpness": 19.165120996355885, "sheerforce": 0.09285894805135497, "swarm": 0.0015306979389260733}, "Items": {"choicescarf": 0.24819314397944478, "focussash": 0.5426939525029637}, "Spreads": {"Adamant:4/252/0/0/0/252": 0.15768440753659418, "Jolly:4/252/0/0/0/252": 0.344857313273971}, "Moves": ["stoneaxe", "xscissor", "protect", "closecombat"], "Tera Types": {"water": 0.2999216348560555, "ghost": 0.22513900715773802, "fighting": 0.30918907557080794}, "Teammates": ["Dondozo", "Tatsugiri", "Incineroar", "Gholdengo", "Porygon2", "Dragonite"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Kleavor’s niche in VGC 2024 rests almost entirely on Stone Axe, a 65 BP Rock move that sets a stackable hazard on the target’s side of the field, chipping every switch-in for 1/8th of their HP. Because hazards remain in Doubles until cleared by Mortal Spin or Rapid Spin, Kleavor can single-handedly punish the ubiquitous pivoting of Incineroar, Gholdengo and Amoonguss while simultaneously chunking the opposing slot. Sharpness is the ability of choice on more than 94% of sets, raising Stone Axe, X-Scissor and, situationally, Dual Wingbeat to 97.5 BP, 120 BP and 90 BP respectively—numbers that let it OHKO frail support Pokémon such as Murkrow, Tornadus-I and even offensive Gholdengo after hazard damage. Choice Scarf variants (24.8%) outspeed the entire unboosted tier except Regieleki and Iron Bundle, turning Kleavor into a reliable late-game cleaner that can still bluff a Focus Sash because of the identical HP numbers. Focus Sash sets (54.3%) trade immediate speed for setup insurance, guaranteeing at least one layer of hazards and often drawing double-targets that free up its partner to set Trick Room, Rain or Dragon Dance. EV spreads are simple: 4 HP / 252 Atk / 252 Spe with either Adamant or Jolly nature; Jolly is the majority (34.5%) because it secures the speed tie against opposing base 105s such as Iron Valiant and ensures the Scarf set outruns +1 Dragonite. Tera Water is the most popular option (30%) because it flips the 4× Fire weakness into a resistance, letting Kleavor survive Heat Wave from Torkoal or Sun-boosted Eruption from Chi-Yu, while Tera Fighting (30.9%) is taken when the team already packs rain or wants a stronger Close Combat to muscle past Kingambit and Ting-Lu. Protect is mandatory in Doubles and appears on virtually every set, giving Kleavor a safe click against Fake Out or priority users and allowing it to preserve Sash or Scout Choice locks.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Kleavor": {"Abilities": {"sharpness": 19.165120996355885, "sheerforce": 0.09285894805135497, "swarm": 0.0015306979389260733}, "Items": {"choicescarf": 0.24819314397944478, "focussash": 0.5426939525029637}, "Spreads": {"Adamant:4/252/0/0/0/252": 0.15768440753659418, "Jolly:4/252/0/0/0/252": 0.344857313273971}, "Moves": ["stoneaxe", "xscissor", "protect", "closecombat"], "Tera Types": {"water": 0.2999216348560555, "ghost": 0.22513900715773802, "fighting": 0.30918907557080794}, "Teammates": ["Dondozo", "Tatsugiri", "Incineroar", "Gholdengo", "Porygon2", "Dragonite"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Kleavor dominates slower, hazard-weak cores that rely on incremental recovery—Sunroom, hard Trick Room and most balance builds appreciate the free damage. Against Sun it can Tera Water, survive Eruption, and OHKO Torkoal with Stone Axe while stacking hazards that punish the inevitable switch to Lilligant or Indeedee. Versus Rain it functions as an anti-meta pick: under Rain its Fire weakness is already reduced, while Stone Axe still dents Pelipper and rain sweepers such as Barraskewda hate hazard chip. Into Tailwind offense Kleavor’s 105 base speed and potential Scarf let it trade positively with Iron Valiant, Chien-Pao and Tornadus, and the hazard pressure forces opponents to clear with Mortal Spin, giving up momentum. Against hard Trick Room it can either double-up with its partner to KO the setter before Room goes up or simply stack hazards so that the incoming slow sweepers are in KO range of its teammates. The only archetype that reliably blanks Kleavor is hyper-Intimidate cores (double Incineroar or Incineroar/Landorus-T) paired with Rocky Helmet chip, as well as Iron Defense Gholdengo that can come in on Stone Axe, boost, and KO back with Make It Rain.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Kleavor is a hyper-offensive pivot that compresses three roles: hazard setter, speed control (via Scarf) and wall breaker. It is brought to games to guarantee residual damage on the entire enemy team, remove Focus Sashes from the likes of Amoonguss and Murkrow, and punch holes with 135 base Attack + Sharpness. Because Stone Axe is a single-target move, Kleavor fits best on teams that already spread damage through Rock Slide, Earthquake or Surf, turning chip into clean KOs. Its typing grants useful resistances to Normal and Bug, letting it switch into Ursaluna’s Fake Out + Headlong Rush combo or Kingambit’s Sucker Punch, then immediately threaten back with Close Combat. Tera expansion gives it the flexibility to act as a one-time tank, either removing a crippling weakness or boosting its own coverage, making it both a lead option and a mid-game breaker.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Kleavor’s most common teammate pairing is Dondozo + Tatsugiri (Commander core), which appreciates hazards breaking Sash on opposing Murkrow or Hatterene that could otherwise stop the Order Up sweep. Incineroar forms a classic pivot core: Intimidate and Parting Shot soften physical threats that outspeed Kleavor, while Kleavor punts Fire-types that trouble Incineroar. Gholdengo blocks Mortal Spin, ensuring hazards stay on the field, and can trade KOs with opposing Ghosts that Kleavor cannot break. Dragonite covers Kleavor’s Fighting weakness and can set Tailwind for Scarf Kleavor to outspeed even +1 Speed Roaring Moon. Rain setters such as Pelipper reduce the omnipresent Fire weakness, while Swift Swim Barraskewda or Floatzel stack physical pressure alongside hazard chip. Finally, Iron Hands is a natural partner under Electric Terrain, as Fake Out + Close Combat breaks Steels that wall Kleavor, while Kleavor removes Flying-types for Hands.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Oranguru carves a unique niche in VGC as a dedicated Trick Room setter and Instruct support, leveraging its combination of Inner Focus (or Telepathy) and Mental Herb to guarantee the first turn of Trick Room against Taunt users. With a spread that maximizes special bulk and a sliver of Speed investment, it sits comfortably below most threats under Trick Room, letting slower partners move first. Its move set—Instruct, Trick Room, Encore, and Psychic—prioritizes utility over damage, turning Ursaluna, Ursaluna-Bloodmoon, Torkoal, and Dragapult into double-action powerhouses while locking faster foes into undesirable moves with Encore. Tera Dark or Tera Fairy patches up its poor defensive typing, giving it a one-time buffer against Ghost or Dark attackers that would otherwise KO it before it can support its team.</OUTPUT>

input:
Write a detailed 'full_analysis' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Oranguru": {"Abilities": {"telepathy": 7.610817223109739, "innerfocus": 11.178625968581517, "symbiosis": 0.5784497026165301}, "Items": {"mentalherb": 0.6818996693019426}, "Spreads": {"Sassy:232/0/228/28/12/8": 0.19447699781710964}, "Moves": ["instruct", "trickroom", "encore", "psychic"], "Tera Types": {"dark": 0.22939389612435956, "fairy": 0.1731838559031213, "steel": 0.1853558995076463}, "Teammates": ["Ursaluna", "Dragapult", "Torkoal", "Ursaluna-Bloodmoon", "Indeedee-F", "Incineroar"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Oranguru’s 90/80/110 bulk is mediocre for a support Pokémon, but its 60 Speed tier is perfect for Trick Room, letting it underspeed all but the slowest titans. Inner Focus is the preferred ability on most teams, preventing flinches from Fake Out or Rock Slide that could stop an opening Trick Room; Telepathy sees niche use alongside Earthquake or Discharge partners, though such synergy is rare in current formats. Mental Herb is the only item worth considering, removing the threat of Taunt or Encore from opposing Whimsicott, Grimmsnarl, or Murkrow and ensuring at least one successful Trick Room. The chosen spread (Sassy 232/0/228/28/12/8) places 232 EVs in HP and 228 in Defense, letting it survive -1 Tera Dark Kingambit Iron Head or Choice Band Dragonite Extreme Speed, while the 28 Special Attack guarantees the OHKO on 4 HP Tera Poison Amoonguss with Psychic. The remaining EVs are split between Special Defense and a token 8 Speed to creep other minimal-speed supports. Instruct is the marquee move: once per turn it orders the target ally to repeat its previous move, effectively doubling the output of heavy hitters like Ursaluna or Torkoal without consuming a second turn. Encore punishes setup sweepers or Protect spam, locking them into a harmless move and buying free turns for the Trick Room sweepers. Psychic prevents Oranguru from being complete Taunt bait and snipes Amoonguss or Toxapex for chip. Tera Dark is the safest option, removing the Ghost weakness and granting immunity to Prankster Taunt, while Tera Fairy offers a Dragon immunity and better synergy against Dark-types; Tera Steel is a distant third, granting a Flash Fire-style resistance but leaving it weak to common Fire and Ground coverage.</OUTPUT>

input:

<DATA>{"Oranguru": {"Abilities": {"telepathy": 7.610817223109739, "innerfocus": 11.178625968581517, "symbiosis": 0.5784497026165301}, "Items": {"mentalherb": 0.6818996693019426}, "Spreads": {"Sassy:232/0/228/28/12/8": 0.19447699781710964}, "Moves": ["instruct", "trickroom", "encore", "psychic"], "Tera Types": {"dark": 0.22939389612435956, "fairy": 0.1731838559031213, "steel": 0.1853558995076463}, "Teammates": ["Ursaluna", "Dragapult", "Torkoal", "Ursaluna-Bloodmoon", "Indeedee-F", "Incineroar"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Against hyper-offense, Oranguru is a coin-flip: if it survives the opening double-target and sets Trick Room, the speed tiers flip and frail attackers crumble to boosted Ursaluna or Torkoal Eruptions. Inner Focus blocks Fake Out leads, but Tailwind variants can still race it if Oranguru’s partner cannot KO the Tailwind setter turn one. Into bulkier balance teams, Encore cripples common Protect + setup cores like Corviknight or Garganacl, while Instruct lets its own breakers overwhelm Toxapex or Dondozo. Against hard Trick Room mirrors, Oranguru is usually outclassed by Indeedee-F’s Follow Me and Psychic Terrain, but it can win the speed tie if it opts for a slower spread and uses Encore to lock the opposing setter into Trick Room. Rain and Sun both pressure it: Sun-boosted Heat Wave or Rain-boosted Hydro Steam can OHKO before it moves, so partners must provide Fake Out or Rage Powder to guarantee the room. Ghost-types such as Aegislash or Dragapult threaten STAB super-effective hits, though Tera Dark patches the weakness; conversely, Dark-types like Kingambit or Chien-Pao force Tera Fairy or Steel to avoid Sucker KO. Overall, Oranguru’s matchup spread hinges on whether it can trade one-for-one with the opposing lead and establish Trick Room; if it does, its win rate skyrockets.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Oranguru": {"Abilities": {"telepathy": 7.610817223109739, "innerfocus": 11.178625968581517, "symbiosis": 0.5784497026165301}, "Items": {"mentalherb": 0.6818996693019426}, "Spreads": {"Sassy:232/0/228/28/12/8": 0.19447699781710964}, "Moves": ["instruct", "trickroom", "encore", "psychic"], "Tera Types": {"dark": 0.22939389612435956, "fairy": 0.1731838559031213, "steel": 0.1853558995076463}, "Teammates": ["Ursaluna", "Dragapult", "Torkoal", "Ursaluna-Bloodmoon", "Indeedee-F", "Incineroar"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Oranguru is a pure support Pokémon that functions as a Trick Room initiator and force multiplier. Its job is to survive turn one, click Trick Room, and then spend the next four turns either Instructing a breaker for double damage or disrupting opponents with Encore. It does not attempt to sweep or wall; instead it acts as a catalyst that converts the team’s slow but powerful attackers into a tempo advantage. Because it carries Mental Herb, it can safely lead into Taunt users and still guarantee room, freeing the second slot for an offensive partner rather than a second support. Once Trick Room is active, it pivots into a pocket playmaker: Instruct on Torkoal turn two yields two Eruptions, while Encore on a predicted Protect or setup grants free switches or double targets. Its low offensive stats mean it will rarely KO anything itself, but the incremental advantage of an extra attack or a lockout turn is often worth more than a KO in Trick Room formats. In the late game it can self-Instruct if it survives, doubling its own Psychic for cleanup, but its primary role is to enable and maintain the room until the sweepers finish the game.</OUTPUT>

Torkoal forms a fire-and-steel core: Oranguru sets room, Torkoal Erupts twice, and both cover each other’s weaknesses—Oranguru handles Water-types with Psychic, Torkoal melts Steel-types. Dragapult is an unusual but effective teammate: a Modest Specs set underspeeds base 100s in room, and Instruct turns two Shadow Balls into a potential double KO; Dragapult also blocks opposing priority with its own speed tier. Indeedee-F is both teammate and competitor: Indeedee-F provides Follow Me and Psychic Terrain to block priority, while Oranguru offers Encore and Instruct; together they form a hybrid room team that can toggle between hyper offense and hard Trick Room. Incineroar rounds out the squad with Intimidate and Parting Shot, creating a soft cycle: Incin can pivot out, drop stats, and let Oranguru re-set room later. The shared Fire weakness is mitigated by Tera Water or Tera Dragon on the sweepers, while Telepathy on Oranguru prevents incidental Earthquake chip from partners.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Oranguru’s biggest enemy is double-target pressure: two super-effective hits from Dragapult Shadow Ball + Chien-Pao Sucker Punch or Kingambit Iron Head + Tera Dark Sneak will KO before it moves, even through Tera. Taunt from faster Prankster users like Murkrow or Whimsicott bypasses Mental Herb if Oranguru does not Tera Dark on the same turn, so proper Tera timing is essential. Ghost-types in general force a Tera or a sack: Aegislash can OHKO with Shadow Ball even after Tera Dark if it has a SpAtk boost, while Mimikyu can Ignore room with Disguise and KO. Dark-types with priority—Kingambit, Chien-Pao, or Ting-Lu—threaten to finish it after chip, especially if Incineroar has already Parting Shot’ed it into -1 Def. Encore users such as opposing Indeedee-F or Gothitelle can lock it into Trick Room or Instruct and waste turns, though Inner Focus blocks flinch-based Encore. Finally, board states where both opposing Pokémon carry Protect can stall out the four turns of Trick Room, leaving Oranguru and its slow partners exposed in the fifth turn. To counter it, bring dual-offensive pressure, prioritize Ghost or Dark STAB, and preserve Taunt or Encore until after Mental Herb is burned; once Trick Room is denied, Oranguru offers almost no value.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Tsareena": {"Abilities": {"queenlymajesty": 18.343058347605854, "leafguard": 0.12242859592438676, "sweetveil": 7.163292396850096e-05}, "Items": {"widelens": 0.6530301636661436}, "Spreads": {}, "Moves": ["powerwhip", "tripleaxel", "helpinghand", "highjumpkick"], "Tera Types": {"fire": 0.18673781089460956, "steel": 0.2953492691758195, "fighting": 0.20681493930063005}, "Teammates": ["Talonflame", "Pelipper", "Tyranitar", "Ursaluna-Bloodmoon", "Salamence", "Torkoal"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Queenly Majesty is the keystone that separates Tsareena from other Grass attackers: by blanking Bullet Punch from Scizor, Sucker Punch from Kingambit or Ting-Lu, and Aqua Jet from Azumarill or Dondozo, it forces opponents to rely on naturally faster moves or spread damage. Offensively, Power Whip supplies a 120 BP STAB capable of 2HKOing most bulky Waters and Grounds, while Triple Axel (triple kick) hits Dragons, Flying, and opposing Grass-types for at least base 60 power per hit, breaking Sash and getting around Covert Cloak. High Jump Kick gives it a 130 BP nuke versus Steel- and Normal-types such as Kingambit or Snorlax, albeit with the usual crash risk. Helping Hand lets Tsareena stay relevant in Doubles even when its coverage is redundant, boosting partner spread moves like Bloodmoon Ursaluna’s Hyper Voice or Pelipper’s Hurricane. EV spreads are not supplied, but the Wide Lens item hints at an accuracy patch for all three attacks, implying a 252 Atk / 4 Def / 252 Spe Jolly or Adamant set is most common, perhaps with a bulk investment to survive a neutral hit. Tera Fire removes Ice and Fairy weaknesses while baiting opposing Sun or Ice teams; Tera Steel grants a pile of resistances plus a Toxic immunity; Tera Fighting boosts High Jump Kick and turns Tsareena into a pseudo-Fighting-type wallbreaker. Overall, Tsareena demands careful positioning but rewards teams that can cover its Flying-, Poison-, and Bug-type shortcomings while exploiting the free turns Queenly Majesty generates.</OUTPUT>

Opposing Sun teams built around Torkoal fear High Jump Kick and Triple Axel, though Tsareena must watch for Tera Fire Torkoal Overheat or Tera Flying Charizard Hurricane. Amoonguss and other Grass-types blank Power Whip and take little from Triple Axel, forcing Tsareena to rely on High Jump Kick or switch out. Consequently, Tsareena performs best when it can pick off weakened threats and protect partners from priority, rather than attempt solo sweeps.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Paldean Tauros-Blaze is the fastest of the three regional Tauros forms and the only one blessed with a dual-type. Fighting/Fire gives it a crucial neutrality to Fairy and a resistance to Ice, Bug and Steel, while 100/105/80 bulk is reasonable when backed by Intimidate. Offensively, 110 Attack and 110 Speed let it speed-tie Iron Valiant and naturally outrun the likes of Chien-Pao, Gholdengo, Bundle, and non-Choice Scarf Dragons. Raging Bull is the star move: a 90 BP STAB that shatters Reflect and Light Screen on contact, punishing the ubiquitous Grimmsnarl/Indeedee set-up cores that define the current metagame. Close Combat provides a second reliable STAB that nails Kingambit, Garganacl and opposing Tauros. Will-o-Wisp lets the bull cripple physical set-up sweepers such as Kingambit, Dragonite and Palafin, while Protect is mandatory for doubles play, enabling partner positioning, Leftovers-less recovery, and prediction games. Tera Grass is chosen on roughly three out of four sets because it removes the 4× Water weakness, turns Electric into a resistance, and leaves Tauros with only a single Fire resistance drop while keeping Raging Bull as a neutral hit. EV spreads are straightforward: Jolly nature with 252 Speed and 4 HP maximises the speed-tie range and ensures the fastest possible Will-o-Wisp or Raging Bull; 252 Attack guarantees key benchmarks such as a 75% chance to OHKO 4 HP Gholdengo with Raging Bull after Intimidate, and 75% to 2HKO 252 HP Garganacl through Tera. Mirror Herb is the only item with meaningful usage, letting Tauros snipe an opposing boost and immediately become a threat, although the low 0.8% usage means most teams treat it as a disposable utility attacker rather than a win-con.</OUTPUT>

Finally, status—especially paralysis—cripples Tauros’s primary selling point of speed control, and passive chip from Rocky Helmet or Garganacl Salt Cure quickly wears it down.</OUTPUT>

Tera Grass is the default to flip the Water matchup and gain an Electric resistance; Tera Fire can be used on sun teams to boost Raging Bull and maintain neutrality to Water under sun, but Grass is overwhelmingly more common.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Scyther carves a niche in Regulation G as a hyper-efficient pivot that leverages Technician-boosted Dual Wingbeat and U-turn alongside the incredible bulk granted by Eviolite. With a blazing 105 base Speed it outspeeds the crowded 90-100 tier, allowing it to tank a hit and either KO back with a 120 BP STAB or safely pivot momentum to a teammate. Tera Steel patches its Stealth Rock weakness, adds invaluable resistances to Fairy/Ice/Rock, and flips the mirror vs opposing priority users, while Tera Fire punts back common Steel-type switch-ins. The set is almost perfectly standardized—Dual Wingbeat, Close Combat, U-turn, Protect—because anything else dilutes the core game plan. Scyther demands support from hazard removal or dual-slot Tailwind but rewards that support by single-handedly soft-checking physical titans like Chien-Pao, Great Tusk, and offensive Gholdengo while maintaining the fastest U-turn in the format.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Scyther": {"Abilities": {"technician": 18.752861908737394, "swarm": 0.04067455868612385, "steadfast": 0.02859398616290232}, "Items": {"eviolite": 0.9807335630397681}, "Spreads": {}, "Moves": ["dualwingbeat", "closecombat", "protect", "uturn"], "Tera Types": {"steel": 0.43992335539613325, "dragon": 0.2106186362535788, "fire": 0.15930051654419147}, "Teammates": ["Garganacl", "Incineroar", "Ninetales-Alola", "Gholdengo", "Sylveon", "Sneasler"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Eviolite single-handedly makes Scyther a legitimate defensive pivot instead of a paper-thin glass cannon. After the item, its effective physical bulk rivals Corviknight’s, while its special bulk sits comfortably above Talonflame’s, letting it survive +1 Ice Spinner from Chien-Pao or Life-Deified Moonblast from Flutter Mane after Tera Steel. Technician transforms Dual Wingbeat into a 120 BP, 90% accurate, multi-hit STAB move that breaks Sash, Disguise, and Sturdy, while also cleanly KOing Amoonguss, bulky Gholdengo, and Tera-Fairy Kingambit after chip. Close Combat punts opposing Steels that otherwise wall you, 2HKOing standard Assault Vest Garganacl and OHKOing Tera-Normal Dragonite through Multiscale after rocks. U-turn is the glue of the set: because Scyther is the fastest user of the move among viable pivots, it almost always gains momentum, and the chip it absorbs while tanking a hit can be converted into free switches for powerful wall-breakers like Sneasler or Specs Sylveon. Protect is obligatory for doubles play, scouting choice locks, stalling Tailwind turns, and enabling partner speed control. Tera Steel is the consensus pick, turning Scyther into a pseudo-steel type with only two weaknesses (Fire and Fighting) and a bevy of crucial resists, but Tera Dragon and Tera Fire remain solid alternatives that respectively punish Rotom-Wash and opposing Steels. Swarm and Steadfast show negligible usage because Technician is the entire reason the set functions; losing that 50% boost on your primary attack is non-negotiable.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Scyther dominates the mid-speed physical metagame. It cleanly beats Chien-Pao, Dragonite, non-Tera-Fire Great Tusk, Kingambit lacking Tera-Fairy, and most non-Ice-typed setup sweepers. Against bulkier balances, it forces Garganacl to choose between recovering and attacking, and it U-turns on Toxapex or Corviknight for free momentum. Versus offense, it trades favorably with Iron Valiant, outspeeds and OHKOs non-Scarf Meowscarada, and tanks a Life-Orb Palafin Jet Punch before KOing back. Where it struggles is versus faster special attackers—Iron Moth, Choice-Specs Gholdengo, and Iron Bundle all OHKO through Eviolite—and versus priority spam from Bisharp or Tera-Normal Dragonite ES. Sun teams also pose problems: Tera-Fire Torkoal Lava Plume and Protosynthesis Chlorophyll sweepers both outspeed and KO. Trick Room variants that drop speed for bulk can flip these matchups, but generally Scyther wants to operate under Tailwind or versus opposing pivot mirrors where its Speed tier shines.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Scyther is a hyper-efficient offensive pivot that compresses speed control, breaking power, and defensive utility into one slot. Its primary job is to tank one hit, remove or heavily dent a threat with Technician Dual Wingbeat, and then U-turn safely to bring in a more specialized breaker. In BO and balance squads it acts as the first layer of speed control, checking setup sweepers and forcing switches that generate free turns for teammates. Because it forces so many 50/50s—Protect vs attack, U-turn vs attack, Tera vs preserve—you can use Scyther to fish for information early game, then clean late game once its checks are Tera-burned or KOed. The presence of Eviolite also means Scyther can double as an emergency physical wall, switching into Great Tusk Headlong Rush or Kingambit Kowtow to buy a turn for your own setup or recovery. Finally, its immunity to ground and resistance to grass makes it a rare pivot that can block Rillaboom Glides and Lando-T Earthquakes while threatening immediate KOes in return.</OUTPUT>

Garganacl is the most common partner: Salt Cure + Protect stalling softens physical checks for Scyther while Scyther U-turns on Garg’s answers like Gholdengo and Kingambit. Incineroar provides Intimidate, Knock Off, and Parting Shot, creating a pivot loop that keeps hazards off and removes opposing Eviolite or Leftovers. Alolan-Ninetales offers Aurora Veil, turning Scyther into an even bulkier monster that can survive Specs Moonbursts and retaliate. Gholdengo blocks opposing hazards and punts Corviknight/Toxapex, while Scyther punts Gholdengo answers like Kingambit and Ting-Lu. Sylveon gives a special presence that scares opposing Dragons and Fighting-types, and Sneasler forms a terrifying offensive core: Scyther U-turns on bulky Waters and Steels, Sneasler comes in for free and sets up or immediately threatens KO. The shared Fighting weakness is patched by Tera-Steel or Tera-Fairy on teammates. Finally, Scyther’s U-turn pairs naturally with Tailwind setters like Roaring Moon or Tornadus-T, ensuring it always operates first and can repeatedly pivot without being punished.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Hariyama’s base 120 HP and 72/60 defenses look mediocre until you factor Thick Fat; in practice it lives Modest Heatran’s Overheat and Timid Iron Valiant’s Ice Spinner, making it one of the few Fighting-types that can stomach Fairy or Fire hits. 12 % of registered sets run Thick Fat, 5 % run Guts and 1 % run Sheer Force, so the meta overwhelmingly prefers the fire-and-ice insulation. Write a detailed 'weaknesses_and_counters' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Hariyama": {"Abilities": {"thickfat": 12.21452183089751, "guts": 5.13684893608123, "sheerforce": 1.1036082487455199}, "Items": {"flameorb": 0.31071622226113804, "assaultvest": 0.6320932059091605}, "Spreads": {"Brave:156/76/52/0/220/0": 0.5136100738168934, "Brave:252/252/0/0/4/0": 0.1878695483851265}, "Moves": ["fakeout", "knockoff", "closecombat", "heavyslam"], "Tera Types": {"steel": 0.23383694085869938, "psychic": 0.5270911261014243}, "Teammates": ["Kingambit", "Primarina", "Sinistcha", "Archaludon", "Ursaluna-Bloodmoon", "Volcarona"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Fast Flying-types—Tornadus-I, offensive Corviknight, and Tera-Flying Iron Valiant—outspeed and OHKO with Hurricane or Brave Bird before Hariyama can respond. Psychic-spam cores of Indeedee + Armarouge or Hatterene ignore Fake Out thanks to Psychic Terrain and OHKO with Expanding Force or Psychic. Tera Ghost users (Dragapult, Aegislash, Ceruledge) blank Fake Out and set up in Hariyama’s face while resisting Heavy Slam. Fairy-types that can survive a Heavy Slam, such as Tera-Fairy Sylveon or Primarina, retalify with Hyper Voice or Moonblast for the KO. Status outside of burn cripples it: paralysis drops its already low Speed, poison wears it down, and sleep from Amoonguss or Venusaur removes it from play for multiple turns. Finally, intimidate cycling from Landorus-T or Arcanine forces it to reset with Guard or Tera, and without attack boosts Hariyama struggles to break bulkier walls.</OUTPUT>

input:
Provide the 'short_summary' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Mimikyu": {"Abilities": {"disguise": 17.254664583070838}, "Items": {"lifeorb": 0.22120718555155564, "mentalherb": 0.5832321604600169}, "Spreads": {"Careful:228/4/228/0/36/12": 0.2442487037745891}, "Moves": ["playrough", "shadowsneak", "taunt", "trickroom"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.26193059093648013, "grass": 0.21971390258902712, "steel": 0.29189957334066285}, "Teammates": ["Incineroar", "Primarina", "Torkoal", "Ursaluna-Bloodmoon", "Annihilape", "Archaludon"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Mimikyu remains a premier Trick Room setter in VGC thanks to its Disguise ability, which guarantees a free turn to get Trick Room up even against double-targets. The sample spread’s heavy investment in HP and Special Defense alongside a Careful nature turns it into a surprisingly bulky support that can survive a wide array of special hits, while 12 Speed EVs let it underspeed neutral-natured base 60s such as Torkoal and Primarina under Trick Room. Life Orb is the dominant damage item, giving Play Rough and Shadow Sneak meaningful chip against frailer threats, whereas Mental Herb is a niche option to shrug off Taunt or Encore and guarantee Trick Room. Tera Ghost is the most common, removing Mimikyu’s Ghost weakness and letting it spinblock as well as dodge Fake Out, while Tera Grass and Tera Steel offer extra resistances to Water and Ice or a full Fairy resistance respectively. The four-moveset of Play Rough / Shadow Sneak / Taunt / Trick Room is standard: Taunt prevents opposing set-up or speed control, Shadow Sneak gives priority chip, and Play Rough is a reliable STAB that pressures Dragons and Dark-types.</OUTPUT>

input:
Create the 'full_analysis' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Mimikyu": {"Abilities": {"disguise": 17.254664583070838}, "Items": {"lifeorb": 0.22120718555155564, "mentalherb": 0.5832321604600169}, "Spreads": {"Careful:228/4/228/0/36/12": 0.2442487037745891}, "Moves": ["playrough", "shadowsneak", "taunt", "trickroom"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.26193059093648013, "grass": 0.21971390258902712, "steel": 0.29189957334066285}, "Teammates": ["Incineroar", "Primarina", "Torkoal", "Ursaluna-Bloodmoon", "Annihilape", "Archaludon"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Disguise is the single biggest reason Mimikyu keeps seeing usage in every Series; a guaranteed non-KO on the first hit means Trick Room is almost always going up unless the opponent commits both slots to double-targeting or uses a bypass like Dragon Darts. Once Trick Room is active, Mimikyu’s awkward base 96 Speed becomes an asset, letting it move before most of the metagame under reversed speeds. Careful nature plus 228 HP / 228 SpD gives Mimikyu enough special bulk to live Life Orb Moonblast from Flutter Mane or Choice Specs Hydro Steam from Walking Wake, meaning it can usually stay on the field for multiple turns to fire off attacks or continued support. Shadow Sneak is deceptely useful: it breaks Focus Sashes, finishes off weakened Dynamax targets, and provides a last-ditch pick-off when Trick Room is about to expire. Play Rough’s 90% accuracy is a drawback, but the Fairy typing is invaluable for punishing Dragons, Urshifu, Chien-Pao, and Kingambit. Taunt shuts down other support Pokémon like Murkrow, Pelipper, or enemy Trick Room setters, while also preventing Recover, Parting Shot, or Tailwind. Life Orb is preferred on offensive teams where Mimikyu doubles as a win-condition, whereas Mental Herb is better on hard Trick Room squads that cannot afford to lose momentum to Taunt or Encore. Tera Ghost is the most flexible, removing the sole Ghost weakness and granting an immunity to Fake Out and Extreme Speed, but Tera Grass lets Mimikyu stomach Kyogre’s Water Spout or Rillaboom’s Grassy Glide, and Tera Steel provides a handy resistance to both Fairy and Ice while keeping a neutrality to Steel-type moves that would otherwise dent Mimikyu.</OUTPUT>

input:
Write the 'matchup_overview' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Mimikyu": {"Abilities": {"disguise": 17.254664583070838}, "Items": {"lifeorb": 0.22120718555155564, "mentalherb": 0.5832321604600169}, "Spreads": {"Careful:228/4/228/0/36/12": 0.2442487037745891}, "Moves": ["playrough", "shadowsneak", "taunt", "trickroom"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.26193059093648013, "grass": 0.21971390258902712, "steel": 0.29189957334066285}, "Teammates": ["Incineroar", "Primarina", "Torkoal", "Ursaluna-Bloodmoon", "Annihilape", "Archaludon"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Against hyper-offense teams that rely on Tailwind or fast threats like Flutter Mane, Iron Bundle, or Chien-Pao, Mimikyu is at its best: Disguise guarantees Trick Room, flipping the speed tiers and forcing the opponent into predictable Protects or switches. Against other Trick Room teams Mimikyu becomes a Taunt bot that can block enemy setters while still threatening STAB Play Roughs; however, it loses to Mental Herb users or Ghost-types that are immune to Shadow Sneak. Stall and bulky balance squads can be awkward because Mimikyu’s offenses are merely average, so if it cannot secure KOs it becomes setup fodder for Pokémon like Corviknight or Dondozo. Sun and Rain can pressure it with spread Water or Fire moves, but Mimikyu’s bulk lets it survive most single-target attacks and retaliate. Steel-types such as Kingambit and Gholdengo wall Mimikyu unless it Terastallizes, while Iron Hands and Ting-Lu shrug off Play Roughs and can retalify with super-effective Steel or Ground coverage. Conversely, Mimikyu pressures Dragon-spam cores, Dark-types like Meowscarada or Grimmsnarl, and Psychic-types such as Indeedee or Calyrex-Ice.</OUTPUT>

input:
Provide the 'role_description' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Mimikyu": {"Abilities": {"disguise": 17.254664583070838}, "Items": {"lifeorb": 0.22120718555155564, "mentalherb": 0.5832321604600169}, "Spreads": {"Careful:228/4/228/0/36/12": 0.2442487037745891}, "Moves": ["playrough", "shadowsneak", "taunt", "trickroom"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.26193059093648013, "grass": 0.21971390258902712, "steel": 0.29189957334066285}, "Teammates": ["Incineroar", "Primarina", "Torkoal", "Ursaluna-Bloodmoon", "Annihilape", "Archaludon"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Mimikyu is first and foremost a dedicated Trick Room setter that compresses speed control, priority damage, and anti-support into one slot. Its unique ability to survive any first hit means it can safely set Trick Room even when the opponent doubles into it, freeing its partner to attack or reposition. Once Trick Room is up, Mimikyu morphs into a mid-speed attacker that cleans weakened foes with Shadow Sneak or breaks holes with Play Rough, while Taunt prevents opposing recovery or status moves. On some teams it functions as a secondary win-condition, using Life Orb plus Swords Dance (if chosen) to sweep, but the sample set focuses on immediate support rather than set-up. Its Ghost typing also lets it block Rapid Spin and act as an emergency spinblocker against teams that rely on hazards in longer formats. The Careful spread and Tera options let it pivot repeatedly, giving Trick Room teams a sturdy backbone that can trade hits through the mid-game.</OUTPUT>

input:
Generate the 'synergy_breakdown' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Mimikyu": {"Abilities": {"disguise": 17.254664583070838}, "Items": {"lifeorb": 0.22120718555155564, "mentalherb": 0.5832321604600169}, "Spreads": {"Careful:228/4/228/0/36/12": 0.2442487037745891}, "Moves": ["playrough", "shadowsneak", "taunt", "trickroom"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.26193059093648013, "grass": 0.21971390258902712, "steel": 0.29189957334066285}, "Teammates": ["Incineroar", "Primarina", "Torkoal", "Ursaluna-Bloodmoon", "Annihilape", "Archaludon"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Mimikyu’s ideal partners are slow, hard-hitting Pokémon that appreciate reversed speed tiers. Incineroar provides Fake Out, Intimidate, and U-turn momentum while handling Steel-types that wall Mimikyu; in return, Mimikyu removes Dragons and Fairies that trouble Incineroar. Primarina is a natural teammate, sharing a Fairy typing and enjoying Trick Room to fire off powerful Hydro Pumps and Hyper Voices; Mimikyu covers its Grass and Electric weaknesses while Primarina smashes Fire and Steel threats. Torkoal offers sun-boosted Eruptions and sets its own weather, and the two can stack residual damage with Shadow Sneak + Lava Plume or Eruption. Ursaluna-Bloodmoon is another perfect partner: under Trick Room it becomes a 500-Attack monster that obliterates anything neutral to its STABs, while Mimikyu handles faster Fairies and Ghosts that can outspeed and KO it. Annihilape benefits from Trick Room to click bulk-up or Rage Fist, appreciates Taunt support, and can take Steel-type hits for Mimikyu. Archaludon covers the Steel and Rock matchups with STAB Flash Cannon and Body Press, while Mimikyu removes Ground and Fighting-types that threaten it. Overall, Mimikyu acts as the glue that enables these slow powerhouses to function in a metagame dominated by Tailwind and priority.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Standard Support: Careful 228 HP / 4 Atk / 228 SpD / 12 Spe with Disguise — Play Rough / Shadow Sneak / Trick Room / Taunt holding Life Orb (Tera Ghost). The EVs survive Life Orb Flutter Mane Moonblast and Modest Walking Wake Hydro Steam, while 12 Speed underspeeds neutral base 60s for Trick Room. Life Orb maximizes damage output; Tera Ghost removes Ghost weakness and blocks Fake Out. Alternative Bulky Mental Herb: same spread but swap Life Orb for Mental Herb and consider Swords Dance over Taunt if the team already has Taunt elsewhere. Offensive Swords Dance: Brave 252 HP / 252 Atk / 4 Def with Disguise — Play Rough / Shadow Sneak / Swords Dance / Trick Room holding Life Orb (Tera Ghost or Tera Fairy) for teams that want Mimikyu to sweep rather than purely support. Tera Steel variant: identical spread but Tera Steel to resist Fairy and Ice, useful on teams weak to Sylveon or Chien-Pao.</OUTPUT>

Write the 'weaknesses_and_counters' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Mimikyu": {"Abilities": {"disguise": 17.254664583070838}, "Items": {"lifeorb": 0.22120718555155564, "mentalherb": 0.5832321604600169}, "Spreads": {"Careful:228/4/228/0/36/12": 0.2442487037745891}, "Moves": ["playrough", "shadowsneak", "taunt", "trickroom"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.26193059093648013, "grass": 0.21971390258902712, "steel": 0.29189957334066285}, "Teammates": ["Incineroar", "Primarina", "Torkoal", "Ursaluna-Bloodmoon", "Annihilape", "Archaludon"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Disguise is a one-time shield; once it’s popped, Mimikyu’s mediocre bulk is exposed. Multi-hit moves like Dragon Darts, Population Bomb, or Bullet Seed break Disguise and KO on the same turn. Status—especially burn—cripples its damage output, while poison wears it down quickly. Steel-types such as Gholdengo, Kingambit, and Corviknight take pitiful damage from Play Rough and can retalify with super-effective Steel moves or set up in Mimikyu’s face. Ghost-types like Aegislash and opposing Mimikyu are immune to Shadow Sneak and can play mind-games with Tera. Faster Taunt users such as Murkrow or Grimmsnarl can shut down Trick Room before Disguise is popped, though Mental Herb variants beat this. Priority users like Extreme Speed Dragonite or First Impression can finish off a chipped Mimikyu after Disguise is gone. Finally, critical hits bypass Disguise, so RNG-reliant moves like Stone Edge or Shadow Claw can occasionally cheese through it.</OUTPUT>

The team can toggle between sun and Trick Room modes, giving flexibility against both fast and slow opponents. Mimikyu’s Taunt stops enemy Tailwind or Trick Room, ensuring tempo stays in your favor.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Cinderace": {"Abilities": {"blaze": 13.809641634043572, "libero": 3.114394668267686}, "Items": {"focussash": 0.8265122688053633}, "Spreads": {"Jolly:36/220/0/0/0/252": 0.7961964818562975}, "Moves": ["coaching", "pyroball", "protect", "willowisp"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.8324362695150338}, "Teammates": ["Dragonite", "Ninetales-Alola", "Gholdengo", "Ursaluna", "Tinkaton", "Tauros-Paldea-Aqua"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>With a blazing 116 base Speed tier and access to Libero, Cinderace’s niche in VGC 2025 lies less in raw power and more in its unique ability to enable physical breakers through Coaching. The listed spread—Jolly with 220 Atk / 36 HP / 252 Spe—outspeeds the crowded 110-115 scarfless meta (Chien-Pao, Iron Valiant, Meowscarada) while preserving enough bulk to survive a modest neutral hit when holding Focus Sash. Coaching is the heart of the set: a +1 Atk/Def boost for any ally on the field, turning slow or frail sweepers into immediate win conditions. Pyro Ball remains one of the strongest single-target Fire moves in the format, nuking common Steel and Grass types such as Amoonguss, Gholdengo and Tinkaton through Tera Ghost for a clean OHKO. Will-o-Wisp provides emergency physical shutdown, crippling the likes of Chien-Pao, Kingambit or opposing Dragonite, while Protect is mandatory for pivoting, Coaching timing, and Focus Sash preservation. Tera Ghost removes the Fighting weakness, blocks Fake Out and grants perfect neutral coverage alongside Pyro Ball, making Cinderace harder to revenge-kill once the sash has been consumed.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Cinderace thrives versus Grass- and Steel-heavy teams that rely on Amoonguss, Corviknight or Tinkaton for redirection or bulk; Coaching plus a boosted ally quickly overwhelms them. It is neutral-to-positive into most Sun cores (Ninetales-A is already a teammate) and can burn physical Chlorophyll sweepers such as Scovillain. It struggles into bulky Water-types like Dondozo and Palafin that shrug off Pyro Ball and can retaliate with Wave Crash or Jet Punch. Trick Room modes also pressure it: Hatterene + Indeedee can set up before Cinderace moves, and Ghost-types like Aegislash ignore Coaching value. Rain teams with Pelipper and Barraskewda force chip onto the sash and punish with strong Aqua Jets.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Priority water attacks (Aqua Jet, Jet Punch) and bulky Water resists such as Dondozo, Slowbro and Rotom-W ignore Coaching value and force chip onto your side. Trick Room setters like Hatterene and Armarouge can move first under TR and KO with Psychic or Heat Wave. Ghost-types such as Aegislash and Dragapult are immune to Coaching and can retalify with Shadow Ball or Dragon Darts. Intimidate cycles from Landorus-T or Arcanine neuter Pyro Ball damage and make Coaching boosts harder to secure. Finally, multi-hit moves like Population Bomb or Rock Blast break Focus Sash and leave Cinderace exposed.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Clefairy": {"Abilities": {"magicguard": 0.025739219221206533, "friendguard": 16.867738729942623, "cutecharm": 0.2520737201641129}, "Items": {"eviolite": 0.9932150281821688}, "Spreads": {"Sassy:252/0/76/0/180/0": 0.17107331936579342, "Sassy:252/0/148/0/108/0": 0.1627452950267127}, "Moves": ["followme", "protect", "helpinghand", "lifedew"], "Tera Types": {"steel": 0.21911178598189288, "grass": 0.2627681153770931, "fairy": 0.26180276863125035}, "Teammates": ["Archaludon", "Incineroar", "Typhlosion-Hisui", "Whimsicott", "Ursaluna-Bloodmoon", "Dragapult"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Clefairy is a premier support Pokémon in VGC, leveraging Friend Guard and Eviolite to tank hits for its partner while redirecting damage with Follow Me and enabling clutch plays with Helping Hand. Its typing and bulk let it glue together offensive cores built around Archaludon, Ursaluna-Bloodmoon or Typhlosion-Hisui, and its flexible Tera options in Steel, Grass or Fairy let it adapt to the most dangerous opposing attackers.</OUTPUT>

input:
Write a detailed 'full_analysis' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Clefairy": {"Abilities": {"magicguard": 0.025739219221206533, "friendguard": 16.867738729942623, "cutecharm": 0.2520737201641129}, "Items": {"eviolite": 0.9932150281821688}, "Spreads": {"Sassy:252/0/76/0/180/0": 0.17107331936579342, "Sassy:252/0/148/0/108/0": 0.1627452950267127}, "Moves": ["followme", "protect", "helpinghand", "lifedew"], "Tera Types": {"steel": 0.21911178598189288, "grass": 0.2627681153770931, "fairy": 0.26180276863125035}, "Teammates": ["Archaludon", "Incineroar", "Typhlosion-Hisui", "Whimsicott", "Ursaluna-Bloodmoon", "Dragapult"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>With Friend Guard reducing incoming damage to its partner by 25 %, Clefairy single-handedly turns fragile but explosive attackers into safe, consistent win conditions. Eviolite pushes its already respectable 95/73/85 bulk to elite levels, allowing it to survive super-effective hits and continue firing off Follow Me, Helping Hand, Protect and Life Dew throughout a long game. The chosen Sassy nature and EV spreads (either 252 HP / 148 Def / 108 SpD or 252 HP / 76 Def / 180 SpD) maximise special bulk while keeping enough Defence to avoid the 2HKO from common physical threats such as Chien-Pao or Kingambit. Follow Me is the cornerstone move, forcing the opponent to target Clefairy and freeing partners to set up, click setup moves, or simply nuke the field with boosted attacks. Helping Hand adds 50 % damage to any ally move, turning would-be survivals into knock-outs and flipping speed-tie scenarios. Life Dew provides 25 % healing to both Clefairy and its partner, punishing opponents for failing to secure simultaneous KOs and giving your side a second lease on the game. Protect is mandatory for stalling out Dynamax turns, blocking Fake Out, and gaining positioning. Terastallization is used reactively: Steel removes the Poison weakness and adds crucial resistances to Dragon and Ice; Grass punishes Water-types looking to soak up hits; Fairy keeps STAB Moonblast options alive on more offensive variants and adds a Dragon immunity. Clefairy fits equally well on hard Trick Room, tailwind, or speed-controlless balance teams because its only goal is to keep the sweepers healthy and swinging.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Clefairy": {"Abilities": {"magicguard": 0.025739219221206533, "friendguard": 16.867738729942623, "cutecharm": 0.2520737201641129}, "Items": {"eviolite": 0.9932150281821688}, "Spreads": {"Sassy:252/0/76/0/180/0": 0.17107331936579342, "Sassy:252/0/148/0/108/0": 0.1627452950267127}, "Moves": ["followme", "protect", "helpinghand", "lifedew"], "Tera Types": {"steel": 0.21911178598189288, "grass": 0.2627681153770931, "fairy": 0.26180276863125035}, "Teammates": ["Archaludon", "Incineroar", "Typhlosion-Hisui", "Whimsicott", "Ursaluna-Bloodmoon", "Dragapult"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Clefairy loves facing single-target attackers such as Dragapult, Chien-Pao or Iron Valiant that rely on spread or snipe KOs, because Follow Me invalidates their game plan. It struggles against Taunt users like Murkrow or Whimsicott that shut off its support moves, and against Mold Breaker or Neutralising Gas Pokémon that ignore Friend Guard. Opposing spread attackers such as Torkoal or Sylveon can damage both Clefairy and its partner simultaneously, circumventing Follow Me, while Poison- and Steel-types can target Clefairy super-effectively and force early Tera decisions. Teams that bring both Fake Out and double-target pressure can break the Follow Me chain and leave Clefairy’s partner exposed.</OUTPUT>

It occupies the "flex slot" on teams that already have speed control (Whimsicott tailwind, Trick Room setter) and simply need a buffer that buys two to three extra turns for the win condition to clean.</OUTPUT>
