<DATA>{"Clefairy": {"Abilities": {"magicguard": 0.025739219221206533, "friendguard": 16.867738729942623, "cutecharm": 0.2520737201641129}, "Items": {"eviolite": 0.9932150281821688}, "Spreads": {"Sassy:252/0/76/0/180/0": 0.17107331936579342, "Sassy:252/0/148/0/108/0": 0.1627452950267127}, "Moves": ["followme", "protect", "helpinghand", "lifedew"], "Tera Types": {"steel": 0.21911178598189288, "grass": 0.2627681153770931, "fairy": 0.26180276863125035}, "Teammates": ["Archaludon", "Incineroar", "Typhlosion-Hisui", "Whimsicott", "Ursaluna-Bloodmoon", "Dragapult"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Archaludon benefits immensely from Friend Guard, surviving Earthquakes and Fire Blasts that would otherwise 2HKO, and appreciates Helping Hand turning Stellar Tera Electro Shot into a guaranteed OHKO on most neutral targets. Incineroar forms a classic intimidate core, dropping opponents’ Attack while Clefairy soaks the redirected hits, and both can cycle Protect and Parting Shot to run away with momentum. Typhlosion-Hisui gains Follow Me protection while it clicks Infernal Parade or Eruption, and Life Dew offsets the recoil from Flare Boost. Whimsicott provides tailwind or Taunt control, letting Clefairy focus on Helping Hand pressure. Ursaluna-Bloodmoon’s enormous bulk plus Friend Guard makes it almost unkillable, and Helping Hand-boosted Blood Moon deletes most resists. Dragapult loves Follow Me when setting up Dragon Dance or when firing off spread Draco Meteors, and both Pokémon share a Fairy Tera option that blanks opposing Dragons.</OUTPUT>

The prevalence of Brave nature (31.6% usage) over Adamant (15.1%) indicates its primary role as a Trick Room attacker, where its base 42 Speed becomes an asset rather than a liability. output: <OUTPUT>Stonjourner is a niche physical attacker in VGC whose only real claim to relevance is its signature Power Spot, an ability that boosts the damage of allies’ spread moves by 30 %. With a usable 100 / 135 / 20 / 20 / 20 / 70 stat line it is essentially a slow, frail, single-purpose support that must be kept alive to justify its slot. The most successful builds are Jolly 252/252 with Focus Sash, running Rock Slide / Wide Guard / Low Kick / Protect, and terastallizing into Ghost or Fighting to dodge Fake Out or boost STAB. It is almost always paired with spread-heavy partners such as Gholdengo, Indeedee, or Archaludon that can abuse Power Spot while Stonjourner itself spams Rock Slide flinches and Wide Guard to block opposing spread pressure.</OUTPUT>

Write a detailed 'full_analysis' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Stonjourner": {"Abilities": {"powerspot": 17.689636533843057}, "Items": {"focussash": 0.9485670204404687}, "Spreads": {"Jolly:4/252/0/0/0/252": 0.25057366801733744, "Jolly:0/252/4/0/0/252": 0.6447429999296421}, "Moves": ["rockslide", "lowkick", "wideguard", "protect"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.21370608086819234, "fighting": 0.6499456444640199}, "Teammates": ["Gholdengo", "Talonflame", "Indeedee", "Murkrow", "Archaludon", "Sneasler"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Power Spot is the sole reason Stonjourner sees tournament play: a passive, field-wide 1.3× multiplier on the base power of allies’ spread moves. Because the boost is applied before other modifiers, it turns modest Earth Powers, Dazzling Gleams and Make It Rains into genuine nukes while still stacking with items like Life Orb or terrain. Stonjourner’s own offenses are merely adequate; 100 Atk and 70 Spe leave it outrun and out-damaged by the metagame’s premier Rock-types such as Tyranitar or Lycanroc, so it leans on utility rather than firepower. Rock Slide is chosen over Stone Edge for the spread chance and Power Spot synergy, while Low Kick nails common threats like Kingambit, Garganacl and opposing Stonjourner. Wide Guard is invaluable into teams that rely on Precipice Blades, Origin Pulse, or Sylveon’s Hyper Voice, and Protect is mandatory on a Pokémon that must survive to keep Power Spot active. Focus Sash guarantees at least one turn of positioning, though the scarcity of item data (only ~0.95 % usage reported) suggests most players simply accept the 4 HP / 0 Def paper defenses. Ghost Tera removes the Normal- and Fighting-type weaknesses that ruin its day, notably dodging Fake Out and Close Combat, while Fighting Tera turns Low Kick into a stronger, spammable STAB and grants a crucial resistance to Dark. In practice Stonjourner functions as a terrain-less, slower Indeedee-F that trades Follow Me for significantly higher damage augmentation, requiring far more proactive protection but rewarding proper positioning with explosive damage output from its teammates.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Stonjourner": {"Abilities": {"powerspot": 17.689636533843057}, "Items": {"focussash": 0.9485670204404687}, "Spreads": {"Jolly:4/252/0/0/0/252": 0.25057366801733744, "Jolly:0/252/4/0/0/252": 0.6447429999296421}, "Moves": ["rockslide", "lowkick", "wideguard", "protect"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.21370608086819234, "fighting": 0.6499456444640199}, "Teammates": ["Gholdengo", "Talonflame", "Indeedee", "Murkrow", "Archaludon", "Sneasler"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Stonjourner loves facing bulky, spread-reliant balance cores that cannot immediately KO it: Garganacl + Torkoal, Sylveon + Radiant Sun, or Gholdengo + Hippowdon give it free turns to click Wide Guard and let partners rip boosted Earth Powers. It struggles into hyper-offense: Chien-Pao, Sneasler, and Choice Band Dragonite all OHKO through Sash with Ice Spinner, Close Combat, or Earthquake respectively, while priority from Kingambit or Brave Bird Talonflame bypasses its speed tier. Rain teams are mixed: Wide Guard blocks Water Spout and Origin Pulse, but Stonjourner folds to specs Hurricane or a simple Flip Turn into Floatzel. Trick Room is a nightmare because Stonjourner underspeeds most setters and cannot stop Indeedee-F expanding its own Psychic Terrain; conversely, Stonjourner’s own team usually wants Tailwind or paralysis support to move before threats. Terastallization match-ups hinge on typing: Ghost Tera blanks Fake Out and Mach Punch but still folds to Knock Off, while Fighting Tera invites Tera Fairy Sylveon or Tera Flying Corviknight to stall it out. Overall, Stonjourner’s match-ups are defined less by itself and more by whether its partner can leverage Power Spot faster than the opponent can remove the statue.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Stonjourner is a static, item-independent support attacker whose only job is to stay on the field amplifying allies’ spread damage while disrupting opposing spread with Wide Guard and Rock Slide flinches. It never aims to sweep; instead it occupies the “enabler” slot common to teams that stack multiple spread attackers (Gholdengo, Indeedee, Archaludon) and need a damage ceiling higher than standard terrain or Helping Hand can provide. Because it cannot pivot, heal, or boost, every turn is spent either Protecting, chipping with Low Kick, or blocking key spread moves, meaning successful pilots treat Stonjourner like a mix of suicide lead and artillery spotter: place it safely, keep it alive for 3–4 turns, and once the boosted barrage has broken the opponent’s board, sacrifice it to bring in a cleaner. Its EV spreads are pure maximization—Jolly 252/252 ensures it speed-creeps other base 70s such as Modest Gholdengo and outspeeds neutral-natured Kingambit under Tailwind—because any bulk investment is futile with 20/20 defenses. In short, Stonjourner is the Pokémon equivalent of a fragile amplifier: indispensable when the composition is built around it, dead weight when it is not.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Stonjourner": {"Abilities": {"powerspot": 17.689636533843057}, "Items": {"focussash": 0.9485670204404687}, "Spreads": {"Jolly:4/252/0/0/0/252": 0.25057366801733744, "Jolly:0/252/4/0/0/252": 0.6447429999296421}, "Moves": ["rockslide", "lowkick", "wideguard", "protect"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.21370608086819234, "fighting": 0.6499456444640199}, "Teammates": ["Gholdengo", "Talonflame", "Indeedee", "Murkrow", "Archaludon", "Sneasler"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Power Spot teams are built on the principle of “spread move stacking,” so teammates must bring multi-target attacks that benefit from the 30 % boost. Gholdengo is the premier partner: Make It Rain under Power Spot reaches absurd damage tiers while the coin-flip Special Drop chance further cripples checks. Indeedee-F is equally potent, turning modest Psychic or Dazzling Gleam into OHKO thresholds on Urshifu and Dragonite while providing its own Follow Me to keep Stonjourner alive. Archaludon offers STAB Stellar Beam and Electro Shot that, after Power Spot, delete Corviknight and Toxapex while maintaining offensive pressure under Tailwind. Talonflame supplies priority Tailwind and can pivot with U-turn, ensuring Stonjourner enters safely; it also appreciates Wide Guard into Rock Slide or Precipice Blades. Murkrow brings Tailwind and Taunt, preventing Trick Room or Recover attempts that would otherwise stall out the Power Spot window, while Sneasler gives a fast offensive mode that can clean once spread damage has softened the field. In the back, bulky pivots like Toxapex or Rotom-W complete the “core + support + cleaner” triangle, absorbing the hits Stonjourner cannot and providing secondary win conditions if the statue falls early. The overarching synergy is a burst-oriented, spread-heavy composition that aims to delete two Pokémon on turn 2 or 3 before the opponent can reset momentum.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Standard Support Amplifier: Stonjourner @ Focus Sash, Jolly Nature, 4 HP / 252 Atk / 252 Spe, Ability: Power Spot, Tera Type: Ghost (or Fighting), Moves: Rock Slide / Low Kick / Wide Guard / Protect. Ghost Tera is default to dodge Fake Out and Fighting-type coverage; Fighting Tera is acceptable if the team already carries a Ghost resist and wants stronger Low Kick. Alternative item choices are virtually non-viable: Sitrus Berry fails to salvage 20/20 defenses, Weakness Policy is impossible to proc reliably, and Assault Vest ignores Wide Guard. A slower Impish spread (252 HP / 252 Atk / 4 Def) exists to underspeed Trick Room attackers, but testing shows the damage loss on Rock Slide flinches and the inability to outrun Kingambit make it inferior. In best-of-three, consider swapping Protect for Stealth Rock only if the team is hyper-offensive and needs hazards to break Focus Sashes on turn 1, but this is fringe. Tera Blast is not recommended because Stonjourner’s special stat is 20 and it would rather spend the Tera on survival than on a one-time nuke.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Stonjourner": {"Abilities": {"powerspot": 17.689636533843057}, "Items": {"focussash": 0.9485670204404687}, "Spreads": {"Jolly:4/252/0/0/0/252": 0.25057366801733744, "Jolly:0/252/4/0/0/252": 0.6447429999296421}, "Moves": ["rockslide", "lowkick", "wideguard", "protect"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.21370608086819234, "fighting": 0.6499456444640199}, "Teammates": ["Gholdengo", "Talonflame", "Indeedee", "Murkrow", "Archaludon", "Sneasler"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Stonjourner’s 20/20 special bulk and average physical bulk mean any super-effective hit—or even strong neutral special move—removes it. Priority users are public enemy #1: Kingambit’s Sucker Punch, Breloom’s Mach Punch, and Bisharp’s Assurance all OHKO through Sash if rocks are up. Faster spread attackers such as Iron Moth, Chi-Yu, and Tatsugiri under Commander boost can double-target around Wide Guard and still KO. Terrain control also cripples it: Psychic Terrain stops priority Tailwind from Talonflame or Murkrow, while Grassy Terrain weakens Low Kick against heavier targets like Garganacl. Status ruins Stonjourner’s day; burn halves its already mediocre damage, and paralysis makes it slower than most Trick Room setters, meaning it cannot even Wide Guard in time. Knock Off is uniquely devastating because removing Focus Sash turns every neutral hit into an OHKO. Finally, phazing moves (Roar, Whirlwind, Dragon Tail) bypass Protect and eject Stonjourner before it can fire off a boosted attack, wasting the Power Spot investment. In team preview, identify whether the opponent carries one of these avenues and plan to either double-protect early or bring a secondary mode (Tailwind + cleaner) that functions without the statue.</OUTPUT>

Lead Stonjourner + Gholdengo against slower teams: turn 1 Protect + Make It Rain for heavy spread and chip, then continue firing boosted spread until Sash is popped. Practice sequencing Protect and Wide Guard to ensure Stonjourner survives exactly three turns—long enough for two boosted spread attacks and one positioning pivot—then sacrifice it to bring in the appropriate cleaner.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Salazzle is a niche but surprisingly effective pick in VGC 2024 Regulation G, leveraging its unique Poison/Fire typing and the Corrosion ability to pressure bulky cores while providing valuable utility through Fake Out and Poison Gas. Though its base stats are modest, its blazing 117 Speed tier and access to spread moves like Heat Wave and Sludge Wave let it function as a fast support-disruptor that can cripple common threats such as Dondozo, Tatsugiri, and Dragonite. The Stellar tera type is overwhelmingly preferred, hinting that players are using Terastallization to keep Salazzle’s offensive coverage intact rather than changing its typing. With Focus Sash as the only item of note, Salazzle is clearly being played as a one-time pivot that guarantees at least one meaningful turn of disruption or damage. Its most common teammates—Dondozo, Tatsugiri, Dragonite, Gholdengo, Kingambit, and Talonflame—form a balanced core that appreciates Salazzle’s ability to break Tera Fairy and Tera Water buffers while itself appreciating redirection, bulk, and priority control from its allies.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Salazzle": {"Abilities": {"corrosion": 14.756976792802456, "oblivious": 0.250170354771483}, "Items": {"focussash": 0.9802007436021732}, "Spreads": {"Timid:4/0/0/252/0/252": 0.9684089540184365}, "Moves": ["heatwave", "fakeout", "sludgewave", "poisongas"], "Tera Types": {"stellar": 0.9239425197119476}, "Teammates": ["Dondozo", "Tatsugiri", "Dragonite", "Gholdengo", "Kingambit", "Talonflame"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Salazzle’s value in the current metagame stems from three factors that very few other Pokémon can replicate simultaneously: access to Corrosion, a 117 Speed tier that outspeeds the crowded base-100 and base-110 crowds, and a dual STAB combination that hits many of the format’s premier threats for super-effective or neutral damage. Corrosion in particular is the selling point: being able to badly poison Tera Fairy Kingambit, Tera Water Dondozo, or opposing Garganacl ignores the usual immunity clauses that keep these threats healthy. Poison Gas, chosen on every sampled set, is the optimal delivery mechanism—100% accurate, spread, and non-attacking, so it bypasses Follow Me and allies can still benefit from the status. Heat Wave provides reliable spread damage into Amoonguss, Kingambit, and Gholdengo while also threatening the ever-present Tera Steel users. Sludge Wave is the strongest spread Poison option available, nailing Tera Fairy users and opposing Dragonite after a Dragon Dance. Fake Out gives the team tempo, letting partners such as Calm Mind Dondozo or Dragonite set up, or simply breaking Focus Sashes and Sturdy. Timid nature with 252 Speed EVs guarantees the speed tie with opposing base-117 threats like Iron Moth and ensures Salazzle always moves before neutral-natured Dragapult, while 252 Special Attack maximizes the damage output of its spread moves. Focus Sash guarantees that Salazzle survives at least one hit, letting it fire off two moves in most games—often one status and one attack. Stellar Terastallization preserves both STABs while giving a one-time power boost that can clinch key KOs on bulkier foes after spread damage has accumulated.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Salazzle": {"Abilities": {"corrosion": 14.756976792802456, "oblivious": 0.250170354771483}, "Items": {"focussash": 0.9802007436021732}, "Spreads": {"Timid:4/0/0/252/0/252": 0.9684089540184365}, "Moves": ["heatwave", "fakeout", "sludgewave", "poisongas"], "Tera Types": {"stellar": 0.9239425197119476}, "Teammates": ["Dondozo", "Tatsugiri", "Dragonite", "Gholdengo", "Kingambit", "Talonflame"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Salazzle performs best against bulky Water, Fairy, and Grass cores that rely on Terastallization to blank conventional Poison or Fire damage. Tera Water Dondozo, Tera Fairy Kingambit, and Tera Fairy Garganacl all lose to Corrosion Poison Gas, forcing them to either switch out or play at a permanent disadvantage. Against offensive teams, Salazzle’s 117 Speed tier lets it outpace and pressure Iron Moth, Dragapult, and Chi-Yu, though it must watch for priority such as Extreme Speed from Dragonite or Sucker Punch from Kingambit. Amoonguss is a mixed bag: Poison Gas ignores Rage Powder but Sludge Wave does not, so Salazzle typically needs an ally to remove Amoonguss or rely on Terastallized Heat Wave calcs. Tailwind and Chlorophyll sweepers can overrun Salazzle if it fails to get off Poison Gas or if Focus Sash is broken by spread damage, so speed control partners are mandatory. Rain teams featuring Pelipper and Barraskewda are problematic, as Barraskewda’s Aqua Jet and rain-boosted Liquidation OHKO through Sash, while Pelipper’s wide-gauge support gives its team tempo. Psychic- and Ground-type attackers such as Indeedee-F and Great Tusk also threaten Salazzle, though they must be wary of switching into Poison Gas.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Salazzle operates as a fast utility pivot whose primary goal is to poison opposing Terastallized walls and break sashes while freeing its teammates to sweep. It is not expected to OHKO targets; instead, it trades its own Focus Sash for widespread status and chip damage that enables partners like Swords Dance Kingambit, Calm Mind Dondozo, or Dragon Dance Dragonite to clean late-game. Because Corrosion ignores type immunities, Salazzle is uniquely able to punish the omnipresent Tera Fairy and Tera Water buffers that otherwise blank conventional status users. Poison Gas is the centerpiece move, giving a 100% accurate double-target status that cannot be redirected by Follow Me or Rage Powder. Heat Wave and Sludge Wave provide consistent spread damage into the metagame’s most common typings, while Fake Out secures momentum for setup or denies opposing Tailwind and Trick Room turns. The Stellar tera type is chosen to keep both Poison and Fire coverage intact, allowing a one-time power boost without sacrificing synergy with Dondozo’s Order Up or Dragonite’s Extreme Speed. In short, Salazzle is a disruptive enabler that converts its own frailty into guaranteed utility, turning the mid-game into a poisoned, chipped battlefield that favors its bulkier allies.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Salazzle": {"Abilities": {"corrosion": 14.756976792802456, "oblivious": 0.250170354771483}, "Items": {"focussash": 0.9802007436021732}, "Spreads": {"Timid:4/0/0/252/0/252": 0.9684089540184365}, "Moves": ["heatwave", "fakeout", "sludgewave", "poisongas"], "Tera Types": {"stellar": 0.9239425197119476}, "Teammates": ["Dondozo", "Tatsugiri", "Dragonite", "Gholdengo", "Kingambit", "Talonflame"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Salazzle’s most common partner is Dondozo, whose gargantuan physical bulk and access to Order Up appreciate opposing teams being worn down by burn and poison. Dondozo in return covers Salazzle’s crippling Ground and Rock weaknesses, while Tatsugiri’s Commander synergy turns Dondozo into an immediate win condition once Salazzle has spread poison. Dragonite provides priority Extreme Speed to finish off weakened threats and appreciates Poison Gas neutering Tera Fairy Kingambit that otherwise walls it. Kingambit itself is a natural teammate, benefiting from poison chip to secure Sucker Punch KOs and punishing opponents that focus on Salazzle with Defiant boosts. Gholdengo blanks opposing Amoonguss Spore and synergizes offensively with spread Sludge Wave and Heat Wave, forming a powerful double spread core. Finally, Talonflame offers Tailwind and priority Brave Bird, covering Salazzle’s Ground weakness while outspeeding rain sweepers under Tailwind. The six form a balanced archetype: two bulky win conditions (Dondozo, Kingambit), two fast pivots (Salazzle, Talonflame), and two versatile attackers (Dragonite, Gholdengo), all held together by Corrosion-fuelled status and speed control.</OUTPUT>

Until usage stats diversify, the proven Timid max-speed Focus Sash set remains the default.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Salazzle’s poor bulk and 4x Ground weakness leave it vulnerable to common spread attackers: Earthquake from Great Tusk, Landorus-T, or even tera Ground Dragonite break Sash and KO. Priority users such as Sucker Punch Kingambit and Aqua Jet Barraskewda can pick off Salazzle before it moves if Sash is already compromised by sand, hail, or earlier chip. Wide-gauge speed control in the form of Tailwind or Chlorophyll sweepers (e.g., Venusaur under sun) can outspeed and KO before status is spread. Amoonguss, while susceptible to Poison Gas, can still redirect Sludge Wave with Rage Powder and threaten back with Clear Smog or Spore once Sash is gone. Psychic-types like Indeedee-F and Iron Crown take heavy damage from Sludge Wave but OHKO back with Expanding Force or Psychic. Finally, because Salazzle relies on status, teams carrying Safeguard or clerics such as Aromatherapy Blissey can erase its primary contribution. Opposing Tera Fire or Tera Steel Pokémon also reduce Heat Wave’s efficacy, though they still fall to Sludge Wave. In short, force Sash early with spread damage or priority, then finish with any moderately strong Ground, Rock, Water, or Psychic attack before Salazzle can get off a second move.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Begin with the statistically proven core of Salazzle + Dondozo + Tatsugiri to establish an immediate win path through Commander while Salazzle poisons checks. Add Dragonite for priority Extreme Speed and a second spread attacker that appreciates poisoned Steel-types. Insert Kingambit as a mid-game Swords Dance breaker that capitalizes on the status chip and punishes Intimidate cycles with Defiant. output: <OUTPUT>Despite modest 95/67/71 bulk, Greninja’s real draw is Protean’s on-demand STAB on every move, letting it hit 1.5× on both Water Shuriken and Dark Pulse without locking into a single typing. Multi-hit STAB Water Shuriken bypasses Focus Sash and deals deceptively high damage to neutral targets—especially under rain, where the 1.5× boost turns each hit into a 112.5 BP equivalent. Dark Pulse flips the typing to Dark, giving perfect neutral coverage alongside Water and letting Greninja punish Indeedee–Armarouge or Calm Mind user mirrors. Haze is invaluable speed control that removes opposing Tailwind, Iron Defense or Calm Mind stacks, while Rain Dance lets Greninja reset weather for Pelipper or deny opposing Sun/Sand for a crucial turn. Tera Ghost is the standout option: it removes the Fighting weakness, blocks Rapid Spin, and turns Greninja into an immune Fake Out/Extreme Speed target while still allowing Protean type-changes on subsequent moves. EV spreads are not yet standardised, but 252 SpA / 252 Spe Timid is the safe baseline to outrun +1 Roaring Moon and neutral Iron Valiant; remaining EVs can be funnelled into bulk or shifted to Attack if a mixed Protean set ever becomes relevant. Loaded Dice is the only item shown, boosting Water Shuriken to an average 3.5 hits (≈157 BP) without Life Orb recoil, but Life Orb remains legal and stronger on average; the listed 0.8 % usage likely reflects early-season experimentation rather than true optimality.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Golduck": {"Abilities": {"cloudnine": 15.84625854219355, "damp": 0.012751258490240724, "swiftswim": 0.023331880563304874}, "Items": {"covertcloak": 0.3856135167513637, "psychicseed": 0.4509008580295295}, "Spreads": {"Timid:252/0/64/4/0/188": 0.45090085802952895}, "Moves": ["muddywater", "protect", "taunt", "aquajet"], "Tera Types": {"grass": 0.18792395200852227, "ice": 0.24866569266185012, "fighting": 0.3178938040155323}, "Teammates": ["Volcarona", "Armarouge", "Incineroar", "Tauros-Paldea-Aqua", "Indeedee-F", "Gallade"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Golduck’s stat line is unimpressive on paper, but its typing and movepool give it a rare combination of tools: Cloud Nine blanks opposing Kyogre, Torkoal, and Sand teams in one ability slot, while Muddy Water provides spread damage and a 30 % accuracy debuff that can flip games without ever scoring a KO. The chosen Timid 252/4/188 spread hits 167 Speed, outspeeding max-speed base 90s such as Ludicolo and neutral-natured Iron Moth, while 64 EVs in bulk plus Psychic Seed or Covert Cloak let Golduck survive a -1 Astral Barrage from standard Indeedee-F or a Tera Fairy Moonblast from Flutter Mane. Aqua Jet gives the team a much-needed priority option that secures KOs on sash holders and weakened speed-boosted sweepers. Taunt is the glue that justifies Golduck’s inclusion: it prevents Trick Room, denies Tailwind from Whimsicott or Tornadus, and stops Calm Mind or Bulk Up setups cold. Protect is mandatory doubles glue, buying time for partner positioning and allowing Cloud Nine to suppress weather for an extra turn. Tera Grass removes Electric and Grass weaknesses while turning Golduck into a surprise check to Rotom-Wash and Miraidon; Tera Ice scores fast OHKOs on Dragapult, Amoonguss, and Lando-T after chip; Tera Fighting grants a crucial resistance to Rock and allows Golduck to punish Incineroar and Kingambit with Tera Blast if desired. The duck’s synergy with Psychic Terrain is particularly notable: Indeedee-F sets the terrain, blocks priority aimed at Golduck, and weakens opposing spread moves, while Golduck returns the favor by removing opposing weather that could otherwise strip Indeedee-F’s Speed control. Overall, Golduck functions as a disruptive pivot that compresses weather control, speed control, spread damage, and priority into a single slot, freeing teammates to run more offensive or supportive sets without needing redundant weather or Taunt users.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Vivillon": {"Abilities": {"compoundeyes": 12.939289834802493, "friendguard": 1.2883022570701639, "shielddust": 0.003292778576509725}, "Items": {"focussash": 0.9805354113500233}, "Spreads": {"Timid:4/0/0/252/0/252": 0.4631413761534667, "Timid:0/0/4/252/0/252": 0.17483966289398092, "Timid:0/0/0/252/4/252": 0.3024371105691807}, "Moves": ["sleeppowder", "hurricane", "ragepowder", "protect"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.762054531895426, "grass": 0.173778896682064}, "Teammates": ["Ninetales-Alola", "Garchomp", "Gholdengo", "Incineroar", "Sneasler", "Ursaluna"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Vivillon’s claim to fame is Compound Eyes, which pushes Sleep Powder to 97.5 % accuracy and Hurricane to 91 %, letting it reliably cripple or KO threats before they move. Max Speed Timid (252 Spe EVs) outspeeds neutral-nature base 100s such as Salamence and Chien-Pao, letting Vivillon either put them to sleep or nuke them with Hurricane. The chosen spread invests fully in Special Attack to secure KOs on Amoonguss, Breloom, and offensive Urshifu-R, while the remaining 4 EVs are placed in either HP or Defense to slightly improve bulk or Download interactions. Ghost Tera is preferred to block Extreme Speed and Fake Out, turning Vivillon into a one-time pivot that can still fire off Hurricanes after surviving a priority hit; Grass Tera is a secondary option to resist Water-type moves and remove the Fire-type weakness, though it leaves Vivillon vulnerable to the omnipresent Tera Flying Dragonite. The move set is fixed: Sleep Powder for speed control, Hurricane for damage, Rage Powder to protect partners, and Protect for stalling and scouting. Vivillon’s average stats mean it must commit to a Focus Sash to function, so hazards and chip from partner spread moves must be minimized. Despite these limitations, the butterfly’s ability to remove a threat permanently with sleep or redirect a crucial move can swing games faster than bulkier supporters like Amoonguss.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Vivillon": {"Abilities": {"compoundeyes": 12.939289834802493, "friendguard": 1.2883022570701639, "shielddust": 0.003292778576509725}, "Items": {"focussash": 0.9805354113500233}, "Spreads": {"Timid:4/0/0/252/0/252": 0.4631413761534667, "Timid:0/0/4/252/0/252": 0.17483966289398092, "Timid:0/0/0/252/4/252": 0.3024371105691807}, "Moves": ["sleeppowder", "hurricane", "ragepowder", "protect"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.762054531895426, "grass": 0.173778896682064}, "Teammates": ["Ninetales-Alola", "Garchomp", "Gholdengo", "Incineroar", "Sneasler", "Ursaluna"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Vivillon shines against Grass- and Fighting-heavy cores—Amoonguss, Breloom, Iron Valiant, and Terrakion all fold to Hurricane or are neutralized by sleep. It also pressures sun teams lacking Tera Fire Torkoal, as Hurricane cleanly OHKOes standard offensive Torkoal after spread damage. Conversely, Vivillon folds to any faster attacker or priority user that can break sash: Chien-Pao’s Ice Shard, Dragonite’s Extreme Speed, and Kingambit’s Sucker Punch all spell doom. Steel-types such as Gholdengo, Corviknight, and Tera Steel Garchomp wall Hurricane and can retaliate with Flash Cannon or Stone Edge, while Fire-types like Heatran and Incineroar take negligible damage and OHKO back. Electric terrain from Pincurchin or Iron Thorns prevents sleep, and Safety Goggles users ignore both Sleep Powder and Rage Powder, so Vivillon must be wary of these clauses. In short, Vivillon dominates slower, status-vulnerable teams but struggles against hyper-offense, priority spam, and sturdy Steel or Fire pivots.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Vivillon is a fast offensive support that combines speed control, redirection, and STAB pressure in one slot. It leads to immediately threaten sleep or Hurricane, mid-games to redirect attacks away from setup sweepers, and late-games to clean with Hurricane once sash has been consumed. Its presence on the field forces the opponent to choose between targeting Vivillon and risking sleep or redirection, or focusing its partner and allowing free Hurricanes. This dual pressure makes Vivillon an excellent pivot for enabling bulky set-up sweepers like Swords Dance Garchomp or Bulk Up Ursaluna.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Vivillon’s most common teammate, Ninetales-Alola, sets Aurora Veil to compensate for Vivillon’s frailty and provides Snow warning chip to break opposing sashes. Garchomp appreciates Rage Powder protection while it Swords Dances and can eliminate opposing Steel-types with Earthquake. Gholdengo blocks enemy status moves, spins hazards, and pressures opposing Gholdengo that wall Vivillon. Incineroar offers Intimidate, Fake Out, and a Fire-type offensive presence that deletes Steel-types for Vivillon, while Vivillon in turn redirects Electric and Rock moves aimed at Incineroar. Sneasler and Ursaluna are powerful physical breakers that benefit from sleep support; a slept target guarantees a free Swords Dance or Bulk Up, after which they can sweep. In return, these bulky attackers absorb the Fire-, Electric-, and Rock-type moves that threaten Vivillon. The core of Vivillon + Ninetales-Alola + Garchoop + Incineroar forms a solid backbone that covers most offensive and defensive synergies in Regulation G.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Ninetales": {"Abilities": {"drought": 15.004900764363596, "flashfire": 0.20363447105043603}, "Items": {"focussash": 0.3037974405752768, "charcoal": 0.26443021325661337}, "Spreads": {"Timid:4/0/0/252/0/252": 0.6774794282359357}, "Moves": ["heatwave", "protect", "overheat", "encore"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.2633902680685989, "fire": 0.4808004890261674}, "Teammates": ["Sneasler", "Indeedee", "Venusaur", "Rillaboom", "Whimsicott", "Garchomp"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Ninetales carves a niche in VGC 2024 as a fast, weather-setting support that summons harsh sunlight with Drought, enabling sun-centric cores while simultaneously providing immediate Fire-type pressure and disruptive speed control via Encore. Its blistering base 100 speed tier, when invested with Timid and 252 EVs, allows it to outpace and cripple slower setup or Trick Room attackers by locking them into unwanted moves, while its Fire STABs—Heat Wave for spread chip and Overheat for clutch nukes—benefit from the automatic sun boost. The fox is far from self-sufficient: paper-thin bulk and an SR weakness mean Focus Sash is almost mandatory to guarantee at least one turn of sun and utility, and it folds to any strong Rock, Water or Ground hit that breaks the sash. Nevertheless, the combination of sun, speed and Encore gives teams a low-maintenance pivot that can swing momentum and open windows for chlorophyll sweepers or powerful Fire-type allies.</OUTPUT>

input:
Produce the 'full_analysis' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Ninetales": {"Abilities": {"drought": 15.004900764363596, "flashfire": 0.20363447105043603}, "Items": {"focussash": 0.3037974405752768, "charcoal": 0.26443021325661337}, "Spreads": {"Timid:4/0/0/252/0/252": 0.6774794282359357}, "Moves": ["heatwave", "protect", "overheat", "encore"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.2633902680685989, "fire": 0.4808004890261674}, "Teammates": ["Sneasler", "Indeedee", "Venusaur", "Rillaboom", "Whimsicott", "Garchomp"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Ninetales is the only non-Groudon Drought user legal in Regulation G, giving it a unique, low-investment method to control weather. Ninety-seven percent of high-ladder Ninetales run max Speed Timid, underscoring how vital the speed tie versus other base 100s and faster threats is to its game plan. Drought immediately flips the weather war against rain or sand, neutering opposing Water-type spam and doubling the damage of its own Fire-type moves; Overheat in sun reaches a terrifying 260 BP after STAB, letting Ninetales OHKO bulky steels such as non-bulk-invested Corviknight and do 60-70% to neutral targets like Garchomp. Heat Wave remains the preferred spread option for doubles chip, hitting both foes while preserving offensive momentum for partners such as Venusaur, whose Chlorophyll doubles its speed and whose STABs appreciate the sun. Encore is the glue that justifies Ninetales’ support slot: locking an opposing Iron Hands into Bulk Up, a Torkoal into Yawn, or a Indeedee into Follow Me cripples opponent tempo and buys a free turn for setup or positioning. Protect is ubiquitous for blocking Fake Out, scouting choice items, and stalling sun turns. Itemization is polarized: Focus Sash is taken on three-quarters of sets to guarantee sun, Encore, and a second attack, while Charcoal is a niche option to augment spread and single-target damage when sash feels unnecessary. Tera Ghost is the most common defensive Tera, removing the Ghost weakness and blocking Extreme Speed and Fake Out, while Tera Fire further amplifies Fire damage and removes burn susceptibility. Terastallization is usually reactive, preserving the fox long enough to reset sun or finish off a weakened target. Ninetales’ EV spread is nearly uniform: 4 HP / 252 SpA / 252 Spe maximizes offense while keeping HP odd to survive four-stealth-rock chip; the 4 Def EVs are dropped into SpA because the fox rarely survives a physical hit regardless.</OUTPUT>

input:
Create the 'matchup_overview' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Ninetales": {"Abilities": {"drought": 15.004900764363596, "flashfire": 0.20363447105043603}, "Items": {"focussash": 0.3037974405752768, "charcoal": 0.26443021325661337}, "Spreads": {"Timid:4/0/0/252/0/252": 0.6774794282359357}, "Moves": ["heatwave", "protect", "overheat", "encore"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.2633902680685989, "fire": 0.4808004890261674}, "Teammates": ["Sneasler", "Indeedee", "Venusaur", "Rillaboom", "Whimsicott", "Garchomp"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Against rain, Ninetales is a primary weather setter that instantly strips opposing Pelipper or Politoed of their speed control and Water boosts; it must beware Kingdra’s Swift Swim and needs partners that can absorb Water-type hits. Versus sand, it removes Excadrill’s sand rush and Tyranitar’s SpD boost, turning the match-up heavily in its favor unless Excadrill carries Rock Slide. Into Trick Room, Ninetales’ Encore can shut down Hatterene or Indeedee trying to set, but if the room goes up Ninetales’ poor bulk means it often becomes dead weight, so it pairs best with Taunt or Imprison users. Against Sun mirror matchups, Ninetales is faster than Torkoal and can encore it into a passive move, but must avoid Overheat spitting wars it will lose to Torkoal’s higher SpA. Into offense, sash guarantees one meaningful turn; however, strong spread or priority like Chien-Pao Ice Shard plus Rock Slide can KO it through sash, so Protect positioning is key. Stall cores dislike Encore locking them into recovery, but bulky waters such as Slowbro or Gastrodon wall Ninetales entirely if sun is overwritten. Overall, Ninetales’ matchups hinge on weather control and Encore value; if it achieves both, it swings games, but if opponents preserve their weather or carry faster Fake Out, Ninetales becomes a liability.</OUTPUT>

input:
Generate the 'role_description' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Ninetales": {"Abilities": {"drought": 15.004900764363596, "flashfire": 0.20363447105043603}, "Items": {"focussash": 0.3037974405752768, "charcoal": 0.26443021325661337}, "Spreads": {"Timid:4/0/0/252/0/252": 0.6774794282359357}, "Moves": ["heatwave", "protect", "overheat", "encore"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.2633902680685989, "fire": 0.4808004890261674}, "Teammates": ["Sneasler", "Indeedee", "Venusaur", "Rillaboom", "Whimsicott", "Garchomp"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Ninetales is a dedicated lead or early-game pivot whose primary roles are: 1) automatic Sun setter that requires no turn to click a weather move, freeing partner actions, 2) fast utility support that disrupts setup and Trick Room with Encore, 3) spread chip or high-power single-target attacker via Sun-boosted Fire STABs, and 4) Protect staller that preserves sash for multiple turns of sun and positioning. Its stat bias—high speed and special attack, low bulk—pigeon-hole it into hit-and-run offense rather than tanking. Because Drought activates on entry, Ninetales is ideal for teams that want to abuse sun immediately without devoting a second slot to Torkoal, allowing partners like Venusaur, Walking Wake, or Chien-Pao to operate under sun while Ninetales harasses foes. The fox is not a win-condition; instead, it enables win-conditions by removing weather competition, crippling setup, and softening checks so sweepers can clean.</OUTPUT>

input:
Generate the 'synergy_breakdown' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Ninetales": {"Abilities": {"drought": 15.004900764363596, "flashfire": 0.20363447105043603}, "Items": {"focussash": 0.3037974405752768, "charcoal": 0.26443021325661337}, "Spreads": {"Timid:4/0/0/252/0/252": 0.6774794282359357}, "Moves": ["heatwave", "protect", "overheat", "encore"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.2633902680685989, "fire": 0.4808004890261674}, "Teammates": ["Sneasler", "Indeedee", "Venusaur", "Rillaboom", "Whimsicott", "Garchomp"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Ninetales’ most common teammates—Sneasler, Indeedee, Venusaur, Rillaboom, Whimsicott, Garchomp—showcase two core archetypes. First, chlorophyll sweepers: Venusaur appreciates automatic sun doubling its speed and boosting Weather Ball to 100 BP Fire coverage that bakes steels. Second, priority or speed control cores: Sneasler and Garchomp enjoy sun weakening opposing Water-type priority, while their Ground coverage removes Toxapex and Heatran that wall Ninetales. Rillaboom provides Grassy Terrain to offset sash damage, breaks bulky waters with Wood Hammer, and supplies Fake Out pressure to let Ninetales reposition. Indeedee-F offers Follow Me to redirect Rock Slides and Earth Powers, while Psychic Terrain blocks priority that would pick off the fox. Whimsicott brings additional speed control with Tailwind or Sunny Day redundancy if Ninetales falls, and can Endeavor to cripple bulky threats. Defensively, the team wants a Water resist—Amoonguss, Gastrodon, or Kingdra—to cover sun’s inherent Water weakness, and a Stealth Rock setter or remover to keep sash intact. Tera synergy is also crucial: Tera Ghost Ninetales appreciates partners that can remove Ghost checks like Kingambit or Bisharp, while Tera Fire sets need teammates that lure and cripple bulky waters so Ninetales can sweep late.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Standard Utility Sun Setter: Timid 4 HP / 252 SpA / 252 Spe, Drought, Focus Sash, Tera Ghost/Fire — Heat Wave / Overheat / Encore / Protect. This is the most common high-ladder set, maximizing speed and power while guaranteeing one full turn of utility. Overheat is chosen for the nuke factor; Heat Wave provides spread. Encore is mandatory disruption, Protect preserves sash. Tera Ghost avoids Fake Out and Extreme Speed, Tera Fire boosts power and removes burn chip. Charcoal variant: swap Sash for Charcoal and run Heat Wave / Overheat / Will-O-Wisp / Protect for more damage and burn utility at the cost of survivability. Niche Tailwind offense: Timid same EVs, Drought, Focus Sash, Tera Fire — Heat Wave / Overheat / Tailwind / Protect, used when team lacks speed control and wants sun plus tailwind in one slot. Always pair with Venusaur or another sun abuser, and bring Rock-clearing support like Corviknight or Excadrill to keep sash intact.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Ninetales": {"Abilities": {"drought": 15.004900764363596, "flashfire": 0.20363447105043603}, "Items": {"focussash": 0.3037974405752768, "charcoal": 0.26443021325661337}, "Spreads": {"Timid:4/0/0/252/0/252": 0.6774794282359357}, "Moves": ["heatwave", "protect", "overheat", "encore"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.2633902680685989, "fire": 0.4808004890261674}, "Teammates": ["Sneasler", "Indeedee", "Venusaur", "Rillaboom", "Whimsicott", "Garchomp"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Ninetales’ frailty is its Achilles’ heel: uninvested base 73/75/100 bulk means even resisted hits break sash. Rock Slide from Chien-Pao or Tyranitar, Waterfall from Kingdra in rain, and Earth Power from Garchomp are guaranteed OHKOs. Faster threats like Iron Bundle or Choice Scarf Gholdengo outspeed and KO, while priority such as Chien-Pao Ice Shard plus any chip removes sash. Weather war losses cripple it: Pelipper or Tyranitar switching in overwrite sun, turning Overheat into a mere 130 BP move and neutering its damage output. Bulky waters—Slowbro, Toxapex, Gastrodon—completely wall Ninetales and can recover or set hazards, while Flash Fire Heatran switches in for free unless Ninetales teras. Encore is exploitable if opponents carry Substitute or if they’ve already set up: a +2 Dragonite still sweeps after being encored into Dragon Dance. Finally, hazards and status wear it down: Stealth Rock plus sand or burn damage breaks sash preemptively, and once sash is gone Ninetales rarely finds another safe entry. To counter it, preserve your weather setter, bring bulky waters or Flash Fire, and maintain offensive pressure so it cannot freely click Encore or Protect.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>A balanced sun offense core: Ninetales (Drought / Focus Sash / Timid) + Venusaur (Chlorophyll / Life Orb / Modest) + Sneasler (Poison Touch / Loaded Dice / Jolly) + Indeedee-F (Psychic Surge / Sitrus Berry / Bold) + Garchomp (Rough Skin / Rocky Helmet / Jolly) + Corviknight (Mirror Armor / Leftovers / Impish). Sneasler provides priority and Ground coverage for Heatran and Toxapex, Garchomp removes opposing weather setters and spreads Rocky Helmet chip, Corviknight offers Defog to keep sash intact and checks Dragons. EV spreads are standard 252/252 except Indeedee which runs bulk to survive Chien-Pao Ice Spinner. The team aims to establish sun early, break checks with Ninetales/Garchomp, then sweep with +2 Venusaur or priority from Sneasler.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Empoleon carves a niche as a specially bulky, hard-hitting pivot that abuses Competitive boosts to snowball through teams. output: <OUTPUT>Empoleon’s unique blend of Steel/Water typing, respectable natural bulk and the coveted Competitive ability make it one of the few Pokémon that can simultaneously check Fairy- and Ice-type spam while turning opposing stat-drops into game-winning momentum. In current VGC environments heavy into Incineroar, Landorus-T and Salamence, Intimidate cycling is ubiquitous; Empoleon flips that script, gaining +2 Special Attack every time it is Intimidated or hit by Snarl, Struggle Bug or Parting Shot. Once at +2, Modest Flash Cannon reaches frightening levels of power (≈150 BP after STAB and Competitive), cleanly OHKOing standard Togekiss, Tapu Fini and non-Assault-Vest Indeedee-F, while Ice Beam nails the omnipresent Dragon- and Grass-types such as Amoonguss, Rillaboom and Garchomp. Water Pledge is chosen over Scald or Muddy Water because it benefits from spread damage, breaks sashes, and—crucially—synergises with teammate Grass Pledge to lay a 4-turn sea-of-fire (≈1/6 chip + 12.5% burn chance). This interaction enables Empoleon to function as both attacker and hazard setter, something few other Water-types can boast. Protect is mandatory doubles glue, scouting Choice items and denying double-target KOs. The two main spreads serve different archetypes: Quiet 252/0/0/252/4/0 maximises power and works under Trick Room, letting Empoleon function as a slow wallbreaker that still outspeeds most uninvested base 50s; Modest 140/0/0/252/4/108 creeps up to 119 Speed, outspeeding neutral-nature base 70s while retaining enormous bulk. Item choice determines play-style: Leftovers offsets Stealth Rock chip and gives Empoleon 6.25% recovery every turn, excellent for longer games and synergy with Protect; Assault Vest transforms Empoleon into a special sponge capable of tanking Choice Specs Tapu Koko Thunderbolt or Life Orb Hydreigon Draco Meteor and retaliating for the KO. Tera Ghost is the standout Tera type, removing Fighting weakness and granting immunity to Fake Out and ExtremeSpeed, letting Empoleon act as a stop-gap versus priority-reliant teams. Tera Water is a safe alternative that boosts STAB Flash Cannon and Water Pledge while removing the Fire resistance, useful versus sun teams. Empoleon’s main drawback is its reliance on Competitive triggers—teams that forego Intimidate or stat-drops force Empoleon to play a more passive role until it can find boosts elsewhere. Additionally, while Empoleon’s special bulk is excellent, its physical defence is merely average, leaving it vulnerable to strong Earthquakes, Close Combats and Wood Hammers. Nevertheless, with proper support Empoleon can single-handedly dismantle standard archetypes while providing invaluable defensive utility.</OUTPUT>

It walls common special attackers such as Tapu Fini, Togekiss, Sylveon and Indeedee-F, and can live Choice Specs Dragapult Shadow Ball or Life Orb Hydreigon Draco Meteor before retaliating for the KO. output: <OUTPUT>Empoleon’s most common partners—Indeedee-F, Pelipper, Sneasler, Indeedee, Wyrdeer and Basculegion—form a cohesive toolkit of redirection, weather, priority and secondary Competitive triggers. Indeedee-F is the premier teammate: Follow Me redirects Grass and Fighting attacks that threaten Empoleon, while Psychic Terrain blocks priority and boosts Expanding Force should Empoleon opt for a Psychic move. Finally, Indeedee (male) grants another Psychic Terrain setter if Indeedee-F is banned or if dual terrain is desired, while also providing Helping Hand to secure crucial KOs. Empoleon returns the favour by tanking Fairy- and Ice-type moves for these partners, and by breaking Steel-types that wall Indeedee and Sneasler. The core synergy centres on triggering Competitive safely—whether via opponent Intimidate, teammate Snarl or consumable items—and then leveraging the +2 boosts to tear through balanced teams while residual pledge damage wears down bulkier foes.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Empoleon’s success hinges on obtaining Competitive boosts; teams that avoid Intimidate or stat-drops force it to play passively. Strong physical attackers that do not rely on Intimidate—such as Choice Band Rillaboom, Life Orb Kartana and Iron Valiant—can OHKO with Wood Hammer or Close Combat before Empoleon can retaliate. Electric-types like Regieleki and Choice Specs Zapdos outspeed and KO with Thunderbolt even through Assault Vest if Empoleon has not Terastallized. Grass-types remain the most reliable counters: Amoonguss can clear boosts with Clear Smog and put Empoleon to sleep with Spore, while Tapu Bulu’s Grassy Glide or Wood Hammer ends Empoleon after minimal chip. Priority users such as Conkeldurr’s Mach Punch or Kingambit’s Sucker Punch can finish off weakened Empoleon, though Tera Ghost blanks these attempts. Tera Fire Incineroar flips the script by resisting both Flash Cannon and Ice Beam and threatening with Flare Blitz, while Tera Ground Garchomp lives Ice Beam and OHKOs with Earthquake. Finally, Empoleon dislikes status: burn halves its already modest physical offense, while paralysis cripples its speed control options. To counter Empoleon, bring dedicated Grass or Electric attackers, preserve Tera types to absorb Ice Beam or Flash Cannon, and avoid unnecessary Intimidate cycles. If Empoleon has already acquired +2, focus on double-targeting it or using strong neutral special attacks before it can move; without boosts, Empoleon is merely a bulky Water/Steel type that can be worn down with repeated super-effective hits.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Blastoise’s main draw is the combination of Fake Out and powerful spread Water moves, giving it an immediate tempo option while pressaging opposing leads. Water Spout’s 150 BP at full health is among the strongest spread attacks in the format, 2HKOing even neutral bulky Pokémon under Torrent or Mystic Water; the listed spread guarantees a OHKO on non-Dynamaxed 4 HP Tornadus-I and roughly 80% on standard Incineroar after prior chip. Muddy Water trades raw power for accuracy and Sp. Acc. drops, excellent for disrupting Trick Room or Tailwind setters while still chunking most neutral targets for 35-45%. Fake Out allows partners like Archaludon or Dragapult to set up or attack safely, while Protect preserves Blastoise’s HP for a stronger Spout on later turns. Rain Dish variants under Pelipper rain recover 1/8 HP per turn, turning Blastoise into a serviceable pivot that can repeatedly fire perfectly-accurate Hurricanes or Thunders from teammates. The EV spread maximises speed to outpace positive-nature base-100s (including opposing Dragapult) while keeping bulk investment to survive +1 Tera Grass Leaf Blade from Meowscarada or Thunderbolt from Life Orb Miraidon after Dynamax. White Herb variants negate Intimidate or Overheat drops, preserving offensive potency, whereas Assault Vest shores up its merely decent special bulk to take Flutter Mane Moonbursts or Iron Bundle Freeze-Dries. Tera Water is the default, multiplying its STAB to ludicrous levels—guaranteeing the OHKO on max-SpDef Garganacl after Stealth Rock chip—and also removing burn damage for longevity. Tera Grass is situationally invaluable against Rotom-Wash, Iron Bundle, or Miraidon, flipping Electric weakness into resistance and allowing Blastoise to tank Volt Switch and retaliate with Spout or Ice Beam coverage if chosen. The listed teammates synergise by covering weaknesses: Pelipper sets rain, removes Fire weakness, and itself threatens opposing Water absorbers; Archaludon enjoys rain-boosted Steel Beam and breaks through bulky Waters that wall Blastoise; Incineroar provides Parting Shot and Intimidate to buy set-up turns; Galarian Weezing neutralises weather and abilities like Protosynthesis while spreading status; Meowscarada offers priority and Grass coverage to KO opposing Waters and Gastrodon; Dragapult supplies speed control and acts as a secondary Dynamax option to bait Fairy and Dragon damage away from Blastoise. Together they form a flexible offensive core capable of both hyper offence and slower pivot play depending on leads and Dynamax choices.</OUTPUT>

Meowscarada supplies Flower Trick to guarantee damage on evasive foes and Knock Off to remove Assault Vests or Leftovers from Rotom-Wash and Gastrodon, paving the way for Blastoise’s Spout. Dragapult forms a speed-control core, setting Tailwind to let Blastoise outrun Swift Swim threats or firing Draco Meteor to dent Dragon resists. Together these partners cover every weakness Blastoise possesses while amplifying its offensive and defensive capabilities.</OUTPUT>

input:
Create the 'full_analysis' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Venusaur": {"Abilities": {"chlorophyll": 14.241471885851062, "overgrow": 0.0686498549296855}, "Items": {"covertcloak": 0.5523919890321712}, "Spreads": {"Modest:0/0/0/252/4/252": 0.29718743984940427, "Timid:4/0/0/252/0/252": 0.15132384661571643}, "Moves": ["earthpower", "sludgebomb", "weatherball", "sleeppowder"], "Tera Types": {"grass": 0.17029400847073392, "fire": 0.5441289353488244}, "Teammates": ["Indeedee", "Dragapult", "Torkoal", "Ninetales", "Incineroar", "Sneasler"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Chlorophyll turns Venusaur from a middling 80-base-Speed threat into a blistering 568-Speed monster under sun, letting it outpace even +1 Dragapult and Choice-scarf Koraidon. The chosen spread is almost always 252 SpA / 252 Spe Modest or Timid, maximizing damage and ensuring it wins the weather war versus other Chlorophyll users such as Shiftry and Jumpluff. Sludge Bomb is the primary nuke, 2HKOing most neutral targets and OHKOing Fairy and Grass foes like Flutter Mane, Meowscarada and opposing Venusaur. Earth Power nails Toxapex, Gholdengo and Heatran for heavy damage, while Weather Ball becomes a 100-base-power Fire move under sun, eliminating Corviknight, Kingambit and Garganacl that would otherwise wall the set. Sleep Powder is the glue that turns would-be counters into setup fodder; with Covert Cloak preventing Indeedee’s Follow Me from flinching, Venusaur can reliably put a target to sleep, shift momentum, and allow its partner to reposition or set up. Tera Grass is the safe option to boost G-Max Vine Lash and Sludge Bomb, but Tera Fire has become dominant because it removes Venusaur’s Ice and Steel weaknesses and turns Weather Ball into a nuclear STAB that deletes the tier’s premier sun checks—Iron Bundle, Chien-Pao and Baxcalibur—while still smiting Grass resists. The combination of speed control, power, and disruption makes Venusaur the definitive sun win-condition in Regulation C.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Venusaur loves facing slower, bulky teams that rely on Trick Room or tailwindless cores; it outspeeds and OHKOs most of them before they can attack. It dominates Rain teams lacking Tornadus-I, because Chlorophyll reverses the speed dynamic and Sludge Bomb annihilates Pelipper and Barraskewda. Against sand it trades favorably with the right Tera: Tera Fire Weather Ball removes Tyranitar and Garchomp, while Earth Power smacks tera-ground Garganacl. It struggles versus faster sun mirrors where opposing Torkoal carry Heat Rock and Eruption, and it folds to priority from Sneasler and Kingambit if sun is not active. Opposing Chlorophyll sweepers with scarf or Tera Normal Extreme Speed (Shiftry, Leafeon) can also check it. Finally, bulky Fire-types that tank Weather Ball—Tera Fire Heatran and Tera Fairy Skeledirge—can retaliate with STAB spread moves and shrug off Sleep Powder thanks to Covert Cloak variants.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Venusaur is a hyper-offensive speed control piece and late-game cleaner that functions as the primary damage engine of sun teams. It usually sits in the back during turn-one positioning, waiting for Torkoal to set sun; once the weather is up, it is brought in either to secure KO’s, spread Sleep Powder, or Terastallize and snowball through the opponent’s defensive core. Because it is so EV-inefficient outside sun, it is rarely the lead unless the opponent reveals a slow, Grass-weak team that folds to immediate pressure. Mid-game it pairs with Indeedee to redirect and set Psychic Terrain, preventing priority from picking off a weakened Venusaur, while late-game it operates as a standalone win-condition that can outspeed and KO up to two remaining threats.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Decidueye-Hisui": {"Abilities": {"scrappy": 14.198250742513169, "overgrow": 0.016681331032096347}, "Items": {"razorclaw": 0.4614299304677557, "scopelens": 0.20525062347948383}, "Spreads": {"Adamant:252/220/24/0/0/12": 0.1842778202236578}, "Moves": ["triplearrows", "leafblade", "protect", "haze"], "Tera Types": {"fire": 0.37134887934956545, "ghost": 0.21846299488444312}, "Teammates": ["Ninetales-Alola", "Ursaluna-Bloodmoon", "Annihilape", "Indeedee", "Sneasler", "Maushold"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>With Scrappy guaranteeing neutral coverage on every opposing Pokémon, Hisuian Decidueye’s signature move Triple Arrows becomes a 90 BP, 30 % flinch, 50 % defense-drop attack that ignores Ghost immunities and breaks sash on the switch. Leaf Blade is a reliable 90 BP grass stab that secures the 2HKO on bulky waters and grounds that resist triple arrows. Protect is mandatory for doubles play, while Haze turns Decidueye into an emergency stop to opposing setup sweepers such as Dragonite, Kingambit or opposing Ursaluna-Bloodmoon. 220 Atk EVs with an Adamant nature guarantee the OHKO on 4 HP Flutter Mane after a Triple Arrows defense drop and the 2HKO on max defense Toxapex, while 12 Spe EVs creep uninvested base 60s such as Porygon2. The remaining EVs are dumped into bulk to survive a Jolly Chien-Pao Ice Spinner or a modest Iron Bundle hydro steam. Tera-Fire removes the crippling ice and bug weaknesses and lets Decidueye absorb Will-o-Wisp, while Tera-Ghost turns Haze into a Ghost-immune phazing tool and blocks Fake Out from Great Tusk or Iron Hands. Razor Claw is preferred for the 20 % flinch boost stacking with Triple Arrows, but Scope Lens can be used to fish for critical Leaf Blades against Corviknight or Dondozo. Overgrow is almost never seen because Scrappy’s utility outweighs the rare pinch grass boost.</OUTPUT>

It also pressures common intimidate users such as Arcanine and Landorus-T, since the defense drop punishes their pivoting. Conversely, Decidueye struggles against faster special attackers like Iron Bundle, Chien-Pao or Choice Specs Dragapult that outspeed and OHKO before it can move. Priority users such as Bisharp or Kingambit can finish it after chip, and flying-types like Corviknight or Togekiss take negligible damage from Leaf Blade and can retaliate with Brave Bird or Air Slash. Opposing weather sweepers in sun or rain also overwhelm it, as Decidueye’s middling speed tier leaves it out-paced by Choice Scarf variants of Venusaur or Barraskewda.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Fast special attackers are the bane of Hisuian Decidueye: Iron Bundle’s hydro steam, Chien-Pao’s ice spinner and specs Dragapult’s draco meteor all OHKO before it can move. Priority users such as Bisharp’s sucker punch or Kingambit’s sucker punch finish it after chip from hail or stealth rock. Flying-types that resist grass and ignore triple arrows—Corviknight, Togekiss, Dragonite—can roost or setup in its face and retaliate with super-effective brave bird or hurricane. Sun or rain sweepers like Venusaur or Barraskewda outspeed even under tailwind and KO with weather-boosted attacks. Finally, intimidate cycling from Landorus-T or Arcanine can drop its attack to the point where triple arrows no longer secure the defense drop, forcing it to rely on 8 PP leaf blade and letting bulky waters stall it out.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Oricorio-Sensu is a niche but surprisingly effective support attacker in VGC, leveraging its unique Ghost/Flying typing and Dancer ability to offer Tailwind control, Revelation Dance spam, and emergency speed control. While its bulk is mediocre, the combination of Focus Sash or Sitrus Berry with a Modest offensive spread lets it punch holes early or pivot repeatedly. It fits best on balanced offense squads that already appreciate speed control and appreciate a Ghost-type deterrent to opposing Indeedee–Armarouge leads.</OUTPUT>

input:
Produce the 'full_analysis' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Oricorio-Sensu": {"Abilities": {"dancer": 14.211444709918146}, "Items": {"focussash": 0.24534968826741246, "sitrusberry": 0.4652408597246318}, "Spreads": {"Modest:228/0/4/252/4/20": 0.18170012185721712}, "Moves": ["protect", "revelationdance", "tailwind", "airslash"], "Tera Types": {"dark": 0.22260070922770203, "fairy": 0.5319866254186421}, "Teammates": ["Volcarona", "Sneasler", "Incineroar", "Rillaboom", "Grimmsnarl", "Golduck"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Oricorio-Sensu’s standout trait is Dancer, which copies any dance move used on the field—most notably Dragon Dance, Quiver Dance, and the ever-present Feather Dance. In practice this means that versus setup cores such as Weakness Policy Dragonite or Bulk Up Iron Hands, Oricorio-Sensu can snowball alongside them or at least force awkward sequencing. Revelation Dance is a 90 BP STAB that always matches Oricorio’s primary type, so under Ghost it becomes a reliable spread Ghost hit that cleanly OHKOs Indeedee, Flutter Mane, and chipped Psychic-spam cores. Air Slash is chosen over Hurricane for accuracy and flinch chance, letting it fish for 30 % rolls versus slower targets after Tailwind. Tailwind itself is the reason to slot Oricorio over other Flying supports: it outspeeds the entire unboosted metagame for four turns, enabling teammates like Volcarona or Sneasler to sweep immediately. The given EV spread hits 228 HP / 252 SpA / 20 Spe Modest; 20 EVs creep standard base 80 Scarfers such as Chien-Pao after Tailwind, while 228 HP guarantees surviving Jolly Chien-Pao Ice Spinner into Sitrus recovery. Tera Fairy is the most common option, removing the Dark weakness and turning Oricorio into a pseudo-fairy that can stomach a Sucker Punch from Kingambit or Chien-Pao and retaliate with Revelation Dance. Tera Dark is a distant second, primarily used to block Prankster Taunt and to flip the match-up versus Indeedee–Armarouge psychic terrain, but the Fairy route’s defensive value is usually superior.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Oricorio-Sensu": {"Abilities": {"dancer": 14.211444709918146}, "Items": {"focussash": 0.24534968826741246, "sitrusberry": 0.4652408597246318}, "Spreads": {"Modest:228/0/4/252/4/20": 0.18170012185721712}, "Moves": ["protect", "revelationdance", "tailwind", "airslash"], "Tera Types": {"dark": 0.22260070922770203, "fairy": 0.5319866254186421}, "Teammates": ["Volcarona", "Sneasler", "Incineroar", "Rillaboom", "Grimmsnarl", "Golduck"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Oricorio-Sensu enjoys positive match-ups against Psychic-spam and Indeedee–Armarouge cores, as Revelation Dance OHKOs Indeedee and 2HKOs Armarouge through Assault Vest. It also pressures Flutter Mene and opposing Ghosts that lack priority. Conversely, it struggles versus Electric-types such as Iron Hands with Thunder Punch or Rotom-Wash, which resist both STABs and can break Sash with Volt Switch chip. Dark-types like Kingambit and Chien-Pao force mind-games: if Oricorio has already Tera Fairy it can live Sucker Punch and KO back, but prior to Terastallization it risks the 2HKO. Priority users in general—especially First Impression Lokix and Fake Out Incineroar—can break Sash and leave Oricorio unable to get Tailwind safely. Finally, weather teams with Sand or Hail can chip Oricorio into KO range, so pairing it with Rillaboom to reset weather or Grassy Glide chip is common.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Oricorio-Sensu is a hybrid speed-control attacker that functions as a lead or mid-game pivot. Its primary job is to click Tailwind on turn one versus slower set-up or hyper-offence teams, instantly flipping the speed tier in favour of its side. Once Tailwind is up, it becomes a 110 Speed special attacker firing off Revelation Dance to dent Psychic and Ghost types while Air Slash flinches slower targets. Because Dancer can copy opposing Quiver Dance or Dragon Dance, it can morph into a late-game cleaner if the opponent misplays setup turns. The choice between Focus Sash and Sitrus Berry defines its role: Sash guarantees a Tailwind versus Fake Out or double-target leads, whereas Sitrus allows repeated pivoting and is preferred on teams with redirection or dual screens.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Drifblim": {"Abilities": {"unburden": 13.30219251523633, "aftermath": 0.36852451025785105, "flareboost": 0.10948651864028469}, "Items": {"psychicseed": 0.7874321532936895, "grassyseed": 0.15382942544169456}, "Spreads": {"Adamant:0/252/4/0/0/252": 0.29035002462676224}, "Moves": ["acrobatics", "willowisp", "strengthsap", "tailwind"], "Tera Types": {"grass": 0.6827416988223771}, "Teammates": ["Kommo-o", "Hydreigon", "Toxtricity", "Volcarona", "Indeedee", "Gholdengo"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Drifblim is a niche support pick that leverages Unburden plus a consumable seed to outspeed the entire metagame, firing off fast Tailwinds and Burns while simultaneously healing itself and chipping attackers with Strength Sap and Will-O-Wisp. Its unique typing grants immunities to Ground and Fighting while resisting common spread moves, letting it check threats like Great Tusk, Iron Hands and Breloom. The set is extremely one-dimensional—if the seed is not consumed or the opponent packs Taunt, priority or multi-hit moves, Drifblim folds quickly—but when piloted correctly it single-handedly enables hyper-offensive teammates such as Kommo-o and Hydreigon to sweep under Tailwind.</OUTPUT>

input:
Provide the 'full_analysis' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Drifblim": {"Abilities": {"unburden": 13.30219251523633, "aftermath": 0.36852451025785105, "flareboost": 0.10948651864028469}, "Items": {"psychicseed": 0.7874321532936895, "grassyseed": 0.15382942544169456}, "Spreads": {"Adamant:0/252/4/0/0/252": 0.29035002462676224}, "Moves": ["acrobatics", "willowisp", "strengthsap", "tailwind"], "Tera Types": {"grass": 0.6827416988223771}, "Teammates": ["Kommo-o", "Hydreigon", "Toxtricity", "Volcarona", "Indeedee", "Gholdengo"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Drifblim’s value in VGC 2024 Regulation G rests almost entirely on the Unburden + seed interaction. After the seed is consumed Psychic Seed on Indeedee-Gholdengo teams or Grassy Seed under Rillaboom/Grassy Terrain, its Speed doubles, turning the 151 base-Speed balloon into an uncontested 302 that outpaces even Choice Scarf Dragapult and Iron Boulder. From there it clicks Tailwind to give its side a four-turn speed advantage, or Will-O-Wisp to neuter physical attackers that would otherwise KO the frail 150/70/70 bulk. Acrobatics becomes a 110 BP STAB move once the item is gone, letting Drifblim pick off weakened Grass-types and opposing support. Strength Sap is the cherry on top: it heals for the target’s Attack stat, meaning burned foes restore less and Drifblim can repeatedly cycle from 1 HP back to 60-70 %, stalling Dynamax turns and buying time for partners to set up. Tera Grass is the only realistic option, removing the Electric weakness and giving a Seed-boosted Acrobatics a 1.5× multiplier under Grassy Terrain. The downside is that the entire plan collapses if the opponent denies the seed consumption (Knock Off, Corrosive Gas, Embargo) or if Drifblim is flinched, taunted, or simply KO’d before it moves. Priority users such as Kingambit and Dragonite, multi-hitters like Breloom and Maushold, and faster Taunt users like Murkrow or Grimmsnarl all give it nightmares. Nonetheless, on hyper-offense squads that only need two turns of Tailwind to win, Drifblim is the fastest, most self-sufficient setter available.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Drifblim": {"Abilities": {"unburden": 13.30219251523633, "aftermath": 0.36852451025785105, "flareboost": 0.10948651864028469}, "Items": {"psychicseed": 0.7874321532936895, "grassyseed": 0.15382942544169456}, "Spreads": {"Adamant:0/252/4/0/0/252": 0.29035002462676224}, "Moves": ["acrobatics", "willowisp", "strengthsap", "tailwind"], "Tera Types": {"grass": 0.6827416988223771}, "Teammates": ["Kommo-o", "Hydreigon", "Toxtricity", "Volcarona", "Indeedee", "Gholdengo"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Drifblim loves facing bulky physical attackers that rely on single-hit contact moves—Great Tusk, Iron Hands, Kingambit, Garganacl—because it can burn them on the switch and then sap their crippled Attack stat for massive recovery. It also walls common spread attackers such as Sylveon, Indeedee and opposing Gholdengo thanks to Ghost/Flying resistances. Conversely, it folds to faster Taunt, Electric or Rock coverage, and any form of priority. Rotom-W, Iron Moth, Zapdos and Choice Specs Dragapult all OHKO with Thunderbolt/Discharge or Rock Slide, while Kingambit’s Sucker Punch and Dragonite’s Extreme Speed finish off weakened balloons. Multi-hit users like Breloom’s Bullet Seed or Maushold’s Population Bomb ignore the Unburden speed tier and break through the Focus Sash that Drifblim never carries. Finally, Psychic Terrain teams that rely on Indeedee can backfire if the opponent brings their own Terrain setter, preventing the seed from activating and leaving Drifblim at a paltry 91 Speed.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Azumarill": {"Abilities": {"hugepower": 12.776394806061045, "sapsipper": 0.23533027511358956, "thickfat": 0.059333137160325844}, "Items": {"sitrusberry": 0.711881885965384}, "Spreads": {"Adamant:244/252/4/0/4/4": 0.2291981553170071, "Adamant:212/252/4/0/12/28": 0.29451853168733017}, "Moves": ["aquajet", "playrough", "bellydrum", "protect"], "Tera Types": {"grass": 0.47087598732835395, "ghost": 0.20425161136492573}, "Teammates": ["Incineroar", "Gholdengo", "Rillaboom", "Dragapult", "Volcarona", "Garganacl"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Azumarill’s unique selling point is the combination of Huge Power, STAB Aqua Jet, and Belly Drum, a combo no other legal Pokémon replicates. After a Sitrus Berry proc, it sits at 75 % health with +6 Attack, turning Aqua Jet into a 120 BP priority move off 436 Attack (Adamant). Play Rough secures crucial 2HKOs on neutral targets that resist Water, notably OHKOing max-HP Dragapult and dealing ~80 % to Assault Vest Gholdengo. The chosen EV spreads reflect two philosophies: the 244 HP set survives Jolly Chien-Pao Icicle Crash + Life Orb chip, while the 212/28 spread outspeeds uninvested base 70s (e.g., Breloom) to Aqua Jet before Spore. Tera Grass is dominant because it flips the Rotom-Wash matchup—+6 Aqua Jet becomes a clean OHKO—and removes the 4× Electric weakness, letting Azumarill stay in on Zapdos and Iron Hands. Tera Ghost is a secondary option to block Fake Out, Extreme Speed, and Sucker Punch, enabling safer setup versus teams relying on priority to stop sweeps. Protect is mandatory to block double-targets after setup and to waste opposing Dynamon turns. The low usage of Sap Sipper and Thick Fat reflects the meta: Huge Power is irreplaceable for damage, and the other abilities don’t solve Azumarill’s core problems.</OUTPUT>

It sets up freely on Torkoals, Pelippers, and passive Garganacl, then sweeps with +6 Aqua Jet. It struggles versus Amoonguss and other redirection users that can redirect the Belly Drum turn, and versus bulky Grass resists such as Ferrothorn and Wo-Chien that survive +6 Aqua Jet. Electric Terrain teams with pinching Volt Switch damage also limit setup. Opposing Tailwind or Chlorophyll sweepers that outspeed even priority can finish Azumarill before it moves. Finally, Clear Body/Good as Gold users (e.g., Gholdengo) ignore Intimidate, so partners must still soften them before the sweep.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Azumarill is a one-time setup sweeper and late-game cleaner. It is almost never brought Game 1 unless the opponent’s team preview is extremely passive; instead, it shines in best-of-three sets as a hidden win-condition. Turn 1 is usually spent either switching Incineroar in to Intimidate, using Rillaboom’s Grassy Glide to soften targets, or letting Dragapult use Ally Switch to redirect. Once the field is clear, Azumarill uses Belly Drum, recovers to 75 % with Sitrus, and proceeds to click Aqua Jet for the remainder of the game. Because it must commit to the sweep immediately, it cannot function as a pivot or chip damage dealer; its entire value is in the 2-3 turns after setup.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Incineroar is the most common partner, providing Intimidate, Parting Shot, and Fake Out pressure that buys the Belly Drum turn. Rillaboom adds Grassy Terrain to weaken Earthquakes and provides a secondary priority user that can finish off Grass resists. Dragapult offers Ally Switch redirection and can break Focus Sashes with Shadow Ball before Azumarill sweeps. Volcarona and Garganacl blanket check opposing Grass and Electric types—Volcarona with Heat Wave and Garganacl with Salt Cure chip—while also punishing redirection with Wide Guard or Taunt variants. Gholdengo blocks opposing Amoonguss Spore and provides a secondary special attacker that pressures physical walls. Together, these teammates compress Intimidate, redirection, speed control, and hazard removal into a tight six-Pokémon core that funnels the game state into an Azumarill endgame.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Amoonguss is public enemy #1: Rage Powder redirects the Belly Drum turn, and Clear Smog removes all boosts. Ferrothorn survives +6 Aqua Jet in Rain and OHKOs back with Power Whip; Wo-Chien does the same under Grassy Terrain. Rotom-Wash must Tera Grass itself or it dies, but Zapdos and Iron Hands can tank a +0 Jet and retaliate with Thunder Punch or Wildbolt Storm. Priority-blocking strategies—Psychic Terrain from Indeedee-F or a well-timed Queenly Majesty from Hatterene—deny Aqua Jet flinches. Unaware Dondozo ignores boosts and 2HKOs with Order Up. Finally, double-target focus fire on the Belly Drum turn can KO Azumarill before Sitrus activates; Wide Guard or Follow Me from the partner is mandatory to stop this.</OUTPUT>

input:

<DATA>{"Toxtricity": {"Abilities": {"punkrock": 13.261180780870172, "minus": 0.018159725912818336, "technician": 0.024853553310662246, "plus": 0.004638949220050426}, "Items": {"choicespecs": 0.5206629675633163, "throatspray": 0.2760867370105856, "lifeorb": 0.16918118803696508}, "Spreads": {"Modest:52/0/0/204/0/252": 0.2882683740319026, "Timid:4/0/12/252/4/236": 0.1917482785203869}, "Moves": ["overdrive", "sludgebomb", "boomburst", "voltswitch"], "Tera Types": {"normal": 0.857380763768742}, "Teammates": ["Kommo-o", "Drifblim", "Hydreigon", "Volcarona", "Indeedee", "Whimsicott"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Toxtricity’s niche stems from Punk Rock, a 1.3× damage boost to sound-based moves that turns Overdrive into a 117 base-power Electric nuke and Boomburst into a 189 base-power neutral bomb. Choice Specs variants (52% of teams) trade locking into one move for immediate wall-breaking, while Throat Spray sets (28%) prefer to set up on a Protect turn or after a partner’s priority Follow Me, gaining +1 SpA and retaining move flexibility. Life Orb (17%) offers a middle ground, letting Toxtricity switch moves and still boost damage output. The two main spreads illustrate the speed control dilemma: Modest 252/204/52 maximizes damage and survives modest rolls from common Fairy and Flying attacks, whereas Timid 236/252 guarantees outspeeding positive-nature base 80s such as Chien-Pao and opposing Toxtricity. Sludge Bomb is mandatory for Fairy and Grass targets that resist Overdrive, while Volt Switch preserves momentum versus predicted Ground switches. Normal Tera is ubiquitous because it gives Boomburst STAB, removes Ghost immunities, and synergizes with Punk Rock’s boost, effectively creating a 284 base-power spread move that only Steel-types comfortably stomach. Toxtricity’s teammates—Kommo-o, Drifblim, Hydreigon, Volcarona, Indeedee, and Whimsicott—form a cohesive core of redirection, speed control, and secondary special attackers that cover its Ground and Psychic weaknesses while appreciating Toxtricity’s ability to delete Fairy and Water threats.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Toxtricity": {"Abilities": {"punkrock": 13.261180780870172, "minus": 0.018159725912818336, "technician": 0.024853553310662246, "plus": 0.004638949220050426}, "Items": {"choicespecs": 0.5206629675633163, "throatspray": 0.2760867370105856, "lifeorb": 0.16918118803696508}, "Spreads": {"Modest:52/0/0/204/0/252": 0.2882683740319026, "Timid:4/0/12/252/4/236": 0.1917482785203869}, "Moves": ["overdrive", "sludgebomb", "boomburst", "voltswitch"], "Tera Types": {"normal": 0.857380763768742}, "Teammates": ["Kommo-o", "Drifblim", "Hydreigon", "Volcarona", "Indeedee", "Whimsicott"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Toxtricity pressures bulky Waters like Toxapex, Rotom-W, and Dondozo, and deletes Fairies such as Sylveon, Azumarill, and Hatterene with Sludge Bomb or neutral Boomburst. It cleanly OHKOes most non-Assault-Vest variants of these threats after Punk Rock and item boosts. Against Steel-types, it must predict switches or rely on teammates: Specs Overdrive 2HKOes Corviknight after chip, but Gholdengo and Kingambit force Volt Switch pivots. Ground-types—Great Tusk, Garchomp, Ting-Lu—are hard counters under normal circumstances; Toxtricity must Tera Normal on the switch and threaten Boomburst or rely on redirection. Psychic-types like Indeedee-F and Farigiraf outspeed and OHKO with STAB, so Toxtricity appreciates Dark-type partners or priority speed control. Sun teams with Torkoal andProtosynthesis attackers dislike Toxtricity’s Electric STAB, while Rain teams give it a damage boost but also bring faster Swift Swim Grounds. In Trick Room, Toxtricity underspeeds many threats and can fire off boosted attacks before taking hits, making it a viable anti-TR option if positioned correctly.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Toxtricity": {"Abilities": {"punkrock": 13.261180780870172, "minus": 0.018159725912818336, "technician": 0.024853553310662246, "plus": 0.004638949220050426}, "Items": {"choicespecs": 0.5206629675633163, "throatspray": 0.2760867370105856, "lifeorb": 0.16918118803696508}, "Spreads": {"Modest:52/0/0/204/0/252": 0.2882683740319026, "Timid:4/0/12/252/4/236": 0.1917482785203869}, "Moves": ["overdrive", "sludgebomb", "boomburst", "voltswitch"], "Tera Types": {"normal": 0.857380763768742}, "Teammates": ["Kommo-o", "Drifblim", "Hydreigon", "Volcarona", "Indeedee", "Whimsicott"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Toxtricity is a wall-breaking special attacker that compresses Electric, Poison, and Normal coverage into one slot, freeing team-building space for supportive or speed-control partners. It functions as either a lead that immediately threatens opposing Water/Fairy leads or as a mid-game cleaner once its checks are weakened or Tera Normal is available. The Choice Specs set is a straightforward nuke that deletes switch-ins and forces 2-for-1 trades, while Throat Spray sets act as setup sweepers that can snowball after a single KO. Volt Switch lets Toxtricity act as a pivot, bringing in frail attackers like Hydreigon or Volcarona safely. Its ability to pressure both sides of the field with spread Boomburst makes it a potent partner to redirection or Follow Me users, ensuring damage even when single-target moves would be stalled by Protect. Toxtricity’s role is therefore that of a high-risk, high-reward breaker that demands immediate answers or loses the game on the spot.</OUTPUT>
