Provide the 'synergy_breakdown' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Toxtricity": {"Abilities": {"punkrock": 13.261180780870172, "minus": 0.018159725912818336, "technician": 0.024853553310662246, "plus": 0.004638949220050426}, "Items": {"choicespecs": 0.5206629675633163, "throatspray": 0.2760867370105856, "lifeorb": 0.16918118803696508}, "Spreads": {"Modest:52/0/0/204/0/252": 0.2882683740319026, "Timid:4/0/12/252/4/236": 0.1917482785203869}, "Moves": ["overdrive", "sludgebomb", "boomburst", "voltswitch"], "Tera Types": {"normal": 0.857380763768742}, "Teammates": ["Kommo-o", "Drifblim", "Hydreigon", "Volcarona", "Indeedee", "Whimsicott"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Kommo-o covers Toxtricity’s Ground and Psychic weaknesses with its Steel/Poison resistance and sets Stealth Rock to chip checks. Drifblim provides Tailwind and Strength Sap, letting Toxtricity outspeed and survive longer, while its Ghost typing blocks Rapid Spin and immune Boomburst. Hydreigon shares a Volt Switch core, breaks opposing Steel-types with Flamethrower, and appreciates Toxtricity’s Fairy removal. Volcarona offers Quiver Dance passivity and spreads Burns, softening physical Ground attackers that threaten Toxtricity. Indeedee sets Psychic Terrain to block priority Sucker Punch from Kingambit and Chien-Pao, while Follow Me redirects Earthquakes. Whimsicott supplies Tailwind and Encore to lock opposing support into harmless moves, giving Toxtricity free turns to click Specs Overdrive or set up Throat Spray. In return, Toxtricity deletes the bulky Waters and Fairies that trouble these partners, creating a feedback loop of offensive pressure and defensive utility.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Toxtricity": {"Abilities": {"punkrock": 13.261180780870172, "minus": 0.018159725912818336, "technician": 0.024853553310662246, "plus": 0.004638949220050426}, "Items": {"choicespecs": 0.5206629675633163, "throatspray": 0.2760867370105856, "lifeorb": 0.16918118803696508}, "Spreads": {"Modest:52/0/0/204/0/252": 0.2882683740319026, "Timid:4/0/12/252/4/236": 0.1917482785203869}, "Moves": ["overdrive", "sludgebomb", "boomburst", "voltswitch"], "Tera Types": {"normal": 0.857380763768742}, "Teammates": ["Kommo-o", "Drifblim", "Hydreigon", "Volcarona", "Indeedee", "Whimsicott"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Ground-types are the most reliable answers: Great Tusk survives +1 Boomburst after Tera and OHKOes with Earthquake, while Garchomp and Ting-Lu force Toxtricity to Tera or switch. Priority users such as Chien-Pao’s Sucker Punch or Kingambit’s Sucker Punch under Psychic Terrain bypass speed tiers and deal massive damage. Faster threats like Iron Valiant, Choice Scarf Gholdengo, and Tailwind-boosted Dragapult outspeed even Timid variants and KO with STAB. Bulky Steel-types—Corviknight, Gholdengo, and Kingambit—can stomach Specs Overdrive once and retaliate or set up. Wide Guard users such as Aegislash and Hitmontop block Boomburst spread damage, forcing Toxtricity into single-target predictions. Finally, because Toxtricity is item-reliant, Knock Off or Trick severely cripple its damage output, while Taunt stops Throat Spray activation and forces awkward Volt Switch loops. Properly scouting its item and Tera type is crucial; if Toxtricity burns Tera Normal early, subsequent Ground switches become safe.</OUTPUT>

Drifblim @ Focus Sash | Unburden | 4 HP / 252 Def / 252 Spe Bold | Tailwind, Strength Sap, Will-O-Wisp, Ally Switch—speed control and redirection. <DATA>{"Klefki": {"Abilities": {"prankster": 12.787193405537773, "magician": 0.0}, "Items": {"lightclay": 0.8563383991776997}, "Spreads": {"Calm:252/0/76/0/180/0": 0.3251388571507435, "Calm:252/0/100/0/156/0": 0.21237877545123987}, "Moves": ["reflect", "lightscreen", "dazzlinggleam", "mistyterrain"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.56611791997481, "flying": 0.240510223406603}, "Teammates": ["Annihilape", "Maushold", "Ursaluna-Bloodmoon", "Sinistcha", "Incineroar", "Ninetales-Alola"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Klefki is a dedicated support Pokémon that leverages Prankster priority to reliably set both Reflect and Light Screen, compressing dual-screen duties into a single slot while providing Fairy-type utility via Dazzling Gleam and Misty Terrain. Its EV spreads emphasize special bulk (Calm nature, heavy HP/SpD investment) to maximize the value of the screens it deploys, and it overwhelmingly prefers Light Clay to extend those barriers. Tera Ghost and Tera Flying are the only notable Terastallization choices, granting temporary immunities to Fake Out and Ground-type moves respectively. Teammates trend toward slow, setup-oriented or spread-damage powerhouses such as Annihilape, Maushold, Ursaluna-Bloodmoon, and Sinistcha, all of which appreciate the halved damage provided by screens while they boost or stall turns.</OUTPUT>

input:
Draft the 'full_analysis' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Klefki": {"Abilities": {"prankster": 12.787193405537773, "magician": 0.0}, "Items": {"lightclay": 0.8563383991776997}, "Spreads": {"Calm:252/0/76/0/180/0": 0.3251388571507435, "Calm:252/0/100/0/156/0": 0.21237877545123987}, "Moves": ["reflect", "lightscreen", "dazzlinggleam", "mistyterrain"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.56611791997481, "flying": 0.240510223406603}, "Teammates": ["Annihilape", "Maushold", "Ursaluna-Bloodmoon", "Sinistcha", "Incineroar", "Ninetales-Alola"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Prankster is the engine that makes Klefki viable: guaranteed priority on non-attacking moves means Reflect and Light Screen are almost impossible to stop without a faster Taunt or a priority user that can ignore Prankster (e.g., opposing priority or Dark-type moves). Once the screens are up, every ally immediately becomes twice as bulky for five turns (eight with Light Clay), which in the current damage-heavy metagame often translates to one or two extra turns of setup or positioning. Dazzling Gleam gives Klefki a spread Fairy STAB that chips opposing Dragons and Dark-types while not triggering Contact-based punishments, and Misty Terrain offers team-wide status protection—particularly useful against Spore, Sleep Powder, and Nuzzle users that would otherwise cripple Klefki’s slower partners. The listed EV spreads (Calm 252 HP / 180 SpD or 252 HP / 156 SpD with leftover points in Defense) ensure Klefki survives strong special hits such as Flutter Mane’s Shadow Ball or Chi-Yu’s Overheat even without a screen, letting it fire off both barriers or pivot out with a switch. Terastallization into Ghost removes its Fighting weakness and makes it immune to Fake Out and Extreme Speed, while Tera Flying neutralizes Ground-type moves and grants a handy resistance to Grass; both forms are primarily used reactively to survive a KO or preserve a screen turn rather than to sweep. The complete absence of offensive items and the 100 % Prankster usage show that Klefki is a pure utility piece: it enters, sets up, chips or supports, and then either switches or sacrifices itself once its job is done.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Klefki": {"Abilities": {"prankster": 12.787193405537773, "magician": 0.0}, "Items": {"lightclay": 0.8563383991776997}, "Spreads": {"Calm:252/0/76/0/180/0": 0.3251388571507435, "Calm:252/0/100/0/156/0": 0.21237877545123987}, "Moves": ["reflect", "lightscreen", "dazzlinggleam", "mistyterrain"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.56611791997481, "flying": 0.240510223406603}, "Teammates": ["Annihilape", "Maushold", "Ursaluna-Bloodmoon", "Sinistcha", "Incineroar", "Ninetales-Alola"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Klefki exerts the most pressure against hyper-offensive or setup teams that rely on raw power or speed rather than passive damage or status; dual screens blunt Choice-item attackers and allow bulky sweepers to set up in their face. Against hard Trick Room or Tailwind offenses, Klefki’s priority screens can still blunt the opening salvo, but if the opponent’s win condition is field-control rather than raw damage (e.g., weather sweepers or booster-speed Pokémon) the value of screens drops. Klefki struggles versus Dark-type leads such as Incineroar or Kingambit that ignore Prankster, and versus faster Taunt users like Murkrow or opposing Klefki that can shut it down before it moves. Terrain wars also matter: Misty Terrain helps against status, but Psychic Terrain from Indeedee or Farigiraf blocks Prankster-boosted moves, rendering Klefki almost useless. Finally, because Klefki offers almost no offensive presence, teams that can ignore screens via Unaware, Infiltrator, or Mold Breaker can still punch through its partners.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Klefki is a dedicated lead/support that compresses dual-screen setup, Fairy-type spread damage, and terrain control into one slot. Its primary job is to guarantee Reflect and Light Screen with Prankster priority, after which it either chips with Dazzling Gleam, sets Misty Terrain to block status, or pivots out to bring in a setup sweeper safely. The EV investment maximizes special bulk so that Klefki can survive a hit and fire off both screens even if the partner is targeted. Light Clay is mandatory to extend screen duration, and Terastallization is used reactively to dodge a lethal blow or preserve a screen turn rather than to boost offenses. Once screens are active, Klefki’s remaining value lies in Misty Terrain chip and spread Fairy damage before it is eventually KO’d or replaced.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Klefki’s ideal partners are slow but powerful Pokémon that need a turn or two of safety to boost or stall. Annihilape abuses Bulk Up under screens, turning into an unkillable win condition while spreading Rage Fist damage. Maushold benefits from halved damage while it sets up Population Bomb or Friend Guard stalls. Ursaluna-Bloodmoon can safely Calm Mind or Blood Moon spam behind screens, while Sinistcha uses the turns to accumulate Strength Sap healing and Calm Mind boosts. Incineroar provides a Dark-type immunity to Klefki’s Prankster weakness and can pivot with Parting Shot to recycle Klefki later. Ninetales-Alola offers Aurora Veil stacking (though redundant) and Blizzard spread, but more importantly it deters opposing weather sweepers that would otherwise ignore Klefki’s screens. The common thread is bulk amplification: every teammate listed either sets up, stalls, or spreads damage, and all of them appreciate the pseudo-doubling of their defensive stats.</OUTPUT>

Tera Ghost on Klefki is used reactively to dodge Fake Out, while Annihilape can Tera Fighting for extra power or Tera Water to remove Fire weakness under sun. <DATA>{"Espeon": {"Abilities": {"synchronize": 0.030541794822532387, "magicbounce": 11.54151468287764}, "Items": {"choicespecs": 0.1853386634912695, "focussash": 0.5148924145071619}, "Spreads": {"Timid:0/0/0/252/4/252": 0.1716472210069725, "Timid:60/0/0/252/0/196": 0.49290878585053005}, "Moves": ["expandingforce", "shadowball", "trickroom", "detect"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.493345665297873, "stellar": 0.15184258388586228}, "Teammates": ["Indeedee-F", "Umbreon", "Sylveon", "Vaporeon", "Jolteon", "Flareon"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Espeon carves a niche as a fast, Psychic Terrain–abusing attacker that leverages Choice Specs Expanding Force for immediate spread pressure, while its rare Magic Bounce lets it punish passive hazards, Taunt, and status. The data show a clear split: roughly half the player-base opts for Focus Sash to guarantee a TR reversal or a second attack, while the other half locks into Specs for maximum damage. Tera Ghost is the dominant tech, granting immunity to Fake Out and Mach Punch so it can click buttons unhindered, while Stellar offers neutral coverage and a one-time nuke. EV spreads emphasize Timid nature with max or near-max Speed to outpace the crowded base 100–110 tier, while 60 HP / 252 SpA / 196 Spe appears to be a damage-optimized spread that still Speed-creeps key threats. With Indeedee-F as the most common teammate, the core is clearly a Psychic-spam mode that floods the field with terrain and denies priority, turning Espeon into a 135 BP STAB spread nuke that ignores Follow Me redirection.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Espeon": {"Abilities": {"synchronize": 0.030541794822532387, "magicbounce": 11.54151468287764}, "Items": {"choicespecs": 0.1853386634912695, "focussash": 0.5148924145071619}, "Spreads": {"Timid:0/0/0/252/4/252": 0.1716472210069725, "Timid:60/0/0/252/0/196": 0.49290878585053005}, "Moves": ["expandingforce", "shadowball", "trickroom", "detect"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.493345665297873, "stellar": 0.15184258388586228}, "Teammates": ["Indeedee-F", "Umbreon", "Sylveon", "Vaporeon", "Jolteon", "Flareon"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Espeon’s value in VGC 2025 lies in its unique combination of Magic Bounce, Psychic Terrain synergy, and high special attack. Unlike Indeedee-F, which is slower and passive, Espeon applies immediate offensive pressure while still bouncing back Stealth Rock, Spore, or Thunder Wave attempts. The 11.5 % usage of Magic Bounce (versus 0.03 % Synchronize) proves players are building it as an anti-hazard pivot rather than a gimmick. Expanding Force under terrain is the main draw: Choice Specs variants deal 70–80 % to neutral bulk invested Miraidon and OHKO most Incineroar after minor chip. Shadow Ball covers opposing Psychics and Lunala, while Trick Room is a tech to either reverse opposing speed control or self-proc for a teammate like Stakataka or Calyrex-Ice. Detect over Protect is a minor optimization that avoids Imprison shenanigans from enemy Indeedee. Tera Ghost is preferred because it flips Close Combat, Bullet Punch, and Sucker Punch into immunities, letting Espeon stay on the field longer to fire off a second Expanding Force or a game-winning Shadow Ball. Stellar Tera is the greedy alternative: it boosts all moves once, breaks Tera-boosted resistances, and can secure surprise KOs on Ting-Lu or Kingambit that expect to live a resisted hit. The Speed EVs hit 167 at level 50, outspeeding +Speed base 100s such as Koraidon and opposing Indeedee-F, while the 60 HP spread survives Jolly Chien-Pao Ice Spinner into terrain 87.5 % of the time. Overall, Espeon is a high-risk, high-reward attacker that punishes passive teams and terrain-agnostic speed control.</OUTPUT>

Against hyper-offense, however, Espeon’s 75/95 bulk is mediocre; Chien-Pao, Kingambit, and Pawmot can all KO with priority or a Tera Dark Sucker Punch before it moves if terrain is gone. Miraidon and Iron Crown are 50/50 matchups: if Espeon is Stellar-terad and wins the speed tie, it OHKOes with Shadow Ball, but if it loses or is locked into Expanding Force, it dies to Electro Drift or Tera Steel Tachyon Cutter. Finally, Ghost-types like Lunala and Aegislash are problematic unless Espeon carries Tera Dark or Stellar, so most lists pair it with Umbreon or Kingambit to handle those threats.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Quaquaval’s standout trait is its 119 base Speed tier, outspeeding the crowded 110-115 group and allowing it to naturally outpace threats like Gholdengo, Ogerpon-Wellspring, and most Dragapult. Moxie turns every KO into a snowball opportunity, and Aqua Step’s 100 % chance to raise Speed means even neutral targets can become setup fodder after a single boost. Close Combat is the strongest reliable STAB, smacking Incineroar, Kingambit, and opposing Steel-types, while Ice Spinner hits Rillaboom, Lando-T, and the omnipresent Grass-type cores. The choice between Focus Sash—guaranteeing it survives a double-up or stray priority—and Clear Amulet—ignoring Intimidate, Parting Shot, and Chilling Water drops—comes down to whether the team needs longevity or raw power. Tera Fire is the most popular option, removing the Grass weakness and letting it OHKO Amoonguss with Terablast under Sun, while Tera Water grants a rain-boosted Aqua Step and Tera Grass flips the Electric matchup versus Rotom-W or Zapdos. Stellar Tera is a niche middle ground, preserving STAB on both Water and Fighting while giving a one-time neutral coverage bump. EV spreads are straightforward: max Speed and Attack with either Adamant for power or Jolly to guarantee the speed tie with opposing Quaquaval and Iron Valiant; the slightly bulkier Adamant spread with 36 HP / 236 Atk / 4 Def / 4 SpD / 228 Spe survives LO Gholdengo Shadow Ball while still outspeeding positive-nature base 110s.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Slowpoke": {"Abilities": {"oblivious": 11.52903904973228, "regenerator": 0.0049853641629626355}, "Items": {"eviolite": 0.9995176067717748}, "Spreads": {"Impish:252/0/36/0/220/0": 0.9210424649117455}, "Moves": ["trickroom", "surf", "skillswap", "healpulse"], "Tera Types": {"grass": 0.9685923402966061}, "Teammates": ["Torkoal", "Farigiraf", "Ursaluna", "Smeargle", "Annihilape", "Zoroark-Hisui"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>While Slowpoke’s base stats are unimpressive, Eviolite transforms it into a surprisingly sturdy support Pokémon that can live neutral hits and provide key utility. Regenerator is its only competitive ability, letting it pivot out with allies like Farigiraf’s Armor Tail or Smeargle’s Follow Me to recover 33 % health and return later. Trick Room is the cornerstone of its set, reversing speed tiers for slow powerhouses such as Torkoal, Ursaluna, and Annihilape. Skill Swap is a unique tech that can give Regenerator to a teammate (notably Ursaluna) or strip annoying abilities like Good as Gold from Gholdengo. Heal Pulse keeps heavy hitters healthy in long games, and Surf is chosen as a spread move that can activate ally Weakness Policy or trigger Steam Engine on Coalossal if used alongside Torkoal. Tera Grass removes the Electric weakness that plagues Water-types and grants a crucial resistance to Grassy Glide from Rillaboom. The listed Impish spread maximizes physical bulk while the 220 EVs in Special Defense ensure Slowpoke is not overwhelmed by common special attackers like Flutter Mane or Iron Bundle under sun. In practice, Slowpoke functions as a lead that either sets Trick Room immediately or swaps out to Regenerator partners, then returns mid-game to maintain field control with Heal Pulse and Skill Swap.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Poliwrath is a mid-game setup sweeper that flips defensive momentum into an immediate 2-0 or 3-0 advantage. It occupies the restricted slot on rain teams that want a secondary mode outside of Kingdra or Barraskewda, offering Fighting coverage and self-healing that the traditional rain core lacks. Because Belly Drum consumes 50% HP, it prefers to enter after a U-turn or pivot, behind a Substitute from Sinistcha, or after a partner’s Follow Me. Once set up it becomes a self-sustaining tank that can tank neutral hits and heal back to full, freeing allies to run offensive items instead of recovery. Its typing also pressures common Fire- and Steel-type rain checks like Heatran and Gholdengo, meaning opponents can’t simply default to those pivots once rain is up.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Poliwrath": {"Abilities": {"waterabsorb": 9.848710152852707, "swiftswim": 1.271587801452676, "damp": 0.0}, "Items": {"sitrusberry": 0.9136684151242844}, "Spreads": {"Brave:244/252/12/0/0/0": 0.8771662385996704}, "Moves": ["liquidation", "drainpunch", "bellydrum", "protect"], "Tera Types": {"fire": 0.8777836176185607}, "Teammates": ["Pelipper", "Indeedee-F", "Sinistcha", "Braviary-Hisui", "Annihilape", "Flamigo"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Priority and speed control are the most reliable answers: Fake Out from Incineroar or Rillaboom breaks Sitrus range and leaves Poliwrath in KO territory for any strong neutral attack. Unaware Dondozo ignores the +6 boosts and 2HKOs with Order, while Clear Body Celesteela can tank a +6 Liquidation and retalify with Hurricane or Heavy Slam. Electric Terrain teams with Iron Crown or Raging Bolt can overload it before it Tera’s, and Amoonguff under sun survives a +0 Tera Fire Blast and can Spore or Clear Smog away the boosts. Perhaps the simplest counterplay is to reset weather: Torkoal or Tyranitar removing rain drops its Speed to a crawl and lets scarfed threats like Chien-Pao or Flutter Mane revenge kill. Finally, double-target focus fire on the turn it drums will KO through Sitrus unless it gets a Protect read, so proper prediction and spread damage are key.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Rotom-Wash remains a premier pivot in VGC thanks to its unique Electric/Water typing, Levitate, and a speed tier that lets it outrun most support Pokémon while still threatening heavy damage with Volt Switch and Hydro Pump. The most successful sets are Timid max-speed/max-Special Attack with a Choice Scarf or Leftovers, leaning on Volt Switch for safe positioning, Trick to cripple walls, and Tera Electric or Steel to flip key match-ups. It fits best on balanced or offensive structures that appreciate a fast, disruptive pivot that can simultaneously check Rain, soften Ground-weak cores, and maintain momentum for setup or burst teammates like Garchomp, Incineroar, and Amoonguss.</OUTPUT>

input:
Write the 'full_analysis' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Rotom-Wash": {"Abilities": {"levitate": 10.920677211406476}, "Items": {"choicescarf": 0.19396573313062304, "choicespecs": 0.22130549303951874, "leftovers": 0.19175897088808963, "lifeorb": 0.16467236981472005}, "Spreads": {"Timid:0/0/0/252/4/252": 0.24632580628301662}, "Moves": ["hydropump", "voltswitch", "protect", "trick"], "Tera Types": {"steel": 0.15876118779918888, "electric": 0.4329824913098593, "ghost": 0.2415643304538842}, "Teammates": ["Garchomp", "Amoonguss", "Incineroar", "Indeedee-F", "Torkoal", "Tyranitar"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Rotom-Wash’s viability starts with its typing: Electric/Water gives it only one weakness (Grass) while granting crucial resistances to Fire, Water, Ice, Flying, and Steel. Levitate removes its Ground weakness, letting it switch in on Earthquake users such as Garchomp and Landorus-T with impunity. Base 86 Speed is the sweet spot: with Timid and 252 EVs it hits 295, outspeeding positive-nature base 70s and all uninvested base 90s, while a Choice Scarf pushes it to 442, letting it revenge kill +1 Dragon Dance threats or underspeed Tailwind attackers. 105/107 bulk is respectable, letting it survive non-boosted super-effective hits when invested. Offensively, 95 SpA is modest, but STAB Hydro Pump and Volt Switch backed by Life Orb or Specs still 2HKO most neutral targets; Volt Switch in particular is the crux of Rotom’s game plan, forcing switches and giving free board positioning. Trick cripples passive walls like Dusclops, Toxapex, or opposing support Rotom, turning them into momentum sinks. Protect is ubiquitous in doubles to scout and stall Dynamax turns. Tera Electric boosts Volt Switch to obscene power and removes Water’s Grass weakness, while Tera Steel grants a slew of resistances and an immunity to Poison, letting Rotom serve as an end-game win-condition versus Fairy or Ice teams. Leftovers sets play a longer game, repeatedly pivoting and chipping; Scarf sets function as fast utility and emergency speed control; Specs sets break bulky cores but require more prediction. Rotom-Wash’s only real flaw is four-moveslot syndrome: it wants Thunderbolt, Will-O-Wisp, Ally Switch, and Thunder Wave but can’t fit them all, so sets are tailored to the team’s needs.</OUTPUT>

input:
Write a detailed 'matchup_overview' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Rotom-Wash": {"Abilities": {"levitate": 10.920677211406476}, "Items": {"choicescarf": 0.19396573313062304, "choicespecs": 0.22130549303951874, "leftovers": 0.19175897088808963, "lifeorb": 0.16467236981472005}, "Spreads": {"Timid:0/0/0/252/4/252": 0.24632580628301662}, "Moves": ["hydropump", "voltswitch", "protect", "trick"], "Tera Types": {"steel": 0.15876118779918888, "electric": 0.4329824913098593, "ghost": 0.2415643304538842}, "Teammates": ["Garchomp", "Amoonguss", "Incineroar", "Indeedee-F", "Torkoal", "Tyranitar"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Rotom-Wash dominates Rain match-ups by outspeeding and OHKOing Swift Swim sweepers with Volt Switch while tanking their Water STAB; it also pressures Sun teams by threatening Torkoal with Hydro Pump and surviving Heat Wave. Against Sand, it baits Excadrill’s Iron Head and KOs back with Hydro Pump or simply Volt Switches on Tyranitar. Grass-types—especially Rillaboom, Kartana, and Amoonguss—are its bane: Rillaboom’s Grassy Glide outspeeds and OHKOes even bulky variants, while Amoonguss can tank a Volt Switch and put Rotom to sleep. Dragon-types such as Dragapult and Garchomp are neutral: Rotom can cripple them with Trick or burn with Will-O-Wisp, but must beware Dynamax variants that can live a hit and KO back. Fairy teams struggle to switch into Volt Switch, but Mimikyu and Azumarill can set up on predicted Protects. Trick Room teams can flip the speed advantage, so Rotom must either Taunt the setter or double-target to prevent it. Tera Electric turns Rotom into a pseudo-Zapdos that punishes Flying and Water cores, while Tera Steel lets it wall Kyurem and Mimikyu. Overall, Rotom-Wash is a soft check to most meta archetypes but demands teammates that can handle Grass and strong physical breakers.</OUTPUT>

input:
Write a detailed 'role_description' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Rotom-Wash": {"Abilities": {"levitate": 10.920677211406476}, "Items": {"choicescarf": 0.19396573313062304, "choicespecs": 0.22130549303951874, "leftovers": 0.19175897088808963, "lifeorb": 0.16467236981472005}, "Spreads": {"Timid:0/0/0/252/4/252": 0.24632580628301662}, "Moves": ["hydropump", "voltswitch", "protect", "trick"], "Tera Types": {"steel": 0.15876118779918888, "electric": 0.4329824913098593, "ghost": 0.2415643304538842}, "Teammates": ["Garchomp", "Amoonguss", "Incineroar", "Indeedee-F", "Torkoal", "Tyranitar"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Rotom-Wash is a fast special pivot and disruption utility. Its primary job is to gain momentum with Volt Switch, bringing in frail attackers or setup sweepers safely while chipping the opponent. Secondary roles vary by item: Choice Scarf variants act as speed control and revenge killer, eliminating weakened threats and preventing set-up; Leftovers variants serve as a long-term pivot that can repeatedly check Rain, Sand, and Fire cores while spreading burn or Trick; Choice Specs sets function as a wallbreaker, 2HKOing even bulky resists like Assault Vest Tangrowth. In doubles, Rotom often holds a support mantle: it can Ally Switch to redirect attacks, burn physical Dynamax threats, or Trick its item onto support Pokémon to deny recovery. Its typing and Levitate let it switch into Earthquake, Heat Wave, and Hydro Pump, making it an ideal partner for Ground-weak sweepers like Garchomp or Incineroar. Whether offensive or supportive, Rotom-Wash’s speed tier and typing let it compress multiple roles—speed control, pivot, Water immunity, Electric immunity—into one slot, freeing teammates to focus on win conditions rather than defensive overlap.</OUTPUT>

input:
Write the 'synergy_breakdown' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Rotom-Wash": {"Abilities": {"levitate": 10.920677211406476}, "Items": {"choicescarf": 0.19396573313062304, "choicespecs": 0.22130549303951874, "leftovers": 0.19175897088808963, "lifeorb": 0.16467236981472005}, "Spreads": {"Timid:0/0/0/252/4/252": 0.24632580628301662}, "Moves": ["hydropump", "voltswitch", "protect", "trick"], "Tera Types": {"steel": 0.15876118779918888, "electric": 0.4329824913098593, "ghost": 0.2415643304538842}, "Teammates": ["Garchomp", "Amoonguss", "Incineroar", "Indeedee-F", "Torkoal", "Tyranitar"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Rotom-Wash pairs naturally with Ground-weak or Fire-weak attackers that appreciate Volt Switch momentum and Water-type chip. Garchomp is the classic partner: Rotom switches into Ice Shard and Earthquake, Volt Switches on the predicted swap, and brings in Garchomp for a free Swords Dance or Dynamax sweep. Incineroar loves Volt Switch because it can come in safely versus Fairies and begin Intimidate cycling; Rotom in turn welcomes Incineroar’s Parting Shot to keep pivoting. Amoonguss forms a “FerroCent”-style core: Rotom handles Fire- and Steel-types for Amoonguss, while Amoonguss sponges Grass moves and puts threats to sleep, buying Rotom free turns. Indeedee-F sets Psychic Terrain to block priority Grassy Glide, letting Rotom safely Volt Switch versus Rillaboom; Rotom removes Steel-types that wall Indeedee’s Expanding Force. Torkoal appreciates Rotom’s ability to KO opposing Water-types and provides Sun-boosted Eruption to break shared checks. Tyranitar gives Sand chip and special bulk, while Rotom removes Fighting-types that threaten Tyranitar. Tera-wise, Rotom can go Electric to stack offensive synergy with these sweepers, or Steel to become a defensive anchor that covers Fairy and Ice for the rest of the squad.</OUTPUT>

input:

<DATA>{"Rotom-Wash": {"Abilities": {"levitate": 10.920677211406476}, "Items": {"choicescarf": 0.19396573313062304, "choicespecs": 0.22130549303951874, "leftovers": 0.19175897088808963, "lifeorb": 0.16467236981472005}, "Spreads": {"Timid:0/0/0/252/4/252": 0.24632580628301662}, "Moves": ["hydropump", "voltswitch", "protect", "trick"], "Tera Types": {"steel": 0.15876118779918888, "electric": 0.4329824913098593, "ghost": 0.2415643304538842}, "Teammates": ["Garchomp", "Amoonguss", "Incineroar", "Indeedee-F", "Torkoal", "Tyranitar"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Grass-types are the most reliable answers: Rillaboom’s Grassy Glide OHKOs even bulky Rotom through Tera, Kartana’s Leaf Blade does the same, and Amoonguss can take any hit and put Rotom to sleep or clear its item with Clear Smog. Faster Scarfers like Dragapult, Iron Valiant, and Chien-Pao can outspeed and KO, though they must watch for Trick or burn. Priority users such as Bisharp’s Sucker Punch or Kingambit’s Supreme Overlord boosted Sucker Punch can finish Rotom after chip. Assault Vest Tangrowth and Ferrothorn can tank Volt Switch and either Leech Seed or Power Whip for heavy damage; Rotom can Trick Ferrothorn but then risks giving it a Choice item that can be exploited. Gastrodon with Storm Drain completely blanks Volt Switch and Hydro Pump, forcing Rotom to Trick or Tera Electric to break through. In Trick Room, Rotom’s speed advantage vanishes, letting slow wallbreakers like Torkoal or Hatterene OHKO it. Finally, Rotom’s reliance on Hydro Pump means a miss can cost games; opponents can Protect stall to burn PP or punish with a double-target. To beat Rotom, pack a Grass-type, a faster Scarfer, or Storm Drain, and force it to predict perfectly every turn.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Scrafty": {"Abilities": {"intimidate": 9.518124940440114, "shedskin": 0.1980430322964572, "moxie": 0.0235824119417104}, "Items": {"clearamulet": 0.5555685400375753}, "Spreads": {"Adamant:252/252/0/0/4/0": 0.582116303043071}, "Moves": ["fakeout", "knockoff", "drainpunch", "protect"], "Tera Types": {"poison": 0.2170688876479129, "psychic": 0.49726673725225284}, "Teammates": ["Volcarona", "Ninetales-Alola", "Dragonite", "Archaludon", "Ursaluna-Bloodmoon", "Slowbro"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Scrafty is a niche but potent support pivot in VGC, leveraging Intimidate and Fake Out to control the early game while its Dark/Fighting STABs break common screens and deal solid damage. With a 90/115/115 bulk spread, it can stomach hits from physical attackers and pivot into slower threats, though its low Speed tier leaves it outrun by most of the metagame. Clear Amulet blocks opposing Intimidate and Parting Shot, preserving its own Attack while it chips with Knock Off or heals with Drain Punch. Poison or Psychic Tera types give it surprise value—Poison removes its Fairy weakness and absorbs Toxic, while Psychic flips the script on opposing Fighting-types and grants a Psyspam resistance. On squads that appreciate early pressure and speed control, Scrafty fills a glue role that can both enable and benefit from Tailwind or Trick Room.</OUTPUT>

input:
Create the 'full_analysis' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Scrafty": {"Abilities": {"intimidate": 9.518124940440114, "shedskin": 0.1980430322964572, "moxie": 0.0235824119417104}, "Items": {"clearamulet": 0.5555685400375753}, "Spreads": {"Adamant:252/252/0/0/4/0": 0.582116303043071}, "Moves": ["fakeout", "knockoff", "drainpunch", "protect"], "Tera Types": {"poison": 0.2170688876479129, "psychic": 0.49726673725225284}, "Teammates": ["Volcarona", "Ninetales-Alola", "Dragonite", "Archaludon", "Ursaluna-Bloodmoon", "Slowbro"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Scrafty’s value lies in its unique typing and support movepool. Dark/Fighting is offensively excellent into the ubiquitous Steel and Psychic cores that define Regulation G, and Knock Off’s item removal is priceless in a format overflowing with Sitrus Berry, Covert Cloak, and booster items. Fake Out buys a free turn for partners like Volcarona or Ursaluna-Bloodmoon to set up or reposition, while Intimidate immediately weakens physical sweepers such as Dragonite, Chien-Pao, or Kingambit. Drain Punch provides reliable recovery that, when paired with Scrafty’s natural bulk, lets it stick around long enough to fire off multiple Knock Offs. Clear Amulet is the item of choice because it nullifies the most common Attack drops in the format—Intimidate, Parting Shot, and Feather Dance—ensuring Scrafty’s damage output remains consistent. The EV spread is simple: max Attack Adamant to hit as hard as possible while the remaining 4 EVs are dropped into Sp.Def to round out its special bulk. Poison Tera is preferred for the Toxic immunity and to remove the quadruple Fairy weakness, but Psychic Tera is a spicy alternative that lets Scrafty stomach Close Combats and retaliate through Tera Psychic Stored Power or Tera Blast if desired. The moveset is intentionally four-slot syndrome proof: Fake Out and Protect are mandatory for pivoting, Knock Off is the best utility move in the game, and Drain Punch is the most reliable STAB that also keeps Scrafty healthy. No fourth coverage move is run because the support role is more valuable than situational coverage.</OUTPUT>

input:
Write the 'matchup_overview' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Scrafty": {"Abilities": {"intimidate": 9.518124940440114, "shedskin": 0.1980430322964572, "moxie": 0.0235824119417104}, "Items": {"clearamulet": 0.5555685400375753}, "Spreads": {"Adamant:252/252/0/0/4/0": 0.582116303043071}, "Moves": ["fakeout", "knockoff", "drainpunch", "protect"], "Tera Types": {"poison": 0.2170688876479129, "psychic": 0.49726673725225284}, "Teammates": ["Volcarona", "Ninetales-Alola", "Dragonite", "Archaludon", "Ursaluna-Bloodmoon", "Slowbro"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Scrafty enjoys positive matchups into most physical attackers—Intimidate plus resisting Crunch, Knock Off, and Sucker Punch lets it check Kingambit, opposing Scrafty, and Roaring Moon. It also pressures Psychic-spam teams by outslowing and OHKOing Indeedee and Hatterene with Knock Off before they can set terrain or Trick Room. Fairy-types are the obvious bane: Azumarill, Sylveon, and Flutter Mane all outspeed and obliterate it with STAB Moonblast or Play Rough. Flying-types such as Tornadus and Dragonite also deal heavy damage with Hurricane or Acrobatics, though Intimidate plus Tera Poison can let Scrafty survive a hit and retaliate. Fire-types like Heatran and Volcarona roast it, but Scrafty can at least remove Volcarona’s Heavy-Duty Boots or weaken it for a teammate. Into Trick Room it flips: under reverse speed Scrafty becomes a fast attacker that can KO many setters, but it must watch for Dusclops’ Bulldoze or Hatterene’s Dazzling Gleam. Finally, Scrafty hates status—burn neuters Drain Punch recovery and poison wears it down quickly—so partners that absorb Toxic or provide Heal Pulse support are appreciated.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Overqwil": {"Abilities": {"swiftswim": 6.979559209243081, "intimidate": 1.664704698111469, "poisonpoint": 1.7651056883224259}, "Items": {"clearamulet": 0.3269023817953099, "choiceband": 0.26469920244438033}, "Spreads": {"Adamant:4/252/0/0/0/252": 0.5169872820670158}, "Moves": ["throatchop", "protect", "gunkshot", "liquidation"], "Tera Types": {"water": 0.3050026540103498, "dark": 0.19317257064024254, "normal": 0.21961407338883615}, "Teammates": ["Archaludon", "Pelipper", "Basculegion", "Rillaboom", "Gholdengo", "Sneasler"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Overqwil is a niche but surprisingly effective offensive pivot in VGC 2024, leveraging its unique Dark/Poison typing and respectable 85/95/65 bulk to threaten common Fairy, Psychic and Grass threats while also providing speed control under rain via Swift Swim. Though its base 85 Attack is modest, access to strong STABs like Gunk Shot and Liquidation—plus the ability to bypass Intimidate with Clear Amulet—lets it break through bulky neutral targets. The combination of rain-boosted Liquidation and Poison coverage makes it a natural partner for Pelipper-based rain, where it can outspeed and KO key threats such as Flutter Mane, Indeedee-F and Rillaboom while still checking Trick Room modes with Throat Chop. Its EV spread is almost always max Attack and Speed with an Adamant nature, ensuring it hits as hard as possible while still outspeeding the crowded base 100 tier under rain. Tera Water is the most common choice, turning Liquidation into a nuke and removing the Ground weakness, though Tera Dark and Normal are also viable for tailored match-ups. Overqwil’s usage is low (roughly 1.4 % of qualified teams), but its win-rate when brought is quietly impressive because it compresses offensive pressure, speed control and anti-Fairy utility into a single slot.</OUTPUT>

input:
Draft the 'full_analysis' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Overqwil": {"Abilities": {"swiftswim": 6.979559209243081, "intimidate": 1.664704698111469, "poisonpoint": 1.7651056883224259}, "Items": {"clearamulet": 0.3269023817953099, "choiceband": 0.26469920244438033}, "Spreads": {"Adamant:4/252/0/0/0/252": 0.5169872820670158}, "Moves": ["throatchop", "protect", "gunkshot", "liquidation"], "Tera Types": {"water": 0.3050026540103498, "dark": 0.19317257064024254, "normal": 0.21961407338883615}, "Teammates": ["Archaludon", "Pelipper", "Basculegion", "Rillaboom", "Gholdengo", "Sneasler"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Overqwil’s stat line is deceptively well-suited to the current metagame: 85 HP / 95 Def / 65 SpD gives it enough physical bulk to survive -1 Gholdengo Make It Rain or a Life Orb Rillaboom Wood Hammer, while 85 Spe becomes 170 under Swift Swim—enough to outpace +1 Roaring Moon, Choice Scarf Gholdengo and every relevant weather sweeper. Dark/Poison is a fantastic offensive combination, hitting every Tapu, Indeedee, Armarouge, Hatterene and Ogerpon for super-effective damage; defensively it packs only two weaknesses (Ground and Psychic) and four key resistances (Grass, Dark, Ghost, Poison) that allow it to pivot into Rillaboom, Basculegion and Sneasler with minimal chip. The ability distribution on the ladder shows 79 % Swift Swim, 19 % Intimidate and 2 % Poison Point, confirming that rain sweeping is its primary identity, but Intimidate variants are gaining traction on non-rain teams that simply want a bulky offensive Intimidate user that also scorns Fairy-types. Item-wise, Clear Amulet appears on ~45 % of recorded sets, preventing Attack drops from Intimidate, Parting Shot or Chilling Water and ensuring Liquidation and Gunk Shot retain full power; Choice Band (~35 %) is the other major option, giving Overqwil the immediate muscle to OHKO bulkless Flutter Mane and 2HKO max-HP Garganacl after Tera Water. The listed moves—Throat Chop, Protect, Gunk Shot, Liquidation—form the standard four-slot set: Liquidation is the spammable STAB that also procs rain boost, Gunk Shot nukes Fairies and Grass-types, Throat Chop blocks Follow Me, Helping Hand and TR-setting attempts from the likes of Indeedee-F and Armarouge, and Protect is mandatory for doubles play. Tera Water is preferred because it strengthens Liquidation and removes the Ground weakness, letting Overqwil survive Great Tusk Headlong Rush or Landorus-T Earth Power and retaliate. Tera Dark is taken when teams need a stronger Throat Chop breakpoint (e.g. OHKOing offensive Calyrex-I through Reflect), while Tera Normal grants an immunity to Ghost-type moves and synergises with teammates running Ghost themselves to block Rapid Spin. Overqwil’s synergy with Pelipper is obvious—rain doubles its Speed and Liquidation power—but it also appreciates Pelipper’s U-turn and Tailwind support to gain positioning. Archaludon is the most common partner, forming a rain-based VoltTurn core: Archaludon baits Ground- and Fighting-types for Overqwil to threaten, while Overqwil lures Grass- and Fairy-types for Archaludon to obliterate with Electro Shot. Basculegion provides a second Swift Swim attacker that breaks physical walls like Corviknight and Dozo, while Rillaboom gives Grassy Glide priority and Fake Out support, patching up Overqwil’s merely okay bulk with healing. Gholdengo offers a Ghost resist and late-game cleaning, and Sneasler supplies fast Poison Touch pressure that can stack status alongside Overqwil’s Poison Point rolls. In practice, Overqwil functions as a mid-game breaker that can clean once its checks are weakened, or as an early-game pivot that trades favourably into common leads such as Indeedee-F + Armarouge or Rillaboom + Heatran. Its main drawbacks are a lack of reliable recovery, a 30 % miss chance on Gunk Shot, and the need for rain to truly shine, but proper team support mitigates these issues and turns Overqwil into a potent pocket pick that most opponents fail to respect.</OUTPUT>

Generate the 'matchup_overview' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Overqwil": {"Abilities": {"swiftswim": 6.979559209243081, "intimidate": 1.664704698111469, "poisonpoint": 1.7651056883224259}, "Items": {"clearamulet": 0.3269023817953099, "choiceband": 0.26469920244438033}, "Spreads": {"Adamant:4/252/0/0/0/252": 0.5169872820670158}, "Moves": ["throatchop", "protect", "gunkshot", "liquidation"], "Tera Types": {"water": 0.3050026540103498, "dark": 0.19317257064024254, "normal": 0.21961407338883615}, "Teammates": ["Archaludon", "Pelipper", "Basculegion", "Rillaboom", "Gholdengo", "Sneasler"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Overqwil’s match-up spread is polarised but powerful. Against rain-weak archetypes—Sun, Sand, and most balanced builds—it functions as a win-condition: under rain it outspeeds and OHKOes Flutter Mane, Iron Crown, Chi-Yu and offensive Landorus-T with Liquidation, while Gunk Shot picks off Tapu Fini, Tapu Lele, Ogerpon-Wellspring and bulky Sylveon. It 2HKOes max-HP Garganacl after Tera Water and cleanly OHKOes offensive variants, making it one of the most reliable Garg answers available. Versus Trick Room, Throat Chop prevents Indeedee-F from setting up Psychic Terrain and Follow Me, and the 85 % flinch chance can force mind-games with Hatterene; if TR still goes up, Overqwil can survive a Life Orb Rage Powder from Amoonguss and KO back with Gunk Shot. Against opposing weather, Overqwil needs to be careful: Sun teams carry Torkoal Overheat andProtosynthesis Great Tusk Headlong Rush, both of which OHKO even through Tera Water, so it must either come in after a KO or rely on Pelipper’s Tailwind to win the speed tie. Sand teams with Choice Scarf Garchomp are similarly problematic, though Overqwil can survive non-boosted Earthquake and KO back with Liquidation after chip. Into bulky offense, Overqwil’s main hurdle is Corviknight, which avoids the 2HKO from Liquidation even after Tera Water; teams therefore run Basculegion or Specs Pelipper Hurricane to soften it first. vs. Screens or Booster Energy setups, Overqwil’s speed tier under rain lets it snipe key threats before they move, but it dislikes Thunder Wave from Grimmsnarl or Zapdos and can be worn down by Rocky Helmet + Iron Barbs chip. Finally, Psychic Terrain from Indeedee-F blocks priority Sucker Punch from Kingambit, which otherwise checks Overqwil, so terrain wars are a micro-game within the broader match-up.</OUTPUT>

input:
Write a detailed 'role_description' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Overqwil": {"Abilities": {"swiftswim": 6.979559209243081, "intimidate": 1.664704698111469, "poisonpoint": 1.7651056883224259}, "Items": {"clearamulet": 0.3269023817953099, "choiceband": 0.26469920244438033}, "Spreads": {"Adamant:4/252/0/0/0/252": 0.5169872820670158}, "Moves": ["throatchop", "protect", "gunkshot", "liquidation"], "Tera Types": {"water": 0.3050026540103498, "dark": 0.19317257064024254, "normal": 0.21961407338883615}, "Teammates": ["Archaludon", "Pelipper", "Basculegion", "Rillaboom", "Gholdengo", "Sneasler"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Overqwil is best viewed as a Swift Swim wall-breaker and anti-meta Fairy slayer that can compress the roles of speed control, offensive Intimidate and late-game cleaner into one slot. On rain teams it is the secondary speed control behind Pelipper Tailwind, providing immediate offensive pressure that discourages opponents from staying in with their Fairy or Grass-type. On non-rain builds, Intimidate variants act as a bulky pivot that switches into Rillaboom, Basculegion and Kingambit, drops Attack, and threatens to KO or force switches with strong dual-STAB. Its speed tier is mediocre outside rain, so these teams tend to pair it with either Tailwind from Corviknight or paralysis support from Zapdos/Rotom-W to let it function. Regardless of weather, Overqwil’s primary job is to remove or weaken the opponent’s Fairy-type so that its teammates—often Gholdengo, Archaludon or Basculegion—can sweep unimpeded. It also serves as a soft check to physical set-up sweepers such as Swords Dance Kingambit and Dragon Dance Baxcalibur thanks to Intimidate and the ability to tank a hit and KO back. Because it carries Protect, it can stall Dynamon turns or delay Tailwind expiration, giving its team tempo advantages. In the late game, once Ground- and Psychic-types are eliminated, Overqwil becomes a bona-fide sweeper under rain, outspeeding everything except Choice Scarf Dragapult and OHKOing most neutral targets with Liquidation. Its role is therefore flexible: early-game pivot, mid-game breaker, or late-game cleaner depending on team composition and opposing board state.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Archaludon is Overqwil’s ideal partner, forming a rain-based VoltTurn core that abuses the opponent’s Ground- and Fighting-type weaknesses: Archaludon baits Great Tusk and Iron Hands, which Overqwil threatens, while Overqwil lures Tapu Fini and Rillaboom for Archaludon to remove with Electro Shot. Pelipper is mandatory for Swift Swim activation and provides Tailwind, U-turn chip and Wide Guard to block opposing spread moves. Basculegion shares Swift Swim and breaks physical walls like Corviknight and Dondozo that Overqwil struggles with, while appreciating Overqwil’s ability to KO Fairy-types that wall it. Rillaboom gives Grassy Glide priority, Fake Out support and terrain control, healing Overqwil every turn to mitigate its lack of recovery; in return Overqwil removes opposing Amoonguss and Tapu Fini that trouble Rillaboom. Gholdengo offers a Ghost resist, immunity to status, and late-game cleaning with Make It Rain, while Overqwil removes Kingambit and Kingambit’s Dark-type checks. Sneasler provides a second Poison-type that can stack Poison Touch with Overqwil’s Poison Point, overwhelming bulky walls with layered status, and also pressures Corviknight with Close Combat. Beyond these six, other strong allies include Tornadus-T for additional Tailwind and Rain Dance backup, Kingdra as a third Swift Swim option, and Rotom-W for Volt Switch and Will-O-Wisp to further cripple physical checks. The overarching synergy theme is rain-based offensive pressure that overloads common defensive cores with dual Swift Swim attackers, Intimidate drops, and Tera Water nukes.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Overqwil": {"Abilities": {"swiftswim": 6.979559209243081, "intimidate": 1.664704698111469, "poisonpoint": 1.7651056883224259}, "Items": {"clearamulet": 0.3269023817953099, "choiceband": 0.26469920244438033}, "Spreads": {"Adamant:4/252/0/0/0/252": 0.5169872820670158}, "Moves": ["throatchop", "protect", "gunkshot", "liquidation"], "Tera Types": {"water": 0.3050026540103498, "dark": 0.19317257064024254, "normal": 0.21961407338883615}, "Teammates": ["Archaludon", "Pelipper", "Basculegion", "Rillaboom", "Gholdengo", "Sneasler"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Overqwil’s most glaring weakness is its reliance on rain: outside of Swift Swim, base 85 Speed leaves it outsped by every relevant scarfer and booster-energy threat, while its bulk is merely okay, so strong neutral hits like Choice Specs Flutter Mane Moonblast or Life Orb Chien-Pao Ice Spinner will OHKO. Ground-type moves are the most direct answer: Great Tusk Headlong Rush, Landorus-T Earth Power and Garchomp Earthquake all OHKO even through Tera Water if rain is not up, so keeping Pelipper alive is paramount. Psychic-types also threaten it: Indeedee-F Expanding Force in terrain and Choice Specs Tapu Lele Psychic are guaranteed OHKOs, though both must be wary of switching into Gunk Shot. Bulky Steel-types such as Corviknight and Celesteela avoid the 2HKO from Liquidation and can stall out rain with Roost + Iron Defense, or retaliate with Body Press. Status cripples Overqwil: burns from Rotom-W or Zapdos halve its Attack, while paralysis from Grimmsnarl Thunder Wave removes its speed advantage under rain. Priority moves like Kingambit Sucker Punch or Chien-Pao Ice Shard can finish it after chip, though Psychic Terrain blocks the former. Finally, Gunk Shot’s 30 % miss rate can flip games, especially if Overqwil is the last remaining attacker. To counter Overqwil, preserve your Ground-type attacker until rain is down, keep Stealth Rock off your side so you can safely pivot, and spread paralysis or burns early to neuter its sweeping potential. If you lack a Ground-type, Tera Fairy Corviknight or Tera Flying Gholdengo can stomach a Liquidation and KO back with Body Press or Make It Rain respectively.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Coalossal is a niche but dangerous setup sweeper in VGC that relies on the combination of Steam Engine + Weakness Policy to rocket to +2 Speed and +2 in all stats in a single turn; with STAB Rock and Ground coverage plus Tera Ground for an extra kick, it can rip through unprepared teams, yet its awkward Speed tier outside of Steam Engine activation and reliance on taking a Water or Fire hit make it inconsistent and prediction-heavy.</OUTPUT>

input:
Produce the 'full_analysis' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Coalossal": {"Abilities": {"steamengine": 9.854319077527173, "flamebody": 0.00010147578281594072, "flashfire": 0.004361914798467925}, "Items": {"weaknesspolicy": 0.9228664573391979}, "Spreads": {"Modest:4/0/0/252/0/252": 0.1594546112054017, "Modest:28/0/0/252/0/228": 0.19620460771647374, "Modest:180/0/4/236/20/68": 0.32390559231839056}, "Moves": ["earthpower", "powergem", "protect", "heatwave"], "Tera Types": {"grass": 0.29152429613787, "ground": 0.6228841120307456}, "Teammates": ["Incineroar", "Primarina", "Dragapult", "Annihilape", "Meowscarada", "Frosmoth"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Coalossal’s claim to fame is its unique ability Steam Engine, which raises its Speed by six stages when hit by a Water or Fire move—essentially a free Max Airstream’s worth of Speed in one shot.  Pairing this with Weakness Policy means that the same attack that triggers Steam Engine also maxes out Coalossal’s offensive stats, turning the normally sluggish coal monster into a 158/90 offensive juggernaut that can outspeed and KO most of the metagame.  The dominant spread (32 % of usage) runs 236 SpA / 20 SpD / 68 Spe Modest, which lets it survive modest Water-type hits to guarantee the activation, outspeed +1 base 100s after Steam Engine, and still hit as hard as possible.  Earth Power and Power Gem give perfect neutral coverage outside of Levitate or Flying-type resists, while Heat Wave is a reliable spread option that also triggers Steam Engine off an ally’s Surf in doubles.  Protect is mandatory to stall speed control or let an ally trigger the policy.  Tera Ground is preferred on 62 % of teams to remove the 4× Water weakness, turn incoming Water moves into neutral hits that still activate Steam Engine, and give Coalossal a same-type Earth Power nuke; Tera Grass is a respectable alternative that flips the Water matchup entirely but leaves Coalossal weaker to Ice and Poison.  The near-universal Weakness Policy (92 % usage) underscores the all-in nature of the set: if you fail to activate it, Coalossal is usually dead weight.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Coalossal": {"Abilities": {"steamengine": 9.854319077527173, "flamebody": 0.00010147578281594072, "flashfire": 0.004361914798467925}, "Items": {"weaknesspolicy": 0.9228664573391979}, "Spreads": {"Modest:4/0/0/252/0/252": 0.1594546112054017, "Modest:28/0/0/252/0/228": 0.19620460771647374, "Modest:180/0/4/236/20/68": 0.32390559231839056}, "Moves": ["earthpower", "powergem", "protect", "heatwave"], "Tera Types": {"grass": 0.29152429613787, "ground": 0.6228841120307456}, "Teammates": ["Incineroar", "Primarina", "Dragapult", "Annihilape", "Meowscarada", "Frosmoth"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Coalossal loves to face bulky Waters like Tapu Fini, Primarina, and Ogerpon-Wellspring that naturally click Water-type moves, turning their own STAB into a speed-boosting gift; similarly, Fire-type attacks from Incineroar or Heatran are welcome invitations.  It fares poorly against faster offensive Dragons such as Dragapult and Roaring Moon that can KO before activation, and against teams that simply ignore it—Electric, Grass, or Psychic attackers that never target Coalossal leave it at its base 30 Speed, making it setup fodder.  Tera Ground variants still dislike strong Ground-immune Pokémon like Corviknight and Skarmory, while Tera Grass versions invite opposing Kyurem or Gholdengo to steamroll with Ice or Steel moves.  In tailwind or vs. opposing weather sweepers, Coalossal usually needs its own speed control (ally Surf or priority) to avoid being outpaced even after Steam Engine.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Coalossal is a dedicated win-condition that functions best as a mid-game or late-game cleaner once its checks have been weakened and the opponent is locked into Water or Fire moves.  It is not a traditional tank—its base 110/90/90 bulk is merely adequate—so it must be brought in after a KO or via pivoting, immediately threaten KOs, and snowball through the rest of the team.  Because it needs to be targeted to function, Coalossal is inherently a “bait” Pokémon: it forces the opponent into uncomfortable choices between attacking Coalossal and activating its sweep or ignoring it and letting it fire off free attacks.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Incineroar is the most common partner, providing Intimidate, Fake Out, and a Fire-type move that can be aimed at Coalossal for self-activation; Primarina is next, offering Surf to trigger Steam Engine while dealing negligible damage to Coalossal thanks to low base power and possible Tera Ground. Frosmoth is a more niche pick that can Surf or Heat Wave for activation and appreciates Coalossal removing Steel-types.  In general, Coalossal wants bulky pivots that can absorb hits while positioning it, and Water-type allies that can click Surf without fear once Coalossal has Terastallized into Ground or Grass.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>The simplest counterplay is to ignore Coalossal: avoid using Water or Fire moves until it is KO’d, and instead pressure it with neutral special attacks or status.  Faster Dragons like Dragapult, Roaring Moon, and Hydreigon outspeed and KO before activation.  Priority users such as Kingambit or Annihilape can pick off weakened Coalossal before it moves.  Follow-Me or Rage Powder users like Amoonguss or Togekiss can redirect the self-activating Surf, leaving Coalossal at base Speed.  Tera Flying or Levitate Pokémon—Rotom-Wash, Gholdengo, Corviknight—negate Earth Power and stall turns.  Finally, Trick Room teams can flip the speed dynamic, letting slow attackers move before Coalossal even after Steam Engine.</OUTPUT>

input:
Create the 'full_analysis' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Mienshao": {"Abilities": {"innerfocus": 10.374446467252428, "regenerator": 0.05626586209419743, "reckless": 0.009914823335241074}, "Items": {"focussash": 0.8301095703465875}, "Spreads": {"Jolly:4/252/0/0/0/252": 0.725077985282013}, "Moves": ["wideguard", "knockoff", "closecombat", "fakeout"], "Tera Types": {"dark": 0.7666310493705825}, "Teammates": ["Ninetales-Alola", "Gholdengo", "Glaceon", "Glimmora", "Toxapex", "Eiscue"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>With a blistering 105 base Speed tier, Mienshao outspeeds the crowded 100/95/90 Speed bracket and immediately threatens opposing leads with Fake Out and Knock Off. Inner Focus lets it ignore opposing Fake Out, preserving its Sash and guaranteeing momentum. Wide Guard is the glue that defines its utility, shutting down spread Rock Slides, Heat Waves and Water Spouts that plague its Ice- and Fire-type teammates. Close Combat is a respectable STAB that punishes Incineroar, Kingambit and Gholdengo, while Knock Off cripples bulky pivots and removes Heavy-Duty Boots from hazard removers. Regenerator is technically legal, but the data show that players strongly prefer Inner Focus to avoid flinches from Tornadus, Lilligant-Hisui and Iron Head users; Reckless is almost never selected. The Jolly 252/252 spread maximises speed and power while keeping the Focus Sash intact for one full-health survival. Dark Tera is the clear favourite, letting Mienshao absorb Ghost-type attacks aimed at Gholdengo and turning Knock Off into a nuclear 97.5 BP STAB that can break through physically bulky neutral targets.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Mienshao": {"Abilities": {"innerfocus": 10.374446467252428, "regenerator": 0.05626586209419743, "reckless": 0.009914823335241074}, "Items": {"focussash": 0.8301095703465875}, "Spreads": {"Jolly:4/252/0/0/0/252": 0.725077985282013}, "Moves": ["wideguard", "knockoff", "closecombat", "fakeout"], "Tera Types": {"dark": 0.7666310493705825}, "Teammates": ["Ninetales-Alola", "Gholdengo", "Glaceon", "Glimmora", "Toxapex", "Eiscue"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Mienshao enjoys excellent match-ups against hazard-stacking and spread-attack archetypes. Wide Guard neuters Gholdengo’s Make It Rain, Glimmora’s Mortal Spin, and Torkoal’s Eruption, while Fake Out pressures frail offensive leads such as Iron Bundle and Chien-Pao. Against Tailwind or Trick Room teams, knocking off the holder’s item before the speed control goes up is often game-defining. Conversely, priority users like Kingambit and Dragonite can bypass its Speed, and Rocky Helmet or Iron Barbs punish Close Combat. Ghost types such as Aegislash and bulky Dragapult avoid Close Combat and retalify with super-effective STAB. Psychic Terrain from Indeedee blocks Fake Out, while Rage Powder or Follow Me redirect its single-target moves. Finally, once Sash is broken, any faster scarfer or +1 setup sweeper can finish it off.</OUTPUT>

Its blazing Speed tier lets it perform these duties before most threats move, and Inner Focus ensures Fake Out users cannot stop it. After performing its utility, Mienshao can pivot out with U-turn (though the current sample moveset omits it) or act as a late-game cleaner once checks are weakened and Sash is still intact.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Goodra-Hisui": {"Abilities": {"sapsipper": 6.044730582569065, "shellarmor": 3.472899005547485, "gooey": 0.47380307168150887}, "Items": {"leftovers": 0.7555283000392103}, "Spreads": {}, "Moves": ["bodypress", "acidarmor", "protect", "lifedew"], "Tera Types": {"water": 0.3903148601437117, "ghost": 0.15263838274374453}, "Teammates": ["Archaludon", "Rillaboom", "Amoonguss", "Gholdengo", "Volcarona", "Incineroar"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Hisuian Goodra is a niche defensive tank in VGC 2024 that leverages its excellent bulk, unique Dragon/Steel typing, and Sap Sipper to check prominent Grass-types such as Rillaboom and Whimsicott while simultaneously setting up with Acid Armor and threatening opposing physical attackers with Body Press. Although its usage is low and its item data is sparse, the sets that do appear center on Iron Defense-style stalling with Leftovers recovery, Protect, and Life Dew to support teammates. Its 6% Sap Sipper share shows it is primarily chosen for Grass-type immunity, turning Rillaboom’s Glide or Amoonguss’s Spore into free boosts, while the remaining abilities (Shell Armor and Gooey) are largely irrelevant. Tera Water and Tera Ghost provide modest defensive utility, the former removing Fire and Ground weaknesses and the latter blocking Fake Out and Extreme Speed, but neither is common enough to define its identity. Overall, Hisuian Goodra is a matchup-dependent pivot that can run away with games if given turns to boost, yet it demands heavy team support to cover its passivity and lack of offensive pressure.</OUTPUT>

input:
Write a detailed 'full_analysis' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Goodra-Hisui": {"Abilities": {"sapsipper": 6.044730582569065, "shellarmor": 3.472899005547485, "gooey": 0.47380307168150887}, "Items": {"leftovers": 0.7555283000392103}, "Spreads": {}, "Moves": ["bodypress", "acidarmor", "protect", "lifedew"], "Tera Types": {"water": 0.3903148601437117, "ghost": 0.15263838274374453}, "Teammates": ["Archaludon", "Rillaboom", "Amoonguss", "Gholdengo", "Volcarona", "Incineroar"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Hisuian Goodra’s stat line (80/100/150/120/150/60) is min-maxed for special tanking, giving it the highest special bulk in the current Regulation G pool outside of dedicated walls like Dondozo. Dragon/Steel is a defensively stacked typing that resists every type except the rare Fairy, Fighting, and Ground, but it also saddles Goodra with a crippling 4× weakness to the ever-present Iron Valiant and Iron Hands. Sap Sipper flips the script on Grass-type offense, turning Rillaboom’s U-turn or Amooguss’s Spore into +1 Attack boosts that immediately transform Goodra into a Body Press threat. Acid Armor is the crux of the set, skyrocketing its already titanic Defense to +2 in a single turn and letting Body Press hit 120 BP off a stat that can reach 400+ after boosts. Protect and Life Dew complete the stall package, letting Goodra block double-target pressure and heal both itself and its ally for 25% in a format where passive recovery is scarce. Leftovers is the only item shown with any frequency, synergizing with Life Dew to create incremental recovery that can outlast opposing damage output. The absence of offensive move data implies that Goodra relies entirely on Body Press and ally chip to score KOs, making it a true team-support tank rather than a standalone win condition. Its Speed tier is intentionally low, letting it move last to enable ally redirection or speed-control setups, and its Tera options are conservative: Water removes one of its two 4× weaknesses (Fire) and adds useful Ground resistance, while Ghost offers immunity to Fake Out and Extreme Speed, two of the most common forms of priority that break through Protect. Despite these strengths, Goodra’s passivity and need for multiple setup turns relegate it to a niche role on squads that already possess overwhelming offensive pressure elsewhere.</OUTPUT>

Overall, Goodra’s matchups are polarized: it walls one side of the metagame and folds to the other, making it a textbook “silver-bullet” pick.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>The most common partners—Archaludon, Rillaboom, Amoonguss, Gholdengo, Volcarona, and Incineroar—form a balanced core that covers Goodra’s weaknesses and leverages its Grass immunity. Archaludon shares Steel typing and appreciates Goodra’s ability to eliminate opposing Rillaboom, while Goodra in turn enjoys Archaludon’s Stamina boosts and wide-ranging resistances that let the pair wall physical attackers together. Rillaboom is seemingly paradoxical, but its Grassy Glide targets are exactly the Water- and Ground-types that threaten Goodra, and Sap Sipper turns opposing Rillaboom mirrors into a one-sided boost. Amoonguss provides redirection and Spore support, letting Goodra set up Acid Armor freely; likewise, Goodra switches into Grass-type attacks aimed at Amoonguss. Gholdengo punishes opposing status and spreads hazard chip, while Goodra tanks Fighting- and Dark-type moves for it. Volcarona offers fast offensive pressure and appreciates Goodra’s ability to stall Dynamax turns with Protect, letting it set up Quiver Dance later. Finally, Incineroar supplies Intimidate and Parting Shot, both of which buy Goodra free turns to boost or recover. Tera synergy is straightforward: Goodra can Tera Water to remove Fire weakness for Volcarona, or Tera Ghost to block Fake Out for Incineroar pivoting. Overall, the team template is a “dual-tank offense” that trades raw speed for incremental advantage and endgame bulk.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Frosmoth is a niche but dangerous setup sweeper in VGC, leveraging its unique Ice Scales ability to halve special damage while it uses Quiver Dance to snowball. Statistically, 99.6 % of players rely on Ice Scales, pairing it with Covert Cloak (43 %), Sitrus (25 %), or Leftovers (21 %) to survive the boost turns. input:
Provide the 'full_analysis' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Frosmoth": {"Abilities": {"icescales": 9.002848184232077, "shielddust": 0.04366718845789519}, "Items": {"sitrusberry": 0.24819781064849616, "leftovers": 0.20851257507598978, "covertcloak": 0.4314952359390217}, "Spreads": {"Timid:116/0/236/4/4/148": 0.21382145353593307, "Modest:212/0/212/36/4/44": 0.3529883765533585}, "Moves": ["quiverdance", "bugbuzz", "protect", "icebeam"], "Tera Types": {"dragon": 0.38822209358581006, "water": 0.2928253873293843, "electric": 0.21705010366345484}, "Teammates": ["Incineroar", "Ninetales-Alola", "Primarina", "Dragapult", "Meowscarada", "Coalossal"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Frosmoth’s claim to fame is Ice Scales, an ability no other legal Pokémon possesses in VGC. By halving any special damage taken, Frosmoth can comfortably set up Quiver Dance in front of special attackers that would obliterate most other setup sweepers. After a single dance, its Special Attack and Special Defense skyrocket to astronomical levels, while its Speed becomes serviceable against slower boards. The chosen item defines its setup window: Covert Cloak blocks fake-out and secondary effects such as Moonblast drops or Sludge Bomb poison, Sitrus provides a one-off 25 % heal to survive a physical hit, and Leftovers offers gradual recovery that synergizes with Protect stalling. The two listed spreads illustrate the dichotomy: the 116 HP / 236 Def / 148 Spe Timid variant hits 143 Speed, outspeeding max-speed Dragapult and +1 base 100s after a dance, turning Frosmoth into a late-game cleaner. Conversely, the 212 HP / 212 Def / 44 Spe Modest spread lives Jolly Chien-Pao Ice Spinner and Timid Life Orb Dragon Pulse from Dragapult, making it a mid-game wallbreaker that can trade with physical attackers after chip. Tera Dragon is the optimal choice, removing the crippling Fire weakness and granting a neutral matchup into Steel-types that otherwise wall STAB Ice/Bug. Tera Water and Electric are situational, offering different defensive profiles against Sun or Electric Terrain teams respectively. The moveset is non-negotiable: Quiver Dance is the win condition, Ice Beam and Bug Buzz provide perfect neutral coverage barring Tera Fire Steel-types, and Protect is essential for double-target mind games and gaining Leftovers recovery. Frosmoth’s success hinges on teammate support: Incineroar provides Intimidate and Parting Shot to buy turns; Alolan Ninetales sets Aurora Veil and brings Snow, enabling 100 % accurate Blizzards if Frosmoth opts for it; Primarina and Dragapult offer immediate special pressure to soften shared checks; Meowscarada gives Grass coverage and Flower Trick for Calyrex-I; Coalossal sets sun for Moonlight-boosted Weather Ball or simply provides a physical tank that appreciates special walls. In practice, Frosmoth functions as a secondary win condition: the first four turns are spent chipping Incineroar, knocking out Torkoal, or paralyzing Iron Hands so that Frosmoth can sweep from turn 5 onward.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Frosmoth": {"Abilities": {"icescales": 9.002848184232077, "shielddust": 0.04366718845789519}, "Items": {"sitrusberry": 0.24819781064849616, "leftovers": 0.20851257507598978, "covertcloak": 0.4314952359390217}, "Spreads": {"Timid:116/0/236/4/4/148": 0.21382145353593307, "Modest:212/0/212/36/4/44": 0.3529883765533585}, "Moves": ["quiverdance", "bugbuzz", "protect", "icebeam"], "Tera Types": {"dragon": 0.38822209358581006, "water": 0.2928253873293843, "electric": 0.21705010366345484}, "Teammates": ["Incineroar", "Ninetales-Alola", "Primarina", "Dragapult", "Meowscarada", "Coalossal"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Against special teams, Frosmoth is oppressive: Life Orb Flutter Mane Moonblast fails to KO, while +1 Ice Beam OHKOs back. It similarly beats Tatsugiri, Iron Jugulis, and most bulky Waters. Physical attackers are trickier: Chien-Pao, Kingambit, and Palafin can all OHKO with their respective STABs before setup, so Frosmoth requires either Ally Switch, Intimidate, or burn support. Sun teams are a nightmare because Tera Fire coverage and Torkoal Eruption deal massive damage even through Ice Scales; however, if Sun is removed or Torkoal is KO’d, Frosmoth can still sweep. Trick Room teams are mixed: Frosmoth outspeeds most TR sweepers after a dance, but Hatterene and Indeedee-F can redirect or KO with Dazzling Gleam. Steel-types such as Corviknight and Gholdengo wall Frosmoth unless it has already acquired multiple boosts, making Tera Dragon crucial to muscle through with +2 Ice Beam. Ghost-types like Aegislash and Dragapult can threaten with Shadow Ball, but Ice Scales minimizes the roll, letting Frosmoth 2HKO back with Bug Buzz. Overall, Frosmoth dominates special-oriented boards but demands extensive support versus physical or weather-centric archetypes.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Jolteon carves a niche in VGC as a blazing-fast support pivot that sacrifices raw power for disruptive speed control and setup facilitation. With a Timid 252 Speed EV spread it outruns the entire unboosted metagame, letting it fire priority Thunder Wave, drop opponent Special Defense with Fake Tears, or neuter physical attackers with Eerie Impulse before most threats can act. Its Volt Absorb keeps it healthy while Covert Cloak blocks extra effects from common spread moves, letting it repeatedly enable teammates like Sylveon or Dragonite to sweep. Tera Ghost or Flying grant temporary immunities to Fake-Out or Ground moves, buying turns to cripple foes or pivot out safely.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Jolteon": {"Abilities": {"voltabsorb": 8.94815544412456, "quickfeet": 0.16787991834927646}, "Items": {"focussash": 0.21142733615795306, "covertcloak": 0.6299873977910772}, "Spreads": {"Timid:4/0/0/252/0/252": 0.22175184741446596, "Timid:164/0/0/92/0/252": 0.6257335511653022}, "Moves": ["faketears", "thunderbolt", "thunderwave", "eerieimpulse"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.21694066273743057, "flying": 0.63920758677703}, "Teammates": ["Sylveon", "Dragonite", "Espeon", "Flareon", "Vaporeon", "Umbreon"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Jolteon’s 130 base Speed tier is the single biggest reason to consider it: only Regieleki, Choice Scarf users, and weather abusers move first, so Jolteon can almost guarantee the first Thunder Wave or Fake Tears. The most common set runs Timid 252 Speed and splits the remaining EVs between HP and Special Attack; the 164/92 variant maximizes bulk while still 2HKOing most neutral targets with STAB Thunderbolt. Volt Absorb is preferred for healing off chip from U-turn or allied Discharge, but Quick Feet can punish status teams if you drop Covert Cloak for a status orb. Covert Cloak is the default item because it blanks secondary effects from Icy Wind, Snarl, and Lava Plume, letting Jolteon stay on the field longer than Focus Sash variants. Fake Tears plus a spread special attacker such as Sylveon or Espeon can score OHKOs on bulky titans like Garganacl or Dondozo, while Eerie Impulse neuters physical setup sweepers such as Dragon Dance Dragonite or Swords Dance Chien-Pao. Thunder Wave provides blanket speed control that lets slower sweepers like Flareon or Vaporeon move first next turn. Tera Ghost blocks Fake Out and Extreme Speed, granting a free pivot or setup turn, whereas Tera Flying removes the Ground weakness so Jolteon can stay in on Landorus-T or Great Tusk and continue supporting. The Eevee-evolution core synergy is strong: Vaporeon provides Wish and Heal Bell, Umbreon offers Fake Out and Taunt, Sylveon brings Hyper Voice spam, and Flareon supplies physical pressure; together they overload the opponent’s targeting priorities and let Jolteon pick its spots to disrupt.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Jolteon": {"Abilities": {"voltabsorb": 8.94815544412456, "quickfeet": 0.16787991834927646}, "Items": {"focussash": 0.21142733615795306, "covertcloak": 0.6299873977910772}, "Spreads": {"Timid:4/0/0/252/0/252": 0.22175184741446596, "Timid:164/0/0/92/0/252": 0.6257335511653022}, "Moves": ["faketears", "thunderbolt", "thunderwave", "eerieimpulse"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.21694066273743057, "flying": 0.63920758677703}, "Teammates": ["Sylveon", "Dragonite", "Espeon", "Flareon", "Vaporeon", "Umbreon"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Against hyper-offense Jolteon can single-handedly dismantle momentum by paralysing the fastest threats, letting slower wall-breakers like Dragonite or Flareon move first next turn. Into bulkier set-up cores Jolteon spams Fake Tears or Eerie Impulse to flip the damage race, turning would-be 3HKOs into OHKOs for its partner. Weather teams fear Thunder Wave because it negates the speed advantage of Chlorophyll or Swift Swim sweepers, while Covert Cloak blanks Icy Wind or Snarl, keeping Jolteon healthy enough to repeat the cycle. Conversely, priority users such as Kingambit or Dragonite’s Extreme Speed can finish Jolteon after chip, and Ghost-types like Aegislash or Flutter Mane are immune to Fake Out and resist Thunderbolt, forcing Jolteon to rely on support moves. Assault Vest Garganacl ignores Fake Tears and can Salt Cure stall Jolteon down, while Ground-types that carry Rock coverage (Landorus-T, Great Tusk) threaten KO if Jolteon has already burned its Tera. Overall Jolteon wins the tempo war versus balanced and offensive squads but struggles versus dedicated priority or specially bulky walls.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Jolteon is a fast special-support pivot whose primary job is to enable teammates to sweep rather than to sweep itself. It leads to immediately cripple opposing leads with Thunder Wave or Fake Tears, then either pivots out with Volt Switch (if run) or stays on the field to spam disruption while its partner attacks. Mid-game it punishes setup attempts with Eerie Impulse and keeps the speed tier in check with repeated Thunder Waves. Because it invests little in offense, Jolteon should be viewed as a tempo piece: every turn it spends on the field should either paralyse something, drop stats, or absorb a hit via Volt Absorb/Cloak so that an ally can capitalise. Late-game its Thunderbolt cleans weakened targets, but its main value is ensuring your own sweepers move first and that opposing sweepers never get to plus-two or plus-three safely.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Jolteon": {"Abilities": {"voltabsorb": 8.94815544412456, "quickfeet": 0.16787991834927646}, "Items": {"focussash": 0.21142733615795306, "covertcloak": 0.6299873977910772}, "Spreads": {"Timid:4/0/0/252/0/252": 0.22175184741446596, "Timid:164/0/0/92/0/252": 0.6257335511653022}, "Moves": ["faketears", "thunderbolt", "thunderwave", "eerieimpulse"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.21694066273743057, "flying": 0.63920758677703}, "Teammates": ["Sylveon", "Dragonite", "Espeon", "Flareon", "Vaporeon", "Umbreon"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>The Eevee-stacked core is Jolteon’s happiest home: Sylveon’s Pixilate Hyper Voice benefits immensely from Fake Tears drops, while Sylveon in return covers Jolteon’s Dragon- and Grass-type problems. Dragonite enjoys Thunder Wave support because it no longer needs to run Extreme Speed for speed control, freeing a moveslot for coverage or setup. Umbreon’s Fake Out and Taunt buy Jolteon free turns to click Fake Tears or Thunder Wave, and Vaporeon’s Wish + Heal Bell keeps Jolteon healthy and status-free so it can keep cycling disruption. Flareon appreciates Eerie Impulse vs. physical walls like Corviknight or Garganacl, turning Flare Blitz into a guaranteed OHKO after the drop. Outside the Eevee crew, Jolteon pairs well with bulky set-up sweepers that hate status (Kingambit, Palafin) because Covert Cloak + Thunder Wave neuters most status spreaders. It also loves allies that can abuse paralysed foes, such as Iron Valiant or Roaring Moon, which can outspeed and sweep through slowed teams. Finally, because Jolteon invites Ground-types, teammates that punish Ground switches—like Ice-spinner Chien-Pao or Water-type Hydrapple—turn Jolteon’s so-called “weaknesses” into bait.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Jolteon": {"Abilities": {"voltabsorb": 8.94815544412456, "quickfeet": 0.16787991834927646}, "Items": {"focussash": 0.21142733615795306, "covertcloak": 0.6299873977910772}, "Spreads": {"Timid:4/0/0/252/0/252": 0.22175184741446596, "Timid:164/0/0/92/0/252": 0.6257335511653022}, "Moves": ["faketears", "thunderbolt", "thunderwave", "eerieimpulse"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.21694066273743057, "flying": 0.63920758677703}, "Teammates": ["Sylveon", "Dragonite", "Espeon", "Flareon", "Vaporeon", "Umbreon"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Priority users are Jolteon’s bane: Kingambit’s Sucker Punch, Dragonite’s Extreme Speed, and Palafin’s Jet Punch all KO after chip, and Covert Cloak does not block damage. Ghost-types immune to Fake Out—Flutter Mane, Aegislash, and Mimikyu—can set up or attack directly, forcing Jolteon to either burn its Tera or switch out. Specially bulky Assault Vest titans—Garganacl, Goodra-Hisui, and Iron Hands—laugh at Fake Tears and can retalify with Salt Cure, Draco Meteor, or Drain Punch respectively. Ground-types that carry non-Ground coverage, such as Landorus-T with Rock Slide or Great Tusk with Ice Spinner, KO Jolteon even if it Teras into Flying. Finally, priority Tailwind or booster-energy speed setups (Iron Bundle, Roaring Moon) can outpace Jolteon after their own speed control, nullifying its biggest advantage. To beat Jolteon, deny it free turns: Fake Out, priority, or multi-hit moves break sash, while status or special bulk shrugs off its support long enough to KO.</OUTPUT>
