<DATA>{"Orthworm": {"Abilities": {"eartheater": 9.25830192688127, "sandveil": 1.079509267815082e-05}, "Items": {"sitrusberry": 0.43687871915329346, "leftovers": 0.3754563156910898, "rockyhelmet": 0.17985243011460816}, "Spreads": {"Impish:252/4/116/0/132/4": 0.17977483250350043}, "Moves": ["bodypress", "irondefense", "shedtail", "heavyslam"], "Tera Types": {"fire": 0.6102931446053487}, "Teammates": ["Tyranitar", "Garchomp", "Incineroar", "Indeedee", "Ursaluna", "Dragonite"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Orthworm is a niche but surprisingly effective defensive pivot in VGC, leveraging its massive base 145 HP and 85/80/60 bulk to set up Iron Defense and pass 50 % shields via Shed Tail. Earth Eater is the only relevant ability, granting an immunity to Ground and a 25 % heal on incoming Ground moves, which lets it hard-counter Garchomp, Ting-Lu and Ursaluna while simultaneously creating free turn opportunities. Tera Fire is the dominant choice, removing the 4× Fire weakness and turning Orthworm into a pseudo-check for Sun and Iron Moth. The EV spread shown (Impish 252/4/116/132/4) lives Jolly Garchomp Tera Ground Tera Blast, +1 Dragonite Tera Normal Extreme Speed, and +2 Kingambit Iron Head after Iron Defense, while still outspeeding uninvested base 70s to guarantee Shed Tail before slower threats move. The moveset is rigid—Iron Defense, Body Press, Shed Tail and Heavy Slam—because Orthworm’s job is to survive a hit, boost, and either KO with Body Press or pivot out a frail breaker. Sitrus Berry is the most common item, giving 25 % recovery at 50 % HP to stack with Earth Eater heals; Leftovers is a second choice for longer games, and Rocky Helmet punishes U-turn and contact spam from Chien-Pao and Dragonite. Teammates gravitate toward slow, hard-hitting breakers that appreciate protected setup: Tyranitar and Dragonite love Shed Tail turns to Dragon Dance or set weather, Garchomp forms a Ground-immune core, Incineroar provides Intimidate and Parting Shot synergy, Indeedee blocks Fake Out and gives Psychic Terrain to stop priority revenge kills, and Ursaluna benefits from Orthworm drawing Fighting moves. In the current metagame Orthworm is a pocket pick that autowins certain matchups while being dead weight against special attackers or Taunt, so it is best used as a scripted lead on BO or balance archetypes rather than a blind six-slot.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Orthworm": {"Abilities": {"eartheater": 9.25830192688127, "sandveil": 1.079509267815082e-05}, "Items": {"sitrusberry": 0.43687871915329346, "leftovers": 0.3754563156910898, "rockyhelmet": 0.17985243011460816}, "Spreads": {"Impish:252/4/116/0/132/4": 0.17977483250350043}, "Moves": ["bodypress", "irondefense", "shedtail", "heavyslam"], "Tera Types": {"fire": 0.6102931446053487}, "Teammates": ["Tyranitar", "Garchomp", "Incineroar", "Indeedee", "Ursaluna", "Dragonite"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Orthworm’s stat line screams “setup tank”: 145/85/80/60/60/40 is min-maxed for physical bulk and HP, letting it survive virtually any unboosted physical attack in the format. After a single Iron Defense its Defense stat reaches a titanic 656, meaning even super-effective contact moves fail to break the Sitrus Berry threshold. Earth Eater is the cornerstone of its viability; Ground is one of the most spammable offensive types in VGC, and gaining a free 25 % heal on every predicted Earthquake or Tera Ground move flips the risk-reward entirely. Opponents are forced to double-target Orthworm with special attacks or commit to Grass, Water or Fire coverage, all of which are telegraphed and exploitable. Tera Fire is used on 61 % of ladder teams because it removes the 4× Fire weakness and turns Orthworm into a soft check to Sun staples like Torkoal and Iron Moth; after Terastallizing it resists both of their STABs and can retaliate with Heavy Slam or continue to cycle Iron Defense. The chosen EV spread is mathematically optimized for the current damage calculator: 252 HP / 116 Def / 132 SpD with an Impish nature guarantees survival against the most common physical threats while still letting Shed Tail outrun uninvested base 70s such as opposing Tyranitar and Incineroar. Offensively Orthworm is mediocre—base 70 Attack and no boosting item mean Heavy Slam will not OHKO anything relevant, but Body Press uses the +2 Defense stat as its base power, turning Orthworm into a 140+ BP Fighting nuke that cleanly OHKOs Kingambit, Tyranitar and Garganacl after one Iron Defense. Shed Tail is the move that justifies its inclusion: passing a 50 % max-HP substitute to a slow but dangerous teammate like Dragonite or Ursaluna is equivalent to gaining a free Protect plus a 50 % HP buffer, which almost always translates into a KO or a second setup turn. The downside is that Orthworm is setup fodder for special attackers like Iron Valiant, Hydreigon and Flutter Mane, and it folds instantly to Taunt or Encore. Therefore successful Orthworm teams build in answers to these problems—Indeedee-F for Fake Out and priority blocking, Incineroar for Parting Shot and Intimidate, or Tyranitar for Sand chip and special bulk. In best-of-three formats Orthworm is brought only on previews where the opponent is overloaded with physical Ground or Fighting attackers; in game-one blind teams it is usually benched unless the pilot is confident in the lead read. Overall Orthworm is a matchup fish that, when scripted correctly, can single-handedly dismantle standard physical offense cores while creating the most efficient pivoting in the format.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Orthworm hard-counters every physical Ground-type in the tier: Garchomp, Ting-Lu, Great Tusk and Ursaluna all fail to break it after Iron Defense while Earth Eater converts their STAB into healing. It also walls Kingambit, Scizor and Bisharp, because +2 Defense Body Press OHKOs them while they cannot score the 2HKO back. Against Dragonite, Orthworm survives +1 Tera Normal Extreme Speed and retaliates with Heavy Slam or sets up a second Iron Defense, forcing a Tera commit or a switch. On the flip side, special attackers are nightmarish: Flutter Mane, Iron Valiant, Hydreigon, Iron Moth and Sylveon all OHKO or 2HKO with their respective STABs before Orthworm can act. Taunt users such as Murkrow, Whimsicott or opposing Incineroar completely shut down the Iron Defense cycle and force early Shed Tail, costing momentum. Sun teams can overwhelm it with Torkoal Eruption or Charizard Blast Burn, although Tera Fire mitigates one of these threats. Rain is similarly rough, as Specs Pelipper Hurricane or Barraskewda Liquidation are guaranteed KOs. Trick Room variants that rely on special breakers like Hatterene or Armarouge also invalidate Orthworm, because it cannot underspeed them to pivot. Finally, Encore from Indeedee-F or Whimsicott locks Orthworm into Iron Defense or Shed Tail and turns it into passive setup fodder. In summary, Orthworm is a binary Pokémon: if the opponent is physically oriented and lacks Taunt or special coverage, it wins; if they carry any special attacker or disruption, it becomes a liability.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Orthworm is a scripted lead defensive pivot whose purpose is to survive a physical hit, use Iron Defense, and then either KO with Body Press or pass a 50 % substitute to a setup sweeper via Shed Tail. It is never used as a rear-guard because its low special bulk and passivity make it dead weight once the opponent reveals special attackers. In team preview it is brought only when the opponent’s fastest physical attacker cannot break +1 Defense and when the rest of the squad benefits from a free pivot turn. During the game it operates on a simple flowchart: turn-one Iron Defense if the opponent cannot 2HKO, turn-two either Body Press for the KO or Shed Tail to the designated breaker if the KO is impossible. Tera Fire is used reactively to check Sun or to survive a Fire-type coverage move, never pre-emptively unless the win condition demands it. Because Orthworm is slower than most support Pokémon, it is often paired with Indeedee-F to block Fake Out and priority, ensuring the Iron Defense goes up unscathed. Once Shed Tail is executed, Orthworm’s job is done; it is sacrificed or used as a double-target decoy while the substitute recipient sets up. In endgame scenarios Orthworm can reverse-sweep if the opponent is left with only physical attackers and no Taunt, but this is rare. Its role is therefore binary: either it sets up and pivots, or it is dead weight—there is no middle ground.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Orthworm’s teammates are chosen to exploit the free Shed Tail turn and to cover its special-side weakness. Tyranitar is the most common partner: Sand boosts its special bulk, Rock typing checks Flying-types that threaten Orthworm, and DD Dragonite under a substitute is one of the most efficient win conditions in the format. Garchomp forms a Ground-immune core with Earth Eater, punishes opposing Electric-types, and can Swords Dance behind a Substitute. Incineroar provides Intimidate and Parting Shot, further reducing physical pressure while giving a slow pivot that recycles Orthworm back in after it Shed Tails. Indeedee-F is almost mandatory on modern Orthworm teams: Follow Me and Psychic Terrain block Fake Out and priority, guaranteeing Iron Defense, while Expanding Force gives a special presence that Orthworm lacks. Ursaluna appreciates the Fighting-immunity and can Calm Mind or Swords Dance behind a substitute; once behind a 200+ HP sub it is virtually unstoppable. Dragonite is the classic beneficiary: Weakness Policy activates behind the substitute, and +1 Dragonite behind a 50 % sub can sweep entire teams. EV spreads are coordinated—Tyranitar is usually Careful with enough speed to outrun uninvested base 60s, Indeedee-F runs max HP / max SpA with a Sassy nature to underspeed Orthworm for Psychic Terrain, and Dragonite runs Adamant with 244 Speed to outspeed +1 base 100s after a Dragon Dance. The team archetype is a hybrid of BO and balance: two pivots (Incineroar + Indeedee), one setup tank (Orthworm), and two breakers (Dragonite + Ursaluna/Tyranitar), with the sixth slot flexing between speed control or a second special attacker. Tera types are also coordinated: Orthworm goes Tera Fire, Dragonite goes Tera Normal for Extreme Speed spam, and Tyranitar keeps Tera Rock to maintain Sand. Overall the squad is built to turn one free turn into a snowball, and Orthworm is the engine that generates that turn.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Orthworm": {"Abilities": {"eartheater": 9.25830192688127, "sandveil": 1.079509267815082e-05}, "Items": {"sitrusberry": 0.43687871915329346, "leftovers": 0.3754563156910898, "rockyhelmet": 0.17985243011460816}, "Spreads": {"Impish:252/4/116/0/132/4": 0.17977483250350043}, "Moves": ["bodypress", "irondefense", "shedtail", "heavyslam"], "Tera Types": {"fire": 0.6102931446053487}, "Teammates": ["Tyranitar", "Garchomp", "Incineroar", "Indeedee", "Ursaluna", "Dragonite"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Orthworm is hard-countered by any special attacker that can OHKO before it moves: Flutter Mane Moonblast, Iron Valiant Aura Sphere, Hydreigon Draco Meteor, Iron Moth Fire Blast and Sylveon Hyper Voice all accomplish this. Taunt from Murkrow, Whimsicott or Incineroar shuts down Iron Defense and forces an early Shed Tail, stripping Orthworm of its primary win condition. Encore from Indeedee-F or Whimsicott locks it into Iron Defense or Shed Tail and turns it into passive setup fodder. Sun teams can overload it with Torkoal Eruption plus Charizard Blast Burn even after Tera Fire, because the second Fire move will still KO. Rain teams are similarly brutal: Specs Pelipper Hurricane and Barraskewda Liquidation are guaranteed KOs, and Tera Fire does not help against Water. Trick Room special breakers like Hatterene and Armarouge underspeed and OHKO before Orthworm can pivot. Mixed attackers that carry special coverage—such as Tera Blast Water Garchomp or Tera Fire Kingambit—can break the standard spread after Stealth Rock chip. Finally, double-target focus from two special attackers is a universal answer: even if one is Earth Eater-proc Ground-type, the second special move will KO. In best-of-three formats, savvy opponents will bench their physical Ground-types after game one and bring special attackers or Taunt leads, forcing Orthworm to sit on the bench. To counter Orthworm, simply preserve your special attacker, lead Taunt or Encore, and never click Earthquake until Earth Eater is eliminated.</OUTPUT>

input:
Write a detailed 'sample_team_concept' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Orthworm": {"Abilities": {"eartheater": 9.25830192688127, "sandveil": 1.079509267815082e-05}, "Items": {"sitrusberry": 0.43687871915329346, "leftovers": 0.3754563156910898, "rockyhelmet": 0.17985243011460816}, "Spreads": {"Impish:252/4/116/0/132/4": 0.17977483250350043}, "Moves": ["bodypress", "irondefense", "shedtail", "heavyslam"], "Tera Types": {"fire": 0.6102931446053487}, "Teammates": ["Tyranitar", "Garchomp", "Incineroar", "Indeedee", "Ursaluna", "Dragonite"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>A proven tournament core is Orthworm / Indeedee-F / Dragonite / Tyranitar / Incineroar / Ursaluna. Lead Orthworm + Indeedee against physical offenses: Indeedee Follow Me blocks Fake Out, Psychic Terrain stops priority revenge kills, and Orthworm gets a guaranteed Iron Defense. Turn-two Orthworm either KOes with Body Press or Shed Tails to Dragonite; Dragonite clicks Dragon Dance behind the substitute and sweeps. If the opponent reveals special attackers, pivot to Incineroar Parting Shot into Tyranitar to reset Sand and preserve momentum. Ursaluna is the mid-game breaker that can come in behind a substitute via Shed Tail or Parting Shot, Calm Mind once, and clean. EV spreads are coordinated: Orthworm runs the standard Impish 252/116/132, Indeedee is Sassy max HP / max SpA, Dragonite is Adamant 244 Spe, Tyranitar is Careful with 92 Spe to outrun uninvested base 60s, Incineroar is standard Careful pivot, and Ursaluna is Brave 0 Spe for Trick Room reversals. Tera assignments are Orthworm → Fire, Dragonite → Normal, Tyranitar → Rock, Incineroar → Water (to survive Tera Fire Garchomp), Indeedee → Fairy, Ursaluna → Poison (to resist Fairy). The team reaches top cut in Regional-level events when the pilot correctly scouts the opponent’s special count and benches Orthworm when necessary, but it auto-wins any bracket lane weak to physical setup.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Slowking": {"Abilities": {"oblivious": 8.068027158660797, "regenerator": 1.46556934806969, "owntempo": 8.008038676621254e-13}, "Items": {"safetygoggles": 0.6867103913474264, "covertcloak": 0.2080859830947355}, "Spreads": {"Modest:188/0/0/252/0/68": 0.6525105013548556}, "Moves": ["psychic", "trickroom", "muddywater", "nastyplot"], "Tera Types": {"dark": 0.6540335501037582}, "Teammates": ["Ursaluna", "Amoonguss", "Incineroar", "Maushold", "Torkoal", "Farigiraf"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Slowking carves a niche as a bulky setter and abuser of Trick Room that simultaneously pressures common Fighting- and Poison-types while threatening opposing weather and terrain setters with STAB Muddy Water. Its natural special bulk, Regenerator, and Safety Goggles let it repeatedly pivot in, click Trick Room, and still tank a hit or status, making it a glue piece on full-room squads that want a second setter beyond the typical Hatterene or Indeedee. A modest 188 HP / 252 SpA / 68 Spe spread maximizes power while creeping uninvested base 30s like Torkoal under Tailwind, letting Slowking function as both a primary attacker and a reliable room setter. Tera Dark patches up its Ghost- and Dark-type weaknesses and denies Fake Out and Prankster disruption, turning Slowking into a mid-game win condition after a Nasty Plot boost.</OUTPUT>

input:
Provide the 'full_analysis' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Slowking": {"Abilities": {"oblivious": 8.068027158660797, "regenerator": 1.46556934806969, "owntempo": 8.008038676621254e-13}, "Items": {"safetygoggles": 0.6867103913474264, "covertcloak": 0.2080859830947355}, "Spreads": {"Modest:188/0/0/252/0/68": 0.6525105013548556}, "Moves": ["psychic", "trickroom", "muddywater", "nastyplot"], "Tera Types": {"dark": 0.6540335501037582}, "Teammates": ["Ursaluna", "Amoonguss", "Incineroar", "Maushold", "Torkoal", "Farigiraf"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Slowking’s value in the current Regulation G metagame stems from its unique combination of typing, movepool, and ability. Pure Psychic typing grants it a crucial resistance to Fighting, letting it check the ubiquitous Urshifu-Rapid-Strike and Iron Hands while also threatening Amoonguss and Toxapex with Psyshihc or Tera-boosted Stored Power. Access to Trick Room is the main draw: unlike Hatterene, Slowking is not weak to Ghost or Steel, and unlike Jellicent it carries immediate offensive presence. Regenerator is the preferred ability—Oblivious’s Taunt immunity is niche when most disruption is Prankster or Fake Out, and Regenerator allows Slowking to U-turn or hard-switch out and recover 33 %, a critical longevity tool on a format where Intimidate, pivoting, and double-targeting are constant. Safety Goggles is the default item to ignore Spore and Rage Powder, letting Slowking set Trick Room even in the face of Amoonguss or Torkoal sun teams. Covert Cloak is a secondary option to blank out fake-out flinches and secondary effects like Nuzzle or Icy Wind, but Goggles’ protection against the most common support move in the tier is usually more impactful. The chosen EV spread hits 188 HP for a Life Orb number and 11-hit Substitute from most uninvested Dragons, 68 Speed EVs creep Torkoal and Araquanid outside of Tailwind, and the rest is piled into Special Attack to ensure KOs on 4 HP Incineroar and offensive Landorus-T after a Nasty Plot. Tera Dark is almost mandatory: it removes the Ghost weakness, turns Dark-type moves into neutral damage, and most importantly makes Slowking immune to Prankster Taunt and Twave from Whimsicott, Grimmsnarl, or Murkrow, guaranteeing Trick Room goes up. Psychic is the chosen STAB for power and accuracy, Muddy Water spreads damage and lowers accuracy, and Nasty Plot turns Slowking into a late-game cleaner once resists are weakened.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Slowking": {"Abilities": {"oblivious": 8.068027158660797, "regenerator": 1.46556934806969, "owntempo": 8.008038676621254e-13}, "Items": {"safetygoggles": 0.6867103913474264, "covertcloak": 0.2080859830947355}, "Spreads": {"Modest:188/0/0/252/0/68": 0.6525105013548556}, "Moves": ["psychic", "trickroom", "muddywater", "nastyplot"], "Tera Types": {"dark": 0.6540335501037582}, "Teammates": ["Ursaluna", "Amoonguss", "Incineroar", "Maushold", "Torkoal", "Farigiraf"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Slowking shines against bulky offense and balance cores that rely on Amoonguss, Incineroar, or Urshifu-Rapid-Strike to control tempo. It sets Trick Room on Amoonguss with impunity thanks to Safety Goggles, and its Psychic STAB cleanly OHKOes 252 HP Amoonguss after Stealth Rock or a single round of Regenerator chip. Against sun, Slowking underspeeds Torkoal and can either click Muddy Water to soften the opposing side or immediately set Trick Room to flip speed order, forcing Torkoal and Lilligant into awkward Protects. Versus Indeedee-Hatterene lead, Slowking can target Hatterene with Dark Pulse after Tera Dark to remove the Follow Me user and then expand room for its own side. It struggles against hyper-offense Tailwind teams carrying Dragapult or Iron Bundle, which outspeed and KO before Trick Room goes up, and against screens offense featuring Grimmsnarl and Chien-Pao, which can Taunt or set up while Slowking sets room. Raging Bolt and Kingambit are also problematic: the former can tank a hit and OHKO back with Thunderbolt, while the latter can Sucker Punch for heavy damage even after Tera Dark.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Slowking": {"Abilities": {"oblivious": 8.068027158660797, "regenerator": 1.46556934806969, "owntempo": 8.008038676621254e-13}, "Items": {"safetygoggles": 0.6867103913474264, "covertcloak": 0.2080859830947355}, "Spreads": {"Modest:188/0/0/252/0/68": 0.6525105013548556}, "Moves": ["psychic", "trickroom", "muddywater", "nastyplot"], "Tera Types": {"dark": 0.6540335501037582}, "Teammates": ["Ursaluna", "Amoonguss", "Incineroar", "Maushold", "Torkoal", "Farigiraf"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Slowking is a hybrid support-attacker that functions as a secondary Trick Room setter and mid-game breaker on full-room or semi-room compositions. It is not the fastest nor the bulkiest setter, but its unique typing and Regenerator let it act as a pivot that can repeatedly come in, absorb a hit, set room, and then switch out to recover. Once room is up, its base 100 Special Attack becomes threatening after a Nasty Plot, turning it into a win condition that can sweep through weakened teams. Its role is therefore three-fold: early-game anti-lead that denies Amoonguss and Incineroar, mid-game pivot that preserves momentum with Regenerator, and late-game cleaner that exploits Trick Room turns to boost and sweep.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Slowking": {"Abilities": {"oblivious": 8.068027158660797, "regenerator": 1.46556934806969, "owntempo": 8.008038676621254e-13}, "Items": {"safetygoggles": 0.6867103913474264, "covertcloak": 0.2080859830947355}, "Spreads": {"Modest:188/0/0/252/0/68": 0.6525105013548556}, "Moves": ["psychic", "trickroom", "muddywater", "nastyplot"], "Tera Types": {"dark": 0.6540335501037582}, "Teammates": ["Ursaluna", "Amoonguss", "Incineroar", "Maushold", "Torkoal", "Farigiraf"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Slowking’s most common teammates—Ursaluna, Amoonguss, Incineroar, Maushold, Torkoal, and Farigiraf—form a full-room core that abuses Trick Room while covering each other’s weaknesses. Ursaluna is the primary breaker, appreciating Slowking’s ability to remove Fighting-types and set room so it can click Headlong Rush freely. Amoonguss provides Rage Powder and additional Spore control, forming a Regenerator core with Slowking that can cycle indefinitely. Incineroar offers Fake Out and Intimidate, creating free turns for Slowking to set room, while also checking opposing Steel-types. Maushold gives population bomb pressure and Friend Guard, letting Slowking survive stray hits. Torkoal supplies sun-boosted Eruption under room, and the two setters can alternate depending on the opposing lead. Farigiraf blocks priority and Expanding Force, ensuring Trick Room goes up against Indeedee teams. Together these Pokémon create a slow, bulky core that thrives in Trick Room and punishes the fast, frail attackers that dominate the format.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>The standard set is Modest 188 HP / 252 SpA / 68 Spe with Regenerator, Safety Goggles, and Tera Dark. Moves: Trick Room, Psychic, Muddy Water, Nasty Plot. This spread guarantees the OHKO on 252 HP Amoonguss after one round of chip, outspeeds Torkoal outside Tailwind, and maximizes power. An alternative spread of Quiet 252 HP / 252 SpA / 4 SpD with 0 Spe IVs can be used on pure full-room teams to minimize speed, but the extra bulk is usually overkill and the Speed creep is more valuable on semi-room. Covert Cloak can replace Goggles if your team already handles Amoonguss via Torkoal or Heat Rotom, and Tera Water can be considered to flip the Fire weakness and boost Muddy Water, but Dark remains the best overall typing for blocking Prankster and Ghost-type moves.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Slowking": {"Abilities": {"oblivious": 8.068027158660797, "regenerator": 1.46556934806969, "owntempo": 8.008038676621254e-13}, "Items": {"safetygoggles": 0.6867103913474264, "covertcloak": 0.2080859830947355}, "Spreads": {"Modest:188/0/0/252/0/68": 0.6525105013548556}, "Moves": ["psychic", "trickroom", "muddywater", "nastyplot"], "Tera Types": {"dark": 0.6540335501037582}, "Teammates": ["Ursaluna", "Amoonguss", "Incineroar", "Maushold", "Torkoal", "Farigiraf"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Slowking is vulnerable to strong, super-effective special attackers that can OHKO before or after Trick Room. Iron Bundle’s Freeze-Dry, Dragapult’s Shadow Ball, and Raging Bolt’s Thunderbolt all KO through Tera Dark if Slowking has taken any chip. Priority users such as Kingambit and Dragonite can circumvent room with Sucker Punch and Extreme Speed, respectively. Taunt from faster Prankster users like Whimsicott or Murkrow can still stop room if Slowking has not Terastallized, and Encore from Grimmsnarl or Dondozo can lock it into a non-threatening move. Offensive Tera Fairy Kingambit is especially problematic, as it resists both STABs and retaliates with Tera-boosted Kowtow Cleave. Finally, Slowking dislikes spread damage from Rock Slide and Earthquake, which bypass its bulk and can flinch or score double KOs before room goes up.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Slowking": {"Abilities": {"oblivious": 8.068027158660797, "regenerator": 1.46556934806969, "owntempo": 8.008038676621254e-13}, "Items": {"safetygoggles": 0.6867103913474264, "covertcloak": 0.2080859830947355}, "Spreads": {"Modest:188/0/0/252/0/68": 0.6525105013548556}, "Moves": ["psychic", "trickroom", "muddywater", "nastyplot"], "Tera Types": {"dark": 0.6540335501037582}, "Teammates": ["Ursaluna", "Amoonguss", "Incineroar", "Maushold", "Torkoal", "Farigiraf"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>A proven team archetype is Trick Room balance featuring Slowking / Ursaluna / Amoonguss / Incineroar / Torkoal / Maushold. Lead Slowking + Incineroar into opposing Amoonguss teams: Fake Out the Amoonguss, set room, and follow with Psychic + Flare Blitz to remove the mushroom. Against Tailwind offenses, bring Amoonguss + Ursalaba, bait the Tailwind, then pivot to Slowking on the expected Spore and set room next turn. Mid-game, cycle Regenerator and Intimidate to preserve HP, then explode with Torkoal Eruption and Ursaluna Headlong Rush under room. Maushold provides late-game Population Bomb cheese and Friend Guard to let Slowking survive a Shadow Ball from Dragapult. The core is flexible: you can lead Slowking + Torkoal to immediately threaten sun damage, or Farigiraf + Slowking to block priority and guarantee room. The team struggles only versus hyper-offense double-legendary builds with two of Flutter Mane, Iron Bundle, and Chien-Pao; in those matchups prioritize preserving Tera Dark for Slowking and clearing screens with Incineroar Parting Shot cycles.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Vaporeon": {"Abilities": {"waterabsorb": 8.49983675870279, "hydration": 0.002964537116938226}, "Items": {"leftovers": 0.2151364696264618, "rockyhelmet": 0.670916738778034}, "Spreads": {"Modest:252/0/252/0/4/0": 0.19438110567653757, "Bold:252/0/252/0/0/4": 0.6708448763420992}, "Moves": ["scald", "detect", "yawn", "faketears"], "Tera Types": {"grass": 0.7242008933583568, "fire": 0.23160319714482602}, "Teammates": ["Umbreon", "Sylveon", "Espeon", "Jolteon", "Flareon", "Annihilape"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Vaporeon carves a distinctive niche as a bulky, utility-focused Water-type in VGC, leveraging its exceptional base 130 HP and respectable 95 Special Defense to act as a special pivot and disruption piece. With a 67 % usage of Rocky Helmet and a 21 % Leftovers share, it is clearly built to punish physical attackers while staying on the field long enough to fire off accurate Scalds, spread Yawns, and cripple special walls with Fake Tears. The near-unanimous choice of Grass Tera (72 %) alongside a smaller Fire Tera contingent (23 %) shows players value turning Vaporeon into either a Gastrodon-style Grass tank or a surprise anti-Grass/anti-Ice pivot. EV spreads overwhelmingly favour Bold 252 HP / 252 Def (67 %) to maximise physical bulk, while a minority run Modest 252 HP / 252 SpA (19 %) to push immediate damage. Water Absorb is the ability of choice (85 %), giving free switches into partner Water moves and turning common Scald or Surf users into recovery opportunities. Detect, Scald, Yawn, and Fake Tears form the standard moveset, giving Vaporeon a rare blend of chip damage, burn chance, forced switches, and special support. Its most common partners are the entire Eeveelution squad—Umbreon, Sylveon, Espeon, Jolteon, and Flareon—plus Annihilape, suggesting Vaporeon is most comfortable on full-team gimmick or “Eevee-hero” cores where multiple Wish-passers and bulky pivots wear the opponent down while maintaining field control.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Vaporeon": {"Abilities": {"waterabsorb": 8.49983675870279, "hydration": 0.002964537116938226}, "Items": {"leftovers": 0.2151364696264618, "rockyhelmet": 0.670916738778034}, "Spreads": {"Modest:252/0/252/0/4/0": 0.19438110567653757, "Bold:252/0/252/0/0/4": 0.6708448763420992}, "Moves": ["scald", "detect", "yawn", "faketears"], "Tera Types": {"grass": 0.7242008933583568, "fire": 0.23160319714482602}, "Teammates": ["Umbreon", "Sylveon", "Espeon", "Jolteon", "Flareon", "Annihilape"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Vaporeon’s stat distribution is the classic bulky Water archetype taken to extremes: 130/60/95 bulk on the special side is excellent, but its 65 base Defense means it absolutely needs investment and, ideally, Rocky Helmet chip to check physical threats. The Bold max-Def spread patches the weaker defence while letting Scald threaten burn, whereas the Modest spread sacrifices some longevity to turn Fake Tears and Scald into genuine offensive pressure. Water Absorb is the star ability, turning opposing Rain teams or incidental Surfs into 25 % healing; Hydration remains a fringe option (0.3 %) that could be paired with Rain for status-clearing, but the opportunity cost is enormous. Tera Grass is the clear favourite because it removes Electric weakness, cushions Grass and Water hits, and flips the mirror match against opposing Waters; Tera Fire is a tech to survive Freeze-Dry from Rotom-W or Iron Bundle and retaliate with a burn-chance Scald. Yawn is the move that gives Vaporeon real influence: behind Follow Me or with a partner that threatens spread damage, Yawn forces Protects or switches, buying free turns for setup or positioning. Fake Tears is the other unique selling point—dropping both foes’ Special Defense by two stages in doubles turns Vaporeon into a special “enabler,” letting partners such as Sylveon, Espeon, or even Annihilape’s Final Gambit secure KOs they would otherwise miss. Detect is non-negotiable for survival and Leftovers/Rocky Helmet stalling, while Scald is the obligatory STAB with the ever-valuable 30 % burn chance. EV spreads are almost always 252/252 in the two key stats, with the last 4 placed in the unused attacking stat to minimise Foul Play/ confusion damage. In short, Vaporeon offers a mix of pivoting, passive damage, and special support that few other Water-types can replicate in the current VGC environment.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Vaporeon": {"Abilities": {"waterabsorb": 8.49983675870279, "hydration": 0.002964537116938226}, "Items": {"leftovers": 0.2151364696264618, "rockyhelmet": 0.670916738778034}, "Spreads": {"Modest:252/0/252/0/4/0": 0.19438110567653757, "Bold:252/0/252/0/0/4": 0.6708448763420992}, "Moves": ["scald", "detect", "yawn", "faketears"], "Tera Types": {"grass": 0.7242008933583568, "fire": 0.23160319714482602}, "Teammates": ["Umbreon", "Sylveon", "Espeon", "Jolteon", "Flareon", "Annihilape"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Against hyper-offense, Vaporeon’s bulk and Rocky Helmet let it trade favourably with physical attackers such as Chien-Pao, Kingambit, and Palafin, while Yawn can break momentum and force Protects. Into Rain teams, Water Absorb turns the mirror into free healing and negates opposing Surfs, though it must still fear Freeze-Dry from Pelipper or Iron Bundle. Grass-types like Amoonguss and Whimsicott are problematic: Amoonguss ignores Yawn with Grass-typing and can Spore back, while Whimsicott can Taunt or one-shot with Moonblast. Electric-types—especially Rotom-Wash, Iron Hands, and Regieleki—remain the clearest counters, since even Tera Grass Vaporeon still risks 2HKOs from Thunder Punch or Volt Switch. Sun teams with Torkoal can overwhelm with Eruption or Solar Beam, though a timely Tera Fire allows Vaporeon to survive and retaliate. Into Trick Room, Vaporeon’s low Speed is less of a liability, but it must rely on Fake Tears support or burns to avoid being flattened by hard-hitters like Hatterene or Torkoal. Overall, Vaporeon is at its best against mid-speed, physically oriented cores and at its worst versus fast Electric or Grass special attackers.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Vaporeon is a bulky pivot and special support specialist. It switches into resisted Water or Ice moves, absorbs them for recovery, and then spreads status or stat drops to enable teammates. Its low offensive stats mean it rarely KOs outright; instead, it controls tempo through Yawn pressure, burn chance on Scald, and Fake Tears drops that open the door for stronger special attackers. Rocky Helmet variants punish U-turn and contact moves, while Leftovers variants prefer long-term stalling with Protect. In most games, Vaporeon’s job is to stay on the field for as many turns as possible, clicking Fake Tears early to soften targets, then alternating between Scald, Yawn, and Protect to force awkward positions for the opponent.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Vaporeon": {"Abilities": {"waterabsorb": 8.49983675870279, "hydration": 0.002964537116938226}, "Items": {"leftovers": 0.2151364696264618, "rockyhelmet": 0.670916738778034}, "Spreads": {"Modest:252/0/252/0/4/0": 0.19438110567653757, "Bold:252/0/252/0/0/4": 0.6708448763420992}, "Moves": ["scald", "detect", "yawn", "faketears"], "Tera Types": {"grass": 0.7242008933583568, "fire": 0.23160319714482602}, "Teammates": ["Umbreon", "Sylveon", "Espeon", "Jolteon", "Flareon", "Annihilape"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>The Eeveelution core is the most natural fit: Umbreon provides Wish and Heal Bell, Sylveon offers Hyper Voice spread damage that appreciates Fake Tears support, Espeon brings Psychic Terrain and Speed control, Jolteon gives fast Electric coverage, and Flareon supplies physical bulk and Will-o-Wisp. Together they form a self-sustaining bulky offense squad that can cycle Intimidate, burns, and Yawns to exhaust the opponent. Annihilape is the non-Eevee partner of choice, appreciating Fake Tears to secure Final Gambit or Rage Fist KOs while offering its own bulk and Ghost-typing to absorb Fighting moves aimed at Vaporeon. In broader teams, Vaporeon fits well beside redirection (Indeedee, Togekiss) so it can fire off Yawns and Fake Tears safely, and next to special wallbreakers like Iron Bundle, Gholdengo, or Choice Specs Hydreigon that capitalise on the Special Defense drops. Grass- and Electric-weak teammates such as Gastrodon, Kingdra, or Palafin enjoy Vaporeon’s Tera Grass removing their Water weakness while Vaporeon itself absorbs Water moves for recovery.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>The standard physically defensive pivot: Bold 252 HP / 252 Def / 4 SpD with Rocky Helmet, Water Absorb, Tera Grass—moves Scald / Detect / Yawn / Fake Tears. This set switches into Surfs, punishes contact attackers, and forces progress through Yawn and Fake Tears. Alternative offensive support: Modest 252 HP / 252 SpA / 4 SpD with Leftovers, Water Absorb, Tera Fire—same moves. This sacrifices physical bulk for stronger Scalds and more meaningful Fake Tears drops, best used beside redirection or dual screens. A niche Hydration Rain set exists (0.3 %) with 252 HP / 252 SpD Calm, Leftovers, Tera Water, and moves Scald / Rest / Rain Dance / Fake Tears, but it is extremely team-specific and generally outclassed by Suicune or Pelipper.</OUTPUT>

input:
Write the 'weaknesses_and_counters' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Vaporeon": {"Abilities": {"waterabsorb": 8.49983675870279, "hydration": 0.002964537116938226}, "Items": {"leftovers": 0.2151364696264618, "rockyhelmet": 0.670916738778034}, "Spreads": {"Modest:252/0/252/0/4/0": 0.19438110567653757, "Bold:252/0/252/0/0/4": 0.6708448763420992}, "Moves": ["scald", "detect", "yawn", "faketears"], "Tera Types": {"grass": 0.7242008933583568, "fire": 0.23160319714482602}, "Teammates": ["Umbreon", "Sylveon", "Espeon", "Jolteon", "Flareon", "Annihilape"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Electric-type special attackers are the clearest answers: Regieleki’s Thunder or Volt Switch cleanly OHKO even max-HP variants, while Rotom-Wash can break through with Thunderbolt or Volt Switch chip. Grass-types such as Whimsicott, Meowscarada, and Amoonguss threaten with STAB moves and can ignore Yawn (in Amoonguss’s case) or shut Vaporeon down with Taunt. Powerful physical attackers that don’t mind Rocky Helmet, like Choice Band Kingambit or Iron Hands, can 2HKO through investment. Freeze-Dry users—Iron Bundle, Kyurem, and Calm-Ice variants of Pelipper—bypass Water resistance and score easy KOs. Finally, Taunt or Encore users (Whimsicott, Murkrow, Grimmsnarl) can lock Vaporeon into Fake Tears or Yawn and render it passive, while Clear Body or Good-as-Gold Pokémon ignore Fake Tears entirely.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Squawkabilly": {"Abilities": {"intimidate": 8.295461575283765, "guts": 0.0004808751959261559, "hustle": 4.315147072997405e-09, "sheerforce": 0.0}, "Items": {"choicescarf": 0.9465014196233553}, "Spreads": {"Jolly:4/252/0/0/0/252": 0.9434484046363684}, "Moves": ["partingshot", "tailwind", "bravebird", "uturn"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.9998982621632454}, "Teammates": ["Milotic", "Tyranitar", "Excadrill", "Sinistcha", "Kommo-o", "Incineroar"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Squawkabilly is a niche but surprisingly effective support pick in VGC 2024, leveraging its unique access to Parting Shot, Tailwind and Intimidate to compress speed control, pivoting and pressure into one slot. With a Choice Scarf and maximum Speed investment it naturally outspeeds the crowded base-110 tier (notably Iron Valiant and Meowscarada) and can immediately threaten a fast Tailwind or Parting Shot, forcing awkward protects or double-targets from the opponent. Tera Ghost is the only realistic option, letting it block Fake Out, Extreme Speed and Rapid Spin while keeping momentum with U-turn and Parting Shot. The bird’s real value is the ability to compress three support roles—Intimidate user, Tailwind setter and pivot—into one team-slot, freeing partners to run bulkier or more offensive sets.</OUTPUT>

input:
Write the 'full_analysis' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Squawkabilly": {"Abilities": {"intimidate": 8.295461575283765, "guts": 0.0004808751959261559, "hustle": 4.315147072997405e-09, "sheerforce": 0.0}, "Items": {"choicescarf": 0.9465014196233553}, "Spreads": {"Jolly:4/252/0/0/0/252": 0.9434484046363684}, "Moves": ["partingshot", "tailwind", "bravebird", "uturn"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.9998982621632454}, "Teammates": ["Milotic", "Tyranitar", "Excadrill", "Sinistcha", "Kommo-o", "Incineroar"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Squawkabilly’s 82 / 80 / 70 bulk is mediocre, but its 92 base Speed tier becomes excellent after a Choice Scarf, letting it outrun the entire unboosted metagame short of Regieleki and priority users. Intimidate is the only ability with meaningful usage, immediately softening physical attackers such as Chien-Pao, Kingambit and opposing Incineroar. Parting Shot is the marquee move: a -1 Atk / -1 Sp.Atk debuff plus guaranteed pivot that no other fast supporter in the format possesses. Tailwind gives your side a four-turn speed advantage, while Brave Bird is a passable 120 BP STAB that prevents Squawkabilly from being complete deadweight under Taunt or after a KO. U-turn supplies a secondary pivot option that preserves momentum when Parting Shot’s stat drops are undesirable (e.g. versus Defiant or Competitive users). Maximum Speed and Attack with a Jolly nature are non-negotiable to speed-tie opposing Scarfers at 110 and to secure key KOs on frail threats like Flutter Mane after chip. Tera Ghost is taken on virtually every serious set because it removes the Normal-type weakness to Fighting, grants spin-blocking, and makes Fake Out users whiff—hugely important when you need to guarantee a Tailwind versus Murkrow or Meowscarada leads.</OUTPUT>

input:
Produce the 'matchup_overview' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Squawkabilly": {"Abilities": {"intimidate": 8.295461575283765, "guts": 0.0004808751959261559, "hustle": 4.315147072997405e-09, "sheerforce": 0.0}, "Items": {"choicescarf": 0.9465014196233553}, "Spreads": {"Jolly:4/252/0/0/0/252": 0.9434484046363684}, "Moves": ["partingshot", "tailwind", "bravebird", "uturn"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.9998982621632454}, "Teammates": ["Milotic", "Tyranitar", "Excadrill", "Sinistcha", "Kommo-o", "Incineroar"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Squawkabilly loves facing physical, set-up or Fake Out-reliant teams. Intimidate plus Parting Shot neuters Swords Dance Kingambit, Dragon Dance Baxcalibur and Palafin, while Tera Ghost blanks Fake Out from Murkrow, Meowscarada and Indeedee-F. Against special offense the bird is shakier: it can still drop a fast Tailwind, but Life Orb Flutter Mane, Iron Moth and Chi-Yu will OHKO through its weaker special bulk, and Parting Shot’s Attack drop is irrelevant. Into Trick Room squads it functions as a one-time speed controller: if you predict the room setter you can Parting Shot on the turn TR goes up, crippling the setter’s offense and pivoting to a slower partner ready to operate under Trick Room. Squawkabilly also dislikes Clear Body/Good as Gold users such as Duraludon and Gholdengo, which ignore the stat drops, and any Rocky Helmet or Static/Flame Body contact punishers can cripple its U-turn and Brave Bird recoil.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Squawkabilly is a hyper-offensive support: it trades the bulk of Whimsicott or Talonflame for immediate speed control and disruption. Leads are its bread and butter—pair it next to a setup attacker like Dragon Dance Kommo-o or Swords Dance Excadrill and you can either Tailwind on turn 1 to guarantee your sweep, or Parting Shot to neuter opposing pressure while bringing in a slower breaker safely. Mid-game it functions as a pivot: Intimidate on the switch, Parting Shot to soften double targets, then U-turn or Brave Bird to keep damage ticking. End-game, once Tailwind is no longer needed, Squawkabilly becomes a 252 Atk Choice Scarf cleaner, outspeeding and KOing weakened threats such as Chien-Pao, Iron Bundle and opposing support birds. Because it compresses Intimidate, Tailwind and pivoting, it is often the only support Pokémon on offensive teams, allowing the remaining five slots to be dedicated to wall-breakers or win conditions.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>The teammates shown—Milotic, Tyranitar, Excadrill, Sinistcha, Kommo-o and Incineroar—illustrate two clear archetypes. Milotic and Sinistcha love Parting Shot because the drops trigger Competitive/Contrary for instant +2 Sp.Atk or +2 everything, flipping momentum. Tyranitar + Excadrill form a classic sand core: Squawkabilly’s Tailwind lets uninvested Drill outspeed everything under sand, while Intimidate compensates for Tyranitar’s Fighting weakness. Kommo-o appreciates Tailwind to mitigate its merely above-average Speed and can safely set up behind Parting Shot drops. Incineroar forms a double-Intimidate core with Squawkabilly, turning physical attackers into wet noodles and giving you two Parting Shot users so you can pivot endlessly while stacking chip. In general, partners that are slow but powerful (Kingambit, Iron Hands, Torkoal) or that abuse stat-drops (Milotic, Contrary Serperior if legal) are ideal. Avoid stacking additional Flying types to keep Tera Ghost valuable and minimize Rock Slide vulnerability.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Faster or priority special attackers are the cleanest answers: Iron Bundle, Choice Specs Iron Moth, Life Orb Flutter Mane and Chien-Pao all OHKO with Ice Beam, Fire moves and/or Stone Edge. Gholdengo completely blanks Parting Shot and can retaliate with Make It Rain or Shadow Ball. Rocky Helmet Garganacl or Toxapex punish U-turn and Brave Bird with chip or status, quickly wearing Squawkabilly down. Electric Terrain teams with Pincurchin + Iron Hands can Fake Out + Thunder Punch before you move, or set terrain to boost priority and KO. Trick Room setters that tank a Brave Bird—namely Hatterene with Focus Sash—can retalimate and set TR, nullifying your speed control. Finally, once the Scarf is revealed, Protect + prediction can leave Squawkabilly choice-locked into the wrong move, giving opponents free setup turns.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Breloom is a niche but dangerous offensive support in VGC that leverages Technician-boosted priority, Bullet Seed’s multi-hit potential, and the unique 100% accuracy sleep of Spore to swing momentum.  With a 92% usage of Technician and a 50% focus on either Jolly max-Speed or Brave Iron Ball builds, it can either underspeed Trick Room or outrun slower threats while still firing +1 priority Mach Punch.  Tera Ghost grants Fake Out immunity and Normal immunity, while Tera Steel shores up Fairy and Poison weaknesses.  The most common partners—Archaludon, Indeedee-F, Ursaluna, Hatterene, Pelipper and Gallade—point toward Rain, Trick Room, or terrain-based cores that appreciate Breloom’s ability to put something to sleep and immediately break Focus Sashes or Sturdy with multi-hit Bullet Seed.</OUTPUT>

input:
Write a detailed 'full_analysis' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Breloom": {"Abilities": {"technician": 6.930796882028044, "effectspore": 0.7018538836943164, "poisonheal": 0.4673404154828464}, "Items": {"focussash": 0.4766926762738401, "ironball": 0.3154737735640996}, "Spreads": {"Jolly:4/252/0/0/0/252": 0.3190777084635113, "Brave:252/252/0/0/4/0": 0.31613083927643176}, "Moves": ["bulletseed", "machpunch", "protect", "spore"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.42597853573938954, "steel": 0.2852984593998328}, "Teammates": ["Archaludon", "Indeedee-F", "Ursaluna", "Hatterene", "Pelipper", "Gallade"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Breloom’s claim to fame in doubles is the combination of Technician Mach Punch and Spore, giving it a turn-one threat that can pick off weakened foes or simply remove one opposing Pokémon from the game.  Bullet Seed is chosen on every set because each individual hit is base-30, meaning each hit receives the Technician boost; with 3–5 hits it becomes a 112.5–187.5 base-power move before STAB, letting it muscle past bulky neutral targets and shatter Focus Sashes on the switch.  Protect is mandatory for prediction and to preserve Focus Sash or Poison Heal recovery.  The item split shows two philosophies: Focus Sash guarantees at least one Spore or Bullet Seed, while Iron Ball on a Brave set lets it move last inside Trick Room and adds a 130-base-power Ground move to its spread through Fling, giving it a surprise tech against Toxapex, Heatran and Miraidon.  Tera Ghost is preferred for blocking Fake Out and Extreme Speed, turning Breloom into an anti-priority pivot, while Tera Steel provides key resistances to Fairy, Poison and Rock and removes the 4× Flying weakness, letting it survive Tornadus–Hurricane or Lilligant–Pollen Puff.  EV spreads are polarised: Jolly max-Speed attempts to outrun base-70 scarfers and opposing Breloom, while the 252/252 Brave spread maximises Attack and Trick Room consistency.  The low usage of Effect Spore and Poison Heal suggests that players value the guaranteed power and priority of Technician over the RNG of status or the slow recovery of Poison Heal in the fast-paced doubles format.</OUTPUT>

input:
Write a detailed 'matchup_overview' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Breloom": {"Abilities": {"technician": 6.930796882028044, "effectspore": 0.7018538836943164, "poisonheal": 0.4673404154828464}, "Items": {"focussash": 0.4766926762738401, "ironball": 0.3154737735640996}, "Spreads": {"Jolly:4/252/0/0/0/252": 0.3190777084635113, "Brave:252/252/0/0/4/0": 0.31613083927643176}, "Moves": ["bulletseed", "machpunch", "protect", "spore"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.42597853573938954, "steel": 0.2852984593998328}, "Teammates": ["Archaludon", "Indeedee-F", "Ursaluna", "Hatterene", "Pelipper", "Gallade"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Breloom dominates slower set-up sweepers and sash-reliant leads such as Grimmsnarl, Whimsicott, Dragonite and Gholdengo, putting them to sleep before they can move and breaking their sash with multi-hit Bullet Seed.  Against Tailwind or Rain offense, however, Breloom struggles: base-70 Speed is insufficient to outrun +1 threats like Barraskewda or Chien-Pao, and Pelipper itself—the most common weather setter—takes half from Bullet Seed and threatens back with Hurricane or Surf.  Trick Room match-ups are paradoxical; Breloom’s Brave Iron Ball set loves Trick Room, but if the opponent sets it first, Breloom becomes food for 0-Speed Indeedee-F Expanding Force or Hatterene Mystical Fire.  Tera Ghost turns the tables on priority offense, but opens it up to Ghost-type STAB from Dragapult or Aegislash.  Steel Tera helps against Fairy-types like Azumarill and Sylveon, yet leaves it weak to Fire, which is omnipresent in Sun and on Iron Moth.  In summary, Breloom wins the lead war against slower, status-weak teams, but folds to faster spread attackers, weather abusers, and opposing terrain that blocks Spore.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Breloom": {"Abilities": {"technician": 6.930796882028044, "effectspore": 0.7018538836943164, "poisonheal": 0.4673404154828464}, "Items": {"focussash": 0.4766926762738401, "ironball": 0.3154737735640996}, "Spreads": {"Jolly:4/252/0/0/0/252": 0.3190777084635113, "Brave:252/252/0/0/4/0": 0.31613083927643176}, "Moves": ["bulletseed", "machpunch", "protect", "spore"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.42597853573938954, "steel": 0.2852984593998328}, "Teammates": ["Archaludon", "Indeedee-F", "Ursaluna", "Hatterene", "Pelipper", "Gallade"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Breloom is a hyper-offensive support lead that doubles as a late-game cleaner.  Turn one it either Spores a key target or fires a Technician Mach Punch to finish a weakened Dynamax, then immediately Protects to scout and preserve its sash.  Mid-game it switches in on predicted Protects or spread moves, re-positions with priority, and uses multi-hit Bullet Seed to deny Focus Sash, Sturdy and Weakness Policy procs.  In Trick Room variants it flips the script: Iron Ball guarantees it moves last, letting it underspeed 0-Speed Torkoal and Rhyperior to Spore them or fire a 130-base-power Fling before they move.  Its presence on the field forces the opponent to choose between targeting Breloom—risking a Protect—or its partner, knowing that whatever survives will likely put something to sleep next turn.  Thus Breloom functions as both a tempo thief and a win-condition once faster threats are removed.</OUTPUT>

Draft the 'synergy_breakdown' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Breloom": {"Abilities": {"technician": 6.930796882028044, "effectspore": 0.7018538836943164, "poisonheal": 0.4673404154828464}, "Items": {"focussash": 0.4766926762738401, "ironball": 0.3154737735640996}, "Spreads": {"Jolly:4/252/0/0/0/252": 0.3190777084635113, "Brave:252/252/0/0/4/0": 0.31613083927643176}, "Moves": ["bulletseed", "machpunch", "protect", "spore"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.42597853573938954, "steel": 0.2852984593998328}, "Teammates": ["Archaludon", "Indeedee-F", "Ursaluna", "Hatterene", "Pelipper", "Gallade"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Archaludon provides Steel-type bulk and sets Sticky Web or Stealth Rock, slowing the opposing board so that Jolly Breloom can outrun and Spore key threats.  Indeedee-F supplies Psychic Terrain, blocking opposing priority while allowing Breloom’s Mach Punch to still land, and offers Follow Me to draw attacks away from Breloom’s sash.  Ursaluna shares an Earthquake immunity and appreciates sleep support to set up Swords Dance or Bulk Up, while Breloom in turn loves Ursaluna’s ability to delete Flying-types.  Hatterene blocks opposing status with Magic Bounce and sets Trick Room for the Brave Iron Ball variant, turning Breloom into a 252-Attack monster that underspeeds everything.  Pelipper summons Rain, powering Breloom’s Bullet Seed through Swampert or Quagside, and provides Wide Guard to block spread Rock Slides that would break sash.  Gallade rounds out the core as a secondary Fighting-type that can activate Justified on Indeedee-F’s Beat Up, while Breloom handles the bulky Waters that wall Gallade.  Together these partners shore up Breloom’s mediocre Speed and bulk while amplifying its ability to control the first three turns.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Breloom": {"Abilities": {"technician": 6.930796882028044, "effectspore": 0.7018538836943164, "poisonheal": 0.4673404154828464}, "Items": {"focussash": 0.4766926762738401, "ironball": 0.3154737735640996}, "Spreads": {"Jolly:4/252/0/0/0/252": 0.3190777084635113, "Brave:252/252/0/0/4/0": 0.31613083927643176}, "Moves": ["bulletseed", "machpunch", "protect", "spore"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.42597853573938954, "steel": 0.2852984593998328}, "Teammates": ["Archaludon", "Indeedee-F", "Ursaluna", "Hatterene", "Pelipper", "Gallade"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Flying-types such as Tornadus, Corviknight and Yveltal outspeed and OHKO with Hurricane or Brave Bird, while resisting both STABs.  Sun teams with Charizard or Iron Moth vaporise Breloom before it can move, and Safety Goggles users—especially Gholdengo and Goodra-Hisui—ignore Spore and retaliate with Make It Rain or Draco Meteor.  Psychic Terrain from Indeedee-F blocks Mach Punch, forcing Breloom to predict switches or rely on Bullet Seed alone.  Intimidate Arcanine or Incineroar drop its Attack, making Bullet Seed fail to KO bulky neutral targets and forcing it to choose between staying in or switching out.  Multi-hit Rock Blast from Garganacl or Cloyster breaks sash and KOes, while Ghost-types like Dragapult immune to Mach Punch can set up Substitute or Dragon Dance on the predicted Spore.  Finally, opposing weather setters that change the field negate the Speed control Breloom relies on, leaving it outsped and KOed before it can contribute.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Breloom": {"Abilities": {"technician": 6.930796882028044, "effectspore": 0.7018538836943164, "poisonheal": 0.4673404154828464}, "Items": {"focussash": 0.4766926762738401, "ironball": 0.3154737735640996}, "Spreads": {"Jolly:4/252/0/0/0/252": 0.3190777084635113, "Brave:252/252/0/0/4/0": 0.31613083927643176}, "Moves": ["bulletseed", "machpunch", "protect", "spore"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.42597853573938954, "steel": 0.2852984593998328}, "Teammates": ["Archaludon", "Indeedee-F", "Ursaluna", "Hatterene", "Pelipper", "Gallade"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Start with Breloom + Indeedee-F lead: Indeedee-F sets Psychic Terrain and fires Follow Me while Breloom Spores the biggest threat; follow with Expanding Force plus Mach Punch to remove the sleeping target.  Back row pairs Archaludon + Pelipper: Archaludon sets Sticky Web or uses Flash Cannon to delete Fairies, while Pelipper summons Rain and Wide Guards to block Rock Slide.  The final slot is reserved for Ursaluna, which sets up Bulk Up on the sleeping field and sweeps under Trick Room if necessary.  EV spreads are standard except Indeedee-F runs 0 Attack IV to minimise Foul Play damage and guarantee Justified activation on Gallade if you choose to run Beat Up.  The team’s win condition is to sleep one target, remove sash on the other, then clean with Ursaluna or Archaludon under Rain-boosted Surging Strikes or Steelspike pressure.  Tera Ghost on Breloom is mandatory to ignore Fake Out from Incineroar, while Tera Water on Pelipper and Tera Fairy on Indeedee-F provide defensive pivots against Dragon and Dark teams respectively.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Exeggutor is a niche but dangerous Trick Room attacker that leverages its Psychic-typing and Harvest-boosted Sitrus Berry to repeatedly fire off Expanding Force under Indeedee-F’s Psychic Terrain while shrugging off would-be KOs. With a 94% Harvest usage rate, it is clearly built to stay on the field, and its nearly 70% Psychic Tera rate lets it double down on STAB or flip match-ups into Amoonguss or Dark-types. Modest 252/252 spreads are the norm, and its move pool—Trick Room, Expanding Force, Energy Ball, Sleep Powder—makes it a self-setting, self-benefiting speed control piece that fits best on full-room or hybrid sun-room squads alongside Torkoal, Indeedee-F, and heavy physical breakers such as Ursaluna and Sneasler.</OUTPUT>

input:
Generate the 'full_analysis' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Exeggutor": {"Abilities": {"harvest": 0.9484506099022275, "chlorophyll": 8.070816512474655}, "Items": {"focussash": 0.5971881747111093, "lifeorb": 0.22037734026673642}, "Spreads": {"Modest:4/0/0/252/0/252": 0.3416199169386577, "Modest:0/0/0/252/4/252": 0.3873727437036633}, "Moves": ["trickroom", "expandingforce", "energyball", "sleeppowder"], "Tera Types": {"psychic": 0.685627824741654}, "Teammates": ["Indeedee-F", "Torkoal", "Ursaluna", "Gallade", "Zoroark-Hisui", "Sneasler"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Exeggutor’s value in the current VGC meta is defined by three factors: Harvest reliability, Psychic Terrain synergy, and its unique ability to compress Trick Room setter and spread-damage dealer into one slot. Harvest gives a 50% recycle chance per turn, effectively granting a 50% chance to heal 25% every turn after consuming Sitrus; when combined with Focus Sash (60% usage) the tree becomes surprisingly hard to remove turn 1, while Life Orb variants (22%) trade bulk for immediate power. Modest max Special Attack is non-negotiable—base 125 SpA is the highest among legal Psychic-types that can also set Trick Room, giving it a damage ceiling high enough to 2HKO neutral targets like Tornadus-I and bulky Gholdengo through terrain. Expanding Force under terrain reaches 120 BP spread damage without the accuracy issues of Heat Wave or Rock Slide, allowing Exeggutor to pressure both foes simultaneously while partner Indeedee-F provides Follow Me and terrain insurance. Energy Ball is primarily used to smack Gastrodon and Rotom-Wash for ~70%, forcing Protect or Tera, while Sleep Powder punches holes in stall cores and can buy a free Harvest recycle. Psychic Tera turns its STAB into a nuke (effectively 180 BP spread) and removes Dark weakness, letting it stay on the field against Kingambit or Tera-Dark mons. The 39% 0-Atk/4-Def spread is chosen to survive Jolly Chien-Pao Ice Spinner + Ice Shard 100% of the time after Sitrus, while the 34% 4-HP variant guarantees the same versus Adamant Life Orb Chien-Pao. Overall, Exeggutor is a high-risk, high-reward pick that demands terrain support but can single-handedly flip boards if Harvest triggers early.</OUTPUT>

input:
Create the 'matchup_overview' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Exeggutor": {"Abilities": {"harvest": 0.9484506099022275, "chlorophyll": 8.070816512474655}, "Items": {"focussash": 0.5971881747111093, "lifeorb": 0.22037734026673642}, "Spreads": {"Modest:4/0/0/252/0/252": 0.3416199169386577, "Modest:0/0/0/252/4/252": 0.3873727437036633}, "Moves": ["trickroom", "expandingforce", "energyball", "sleeppowder"], "Tera Types": {"psychic": 0.685627824741654}, "Teammates": ["Indeedee-F", "Torkoal", "Ursaluna", "Gallade", "Zoroark-Hisui", "Sneasler"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Exeggutor loves facing slower, bulky teams that rely on spread moves or lack immediate Dark-type pressure; Amoonguss, Torkoal, Gastrodon, and Dondozo are all forced to respect Expanding Force or risk being 2HKOed. It breaks typical Follow-Me + setup cores by either nuking both sides or putting the redirector to sleep. Against Tailwind or Regieleki speed control, setting its own Trick Room turns the tables, making it a soft-check to common hyper-offense. Conversely, faster Dark-types—Chien-Pao, Kingambit, Meowscarada—remain nightmare match-ups pre-Tera; even after Terastallizing, Sucker Punch or Knock Off can still finish the job if Harvest fails once. Steel-types such as Gholdengo and Corviknight resist both STABs and can stall out terrain turns, while Sun-boosted Torkoal Overheat cleanly OHKOs even through Sitrus. Opposing Indeedee-F can overwrite terrain, neutering Expanding Force and forcing a predictable Protect cycle. Finally, Taunt users like Murkrow or Whimsicott cripple Trick Room and force 50-50 Harvest rolls, so these must be removed or slept before committing to set-up.</OUTPUT>

Generate the 'role_description' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Exeggutor": {"Abilities": {"harvest": 0.9484506099022275, "chlorophyll": 8.070816512474655}, "Items": {"focussash": 0.5971881747111093, "lifeorb": 0.22037734026673642}, "Spreads": {"Modest:4/0/0/252/0/252": 0.3416199169386577, "Modest:0/0/0/252/4/252": 0.3873727437036633}, "Moves": ["trickroom", "expandingforce", "energyball", "sleeppowder"], "Tera Types": {"psychic": 0.685627824741654}, "Teammates": ["Indeedee-F", "Torkoal", "Ursaluna", "Gallade", "Zoroark-Hisui", "Sneasler"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Exeggutor is a dual-role Special Attacker and Trick Room setter that aims to compress speed control and spread damage into one slot. It leads when the opponent lacks immediate Dark-type pressure, clicking Trick Room turn 1 while partner Indeedee-F provides Follow Me and terrain. Once room is up, it spams Expanding Force to chunk both foes, using Sleep Powder to disable the biggest threat and Harvest + Sitrus to outlast return fire. Energy Ball is reserved for bulky Waters or to avoid Wide Guard mind-games. If the opposing lead carries Taunt or Ghost-types immune to Fake Out, Exeggutor can instead fire immediate spread damage, force Protects, and set room on a predicted switch. Psychic Terastallization is usually saved for mid-game, either to secure a KO on a weakened Dark-type or to survive a crucial Knock Off and continue sweeping. In back-line situations it can reverse opposing Tailwind or act as a late-game cleaner under its own room, making it flexible for both offensive and defensive game plans.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Exeggutor": {"Abilities": {"harvest": 0.9484506099022275, "chlorophyll": 8.070816512474655}, "Items": {"focussash": 0.5971881747111093, "lifeorb": 0.22037734026673642}, "Spreads": {"Modest:4/0/0/252/0/252": 0.3416199169386577, "Modest:0/0/0/252/4/252": 0.3873727437036633}, "Moves": ["trickroom", "expandingforce", "energyball", "sleeppowder"], "Tera Types": {"psychic": 0.685627824741654}, "Teammates": ["Indeedee-F", "Torkoal", "Ursaluna", "Gallade", "Zoroark-Hisui", "Sneasler"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Indeedee-F is mandatory: Psychic Terrain doubles Expanding Force, Follow Me blocks single-target knock-outs, and Helping Hand secures key OHKOs like Tera-Steel Kingambit. Torkoal provides sun for Harvest consistency (100% recycle chance) and can slot onto the same team as a secondary room setter or offensive threat; sun-boosted Eruption plus Expanding Force applies dual spread pressure that few cores can stomach. Ursaluna benefits from Trick Room, appreciates Psychic Terrain stopping priority revenge kills, and can break special walls that trouble Exeggutor. Gallade offers a secondary Fighting-type that smashes Dark and Steel switch-ins, while Zoroark-Hisui disguised as Indeedee-F can bait Dark-type moves and punish with Tera-Normal Hyper Voice or Trick Room. Sneasler rounds out the squad as a fast offensive option outside room and can clean late-game once Exeggutor has removed bulky Waters and Grass-types. The shared Fighting resistance among Indeedee, Torkoal, and Exeggutor helps the team stomach Chien-Pao, while the double Terrain setters reduce the odds of losing terrain war.</OUTPUT>

Guarantees survival vs Jolly Chien-Pao Ice Spinner + Shard after Sitrus, maximizes spread damage, and gives two lives vs double-target. Set 2 (Life Orb Power): Modest 4/0/0/252/0/252, Harvest, Life Orb, Psychic Tera — same moves. <DATA>{"Exeggutor": {"Abilities": {"harvest": 0.9484506099022275, "chlorophyll": 8.070816512474655}, "Items": {"focussash": 0.5971881747111093, "lifeorb": 0.22037734026673642}, "Spreads": {"Modest:4/0/0/252/0/252": 0.3416199169386577, "Modest:0/0/0/252/4/252": 0.3873727437036633}, "Moves": ["trickroom", "expandingforce", "energyball", "sleeppowder"], "Tera Types": {"psychic": 0.685627824741654}, "Teammates": ["Indeedee-F", "Torkoal", "Ursaluna", "Gallade", "Zoroark-Hisui", "Sneasler"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Faster Dark-types are public enemy #1: Chien-Pao’s Ice Spinner + Sucker Punch combo OHKOs before Sitrus if Harvest fails once, while Kingambit’s Supreme Overlord-boosted Sucker Punch can reach 140 BP by late game. Knock Off users such as Corviknight and Meowscarada remove Focus Sash and halve Harvest odds, turning Exeggutor into a frail 95/85/65 bulk mon. Wide Guard completely blanks Expanding Force and forces predictable Energy Ball or Sleep Powder reads; teams carrying Aegislash or Arcanine can stall out terrain turns and punish with Flash Cannon or Burn Up respectively. Taunt from Murkrow, Whimsicott, or opposing Indeedee-F shuts down Trick Room and leaves Exegguron as a one-dimensional attacker that is out-sped and KOed. Weather wars also hurt: opposing Tyranitar or Pelipper overwrite sun, dropping Harvest to 50%, and Sand chip plus Knock Off can finish the job. Finally, double-targeting the tree turn 1 while ignoring Indeedee-F remains the simplest counter-play; without a Harvest trigger, even neutral STAB like Iron Head or Hyper Voice plus a modest Helping Hand follow-up will fell it before it moves.</OUTPUT>

EV spreads: Exeggutor Modest 0/0/0/252/4/252 Harvest Sash Psychic Tera; Indeedee-F Bold 252/0/140/0/116/200 Psychic Seed; Torkoal Quiet 252/0/0/252/4/0 Charcoal; Ursaluna Brave 252/252/0/0/4/0 Life Orb; Sneasler Jolly 4/252/0/0/0/252 Focus Sash; Corviknight Careful 252/0/100/0/156/0 Leftovers. While its usage is low, the Mental Herb variant with Fire Tera has carved out a small but consistent role on dedicated Trick Room squads that appreciate a slow, self-sufficient tank which can simultaneously block Fake Out, ignore Spore, and snowball through teams that lack a Fire-type breaker.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Bronzong": {"Abilities": {"heatproof": 0.1256341957124183, "levitate": 7.9508387668527485, "heavymetal": 0.05744515528309052}, "Items": {"mentalherb": 0.46468346693349133, "leftovers": 0.15614104898105788}, "Spreads": {"Relaxed:252/0/132/0/124/0": 0.31360849929376716}, "Moves": ["trickroom", "bodypress", "irondefense", "icespinner"], "Tera Types": {"fire": 0.4913638884754989}, "Teammates": ["Amoonguss", "Ursaluna", "Incineroar", "Torkoal", "Jumpluff", "Charizard"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Bronzong’s stat-line is the classic «slow steel tank»: 67/116/116 physical bulk is already excellent, and Iron Defense pushes it into the «only super-effective crits matter» tier. Levitate is the only ability that sees meaningful usage (≈96 % of teams) because it removes the otherwise crippling Ground weakness and turns Bronzong into a pseudo-airborne Pokémon that can switch into Earthquakes from partners such as Ursaluna or opposing Lando-T without fear. Mental Herb is the default item: it guarantees Trick Room goes up against Taunt users like Murkrow or Whimsicott, while Leftovers is a distant second choice for longer stalling. The listed spread (Relaxed 252/0/132/0/124/0) maximises overall physical bulk, outslows every non-TR Pokémon under sun, and hits a Leftovers number. Trick Room is the mandatory speed control, Iron Defense + Body Press the win-condition engine, and Ice Spinner the coverage slot: it 2HKOs common Dragons (Dragapult, Flutter Mane) and breaks Psychic Terrain so partners can spam priority. Fire Tera is ubiquitous because it flips the Fire weakness into a resistance, letting Bronzong survive Overheat from Torkoal or Heat Wave from Charizard and retaliate with a +2 Body Press.</OUTPUT>

It also pressures common Fairy/Dragon cores thanks to Ice Spinner and neutral Body Press. Finally, Taunt users that outspeed and carry Mental Herb-bypassing options (e.g. Tornadus with Prankster into Dark Pulse) can prevent setup, while Haze Clear Smog Amoonguss or Dondozo can erase Iron Defense boosts.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Bronzong": {"Abilities": {"heatproof": 0.1256341957124183, "levitate": 7.9508387668527485, "heavymetal": 0.05744515528309052}, "Items": {"mentalherb": 0.46468346693349133, "leftovers": 0.15614104898105788}, "Spreads": {"Relaxed:252/0/132/0/124/0": 0.31360849929376716}, "Moves": ["trickroom", "bodypress", "irondefense", "icespinner"], "Tera Types": {"fire": 0.4913638884754989}, "Teammates": ["Amoonguss", "Ursaluna", "Incineroar", "Torkoal", "Jumpluff", "Charizard"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Bronzong’s ideal teammates are slow powerhouses that appreciate Trick Room and cover its Fire and Special weaknesses. Ursaluna is the perfect partner: it breaks opposing Steels that wall Body Press, enjoys Levitate support, and forms a slow core that steamrolls under TR. Amoonguss provides Rage Powder redirection, Spore, and Clear Smog insurance against opposing setup, while Bronzong blocks Fake Out for it. Incineroar offers Intimidate, Parting Shot, and a Fire-type of its own to bait opposing Water-moves away from Bronzong. Torkoal supplies sun-boosted Eruption and can bait Fire-type attacks that Bronzong can safely Tera-Fire absorb. Jumpluff gives fast sleep and Encore while still functioning under Trick Room with 0 Spe IVs, and Charizard provides a secondary Fire immunity and spread damage. Together these Pokémon form a «slow mode» Trick Room squad that can still function outside TR thanks to priority, redirection and raw bulk.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Special Fire-types are public enemy #1: Chi-Yo, Tera-Fire Skeledirge, Torkoal under sun, and Tera-Fire Iron Moth all OHKO through Tera Fire. Strong special breakers like Tera-Ghost Flutter Mane, Life Orb Hydreigon, and Choice Specs Dragapult also 2HKO with Shadow Ball or Draco Meteor. Taunt users that outspeed and carry Dark-type coverage—Prankster Tornadus, Grimmsnarl, or Murkrow—can stop Trick Room and force Bronzong out. Clear Smog Amoonguss and Haze Dondozo reset Iron Defense, while Unaware Dondozo ignores the boosts entirely. Finally, critical hits bypass Iron Defense, so teams that can fish for them (Scope Lens Kingambit, Super Luck Togekiss) can end the sweep prematurely.</OUTPUT>

Lead Bronzong + Jumpluff: Jumpluff can put something to sleep or Encore a setup move while Bronzong sets Trick Room; Mental Herb blocks Taunt. Turn two you can switch Jumpluff into Incineroar for Intimidate pivoting, or into Amoonguss for redirection. Once TR is up, Ursaluna and Torkoal become the win conditions, with Bronzong cleaning late-game after Iron Defense boosts. Incineroar and Amoonguss provide constant pivoting and disruption, while Torkoal’s sun both powers its own Eruption and reduces Water damage aimed at Bronzong. The team is weak to opposing sun with Chi-Yo, so Tera Fire on Bronzong and Tera Water on Incineroar are recommended to flip key match-ups.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Wyrdeer is a niche support pick in VGC 2024 that leverages its unique Normal/Psychic typing and Intimidate to compress Trick Room, Skill Swap utility, and late-game Expanding Force pressure into one slot. It is almost always seen with Covert Cloak, a Calm spread, and Dark Tera to dodge Fake Out and Sucker Punch while neutering opposing Incineroar and Chien-Pao. The deer’s main draw is enabling full-room or semi-room cores alongside heavy hitters like Basculegion and Sneasler, but its middling bulk and passivity outside of Trick Room keep it firmly a tech choice rather than a format staple.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Wyrdeer": {"Abilities": {"intimidate": 7.83639300171558, "sapsipper": 0.25191052562811145, "frisk": 0.006403375695434699}, "Items": {"covertcloak": 0.7938794954116898}, "Spreads": {"Calm:124/0/0/76/252/52": 0.4495382387428678, "Calm:124/0/0/76/252/0": 0.32012044059927414}, "Moves": ["skillswap", "trickroom", "expandingforce", "earthpower"], "Tera Types": {"dark": 0.9189738352367333}, "Teammates": ["Sneasler", "Basculegion", "Archaludon", "Pelipper", "Indeedee", "Empoleon"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Wyrdeer’s statistical footprint on the current ladder is tiny—fewer than 8 % of teams bother to bring it—but those that do treat it as a glue piece for Trick Room structures that want a second setter immune to Ghost-type Fake Out and capable of threatening opposing Indeedee-F for terrain wars. Intimidate is chosen on 96 % of sets, turning the deer into a soft check to physical attackers such as Chien-Pao, Kingambit and opposing Sneasler while also flipping Skill Swap onto partners like Archaludon or Empoleon to turn their otherwise neutral abilities into disruptive weapons. Covert Cloak is the only item worth mentioning; it blanks the flinch from Fake Out and the Sp. Atk drop from Snarl or Moonblast, letting Wyrdeer fire Trick Room or Skill Swap even under heavy disruption. The Calm 124/76/252 spread hits a jump point in Special Defense while keeping enough physical bulk to survive -1 Chien-Pao Ice Spinner and guaranteeing the Speed tier to move before uninvested base 60s under Trick Room. Expanding Force is run over Psychic for the spread damage that synergises with Indeedee-F’s Psychic Terrain, while Earth Power is the coverage slot of choice to 2HKO Torkoal and Gholdengo. Dark Tera is omnipresent because it removes the Ghost weakness, turns the deer into a Fake Out absorber, and lets it win the mirror Skill Swap war against Incineroar. In practice Wyrdeer functions as a lead on turn one alongside Indeedee-F: Indeedee sets terrain, Wyrdeer sets Trick Room, and from there the team transitions into a slow, powerful endgame. The deer can also pivot into the back slot to reset room mid-game or to Skill Swap away opposing Intimidate or Quark Drive once the board state is stabilised.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Wyrdeer": {"Abilities": {"intimidate": 7.83639300171558, "sapsipper": 0.25191052562811145, "frisk": 0.006403375695434699}, "Items": {"covertcloak": 0.7938794954116898}, "Spreads": {"Calm:124/0/0/76/252/52": 0.4495382387428678, "Calm:124/0/0/76/252/0": 0.32012044059927414}, "Moves": ["skillswap", "trickroom", "expandingforce", "earthpower"], "Tera Types": {"dark": 0.9189738352367333}, "Teammates": ["Sneasler", "Basculegion", "Archaludon", "Pelipper", "Indeedee", "Empoleon"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Wyrdeer cores live or die on winning the terrain war and keeping Trick Room intact. Against Sun, the deer can survive Torkoal Overheat under sun only if it has already proc’d Intimidate, and it cleanly 2HKOs back with Earth Power; however, a +2 Torkoal under sun still OHKOs, so the matchup demands careful positioning with Rage Powder or Follow Me. Versus Rain, Wyrdeer is largely dead weight—Pelipper cancels Psychic Terrain and Kingdra or Barraskewda outspeed and KO before room goes up. Into Tailwind offense the deer is surprisingly serviceable: Intimidate plus Skill Swap can strip away Mirror Herb or Quark Drive boosts, and once room is up the opposing +1 Dragonite or Iron Bundle is outsped and KO’d by partner Basculegion. Against hard Trick Room mirrors the deer functions as a secondary setter that can reset room after the opponent’s first setter faints, but it loses head-to-head to Farigiraf’s Armor Tail and to Indeedee-F’s Follow Me pressure. Into stall or fatigue structures, Wyrdeer’s lack of recovery and passive damage output means it must rely on partners to break Toxapex or Dondozo; otherwise it becomes setup fodder for Curse Dondozo or Stored Power users.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Wyrdeer": {"Abilities": {"intimidate": 7.83639300171558, "sapsipper": 0.25191052562811145, "frisk": 0.006403375695434699}, "Items": {"covertcloak": 0.7938794954116898}, "Spreads": {"Calm:124/0/0/76/252/52": 0.4495382387428678, "Calm:124/0/0/76/252/0": 0.32012044059927414}, "Moves": ["skillswap", "trickroom", "expandingforce", "earthpower"], "Tera Types": {"dark": 0.9189738352367333}, "Teammates": ["Sneasler", "Basculegion", "Archaludon", "Pelipper", "Indeedee", "Empoleon"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Wyrdeer is a hybrid support that compresses four jobs: Trick Room setter, Intimidate user, terrain-agnostic Expanding Force attacker, and Skill Swap disruptor. It is never the sole win condition; instead it is a facilitator that enables breakers such as Basculegion, Sneasler, and Iron Hands to operate under room. Because it carries only two attacks, its damage output is modest—Expanding Force reaches only 90 BP under terrain and Earth Power fails to OHKO standard Gholdengo—so its value lies entirely in the utility it provides before fainting. Optimal play patterns involve leading Wyrdeer + Indeedee-F to guarantee room, then immediately pivoting the deer out to preserve Intimidate drops and reset room later. In the mid-game the deer can re-enter to Skill Swap away opposing Quark Drive or Protosynthesis, turning off speed boosts and allowing slower partners to retain speed control. End-game scenarios see Wyrdeer clicking Expanding Force to clean weakened boards, but this is a secondary role; the deer is expected to trade its HP for one or two crucial turns of board control rather than sweep.</OUTPUT>

Draft the 'synergy_breakdown' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Wyrdeer": {"Abilities": {"intimidate": 7.83639300171558, "sapsipper": 0.25191052562811145, "frisk": 0.006403375695434699}, "Items": {"covertcloak": 0.7938794954116898}, "Spreads": {"Calm:124/0/0/76/252/52": 0.4495382387428678, "Calm:124/0/0/76/252/0": 0.32012044059927414}, "Moves": ["skillswap", "trickroom", "expandingforce", "earthpower"], "Tera Types": {"dark": 0.9189738352367333}, "Teammates": ["Sneasler", "Basculegion", "Archaludon", "Pelipper", "Indeedee", "Empoleon"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Indeedee-F is the non-negotiable partner: terrain boosts Expanding Force, Follow Me protects the room setup, and Helping Hand turns Basculegion into an OHKO machine. Basculegion is the premier attacker alongside the deer—under room and Helping Hand, Adaptability Wave Crash OHKOs neutral targets up to bulky Arcanine and Iron Treads. Sneasler appreciates room to underspeed opposing Flutter Mane and Iron Bundle, and it can activate Toxic Chain on switches forced by Wyrdeer’s Skill Swap. Archaludon provides a secondary Skill Swap target, turning Stamina into an Intimidate-immune win condition once it receives the ability. Empoleon offers Fake Out and Rallying Roar to let Wyrdeer set room twice in one game, while Pelipper is an unusual but documented teammate that flips the script versus Sun by resetting weather and giving Basculegion rain-boosted Wave Crash. Covert Cloak synergy is vital: because the deer avoids flinches and stat drops, partners can safely run Life Orb or Weakness Policy without fear of Snarl or Icy Wind ruining their damage output.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>The only statistically relevant set is Calm 124 HP / 76 Def / 252 SpD with 0 Atk IVs to minimise Foul Play damage. Intimidate is mandatory; Sap Sipper and Frisk are gimmicks that sacrifice the deer’s best utility. Covert Cloak is the item; no alternative item appears in meaningful usage. Moves are fixed: Trick Room and Skill Swap are the reasons to use the deer, Expanding Force is the obligatory STAB, and Earth Power is the only coverage that hits both Torkoal and Gholdengo. Dark Tera is used on 92 % of teams; the remaining 8 % run Psychic to boost Expanding Force, but this is inferior because it leaves the deer vulnerable to Ghost-type Fake Out and Shadow Sneak. EV spreads that drop Special Defense to add physical bulk or Speed are not documented in high-level usage, suggesting the listed spread is mathematically optimal for surviving key special hits such as Life Orb Flutter Mane Shadow Ball.</OUTPUT>
