Provide the 'weaknesses_and_counters' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Wyrdeer": {"Abilities": {"intimidate": 7.83639300171558, "sapsipper": 0.25191052562811145, "frisk": 0.006403375695434699}, "Items": {"covertcloak": 0.7938794954116898}, "Spreads": {"Calm:124/0/0/76/252/52": 0.4495382387428678, "Calm:124/0/0/76/252/0": 0.32012044059927414}, "Moves": ["skillswap", "trickroom", "expandingforce", "earthpower"], "Tera Types": {"dark": 0.9189738352367333}, "Teammates": ["Sneasler", "Basculegion", "Archaludon", "Pelipper", "Indeedee", "Empoleon"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Wyrdeer is extremely vulnerable to Taunt and Ghost-type Fake Out from mons like Mimikyu and Annihilape; because it is slower than both, it cannot set room before being Taunted or KO’d. Dark Tera helps but does not solve the problem—Mimikyu can still Shadow Sneak for the KO after Disguise breaks. Opposing Farigiraf with Armor Tail blanks Trick Room entirely, forcing the deer to click Skill Swap or Earth Power while the giraffe sets up Calm Mind. Chien-Pao is a nightmare: even at -1, Ice Spinner into Ice Shard KOes the deer through Covert Cloak, and Intimidate does not stop Sword of Ruin. Iron Bundle outspeeds and 2HKOs with Freeze-Dry, and because the deer lacks recovery it cannot afford to switch in more than once. Finally, any team that can deny terrain—whether via opposing Indeedee, Psychic Seed Iron Treads, or simple weather war—cuts Expanding Force to 80 BP and turns Wyrdeer into dead weight. Once Trick Room is denied, the deer becomes setup fodder for Kingambit, Iron Valiant, or Curse Dondozo.</OUTPUT>

Generate the 'sample_team_concept' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Wyrdeer": {"Abilities": {"intimidate": 7.83639300171558, "sapsipper": 0.25191052562811145, "frisk": 0.006403375695434699}, "Items": {"covertcloak": 0.7938794954116898}, "Spreads": {"Calm:124/0/0/76/252/52": 0.4495382387428678, "Calm:124/0/0/76/252/0": 0.32012044059927414}, "Moves": ["skillswap", "trickroom", "expandingforce", "earthpower"], "Tera Types": {"dark": 0.9189738352367333}, "Teammates": ["Sneasler", "Basculegion", "Archaludon", "Pelipper", "Indeedee", "Empoleon"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>A proven six that maximises Wyrdeer’s value is: Wyrdeer / Indeedee-F / Basculegion / Sneasler / Iron Hands / Arcanine. Lead Wyrdeer + Indeedee-F: turn one Indeedee Follow Me while Wyrdeer sets Trick Room; turn two Helping Hand + Wave Crash secures an early KO. Basculegion is the primary breaker under room, while Sneasler provides a fast mode outside room and can Toxic Chain stall opposing walls. Iron Hands is the secondary room abuser with Fake Out and Drain Punch to keep the deer healthy. Arcanine compresses a second Intimidate user and can flip to Will-o-Wisp or Snarl to soften physical threats for the deer’s second room cycle. Tera Dark on Wyrdeer, Tera Water on Basculegion, and Tera Fairy on Iron Hands give the squad flexible type-changes to absorb opposing Dragon, Dark, and Fighting moves. The team is weak to Rain and to Farigiraf, so the pilot must conserve Arcanine’s Snarl and Sneasler’s Taunt to shut down those matchups. Overall the core is a hyper-offensive room squad that aims to trade two-for-two in the first four turns, then reset room with Wyrdeer and clean with whichever breaker remains.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Hydrapple": {"Abilities": {"supersweetsyrup": 1.2068510608464904, "stickyhold": 0.002976200220460967, "regenerator": 6.518169685909137}, "Items": {"assaultvest": 0.7441439171181236}, "Spreads": {"Bold:252/0/156/4/92/4": 0.43834070375849804}, "Moves": ["ficklebeam", "gigadrain", "earthpower", "pollenpuff"], "Tera Types": {"steel": 0.26842106312814806, "fire": 0.4617997867605698}, "Teammates": ["Milotic", "Ursaluna", "Garchomp", "Kingambit", "Baxcalibur", "Volcarona"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Hydrapple is a niche but surprisingly effective special attacker in VGC, leveraging its unique Grass/Dragon typing and access to Supersweet Syrup to break through common cores. With Fickle Beam, Giga Drain, Earth Power, and Pollen Puff it compresses offensive pressure, recovery, and ally healing into one slot, while Assault Vest patches its merely average bulk. A Bold 252/156/92 spread maximises physical bulk while still letting its 110 base SpA threaten OHKOs on Incineroar, Gholdengo and Rotom-W after Syrup’s SpD drop. Tera Steel or Fire removes Ice and Fairy weaknesses respectively and grants key resistances to round out match-ups versus top-tier threats like Chien-Pao, Sun cores, and Kingambit. Although its 59 base Speed is low, it fits naturally on bulky offence squads that already pack speed control from partners such as Milotic Icy Wind or Chomp Rock Slide flinches.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Hydrapple": {"Abilities": {"supersweetsyrup": 1.2068510608464904, "stickyhold": 0.002976200220460967, "regenerator": 6.518169685909137}, "Items": {"assaultvest": 0.7441439171181236}, "Spreads": {"Bold:252/0/156/4/92/4": 0.43834070375849804}, "Moves": ["ficklebeam", "gigadrain", "earthpower", "pollenpuff"], "Tera Types": {"steel": 0.26842106312814806, "fire": 0.4617997867605698}, "Teammates": ["Milotic", "Ursaluna", "Garchomp", "Kingambit", "Baxcalibur", "Volcarona"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Hydrapple’s claim to fame is Supersweet Syrup, a once-per-battle Accuracy-ignoring, guaranteed Special Defence drop that turns every neutral hit into a pseudo-STAB nuke. After the Syrup trigger, Fickle Beam becomes a 120 BP Dragon move capable of 2HKOing even specially defensive Dondozo, while Giga Drain provides reliable Grass STAB that heals back chip from U-turns and Brave Birds. Earth Power nails Toxapex, Gholdengo and opposing Heat Rotom, and Pollen Puff gives the squad a clutch 80 BP Bug special move that can either smack Psychic-types or heal a partner for 50 %—a priceless option under Assault Vest. The chosen EV spread survives Jolly Chomp Tera Dragon Tera Blast, +1 Ice Spinner from Palafin, and two Life-Orb Moonblasts from Specs Sylveon after Syrup defence drop, while 4 SpA and a Modest nature secure the OHKO on 252 HP Incineroar after Syrup. Assault Vest pushes its special bulk to effective 170/202 levels, letting it live Choice Specs Tera Water Hydro Pump from Walking Wake and retaliate with Giga Drain. Tera Steel is the default: it removes the 4× Ice weakness, grants a Toxic immunity, and turns Hydrapple into a Fairy resist that can comfortably sit on Sylveon and Azumarill. Tera Fire is an excellent alternative on sun-style teams, letting it absorb Moonblasts and Overheat while boosting its own Fire-type moves should it carry Flamethrower over Pollen Puff. Regenerator sets are occasionally seen with Leftovers or Sitrus for pivoting, but without the immediate breaking power of Syrup the Pokémon becomes underwhelming. Sticky Hold is irrelevant once Knock Off became less common.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Hydrapple": {"Abilities": {"supersweetsyrup": 1.2068510608464904, "stickyhold": 0.002976200220460967, "regenerator": 6.518169685909137}, "Items": {"assaultvest": 0.7441439171181236}, "Spreads": {"Bold:252/0/156/4/92/4": 0.43834070375849804}, "Moves": ["ficklebeam", "gigadrain", "earthpower", "pollenpuff"], "Tera Types": {"steel": 0.26842106312814806, "fire": 0.4617997867605698}, "Teammates": ["Milotic", "Ursaluna", "Garchomp", "Kingambit", "Baxcalibur", "Volcarona"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Hydrapple’s typing gives it natural advantages against Water-Ground cores (Swampert, Quagsire, Clodsire) and Rain staples such as Pelipper and offensive Toxapex. After Syrup, it flips the Kingambit match-up from shaky to favourable, dropping the Dark/Steel Pokémon into guaranteed 2HKO range of Earth Power while living a +1 Sucker Punch. Against Sun, Tera Fire Hydrapple can stomach Torkoal Overheat and return fire with Earth Power; versus Snow, Tera Steel avoids the 4× Ice Shard weakness and lets it stay in on Tera Ice Chien-Pao. Fairy-types remain problematic: Tera Fairy Sylveon still 2HKOes with Hyper Voice through Vest, while Choice Specs Flutter Mane outspeeds and OHKOes with Dazzling Gleam unless you Tera Steel on the switch. Dragonite with Tera Normal Extreme Speed is another headache, though a healthy Hydrapple can survive one +2 ES and KO back with Fickle Beam after Syrup. Speed control is the overarching issue—base 59 leaves it outrun by every relevant scarfer and most support Pokémon, so it demands either Tailwind, Icy Wind, or Trick Room to function.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Hydrapple": {"Abilities": {"supersweetsyrup": 1.2068510608464904, "stickyhold": 0.002976200220460967, "regenerator": 6.518169685909137}, "Items": {"assaultvest": 0.7441439171181236}, "Spreads": {"Bold:252/0/156/4/92/4": 0.43834070375849804}, "Moves": ["ficklebeam", "gigadrain", "earthpower", "pollenpuff"], "Tera Types": {"steel": 0.26842106312814806, "fire": 0.4617997867605698}, "Teammates": ["Milotic", "Ursaluna", "Garchomp", "Kingambit", "Baxcalibur", "Volcarona"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Hydrapple is a wall-breaker/sustain hybrid that occupies a special-attacker slot on bulky offence or balance teams. Its primary job is to click Syrup on turn 1 (or immediately after a Protect) to secure the SpD drop, then fire off perfectly accurate, deceptively powerful attacks while healing itself and allies. Because it carries Assault Vest it cannot Protect, so partners must provide redirection (Wide Guard, Follow Me) or speed control to let it move safely. The ability to heal 50 % of a teammate’s HP with Pollen Puff gives it unique mid-game utility, turning 2v2 endgames in your favour by reviving a weakened sweeper or support without spending a turn on Recover. In Trick Room it becomes a respectable attacker, outslowing Indeedee-F and Hatterene to break Psychic Terrain or sweep after a Sylveon KO. Outside of TR it functions as a decoy: opponents often overcommit to KOing it, allowing set-up sweepers such as Swords Dance Kingambit or Dragon Dance Baxcalibur to snowball.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Hydrapple": {"Abilities": {"supersweetsyrup": 1.2068510608464904, "stickyhold": 0.002976200220460967, "regenerator": 6.518169685909137}, "Items": {"assaultvest": 0.7441439171181236}, "Spreads": {"Bold:252/0/156/4/92/4": 0.43834070375849804}, "Moves": ["ficklebeam", "gigadrain", "earthpower", "pollenpuff"], "Tera Types": {"steel": 0.26842106312814806, "fire": 0.4617997867605698}, "Teammates": ["Milotic", "Ursaluna", "Garchomp", "Kingambit", "Baxcalibur", "Volcarona"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Milotic is the premier partner: Competitive deters Intimidate cycles, Icy Wind provides speed control, and Coil + Recover lets it act as a secondary win-con while Hydrapple breaks walls. Ursaluna appreciates Pollen Puff healing and Syrup-boosted Earth Powers removing Steel-types that would otherwise wall Headlong Rush. Garchomp forms a Dragon-spam core, punishing opposing Ice-types with Tera Fire Chomp while Hydrapple lures and weakens Fairies for Chomp to sweep late-game. Kingambit offers priority, Defiant pressure, and a strong Fairy answer; Hydrapple in return removes Corviknight and Toxapex for Kingambit. Baxcalibur loves the removal of bulky Waters and Fairies, while its Snow-boosted Ice Shard can pick off faster threats that would KO Hydrapple. Volcarona covers the Bug and Fairy weaknesses, provides Tailwind or Rage Powder support, and breaks down Steel-types so Hydrapple can more freely click Fickle Beam. In general, bring Hydrapple alongside at least one speed-control option and one Fairy resist, then fill the last slots with either a second mode of speed control or a set-up cleaner that exploits the holes Hydrapple punches.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Flareon": {"Abilities": {"flashfire": 5.755014162304714, "guts": 1.6983911626072299}, "Items": {"toxicorb": 0.2270646855038324, "safetygoggles": 0.765288953599277}, "Spreads": {"Adamant:236/252/0/0/0/20": 0.7652889535992768, "Adamant:252/76/100/0/4/76": 0.22174883092767494}, "Moves": ["flareblitz", "quickattack", "detect", "roar"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.9870898550399415}, "Teammates": ["Jolteon", "Vaporeon", "Sylveon", "Umbreon", "Espeon", "Hitmontop"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Flareon’s offensive profile is defined by 130 Attack and access to strong Fire-type STAB, yet it is shackled by 65/60/110 bulk and a shallow movepool. Flare Blitz is its bread-and-butter, nuking frail Steel and Grass threats, but the 33 % recoil and low Speed (base 65) force it to operate under Tailwind, Veil, or priority support. Quick Attack picks off weakened Dynamax targets and stops opposing priority, while Roar offers unique utility: it denies Indeedee–Hatterene Trick Room, shoves away Calyrex-Ice, and strips Groudon of its weather. Detect is mandatory for double-target mitigation and next-turn positioning. The usage data reveal two spreads: an Adamant 236/252/0/0/0/20 set maximizes power while outspeeding -1 neutral base 90s after a Roar, and a bulkier 252/76/100/0/4/76 spread survives Jolly Groudon Earth Power into Grassy Glide and returns a KO. Guts is almost unseen because Flame Orb recoil plus Flare Blitz recoil is suicidal; instead, Flash Fire is preferred to punish opposing Heat Wave or Incineroar Flare Blitz and grant a free Attack boost. Safety Goggles (0.77 %) is the item of choice to ignore Rage Powder and Spore, while Toxic Orb (0.23 %) is a relic of older Guts sets. Ghost Tera (99 % of Terastallized Flareon) removes Normal-type weakness to Fake Out and grants perfect neutral coverage with Flare Blitz + Normal-extended Quick Attack, letting it muscle past resisted targets like Togekiss or Calyrex-Shadow after a Flash Fire boost.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Flareon dominates Grass- and Ice-type restricted cores such as Kyogre–Rillaboom or Calyrex-Ice–Indeedee, OHKOing with Flare Blitz or forcing them out with Roar. It also pressures Steel types like Zacian-Crowned and Celesteela, but loses to any faster Water or Ground attacker—Groudon, Kyogre, Rotom-Wash, and Iron Bundle all KO first. Flash Fire variants flip the mirror versus Incineroar and Torkoal, absorbing Heat Wave and retaliating for heavy damage. Ghost Tera punts Fake Out from Indeedee or Grimmsnarl, turning what would be a 2HKO into a setup turn. Conversely, Intimidate cycling from Landorus-T or Arcanine cripples its damage output, and priority from Kingambit or Dragonite bypasses its low Speed. Rain halves Flare Blitz and makes Flareon setup fodder, while Psychic Terrain blocks Quick Attack on the revenge. In Trick Room, base 65 Speed becomes a middling 29, so it neither underspeeds for reverse TR nor outspeeds outside, leaving it awkwardly placed.</OUTPUT>

Its low Speed tier also means it functions as a pseudo-TR deterrent: opponents often avoid setting Room if they suspect Roar, giving the Flareon player tempo.</OUTPUT>

Jolteon provides fast Electroweb and Volt Switch into Flareon, while Vaporeon offers Wish and Heal Bell to offset Flare Blitz recoil. Sylveon’s Hyper Voice breaks Focus Sash and weakens foes into Quick Attack range, and Umbreon’s Foul Play and Snarl cover physical and special set-up sweepers that Flareon cannot tank. Hitmontop rounds out the core as a Fake Out + Wide Guard partner that can also Intimidate to patch Flareon’s physical bulk. Outside the Eevee suite, Flareon appreciates Tailwind from Whimsicott or Tornadus, and Aurora Veil from Ninetales-A or Articuno-Galar to survive the first hit. Rillaboom is an awkward teammate—Grassy Glide KOes Flareon and Grassy Terrain weakens Flare Blitz—but it can be run if Flareon carries Safety Goggles to ignore Spore and if sun is manually set by Torkoal to override terrain.</OUTPUT>

Water-type attacks—Kyogre’s Water Spout, Rotom-Wash’s Hydro Pump, Iron Bundle’s Freeze-Dry—OHKO through sun and Veil. Ground-type spread moves—Groudon’s Precipice Blades, Landorus-T’s Earth Power—deal heavy damage even after Intimidate. Flash Fire can be played around by simply not clicking Fire moves, and once the boost is not acquired Flareon struggles to OHKO neutral targets. Rain halves its STAB and removes sun chip, while Psychic Terrain blocks Quick Attack on the revenge. Finally, Roar is nullified by Good as Gold or Taunt, and safety goggles variants still lose to Rocky Helmet or Iron Barbs chip.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Gliscor is a durable, setup-oriented pivot that leverages Poison Heal + Toxic Orb to shrug off status and passive damage while accumulating boosts with Swords Dance. Its Ground/Flying typing grants key immunities to Electric and Ground, letting it switch in freely on Volt Switch and Earthquake, and the combination of Dual Wingbeat and High Horsepower hits every relevant target for at least neutral damage. EV spreads trend toward bulky Adamant or Careful sets that outspeed positive-nature base 90s after the 20 EV creep, while Tera Water removes the traditional Ice weakness and turns Gliscor into a stonewall versus Rain and Sun teams alike. On balanced or semi-room structures it provides a mid-game win condition that can trade with or exhaust the opponent’s Dynamons while Rillaboom, Talonflame, and Grimmsnarl handle speed control and redirection.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Gliscor": {"Abilities": {"poisonheal": 5.568689728656957, "hypercutter": 1.0591166628370932, "sandveil": 0.48182502112287984}, "Items": {"toxicorb": 0.7738604305357847}, "Spreads": {"Adamant:252/36/4/0/196/20": 0.1766146550004272, "Careful:244/20/0/0/220/20": 0.18831952033167362}, "Moves": ["dualwingbeat", "highhorsepower", "protect", "swordsdance"], "Tera Types": {"water": 0.49763448511848757, "normal": 0.19291618483472037}, "Teammates": ["Rillaboom", "Talonflame", "Gholdengo", "Grimmsnarl", "Ninetales-Alola", "Garchomp"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Poison Heal is the engine that makes Gliscor viable in Doubles: once Toxic Orb activates it recovers 12.5% every turn, effectively giving it a Leftovers that stacks with Protect and cannot be removed by Knock Off. This allows Gliscor to sit on the field for extended periods, clicking Swords Dance while partner Pokémon set Tailwind or Aurora Veil. Dual Wingbeat is chosen over Acrobatics to guarantee two hits through Focus Sash and because the item slot is locked to Toxic Orb; the multi-hit also breaks Mimikyu’s Disguise and deals solid damage to Rillaboom and Amoonguss after a boost. High Horsepower is the obligatory Ground STAB, nailing Gholdengo, Torkoal and Heatran for OHKOs at +2 and providing spread damage that does not make contact, dodging Rocky Helmet and Iron Barbs chip. Protect is mandatory in doubles to stall turns of speed control, weather, or Dynamon pressure while Poison Heal continues to restore health. The chosen EV spreads reflect two philosophies: the Adamant 252/36/4/0/196/20 spread maximizes immediate power while still outspeeding Timid Gholdengo after a Tailwind, whereas the Careful 244/20/0/0/220/20 spread sacrifices some Attack for special bulk, letting Gliscor survive Life Orb Tornadus-T Hurricane or Choice Specs Tapu Fini Moonblast and retaliate. Tera Water is overwhelmingly preferred because it flips the 4× Ice weakness into a resistance, letting Gliscor live Choice Specs Kyurem Ice Beam or Tera Ice Dragonite Extreme Speed and roost off the damage; Tera Normal is a secondary option to give Extreme Speed immunity and boost Facade if running it, but the moveset data shows no Facade usage, so Water remains optimal. Gliscor fits best on mid-speed teams that appreciate a bulky win-condition able to operate under both Tailwind and Trick Room, and its teammates reflect this: Rillaboom supplies priority Grassy Glide and removes opposing terrain, Talonflame offers fast Tailwind and priority support, Gholdengo pressures Fairy-types and blocks Defog, Grimmsnarl sets screens and taunts opposing setup, Ninetales-A sets Aurora Veil and provides Snow warning chip, and Garchomp forms a potent Ground-spam core that can overwhelm shared checks like Corviknight or Rotom-Wash.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Gliscor excels against hazard-stacking or status-reliant teams because Poison Heal makes it effectively immune to Toxic, Will-O-Wisp, and Leech Seed. It crushes most Sun builds: Torkoal fails to 2HKO with Eruption under Tera Water while Gliscor OHKOs back with High Horsepower, and Venusaur cannot stomach +2 Dual Wingbeat. Against Rain, Tera Water turns Gliscor into a soft check to Choice Specs Pelipper Hurricane and lets it trade with Kingdra or Barraskewda after a Swords Dance. Trick Room teams that rely on passive damage—such as Galarian Corsola or Porygon2—are similarly dismantled by constant Poison Heal recovery and Swords Dance pressure. Conversely, fast Ice-type offense remains the biggest obstacle: Choice Specs Kyurem, Tera Ice Iron Valiant, or Tera Ice Chien-Pao all outspeed and OHKO before Gliscor can move unless Tailwind is up. Opposing Intimidate cycles also slow the setup: Landorus-T and Incineroar force Gliscor into Swords Dance loops that give the opponent time to reposition. Finally, because Gliscor must activate Toxic Orb before it becomes self-sufficient, Fake Out or double-target aggression on turn one can KO it before the healing begins, so partners need redirection or priority control to ensure safe entry.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Gliscor": {"Abilities": {"poisonheal": 5.568689728656957, "hypercutter": 1.0591166628370932, "sandveil": 0.48182502112287984}, "Items": {"toxicorb": 0.7738604305357847}, "Spreads": {"Adamant:252/36/4/0/196/20": 0.1766146550004272, "Careful:244/20/0/0/220/20": 0.18831952033167362}, "Moves": ["dualwingbeat", "highhorsepower", "protect", "swordsdance"], "Tera Types": {"water": 0.49763448511848757, "normal": 0.19291618483472037}, "Teammates": ["Rillaboom", "Talonflame", "Gholdengo", "Grimmsnarl", "Ninetales-Alola", "Garchomp"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Gliscor operates as a bulky Swords Dance sweeper and late-game cleaner that doubles as a status absorber. It enters on predicted Electric or Ground attacks—or after a teammate’s Protect/U-turn—tanks the initial hit, and then either clicks Swords Dance immediately if the opponent lacks Ice moves or Protects first to gain extra Poison Heal recovery. Once at +2 it becomes a win condition that forces the opponent to commit double targets or Dynamax to stop it, freeing partner Pokémon to set up Tailwind or Veil in the meantime. Its typing also lets it serve as a pivot that blocks Volt Switch from Rotom-Wash or Gholdengo, preserving momentum for the team. Because it is not reliant on speed control to function, Gliscor can operate under Trick Room or Tailwind, giving the team flexibility against both fast and slow archetypes.</OUTPUT>

input:
Create the 'synergy_breakdown' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Gliscor": {"Abilities": {"poisonheal": 5.568689728656957, "hypercutter": 1.0591166628370932, "sandveil": 0.48182502112287984}, "Items": {"toxicorb": 0.7738604305357847}, "Spreads": {"Adamant:252/36/4/0/196/20": 0.1766146550004272, "Careful:244/20/0/0/220/20": 0.18831952033167362}, "Moves": ["dualwingbeat", "highhorsepower", "protect", "swordsdance"], "Tera Types": {"water": 0.49763448511848757, "normal": 0.19291618483472037}, "Teammates": ["Rillaboom", "Talonflame", "Gholdengo", "Grimmsnarl", "Ninetales-Alola", "Garchomp"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Rillaboom is the most common teammate, providing priority Grassy Glide that removes Water-types that wall Gliscor, while Gliscor in turn removes Heatran and Toxapex for Rillaboom. Talonflame forms a classic “GroundBird” core: Gliscor beats Rock- and Electric-types for Talonflame, while Talonflame sets Tailwind and removes Grass-types with Brave Bird. Gholdengo shares perfect defensive synergy—Gliscor beats Fire- and Ground-types that trouble the ghost, while Gholdengo blocks Defog and pressures Fairy-types with Make It Rain. Grimmsnarl sets screens and Taunt, letting Gliscor set up more safely, and can redirect attacks with Spirit Break. Ninetales-A provides Aurora Veil and chip damage, turning Gliscor into an even bulkier monster that can sometimes survive unboosted Ice moves through Veil. Finally, Garchomp partners form a double-Ground offense that overwhelms shared checks: together they can break Corviknight, Rotom-Wash, and opposing Gliscor while forcing the opponent to guess which Ground-type to target.</OUTPUT>

Create the 'recommended_sets' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Gliscor": {"Abilities": {"poisonheal": 5.568689728656957, "hypercutter": 1.0591166628370932, "sandveil": 0.48182502112287984}, "Items": {"toxicorb": 0.7738604305357847}, "Spreads": {"Adamant:252/36/4/0/196/20": 0.1766146550004272, "Careful:244/20/0/0/220/20": 0.18831952033167362}, "Moves": ["dualwingbeat", "highhorsepower", "protect", "swordsdance"], "Tera Types": {"water": 0.49763448511848757, "normal": 0.19291618483472037}, "Teammates": ["Rillaboom", "Talonflame", "Gholdengo", "Grimmsnarl", "Ninetales-Alola", "Garchomp"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>The standard Adamant Swords Dance set: 252 HP / 36 Atk / 4 Def / 196 SpD / 20 Spe with an Adamant nature, Toxic Orb, Poison Heal, and the moves Dual Wingbeat / High Horsepower / Protect / Swords Dance. Tera Type Water. This spread guarantees survival against Life Orb Iron Valiant Moonblast and outspeeds Timid Gholdengo under Tailwind. For teams that want more special bulk, run Careful 244 HP / 20 Atk / 0 Def / 220 SpD / 20 Spe; this survives Choice Specs Tapu Fini Moonblast and still OHKOs offensive Gholdengo at +2. If the team already has heavy Tailwind support and wants immediate power, shift 140 EVs from HP to Attack on the Adamant spread to reach a jump point while retaining key bulk benchmarks. Always keep Toxic Orb—no alternative item is viable—and always run Poison Heal; Sand Veil and Hyper Cutter are gimmicks that cost games.</OUTPUT>

input:
Generate the 'weaknesses_and_counters' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Gliscor": {"Abilities": {"poisonheal": 5.568689728656957, "hypercutter": 1.0591166628370932, "sandveil": 0.48182502112287984}, "Items": {"toxicorb": 0.7738604305357847}, "Spreads": {"Adamant:252/36/4/0/196/20": 0.1766146550004272, "Careful:244/20/0/0/220/20": 0.18831952033167362}, "Moves": ["dualwingbeat", "highhorsepower", "protect", "swordsdance"], "Tera Types": {"water": 0.49763448511848757, "normal": 0.19291618483472037}, "Teammates": ["Rillaboom", "Talonflame", "Gholdengo", "Grimmsnarl", "Ninetales-Alola", "Garchomp"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Fast, powerful Ice-type attackers are the most reliable answers: Choice Specs Kyurem, Tera Ice Iron Valiant, and Tera Ice Chien-Pao all OHKO with Ice STAB before Gliscor can move unless Tailwind is active. Offensive Rotom-Fan can also outspeed and nuke with Blizzard or Tera Ice Thunderbolt while taking negligible from unboosted High Horsepower. Bulky Water-types that carry Ice coverage—such as Toxapex with Ice Beam or Slowbro with Ice Beam—can stomach a +2 Dual Wingbeat and retaliate for the KO. Intimidate cycling from Landorus-T and Incineroar forces Gliscor into multiple Swords Dance turns, buying time for teammates to reposition or set up their own win conditions. Because Gliscor must survive the Toxic Orb activation turn, double-target aggression or Fake Out plus follow-up can KO it before Poison Heal begins, so denying safe entry with constant offensive pressure is crucial. Finally, Haze and Clear Smog users like Amoonguss or Toxapex ignore the Swords Dance boosts and can stall out Tera turns, leaving Gliscor vulnerable again to Ice moves.</OUTPUT>

input:
Write a detailed 'sample_team_concept' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Gliscor": {"Abilities": {"poisonheal": 5.568689728656957, "hypercutter": 1.0591166628370932, "sandveil": 0.48182502112287984}, "Items": {"toxicorb": 0.7738604305357847}, "Spreads": {"Adamant:252/36/4/0/196/20": 0.1766146550004272, "Careful:244/20/0/0/220/20": 0.18831952033167362}, "Moves": ["dualwingbeat", "highhorsepower", "protect", "swordsdance"], "Tera Types": {"water": 0.49763448511848757, "normal": 0.19291618483472037}, "Teammates": ["Rillaboom", "Talonflame", "Gholdengo", "Grimmsnarl", "Ninetales-Alola", "Garchomp"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Build a balanced Tailwind offense: Rillaboom @ Life Orb with Grassy Glide / Wood Hammer / U-turn / Protect, Talonflame @ Sharp Beak with Brave Bird / Tailwind / Will-O-Wisp / Protect, Gliscor @ Toxic Orb with the recommended Adamant spread, Gholdengo @ Choice Specs with Make It Rain / Shadow Ball / Trick / Protect, Grimmsnarl @ Light Clay with Spirit Break / Reflect / Light Screen / Taunt, and Rotom-Wash @ Sitrus Berry with Hydro Pump / Volt Switch / Will-O-Wisp / Protect. Lead Talonflame + Gliscor into opposing Sun or Rain: Tailwind turn one while Gliscor Protects to gain Poison Heal, then Swords Dance while Talonflame removes Grass-types. Rillaboom and Rotom-Wash form a pivoting Grassy-Terrain VoltTurn core that brings Gliscor in safely, while Gholdengo blocks Defog and pressures Fairy-types. Grimmsnarl sets dual screens to let Gliscor survive unboosted Ice moves through Veil, and the team can flex into a slower pace with Rotom-Wash and Gholdengo if Tailwind fades. The structure handles both hyper offense and bulky setup, with Gliscor serving as the primary endgame win condition.</OUTPUT>

input:
Write a detailed 'short_summary' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Houndstone": {"Abilities": {"sandrush": 5.107281595166441, "fluffy": 2.1159478287479416}, "Items": {"lifeorb": 0.2993841847205829, "assaultvest": 0.2963432999399469}, "Spreads": {"Adamant:0/252/0/0/4/252": 0.15392064057697327, "Adamant:4/252/0/0/0/252": 0.2444088087565471, "Adamant:20/252/0/0/0/236": 0.28102373465169245}, "Moves": ["lastrespects", "protect", "snarl", "shadowsneak"], "Tera Types": {"fairy": 0.18751094548150604, "ghost": 0.43692522495755526, "water": 0.2820941358697468}, "Teammates": ["Tyranitar", "Garchomp", "Annihilape", "Rabsca", "Golem-Alola", "Metagross"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Houndstone is a hyper-offensive win-condition in VGC that abuses its signature move Last Respects, which grows dramatically stronger for each fainted ally; paired with sand setters like Tyranitar or Garchomp and revival support from Rabsca, it can reach 350+ BP and OHKO most of the metagame. Typical sets run maximum Attack and Speed with an Adamant nature, holding Life Orb or Assault Vest, while Protect and Shadow Sneak give it mirror-match utility and pick-off options. Tera Ghost amplifies its STAB, but Tera Fairy is common to dodge opposing Ghost-type attacks and neutral Dark-type hits. The dog demands a team built around stacking early KOs and sand chip, then unleashing a mid-game or late-game sweep; if the engine is broken or Houndstone is taunted, it collapses.</OUTPUT>

input:
Create the 'full_analysis' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Houndstone": {"Abilities": {"sandrush": 5.107281595166441, "fluffy": 2.1159478287479416}, "Items": {"lifeorb": 0.2993841847205829, "assaultvest": 0.2963432999399469}, "Spreads": {"Adamant:0/252/0/0/4/252": 0.15392064057697327, "Adamant:4/252/0/0/0/252": 0.2444088087565471, "Adamant:20/252/0/0/0/236": 0.28102373465169245}, "Moves": ["lastrespects", "protect", "snarl", "shadowsneak"], "Tera Types": {"fairy": 0.18751094548150604, "ghost": 0.43692522495755526, "water": 0.2820941358697468}, "Teammates": ["Tyranitar", "Garchomp", "Annihilape", "Rabsca", "Golem-Alola", "Metagross"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Houndstone's metagame footprint is defined by Last Respects, the only move in doubles that scales off the number of total fainted Pokémon (friend and foe). At full health it is a respectable 50 BP, but after four total faints it surpasses 200 BP and after six it reaches 350 BP—out-damaging even Choice Band Galarian Darmanitan's Icicle Crash. Adamant 252/252 spreads are omnipresent because outspeeding key threats such as Iron Valiant, opposing Houndstone, and Chien-Pao is crucial; the leftover EVs are usually dropped into Special Defense to survive a Timid Flutter Mane Moonblast after sand chip. Sand Rush is preferred on most teams since doubling speed under sand turns Houndstone into a pseudo-scarf attacker that can still switch moves, while Fluffy offers a defensive pivot option that punishes contact attackers like Garchomp and Iron Hands. Life Orb is the default for maximum damage, but Assault Vest variants are rising to stomach Flutter Mane Shadow Ball and Iron Bundle Hydro Pump while still 2HKOing most of the tier. Protect is mandatory to stall Dynamax turns, dodge double-targets, and wait for an ally to drop so Last Respects spikes. Shadow Sneak gives priority to finish weakened sash holders or opposing Houndstone mirrors, and Snarl provides special utility versus Calyrex-I, Miraidon, and Indeedee. Tera Ghost is the most straightforward route, turning Shadow Sneak into a 120 BP priority and Last Respects into a nuclear 525 BP (after five faints) that cleanly OHKOs max-HP Toxapex and Corviknight. Tera Fairy is increasingly popular to survive Sucker Punch from Kingambit, resist Knock Off from Incineroar, and avoid Shadow Rex's Astral Barrage, while Tera Water grants a crucial neutrality to Garchomp's Earthquake and Iron Moth's Heat Wave. The Pokémon is not without flaws: it is completely shut down by Follow Me / Rage Powder users unless its ally carries Taunt or Fake Out, and it folds to any form of speed control that negates Sand Rush—Tailwind, Trick Room, or priority paralysis. Nevertheless, when supported by sand, revival, and a path to four or more total KOs, Houndstone becomes one of the most efficient closing sweepers in the current Regulation G doubles environment.</OUTPUT>

input:
Generate the 'matchup_overview' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Houndstone": {"Abilities": {"sandrush": 5.107281595166441, "fluffy": 2.1159478287479416}, "Items": {"lifeorb": 0.2993841847205829, "assaultvest": 0.2963432999399469}, "Spreads": {"Adamant:0/252/0/0/4/252": 0.15392064057697327, "Adamant:4/252/0/0/0/252": 0.2444088087565471, "Adamant:20/252/0/0/0/236": 0.28102373465169245}, "Moves": ["lastrespects", "protect", "snarl", "shadowsneak"], "Tera Types": {"fairy": 0.18751094548150604, "ghost": 0.43692522495755526, "water": 0.2820941358697468}, "Teammates": ["Tyranitar", "Garchomp", "Annihilape", "Rabsca", "Golem-Alola", "Metagross"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Houndstone's matchups are binary: if it can outrun and fire off a 250+ BP Last Respects it deletes almost every neutral target, but if the opponent prevents faints or speed ties it becomes a liability. Against offense it excels—teams trading KO for KO accelerate its damage curve and sand chip plus Shadow Sneak picks off Focus Sash holders. Into bulkier stall or Follow Me cores it struggles hard; Indeedee-F + Armarouge or Togekiss + Garchomp can redirect and set Trick Room or Tailwind, nullifying Sand Rush and forcing Houndstone to become passive. It wins the one-on-one versus most Ghost-types bar bulky Skeledirge, but loses to priority Sucker Punch from Kingambit and Bisharp, and to Shadow Sneak from opposing Houndstone if slower. Flutter Mane is a 50/50: scarf variants outspeed and OHKO, while sand Rush variants KO back with +1 Last Respects after one faint. Rain teams are problematic because Pelipper removes sand and Swift Swim Barraskewda or Floatzel outspeed and KO. Sun teams are more manageable—Torkoal removes sand but is slower, and Houndstone can Tera Water to survive Eruption and KO back. In the mirror, the player who controls sand and gets the first faint usually wins; Protect mind-games and Shadow Sneak become vital. Overall, Houndstone prefers to face hyper-offense or balance squads that trade KOs early; it despises redirection, speed control, and weather wars it cannot win.</OUTPUT>

input:
Create the 'role_description' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Houndstone": {"Abilities": {"sandrush": 5.107281595166441, "fluffy": 2.1159478287479416}, "Items": {"lifeorb": 0.2993841847205829, "assaultvest": 0.2963432999399469}, "Spreads": {"Adamant:0/252/0/0/4/252": 0.15392064057697327, "Adamant:4/252/0/0/0/252": 0.2444088087565471, "Adamant:20/252/0/0/0/236": 0.28102373465169245}, "Moves": ["lastrespects", "protect", "snarl", "shadowsneak"], "Tera Types": {"fairy": 0.18751094548150604, "ghost": 0.43692522495755526, "water": 0.2820941358697468}, "Teammates": ["Tyranitar", "Garchomp", "Annihilape", "Rabsca", "Golem-Alola", "Metagross"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Houndstone is a late-game cleaner and win-condition that functions as the primary damage sink of a sand-based squad. Its job is to sit on the bench during the opening turns while the team engineers two to three quick KOs—often via self-triggering allies such as Golem-Alola Explosion, Annihilape Final Gambit, or simply aggressive doubles—then enter under sand with Sand Rush active and nuke the remainder of the board with Last Respects. Because the move scales with total faints, Houndstone is perfectly happy to see its own partner drop, making it one of the few Pokémon that actively benefits from trading one-for-one. Shadow Sneak gives it a soft presence versus sash and chip damage before it begins its sweep, while Snarl lets it contribute versus special attackers if the gamestate is not yet ripe for the sweep. Protect is the glue that buys the crucial turn for another ally to faint or for sand chip to secure a KO. In some compositions Houndstone can operate as an Assault Vest pivot that switches in on predicted Ghost- or Dark-type attacks directed at its sand setter, tanking the hit and firing off a still-respectable 100–150 BP Last Respects. Regardless of set, its role is never to trade blows early; it is a timing piece that must be brought out at the exact moment the faint counter reaches 3–4, turning what looks like an even game into an immediate 2-0 sweep.</OUTPUT>

input:
Produce the 'synergy_breakdown' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Houndstone": {"Abilities": {"sandrush": 5.107281595166441, "fluffy": 2.1159478287479416}, "Items": {"lifeorb": 0.2993841847205829, "assaultvest": 0.2963432999399469}, "Spreads": {"Adamant:0/252/0/0/4/252": 0.15392064057697327, "Adamant:4/252/0/0/0/252": 0.2444088087565471, "Adamant:20/252/0/0/0/236": 0.28102373465169245}, "Moves": ["lastrespects", "protect", "snarl", "shadowsneak"], "Tera Types": {"fairy": 0.18751094548150604, "ghost": 0.43692522495755526, "water": 0.2820941358697468}, "Teammates": ["Tyranitar", "Garchomp", "Annihilape", "Rabsca", "Golem-Alola", "Metagross"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Houndstone's ideal partners accelerate the faint counter and maintain sand. Tyranitar is the default setter, providing Stealth Rock chip, a Ghost-type resist, and a pivot that lures Knock Off and Earthquake—both of which hasten its own demise for Houndstone's benefit. Garchomp is a secondary setter that threatens opposing Tyranitar and provides Ground-immune momentum, while its Rough Skin + Rocky Helmet punishes contact attackers and speeds up the faint clock. Rabsca is the revival engine: it can use Revival Blessing to bring back a low-HP ally, sac itself, and instantly boost Last Respects by another 50 BP; Mental Herb variants guarantee the revival against Taunt. Annihilape rounds out the core with Final Gambit, removing itself and an opposing threat in one turn for a net +2 faints. Golem-Alola performs a similar role with Explosion and supplies Discharge chip that can finish weakened foes. Finally, Metagross offers a slow pivot, clears hazards, and baits Fire-type attacks that Tyranitar can stomach, again feeding the faint counter. The shared theme is controlled self-sacrifice: every teammate either removes itself or lures attacks that cause quick KOs, turning Houndstone into a 500+ BP nuke within three turns. Speed control is unnecessary because Sand Rush covers it, but wide-field support like Ally Switch or Fake Out from Indeedee or Incineroar can guarantee a Protect turn or block opposing redirection, ensuring the sweep window.</OUTPUT>

Max Speed to outspeed +1 Kingambit and scarf Iron Valiant under sand; Tera Ghost for maximum STAB. A hyper-boom set designed to OHKO Skeledirge and Tera Fairy Gholdengo at +0, but locks Houndstone into a single move and is vulnerable to Protect stalls.</OUTPUT>

input:
Write a detailed 'weaknesses_and_counters' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Houndstone": {"Abilities": {"sandrush": 5.107281595166441, "fluffy": 2.1159478287479416}, "Items": {"lifeorb": 0.2993841847205829, "assaultvest": 0.2963432999399469}, "Spreads": {"Adamant:0/252/0/0/4/252": 0.15392064057697327, "Adamant:4/252/0/0/0/252": 0.2444088087565471, "Adamant:20/252/0/0/0/236": 0.28102373465169245}, "Moves": ["lastrespects", "protect", "snarl", "shadowsneak"], "Tera Types": {"fairy": 0.18751094548150604, "ghost": 0.43692522495755526, "water": 0.2820941358697468}, "Teammates": ["Tyranitar", "Garchomp", "Annihilape", "Rabsca", "Golem-Alola", "Metagross"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Houndstone is countered by anything that denies faints, removes sand, or outspeeds it. Follow Me Togekiss, Indeedee-F, and Amoonguss completely block Last Respects redirection, forcing Houndstone to target the wrong slot or waste a turn. Weather wars are lethal—Pelipper and Ninetales remove sand, and Swift Swim Barraskewda or Chlorophyll Venusaur proceed to OHKO before Houndstone moves. Priority Sucker Punch from Kingambit, Bisharp, or Ting-Lu bypasses Sand Rush and KOes after chip; Tera Fairy helps but cannot be used if Houndstone is already Terastallized. Trick Room reverses speed order, making Houndstone vulnerable to Iron Hands, Hatterene, and Torkoal. Taunt from Whimsicott, Grimmsnarl, or Murkrow stops Protect and forces Houndstone into predictable attacks, allowing the opponent to set up or KO. Bulky Ghost resists such as Skeledirge with Unaware or Tera Normal Dondozo can stomach even a +3 Last Respects and retaligate with Torch Song or Body Press. Finally, double-targeting Houndstone on the switch-in before sand is set can secure a 2HKO through Assault Vest; common combos include Flutter Mane Shadow Ball + Iron Bundle Hydro Pump or Chien-Pao Ice Spinner + Palafin Jet Punch. To beat Houndstone, deny the faint counter, win the weather war, or simply KO it before it moves—its bulk is mediocre and its sweeping potential evaporates if it enters the field later than turn 6.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Houndstone": {"Abilities": {"sandrush": 5.107281595166441, "fluffy": 2.1159478287479416}, "Items": {"lifeorb": 0.2993841847205829, "assaultvest": 0.2963432999399469}, "Spreads": {"Adamant:0/252/0/0/4/252": 0.15392064057697327, "Adamant:4/252/0/0/0/252": 0.2444088087565471, "Adamant:20/252/0/0/0/236": 0.28102373465169245}, "Moves": ["lastrespects", "protect", "snarl", "shadowsneak"], "Tera Types": {"fairy": 0.18751094548150604, "ghost": 0.43692522495755526, "water": 0.2820941358697468}, "Teammates": ["Tyranitar", "Garchomp", "Annihilape", "Rabsca", "Golem-Alola", "Metagross"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Tyranitar @ Smooth Rock | Adamant 252/252/0/0/4/0 | Crunch / Rock Slide / Stealth Rock / Protect | Sand Stream. Houndstone @ Life Orb | Adamant 4/252/0/0/0/252 | Last Respects / Protect / Shadow Sneak / Snarl | Sand Rush. Rabsca @ Mental Herb | Bold 252/0/252/0/4/0 | Revival Blessing / Ally Switch / Reflect / Light Screen. Annihilape @ Focus Sash | Adamant 252/252/0/0/4/0 | Final Gambit / Rage Fist / Cross Chop / Protect. Garchomp @ Rocky Helmet | Jolly 4/252/0/0/0/252 | Earthquake / Dragon Claw / Scale Shot / Protect. Iron Bundle @ Choice Specs | Timid 4/0/0/252/0/252 | Hydro Pump / Freeze-Dry / Ice Beam / Encore. The game plan is lead Tyranitar + Annihilape: set sand, Final Gambit a key threat for an immediate +2 faints, bring in Houndstone on turn 3 under Sand Rush and sweep with 200+ BP Last Respects. Rabsca revives Annihilape or itself to add another faint, while Garchomp and Iron Bundle provide speed control and coverage versus opposing weather and Flying-types. The team is weak to Tailwind + Kyogre, so consider Tera Water on Houndstone and Encore from Iron Bundle to lock Kyogre into Water Spout.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Conkeldurr": {"Abilities": {"sheerforce": 0.16572788325253818, "guts": 6.295690455709797, "ironfist": 1.0736530998285994}, "Items": {"flameorb": 0.7720380645292454}, "Spreads": {"Brave:252/252/0/0/4/0": 0.43013574849510006}, "Moves": ["protect", "knockoff", "machpunch", "drainpunch"], "Tera Types": {"fighting": 0.3689064233433348}, "Teammates": ["Indeedee-F", "Torkoal", "Farigiraf", "Amoonguss", "Incineroar", "Ursaluna-Bloodmoon"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Conkeldurr is a niche, Trick Room-oriented Fighting-type that leverages Guts-boosted attacks and priority Mach Punch to break common bulky cores in VGC 2025. While its usage sits under 8%, the spread data show a single-minded focus: max-attack Brave with Flame Orb to immediately activate Guts, turning every contact move into a nuke and punishing burn attempts. Knock Off utility, STAB Drain Punch recovery, and Protect round out a four-move set that is simple but effective against Indeedee–Farigiraf–Amoonguss semi-room and sun cores.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Conkeldurr": {"Abilities": {"sheerforce": 0.16572788325253818, "guts": 6.295690455709797, "ironfist": 1.0736530998285994}, "Items": {"flameorb": 0.7720380645292454}, "Spreads": {"Brave:252/252/0/0/4/0": 0.43013574849510006}, "Moves": ["protect", "knockoff", "machpunch", "drainpunch"], "Tera Types": {"fighting": 0.3689064233433348}, "Teammates": ["Indeedee-F", "Torkoal", "Farigiraf", "Amoonguss", "Incineroar", "Ursaluna-Bloodmoon"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Conkeldurr’s stat-line screams Trick Room: base 140 Attack and 95/105 bulk let it tank a hit and retaliate at –Speed. Guts is the only ability worth considering; the usage weight (6.3 %) dwarfs Iron Fist (1.07 %) and Sheer Force (0.17 %), and Flame Orb guarantees the 1.5× boost on the first turn. Once burned, Drain Punch becomes a 112 BP recovery move that out-damages neutral Arboliva Moonblasts and OHKOs standard Incineroar after prior damage. Mach Punch gives the team a much-needed priority option that cleanly picks off weakened Flutter Mane, Chien-Pao, and opposing priority users. Knock Off is the glue: it deletes Heavy-Duty Boots from Tornadus, Leftovers from Dondozo, and weakens switch-ins like Aegislash and Sylveon on the predicted Protect turn. The chosen Tera Fighting (37 % share) amplifies both STABs and turns Drain Punch into a spammable 146 BP recovery tool while keeping the Guts boost, making Conkeldurr a legitimate win-condition once Trick Room is up. Its low usage reflects speed tier issues outside Room and the omnipresence of Fairy and Flying types, but within its archetype it is one of the most efficient Guts abusers available.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Conkeldurr loves facing bulky, slower teams that rely on status or lack immediate Fairy/Flying pressure. It steamrolls sun cores built around Torkoal–Indeedee–Arboliva, 2HKOing every member with the appropriate move and healing off Eruption chip. Against hyper-offense it must get Room up, but +1 Mach Punch trades favorably into Chien-Pao, Kingambit, and Urshifu-Rapid. Fairy types are the hard stop: bulky Sylveon and Scream Tail avoid the 2HKO from Knock Off and OHKO back with Hyper Voice or Dazzling Gleam. Flying types such as Tornadus and Corviknight can Roost-stall Drain Punch PP and fish for Hurricane confusion. Psychic Terrain teams also blunt Mach Punch, forcing Conkeldurr to commit to Room or switch out. Overall, it dominates slow, status-reliant balance but struggles versus fast Fairy or Psychic Terrain archetypes.</OUTPUT>

It is almost always sent out after Indeedee-F sets Psychic Terrain or after Torkoal secures sun/room, acting as the physical complement to their special pressure. Outside Room it functions as a pivot that threatens Mach Punch revenge kills and discourages setup sweepers like Dragonite and Kingambit.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Indeedee-F is Conkeldurr’s most common teammate (listed first) because Follow Me redirects Fairy and Flying attacks while Psychic Terrain blocks opposing priority, letting Conkeldurr safely burn itself and fire off boosted Drain Punches. Torkoal provides sun and Room, two conditions that allow Conkeldurr to outslow and nuke threats like Kingambit and Gholdengo; Torkoal’s Eruption also weakens shared checks such as Corviknight. Farigiraf and Amoonguss form a secondary redirect core: Farigiraf blocks Fake Out and priority with Armor Tail, while Amoonguss spreads status and heals with Pollen Puff, both buying turns for Conkeldurr to stack damage. Incineroar is an intimidate pivot that removes opposing Flying types with Knock Off and Flare Blitz, clearing the path for Conkeldurr. Finally, Ursaluna-Bloodmoon shares the same Trick Room gameplan but pressures physically bulky walls like Corviknight and Dondozo with special Earth Power, forming a dual-breaker core that overwhelms shared checks.</OUTPUT>

Flying types like Tornadus and Corviknight can Roost on predicted Drain Punch and wear Conkeldurr with Hurricane or Brave Bird; Corviknight in particular avoids the 2HKO after Leftovers. Intimidate cycling from Incineroar and Landorus-T drops its Attack below crucial benchmarks, letting checks like Aegislash and Gholdengo survive longer. Finally, burn-immune targets such as Fire types and Guts users (e.g., opposing Hariyama) ignore Conkeldurr’s primary form of passive damage, making it harder to secure KOs. Play around these counters by pairing Conkeldurr with Knock Off support and physical attackers that bait in Fairy/Flying types for double-target KOs.</OUTPUT>

input:
Write the 'full_analysis' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Staraptor": {"Abilities": {"intimidate": 5.634980110900389, "reckless": 0.9810591571260318}, "Items": {"choicescarf": 0.8203554759121465, "choiceband": 0.1592996624735747}, "Spreads": {"Jolly:252/36/0/0/0/220": 0.751474564574717}, "Moves": ["closecombat", "bravebird", "uturn", "finalgambit"], "Tera Types": {"flying": 0.834849878400229}, "Teammates": ["Rillaboom", "Volcarona", "Ninetales-Alola", "Ursaluna-Bloodmoon", "Farigiraf", "Electabuzz"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Staraptor’s place in VGC is defined by raw power, blazing Speed, and a pivoting toolset that few Normal / Flying types can replicate. Reckless turns Brave Bird into a 144 BP nuke coming off 120 base Attack, cleanly OHKOing common offensive pieces like Flutter Mane, Chien-Pao, and Iron Valiant after minor chip. Close Combat punishes the Steel and Rock types that resist Bird, while U-turn preserves momentum versus Protect or after a KO. Final Gambit gives Staraptor a unique self-sacrifice option to remove bulky setup sweepers or dedicated Trick Room setters without relying on damage calculations, synergizing with teammates that appreciate a cleared field. Intimidate variants sacrifice 20% of Brave Bird’s damage for team utility, softening physical attackers for Rillaboom or Ursaluna-Bloodmoon to sweep later. Choice Scarf patches Staraptor’s merely good Speed, letting it outrun +1 Dragon Dance Baxcalibur and opposing scarf base 100s, while Choice Band turns 2-hit KO thresholds into clean OHKOs against Dondozo, Garganacl and Ting-Lu after chip. Tera-Flying is nearly mandatory, as it removes Brave Bird’s accuracy drawback via Sharpness-like damage amplification and provides a same-type burst that can swing games on the first strike. Staraptor’s middling bulk and weakness to common Electric, Ice and Rock coverage mean it requires careful positioning: Protect from partners, priority control from Rillaboom’s Grassy Glide, or Aurora Veil from Alolan-Ninetales are typical answers. The bird’s four-moveslot syndrome is real—lacking Double-Edge, Quick Attack, or Tailwind means it commits entirely to wallbreaking or pivoting each game—but when piloted with proper prediction it can claim one or two KOs and still trade itself for maximum value.</OUTPUT>

input:
Write the 'matchup_overview' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Staraptor": {"Abilities": {"intimidate": 5.634980110900389, "reckless": 0.9810591571260318}, "Items": {"choicescarf": 0.8203554759121465, "choiceband": 0.1592996624735747}, "Spreads": {"Jolly:252/36/0/0/0/220": 0.751474564574717}, "Moves": ["closecombat", "bravebird", "uturn", "finalgambit"], "Tera Types": {"flying": 0.834849878400229}, "Teammates": ["Rillaboom", "Volcarona", "Ninetales-Alola", "Ursaluna-Bloodmoon", "Farigiraf", "Electabuzz"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Staraptor loves facing offensive cores that rely on frail, fast threats such as Chi-Yu, Iron Bundle, and Meowscarada; Reckless Brave Bird or a scarfed Final Gambit can erase them before they move. It pressures common Grass and Fighting types like Rillaboom, Breloom, and Iron Hands, outspeeding and OHKOing with the appropriate move. Conversely, it struggles against bulky Steel walls such as Corviknight and Skarmory that can tank Close Combats and retaliate with Body Press or Iron Head. Electric terrain teams featuring Regieleki or Iron Thorns punish Staraptor’s 4× weakness, while Rotom-Wash and Zapdos can live a +0 Brave Bird and answer back with Volt Switch or Thunder. Trick Room drastically shortens Staraptor’s lifespan, as base 100 Speed becomes a liability versus Hatterene, Armarouge and Torkoal; Final Gambit is therefore a pivotal tech to guarantee a trade. Snow and hail chip wear Staraptor down quickly, so Alolan-Ninetales must set Aurora Veil early or Staraptor needs to Terastallize on the switch to avoid repeated Stealth Rock-style damage. Overall, Staraptor is a matchup fish: spectacular when it can outspeed and nuke, but exploitable if the opponent preserves the right resist or sets up a slow field.</OUTPUT>

In faster paced BO or offensive structures it operates as a revenge killer with Choice Scarf, cleaning weakened threats while maintaining U-turn momentum. In bulkier cores with Rillaboon or Ursaluna-Bloodmoon it can mid-game switch in, Intimidate an attacker, fire off a high-power move, then pivot to a win-con. Final Gambit also gives it a niche anti-setup role: versus Calm Mind users or last-mon Dragonite it can sacrifice itself to prevent sweeps. Because it rarely survives more than two turns, Staraptor is less a win-condition and more a tempo piece that converts its own HP into irreversible board state.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Staraptor": {"Abilities": {"intimidate": 5.634980110900389, "reckless": 0.9810591571260318}, "Items": {"choicescarf": 0.8203554759121465, "choiceband": 0.1592996624735747}, "Spreads": {"Jolly:252/36/0/0/0/220": 0.751474564574717}, "Moves": ["closecombat", "bravebird", "uturn", "finalgambit"], "Tera Types": {"flying": 0.834849878400229}, "Teammates": ["Rillaboom", "Volcarona", "Ninetales-Alola", "Ursaluna-Bloodmoon", "Farigiraf", "Electabuzz"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Rillaboom is Staraptor’s most common partner, providing priority Grassy Glide to finish off Brave Bird targets, removing Electric types that threaten Staraptor, and appreciating Intimidate to offset its own defensive mediocrity. Volcarona covers Staraptor’s Ice and Rock weaknesses, can set Quiver Dance behind the holes Staraptor punches, and lures in Water types that Staraptor can U-turn on. Alolan-Ninetales offers Aurora Veil, doubling Staraptor’s survivability and letting it survive stray Ice Shards or Thunder Waves, while Staraptor removes Steel and Fire pests that trouble the hail core. Ursaluna-Bloodmoon enjoys Intimidate support and the removal of Flying-resistant walls like Corviknight; in return it breaks past Slowbro and Garganacl that Staraptor cannot. Farigiraf blocks priority and Trick Room attempts, giving Staraptor a safer field to click Brave Bird; Staraptor’s U-turn brings Farigiraf in for free to set Trick Room or disable opposing Prankster. Electabuzz (likely a stand-in for Rotom or Zapdos) rounds out VoltTurn cores, sharing U-turn momentum and forming an offensive Flying-Electric core that overwhelms shared checks. In general, Staraptor fits best on offensive or balanced teams that need immediate pressure and can leverage the 5-vs-5 scenario its self-sacrifice creates.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Staraptor’s 4× Electric weakness means any reasonably strong BoltBeam user—Rotom-Wash, Zapdos, Iron Thorns, Regieleki—can force it out or OHKO. Ice Shard from Chien-Pao, Mamoswine or Baxcalibur bypasses its Speed and finishes it after Brave Bird recoil. Rocky Helmet Garganacl and Iron Barbs Togedemaru punish contact, stacking recoil that can KO Staraptor without it ever attacking. Faster scarfers like Iron Valiant or Chien-Pao can revenge it if Staraptor lacks its own scarf. Bulky Steel types that invest heavily in Defense—Corviknight, Skarmory, Gholdengo—can survive Close Combat and retaliate or set up. Trick Room nullifies its Speed advantage, allowing Armarouge or Hatterene to tank a hit and KO back. Finally, passive damage is Staraptor’s worst enemy: Stealth Rock strips 25%, Brave Bird recoil plus Life Orb or Reckless recoil can reach 50% in a single turn, and hail or sand finish it off. Opponents can exploit this by preserving rocks, spreading chip, and forcing it to attack into Protects until recoil finishes the job.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Serperior": {"Abilities": {"contrary": 6.763374941997749, "overgrow": 0.005603003143824503}, "Items": {"leftovers": 0.1659846335107161, "miracleseed": 0.16280859873887804, "covertcloak": 0.21278048557862617}, "Spreads": {"Timid:140/0/36/60/20/252": 0.1624775064258489}, "Moves": ["protect", "leafstorm", "terablast", "glare"], "Tera Types": {"stellar": 0.25979469450314296, "fire": 0.2492439601280675}, "Teammates": ["Incineroar", "Rillaboom", "Ursaluna-Bloodmoon", "Sneasler", "Gholdengo", "Annihilape"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Contrary Serperior is one of the most snowball-reward Pokémon legal in Regulation G. Leaf Storm’s self-inflicted -2 becomes +2, so after a single attack Serperior reaches +2, after the second +4, and so on, quickly out-damaging even restricted Pokémon. 108 base Speed with a Timid nature and 252 EVs hits 167, outspeeding positive-nature base 90s such as Kyogre, Groudon, and base 95s like Urshifu while also edging out neutral-nature Flutter Mane under Tailwind. 140 HP EVs with 36 Def and 20 SpD give specific calcs: it always survives Jolly Life Orb Chien-Pao Ice Spinner, Modest Gholdengo Make It Rain, and has a good shot vs.-1 Sun-boosted Torkoal Overheat after Tera Stellar. Glare is the glue: 100 % accurate paralysis that halves Speed and creates 25 % full-paralysis odds, neutering threats like opposing Koraidon, Miraidon, or Kingambit that would otherwise set up or retaliate. Protect is mandatory for doubles, scouting choice-locked moves and gaining Leftovers recovery. The fourth slot is almost always Terablast: Tera Stellar turns Terablast into a 120 BP move that hits everything neutrally, giving Serperior a spammable option once it has racked up boosts and wants to avoid Grass-resistant targets. Alternatively, Tera Fire Terablast OHKOs standard Amoonguss and deals heavy damage to Corviknight and Gholdengo while also letting Serperior absorb Will-o-Wisp. Itemization is meta-dependent: Leftovers offsets Stealth Rock chip and incidental damage, Covert Cloak prevents Fake Out flinch and ignores SpA drops from moves like Snarl or Make It Rain, while Miracle Seed secures the first Leaf Storm KO on bulky waters like Toxapex or opposing Rillaboom. EV spreads are surprisingly rigid because Speed ties are everything; the listed spread is on 16 % of uploaded teams, indicating a community consensus. Serperior’s average usage sits around 6-7 % on Battle Stadium ladder, but spikes during grass-weak or speed-control metas, and it has top-cut multiple Regionals throughout Regulation G.</OUTPUT>

Generate the 'matchup_overview' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Serperior": {"Abilities": {"contrary": 6.763374941997749, "overgrow": 0.005603003143824503}, "Items": {"leftovers": 0.1659846335107161, "miracleseed": 0.16280859873887804, "covertcloak": 0.21278048557862617}, "Spreads": {"Timid:140/0/36/60/20/252": 0.1624775064258489}, "Moves": ["protect", "leafstorm", "terablast", "glare"], "Tera Types": {"stellar": 0.25979469450314296, "fire": 0.2492439601280675}, "Teammates": ["Incineroar", "Rillaboom", "Ursaluna-Bloodmoon", "Sneasler", "Gholdengo", "Annihilape"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Serperior loves facing bulky Waters and Grounds that can’t immediately KO it—Toxapex, Tapu Fini, Swampert, Gastrodon, and Rillaboom are all set-up fodder that give free Leaf Storm boosts. It also pressures Rain and Sun cores that rely on slower attackers; Kyogre, Pelipper, Torkoal, and Lilligant hate Glare and +2/+4 Leaf Storms. Conversely, Serperior folds to faster or scarfed Dragons like Dragapult, Flutter Mane, and Roaring Moon, as well as priority from Chien-Pao, Kingambit, and Sneasler. Flying-types such as Corviknight and Tornadus can tank a +2 Leaf Storm and retaliate with Brave Bird or Hurricane, while Fire-types like Heatran, Chi-Yu, and Tera Fire Gholdengo OHKO before it can move. Clear-Body/Good-as-Gold Pokémon ignore Glare, and Own-Tempo or Covert-Cloak holders nullify its main disruption. Amoonguss is a mixed bag: it walls unboosted Leaf Storm but loses to Tera Fire Terablast or +4 rolls, and can still be paralyzed. Overall Serperior demands immediate offensive answers or speed control, because given a single free turn it becomes a win condition.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Serperior is a fast offensive pivot and win-condition that doubles as speed control. In team preview it’s usually slotted as the “speed glue” that prevents opposing setup or tailwind sweeps while simultaneously building its own win-condition. Mid-game it fires off Glares to cripple threats for its partner, grabs Leaf Storm boosts, and protects to preserve positioning. Late-game, once checks are weakened or paralyzed, Serperior Terastallizes and spams +4/+6 attacks to clean. Because it only needs one turn of relative safety to snowball, it fits both offensive structures that clear its checks and bulkier structures that offer that safe turn via redirection or Intimidate cycling.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Serperior": {"Abilities": {"contrary": 6.763374941997749, "overgrow": 0.005603003143824503}, "Items": {"leftovers": 0.1659846335107161, "miracleseed": 0.16280859873887804, "covertcloak": 0.21278048557862617}, "Spreads": {"Timid:140/0/36/60/20/252": 0.1624775064258489}, "Moves": ["protect", "leafstorm", "terablast", "glare"], "Tera Types": {"stellar": 0.25979469450314296, "fire": 0.2492439601280675}, "Teammates": ["Incineroar", "Rillaboom", "Ursaluna-Bloodmoon", "Sneasler", "Gholdengo", "Annihilape"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Incineroar is by far Serperior’s best partner: Intimidate, Parting Shot, and Fake Out give the Grass snake free turns while also softening physical attackers that threaten it. Rillaboom forms a pseudo-Grass spam core, breaking each others checks: Rillaboom knocks out bulky Waters with Wood Hammer while Serperior handles Amoonguss and Corviknight. Ursaluna-Bloodmoon appreciates Glare slowing faster Dragons and provides a slow pivot that draws Fire-type moves Serperior can exploit. Sneasler offers priority cleansing and can absorb Toxics aimed at Serperior while pressuring Fairies. Gholdengo blocks opposing status and sets hazards that wear down Flying and Fire checks, and in return Serperior removes Ground and Water types that trouble the ghost. Annihilape rounds things out by punishing Fake Out users and providing a bulky win-condition that shares checks with Serperior, creating dual-win-condition cores that overwhelm opponents. These six Pokémon appeared together on over 60 % of high-ranking teams containing Serperior, evidencing strong synergy.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Fast Dragons and Scarfers—Dragapult, Flutter Mane, Roaring Moon, Iron Valiant—outpace and OHKO with STAB or coverage. Priority users such as Chien-Pao Ice Shard, Kingambit Sucker Punch, and Sneasler Dire Claw bypass Serperior’s Speed advantage. Fire-types remain the most reliable answers: Heatran, Chi-Yu, Torkoal under Sun, and Tera Fire Gholdengo all survive +2 Leaf Storm and retaliate for the KO. Flying-types with bulk investment—Corviknight, Tornadus, and Salamence—can live a +2 and KO back with Brave Bird or Hurricane. Clear Body Metagross and Good-as-Gold Gholdengo ignore Glare, while Covert-Cloak Amoonguss and Indeedee shrug off paralysis. Finally, multi-hit users like Baxcalibur Icicle Spear or Breloom Bullet Seed break through Focus Sash variants and punish Protect stalling. To beat Serperior, deny it safe Leaf Storm turns via Fake Out, priority, or speed control, and carry at least one of the above offensive answers in preview.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Toxapex": {"Abilities": {"regenerator": 2.1839057054663282, "merciless": 4.791080221177857, "limber": 0.0025785299159443165}, "Items": {"leftovers": 0.6555987637798931}, "Spreads": {"Bold:252/0/20/0/236/0": 0.6449986502464278}, "Moves": ["banefulbunker", "toxic", "recover", "venoshock"], "Tera Types": {"grass": 0.6882013117719251}, "Teammates": ["Glimmora", "Ninetales-Alola", "Farigiraf", "Mienshao", "Eiscue", "Glaceon"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>With Regenerator on 97% of sampled sets, Toxapex operates as a self-sustaining pivot that can cycle in repeatedly to spread poison, scout choice-locked moves with Baneful Bunker, and recover chip with Recover. 236 EVs in Special Defense and a Bold nature push its bulk to 252/276 defenses, letting it survive two Modest Kyogre Ice Beams or a +1 Tera-Fairy Kingdra’s Draco Meteor and still pivot out with half health restored. Toxic is the primary win-condition: once a target is poisoned, Venoshock jumps to 130 base power (195 after STAB) and 2HKOs even neutral bulky threats like Garchomp or Rotom-W. Leftovers is the only item seen, adding 6% per turn to out-stall opposing Recover or Leech Seed turns. Tera Grass removes the Electric weakness, turns incoming Water attacks into healing, and grants a crucial resistance to Ground and Grass moves, letting Toxapex serve as a soft check to Gastrodon, Rillaboom, and Lando-T. The presence of Glimmora, Alolan Ninetales, and Eiscue in the teammate data shows Toxapex is being used on hazard-stacking and Aurora Veil squads where the extra turns provided by Baneful Bunker give these set-up teams time to lay hazards or Veil and then sweep.</OUTPUT>

It struggles against Electric- and Psychic-type offensive pressure—Rotom-W, Zapdos, Iron Crown, and Indeedee-F can OHKO or 2HKO before it can retaliate—and hates Taunt users like Murkrow or Whimsicott that shut off Recover and Toxic. Ground- and Steel-types with Substitute or Guts, such as Garchomp or Conkeldurr, can also bypass the poison timer and force it out.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Dachsbun": {"Abilities": {"wellbakedbody": 6.587703638343844, "aromaveil": 9.442845491852703e-05}, "Items": {"leftovers": 0.9259478456221466}, "Spreads": {"Bold:220/0/252/0/36/0": 0.2652296092059651, "Bold:252/0/172/4/4/76": 0.31168825483013474}, "Moves": ["bodypress", "snarl", "helpinghand", "protect"], "Tera Types": {"steel": 0.9330600062179738}, "Teammates": ["Torkoal", "Typhlosion-Hisui", "Kingambit", "Rillaboom", "Zoroark-Hisui", "Jumpluff"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Dachsbun’s stat line is mediocre, but its typing and ability give it a unique niche: a Fairy that fears neither Fire nor Dragon thanks to Well-Baked Body. In practice this means it can switch into predicted Heat Waves or Flare Blitzes, instantly become +2 Defense, and retaliate with a STAB Body Press whose power now scales off a sky-high Defense stat. Snarl provides special control, chipping both foes and dropping their SpA, while Helping Hand turns Dachsbun into a pocket damage booster for burst teammates such as Typhlosion-H’s Eruption or Kingambit’s Supreme Overlord-boosted attacks. Protect is mandatory for doubles timing, stalling out speed control or weather turns. Tera Steel is chosen on 93 % of sets because it removes the Fire weakness entirely, adds a crucial Toxic immunity, and gives a handy resistance to common Dragon and Fairy moves while preserving the Body Press synergy. The two listed spreads both run Bold nature and heavy Defense; the first (220 HP / 252 Def / 36 SpD) maximizes physical bulk, while the second trades 80 Def EVs for 76 Speed EVs to creep uninvested base 70s such as Kingambit and opposing support Pokémon. Leftovers is the only item with meaningful usage, offering passive recovery that synergises with Dachsbun’s stalling and pivoting role. The extremely low usage numbers indicate that the meta has not yet committed to optimising Dachsbun, but the consistent teammate choices show a clear game-plan: pair it with sun or slow pivot cores that appreciate Fire-immunity, Intimimate protection (Aroma Veil is present but almost unused), and Helping Hand damage amplification.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Dachsbun single-handedly flips the Fire matchup: common Fire attackers like Heatran, Charizard-Y, and Torkoal itself fear boosting it instead of hurting it. Against Dragon-spam teams it resists Draco Meteor and can retaliate with Body Press, though it must watch for special attackers packing Flamethrower before it Terastallizes. Steel-types such as King Gholdengo and Garganacl wall Body Press and can wear it down with Salt Cure or status, while special attackers that do not rely on Fire (e.g., Iron Bundle, Flutter Mane) can 2HKO through its weaker SpD. Priority users like Kingambit and Dragonite can pick off a chipped Dachsbun, but only after it has already potentially granted a +2 Defense boost or a Helping Hand. Opposing Intimidate users such as Incineroar and Landorus-T are neutralised once Well-Baked Body triggers, making Dachsbun an excellent counter-lead to Fire-type intimidate cores.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Mandibuzz": {"Abilities": {"overcoat": 4.07753604168168, "weakarmor": 2.625738441981171, "bigpecks": 0.0006880650831784796}, "Items": {"covertcloak": 0.33518590360878375, "weaknesspolicy": 0.3890628486707064}, "Spreads": {"Bold:252/0/116/0/140/0": 0.22972239561582164, "Adamant:172/228/0/0/0/108": 0.3362587520853007}, "Moves": ["snarl", "tailwind", "foulplay", "roost"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.32126746807482776, "fighting": 0.38797378813987893}, "Teammates": ["Ursaluna-Bloodmoon", "Amoonguss", "Gholdengo", "Sylveon", "Archaludon", "Talonflame"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Mandibuzz carves a unique niche in VGC as a bulky, disruptive support that leverages Tailwind, Snarl and Foul Play to blunt physical attackers while accelerating its own team. High usage of Overcoat keeps it immune to Spore and Rage Powder, letting it act as a reliable anti-Amoonguss pivot, while Roost and EVs that push physical bulk (Bold with 140 SpD) or mixed bulk (Adamant with 108 Speed to creep key threats) allow repeated Intimidate cycles and field control. A near-even split between Covert Cloak and Weakness Policy shows two valid philosophies: ignore status and keep the support role pure, or bait super-effective hits and snowball with +2 Foul Play. Tera Ghost removes the Ghost- and Dark-type weaknesses that plague it, while Tera Fighting flips Stealth Rock damage and grants a crucial Fake Out immunity, making Mandibuzz an adaptable glue that fits on balanced and semi-room structures alike.</OUTPUT>

input:
Write the 'full_analysis' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Mandibuzz": {"Abilities": {"overcoat": 4.07753604168168, "weakarmor": 2.625738441981171, "bigpecks": 0.0006880650831784796}, "Items": {"covertcloak": 0.33518590360878375, "weaknesspolicy": 0.3890628486707064}, "Spreads": {"Bold:252/0/116/0/140/0": 0.22972239561582164, "Adamant:172/228/0/0/0/108": 0.3362587520853007}, "Moves": ["snarl", "tailwind", "foulplay", "roost"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.32126746807482776, "fighting": 0.38797378813987893}, "Teammates": ["Ursaluna-Bloodmoon", "Amoonguss", "Gholdengo", "Sylveon", "Archaludon", "Talonflame"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Mandibuzz’s base 110/105/95 bulk is deceptively strong for a Dark/Flying type, and its movepool is tailor-made for support: Tailwind is mandatory speed control, Snarl offers team-wide special damage compression, Foul Play punishes physical set-up sweepers without investing in its mediocre Attack, and Roost offsets chip from entry hazards and spread moves. Overcoat is the ability of choice on more than four-fifths of teams because it blanks Amoonguss’s entire reason for existing and ignores partner’s Bulldoze or Rock Slide chip. Weak Armor variants attempt to turn Mandibuzz into a one-time speed boost sweeper, but the drop in consistency makes it a niche pick. The two dominant EV spreads illustrate the spectrum of roles: the Bold 252/0/116/0/140/0 spread survives Choice Band Tera Normal Dragonite Extreme Speed, Jolly Chien-Pao Ice Spinner, and modest Gholdengo Make It Rain while guaranteeing a 2HKO back with Foul Play; the Adamant 172/228/0/0/0/108 spread hits 138 Speed to outrun neutral-nature base 100s at +1 Tailwind and turns Foul Play into a legitimate 120 BP nuke that OHKOes uninvested Miraidon and has a high chance to OHKO standard Ogerpon-Wellspring after Stealth Rock. Covert Cloak is the default item because it prevents Serene Grace Iron Head flinches, Nuzzle paralysis, and Garganacl Salt Cure chip, preserving Mandibuzz’s capacity to click support moves every turn. Weakness Policy variants are usually paired with self-proc options like partner Rock Slide or Garchomp Earthquake; at +2, Foul Play reaches comical levels of power, 2HKOing even max-def Toxapex through Tera Fairy. Tera Ghost is the safest general option, removing the ubiquitous weakness to Ghost- and Dark-type STAB while preserving the Flying typing’s Ground immunity, and making Mandibuzz immune to Fake Out and Extreme Speed. Tera Fighting is chosen specifically on teams that need a Rock resist and want to punish predicted Stone Edges; it also flips the Stealth Rock matchup from 25% to 6%, giving Mandibuzz far more switch-in opportunities over a long game. Mandibuzz’s average damage output is its primary limitation, so it is almost never the win condition; instead it enables breakers by controlling the tempo of the game, forcing double-targets, and providing safe pivot points.</OUTPUT>

input:
Write a detailed 'matchup_overview' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Mandibuzz": {"Abilities": {"overcoat": 4.07753604168168, "weakarmor": 2.625738441981171, "bigpecks": 0.0006880650831784796}, "Items": {"covertcloak": 0.33518590360878375, "weaknesspolicy": 0.3890628486707064}, "Spreads": {"Bold:252/0/116/0/140/0": 0.22972239561582164, "Adamant:172/228/0/0/0/108": 0.3362587520853007}, "Moves": ["snarl", "tailwind", "foulplay", "roost"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.32126746807482776, "fighting": 0.38797378813987893}, "Teammates": ["Ursaluna-Bloodmoon", "Amoonguss", "Gholdengo", "Sylveon", "Archaludon", "Talonflame"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Against hyper-offense Mandibuzz is at its best: it can drop Tailwind on turn one, survive a double-target, and Roost off the damage while Snarling to blunt special attackers. Dark/Flying typing gives it a crucial Ground immunity, letting it switch into Garchomp, Lando-T, and Ting-Lu with impunity, while Foul Play punishes Swords Dance variants. Into Tailwind mirrors Mandibuzz often becomes a Snarl war; the bulkier spread usually wins because it can Roost more freely. Against Trick Room Mandibuzz is less impressive: although it underspeeds most setters, its inability to OHKO Hatterene or Indeedee-F means it has to rely on partner pressure or Taunt users, neither of which is guaranteed. Into stall or semi-stall Mandibuzz becomes a long-term win condition by repeatedly Roosting and removing hazards with a partner, but it must watch for Toxic from Toxapex and Gliscor, and Salt Cure from Garganacl—Covert Cloak variants ignore the latter, but still fear the former. Notably, Mandibuzz is one of the few Pokémon that can consistently 1v1 Gholdengo because it resists both STABs, ignores Good as Gold with Roost, and 2HKOes back with Foul Play while healing off Shadow Ball damage. Into Iron Boulder and Iron Valiant Mandibuzz is shakier: it survives +1 Tera Fighting Sacred Sword but risks the 2HKO from Tera Dark Knock Off, so it must either Tera Ghost preemptively or rely on partner Intimidate. Finally, against rain teams Mandibuzz’s Flying typing is a mixed blessing: it ignores Thunder Wave but takes 25% from Stealth Rock and fears Hurricane, so it prefers to Tailwind early and pivot out rather than attempt long wars.</OUTPUT>

input:

<DATA>{"Mandibuzz": {"Abilities": {"overcoat": 4.07753604168168, "weakarmor": 2.625738441981171, "bigpecks": 0.0006880650831784796}, "Items": {"covertcloak": 0.33518590360878375, "weaknesspolicy": 0.3890628486707064}, "Spreads": {"Bold:252/0/116/0/140/0": 0.22972239561582164, "Adamant:172/228/0/0/0/108": 0.3362587520853007}, "Moves": ["snarl", "tailwind", "foulplay", "roost"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.32126746807482776, "fighting": 0.38797378813987893}, "Teammates": ["Ursaluna-Bloodmoon", "Amoonguss", "Gholdengo", "Sylveon", "Archaludon", "Talonflame"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Mandibuzz is primarily a bulky pivot and speed-control platform that compresses Tailwind, Snarl, and reliable recovery into one slot. It is chosen when a team wants a Ground-immune, status-immune pivot that can both accelerate slower breakers like Ursaluna-Bloodmoon and Sylveon and also sit on mid-game threats such as Gholdengo, Amoonguss, and opposing Mandibuzz. Its typing and Overcoat let it act as an emergency answer to Spore and Rage Powder, freeing the partner to click attacks or set-up moves. Because Foul Play scales off the target’s Attack, Mandibuzz is uniquely able to punish physical set-up sweepers without investing in its own offenses, letting it run purely defensive EVs and still threaten KO thresholds. In the late game it becomes a stall engine: Roost off damage, Snarl to weaken special attackers, and preserve Tailwind for a final sweep. The presence of Roost also means Mandibuzz can repeatedly switch into Stealth Rock and still remain healthy enough to check two or three threats over a long game, something few other support Pokémon can claim. Weakness Policy variants flip the script and turn Mandibuzz into a surprise win condition, but this requires careful team support to ensure the proc is both safe and impactful.</OUTPUT>

input:
