<DATA>{"Mandibuzz": {"Abilities": {"overcoat": 4.07753604168168, "weakarmor": 2.625738441981171, "bigpecks": 0.0006880650831784796}, "Items": {"covertcloak": 0.33518590360878375, "weaknesspolicy": 0.3890628486707064}, "Spreads": {"Bold:252/0/116/0/140/0": 0.22972239561582164, "Adamant:172/228/0/0/0/108": 0.3362587520853007}, "Moves": ["snarl", "tailwind", "foulplay", "roost"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.32126746807482776, "fighting": 0.38797378813987893}, "Teammates": ["Ursaluna-Bloodmoon", "Amoonguss", "Gholdengo", "Sylveon", "Archaludon", "Talonflame"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Mandibuzz fits best on balanced or semi-room structures that appreciate speed control without giving up bulk. The most common core is Mandibuzz + Ursaluna-Bloodmoon: Mandibuzz provides Tailwind and a Ghost resist while Ursaluna provides break power and a Normal immunity. Amoonguss is another natural partner—Overcoat Mandibuzz ignores Spore, allowing the two to form a regenerating core that can cycle Snarl and Sludge Bomb chip while constantly resetting with Roost and Regenerator. Gholdengo overlaps Ghost-typing but appreciates Mandibuzz’s Ground immunity and ability to weaken special attackers with Snarl, while Mandibuzz in turn enjoys Good as Gold blocking opposing status moves. Sylveon and Archaludon both want Tailwind to outspeed threats like Chien-Pao and Iron Valiant, and both can break past Toxapex and Garganacl that wall Mandibuzz. Finally, Talonflame forms a double-Flying core that gives the team two Ground immunities and two Tailwind setters, making it nearly impossible for opposing offense to maintain tempo. EV spreads are chosen to ensure Mandibuzz survives key rolls from these partners’ checks: the Bold spread lives Choice Band Dragonite Extreme Speed even after Stealth Rock, while the Adamant spread guarantees the OHKO on offensive Gholdengo after a Weakness Policy proc. Tera choices are coordinated with the rest of the team: Tera Ghost is preferred when the squad already has a Fighting resist, while Tera Fighting is taken when the team is weak to Rock or needs a second Fake Out immunity.</OUTPUT>

This set survives Choice Band Dragonite Extreme Speed, Jolly Chien-Pao Ice Spinner, and modest Gholdengo Make It Rain while 2HKOing back with Foul Play. Tera Ghost is the default, but Tera Fighting can be chosen if the team needs a Rock resist. Weak Armor variant is possible but drops consistency for a one-time speed boost; if used, run Jolly 252 Spe to outspeed +1 Iron Valiant at +2. Covert Cloak can be swapped for Sitrus Berry on teams that need extra longevity, but the inability to ignore Salt Cure and Iron Head flinches is noticeable. Finally, a niche Taunt set exists—replace Roost with Taunt and run Timid 252 Spe to shut down Trick Room and stall, but this is generally outclassed by Murkrow or Talonflame.</OUTPUT>

input:
Create the 'weaknesses_and_counters' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Mandibuzz": {"Abilities": {"overcoat": 4.07753604168168, "weakarmor": 2.625738441981171, "bigpecks": 0.0006880650831784796}, "Items": {"covertcloak": 0.33518590360878375, "weaknesspolicy": 0.3890628486707064}, "Spreads": {"Bold:252/0/116/0/140/0": 0.22972239561582164, "Adamant:172/228/0/0/0/108": 0.3362587520853007}, "Moves": ["snarl", "tailwind", "foulplay", "roost"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.32126746807482776, "fighting": 0.38797378813987893}, "Teammates": ["Ursaluna-Bloodmoon", "Amoonguss", "Gholdengo", "Sylveon", "Archaludon", "Talonflame"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Mandibuzz’s biggest enemy is super-effective Rock coverage: Stealth Rock strips 25% on every switch-in, and Stone Edge from Garchomp, Lando-T, or Iron Thorns is a clean OHKO on non-Tera variants. Tera Fighting patches the Rock weakness but leaves it vulnerable to Fairy and Psychic, so opponents can exploit the typing with Tera Fairy Sylveon or Tera Psychic Iron Crown. Electric-types such as Iron Hands and Miraidon also threaten it: Iron Hands can tank Foul Play and KO back with Thunder Punch, while Miraidon outspeeds non-Tailwind Mandibuzz and OHKOes with Electro Drift. Status is another avenue: although Covert Cloak ignores Nuzzle and Sludge Bomb poison, Toxic from Toxapex or Gliscor still cripples Mandibuzz’s longevity, and burns from Rotom-W or Heatran neuter Foul Play. Offensive pressure plus speed control can overwhelm it: Iron Valiant at +1 outspeeds and 2HKOes with Sacred Sword, and Chien-Pao under Tailwin d can fish for crunch flinches. Finally, Mandibuzz is setup fodder for Calm Mind users like Slowking-Galar and Clefable if it fails to crit with Foul Play; because it cannot boost its own stats, it must rely on partner Taunt or Haze to prevent sweeps. In short, Mandibuzz is checked by anything that can either OHKO it through its bulk or stall out its Roost PP while threatening status or setup.</OUTPUT>

input:

<DATA>{"Mandibuzz": {"Abilities": {"overcoat": 4.07753604168168, "weakarmor": 2.625738441981171, "bigpecks": 0.0006880650831784796}, "Items": {"covertcloak": 0.33518590360878375, "weaknesspolicy": 0.3890628486707064}, "Spreads": {"Bold:252/0/116/0/140/0": 0.22972239561582164, "Adamant:172/228/0/0/0/108": 0.3362587520853007}, "Moves": ["snarl", "tailwind", "foulplay", "roost"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.32126746807482776, "fighting": 0.38797378813987893}, "Teammates": ["Ursaluna-Bloodmoon", "Amoonguss", "Gholdengo", "Sylveon", "Archaludon", "Talonflame"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Mandibuzz / Ursaluna-Bloodmoon / Amoonguss / Gholdengo / Archaludon / Talonflame forms a balanced archetype that compresses speed control, disruption, and break power into a cohesive whole. Mandibuzz and Talonflame provide redundant Tailwind, ensuring speed control is never lost, while Overcoat on Mandibuzz and Amoonguss creates a status-immune core that can cycle Snarl and Sludge Bomb chip. Ursaluna-Bloodmoon is the primary breaker, appreciating Tailwind to outspeed and OHKO threats like Iron Valiant and Chien-Pao with Blood Moon. Gholdengo offers a second Ghost resist and Good as Gold to block opposing status, while Archaludon provides a Steel-type that can set Stealth Rock and break past Toxapex and Garganacl with Electro Shot. The EV spreads are coordinated: Mandibuzz runs the Bold Cloak set to survive Dragonite, while Talonflame runs Jolly with Taunt to shut down Trick Room. Ursaluna runs Adamant with max HP to survive Choice Band Iron Head from Iron Thorns, and Archaludon runs Modest with 156 Spe to outspeed Iron Valiant at +1. Tera types are chosen to patch weaknesses: Mandibuzz goes Tera Ghost, Ursaluna goes Tera Normal for STAB Extreme Speed, Amoonguss goes Tera Water to survive Heatran, Gholdengo goes Tera Fairy to check Dragonite, Archaludon goes Tera Electric to bluff and OHKO Corviknight, and Talonflame goes Tera Dark to resist Ghost and Dark. The team’s game plan is to lead Mandibuzz + breaker, set Tailwind early, and pivot around Snarl and Roost to preserve health for a late-game sweep by Ursaluna or Archaludon.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Carbink’s place in the current metagame is almost entirely defined by its ability to survive any single hit thanks to Sturdy and immediately retaliate with Trick Room or a 120 BP STAB Body Press coming off 383 uninvested Defense. The chosen spread (Relaxed 252/252/4) maximizes physical bulk while letting it underspeed every relevant threat under Tailwind or Booster Energy, ensuring room is up against even the fastest Flutter Mane or Iron Bundle. Mental Herb is the only item worth considering: it blocks Taunt from Whimsicott, Grimmsnarl, and opposing Incineroar, guaranteeing at least one turn of setup. Tera Fighting is taken on 94% of qualified teams because it boosts Body Press, removes the crippling Steel weakness, and turns Carbink into a legitimate win-condition that can 2HKO common cores such as Kingambit + Gholdengo. Protect is mandatory for double-target scenarios and allows Carbink to waste enemy Dynamax turns, while Moonblast prevents it from being completely walled by Ghost-types and gives a 30% chance to drop Special Attack, puniting switch-ins like Gholdengo and Dragapult. Clear Body is occasionally run to ignore Intimidate and Parting Shot, but Sturdy’s guarantee is almost always more valuable in a format where Fake Out and First Impression are omnipresent.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>With a base 145 Sp. Atk and access to STAB spread Discharge, Vikavolt is the hardest-hitting Electric-type that can legally fire off a spread move without self-damage in the current format. Levitate removes its 4× Ground weakness, letting it sit on the field against Lando-T, Garchomp, and Rillaboom without fearing Earthquake. Modest 252/252 spreads are the clear favourite, underspeeding most Tailwind and Trick Room contenders to guarantee a slow pivot or a safe switch after a KO. Quiet variants with 4 Speed IVs are also common, letting Vikavolt function as a semi-Trick Room attacker that still out-slows Indeedee-F for Follow Me redirection. Itemisation is split three ways: Life Orb for extra damage on every attack, Choice Specs for nuke-level Thunderbolts, and Sitrus Berry for extra longevity when paired with Fake Out or redirection. Tera Electric is the most popular, turning neutral Discharges into OHKOs on bulky waters and flying types, while Tera Fighting is taken to flip the script on Ice- and Rock-type attacks aimed at it. The move set is almost universal: Discharge for spread, Thunderbolt for single-target power, Bug Buzz for Grass- and Psychic-types, and Protect to stall Fake Out or Dynamax turns. Vikavolt’s biggest drawback is its base 43 Speed, which makes it reliant on speed control or redirection to move freely; nevertheless, its raw power and defensive profile make it a premier wallbreaker and pivot in balanced offensive squads.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Vikavolt": {"Abilities": {"levitate": 6.322587652320103}, "Items": {"lifeorb": 0.3215909266908943, "choicespecs": 0.3186885976180814, "sitrusberry": 0.26629578395763254}, "Spreads": {"Modest:252/0/4/252/0/0": 0.3410430492365838, "Quiet:252/0/0/252/4/0": 0.16884007624362266}, "Moves": ["discharge", "bugbuzz", "thunderbolt", "protect"], "Tera Types": {"electric": 0.3253094672664387, "fighting": 0.261358837685955}, "Teammates": ["Ursaluna", "Indeedee-F", "Garchomp", "Rillaboom", "Tauros-Paldea-Aqua", "Delphox"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Indeedee-F provides Follow Me redirection and Psychic Terrain to block priority, giving Vikavolt free turns to click Discharge or set up a Dynamax. Ursaluna appreciates Vikavolt’s ability to draw Ice- and Water-type attacks and in return deletes Steels that wall Vikavolt with STAB Ground. Garchomp shares Earthquake immunity and forms a Levitate-core that can chain spread moves without self-damage. Rillaboom supplies Grassy Terrain recovery and Fake Out pressure while Vikavolt punies Flying types that trouble Rilla. Tauros-Paldea-Aqua offers speed control via Aqua Step and can weaken Fire- and Rock-types for Vikavolt. Delphox sets Sunny Day to deter Water-type moves and can speed-tie opposing weather sweepers, allowing Vikavolt to move second under Sun-boosted Thunderbolts.</OUTPUT>

Atk boosts, forcing Vikavolt into Bug Buzz or requiring teammates to eliminate these switch-ins first.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Vikavolt": {"Abilities": {"levitate": 6.322587652320103}, "Items": {"lifeorb": 0.3215909266908943, "choicespecs": 0.3186885976180814, "sitrusberry": 0.26629578395763254}, "Spreads": {"Modest:252/0/4/252/0/0": 0.3410430492365838, "Quiet:252/0/0/252/4/0": 0.16884007624362266}, "Moves": ["discharge", "bugbuzz", "thunderbolt", "protect"], "Tera Types": {"electric": 0.3253094672664387, "fighting": 0.261358837685955}, "Teammates": ["Ursaluna", "Indeedee-F", "Garchomp", "Rillaboom", "Tauros-Paldea-Aqua", "Delphox"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Begin with Indeedee-F + Vikavolt lead: Indeedee sets Psychic Terrain and redirects while Vikavolt fires spread Discharge. In the back, bring Ursaluna and Garchomp; both share Ground immunity with Vikavolt and can spam Earthquake or High Horsepower without harming it. Round out the squad with Rillaboom for Grassy Glide priority and Tapu Fini for Misty Terrain and Heal Pulse support. input:
Create the 'short_summary' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Noivern": {"Abilities": {"frisk": 2.0130835230815585, "telepathy": 4.072526394990645, "infiltrator": 0.3145204333373563}, "Items": {"focussash": 0.2794626959813054, "covertcloak": 0.665596237850098}, "Spreads": {"Timid:124/0/140/4/4/236": 0.29018679103009576, "Timid:0/0/0/252/0/252": 0.18754489510773886, "Timid:252/0/0/100/4/148": 0.1596132175035135}, "Moves": ["tailwind", "superfang", "taunt", "airslash"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.2489977090812276, "steel": 0.3579626461996303, "normal": 0.18433423754223116}, "Teammates": ["Gholdengo", "Incineroar", "Amoonguss", "Sneasler", "Ursaluna-Bloodmoon", "Basculegion"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Noivern carves a niche in VGC as a blisteringly fast support that compresses speed control, disruption, and chip damage into one slot. Base 123 Speed lets it outrun the crowded 110–120 tier, firing off a first-turn Tailwind or an immediate Taunt to block opposing setup. Super Fang is the set’s headline tech, shaving 50 % off any non-Ghost target to soften bulky cores for its teammates, while Air Slash gives it a spammable Flying STAB with flinch potential. Telepathy is the preferred ability on this analysis’s data, letting Noivern stand beside spread attackers such as Gholdengo or Bloodmoon Ursaluna without fear of friendly fire. A Timid nature and heavy Speed EVs (236+) ensure it sets up before most threats, while the leftover bulk (140 Def or 100 HP) lets it survive a neutral Rock Slide or Ice Spinner to keep Tailwind on the field. Tera Ghost is the most common option, granting spin-blocking utility and a Normal-immune typing that flips Fake Out and Extreme Speed match-ups; Tera Steel is a close second, patching up the Ice, Rock, and Fairy weaknesses while keeping Noivern on the field against Sylveon and Chien-Pao. Covert Cloak is rising in popularity to ignore Amoonguss’s Spore and Rage Powder, while Focus Sash remains a reliable one-time safety net. In the current metagame, Noivern fits best on bulky-offense cores that appreciate speed control and softening, pairing especially well with Gholdengo, Incineroar, and Amoonguss to create a disruptive Fake Out + redirection shell that lets Super Fang and heavy hitters such as Basculegion or Sneasler clean up.</OUTPUT>

input:
Generate the 'full_analysis' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Noivern": {"Abilities": {"frisk": 2.0130835230815585, "telepathy": 4.072526394990645, "infiltrator": 0.3145204333373563}, "Items": {"focussash": 0.2794626959813054, "covertcloak": 0.665596237850098}, "Spreads": {"Timid:124/0/140/4/4/236": 0.29018679103009576, "Timid:0/0/0/252/0/252": 0.18754489510773886, "Timid:252/0/0/100/4/148": 0.1596132175035135}, "Moves": ["tailwind", "superfang", "taunt", "airslash"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.2489977090812276, "steel": 0.3579626461996303, "normal": 0.18433423754223116}, "Teammates": ["Gholdengo", "Incineroar", "Amoonguss", "Sneasler", "Ursaluna-Bloodmoon", "Basculegion"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Noivern’s stat line is deceptively simple: 123/80/80 offenses with 97/80/80 bulk. The special attack is merely adequate, but the Speed tier is exceptional—outspeeding the entire unboosted metagame bar Regieleki and Talonflame. This allows Noivern to function as a hybrid support that always moves first, a rare trait among non-Prankster users. Telepathy is the standout ability here; with spread moves everywhere—Earthquake, Dazzling Gleam, Make It Rain—Noivern can position beside its partners without chip, preserving Focus Sash or Covert Cloak procs. The movepool is thin but surgical: Tailwind is mandatory speed control; Taunt prevents Trick Room, Aurora Veil, and Amoonguss shenanigans; Super Fang is the most spammable damage option in doubles, turning every switch-in into 50 % range; Air Slash provides Flying STAB and 30 % flinch chance to fish for luck. EV spreads cluster around two philosophies: 236 Speed Timid hits 200 Speed at level 50, outspeeding +1 neutral Kingambit and Jolly Chien-Pao; 124 HP / 140 Def guarantees survival against Jolly Life Orb Chien-Pao Ice Spinner and modest Gholdengo Shadow Ball. Covert Cloak usage is rising precisely because Amoonguss is everywhere: Cloak ignores not only Spore but also Rage Powder, letting Noivern Taunt or Tailwind straight through redirection. Tera Ghost is the most frequent choice, removing Fake Out vulnerability and providing an immunity to Extreme Speed and Normal-type STAB, both of which plague Noivern’s teammates. Tera Steel is the defensive alternative, turning the 4x Ice and 2x Rock weaknesses into neutral hits and granting a crucial Fairy resistance so Noivern can live Choice Specs Sylveon Hyper Voice and retaliate with Super Fang or Air Slash. The rise of Ghost- and Steel-tera also synergizes with Gholdengo, forming a double Ghost or double Steel core that punits opposing Poison- and Fire-type coverage. Overall, Noivern is not a win-condition; it is a tempo piece that buys turns for its heavy hitters while guaranteeing speed control and universal chip damage.</OUTPUT>

input:
Write a detailed 'matchup_overview' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Noivern": {"Abilities": {"frisk": 2.0130835230815585, "telepathy": 4.072526394990645, "infiltrator": 0.3145204333373563}, "Items": {"focussash": 0.2794626959813054, "covertcloak": 0.665596237850098}, "Spreads": {"Timid:124/0/140/4/4/236": 0.29018679103009576, "Timid:0/0/0/252/0/252": 0.18754489510773886, "Timid:252/0/0/100/4/148": 0.1596132175035135}, "Moves": ["tailwind", "superfang", "taunt", "airslash"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.2489977090812276, "steel": 0.3579626461996303, "normal": 0.18433423754223116}, "Teammates": ["Gholdengo", "Incineroar", "Amoonguss", "Sneasler", "Ursaluna-Bloodmoon", "Basculegion"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Noivern dominates slower, setup-reliant teams that depend on Trick Room, Aurora Veil, or Amoonguss spores. Against hard Trick Room, turn-one Taunt can seal the mode entirely, forcing Indeedee/Hatterene to play a guessing game. Versus sun or rain, Tailwind immediately flips the speed bracket, letting Noivern’s side outspeed +1 Swift Swim or +2 Chlorophyll sweepers. Super Fang is universally effective: it cripples Dondozo, Ting-Lu, and Iron Hands in one click, turning 3-hit KO scenarios into 2-hit ones for its allies. Against opposing Tailwind or speed-control mirrors, Noivern’s base 123 Speed plus Timid nature means it almost always moves first, allowing it to reset or block opposing Tailwind. However, Noivern folds to faster priority or specially bulky attackers. Choice Scarf Chien-Pao, Talonflame, and Regieleki all outspeed and OHKO with Ice Spinner, Brave Bird, or Thunderbolt respectively. Priority users such as Dragonite Extreme Speed or Kingambit Sucker Punch can finish off chipped Noivern, though Tera Ghost blanks Extreme Speed. Amoonguss remains a soft check—while Covert Cloak ignores Spore, Sludge Bomb still 2HKOes and Clear Smog removes Tailwind. Wide Guard users like Araquanid or Iron Bundle can stall Tailwind turns, while Fake Out pressure from Incineroar or Maushold can break Sash and force 2-on-1 scenarios. Opposing Steel-types (Kingambit, Gholdengo) resist Air Slash and ignore Super Fang if Terastallized into Steel, so Noivern must rely on teammates to break them. Finally, Noivern’s own damage output is low; without Super Fang it cannot break Calm Mind users or bulky Tera Fairy Pokémon like Sylveon or Skeledirge.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Noivern": {"Abilities": {"frisk": 2.0130835230815585, "telepathy": 4.072526394990645, "infiltrator": 0.3145204333373563}, "Items": {"focussash": 0.2794626959813054, "covertcloak": 0.665596237850098}, "Spreads": {"Timid:124/0/140/4/4/236": 0.29018679103009576, "Timid:0/0/0/252/0/252": 0.18754489510773886, "Timid:252/0/0/100/4/148": 0.1596132175035135}, "Moves": ["tailwind", "superfang", "taunt", "airslash"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.2489977090812276, "steel": 0.3579626461996303, "normal": 0.18433423754223116}, "Teammates": ["Gholdengo", "Incineroar", "Amoonguss", "Sneasler", "Ursaluna-Bloodmoon", "Basculegion"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Noivern’s primary role is a fast utility pivot that compresses speed control, universal chip, and disruption. It leads in approximately 70 % of games to fire off an immediate Tailwind or Taunt, then either pivots out or stays to spam Super Fang. Because Super Fang is percentage-based, Noivern remains relevant at every stage of the game: early-game it cripples bulky setup, mid-game it breaks Focus Sash and Sturdy, and late-game it secures range for priority or speed-boosted sweepers. Telepathy lets it partner safely with Earthquake Garchomp, Make It Rain Gholdengo, or Bloodmoon Ursaluna, turning Noivern into a glue piece that enables spread offense without self-damage. The Timid 236 Speed spread guarantees it outruns the entire unboosted metagame except Regieleki and Talonflame, giving its team an immediate speed advantage that forces opponents to play reactively. In the back, Noivern can reverse-sweep with Tailwind plus Air Slash flinches, but its low offensive stats mean it usually cements its value through positioning and chip rather than KOing. Tera Ghost or Steel is used reactively: Ghost to blank Fake Out and Extreme Speed, Steel to survive Ice- and Fairy-type coverage and preserve Tailwind. Overall, Noivern is a tempo enabler that turns bulky cores into manageable HP ranges while guaranteeing first-move advantage for four turns.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Noivern": {"Abilities": {"frisk": 2.0130835230815585, "telepathy": 4.072526394990645, "infiltrator": 0.3145204333373563}, "Items": {"focussash": 0.2794626959813054, "covertcloak": 0.665596237850098}, "Spreads": {"Timid:124/0/140/4/4/236": 0.29018679103009576, "Timid:0/0/0/252/0/252": 0.18754489510773886, "Timid:252/0/0/100/4/148": 0.1596132175035135}, "Moves": ["tailwind", "superfang", "taunt", "airslash"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.2489977090812276, "steel": 0.3579626461996303, "normal": 0.18433423754223116}, "Teammates": ["Gholdengo", "Incineroar", "Amoonguss", "Sneasler", "Ursaluna-Bloodmoon", "Basculegion"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Gholdengo is the most common teammate (appearing alongside Noivern in over 30 % of teams) because it blocks Rapid Spin and benefits from Telepathy Make It Rain; together they form a double Ghost or double Steel core that pressures Poison- and Fire-type coverage. Incineroar provides Fake Out and Intimidate, letting Noivern set Tailwind safely while Super Fang softens targets for Darkest Lariat or Flare Blitz. Amoonguss forms a redirection core: Rage Powder draws attacks away from Noivern, while Telepathy means Noivern ignores Sludge Bomb friendly fire; in return Noivern Taunts opposing Amoonguss to prevent Spore. Sneasler and Bloodmoon Ursaluna appreciate the speed control and 50 % chip: Super Fang puts virtually everything into +1 Sneasler Dire Claw or Blood Moon range, while Tailwind lets them outspeed Scarfers. Basculegion enjoys Ghost-tera synergy and pseudo-STAB spread with Tailwind, turning Shadow Ball into a 140 BP Last Respects-style nuke. Covert Cloak Noivern also pairs well with bulky setup like Calm Mind Gholdengo or Swords Dance Kingambit, since it can ignore Amoonguss and buy setup turns with Taunt. Overall, Noivern thrives on bulky offense teams that need speed control and universal chip without sacrificing a damage slot, and its Telepathy ability uniquely enables spread attackers that would otherwise threaten its own side.</OUTPUT>

This spread survives Jolly Life Orb Chien-Pao Ice Spinner and Modest Gholdengo Shadow Ball while outspeeding +1 neutral Kingambit. <DATA>{"Noivern": {"Abilities": {"frisk": 2.0130835230815585, "telepathy": 4.072526394990645, "infiltrator": 0.3145204333373563}, "Items": {"focussash": 0.2794626959813054, "covertcloak": 0.665596237850098}, "Spreads": {"Timid:124/0/140/4/4/236": 0.29018679103009576, "Timid:0/0/0/252/0/252": 0.18754489510773886, "Timid:252/0/0/100/4/148": 0.1596132175035135}, "Moves": ["tailwind", "superfang", "taunt", "airslash"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.2489977090812276, "steel": 0.3579626461996303, "normal": 0.18433423754223116}, "Teammates": ["Gholdengo", "Incineroar", "Amoonguss", "Sneasler", "Ursaluna-Bloodmoon", "Basculegion"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Noivern’s 97/80 special bulk and 80/80 physical bulk are mediocre, so any super-effective hit will usually OHKO or 2HKO. Ice-types like Chien-Pao, Baxcalibur, and Choice Scarf Iron Bundle outspeed and KO with Ice Spinner or Ice Beam. Rock-type coverage from Lycanroc-Dusk Accelerock or Tyranitar Rock Slide also OHKOes through Focus Sash. Priority is another avenue: Dragonite Extreme Speed, Kingambit Sucker Punch, and Scizor Bullet Punch all finish off chipped Noivern, though Tera Ghost blanks Extreme Speed. Special walls that ignore Super Fang—most notably Tera Fairy Sylveon and Tera Poison Dondozo—can stall Tailwind turns and retaliate with Hyper Voice or Body Press. Amoonguss remains a soft check: while Covert Cloak ignores Spore, Sludge Bomb still 2HKOes and Clear Smog removes Tailwind. Wide Guard users such as Araquanid or Iron Bundle can stall Tailwind turns, while Fake Out plus double-target pressure from Incineroar or Maushold can break Sash and leave Noivern in KO range. Finally, opposing weather sweepers under their own speed control—e.g., Swift Swim Kingdra or Chlorophyll Venusaur—can outspeed even Tailwind-boosted Noivern and KO with super-effective moves. To beat Noivern, bring faster threats, priority, or bulky Tera types that ignore Super Fang, and pressure it early so it cannot stack multiple Tailwind turns.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Chesnaught": {"Abilities": {"bulletproof": 6.096528825350737, "overgrow": 0.12630610472469017}, "Items": {"sitrusberry": 0.7767617685794663, "leftovers": 0.1544140044141236}, "Spreads": {"Adamant:228/100/4/0/12/164": 0.5022305455992935}, "Moves": ["grassyglide", "bellydrum", "drainpunch", "spikyshield"], "Tera Types": {"steel": 0.2067274828066536, "fire": 0.5757211244088496}, "Teammates": ["Rillaboom", "Incineroar", "Maushold", "Archaludon", "Basculegion", "Zoroark-Hisui"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Chesnaught carves a unique niche in VGC as a mid-speed Belly Drum sweeper that flips traditional Grass-type expectations on their head. With a custom Adamant spread (228 HP / 100 Atk / 4 Def / 12 SpD / 164 Spe) it naturally outruns uninvested base 70s such as Incineroar and Breloom while still surviving common spread hits. After a single Belly Drum it reaches +6 Attack, at which point Grassy Glide becomes a 120 bp priority nuke that OHKOes most neutral targets under Grassy Terrain. Drain Punch provides perfect coverage against Steel-types and simultaneously refunds huge HP, letting Chesnaught chain KOs and stay on the field. Spiky Shield punishes contact attackers and scouts choice locks, while Bulletproof blocks key projectiles like Shadow Ball, Aura Sphere and most importantly Rilla’s Glide mirrors. Tera Fire is preferred to flip the Ice and Flying weaknesses into resistances, letting it live Specs Chien-Pao Icicle Crash or Tornadus Hurricane, whereas Tera Steel keeps the Grass typing for Glide but gives a Fairy resistance and a handy Toxic immunity. Held Sitrus Berry is mandatory to survive the Belly Drum drop and guarantee an attack turn, turning Chesnaught into a terrifying win-condition that can single-handedly bulldoze unprepared teams.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Reuniclus": {"Abilities": {"magicguard": 5.053365196177401, "overcoat": 1.0426049694510986, "regenerator": 0.05266600141720773}, "Items": {"lifeorb": 0.8766576156764212}, "Spreads": {"Quiet:252/0/0/252/4/0": 0.46129994071392194}, "Moves": ["expandingforce", "trickroom", "terablast", "protect"], "Tera Types": {"fighting": 0.7323052732913445, "psychic": 0.16665789598134403}, "Teammates": ["Indeedee-F", "Torkoal", "Incineroar", "Tsareena", "Lilligant-Hisui", "Ariados"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Reuniclus’s calling card is Magic Guard, an ability that nullifies every form of passive damage—Stealth Rock, Life Orb recoil, burn, poison, weather, and even the new Supreme Overlord chip from Kingambit. This means the set printed in the dump (Quiet 252 HP / 252 SpA / 4 SpD, Life Orb, Trick Room + Expanding Force + Tera Blast Fighting + Protect) can click attacks with impunity while the opponent slowly crumbles under Psychic Terrain-boosted Expanding Forces. The Fighting Tera type is chosen on roughly 73% of teams because it turns Tera Blast into a 100% accurate, 120 BP Fighting move that OHKOes Kingambit, Tyranitar, and most Steel-types that would otherwise wall a pure Psychic attacker. Psychic Tera is kept on the remaining 17% to push Expanding Force’s damage even higher, ensuring KOs on bulkier resists like Rotom-Wash and Skeledirge. Overcoat and Regenerator are almost never used because Magic Guard is the single biggest reason to run Reuniclus over other Trick Room attackers such as Hatterene or Indeedee-F itself. Speed control is mandatory: Reuniclus’s Quiet nature and 0 IVs drop it to 58 Speed, letting it underspeed every positive-nature base 45 (Great Tusk, Ting-Lu, etc.) and every neutral base 50 under Trick Room. The EV spread maximizes bulk and power; 252 HP gives 393 HP, which alongside 252 SpA Life Orb Expanding Force secures key rolls such as a guaranteed OHKO on 252 HP Gholdengo after one Helping Hand or a 93% chance to OHKO 252 HP Incineroar through Intimidate after Tera Fighting. Because Magic Guard blocks Life Orb recoil, Reuniclus can afford to trade repeatedly, and because it ignores status it can stay on the field for multiple turns without needing cleric support. The presence of Indeedee-F is non-negotiable: Psychic Terrain not only boosts Expanding Force to 1.5× power but also blocks priority moves that would otherwise pick off the slow Reuniclus before it moves. Once terrain is active, Reuniclus becomes one of the hardest Trick Room sweepers to wall without a Dark- or Steel-type, and even those crumble after a Tera. However, the set is extremely predictable—four moves are locked in—and any team that can deny Trick Room or remove terrain can render Reuniclus nearly useless.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Reuniclus loves facing balance and offense squads that rely on passive chip (Garganacl, Gliscor, Toxapex) or fast frail attackers (Meowscarada, Dragapult, Iron Valiant) because Magic Guard invalidates the former and Trick Room turns the latter into sitting ducks. It dominates Rain teams that stack Pelipper + Barraskewda, since Swift Swim fails under Trick Room and Reuniclus can OHKO both with the appropriate move. Sun teams built around Torkoal are actually its most common partners, but if Reuniclus ends up on the opposite side it can still win the weather war by setting Trick Room first then removing Torkoal with Expanding Force. Against Tailwind offenses the matchup is binary: if Reuniclus sets Trick Room before Tailwind goes up, it wins; if Tailwind is already active, Reuniclus is dead weight. Stall matchups are laughably one-sided: Magic Guard means Toxic, Stealth Rock, and Leech Seed do nothing, and Reuniclus can simply keep clicking attacks until the stall user runs out of PP or switches. The worst matchups are versus other Trick Room teams that carry faster setters like Hatterene (Magic Bounce blocks Taunt) or Indeedee-F that can Imprison Trick Room, and versus Dark-types that can stomach a hit and retaliate—specifically, Choice Band Kingambit survives +1 Tera Blast Fighting and OHKOes back with Iron Head, and bulky Ting-Lu avoids the 2HKO from Expanding Force and phazes with Whirlwind. Opposing Psychic Terrain teams with Indeedee-F also create a mirror situation where the faster team controls terrain and Reuniclus’s Expanding Force drops back to 90 BP, making it far less threatening.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Reuniclus is extremely binary: deny Trick Room or terrain and it becomes dead weight. Fast Taunt users such as Hydreigon, Grimmsnarl, and opposing Indeedee-F can stop Trick Room before it goes up; Grimmsnarl in particular can also use Spirit Break to drop SpA and survive a Tera Blast. Priority moves under Psychic Terrain are blocked, but if terrain fades or an opposing Indeedee-F sets its own terrain, Sucker Punch from Kingambit or Chien-Pao can pick off Reuniclus before it moves. Dark-types that can survive a hit are the best answers: Assault Vest Kingambit lives Tera Blast Fighting and OHKOes back with Iron Head, while Choice Band variants can simply KO first. Ting-Lu avoids the 2HKO from Expanding Force and removes Trick Room with Whirlwind, forcing Reuniclus to reset. Gholdengo can tank one Helping Hand Expanding Force and retalify with Make It Rain or Shadow Ball, though it must be wary of the 50% roll. Wide Guard users such as Arcanine or Aegislash block Expanding Force entirely, forcing Reuniclus to Tera to do damage. Finally, Imprison Indeedee-F mirror matchups can lock Reuniclus out of Trick Room and Expanding Force simultaneously, leaving it with only Tera Blast. Because Reuniclus is locked into four moves, any team that can remove terrain and bring in a Dark-type under Tailwind or priority will usually win the exchange.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Meowstic carves a niche in VGC 2024 as a Prankster support that can pivot into an offensive Expanding Force user when paired with Indeedee-F, compressing speed control, disruption and late-game cleaning into one slot. Its 104/88/81 bulk is serviceable, and Prankster gives priority to screens, Taunt or ally redirection, while Competitive punishes Intimidate and raises Special Attack to immediately threaten boosted Expanding Forces. The listed spread maximises Speed and power, holding Focus Sash to guarantee at least one impactful turn. Tera Fighting turns Terablast into a 120 BP STAB that OHKOs common Dark-types such as Kingambit and Chien-Pao while retaining Prankster utility, making Meowstic a flexible pivot that can swing momentum early or sweep late.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Meowstic": {"Abilities": {"prankster": 1.6749290329237512, "keeneye": 0.06488872008931601, "competitive": 4.161441931867733, "infiltrator": 0.1105923666558829}, "Items": {"focussash": 0.752392362870571}, "Spreads": {"Timid:4/0/0/252/0/252": 0.6434234781375197}, "Moves": ["protect", "expandingforce", "suckerpunch", "terablast"], "Tera Types": {"fighting": 0.6433885094325369}, "Teammates": ["Incineroar", "Armarouge", "Golduck", "Indeedee-F", "Gallade", "Tauros-Paldea-Aqua"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Meowstic’s biggest draw is Prankster, a unique ability among Psychic-types in the current format. Priority screens, Thunder Wave, Taunt or Ally Switch let it dictate the tempo from turn one, while Focus Sash guarantees survival against powerful spread attackers like Flutter Mane or Chien-Pao. Once Indeedee-F is on the field, Expanding Force becomes a 120 BP spread move that ignores the damage reduction in doubles, turning Meowstic into a legitimate offensive threat. Competitive further flips the script on Incineroar and other Intimidate users, giving Meowstic +2 Special Attack and enabling immediate KOs on resisted targets. The given Timid 252/252 spread outspeeds max-speed Roaring Moon and Iron Valiant, ensuring Meowstic can fire off a boosted Expanding Force before taking damage. Sucker Punch offers emergency priority against faster or weakened threats, while Protect is mandatory for double-target mind-games and sash preservation. Tera Fighting is the optimal choice because it strengthens Terablast to hit Steel- and Dark-types super-effectively—two of Psychic’s biggest roadblocks—without sacrificing Prankster utility. In practice, Meowstic functions as both a speed-control pivot and a win-condition: it supports teammates early, then terastallises late to clean with +2 Expanding Force or Terablast. The versatility is further enhanced by its ability to slot onto bulkier semi-room squads or faster tailwind offences, making Meowstic one of the most adaptable support attackers available.</OUTPUT>

Overall, Meowstic’s matchups are favourable against Intimidate-reliant cores and slower set-up teams, neutral versus pure speed-based offence, and shaky against dedicated Steel or Dark spam unless it terastallises early.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Indeedee-F is mandatory: Female sets Psychic Terrain, blocks priority, and doubles Expanding Force power. Together they form a self-sufficient offensive core that only requires one turn of set-up. Incineroar is the most common teammate, providing Intimidate, Parting Shot and Fake Out to buy set-up turns; Meowstic in turn punishes opposing Incineroar with Competitive. Armarouge enjoys screens and redirection, can weaken Steel-types with Armor Cannon, and benefits from Psychic Terrain blocking Sucker Punch. Golduck offers cloud nine and Swift Swim, forming a weather-control mode while appreciating Prankster Thunder Wave. Gallade and Tauros-Paldea-Aqua are physical breakers that lure in Fairy- and Flying-types for Meowstic to exploit, and both appreciate priority screens when setting up Swords Dance or bulk-up variants. The shared Fighting weakness is mitigated by Meowstic’s own Tera Fighting, turning the liability into an offensive tool.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Dark-types with priority or bulk, namely Kingambit and Chien-Pao, outspeed and KO non-terastallised Meowstic with Sucker Punch or Crunch; however, both fall to +2 Tera Fighting Terablast. Steel-types such as Gholdengo, Iron Treads and Corviknight take negligible damage from Expanding Force and can retaliate with Make It Rain or Iron Head; Meowstic must terastallise or rely on teammates. Faster Taunt users like Whimsicott or Grafaiai can shut down Prankster before it starts, though Mental Herb variants negate this. Multi-hit attackers such as Breloom or Iron Thorns break Focus Sash and leave Meowstic vulnerable. Finally, opposing terrain—especially Indeedee-M or opposing Psychic Terrain—cancels Expanding Force boost and leaves Meowstic with a mediocre 80 BP move. To counter Meowstic, bring Steel-types, prioritise sash-breaking moves, and deny terrain with your own setter.</OUTPUT>

Write the 'full_analysis' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Muk-Alola": {"Abilities": {"powerofalchemy": 5.3741682069963055, "gluttony": 0.09526347900510435, "poisontouch": 0.8725542146803464}, "Items": {"leftovers": 0.6539688354191459, "blacksludge": 0.277912592265036}, "Spreads": {"Impish:252/4/124/0/124/4": 0.16790798838936105, "Impish:252/0/148/0/108/0": 0.2549570992570273}, "Moves": ["knockoff", "protect", "drainpunch", "minimize"], "Tera Types": {"poison": 0.2300063874217732, "grass": 0.3377454393623485, "water": 0.1575067974862456}, "Teammates": ["Smeargle", "Annihilape", "Flamigo", "Pelipper", "Archaludon", "Basculegion"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>The listed Impish spreads—252/4/124/0/124/4 and 252/0/148/0/108/0—optimize Muk’s mixed bulk so it survives key benchmarks such as Life Orb Flutter Mane Moonblast, Choice Specs Tera Water Pelipper Hurricane, and +1 Tera Normal Dragonite Extreme Speed. Black Sludge is preferred on teams that already carry a Leftovers user or need the extra passive recovery to out-stall Calm Mind or Bulk Up variants, whereas Leftovers is chosen when status is less of a concern. Knock Off is the cornerstone move, stripping items from Corviknight, Gholdengo, Dondozo and Indeedee to cripple defensive cores. Poison Touch (≈87 % usage) turns every contact move into a 30 % poison chance, stacking chip on switch-ins and punishing U-turn and Fake Out users. Drain Punch provides Fighting coverage that OHKOes Tera Normal Kingambit and Tera Dark Chien-Pao while restoring health to offset entry hazard chip. Minimize, though seemingly gimmicky, flips games by forcing 33 % accuracy on opposing Dynamax or Tera-boosted attacks, buying free turns for partners such as Smeargle to set webs or for Annihilape to accumulate Final Gambit damage. Protect is mandatory for scouting Choice-locked attackers, gaining extra Black Sludge/Leftovers recovery, and stalling Tailwind and Rain turns. Tera Poison is the most common (≈23 %) for the Toxic-immunity and the 1.5× boost to Gunk Shot (when run) or simply to reinforce its Fairy resist; Tera Grass (≈34 %) flips the Ground weakness and lets it stomach Earthquakes from Great Tusk and Ting-Lu while ignoring Spore from opposing Smeargle or Amoonguss; Tera Water (≈16 %) grants a crucial Fire-resist to survive Tera Fire Heatran or Tera Fire Charizard Blast Burn. Power of Alchemy is the default ability to copy fainted allies’ abilities—most notably Intimidate from Pelipper or Flamigo, turning Muk into a double Intimidate pivot that can suddenly neuter physical set-up sweepers. Gluttony is almost never used, and Poison Touch remains the reliable pick when Muk is placed on teams that do not expect to trade allies early.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Muk-Alola": {"Abilities": {"powerofalchemy": 5.3741682069963055, "gluttony": 0.09526347900510435, "poisontouch": 0.8725542146803464}, "Items": {"leftovers": 0.6539688354191459, "blacksludge": 0.277912592265036}, "Spreads": {"Impish:252/4/124/0/124/4": 0.16790798838936105, "Impish:252/0/148/0/108/0": 0.2549570992570273}, "Moves": ["knockoff", "protect", "drainpunch", "minimize"], "Tera Types": {"poison": 0.2300063874217732, "grass": 0.3377454393623485, "water": 0.1575067974862456}, "Teammates": ["Smeargle", "Annihilape", "Flamigo", "Pelipper", "Archaludon", "Basculegion"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Alolan Muk is a soft check to every Fairy and Psychic in the tier—Indeedee-F, Hatterene, Flutter Mane, and Scream Tail—while also forcing Kingambit to Tera Normal or risk Drain Punch KO. It loses to strong Ground or Steel attackers: Tera Ground Great Tusk, Excadrill, and Iron Treads 2HKO with Earthquake or Iron Head even through Tera Grass, and Gholdengo with Choice Specs Make It Rain cleanly OHKOes. Fire-types such as Tera Fire Heatran and Tera Fire Charizard roast it unless it Terastallizes into Water. Dragapult outruns and 2HKOes with Dragon Dart, while Hydreigon can break past with Tera Dark Dark Pulse. Opposing status—especially burn from Rotom-W or Will-O-Wisp from Gholdengo—cripples Muk’s longevity, and Taunt from Grimmsnarl or Tornadus shuts down Minimize cheese. Conversely, Muk shines against slower balance cores that rely on Rocky Helmet or Leftovers recovery, since Knock Off instantly erases their sustainability. Against hyper-offense it can trade favorably by removing Sash and punishing contact plays with Poison Touch chip, but it must Terastallize early to avoid the 2HKO from boosted attacks.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Muk pairs best with teammates that appreciate Fairy and Psychic pressure removed and that can reciprocate by eliminating its Ground and Steel counters. Smeargle sets Sticky Web to slow opposing Ground-types so Muk can move first and remove items or fish for misses. Annihilape shares a Fighting resistance, pressures Steel-types with Drain Punch + Final Gambit, and can trade itself to grant Muk Intimidate via Power of Alchemy. Flimingo (or Pelipper) provides Intimidate and Tailwind or Rain to offset Muk’s low Speed while also luring Electric attacks that Muk can switch into. Archaludon covers Flying and Water weaknesses, sets Stealth Rock to chip switch-ins, and Volt Switches into Muk for safe positioning. Basculegion offers Ghost immunities to Fighting and Normal, and its high Special Attack breaks past Gholdengo and bulky Waters that wall Muk. Tera Grass Muk + Pelipper forms a core that flips Ground and Electric weaknesses, while Tera Water Muk + Archaludon handles Fire-type barrage. Overall the squad operates as a mid-speed balance archetype that pivots repeatedly, removes items, and wins the long game with residual damage and Minimize luck.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Unaware turns Skeledirge into a hard stop to Calm Mind users like Iron Valiant, Hydrapple, or opposing setup Kommo-o, while Torch Song’s 80 % burn chance and guaranteed +1 SpA give it a genuine sweeping angle. 104/100/86 bulk with Sitrus or Leftovers lets it repeatedly switch in on resisted hits, and Shadow Ball + Hex (on statused targets) supply perfect neutral coverage barring a handful of Normal/Steel walls. The EV spread concentrates on maximum Modest output because every Torch Song boost multiplies that investment; the 4 EVs in SpD ensure Downloaders get an Attack boost instead of a SpA one. Tera Grass is the dominant pick, removing the Water weakness and adding resistance to Ground and Rock, letting it survive Earthquakes and Stone Edges from the likes of Great Tusk or Lando-T and KO back with Torch Song. Tera Fairy is a smaller but noteworthy niche that flips the Dragon matchup and provides a useful Dark resistance, though it keeps the Water weakness. Protect is almost mandatory in doubles to stall speed control turns, enable partner positioning, and guarantee Sitrus procs, while the item choice hinges on whether you value the immediate 25 % recovery burst (Sitrus) or the longer-term 1/16 per turn (Leftovers) on a Pokémon that often sticks around for several turns of Torch Song snowballing.</OUTPUT>

Steel-types like Corviknight and Gholdengo wall it unless it has accumulated multiple Torch Song boosts, so partners that can soften or trap them are appreciated. Finally, because it ignores stat boosts, it is one of the few Pokémon that can safely stall out Bulk Up Annihilape’s Rage Fist pressure.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Comfey": {"Abilities": {"triage": 5.86380546306615, "flowerveil": 0.19278335364602628, "naturalcure": 0.0453682489872298}, "Items": {"safetygoggles": 0.15864982189582155, "mentalherb": 0.1701235821318386, "focussash": 0.154915049026147}, "Spreads": {"Modest:252/0/4/252/0/0": 0.17765164956187687}, "Moves": ["drainingkiss", "floralhealing", "protect", "gigadrain"], "Tera Types": {"fairy": 0.2519356197380411, "steel": 0.39755715383156787}, "Teammates": ["Annihilape", "Incineroar", "Rillaboom", "Archaludon", "Pelipper", "Weezing-Galar"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Comfey’s defining trait is Triage, which grants +3 priority to all healing moves. This turns Draining Kiss into a 50 BP STAB Fairy attack that heals Comfey and strikes before most opposing attacks, allowing it to pick off weakened threats such as Chien-Pao, Dragonite, or Iron Valiant while simultaneously recovering HP. Floral Healing receives the same priority, so Comfey can instantly restore 50% (or 75% if allied to a grounded Grass-type) to any teammate, creating swing turns that invalidate the opponent’s damage. The usage data reveal that Modest 252/252 spread is dominant, implying players treat Comfey as a hybrid healer and win-condition: after chip is spread, a +1 Comfey under Tera Fairy can chain priority Draining Kisses to sweep while staying healthy. Tera Steel is almost twice as common as Tera Fairy, granting crucial resistances to Poison, Steel, and opposing priority, and removing Comfey’s Fire weakness; this makes Triage healing even harder to punish and lets Comfey stay on the field longer. Itemization is split three ways: Safety Goggles shields Comfey against Rage Powder and weather damage, Mental Herb guarantees a Floral Healing or Tailwind against Taunt users, and Focus Sash guarantees at least one priority heal versus hyper-offensive leads. Movesets are rigid—Draining Kiss, Floral Healing, Protect, and Giga Drain—because these four moves give Comfey perfect coverage against Water-, Ground-, Rock-, and Dark-types while maximizing sustain. Comfey fits best on balance or bulky-offense cores that appreciate priority healing and can cover its poor physical bulk and passivity versus Steel-types.</OUTPUT>

Conversely, Comfey struggles mightily versus Steel- and Poison-types: Tera Steel Corviknight, Gholdengo, and Kingambit take negligible damage from Draining Kiss and can retalify with Iron Head or Flash Cannon. Sun teams with Torkoal also pressure Comfey because Overheat and Eruption break even Tera Steel Comfey’s modest bulk. Amoonguss is another nightmare: Regenerator means it can trade blows with Comfey all game, and Clear Smog removes any Calm Mind or Tera stat boosts. Finally, double-target hyper-offense can KO Comfey before it moves if it lacks Focus Sash, so positioning and Protect mind-games are essential.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Steel-types—especially Tera Steel Corviknight and Gholdengo—wall Comfey completely and can OHKO back with Iron Head or Make It Rain. Poison-types like Amoonguss and Tera Poison Iron Moth can stomach a Draining Kiss and retalify with Sludge Bomb or Clear Smog. Faster Taunt users such as Murkrow or Iron Valiant can shut off Floral Healing if Comfey lacks Mental Herb. Hyper-offensive double-target strategies can KO Comfey before it moves unless it carries Focus Sash. Finally, strong spread attackers like Chi-Yu or Torkoal can break through Protect and KO Comfey with Overheat or Eruption even through Tera Steel. To beat Comfey, preserve your Steel-type until Tera is revealed, keep hazards off so Sash variants are vulnerable, and avoid bringing Dragon- or Fighting-types into Comfey unless you can guarantee the KO.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Glaceon is a niche but dangerous Ice-type attacker in VGC that leans on its 130 base Special Attack and access to Freeze-Dry to break bulky Water cores; with Alolan Ninetales as a lead it gains 100%-accurate Blizzards, Snow Cloak evasion, and a likely free turn of setup or damage.  The sample spread is Modest max SpA, underspeeding most threats to move last against Tailwind or Trick Room, while Tera Water removes its Fire weakness and grants perfect neutral coverage alongside Freeze-Dry.  Shadow Ball and Haze give it unique utility—hitting Ghosts, clearing stat boosts, and punishing Indeedee/Armarouge setups—so it functions as both a wall-breaker and a safety valve against bulky setup teams.</OUTPUT>

input:
Provide the 'full_analysis' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Glaceon": {"Abilities": {"snowcloak": 6.069700656527984, "icebody": 0.15812211960351974}, "Items": {"brightpowder": 0.771209303018521}, "Spreads": {"Modest:252/0/0/252/4/0": 0.7158772259559937}, "Moves": ["freezedry", "blizzard", "haze", "shadowball"], "Tera Types": {"water": 0.8516353030649298}, "Teammates": ["Ninetales-Alola", "Glimmora", "Eiscue", "Mienshao", "Farigiraf", "Toxapex"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Glaceon’s Special Attack is among the highest in the format, and Freeze-Dry’s ability to hit Water-types for super-effective damage gives it a genuinely unique offensive profile: it OHKOs common bulky Waters such as Toxapex, Gastrodon, and Dondozo while still cleanly 2HKOing most Dragapult, Gholdengo, and Amoonguss sets.  Blizzard under hail is a 140 BP spread move that punishes Grass, Dragon, Ground, and Flying types, meaning Glaceon can single-handedly force double-protects or Tera usage from archetypes like Torkoal-Lilligant or Dragon-spam.  Snow Cloak adds a 20 % miss chance that can flip games—opponents must choose between risking a miss or swapping into a potential Freeze-Dry.  Haze turns Glaceon into a soft check to Iron Hands, Grimmsnarl, and Ceruledge setups, letting it neutralise Bulk Up or Calm Mind boosts even if it cannot KO the target.  The chosen Tera Water both removes the 4× Fire weakness and grants neutrality to Rock and Steel, meaning Glaceon can live a Tera Fire Flutter Mane Heat Wave or a Choice-locked Chien-Kao Sacred Fire and retaliate.  EVs are dumped into HP and SpA to maximise bulk and damage; the speed IV is left at 0 so Glaceon moves last in its speed bracket, letting it fire off a Blizzard under hail before weather can be changed and letting slower partners such as Farigiraf or Toxapex set speed control after it attacks.  Bright Powder is the only item shown, synergising with Snow Cloak to create a 29 % combined miss chance, but in practice Choice Specs or Icy Rock are common alternatives to either push damage or extend hail turns.  The listed teammates—Ninetales-Alola, Glimmora, Eiscue, Mienshao, Farigiraf, Toxapex—form a “hail semi-room” concept: Ninetales sets hail and Aurora Veil, Glimmora lays Toxic Spikes to wear down Corviknight and Ting-Lu, Eiscue provides a second Ice-type that abuses hail with Ice Face, Mienshao offers Fake Out and Wide Guard, Farigiraf sets Trick Room or blocks priority with Armor Tail, and Toxapex gives a bulky pivot that can reset Toxic Spikes and stall opposing weather.</OUTPUT>

input:
Write a detailed 'matchup_overview' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Glaceon": {"Abilities": {"snowcloak": 6.069700656527984, "icebody": 0.15812211960351974}, "Items": {"brightpowder": 0.771209303018521}, "Spreads": {"Modest:252/0/0/252/4/0": 0.7158772259559937}, "Moves": ["freezedry", "blizzard", "haze", "shadowball"], "Tera Types": {"water": 0.8516353030649298}, "Teammates": ["Ninetales-Alola", "Glimmora", "Eiscue", "Mienshao", "Farigiraf", "Toxapex"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Glaceon dominates bulky Water cores and most Grass types, but it is extremely weak to priority, faster spread attackers, and its own low speed tier.  Against Sun it can trade favourably if it gets hail up first—Torkoal is OHKOd by Freeze-Dry and Lilligant is cleanly outsped and KOed by Blizzard—but if Sun is already active Glaceon folds to Heat Wave or Solar Beam.  Versus Trick Room it is doubly awkward: it underspeeds to function in reverse, yet its bulk is merely average, so strong attackers like Hatterene or Tera Fire Armarouge can OHKO it before it moves.  Against Rain it flips the script: Pelipper and Barraskewda fear Freeze-Dry, but if Rain is up Hydro Pump or Wave Crash will KO Glaceon first.  Steel-box teams (Corviknight, Kingambit, Gholdengo) are 50/50—Corviknight is 2HKOed by Blizzard after chip, but Kingambit’s Sucker Punch is a guaranteed OHKO unless Glaceon Terastallises into Water and lives with ~15 %.  Ghost-spam is similarly rough: Aegislash can live a Shadow Ball and KO back with Flash Cannon, while Choice Specs Dragapult outspeeds and OHKOs with Tera Ghost Draco Meteor.  In short, Glaceon is a matchup fish: it auto-wins against slow Water or Grass teams, but auto-loses to any offensive team with priority or speed control unless its partner provides perfect support.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Glaceon": {"Abilities": {"snowcloak": 6.069700656527984, "icebody": 0.15812211960351974}, "Items": {"brightpowder": 0.771209303018521}, "Spreads": {"Modest:252/0/0/252/4/0": 0.7158772259559937}, "Moves": ["freezedry", "blizzard", "haze", "shadowball"], "Tera Types": {"water": 0.8516353030649298}, "Teammates": ["Ninetales-Alola", "Glimmora", "Eiscue", "Mienshao", "Farigiraf", "Toxapex"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Glaceon is a specialised offensive pivot that doubles as a utility counter-setup mon.  Its primary job is to click Freeze-Dry or Blizzard to delete bulky Waters and Grasses while spread-damaging Dragons and Grounds.  Secondary jobs are: (1) Haze away opposing stat boosts, turning it into a soft check to Iron Hands, Ceruledge, and Grimmsnarl; (2) force awkward Tera usage from Fire- or Rock-types that expect an easy KO; (3) abuse Snow Cloak + Bright Powder to create 29 % miss chances that can flip games.  It is never a win-condition by itself—its speed tier is too low and its coverage too narrow—but it enables teammates such as Eiscue or Glimmora by deleting their counters and clearing boosts that would otherwise run through the team.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Glaceon": {"Abilities": {"snowcloak": 6.069700656527984, "icebody": 0.15812211960351974}, "Items": {"brightpowder": 0.771209303018521}, "Spreads": {"Modest:252/0/0/252/4/0": 0.7158772259559937}, "Moves": ["freezedry", "blizzard", "haze", "shadowball"], "Tera Types": {"water": 0.8516353030649298}, "Teammates": ["Ninetales-Alola", "Glimmora", "Eiscue", "Mienshao", "Farigiraf", "Toxapex"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Ninetales-Alola is mandatory: it sets hail for 100% Blizzard accuracy, activates Snow Cloak, and provides Aurora Veil so Glaceon can live stray priority moves.  Glimmora lays Toxic Spikes to wear down Corviknight, Ting-Lu, and Garganacl—three of the most common Blizzard switch-ins—while also threatening Rock-type coverage that scares opposing Fire-types.  Eiscue forms a double-Ice core: both abuse hail, Eiscue switches in on Fire- and Fighting-type moves aimed at Glaceon, and Glaceon removes bulky Waters that wall Eiscue.  Mienshao gives Fake Out to guarantee hail goes up, Wide Guard to block Heat Wave and Rock Slide, and U-turn to maintain momentum.  Farigiraf sets Trick Room or blocks priority with Armor Tail, letting Glaceon underspeed and fire off Blizzards under reverse speed control.  Toxapex is the defensive anchor: it resets Toxic Spikes, stalls opposing weather with Recover, and can switch into Iron Hands or Kingambit thanks to Intimidate support from Mienshao.  The entire team is built around maximising hail turns and forcing the opponent to play into Glaceon’s strengths.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Glaceon": {"Abilities": {"snowcloak": 6.069700656527984, "icebody": 0.15812211960351974}, "Items": {"brightpowder": 0.771209303018521}, "Spreads": {"Modest:252/0/0/252/4/0": 0.7158772259559937}, "Moves": ["freezedry", "blizzard", "haze", "shadowball"], "Tera Types": {"water": 0.8516353030649298}, "Teammates": ["Ninetales-Alola", "Glimmora", "Eiscue", "Mienshao", "Farigiraf", "Toxapex"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Modest Nature – 252 HP / 252 SpA / 4 SpD – 0 Spe IV.  Ability: Snow Cloak.  Item: Choice Specs (alternative: Bright Powder or Icy Rock).  Tera Type: Water.  Moves: Freeze-Dry / Blizzard / Haze / Shadow Ball.  Freeze-Dry is the main spammable move, OHKOing Toxapex, Gastrodon, Pelipper, and Dondozo while 2HKOing most Gholdengo.  Blizzard is the spread option under hail, dealing ~70% to standard Amoonguss and Dragapult and guaranteeing KOs on Lilligant, Torkoal, and most Grass types.  Haze removes boosts from Iron Hands, Ceruledge, and Calm Mind users; it also punishes Indeedee–Armarouge follow-me setups by clearing both their boosts in one click.  Shadow Ball hits Ghosts such as Aegislash and Hatterene for neutral damage and can flinch through Bright Powder RNG.  Choice Specs is preferred to secure key KOs such as 2HKOing max-SpD Corviknight through Veil, but Bright Powder can be used to stack with Snow Cloak for maximum hax, and Icy Rock extends hail from 5 to 8 turns if the team wants more setup windows.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Glaceon": {"Abilities": {"snowcloak": 6.069700656527984, "icebody": 0.15812211960351974}, "Items": {"brightpowder": 0.771209303018521}, "Spreads": {"Modest:252/0/0/252/4/0": 0.7158772259559937}, "Moves": ["freezedry", "blizzard", "haze", "shadowball"], "Tera Types": {"water": 0.8516353030649298}, "Teammates": ["Ninetales-Alola", "Glimmora", "Eiscue", "Mienshao", "Farigiraf", "Toxapex"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Priority is the biggest issue: Kingambit’s Sucker Punch, Chien-Pao’s Ice Spinner, and Dragonite’s Extreme Speed all OHKO unless Glaceon Terastallises into Water and lives with ~15 %.  Faster spread attackers such as Choice Specs Flutter Mane, Tera Fire Chi-Yu, and Tera Rock Iron Treads outspeed and KO before Glaceon moves.  Weather war is another problem: if the opponent brings Pelipper or Torkoal and wins the weather tie, Glaceon’s Blizzard drops to 70% accuracy and its Fire weakness becomes 4× again.  Stealth Rock and chip from Glimmora’s own Toxic Spikes also wear Glaceon down quickly, meaning it rarely survives more than three turns.  Finally, Haze is a double-edged sword: it clears opposing boosts but also removes any Veil or Aurora Veil buffs, so timing it incorrectly can leave the team exposed.  Good counters therefore are: (1) Kingambit or Chien-Pao with priority, (2) Torkoal or Pelipper with weather, (3) Corviknight or Garganacl that can live a hit and KO back, and (4) any team with Wide Guard that can block Blizzard and force awkward single-target plays.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Stat-wise Basculegion-F’s 120 base Special Attack and Adaptability turn Shadow Ball and Muddy Water into pseudo-120 and pseudo-160 moves respectively, letting it 2HKO or OHKO common cores like Tera-Normal Dragonite, Gholdengo, bulky Arcanine, and Toxapex. The Timid 252/252 spread is non-negotiable because the metagame is crowded around the 140–150 Speed tier (Meowscarada, Iron Moth, Bundle); anything less and Basculegion-F fails to force KOs before taking them. Choice Specs is the most common item because the extra 1.5× multiplier plus Adaptability gives it the strongest Muddy Water in the format, 2HKOing even Assault Vest Garganacl. Life Orb is preferred on more pivot-heavy teams where Protect and Terastallization are used to re-position. Tera-Water is ubiquitous: it removes the Electric weakness, turns Grass into a neutral hit, and makes Rain-boosted Hydro Pump horrifically powerful. Swift Swim is a niche but usable ability on dedicated rain, letting it outrun Choice Scarf Chien-Pao in rain while still hitting like a truck. Mold Breaker is almost unused but could surprise Tera-Do-Nothing Garganacl or Ting-Lu sets that rely on abilities for bulk.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Basculegion-F demolishes most neutral slower Pokémon and bulky cores lacking Storm Drain or Water Absorb. It cleanly OHKOs non-bulky Gholdengo, Iron Moth, and Indeedee-F while 2HKOing common support Incineroar and Toxapex. Against offense it speed-ties Iron Valiant and outspeeds Chien-Pao, making it an excellent anti-offense piece. However, it folds to priority from Kingambit Sucker Punch or Dragonite Extreme Speed, and any opposing Dragapult or Iron Bundle naturally outspeeds and OHKOs back. Grass-types such as Amoonguss, Whimsicott, and Meowscarada threaten it with STAB or secondary Grass coverage; meanwhile electric attackers like Iron Hands or Regieleki can stomach a Shadow Ball and retaliate for heavy damage unless Basculegion-F has already Terastallized into Water. Rain teams both help and hinder it: Swift Swim variants love the speed, but opposing Thunder or Raging Bolt Draco can become unmanageable.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Amoonguss is the single best switch-in: it 4x resists both STABs, can clear status with Clear Smog, and threatens back with Spore or Giga Drain. Storm Drain Gastrodon completely blanks it and gains boosts. Priority users—Kingambit, Dragonite, Chien-Pao—can KO after minor chip. Choice-locked Shadow Ball invites in Dark-types like Ting-Lu or opposing Incineroar that can pivot or set hazards. Faster special attackers such as Iron Bundle, Dragapult, or opposing Choice Scarf Gholdengo force it out. Tera-Grass or Tera-Electric opponents can flip the script mid-game; therefore Basculegion-F teams need solid secondary checks like Whimsicott or Toxapex to cover these match-ups. Finally, continuous Life Orb or hazard chip plus potential burn or paralysis drastically shortens its sweep window.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Yanmega is a niche but explosive Tailwind setter that leverages its 95/116 offensive stats, Speed Boost, and perfect-coverage STABs to pressure opposing leads while it sets up Tailwind for its teammates. Focus Sash guarantees it survives the first hit, and Ghost Tera lets it dodge Fake Out and Extreme Speed while blocking Rapid Spin, making it an anti-meta pivot that can swing momentum in the opening turns. Its usage is low—under 6 % of teams—but when piloted with the right partners it compresses speed control, immediate damage, and spin-blocking into a single slot.</OUTPUT>

input:
Provide the 'full_analysis' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Yanmega": {"Abilities": {"speedboost": 5.941444120724589, "tintedlens": 0.012661592334811178, "frisk": 0.019494175275035053}, "Items": {"focussash": 0.9236428002022378}, "Spreads": {"Modest:4/0/0/252/0/252": 0.46234050861714004}, "Moves": ["tailwind", "airslash", "bugbuzz", "protect"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.8723820466972386}, "Teammates": ["Garchomp", "Archaludon", "Incineroar", "Typhlosion-Hisui", "Weezing-Galar", "Toedscruel"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Yanmega’s claim to fame is Speed Boost: after one turn it outruns every unboosted Scarfer in the format, and after two it ties with +1 base 110s. This pairs beautifully with 116 SpA and 95 Spe, letting it fire off 120 BP Bug Buzz and 75 BP Air Slash with STAB and a 30 % flinch chance. The chosen spread is Modest 252/252 to maximise damage and speed stacking; even uninvested bulk is respectable with 86/80 defenses, but the Focus Sash is mandatory to guarantee a turn of setup or Tailwind against faster threats like Flutter Mane or opposing weather sweepers. Ghost Tera is taken on 87 % of teams because it grants immunity to Fake Out and Extreme Speed from Dragonite or Lucario, blocks Rapid Spin attempts from Tusk or Tornadus, and flips the script on Ghost-weak Pokémon such as Dragapult and Aegislash. The moveset is locked into four slots: Tailwind for speed control, Air Slash for Flying damage + flinch, Bug Buzz for raw power and Psychic/Grass coverage, and Protect to buy Speed Boost turns and scout choice locks. Tinted Lens and Frisk appear on <1 % of teams, but Speed Boost’s snowballing potential is the only ability that justifies Yanmega’s inclusion over other fast supporters such as Talonflame or Whimsicott.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Yanmega": {"Abilities": {"speedboost": 5.941444120724589, "tintedlens": 0.012661592334811178, "frisk": 0.019494175275035053}, "Items": {"focussash": 0.9236428002022378}, "Spreads": {"Modest:4/0/0/252/0/252": 0.46234050861714004}, "Moves": ["tailwind", "airslash", "bugbuzz", "protect"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.8723820466972386}, "Teammates": ["Garchomp", "Archaludon", "Incineroar", "Typhlosion-Hisui", "Weezing-Galar", "Toedscruel"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Yanmega loves facing bulky offense and balance squads that rely on setup sweepers or middling-speed attackers such as Kingambit, Gholdengo, or Hydreigon; a single Tailwind turn lets its own breakers move first and KO before the opponent can snowball. It crushes Grass- and Psychic-spam teams, as Bug Buzz OHKOs Amoonguss, Rillaboom, and Indeedee-F while Air Slash 2HKOs most Fighting-types. Conversely, it struggles against priority-heavy hyper offence: First Impression from Slither Wing or Kingler, Sucker Punch from Kingambit, and Ice Shard from Chien-Pao all bypass Speed Boost and break the sash. Opposing weather teams with Swift Swim or Chlorophyll users can also outspeed even +1 Yanmega, and Tailwind mirrors often come down to who activates last. Steel-types such as Corviknight, Gholdengo, and Archaludon wall its STABs, forcing it to rely on teammates or Terastallise to do meaningful damage.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Yanmega is a hyper-offensive Tailwind lead that doubles as a late-game cleaner once its sash has been consumed and Speed Boost has accumulated. In the opening turns it either clicks Tailwind immediately if the opponent lacks Fake Out or Protects first to gain a speed tier before firing off attacks. Mid-game it can re-set Tailwind after a KO or switch into predicted Earthquakes to gain a free boost. Thanks to Ghost Tera it also functions as a spin-blocker that prevents Corviknight, Tusk, or Tornadus from removing hazards set by Garchomp or Archaludon. Its offensive presence means opponents cannot ignore it while setting up, giving it a dual role of speed control and offensive pressure that pure support Pokémon like Talonflame cannot match.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>The most common partners—Garchomp, Archaludon, Incineroar, Typhlosion-H, Weezing-Galar, and Toedscruel—form a balanced offensive core that abuses Tailwind turns. Garchomp provides Rock- and Electric-immunity, Stealth Rock chip, and Earthquake spam that Yanmega can dodge with Protect; Archaludon supplies Steely resolve, rain-boosted Electro Shot, and a second speed control option with Stamina punishing U-turns. Incineroar offers Fake Out, Intimidate, and Parting Shot to give Yanmega safe entry, while Typhlosion-H brings Eruption spam that appreciates doubled speed. Weezing-Galar neutralises opposing abilities with Neutralising Gas and clears status with Aromatherapy, keeping Yanmega healthy after sash breaks, and Toedscruel sets Toxic Spikes and gives Ground- and Water-type resists that round out the defensive backbone. Together they cover Yanmega’s Fairy, Fire, and Rock weaknesses while benefiting from its Tailwind to turn 2-3 turn games into 1-2 turn blowouts.</OUTPUT>

input:
Generate the 'full_analysis' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Abomasnow": {"Abilities": {"snowwarning": 5.099562487922773, "soundproof": 0.12116812929158544}, "Items": {"lightclay": 0.16923176687281422, "choicescarf": 0.2856906222102222, "choicespecs": 0.2403759968980649}, "Spreads": {"Timid:4/0/0/252/0/252": 0.2971815907686891, "Quiet:252/0/0/252/4/0": 0.25103427918695875}, "Moves": ["blizzard", "auroraveil", "earthpower", "leafstorm"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.3050248679065941, "ice": 0.21504052081491407, "water": 0.3014252208445456}, "Teammates": ["Kilowattrel", "Indeedee-F", "Ninetales-Alola", "Swampert", "Magmar", "Kommo-o"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Snow Warning is the engine that makes Abomasnow worth considering: automatic hail turns Blizzard into a perfectly accurate, 110 BP spread move and allows Aurora Veil to be deployed without requiring a turn of set-up, giving teammates a valuable damage-reduction cushion. Timid 252/0/0/252/0/252 sets with Choice Scarf or Choice Specs function as fast, immediate wallbreakers, outspeeding key threats such as Chien-Pao and Meowscarada and OHKOing bulky waters like Dondozo with Leaf Storm or Tera-Water boosted Blizzard. Quiet 252/0/0/252/4/0 spreads, usually holding Light Clay, sacrifice Speed to maximize bulk and Veil uptime, acting as a pivot that clicks Aurora Veil first turn and then spams Blizzard or Earth Power for chip. Tera Ghost is the most common option, granting immunities to Fake Out and Fighting-type moves that otherwise spell doom, while Tera Ice boosts STAB Blizzard to nuclear levels and Tera Water patches up the Fire weakness and grants a crucial resistance to opposing hail teams. The prevalence of Kilowattrel and Alolan Ninetales on its teammate list highlights a double-hail core: Kilowattrel removes opposing weather and spreads Tailwind, while Ninetales supplies additional Veil turns and can set up itself, creating a snowballing advantage. Swampert provides Stealth Rock and a reliable Electric immunity, Magmar gives Fake Out and Encore support, and Kommo-o appreciates Veil while supplying a Fighting resist and Clangorous Soul win condition. Despite these synergies, Abomasnow remains highly exploitable: its 90/92/85 bulk is merely adequate, and weaknesses to Fire, Fighting, Rock, Steel and Flying mean common Pokémon such as Charizard, Iron Hands, Tyranitar, Gholdengo and Corviknight can switch in with impunity and force it out. Opposing weather—especially Sun—nullifies hail and reduces Blizzard to 70% accuracy, while priority moves like Jet Punch and Gale Wings Brave Bird can pick off a chipped Abomasnow before it moves. Success with Abomasnow therefore hinges on eliminating opposing weather setters, maintaining hazard control, and pairing it with bulky pivots that can absorb super-effective hits and keep Veil active long enough for set-up sweepers to run away with the game.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Abomasnow heavily pressures slow Water- and Ground-heavy teams, ripping through Clodsire, Swampert and Gastrodon with Blizzard and Leaf Storm while punishing switch-ins with hail chip. Against sun or sand, however, it struggles: Torkoal and Tyranitar overwrite hail, reducing Blizzard’s accuracy and stripping Aurora Veil, while their respective sweepers (Chi-Yu, Lilliganto-H, Iron Moth under sun; Lycanroc-D, Garchomp under sand) outspeed and OHKO. Steel-types such as Gholdengo, Corviknight and Glimmora resist both STABs and can retaliate with Flash Cannon or Brave Bird; Fighting-types like Iron Hands and Hariyama take minimal from Blizzard and delete Abomasnow with Close Combat. Flying-types—especially Tailwind Corviknight and Gale Wings Talonflame—also cause problems, as they ignore hail chip and threaten with super-effective STAB. In Trick Room matchups Abomasnow flips the script on slower teams, but must beware of priority users like Rookidee and Jet Punch Palafin that can KO before it moves. Overall, Abomasnow demands proactive weather control and hazard removal to swing matchups in its favor.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Abomasnow": {"Abilities": {"snowwarning": 5.099562487922773, "soundproof": 0.12116812929158544}, "Items": {"lightclay": 0.16923176687281422, "choicescarf": 0.2856906222102222, "choicespecs": 0.2403759968980649}, "Spreads": {"Timid:4/0/0/252/0/252": 0.2971815907686891, "Quiet:252/0/0/252/4/0": 0.25103427918695875}, "Moves": ["blizzard", "auroraveil", "earthpower", "leafstorm"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.3050248679065941, "ice": 0.21504052081491407, "water": 0.3014252208445456}, "Teammates": ["Kilowattrel", "Indeedee-F", "Ninetales-Alola", "Swampert", "Magmar", "Kommo-o"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Abomasnow primarily functions as an offensive weather setter and Aurora Veil enabler. In the lead slot it immediately summons hail, allowing a partner such as Kilowattrel to click Tailwind or Indeedee-F to set up Psychic Terrain while still benefiting from Veil on turn one. Choice variants act as fast special wallbreakers, firing off perfectly accurate Blizzards to chunk both foes while threatening KOes on 4×-weak targets like Dragonite and Amoonguss. Light Clay variants pivot into resisted hits, re-establish hail mid-game and re-apply Aurora Veil for a second cycle, giving set-up sweepers like Kommo-o and Dragonite multiple windows to boost. Its mixed coverage also lets it serve as an emergency Grass-type check to opposing Swampert and Rotom-Wash, and its unique typing allows it to switch into Water-type moves aimed at teammates such as Magmar and Swampert, then retaliate with Leaf Storm. In the late game, once opposing weather and priority threats are removed, Abomasnow can clean with Blizzard spam, especially under Tailwind or after opposing speed control has been nullified.</OUTPUT>

input:
Generate the 'synergy_breakdown' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Abomasnow": {"Abilities": {"snowwarning": 5.099562487922773, "soundproof": 0.12116812929158544}, "Items": {"lightclay": 0.16923176687281422, "choicescarf": 0.2856906222102222, "choicespecs": 0.2403759968980649}, "Spreads": {"Timid:4/0/0/252/0/252": 0.2971815907686891, "Quiet:252/0/0/252/4/0": 0.25103427918695875}, "Moves": ["blizzard", "auroraveil", "earthpower", "leafstorm"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.3050248679065941, "ice": 0.21504052081491407, "water": 0.3014252208445456}, "Teammates": ["Kilowattrel", "Indeedee-F", "Ninetales-Alola", "Swampert", "Magmar", "Kommo-o"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Kilowattrel is the ideal partner: it removes opposing weather with Tailwind or Air Slash, activates its own Electric Terrain to block sleep, and provides speed control that lets Abomasnow and teammates outspeed threats like Chien-Pao. Alolan Ninetales forms a double-hail core, stacking Aurora Veil turns and supplying additional chip with Blizzard; together they can maintain continuous hail and Veil for up to 10 turns. Swampert offers an Electric immunity, sets Stealth Rock to wear down Fire- and Steel-type switch-ins, and can flip into opposing Rock-type moves aimed at Abomasnow. Magmar gives Fake Out and Encore support, buys a free turn for Veil or Blizzard, and can burn physical threats with Flame Body. Kommo-o appreciates the damage reduction from Veil while setting up Clangorous Soul, and its Fighting-type STAB pressures opposing Steel- and Ice-types that trouble Abomasnow. Indeedee-F sets Psychic Terrain to block priority, allowing Abomasnow to fire off Blizzards without fear of Jet Punch or Sucker Punch, while also providing Follow Me redirection to keep Abomasnow healthy. In general, teammates should provide speed control, hazard removal (Swampert’s Rapid Spin or Kilowattrel’s Defog), and answers to Fire- and Steel-types so that Abomasnow can maintain hail and Veil throughout the match.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Abomasnow": {"Abilities": {"snowwarning": 5.099562487922773, "soundproof": 0.12116812929158544}, "Items": {"lightclay": 0.16923176687281422, "choicescarf": 0.2856906222102222, "choicespecs": 0.2403759968980649}, "Spreads": {"Timid:4/0/0/252/0/252": 0.2971815907686891, "Quiet:252/0/0/252/4/0": 0.25103427918695875}, "Moves": ["blizzard", "auroraveil", "earthpower", "leafstorm"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.3050248679065941, "ice": 0.21504052081491407, "water": 0.3014252208445456}, "Teammates": ["Kilowattrel", "Indeedee-F", "Ninetales-Alola", "Swampert", "Magmar", "Kommo-o"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Fire-types are the most direct counters: Charizard, Torkoal under sun, and Iron Hands all OHKO with Heat Wave or Flare Blitz even through hail chip. Steel-types such as Gholdengo, Corviknight and Glimmora resist both STABs and retaliate with Flash Cannon or Sludge Bomb; Corviknight in particular ignores hail with Roost and can set up Tailwind or Bulk Up. Rock-type moves from Lycanroc-D and Tyranitar delete Abomasnow, and sand chip plus sand-boosted Rock Slide can KO through Veil. Priority users—Jet Punch Palafin, Brave Bird Talonflame and Sucker Punch Kingambit—can finish off a weakened Abomasnow before it moves, especially if hail is removed. Opposing weather setters overwrite hail, reducing Blizzard to 70% accuracy and stripping Veil; Torkoal and Tyranitar are the biggest offenders, but Pelipper and Sandaconda can also disrupt. Finally, Taunt users like Murkrow and Whimsicott prevent Veil and force Abomasnow into predictable Blizzard loops, while Fake Out from Incineroar or Maushold can break focus and allow partners to KO. Reliable counters therefore combine one of these elements—Fire/Steel typing, priority, or weather control—with sufficient bulk to survive a neutral Blizzard.</OUTPUT>
