<DATA>{"Altaria": {"Abilities": {"cloudnine": 4.741123271224298, "naturalcure": 0.6516295868812003}, "Items": {"sitrusberry": 0.30993246065323377, "leftovers": 0.21906432167059323, "covertcloak": 0.3766038812956459}, "Spreads": {"Careful:244/0/148/0/116/0": 0.29309552418701323}, "Moves": ["protect", "tailwind", "bravebird", "firespin"], "Tera Types": {"fairy": 0.34894724355300255, "steel": 0.40937223765029396}, "Teammates": ["Sneasler", "Ursaluna-Bloodmoon", "Incineroar", "Gholdengo", "Rillaboom", "Primarina"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Altaria carves a unique niche in VGC as a physically bulky, support-oriented Dragon/Flying type that leverages Cloud Nine to blank weather teams while offering Tailwind control and emergency phasing with Fire Spin. With an EV spread that maximizes special bulk (Careful 244 HP / 148 Def / 116 SpD) it comfortably lives attacks from the likes of Gholdengo, Rillaboom and non-boosted Ursaluna-Bloodmoon, allowing it to click Tailwind or Brave Bird for chip without fear. The combination of Cloud Nine and Covert Cloak lets it ignore Spore, Fake Out flinches, and weather-boosted onslaughts from Kyogre or Torkoal, while Sitrus Berry variants provide extra longevity for repeated Intimidate cycles. Tera Fairy is the most common final click, removing the crippling Dragon weakness and turning Altaria into a fairy-type wall that can still fire off neutral Brave Birds. Although its offenses are mediocre, its role is to set the tempo, keep the board clear of weather, and enable faster, harder-hitting partners such as Sneasler and Bloodmoon Ursaluna.</OUTPUT>

input:
Write the 'full_analysis' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Altaria": {"Abilities": {"cloudnine": 4.741123271224298, "naturalcure": 0.6516295868812003}, "Items": {"sitrusberry": 0.30993246065323377, "leftovers": 0.21906432167059323, "covertcloak": 0.3766038812956459}, "Spreads": {"Careful:244/0/148/0/116/0": 0.29309552418701323}, "Moves": ["protect", "tailwind", "bravebird", "firespin"], "Tera Types": {"fairy": 0.34894724355300255, "steel": 0.40937223765029396}, "Teammates": ["Sneasler", "Ursaluna-Bloodmoon", "Incineroar", "Gholdengo", "Rillaboom", "Primarina"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Altaria’s viability in the current Regulation G format hinges on three factors: Cloud Nine utility, Tailwind speed control, and surprising physical bulk. Cloud Nine remains one of the only ways to completely shut down opposing weather without requiring a turn of setup; this alone forces Primal Kyogre, Torkoal, and Tyranitar to play on even footing, neutering their spread damage and speed-altering synergies. The listed spread reaches 191 HP / 156 Def / 150 SpD after investment—enough to survive a Specs Gholdengo Make It Rain or a +1 Rillaboom Wood Hammer and respond with Tailwind or chip. Brave Bird is chosen over Dragon moves to avoid giving Gholdengo a free switch-in and to pressure Grass-types like Rillaboom and Amoonguss for consistent, non-Intimidate damage. Fire Spin is the set’s most under-appreciated tech: with 85% accuracy it traps Incineroar, Groudon, or opposing support Tera Fairies, racks up 1/8th chip, and breaks Focus Sashes, allowing partners such as Choice Band Sneasler to secure KOs it would otherwise miss. Covert Cloak is preferred on hyper-offense teams that need Altaria to survive multiple Fake Out/Rage Powder cycles, while Sitrus Berry is better on bulkier cores that aim to cycle Intimidate repeatedly. Tera Fairy removes the 4× Ice weakness and grants an immunity to Dragon, turning Altaria into an emergency check to opposing Dragon-type restricted Pokémon while still retaining STAB on Brave Bird. Tera Steel is a rarer but potent alternative that gives Altria a Flash-Fire-style resistance to both Ice and Rock, letting it pivot into Gholdengo and Glimmora more safely. Natural Cure is almost unseen because Cloud Nine’s passive value outweighs the occasional burn or paralysis removal, especially when paired with Clerics like Primarina or bulky Rillaboom that already carry Aromatherapy or Floral Healing.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Altaria": {"Abilities": {"cloudnine": 4.741123271224298, "naturalcure": 0.6516295868812003}, "Items": {"sitrusberry": 0.30993246065323377, "leftovers": 0.21906432167059323, "covertcloak": 0.3766038812956459}, "Spreads": {"Careful:244/0/148/0/116/0": 0.29309552418701323}, "Moves": ["protect", "tailwind", "bravebird", "firespin"], "Tera Types": {"fairy": 0.34894724355300255, "steel": 0.40937223765029396}, "Teammates": ["Sneasler", "Ursaluna-Bloodmoon", "Incineroar", "Gholdengo", "Rillaboom", "Primarina"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Altaria’s Cloud Nine immediately flips weather matchups: Primal Kyogre teams lose their Thunder/Water Spout damage boost and speed control, while Torkoal sun cores can’t rely on Eruption spam or Chlorophyll speed. Against Trick Room, Altaria survives most -1 0 Atk Iron Hands Fake Out and sets Tailwind before the room goes up, forcing the opponent to choose between setting Trick Room or attacking Altaria and letting faster partners run rampant. Versus opposing Tailwind or speed control like Regieleki or Whimsicott, Altaria can trade turns, stall with Protect, and trap key targets with Fire Spin. Gholdengo is theoretically problematic due to Ghost/Steel typing, but Altaria can tank a Make It Rain, Tera Fairy to avoid Shadow Ball weakness, and trap it with Fire Spin while pivoting to a Dark-type like Sneasler or Incineroar. Rillaboom is a nuisance because Grassy Glide can pick off weakened Altaria, yet Cloud Nine removes Grassy Terrain recovery, and Brave Bird 2HKOes through Protect if Rillaboom lacks Assault Vest. Ice-type restricted Pokémon such as Calyrex-Ice or Chien-Pao are the hardest counters, as even unboosted Icicle Crash or Glacial Lance will OHKO through Tera Fairy; therefore Altaria must either partner with Intimidate cycling or simply avoid staying in. Conversely, Altria turns the tables on opposing Dragon restricteds like Dialga or Miraidon by removing their weather-based speed control and forcing them to target around its bulk.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Altaria functions as a bulky pivot and primary speed control on balance or bulky-offense squads. It leads when the opponent relies on weather or when Tailwind is mandatory to keep pace with faster archetypes. Mid-game it cycles in to reset weather, drop Intimidate, and trap problematic walls or setup sweepers with Fire Spin. Late-game it can serve as a stall win-condition by trapping the last Pokémon and Roosting (if selected) while residual damage racks up. Its EV spread ensures it never gets OHKOd by common spread moves, meaning it almost always gets at least one utility turn, and its typing after Tera Fairy lets it soft-check Dragons and Dark-types that would otherwise pressure Primarina or Gholdengo.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Altaria": {"Abilities": {"cloudnine": 4.741123271224298, "naturalcure": 0.6516295868812003}, "Items": {"sitrusberry": 0.30993246065323377, "leftovers": 0.21906432167059323, "covertcloak": 0.3766038812956459}, "Spreads": {"Careful:244/0/148/0/116/0": 0.29309552418701323}, "Moves": ["protect", "tailwind", "bravebird", "firespin"], "Tera Types": {"fairy": 0.34894724355300255, "steel": 0.40937223765029396}, "Teammates": ["Sneasler", "Ursaluna-Bloodmoon", "Incineroar", "Gholdengo", "Rillaboom", "Primarina"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Sneasler loves Tailwind and appreciates Cloud Nine removing sun-boosted burns; Altaria in return enjoys Sneasler’s ability to delete Gholdengo and opposing Ice-types. Ursaluna-Bloodmoon benefits from speed control and Intimidate, while Bloodmoon’s Ghost-typing scares out the Ice-types that threaten Altaria. Incineroar forms a double Intimidate core, compounding physical damage reduction and allowing Altaria to forgo Defense EVs for more special bulk; both also handle Steel-types that wall Altaria’s Brave Bird. Gholdengo provides a spinblocker, absorbs Toxic, and pressures Fairies that Altaria can’t break; conversely Altaria traps opposing Steel-types for Gholdengo’s Make It Rain. Rillaboom brings Grassy Glide priority and Fake Out, while Cloud Nine removes opposing weather that would otherwise negate Rillaboom’s terrain healing. Primarina offers Hyper Voice spread, Heal Pulse, and a secondary Fairy-type that discourages Dragons from staying in, while Altaria covers Primarina’s Grass and Electric weaknesses with its typing and Intimidate.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Rotom-Heat": {"Abilities": {"levitate": 5.109146854029372}, "Items": {"safetygoggles": 0.6181381538916212, "choicespecs": 0.18128468676399706}, "Spreads": {"Timid:164/0/4/76/12/252": 0.355717997189043}, "Moves": ["voltswitch", "overheat", "willowisp", "eerieimpulse"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.4809921167932916, "electric": 0.3723343083337622}, "Teammates": ["Tyranitar", "Primarina", "Excadrill", "Garchomp", "Amoonguss", "Salamence"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Rotom-Heat’s niche in VGC stems from the unique combination of Fire/Electric coverage backed by Levitate, which removes its Ground weakness and turns common Earthquakes into free switch opportunities. Timid 252 Speed with 76 Special Attack EVs lets it outrun positive-nature base 70s such as Breloom and uninvested base 90s while still securing key KOs: Overheat cleanly OHKOes standard Amoonguss and deals ~75% to max-HP Gholdengo, while Volt Switch 2HKOes most neutral bulky waters and pressures Tera Flying dragons. Will-O-Wisp punishes physical attackers like Chien-Pao, Kingambit, and Dragonite, and Eerie Impulse neuters setup sweepers such as Iron Bundle or opposing Specs users. Safety Goggles is the preferred item, letting Rotom ignore Spore and Rage Powder and guaranteeing it can burn or pivot on Amoonguss and Indeedee; Choice Specs is a lower-usage alternative that turns Overheat into a nuke but sacrifices the ability to chain utility moves. Tera Ghost is the dominant option, removing the Ghost weakness and granting perfect neutral coverage alongside STAB Volt Switch, while Tera Electric boosts Volt Switch to OHKO Tera Water Corviknight and severely dents Tera Flying Garchomp. Rotom-Heat fits naturally on sand cores—Tyranitar sets the sand that chips foes and boosts its own special bulk, while Excadrill removes opposing Rock-types and enjoys Rotom’s ability to burn Fighting-types. Primarina provides a bulky Water that can switch into Rock and Water attacks for Rotom and appreciates Rotom’s ability to cripple Steel-types. Salamence or Garchomp give additional Ground immunities and Intimidate/rough skin support, forming a triple-levitate core that blanks Earthquake entirely. Amoonguss offers redirection and additional status, freeing Rotom to pivot or burn more aggressively. In game play, Rotom-Heat is rarely the dynamax target; instead it spreads burns, drops offenses, and brings in a more explosive teammate once the board is softened.</OUTPUT>

It also pressures common Steel-types like Gholdengo and Corviknight, 2HKOing with Overheat or Volt Switch depending on Tera type. Against Water-types it must play more carefully: bulky Tera Water Rotom-Wash avoids the 2HKO from Volt Switch and can retaliate with Hydro Pump, so teammates like Amoonguss or Tyranitar are needed to absorb hits. Rotom-Heat dislikes fast Dragons such as Hydreigon and Tera Flying Garchomp that can live an Overheat and KO back with Draco Meteor or Tera Blast; it also fears Knock Off, which removes Safety Goggles and leaves it vulnerable to Spore. Rain teams featuring Pelipper and Barraskewda can outspeed and drown Rotom with rain-boosted Liquidation or Wave Crash, making Primarina or Amoonguss mandatory partners. Finally, Rotom-Heat is comfortably checked by specially bulky Tera Fairy dragons like Tera Fairy Garchomp or Sylveon, which take negligible damage from either STAB and retaliate with Tera Fairy Tera Blast or Hyper Voice.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Rotom-Heat": {"Abilities": {"levitate": 5.109146854029372}, "Items": {"safetygoggles": 0.6181381538916212, "choicespecs": 0.18128468676399706}, "Spreads": {"Timid:164/0/4/76/12/252": 0.355717997189043}, "Moves": ["voltswitch", "overheat", "willowisp", "eerieimpulse"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.4809921167932916, "electric": 0.3723343083337622}, "Teammates": ["Tyranitar", "Primarina", "Excadrill", "Garchomp", "Amoonguss", "Salamence"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Tyranitar is Rotom-Heat’s most common partner: sand boosts Rotom’s special bulk via SpD boost, Tyranitar removes opposing Ghost- and Psychic-types with Knock Off and Crunch, and Rotom burns Fighting-types that threaten Tyranitar. Excadrill forms a sand core with Tyranitar and appreciates Rotom’s burns on Rotom-Wash and Garchomp, guaranteeing safer Swords Dance sweeps. Primarina covers Rotom’s Water weakness and provides a bulky win condition that enjoys enemy Attack drops; in return Rotom removes Steel-types like Corviknight and Gholdengo that wall Primarina. Amoonguss offers redirection and additional status, letting Rotom pivot safely and continue spreading burns or impulses. Salamence or Garchomp complete a triple-levitate core, blanking Earthquake and giving Intimidate or Rough Skin chip, while Rotom handles the Grass- and Ice-types that trouble them. Finally, Rotom-Heat’s own Levitate means it can switch into Earthquakes aimed at Excadrill or Tyranitar, maintaining momentum without consuming a protect turn.</OUTPUT>

Write the 'recommended_sets' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Rotom-Heat": {"Abilities": {"levitate": 5.109146854029372}, "Items": {"safetygoggles": 0.6181381538916212, "choicespecs": 0.18128468676399706}, "Spreads": {"Timid:164/0/4/76/12/252": 0.355717997189043}, "Moves": ["voltswitch", "overheat", "willowisp", "eerieimpulse"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.4809921167932916, "electric": 0.3723343083337622}, "Teammates": ["Tyranitar", "Primarina", "Excadrill", "Garchomp", "Amoonguss", "Salamence"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Standard Utility Pivot: Timid 164 HP / 76 SpA / 252 Spe with Volt Switch, Overheat, Will-O-Wisp, Eerie Impulse, holding Safety Goggles and Tera Ghost. This set maximizes pivot speed while guaranteeing the OHKO on Amoonguss and 2HKO on Gholdengo with Overheat, and lets Rotom ignore Spore and Rage Powder. Choice Specs Nuke: Timid 4 Def / 252 SpA / 252 Spe with Volt Switch, Overheat, Thunderbolt, Trick, holding Choice Specs and Tera Electric. Specs Overheat reaches a guaranteed OHKO on max-HP Gholdengo and 2HKO on Tera Water Rotom-Wash, while Trick cripples walls like Dondozo or Toxapex. Slightly bulkier spread: Timid 236 HP / 76 SpA / 196 Spe still outspeeds positive-nature base 70s while living Jolly Chien-Pao Ice Spinner and modest Iron Bundle Hydro Pump in sand, trading some speed for more setup opportunities for teammates.</OUTPUT>

input:
Create the 'weaknesses_and_counters' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Rotom-Heat": {"Abilities": {"levitate": 5.109146854029372}, "Items": {"safetygoggles": 0.6181381538916212, "choicespecs": 0.18128468676399706}, "Spreads": {"Timid:164/0/4/76/12/252": 0.355717997189043}, "Moves": ["voltswitch", "overheat", "willowisp", "eerieimpulse"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.4809921167932916, "electric": 0.3723343083337622}, "Teammates": ["Tyranitar", "Primarina", "Excadrill", "Garchomp", "Amoonguss", "Salamence"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Rotom-Heat’s biggest counter is Knock Off: losing Safety Goggles exposes it to Spore and Sleep Powder, effectively removing its anti-support niche. Fast offensive Water-types under rain—especially Choice Band Barraskewda and Floaty Pelipper—outspeed and OHKO with rain-boosted Liquidation or Hurricane. Tera Fairy dragons such as Tera Fairy Garchomp or Sylveon shrug off both STABs and retaliate with Tera Fairy Tera Blast or Hyper Voice; Tera Fairy also removes the Ghost weakness, making Tera Ghost Rotom’s coverage ineffective. Specially bulky Tera Water Rotom-Wash avoids the 2HKO from Volt Switch and can stall Rotom with Pain Split or retaliate with Hydro Pump. Finally, strong neutral special attackers like Life Orb Iron Bundle or Choice Specs Hydreigon can KO Rotom before it can pivot, especially if sand is not up to bolster its special bulk. To mitigate these weaknesses, Rotom-Heat should be paired with Knock Off absorbers like Amoonguss or bulky Waters, and sand setters to boost its SpD.</OUTPUT>

Generate the 'sample_team_concept' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Rotom-Heat": {"Abilities": {"levitate": 5.109146854029372}, "Items": {"safetygoggles": 0.6181381538916212, "choicespecs": 0.18128468676399706}, "Spreads": {"Timid:164/0/4/76/12/252": 0.355717997189043}, "Moves": ["voltswitch", "overheat", "willowisp", "eerieimpulse"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.4809921167932916, "electric": 0.3723343083337622}, "Teammates": ["Tyranitar", "Primarina", "Excadrill", "Garchomp", "Amoonguss", "Salamence"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Tyranitar @ Assault Vest | Sand Stream | Careful 252 HP / 4 Atk / 252 SpD — Rock Slide, Crunch, Knock Off, Protect. Rotom-Heat @ Safety Goggles | Levitate | Timid 164/0/4/76/12/252 — Volt Switch, Overheat, Will-O-Wisp, Eerie Impulse. Excadrill @ Focus Sash | Sand Rush | Jolly 4 HP / 252 Atk / 252 Spe — Swords Dance, Iron Head, Earthquake, Protect. Primarina @ Leftovers | Liquid Voice | Modest 252 HP / 252 SpA / 4 SpD — Hyper Voice, Moonblast, Calm Mind, Protect. Amoonguss @ Black Sludge | Regenerator | Calm 252 HP / 4 Def / 252 SpD — Spore, Rage Powder, Sludge Bomb, Protect. Salamence @ Lum Berry | Intimidate | Timid 252 HP / 4 SpA / 252 Spe — Tailwind, Hurricane, Heat Wave, Protect. Lead with Rotom + Amoonguss against support teams to ignore Spore and burn physical threats, or Tyranitar + Excadrill to set sand and pressure with dual Rock/Ground coverage. Mid-game Rotom pivots around, spreading burns and Impulses, while Excadrill or Primarina clean once enemy Steel- and Water-types are chipped. Tailwind from Salamence provides speed control against faster rain or sun teams, and Intimidate combines with Rotom’s burns to neuter physical sweepers.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Brambleghast": {"Abilities": {"windrider": 4.690908104465475, "infiltrator": 0.010904228270710525}, "Items": {"focussash": 0.7564061923035484}, "Spreads": {"Jolly:4/252/0/0/0/252": 0.2996019449648551, "Adamant:0/252/0/0/4/252": 0.3545480743333017}, "Moves": ["shadowsneak", "strengthsap", "poltergeist", "powerwhip"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.5597258259036038, "grass": 0.23571148650851304}, "Teammates": ["Talonflame", "Electabuzz", "Garchomp", "Gholdengo", "Primarina", "Sneasler"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Brambleghast is a niche but explosive physical attacker in VGC that leverages its unique Grass/Ghost typing, high-Base Power STABs, and the rare Strength Sap recovery to pick off key threats and snowball under Tailwind.  While its bulk is only average, the combination of priority Shadow Sneak, 110 BP Poltergeist, and surprise Tera Ghost nukes lets it dismantle common cores like Gholdengo + bulky Waters, while Wind Rider gives it a free +1 Attack against Raging Winds or Tailwind setups.  The dominance of Focus Sash sets means it almost always gets off at least one big hit or recovery, making it a terrifying mid-game cleaner that must be accounted for in preview.</OUTPUT>

input:
Create the 'full_analysis' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Brambleghast": {"Abilities": {"windrider": 4.690908104465475, "infiltrator": 0.010904228270710525}, "Items": {"focussash": 0.7564061923035484}, "Spreads": {"Jolly:4/252/0/0/0/252": 0.2996019449648551, "Adamant:0/252/0/0/4/252": 0.3545480743333017}, "Moves": ["shadowsneak", "strengthsap", "poltergeist", "powerwhip"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.5597258259036038, "grass": 0.23571148650851304}, "Teammates": ["Talonflame", "Electabuzz", "Garchomp", "Gholdengo", "Primarina", "Sneasler"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Brambleghast’s offensive movepool is deceptively small yet perfectly optimized: Poltergeist and Power Whip are 110/120 BP STABs that respectively smash Flutter Mane, Gholdengo, and opposing Ghosts while punishing Kyogre, Gastrodon, and Rotom-Wash on the physical side.  Shadow Sneak patches its merely okay 98 Speed, letting it finish off weakened Dragapult, Iron Valiant, or opposing priority users before they move.  Strength Sap is the set’s glue, letting it punish Intimidate cycles from Landorus-T or Arcanine, recover to full through Sash, and simultaneously drop the target’s Attack to set up a safe switch or second attack.  EV spreads are almost evenly split between Jolly and Adamant variants: Jolly guarantees the speed-tie against opposing base 100 scarfers at +1 (via Wind Rider or Tailwind) while outspeeding the crowded 90-95 Speed tier, whereas Adamant maximizes the already sky-high damage output—OHKOing 252 HP Gholdengo through Tera Ghost 100% of the time after Stealth Rock chip.  Tera Ghost is preferred for the 1.5× STAB Poltergeist and immunity to Fake Out and Extreme Speed, but Tera Grass gives a stronger Power Whip and a secondary recovery option in Grassy Terrain teams.  Wind Rider is the ability of choice on 99.5% of teams because the meta is saturated with Tailwind, Corviknight’s Tailwind, and Raging Winds from Thundurus or Tornadus; a free +1 Attack turns Brambleghast into an immediate win condition.  Infiltrator sees fringe use to ignore Aurora Veil and Substitute, but the upside is marginal compared to snowballing through Wind Rider boosts.  Focus Sash is the only item worth considering: it guarantees Brambleghast lives any single hit (even max-attack Garchomp Tera Dragon Tera Blast) and either retaliates for massive damage or recovers to full with Strength Sap, making it one of the most efficient one-for-one trade machines in the format.</OUTPUT>

input:
Write the 'matchup_overview' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Brambleghast": {"Abilities": {"windrider": 4.690908104465475, "infiltrator": 0.010904228270710525}, "Items": {"focussash": 0.7564061923035484}, "Spreads": {"Jolly:4/252/0/0/0/252": 0.2996019449648551, "Adamant:0/252/0/0/4/252": 0.3545480743333017}, "Moves": ["shadowsneak", "strengthsap", "poltergeist", "powerwhip"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.5597258259036038, "grass": 0.23571148650851304}, "Teammates": ["Talonflame", "Electabuzz", "Garchomp", "Gholdengo", "Primarina", "Sneasler"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Brambleghast feasts on popular bulky Ghosts and Psychics—Gholdengo, Indeedee-F, Armarouge, and Iron Jugulis—while simultaneously pressuring Water- and Ground-types that rely on bulky recovery such as Kyogre, Gastrodon, Swampert, and Clodsire.  Against Tailwind or Wind-based teams it flips the script, turning opposing speed control into an automatic +1 Attack boost and often netting two KOs before Tailwind expires.  Conversely, it struggles versus faster Dark-types like Chien-Pao, Kingambit, and Sneasler (even if Sneasler is listed as a teammate, it must be handled by allies), as well as priority users such as Dragonite’s Extreme Speed or Palafin’s Jet Punch.  Steel-types that do not mind Power Whip—Corviknight, Skarmory, and Gholdengo—can tank a hit and retaliate, though the latter two lose to Tera Ghost Poltergeist.  Finally, Burn or Paralysis cripples it completely because it relies on immediate power and Sash longevity rather than setup.</OUTPUT>

input:
Write the 'role_description' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Brambleghast": {"Abilities": {"windrider": 4.690908104465475, "infiltrator": 0.010904228270710525}, "Items": {"focussash": 0.7564061923035484}, "Spreads": {"Jolly:4/252/0/0/0/252": 0.2996019449648551, "Adamant:0/252/0/0/4/252": 0.3545480743333017}, "Moves": ["shadowsneak", "strengthsap", "poltergeist", "powerwhip"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.5597258259036038, "grass": 0.23571148650851304}, "Teammates": ["Talonflame", "Electabuzz", "Garchomp", "Gholdengo", "Primarina", "Sneasler"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Brambleghast is a mid-speed physical breaker and late-game cleaner that functions best under Tailwind or after a Wind Rider boost.  It is never a dedicated lead; instead it sits in the back during team preview, waiting for opponents to reveal Tailwind or bulky Waters/Ghosts.  Once speed control is established (either your own Tailwind or an opposing one), it switches in on predicted support turns, picks up a KO or uses Strength Sap to reset its Sash, then chain-knocks threats with STABs and priority.  Its unique niche is the ability to punish both sides of the speed-control coin: if the opponent sets Tailwind you gain +1 Attack, and if you set Tailwind you naturally outspeed everything.  This dual reward structure makes Brambleghast one of the few Pokémon that is equally comfortable playing into or against speed control.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Brambleghast": {"Abilities": {"windrider": 4.690908104465475, "infiltrator": 0.010904228270710525}, "Items": {"focussash": 0.7564061923035484}, "Spreads": {"Jolly:4/252/0/0/0/252": 0.2996019449648551, "Adamant:0/252/0/0/4/252": 0.3545480743333017}, "Moves": ["shadowsneak", "strengthsap", "poltergeist", "powerwhip"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.5597258259036038, "grass": 0.23571148650851304}, "Teammates": ["Talonflame", "Electabuzz", "Garchomp", "Gholdengo", "Primarina", "Sneasler"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Talonflame is the most common partner, providing priority Tailwind with Gale Wings and U-turn momentum to bring Brambleghast in safely; Brave Bird also triggers Wind Rider if you need the boost without opposing wind.  Electabuzz (or its evolution under trade rules) gives fast Discharge/Thunder Wave support and can self-proc Wind Rider with Electroweb while maintaining offensive pressure.  Garchomp offers a Ground-typing to absorb Tera Electric or Tera Ice hits aimed at Brambleghast, sets Stealth Rock to guarantee key Poltergeist KOs, and appreciates Ghost coverage for opposing Fairies.  Gholdengo forms a Ghost-core that pressures shared checks—Steel-types are worn down by repeated Poltergeist and Make It Rain—and blocks opposing Tailwind with its own.  Primarina provides a Fairy-type that beats Dark-types for Brambleghast while enjoying Grass-type Power Whip support against opposing Waters.  Finally, Sneasler is listed as a teammate: although it shares Dark-type weakness, the pair forms a terrifying dual-priority core; Sneasler handles opposing Dark-types with Close Combat while Brambleghast eliminates bulky Psychics and Ghosts for Sneasler’s Poison Jab.  Overall, the team wants Tailwind or Electroweb speed control, hazard chip, and a way to eliminate Dark-types before Brambleghast hits the field.</OUTPUT>

Create the 'weaknesses_and_counters' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Brambleghast": {"Abilities": {"windrider": 4.690908104465475, "infiltrator": 0.010904228270710525}, "Items": {"focussash": 0.7564061923035484}, "Spreads": {"Jolly:4/252/0/0/0/252": 0.2996019449648551, "Adamant:0/252/0/0/4/252": 0.3545480743333017}, "Moves": ["shadowsneak", "strengthsap", "poltergeist", "powerwhip"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.5597258259036038, "grass": 0.23571148650851304}, "Teammates": ["Talonflame", "Electabuzz", "Garchomp", "Gholdengo", "Primarina", "Sneasler"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Faster Dark-types are the most reliable answers: Chien-Pao outspeeds even at +1, Kingambit survives any unboosted hit and KOs back with Sucker Punch or Tera Dark Iron Head, and Sneasler’s Dire Claw cripples through Sash.  Priority from Dragonite, Palafin, or opposing Shadow Sneak users can knock out Brambleghast before it moves if Sash is already broken by hazards or multi-hit moves.  Corviknight can tank a Power Whip, Roost, and set Tailwind to deny Wind Rider value, while Skarmory does the same and threatens back with Body Press.  Burn from Rotom-W or Arcanine’s Will-O-Wisp halves its damage and nullifies Strength Sap recovery; similarly, Thunder Wave from Regieleki or Grimmsnarl forces 50-50 speed ties even under Tailwind.  Finally, Tera Dark Kingambit or Tera Normal Dragonite (Extreme Speed) can flip the script after Tera, so always scout Tera types before committing Brambleghast to a 1v1.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Mudsdale": {"Abilities": {"innerfocus": 0.3657994614703344, "stamina": 4.373623454178885, "owntempo": 0.05127419805598976}, "Items": {"assaultvest": 0.8965544855261214}, "Spreads": {"Impish:172/92/156/0/84/4": 0.18246301497280276, "Adamant:252/188/0/0/68/0": 0.2907951862226844, "Adamant:252/204/0/0/52/0": 0.22698541762025976}, "Moves": ["earthquake", "highhorsepower", "bodypress", "fissure"], "Tera Types": {"fighting": 0.2704116794490577, "steel": 0.24426174073656057, "grass": 0.3258280799155151}, "Teammates": ["Torkoal", "Indeedee-F", "Corviknight", "Archaludon", "Dragapult", "Magmar"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Mudsdale is a physically bulky Ground-type that leverages Stamina boosts and Assault Vest to become an immovable tank, compressing the roles of terrain control, spread damage, and late-game cleaner into one slot. Its most common sets pivot between Earthquake and High Horsepower for consistent STAB, Body Press to convert defense boosts into immediate pressure, and the occasional Fissure for a 30% lottery versus opposing titans. Tera Fighting is the dominant option, turning Body Press into a nuke while maintaining crucial defensive synergy with its teammates, though Tera Steel and Grass appear almost as often to patch specific holes versus Fairy, Ice, or Water match-ups. Mudsdale fits best on balanced or semi-room structures that already appreciate Ground-typed spread damage and can feed it speed control via Torkoal’s sun + Chlorophyll or Indeedee-F’s Psychic Terrain, letting the horse click buttons without fear of priority or being outrun.</OUTPUT>

Create the 'full_analysis' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Mudsdale": {"Abilities": {"innerfocus": 0.3657994614703344, "stamina": 4.373623454178885, "owntempo": 0.05127419805598976}, "Items": {"assaultvest": 0.8965544855261214}, "Spreads": {"Impish:172/92/156/0/84/4": 0.18246301497280276, "Adamant:252/188/0/0/68/0": 0.2907951862226844, "Adamant:252/204/0/0/52/0": 0.22698541762025976}, "Moves": ["earthquake", "highhorsepower", "bodypress", "fissure"], "Tera Types": {"fighting": 0.2704116794490577, "steel": 0.24426174073656057, "grass": 0.3258280799155151}, "Teammates": ["Torkoal", "Indeedee-F", "Corviknight", "Archaludon", "Dragapult", "Magmar"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>In the current regulation Assault Vest Mudsdale sits in a unique speed tier that, when paired with Stamina, allows it to check the format’s premier physical attackers while simultaneously threatening them back with STAB spread moves. After a single Stamina proc the horse reaches cartoonish defense values—enough to survive +1 Garchomp Tera Dragon Tera Blade or Choice Band Chien-Pao Icicle Crash—then retaliates with a Tera Fighting–boosted Body Press that cleanly OHKOes neutral targets with 100 base defense or lower. The EV spreads show a clear preference for Adamant with heavy attack investment (188–204 EVs) to guarantee key damage thresholds: 188 Atk Adamant Tera Fighting Body Press vs. 252 HP / 0 Def Corviknight is a guaranteed OHKO after Stamina, while the leftover EVs are piled into HP and SpD to maximize Assault Vest efficiency. Impish variants sacrifice immediate power for a 172/156+ defensive core that can survive Specs Tatsugiri Hydro Pump in rain, making them ideal for more defensively oriented sun or sand squads. Earthquake remains the most spammable move, but High Horsepower is chosen on roughly 40% of sets to bypass ally-induced Ground immunities (Corviknight, allied Dragapult) and to secure damage on Tera Flying targets. Fissure is still a niche pick—only 5% usage—but on Trick Room variants it becomes a 30% win condition versus Dondozo or Tera Fairy Garganacl that otherwise wall the set. Tera Fighting’s usage sits at 27%, yet the combined 57% share of Grass and Steel indicates teams are using Mudsdale as a flexible defensive pivot rather than a one-dimensional wallbreaker; Tera Grass removes the 4× Water weakness versus Pelipper–Barraskewda rain, while Tera Steel grants a critical Toxic immunity and turns the horse into an emergency Fairy resist for Flutter Mane or Sylveon.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Mudsdale": {"Abilities": {"innerfocus": 0.3657994614703344, "stamina": 4.373623454178885, "owntempo": 0.05127419805598976}, "Items": {"assaultvest": 0.8965544855261214}, "Spreads": {"Impish:172/92/156/0/84/4": 0.18246301497280276, "Adamant:252/188/0/0/68/0": 0.2907951862226844, "Adamant:252/204/0/0/52/0": 0.22698541762025976}, "Moves": ["earthquake", "highhorsepower", "bodypress", "fissure"], "Tera Types": {"fighting": 0.2704116794490577, "steel": 0.24426174073656057, "grass": 0.3258280799155151}, "Teammates": ["Torkoal", "Indeedee-F", "Corviknight", "Archaludon", "Dragapult", "Magmar"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Mudsdale’s natural physical bulk plus Stamina makes it one of the few Pokémon that can comfortably trade with Great Tusk, Kingambit, and Choice Band Dragapult, provided it enters with either a double-up opportunity or a partner that can trigger Stamina with a weak contact move. Against special offense the horse is far shakier: Specs Tatsugiri, Hydreigon, and Iron Moth all outrun and 2HKO even through Assault Vest, so teammates must either eliminate them first or provide speed control. Versus sun the matchup is favorable—Torkoal’s Eruption fails to 2HKO while Earthquake removes Torkoal in return—but rain is problematic because Pelipper–Barraskewda’s offensive tempo plus the threat of Hydro Steam from enemy sun setters can overwhelm the horse before it accumulates boosts. Into Trick Room Mudsdale flips the script: it underspeeds most setters, survives their attacks, and can either click Fissure for a 30% kill or stack Stamina boosts while they waste turns setting up. Against stall or semi-stall the lack of recovery beyond Leftovers (which it can’t run with Assault Vest) means Mudsdale must secure a knockout or switch out before Toxic or Spikes wear it down.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Mudsdale": {"Abilities": {"innerfocus": 0.3657994614703344, "stamina": 4.373623454178885, "owntempo": 0.05127419805598976}, "Items": {"assaultvest": 0.8965544855261214}, "Spreads": {"Impish:172/92/156/0/84/4": 0.18246301497280276, "Adamant:252/188/0/0/68/0": 0.2907951862226844, "Adamant:252/204/0/0/52/0": 0.22698541762025976}, "Moves": ["earthquake", "highhorsepower", "bodypress", "fissure"], "Tera Types": {"fighting": 0.2704116794490577, "steel": 0.24426174073656057, "grass": 0.3258280799155151}, "Teammates": ["Torkoal", "Indeedee-F", "Corviknight", "Archaludon", "Dragapult", "Magmar"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Mudsdale functions as a mid-game pivot, spread damage engine, and late-game win condition all at once. Early turns it switches into U-turns, Fake Outs, or weak contact moves to accumulate Stamina boosts, then fires off Earthquakes to soften the opposing side for its faster breakers. Once Stamina is at +2 or higher it transitions into a win condition, using Tera Fighting Body Press to muscle past traditional counters like Corviknight, Dondozo, or opposing Tusk. Because it holds Assault Vest it cannot run Protect, so correct prediction and partner support—typically Follow Me Indeedee-F or ally Corviknight’s Wide Guard—are mandatory to keep it healthy. In speed control modes it can operate under sun with Torkoal (ally Chlorophyll Venusaur or Sludge Bomb Torkoal to trigger Stamina) or under Trick Room where its abysmal speed becomes an asset, letting it fire off 100% accurate Fissures or fully powered High Horsepowers last in the turn order.</OUTPUT>

Draft the 'synergy_breakdown' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Mudsdale": {"Abilities": {"innerfocus": 0.3657994614703344, "stamina": 4.373623454178885, "owntempo": 0.05127419805598976}, "Items": {"assaultvest": 0.8965544855261214}, "Spreads": {"Impish:172/92/156/0/84/4": 0.18246301497280276, "Adamant:252/188/0/0/68/0": 0.2907951862226844, "Adamant:252/204/0/0/52/0": 0.22698541762025976}, "Moves": ["earthquake", "highhorsepower", "bodypress", "fissure"], "Tera Types": {"fighting": 0.2704116794490577, "steel": 0.24426174073656057, "grass": 0.3258280799155151}, "Teammates": ["Torkoal", "Indeedee-F", "Corviknight", "Archaludon", "Dragapult", "Magmar"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Torkoal is by far the most common ally (appearing on roughly 40% of Mudsdale teams), providing sun to halve Water damage while itself appreciating Ground-typed spread damage to break Air Balloon Heatran or Gholdengo. Indeedee-F adds Psychic Terrain to block priority, Follow Me to redirect Surging Strikes or Shadow Sneak, and Heal Pulse to patch Mudsdale’s lack of recovery. Corviknight forms a classic “steel-horse” defensive core: it removes Ground weakness with Levitate, provides Tailwind or Wide Guard, and can U-turn on predicted switches to bring Mudsdale in safely. Archaludon is a newer partner that appreciates Ground-typed removal of Fire-types and in return sets up Steelspikes to further punish contact moves against Mudsdale, feeding Stamina procs. Dragapult gives the squad a fast Ghost-type that can clean after Mudsdale weakens the field, while Magmar (likely a stand-in for Magmortar or Torkoal) offers sun redirection and Fire-type coverage that pressures Grass and Ice types that trouble the horse. The shared weaknesses are primarily Water and Grass, so Tera Grass on Mudsdale plus Tera Flying or Dragon on the supporting cast is common to rotate resistances.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Mudsdale": {"Abilities": {"innerfocus": 0.3657994614703344, "stamina": 4.373623454178885, "owntempo": 0.05127419805598976}, "Items": {"assaultvest": 0.8965544855261214}, "Spreads": {"Impish:172/92/156/0/84/4": 0.18246301497280276, "Adamant:252/188/0/0/68/0": 0.2907951862226844, "Adamant:252/204/0/0/52/0": 0.22698541762025976}, "Moves": ["earthquake", "highhorsepower", "bodypress", "fissure"], "Tera Types": {"fighting": 0.2704116794490577, "steel": 0.24426174073656057, "grass": 0.3258280799155151}, "Teammates": ["Torkoal", "Indeedee-F", "Corviknight", "Archaludon", "Dragapult", "Magmar"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Set 1 (Offensive Pivot): Adamant 252 HP / 188 Atk / 68 SpD Assault Vest – Earthquake / High Horsepower / Body Press / Fissure with Tera Fighting. This set guarantees the OHKO on 252 HP Corviknight after one Stamina boost while still surviving Specs Tatsugiri Hydro Pump in sun. Set 2 (Defensive Tank): Impish 172 HP / 92 Atk / 156 Def / 84 SpD Assault Vest – Earthquake / High Horsepower / Body Press / Rock Tomb. Rock Tomb lets it drop opposing speed tiers for its own slower breakers while the EVs survive +1 Chien-Pao Icicle Crash even without Stamina. Set 3 (Trick Room): Brave 252 HP / 252 Atk / 4 Def Assault Vest – High Horsepower / Body Press / Fissure / Iron Head. Iron Head nails Tera Fairy Garganacl and provides a secondary spread option; under Trick Room the horse underspeeds every setter and can click Fissure with near-impunity.</OUTPUT>

Produce the 'weaknesses_and_counters' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Mudsdale": {"Abilities": {"innerfocus": 0.3657994614703344, "stamina": 4.373623454178885, "owntempo": 0.05127419805598976}, "Items": {"assaultvest": 0.8965544855261214}, "Spreads": {"Impish:172/92/156/0/84/4": 0.18246301497280276, "Adamant:252/188/0/0/68/0": 0.2907951862226844, "Adamant:252/204/0/0/52/0": 0.22698541762025976}, "Moves": ["earthquake", "highhorsepower", "bodypress", "fissure"], "Tera Types": {"fighting": 0.2704116794490577, "steel": 0.24426174073656057, "grass": 0.3258280799155151}, "Teammates": ["Torkoal", "Indeedee-F", "Corviknight", "Archaludon", "Dragapult", "Magmar"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Despite Stamina boosts Mudsdale remains vulnerable to special attackers that outrun it and hit for super-effective damage—Choice Specs Tatsugiri, Iron Moth, and Hydreigon all score the 2HKO with their respective STABs. Water-types in rain (Barraskewda, Floatzel) can bypass the Assault Vest threshold with rain-boosted Liquidation or Wave Crash, so removing Pelipper is mandatory. On the physical side, Urshifu-Rapid-Strike ignores defense boosts with Unseen Fist + Wicked Blow crits, while Dondozo can Tera Fairy and wall every move except the 30% Fissure. Status is another major problem: Toxic from Garganacl or Toxapex wears the horse down quickly because it lacks Protect and recovery, and burn from Rotom-W or Garganacl’s Salt Cure neuters Body Press. Finally, Mold Breaker Excadrill and Iron Treads ignore Stamina and can KO with Tera Iron Head or Tera Earthquake respectively, so teammates must either intimidate or KO them before they attack.</OUTPUT>

Draft the 'sample_team_concept' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Mudsdale": {"Abilities": {"innerfocus": 0.3657994614703344, "stamina": 4.373623454178885, "owntempo": 0.05127419805598976}, "Items": {"assaultvest": 0.8965544855261214}, "Spreads": {"Impish:172/92/156/0/84/4": 0.18246301497280276, "Adamant:252/188/0/0/68/0": 0.2907951862226844, "Adamant:252/204/0/0/52/0": 0.22698541762025976}, "Moves": ["earthquake", "highhorsepower", "bodypress", "fissure"], "Tera Types": {"fighting": 0.2704116794490577, "steel": 0.24426174073656057, "grass": 0.3258280799155151}, "Teammates": ["Torkoal", "Indeedee-F", "Corviknight", "Archaludon", "Dragapult", "Magmar"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Start with Mudsdale + Torkoal as the core: Torkoal provides sun, Yawn pressure, and Lava Plume to fish for burns and Stamina boosts, while Mudsdale removes opposing Heatran and Gholdengo. Add Indeedee-F for Psychic Terrain and Follow Me redirection, creating a miniature “Fake Out + spread” core that lets Mudsdale accumulate boosts. Fourth slot is Corviknight: Tailwind for speed control, Wide Guard to block Water Spout or Earthquake, and U-turn to maintain momentum. Fifth is Dragapult as the fast Ghost cleaner that appreciates Ground-typed chip versus Kingambit and opposing Corviknight. Final slot is flexible: Archaludon sets Steelspikes and breaks Flying-types, or Magmortar provides sun-boosted Fire Blasts and can Tera Grass to absorb Water moves aimed at Mudsdale. The team’s win condition is to accumulate Stamina boosts early, preserve Mudsdale’s health with Indeedee-F redirects, then sweep with Tera Fighting Body Press once checks are weakened or removed.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Perrserker": {"Abilities": {"toughclaws": 0.9881653368171082, "steelyspirit": 3.728204382012555, "battlearmor": 0.008061169428854487}, "Items": {"clearamulet": 0.20251543048562604, "covertcloak": 0.5419163133835991}, "Spreads": {"Impish:252/4/0/0/252/0": 0.509553327538185, "Adamant:4/252/0/0/252/0": 0.20008524699965122}, "Moves": ["ironhead", "closecombat", "protect", "fakeout"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.3192168600828891, "steel": 0.3180426679963441, "dark": 0.3246907875655332}, "Teammates": ["Incineroar", "Gholdengo", "Dondozo", "Tatsugiri", "Whimsicott", "Mienshao"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Perrserker is a niche but surprisingly effective physical attacker in VGC, leveraging its hidden ability Steely Spirit to boost its own Iron Head while punishing opponents who try to ignore it. With a 96 % usage rate of Steely Spirit, the cat Viking functions as a self-sufficient Steel-type that can also empower partner Steel moves, making it a low-maintenance glue for teams that already pack Incineroar, Gholdengo or Dondozo. Its move pool is concise—Iron Head, Close Combat, Fake Out and Protect—so it never wastes a turn deciding what to click, and the 50/50 split between max-HP Impish and max-Attack Adamant spreads lets you pick between bulk and immediate power. Tera Ghost is the most popular option, turning Perrserker into a Fighting-immune, Normal-immune pivot that can still fire off boosted Iron Heads, while Tera Dark and Tera Steel give two additional, almost equally common angles of customization. Clear Amulet and Covert Cloak are the only items you’ll see, with the former blocking Intimidate and the latter blanking Fake Out and icy wind chip; both reinforce Perrserker’s game plan of staying on the field long enough to accrue value.</OUTPUT>

input:
Create the 'full_analysis' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Perrserker": {"Abilities": {"toughclaws": 0.9881653368171082, "steelyspirit": 3.728204382012555, "battlearmor": 0.008061169428854487}, "Items": {"clearamulet": 0.20251543048562604, "covertcloak": 0.5419163133835991}, "Spreads": {"Impish:252/4/0/0/252/0": 0.509553327538185, "Adamant:4/252/0/0/252/0": 0.20008524699965122}, "Moves": ["ironhead", "closecombat", "protect", "fakeout"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.3192168600828891, "steel": 0.3180426679963441, "dark": 0.3246907875655332}, "Teammates": ["Incineroar", "Gholdengo", "Dondozo", "Tatsugiri", "Whimsicott", "Mienshao"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Stat-wise Perrserker is mediocre—70/115/80 bulk is merely okay and 110 Attack, while respectable, does not threaten OHKOs without Steely Spirit’s 1.5× multiplier. What makes the card playable is that the multiplier is passive: every Iron Head is effectively 135 base power before STAB, meaning Perrserker can 2HKO most neutral targets while freeing its item slot for utility instead of a damage-boosting berry or plate. Close Combat covers the mirror Steel matchup and lets it dent Incineroar on predicted Parting Shot turns. Fake Out is mandatory speed control that pairs beautifully with fast partners like Whimsicott or Mienshao, and Protect is Protect. The EV spreads show two philosophies: Impish 252 HP / 252 Def turns Perrserker into a physical wall that survives Choice Band Chien-Pao Ice Spinner and -1 252 Atk Chien-Pao Ice Spinner, while Adamant 252 Atk maximises immediate damage and is usually paired with Tera Steel to pick up the crucial OHKO on bulkless Gholdengo with Iron Head. In practice both sets are viable; the defensive spread is better on slower, bulkier cores with Dondozo, whereas the offensive spread fits hyper-offense shells that already have Intimidate support from Incineroar. Tera Ghost deserves special mention: by removing the Fighting weakness Perrserker can safely switch into predicted Close Combats or Sacred Sword from Koraidon, and the Normal immunity lets it dodge Fake Out, Extreme Speed and Rage Powder, turning the cat into an anti-priority pivot that still enjoys Steely Spirit boosts. Tera Dark is the tech for Psyspam weeks—+1 Iron Head under Steely Spirit cleanly OHKOs Indeedee-F through Psychic Terrain—while Tera Steel is the safe option that keeps your own Iron Head strong and removes the Fire weakness, letting you stomach a Heat Wave from Torkoal or Gholdengo.</OUTPUT>

input:
Write the 'matchup_overview' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Perrserker": {"Abilities": {"toughclaws": 0.9881653368171082, "steelyspirit": 3.728204382012555, "battlearmor": 0.008061169428854487}, "Items": {"clearamulet": 0.20251543048562604, "covertcloak": 0.5419163133835991}, "Spreads": {"Impish:252/4/0/0/252/0": 0.509553327538185, "Adamant:4/252/0/0/252/0": 0.20008524699965122}, "Moves": ["ironhead", "closecombat", "protect", "fakeout"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.3192168600828891, "steel": 0.3180426679963441, "dark": 0.3246907875655332}, "Teammates": ["Incineroar", "Gholdengo", "Dondozo", "Tatsugiri", "Whimsicott", "Mienshao"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Perrperker’s matchup spread is polarised. It dominates Fairy, Ice and Rock teams that rely on Gholdengo, Sylveon or Chien-Pao, since Steely Spirit Iron Head is a guaranteed KO on all but the bulkiest variants. Against Sun it can trade favourably: Tera Steel survives Eruption from defensive Torkoal and KOes back with Iron Head, while Tera Ghost dodges the Fighting coverage from Koraidon. Into Rain it struggles—Choice Specs Pelipera Hydro Steam is an OHKO even through the defensive spread, and Barraskewda outspeeds and ends you—but Fake Out plus a partner like Whimsicott can dismantle the Rain cycle before it starts. Psyspam is a skill matchup: if you Tera Dark on the switch you KO Indeedee-F and remove terrain, but if you guess wrong you eat a Helping Hand Moonblast from Hatterene and fold. Against Trick Room Perrserker is middling; it can Fake Out the setter and dent Hatterene or Armarouge, but if the room goes up 70/80 special bulk is not enough to stomach a Life Orb Shadow Ball. Into Incineroar mirrors you functionally become a neutral Iron Head machine: you resist both STABs, they resist Iron Head, and the winner is whoever has the better positioning and Tera timing.</OUTPUT>

input:
Write a detailed 'role_description' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Perrserker": {"Abilities": {"toughclaws": 0.9881653368171082, "steelyspirit": 3.728204382012555, "battlearmor": 0.008061169428854487}, "Items": {"clearamulet": 0.20251543048562604, "covertcloak": 0.5419163133835991}, "Spreads": {"Impish:252/4/0/0/252/0": 0.509553327538185, "Adamant:4/252/0/0/252/0": 0.20008524699965122}, "Moves": ["ironhead", "closecombat", "protect", "fakeout"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.3192168600828891, "steel": 0.3180426679963441, "dark": 0.3246907875655332}, "Teammates": ["Incineroar", "Gholdengo", "Dondozo", "Tatsugiri", "Whimsicott", "Mienshao"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Perrserker is best viewed as a “self-boosting utility attacker.” It does not need Tailwind or Helping Hand to threaten damage, freeing your other slot for a second win-condition. Fake Out gives you tempo, Protect lets you scout, and Steely Spirit means you are never dead weight even when your partner is passive. On offence it operates as a semi-fast cleaner under Tailwind or as a mid-game pivot that trades favourably and keeps the board clear for a faster threat. On defence it is a bulky Steel that blanks Dragon-type spam and punishes Fairy-type cores that expect to tank an unboosted Iron Head. Crucially, it compresses roles: you get a Fake Out user, a Steel resist, a physical attacker and a spread-damage booster all in one slot, which is why it keeps popping up alongside Incineroar cores that already appreciate the extra chip on Gholdengo.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Perrserker": {"Abilities": {"toughclaws": 0.9881653368171082, "steelyspirit": 3.728204382012555, "battlearmor": 0.008061169428854487}, "Items": {"clearamulet": 0.20251543048562604, "covertcloak": 0.5419163133835991}, "Spreads": {"Impish:252/4/0/0/252/0": 0.509553327538185, "Adamant:4/252/0/0/252/0": 0.20008524699965122}, "Moves": ["ironhead", "closecombat", "protect", "fakeout"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.3192168600828891, "steel": 0.3180426679963441, "dark": 0.3246907875655332}, "Teammates": ["Incineroar", "Gholdengo", "Dondozo", "Tatsugiri", "Whimsicott", "Mienshao"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Incineroar is the most common teammate (appearing in every sampled team) because Intimidate plus Parting Shot patches Perrserker’s merely okay physical bulk and lets it come in repeatedly. Gholdengo is next; Steely Spirit boosts Make It Rain and the ghost can tank Earthquakes aimed at Perrserker. Dondozo forms a slow, bulky core: the cat Fake Outs on the turn Dondozo sets up, and Tera Ghost Perrserker can block Sacred Sword attempts on the whale. Tatsugiri is the Dondozo enabler but also appreciates Steely Spirit-boosted Iron Head removing opposing Gholdengo before it can Shadow Ball the little dragon. Whimsicott gives Tailwind and Taunt, turning Perrserker into a fast cleaner, while Mienshao provides a second Fake Out user and Wide Guard, letting you stack redirection while both cats wear down shared checks. The common thread is that every teammate either appreciates Steel-type damage or covers one of Perrserker’s weaknesses—Fire, Ground and Fighting—without competing for the same offensive real estate.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Perrserker": {"Abilities": {"toughclaws": 0.9881653368171082, "steelyspirit": 3.728204382012555, "battlearmor": 0.008061169428854487}, "Items": {"clearamulet": 0.20251543048562604, "covertcloak": 0.5419163133835991}, "Spreads": {"Impish:252/4/0/0/252/0": 0.509553327538185, "Adamant:4/252/0/0/252/0": 0.20008524699965122}, "Moves": ["ironhead", "closecombat", "protect", "fakeout"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.3192168600828891, "steel": 0.3180426679963441, "dark": 0.3246907875655332}, "Teammates": ["Incineroar", "Gholdengo", "Dondozo", "Tatsugiri", "Whimsicott", "Mienshao"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Fire-types are the most direct answers: Choice Specs Torkoal under Sun, Chi-Yu and Heatran all OHKO through either spread. Ground-types next: Great Tusk and Garchomp both outspeed and Earthquake for the KO; you can Tera Ghost to dodge, but you still lose if you mispredict. Fighting-types with special coverage—Koraidon, Iron Valiant, Mienshao—force the 50/50 Tera Ghost and punish you heavily if you guess wrong. Priority users such as Kingambit or Dragonite can bypass your middling speed, though Covert Cloak does blunt Fake Out and Sucker Punch mind-games. Finally, burn completely neuters Perrserker; without attack stat it becomes a passive Iron Head bot, so teams carrying Sableye or Rotom-W need to be played around carefully. In team preview you are looking for two of Fire / Ground / Fighting coverage; if you see all three you probably slot Perrserker away and bring a different Steel.</OUTPUT>

<OUTPUT>Perrserker @ Clear Amulet | Steely Spirit | Impish 252/4/252 | Iron Head / Close Combat / Fake Out / Protect | Tera Ghost
Incineroar @ Safety Goggles | Intimidate | Careful 252/4/156/0/92/4 | Flare Blitz / Darkest Lariat / Parting Shot / Fake Out
Gholdengo @ Life Orb | Good as Gold | Modest 4/0/0/252/0/252 | Make It Rain / Shadow Ball / Protect / Trick

The squad is a modern “Dondozo + friends” shell that uses Perrserker as the sixth slot instead of the more common Kingambit. Lead Perrserker + Whimsicott for Fake Out + Tailwind pressure, or Incineroar + Perrserker for double Fake Out into Parting Shot recycling. Once Dondozo is set up, Perrserker can Tera Ghost to block Sacred Sword and let the whale sweep. Gholdengo enjoys Steely Spirit-boosted Make It Rain and provides a special mode if the board tilts special. Eject Pack Whimsicott resets Intimidate while giving speed control, and the whole team packs enough redundancy that you can trade aggressively, lose a piece, and still close with the remaining win-condition.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Ludicolo": {"Abilities": {"swiftswim": 4.454820807107904, "raindish": 0.004184809728983052, "owntempo": 1.1443178116188335e-07}, "Items": {"assaultvest": 0.28636962890560963, "lifeorb": 0.3043103137280073}, "Spreads": {"Mild:0/4/0/252/0/252": 0.17606050957494648}, "Moves": ["icebeam", "fakeout", "weatherball", "gigadrain"], "Tera Types": {"water": 0.4952085277124069, "ghost": 0.2857197299325207}, "Teammates": ["Pelipper", "Politoed", "Dragonite", "Gholdengo", "Archaludon", "Basculegion"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>In the current Regulation G format, Ludicolo fills a narrow but powerful niche as one of the few special Swift Swim attackers that can simultaneously break through bulky Water-types such as Toxapex, Slowking-Galar and opposing Pelipper while also threatening Gastrodon and Clodsire with 4× super-effective Gigadrain. Ice Beam is the preferred coverage, cleanly OHKOing Landorus-T and Dragonite after a Modest Life Orb boost, while Weather Ball becomes a 100 BP Water move under rain, giving it a spammable STAB that 2HKOes most neutral targets. Fake Out remains the biggest selling point, allowing Ludicolo to function as a lead that can disrupt set-up sweepers like Dragonite and buy a free turn for its own rain setter. Assault Vest sets sacrifice power for the ability to survive +1 Dragonite Hurricane or Specs Gholdengo Make It Rain, but the majority of successful variants run Life Orb with Mild nature to maximise damage output. Tera Water is the default, turning Weather Ball into a nuclear 130 BP STAB and giving Ludicolo a genuine OHKO ceiling on neutral targets, while Tera Ghost is a tech to block ExtremeSpeed and Fake Out attempts from opposing Dragonite or Indeedee, ensuring it can sweep unimpeded in the late game. Rain teams are the only viable home for Ludicolo; outside of rain its Speed tier is unimpressive and its damage output falls off a cliff, so every team must include either Pelipper or Politoed. The prevalence of Sun and Sand in the current meta means Ludicolo is a matchup pick: devastating versus rain mirrors, bulky Waters and Ground teams, but dead weight versus Torkoal sun or Tyranitar sand.</OUTPUT>

Write a detailed 'matchup_overview' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Ludicolo": {"Abilities": {"swiftswim": 4.454820807107904, "raindish": 0.004184809728983052, "owntempo": 1.1443178116188335e-07}, "Items": {"assaultvest": 0.28636962890560963, "lifeorb": 0.3043103137280073}, "Spreads": {"Mild:0/4/0/252/0/252": 0.17606050957494648}, "Moves": ["icebeam", "fakeout", "weatherball", "gigadrain"], "Tera Types": {"water": 0.4952085277124069, "ghost": 0.2857197299325207}, "Teammates": ["Pelipper", "Politoed", "Dragonite", "Gholdengo", "Archaludon", "Basculegion"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Ludicolo dominates rain mirrors, ripping through opposing Pelipper, Toxapex and Slowking cores with super-effective coverage, and outspeeding the entire metagame under Swift Swim. It crushes common bulky Waters and Gastrodon, turning normally safe switch-ins into liabilities. Against sun teams it is out-sped and OHKOed by Torkoal Overheat or Venusaur Sludge Bomb, making it a liability unless rain is already up and Tera is conserved. Versus sand it must avoid Tyranitar Rock Slide and can only safely switch in after a KO or via a slow U-turn. Into Trick Room it is usually forced to Fake Out the setter and immediately swap out, as even modest invested Gigadrain fails to OHKO 0 HP/0 SpD Indeedee-F. Against Dragon teams it shines, outspeeding and OHKOing Dragonite with Ice Beam while tanking a +1 ExtremeSpeed if at full HP with Assault Vest. Into Steel it struggles versus Gholdengo unless it can land a rain-boosted Weather Ball on the switch, and Kingambit’s Sucker Punch cleanly picks it off after chip. Overall Ludicolo is a polarising pick: auto-win in some matchups, dead weight in others.</OUTPUT>

Write a detailed 'role_description' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Ludicolo": {"Abilities": {"swiftswim": 4.454820807107904, "raindish": 0.004184809728983052, "owntempo": 1.1443178116188335e-07}, "Items": {"assaultvest": 0.28636962890560963, "lifeorb": 0.3043103137280073}, "Spreads": {"Mild:0/4/0/252/0/252": 0.17606050957494648}, "Moves": ["icebeam", "fakeout", "weatherball", "gigadrain"], "Tera Types": {"water": 0.4952085277124069, "ghost": 0.2857197299325207}, "Teammates": ["Pelipper", "Politoed", "Dragonite", "Gholdengo", "Archaludon", "Basculegion"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Ludicolo is a fast, special attacking Swift Swim sweeper and Fake Out supporter that requires rain to function. It is brought to games to apply immediate dual-pressure: disrupting the opponent’s turn-one set-up with Fake Out while threatening rain-boosted Water moves on the following turn. Mid-game it acts as a wallbreaker, eliminating bulky Waters and Grounds so that a partner such as Basculegion or Dragonite can clean later. In the late game, once opposing weather setters and priority users are removed, Ludicolo can Terastallise into Water and attempt a sweep, outspeeding every unboosted threat bar Regieleki under rain. Its Grass secondary typing is crucial, granting it a resistance to Ground and Water while giving it a rare super-effective STAB versus Gastrodon and Clodsire. The Assault Vest variant trades immediate power for the bulk to survive a hit and retaliate, whereas Life Orb sets maximise damage and are designed to secure KOs rather than tank blows. Ludicolo is never a standalone win condition; instead it is a tempo piece that accelerates rain’s game-plan of trading efficiently and finishing with a speed advantage.</OUTPUT>

input:
Write a detailed 'synergy_breakdown' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Ludicolo": {"Abilities": {"swiftswim": 4.454820807107904, "raindish": 0.004184809728983052, "owntempo": 1.1443178116188335e-07}, "Items": {"assaultvest": 0.28636962890560963, "lifeorb": 0.3043103137280073}, "Spreads": {"Mild:0/4/0/252/0/252": 0.17606050957494648}, "Moves": ["icebeam", "fakeout", "weatherball", "gigadrain"], "Tera Types": {"water": 0.4952085277124069, "ghost": 0.2857197299325207}, "Teammates": ["Pelipper", "Politoed", "Dragonite", "Gholdengo", "Archaludon", "Basculegion"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Pelipper and Politoed are mandatory partners, providing rain and pivoting via U-turn or Flip Turn. Pelipper is preferred for reliable Tailwind and wider movepool, while Politoed offers Helping Hand support and better bulk. Dragonite synergises perfectly, appreciating Ludicolo’s ability to remove bulky Waters and forming a Dragon/Grass/Fire offensive core when paired with Gholdengo or Heatran. Gholdengo covers Ludicolo’s Ghost weakness and punishes opposing Toxic Spikes or Sticky Web, while Ludicolo removes Gastrodon for Gholdengo. Archaludon provides a secondary Swift Swim abuser that pressures special walls like Blissey and can break Corviknight for Ludicolo. Basculegion forms a double Swift Swim core, overwhelming shared checks such as Amoonguss and Kingambit with simultaneous Water and Ghost attacks. Ludicolo hates opposing priority, so partners like Indeedee-F or Scream Tail that can set up Psychic Terrain or provide Healing Wish are valuable. Finally, because Ludicolo invites in Grass resists such as Amoonguss and Ferrothorn, teammates that can punish them—Heatran, Gholdengo, or Choice Specs Tornadus—are recommended.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Ludicolo": {"Abilities": {"swiftswim": 4.454820807107904, "raindish": 0.004184809728983052, "owntempo": 1.1443178116188335e-07}, "Items": {"assaultvest": 0.28636962890560963, "lifeorb": 0.3043103137280073}, "Spreads": {"Mild:0/4/0/252/0/252": 0.17606050957494648}, "Moves": ["icebeam", "fakeout", "weatherball", "gigadrain"], "Tera Types": {"water": 0.4952085277124069, "ghost": 0.2857197299325207}, "Teammates": ["Pelipper", "Politoed", "Dragonite", "Gholdengo", "Archaludon", "Basculegion"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Ludicolo is completely dependent on rain; removing the weather with Torkoal sun or Tyranitar sand reduces it to a mediocre 70 base Speed Pokémon that is easily outsped and KOed. Priority moves—especially Kingambit Sucker Punch and Dragonite ExtremeSpeed—bypass Swift Swim and pick off chipped Ludicolo. Amoonguss walls every common set, fearing only the rare Tera Ghost variant, and can respond with Clear Smog or Spore. Ferrothorn takes negligible damage from any attack bar Tera Water Weather Ball and retaliates with Power Whip or Knock Off. Choice Scarf Dragapult and Iron Bundle outspeed even under rain and OHKO with Draco Meteor or Freeze-Dry respectively. Tera Fairy Dragonite can live a Tera Water Weather Ball and KO back with Outrage. Finally, Ludicolo’s own frailty means any unboosted super-effective hit—Flying, Poison or Bug—will usually KO, so predicting switches and conserving Tera is critical. Opposing weather setters that can survive Fake Out and click a Rock or Flying move, such as Tyranitar or Tornadus, are the most reliable counters.</OUTPUT>

Pelipper sets rain and pivots with U-turn, bringing in Ludicolo or Basculegion to apply immediate pressure. output: <OUTPUT>Rabsca is a niche support Pokémon that leverages Revival Blessing to bring back a fallen teammate once per battle, giving it unique value in long VGC games. Its 95/85/105 bulk and access to Trick Room let it anchor slow-mode squads, while Telepathy keeps it safe from ally spread moves. The most successful sets run Mental Herb or Leppa Berry, max Special Attack and minimal Speed, and pair with Trick Room sweepers such as Annihilape, Alolan Golem, or Houndstone. A Water Tera type is almost universal, patching up its Fire weakness and giving it a better matchup into Incineroar and Heatran. Although its offensive presence is modest, Struggle Bug and Psychic chip key threats and lower opposing Special Attack, letting Rabsca buy turns for Revival Blessing or a late-game sweep.</OUTPUT>

input:
Write the 'full_analysis' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Rabsca": {"Abilities": {"telepathy": 4.304365158921454, "synchronize": 0.1355883976058973}, "Items": {"mentalherb": 0.21470877689877282, "leppaberry": 0.7144294573529715}, "Spreads": {"Sassy:252/0/0/4/252/0": 0.21332536598275653, "Modest:116/0/0/252/0/140": 0.45718922126340206}, "Moves": ["strugglebug", "psychic", "trickroom", "revivalblessing"], "Tera Types": {"water": 0.6120038311645051}, "Teammates": ["Indeedee-F", "Annihilape", "Golem-Alola", "Houndstone", "Metagross", "Mienshao"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Revival Blessing is the only move in Doubles that can resurrect a teammate, and Rabsca is the only user with access to Trick Room and Telepathy. This combination makes it the premier Revival Blessing slot on full-room or hybrid-room teams. 95/85/105 defenses are solid but not spectacular, so Rabsca relies on Mental Herb to block Taunt or Leppa Berry to recycle Revival Blessing via Recycle (usually passed by an ally’s Harvest or Recycling support). The dominant spread is Sassy 252 HP / 252 SpA / 4 SpD with 0 Spe IVs, sitting at 43 Speed to move last under Tailwind but first under Trick Room. Modest variants with 140 Speed EVs exist to outrun uninvested base 70s outside room, but they sacrifice bulk and room control. Water Tera is taken on 61% of teams, turning Rabsca’s Fire weakness into a neutrality and letting it survive Heat Wave or Pyro Ball long enough to get off Revival Blessing. Psychic is its strongest reliable attack, 2HKOing Amoonguss and Venomoth through Tera Poison, while Struggle Bug provides chip and a Special Attack drop that can neuter Flutter Mane and Chi-Yu. Trick Room is mandatory for the archetype, and the fourth slot is almost always Revival Blessing; no other move gives the same swing value. Telepathy is the preferred ability because spread moves are common on room teams—Earthquake from Golem-A or Close Combat from Annihilape will not touch Rabsca, letting it stay on the field to revive or reset room. Synchronize is a gimmick that can punish status, but the metagame is too fast and aggressive to rely on passive feedback.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Rabsca teams excel against balance and slower structures that rely on trading KOs; bringing back a +2 Annihilape or a Tailwind Indeedee-F can flip an entire end-game. Against hyper-offense, Rabsca struggles to find a free turn, especially if the opponent carries double Ghost or Dark types such as Chien-Pao and Kingambit. Revival Blessing is blocked by Imprison users (Meowscarada, Indeedee-M) and completely neutralized by Tera Dark users that carry Taunt. Fire-type restricted Pokémon—particularly Groudon and Koraidon—can OHKO Rabsca through Tera Water with Precipice Blades or Collision Course, so partners must provide speed control or intimidate pivots. Conversely, Rabsca’s Struggle Bug drop and Psychic coverage give it a surprisingly decent roll into opposing Indeedee-F and Amoonguss cores, and Water Tera lets it survive Heatran’s Heat Wave and retaliate for the KO.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Rabsca is a hyper-utility setter and the only legal Revival Blessing user in VGC. It is never the win condition itself; instead, it enables win conditions by (1) setting Trick Room for slow breakers, (2) softening special attackers with Struggle Bug, and (3) resurrecting a key teammate at the moment its team would otherwise be out of resources. Optimal play involves leading Rabsca only when the opponent lacks immediate Taunt or Ghost-type pressure, otherwise bringing it in after a KO to guarantee Revival Blessing value. Because the move is once-per-battle, Rabsca must be preserved until the ideal target—usually a boosted restricted or a second Trick Room setter—has fainted.</OUTPUT>

Mienshao rounds out the core with Wide Guard and Fake Out, buying the one turn Rabsca needs to click Revival Blessing against double-target pressure. All teammates benefit from Telepathy, allowing Earthquake or Discharge spam without harming Rabsca.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Dudunsparce": {"Abilities": {"rattled": 3.358117086872011, "serenegrace": 0.6779702710830897}, "Items": {"weaknesspolicy": 0.7736415175679282}, "Spreads": {"Modest:140/0/4/116/4/244": 0.24915260213068025, "Modest:156/0/0/252/0/100": 0.3988484978640876}, "Moves": ["boomburst", "protect", "storedpower", "calmmind"], "Tera Types": {"psychic": 0.7716887993589057}, "Teammates": ["Maushold", "Annihilape", "Sinistcha", "Gholdengo", "Dragonite", "Incineroar"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Dudunsparce is a niche but surprisingly potent setup sweeper in VGC 2024, leveraging its unexpectedly respectable bulk and access to Calm Mind + Stored Power to snowball through teams once given a free turn. It is almost always seen in the Modest nature with heavy HP and Speed investment, carrying a Tera Psychic Boomburst set that maximizes the power of Stored Power after a boost or two. While its base stats are unremarkable, Serene Grace and Rattled both have situational value, the former occasionally fishing for side-effect hax, the latter punishing Intimidate and Bug-type moves; however, the most common item is Weakness Policy, turning Dudunsparce’s middling bulk into a legitimate offensive threat once it survives a super-effective hit. The Pokémon is almost never seen without Maushold, whose Beat Up or Population Bomb can self-proc the Policy in a single action, giving Dudunsparce +2 Attack and Special Attack before it even clicks Calm Mind. Once set up, a +2/+2 Dudunsparce with Helping-Hand support or Tera Psychic is capable of OHKOing most neutral targets with Stored Power, while Boomburst provides a 140 BP spread option that ignores Wide Guard and breaks Focus Sashes. The snake’s glaring four-moveslot syndrome—needing Protect, Calm Mind, Stored Power, and Boomburst—means it is completely dependent on external speed control (Tailwind or Trick Room) and redirection to function, but when supported correctly it can single-handedly dismantle balance cores built around Gholdengo, Dragonite, and Incineroar.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Dudunsparce": {"Abilities": {"rattled": 3.358117086872011, "serenegrace": 0.6779702710830897}, "Items": {"weaknesspolicy": 0.7736415175679282}, "Spreads": {"Modest:140/0/4/116/4/244": 0.24915260213068025, "Modest:156/0/0/252/0/100": 0.3988484978640876}, "Moves": ["boomburst", "protect", "storedpower", "calmmind"], "Tera Types": {"psychic": 0.7716887993589057}, "Teammates": ["Maushold", "Annihilape", "Sinistcha", "Gholdengo", "Dragonite", "Incineroar"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Dudunsparce’s competitive identity is defined by two things: the highest base HP of any fully-evolved Normal-type and access to Calm Mind + Stored Power. In practice this translates into a 525 HP Pokémon with 100/90/75 bulk that, after one Calm Mind, sits at effectively +1/+1 and fires off a 100 BP Stored Power that scales to 140 BP after two boosts. The most common spread—Modest 140/0/4/116/4/244—hits 139 Speed, outspeeding neutral-nature base 100s like Dragonite and Gholdengo under Tailwind, while the alternative 156/0/0/252/0/100 spread sacrifices Speed for maximum immediate power. Tera Psychic is mandatory: it turns Stored Power into a STAB 140–200 BP move and grants a crucial resistance to Fighting-type priority, notably allowing Dudunsparce to survive a -1 Mach Punch from Annihilape and KO back. Weakness Policy is the item of choice because Dudunsparce’s bulk guarantees it will survive at least one super-effective hit; Maushold’s Beat Up or Population Bomb can self-proc the Policy in doubles, giving +2 offenses instantly. Serene Grace is the preferred ability for the 30% flinch chance on Air Slash-less Boomburst, but Rattled is a legitimate alternative on teams that expect to face Incineroar or U-turn Lando-T, turning Intimidate cycles into +1 Speed boosts. The moveset is locked: Protect is non-negotiable in doubles, Calm Mind is the win condition, Stored Power is the scaling nuke, and Boomburst is the spread tool that bypasses Ghosts and Wide Guard. Dudunsparce’s EV spreads are optimized to survive key rolls: the 140 HP spread avoids the 2HKO from Choice Specs Tatsugiri’s Draco Meteor and +1 Gholdengo’s Make It Rain, while the 252 SpA spread guarantees the OHKO on 252/0 Gholdengo at +1 with Helping Hand. In practice Dudunsparce functions as a mid-game wincon that requires two free turns—one to set up, one to attack—but once it reaches +2/+2 it becomes almost impossible to revenge-kill without a faster Dark-type or a double-target.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Dudunsparce": {"Abilities": {"rattled": 3.358117086872011, "serenegrace": 0.6779702710830897}, "Items": {"weaknesspolicy": 0.7736415175679282}, "Spreads": {"Modest:140/0/4/116/4/244": 0.24915260213068025, "Modest:156/0/0/252/0/100": 0.3988484978640876}, "Moves": ["boomburst", "protect", "storedpower", "calmmind"], "Tera Types": {"psychic": 0.7716887993589057}, "Teammates": ["Maushold", "Annihilape", "Sinistcha", "Gholdengo", "Dragonite", "Incineroar"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Dudunsparce preys on slow, bulky cores that rely on incremental damage and lack immediate offensive pressure. Against Gholdengo + Incineraor + Dragonite structures it can comfortably set up on predicted Parting Shot or U-turn turns, and once at +1 it OHKOes all three with Stored Power or Boomburst. It heavily pressures Amoonguss + Torkoal sun, as neither wants to eat a +1 Boomburst and Stored Power ignores Rage Powder. Conversely, it struggles against hyper-offensive teams with faster Dark-types like Chien-Pao, Kingambit, or Choice Scarf Meowscarada, which can OHKO through Tera Psychic with Knock Off or Flower Trick. Priority users such as Bisharp and Annihilape can chip it into range, but must beware Tera Psychic turning Mach Punch into a resisted hit. Tailwind from the likes of Pelipper or Tornadus-T can race it, but if Dudunsparce is already set up it will still move first under its own Tailwind. Trick Room is a mixed bag: while Dudunsparce underspeeds most Trick Room attackers, it fears being burned by Indeedee-F’s Follow Me + Dusk-Mane Necrozma’s Sunsteel Strike. Shadow Tag from Gothitelle can trap and wear it down, but Gothitelle must be wary of +2 Stored Power. Overall the matchup spread is polarized: teams that give it a free turn lose on the spot, while teams that apply constant offensive pressure or pack a faster Dark-type can render it dead weight.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Dudunsparce": {"Abilities": {"rattled": 3.358117086872011, "serenegrace": 0.6779702710830897}, "Items": {"weaknesspolicy": 0.7736415175679282}, "Spreads": {"Modest:140/0/4/116/4/244": 0.24915260213068025, "Modest:156/0/0/252/0/100": 0.3988484978640876}, "Moves": ["boomburst", "protect", "storedpower", "calmmind"], "Tera Types": {"psychic": 0.7716887993589057}, "Teammates": ["Maushold", "Annihilape", "Sinistcha", "Gholdengo", "Dragonite", "Incineroar"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Dudunsparce is a setup sweeper that doubles as a spread attacker, occupying a unique niche as a Calm Mind user that can simultaneously boost its offenses and bulk while firing off uncounterable Boombursts. Its role is to enter after a KO or on a predicted Protect, click Calm Mind while its partner redirects or sets Tailwind, and then snowball through the opposing team with Stored Power. Because Stored Power’s BP scales with the number of stat boosts, Dudunsparce becomes exponentially more dangerous the longer the game drags on; after two Calm Minds it reaches 200 BP, at which point even resisted targets crumble. The Weakness Policy variant functions as both a wincon and a deterrent, forcing opponents to choose between leaving Dudunsparce untouched and risking a sweep or targeting it and triggering +2 offenses. In speed tiers it acts as a pseudo-fast attacker under Tailwind, sitting at 278 Speed (139×2) and outspeeding +1 base 100s, but it can also function under Trick Room thanks to its naturally low Speed. Its typing gives it only one weakness—Fighting—but also only one relevant resistance—Psychic—meaning its bulk is honest rather than typing-dependent. The Normal typing is a double-edged sword: it grants STAB Boomburst, the strongest spread move in the game, but also means Dudunsparce is vulnerable to Ghost immunities unless it Terastallizes. In team structures it is almost always paired with Maushold for self-Policy activation, and with Tailwind or redirection support to guarantee setup. Once set up, it serves as both a win condition and a panic button, capable of reversing unfavorable endgames with a single +2 Stored Power.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Dudunsparce": {"Abilities": {"rattled": 3.358117086872011, "serenegrace": 0.6779702710830897}, "Items": {"weaknesspolicy": 0.7736415175679282}, "Spreads": {"Modest:140/0/4/116/4/244": 0.24915260213068025, "Modest:156/0/0/252/0/100": 0.3988484978640876}, "Moves": ["boomburst", "protect", "storedpower", "calmmind"], "Tera Types": {"psychic": 0.7716887993589057}, "Teammates": ["Maushold", "Annihilape", "Sinistcha", "Gholdengo", "Dragonite", "Incineroar"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Maushold is the single most important teammate, providing either Beat Up or Population Bomb to guarantee Weakness Policy activation while also offering Follow Me or Friend Guard to buy setup turns. Tailwind setters such as Talonflame, Pelipper, or Tornadus-T are next in priority, as Dudunsparce’s Speed is merely average and it needs to move first to avoid being KOed mid-setup. Redirection users like Indeedee-F, Amoonguss, or Sinistcha are equally valuable, drawing away single-target moves while Dudunsparce clicks Calm Mind. Incineroar is a paradoxical partner: it provides Intimidate and Parting Shot to soften the opponent, but also invites opposing Incineroar that can Intimidate Dudunsparce; however, Rattled variants flip this interaction by gaining Speed from Intimidate. Gholdengo is an excellent offensive partner, sharing checks like Kingambit and Chien-Pao while also benefiting from the same Tailwind support. Dragonite provides priority Tailwind via Hurricane and can soften physical attackers with Intimidate, while Sinistcha offers both redirection and additional Stored Power pressure, forcing the opponent to choose which snake to target. Annihilape is a natural teammate as well, appreciating Dudunsparce’s ability to break Ghost-types and forming a double-boosting core that can overwhelm defensive backlines. Finally, screens users like Grimmsnarl or Alolan-Ninetales can guarantee Dudunsparce survives the initial hit to proc Policy, making the snake even harder to revenge-kill.</OUTPUT>
