output: <OUTPUT>The standard Weakness Policy set is non-negotiable: Dudunsparce @ Weakness Policy, Modest nature, 140 HP / 4 Def / 116 SpA / 4 SpD / 244 Spe (or 156 HP / 252 SpA / 100 Spe for maximum power), with the moves Calm Mind, Stored Power, Boomburst, and Protect. Tera Psychic is mandatory; no other Tera type provides the same power and defensive utility. The EV spread hits 139 Speed to outspeed neutral base 100s under Tailwind while surviving Choice Specs Tatsugiri’s Draco Meteor and +1 Gholdengo’s Make It Rain. An alternative Rattled set drops Weakness Policy for Leftovers or Shell Bell, instead relying on Incineroar or U-turn Lando-T to gain Speed boosts; this variant runs 252 HP / 252 SpA / 4 SpD with a Quiet nature to underspeed Trick Room attackers while still hitting 278 Speed after a Rattled boost. A third, niche Serene Grace set can forgo Calm Mind entirely and run Air Slash + Boomburst for 60% flinch chance, but this is generally inferior to the scaling power of Stored Power. The only real item flexibility is between Weakness Policy and Leftovers on non-Maushold teams, but the loss of immediate power is noticeable. Moveslots are completely fixed; attempting to slot coverage like Shadow Ball or Ice Beam costs Dudunsparce its only form of spread damage and its win condition. In best-of-three environments, always bring the Policy variant game one and consider swapping to Rattled only if the opponent reveals multiple Intimidate users or U-turn spam.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Dudunsparce": {"Abilities": {"rattled": 3.358117086872011, "serenegrace": 0.6779702710830897}, "Items": {"weaknesspolicy": 0.7736415175679282}, "Spreads": {"Modest:140/0/4/116/4/244": 0.24915260213068025, "Modest:156/0/0/252/0/100": 0.3988484978640876}, "Moves": ["boomburst", "protect", "storedpower", "calmmind"], "Tera Types": {"psychic": 0.7716887993589057}, "Teammates": ["Maushold", "Annihilape", "Sinistcha", "Gholdengo", "Dragonite", "Incineroar"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Faster Dark-types are the hard stop: Choice Scarf Meowscarada’s Flower Trick, Kingambit’s Sucker Punch, and Chien-Pao’s Ice Shard all OHKO through Tera Psychic. Priority users that can tank a hit—such as Bisharp with Focus Sash or Annihilape with Rage Fist—can chip Dudunsparce into range before it sets up. Taunt completely shuts it down, as Dudunsparce needs Calm Mind to scale; Murkrow, Whimsicott, and Grimmsnarl can all outspeed and Taunt before it moves. Double-targeting the turn it sets up is the most reliable answer: even with Tera Psychic, Dudunsparce’s uninvested defenses leave it vulnerable to simultaneous super-effective hits, and without Policy activation it remains a modest threat. Ghost-types like Aegislash and Gholdengo can wall Boomburst and force a Tera commit, though both lose to +2 Stored Power. Wide Guard from Tornadus-T or Araquanid blocks Boomburst, but Stored Power still hits through it. Trick Room can backfire if Dudunsparce is already set up, but leading with a fast TR setter like Hatterene can deny it the initial turn. Finally, phazing moves like Roar and Dragon Tail erase its boosts, though these are rare in doubles. In team preview, identify whether the opponent carries a faster Dark-type or Taunt user; if so, preserve Dudunsparce for late-game cleanup rather than attempting an early sweep, and always pair it with redirection to minimize the chance of being double-targeted.</OUTPUT>

Next add Talonflame @ Sharp Beak, Jolly, 252 Atk / 252 Spe / 4 HP, Tailwind / Brave Bird / Taunt / Protect to guarantee Tailwind turn one. Incineroar @ Sitrus Berry, Careful, 252 HP / 252 SpD / 4 Atk, Parting Shot / Flare Blitz / Darkest Lariat / Protect provides Intimidate and pivoting, while also baiting opposing Incineroar for Rattled variants. The game plan is simple: lead Maushold + Tailwind setter, click Beat Up on Dudunsparce turn one, switch Maushold into redirection, set up Calm Mind while the opponent is forced to target around Follow Me, and sweep with +2 Stored Power or Boomburst. The team packs multiple speed control modes—Tailwind, Rattled, and optional Trick Room from Sinistcha—ensuring Dudunsparce can function under any tempo.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Snorlax": {"Abilities": {"thickfat": 2.1090509309842917, "gluttony": 1.6741773122999437, "immunity": 0.0038203659947950164}, "Items": {"leftovers": 0.4134333572174294, "custapberry": 0.1511851181907602, "salacberry": 0.2153431440392378}, "Spreads": {"Sassy:252/0/180/0/76/0": 0.3983243388987797}, "Moves": ["protect", "facade", "bellydrum", "bodyslam"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.48688466968024036, "ground": 0.21550884746793894}, "Teammates": ["Gastrodon", "Incineroar", "Sinistcha", "Smeargle", "Annihilape", "Garganacl"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Snorlax’s niche in the current doubles environment is defined by its ability to flip games in a single turn through Belly Drum. After halving its own HP it triggers either Salac Berry (for speed) or Custap Berry (for priority) via Gluttony, letting it outspeed or out-priority most of the metagame at +6 Attack. Facade is the preferred STAB: with a status condition (most commonly self-induced via Flame Orb or an ally’s status move) it reaches a blistering 140 base power, cleanly OHKOing neutral targets even through Dynamax bulk. Body Slam is kept for situations where burn or poison is undesirable, offering a useful 30 % paralysis chance that can further aid a sweep. Protect is mandatory for enabling a safe Drum turn or for stalling out opposing Dynamax turns. Thick Fat is the most common ability because it removes two otherwise troublesome weaknesses; Gluttony, however, is the lynchpin of the Berry sets and is run almost as frequently. Sassy nature with heavy Special Defense investment lets Snorlax stomach strong special attackers—most notably Miraidon, Iron Valiant, and Tornadus—and still have enough HP left after Belly Drum to activate its Berry. Tera Ghost is dominant because it provides a Fighting immunity, blocks Fake Out, and makes it immune to Extreme Speed from opposing Dragonite or Lucario, while Tera Ground grants an Electric immunity and removes the Toxic vulnerability that can otherwise stall out Custap variants. EV spreads aim to guarantee survival against common spread attackers like Flutter Mane and Iron Bundle while still maximizing Attack after Drum.</OUTPUT>

Finally, multi-hit attackers like Breloom’s Bullet Seed or Maushold’s Population Bomb can break through Custap variants before the Berry activates.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Alolan Golem is a niche but explosive offensive pivot in VGC whose entire identity revolves around Galvanize-boosted Explosion. With a 92/252/0/0/0/164 Adamant spread it outspeeds key threats such as uninvested base 90s while still maximizing Attack, letting it fire off a nuclear Double-Edge or Explosion before going down. Clear Amulet is the item of choice to block intimidate and other stat drops, ensuring its damage stays pristine. <DATA>{"Golem-Alola": {"Abilities": {"galvanize": 3.820482111187623, "magnetpull": 0.003748574805276128, "sturdy": 0.005743766544864692}, "Items": {"clearamulet": 0.5346438801140176}, "Spreads": {"Adamant:252/252/0/0/4/0": 0.2283639013431073, "Brave:252/252/0/0/4/0": 0.18068973004608735, "Adamant:92/252/0/0/0/164": 0.53000325044189}, "Moves": ["protect", "rockslide", "explosion", "doubleedge"], "Tera Types": {"electric": 0.3129397011554761, "flying": 0.6009281730494898}, "Teammates": ["Rabsca", "Annihilape", "Houndstone", "Indeedee-F", "Metagross", "Mienshao"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Alolan Golem’s stat-line is awkward—great Attack and serviceable bulk, but a quadruple weakness to Ground and mediocre Speed. Galvanize turns its Normal moves into Electric, giving Explosion an effective base power north of 300 after STAB and terrain, enough to OHKO even bulky resists that aren’t Ground-type. Because it almost always faints after pulling the trigger, the EV spread focuses on maximizing that initial impact: 252 Atk and an Adamant nature hit as hard as possible, 164 Speed EVs let it creep positive-natured base 90s and slower, and the remaining 92 HP give it just enough bulk to survive a modest hit before retaliating. Clear Amulet prevents Intimidate, Snarl, or Parting Shot from shaving damage off the explosion, while Tera Electric grants a second STAB and pseudo-levitate versus Earthquake, and Tera Flying removes the Ground weakness entirely for a turn. Rock Slide is mandatory spread pressure that flinches opposing leads, and Protect buys a turn to read the opponent or let an ally set up. The result is a Pokémon that dictates the first three turns: either it claims a KO immediately, or forces the opponent into awkward double-protects and positioning, creating free setup for partners.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Golem-Alola": {"Abilities": {"galvanize": 3.820482111187623, "magnetpull": 0.003748574805276128, "sturdy": 0.005743766544864692}, "Items": {"clearamulet": 0.5346438801140176}, "Spreads": {"Adamant:252/252/0/0/4/0": 0.2283639013431073, "Brave:252/252/0/0/4/0": 0.18068973004608735, "Adamant:92/252/0/0/0/164": 0.53000325044189}, "Moves": ["protect", "rockslide", "explosion", "doubleedge"], "Tera Types": {"electric": 0.3129397011554761, "flying": 0.6009281730494898}, "Teammates": ["Rabsca", "Annihilape", "Houndstone", "Indeedee-F", "Metagross", "Mienshao"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Alolan Golem loves facing bulky offense that relies on non-Ground physical attackers—teams built around Gholdengo, Iron Hands, or Dragonite give it free explosion targets. Conversely, it struggles against dedicated Ground-types such as Garchomp, Great Tusk, or Ting-Lu, which can survive any hit and retaliate with STAB Earthquake. Priority users like Kingambit or Dragonite with Extremespeed can pick off a chipped Golem before it explodes, while Follow Me or Rage Powder from Indeedee or Amoonguss can redirect the boom. Opposing weather teams that pack Swift Swim or Sand Rush can also outspeed and KO before Golem moves. In Trick Room matchups Golem flips the script: under Trick Room the Brave 0-Speed variant becomes a terrifying tank that can afford to run Sturdy and survive a hit, guaranteeing the explosion. Electric Terrain teams are double-edged—terrain boosts its own attacks but also powers up opposing Iron Hands or Pincurchin.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Golem-Alola": {"Abilities": {"galvanize": 3.820482111187623, "magnetpull": 0.003748574805276128, "sturdy": 0.005743766544864692}, "Items": {"clearamulet": 0.5346438801140176}, "Spreads": {"Adamant:252/252/0/0/4/0": 0.2283639013431073, "Brave:252/252/0/0/4/0": 0.18068973004608735, "Adamant:92/252/0/0/0/164": 0.53000325044189}, "Moves": ["protect", "rockslide", "explosion", "doubleedge"], "Tera Types": {"electric": 0.3129397011554761, "flying": 0.6009281730494898}, "Teammates": ["Rabsca", "Annihilape", "Houndstone", "Indeedee-F", "Metagross", "Mienshao"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Golem is a lead-oriented suicide attacker whose job is to remove one opposing Pokémon and inflict 30–50 % chip on the partner, effectively turning the game into a 3-v-2 by turn two. Because it almost always faints, it appreciates Revival Blessing support to recycle the slot later in the match. It also functions as a late-game cleaner when resists are weakened and Protects are exhausted. On hyper-offense squads it can open alongside another breaker like Iron Moth or Chien-Pao, forcing the opponent to choose which threat to target. On more balanced teams it pairs with Trick Room setters such as Indeedee-F or Rabsca, which can reset room after the explosion and provide Follow Me redirection. The threat of explosion forces Protects, which partners can exploit with setup moves like Swords Dance or Calm Mind. In short, Golem is less a traditional attacker and more a resource equalizer that trades itself for tempo.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Golem-Alola": {"Abilities": {"galvanize": 3.820482111187623, "magnetpull": 0.003748574805276128, "sturdy": 0.005743766544864692}, "Items": {"clearamulet": 0.5346438801140176}, "Spreads": {"Adamant:252/252/0/0/4/0": 0.2283639013431073, "Brave:252/252/0/0/4/0": 0.18068973004608735, "Adamant:92/252/0/0/0/164": 0.53000325044189}, "Moves": ["protect", "rockslide", "explosion", "doubleedge"], "Tera Types": {"electric": 0.3129397011554761, "flying": 0.6009281730494898}, "Teammates": ["Rabsca", "Annihilape", "Houndstone", "Indeedee-F", "Metagross", "Mienshao"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Rabsca is the single best partner, offering Revival Blessing to bring Golem back for a second boom and providing Trick Room control. Annihilape appreciates the early KO pressure, letting it snowshot with Rage Fist boosts while the opponent is 4-on-3. Houndstone benefits from the same tempo, as Golem’s explosion weakens the board for a late-game Last Respects sweep. Indeedee-F supplies Follow Me and Psychic Terrain to block priority, ensuring Golem survives to explode, while also setting Trick Room for the Brave variant. Metagross forms a psuedo-momentum core—both lure Ground-types and wear down shared checks, and Metagross can Bullet Punch to finish off whatever survives the boom. Mienshao rounds out the squad with Fake Out and Wide Guard, protecting Golem from spread Earthquakes and buying a free turn to explode. Together these teammates create a self-reinforcing cycle of pressure, revival, and positioning that maximizes Golem’s one-time nuke.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Golem-Alola": {"Abilities": {"galvanize": 3.820482111187623, "magnetpull": 0.003748574805276128, "sturdy": 0.005743766544864692}, "Items": {"clearamulet": 0.5346438801140176}, "Spreads": {"Adamant:252/252/0/0/4/0": 0.2283639013431073, "Brave:252/252/0/0/4/0": 0.18068973004608735, "Adamant:92/252/0/0/0/164": 0.53000325044189}, "Moves": ["protect", "rockslide", "explosion", "doubleedge"], "Tera Types": {"electric": 0.3129397011554761, "flying": 0.6009281730494898}, "Teammates": ["Rabsca", "Annihilape", "Houndstone", "Indeedee-F", "Metagross", "Mienshao"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Ground-types are the hard counter: Garchomp, Great Tusk, Ting-Lu, and even Donphan survive any hit and OHKO back with Earthquake. Priority users such as Kingambit or Dragonite with Extremespeed can finish off a chipped Golem before it moves. Follow Me or Rage Powder redirect the explosion, wasting the boom and leaving Golem vulnerable. Wide Guard from Pelipper or Araquanid blocks both Rock Slide and Explosion entirely. Intimidate + Parting Shot cores (e.g., Incineroar + Gholdengo) can drop its Attack below the OHKO threshold, though Clear Amulet negates this. Finally, Protect spam and smart switching can waste the explosion turn, forcing Golem to either self-destruct for little value or switch out and lose momentum. Because Golem is a one-time threat, any strategy that denies the boom—whether by KO, redirection, or Protect—effectively removes it from the game.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Rhyperior is a slow, physically bulky attacker that thrives in Trick Room or under Drought-boosted Eruption support, leveraging STAB Earthquake and Rock Slide to apply immediate spread pressure while its solid natural bulk and Solid Rock let it survive super-effective hits that would KO most other Rock- or Ground-types. Assault Vest and Clear Amulet variants punish special attackers and Intimidate users respectively, while Weakness Policy sets flip the script on opponents who try to KO it quickly, turning Rhyperior into a nuke that can single-handedly dismantle unprepared teams.</OUTPUT>

input:

<DATA>{"Rhyperior": {"Abilities": {"lightningrod": 1.5257482402689984, "solidrock": 2.3414387796992235, "reckless": 0.016535337949960316}, "Items": {"assaultvest": 0.3140450673818, "weaknesspolicy": 0.30592808268911054, "clearamulet": 0.23601706805897577}, "Spreads": {"Adamant:252/252/0/0/4/0": 0.2467893565055232, "Brave:252/252/0/0/4/0": 0.36925177548315924}, "Moves": ["earthquake", "rockslide", "highhorsepower", "protect"], "Tera Types": {"ground": 0.22727793380178749, "grass": 0.21934234062543317, "poison": 0.228117041184484}, "Teammates": ["Torkoal", "Incineroar", "Indeedee-F", "Hatterene", "Oranguru", "Smeargle"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Rhyperior’s 115 / 130 / 55 / 55 / 115 / 40 stat line is the textbook definition of a tank: enormous physical bulk, acceptable special bulk once Assault Vest is factored in, and a gargantuan 140 BP STAB spread move in Earthquake that cleanly OHKOs most neutral targets lacking defensive investment. Rock Slide provides secondary spread damage with a coveted flinch chance, while High Horsepower offers a single-target Ground option that avoids Earthquake’s partner damage, letting Rhyperior function outside of Telepathy or Protect support. Protect is mandatory on every set because Rhyperior is slow enough to move last in most speed tiers, meaning it can safely scout choice-locked opponents or wait out Dynamon turns while partners redirect or set Trick Room. Solid Rock is the most common ability (≈59 % usage) because it effectively gives Rhyperior 4/3 bulk against super-effective hits, letting it survive rain-boosted Surging Strikes, Moonblast + Mystical Fire from Flutter Mane, or even max SpA Life Orb Gholdengo Make It Rain. Lightning Rod is situationally useful on teams that stack Discharge or Thunder Wave users such as Togekiss or Zapdos, turning Rhyperior into a lightning rod that simultaneously boosts its otherwise mediocre SpA, though the boost is rarely relevant outside of mirror matches. Reckless is almost unseen but technically legal, powering up High Horsepower and the seldom-used Rock Wrecker if one opts for a meme set. Terastallization gives Rhyperior a second life: Tera Ground boosts STAB Earthquake to nuclear levels while removing the 4× Grass and Water weaknesses, Tera Grass flips the script on Water- and Grass-type attackers by turning them into resisted hits, and Tera Poison grants a crucial Toxic immunity and useful resistances to Fairy and Fighting while retaining the Rock typing’s Flying and Bug resistances. Usage data shows an almost perfectly even split among these three Tera types, underscoring Rhyperior’s flexibility.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Rhyperior": {"Abilities": {"lightningrod": 1.5257482402689984, "solidrock": 2.3414387796992235, "reckless": 0.016535337949960316}, "Items": {"assaultvest": 0.3140450673818, "weaknesspolicy": 0.30592808268911054, "clearamulet": 0.23601706805897577}, "Spreads": {"Adamant:252/252/0/0/4/0": 0.2467893565055232, "Brave:252/252/0/0/4/0": 0.36925177548315924}, "Moves": ["earthquake", "rockslide", "highhorsepower", "protect"], "Tera Types": {"ground": 0.22727793380178749, "grass": 0.21934234062543317, "poison": 0.228117041184484}, "Teammates": ["Torkoal", "Incineroar", "Indeedee-F", "Hatterene", "Oranguru", "Smeargle"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Rhyperior’s worst enemies are faster Grass- and Water-type attackers that can outspeed and KO before it moves. Ludicolo under rain, Iron Bundle, and Choice Specs Pelipper’s Hurricane are all guaranteed OHKOs even through Solid Rock, while Meowscarada, Breloom, and Tsareena cleanly KO with Grass Knot or Power Whip. On the physical side, Iron Valiant, Chien-Pao, and Kingambit all 2HKO through Solid Rock with Close Combat or Kowtow Cleave, though they risk eating a Tera-boosted Earthquake in return. Conversely, Rhyperior demolishes most Fire-, Electric-, Poison-, and Steel-types: Torkoal, Arcanine, Rotom-W, Gholdengo, Tyranitar, and Kingambit are all OHKOd by Earthquake or Rock Slide, while bulky pivots like Corviknight and Assault Vest Garganacl are 2HKOd. Against Tailwind or Regieleki-speed teams, Rhyperior relies on partners to set Trick Room or redirect, after which it becomes one of the format’s most efficient sweepers, scoring simultaneous KOs with spread moves while shrugging off most priority.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Rhyperior": {"Abilities": {"lightningrod": 1.5257482402689984, "solidrock": 2.3414387796992235, "reckless": 0.016535337949960316}, "Items": {"assaultvest": 0.3140450673818, "weaknesspolicy": 0.30592808268911054, "clearamulet": 0.23601706805897577}, "Spreads": {"Adamant:252/252/0/0/4/0": 0.2467893565055232, "Brave:252/252/0/0/4/0": 0.36925177548315924}, "Moves": ["earthquake", "rockslide", "highhorsepower", "protect"], "Tera Types": {"ground": 0.22727793380178749, "grass": 0.21934234062543317, "poison": 0.228117041184484}, "Teammates": ["Torkoal", "Incineroar", "Indeedee-F", "Hatterene", "Oranguru", "Smeargle"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Rhyperior is first and foremost a Trick Room attacker, though it can also function as a mid-speed tank on sun teams that support it with Drought Torkoal’s Eruption pressure and Chlorophyll partners that draw Grass- and Water-type coverage away from it. Its ability to threaten both spread and single-target damage makes it an excellent anti-meta pick against popular cores like Togekiss + Gholdengo or Incineroar + Regieleki. Because it is weak to the two most common spread types—Water and Grass—Rhyperior demands either redirection (Indeedee-F, Oranguru) or speed control (Trick Room, Icy Wind support) to function consistently. Once properly supported, however, it compresses the roles of wallbreaker, Dynamax target, and late-game cleaner into a single slot, freeing teammates to focus on utility or speed control.</OUTPUT>

Incineroar forms the classic “Rock-Fire-Grass” defensive core, resisting every type that threatens Rhyperior while providing Intimidate, Fake Out, and Parting Shot to let Rhyperior come in repeatedly without wasting Protect turns. output: <OUTPUT>Rhyperior’s 4× Grass and Water weaknesses are exploitable by virtually every top-tier offensive threat. Grass Knot from Iron Valiant, Meowscarada, or Rillaboom is a guaranteed OHKO even through Solid Rock. On the special side, Choice Specs Drizzle-boosted Hydro Pump from Pelipper or Palafin is similarly lethal. Priority users like Chien-Pao’s Ice Shard or Kingambit’s Sucker Punch can pick off a weakened Rhyperior after chip. Defensively, Rotom-W and Rotom-H can pivot in, Intimidate, and Volt Switch out, while Corviknight and Skarmory wall Rhyperior entirely if it lacks Fire Punch or Tera Fire. The most reliable counterplay is simply to deny Trick Room: Regieleki, Tailwind Dragonite, or Chlorophyll Venusaur can all outspeed and KO before Rhyperior moves, while Taunt users like Murkrow or Grimmsnarl prevent setup in the first place.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Start with the core six: Rhyperior (Brave Weakness Policy Solid Rock, Tera Ground), Torkoal (Quiet Eruption Heat Rock Drought), Incineroar (Careful Snarl Intimidate), Indeedee-F (Sassy Follow Me Psychic Surge), Hatterene (Quiet Trick Room Magic Bounce), and Smeargle (Jolly Spore Moody). <DATA>{"Torterra": {"Abilities": {"shellarmor": 0.7456564449698064, "overgrow": 2.73041092384108}, "Items": {"lifeorb": 0.7678612058293389}, "Spreads": {"Adamant:68/252/4/0/36/148": 0.7678612058293389}, "Moves": ["protect", "headlongrush", "woodhammer", "earthquake"], "Tera Types": {"ground": 0.7182910427122158}, "Teammates": ["Tatsugiri", "Tinkaton", "Glimmora", "Kilowattrel", "Dondozo", "Tyranitar"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Torterra is a niche, physically-bulky attacker that leverages Shell Armor and a Ground Tera-type to become a reliable mid-speed breaker in Trick Room or tailwind contexts. While its 4× Ice weakness and merely average Attack hold it back, it offers unique Ground/Grass dual STAB with Headlong Rush and Wood Hammer—both 120 BP moves backed by Life Orb and an Adamant nature—to dent common Water-, Rock-, and Steel-type cores. The chosen spread (Adamant 68/252/4/0/36/148) hits 140 Speed at level 50, enough to outrun uninvested base 90s and most support Pokémon under tailwind, while 68 HP plus 36 SpD guarantees it survives modest Ice Beam or Dazzling Gleam rolls. Shell Armor eliminates the threat of random critical hits, making it a dependable Dynamax candidate that can set its own Gravity or grassy terrain via Max Quake and Max Overgrowth. Its teammates—Tatsugiri, Dondozo, Tinkaton, Glimmora, Kilowattrel, and Tyranitar—point toward a balanced offense that manipulates speed control via Dondozo–Tatsugiri synergy, hazard pressure from Glimmora, and flying-type speed control from Kilowattrel. Torterra’s main job is to soften bulky Waters and Gastrodon for Dondozo, break Tinkaton and Gholdengo for Tyranitar, and provide a secondary Max Quake user that raises SpD for the whole squad. It demands heavy team support to cover Ice-, Flying-, and Bug-type weaknesses, but it can single-handedly flip matchups against Rain, Sand, and Gastrodon-centric balances.</OUTPUT>

input:
Draft the 'full_analysis' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Torterra": {"Abilities": {"shellarmor": 0.7456564449698064, "overgrow": 2.73041092384108}, "Items": {"lifeorb": 0.7678612058293389}, "Spreads": {"Adamant:68/252/4/0/36/148": 0.7678612058293389}, "Moves": ["protect", "headlongrush", "woodhammer", "earthquake"], "Tera Types": {"ground": 0.7182910427122158}, "Teammates": ["Tatsugiri", "Tinkaton", "Glimmora", "Kilowattrel", "Dondozo", "Tyranitar"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Torterra’s base stats are deceptively middling—95/109/105/75/85/56—yet its typing grants it valuable resistances to Rock and Electric and an immunity to Electric once grounded. The dominant ability choice, Shell Armor (seen on ~75 % of sampled builds), patches its otherwise crippling vulnerability to critical hits, a crucial boon when it is expected to trade with Life Orb recoil and sand or hail chip. Overgrow variants exist but are strictly worse: the power bonus is unreliable and Shell Armor’s consistency is why Torterra even sees experimentation. Life Orb is the only item worth considering; without it Torterra fails to secure key KOs such as 252 HP Gastrodon after Stealth Rock or 252 HP Torkoal through sun-boosted Max Overgrowth. The EV spread maximizes Attack, drops Defense to 4, and invests 148 EVs in Speed to reach 140 at L50, outpacing max-Speed neutral-nature base 70s (Bisharp, Lilligant) and creeping bulky Rotom-W and Indeedee. 68 HP plus 36 SpD lets it survive modest Ice Beam from Pelipper or Sylveon after Life Orb recoil. The four-move set is non-negotiable: Protect buys positioning turns next to Dondozo or Tatsugiri, Headlong Rush is a 120 BP Ground move that drops Defense but nukes Toxapex, Gholdengo, and opposing Tyranitar, Wood Hammer is a 120 BP Grass move that OHKOes Gastrodon and Rotom-W while 2HKOing Slowking-G, and Earthquake is a spread option that avoids Defense drops and synergizes with ally Tatsugiri’s Ally Switch or Dondozo’s wide Guard. Ground Tera is taken on ~72 % of teams, turning Headlong Rush into a 140 BP STAB and removing the Ice weakness for a turn while preserving Grass STAB for Max Overgrowth. Tera Ground also lets Tortera survive a Timid Specs Tatsugiri Draco Meteor or modest Iron Bundle Freeze-Dry and retaliate. The biggest drawback is the 4× Ice weakness: Kyurem, Iron Bundle, and Abomasnow shred it, while Flying-types like Corviknight, Kilowattrel, and Tornadus can pivot on it freely. Torterra also dislikes Intimidate cycles and burns, since it relies on immediate power rather than setup. Nevertheless, it occupies a unique speed tier between true Trick Room abusers and fast attackers, letting it function in both modes depending on partner speed control. Dondozo’s Order Up boosts can raise its Attack, while Tinkaton’s Gigaton Hammer removes opposing Flying-types. Glimmora sets Toxic Spikes to wear down bulky Waters that wall Torterra, and Kilowattrel provides Tailwind or Rain to let Torterra outpace scarf threats. Tyranitar sets sand to break Focus Sashes and adds Rock-type chip to Flying- and Ice-types. Overall, Torterra is a high-maintenance but rewarding pick that compresses roles of breaker, secondary Dynamax, and terrain setter into one slot.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Torterra": {"Abilities": {"shellarmor": 0.7456564449698064, "overgrow": 2.73041092384108}, "Items": {"lifeorb": 0.7678612058293389}, "Spreads": {"Adamant:68/252/4/0/36/148": 0.7678612058293389}, "Moves": ["protect", "headlongrush", "woodhammer", "earthquake"], "Tera Types": {"ground": 0.7182910427122158}, "Teammates": ["Tatsugiri", "Tinkaton", "Glimmora", "Kilowattrel", "Dondozo", "Tyranitar"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Against Rain, Torterra is a star: it OHKOes Pelipper with Stone Edge (via Max Rockfall) and 2HKOes Swampert and Toxapex with Wood Hammer while surviving modest Ice Beam. Pelipper must Tera Water or bring Rindo Berry to avoid the roll. Against Sun, it baits Torkoal and survives modest Overheat, then OHKOes back with Max Quake; Torkoal needs Helping Hand or Sun-boosted Eruption to secure the KO. Versus Sand, Torterra pressures Tyranitar and Gastrodon, but must watch for Iron Head flinches and Dracovish’s Fishious Rend; it can Tera Ground to survive Specs Draco from Hydreigon and retaliate. Against Trick Room, Torterra is a reliable mid-speed attacker that underspeeds Indeedee and Hatterene but outspeeds Torkoal and Porygon2 under Trick Room, letting it clean with Earthquake or Wood Hammer. It hates Iron Bundle and Kyurem, which outspeed even in Tailwind and OHKO with Freeze-Dry; accordingly, it requires Tera or ally Kilowattrel to remove them. Corviknight walls it unless Torterra carries Flamethrower (it doesn’t), so Tinkaton or Tyranitar must deal with it. Amoonguss blanks both STABs and must be poisoned by Glimmora or cleared by Kilowattrel’s Hurricane. Overall, Torterra’s matchups are polarized: it dominates slow Water- and Rock-centric teams but folds to fast Ice- and Flying-type offenses unless supported.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Torterra is a mid-speed physical wallbreaker that doubles as a Dynamax win-condition. It enters on predicted Electric- or Rock-type moves, behind Wide Guard from Dondozo or Tinkaton, and immediately threatens opposing Waters and Steels. Its primary role is to remove Gastrodon, Toxapex, and Rotom formes so that Dondozo can sweep; secondarily, it baits Ice- and Flying-type attacks for Kilowattrel and Tinkaton to switch in and gain momentum. Under Dynamax, it sets Gravity with Max Quake (raising SpD for the team) or Grassy Terrain with Max Overgrowth (healing allies and weakening opposing Earthquake). After Tera Ground, it becomes a short-lived tank that can trade with Specs users and survive super-effective hits. Because it carries Protect, it can stall Dynamax turns or wait for speed control to be established. It is not a dedicated lead, but rather a mid-game pivot that thrives once opposing Ice- and Flying-types are chipped or removed.</OUTPUT>

Tyranitar sets sand, breaks Sashes, and lures in Fighting-types that Torterra can safely switch into. The six together form a balanced offense with multiple speed modes (Tailwind, Rain, Trick Room) and layered hazard control.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Torterra": {"Abilities": {"shellarmor": 0.7456564449698064, "overgrow": 2.73041092384108}, "Items": {"lifeorb": 0.7678612058293389}, "Spreads": {"Adamant:68/252/4/0/36/148": 0.7678612058293389}, "Moves": ["protect", "headlongrush", "woodhammer", "earthquake"], "Tera Types": {"ground": 0.7182910427122158}, "Teammates": ["Tatsugiri", "Tinkaton", "Glimmora", "Kilowattrel", "Dondozo", "Tyranitar"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Fast Ice-types—Iron Bundle, Kyurem, Abomasnow—OHKO with Freeze-Dry before Torterra can move unless it Teras. Flying-types—Corviknight, Tornadus, Kilowettrel—resist both STABs and retaliate with super-effective Brave Bird or Hurricane; Corviknight in particular walls Torterra completely unless Overgrow is triggered. Intimidate cycles from Arcanine, Incineroar, or Landorus-T force it to switch or risk doing negligible damage. Burn from Sableye or Rotom-W cripples its power and compounds Life Orb recoil. Trick Room reversals from Hatterene or Indeedee can leave it outspeeding its own partners and KOing them with Earthquake. Priority from Bisharp’s Sucker Punch or Kingambit’s Sucker Punch finishes it after chip. Finally, Protect stalling can waste its Dynamax turns, and once Tera is burned it remains weak to Ice and Flying for the rest of the game. Reliable answers are to bring at least one Ice- or Flying-type attacker, keep Corviknight healthy, and preserve Tera for the moment Torterra commits.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Krookodile": {"Abilities": {"intimidate": 2.23792049195171, "moxie": 0.9816951090332309, "angerpoint": 0.5240046588098463}, "Items": {"assaultvest": 0.20773695521266267, "focussash": 0.21771628163161158, "choicescarf": 0.17258054926896232}, "Spreads": {"Jolly:0/252/0/0/4/252": 0.18766511063484448, "Adamant:76/252/0/0/84/92": 0.19616429828976015, "Adamant:68/180/4/0/4/252": 0.1562183977262282, "Adamant:196/4/116/0/156/36": 0.1669533225056293}, "Moves": ["protect", "knockoff", "earthquake", "highhorsepower"], "Tera Types": {"poison": 0.29472687046599844, "flying": 0.20019706762000233, "ghost": 0.2571818547454477}, "Teammates": ["Ninetales-Alola", "Kilowattrel", "Gholdengo", "Amoonguss", "Dragonite", "Chandelure"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Base 117 Attack and 92 Speed give Krookodile a natural jump on mid-speed threats such as Gholdengo, Chandelure and opposing Dragapult after a Scarf. Intimidate is chosen on roughly two-thirds of teams, compressing bulk and disruption, while Moxie sets aim to snowball late-game once Fairy, Fighting and Grass answers are weakened. Assault Vest variants (≈21 %) raise Sp.Def to 252+ neutral, letting Krookodile survive Moonblast from Tera Fairy Flutter Mane or Hydro Pump from Pelipper and KO back with Tera Poison Knock Off. Focus Sash (≈22 %) guarantees a hit versus faster threats or allows a double-up into bulky Tailwind setters. Choice Scarf (≈17 %) outspeeds +1 Dragonite and Modest Iron Moth, turning Krookodile into a surprise revenge killer. EV spreads range from max-max Jolly for pure speed, to Adamant with bulk investment (76/84/156) that avoids 2HKO from Life Orb Gholdengo Make It Rain while still outspeeding positive base 80s. Tera Poison is the dominant choice, neutering Fairy, Grass and Toxic status; Tera Flying removes Ground weakness and grants a Turn-one Earthquake immunity versus Garchomp or opposing Krookodile; Tera Ghost blocks Fake Out and Extreme Speed while keeping STAB on Knock Off. Knock Off is mandatory for item control, Earthquake or High Horsepower provide spread damage, Protect is universal, with Stealth Rock or Taunt occasionally filling the fourth slot on non-Assault Vest sets. Krookodile appreciates speed control: Alolan Ninetales sets Aurora Veil and threatens Dragons with Freeze-Dry; Kilowattrel clicks Tailwind and absorbs Grass attacks; Gholdengo blocks status and pressures Fairies with Make It Rain; Amoonguss offers redirection and healing; Dragonite sets up behind screens; Chandelure breaks bulky Steel-types. Together they form a balanced core that covers Krookodile’s four weaknesses (Water, Grass, Ice, Fairy) while exploiting the item-removal and Intimidate pressure it provides.</OUTPUT>

Psychic Spam appreciates Intimidate pressure, although Indeedee-F Follow Me can redirect. Overall Krookodile demands Tera commitment early versus Water/Ice and prefers to clean late versus weakened Fairy/Grass.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Krookodile is a utility pivot and late-game cleaner. Intimidate sets act as a physical blanket check, dropping Attack on switch-in and forcing opponents to either double or accept weaker damage. Assault Vest variants serve as a special sponge that removes items and spreads Ground damage; they often lead to exploit early Knock Offs. Focus Sash sets function as a fast Taunt lead or suicide attacker, guaranteeing a KO or Rock Tomb speed drop. Moxie versions are reserved for Tailwind or Aurora Veil teams, entering after a KO to snowball through weakened teams. Choice Scarf turns Krookodile into an offensive speed control piece that outspeeds +1 Dragonite, Chien-Pao and Iron Valiant, providing a surprise check to set-up sweepers. In all roles Krookodile’s main value is item control—Knock Off is the most spammable move in VGC 2024—and the ability to Tera into Poison to flip Fairy and Grass match-ups while blocking status.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Krookodile": {"Abilities": {"intimidate": 2.23792049195171, "moxie": 0.9816951090332309, "angerpoint": 0.5240046588098463}, "Items": {"assaultvest": 0.20773695521266267, "focussash": 0.21771628163161158, "choicescarf": 0.17258054926896232}, "Spreads": {"Jolly:0/252/0/0/4/252": 0.18766511063484448, "Adamant:76/252/0/0/84/92": 0.19616429828976015, "Adamant:68/180/4/0/4/252": 0.1562183977262282, "Adamant:196/4/116/0/156/36": 0.1669533225056293}, "Moves": ["protect", "knockoff", "earthquake", "highhorsepower"], "Tera Types": {"poison": 0.29472687046599844, "flying": 0.20019706762000233, "ghost": 0.2571818547454477}, "Teammates": ["Ninetales-Alola", "Kilowattrel", "Gholdengo", "Amoonguss", "Dragonite", "Chandelure"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Water-types are the biggest obstacle: Pelipper, Walking Wake and Iron Bundle all OHKO with rain orProtosynthesis-boosted moves before Krookodile can Tera. Priority Grass Knot from Amoonguss or Rillaboom also scores big damage. Faster Fairy Scarfers like Tera Fairy Iron Valiant outspeed and KO. Intimidate cycling can be punished by Clear Body Corviknight or Defiant Bisharp, which set up on Krookodile’s switch-ins. Ghost-types such as Aegislash and Tera Ghost Gholdengo avoid Earthquake and retaliate with Shadow Ball. Protect + status from Rotom-W or Slowbro can burn or paralyse, crippling Krookodile’s speed. Finally, Tera Normal Extreme Speed Dragonite or Chien-Pao can finish off chipped Krookodile before it moves. Counterplay revolves around keeping Water/Fairy threats healthy, preserving speed control, and using Protect reads to waste Tera turns.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Shiftry is a niche, high-risk/high-reward glass cannon that tries to exploit Wind Rider boosts and powerful STAB priority to delete foes before its poor bulk betrays it; in Regulation G it sits on the absolute fringe of viability, but a single Sucker Punch or Knock Off under Tailwind or Chlorophyll sun can still swing games if piloted perfectly.</OUTPUT>

input:
Create the 'full_analysis' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Shiftry": {"Abilities": {"windrider": 3.169000160069455, "chlorophyll": 0.20825280958503073, "pickpocket": 0.0}, "Items": {"focussash": 0.8121121287520456}, "Spreads": {"Adamant:0/252/0/0/4/252": 0.7820422543412427}, "Moves": ["knockoff", "suckerpunch", "protect", "leafblade"], "Tera Types": {"dark": 0.7251335922807615}, "Teammates": ["Gholdengo", "Ursaluna", "Ursaluna-Bloodmoon", "Talonflame", "Dragonite", "Porygon2"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>With paper-thin natural bulk and a merely respectable 100 / 90 offensive stat pair, Shiftry’s only ticket to relevance is stacking as many multipliers as possible. Wind Rider grants a free +1 Attack when hit by a wind move or when an ally uses Tailwind, turning Shiftry into a 140-Base-Attack menace without wasting a turn to set up. Once boosted, STAB Sucker Punch (priority) and Knock Off (removal + high BP) give it immediate, board-wide pressure, while Leaf Blade covers Rock- and Water-types that shrug off Dark damage. Tera Dark is taken on three quarters of sets because it amplifies both STABs and turns Sucker Punch into a nuclear 80 → 120 BP option, letting Shiftry pick off faster threats such as Flutter Mane, Dragapult, and weakened Terapagos before they move. Focus Sash is the only common item: it guarantees Shiftry survives at least one hit so it can either retaliate or get a Protect read for partner positioning. Adamant 252/252 spreads maximise damage and ensure a 75% chance to OHKO 0 HP Flutter Mane through Tera Dark, while the remaining 4 EVs are dropped into Sp. Def to slightly improve its poor special bulk. Chlorophyll is occasionally run on sun teams, but the data show Wind Rider is overwhelmingly preferred because Tailwind is ubiquitous and self-triggering the boost is more reliable than depending on nine-turn sun. Pickpocket remains a non-factor. Overall Shiftry is a matchup fish: into teams that rely on Tailwind or lack Fake Out / priority of their own, it can feel oppressive; into more traditional Incineroar / Rillaboard cores it struggles to get on the field at all.</OUTPUT>

input:
Draft the 'matchup_overview' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Shiftry": {"Abilities": {"windrider": 3.169000160069455, "chlorophyll": 0.20825280958503073, "pickpocket": 0.0}, "Items": {"focussash": 0.8121121287520456}, "Spreads": {"Adamant:0/252/0/0/4/252": 0.7820422543412427}, "Moves": ["knockoff", "suckerpunch", "protect", "leafblade"], "Tera Types": {"dark": 0.7251335922807615}, "Teammates": ["Gholdengo", "Ursaluna", "Ursaluna-Bloodmoon", "Talonflame", "Dragonite", "Porygon2"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Shiftry loves opposing Tailwind and hates Incineroar. Against common Regulation G cores it threatens Flutter Mane, Calyrex-I, Ogerpon-W, and slower support like Amoonguss or Porygon2, but folds instantly to any faster Fake Out, priority, or spread that breaks Sash before it acts. Rain and sun both help and hinder it: sun weakens Leaf Blade but doubles its Speed under Chlorophyll, while rain boosts its Water weakness yet makes Sucker Punch more valuable into sun-boosted threats. Into stall or Trick Room it can act as a reverse-sweeper, picking off wounded setters, but full Trick Room teams that drop it to -2 or -3 Speed render Sucker Punch useless. Steel-types such as Gholdengo, Kingambit, and Corviknight completely blank its STABs and force the Leaf Blade slot, making prediction imperative. Finally, any multi-hit user (Glaive Rush Dragonite, Baxcalibur, Maushold) or Rocky Helmet contact punishers can break Sash and end Shiftry’s game on the spot.</OUTPUT>

input:
Write a detailed 'role_description' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Shiftry": {"Abilities": {"windrider": 3.169000160069455, "chlorophyll": 0.20825280958503073, "pickpocket": 0.0}, "Items": {"focussash": 0.8121121287520456}, "Spreads": {"Adamant:0/252/0/0/4/252": 0.7820422543412427}, "Moves": ["knockoff", "suckerpunch", "protect", "leafblade"], "Tera Types": {"dark": 0.7251335922807615}, "Teammates": ["Gholdengo", "Ursaluna", "Ursaluna-Bloodmoon", "Talonflame", "Dragonite", "Porygon2"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Shiftry’s primary role is a mid-speed, self-boosting offensive pivot that functions as both a Tailwind deterrent and a late-game cleaner. It is brought to teams that already plan on clicking Tailwind themselves, guaranteeing Wind Rider activation without relying on the opponent. Once at +1 it becomes a priority attacker that trades one-for-one at worst and can snowball if given free turns. Protect is mandatory to stall out opposing speed control, enable partner targeting, and keep Sash intact. In practice Shiftry is deployed as a surprise factor: most opponents assume the slot is a more standard Tailwind attacker like Dragonite or Tornadus, and may mis-play the Sucker Punch mind-games early on.</OUTPUT>

input:
Write a detailed 'synergy_breakdown' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Shiftry": {"Abilities": {"windrider": 3.169000160069455, "chlorophyll": 0.20825280958503073, "pickpocket": 0.0}, "Items": {"focussash": 0.8121121287520456}, "Spreads": {"Adamant:0/252/0/0/4/252": 0.7820422543412427}, "Moves": ["knockoff", "suckerpunch", "protect", "leafblade"], "Tera Types": {"dark": 0.7251335922807615}, "Teammates": ["Gholdengo", "Ursaluna", "Ursaluna-Bloodmoon", "Talonflame", "Dragonite", "Porygon2"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>The most common partners—Gholdengo, Ursaluna, Ursaluna-Bloodmoon, Talonflame, Dragonite, and Porygon2—paint a clear picture of a bulky-offence core that wants to control speed while breaking walls. Gholdengo blocks opposing Tailwind (and therefore priority Tornadus) with its own, while also immune to Fake Out, letting Shiftry receive the boost unimpeded. Both Ursaluna forms appreciate Dark- and Ghost-types removed, which Shiftry can accomplish with Knock Off or Sucker Punch; in return they obliterate Steel- and Rock-types that wall Shiftry. Talonflame provides fast Tailwind and can pivot with Flip Turn into Shiftry for a safe boost, whereas Dragonite offers bulk, priority Extremespeed to finish what Sucker Punch starts, and defensive Tera to soak Ice- and Fairy-type hits aimed at Shiftry. Finally, Porygon2 supplies Trick Room reversal, Ice Beam coverage for Dragonite, and Download boosts that soften special walls for Shiftry’s mixed pressure. The overarching synergy is simple: keep Tailwind up, remove Steel-types, and ensure Shiftry can attack twice before dying.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>The statistically dominant set is already optimal: Adamant nature, 252 Atk / 4 SpD / 252 Spe, holding Focus Sash with Wind Rider. Moves should be Knock Off / Sucker Punch / Leaf Blade / Protect. Tera Type must be Dark; no alternative Tera provides equivalent power and coverage. If running Chlorophyll instead (only advised on dedicated sun), swap the speed EVs into HP and run Life Orb to secure KOs on neutral targets, though this is markedly less consistent. No other item sees meaningful usage—Assault Vest fails to patch its bulk enough, Choice Band locks it into prediction-heavy mind-games, and Weakness Policy requires too much support to trigger reliably.</OUTPUT>

input:
Create the 'weaknesses_and_counters' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Shiftry": {"Abilities": {"windrider": 3.169000160069455, "chlorophyll": 0.20825280958503073, "pickpocket": 0.0}, "Items": {"focussash": 0.8121121287520456}, "Spreads": {"Adamant:0/252/0/0/4/252": 0.7820422543412427}, "Moves": ["knockoff", "suckerpunch", "protect", "leafblade"], "Tera Types": {"dark": 0.7251335922807615}, "Teammates": ["Gholdengo", "Ursaluna", "Ursaluna-Bloodmoon", "Talonflame", "Dragonite", "Porygon2"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Incineroar is public enemy #1: Fake Out into Parting Shot or Flare Blitz breaks Sash and drops Attack, neutering Shiftry for the remainder of the game. Priority from opposing Sucker Punch users (Kingambit, Ting-Lu under Tera Dark, opposing Shiftry) can turn the same mind-games back on it. Faster Tailwind setters like Tornadus-I and Iron Jugulis can simply click Tailwind again after Wind Rider, denying the speed advantage. Multi-hit moves—Population Bomb Maushold, Glaive Rush Dragonite, Baxcalibur—ignore Sash, while Rocky Helmet or Iron Barbs punish contact attempts. Steel-types that do not fear Leaf Blade (Corviknight, Gholdengo, Tera-Steel Kyurem) can stall out boosts and KO back with Body Press or Make It Rain. Finally, any spread move that targets both slots (Dazzling Gleam, Rock Slide, Heat Wave) can score the double KO if Shiftry’s partner is also frail, so wide-guard support or careful positioning is essential.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Regulation G bulky Tailwind: Gholdengo @ Choice Specs (Trick, Shadow Ball, Make It Rain, Protect), Shiftry @ Focus Sash (Knock Off, Sucker Punch, Leaf Blade, Protect), Ursaluna-Bloodmoon @ Assault Vest (Blood Moon, Earth Power, Hyper Voice, Ice Spinner), Talonflame @ Sharp Beak (Tailwind, Brave Bird, Flare Blitz, Protect), Porygon2 @ Eviolite (Trick Room, Ice Beam, Recover, Ally Switch), Iron Hands @ Sitrus Berry (Fake Out, Drain Punch, Volt Switch, Wild Charge). Lead Gholdengo + Shiftry: click Tailwind, trigger Wind Rider, and immediately pressure opposing Fairy- and Ghost-types. Rotate into Ursaluna-Bloodmoon or Iron Hands to break Steel-types, use Porygon2 to reverse opposing Trick Room, and keep Talonflame in the back for late-game Tailwind refresh. The core offers both offensive burst and defensive flexibility, with Shiftry acting as the surprise nuke that cleans once shared checks are weakened.</OUTPUT>

input:

<DATA>{"Gholdengo": {"Abilities": {"goodasgold": 2150.0674341869494}, "Items": {"lifeorb": 0.40078689096573855, "choicespecs": 0.283475718438179}, "Spreads": {"Modest:4/0/0/252/0/252": 0.1762777004844856}, "Moves": ["makeitrain", "shadowball", "nastyplot", "protect"], "Tera Types": {"water": 0.37287903306152614, "steel": 0.45402448761654873}, "Teammates": ["Incineroar", "Archaludon", "Sneasler", "Rillaboom", "Dragonite", "Ursaluna-Bloodmoon"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Gholdengo is a premier special attacker in VGC, leveraging its signature ability Good as Gold—an immunity to status moves—to serve as an unflinching offensive pivot. With a Life Orb or Choice Specs set, it fires off high-powered STAB Make It Rain and Shadow Ball while setting up Nasty Plot to break through bulky cores. Its flexible Tera options in Water and Steel let it flip match-ups on the fly, and it slots naturally into balanced squads alongside Incineroar, Archaludon and Rillaboom that provide speed control, Fake Out and terrain support.</OUTPUT>

input:
Write the 'full_analysis' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Gholdengo": {"Abilities": {"goodasgold": 2150.0674341869494}, "Items": {"lifeorb": 0.40078689096573855, "choicespecs": 0.283475718438179}, "Spreads": {"Modest:4/0/0/252/0/252": 0.1762777004844856}, "Moves": ["makeitrain", "shadowball", "nastyplot", "protect"], "Tera Types": {"water": 0.37287903306152614, "steel": 0.45402448761654873}, "Teammates": ["Incineroar", "Archaludon", "Sneasler", "Rillaboom", "Dragonite", "Ursaluna-Bloodmoon"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Good as Gold is the engine that makes Gholdengo oppressive: ignoring Taunt, Thunder Wave, Spore or Parting Shot means it can click Nasty Plot or attack with impunity against would-be disruptors. Modest 252/252 spread maximises offensive output, allowing +2 Life Orb Make It Rain to OHKO neutral targets up to 140/95 bulk and 2HKO most dedicated walls. Shadow Ball provides perfect neutral coverage alongside Make It Rain, hitting opposing Ghosts and Psychics while avoiding the Sp. Atk drop from Make It Rain when cleaning late-game. Protect is mandatory in doubles to shield Gholdengo from double-targets and buy a turn for partners to reposition or reset weather/terrain. Tera Water removes the Fire weakness and turns Gholdengo into a rain-proof sweeper that can survive a +1 Ursaluna-Bloodmoon Earthquake, while Tera Steel grants a clutch Toxic immunity and turns it into a pseudo-steel that resists opposing Gholdengo Shadow Balls and Rillaboom Glide. Life Orb is the default for flexibility, but Choice Specs turns every attack into a nuke—just be wary of lock-in versus dynamic boards. The modest nature is favoured over timid because the current metagame’s speed tiers centre around 90–100 base; Gholdengo naturally underspeeds most threats it wants to out-damage rather than outrun, and the extra power secures KOs on bulky Rotom-W, Tornadus-T and Ting-Lu after a single Nasty Plot.</OUTPUT>

input:
Write the 'matchup_overview' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Gholdengo": {"Abilities": {"goodasgold": 2150.0674341869494}, "Items": {"lifeorb": 0.40078689096573855, "choicespecs": 0.283475718438179}, "Spreads": {"Modest:4/0/0/252/0/252": 0.1762777004844856}, "Moves": ["makeitrain", "shadowball", "nastyplot", "protect"], "Tera Types": {"water": 0.37287903306152614, "steel": 0.45402448761654873}, "Teammates": ["Incineroar", "Archaludon", "Sneasler", "Rillaboom", "Dragonite", "Ursaluna-Bloodmoon"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Gholdengo bullies status-reliant teams—Amoonguss, Pelipper rain, or Grimmsnarl screens—by ignoring their primary disruption tools. It pressures most restricted legends (Kyogre, Miraidon, Calyrex-S) with neutral STAB and sets up freely on predicted Protects or switches. Against sun, it can Tera Water to stomach Chi-Yar Overheat and retaliate; versus sand it can Tera Steel to stomach Excadrill Rock Slide. It struggles versus specially bulky Dark-types like Incineroar and Kingambit, which can Knock Off its item or Sucker Punch for heavy damage, and versus fast physical Dragons such as Dragonite or opposing Flutter Mane that outspeed and KO before a boost. Terrain wars matter: Rillaboom Glide under Grassy Terrain can KO after prior damage, while opposing Psychic Terrain from Indeedee blocks priority Sucker Punch partners from finishing off weakened threats. Overall it is a meta-defining breaker that forces every team to carry either a strong Dark-type or a way to OHKO it before it sets up.</OUTPUT>

input:
Write a detailed 'role_description' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Gholdengo": {"Abilities": {"goodasgold": 2150.0674341869494}, "Items": {"lifeorb": 0.40078689096573855, "choicespecs": 0.283475718438179}, "Spreads": {"Modest:4/0/0/252/0/252": 0.1762777004844856}, "Moves": ["makeitrain", "shadowball", "nastyplot", "protect"], "Tera Types": {"water": 0.37287903306152614, "steel": 0.45402448761654873}, "Teammates": ["Incineroar", "Archaludon", "Sneasler", "Rillaboom", "Dragonite", "Ursaluna-Bloodmoon"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Gholdengo is the archetypal set-up special sweeper and secondary lead. It comes in on passive supports or predicted Protects, uses the free turn to Nasty Plot, then fires spread or single-target attacks to dismantle the enemy core. Because Good as Gold blocks Fake Out and status, it is one of the safest Pokémon to position next to a support like Incineroar or Rillaboom that provides speed control via Parting Shot or Glide. After a boost it functions as a win-condition that must be answered immediately, forcing double-targets or Terastalisation from the opponent. Mid-game it doubles as a pivot that can Protect while partners reset terrain or weather, and late-game it cleans with Shadow Ball once spread moves have chipped the bench.</OUTPUT>

input:
Create the 'synergy_breakdown' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Gholdengo": {"Abilities": {"goodasgold": 2150.0674341869494}, "Items": {"lifeorb": 0.40078689096573855, "choicespecs": 0.283475718438179}, "Spreads": {"Modest:4/0/0/252/0/252": 0.1762777004844856}, "Moves": ["makeitrain", "shadowball", "nastyplot", "protect"], "Tera Types": {"water": 0.37287903306152614, "steel": 0.45402448761654873}, "Teammates": ["Incineroar", "Archaludon", "Sneasler", "Rillaboom", "Dragonite", "Ursaluna-Bloodmoon"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Incineroar is the ideal partner: Intimidate and Parting Shot soften physical attackers that threaten Gholdengo, while Gholdengo in return ignores Parting Shot drops and nukes the Water-types that wall Incineroar. Archaludon shares a Steel typing and appreciates Gholdengo’s ability to remove opposing Ground-types and Rotom-W; together they form a sturdy Steel backbone that can Tera Water/Steel to flip match-ups. Rillaboom provides priority Glide to finish off weakened threats after a Make It Rain drop, sets Grassy Terrain to recover chip, and breaks opposing screens or Sturdy with Knock Off. Sneasler offers fast Poison-type pressure and can activate Weakness Policy on purpose to snowball, while Gholdengo punges Psychic-types for it. Dragonite and Ursaluna-Bloodmoon are powerful physical breakers that enjoy Gholdengo removing bulky Waters and Corviknight; Dragonite can also provide Tailwind to patch Gholdengo’s middling speed or use Inner Focus to ignore Fake Out alongside Good as Gold. In return Gholdengo covers their Fairy and Ice weaknesses with STAB Shadow Ball and Make It Rain respectively.</OUTPUT>

input:
Write the 'full_analysis' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Incineroar": {"Abilities": {"intimidate": 1849.89491476173, "blaze": 1.8913728885438532}, "Items": {"safetygoggles": 0.44532400149758045, "assaultvest": 0.21163262743097871}, "Spreads": {}, "Moves": ["partingshot", "fakeout", "flareblitz", "knockoff"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.5878268087727537, "grass": 0.24986993222417095}, "Teammates": ["Gholdengo", "Amoonguss", "Rillaboom", "Ursaluna-Bloodmoon", "Sneasler", "Dragonite"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Intimidate is the engine that makes Incineroar indispensable: dropping the opponent’s Attack on entry immediately swings damage races, while Fake Out buys a free turn for partners to reposition or set up. Parting Shot is the single safest move in doubles: it neuters special attackers, triggers your own switch, and preserves momentum in a single click. Flare Blitz gives the set a legitimate 120 BP STAB nuke that OHKOes max-HP Amoonguss after a burn or chip, and Knock Off deletes opposing items—most importantly removing Heavy-Duty Boots from Gholdengo or Leftovers from Ursaluna-Bloodmoon. Safety Goggles variants blank opposing Amoonguss’s Spore and Rage Powder, turning the usual mushroom into setup fodder, while Assault Vest sets sacrifice Parting Shot but tank Moonblast from Flutter Mane and Ice Beam from Iron Bundle. Tera Ghost removes the Fighting weakness, blocks Fake Out, and turns Parting Shot into a pseudo-immunity vs. Extreme Speed Dragonite, whereas Tera Grass flips the Water matchup and lets Incineroar survive Rillaboom’s Grassy Glide. EV spreads are almost always 252 HP / 116 Def / 140 SpD with a Careful nature, living Life Orb Gholdengo Make It Rain and Jolly Chien-Pao Ice Spinner while still retaliating for heavy damage. The cat’s low Speed is a feature, not a bug: moving last guarantees ally protection, slow pivots, and the ability to underspeed opposing Incineroar in mirror Parting-Shot wars.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Incineroar dominates physical attackers—Chien-Pao, Kingambit, and Dragonite all lose the 1v1 after Intimidate and burn chance—but folds quickly to special attackers that ignore Attack drops: Flutter Mane, Iron Bundle, and Iron Moth all 2HKO with STAB. Water-types like Rotom-Wash and Dondozo wall Flare Blitz and threaten back with Hydro Pump, while Ground-types such as Garchomp and Lando-T take neutral from Knock Off and retaliate with Earthquake. The mirror matchup is a momentum sink: both sides spam Parting Shot until one player runs out of safe switches. Tera Ghost versions beat Fighting-types but invite opposing Knock Off spam; Tera Grass beats Waters but loses to Gholdengo. Overall, Incineroar is at its best vs. balanced or hyper-offense builds that rely on physical burst, and at its worst versus special rain or psy-spam archetypes that overload its weaker special bulk.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Ursaluna-Bloodmoon": {"Abilities": {"mindseye": 1601.977697552006}, "Items": {"lifeorb": 0.2788775780342926, "assaultvest": 0.3917231616383425, "leftovers": 0.25121522154857673}, "Spreads": {}, "Moves": ["bloodmoon", "hypervoice", "protect", "earthpower"], "Tera Types": {"normal": 0.3769252282197783, "electric": 0.23967031618627155}, "Teammates": ["Incineroar", "Rillaboom", "Annihilape", "Ninetales-Alola", "Gholdengo", "Dragonite"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Ursaluna-Bloodmoon is a fearsome special attacker in VGC, leveraging its signature Blood Moon to nuke most neutral targets while enjoying perfect accuracy in Misty Terrain thanks to Mind’s Eye. With Assault Vest or Life Orb as the two most common items, it can either bolster its special bulk to tank key hits or push its already sky-high damage output to oppressive levels. A spread of 212 HP / 4 Def / 252 SpA / 4 SpD / 36 Modest reaches 200 HP for Life Orb numbers, maximizes Blood Moon’s power, and outspeeds uninvested base 50s such as Amoonguss and Torkoal. Tera Normal turns Blood Moon into a 180 BP STAB nuke that cleanly OHKOes even Dynamax Kyogre, while Tera Electric patches up its Flying weakness and lets it blast Corviknight and bulky Waters with Tera-boosted Hyper Voice. Protect is mandatory for positioning next to redirection or Fake Out, Earth Power rounds the coverage by nailing Toxapex and Gholdengo for solid damage, and Hyper Voice provides spread pressure that bypasses Follow Me. In practice the bear functions as a mid-game breaker that can trade two-for-one once Terrain is secured, or a late-game cleaner under Tailwind or versus a depleted field.</OUTPUT>

input:
Write the 'full_analysis' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Ursaluna-Bloodmoon": {"Abilities": {"mindseye": 1601.977697552006}, "Items": {"lifeorb": 0.2788775780342926, "assaultvest": 0.3917231616383425, "leftovers": 0.25121522154857673}, "Spreads": {}, "Moves": ["bloodmoon", "hypervoice", "protect", "earthpower"], "Tera Types": {"normal": 0.3769252282197783, "electric": 0.23967031618627155}, "Teammates": ["Incineroar", "Rillaboom", "Annihilape", "Ninetales-Alola", "Gholdengo", "Dragonite"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Blood Moon’s 140 BP, 100% accuracy, and single-target Ground-immune profile make it the most spammable nuke in the current format. Mind’s Eye ignores accuracy drops and the evasion granted by opponent’s Bright Powder or Snow Cloak, while also letting Ursaluna-Bloodmoon hit Ghost-types with Normal moves and ignore the damage reduction of Protect, turning standard Protect stalling tactics into risky gambles. 140 special attack with Life Orb or the 1.2× boost from Assault Vest means that even resisted Blood Moons deal 40–50% to neutral Dynamax targets, allowing the bear to soften checks such as Corviknight, Rotom-W, and bulky Garganacl for teammates. The EV spread listed above guarantees that Ursaluna-Bloodmoon lives a +1 Max Airstream from Dragonite and a Specs Tera Water Spout from Kyogre in Rain, while still 2HKOing most of the tier with Blood Moon. Leftovers variants sacrifice immediate power for longevity and are usually paired with Aurora Veil or Reflect/Light Screen to create setup windows for partners like Dragonite or Rillaboom. Hyper Voice is deceptally strong after STAB and spread modifiers, doing ~35% to both foes on the field and breaking Focus Sashes on frail leads such as Talonflame or Indeedee. Earth Power is the only coverage needed because Blood Moon already hits every Grass, Water, and Psychic-type for neutral or better damage; the slot is flexible and some teams drop it for Calm Mind, Substitute, or even Tera Blast Ice to lure Landorus-T and Dragonite. Tera Normal is the default because it maximises Blood Moon and grants a Ghost immunity, flipping matchups versus Aegislash and Dragapult. Tera Electric is the next most popular, removing the Flying weakness and giving a BoltBeam-esque coverage alongside Hyper Voice, while also letting Ursaluna-Bloodmoon overload common Water-type pivots such as Pelipper and Toxapex. The bear’s biggest drawback is its glacial 52 base Speed tier, which forces it to rely on Tailwind, Trick Room, or priority control from Incineroar and Rillaboom to move before key threats like Flutter Mane and Iron Valiant.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Ursaluna-Bloodmoon": {"Abilities": {"mindseye": 1601.977697552006}, "Items": {"lifeorb": 0.2788775780342926, "assaultvest": 0.3917231616383425, "leftovers": 0.25121522154857673}, "Spreads": {}, "Moves": ["bloodmoon", "hypervoice", "protect", "earthpower"], "Tera Types": {"normal": 0.3769252282197783, "electric": 0.23967031618627155}, "Teammates": ["Incineroar", "Rillaboom", "Annihilape", "Ninetales-Alola", "Gholdengo", "Dragonite"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Ursaluna-Bloodmoon demolishes most offense cores that rely on frail pivots like Dragapult, Iron Bundle, and Meowscarada, as Blood Moon cleanly OHKOes all of them before they can retaliate. It also pressures common balance staples such as Toxapex, Garganacl, and Amoonguss, forcing them to Recover or Protect on prediction lest they fall to two consecutive nukes. Against rain, the bear 2HKOs Pelipper and can Tera Electric to shrug off Hurricane, though it must watch for Specs Hydro Pump in return. Sun teams are more problematic: Torkoal underspeeds and can burn with Heat Wave or set Sun for Chlorophyll Venusaur, which outspeeds and puts the bear to sleep. Trick Room variants appreciate Ursaluna-Bloodmoon’s low Speed, turning it into a terrifying win-condition under reversed speeds, but must still beware of priority from Shadow Sneak Aegislash or Sucker Punch Kingambit. Stall or semi-stall builds that stack Intimidate and recovery—Incineroar + Corviknight + Dondozo—can stall out Life Orb recoil and PP, but crumble if the bear carries Substitute or Calm Mind. Ghost-types such as Aegislash and Mimikyu can switch into Blood Moon once, but risk a 2HKO from Hyper Voice or a follow-up Tera Normal Blood Moon that ignores Protect. Overall, Ursaluna-Bloodmoon dictates the tempo of the game: if it clicks Blood Moon freely, the opponent bleigh tempo; if it is forced to Protect or switch, the opponent gains momentum.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Ursaluna-Bloodmoon is a special wall-breaker and late-game cleaner that compresses the roles of nuker, Terrain abuser, and Ghost answer into one slot. It fits best on bulky offense or balance squads that can provide speed control (Tailwind from Dragonite or Alolan-Ninetales), redirection (Indeedee-F, Togekiss), or passive chip (Rocky Helmet Incineroar, Rough Skin Garchomp) to soften checks. The Assault Vest set acts as a pivot that can switch into Flutter Mane’s Shadow Ball or Gholdengo’s Make It Rain, retaliate with Earth Power or Blood Moon, and maintain offensive momentum. Life Orb variants are more explosive and prefer to lead early alongside Fake Out or Follow Me to guarantee a first-turn kill, then return later once checks are weakened. Because Blood Moon ignores Protect, the bear is one of the few Pokémon that can punish double-Protect stalling and force 2v2 trades in your favor. Its Ghost immunity after Tera Normal also lets it serve as an emergency spinblocker versus Rapid Spin Gholdengo or Iron Treads, preserving hazards for teammates like Gholdengo or Dragonite. In Tailwind mirrors, Ursaluna-Bloodmoon becomes a 90-base Speed monster that outspeeds and OHKOes Timid Flutter Mane, turning the mirror on its head. In Trick Room, its natural 52 Speed becomes an asset, outslowing even minimum Speed Torkoal and Dondozo under reversed speeds. The bear’s role is therefore flexible: breaker early, pivot mid, or cleaner late, depending on team composition and opposing archetype.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Ursaluna-Bloodmoon": {"Abilities": {"mindseye": 1601.977697552006}, "Items": {"lifeorb": 0.2788775780342926, "assaultvest": 0.3917231616383425, "leftovers": 0.25121522154857673}, "Spreads": {}, "Moves": ["bloodmoon", "hypervoice", "protect", "earthpower"], "Tera Types": {"normal": 0.3769252282197783, "electric": 0.23967031618627155}, "Teammates": ["Incineroar", "Rillaboom", "Annihilape", "Ninetales-Alola", "Gholdengo", "Dragonite"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>The single biggest check to Ursaluna-Bloodmoon is speed: any offensive Pokémon that naturally outspeeds and carries a super-effective move—Flutter Mane with Moonblast, Iron Valiant with Spirit Break, or Chien-Pao with Ice Spinner—can OHKO before it moves. Priority also bypasses its low Speed: Shadow Sneak Aegislash, Sucker Punch Kingambit, and Aqua Jet Dondozo all do 60–70% and force Protect or Tera. Intimidate cycling from Incineroar and Landorus-T drops its modest 140 SpA to manageable levels, letting Corviknight and Rotom-W recover off the damage. Bulky resists such as Toxapex and Dondozo can Toxic or Haze away Calm Mind boosts, though they must beware of Tera Electric Hyper Voice. Sun teams with Torkoal and Venusaur outspeed and sleep or burn the bear, while Chlorophyll Venusaur cleanly OHKOes with Leaf Storm. Wide Guard Aegislash or Iron Hands completely blanks Blood Moon and Hyper Voice for a turn, buying momentum. Finally, the 10% Mind’s Eye flinch chance is irrelevant, but the 8 PP on Blood Moon can be stalled by repeated Protects and recovery; once Blood Moon is gone, the bear’s damage drops markedly. To counter it, bring speed control, priority, or a sturdy resist that can recover and force it to waste PP. If you can deny Tailwind or Trick Room, Ursaluna-Bloodmoon becomes much more manageable.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Team: Incineroar / Rillaboom / Ursaluna-Bloodmoon / Alolan-Ninetales / Gholdengo / Dragonite. Core concept: bulky offense with dual Terrain and speed control. Incineroar provides Fake Out, Intimidate, and U-turn momentum; Rillaboom sets Grassy Terrain and removes opposing Psychic Terrain while offering priority Glide. Alolan-Ninetales sets Aurora Veil with Light Clay and provides Freeze-Dry for Water-types; it also carries Helping Hand to boost Blood Moon into guaranteed OHKO thresholds versus Dynamax targets. Gholdengo blocks Rapid Spin, sets hazards, and beats opposing Fairy-types with Steel Beam. Dragonite offers Tailwind and Tera-boosted Extreme Speed to clean after Ursaluna-Bloodmoon has punched holes. The bear itself runs Life Orb Tera Normal as the primary win-condition. Lead options include Incineroar + Ninetales for Veil + Fake Out, or Rillaboom + Ursaluna-Bloodmoon for immediate Terrain and a turn-one nuke. Versus Sun, lead Ninetales + Dragonite to set Tailwind and KO Venusaur with Ice Spinner. Versus Trick Room, lead Incineroar + Gholdengo to block Ghost-spin and pressure setters with Flare Blitz + Steel Beam. The team is weak to opposing Tailwind Flutter Mane, so preserve Incineroar’s health and consider Tera Dark on the cat to survive Moonblast. Overall the squad balances power, bulk, and speed control, letting Ursaluna-Bloodmoon click Blood Moon freely while the supporting cast covers every major archetype in the current meta.</OUTPUT>

With Fake Out pressure, powerful Wood Hammer/Grassy Glide coverage, and High Horsepower to nail Steels, it compresses speed control, terrain, and damage into one slot. Its most common set runs Assault Vest for surprise special bulk, Tera Fire to flip the Fire weakness, and is almost always paired with Incineroar for classic “Grass-Fire-Steel” synergy or with fast breakers like Sneasler and Bloodmoon Ursaluna that appreciate terrain chip and priority support.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Rillaboom": {"Abilities": {"grassysurge": 1589.6471445076622, "overgrow": 1.2058652370517196}, "Items": {"assaultvest": 0.7609200177033827}, "Spreads": {}, "Moves": ["fakeout", "woodhammer", "grassyglide", "highhorsepower"], "Tera Types": {"fire": 0.7402544531374183}, "Teammates": ["Incineroar", "Sneasler", "Ursaluna-Bloodmoon", "Gholdengo", "Ninetales-Alola", "Dragonite"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Grassy Surge is the single biggest reason Rillaboom sees 1,589 usage points in the data set; the immediate terrain not only grants its signature move Grassy Glide a pseudo-Quick-Attack level of speed control but also halves the damage of Earthquake and Bulldoze for the entire team, neutering one of the most common spread options in the format. The Assault Vest build capitalizes on Rillaboom’s naturally high HP stat to let it survive key special hits such as Life-Orb Flutter Mane Moonblast or Gholdengo Shadow Ball, retaliate with a STAB Wood Hammer or super-effective High Horsepower, and still pick off faster threats with Grassy Glide. EV spreads are not listed, but standard competitive sets aim for enough Speed to outrun uninvested base 70s (144 EVs with a neutral nature) while dumping the rest into HP and Attack; Tera Fire is taken on 74% of teams to bait opposing Fire-type attacks and remove the 4× weakness, turning would-be KOes into setup opportunities for partners. Fake Out provides invaluable tempo, allowing teammates such as Sneasler or Bloodmoon Ursaluna to set up Swords Dance or Blood Moon under protection, while the double-Grass STAB combination of Wood Hammer and Grassy Glide gives Rillaboom the strongest priority in the game and a nuke option against Kyogre, Groudon, and bulky Waters. High Horsepower rounds the set by hitting Toxapex, Gholdengo, and Glimmora for super-effective damage, preventing Rillaboom from being walled by Steel or Poison types. Because it carries no speed-boosting item, Rillaboom fits best on balanced or bulk-offense squads that can provide Tailwind or speed control elsewhere, hence its synergy with fast pivots like Alolan Ninetales (Aurora Veil) and Dragonite (Extreme Speed) that appreciate terrain chip and Fake Out support.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Rillaboom warps the metagame around terrain mirrors: against other Grassy Surge users it becomes a speed-tie for Glide priority, while versus Electric Surge teams it instantly removes Psychic Terrain, re-enabling Fake Out and priority moves against Indeedee–Armarouge or Tapu Lele setups. Offensively it pressures Kyogre, Gastrodon, and bulky Waters, but fears Zapdos, Tornadus, and any fast Flying-type with Hurricane; Tera Fire patches the Fire weakness, yet Sun-boosted Eruptions from Groudon or Torkoal still OHKO through Vest. Rillaboom also struggles against Ice- and Fairy-type restricteds like Calyrex-Ice and Flutter Mane if it has already Terastallized, and can be worn down quickly by Iron Barbs/Rocky Helmet or repeated Wood Hammer recoil. Defensively, it checks Ground-spam cores by halving their spread damage, but must watch for Mold Breaker Excadrill or Iron Treads that ignore terrain. In tailwind or versus Trick Room it flips from attacker to support, using Fake Out to deny turns and Glide to pick off weakened threats, making the matchup dynamic rather than static.</OUTPUT>

Because it holds Assault Vest, it cannot provide Protect or status, so it must rely on raw bulk and positioning; consequently it is less a support mon and more a bulky attacker that happens to bring free terrain. Its Fairy/Flex Tera options, single-digit usage stats and synergy with top-tier glue Pokémon like Incineroar and Rillaboom make it a surprise factor rather than a staple, yet it can single-handedly swing match-ups where opposing Tailwind or Trick Room is mandatory.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Dragonite": {"Abilities": {"multiscale": 1209.5531455400278, "innerfocus": 216.0572572808025}, "Items": {"loadeddice": 0.7968275547965092}, "Spreads": {"Adamant:4/252/0/0/0/252": 0.3227065220731568}, "Moves": ["haze", "protect", "scaleshot", "tailwind"], "Tera Types": {"fairy": 0.4716164444807127, "steel": 0.24834140602241248}, "Teammates": ["Rillaboom", "Gholdengo", "Incineroar", "Ninetales-Alola", "Ursaluna-Bloodmoon", "Annihilape"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Multiscale is the engine that makes this set viable: at full HP Dragonite lives any unboosted super-effective hit in the format, allowing it to click Tailwind against the likes of Choice Specs Tornadus–Hurricane or Chien-Pao Ice Spinner, then retaliate or support next turn. Haze is an extremely rare but powerful tool in an era of Blood Moon, Dondozo, and Iron Hands setups, letting Dragonite erase all stat changes on both foes without targeting, bypassing Follow Me and Good as Gold. Scale Shot with Loaded Dice averages 3.5 hits, giving roughly a 66% chance to raise Speed; after one boost Dragonite reaches 490+ Speed in Tailwind, outpacing +1 Roaring Moon and neutral Speed Deoxys-S, turning it into a late-game win condition. Protect is mandatory doubles tech, while the last slot is almost always Tailwind—Dragonite’s primary reason for being considered. EVs maximize Atk and Speed with an Adamant nature: Multiscale already covers bulk, so the emphasis is on immediate damage and Speed ties versus other base-80s such as Modest Gholdengo or Adamant Kingambit. Tera Fairy removes the Dragon typing, granting neutrality to Ice and Dragon while providing a crucial immunity to opposing Dragon- and Dark-type spam; Tera Steel is an alternative that keeps Dragonite’s Flying type, giving it a handy Toxic immunity and turning it into a pseudo-steel wall versus Sylveon and Togekiss while still baiting Iron Head from opposing Fairies. The relatively low usage numbers (≈1.2k Multiscate vs >20k for Incineroar) mean opponents rarely prepare for Dragonite, so the surprise factor often translates into free turns.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Dragonite loves facing bulky setup cores—Dondozo, Tatsugiri, Iron Hands, and Calm Mind Gholdengo—because Haze instantly invalidates their win conditions while Multiscale ensures it survives the retaliation. Against hyper-offense it performs a more neutral role: Tailwind is still valuable, but Scale Shot speed boosts are harder to fish when spread damage is flying around. Rain and Sun both pressure Multiscale via spread Water Spout or Overheat, yet Tailwind can flip those speed match-ups and allow your own weather sweepers to move first. Dragonite struggles versus priority spam from Kingambit and Dragonite’s own Mirror Match; Fake Out + Double Target can break Multiscale pre-turn-one, so it appreciates partners that can redirect or tank those hits. Ice-type Pokémon like Chien-Pao and Baxcalibur are technically threatening but usually fail to OHKO through Multiscale, allowing Dragonite to either set Tailwind or Tera Fairy and survive. Trick Room is a mixed bag: if setters carry Rock Slide or Ice Punch they can KO Dragonite after Multiscale is gone, but if they rely on support damage Dragonite can Tailwind first, then Haze away the Trick Room buffs next turn.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Dragonite": {"Abilities": {"multiscale": 1209.5531455400278, "innerfocus": 216.0572572808025}, "Items": {"loadeddice": 0.7968275547965092}, "Spreads": {"Adamant:4/252/0/0/0/252": 0.3227065220731568}, "Moves": ["haze", "protect", "scaleshot", "tailwind"], "Tera Types": {"fairy": 0.4716164444807127, "steel": 0.24834140602241248}, "Teammates": ["Rillaboom", "Gholdengo", "Incineroar", "Ninetales-Alola", "Ursaluna-Bloodmoon", "Annihilape"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Multiscale is only active at full HP, so any form of chip—Stealth Rock in Bo3 formats, spread Icy Wind, or Rocky Helmet contact—immediately removes Dragonite’s safety net. Priority users like Kingambit and Breloom can KO after minor damage; a +1 Sucker Punch from Kingambit deals ~75% to uninvested Dragonite, finishing it after Life Orb round. Rock-type coverage (Rock Slide, Stone Edge) remains a clean OHKO even through Multiscale, so Tyranitar and Lycanroc-Dusk can punish Tailwind attempts. Ice Shard from Chien-Pao or Baxcalibur does ~60%, breaking Multiscale for partner follow-ups. Opposing Tailwind or Trick Room can invalidate Dragonite’s primary purpose, forcing it to Tera and gamble on Scale Shot boosts. Finally, because this set lacks recovery, residual damage from burn, poison, or Rocky Helmet will quickly render Dragonite useless, so status spreaders and Helmet tanks like Corviknight and Garganacl are soft counters.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Dragonite": {"Abilities": {"multiscale": 1209.5531455400278, "innerfocus": 216.0572572808025}, "Items": {"loadeddice": 0.7968275547965092}, "Spreads": {"Adamant:4/252/0/0/0/252": 0.3227065220731568}, "Moves": ["haze", "protect", "scaleshot", "tailwind"], "Tera Types": {"fairy": 0.4716164444807127, "steel": 0.24834140602241248}, "Teammates": ["Rillaboom", "Gholdengo", "Incineroar", "Ninetales-Alola", "Ursaluna-Bloodmoon", "Annihilape"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Rillaboom @ Assault Vest – Grassy Glide / Wood Hammer / Fake Out / Superpower – Incineroar @ Sitrus Berry – Flare Blitz / Parting Shot / Fake Out / Taunt – Dragonite @ Loaded Dice – Tailwind / Scale Shot / Haze / Protect – Gholdengo @ Life Orb – Make It Rain / Shadow Ball / Protect / Trick – Ninetales-A @ Light Clay – Blizzard / Moonblast / Aurora Veil / Protect – Ursaluna-Bloodmoon @ Choice Specs – Blood Moon / Hyper Voice / Focus Blast / Protect. Lead Dragonite + Incineroar: Fake Out plus Tailwind guarantees speed control; versus setup you can Haze turn 2 while Incineroar Parting Shots into Gholdengo or Ursaluna to begin the offensive onslaught. Veil from Ninetales gives Dragonite a second life, while Rillaboom removes Electric and Water threats and provides late-game Glide cleanup. The team is weak to opposing Rock Slide, so Tera Steel on Dragonite and Tera Flying on Gholdengo are recommended early plays.</OUTPUT>
