<DATA>{"Annihilape": {"Abilities": {"defiant": 1274.5588729157382, "vitalspirit": 17.766750679056106, "innerfocus": 3.2154135006147357}, "Items": {"leftovers": 0.22321001060854886, "safetygoggles": 0.2506430473941002, "sitrusberry": 0.3136829449479308}, "Spreads": {"Jolly:180/68/4/0/4/252": 0.19094705070879317}, "Moves": ["bulkup", "protect", "drainpunch", "ragefist"], "Tera Types": {"water": 0.18861907911623707, "fire": 0.4257019949523642}, "Teammates": ["Incineroar", "Rillaboom", "Ursaluna-Bloodmoon", "Dragonite", "Gholdengo", "Ninetales-Alola"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Annihilape is a dangerous setup sweeper that leverages Bulk Up, Drain Punch recovery, and the ever-scaling power of Rage Fist to snowball through teams once it finds a free turn. Its near-exclusive reliance on Defiant discourages Intimidate cycling while letting it punish opposing stat-drops, and a blistering 252+ Speed Jolly spread allows it to outpace the crowded base-90–100 tier and most support Pokémon. With Tera Water or Fire it can flip key match-ups—turning resisted Waterfalls into neutral hits or shrugging off Fairy and Grass damage—and partners such as Incineroar, Rillaboom, and Alolan Ninetales provide Fake Out, Grassy Terrain chip, and Aurora Veil to buy the ape the single turn it often needs to begin its sweep.</OUTPUT>

input:
Write a detailed 'full_analysis' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Annihilape": {"Abilities": {"defiant": 1274.5588729157382, "vitalspirit": 17.766750679056106, "innerfocus": 3.2154135006147357}, "Items": {"leftovers": 0.22321001060854886, "safetygoggles": 0.2506430473941002, "sitrusberry": 0.3136829449479308}, "Spreads": {"Jolly:180/68/4/0/4/252": 0.19094705070879317}, "Moves": ["bulkup", "protect", "drainpunch", "ragefist"], "Tera Types": {"water": 0.18861907911623707, "fire": 0.4257019949523642}, "Teammates": ["Incineroar", "Rillaboom", "Ursaluna-Bloodmoon", "Dragonite", "Gholdengo", "Ninetales-Alola"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>The data show that virtually every serious Annihilape runs Defiant, underscoring its primary niche: punishing Intimidate and Snarl cycles while gaining +2 Attack for free. A Jolly 252 EV investment is non-negotiable; the ape needs the Speed tie against Flutter Mane, opposing base-91 scarfers, and the litany of bulky support Pokémon hovering around that benchmark. Bulk Up patches its merely decent base 110 Attack and pushes its already respectable bulk—110/80/90—to stalling thresholds, especially when combined with Drain Punch recovery. Rage Fist starts at 50 BP but climbs by 50 for every hit the ape endures, turning it into a 350 BP nuke after just six pings. Protect is omnipresent because it both scouts choice locks and accelerates Rage Fist stacking. Tera usage is split between Water (to remove a nasty Fairy weakness and neuter common Water-type moves) and Fire (to exploit Sun teams and remove a Grass weakness), with Water slightly edging out Fire in popularity. Itemization is surprisingly sparse—Leftovers, Safety Goggles, and Sitrus Berry each appear at under 0.4% usage—indicating that most players treat Annihilape as a disposable win-condition rather than a long-term tank. The preferred teammates form a balanced core: Incineroar for Fake Out and Intimidate, Rillaboom for priority Grassy Glide and terrain control, Ursaluna-Bloodmoon as a secondary breaker that lures similar checks, Dragonite for spread offense and Extreme Speed cleanup, Gholdengo for hazard control and spin-blocking, and Alolan Ninetales for Veil support and Blizzard spam. Together they compress speed control, priority, terrain, weather, and hazard removal into a single six-Pokémon roster that lets Annihilape focus on setting up.</OUTPUT>

input:
Produce the 'matchup_overview' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Annihilape": {"Abilities": {"defiant": 1274.5588729157382, "vitalspirit": 17.766750679056106, "innerfocus": 3.2154135006147357}, "Items": {"leftovers": 0.22321001060854886, "safetygoggles": 0.2506430473941002, "sitrusberry": 0.3136829449479308}, "Spreads": {"Jolly:180/68/4/0/4/252": 0.19094705070879317}, "Moves": ["bulkup", "protect", "drainpunch", "ragefist"], "Tera Types": {"water": 0.18861907911623707, "fire": 0.4257019949523642}, "Teammates": ["Incineroar", "Rillaboom", "Ursaluna-Bloodmoon", "Dragonite", "Gholdengo", "Ninetales-Alola"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Annihilape’s match-up spread is binary: if it sets up safely, it steamrolls; if it faces a faster Taunt, burn, or Fairy-type attacker before it can Bulk Up, it folds. The Jolly spread lets it outrun and OHKO most support Pokémon with a +1 Drain Punch or a moderately stacked Rage Fist, but it still fears faster threats like Iron Bundle, Choice Scarf Koraidon, and priority Brave Bird from Corviknight or Talonflame. Tera Water versions flip the script on Azumarill, Tapu Fini, and rain teams by removing a weakness and retaliating with boosted Rage Fist, while Tera Fire variants punish Sun teams and Rillaboom. Psychic-type attackers—Indeedee, Scream Tail, and Iron Crown—remain problematic unless the ape has already accumulated boosts. Ghost resistances are rare in the current metagame, so once Rage Fist reaches 200–250 BP it becomes nigh-unwallable, forcing opponents to out-offense rather than out-bulk the ape.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Annihilape is a mid-speed setup sweeper and punisher of stat-drops. It occupies the third or fourth slot on balanced offenses that already pack hazard control and speed control, entering play after Incineroar or Rillaboom has forced an Intimidate, after a teammate has fainted to accumulate the first Rage Fist boost, or under Aurora Veil. Its job is to force 50-50s: the opponent must either target the ape—feeding Rage Fist—or target its partner, risking a free Bulk Up. Once at +1/+1, Drain Punch recovers ~40% on standard spreads, meaning the ape can outlast neutral hits while continuing to boost. In endgames, it functions as a cleaner that outruns and KO’s most non-scarfers with a 300+ BP Rage Fist.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Archaludon is a niche but surprisingly effective special attacker in VGC, leveraging its signature move Electro Shot to become a potent late-game cleaner under rain. With Sturdy guaranteeing at least one turn of action and a Timid 252/252 spread maximizing Speed and Special Attack, it functions as a surprise win-condition that can flip momentum after opposing Fake Out and priority users have been chipped. While its movepool is shallow, the combination of STAB Flash Cannon and Draco Meteor backed by Tera Electric or Tera Ghost grants it just enough coverage to break through common cores, provided rain support from Pelipper is on the field to turn Electro Shot into a 100 % accurate, auto-charging 140 BP Thunder-cannon.</OUTPUT>

input:
Write the 'full_analysis' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Archaludon": {"Abilities": {"stamina": 555.7680171630652, "sturdy": 701.6491054914014, "stalwart": 34.114052027179696}, "Items": {"assaultvest": 0.4012769067035504, "powerherb": 0.5713834779254249}, "Spreads": {"Timid:4/0/0/252/0/252": 0.1799386204676905}, "Moves": ["electroshot", "flashcannon", "dracometeor", "protect"], "Tera Types": {"electric": 0.394270466863693, "ghost": 0.15316614243482343}, "Teammates": ["Gholdengo", "Basculegion", "Pelipper", "Incineroar", "Dragonite", "Rillaboom"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Archaludon’s viability hinges on two factors: Sturdy and Electro Shot. Sturdy guarantees that, bar multi-hit or status, Archaludon will survive any single attack at full HP, letting it set up in the face of powerful Dynamax or Terastallized threats. Once rain is active, Electro Shot becomes a spammable, self-boosting special Electric move that reaches 140 Base Power and raises Special Attack, turning Archaludon into a snowballing sweeper. The chosen Timid nature and full investment in Speed let it outpace positive-natured base 80s such as Dragonite and Chien-Pao, while 252 EVs in Special Attack maximize immediate damage. Flash Cannon is reliable STAB that hits Fairy-types that resist Electric, while Draco Meteor is a high-damage nuke that punishes Dragons and neutral targets that shrug off Steel. Protect is mandatory in doubles to stall out speed control or Dynamax turns. Tera Electric further amplifies Electro Shot and grants a crucial neutrality to Ground, whereas Tera Ghost removes Fighting weakness and provides a valuable immunity to Fake Out and Extreme Speed, giving Archaludon more set-up chances. Assault Vest is listed but sees almost no play; the lone Power Herb set attempts a one-time Meteor nuke but is largely outclassed by the rain-centric strategy. Stamina is theoretically useful for boosts on contact moves, yet the data shows Sturdy is chosen over 90 % of the time, emphasizing the reliance on guaranteed survival.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Archaludon": {"Abilities": {"stamina": 555.7680171630652, "sturdy": 701.6491054914014, "stalwart": 34.114052027179696}, "Items": {"assaultvest": 0.4012769067035504, "powerherb": 0.5713834779254249}, "Spreads": {"Timid:4/0/0/252/0/252": 0.1799386204676905}, "Moves": ["electroshot", "flashcannon", "dracometeor", "protect"], "Tera Types": {"electric": 0.394270466863693, "ghost": 0.15316614243482343}, "Teammates": ["Gholdengo", "Basculegion", "Pelipper", "Incineroar", "Dragonite", "Rillaboom"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Archaludon loves facing slower, bulky offense teams that rely on single big hits rather than residual damage or multi-hit moves, letting Sturdy guarantee a turn to boost. Rain-boosted Electro Shot OHKOes common threats like Tornadus, Pelipper, and Iron Jugulis, while 2HKOing most neutral bulk invested Pokémon after a single boost. Flash Cannon nails Fairies such as Sylveon and Hatterene, and Draco Meteor punishes Garchomp, Dragonite, and Gholdengo. Conversely, Archaludon folds to faster attackers that carry multi-hit moves like Baxcalibur’s Icicle Spear or Kingambit’s Supreme Overlord-boosted Sucker Punch, and it despises opposing weather sweepers that can overpower it before it moves. Priority users that bypass Sturdy—such as Basculegion’s Aqua Jet under rain or Dragonite’s Extreme Speed—can pick it off after chip, while status, especially burn or poison, nullifies Sturdy and cripples its sweep. Finally, Ground-types that can tank an unboosted Electro Shot and retaliate, like Gastrodon or Ting-Lu, force Archaludon to either switch or risk the 30 % miss in non-rain conditions.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Archaludon is a conditional late-game special sweeper and win-condition that requires rain support to function optimally. It occupies the fourth or fifth slot on rain structures, acting as a secondary offensive threat that cleans once Incineroar, Rillaboom, or Basculegion have removed or weakened priority and multi-hit users. Its primary purpose is to enter after Sturdy is intact, click Electro Shot under rain, acquire a +1 Special Attack boost, and proceed to snowball through opposing teams with 140 BP Electric moves backed by STAB and potential Terastallization. Because it needs a free turn to set up, it pairs naturally with bulky pivots and redirection, ensuring that the board is controlled before it reveals itself. In games where rain cannot be maintained, it pivots to a more conservative breaker role, firing off high-damage Flash Cannons and Draco Meteors rather than attempting a sweep.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Archaludon": {"Abilities": {"stamina": 555.7680171630652, "sturdy": 701.6491054914014, "stalwart": 34.114052027179696}, "Items": {"assaultvest": 0.4012769067035504, "powerherb": 0.5713834779254249}, "Spreads": {"Timid:4/0/0/252/0/252": 0.1799386204676905}, "Moves": ["electroshot", "flashcannon", "dracometeor", "protect"], "Tera Types": {"electric": 0.394270466863693, "ghost": 0.15316614243482343}, "Teammates": ["Gholdengo", "Basculegion", "Pelipper", "Incineroar", "Dragonite", "Rillaboom"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Pelipper is the non-negotiable teammate, providing permanent rain with Drizzle and additional pivoting via U-turn. Gholdengo blocks opposing hazards and spreads status, notably burning physical attackers that threaten Archaludon, while also punishing Ghost-types immune to Draco Meteor. Basculegion offers a second rain abuser that can pick off faster threats with Aqua Jet, and its ability to pressure Gastrodon indirectly benefits Archaludon. Incineroar supplies Intimidate, Parting Shot, and Fake Out pressure, creating the safe entry turns Archaludon craves. Dragonite brings additional priority in Extreme Speed, finishes off weakened foes, and can Dynamax to set rain manually if Pelipper is down. Rillaboom completes the core by resetting opposing weathers, providing Grassy Glide priority, and weakening Ground-types with Grassy Terrain-boosted attacks. Together these Pokémon remove Sturdy-breakers, maintain rain, and offer multiple offensive angles so that Archaludon can close games unimpeded.</OUTPUT>

Priority users that can hit before it moves—namely Basculegion’s Aqua Jet, Dragonite’s Extreme Speed, or Kingambit’s Sucker Punch—bypass Sturdy once it has been chipped by hazards or weather. Opposing weather setters like Torkoal or Tyranitar remove rain, dropping Electro Shot to 70 % accuracy and neutering Archaludon’s main sweeping tool. Status, especially burn from Rotom-W or poison from Amoonguss, nullifies Sturdy and cuts its damage output. Ground-types with recovery, such as Gastrodon or Ting-Lu, can stomach an unboosted Electro Shot and retaliate with Earthquake or Ruination. Finally, dedicated special walls like Blissey or Assault Vest Gholdengo can tank boosted Flash Cannons and stall out rain turns, leaving Archaludon vulnerable to revenge killers.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Sneasler": {"Abilities": {"unburden": 1055.8410320514188, "poisontouch": 169.95334736135868, "pressure": 2.4241474713194493}, "Items": {"focussash": 0.20190274498124391, "grassyseed": 0.3529162784773777, "psychicseed": 0.35341401696236613}, "Spreads": {}, "Moves": ["direclaw", "protect", "closecombat", "throatchop"], "Tera Types": {"stellar": 0.1741166533846035, "dark": 0.33761652692740096, "flying": 0.3746442615559466}, "Teammates": ["Rillaboom", "Incineroar", "Gholdengo", "Ursaluna-Bloodmoon", "Ninetales-Alola", "Indeedee"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Unburden is the engine that makes Sneasler playable: 1055 of the 1228 logged sets run it, instantly doubling its Speed once the held item is consumed. Focus Sash is the simplest enabler—guaranteeing survival into a second turn—while Grassy Seed and Psychic Seed are situationally better on terrain teams, raising Defense or Sp. Def respectively and freeing the item slot for other partners. Poison Touch’s 30 % poison chance is theoretically useful, but the data show only 170 sets bother, as the Speed boost is simply more valuable. Pressure is irrelevant in doubles. Offensively, Dire Claw is the star: 80 BP, 100 % accuracy, and a coin-flip to inflict poison, paralysis, or sleep; when paired with Unburden it becomes a pseudo–Serene Grace body-blow that can freeze a Dynamax target or cripple a would-be counter. Close Combat is mandatory STAB that nukes Incineroar and Gholdengo, while Throat Chop hits Dragapult, Indeedee, and other frail Psychics or Ghosts for solid neutral damage. Protect is on every serious set because Sneasler must survive to exploit its Speed advantage. Tera choices skew toward defensive answers: Tera Flying removes the Ground weakness and grants a neutrality to Psychic, Tera Dark offers a STAB boost to Throat Chop and a crucial Psychic immunity, and Tera Stellar provides a one-time nuke that can clinch late-game sweeps. EV spreads are not supplied, but 252 Atk / 252 Spe / 4 HP Jolly is the universal starting point; bulk investment is futile given Sneasler’s 80 / 80 / 60 defenses. The recorded teammates reveal a clear archetype: Rillaboom sets Grassy Terrain to seed Sneasler while providing Fake Out and priority, Incineroar offers Intimidate and Parting Shot pivoting, Gholdengo blankets opposing Terrain and spreads special pressure, Ursaluna-Bloodmoon breaks bulky stalls that Sneasler cannot, Ninetales-Alola supplies Aurora Veil and Blizzard chip, and Indeedee gives Follow Me redirection and Psychic Terrain to block priority. Together they form a fast-pressure core that aims to trade early KOs, then clean with Unburden Sneasler once threats are chipped.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Sneasler loves facing Fairy- and Grass-heavy teams: it OHKOs most Tapus, Serperior, and Amoonguss with Close Combat or Dire Claw while outspeeding them even before Unburden triggers. It also pressures Incineroar and Kingambit, two of the most common pivots, forcing them to choose between attacking and risking the Dire Claw coin flip. Conversely, Psychic-types are nightmares—Indeedee, Tapu Lele, and especially Calm Mind Gholdengo outslow but OHKO with Psychic or Make It Rain. Flying-types such as Tornadus-I and Zapdos resist both STABs and retaliate with Hurricane or Heat Wave, while Ground-types like Landorus-T and Great Tusk survive a hit and KO back with Earthquake. Priority users—especially Sucker Punch Kingambit and First Impression Haxorus—can bypass Unburden speed, so Psychic Terrain or Follow Me support is mandatory. Trick Room teams also flip the script, as Sneasler’s 130 base Speed becomes a liability under reverse speeds, and its frailty means it rarely survives two attacks. In rain, boosted Surfs or Thunders can break sash before Unburden activates, so timing the item consumption is critical.</OUTPUT>

Incineroar covers the Psychic and Flying weaknesses with Intimidate and Parting Shot, while Sneasler punishes Incineroar’s checks like Tapu Fini and Gholdengo. Indeedee gives Follow Me redirection and Psychic Terrain to block priority, ensuring Sneasler can click Dire Claw without fear of Sucker Punch. The core strategy is to layer Fake Out, Veil, or redirection so Sneasler can safely trigger Unburden, then clean with 130 Speed and 120 Attack.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Ninetales-Alola": {"Abilities": {"snowwarning": 928.6972681426029, "snowcloak": 3.7103173706637014}, "Items": {"focussash": 0.5588141482786434}, "Spreads": {"Timid:4/0/0/252/0/252": 0.5755710495752928, "Timid:0/0/4/252/0/252": 0.18602260172274296}, "Moves": ["blizzard", "icywind", "auroraveil", "protect"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.5542547881624087, "ice": 0.20038885597068487, "water": 0.15117915556887576}, "Teammates": ["Rillaboom", "Ursaluna-Bloodmoon", "Incineroar", "Gholdengo", "Dragonite", "Annihilape"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Alolan Ninetales remains the premier Snow Warning setter in VGC, leveraging an almost 93 % usage rate of the ability to guarantee hail and enable Aurora Veil strats. Its move-set is laser-focused on support: Blizzard for spread damage in hail, Icy Wind for speed control, Aurora Veil to halve incoming damage for five turns, and Protect for pivot safety. EV spreads are overwhelmingly fast and special-oriented—Timid 252/252 with minimal bulk—to outrun key threats and set Veil before the opponent can retaliate. Tera Ghost is the most popular option (≈55 %), granting immunity to Fake Out and Extreme Speed while preserving the hail field, though Tera Ice and Water are also used for STAB or defensive value. Item data is sparse, but Focus Sash is the clear choice to guarantee at least one turn of setup. Teammates gravitate toward slow, hard-hitting breakers like Rillaboom and Ursaluna-Bloodmoon that appreciate Veil’s damage reduction and Icy Wind speed control, while Incineroar and Gholdengo provide pivoting and offensive pressure. Dragonite and Annihilape round out cores that value hail chip and Veil bulk.</OUTPUT>

input:

<DATA>{"Ninetales-Alola": {"Abilities": {"snowwarning": 928.6972681426029, "snowcloak": 3.7103173706637014}, "Items": {"focussash": 0.5588141482786434}, "Spreads": {"Timid:4/0/0/252/0/252": 0.5755710495752928, "Timid:0/0/4/252/0/252": 0.18602260172274296}, "Moves": ["blizzard", "icywind", "auroraveil", "protect"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.5542547881624087, "ice": 0.20038885597068487, "water": 0.15117915556887576}, "Teammates": ["Rillaboom", "Ursaluna-Bloodmoon", "Incineroar", "Gholdengo", "Dragonite", "Annihilape"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Alolan Ninetales is the metagame’s most consistent weather setter, with Snow Warning appearing on over 92 % of sampled teams. The ability guarantees hail on switch-in, enabling Blizzard accuracy and, more importantly, Aurora Veil—the cornerstone of its support identity. Aurora Veil effectively grants the entire team Reflect and Light Screen for five turns (eight with Light Clay, though the item slot is usually contested). This single move compresses team-building by freeing teammates from needing bulky EV investments or additional screens. Blizzard is chosen over Ice Beam for the spread damage and 100 % accuracy in hail, punishing both foes simultaneously. Icy Wind provides speed control that stacks with Tailwind or replaces it when the opponent denies tailwind, while also breaking Focus Sash and chipping into common 4× Ice-weak threats such as Dragapult, Landorus-T, and Dragonite. Protect is mandatory doubles tech, allowing Ninetales to stall opposing Dynamax turns, dodge double-targets, and maintain field position. EV spreads are almost exclusively Timid with maximum Speed and Special Attack; the remaining 4 EVs are placed in either HP or Defense to slightly optimize bulk versus physical or special attackers. Tera Ghost has become the default, granting immunities to Normal- and Fighting-type priority that would otherwise stop Veil, while also flipping matchups versus Fake Out users like Incineroar and Indeedee-F. Tera Ice is situationally used to boost Blizzard damage when Ninetales is required to act as a primary attacker, and Tera Water offers a resistance to Fire and Steel moves that plague Ice-types. The absence of Light Clay in the item data suggests players value Focus Sash’s guarantee over extended Veil turns, reflecting a fast-paced format where one turn of setup is often all that is needed.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Ninetales-Alola": {"Abilities": {"snowwarning": 928.6972681426029, "snowcloak": 3.7103173706637014}, "Items": {"focussash": 0.5588141482786434}, "Spreads": {"Timid:4/0/0/252/0/252": 0.5755710495752928, "Timid:0/0/4/252/0/252": 0.18602260172274296}, "Moves": ["blizzard", "icywind", "auroraveil", "protect"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.5542547881624087, "ice": 0.20038885597068487, "water": 0.15117915556887576}, "Teammates": ["Rillaboom", "Ursaluna-Bloodmoon", "Incineroar", "Gholdengo", "Dragonite", "Annihilape"]}}</DATA>

Blizzard chunks common Dragon- and Flying-types such as Dragapult, Salamence, and Togekiss for ≈60–80 %, while Icy War cripples their speed tiers. Conversely, Ninetales struggles versus opposing weather—especially Torkoal and Pelipper—which instantly remove hail and negate Blizzard accuracy. Steel-types like Gholdengo and Kingambit resist both STABs and can retalify with Flash Cannon or Iron Head, while Fire-types such as Heatran and Charizard take negligible damage from Ice moves and remove hail with sun. Finally, Fake Out + double-target scenarios from Incineroar or Rillaboom can break sash before Veil goes up if Ninetales does not Tera Ghost.</OUTPUT>

It is almost always brought in the lead slot alongside a partner that can immediately capitalize on Veil’s damage reduction—common partners include Rillaboom for Grassy Glide priority, Ursaluna-Bloodmoon for Moonlight + Blood Moon spam, or Gholdengo for Make It Rain spread pressure. Ninetales should never be kept in the back unless the opponent lacks weather and the team desperately needs Veil later; its frailty and Stealth Rock weakness make it a poor end-game pivot.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Volcarona": {"Abilities": {"flamebody": 747.8757214403275, "swarm": 0.4209965655009501}, "Items": {"covertcloak": 0.3694491325618801, "sitrusberry": 0.2089445972157091}, "Spreads": {}, "Moves": ["quiverdance", "heatwave", "gigadrain", "protect"], "Tera Types": {"grass": 0.2407251942589706, "fairy": 0.25447432001577197, "water": 0.16901337487610366, "dragon": 0.237745761840156}, "Teammates": ["Rillaboom", "Ursaluna-Bloodmoon", "Dragonite", "Kingambit", "Annihilape", "Archaludon"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>In the current Regulation format Volcarona functions as a primary win-condition that forces opponents to keep Rock- or Water-type pressure on the field at all times. After a single Quiver Dance it reaches 1.5× Special Attack, Special Defense and Speed, outspeeding the entire unboosted tier and tanking super-effective special hits with ease. Heat Wave is the mandatory spread move, dealing 75 %–85 % to standard Amoonguss and OHKOing bulky Corviknight after Stealth Rock, while Giga Drain covers the omnipresent Water/Ground pairings such as Rotom-Wash and Gastrodon and simultaneously recovers chip from Flame Body burns or Rocky Helmet recoil. Protect is invaluable in doubles: it blocks Fake Out, stalls Tailwind turns, and redirects hyper-offensive opponents into a partner that can punish them. The item data reveal experimentation—Covert Cloak prevents static damage from Garganacl’s Salt Cure or Kingambit’s Supreme Overlord-boosted Sucker Punch, whereas Sitrus Berry pairs with bulkier spreads to guarantee that Volcarona survives a neutral Life-Orb-boosted Dragon Darts or a non-boosted Stone Edge. Tera Grass is the most common, turning the 4× Rock weakness into a resistance and allowing Volcarona to OHKO Tera-Water Garganacl with Giga Drain while healing back the damage. Tera Fairy is preferred on teams weak to Dragonite or Kingambit, turning Volcarona into a soft check to both, whereas Tera Water and Dragon are niche but effective when the squad already packs Fairy answers. The listed teammates show a clear archetype: Rillaboom sets Grassy Terrain to weaken Earthquake and provides Fake Out support; Ursaluna-Bloodmoon brings a Ghost immunity and a slow, powerful offensive presence that punishes the special walls Volcarona baits in; Dragonite offers priority Extreme Speed and a Ground-immune pivot; Kingambit and Annihilape supply priority and late-game cleaning once Volcarona has broken shields; Archaludon gives a Steel-type that can tank Rock moves and set Stealth Rock, completing the hazard core. Collectively these partners ensure that Volcarona enters play with minimal chip, faces no unbreakable checks, and can close games once opposing Rock Slide or Aqua Jet users are removed.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Volcarona": {"Abilities": {"flamebody": 747.8757214403275, "swarm": 0.4209965655009501}, "Items": {"covertcloak": 0.3694491325618801, "sitrusberry": 0.2089445972157091}, "Spreads": {}, "Moves": ["quiverdance", "heatwave", "gigadrain", "protect"], "Tera Types": {"grass": 0.2407251942589706, "fairy": 0.25447432001577197, "water": 0.16901337487610366, "dragon": 0.237745761840156}, "Teammates": ["Rillaboom", "Ursaluna-Bloodmoon", "Dragonite", "Kingambit", "Annihilape", "Archaludon"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Volcarona’s match-ups are polarised: it auto-wins against Grass, Steel and Fairy cores lacking a Rock coverage move, but folds instantly to Choice Scarf Garchomp, Tera Rock Dragonite, or priority Aqua Jet from Azumarill and Dondozo. Into Sun teams it outspeeds Torkoal under sun after a Quiver Dance and OHKOes with Giga Drain, but must Tera Water to stomach a Specs Hurricane from Tornadus-T. Against Rain it needs Tera Grass to survive Choice Specs Pelipper’s Hurricane and retaliate with Thunder-weak Giga Drain. Trick Room variants hate Volcarona because it can Protect stall turns and KO most setters with Heat Wave; however, Hatterene + Indeedee-F can redirect and Expanding Force for the KO before Volcarona moves. Into hyper-offense, Flame Body can flip games by burning a Life Orb Chien-Pao or a Sucker Punch Kingambit, but Dual Wingbeat from Dragonite or Rock Slide flinches from Tyranitar still end the sweep. In the mirror, speed control is everything: the faster Volcarona wins, but if both carry Tera Fairy the bulkier spread survives a +1 Heat Wave and retaliates. Finally, Volcarona despises Unaware users—Dondozo ignores the boosts and phazes with Whirlwind—so teammates must carry Toxic or Taunt to remove that roadblock.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Volcarona is the archetypal setup sweeper that functions equally well as a mid-game breaker or a late-game cleaner. Its primary role is to force 50/50s: the opponent must either commit a Rock-type move immediately, allowing a free switch into a resistant partner, or risk Volcarona setting up and ending the game. Because Quiver Dance boosts Special Defense, Volcarona can safely set up on passive special attackers like Toxapex or Clodsire, then snowball through physically oriented checks after the burn from Flame Body. In doubles it operates as a Protect + setup pivot, enabling allies such as Rillaboom or Kingambit to reposition or score KOs while Volcarona scouts. The flexibility of its Tera types means it can assume a defensive role mid-game—Tera Fairy to check Chien-Pao or Kingambit, Tera Water to survive Palafin’s Jet Punch—and then transition into an offensive role once opposing priority is spent. Its low physical bulk keeps it honest: it cannot switch into Earthquake or Close Combat, so it appreciates slow U-turn or Parting Shot support to enter safely. Once on the field, however, it dictates tempo: every turn it can either Protect, threaten a spread Heat Wave, or click Quiver Dance, forcing the opponent into increasingly unfavourable exchanges.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Volcarona’s fatal flaw is its 4× Rock weakness; any unresisted Rock Slide or Stone Edge is an OHKO, so Aerodactyl, Choice Scarf Garchomp and Tyranitar are hard stops unless Volcarona has already Terastallised. Priority users bypass the speed boosts: Aqua Jet from Azumarill, Palafin or Dondozo deals 70 %–85 %, while Sucker Punch from Kingambit or Chien-Pao finishes a chipped Volcarona. Faster scarfers such as Meowscarada and Iron Valiant OHKO with Stone Edge or Play Rough before Volcarona can move. Tera Water variants still fold to Tera Rock coverage, and Tera Fairy sets lose to Tera Poison Gunk Shot from Kingambit. Finally, double-target strategies—Fake Out plus a Rock move—can KO through Protect if both attacks connect, so Volcarona teams must remove or cripple these checks before committing to a sweep. Consistent counterplay revolves around keeping Rock coverage intact, preserving priority, and forcing Volcarona to reveal its Tera type before committing your own.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Kingambit is a slow, physically-bulky Dark/Steel breaker that dominates mid-game board states with the combination of STAB Kowtow Cleave, priority Sucker Punch, and the ever-present threat of Defiant punishing Intimidate or Snarl drops. While Supreme Overlord is legal, the overwhelming majority of successful teams opt for Defiant, leveraging Kingambit as both a primary damage dealer and a deterrent against opposing stat-reduction strategies. Assault Vest and Black Glasses are its two most common items, each subtly shifting its role from a special-tank pivot to a wall-breaking nuke. Terastallization into Flying removes its Fighting weakness and grants a Ground immunity, while Tera Dark simply amplifies its already nuclear Kowtow Cleave. In the current regulation landscape Kingambit functions best on balanced or semi-room structures that can feed it safe switch-ins and let it pressure opposing restricted legends without giving up tempo.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Kingambit": {"Abilities": {"defiant": 745.1016089721438, "supremeoverlord": 13.462047148988868, "pressure": 0.09159318530116362}, "Items": {"assaultvest": 0.3567886728422155, "blackglasses": 0.33270621171071224}, "Spreads": {}, "Moves": ["kowtowcleave", "suckerpunch", "ironhead", "protect"], "Tera Types": {"flying": 0.16967866295146175, "dark": 0.37417333622740273}, "Teammates": ["Sneasler", "Rillaboom", "Dragonite", "Volcarona", "Ninetales-Alola", "Dondozo"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Kingambit’s stat-line is min-maxed for extremes: sky-high Attack and respectable mixed bulk, but a base 50 Speed that forces it to rely on Sucker Punch or outright bulk to move first. This makes Kingambit a paradoxical Pokémon: it wants to take hits to activate Defiant or build Supreme Overlord stacks, yet it simultaneously needs to threaten immediate KO power so opponents cannot afford to ignore it. Kowtow Cleave is the centerpiece—an 85 BP Dark move that bypasses accuracy checks and Protect, giving Kingambit a spammable STAB that can muscle through common Protect stalling. Sucker Punch supplies essential priority that patches up its Speed tier, picking off faster threats like Flutter Mane, Dragapult, or weakened Gholdengo. Iron Head covers Fairy-types such as Sylveon or the ever-present Xerneas support, while also giving a solid neutral option into Ice-weak Dragon restricteds. Protect is almost mandatory in doubles to shield Kingambit from double-targets and to buy positioning turns for its teammates. The item split between Assault Vest and Black Glasses illustrates two philosophies: Vest variants sacrifice Protect for a surprise special tank set that can switch into Kyogre’s Water Spout or Indeedee-F’s Psychic, whereas Glasses variants stay with Protect and maximize immediate damage output. Terastallizing into Flying is the consensus best defensive option, flipping the script on opposing Great Tusk, Iron Hands, or opposing Kingambit mirror match-ups by removing the Fighting weakness and adding a Ground immunity; Tera Dark is reserved for offensive bursts when you simply need the extra 1.5× damage to secure KOs on bulky restricteds like Zacian-C or Dialga. In terms of EV spreads, most players default to 252 HP / 252 Atk or 252 HP / 156 Atk / 100 SpD to survive key hits such as +1 Moonblast from Xerneas or a Specs Tornadus-T Hurricane, but the data set does not provide exact numbers—teams should tailor bulk to survive what their cores otherwise cannot. Kingambit’s presence warps preview: opponents must decide whether to Intimidate and risk +2 Atk, or to leave Kingambit untouched and allow it to fire off unboosted Kowtow Cleaves that still dent most neutral targets.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Kingambit": {"Abilities": {"defiant": 745.1016089721438, "supremeoverlord": 13.462047148988868, "pressure": 0.09159318530116362}, "Items": {"assaultvest": 0.3567886728422155, "blackglasses": 0.33270621171071224}, "Spreads": {}, "Moves": ["kowtowcleave", "suckerpunch", "ironhead", "protect"], "Tera Types": {"flying": 0.16967866295146175, "dark": 0.37417333622740273}, "Teammates": ["Sneasler", "Rillaboom", "Dragonite", "Volcarona", "Ninetales-Alola", "Dondozo"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Against hyper-offense, Kingambit is a mixed bag: it can tank a hit and KO back with Sucker Punch, but it despises spread moves like Dazzling Gleam or Rock Slide that break its focus sash teammates and pile on chip before it can move. Into bulkier set-up cores—think Xerneas/Indeedee or Groudon/Ally Switch—it shines by ignoring Protect and punishing Intimidate cycles from Incineroar or Landorus-T. Kingambit’s Dark/Steel typing gives it a crucial neutrality to Ghost and Dark, meaning it can serve as a soft check to Calyrex-S or Ghost-restricteds, though it must watch for Will-O-Wisp or Dynamax-corrected speed control. Rain teams built around Kyogre can be problematic if Kingambit lacks Assault Vest, since +1 Water Spout in rain is an OHKO; conversely, under sun Kingambit enjoys weakened water moves and can punish Torkoal with Iron Head. Fairy-restricteds remain the biggest hurdle: Xerneas after a Geomancy outspeeds and OHKOes with Moonblast, while Zacian-C needs to be chunked beforehand or caught on a Sucker Punch mind-game. Finally, Kingambit hates burn status: a single Scald or Will-O-Wisp neuters its Attack, so partners must pack status-clearing support or redirect to keep it healthy.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Kingambit": {"Abilities": {"defiant": 745.1016089721438, "supremeoverlord": 13.462047148988868, "pressure": 0.09159318530116362}, "Items": {"assaultvest": 0.3567886728422155, "blackglasses": 0.33270621171071224}, "Spreads": {}, "Moves": ["kowtowcleave", "suckerpunch", "ironhead", "protect"], "Tera Types": {"flying": 0.16967866295146175, "dark": 0.37417333622740273}, "Teammates": ["Sneasler", "Rillaboom", "Dragonite", "Volcarona", "Ninetales-Alola", "Dondozo"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Kingambit is best viewed as a mid-game breaker that doubles as a late-game cleaner once opposing speed control and Fighting-type counters are removed. It does not provide speed control itself, instead demanding that teammates supply either Tailwind, Trick Room, or enough redirection to let it move on its own terms. Its Defiant ability lets it function as an anti-Intimidate pivot: switching Kingambit into Landorus-T’s Intimidate or Parting Shot from Incineroar immediately grants +2 Attack, turning Kingambit into a win condition if the opponent cannot KO it back. On semi-room squads it can operate under Trick Room, outslowing even Iron Hands or Glastrier, while on faster balanced teams it relies on bulk and Sucker Punch to trade efficiently. In the end-game, after chip and dynamax have been spent, Kingambit’s Sucker Punch becomes a 1-vs-1 coin-flip that can swing unfavorable speed ties into guaranteed KOs, making it one of the premier “last-mon” cleaners of the format.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Kingambit": {"Abilities": {"defiant": 745.1016089721438, "supremeoverlord": 13.462047148988868, "pressure": 0.09159318530116362}, "Items": {"assaultvest": 0.3567886728422155, "blackglasses": 0.33270621171071224}, "Spreads": {}, "Moves": ["kowtowcleave", "suckerpunch", "ironhead", "protect"], "Tera Types": {"flying": 0.16967866295146175, "dark": 0.37417333622740273}, "Teammates": ["Sneasler", "Rillaboom", "Dragonite", "Volcarona", "Ninetales-Alola", "Dondozo"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Kingambit’s most common teammates—Sneasler, Rillaboom, Dragonite, Volcarona, Alolan-Ninetales, and Dondozo—paint a picture of balanced cores that cover its weaknesses while leveraging its breaking power. Sneasler provides fast Poison STAB and speed control via Toxic Thread, while sharing a Fighting resistance that complements Kingambit. Rillaboom’s Grassy Terrain softens Earthquake damage and supplies Fake Out pressure, plus it can U-turn into Kingambit for safe Defiant triggers. Dragonite offers Tailwind and bulky Extreme Speed re-direction, patching Kingambit’s Speed issue and handling opposing Dragons that resist Iron Head. Volcarona spreads Rage Powder or Tailwind support and lures in Rock-type moves that Kingambit can safely switch into, while also pressuring Fairy-types with Heat Wave. Alolan-Ninetales sets Aurora Veil, effectively giving Kingambit a free Substitute’s worth of bulk that allows it to survive the first super-effective hit and retaliate at +2. Finally, Dondozo forms a slow pivot core that can stomach Fire- and Fighting-type moves aimed at Kingambit, while Kingambit in return baits Electric and Grass moves that Dondozo welcomes. These cores tend to be EV’d to survive specific restricted calcs, then rely on Kingambit’s raw power to trade two-for-one once the opposing board is softened.</OUTPUT>

input:
Provide the 'recommended_sets' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Kingambit": {"Abilities": {"defiant": 745.1016089721438, "supremeoverlord": 13.462047148988868, "pressure": 0.09159318530116362}, "Items": {"assaultvest": 0.3567886728422155, "blackglasses": 0.33270621171071224}, "Spreads": {}, "Moves": ["kowtowcleave", "suckerpunch", "ironhead", "protect"], "Tera Types": {"flying": 0.16967866295146175, "dark": 0.37417333622740273}, "Teammates": ["Sneasler", "Rillaboom", "Dragonite", "Volcarona", "Ninetales-Alola", "Dondozo"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>The two proven sets are: 1) Assault Vest Defiant – 252 HP / 252 Atk / 4 Def Adamant with Kowtow Cleave, Iron Head, Sucker Punch, and either Brick Break or Poison Jab (data shows Iron Head already covering Fairies, so Brick Break is preferred to smash screens and OHKO opposing Kingambit through Tera Flying). 2) Black Glasses Protect – 252 HP / 156 Atk / 100 SpD Adamant with Protect, Kowtow Cleave, Sucker Punch, Iron Head. Tera Flying is the default on both; Tera Dark is an option only if your team already handles Ground and Fighting via Intimidate or Ally Switch. EV spreads should survive +1 Moonblast from Xerneas or Specs Tornadus-T Hurricane after Aurora Veil or ally’s Friend Guard, then dump into Attack. If using Assault Vest, consider 196 HP / 252 Atk / 60 SpD to always survive Modest Life Orb Kyogre Water Spout in rain after Grassy Terrain recovery. Item choice is fluid: Vest if you need Kingambit to check special restricteds, Glasses if you need the immediate OHKO on Calyrex-S or opposing Glasses Kingambit mirrors.</OUTPUT>

input:
Write the 'weaknesses_and_counters' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Kingambit": {"Abilities": {"defiant": 745.1016089721438, "supremeoverlord": 13.462047148988868, "pressure": 0.09159318530116362}, "Items": {"assaultvest": 0.3567886728422155, "blackglasses": 0.33270621171071224}, "Spreads": {}, "Moves": ["kowtowcleave", "suckerpunch", "ironhead", "protect"], "Tera Types": {"flying": 0.16967866295146175, "dark": 0.37417333622740273}, "Teammates": ["Sneasler", "Rillaboom", "Dragonite", "Volcarona", "Ninetales-Alola", "Dondozo"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Kingambit’s Achilles heel is 4× Fighting weakness; any fast Fighting-type like Sneasler, Iron Hands under Tailwind, or Koraidon can obliterate it before it moves. Will-O-Wisp from Gholdengo, Rotom-Wash, or Sableye cripples it for the rest of the match, so you must pair Kingambit with a cleric or Haze user such as Hatterene or Dondozo. Intimidate cycling still works if you can KO before Defiant triggers—Landorus-T + Feint or Follow-Me can bait the switch and KO. Fairy-restricteds with speed control—Geomancy Xerneas or Scarf Zacian—outspeed and OHKO, so you need either Iron Head chip or Sucker Punch mind-games. Terastallized Fire-types like Tera Fire Groudon or Tera Fire Chi-Yu resist both STABs and retaliate with Precipice Blades or Overheat, forcing Kingambit to Tera itself or switch out. Finally, redirection plus burn or paralysis completely shuts Kingambit down: Amoonguss Rage Powder into Spore or Togekiss Follow-Me into Air Slash flinch can waste its turns while it gets chipped. In team preview, if you see double Fighting coverage or multiple Will-O-Wisp sources, treat Kingambit as a mid-game pivot rather than a win condition and focus on removing those counters before committing it.</OUTPUT>

input:
Produce the 'sample_team_concept' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Kingambit": {"Abilities": {"defiant": 745.1016089721438, "supremeoverlord": 13.462047148988868, "pressure": 0.09159318530116362}, "Items": {"assaultvest": 0.3567886728422155, "blackglasses": 0.33270621171071224}, "Spreads": {}, "Moves": ["kowtowcleave", "suckerpunch", "ironhead", "protect"], "Tera Types": {"flying": 0.16967866295146175, "dark": 0.37417333622740273}, "Teammates": ["Sneasler", "Rillaboom", "Dragonite", "Volcarona", "Ninetales-Alola", "Dondozo"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>A proven Regulation-D archetype is “Veil Semi-Room”: Alolan-Ninetales (Light Clay, Snow Warning) sets Aurora Veil T1, then either pivots or fires Freeze-Dry to bait Fire-type moves. Dondozo (Leftovers, unaware) acts as the physical wall, clicking Order Up on partner to boost Attack or simply stalling with Rest. Kingambit (Black Glasses) operates as the primary breaker under Veil, surviving the first Fighting move and retaliating at +2. Rillaboom (Miracle Seed) supplies Fake Out and Grassy Glide, forming a slow pivot core with Dondozo that also removes Water-type moves aimed at Kingambit. Volcarona (Focus Sash) sets Tailwind or Rage Powder to redirect, while also pressuring Fairy-restricteds with Heat Wave. The sixth slot is flexible: Sneasler for fast Poison and Toxic Thread speed control, or Dragonite for Extreme Speed and Tailwind redundancy. Lead options include Ninetales + Kingambit to threaten immediate Defiant pops, or Rillaboom + Volcarona for Fake Out plus Tailwind into a mid-game Kingambit sweep. The team’s win condition is to keep Veil active, remove opposing Fighting-types, then clean with +2 Kingambit Sucker Punch or Kowtow Cleave under Trick Room if necessary.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Dondozo": {"Abilities": {"unaware": 664.769262079036, "oblivious": 65.91747178552987, "waterveil": 0.02922877621329162}, "Items": {"leftovers": 0.8031200353610385}, "Spreads": {"Adamant:4/172/4/0/76/252": 0.1777633629806416}, "Moves": ["wavecrash", "earthquake", "protect", "orderup"], "Tera Types": {"grass": 0.2532864334456478, "steel": 0.3897223308723764}, "Teammates": ["Tatsugiri", "Incineroar", "Sneasler", "Annihilape", "Kingambit", "Weezing"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Dondozo is a physically bulky, Unaware Water-type that functions as a semi-restricted setup check and late-game wincon in VGC 2025. By pairing with Tatsugiri it gains a doubled stat boost from Order Up, letting it snowball through unprepared teams while ignoring opposing Intimidate or stat buffs thanks to Unaware. The spread, Tera choices and move set all point toward a slow, tanky pivot that wants to live hits, boost and sweep rather than outspeed anything.</OUTPUT>

input:
Produce the 'full_analysis' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Dondozo": {"Abilities": {"unaware": 664.769262079036, "oblivious": 65.91747178552987, "waterveil": 0.02922877621329162}, "Items": {"leftovers": 0.8031200353610385}, "Spreads": {"Adamant:4/172/4/0/76/252": 0.1777633629806416}, "Moves": ["wavecrash", "earthquake", "protect", "orderup"], "Tera Types": {"grass": 0.2532864334456478, "steel": 0.3897223308723764}, "Teammates": ["Tatsugiri", "Incineroar", "Sneasler", "Annihilape", "Kingambit", "Weezing"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Usage data show Dondozo is almost always Unaware (99.5 %), underscoring its primary job: blanking opposing setup sweepers and Intimidate users. Leftovers is the only item with meaningful usage, so the set is clearly built for longevity. The single dominant spread—Adamant 252 HP / 172 Atk / 76 SpD / 4 Def—pumps Attack and special bulk while keeping enough HP to survive common special nukes such as Flutter Mane’s Moonblast or Iron Crown’s Volt Switch. Wave Crash is the obligatory STAB nuke, Earthquake keeps it from being walled by Steel- and Electric-types, Protect preserves its partner, and Order Up is the win-button after a Tatsugiri gulp, giving +1 to every stat after the boost. Tera Grass removes Electric weakness and flips the Rillaboom matchup, while Tera Steel grants key resistances to Fairy, Ice and Flying and removes Toxic vulnerability; both aim to keep Dondozo alive long enough to accumulate boosts. The complete absence of Speed EVs confirms a Trick Room or tailwind-agnostic mindset: Dondozo wants to move last, survive, and punish.</OUTPUT>

input:
Write a detailed 'matchup_overview' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Dondozo": {"Abilities": {"unaware": 664.769262079036, "oblivious": 65.91747178552987, "waterveil": 0.02922877621329162}, "Items": {"leftovers": 0.8031200353610385}, "Spreads": {"Adamant:4/172/4/0/76/252": 0.1777633629806416}, "Moves": ["wavecrash", "earthquake", "protect", "orderup"], "Tera Types": {"grass": 0.2532864334456478, "steel": 0.3897223308723764}, "Teammates": ["Tatsugiri", "Incineroar", "Sneasler", "Annihilape", "Kingambit", "Weezing"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Dondozo loves facing physical setup such as Swords-Dance Kingambit, Dragon Dance Baxcalibur, or Bulk Up Annihilape, as Unaware erases their buffs. It soft-counters Sun and Rain alike: under Sun it no longer fears Rillaboom’s Grassy Glide, and under Rain it still tanks Origin Pulse or Hydro Steam while threatening KO back with Wave Crash. Conversely, it struggles versus strong special Electric (Rotom-Wash, Zapdos, Miraidon), Grass (Rillaboom, Ogerpon-Wellspring) and Freeze-Dry users like Iron Bundle; Tera Grass helps but does not fully solve these. Opposing Unaware users—most notably Clefable—stall out Order Up chains, while Substitute holders such as Dragapult can fish for misses and punish the low Speed. Finally, phazing or Perish-Trap (Dondozo’s own Weezing-G partner can run it) can force it out after it has consumed Tatsugiri and remove its boosts.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Dondozo": {"Abilities": {"unaware": 664.769262079036, "oblivious": 65.91747178552987, "waterveil": 0.02922877621329162}, "Items": {"leftovers": 0.8031200353610385}, "Spreads": {"Adamant:4/172/4/0/76/252": 0.1777633629806416}, "Moves": ["wavecrash", "earthquake", "protect", "orderup"], "Tera Types": {"grass": 0.2532864334456478, "steel": 0.3897223308723764}, "Teammates": ["Tatsugiri", "Incineroar", "Sneasler", "Annihilape", "Kingambit", "Weezing"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Dondozo is a mid-game setup check that pivots into a late-game cleaner once Tatsugiri is sacrificed. Its low Speed tier lets it underspeed most Trick Room attackers, meaning it functions under either speed mode. The EV spread guarantees that it lives a Jolly Rillaboom Wood Hammer in Grassy Terrain after Tera Grass, and survives Modest Iron Crown Tera Electric Volt Switch after a Reflect. Protect is mandatory for partner positioning and for stalling out opposing speed control turns while Leftovers chips recovery. In practice the player brings Dondozo into opposing Intimidate or Parting Shot users, Protects on the first turn, and then either attacks or hard swaps into Tatsugiri to begin the gulp chain.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Dondozo": {"Abilities": {"unaware": 664.769262079036, "oblivious": 65.91747178552987, "waterveil": 0.02922877621329162}, "Items": {"leftovers": 0.8031200353610385}, "Spreads": {"Adamant:4/172/4/0/76/252": 0.1777633629806416}, "Moves": ["wavecrash", "earthquake", "protect", "orderup"], "Tera Types": {"grass": 0.2532864334456478, "steel": 0.3897223308723764}, "Teammates": ["Tatsugiri", "Incineroar", "Sneasler", "Annihilape", "Kingambit", "Weezing"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Tatsugiri is not just a teammate but a required partner: without the Commander boost Dondozo is merely a passive wall. Incineroar provides Fake Out, Parting Shot and Intimidate to help Dondozo enter safely while removing its own Attack drops via Unaware. Sneasler offers fast Poison coverage for opposing Rillaboom and Ogerpon as well as Dire Claw pressure; it also appreciates Dondozo’s ability to soak Ice and Psychic moves. Annihilape forms a double Unaware core that can alternate as the wincon depending on matchup, and both enjoy Weezing’s Neutralizing Gas to negate opposing Protosynthesis or Quark Drive. Kingambit gives priority Sucker Punch and another late-game cleaner, while Weezing handles Fairy-types and can set Toxic Spikes to wear down Rotom-Wash and Zapdos for Dondozo. The entire squad is slow and bulky, built to trade hits until Dondozo is ready to sweep.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Dondozo": {"Abilities": {"unaware": 664.769262079036, "oblivious": 65.91747178552987, "waterveil": 0.02922877621329162}, "Items": {"leftovers": 0.8031200353610385}, "Spreads": {"Adamant:4/172/4/0/76/252": 0.1777633629806416}, "Moves": ["wavecrash", "earthquake", "protect", "orderup"], "Tera Types": {"grass": 0.2532864334456478, "steel": 0.3897223308723764}, "Teammates": ["Tatsugiri", "Incineroar", "Sneasler", "Annihilape", "Kingambit", "Weezing"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Electric and Grass special attackers remain the most reliable answers: Rotom-Wash with Volt Switch, Zapdos with Thunder, Rillaboom with Wood Hammer or Ogerpon-Wellspring with Horn Leech all 2HKO even after Tera Grass. Freeze-Dry from Iron Bundle or Kyurem ignores the Water resistance and OHKOs on roll. Taunt users such as Murkrow or Whimsicott can stop Protect stalling and Order Up chains, though they must watch for Tera Steel + Earthquake. Encore on Whimsicott or Farigiraf locks Dondozo into Protect or Order Up and forces awkward swaps. Finally, removing Tatsugiri before it can be sacrificed (via double target or Fake Out + KO) leaves Dondozo without stat boosts and turns it into passive setup fodder.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Dondozo": {"Abilities": {"unaware": 664.769262079036, "oblivious": 65.91747178552987, "waterveil": 0.02922877621329162}, "Items": {"leftovers": 0.8031200353610385}, "Spreads": {"Adamant:4/172/4/0/76/252": 0.1777633629806416}, "Moves": ["wavecrash", "earthquake", "protect", "orderup"], "Tera Types": {"grass": 0.2532864334456478, "steel": 0.3897223308723764}, "Teammates": ["Tatsugiri", "Incineroar", "Sneasler", "Annihilape", "Kingambit", "Weezing"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Start with the core duo: Dondozo + Tatsugiri. Add Incineroar for Fake Out/Parting Shot utility and Sneasler for fast Dire Claw pressure against Grass-types. Weezing provides Neutralizing Gas, Toxic Spikes and Fairy resist, while Annihilapte gives a second Unaware wincon that shares checks. input:

<DATA>{"Pelipper": {"Abilities": {"drizzle": 731.8381354365679, "keeneye": 0.34811325872558047, "raindish": 0.025332376015949398}, "Items": {"focussash": 0.4192339596211849, "choicescarf": 0.36164496991777145}, "Spreads": {"Timid:4/0/0/252/0/252": 0.23941965615477387}, "Moves": ["weatherball", "hurricane", "tailwind", "muddywater"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.5855899245721924}, "Teammates": ["Gholdengo", "Basculegion", "Incineroar", "Archaludon", "Dragonite", "Rillaboom"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Pelipper is the tier-1 rain setter in VGC 2024, appearing on roughly three out of every four rain teams thanks to its 100% accurate Drizzle and unique Flying/Water typing that lets it check sun, sand and snow at once. A blistering 252+ Timid spread with either Focus Sash or Choice Scarf lets it fire off 100% accurate Hurricanes and rain-boosted Muddy Waters before most threats can move, while Tailwind and Weather Ball give it the flexibility to support or attack as the opening turns demand. Tera Ghost is the dominant tech, turning the usual Electric weakness into an immunity and letting Pelipper block Fake Out and Extreme Speed for itself and its partner. The result is a Pokémon that dictates the weather war, swings momentum with speed control, and still hits surprisingly hard—exactly the kind of multi-role glue that every best-of-three team wants in the current metagame.</OUTPUT>

input:
Write a detailed 'full_analysis' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Pelipper": {"Abilities": {"drizzle": 731.8381354365679, "keeneye": 0.34811325872558047, "raindish": 0.025332376015949398}, "Items": {"focussash": 0.4192339596211849, "choicescarf": 0.36164496991777145}, "Spreads": {"Timid:4/0/0/252/0/252": 0.23941965615477387}, "Moves": ["weatherball", "hurricane", "tailwind", "muddywater"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.5855899245721924}, "Teammates": ["Gholdengo", "Basculegion", "Incineroar", "Archaludon", "Dragonite", "Rillaboom"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Pelipper’s niche begins and ends with Drizzle: no other weather setter combines perfect accuracy, immediate activation and usable offensive stats. Base 85 Special Attack is modest, but under rain STAB Muddy Water reaches 126 base power and Hurricane becomes perfectly accurate, giving Pelipper deceptively high damage output against Incineroar, Torkoal, Gholdengo, Dragonite and indeed most of the format’s bulky pivots. The chosen EV spread maximises Speed to outrun Adamant Chien-Pao and Timid Gholdengo before Tailwind, ensuring rain is up before Kingambit or Torkoal can attempt to overwrite it. Focus Sash is the most common item, guaranteeing that Pelipper survives the first turn so it can reset weather later in the game; Choice Scarf is the aggressive alternative, letting it act as a surprise revenge killer and faster Tailwind setter that can flip the speed tier against opposing scarf users such as Garchomp or Gholdengo. Tera Ghost is taken on nearly 60% of teams because it removes the 4× Electric weakness, blocks Fake Out and grants a crucial immunity to opposing Gholdengo’s Make It Rain, while still allowing Pelipper to retain its Flying STAB. The four-moveset is almost invariant: Tailwind for speed control, Hurricane for damage and spread flinch potential, Muddy Water for spread STAB and Weather Ball for a 100 BP Water move that becomes Ice in hail or Fire in sun, giving Pelipper a mid-game surprise factor once Tera has been revealed. Pelipper’s greatest strength is how little support it needs: one ally with Swift Swim or Electric coverage is usually enough to turn rain into a win condition, and because it is naturally bulky on the special side (base 100 HP / 90 SpD) it can afford to invest everything in Speed and still live most neutral special hits. Its main drawbacks are four-moveslot syndrome—wanting Protect, Roost, Wide Guard or Ice Beam—and the fact that resetting weather is a commitment: once Pelipper is KOed, rain teams often collapse to sun or sand in the end-game. Nevertheless, the duck remains the single most important weather setter in the format, and any team that hopes to succeed in a Bo3 environment needs a specific answer to it.</OUTPUT>

input:
Create the 'matchup_overview' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Pelipper": {"Abilities": {"drizzle": 731.8381354365679, "keeneye": 0.34811325872558047, "raindish": 0.025332376015949398}, "Items": {"focussash": 0.4192339596211849, "choicescarf": 0.36164496991777145}, "Spreads": {"Timid:4/0/0/252/0/252": 0.23941965615477387}, "Moves": ["weatherball", "hurricane", "tailwind", "muddywater"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.5855899245721924}, "Teammates": ["Gholdengo", "Basculegion", "Incineroar", "Archaludon", "Dragonite", "Rillaboom"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Pelipper’s rain immediately flips the offensive math against sun, sand and snow: Torkoal’s Eruption drops to 50% power while Basculegion’s Hydro Steam doubles, and Sand Rush Lycanroc or Snow Warning Cetitan lose their weather-based speed tiers. Against opposing weatherless teams Pelipper behaves like a fast utility pivot, outspeeding and 2HKOing most Incineroar variants with Hurricane while threatening Gholdengo and Dragonite with rain-boosted Muddy Water. Electric-types are the obvious counters, but because Pelipper usually Tera Ghosts on turn 1 the traditional Rotom-W or Iron Hands must instead rely on neutral STAB or coverage moves, giving Pelipper one free turn to set Tailwind or attack. Grass-types such as Rillaboom and Amoonguss are problematic if rain is already up, since they resist both STABs and can retalitate with Glide or Spore; however, Pelipper can Terastallise and click Hurricane for heavy damage, or simply switch to a teammate like Gholdengo or Incineroar that enjoys Grass targets. Kingambit is a mixed bag: it fears rain-boosted Muddy Water but can Sucker Punch Pelipper into sash range and then finish with Iron Head if rain has been overwritten. In the mirror, speed control becomes paramount: the faster Pelipper wins the weather war, so Choice Scarf variants have a massive edge, and both players often burn Tera Ghost early to block Fake Out from the opposing Incineroar. Overall Pelipper’s matchups are favourable against every major archetype except dedicated Electric spam or Grass spam, and even those can be managed with correct Tera timing and ally support.</OUTPUT>

input:
Write a detailed 'role_description' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Pelipper": {"Abilities": {"drizzle": 731.8381354365679, "keeneye": 0.34811325872558047, "raindish": 0.025332376015949398}, "Items": {"focussash": 0.4192339596211849, "choicescarf": 0.36164496991777145}, "Spreads": {"Timid:4/0/0/252/0/252": 0.23941965615477387}, "Moves": ["weatherball", "hurricane", "tailwind", "muddywater"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.5855899245721924}, "Teammates": ["Gholdengo", "Basculegion", "Incineroar", "Archaludon", "Dragonite", "Rillaboom"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Pelipper is the quintessential lead weather setter and fast utility attacker. It opens the game by clicking Drizzle, immediately reshaping the damage output of both sides, and then either fires off perfectly accurate Hurricanes or sets Tailwind to enable Swift Swim sweepers such as Basculegion or Barraskewda. Thanks to its high natural bulk and Focus Sash it is also a mid-game pivot: it can switch in on predicted Earthquakes or Gholdengo Shadow Balls, reset weather, and either attack again or set a second Tailwind for the end-game. Choice Scarf variants sacrifice durability for the ability to act as a surprise revenge killer, outspeeding and KOing threats such as Chien-Pao, Garchomp or opposing Gholdengo while still providing rain for its teammates. Tera Ghost turns Pelipper into a pseudo-status absorber and Fake Out blocker, letting it protect frail Swift Swim partners during the crucial opening turns. Because its STAB combination is only resisted by Rotom-W, Tyranitar and Shedinja, Pelipper can also function as a late-game cleaner once opposing Electric-types have been eliminated, firing off 100% accurate Hurricanes or spread Muddy Waters to finish weakened boards. In short, Pelipper is simultaneously weather setter, speed controller, pivot and secondary attacker—a four-role Swiss-army knife that holds rain teams together.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Pelipper": {"Abilities": {"drizzle": 731.8381354365679, "keeneye": 0.34811325872558047, "raindish": 0.025332376015949398}, "Items": {"focussash": 0.4192339596211849, "choicescarf": 0.36164496991777145}, "Spreads": {"Timid:4/0/0/252/0/252": 0.23941965615477387}, "Moves": ["weatherball", "hurricane", "tailwind", "muddywater"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.5855899245721924}, "Teammates": ["Gholdengo", "Basculegion", "Incineroar", "Archaludon", "Dragonite", "Rillaboom"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Pelipper’s most common teammates—Gholdengo, Basculegion, Incineroar, Archaludon, Dragonite and Rillaboom—illustrate how rain squads are built. Gholdengo provides a Ghost-type immune to Fake Out and Explosion, benefits from rain weakening Fire moves, and pressures opposing Grass-types with Make It Rain; in return Pelipper removes Ghost’s Ghost weaknesses and gives Gholdengo perfect-accuracy Thunders if it chooses to run them. Basculegion is the premier Swift Swim attacker, doubling its Speed in rain and firing off 150 BP Hydro Steams that OHKO most neutral targets; Pelipper guarantees the weather and can Tera Ghost to block priority so Basculegion can sweep unscathed. Incineroar offers Intimidate, Parting Shot and Fake Out, forming a defensive backbone that allows Pelipper to survive the first turn without burning Sash, while Pelipper’s rain halves Incineroar’s Fire weakness and gives it perfectly accurate Hurricanes if it runs Air Balloon or Tera Flying. Archaludon is a pseudo Swift Swim user that enjoys rain boosting its Electro Shot while providing a Steel-type that sponges Ice and Fairy moves for Pelipper; together they form a potent Steel-Flying-Water defensive core that only fears strong Earthquakes. Dragonite appreciates rain halving its Ice weakness and can run Thunder or Hurricane itself, giving the team a second fast Tailwind setter and a bulky win condition that can Roost stall in the end-game. Finally Rillaboom offers Grassy Glide priority, breaking opposing Water-types and providing terrain to cushion Earthquakes that would otherwise threaten Pelipper and its Electric-weak allies. These six Pokémon together produce a balanced rain squad with multiple speed control modes, defensive pivots and offensive win conditions that can adapt to any opposing archetype.</OUTPUT>

This set guarantees rain, survives any single hit, and can reset weather late-game while providing speed control and spread damage. input:
Write the 'weaknesses_and_counters' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Pelipper": {"Abilities": {"drizzle": 731.8381354365679, "keeneye": 0.34811325872558047, "raindish": 0.025332376015949398}, "Items": {"focussash": 0.4192339596211849, "choicescarf": 0.36164496991777145}, "Spreads": {"Timid:4/0/0/252/0/252": 0.23941965615477387}, "Moves": ["weatherball", "hurricane", "tailwind", "muddywater"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.5855899245721924}, "Teammates": ["Gholdengo", "Basculegion", "Incineroar", "Archaludon", "Dragonite", "Rillaboom"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Pelipper’s most reliable counter is a fast Electric-type that can outspeed and KO before Tera, such as Choice Specs Iron Hands or Rotom-Wash with Thunderbolt; however, both must beware Tera Ghost turning the 4× weakness into an immunity and then eating a rain-boosted Muddy Water in return. Grass-types like Rillaboom and Amoonguss resist both STABs and can retaliate with Glide or Spore, but they hate Hurricane’s 30% confusion and can be worn down by spread Muddy Water or a Tera Water Weather Ball. Kingambit can Sucker Punch into sash range and finish with Iron Head if rain has been overwritten, but it fears the 2HKO from Muddy Water and must invest heavily in special bulk to survive. Faster weather setters such as Torkoal in sun or Abomasnow in hail can overwrite Pelipper’s rain, but they must survive a Hurricane or Muddy Water first, and if Pelipper carries Choice Scarf it will usually move first. Priority users like Dragonite Extreme Speed or Chien-Pao Ice Shard can break sash, but again Tera Ghost blocks the first hit and leaves Pelipper free to attack or set Tailwind. Finally, because Pelipper almost never runs Protect, double-targeting it turn one is a common counterplay: if both attacks land it will fall, but this commits resources that could otherwise be spent on its Swift Swim partner. In short, Pelipper is difficult to OHKO without Electric STAB, and even then Tera timing and sash mean opponents usually need two turns or a multi-hit move to remove it—turns in which rain teams can already pivot to a more favourable position.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Basculegion’s unique typing and movepool give it a niche no other Pokémon occupies: a physical Water/Ghost breaker that can double as a revenge killer and pivot. Adaptability is the engine that makes its offenses oppressive—Wave Crash becomes a 234-base-power nuke before STAB, and Last Respects scales to 300+ power once three teammates have fainted. The Pokémon’s fragility (base 80/78/78 bulk) means it almost always carries Focus Sash or a Choice item; the data show an almost perfect three-way split between Band, Scarf, and Sash, indicating that the correct item is highly team-dependent. Adamant nature is ubiquitous, and the 252/252 spread maximizes damage while ensuring Basculegion can either outspeed in rain or under Tailwind, or survive one hit via Sash. Tera Water is preferred for the guaranteed boost to Wave Crash and Flip Turn, but Tera Ghost is equally viable to turn Last Respects into a guaranteed neutral hit against every Pokémon in the format. The combination of Flip Turn and Aqua Jet gives Basculegion unmatched momentum and pick-off power, letting it chip and pivot early before returning late-game to sweep with Last Respects. Rain teams appreciate Swift Swim variants, but the data show Adaptability is overwhelmingly favored, implying that most successful Basculegion builds rely on raw power rather than weather speed control.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Basculegion annihilates slower, bulkier teams that rely on Toxapex, Amoonguss, Garganacl, or Gholdengo to sponge hits; Adaptability Wave Crash cleanly OHKOes all of them after minor chip. Against hyper-offensive squads, Basculegion’s Focus Sash set can trade one-for-one and pivot out, while Choice Scarf variants outspeed and eliminate common threats like Iron Valiant, Chien-Pao, and opposing Swift Swim sweepers. Into Tailwind or rain mirrors, Basculegion becomes a speed-tie roll, so most teams pair it with their own speed control to ensure Last Respects can be fired off before the opponent can KO. Grass-types such as Rillaboom and Amoonguss must fear Tera Ghost Last Respects, while Steel-types like Kingambit and Corviknight hate Tera Water Wave Crash. The only true defensive answers are bulky Water-absorbers (Toxapex with Water immunity, Dondozo) or Ghost-immune Normals like Indeedee-F, but even these can be overwhelmed once Basculegion’s Tera is revealed.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Basculegion": {"Abilities": {"swiftswim": 231.78788608009714, "adaptability": 493.6117903068877, "moldbreaker": 0.0034292253669445105}, "Items": {"choiceband": 0.2377339091651187, "choicescarf": 0.33995989542404603, "focussash": 0.3367424782559069}, "Spreads": {"Adamant:4/252/0/0/0/252": 0.2324647695474018, "Adamant:0/252/4/0/0/252": 0.15551559290830422}, "Moves": ["wavecrash", "flipturn", "lastrespects", "aquajet"], "Tera Types": {"water": 0.43365097874434066, "ghost": 0.37409869958643643}, "Teammates": ["Gholdengo", "Pelipper", "Incineroar", "Archaludon", "Rillaboom", "Ursaluna-Bloodmoon"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Basculegion’s biggest enemy is its own fragility: any strong neutral hit or super-effective priority (Sucker Punch, Shadow Sneak, Aqua Step) breaks Sash and leaves it dead weight. Faster Scarfers like Iron Valiant, Chien-Pao, and opposing weather sweepers can KO before it moves. Bulky Water-immune Pokémon such as Toxapex with Water Absorb or Dondozo can stall out Last Respects PP, while Normal-types like Indeedee-F or bulky Ghost-immune Kingambit can tank a hit and retaliate. Priority Tailwind or Trick Room teams can flip the speed bracket, forcing Basculegion to either predict switches or waste its Sash. Finally, Protect + prediction can waste the Choice-locked move, and once Last Respects is exhausted Basculegion’s damage output drops dramatically. Teams should carry at least one of these answers and preserve it until Basculegion’s Tera is revealed.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Maushold": {"Abilities": {"friendguard": 391.4414979300876, "technician": 213.8694108072639, "cheekpouch": 0.24732864932033305}, "Items": {"safetygoggles": 0.1533147346013117, "widelens": 0.38901440139415483, "focussash": 0.21735779378364078, "rockyhelmet": 0.19753093414214995}, "Spreads": {"Jolly:4/252/0/0/0/252": 0.17583953121552048}, "Moves": ["superfang", "followme", "protect", "beatup"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.6505719221070728}, "Teammates": ["Dragonite", "Annihilape", "Incineroar", "Rillaboom", "Ursaluna-Bloodmoon", "Gholdengo"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>The data show an overwhelming preference for the Technician ability (≈214 uses), doubling the power of Beat Up’s multi-strike chip and giving Maushold a uniquely offensive support niche. Friend Guard (≈391 uses) is even more common, underscoring its primary role as a damage-reducing pivot that keeps key sweepers healthy. Cheek Pouch is virtually unseen. Itemisation is varied but purposeful: Wide Lens (≈0.39) raises Beat Up accuracy and lets Super Fang always land, Focus Sash (≈0.22) guarantees at least two turns of redirection, Rocky Helmet (≈0.20) punishes contact attackers like Palafin and Chien-Pao, and Safety Goggles (≈0.15) blanks Amoonguss and Torkoal. The near-universal Jolly 252/252 spread maximises speed-ties versus base-95 threats such as Dragonite while still letting the mouse survive key rolls through Friend Guard. Ghost Tera (~65 %) removes its Fighting weakness, blocks Fake Out, and grants perfect neutral coverage against the omnipresent Flutter Mane and Gholdengo. The four-moveset is locked: Super Fang for instant 50 % nuke on any wall, Follow Me for ally protection, Protect for stalling and scouting, and Beat Up for breaking Focus Sashes or stacking damage on frail leads. Together these elements create a deceptively fast support that dictates target selection while either enabling or directly contributing to KOs.</OUTPUT>

Priority Encore or double-target pressure can also break its Focus Sash and end its game early.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Maushold is a dedicated support that compresses redirection, percentage damage, and multi-hit chip into one slot. In the early game it soaks damage for setup sweepers, mid-game it slices health bars with Super Fang to open KOs for Dragonite or Ursaluna-Bloodmoon, and late-game it cleans weakened boards with Technician Beat Up. Because it rarely attacks for more than chip, its value is measured in turns bought and damage shared, not raw KO count.</OUTPUT>

input:
Generate the 'synergy_breakdown' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Maushold": {"Abilities": {"friendguard": 391.4414979300876, "technician": 213.8694108072639, "cheekpouch": 0.24732864932033305}, "Items": {"safetygoggles": 0.1533147346013117, "widelens": 0.38901440139415483, "focussash": 0.21735779378364078, "rockyhelmet": 0.19753093414214995}, "Spreads": {"Jolly:4/252/0/0/0/252": 0.17583953121552048}, "Moves": ["superfang", "followme", "protect", "beatup"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.6505719221070728}, "Teammates": ["Dragonite", "Annihilape", "Incineroar", "Rillaboom", "Ursaluna-Bloodmoon", "Gholdengo"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Dragonite appreciates Follow Me while it sets up Dragon Dance and loves Beat Up for Weakness Policy activation; Annihilape converts every Follow Me turn into Rage Fist snowballing; Incineroar forms a disruptive core, Intimidating on the same turn Maushold redirects, while both shrug off Ghost and Dark moves for each other. Rillaboom provides priority Grassy Glide to finish Super Fang damage, breaks enemy Sash with Beat Up, and removes terrain that hampers sleep. Ursaluna-Bloodmoon benefits from Friend Guard to survive special hits while it sets up Blood Moon, and Gholdengo blocks opposing status and spreads Make It Rain behind Maushold’s redirection. In return, Maushold relies on these partners to handle Ghosts, spread burn or paralysis, and apply immediate offensive pressure so its support isn’t wasted.</OUTPUT>

Create the 'weaknesses_and_counters' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Maushold": {"Abilities": {"friendguard": 391.4414979300876, "technician": 213.8694108072639, "cheekpouch": 0.24732864932033305}, "Items": {"safetygoggles": 0.1533147346013117, "widelens": 0.38901440139415483, "focussash": 0.21735779378364078, "rockyhelmet": 0.19753093414214995}, "Spreads": {"Jolly:4/252/0/0/0/252": 0.17583953121552048}, "Moves": ["superfang", "followme", "protect", "beatup"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.6505719221070728}, "Teammates": ["Dragonite", "Annihilape", "Incineroar", "Rillaboom", "Ursaluna-Bloodmoon", "Gholdengo"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Ghost-types such as Aegislash and opposing Ghost-Tera Maushold ignore Follow Me and OHKO with Shadow Ball or Flash Cannon. Faster Taunt or Encore users—Meowscarada, Grimmsnarl, Talonflame—shut down its support options before it moves. Spread attackers like Sylveon, Tatsugiri, or Landorus-T ignore redirection and KO through Friend Guard. Priority users that can double-target (Chien-Pao + Kingambit) break its Sash and prevent Follow Me from ever going up. Finally, Iron Hands and Ting-Lu survive Super Fang and retaliate with powerful spread moves, forcing Maushold to waste turns Protecting instead of supporting.</OUTPUT>

input:
Provide the 'sample_team_concept' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Maushold": {"Abilities": {"friendguard": 391.4414979300876, "technician": 213.8694108072639, "cheekpouch": 0.24732864932033305}, "Items": {"safetygoggles": 0.1533147346013117, "widelens": 0.38901440139415483, "focussash": 0.21735779378364078, "rockyhelmet": 0.19753093414214995}, "Spreads": {"Jolly:4/252/0/0/0/252": 0.17583953121552048}, "Moves": ["superfang", "followme", "protect", "beatup"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.6505719221070728}, "Teammates": ["Dragonite", "Annihilape", "Incineroar", "Rillaboom", "Ursaluna-Bloodmoon", "Gholdengo"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Build a bulky offensive core around Technician Maushold, Dragonite, and Annihilape. Lead Maushold + Dragonite: Turn 1 Follow Me + Dragon Dance; Turn 2 Beat Up activates Weakness Policy for a +2/+1 sweep. Back row Annihilape + Incineroar: once Dragonite softens the field, bring in the apes to clean with Rage Fist and Parting Shot pressure. Rillaboom as a flex slot sets Grassy Terrain, breaks Sashes with Glide, and knocks Flying-types out of the sky. Finish with Gholdengo to block status and spread Make It Rain, and a Choice Specs Tatsugiri to nuke troublesome Waters and provide speed control via Icy Wind. EV spreads focus on surviving Flutter Mane Moonblast and Kingambit Sucker Punch while outspeeding base-95s; Maushold’s Ghost Tera ties the team together by blanking Fake Out and turning Fighting weaknesses neutral.</OUTPUT>
