<DATA>{"Tatsugiri": {"Abilities": {"stormdrain": 10.530342023448558, "commander": 567.1806461406508}, "Items": {"choicescarf": 0.3566062486259786, "safetygoggles": 0.3579639705976813}, "Spreads": {"Timid:0/0/0/252/4/252": 0.18425297054941883, "Modest:156/0/132/4/4/212": 0.22424926574951734}, "Moves": ["dracometeor", "protect", "icywind", "muddywater"], "Tera Types": {"fairy": 0.4675887492275469, "steel": 0.27926971547233315}, "Teammates": ["Dondozo", "Incineroar", "Annihilape", "Glimmora", "Kingambit", "Weezing"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Tatsugiri is a niche support Pokémon whose entire competitive identity hinges on the Commander ability, which lets it perch on Dondozo and gift it a free +2 to every stat. While its own base stats are unimpressive, the dragon sees consistent usage (567% usage share) precisely because it turns Dondozo into an end-game win condition. Outside of this one combo it offers little—its movepool is shallow, its bulk is paper-thin, and it is almost always one-shot if forced to take a hit—so every team that includes it is built around enabling the “Big Fish” duo.</OUTPUT>

input:
Provide the 'full_analysis' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Tatsugiri": {"Abilities": {"stormdrain": 10.530342023448558, "commander": 567.1806461406508}, "Items": {"choicescarf": 0.3566062486259786, "safetygoggles": 0.3579639705976813}, "Spreads": {"Timid:0/0/0/252/4/252": 0.18425297054941883, "Modest:156/0/132/4/4/212": 0.22424926574951734}, "Moves": ["dracometeor", "protect", "icywind", "muddywater"], "Tera Types": {"fairy": 0.4675887492275469, "steel": 0.27926971547233315}, "Teammates": ["Dondozo", "Incineroar", "Annihilape", "Glimmora", "Kingambit", "Weezing"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Commander is the only reason Tatsugiri exists in VGC 2024. On turn one it can hop into Dondozo’s mouth, become untargetable, and immediately donate +2 Attack, Defense, Special Attack, Special Defense and Speed. In one action you compress Dragon Dance, Calm Mind and Iron Defense into a single slot, allowing Dondozo to outspeed the unboosted metagame and OHKO most neutral targets with Liquidation or Wave Crash. Tatsugiri’s own spread is EVed to survive incidental spread damage (Modest 156/0/132/4/4/212) or maximize Speed to fire off fast Icy Winds and Draco Meteors (Timid 252 Spe). Draco Meteor gives it a 130 BP STAB nuke that still does respectable chip to neutral targets even with no investment, while Muddy Water provides spread damage and a handy 30 % accuracy debuff for end-game fishing. Icy Wind is the preferred speed-control option because it works from the safety of Commander, letting Dondozo outspeed key threats without requiring Tera or further support. Protect is mandatory when you are eventually forced onto the field, because almost any unresisted STAB attack will KO. Tera Fairy is the default to dodge Dragon-type retaliation aimed at Dondozo and to gain a crucial resistance to Dark and Fighting moves; Tera Steel is an alternative that flips the Fairy and Ice weaknesses into resistances, making it easier to stomach a Moonblast or an Ice Spinner. Choice Scarf is occasionally run to outspeed opposing Scarfers when Tatsugiri is forced to fight alone, but Safety Goggles is the preferred item to ignore enemy Amoonguss and Glimmora hazards while you set up the combo.</OUTPUT>

input:
Write the 'matchup_overview' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Tatsugiri": {"Abilities": {"stormdrain": 10.530342023448558, "commander": 567.1806461406508}, "Items": {"choicescarf": 0.3566062486259786, "safetygoggles": 0.3579639705976813}, "Spreads": {"Timid:0/0/0/252/4/252": 0.18425297054941883, "Modest:156/0/132/4/4/212": 0.22424926574951734}, "Moves": ["dracometeor", "protect", "icywind", "muddywater"], "Tera Types": {"fairy": 0.4675887492275469, "steel": 0.27926971547233315}, "Teammates": ["Dondozo", "Incineroar", "Annihilape", "Glimmora", "Kingambit", "Weezing"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>The duo autowins against teams that lack either (a) a way to KO Dondozo through its boosts or (b) Unaware or Haze users. Against standard hyper-offense you simply click Commander, survive the double-target with your partner’s redirection, and proceed to sweep. Into Tailwind or Chlorophyll teams you often need to Tera Dondozo to live a +1 or +2 attack and then KO back, but you still retain favorable odds. Where the strategy struggles is versus Iron Hands and Iron Bundle, both of which can survive a +2 Liquidation and retaliate with strong Electric or Freeze-Dry damage; versus Unaware Dondozo mirrors that ignore your boosts; and versus Haze Toxapex or Amoonguss that can clear stats after you’ve committed your resources. Opposing Incineroar is annoying because Intimidate neuters your first boost, forcing you to Tera or switch out and reset. Psychic-spam teams with Indeedee–Armarouge also threaten to OHKO Tatsugiri before it can merge, so you need Fake Out or Follow Me support to guarantee the combo.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Tatsugiri": {"Abilities": {"stormdrain": 10.530342023448558, "commander": 567.1806461406508}, "Items": {"choicescarf": 0.3566062486259786, "safetygoggles": 0.3579639705976813}, "Spreads": {"Timid:0/0/0/252/4/252": 0.18425297054941883, "Modest:156/0/132/4/4/212": 0.22424926574951734}, "Moves": ["dracometeor", "protect", "icywind", "muddywater"], "Tera Types": {"fairy": 0.4675887492275469, "steel": 0.27926971547233315}, "Teammates": ["Dondozo", "Incineroar", "Annihilape", "Glimmora", "Kingambit", "Weezing"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Tatsugiri is a dedicated enabler whose sole job is to press Commander, then spam Icy Wind or Muddy Water from the safety of its partner’s throat. It is not a win condition itself; instead it functions as a one-time consumable resource that converts board positioning into an almost unstoppable end-game sweeper. After the boost is secured it pivots into a passive speed-control slot, slowing faster threats so Dondozo can continue to move first without requiring Tailwind or Chlorophyll. Because it cannot be targeted while merged, it also acts as a pseudo-protect for Dondozo, forcing opponents to waste turns or spread damage onto the other slot.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Tatsugiri": {"Abilities": {"stormdrain": 10.530342023448558, "commander": 567.1806461406508}, "Items": {"choicescarf": 0.3566062486259786, "safetygoggles": 0.3579639705976813}, "Spreads": {"Timid:0/0/0/252/4/252": 0.18425297054941883, "Modest:156/0/132/4/4/212": 0.22424926574951734}, "Moves": ["dracometeor", "protect", "icywind", "muddywater"], "Tera Types": {"fairy": 0.4675887492275469, "steel": 0.27926971547233315}, "Teammates": ["Dondozo", "Incineroar", "Annihilape", "Glimmora", "Kingambit", "Weezing"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Dondozo is obviously mandatory—without it Tatsugiri is a liability. The pair is almost always rounded out with Incineroar, which provides Fake Out, Intimidate and Parting Shot to buy the setup turn and later slow opposing physical attackers. Annihilape gives a secondary win condition that abuses the same speed-control, while Glimmora sets Toxic Spikes to wear down bulky Water and Steel answers to Dondozo. Kingambit offers priority and Defiant to punish Intimidate cycles, and Weezing-Galar neutralizes opposing abilities that could block the sweep. In general you want one slot that can redirect or Fake Out, one slot that can remove hazards or set your own, and one flexible attacker that can clean if Dondozo is compromised.</OUTPUT>

Unaware users—most notably opposing Dondozo and Clefable—ignore the boosts and stall you out with Seismic Toss or Moonblast. Priority Tailwind or Chlorophyll plus a Grass-type attacker (Whimsicott + Venusaur) can outspeed and KO even after the boost. Finally, Perish Song and trapping moves like Mean Look or Fire Spin can force a timer that the fish struggle to break.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Amoonguss is a premier support pivot in Regulation G doubles, leveraging Regenerator, redirection, and status to grind down foes while keeping partners healthy; its near-universal presence on bulky balance squads stems from the combination of Spore’s game-swinging sleep, Rage Powder’s invaluable redirection, and Pollen Puff’s dual utility of healing allies or damaging enemies, all backed by deceptively solid bulk and a Tera Water option that flips Fire- and Ice-type matchups.</OUTPUT>

input:
Create the 'full_analysis' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Amoonguss": {"Abilities": {"regenerator": 547.9858885313957, "effectspore": 11.47929950730025}, "Items": {"sitrusberry": 0.4549350312109706, "rockyhelmet": 0.16073960877572635, "covertcloak": 0.18272516896270008}, "Spreads": {}, "Moves": ["spore", "ragepowder", "pollenpuff", "protect"], "Tera Types": {"water": 0.5310972294639063}, "Teammates": ["Gholdengo", "Basculegion", "Incineroar", "Archaludon", "Ursaluna-Bloodmoon", "Porygon2"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Amoonguss’s EV spreads are omitted from the data, but ladder usage overwhelmingly favors Regenerator (≈96 %), underscoring its role as a hit-and-run pivot that recovers 33 % on every switch. Sitrus Berry is the most common item, granting a 25 % heal at 50 % HP that synergizes with Regenerator to let Amoonguss tank super-effective hits and remain on the field longer; Rocky Helmet punishes contact attackers like Urshifu, Chien-Pao, and opposing Incineroar, while Covert Cloak blanks secondary effects such as Nuzzle, Snarl, and opposing Effect Spore procs. Spore remains the best single-target disruption tool in doubles, forcing either a switch or a wasted turn, while Rage Powder guarantees that Amoonguss can redirect Electric-, Grass-, or Dragon-type attacks away from frail sweepers. Pollen Puff provides emergency 50 % healing to key partners such as Gholdengo or Basculegion while still threatening opposing Pokémon for modest damage. Protect rounds out the set, scouting choice-locked attackers and stalling out speed control or weather turns. Tera Water is the dominant Tera type, removing the Fire weakness and turning 4× Ice neutrality into a resistance, letting Amoonguss stomach Ice Spinner or Chien-Pao Icicle Crash and continue supporting the team. The lack of offensive moves reflects Amoonguss’s philosophy: every turn is spent either neutralizing threats or enabling allies, never wasting time on low-damage Sludge Bombs.</OUTPUT>

input:
Write the 'matchup_overview' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Amoonguss": {"Abilities": {"regenerator": 547.9858885313957, "effectspore": 11.47929950730025}, "Items": {"sitrusberry": 0.4549350312109706, "rockyhelmet": 0.16073960877572635, "covertcloak": 0.18272516896270008}, "Spreads": {}, "Moves": ["spore", "ragepowder", "pollenpuff", "protect"], "Tera Types": {"water": 0.5310972294639063}, "Teammates": ["Gholdengo", "Basculegion", "Incineroar", "Archaludon", "Ursaluna-Bloodmoon", "Porygon2"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Amoonguss shines against setup or speed-control cores that rely on single-target moves—Flutter Mane, Calyrex-I, and Dragon Dance Archaludon hate Spore and Rage Powder. It neutralizes opposing support Pokémon such as Murkrow, Indeedee, and enemy Amoonguss by outslowing them and absorbing or redirecting their priority. Against hyper-offense, Amoonguss can trade one-for-one with a key sleep or redirect a Dynamax move, buying a free turn for its partner to sweep. However, it struggles against Safety Goggles users (notably Tusk and opposing Ogerpon), Taunt users like Chien-Pao or Tornadus, and spread attackers such as Koraidon and Iron Treads that ignore Rage Powder. Sun teams with Torkoal also pressure Amoonguss, as Eruption under sun cleanly OHKOes even bulky spreads unless Amoonguss Terastallizes to Water.</OUTPUT>

It is almost always brought to game 1 because it simultaneously checks opposing support, protects its own sweepers, and provides a Regenerator safety net that punishes passive play. In the mid-game it switches repeatedly, recovering chip and spreading status, while in the endgame it can Spore the last threat or Pollen Puff a low-health teammate to clinch a 1-0. Its low Speed is an asset, letting it move last to redirect or underspeed Trick Room attackers.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Gholdengo pairs perfectly: it blocks enemy Spore with Good-as-Gold, benefits from Rage Powder redirection, and appreciates Pollen Puff healing while it sets up or fires Make-It-Rain. Basculegion’s Ghost typing removes the Normal-type immunity to Spore, and Amoonguss redirects Electric moves aimed at Basculegion while Basculegion deletes opposing Psychic- or Ghost-types that threaten Amoonguss. Incineroar forms a classic “Fungi-core,” cycling Intimidate and Parting Shot to soften physical attackers while Amoonguss sponges special hits; both have pivoting moves and Regenerator, so the duo can switch endlessly and wear down teams. Archaludon loves redirection while it sets up Stamina and Dragon Cheer; Amoonguss in turn covers the Fighting- and Ground-type moves that trouble Archaludon. Ursaluna-Bloodmoon enjoys Spore support to set up Calm Minds or Blood Moon nukes, and Amoonguss heals it with Pollen Puff after Substitute or Calm Mind chip. Porygon2 completes a bulky Trick Room mode, with Amoonguss underspeeding to redirect and letting Porygon2 fire Download-boosted Tri-Attacks or set Trick Room for the rest of the slow core.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Ursalina is a physically monstrous, status-immune wallbreaker that thrives under Trick Room: Guts-boosted Facade and STAB Earthquake/Headlong Rush rip through common Incineroar, Gholdengo and non-Tera Archaludon cores, while Flame Orb blocks sleep and burns so it can swing even when targeted by support Pokémon.  The bear is almost always paired with Incineroar, Indeedee-F and Torkoal—three staples that set sun, redirect, Intimidate and provide speed control—letting Ursalina focus on raw damage and positioning rather than speed investment.  Its only real drawbacks are a middling special bulk and a 4× weakness to Water under sun, so teams usually carry at least two Water resists and a slow pivot game-plan to bring it in safely.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Ursaluna": {"Abilities": {"guts": 443.2352267963257, "bulletproof": 45.37902404523216, "unnerve": 0.00016704902150121992}, "Items": {"flameorb": 0.9051939135811934}, "Spreads": {}, "Moves": ["facade", "earthquake", "headlongrush", "protect"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.7900964935621629}, "Teammates": ["Incineroar", "Indeedee-F", "Torkoal", "Archaludon", "Gholdengo", "Sinistcha"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>The data show a hyper-specialised spread: Guts appears on 89 % of teams, Flame Orb on 91 %, and Facade + dual-STAB Ground moves are virtually mandatory, with Protect rounding out the set.  This tells us players treat Ursalina as a one-dimensional but extremely efficient breaker: switch in on expected WoW or Spore, absorb the status, click Facade for 140 × 1.5 × STAB off 145 base Attack, and delete whatever doesn’t resist.  Headlong Rush is preferred over Earthquake on roughly half the teams because the extra 20 BP plus Terrain control lets it OHKO max-HP Gholdengo through Tera Steel, while Earthquake remains the spread option for doubles.  Tera Ghost (79 %) is the only Tera type recorded, a clear nod to making it immune to both Fake Out and its own Earthquake while also dodging Fighting-type revenge-killing attempts from Pokemon like Iron Hands or opposing Ursalina.  The absence of recorded Speed EV spreads suggests almost every build is 0 Spe IV Quiet nature under Trick Room, underscoring the bear’s identity as a Room abuser rather than a mid-speed tank.  Teammate frequencies reinforce this: Incineroar (Intimidate, Parting Shot), Indeedee-F (Follow Me, Psychic Terrain) and Torkoal (sun + Eruption) form the classic “sun-Room” shell, giving Ursalina free switches, redirect, and a weather that neuters opposing Water moves.  Archaludon and Gholdengo appear as back-up slow breakers that appreciate Ground-immune partners, while Sinistcha offers additional burn spreading and passive healing to offset Flame Orb chip.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Ursalina is oppressive into Fire-, Steel-, Electric- and Poison-type cores—common in sun teams—because Facade and Headlong Rush both land super-effective or neutral while Ursalina ignores burns.  It cleanly OHKOs standard Incineroar, Gholdengo and Iron Moth, and 2HKOs most Archaludon and Tera-Fairy Sinistcha.  Conversely, Rain teams or anything carrying fast Water-types (Pelipper, Barraskewda, Iron Bundle) force it out immediately; a max-attack Liquidation from Iron Bundle in rain is a guaranteed KO.  Priority users that can hit before Room goes up—Dragonite Extreme Speed, Kingambit Sucker Punch—also threaten to finish it off after chip.  Finally, burn-immune physical walls such as Dondozo and Tera-Water Garganacl can stall Facade PP and outlast it.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Whimsicott": {"Abilities": {"prankster": 474.59478988407443, "infiltrator": 0.0025100258587175683, "chlorophyll": 2.860211315321871}, "Items": {"covertcloak": 0.6915619321576226, "focussash": 0.294711292319046}, "Spreads": {"Timid:4/0/0/252/0/252": 0.16372904441065048}, "Moves": ["tailwind", "moonblast", "faketears", "encore"], "Tera Types": {"steel": 0.3348838901152788, "ghost": 0.2830203314120877}, "Teammates": ["Incineroar", "Basculegion", "Pelipper", "Archaludon", "Gholdengo", "Ursaluna-Bloodmoon"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Whimsicott is a premier support Pokémon in VGC thanks almost entirely to Prankster, which turns its already disruptive movepool into priority utility. With a single Timid 252/252 spread it outspeeds the entire unboosted metagame and fires off guaranteed-first Tailwind, Encore, or Fake Tears, swinging momentum before the opponent can blink. Moonblast gives it just enough offensive presence to finish weakened foes or chip Dragons and Dark-types, while Covert Cloak shields it from Rage Powder/Fake Out shenanigans and Focus Sash guarantees at least one turn of setup. Tera Steel or Ghost patch its middling bulk and create temporary immunities, letting it live long enough to cycle Tailwind twice in a match. The data show it is almost always drafted alongside bulky pivots like Incineroar or Archaludon and hard-hitting special attackers such as Basculegion and Bloodmoon Ursaluna, forming a classic “speed-control plus breaker” core that dominates mid-game positioning.</OUTPUT>

input:
Write a detailed 'full_analysis' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Whimsicott": {"Abilities": {"prankster": 474.59478988407443, "infiltrator": 0.0025100258587175683, "chlorophyll": 2.860211315321871}, "Items": {"covertcloak": 0.6915619321576226, "focussash": 0.294711292319046}, "Spreads": {"Timid:4/0/0/252/0/252": 0.16372904441065048}, "Moves": ["tailwind", "moonblast", "faketears", "encore"], "Tera Types": {"steel": 0.3348838901152788, "ghost": 0.2830203314120877}, "Teammates": ["Incineroar", "Basculegion", "Pelipper", "Archaludon", "Gholdengo", "Ursaluna-Bloodmoon"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Prankster is the engine that makes Whimsicott irreplaceable: every non-damaging move gains +1 priority, so Tailwind, Encore, and Fake Tears all outpace even opposing priority. This allows Whimsicott to punish setup sweepers, lock support Pokémon into Protect or useless status moves, and instantly tilt the speed tiers for its slower but powerful partners. The chosen Timid 252 HP / 252 Speed spread maximises both bulk and speed; at 116 base Speed it naturally outruns the crowded 100-110 tier, while the remaining EVs are dumped into HP to survive stray spread moves or a single neutral hit. Covert Cloak is the item of choice because it ignores the secondary effects of Fake Out, Rock Slide flinches, and Nuzzle paralysis, ensuring Whimsicott executes its game plan even under pressure. Focus Sash is a lower-usage but still valid option on more offensive teams that need to guarantee Tailwind versus double-target focus fire. Tera Steel is preferred for the key resistances to Rock, Poison, and Ice—common spread-move types—plus a crucial Toxic immunity, while Tera Ghost blocks Extreme Speed and gives a one-turn dodge to Fake Out and Rapid Spin. Encore is the most punishing tool: after an opponent uses Protect or a setup move, locking them into it for even one turn usually nets a free switch or double-up opportunity. Fake Tears is a 2-for-1 special defense drop that turns standard calcs into OHKOs for the likes of Basculegion’s Hydro Pump or Gholdengo’s Make It Rain. Moonblast rounds the set by giving Whimsicott a spammable STAB that 2HKOs most Dragons and Dark-types while occasionally dropping their special attack. The listed teammates—Incineroar, Basculegion, Pelipper, Archaludon, Gholdengo, Ursaluna-Bloodmoon—illustrate two archetypes: rain/bulky pivot builds that abuse perfect accuracy Thunders and Hurricanes, and hard-hitting Trick Room counter builds that want Tailwind to reverse opposing room or to operate outside room themselves. Whimsicott’s presence forces opponents to respect both speed brackets, compressing their options and often causing over-protecting or mis-clicking into Encore.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Whimsicott": {"Abilities": {"prankster": 474.59478988407443, "infiltrator": 0.0025100258587175683, "chlorophyll": 2.860211315321871}, "Items": {"covertcloak": 0.6915619321576226, "focussash": 0.294711292319046}, "Spreads": {"Timid:4/0/0/252/0/252": 0.16372904441065048}, "Moves": ["tailwind", "moonblast", "faketears", "encore"], "Tera Types": {"steel": 0.3348838901152788, "ghost": 0.2830203314120877}, "Teammates": ["Incineroar", "Basculegion", "Pelipper", "Archaludon", "Gholdengo", "Ursaluna-Bloodmoon"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Whimsicott single-handedly flips the speed war versus most offensive teams, so hyper-offense builds that rely on outspeeding with booster energy or Choice Scarf (Kilowattel, Iron Moth, Chien-Pao) struggle if they fail to OHKO it before it sets Tailwind. Against bulkier balanced cores, Encore cripples common Protect/Parting Shot cycles from Incineroar or Toxapex, while Fake Tears breaks open standard special walls like Garganacl and Ting-Lu. Stall and semi-stall hate the combination of priority Tailwind and Encore because it denies their usual Protect stalling and Trick Room reversals. Whimsicott is only truly poor into opposing Dark-types—especially Kingambit and Chien-Pao—whose Dark typing blanks Prankster, and into Iron Bundle/Iron Jugulis that outspeed even at -1 and threaten OHKOs with Freeze-Dry or Iron Head. Teams packing multiple forms of priority (Dragonite E-Speed, Kingambit Sucker Punch) can also stack damage to break Sash or Cloak variants. Nonetheless, the threat of Encore often forces those Pokémon to attack into Protect or switch, giving Whimsicott’s partner free rein.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Whimsicott is a dedicated speed-control and disruption support. It occupies the “fast utility” slot, compressing Tailwind setter, Encore trapper, and special defense shredder into one slot. In team preview it signals an aggressive tempo: either your own Tailwind turns or a denial of the opponent’s setup. It does not attempt to sweep or tank; instead it guarantees one to two momentum swings per game, after which it sacrifices itself or switches out to bring in a breaker under Tailwind. Its offensive output is deliberately minimal—Moonblast is present only to avoid being complete Taunt bait and to chip targets into range of partner attacks. EVs and item are optimised for survival of the first two turns, because if Whimsicott gets two non-damaging moves off, the mathematical advantage gained through Encore or Fake Tears is usually game-winning.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Incineroar is the ideal partner: Intimidate and Parting Shot soften physical attackers that threaten Whimsicott, while Whimsicott returns the favour by Encoring predicted Protects or by setting Tailwind so Incineroar can outspeed and Snarl first. Basculegion and Bloodmoon Ursaluna are special breakers that adore Fake Tears: after a single drop their STABs climb to guaranteed OHKOs on neutral targets, and under Tailwind they outspeed even scarfed base 100s. Pelipper brings rain, which halves Fire damage for Whimsicort and enables perfect-accuracy Hurricanes from itself or partners; Whimsicott can Encore drought setters like Torkoal to keep rain up. Archaludon offers a slow pivot with massive physical bulk that can tank Iron Heads for Whimsicott and immediately threaten KO back with Steel Beam or Flash Cannon under Tailwind. Gholdengo blocks opposing status and Rapid Spin, ensuring hazards stay up, while Whimsicott’s Encore keeps Gholdengo free to spam Make It Rain. Across these six teammates, the core concept is “set Tailwind, drop special defense, pivot to breaker” executed with priority, making the team function like a well-oiled machine that can flip between rain and standard Tailwind modes at team preview.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Whimsicott": {"Abilities": {"prankster": 474.59478988407443, "infiltrator": 0.0025100258587175683, "chlorophyll": 2.860211315321871}, "Items": {"covertcloak": 0.6915619321576226, "focussash": 0.294711292319046}, "Spreads": {"Timid:4/0/0/252/0/252": 0.16372904441065048}, "Moves": ["tailwind", "moonblast", "faketears", "encore"], "Tera Types": {"steel": 0.3348838901152788, "ghost": 0.2830203314120877}, "Teammates": ["Incineroar", "Basculegion", "Pelipper", "Archaludon", "Gholdengo", "Ursaluna-Bloodmoon"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Standard Support: Timid 252 HP / 4 Def / 252 Spe — Prankster — Covert Cloak — Tailwind / Moonblast / Encore / Fake Tears — Tera Steel. This is the most common and consistent variant: it outspeeds everything unboosted, ignores flinch/para, and survives most spread hits long enough to fire two moves. Sash Variant: Timid 252 HP / 4 Def / 252 Spe — Prankster — Focus Sash — Tailwind / Moonblast / Encore / Fake Tears — Tera Ghost. Run this when you expect double-target focus fire or when your team already carries Covert Cloak on another slot; Tera Ghost blocks Fake Out and Extreme Speed, guaranteeing Tailwind versus priority-heavy teams. output: <OUTPUT>Indeedee single-handedly flips match-ups against priority-reliant teams. Into Incineroar, Kingambit, or Breloom squads that lean on Fake Out + Sucker Punch cores, Psychic Terrain turns their game plan off and forces them to play honest, slower tempo. Against faster offensive squads built around Dragapult, Iron Valiant, or Choice-scarf Koraidon, Indeedee can trade turns: it either sets Trick Room to let its own slower threats move first, or fires a spread Expanding Force to chunk the opposition before going down. Terrain also neuters Amoonguss, the most common support Pokémon in the format, by blocking Spore and Rage Powder, allowing partners such as Gholdengo or Annihilape to click attacks or set up without disruption. On the flip side, Steel-types such as Gholdengo and Kingambit shrug off Expanding Force, while Dark-types like Tyranitar and Chien-Pao are immune and can retaliate with heavy damage. Shadow Rider Calyrex outspeeds and OHKOes with Astral Barrage, and any faster Taunt user (e.g., Whimsicott, Grimmsnarl) can shut down Trick Room attempts. Terrain only affects grounded Pokémon, so flying or levitating attackers such as Tornadus, Lando-T, or Flutter Mane still enjoy their priority options. Finally, because Indeedee is almost always Sashed or Scarfed, multi-hit attackers like Breloom’s Bullet Seed or Kingambit’s Supreme Overlord-boosted attacks can break the Sash and KO, while residual damage from Rocky Helmet or Iron Barbs can cripple it before it accomplishes its mission.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Indeedee": {"Abilities": {"psychicsurge": 450.6195177977429, "innerfocus": 0.9135525475409073, "synchronize": 2.02201999588425e-09}, "Items": {"focussash": 0.6157616120249902, "choicescarf": 0.3024610888017483}, "Spreads": {"Timid:4/0/0/252/0/252": 0.32682938390349775, "Modest:4/0/0/252/0/252": 0.16284509720871687, "Timid:0/0/0/252/4/252": 0.19632320085849822}, "Moves": ["expandingforce", "trickroom", "protect", "terablast"], "Tera Types": {"psychic": 0.669118618744047}, "Teammates": ["Gholdengo", "Sneasler", "Dondozo", "Tatsugiri", "Annihilape", "Tyranitar"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Indeedee’s most common partners—Gholdengo, Sneasler, Dondozo, Tatsugiri, Annihilape, and Tyranitar—form a clear picture of the archetype it enables. Gholdengo shares an immunity to Fake Out and benefits from blocked Bullet Punch and Sucker Punch, allowing it to spam Make It Rain or set up Calm Minds safely. Annihilape and Tyranitar are slow, bulky attackers that love Trick Room and hate priority: under terrain they can click Rage Fist or Crunch without fear of Aqua Jet or Sucker Punch finishes. Dondozo + Tatsugiri is a classic slow core that appreciates both the removal of sleep and the reversal of speed brackets; Indeedee can set Trick Room, then sac itself so Dondozo can sweep under Commander boosts. Sneasler, although fast, is often run in bulkier Tailwind-less squads that pivot into Trick Room mode, and it enjoys terrain blocking Mach Punch and Bullet Punch that would otherwise pick it off after a Toxic Boost. All of these Pokémon are grounded and thus receive the full benefit of Psychic Terrain, while their shared weaknesses to Ghost and Dark are partially mitigated by Indeedee’s ability to remove opposing Ghost-type priority. In return, they cover Indeedee’s inability to break Steel-types (Gholdengo, Tyranitar) or to handle fast Flying-type offense (Dondozo, Annihilape).</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Standard Support Lead: Timid nature, 4 HP / 0 Atk / 0 Def / 252 SpA / 0 SpD / 252 Spe, Focus Sash, Psychic Surge – Expanding Force / Trick Room / Protect / Tera Blast, Tera Psychic. This is the most common variant, guaranteeing terrain and one additional move before fainting. Choice Scarf Pivot: Timid nature, 0 Atk / 0 Def / 252 SpA / 0 SpD / 252 Spe, Choice Scarf, Psychic Surge – Expanding Force / Trick Room / Protect / Tera Blast, Tera Psychic. This set underspeeds most Scarfers after Trick Room, letting it revenge kill or set room mid-game. Modest Wallbreaker: Modest nature, 4 HP / 0 Atk / 0 Def / 252 SpA / 0 SpD / 252 Spe, Focus Sash, Psychic Surge – Expanding Force / Trick Room / Protect / Tera Blast, Tera Psychic. The extra power guarantees key OHKOs on neutral targets such as non-bulk Dragonite and Ogerpon-Wellspring at the cost of losing the speed tie against opposing Timid base 95s. All three sets run minimal bulk because Indeedee’s role is to trade itself for terrain and either Trick Room or immediate damage; investment in bulk rarely yields extra turns in the current offensive metagame.</OUTPUT>

input:
Generate the 'weaknesses_and_counters' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Indeedee": {"Abilities": {"psychicsurge": 450.6195177977429, "innerfocus": 0.9135525475409073, "synchronize": 2.02201999588425e-09}, "Items": {"focussash": 0.6157616120249902, "choicescarf": 0.3024610888017483}, "Spreads": {"Timid:4/0/0/252/0/252": 0.32682938390349775, "Modest:4/0/0/252/0/252": 0.16284509720871687, "Timid:0/0/0/252/4/252": 0.19632320085849822}, "Moves": ["expandingforce", "trickroom", "protect", "terablast"], "Tera Types": {"psychic": 0.669118618744047}, "Teammates": ["Gholdengo", "Sneasler", "Dondozo", "Tatsugiri", "Annihilape", "Tyranitar"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Indeedee is frail and prediction-reliant. Any faster Dark-type—Chien-Pao, Tyranitar, Kingambit—can switch in on Expanding Force for free and OHKO with Knock Off or Kowtow Cleave. Shadow Rider Calyrex outspeeds and deletes with Astral Barrage even through Sash, while Flutter Mane can live one Tera Blast and retaliate with Shadow Ball. Priority that bypasses terrain, such as Tornadus’s Flying-type Tailwind + Hurricane or Iron Jugulis’s Air Slash, still threatens it. Taunt users—Whimsicott, Grimmsnarl, or Iron Valiant—shut down Trick Room and force Indeedee to attack into potential immunities. Multi-hit moves like Breloom’s Bullet Seed or Kingambit’s Supreme Overlord-boosted attacks break Sash and KO, while Rocky Helmet or Iron Barbs chip can deny the second turn. Terrain only affects grounded Pokémon, so Levitate Bronzong or Flying-type Pokémon such as Corviknight or Togekiss still fire priority moves. Finally, because Indeedee is almost always the first Pokémon to faint, opposing teams can simply ignore it, KO the partner, and deal with terrain later; if Indeedee fails to set Trick Room or land meaningful damage, it becomes a 3-v-4 uphill battle.</OUTPUT>

input:
Provide the 'sample_team_concept' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Indeedee": {"Abilities": {"psychicsurge": 450.6195177977429, "innerfocus": 0.9135525475409073, "synchronize": 2.02201999588425e-09}, "Items": {"focussash": 0.6157616120249902, "choicescarf": 0.3024610888017483}, "Spreads": {"Timid:4/0/0/252/0/252": 0.32682938390349775, "Modest:4/0/0/252/0/252": 0.16284509720871687, "Timid:0/0/0/252/4/252": 0.19632320085849822}, "Moves": ["expandingforce", "trickroom", "protect", "terablast"], "Tera Types": {"psychic": 0.669118618744047}, "Teammates": ["Gholdengo", "Sneasler", "Dondozo", "Tatsugiri", "Annihilape", "Tyranitar"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Indeedee @ Focus Sash – Timid – Psychic Surge – Expanding Force / Trick Room / Protect / Tera Blast – Tera Psychic. Gholdengo @ Life Orb – Modest – Good as Gold – Make It Rain / Shadow Ball / Protect / Recover – Tera Steel. Annihilape @ Leftovers – Brave – Defiant – Rage Fist / Drain Punch / Bulk Up / Protect – Tera Fighting. Dondozo @ Sitrus Berry – Relaxed – Unaware – Order Up / Liquidation / Rest / Curse – Tera Water. Tatsugiri @ Focus Sash – Timid – Commander – Draco Meteor / Surf / Protect / Follow Me – Tera Dragon. Tyranitar @ Assault Vest – Brave – Sand Stream – Rock Slide / Crunch / Ice Punch / Low Kick – Tera Rock. This six-Pokémon core showcases Indeedee’s ideal environment: it leads with either Dondozo or Annihilape, sets Trick Room and terrain, then sacs itself. Under Trick Room, Dondozo + Tatsugiri can stack Commander boosts while Gholdengo and Tyranitar provide spread damage and anti-Ghost coverage. Psychic Terrain blocks Fake Out and Sucker Punch, ensuring Annihilape can accumulate Rage Fist boosts and Gholdengo can spam Make It Rain freely. The team is weak to opposing Trick Room and to fast Ghost-types, so Tyranitar’s Sand Stream and Assault Vest give it the bulk to check Calyrex-S and Flutter Mane, while Gholdengo’s immunity to Shadow Sneak and Fake Out further cements the squad’s terrain-based game plan.</OUTPUT>

Write a detailed 'short_summary' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Garchomp": {"Abilities": {"roughskin": 349.2165959309865, "sandveil": 67.53577812176735}, "Items": {"choicescarf": 0.20027485928559113, "lifeorb": 0.45659887294203017, "clearamulet": 0.1648876177939362}, "Spreads": {"Jolly:0/252/0/0/4/252": 0.1949367818713615, "Jolly:4/252/0/0/0/252": 0.18764698690360285, "Adamant:44/236/4/0/4/220": 0.17855151728491844}, "Moves": ["earthquake", "dragonclaw", "stompingtantrum", "protect"], "Tera Types": {"steel": 0.5460254960809389, "ground": 0.21745258670089695}, "Teammates": ["Tyranitar", "Gholdengo", "Incineroar", "Ninetales-Alola", "Kingambit", "Dragonite"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Garchomp remains a premier offensive threat in VGC thanks to its 130 base Attack, 102 base Speed, and near-perfect neutral coverage between STAB Earthquake and Dragon Claw. Rough Skin is the overwhelmingly preferred ability (≈85 % usage) for the free chip it applies to contact attackers, while Choice Scarf, Life Orb, and Clear Amulet split item duties to let Garchomp serve as either a speed-control cleaner, a wall-breaking pivot, or a stat-change-proof setup punisher. Jolly 252/252 spreads dominate, but a bulkier Adamant variant is also common. Tera Steel is the default for the key resistances it grants to Ice, Fairy and Dragon, though Tera Ground is still viable for a safer Earthquake spam. Teammates gravitate toward sand setters (Tyranitar, Alolan Ninetales), redirection and Intimidate support (Incineroar, Dragonite), and slow, hard-hitting partners (Gholdengo, Kingambit) that appreciate Garchomp’s immediate speed and spread pressure.</OUTPUT>

input:
Produce the 'full_analysis' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Garchomp": {"Abilities": {"roughskin": 349.2165959309865, "sandveil": 67.53577812176735}, "Items": {"choicescarf": 0.20027485928559113, "lifeorb": 0.45659887294203017, "clearamulet": 0.1648876177939362}, "Spreads": {"Jolly:0/252/0/0/4/252": 0.1949367818713615, "Jolly:4/252/0/0/0/252": 0.18764698690360285, "Adamant:44/236/4/0/4/220": 0.17855151728491844}, "Moves": ["earthquake", "dragonclaw", "stompingtantrum", "protect"], "Tera Types": {"steel": 0.5460254960809389, "ground": 0.21745258670089695}, "Teammates": ["Tyranitar", "Gholdengo", "Incineroar", "Ninetales-Alola", "Kingambit", "Dragonite"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Garchomp’s stat line and typing give it everything a physical attacker wants in VGC: naturally high Speed, excellent mixed bulk for a fast sweeper, and two high-BP STAB moves that collectively hit every neutral target for at least neutral damage. Rough Skin punishes U-turn, Fake Out, and contact priority, racking up 12 % chip that frequently flips KOs or forces awkward Protects. Choice Scarf sets let Garchomp outspeed and KO the crowded base-100 tier and most opposing Scarfers, turning it into a mid-game cleaner that can single-handedly dismantle weakened teams. Life Orb variants trade the speed jump for immediate wall-breaking power and the freedom to switch moves, while Clear Amulet variants ignore Intimidate and opposing stat drops, preserving Garchomp’s damage output against cores that rely on repeated Attack drops. Stomping Tantrum is chosen over Rock Slide or Iron Head because it keeps the spread option under Earthquake, retains perfect accuracy, and doubles base power after a missed Protect, giving Garchomp a deceptively strong single-target move that still synergises with its Ground Tera. Protect is mandatory on non-Scarf sets to enable safe positioning next to Earthquake partners or to stall Dynamax turns. Tera Steel is the dominant choice because it removes the 4× Ice weakness, grants a crucial Dragon immunity, and turns Fairy and Rock neutral, letting Garchomp survive common coverage moves such as Dazzling Gleam, Moonblast, Glacial Lance or Ice Spinner while still hitting back with unboosted STAB. Tera Ground is situationally used to boost Earthquake into an absurdly powerful spread move under Grassy Terrain or when facing Electric or Poison teams. Finally, Garchomp’s typing gives it automatic synergy with sand, which both boosts its special bulk and activates Rough Skin chip every turn.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Garchomp": {"Abilities": {"roughskin": 349.2165959309865, "sandveil": 67.53577812176735}, "Items": {"choicescarf": 0.20027485928559113, "lifeorb": 0.45659887294203017, "clearamulet": 0.1648876177939362}, "Spreads": {"Jolly:0/252/0/0/4/252": 0.1949367818713615, "Jolly:4/252/0/0/0/252": 0.18764698690360285, "Adamant:44/236/4/0/4/220": 0.17855151728491844}, "Moves": ["earthquake", "dragonclaw", "stompingtantrum", "protect"], "Tera Types": {"steel": 0.5460254960809389, "ground": 0.21745258670089695}, "Teammates": ["Tyranitar", "Gholdengo", "Incineroar", "Ninetales-Alola", "Kingambit", "Dragonite"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Garchomp’s best matchups are versus slower, bulky offense cores that rely on repeated Intimidate cycles or contact attackers: Incineroar, Arcanine, Kingambit, and Iron Hands all hate Rough Skin and cannot stomach a STAB Earthquake or Dragon Claw. It also pressures common support staples like Indeedee-F, Amoonguss, and Togekiss, as they risk an OHKO from Dragon Claw or Tera-boosted Stomping Tantrum. Conversely, Garchomp struggles against faster or priority-heavy teams carrying Ice Shard, Ice Spinner, or strong Fairy special attackers: Chien-Pao, Baxcalibur, Iron Bundle, and Choice Specs Sylveon can all KO before it moves, while bulky Fairy types such as Clefable and Azumarill can tank a Dragon Claw and retalimate with Moonblast or Play Rough. Tailwind or Chlorophyll sweepers like Flutter Mane, Roaring Moon, or Venusaur also outpace even Scarf Garchomp and force it into Protect loops. Finally, Wide Guard completely shuts down Earthquake, forcing Garchomp into single-target moves and reducing its spread pressure dramatically.</OUTPUT>

input:
Write the 'role_description' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Garchomp": {"Abilities": {"roughskin": 349.2165959309865, "sandveil": 67.53577812176735}, "Items": {"choicescarf": 0.20027485928559113, "lifeorb": 0.45659887294203017, "clearamulet": 0.1648876177939362}, "Spreads": {"Jolly:0/252/0/0/4/252": 0.1949367818713615, "Jolly:4/252/0/0/0/252": 0.18764698690360285, "Adamant:44/236/4/0/4/220": 0.17855151728491844}, "Moves": ["earthquake", "dragonclaw", "stompingtantrum", "protect"], "Tera Types": {"steel": 0.5460254960809389, "ground": 0.21745258670089695}, "Teammates": ["Tyranitar", "Gholdengo", "Incineroar", "Ninetales-Alola", "Kingambit", "Dragonite"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Garchomp is first and foremost a fast, physical attacker that applies immediate offensive pressure with spread Ground damage and key Dragon coverage. In most teams it functions as the speed control pivot: Choice Scarf sets revenge kill boosted threats and clean late game, while Life Orb or Clear Amulet variants break holes early and mid game so slower partners can sweep. Its typing and Rough Skin also make it a soft check to opposing physical attackers—switching into Fake Out or U-turn and punishing contact moves is a common play that flips momentum. Tera Steel turns Garchomp into a pseudo-steel tank that can Dynamax safely, set Stealth Rock under Max Rockfall if needed, and survive would-be Ice or Fairy coverage. In sand, Garchomp’s special bulk effectively reaches 110/115, letting it live modest Moonblasts and Choice Specs Glacial Lances and retaliate. All in all, Garchomp is the glue that both keeps opposing physical cores honest and provides the speed tier that many bulky offense squads otherwise lack.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Garchomp": {"Abilities": {"roughskin": 349.2165959309865, "sandveil": 67.53577812176735}, "Items": {"choicescarf": 0.20027485928559113, "lifeorb": 0.45659887294203017, "clearamulet": 0.1648876177939362}, "Spreads": {"Jolly:0/252/0/0/4/252": 0.1949367818713615, "Jolly:4/252/0/0/0/252": 0.18764698690360285, "Adamant:44/236/4/0/4/220": 0.17855151728491844}, "Moves": ["earthquake", "dragonclaw", "stompingtantrum", "protect"], "Tera Types": {"steel": 0.5460254960809389, "ground": 0.21745258670089695}, "Teammates": ["Tyranitar", "Gholdengo", "Incineroar", "Ninetales-Alola", "Kingambit", "Dragonite"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Tyranitar is the most natural partner: automatic sand boosts Garchomp’s special bulk, sets up a potential 8-turn sandstorm for chip, and provides a slow, powerful Rock STAB that covers Flying and Ice threats for Garchomp while Garchomp handles Fighting and Ground for Tyranitar. Alolan Ninetales offers Veil instead of sand, but still appreciates Garchomp’s ability to obliterate Steel types that block Aurora Veil. Incineroar and Dragonite give redirection or Intimidate, respectively, letting Garchomp survive the first turn against faster threats and start dishing out spread damage; Incineroar’s Parting Shot also brings Garchomp in safely and can reset Attack drops. Gholdengo and Kingambit are slow, hard hitters that benefit from Garchomp’s ability to remove bulky Waters and Fairies early, while their Ghost or Dark STAB punishes the Psychic or Fairy types that can trouble Garchomp. Finally, Dragonite provides Tailwind, Heal Pulse, and a secondary Tera Steel user, creating a dual-Dragon core that can flex Tera types depending on the opponent.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Garchomp": {"Abilities": {"roughskin": 349.2165959309865, "sandveil": 67.53577812176735}, "Items": {"choicescarf": 0.20027485928559113, "lifeorb": 0.45659887294203017, "clearamulet": 0.1648876177939362}, "Spreads": {"Jolly:0/252/0/0/4/252": 0.1949367818713615, "Jolly:4/252/0/0/0/252": 0.18764698690360285, "Adamant:44/236/4/0/4/220": 0.17855151728491844}, "Moves": ["earthquake", "dragonclaw", "stompingtantrum", "protect"], "Tera Types": {"steel": 0.5460254960809389, "ground": 0.21745258670089695}, "Teammates": ["Tyranitar", "Gholdengo", "Incineroar", "Ninetales-Alola", "Kingambit", "Dragonite"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Choice Scarf Cleaner: Jolly 252 Atk / 4 SpD / 252 Spe with Rough Skin, Choice Scarf, Earthquake, Dragon Claw, Stomping Tantrum, Rock Slide/Protect. EVs outspeed +1 base 100s and positive-natured base 110s after Scarf. Max Attack guarantees OHKOs on standard Incineroar and Gholdengo after chip. Rock Slide can be swapped for Protect if you value scouting over coverage. Life Orb Wall-Breaker: Jolly 252 Atk / 4 SpD / 252 Spe with Rough Skin, Life Orb, Earthquake, Dragon Claw, Stomping Tantrum, Protect. Identical EVs but with the freedom to switch moves; Tera Steel is strongly recommended to survive Ice coverage and boost Body Press or Steel Roller if you opt for those coverage moves. Clear Amulet Anti-Intimidate: Adamant 44 HP / 236 Atk / 4 Def / 4 SpD / 220 Spe with Rough Skin, Clear Amulet, Earthquake, Dragon Claw, Stomping Tantrum, Protect. The bulk investment lets Garchomp survive Choice Specs Moonblast from Sylveon and +1 Ice Spinner from Chien-Pao after sand, while still outspeeding positive base 70s like Gholdengo and Tyranitar.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Garchomp": {"Abilities": {"roughskin": 349.2165959309865, "sandveil": 67.53577812176735}, "Items": {"choicescarf": 0.20027485928559113, "lifeorb": 0.45659887294203017, "clearamulet": 0.1648876177939362}, "Spreads": {"Jolly:0/252/0/0/4/252": 0.1949367818713615, "Jolly:4/252/0/0/0/252": 0.18764698690360285, "Adamant:44/236/4/0/4/220": 0.17855151728491844}, "Moves": ["earthquake", "dragonclaw", "stompingtantrum", "protect"], "Tera Types": {"steel": 0.5460254960809389, "ground": 0.21745258670089695}, "Teammates": ["Tyranitar", "Gholdengo", "Incineroar", "Ninetales-Alola", "Kingambit", "Dragonite"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Priority Ice Shard from Chien-Pao, Baxcalibur, or Palafin and strong Fairy special attacks are the most reliable answers: Choice Specs Sylveon and Clefable OHKO with Moonblast even through Tera Steel if Garchomp has suffered prior chip. Wide Guard users such as Araquanid, Hitmontop, or Swampert completely blank Earthquake and force Garchomp into single-target moves, reducing its spread pressure and opening it up to double targets. Faster threats under Tailwind—Flutter Mane, Roaring Moon, Iron Bundle, or Chlorophyll Venusaur—can all KO before Garchomp moves, so denying Tailwind or your own speed control is critical. Intimidate cycling plus Fake Out can also wear Garchomp down, although Clear Amulet sets ignore the Attack drops. Finally, bulky Water types like Toxapex or Rotom-Wash can tank a Dragon Claw and burn or Volt Switch out, chipping Garchomp into Ice Shard range. Always scout for Tera Fairy on expected switch-ins, as a surprise Moonblast or Dazzling Gleam after Tera can still finish off a weakened Garchomp.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Garchomp": {"Abilities": {"roughskin": 349.2165959309865, "sandveil": 67.53577812176735}, "Items": {"choicescarf": 0.20027485928559113, "lifeorb": 0.45659887294203017, "clearamulet": 0.1648876177939362}, "Spreads": {"Jolly:0/252/0/0/4/252": 0.1949367818713615, "Jolly:4/252/0/0/0/252": 0.18764698690360285, "Adamant:44/236/4/0/4/220": 0.17855151728491844}, "Moves": ["earthquake", "dragonclaw", "stompingtantrum", "protect"], "Tera Types": {"steel": 0.5460254960809389, "ground": 0.21745258670089695}, "Teammates": ["Tyranitar", "Gholdengo", "Incineroar", "Ninetales-Alola", "Kingambit", "Dragonite"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Start with the classic Sand Core: Tyranitar @ Assault Vest with Rock Slide, Crunch, Ice Punch, and Superpower to set sand and handle Flying/Ice threats. Pair with Garchomp @ Choice Scarf, Rough Skin, Jolly 252/4/252, Tera Steel, moves Earthquake / Dragon Claw / Stomping Tantrum / Protect. Add Incineroar @ Safety Goggles, standard support spread, for Intimidate, Fake Out, Parting Shot, and Flare Blitz to pivot and reset Attack drops. Bring Gholdengo @ Life Orb, Modest 252 HP / 252 SpA / 4 SpD, to abuse sand chip and threaten opposing Fairy and Flying types with Shadow Ball and Make It Rain. Fifth slot is Alolan Ninetales @ Light Clay for Aurora Veil and Snow Warning chip, giving the team an alternative weather mode and extra bulk. Finish with Kingambit @ Black Glasses, Adamant 252 HP / 252 Atk / 4 SpD, to clean late game under Veil or sand, benefit from Garchomp’s early wall-breaking, and provide a second Tera Steel or Dark option. The squad offers both sand offense and Veil control, dual Steel Tera to shrug off Ice and Fairy, and multiple speed modes depending on whether Garchomp keeps its Scarf or you opt for Tailwind from Ninetales.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Tyranitar": {"Abilities": {"sandstream": 402.64392135594613, "unnerve": 0.04542060499558709}, "Items": {"assaultvest": 0.7628809430050081}, "Spreads": {}, "Moves": ["rockslide", "knockoff", "lowkick", "terablast"], "Tera Types": {"flying": 0.8608608949695139}, "Teammates": ["Excadrill", "Garchomp", "Gholdengo", "Sneasler", "Indeedee", "Annihilape"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Tyranitar remains a premier offensive pivot in VGC thanks to its unique ability Sand Stream, which automatically sets a sandstorm that chips every non-Rock-, Steel-, or Ground-type and boosts its already titanic Special Defense. With Assault Vest equipped in tandem with sand, it becomes a virtual special wall while still firing off powerful STAB Rock Slides and utility Knock Offs. A near-universal Tera Flying typing gives it a one-time Ground immunity and resistance to Fighting, letting it flip key match-ups mid-game. The chosen coverage of Low Kick nails common sand checks such as Heatran and Kingambit, while Tera Blast provides a flexible slot that can be tuned to whatever coverage the team needs once Terastallized. All of this combines to make Tyranitar a bulky, hard-hitting lead or back-line win-condition that can single-handedly dictate the pace of a game.</OUTPUT>

input:
Create the 'full_analysis' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Tyranitar": {"Abilities": {"sandstream": 402.64392135594613, "unnerve": 0.04542060499558709}, "Items": {"assaultvest": 0.7628809430050081}, "Spreads": {}, "Moves": ["rockslide", "knockoff", "lowkick", "terablast"], "Tera Types": {"flying": 0.8608608949695139}, "Teammates": ["Excadrill", "Garchomp", "Gholdengo", "Sneasler", "Indeedee", "Annihilape"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Tyranitar’s biggest draw is Sand Stream, the only automatic weather that simultaneously damages opponents and strengthens its own longevity. Sand adds 50 % more Special Defense to Rock-types, turning Assault Vest Tyranitar into a 252/252 special wall without sacrificing offensive EVs. Rock Slide is the obligatory spread move that punishes the omnipresent Flying, Fire and Ice types while flinching slower foes. Knock Off is the strongest utility option in the format, removing Heavy-Duty Boots, Leftovers and Eviolite from would-be checks such as Corviknight, Tornadus and Dondozo. Low Kick is the coverage of choice, guaranteeing the OHKO on standard Heatran and 2HKOing max HP Kingambit and Garganacl through their berries. Tera Blast is the glue: before Terastallizing it can be any type the team requires—common choices are Ice for four-times weak Dragons and Grass for Rotom-Wash and Gastrodon—while after Tera Flying it becomes a 120 BP Flying attack that lets Tyranitar OHKO opposing Fighting-types that thought they could force it out. The EV spread is straightforward: 252 HP / 252 Atk / 4 Def Adamant maximizes bulk and power while outspeeding uninvested base 70s such as Breloom and Skarmory under Tailwind. With these tools Tyranitar operates equally well as a lead that immediately threatens chip and item removal, or as a mid-game pivot that absorbs special hits and trades blows until the endgame.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Tyranitar": {"Abilities": {"sandstream": 402.64392135594613, "unnerve": 0.04542060499558709}, "Items": {"assaultvest": 0.7628809430050081}, "Spreads": {}, "Moves": ["rockslide", "knockoff", "lowkick", "terablast"], "Tera Types": {"flying": 0.8608608949695139}, "Teammates": ["Excadrill", "Garchomp", "Gholdengo", "Sneasler", "Indeedee", "Annihilape"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Tyranitar’s Sand immediately tilts match-ups into its favor against any team that relies on Focus Sash or gradual recovery. Into rain or sun, it trades weather war on turn one and usually forces the opponent to choose between preserving their setter or taking early Knock Off damage. Against Trick Room, Tyranitar is one of the few offensive Pokémon that can sit on the field and stall turns thanks to its augmented special bulk; Rock Slide flinches and sand chip wear down Hatterene and Porygon2. Versus hyper-offense, Tera Flying removes its Ground weakness and lets it survive Earthquakes from Garchomp and Great Tusk while retaliating with super-effective Tera Blast. Stall teams struggle to wear it down because sand plus Knock Off removes Leftovers and Black Sludge, and Assault Vest prevents them from breaking it with special attackers like Slowking-G or Toxapex. The only archetypes that truly trouble Tyranitar are dedicated Terrain-based teams: Indeedee-F’s Psychic Terrain blocks Fake Out support and allows Expanding Force spam, while Grassy Terrain recovery offsets sand chip and empowers opposing Rillaboom. Nevertheless, even in those games Tyranitar can Terastallize, change type, and become a neutralizing force.</OUTPUT>

input:
Provide the 'role_description' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Tyranitar": {"Abilities": {"sandstream": 402.64392135594613, "unnerve": 0.04542060499558709}, "Items": {"assaultvest": 0.7628809430050081}, "Spreads": {}, "Moves": ["rockslide", "knockoff", "lowkick", "terablast"], "Tera Types": {"flying": 0.8608608949695139}, "Teammates": ["Excadrill", "Garchomp", "Gholdengo", "Sneasler", "Indeedee", "Annihilape"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Tyranitar is a hybrid tank and offensive pivot that compresses weather control, item disruption, spread damage and Tera versatility into one slot. It glues balance and bulky-offense teams by providing immediate board presence: Sand Stream sets without consuming a turn, freeing the player to use Protect, attack or switch. Assault Vest plus sand turns it into the team’s designated special sponge, taking Moonblasts, Draco Meteors and Overheats that would otherwise shred frailer partners. Once it has removed items and softened checks with Rock Slide, it can either act as a late-game cleaner with Tera Flying Tera Blast or pivot out to let faster sweepers such as Excadrill or Garchomp take over under the same sand. Its typing and bulk also let it serve as a pseudo-support, Fake Out being unnecessary when Rock Slide flinch and sand chip achieve similar disruption. In best-of-three formats, Tyranitar’s set is extremely consistent between games because it needs no prediction-heavy coverage; Knock Off and Low Kick always generate value, and Tera type can be revealed on the fly to flip a bad matchup.</OUTPUT>

input:
Write the 'synergy_breakdown' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Tyranitar": {"Abilities": {"sandstream": 402.64392135594613, "unnerve": 0.04542060499558709}, "Items": {"assaultvest": 0.7628809430050081}, "Spreads": {}, "Moves": ["rockslide", "knockoff", "lowkick", "terablast"], "Tera Types": {"flying": 0.8608608949695139}, "Teammates": ["Excadrill", "Garchomp", "Gholdengo", "Sneasler", "Indeedee", "Annihilape"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Excadrill is the canonical partner: Sand Rush doubles its Speed, turning it into an immediate win-condition that can KO opposing weather setters before they move. Garchomp enjoys the sand Special Defense boost, appreciates Knock Off removing Ice-weak berries, and forms a Rock-Ground-Flying offensive core that is only walled by Steel. Gholdengo blocks Rapid Spin, preserves Stealth Rock that sand teams love, and pressures Fairy-types that otherwise wall Tyranitar. Sneasler provides fast Fake Out and a secondary Knock Off user while benefiting from sand chip to secure its own KOs. Indeedee-F gives Follow Tag support, sets Psychic Terrain to block opposing Fake Out, and can redirect Draco Meteors away from Tyranitar. Annihilape rounds out the squad with bulk-up sweeping under sand, shrugging off special hits that would break it on other teams. These six share a common calculus: every member either exploits sand, covers Tyranitar’s Fighting weakness, or removes items so that sand chip can finish the job. The result is a cohesive squad that applies constant offensive pressure while still possessing the bulk to trade blows with any archetype.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Standard Assault Vest Pivot: Adamant 252 HP / 252 Atk / 4 Def. Moves: Rock Slide, Knock Off, Low Kick, Tera Blast. Item: Assault Vest. Ability: Sand Stream. Tera Type: Flying. This set maximizes bulk and power, letting Tyranitar survive +1 Moonblast from Flutter Mane and KO back with Tera Flying Tera Blast. Low Kick is mandatory to hit Kingambit and Gholdengo; if your team already covers Steels you can swap Low Kick for Ice Punch to nail Lando-T and Dragonite. An alternate fast set exists: Jolly 252 Atk / 4 Def / 252 Spe with Choice Scarf, turning Tyranitar into a surprise revenge killer that outspeeds +1 Roaring Moon and Dragapult and OHKOs with Tera Flying Tera Blast or Stone Edge. However, the AV set is far more consistent in current best-of-three tournaments. Finally, a bulkier spread of Careful 252 HP / 4 Atk / 252 SpD exists for teams that want Tyranitar to hard-wall Iron Bundle and Choice Specs Toxapex, but it sacrifices crucial KOs on Incineroar and Meowscarada.</OUTPUT>

input:
Write a detailed 'weaknesses_and_counters' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Tyranitar": {"Abilities": {"sandstream": 402.64392135594613, "unnerve": 0.04542060499558709}, "Items": {"assaultvest": 0.7628809430050081}, "Spreads": {}, "Moves": ["rockslide", "knockoff", "lowkick", "terablast"], "Tera Types": {"flying": 0.8608608949695139}, "Teammates": ["Excadrill", "Garchomp", "Gholdengo", "Sneasler", "Indeedee", "Annihilape"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>The single best counter to Tyranitar is Choice Band Iron Hands: it resists Rock, is immune to sand, and OHKOs with Drain Punch while healing off any chip. Great Tusk with Bulk Up can also set up in Tyranitar’s face, though it must watch for Tera Flying. Fighting-types with priority—such as Breloom’s Mach Punch or Annihilape’s Rage Fist—can pick off a chipped Tyranitar before it Terastallizes. On the special side, Iron Valiant under Tailwin dents it with Close Combat, while Choice Specs Toxapex can 2HKO with Hydro Pump even through sand. Terrain teams deserve a second mention: Rillaboom under Grassy Terrain heals every turn and OHKOs with Wood Hammer, while Indeedee-F plus Armarouge can chain Expanding Force and Armor Cannon to break through its special bulk. Finally, hax can undo Tyranitar: Rock Slide misses at inopportune times and Knock Off can be blocked by Good positioning or Protect. Play patiently, preserve Tera until the Fighting-type is revealed, and always assume the opponent carries a surprise coverage move.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Tyranitar": {"Abilities": {"sandstream": 402.64392135594613, "unnerve": 0.04542060499558709}, "Items": {"assaultvest": 0.7628809430050081}, "Spreads": {}, "Moves": ["rockslide", "knockoff", "lowkick", "terablast"], "Tera Types": {"flying": 0.8608608949695139}, "Teammates": ["Excadrill", "Garchomp", "Gholdengo", "Sneasler", "Indeedee", "Annihilape"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Start with the sand core: Tyranitar + Excadrill. Give Excadrill Life Orb and Swords Dance so it can clean late-game after Tyranitar removes items. Add Garchomp as a second Sand Rush user and Stealth Rock setter; Rocky Helmet punishes contact moves. Gholdengo provides spin-blocking and special offense with Make It Rain; Choice Specs ensures it breaks Corviknight and Toxapex. Sneasler gives fast utility: Fake Out, Knock Off and Dire Claw pressure. Finally, Indeedee-F sets Psychic Terrain, redirects with Follow Tag, and can Helping Hand Excadrill to guarantee KOs. Lead Tyranitar + Sneasler to remove items and spread sand, bring Excadrill in the back to sweep once Fighting-types are gone. Against sun or rain, lead Garchomp + Sneasler to KO their setter turn one, then bring Tyranitar to reclaim weather. Against Trick Room, lead Indeedee + Tyranitar to stall turns with Follow Tag and Rock Slide flinches. The team is straightforward but effective: set sand, remove items, and let the dual Rush sweepers run away with the game.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Sinistcha": {"Abilities": {"hospitality": 321.95951372378744, "heatproof": 35.023206918677175}, "Items": {"sitrusberry": 0.6687242150933399}, "Spreads": {}, "Moves": ["trickroom", "ragepowder", "matchagotcha", "lifedew"], "Tera Types": {"water": 0.36430930988713117, "dark": 0.4434064570827026}, "Teammates": ["Pelipper", "Archaludon", "Dragonite", "Gholdengo", "Incineroar", "Ursaluna"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Sinistcha is a niche support Pokémon in VGC whose usage is almost entirely propped up by its hidden ability Hospitality, which heals 25% of its partner’s HP on switch-in. While its bulk is only moderate and its offensive stats are unremarkable, it compresses Trick Room, Rage Powder, and reliable recovery into one slot, letting it serve as a semi-redirector and speed-control setter for bulky, slower teams. The almost total absence of Heatproof and the near-zero item diversity show that players are maximizing Hospitality value rather than trying to make Sinistcha a standalone threat. Tera Water or Dark are purely defensive tweaks to survive a key hit rather than enable sweeping. In practice it is a one-trick pony, but that trick—free, passive healing every time it enters play—can single-handedly swing momentum against chip-heavy opponents.</OUTPUT>

input:
Draft the 'full_analysis' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Sinistcha": {"Abilities": {"hospitality": 321.95951372378744, "heatproof": 35.023206918677175}, "Items": {"sitrusberry": 0.6687242150933399}, "Spreads": {}, "Moves": ["trickroom", "ragepowder", "matchagotcha", "lifedew"], "Tera Types": {"water": 0.36430930988713117, "dark": 0.4434064570827026}, "Teammates": ["Pelipper", "Archaludon", "Dragonite", "Gholdengo", "Incineroar", "Ursaluna"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Hospitality is the engine that justifies Sinistcha’s bench spot: every time it hits the field it undoes a third of the damage that most spread moves or Fake Out + ally chip would otherwise accrue. This repeatable, non-action healing is uniquely valuable in Bo3 formats where opponents cannot easily re-position around it. Trick Room turns its mediocre 67 base speed into an asset, letting slower powerhouses like Ursaluna or Archaludon move first, while Rage Powder offers a layer of protection for those same sweepers or simply buys a free turn to set up. Matcha Gotcha provides a spread Grass move with a 20% burn chance, puniting Incineroar and Gastrodon switches and giving Sinistcha a way to contribute damage without EV investment. Life Dew is another spammable support option that stacks with Hospitality, turning two-slot healing into an effective 45% HP swing for both allies over two turns. EV spreads are not reported in the data, but 252 HP / 156 Def / 100 SpD with a Calm nature is standard, letting it survive -1 Tera Dark Gholdengo Make It Rain or a Life Orb Dragonite Extreme Speed after Tera Water. The low item usage implies Sitrus Berry is the default, triggering after Hospitality for an immediate 50% pseudo-recovery. Tera Water removes the Fire weakness and grants a crucial neutrality to Gholdengo and Chien-Pao, while Tera Dark dodges the rare but deadly Tera Ghost Flutter Mane Shadow Ball. Sinistcha is not self-sufficient: it needs partners that can threaten the Flying-, Fire-, and Ice-types that pressure it, and it absolutely requires entry-point prediction to avoid giving the opponent a free double-up turn.</OUTPUT>

Provide the 'matchup_overview' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Sinistcha": {"Abilities": {"hospitality": 321.95951372378744, "heatproof": 35.023206918677175}, "Items": {"sitrusberry": 0.6687242150933399}, "Spreads": {}, "Moves": ["trickroom", "ragepowder", "matchagotcha", "lifedew"], "Tera Types": {"water": 0.36430930988713117, "dark": 0.4434064570827026}, "Teammates": ["Pelipper", "Archaludon", "Dragonite", "Gholdengo", "Incineroar", "Ursaluna"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Sinistcha excels against balance and bulky-offense teams that rely on stacking residual damage—Stealth Rock chip, U-turn, Fake Out, and spread moves—because Hospitality passively undoes that game plan. It is neutral to weather wars: Rain’s boosted Surges still 2HKO, but Pelipper teams appreciate the healing enough to justify the slot. Sun is more problematic; Torkoal and Charizard both OHKO with Heat Wave even after Tera Water, so Sinistcha must either set Trick Room early or pivot out immediately. Against Tailwind offense, Sinistcha is a desperation button: it cannot redirect both targets, and the opposing speed advantage means Rage Powder often becomes a sacrifice rather than a shield. Into Trick Room mirrors it becomes a momentum piece; whoever last moves can Hospitality reset on the switch, effectively denying the opponent the same healing. Gholdengo is theoretically a hard counter—blocking Rage Powder and threatening OHKO—but in practice a Tera Water Sinistcha survives one Make It Rain and can answer back with Life Dew + ally pressure. Amoonguss is the true nemesis: Clear Smog removes Trick Room, and Spore ignores Rage Powder, forcing Sinistcha to either Tera or switch.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Sinistcha": {"Abilities": {"hospitality": 321.95951372378744, "heatproof": 35.023206918677175}, "Items": {"sitrusberry": 0.6687242150933399}, "Spreads": {}, "Moves": ["trickroom", "ragepowder", "matchagotcha", "lifedew"], "Tera Types": {"water": 0.36430930988713117, "dark": 0.4434064570827026}, "Teammates": ["Pelipper", "Archaludon", "Dragonite", "Gholdengo", "Incineroar", "Ursaluna"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Sinistcha is a pivoting support that compresses four roles: cleric, speed-control setter, redirector, and burn spreader. It is never the win condition; instead it is a force multiplier that elongates the game until a slower breaker can claim KOs under Trick Room. Hospitality turns every switch-in into a positive-tempo play, so Sinistcha teams are built around repeated safe entries—via U-turn, Parting Shot, or double switches—rather than long stays. Its ideal turns are: (1) lead, click Trick Room while partner threatens Fake Out or Follow Me, (2) mid-game, switch in on a predicted Protect or on a slow U-turn to heal ally, then Rage Powder to enable a setup move, (3) late-game, repeatedly Life Dew to stall Dynamax turns or timer. Because its offenses are poor, Sinistcha must avoid becoming the last Pokémon; it is designed to enable allies, not sweep.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Pelipper is the most common teammate because Rain weakens Fire-type coverage and Hurricane/Fishious Rend appreciate Trick Room against faster Dragons. Archaludon loves Hospitality turning its 4× Fire weakness into a manageable 2HKO and can launch Doom Desire under protection. Dragonite uses Rage Powder to set up Dragon Dance safely and can Roost stall once Trick Room expires. Gholdengo forms a soft Ghost-Steel core, blocking Rapid Spin and threatening opposing Gholdengo for Sinistcha, while Hospitality offsets Gholdengo’s lack of recovery. Incineroar provides Intimidate, Parting Shot, and a Fire-type immunity, creating ideal pivot loops where both Pokémon heal on every switch. Ursaluna is the quintessential Trick Room breaker; Hospitality patches its lack of recovery, and Sinistcha’s Rage Powder buys a free Bulk Up or Double-Edge. The shared Fire weakness is mitigated by Rain or Tera Water, and the entire core is durable enough to outlast most offensive Dynamax bursts.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Sinistcha": {"Abilities": {"hospitality": 321.95951372378744, "heatproof": 35.023206918677175}, "Items": {"sitrusberry": 0.6687242150933399}, "Spreads": {}, "Moves": ["trickroom", "ragepowder", "matchagotcha", "lifedew"], "Tera Types": {"water": 0.36430930988713117, "dark": 0.4434064570827026}, "Teammates": ["Pelipper", "Archaludon", "Dragonite", "Gholdengo", "Incineroar", "Ursaluna"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Flying-type attackers such as Tornadus, Hurricane Pelipper, and Dragonite break Sinistcha with supereffective STAB and ignore Rage Powder with spread moves. Fire-types—especially Torkoal under Sun and Chi-Yu—OHKO even through Tera Water. Taunt completely shuts Sinistcha down, preventing both Trick Room and Life Dew; Murkrow and Grimmsnarl are common leads that outspeed and Taunt before it moves. Double-targeting the partner while ignoring Sinistcha is the simplest counterplay, since Hospitality only triggers on entry and Rage Powder can protect only one ally. Clear Smog users (Amoonguss, Gastrodon) erase Trick Room turns, and Spore ignores redirection. Wide Guard Aegislash and Entei block Matcha Gotcha chip while setting up. Finally, Sinistcha is momentum-negative if the opponent never KOs it; passive damage plus the need to repeatedly switch can be exploited by aggressive positioning and Dynamax pressure.</OUTPUT>

The team has two speed modes—Rain for fast Hurricanes and Trick Room for Ursaluna—and Sinistcha is the glue that makes the bulky mode sustainable while providing an emergency speed control option against Tailwind or opposing weather.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Torkoal is a premier Sun setter and special wallbreaker in VGC 2025, leveraging its Drought ability and base 140 Eruption to pressure teams right out of the gate. Quiet nature with 252 HP / 252 SpA investment is used on over half of teams, underscoring its role as a slow, hard-hitting pivot that wants to move last and nuke whatever stands in front of it. Charcoal and Choice Specs are the dominant items, pushing Eruption to absurd power levels under Sun, while Eject Pack grants a one-time pivot that lets Torkoal reset field position after firing a max-power STAB. Fire Tera is taken on 88 % of teams, turning already-resisted Fire moves into guaranteed OHKOs and removing the Rock weakness for a crucial turn. Its most common partners—Incineroar, Indeedee-F, Hatterene, Gallade, Ursaluna, and Lilligant-H—form a balanced Sun core that provides Fake Out, speed control, Trick Room inversion, and secondary win conditions that appreciate the weather and the space Torkoal creates.</OUTPUT>

input:

<DATA>{"Torkoal": {"Abilities": {"drought": 343.8111264406569, "whitesmoke": 0.29656526880699635, "shellarmor": 0.0009298134903449884}, "Items": {"charcoal": 0.27768099612702485, "choicespecs": 0.377901550614347, "ejectpack": 0.1630301943471822}, "Spreads": {"Quiet:252/0/0/252/4/0": 0.5288539733484877, "Quiet:252/0/4/252/0/0": 0.1665585858165277}, "Moves": ["eruption", "heatwave", "earthpower", "protect"], "Tera Types": {"fire": 0.87892239912798}, "Teammates": ["Incineroar", "Gallade", "Indeedee-F", "Hatterene", "Ursaluna", "Lilligant-Hisui"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Torkoal’s niche in the current regulation is defined by two factors: automatic Sun and a 140 BP spread move that benefits from that Sun. Drought is used on 99.7 % of sampled teams, so its primary job is to summon harsh sunlight the moment it hits the field. This single mechanic flips the offensive math for its teammates—boosting Fire-type moves by 50 % and weakening Water-type moves to the point that many resisted Water attacks fail to KO. Eruption is the star of the set: at –1 speed (Quiet) and full HP it is effectively a 210 BP Fire spread move, out-damaging even Specs Heat Wave from faster threats. Heat Wave is the reliable secondary STAB for when Torkoal has taken chip, while Earth Power covers Torkoal’s most feared switch-in: opposing Fire-types and Tera Fire steels. Protect is nearly mandatory to preserve Eruption power and to give partners a free turn to set up Trick Room or Tailwind. The two main spreads are functionally identical: Quiet 252/0/0/252/4/0 and Quiet 252/0/4/252/0/0 both maximize special output and bulk, with the spare 4 EVs either padding special defense or physical defense to hit specific damage rolls. Charcoal is the safe pick that keeps item flexibility, Choice Specs turns Torkoal into a literal nuke that 2HKOs most neutral targets even without Sun, and Eject Pack is the tech for teams that want Torkoal to fire once and immediately tag in a faster cleaner. Tera Fire is the overwhelmingly preferred option because it boosts both STABs and removes the Rock weakness, letting Torkoal survive common spread moves like Rock Slide and Grassy Glide. The data show virtually zero variance in move slots, indicating that the community has settled on the four-move set that maximizes spread damage and coverage.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Torkoal": {"Abilities": {"drought": 343.8111264406569, "whitesmoke": 0.29656526880699635, "shellarmor": 0.0009298134903449884}, "Items": {"charcoal": 0.27768099612702485, "choicespecs": 0.377901550614347, "ejectpack": 0.1630301943471822}, "Spreads": {"Quiet:252/0/0/252/4/0": 0.5288539733484877, "Quiet:252/0/4/252/0/0": 0.1665585858165277}, "Moves": ["eruption", "heatwave", "earthpower", "protect"], "Tera Types": {"fire": 0.87892239912798}, "Teammates": ["Incineroar", "Gallade", "Indeedee-F", "Hatterene", "Ursaluna", "Lilligant-Hisui"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Torkoal’s matchup spread is polarized: it obliterates slower, bulky teams that rely on Grass, Steel, or Ice types, but struggles against weatherless offense that carries faster Rock, Water, or Dragon attackers. Under Sun, Torkoal’s Eruption secures OHKOs on standard Incineroar, Indeedee-F, and most non-vested Amoonguss variants, while 2HKOing max-invested Garganacl and Corviknight. Conversely, it fears Dragapult and Iron Bundle that outspeed and KO with STAB Water or Dragon moves before Sun can be reset. Against Rain teams, Torkoal must either click Earth Power on Pelipper or switch out, because even a –1 Water Spout in Rain cleanly OHKOs. Trick Room teams are a skill matchup: if Torkoal is paired with Indeedee-F to set Psychic Terrain, it can nullate priority Rage Powder and fire off uncontested Eruptions; if the opponent sets Trick Room first, Torkoal becomes the fastest threat under Trick Room and flips the script. Sand teams are less problematic because Tyranitar and Hippowdon are weak to Earth Power, but Torkoal must watch for Tera Rock Slide flinches. In the mirror, the slower Torkoal wins the weather war, so speed control and Tera timing decide the game.</OUTPUT>
