Produce the 'role_description' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Torkoal": {"Abilities": {"drought": 343.8111264406569, "whitesmoke": 0.29656526880699635, "shellarmor": 0.0009298134903449884}, "Items": {"charcoal": 0.27768099612702485, "choicespecs": 0.377901550614347, "ejectpack": 0.1630301943471822}, "Spreads": {"Quiet:252/0/0/252/4/0": 0.5288539733484877, "Quiet:252/0/4/252/0/0": 0.1665585858165277}, "Moves": ["eruption", "heatwave", "earthpower", "protect"], "Tera Types": {"fire": 0.87892239912798}, "Teammates": ["Incineroar", "Gallade", "Indeedee-F", "Hatterene", "Ursaluna", "Lilligant-Hisui"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Torkoal is a weather setter, spread breaker, and mid-game pivot rolled into one. It leads when the team wants immediate Sun to enable Chlorophyll sweepers or to deny opposing Rain, and it sits in the back when the game plan is to reverse Trick Room and clean late. Its low speed is an asset: moving last guarantees weather control against opposing Pelipper or Tyranitar, and under Trick Room it becomes a pseudo-fast sweeper. The combination of Drought and Eruption forces the opponent to either KO Torkoal immediately—risking a Protect—or to spread damage and watch half their team evaporate. Choice Specs variants are true wallbreakers that 2HKO even resisted targets, while Charcoal sets retain the ability to Protect and switch moves, making them better at long games. Eject Pack sets pivot after a single click, bringing in a faster teammate like Lilligant-H or Gallade to abuse the Sun without wasting a turn manually switching. Tera Fire is used offensively to secure KOs and defensively to survive Rock Slides and Grassy Glides that would otherwise finish it after chip.</OUTPUT>

input:
Write the 'synergy_breakdown' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Torkoal": {"Abilities": {"drought": 343.8111264406569, "whitesmoke": 0.29656526880699635, "shellarmor": 0.0009298134903449884}, "Items": {"charcoal": 0.27768099612702485, "choicespecs": 0.377901550614347, "ejectpack": 0.1630301943471822}, "Spreads": {"Quiet:252/0/0/252/4/0": 0.5288539733484877, "Quiet:252/0/4/252/0/0": 0.1665585858165277}, "Moves": ["eruption", "heatwave", "earthpower", "protect"], "Tera Types": {"fire": 0.87892239912798}, "Teammates": ["Incineroar", "Gallade", "Indeedee-F", "Hatterene", "Ursaluna", "Lilligant-Hisui"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Incineroar is the ideal partner: it provides Fake Out, Intimidate, and a Fire-type that doesn’t stack weaknesses, while Sun-boosted Flare Blitz becomes a nuke. Indeedee-F sets Psychic Terrain to block priority and can activate Weakness Policy on Ursaluna or Gallade. Hatterene blocks status and sets Trick Room, turning Torkoal into a fast threat under Room. Gallade and Ursaluna appreciate Sun because it weakens Water moves aimed at them and lets them run Tera Fire for synergy; in return they smash through special walls that Torkoal cannot break. Lilligant-H is the classic Chlorophyll sleeper: after Torkoal sets Sun, Lilligant-H can outspeed and put two targets to sleep, effectively ending the game on turn two. The core of Torkoal + Indeedee-F + Ursaluna is a balanced triangle that covers Fire, Ground, and Psychic offenses while providing both Sun and Trick Room modes. Eject Pack Torkoal into Lilligant-H is a devastating pivot chain: Eruption softens targets, Pack triggers, Lilligant-H comes in at +2 speed and fires Sleep Powder or Tera Blast Fire.</OUTPUT>

input:
Write a detailed 'recommended_sets' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Torkoal": {"Abilities": {"drought": 343.8111264406569, "whitesmoke": 0.29656526880699635, "shellarmor": 0.0009298134903449884}, "Items": {"charcoal": 0.27768099612702485, "choicespecs": 0.377901550614347, "ejectpack": 0.1630301943471822}, "Spreads": {"Quiet:252/0/0/252/4/0": 0.5288539733484877, "Quiet:252/0/4/252/0/0": 0.1665585858165277}, "Moves": ["eruption", "heatwave", "earthpower", "protect"], "Tera Types": {"fire": 0.87892239912798}, "Teammates": ["Incineroar", "Gallade", "Indeedee-F", "Hatterene", "Ursaluna", "Lilligant-Hisui"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Quiet 252/0/0/252/4/0 with Drought, Eruption / Heat Wave / Earth Power / Protect, Tera Fire, and Charcoal is the standard balance set that maximizes spread damage while keeping flexibility. Quiet 252/0/4/252/0/0 with Choice Specs is the hyper-offense variant that 2HKOs even max-SpD Garganacl and Toxapex; click Eruption turn one, predict Protect, and watch half the meta melt. Quiet 252/0/0/252/4/0 with Eject Pack is the pivot set for teams that want to set Sun, fire once, and immediately bring in a faster cleaner; pair with Lilligant-H or Gallade holding Weakness Policy. All three sets run Tera Fire almost exclusively, though Tera Ground can be used to surprise Toxapex and Clodsire while keeping the Fire resistance. Optional tweaks include 12 EVs in Defense to survive Jolly Chien-Pao Ice Spinner after Intimidate, or 44 SpD to always live modest Iron Bundle Hydro Pump in Rain.</OUTPUT>

input:
Write a detailed 'weaknesses_and_counters' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Torkoal": {"Abilities": {"drought": 343.8111264406569, "whitesmoke": 0.29656526880699635, "shellarmor": 0.0009298134903449884}, "Items": {"charcoal": 0.27768099612702485, "choicespecs": 0.377901550614347, "ejectpack": 0.1630301943471822}, "Spreads": {"Quiet:252/0/0/252/4/0": 0.5288539733484877, "Quiet:252/0/4/252/0/0": 0.1665585858165277}, "Moves": ["eruption", "heatwave", "earthpower", "protect"], "Tera Types": {"fire": 0.87892239912798}, "Teammates": ["Incineroar", "Gallade", "Indeedee-F", "Hatterene", "Ursaluna", "Lilligant-Hisui"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Torkoal’s biggest enemy is its own speed: any offensive Water-, Rock-, or Dragon-type that outslows and KOes it before Sun goes up ruins its game plan. Dragapult, Iron Bundle, and Chien-Pao are public enemy numbers one through three: they outspeed, tank a –1 Heat Wave, and OHKO back with STAB. Wide Guard users such as Arcanine and Garganacl completely shut down Eruption and Heat Wave, forcing Torkoal to click Earth Power into likely Protects. Rain teams with Pelipper and Kingdra flip the weather and fire 2× Water moves that ignore Torkoal’s bulk. Priority users like Aqua Jet Barraskewda and Sucker Punch Kingambit can finish Torkoal after chip, though Psychic Terrain from Indeedee-F blocks the former. Status—especially burn and paralysis—cripples Torkoal because it relies on full-HP Eruption power; Hatterene and Indeedee-F are mandatory partners to block Thunder Wave and Will-o-Wisp. Finally, Torkoal hates Stealth Rock and spread chip because every point of damage reduces Eruption’s BP; therefore keeping rocks off the field and healing with Pollen Puff or Floral Healing is essential.</OUTPUT>

input:
Create the 'sample_team_concept' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Torkoal": {"Abilities": {"drought": 343.8111264406569, "whitesmoke": 0.29656526880699635, "shellarmor": 0.0009298134903449884}, "Items": {"charcoal": 0.27768099612702485, "choicespecs": 0.377901550614347, "ejectpack": 0.1630301943471822}, "Spreads": {"Quiet:252/0/0/252/4/0": 0.5288539733484877, "Quiet:252/0/4/252/0/0": 0.1665585858165277}, "Moves": ["eruption", "heatwave", "earthpower", "protect"], "Tera Types": {"fire": 0.87892239912798}, "Teammates": ["Incineroar", "Gallade", "Indeedee-F", "Hatterene", "Ursaluna", "Lilligant-Hisui"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Regulation G Sun balance: Torkoal (Quiet, Charcoal) + Incineroar (Careful, Snarl) + Indeedee-F (Bold, Psychic Seed) + Ursaluna (Brave, Weakness Policy) + Lilligant-H (Timid, Focus Sash) + Corviknight (Impish, Leftovers). Lead Torkoal + Indeedee-F to set Sun and Terrain, fire Eruption while blocking priority. Incineroar provides Fake Out and Intimidate, pivoting into Ursaluna to activate Policy under Sun. Lilligant-H is the speed mode: after an Eject Pack pivot it comes in at +2 and puts threats to sleep. Corviknight gives a Flying resist and Defog to keep rocks off for Torkoal. The team has two win conditions: early spread pressure with Eruption + Psychic, or late Trick Room inversion where Torkoal becomes the fastest threat and Ursaluna cleans. EV spreads are standard except Corviknight runs 252 HP / 252 Def to live –1 Kingambit Sacred Sword and Roost stall.</OUTPUT>

input:
Draft the 'short_summary' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Gallade": {"Abilities": {"sharpness": 316.87708895268287, "justified": 0.25231685711229723, "steadfast": 1.035874438502944}, "Items": {"clearamulet": 0.27117779803292325, "sitrusberry": 0.40967986055092837, "focussash": 0.2531004017967513}, "Spreads": {"Adamant:252/116/132/0/4/4": 0.41054857088353974, "Adamant:0/252/4/0/0/252": 0.23255471404934683}, "Moves": ["trickroom", "psychocut", "sacredsword", "protect"], "Tera Types": {"grass": 0.21327859519561496, "water": 0.416472097573779, "stellar": 0.23744014984552833}, "Teammates": ["Indeedee-F", "Annihilape", "Zoroark-Hisui", "Archaludon", "Rillaboom", "Volcarona"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Gallade carves a unique niche in VGC 2024 as a dedicated Trick Room setter that immediately threatens common opposing setters like Indeedee-F and opposing Gallade with STAB Psycho Cut, while Sharpness-boosted Sacred Sword punks most Follow-Me users and bulky neutrals such as Kingambit, Gholdengo and Tyranitar. A physically bulky Adamant spread with 116 HP / 132 Def survives -1 252 Atk Chien-Pao Ice Spinner and lives most non-STAB super-effective hits long enough to fire off its moves or set Trick Room, after which it becomes a 112 BP Psycho Cut / 117 BP Sacred Sword wrecking ball that single-target pressure teams struggle to swap into. Tera Water removes the Fire and Flying weaknesses that otherwise force it out, while Tera Grass flips the matchup versus Gastrodon and Rotom-Wash; Tera Stellar gives a one-time nuke option late game. Gallade fits best on semi-room or hybrid balance squads that appreciate a fast, self-sufficient setter that can also function under opposing speed control.</OUTPUT>

input:
Provide the 'full_analysis' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Gallade": {"Abilities": {"sharpness": 316.87708895268287, "justified": 0.25231685711229723, "steadfast": 1.035874438502944}, "Items": {"clearamulet": 0.27117779803292325, "sitrusberry": 0.40967986055092837, "focussash": 0.2531004017967513}, "Spreads": {"Adamant:252/116/132/0/4/4": 0.41054857088353974, "Adamant:0/252/4/0/0/252": 0.23255471404934683}, "Moves": ["trickroom", "psychocut", "sacredsword", "protect"], "Tera Types": {"grass": 0.21327859519561496, "water": 0.416472097573779, "stellar": 0.23744014984552833}, "Teammates": ["Indeedee-F", "Annihilape", "Zoroark-Hisui", "Archaludon", "Rillaboom", "Volcarona"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Sharpness is the clear ability of choice, turning Gallade’s already respectable 90/125 attacking stats into effectively 135 BP Psycho Cut and 117 BP Sacred Sword without any drawbacks, letting it OHKO standard Indeedee-F and 2HKO most neutral targets that don’t resist. Justified’s 0.25% usage is a relic from older formats where Dark-type targets were more common; Steadfast’s 1% is pure cheese that rarely activates in doubles. Item-wise Gallade is surprisingly flexible: Clear Amulet (27%) blocks Intimidate and Parting Shot, preserving its damage output versus Incineroar and opposing Attack drops; Sitrus (41%) is the most consistent, giving it a 25% heal after the 50% threshold, which combined with its EV bulk lets it survive two neutral 90 BP moves or one super-effective 120 BP move; Focus Sash (25%) guarantees a Trick Room versus faster leads like Chien-Pao or Iron Bundle, but is more exploitable with spread and multi-hit moves. The two dominant spreads both run Adamant nature: the bulky 252 HP / 116 Atk / 132 Def / 4 SpD / 4 Spe outspeeds uninvested base 80s while living key rolls such as Life Orb Gholdengo Shadow Ball and +1 Dragonite Extreme Speed; the fast 252 Atk / 252 Spe set is used when Gallade is expected to operate outside Trick Room, notably on teams with Zoroark-Hisui or Annihilape that want the option to flip between speed modes. Move slots are almost fixed: Trick Room is mandatory for the archetype, Psychic and Sacred Sword are the Sharpness-boosted STABs that hit everything bar Fairies and ghosts for neutral or better, and Protect is Protect. Tera Water is the most popular because it removes the 4× Fire and 2× Flying weaknesses, letting Gallade stomach Heat Wave from Tornadus or Charizard and retaliate; Tera Grass flips the Gastrodon and Rotom-Wash matchups and halves Water damage from Pelipper rain teams; Tera Stellar is a tech for end-game cleaning, giving a one-time 1.2× damage boost to both STABs and removing weaknesses for a turn. Gallade’s synergy partners—Indeedee-F, Annihilape, Zoroark-Hisui, Archaludon, Rillaboom and Volcarona—showcase its role as the primary setter on semi-room: Indeedee-F sets Psychic Terrain to block priority and lets Gallade click Trick Room safely; Annihilape appreciates Psychic Terrain and Trick Room to spam Rage Fist; Zoroark-Hisui disguised as Gallade can bluff the set while Gallade itself can underspeed to operate under opposing Trick Room; Archaludon and Volcarona are powerful slow attackers that thrive under room, while Rillaboom gives Grassy Terrain recovery and priority Fake Out to ease setup. Overall Gallade is a low-usage but highly specialized pick that compresses speed control and immediate offensive pressure into one slot, punishing teams that rely on Follow-Me or Intimidate cores to stop Trick Room.</OUTPUT>

input:
Generate the 'matchup_overview' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Gallade": {"Abilities": {"sharpness": 316.87708895268287, "justified": 0.25231685711229723, "steadfast": 1.035874438502944}, "Items": {"clearamulet": 0.27117779803292325, "sitrusberry": 0.40967986055092837, "focussash": 0.2531004017967513}, "Spreads": {"Adamant:252/116/132/0/4/4": 0.41054857088353974, "Adamant:0/252/4/0/0/252": 0.23255471404934683}, "Moves": ["trickroom", "psychocut", "sacredsword", "protect"], "Tera Types": {"grass": 0.21327859519561496, "water": 0.416472097573779, "stellar": 0.23744014984552833}, "Teammates": ["Indeedee-F", "Annihilape", "Zoroark-Hisui", "Archaludon", "Rillaboom", "Volcarona"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Gallade loves facing opposing Trick Room teams that rely on bulky setters like Indeedee-F, Hatterene or Bronzong, since Sharpness Psycho Cut cleanly OHKOes all of them before they can move, effectively flipping the speed control war. It also pressures most Follow-Me users—Togekiss, Farigiraf and Maushold all take ~70% from Sacred Sword and cannot afford to redirect—so teams that depend on redirection to set up or stall out room turns struggle. Against hyper-offense Gallade can either click Trick Room versus tailwind leads like Tornadus or Dragonite and then tank a hit with Sitrus or Sash, or simply attack if the opponent is frail; Chien-Pao and Iron Bundle outspeed and KO non-Sash variants, so predicting the lead is crucial. Stall and balance cores that pack bulky Fairy-types (Sylveon, Clefable, Mimikyu) or Ghost-types (Aegislash, Skeledirge) give Gallade headaches, as it has no coverage to hit them super-effectively and must rely on teammates or Terastallization to break through. Sun teams with Torkoal and Venusaur can OHKO with Heat Wave or Sludge Bomb before Gallade moves unless it Teras Water, while rain teams with Pelipper and Kingdra outspeed and KO outside Trick Room; however, if Gallade successfully sets room, the same rain and sun attackers become liabilities. Tera Fairy or Tera Ghost opponents completely wall Gallade’s dual STABs, so scouting Tera types is essential before committing attacks.</OUTPUT>

input:
Draft the 'role_description' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Gallade": {"Abilities": {"sharpness": 316.87708895268287, "justified": 0.25231685711229723, "steadfast": 1.035874438502944}, "Items": {"clearamulet": 0.27117779803292325, "sitrusberry": 0.40967986055092837, "focussash": 0.2531004017967513}, "Spreads": {"Adamant:252/116/132/0/4/4": 0.41054857088353974, "Adamant:0/252/4/0/0/252": 0.23255471404934683}, "Moves": ["trickroom", "psychocut", "sacredsword", "protect"], "Tera Types": {"grass": 0.21327859519561496, "water": 0.416472097573779, "stellar": 0.23744014984552833}, "Teammates": ["Indeedee-F", "Annihilape", "Zoroark-Hisui", "Archaludon", "Rillaboom", "Volcarona"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Gallade is a hybrid offensive Trick Room setter that compresses speed control and immediate wall-breaking into one slot. Unlike passive setters such as Bronzong or Oranguru, Gallade threatens to OHKO or 2HKO most opposing setters and Follow-Me users, deterring them from staying in and allowing its own team to claim the room. Once Trick Room is active, Gallade becomes a 112 BP Psycho Cut / 117 BP Sacred Sword attacker that forces switches and chips bulky neutrals into range of slower teammates like Annihilape or Volcarona. Its EV spreads are tuned to survive the most common spread and single-target hits while retaining enough attack to secure KOs—after Stealth-of-stone damage or chip, Gallade’s Sacred Sword always KOs 252 HP Incineroar and 2HKOs 252 HP Gholdengo. The presence of Clear Amulet or Sitrus Berry lets it function as a soft check to Intimidate and Fake Out cores, while Tera Water turns it into a temporary tank versus Fire- and Flying-type moves that normally force it out. In short, Gallade is the “offensive setter” that trades the longevity of Dusclops or the support movepool of Indeedee-F for the ability to delete problematic Psychic-weak or Defense-dropping threats before they can act.</OUTPUT>

input:
Write the 'synergy_breakdown' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Gallade": {"Abilities": {"sharpness": 316.87708895268287, "justified": 0.25231685711229723, "steadfast": 1.035874438502944}, "Items": {"clearamulet": 0.27117779803292325, "sitrusberry": 0.40967986055092837, "focussash": 0.2531004017967513}, "Spreads": {"Adamant:252/116/132/0/4/4": 0.41054857088353974, "Adamant:0/252/4/0/0/252": 0.23255471404934683}, "Moves": ["trickroom", "psychocut", "sacredsword", "protect"], "Tera Types": {"grass": 0.21327859519561496, "water": 0.416472097573779, "stellar": 0.23744014984552833}, "Teammates": ["Indeedee-F", "Annihilape", "Zoroark-Hisui", "Archaludon", "Rillaboom", "Volcarona"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Indeedee-F is the most natural partner: Psychic Terrain blocks priority Fake Out and Bullet Punch that would otherwise stop Trick Room, while Helping Hand-boosted Psycho Spam from both Pokémon overwhelms most neutral targets. Annihilape benefits from the same terrain and room, turning Gallade’s early-game KOs into 140 BP Rage Fist nukes; both share a Fighting typing that pressures Dark- and Steel-types that annoy each other. Zoroark-Hisui disguised as Gallade can bluff the Trick Room set while the real Gallade underspeeds to operate under opposing room; Illusion plus Sharpness Sacred Sword punks would-be counters. Archaludon is a slow, specially bulky attacker that loves room and covers Gallade’s Fairy weakness with Flash Cannon while Gallade deletes Fighting-types for it. Rillaboom gives Grassy Terrain recovery that stacks with Sitrus for 30% total healing, and priority Fake Out eases setup versus faster leads; Wood Hammer also removes bulky Waters that wall Gallade. Volcarona is another room abuser that appreciates Gallade removing Rock- and Water-types with Sacred Sword, while Quiver Dance under room turns Volcarona into an unstoppable cleaner. All six teammates are either slow sweepers that want room or supportive Pokémon that secure the setup, illustrating Gallade’s role as the fulcrum of a semi-room core rather than a standalone win condition.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Gallade": {"Abilities": {"sharpness": 316.87708895268287, "justified": 0.25231685711229723, "steadfast": 1.035874438502944}, "Items": {"clearamulet": 0.27117779803292325, "sitrusberry": 0.40967986055092837, "focussash": 0.2531004017967513}, "Spreads": {"Adamant:252/116/132/0/4/4": 0.41054857088353974, "Adamant:0/252/4/0/0/252": 0.23255471404934683}, "Moves": ["trickroom", "psychocut", "sacredsword", "protect"], "Tera Types": {"grass": 0.21327859519561496, "water": 0.416472097573779, "stellar": 0.23744014984552833}, "Teammates": ["Indeedee-F", "Annihilape", "Zoroark-Hisui", "Archaludon", "Rillaboom", "Volcarona"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>The standard bulky setter: Gallade @ Sitrus Berry, Adamant, Sharpness, 252 HP / 116 Atk / 132 Def / 4 SpD / 4 Spe. Moves: Trick Room, Psycho Cut, Sacred Sword, Protect. Tera Type: Water. This spread lives -1 252 Atk Chien-Pao Ice Spinner, 252 SpA Life Orb Gholdengo Shadow Ball, and +1 Dragonite Extreme Speed, while 116 Atk guarantees the OHKO on 252 HP Indeedee-F and the 2HKO on 252 HP Gholdengo after minor chip. Sitrus plus bulk gives two-hit survivability versus most neutral spread moves. Tera Water is the safest default, removing Fire and Flying weaknesses and turning Heat Wave into a 3HKO. Alternative fast set: Gallade @ Focus Sash, Adamant, Sharpness, 0 HP / 252 Atk / 4 Def / 0 SpA / 0 SpD / 252 Spe. Moves identical. Tera Type: Grass. This variant outspeeds positive-nature base 80s and is designed to set Trick Room versus opposing tailwind or hyper-offense leads, then immediately pressure with 135 BP Psycho Cut; Sash guarantees the room versus Chien-Pao or Iron Bundle. Tera Grass flips the Rotom-Wash and Gastrodon matchups and halves Pelipper’s Hurricanes. Clear Amulet can replace Sitrus on the bulky set if Incineroar and Parting Shot Lando-T are rampant in the meta, preserving attack stage and letting Gallade muscle past Intimidate loops.</OUTPUT>

input:
Write a detailed 'weaknesses_and_counters' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Gallade": {"Abilities": {"sharpness": 316.87708895268287, "justified": 0.25231685711229723, "steadfast": 1.035874438502944}, "Items": {"clearamulet": 0.27117779803292325, "sitrusberry": 0.40967986055092837, "focussash": 0.2531004017967513}, "Spreads": {"Adamant:252/116/132/0/4/4": 0.41054857088353974, "Adamant:0/252/4/0/0/252": 0.23255471404934683}, "Moves": ["trickroom", "psychocut", "sacredsword", "protect"], "Tera Types": {"grass": 0.21327859519561496, "water": 0.416472097573779, "stellar": 0.23744014984552833}, "Teammates": ["Indeedee-F", "Annihilape", "Zoroark-Hisui", "Archaludon", "Rillaboom", "Volcarona"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Fairy-types are the hard stop: Sylveon, Clefable and Mimikyu all shrug off both STABs and OHKO back with Moonblast or Play Rough; Mimikyu’s Disguise even lets it survive a potential Tera-boosted attack. Ghost-types such as Aegislash and Skeledirge are similarly immune to Sacred Sword and resist Psycho Cut, while Burns from Will-O-Wisp or Torch Song cripple Gallade’s offensive presence. Faster special attackers with super-effective coverage—Iron Bundle Freeze-Dry, Chien-Pao Ice Spinner, Tornadus Hurricane—can KO before it moves unless it carries Sash or Teras Water. Multi-hit moves like Maushold Population Bomb or Kingambit Supreme Overlord boosted Sucker Punch break through Focus Sash and punish Gallade’s lack of resist berries. Priority Fake Out from Incineroar or Rillaboom combined with a partner’s spread move can double-target it before it sets Trick Room, especially if Psychic Terrain is not active. Finally, Tera Fairy or Tera Ghost opponents completely wall its dual STABs, forcing Gallade to either Tera itself to neutral or switch out, losing momentum. To mitigate these issues, Gallade teams must pack answers like Archaludon Flash Cannon or Volcarona Bug Buzz for Fairies, and either Indeedee-F terrain or their own Fake Out to guarantee the room versus faster Fake Out leads.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Semi-room Psychic-spam: Indeedee-F (F) @ Focus Sash, Psychic Surge, 252 HP / 252 SpA / 4 SpD, Modest, Helping Hand / Psychic / Shadow Ball / Protect; Gallade (M) @ Sitrus Berry, Adamant, Sharpness, 252 HP / 116 Atk / 132 Def / 4 SpD / 4 Spe, Trick Room / Psycho Cut / Sacred Sword / Protect, Tera Water; Annihilape (M) @ Leftovers, Defiant, 252 HP / 252 Atk / 4 SpD, Brave, Rage Fist / Drain Punch / Ice Punch / Protect, Tera Fighting; Archaludon @ Assault Vest, Sturdy, 252 HP / 252 SpA / 4 SpD, Quiet, Flash Cannon / Electro Shot / Dragon Pulse / Body Press, Tera Steel; Volcarona @ Life Orb, Flame Body, 252 HP / 252 SpA / 4 SpD, Quiet, Heat Wave / Bug Buzz / Quiver Dance / Protect, Tera Fire; Rillaboom (M) @ Miracle Seed, Grassy Surge, 252 HP / 252 Atk / 4 SpD, Brave, Wood Hammer / Grassy Glide / Fake Out / Protect, Tera Grass. Lead Indeedee + Gallade versus most opponents: terrain blocks priority, Trick Room goes up, then Helping Hand Psychic Spam or Sacred Sword removes threats. Annihilae and Volcarona clean under room, Archaludon covers Fairies and Flying-types, Rillaboom gives mid-game priority and Grassy recovery that stacks with Sitrus for 30% total healing. The squad can flip between fast and slow modes depending on the matchup, with Gallade as the pivot that decides which speed tier to abuse.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Liquid Voice turns Primarina’s sound-based moves into Water-type attacks, giving STAB on Hyper Voice and a pseudo-second STAB that smacks Fire- and Rock-types that normally wall Moonblast. With 126 base Special Attack and respectable bulk (80/74/116), Primarina can trade hits or fire off Life-Orb-boosted spread damage that ignores Wide Guard. Hyper Voice + Moonblast provides near-perfect neutral coverage, while Protect is mandatory for doubles play and Haze erases opposing boosts from setup sweepers like Dragonite, Kingambit, or Weakness-Policy Regidrago. Tera options are flexible: Tera Water amplifies Liquid Voice Hyper Voice into a nuke, Tera Poison removes Grass weakness and beats Amoonguss 1v1, Tera Steel grants a suite of resistances for surviving Gholdengo and Dragonite, and Tera Grass flips the matchup versus Rotom-Wash and opposing Primarina. The lack of recorded spreads implies most builds run 252 HP / 252 SpA / 4 SpD Modest or 172 HP / 116 Def / 220 Modest to survive key rolls, but the raw usage rate of Liquid Voice (99 %) shows the ability is non-negotiable.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Dragapult": {"Abilities": {"clearbody": 240.62077936020725, "infiltrator": 7.902720628067861, "cursedbody": 4.033538356688714}, "Items": {"choiceband": 0.8318719016970352}, "Spreads": {"Adamant:0/252/0/0/4/252": 0.16485798536850352, "Jolly:0/252/0/0/4/252": 0.15292267272766188}, "Moves": ["dragondarts", "outrage", "phantomforce", "uturn"], "Tera Types": {"dragon": 0.745103821350272}, "Teammates": ["Sneasler", "Incineroar", "Rillaboom", "Kingambit", "Ursaluna-Bloodmoon", "Dondozo"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Choice Band Dragapult is one of the most immediate offensive threats in the current regulation. Dragon Darts’ multi-target property lets it delete both foes in doubles without suffering spread reduction, while Outrage provides a nuclear single-target option against Dynamax or bulky pivots. Phantom Force is the mandatory stall-breaking tool that also grants a semi-invulnerable turn, letting Pult dodge Fake Out or opposing Max Moves and re-position safely. Clear Body is taken on 94% of sampled sets because it neutralizes the omnipresent Intimidate from Incineroar and Landorus-T as well as Snarl or Parting Shot drops, ensuring the Band-boosted attack always lands at full power. Tera Dragon is used on three-quarters of teams: it removes Ghost- and Dragon-type weaknesses, turns resisted Fire/Water/Grass/Electric coverage into neutral hits, and gives Pult a second STAB that nothing short of Steel- or Fairy-types can stomach. EV spreads are binary—either Adamant or Jolly with maximum Attack and Speed—because Dragapult’s value lies in outpacing and obliterating the metagame’s fastest threats such as Iron Valiant, opposing Pult, and Flutter Mane. The complete absence of bulk investment reflects its hit-and-run nature; it aims to trade at worst and sweep at best, making Protect unnecessary when it can simply delete something instead.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Dragapult": {"Abilities": {"clearbody": 240.62077936020725, "infiltrator": 7.902720628067861, "cursedbody": 4.033538356688714}, "Items": {"choiceband": 0.8318719016970352}, "Spreads": {"Adamant:0/252/0/0/4/252": 0.16485798536850352, "Jolly:0/252/0/0/4/252": 0.15292267272766188}, "Moves": ["dragondarts", "outrage", "phantomforce", "uturn"], "Tera Types": {"dragon": 0.745103821350272}, "Teammates": ["Sneasler", "Incineroar", "Rillaboom", "Kingambit", "Ursaluna-Bloodmoon", "Dondozo"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Dragapult annihilates most neutral targets: resisted Dragon Darts still 2HKO bulky Rotom-Wash and Garganacl, while Outrage cleanly OHKOs standard bulk Gholdengo and Ting-Lu after Tera. It terrorizes offensive cores built around Flutter Mane, Iron Valiant, and Chien-Pao, outrunning and KOing all of them. Fairy-types are the obvious hard wall—Scarf Sylveon and bulky Arcanine take negligible damage and retalivate with Hyper Voice or Play Rough—but they must be wary of U-turn chip and potential partner redirection. Steel-types such as Kingambit and Corviknight can stomach a hit but dislike eating a +1 (Tera) Outrage or being worn down by Phantom Force stalling. Trick Room teams that rely on hard-pressing Pult with follow-up priority or status can succeed if they set before Pult enters, otherwise Pult simply picks off the setter first. Overall, Dragapult forces opponents to preserve Fairy-type answers or risk being swept once opposing speed control is removed.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Fairy-types—Scarf Sylveon, bulky Arcanine, Azumarill, and Scream Tail—are the premier answers, taking negligible damage and OHKOing back with their STAB. Priority users such as Kingambit’s Sucker Punch or Dragonite’s Extreme Speed can finish off chipped Pult, though they must beware Phantom Force’s semi-invulnerability. Choice Scarf users faster than base 142 (Iron Valiant, opposing Jolly Pult) force a 50-50 if Pult is Adamant. Bulky Steel-types like Corviknight and Gholdengo can tank one Outrage and retaliate with Iron Head or Make It Rain, but neither enjoys repeated hits or U-turn chip. Finally, Protect + predicting the lock is a universal answer: once Put locks into Outrage, a well-timed Protect from a Fairy or Steel partner leaves it confused and exposed. Because Pult is rarely bulk-invested, any neutral super-effective move or strong priority that lands cleanly will KO it.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Porygon2’s dominance in the current format stems from its unique combination of natural bulk, Eviolite multiplication, and Download’s ability to grant a free +1 to its higher offensive stat. Modest nature maximizes its damage output, allowing uninvested Ice Beam to OHKO 4 HP Dragonite and 2HKO most Landorus-T variants after a Download boost. Tera Electric is preferred (23.6%) to flip the Water matchup, letting Porygon2 survive Choice Specs Pelipper’s Hydro Vortex and retaliate with Thunderbolt, while Tera Fighting (51.8%) grants neutrality to Knock Off and a powerful Tera Blast that OHKOs common Dark-types such as Kingambit and Ting-Lu. Recover provides longevity, enabling Porygon2 to repeatedly set Trick Room against faster offenses and outlast opposing support Pokémon. Trace remains a niche option (7.2%) to copy Intimidate, Drought, or Protosynthesis for immediate utility, but Download’s raw power and snowball potential are overwhelmingly preferred. The listed spread survives Jolly Choice Band Chien-Pao’s Icicle Crash and Timid Gholdengo’s Make It Rain, ensuring Trick Room goes up in the face of the tier’s strongest attackers.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Ribombee": {"Abilities": {"shielddust": 232.19407542653065, "sweetveil": 1.0267451737225826, "honeygather": 0.10950820561175612}, "Items": {"focussash": 0.9965980999787839}, "Spreads": {"Timid:4/0/0/252/0/252": 0.46295644699609617, "Timid:0/0/4/252/0/252": 0.37427555832349163}, "Moves": ["moonblast", "tailwind", "faketears", "strugglebug"], "Tera Types": {"fairy": 0.3109897584155033, "ghost": 0.2261524553558226, "grass": 0.4089090472786543}, "Teammates": ["Gholdengo", "Incineroar", "Indeedee-F", "Ursaluna-Bloodmoon", "Armarouge", "Kingambit"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>In the current metagame Ribombee occupies a micro-role as a hyper-speed utility pivot. Base 124 Speed outpaces the crowded base 110–120 tier, ensuring Tailwind goes up before Kingambit, Gholdengo, and most Dragons. Once Tailwind is active its job usually ends, yet it can still apply Fake Tears pressure to soften special checks like Ting-Lu or bulky Arcanine, or drop Struggle Bug to shave 25% off opposing Flutter Mane or Spectrier-style special sweepers. Moonblast prevents it from being complete setup fodding and secures a KO on Dragapult after prior chip. Focus Sash is mandatory; with no HP investment and only 60/80/90 bulk any neutral hit breaks it. Shield Dust is by far the preferred ability—blocking Sludge Bomb poison, Moonblast drops, or Lava Plume burns preserves its one-shot survivability and keeps your momentum intact. Sweet Veil or Honey Gather are gimmicks at best. Tera Grass is the most common, flipping the matchup vs opposing Water- and Ground-types such as Palafin or Great Tusk while removing the Electric weakness; Tera Ghost offers immunity to Fake Out and Extreme Speed, letting it survive a turn to reset Tailwind late-game; Tera Fairy is neutral but grants a stronger Moonblast and a Dragon immunity if you anticipate a Roaring Moon Draco. EV spreads are simple: max Speed Timid plus either 4 Def or 4 HP to slightly tweak download or opposing damage rolls; the rest is dumped into Special Attack to give Moonblast a touch more bite. Ribombee rarely sticks around more than three turns, so every action must be deliberate—set Tailwind, cripple something, then sacrifice or pivot to let a bulkier win-condition sweep.</OUTPUT>

It struggles against priority-heavy archetypes: Basculegion’s Aqua Jet, Dragonite’s Extreme Speed, or Kingambit’s Sucker Punch all bypass its Speed and break Sash. Opposing weather or Booster Energy speedsters like Flutter Mane, Iron Bundle, or Chien-Pao can still underspeed and KO before it acts if their speed stats are already boosted. Dual-Incineroar mirrors also annoy it because Intimidate plus Flare Blitz KOes through Sash if rocks are up, while Parting Shot undoes Fake Tears drops. Tera Grass variants mitigate Rotom-W and Palafin, but Amoonguss completely walls it and can Spore back after Sash is gone; Tera Ghost helps versus Fake Out users but leaves it weaker to common dark coverage. Overall Ribombee is matchup-fishy—excellent in scripted, speed-controlling positions, yet a dead slot if the enemy packs sturdy priority or hyper-offense.</OUTPUT>

The goal is to disguise Zoroark as one of its common partners—Incineroar, Rillaboon, Gallade, Annihilape, Archaludon or Volcarona—so that opponents mis-target or mis-predict on turn 1. Once the disguise breaks, Zoroark’s job is usually already done: either it has fired a Specs-boosted Shadow Ball, spread Speed control with Icy Wind, or shut down an opposing setter with Taunt. 252 Timid with max Speed investment is non-negotiable; the Pokémon needs to outrun as much as possible so that Illusion is still intact when it moves. Tera Rock is the most common Tera type, presumably to flip the Normal-weakness into a resistance and survive a Fake Out or Extreme Speed, while Tera Stellar offers a neutral STAB boost to Shadow Ball once the surprise is revealed. Focus Sash guarantees at least one attack if you suspect spread damage or priority, whereas Choice Specs maximises immediate damage output at the cost of locking yourself into one move. The lack of coverage beyond Shadow Ball and Tera Blast means Zoroark struggles into Dark- and Steel-types, so successful teams pair it with Fighting or Fairy pressure to clear those obstacles before Zoroark hits the field.</OUTPUT>

It is not a win-condition itself but a force multiplier that lets its actual sweepers set up or reposition safely.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Timid 252/0/0/252/0/252 is the only spread on usage tables and for good reason—outspeeding as much as possible is mandatory. Focus Sash gives you guaranteed disruption: Icy Wind for speed control, Shadow Ball for STAB damage, Taunt to stop Trick Room or Tailwind, and Tera Blast (Rock) to hit Fire- and Flying-types while gaining a useful resistance. Choice Specs trades survivability for power: Shadow Ball becomes a legitimate nuke capable of OHKOing uninvested Miraidon and dealing ~70% to neutral bulk Koraidon; run Trick over Taunt if you want to cripple walls like Dondozo or Toxapex, or keep Taunt for the same anti-setup utility. Tera Rock is preferred on both sets to flip the Normal immunity and survive Fake Out, though Tera Stellar can be used if you value the pure STAB boost after Illusion breaks.</OUTPUT>

Finally, once Illusion is revealed, any Choice-locked set becomes exploitable: a predicted Shadow Ball lets the opponent freely bring in a Dark-type or set up Protects to waste your PP.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Kommo-o": {"Abilities": {"overcoat": 154.61033294354777, "bulletproof": 6.858067374888256, "soundproof": 63.65881564758718}, "Items": {"leftovers": 0.41488502918069486, "throatspray": 0.3669975434569414, "lifeorb": 0.16946858377812105}, "Spreads": {"Bold:252/0/156/4/92/4": 0.2556533848281827, "Modest:0/0/0/252/4/252": 0.1654557181645273}, "Moves": ["protect", "flamethrower", "clangingscales", "aurasphere"], "Tera Types": {"fire": 0.818955693367224}, "Teammates": ["Rillaboom", "Ursaluna-Bloodmoon", "Porygon2", "Incineroar", "Amoonguss", "Gholdengo"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Kommo-o carves a niche as a bulky, specially oriented Dragon that leverages its unique STAB combination and respectable natural bulk to pressure common Fairy-weak cores while compressing the roles of Tailwind deterrent, spread attacker, and late-game cleaner. With a 92% usage rate for Overcoat, it blanks every opposing Amoonguss, Rage Powder, and weather chip, letting it stay on the field longer than most Dragons and repeatedly fire off Clanging Scales and coverage. The given spread—Bold with 156 Def and 92 SpD—lets it survive Moonblast + Shadow Ball from Flutter Mane, survive Life Orb Ursaluna-Bloodmoon Earthquake, and always live Jolly Chien-Pao Ice Spinner, while 252+ SpA investment still secures the OHKO on standard Gholdengo and 2HKO on bulky Torkoal through Tera Fire. Tera Fire is chosen on 82% of teams to flip the Fairy matchup, turning Moonblast into a neutral hit and letting Kommo-o win the 1-v-1 against opposing Sylveon and Azumarill. The four-move set of Protect / Clanging Scales / Flamethrower / Aura Sphere offers perfect neutral coverage barring Tera Fairy, and because both STABs trigger Throat Spray, Kommo-o can boost to +1 SpA without wasting a turn, turning 2HKOs into OHKOs on the likes of Kingambit and Gholdengo. While its Speed tier is only middling, the omnipresent Tailwind and Icy Wind support from partners such as Porygon2 and Amoonguss let it outpace the metagame’s scarfers after a single speed-control drop. In short, Kommo-o is a low-maintenance, high-reward pivot that punishes passive teams and provides an emergency check to both physical and special threats while blanking the most common form of speed control in Tailwind.</OUTPUT>

input:
Create the 'full_analysis' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Kommo-o": {"Abilities": {"overcoat": 154.61033294354777, "bulletproof": 6.858067374888256, "soundproof": 63.65881564758718}, "Items": {"leftovers": 0.41488502918069486, "throatspray": 0.3669975434569414, "lifeorb": 0.16946858377812105}, "Spreads": {"Bold:252/0/156/4/92/4": 0.2556533848281827, "Modest:0/0/0/252/4/252": 0.1654557181645273}, "Moves": ["protect", "flamethrower", "clangingscales", "aurasphere"], "Tera Types": {"fire": 0.818955693367224}, "Teammates": ["Rillaboom", "Ursaluna-Bloodmoon", "Porygon2", "Incineroar", "Amoonguss", "Gholdengo"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Kommo-o’s viability in the current regulation stems from three factors: Overcoat’s immunity to spore and chip, a STAB spread move that bypasses Follow Me, and Tera Fire’s ability to flip one of the worst defensive typings in the game into a neutral-or-better answer to Fairies. Overcoat is the clear ability of choice, appearing on 154.6 out of every 165 Kommo-o, because it single-handedly removes the single biggest obstacle to Dragon-type progress: Amoonguss. With Rage Powder and Spore nullified, Kommo-o can freely target the slot it needs to, and because Clanging Scales is a spread move, it still damages both foes even when a partner cycles into Protect. The chosen EV spread maximizes physical bulk while retaining enough special bulk to survive Life Orb Flutter Mane Shadow Ball + Moonblast, and because Kommo-o’s base 110 Special Attack is naturally high, it can afford to run Bold nature and still hit key benchmarks: +1 252+ SpA Clanging Scales always OHKOs standard Gholdengo and 2HKOs 252 HP Dondozo, while uninvested Flamethrower cleanly OHKOs 252 HP Corviknight through Tera Fire. Aura Sphere rounds out coverage by nailing Kingambit and Tyranitar for OHKOs after a Throat Spray boost, and because both STABs trigger the item, Kommo-o can boost simply by attacking. Tera Fire is non-negotiable: it removes the Fairy weakness, turns Moonblast into a neutral 80 BP hit, and grants a crucial Ice resistance that lets Kommo-o survive Chien-Pao’s Ice Spinner and Glaive Rush. The 8% of sets that opt for Bulletproof or Soundproof are largely gimmicks—Bulletproof does block Shadow Ball and Sludge Bomb, but Overcoat’s utility against Amoonguss and opposing weather chip is simply too valuable. Item-wise, Throat Spray’s 0.37% usage belies its importance: once Kommo-o clicks either STAB, it immediately becomes a +1 Special Attacker, turning 2HKOs into OHKOs without the predictability of a setup turn. Life Orb appears on only 0.17% of teams, suggesting players prefer the free boost and longevity that Throat Spray and Leftovers provide. In practice, Kommo-o functions as a mid-game pivot that can trade positively against most of the tier’s top threats—Gholdengo, Kingambit, Corviknight, and opposing Dragons—while blanking Amoonguss entirely. Its ability to compress the roles of speed control deterrent, spread attacker, and Tera user into a single slot makes it one of the most slot-efficient Pokémon in the format.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Kommo-o": {"Abilities": {"overcoat": 154.61033294354777, "bulletproof": 6.858067374888256, "soundproof": 63.65881564758718}, "Items": {"leftovers": 0.41488502918069486, "throatspray": 0.3669975434569414, "lifeorb": 0.16946858377812105}, "Spreads": {"Bold:252/0/156/4/92/4": 0.2556533848281827, "Modest:0/0/0/252/4/252": 0.1654557181645273}, "Moves": ["protect", "flamethrower", "clangingscales", "aurasphere"], "Tera Types": {"fire": 0.818955693367224}, "Teammates": ["Rillaboom", "Ursaluna-Bloodmoon", "Porygon2", "Incineroar", "Amoonguss", "Gholdengo"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Kommo-o’s matchup spread is defined by its typing and Tera Fire. Against Fairy teams it goes from a liability to a neutral-to-favorable encounter: Tera Fire removes the 4× weakness, letting it survive Moonblast from Choice Specs Sylveon and 2HKO back with Clanging Scales. Against Steel, it dominates: Flamethrower OHKOs Gholdengo, Corviknight, and Kingambit, while Aura Sphere handles Tera Fairy Kingambit. Against Grass, Overcoat blank Amoonguss and lets Kommo-o ignore Rage Powder, turning the matchup into a free double-target scenario. Against Ice, Tera Fire is again crucial, letting it live Chien-Pao’s Ice Spinner and retaliate with Aura Sphere for the OHKO. Against Psychic, it checks Indeedee–Armarouge cores by ignoring Follow Me and OHKOing Armarouge with Clanging Scales while tanking Indeedee’s Helping Hand Psychic. Against Fire, it struggles pre-Tera but can still survive Torkoal Eruption in sun and 2HKO back with Clanging Scales; post-Tera Fire, it becomes neutral to Fire moves and can trade evenly. Against Ghost, it beats Gholdengo and Aegislash but must watch for Tera Fairy Annihilape. Against Dragon, it out-bulks all non-Tera Fairy variants and wins the mirror by surviving opposing Clanging Scales and retaliating for the KO. Against Ground, it survives Life Orb Great Tusk Headlong Rush and OHKOs back with Aura Sphere. In short, Kommo-o’s matchups are overwhelmingly positive against Steel, Grass, Psychic, and Dragon cores, neutral against Fire and Ice after Tera, and only truly poor against Tera Fairy variants that it cannot outpace without speed control.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Kommo-o": {"Abilities": {"overcoat": 154.61033294354777, "bulletproof": 6.858067374888256, "soundproof": 63.65881564758718}, "Items": {"leftovers": 0.41488502918069486, "throatspray": 0.3669975434569414, "lifeorb": 0.16946858377812105}, "Spreads": {"Bold:252/0/156/4/92/4": 0.2556533848281827, "Modest:0/0/0/252/4/252": 0.1654557181645273}, "Moves": ["protect", "flamethrower", "clangingscales", "aurasphere"], "Tera Types": {"fire": 0.818955693367224}, "Teammates": ["Rillaboom", "Ursaluna-Bloodmoon", "Porygon2", "Incineroar", "Amoonguss", "Gholdengo"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Kommo-o is best described as a bulky offensive pivot that compresses three jobs into one slot: Amoonguss counter, spread attacker, and Tera sink. It is not a dedicated win-condition, nor is it a pure support Pokémon; instead, it occupies the flexible “third slot” on teams that already have a dedicated lead duo and a restricted legendary. Because Overcoat blanks spore and chip, Kommo-o can switch into Amoonguss freely, forcing the opponent to either double-target it—risking a Protect—or allow it to fire off a free Clanging Scales. Once Throat Spray is triggered, its Special Attack jumps to effectively 604, letting it OHKO or 2HKO the majority of the tier without further setup. The Tera Fire transformation is usually timed mid-game, either to flip a Fairy matchup or to survive an otherwise lethal Ice-type move, after which Kommo-o becomes a 118/125/125 bulk monster that still hits 332 Special Attack. Its speed tier of 259 (after Icy Wind) outspeeds positive-nature base 135s such as Chien-Pao, meaning that with a single speed-control drop it can operate as a pseudo-scarfer. In the late game, Kommo-o can clean weakened teams by alternating between Clanging Scales and coverage, and because both STABs trigger Throat Spray, it can boost on the same turn it attacks, making it extremely low-maintenance. The presence of Kommo-o on a team also forces opponents to play more conservatively around Amoonguss, effectively granting the rest of the squad more breathing room.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Kommo-o": {"Abilities": {"overcoat": 154.61033294354777, "bulletproof": 6.858067374888256, "soundproof": 63.65881564758718}, "Items": {"leftovers": 0.41488502918069486, "throatspray": 0.3669975434569414, "lifeorb": 0.16946858377812105}, "Spreads": {"Bold:252/0/156/4/92/4": 0.2556533848281827, "Modest:0/0/0/252/4/252": 0.1654557181645273}, "Moves": ["protect", "flamethrower", "clangingscales", "aurasphere"], "Tera Types": {"fire": 0.818955693367224}, "Teammates": ["Rillaboom", "Ursaluna-Bloodmoon", "Porygon2", "Incineroar", "Amoonguss", "Gholdengo"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Kommo-o’s most common teammates—Rillaboom, Ursaluna-Bloodmoon, Porygon2, Incineroar, Amoonguss, and Gholdengo—each solve one of its three problems: speed, physical power, and Fairy pressure. Rillaboom provides priority Grassy Glide to pick off faster threats that Kommo-o cannot outpace, notably Chien-Pao and Flutter Mane, while Grassy Terrain adds passive recovery that stacks with Leftovers to keep Kommo-o healthy throughout a long game. Ursaluna-Bloodmoon offers a physical breaker that can overwhelm Tera Fairy targets that Kommo-o cannot fully remove, while Kommo-o in return handles Corviknight and Gholdengo for the bear. Porygon2 provides Icy Wind and Trick Room control, letting Kommo-o function under either speed mode and guaranteeing the Icy Wind drop that turns Kommo-o into a pseudo-scarfer. Incineroar supplies Fake Out and Intimidate, creating safe entry turns for Kommo-o to Protect and scout, while Flare Blitz covers the rare Steel-types that Kommo-o cannot break. Amoonguss forms a classic “grass-and-dragon” core: Kommo-o blanks opposing Amoonguss, while its own Amoonguss redirects attacks and puts pressure with Spore, creating a feedback loop that punishes double-targets. Finally, Gholdengo provides a secondary answer to Fairy-types and a spin-blocker that keeps hazards up for Kommo-o’s chip game, while Kommo-o removes Kingambit and Corviknight that trouble the ghost. Together these teammates form a balanced core that can operate under Tailwind, Trick Room, or Icy Wind speed control, and each member appreciates Kommo-o’s unique ability to ignore Amoonguss while firing off spread damage.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Kommo-o": {"Abilities": {"overcoat": 154.61033294354777, "bulletproof": 6.858067374888256, "soundproof": 63.65881564758718}, "Items": {"leftovers": 0.41488502918069486, "throatspray": 0.3669975434569414, "lifeorb": 0.16946858377812105}, "Spreads": {"Bold:252/0/156/4/92/4": 0.2556533848281827, "Modest:0/0/0/252/4/252": 0.1654557181645273}, "Moves": ["protect", "flamethrower", "clangingscales", "aurasphere"], "Tera Types": {"fire": 0.818955693367224}, "Teammates": ["Rillaboom", "Ursaluna-Bloodmoon", "Porygon2", "Incineroar", "Amoonguss", "Gholdengo"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>The standard set is Bold 252 HP / 156 Def / 92 SpD / 4 Spe with Overcoat, Throat Spray, and Tera Fire. Moves are Protect / Clanging Scales / Flamethrower / Aura Sphere. The EV spread survives Life Orb Flutter Mane Shadow Ball + Moonblast, Jolly Chien-Pao Ice Spinner, and Great Tusk Headlong Rush, while still OHKOing Gholdengo with +1 Clanging Scales. For teams that prefer more immediate power, a Modest 0/0/0/252/4/252 spread with Life Orb can be used, trading bulk for the guarantee that uninvested Flamethrower OHKOs 252 HP Corviknight and Clanging Scales always OHKOs bulky Dondozo. Throat Spray is mandatory on the bulky set; Leftovers is an option on teams that expect long games, but the +1 boost is usually more impactful than 6% recovery per turn. Tera Fire is non-negotiable—no other Tera type removes both Fairy and Ice weaknesses while retaining STAB on Dragon and Fire moves. For best-of-three sets, consider swapping Aura Sphere for Flash Cannon if Tera Fairy Kingambit is rampant in your local meta, but Aura Sphere’s superior neutral coverage against Tyranitar and Ursaluna-Bloodmoon makes it the default. Finally, always pair Kommo-o with either Icy Wind or Tailwind support; without a speed-control drop it fails to outpace positive-nature base 135s, which is the single most important benchmark in the current format.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Kommo-o": {"Abilities": {"overcoat": 154.61033294354777, "bulletproof": 6.858067374888256, "soundproof": 63.65881564758718}, "Items": {"leftovers": 0.41488502918069486, "throatspray": 0.3669975434569414, "lifeorb": 0.16946858377812105}, "Spreads": {"Bold:252/0/156/4/92/4": 0.2556533848281827, "Modest:0/0/0/252/4/252": 0.1654557181645273}, "Moves": ["protect", "flamethrower", "clangingscales", "aurasphere"], "Tera Types": {"fire": 0.818955693367224}, "Teammates": ["Rillaboom", "Ursaluna-Bloodmoon", "Porygon2", "Incineroar", "Amoonguss", "Gholdengo"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Despite Tera Fire, Kommo-o still dislikes facing Tera Fairy variants that it cannot outpace without speed control, especially Choice Specs Sylveon and Tera Fairy Iron Valiant. Pre-Tera, any strong Fairy move from a base 110 Special Attack or higher will 2HKO, so Moonblast from Flutter Mane or Sylveon will force the Tera early and leave Kommo-o chipped for the rest of the game. Physical Dragons that carry Tera Fairy, such as Garchomp or opposing Kommo-o, can survive a Clanging Scales and retaliate with Tera Fairy Outrage or Close Combat for the KO. Priority users such as Kingambit’s Sucker Punch or Chien-Pao’s Ice Shard can finish off a weakened Kommo-o after it has taken a Moonblast or Icy Wind chip. Status—especially burn from Rotom-W or Gholdengo—removes Kommo-o’s longevity and makes it harder to trigger Throat Spray safely. Finally, phazing moves such as Roar from Ting-Lu or Dondozo can remove Kommo-o’s stat boosts and force it to re-enter on a dangerous field. The simplest counterplay is to deny speed control: if Kommo-o cannot get an Icy Wind or Tailwind up, it fails to outpace base 135 scarfers and becomes relegated to trading one-for-one. Teams that carry dual Fairy pressure—e.g., Choice Specs Sylveon and Tera Fairy Kingambit—can force Kommo-o to Tera to survive the first, then finish it with the second. Lastly, because Kommo-o relies on Throat Spray, Encore users such as Murkrow or opposing Kommo-o can lock it into Protect or Clanging Scales and waste the item window.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>A proven Regulation-D core is Kommo-o / Rillaboom / Porygon2 / Incineroar / Gholdengo / Ursaluna-Bloodmoon. Lead Rillaboom + Incineroar against most teams: Fake Out + U-turn creates early momentum while Grassy Terrain chips and provides recovery. In the back, Kommo-o and Porygon2 form a slow pivot core: Porygon2 clicks Icy Wind or Trick Room depending on the matchup, while Kommo-o Protects or fires off Clanging Scales. Gholdengo and Ursaluna-Bloodmoon provide the heavy artillery—Gholdengo removes hazards and pressures Fairy-types, while Ursaluna-Bloodmoon breaks through Tera Fairy targets with Blood Moon. Against Amoonguss teams, simply bring Kommo-o early, ignore Rage Powder, and click Clanging Scales to trigger Throat Spray; follow with Icy Wind to outspeed and clean. Against Tailwind offenses, lead Porygon2 + Incineroar, set Trick Room, and reverse speed control while Kommo-o comes in on the predicted Protect turn. Tera Fire is timed when facing Sylveon or Chien-Pao: survive the Moonblast or Ice Spinner and retaliate for the KO. The team has no dedicated restricted legendary, instead relying on compression and synergy to handle the entire metagame. EV spreads are standard: Rillaboom Adamant 252/252 with Miracle Seed, Incineroar Careful 252/140/116 with Figy Berry, Porygon2 Bold 252/100/156 with Eviolite, Gholdengo Modest 252/252 with Choice Specs, Ursaluna-Bloodmoon Brave 252/252 with Life Orb, and Kommo-o as above. The concept is flexible enough to reach top-cut at both Regional and International levels.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Farigiraf’s 110/80/85 bulk is merely decent, but Armor Tail single-handedly justifies its inclusion: Fake Out, Sucker Punch, First Impression, and Aqua Jet all fail, letting partners like Ursaluna-Bloodmoon or Torkoal set up or attack unimpeded. Psychic + Hyper Voice gives perfect neutral coverage against every relevant target bar Steel-types, while Protect preserves its modest longevity and allows prediction around double-targets. The EV spread is not specified in the data, but the community standard is 252 HP / 156 Def / 100 SpA with a Quiet nature—enough to survive -1 Tera Blast Dragon from Dragapult and OHKO 4 HP Tornadus with Psychic after Throat Spray. Throat Spray is the only boosting item shown, proccing on Hyper Voice to reach a game-breaking 1.5× SpA in one turn; Sitrus Berry is an alternative for teams that prefer immediate recovery over snowball potential. Tera Fire removes the Ice and Bug weaknesses, Tera Fairy flips the Dark weakness into a resistance, and Tera Water punishes Sun teams expecting a free Heat Rock Torkoal KO. Sap Sipper is listed but almost never run—Grass immunity is cute versus Rillaboom, but losing Armor Tail turns Farigiraf into a strictly worse Indeedee. Cud Chew is pure theory-crafting and sees zero high-level play.</OUTPUT>

Against other Trick Room mirrors, Farigiraf is faster than most setters (base 65) and can click Psychic to KO Hatterene through Focus Sash, but loses hard to Ghost-types like Aegislash and Annihilape if it has not Tera Fairy. <DATA>{"Weezing": {"Abilities": {"levitate": 0.4780722163434653, "neutralizinggas": 184.78465190865194, "stench": 0.0}, "Items": {"sitrusberry": 0.18669911533523645, "mentalherb": 0.7000898852277965}, "Spreads": {"Careful:252/4/4/0/236/12": 0.6890537653037525}, "Moves": ["protect", "poisongas", "toxicspikes", "gunkshot"], "Tera Types": {"grass": 0.7037676794949288}, "Teammates": ["Incineroar", "Annihilape", "Slaking", "Dondozo", "Tatsugiri", "Sableye"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Weezing carves a unique niche in VGC as a disruptive support Pokémon that abuses Neutralizing Gas to shut off nearly every ability-based strategy in the tier. With 184 out of every 185 high-level sets running Neutralizing Gas, it single-handedly invalidates Huge Power, Protosynthesis, Quark Drive, Good as Gold, Purifying Salt, and a host of other meta-defining abilities. Its near-universal 252 HP / 236 SpD Careful spread with a Grass Tera type lets it survive Flutter Mane Moonblasts, Raging Bolt Dracos, and other key special hits while also flipping the script on Landorus-T Earth Powers and turning Amoonguss Spores into free setup turns. Poison Gas and Toxic Spikes provide unique, non-Tauntable status pressure that no other VGC Pokémon replicates, letting Weezing cripple physical set-up sweepers and stall out bulkier cores alike. Although its offensive stats are mediocre, Gunk Shot still 2HKOs most Fairy-types and prevents it from being complete Taunt bait. Weezing’s presence forces opponents to play a fundamentally different game—one where their usual ability-based safety nets vanish and every switch carries the risk of a badly poisoned endgame.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Weezing": {"Abilities": {"levitate": 0.4780722163434653, "neutralizinggas": 184.78465190865194, "stench": 0.0}, "Items": {"sitrusberry": 0.18669911533523645, "mentalherb": 0.7000898852277965}, "Spreads": {"Careful:252/4/4/0/236/12": 0.6890537653037525}, "Moves": ["protect", "poisongas", "toxicspikes", "gunkshot"], "Tera Types": {"grass": 0.7037676794949288}, "Teammates": ["Incineroar", "Annihilape", "Slaking", "Dondozo", "Tatsugiri", "Sableye"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Neutralizing Gas is the strongest disruptive ability ever legalized in VGC, and Weezing is its only user. By simply being on the field, it removes every speed control granted by Protosynthesis/Quark Drive, strips Ting-Lu of its bulk boost, denies Garganacl its Salt Cure recovery, and turns Kingambit’s Supreme Overlord into dead weight. This creates a ripple effect: partners that normally lose to Sun or Electric Terrain suddenly become viable, and opponents must rely on raw stats rather than their customary crutches. Weezing’s own stats are deliberately invested in special bulk; with Grass Tera it avoids the 2HKO from +1 Flutter Mane Shadow Ball and lives +2 Raging Bolt Draco Meteor, allowing it to retaliate with Tera Grass-boosted Gunk Shot or continue spreading poison. Poison Gas is the preferred status because it bypasses Grass-types, Safety Goggles, and covers both foes, while Toxic Spikes punishes long games and forces opponents to keep their grounded Poison-type alive to absorb them. Mental Herb is the item of choice on 70 % of teams to guarantee the first Gas or hazard against Taunt users like Whimsicott or Sableye, while the remainder prefer Sitrus for extra longevity. Protect is mandatory for stalling out poison damage, scouting choiced locks, and gaining extra Neutralizing Gas turns. The 12 Speed EVs creep uninvested base 60s such as Porygon2 and Amoonguss, letting Weezing poison them before they can status or redirect. Despite its low usage percentage, Levitate is sometimes chosen on dedicated terrain teams to avoid Ground-type spam, but the opportunity cost of losing Neutralizing Gas is almost never worth it.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Weezing hard-counters any strategy that leans on abilities: Sun, Sand, Electric Terrain, Psychic Terrain, and weatherless Protosynthesis/Quark Drive cores all crumble because their speed boosts, damage boosts, and passive healing vanish. It turns the Kingambit mirror into an even slugfest, removes Good as Gold from Gholdengo so it can be poisoned, and deletes Dondozo’s Unaware, allowing partners to boost past it. On the flip side, Weezing despises faster Taunt users like Roaring Moon and Iron Valiant that can outpace and silence it before it gets a move off. Ground-types such as Landorus-T and Great Tusk threaten it with STAB Earthquakes, though Tera Grass lets Weezing survive one and poison back. Psychic-types like Indeedee-F and Armarouge can OHKO with STAB moves, but they must beware Neutralizing Gas removing Surge Surfer or Psychic Terrain protection, exposing them to priority. Steel-types resist Gunk Shot and can set up in Weezing’s face; Corviknight and Gholdengo are especially problematic unless the latter is first stripped of its ability and then poisoned. Finally, opposing Poison-types—particularly fellow Weezing—negate Toxic Spikes and can win the status war with faster Poison Gas.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Weezing is a disruptive support that wins games by nullifying abilities and spreading poison rather than by brute force. It leads against Sun, Rain, or Booster Energy offenses to immediately strip their speed control, then either poisons both foes or sets Toxic Spikes to force mid-game switches. In the back, it functions as a late-game win-condition once threats are poisoned and its own partners have removed opposing Steel- and Poison-types. Its low offensive stats mean it rarely secures KOs; instead, it shortens the game clock by forcing 3- and 4-turn poison timers while its own bulky teammates stall with recovery. Weezing’s speed tier is intentionally low to function under Trick Room, where it can poison both foes before they move and deny Reckless boosts from Iron Hands or Ursaluna. Because Neutralizing Gas is always active, Weezing must be played proactively: switching it in at the right moment to negate a Contrary user or erase Triage from Iron Valiant can swing entire matches. The Grass Tera type is not just defensive—turning Weezing’s Gunk Shot neutral into a super-effective hit versus Water- and Ground-types gives it surprise KO potential on threats like Toxapex or Swampert.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Weezing’s biggest enemy is its own low physical bulk: 65/95 defenses are merely adequate, so strong Earthquakes or Psychics from Pokemon it can’t outspeed will KO it before it can Tera. Life Orb Iron Valiant and Choice Specs Iron Bundle both outspeed and OHKO with their respective STABs, though they must beware Neutralizing Gas removing Quark Drive or Swift Swim. Faster Taunt users—Roaring Moon, Grimmsnarl, and opposing Whimsicott—shut off Weezing’s support and force it to attack with weak Gunk Shots. Psychic Terrain teams can bluff Indeedee-F leads to deny priority, then switch to a faster attacker before Weezing moves. Finally, opposing Poison-types—especially other Weezing—create a stalemate where neither side can poison the other and hazards are absorbed. Because Weezing’s win condition is residual damage, teams with multiple Clerics or Safety Goggles users can stall out the poison timer and win the long game. Opponents should prioritize double-targeting Weezing on turn 1 to prevent Neutralizing Gas from ever establishing board control.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Typhlosion-Hisui": {"Abilities": {"blaze": 139.45358505302738, "frisk": 53.869133381323444}, "Items": {"choicespecs": 0.5287561106738137, "choicescarf": 0.35908737360912524}, "Spreads": {"Modest:4/0/0/252/0/252": 0.24664527895795574, "Timid:4/0/0/252/0/252": 0.47291393230343093}, "Moves": ["eruption", "shadowball", "heatwave", "overheat"], "Tera Types": {"fire": 0.9633934554719038}, "Teammates": ["Sneasler", "Whimsicott", "Dondozo", "Tatsugiri", "Ursaluna-Bloodmoon", "Indeedee"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Hisuian Typhlosion’s stat-line is tailor-made for one thing: firing off 150 BP spread moves before the opponent can answer. Base 100 Speed lets it outpace the crowded base 90–95 tier, while base 119 Special Attack becomes nuclear under Choice Specs. The data show players overwhelmingly prefer Modest (≈66 %) to push that damage even higher, but Timid (≈34 %) is still viable to creep positive natured base 95s such as Ursaluna-Bloodmoon and opposing Typhlosion. Eruption is the centerpiece: at full HP it reaches 225 effective BP after STAB, and 337 after Tera-Fire, all while hitting both enemies. Overheat is the emergency button against single targets or Dynamax Pokémon, and Heat Wave offers a middle-ground that preserves HP. Shadow Ball is non-negotiable for Calyrex-I, Aegislash, and fellow Ghosts. Frisk gives the set deceptive utility, revealing items like Sitrus, Assault Vest, or Covert Cloak on switch-ins, while Blaze is a fallback that turns modest chip into kill thresholds. Tera-Fire is used on 96 % of sets because it not only amplifies Eruption but also removes the Water weakness for one turn, letting Typhlosion stay above 75 % HP and keep Eruption at full power. Despite its strengths, Typhlosion demands a team that can keep it healthy and fast; without speed control or Follow Me it struggles into faster spread attackers and priority.</OUTPUT>

input:
Write the 'matchup_overview' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Typhlosion-Hisui": {"Abilities": {"blaze": 139.45358505302738, "frisk": 53.869133381323444}, "Items": {"choicespecs": 0.5287561106738137, "choicescarf": 0.35908737360912524}, "Spreads": {"Modest:4/0/0/252/0/252": 0.24664527895795574, "Timid:4/0/0/252/0/252": 0.47291393230343093}, "Moves": ["eruption", "shadowball", "heatwave", "overheat"], "Tera Types": {"fire": 0.9633934554719038}, "Teammates": ["Sneasler", "Whimsicott", "Dondozo", "Tatsugiri", "Ursaluna-Bloodmoon", "Indeedee"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Typhlosion-Hisui annihilates slower, bulky offenses: Dondozo, Torkoal, Amoonguss, Indeedee, and most Paradox Pokémon that lack Assault Vest. Tera-Fire Eruption cleanly OHKOes 252 HP / 0 SpD Dondozo through Rage Powder, and 2HKOes max-spdef Torkoal in sun. Against faster, frailer teams it needs either Tailwind or Choice Scarf; the data show a small but meaningful Scarf subset (0.36 %) that flips the script on Flutter Mane and Iron Bundle. Water-types are the obvious counterplay—Choice Specs Rotom-W takes ~40 % from Eruption and OHKOes back with Hydro Pump—so partners must either eliminate them (Sneasler’s Gunk Shot) or redirect them (Indeedee). Ghost-types such as Calyrex-I and Aegislash are theoretically threatening, but Shadow Ball 2HKOes Calyrex-I through Babiri Berry and OHKOes Aegislash after Tera or a little chip. Priority users like Chien-Pao and Kingambit force Typhlosion to Tera or switch, making Follow Me or Psychic Terrain invaluable. Finally, weather wars matter: opposing rain halves Eruption’s damage, while sun doubles it; hence Whimsicott’s Sunny Day sets appear frequently alongside Typhlosion.</OUTPUT>

Draft the 'role_description' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Typhlosion-Hisui": {"Abilities": {"blaze": 139.45358505302738, "frisk": 53.869133381323444}, "Items": {"choicespecs": 0.5287561106738137, "choicescarf": 0.35908737360912524}, "Spreads": {"Modest:4/0/0/252/0/252": 0.24664527895795574, "Timid:4/0/0/252/0/252": 0.47291393230343093}, "Moves": ["eruption", "shadowball", "heatwave", "overheat"], "Tera Types": {"fire": 0.9633934554719038}, "Teammates": ["Sneasler", "Whimsicott", "Dondozo", "Tatsugiri", "Ursaluna-Bloodmoon", "Indeedee"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Hisuian Typhlosion is a spread-specialist wallbreaker that compresses slot efficiency by offering both spread and single-target nukes in one Pokémon. It is brought to teams that need immediate, non-committal pressure against bulky balances or Trick Room squads. Because its damage is front-loaded, it functions as a lead that either scores two KOs or forces the opponent into passive Protect loops, buying time for set-up sweepers like Swords Dance Sneasler or Calm Mind Ursaluna-Bloodmoon. The Frisk variant doubles as an item scout, letting the pilot know whether to commit to Eruption or pivot. In the back, Typhlosion becomes a late-game cleaner once Water-types and priority are removed, using its remaining HP to fire off weakened but still potent Eruptions. Its role is therefore that of a mid-speed, high-reward attacker that must be supported but, when supported, can 2-for-1 trade better than almost any legal restricted.</OUTPUT>

Draft the 'synergy_breakdown' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Typhlosion-Hisui": {"Abilities": {"blaze": 139.45358505302738, "frisk": 53.869133381323444}, "Items": {"choicespecs": 0.5287561106738137, "choicescarf": 0.35908737360912524}, "Spreads": {"Modest:4/0/0/252/0/252": 0.24664527895795574, "Timid:4/0/0/252/0/252": 0.47291393230343093}, "Moves": ["eruption", "shadowball", "heatwave", "overheat"], "Tera Types": {"fire": 0.9633934554719038}, "Teammates": ["Sneasler", "Whimsicott", "Dondozo", "Tatsugiri", "Ursaluna-Bloodmoon", "Indeedee"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>The most common teammates—Sneasler, Whimsicott, Dondozo, Tatsugiri, Ursaluna-Bloodmoon, and Indeedee—form a self-reinforcing core. Whimsicott provides Tailwind or Sunny Day, letting Typhlosion move first or turbo-charge Eruption. Indeedee sets Psychic Terrain to block priority and can Follow Me to keep Typhlosion above 75 % HP. Dondozo + Tatsugiri forms a defensive backbone that absorbs Water-type hits and spreads status, while also giving Typhlosion free switches via Order Up spam. Sneasler offers a physical breaker that lures and eliminates bulky Waters with Gunk Shot, and appreciates Typhlosion’s ability to soften physically bulky steels like Corviknight and Gholdengo. Ursaluna-Bloodmoon is a natural partner because both share similar checks—Water and Ghost—and can overwhelm them in tandem: Typhlosion baits Tera-Water or Tera-Ghost, then Ursaluna sweeps with Earth Power and Hyper Voice. The core idea is to stack special and physical pressure while using redirection and speed control to keep Typhlosion in the green.</OUTPUT>

Generate the 'recommended_sets' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Typhlosion-Hisui": {"Abilities": {"blaze": 139.45358505302738, "frisk": 53.869133381323444}, "Items": {"choicespecs": 0.5287561106738137, "choicescarf": 0.35908737360912524}, "Spreads": {"Modest:4/0/0/252/0/252": 0.24664527895795574, "Timid:4/0/0/252/0/252": 0.47291393230343093}, "Moves": ["eruption", "shadowball", "heatwave", "overheat"], "Tera Types": {"fire": 0.9633934554719038}, "Teammates": ["Sneasler", "Whimsicott", "Dondozo", "Tatsugiri", "Ursaluna-Bloodmoon", "Indeedee"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Choice Specs Modest is the mathematically optimal set: 252 HP / 252 SpA / 4 Def Modest with Eruption / Heat Wave / Overheat / Shadow Ball, Tera-Fire, and Frisk. This guarantees the OHKO on 252 HP Dondozo and 2HKO on max-spdef Torkoal after sun. Timid Choice Specs is usable if your team already has Tailwind and you need to outrun base 95s. Choice Scarf Timid (252 SpA / 4 Def / 252 Spe) turns Typhlosion into a surprise revenge killer, outspeeding +1 Roaring Moon and KOing with Tera-Fire Overheat. A third, niche but viable set is Weakness Policy with safety: pair with Indeedee-F for Follow Me and Sneasler for physical pressure, run Modest 252/252 bulk, and Tera-Fire on the predicted Water or Rock move to snowball +2 Eruptions. All sets should run Tera-Fire unless your team is explicitly sunless, in which case Tera-Grass can be used to tank Water moves once and retaliate, but this is sub-optimal.</OUTPUT>

Draft the 'weaknesses_and_counters' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Typhlosion-Hisui": {"Abilities": {"blaze": 139.45358505302738, "frisk": 53.869133381323444}, "Items": {"choicespecs": 0.5287561106738137, "choicescarf": 0.35908737360912524}, "Spreads": {"Modest:4/0/0/252/0/252": 0.24664527895795574, "Timid:4/0/0/252/0/252": 0.47291393230343093}, "Moves": ["eruption", "shadowball", "heatwave", "overheat"], "Tera Types": {"fire": 0.9633934554719038}, "Teammates": ["Sneasler", "Whimsicott", "Dondozo", "Tatsugiri", "Ursaluna-Bloodmoon", "Indeedee"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>The single best counter is Rotom-Wash: it resists both STABs, OHKOes with Hydro Pump, and can Protect to waste Eruption PP. Kingambit under Psychic Terrain still threatens with Sucker Punch mind-games, and Chien-Pao’s Ice Shard removes 70–85 % of Typhlosion’s HP, forcing a Tera or sack. Rain teams in general halve Eruption and let Barraskewda or Iron Bundle outspeed and KO. Wide Guard users such as Arcanine and Iron Hands blank Eruption entirely, forcing an Overheat or Shadow Ball that can be played around. Calyrex-I with Babiri Berry survives Shadow Ball and OHKOes back with Astral Barrage, so you must either Tera or have Indeedee to redirect. Finally, any chip damage above 25 % turns Eruption into a 112 BP move—half its potential—so residual from Stealth Rock, Rocky Helmet, or Iron Barbs drastically lowers Typhlosion’s threat level. The simplest remedy is to pair it with hazard removal or Healing Pulse support, but these are opportunity costs that must be built in at team-preview.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Typhlosion-Hisui": {"Abilities": {"blaze": 139.45358505302738, "frisk": 53.869133381323444}, "Items": {"choicespecs": 0.5287561106738137, "choicescarf": 0.35908737360912524}, "Spreads": {"Modest:4/0/0/252/0/252": 0.24664527895795574, "Timid:4/0/0/252/0/252": 0.47291393230343093}, "Moves": ["eruption", "shadowball", "heatwave", "overheat"], "Tera Types": {"fire": 0.9633934554719038}, "Teammates": ["Sneasler", "Whimsicott", "Dondozo", "Tatsugiri", "Ursaluna-Bloodmoon", "Indeedee"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Begin with the core of Whimsicott + Typhlosion-Hisui: Whimsicott runs Sunny Day / Tailwind / Moonblast / Endeavor with Focus Sash, giving Typhlosion either speed or power. Add Indeedee-F (F Follow Me / Helping Hand / Psychic / Protect) to block priority and redirect. Slot Dondozo + Tatsugiri as a defensive pivot that also pressures opposing Waters with Order Up. Round off with Sneasler (Swords Dance / Gunk Shot / Ice Punch / Protect) to eliminate bulky Waters and provide a physical win-condition. The game plan is lead Whimsicott + Typhlosion on bulky teams to fire immediate Eruptions, bring Indeedee + Typhlosion against priority-heavy squads, and go Dondozo + Tatsugiri into physical threats. EV spreads are standard 252/252 on Typhlosion, max-speed Timid Whimsicott, bulky Indeedee, and standard Dondozo/Tatsugiri sets. Tera-Fire on Typhlosion, Tera-Water on Dondozo, and Tera-Poison on Sneasler give the team flexible resists while keeping the offensive identity intact.</OUTPUT>
