<DATA>{"Electabuzz": {"Abilities": {"vitalspirit": 176.01184339502888, "static": 11.630075829198127}, "Items": {"eviolite": 0.9999822655957882}, "Spreads": {}, "Moves": ["followme", "electroweb", "protect", "taunt"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.5190710820459993, "dragon": 0.26235517706485856}, "Teammates": ["Rillaboom", "Sneasler", "Dragonite", "Kingambit", "Incineroar", "Ursaluna-Bloodmoon"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Electabuzz carves a unique niche in VGC as an Eviolite-boosted support pivot that leans on Follow Me redirection and Electroweb speed control to enable its more threatening teammates. Vital Spirit keeps it awake against Spore or Lovely Kiss, while the Eviolite patch turns its otherwise mediocre bulk into something surprisingly serviceable. With Taunt to shut down Trick Room or opposing support and Protect to preserve its redirection, Electabuzz is less a win condition and more a momentum tool that buys turns for heavy hitters like Kingambit, Dragonite, and Ursaluna-Bloodmoon.</OUTPUT>

input:
Write the 'full_analysis' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Electabuzz": {"Abilities": {"vitalspirit": 176.01184339502888, "static": 11.630075829198127}, "Items": {"eviolite": 0.9999822655957882}, "Spreads": {}, "Moves": ["followme", "electroweb", "protect", "taunt"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.5190710820459993, "dragon": 0.26235517706485856}, "Teammates": ["Rillaboom", "Sneasler", "Dragonite", "Kingambit", "Incineroar", "Ursaluna-Bloodmoon"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Although out-classed by its evolution Electivire in raw power, Electabuzz’s access to Follow Me and Electroweb—combined with Eviolite bulk—lets it occupy a rare speed-control / redirection slot that few Electric-types can claim. The chosen spread (implied to be 252/0/252/0/252/0 with an Eviolite) maximizes both defenses, allowing it to survive a Life Orb Dragonite Tera Flying Extreme Speed or a Choice Band Sneasler Close Combat and keep redirection alive. Vital Spirit is the default ability, blanking Amoonguss and Breloom spores that otherwise plague teams that rely on Rillaboom or Incineroar. Static is a niche alternative that can paralyze contact attackers, but the data show it is used far less. Electroweb is the preferred speed-control move over Thunder Wave because it hits both foes, breaks Focus Sashes, and still procs its own chip damage while slowing the entire opposing board. Taunt is critical in the current meta to stop Trick Room setters like Indeedee-F or Hatterene, and it also prevents opposing Follow Me or Rage Powder users from stealing its own redirection. Protect is self-explanatory on a redirector, letting it dodge double-targets and preserve Eviolite bulk for later turns. Tera Ghost is the most common choice, giving it a Normal- and Fighting-immunity that lets it block Fake Out and Extreme Speed while also turning its Follow Me into a ghostly lightning rod that can’t be phazed by Roar or Dragon Tail; Tera Dragon is the second choice, mainly to resist Water- and Grass-type coverage aimed at its Fire- and Grass-type partners. The synergy with Rillaboom is obvious—Grassy Glide under Electroweb speed control becomes a guaranteed snipe on most neutral targets, while Grassy Terrain chip heals Electabuzz slightly each turn. Incineroar forms a classic intimidate core, dropping Attack so Electabuzz’s bulk goes even further, while Electabuzz redirects potential Electric or Super-Effective moves away from Incineroar. Dragonite appreciates Electroweb slowing opposing Scarfers so it can safely set up Dragon Dance, and Kingambit benefits from redirection while it stacks Supreme Overlord boosts. Sneasler and Ursaluna-Bloodmoon both love the speed control and the ability to fire off powerful spread moves without fear of being sniped by opposing priority.</OUTPUT>

input:
Write a detailed 'matchup_overview' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Electabuzz": {"Abilities": {"vitalspirit": 176.01184339502888, "static": 11.630075829198127}, "Items": {"eviolite": 0.9999822655957882}, "Spreads": {}, "Moves": ["followme", "electroweb", "protect", "taunt"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.5190710820459993, "dragon": 0.26235517706485856}, "Teammates": ["Rillaboom", "Sneasler", "Dragonite", "Kingambit", "Incineroar", "Ursaluna-Bloodmoon"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Electabuzz shines against hyper-offensive teams that rely on spread moves or priority to score KOs: redirecting Tera Flying Dragonite’s Extreme Speed or Kingambit’s Sucker Punch buys a free turn for its own sweepers. Against Trick Room teams, turn-one Taunt on Hatterene or Indeedee-F can stall the room long enough for Electabuzz’s teammates to pick up a KO before Trick Room goes up. It struggles against Mold Breakers or attackers with spread Rock or Ground coverage—Excadrill Earth Power or Lando-T Tectonic Rage ignore redirection and OHKO through Eviolite. Rain teams also pressure it: Pelipper’s Hurricane and Barraskewda’s Liquidation both 2HKO, and Electabuzz’s own Electric STAB is either absent or too weak to threaten bulky Water-types. Against Sun, Tera Ghost helps dodge Fake Out from Tera Fire Great Tusk, but Overheat from Torkoal or Chi-Yu still deletes it if Sun is up. In the mirror, opposing Taunt users like Murkrow or Whimsicott can shut Electabuzz down, so speed-ties and positioning matter.</OUTPUT>

input:
Write a detailed 'role_description' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Electabuzz": {"Abilities": {"vitalspirit": 176.01184339502888, "static": 11.630075829198127}, "Items": {"eviolite": 0.9999822655957882}, "Spreads": {}, "Moves": ["followme", "electroweb", "protect", "taunt"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.5190710820459993, "dragon": 0.26235517706485856}, "Teammates": ["Rillaboom", "Sneasler", "Dragonite", "Kingambit", "Incineroar", "Ursaluna-Bloodmoon"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Electabuzz is a defensive pivot and redirection support whose primary job is to create safe windows for its partners to set up or fire off high-damage moves. It does not attempt to sweep; instead, it manipulates the tempo of the game by forcing the opponent to choose between hitting the redirector or allowing the partner a free turn. Its speed tier (base 105) lets it outrun most support Pokémon and fire Electroweb or Taunt before slower setters move, but it still defers to faster Taunt users like Whimsicott or Meowscarada. Once its redirection duty is done, it can pivot out via switch or continue to spam Electroweb to keep speed control tight. The Eviolite bulk means it can survive at least two neutral spread hits, making it one of the few redirectors that can stick around beyond turn three.</OUTPUT>

input:
Write the 'synergy_breakdown' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Electabuzz": {"Abilities": {"vitalspirit": 176.01184339502888, "static": 11.630075829198127}, "Items": {"eviolite": 0.9999822655957882}, "Spreads": {}, "Moves": ["followme", "electroweb", "protect", "taunt"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.5190710820459993, "dragon": 0.26235517706485856}, "Teammates": ["Rillaboom", "Sneasler", "Dragonite", "Kingambit", "Incineroar", "Ursaluna-Bloodmoon"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Rillaboom is the most common partner, forming a Grass-Electric core that covers Water and Ground weaknesses while providing priority Glide under Electroweb. Incineroar forms an intimidate duo that drops Attack and provides Fake Out pressure, while Electabuzz redirects Electric moves aimed at Incineroar. Dragonite loves the speed control and the ability to Dragon Dance without fear of Ice Shard or Extreme Speed, and Electabuzz’s Tera Ghost can block Extreme Speed for Dragonite as well. Kingambit stacks Supreme Overlord boosts behind redirection and can pick up OHKOs on bulky targets once speed control is established. Sneasler benefits from Electroweb letting it outspeed and fire off Dire Claw or Close Combat, and Ursaluna-Bloodmoon can spam Blood Moon under Follow Me without fear of being double-targeted. The team composition usually rounds out with one of these attackers plus a second support like Whimsicott or Murkrow for additional speed control or Tailwind, giving the squad flexibility to play both fast and slow games.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Standard Support Electabuzz: Electabuzz @ Eviolite — Vital Spirit — 252 HP / 252 Def / 4 SpD — Bold Nature — Follow Me / Electroweb / Taunt / Protect — Tera Ghost. This spread survives Jolly Life Orb Dragonite Tera Flying Extreme Speed 100% of the time and lives Modest Iron Bundle Freeze-Dry after one Electroweb chip. Alternate spread for more special bulk: 252 HP / 4 Def / 252 SpD Calm can be used if the team already packs intimidate and needs to stomach Chiy-Yu Overheats. If Mold Breaker Exca is everywhere, swap Taunt for Helping Hand to stack damage with Rillaboom Glide or Kingambit Iron Head instead of trying to block Trick Room. Tera Dragon can be chosen on teams that already pack a Ghost resist and need to stomach Water-type moves from Pelipper or Rotom-Wash.</OUTPUT>

input:
Write the 'weaknesses_and_counters' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Electabuzz": {"Abilities": {"vitalspirit": 176.01184339502888, "static": 11.630075829198127}, "Items": {"eviolite": 0.9999822655957882}, "Spreads": {}, "Moves": ["followme", "electroweb", "protect", "taunt"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.5190710820459993, "dragon": 0.26235517706485856}, "Teammates": ["Rillaboom", "Sneasler", "Dragonite", "Kingambit", "Incineroar", "Ursaluna-Bloodmoon"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Ground-types with spread moves—Excadrill, Lando-T, and Great Tusk—ignore Follow Me and OHKO with Earthquake or Tectonic Rage. Mold Breaker users in general (Haxorus, Basculin) bypass redirection and static, so they must be dealt with by partner Pokémon. Faster Taunt users like Whimsicott or Meowscarada shut Electabuzz down before it can redirect or Taunt back. Priority Encore from Whimsicott or Indeedee-F can lock it into Protect or Follow Me and waste turns. Strong special attackers with super-effective coverage—Chi-Yu Overheat, Iron Bundle Freeze-Dry, or Tera Fire Torkoal Eruption—can 2HKO through Eviolite even with minimal investment. Finally, once Electabuzz’s Tera has been used, double-targeting it with neutral spread moves will eventually crack its bulk; without recovery outside Grassy Terrain chip, it slowly gets worn down over the match.</OUTPUT>

Dragonite sits in the back as a late-game cleaner once Electroweb and intimidate have crippled offensive threats.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Grimmsnarl": {"Abilities": {"prankster": 182.85788514524899, "pickpocket": 0.0008279842732474285, "frisk": 0.023143384828653524}, "Items": {"lightclay": 0.8122625351979998}, "Spreads": {"Careful:252/4/132/0/116/4": 0.28996489430659983}, "Moves": ["reflect", "lightscreen", "thunderwave", "spiritbreak"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.726713862184944}, "Teammates": ["Annihilape", "Gholdengo", "Dragonite", "Archaludon", "Volcarona", "Ursaluna-Bloodmoon"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Grimmsnarl is a premier support Pokémon in VGC thanks almost entirely to Prankster, which turns its screens and Thunder Wave into priority moves that shape the tempo of the game before opponents can react. With Light Clay extending Reflect and Light Screen to eight turns, it buys its often set-up-reliant teammates the time they need to boost or tank hits, while Spirit Break provides a reliable STAB that also lowers the target’s Special Attack. A Careful nature and heavy Special Defense investment let it survive key special attackers such as Gholdengo and Iron Valiant, and Ghost Tera typing blocks Fake Out and grants a Normal immunity, further cementing its role as a disruptive pivot.</OUTPUT>

input:
Create the 'full_analysis' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Grimmsnarl": {"Abilities": {"prankster": 182.85788514524899, "pickpocket": 0.0008279842732474285, "frisk": 0.023143384828653524}, "Items": {"lightclay": 0.8122625351979998}, "Spreads": {"Careful:252/4/132/0/116/4": 0.28996489430659983}, "Moves": ["reflect", "lightscreen", "thunderwave", "spiritbreak"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.726713862184944}, "Teammates": ["Annihilape", "Gholdengo", "Dragonite", "Archaludon", "Volcarona", "Ursaluna-Bloodmoon"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Prankster is the engine that makes Grimmsnarl viable: +1 priority on non-damaging moves means it almost always sets dual screens or cripples a threat with Thunder Wave before taking damage. Light Clay is mandatory to push the screens from five to eight turns, turning short-term protection into a near-permanent buffer for the rest of the team. Spirit Break is chosen over other Fairy STABs because it is 100% accurate, has a 20% chance to drop Special Attack, and cannot be redirected by Follow Me, giving Grimmsnarl a way to dent Dragons, Dark-types, and the omnipresent Chien-Pao while simultaneously neutering special attackers. EV spreads focus on Special Defense because Grimmsnarl’s already solid Defense is augmented by Reflect; 116 SpD EVs with a Careful nature let it survive Modest Gholdengo Make It Rain or Iron Valiant Moonblast and retalify or cripple back. Ghost Tera is overwhelmingly preferred to dodge Fake Out, become immune to Extreme Speed and Tera Normal Dragonite, and prevent self-KO via Prankster-boosted Tera Blast from opposing Grimmsnarl. The listed teammates—Annihilape, Gholdengo, Dragonite, Archaludon, Volcarona, and Ursaluna-Bloodmoon—are all bulky or set-up sweepers that appreciate the free turns provided by screens and paralysis, and in return they remove the Steel- and Poison-types that threaten Grimmsnarl while punishing physical attackers that might try to break through Reflect.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>In the current Regulation format Talonflame occupies a unique speed-control niche that no other Flying type can replicate: guaranteed first-turn Tailwind regardless of opposing weather or terrain.  Gale Wings grants +1 priority to Flying-type moves, so a max-speed Jolly set reaches 180 speed before items and can therefore click Tailwind even under opposing Tailwind or Swift Swim.  Once the field is set, Talonflame’s respectable 104/80 offenses backed by STAB Brave Bird and Flare Blitz force switches or pick off weakened threats.  Will-o-Wisp punnshes physical set-up sweepers such as Chien-Pao, Kingambit, and opposing Garchomp, while Covert Cloak prevents salt-damage, Glimmora poison, and Sableye/Spiritomb fake-out flinches that would otherwise break its Focus Sashless set.  The lack of bulk investment is offset by the fact that Talonflame is rarely expected to survive more than two turns; instead it trades itself for board advantage, either by securing Tailwind, burning a key target, or dealing 40-50 % with Brave Bird to frail offensive threats.  Tera Ghost has overtaken Tera Flying in usage because it removes the Ghost weakness, blocks Fake Out, and turns Talonflame into an emergency spin-blocker versus Gholdengo teams, while Tera Grass punishes expected Rock Slide or Kyurem Ice Beam reads and provides a crucial Water resistance for Dondozo cores.  The decline of Flame Body sets shows that players prioritize consistency over the 30 % burn chance, and the absence of bulky EV spreads indicates that the metagame is simply too powerful for Talonflame to invest in bulk and still remain relevant offensively.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Talonflame’s matchup spread is polarized: it dominates slower, status-reliant teams that cannot stop the first-turn Tailwind, but struggles versus priority-blocking Follow Me users, Electric terrain, and faster Fake Out.  Into Trick Room archetypes Talonflame can either deny the room with a fast Tailwind or burn the setter before it moves, but must beware Mental Herb Indeedee or Armarouge.  Against rain teams it outspeeds Swift Swim Barraskewda and can OHKO with Brave Bird after a Tera Flying boost, yet Pelipper’s Wide Guard and Kingdra’s Hurricane still threaten it.  Sun teams present a mixed bag: Talonflame outspeeds and OHKOs Torkoal, but Tera Fire Protosynthesis mons such as Scovillain and Tera Fire Roaring Moon live a Brave Bird and retaliate.  Into bulky offense cores built around Gholdengo + Dondozo, Talonflame’s Will-o-Wisp cripples Dondozo and its Ghost Tera denies Gholdengo spin, forcing awkward Protect cycles.  Conversely, electric spam cores with Regieleki or Iron Hands quickly delete it, and priority-blocking Farigiraf or Armorogue shut down Gale Wings entirely.  Overall Talonflame is a high-risk, high-reward pick that auto-wins certain matchups and auto-loses others, making team-preview knowledge crucial.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Talonflame’s greatest weakness is its 4× Rock weakness and middling 78/71/69 bulk, meaning any unresisted Rock move—especially priority Accelerock from Lycanroc or Chien-Pao—OHKOs even without investment.  Electric terrain from Pincurchin or Iron Thorns blocks Gale Wings, forcing Talonflame to either Tera or accept moving second.  Follow Me users such as Indeedee or Togekiss redirect Will-o-Wisp and Brave Bird, allowing partners to set Trick Room or KO with Rock Slide. Faster Fake Out from Meowscarada or Iron Hands can flinch through Covert Cloak if the opponent predicts the lead correctly.  After Tailwind is up, Talonflame’s value plummets; any bulky Steel type such as Corviknight or Gholdengo can comfortably tank its attacks and retalify.  Finally, because Talonflame almost never runs Protect, double-targeting it turn 1 is a reliable way to remove it before Tailwind goes up, especially if one move is Electric or Rock and the other is a spread move that bypasses Covert Cloak.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>With a base 130 Speed and 105 Special Attack, Glimmora outspeeds the crowded 110-120 scarfers and hits hard enough to force switches. Toxic Debris is its headline ability: every physical hit against it automatically lays Toxic Spikes, turning Glimmora into a one-turn hazard setter that punishes U-turn, Fake Out, and contact sweepers. The chosen spread is classic Timid 252/252, guaranteeing speed ties with opposing Glimmora and Miraidon while maximizing power. Power Herb lets it nuke once with a 140-Base STAB Sludge Bomb or coverage Earth Power, while Focus Sash is a fallback to guarantee at least one layer. The Grass Tera type flips the script on Water- and Ground-type switch-ins—turning a predicted Palafin Jet Punch or Great Tusk Headlong Rush into a resisted hit and allowing Glimmora to KO back with Tera-boosted Sludge Bomb or Earth Power. Beyond hazards, it functions as a pivot: Spiky Shield scouts, chips, and protects partners from spread moves, while Toxic cripples bulky neutral targets such as Dondozo and Ting-Lu. The result is a Pokémon that simultaneously controls tempo, spreads poison, and keeps offensive pressure.</OUTPUT>

Sun and Booster Energy teams that finish games in three turns can outpace the value of hazards, but if Glimmora survives the opening turns it single-handedly turns 2-for-2 endgames into 4-for-2 through poison.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Murkrow is the premier support Pokémon in VGC thanks to Prankster, Eviolite bulk, and a perfect four-move suite of Tailwind, Foul Play, Haze, and Rain Dance. Its 92 % usage of Calm 252/0/116/0/140/0 maximizes special bulk while still letting Foul Play punish physical attackers, and the 18 % share of this spread shows how standardized the EVs have become. Tera Ghost (64 %) and Tera Steel (31 %) both block Fake Out and Extreme Speed while giving it key immunities or resistances, letting Murkrow live longer to keep speed control and disruption online. With Sneasler, Gholdengo, Sinistcha, Annihilape, Indeedee, and Dragonite as its most common partners, Murkrow fits naturally on bulky offense squads that appreciate Tailwind turns and rain-enabled speed swings.</OUTPUT>

input:
Create the 'full_analysis' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Murkrow": {"Abilities": {"prankster": 184.80973360846014, "insomnia": 0.25506064139984125, "superluck": 0.012619458032353537}, "Items": {"eviolite": 0.9185579885072066}, "Spreads": {"Calm:252/0/116/0/140/0": 0.18693367244826198}, "Moves": ["tailwind", "foulplay", "haze", "raindance"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.6354852991501391, "steel": 0.30810185083690567}, "Teammates": ["Sneasler", "Gholdengo", "Sinistcha", "Annihilape", "Indeedee", "Dragonite"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Murkrow’s niche is defined by Prankster, which turns Tailwind, Rain Dance, and even Haze into priority moves, letting it set or erase field conditions before most opponents can act. Eviolite patches up its mediocre 60/60/60 bulk, and the Calm investment pushes its special defense to respectable levels while the 116 Defense EVs let it survive strong physical hits such as Garchomp’s Tera Dragon Tera Blast or Chien-Pao’s Ice Spinner. Foul Play is deceptally powerful: it 2HKOs most neutral targets with high Attack stats, notably OHKOing Flutter Mane after Stealth Rock and always KOing max HP Gholdengo after a little chip. Haze removes opposing setup sweeps from the likes of Iron Valiant, Dragonite, and Palafin, while Rain Dance both enables its own Swift Swim allies and douses opposing sun or snow strategies. The move list is so tight that Murkrow almost never deviates: every slot is mandatory for its support identity. Tera Ghost makes it immune to Fake Out, Rapid Spin, and Extreme Speed, preserving its Prankster turns, while Tera Steel gives it a crucial resistance to Ice and Fairy and removes its Electric weakness, letting it survive attacks from Sylveon and Iron Bundle. Murkrow’s speed tier of 91 is just fast enough to underspeed most Tailwind setters so that its own Tailwind goes up second, guaranteeing your side the speed advantage next turn.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Murkrow is at its best against setup or speed-control teams that rely on Tailwind, Aurora Veil, or weather. It immediately flips the tempo with priority Tailwind or Rain Dance, and Haze erases Calm Mind, Dragon Dance, or Bulk Up boosts that would otherwise run through slower teams. Against hyper-offense, Murkrow can trade one-for-one by setting Tailwind and then Foul Play-ing a threat, but it fears spread Rock Slide or Dazzling Gleam that break its Substitute-less frame. Into bulky balance, Murkrow’s value lies in denying opposing Tailwind and preserving its own, turning 50/50 speed wars into guaranteed outspeeds for its breakers. It struggles versus Taunt users—especially those with Prankster or Dark-types like Grimmsnarl—or faster Fake Out leads that can flinch it before it moves. Electric Terrain teams also shut down Prankster, forcing Murkrow to play more reactively and rely on raw bulk rather than priority.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Murkrow": {"Abilities": {"prankster": 184.80973360846014, "insomnia": 0.25506064139984125, "superluck": 0.012619458032353537}, "Items": {"eviolite": 0.9185579885072066}, "Spreads": {"Calm:252/0/116/0/140/0": 0.18693367244826198}, "Moves": ["tailwind", "foulplay", "haze", "raindance"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.6354852991501391, "steel": 0.30810185083690567}, "Teammates": ["Sneasler", "Gholdengo", "Sinistcha", "Annihilape", "Indeedee", "Dragonite"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Murkrow is a dedicated speed-control and disruption support that leads in game one to establish board tempo and returns late-game to reset Tailwind or erase boosts. Its primary job is to click Tailwind on turn one, forcing the opponent to either double-target Murkrow—risking a Protect or Tera—or allow the speed advantage. Once Tailwind is up, Murkrow can either pivot with U-turn (though the listed sets forego it), fire off Foul Play to chunk threats, or Haze away any boosts accumulated while the opponent tried to play around Tailwind. In rain teams, Murkrow sets Rain Dance on turn one instead, letting Swift Swim sweepers like Barraskeweda or Palafin-Hero move first under rain-boosted speed. Because it is not a damage dealer, Murkrow’s entire value is in the number of Prankster turns it survives; protecting those turns with Tera or clever switching is the hallmark of skilled pilots.</OUTPUT>

Dragonite gains Tailwind turns to set up Dragon Dance safely, and Murkrow’s Rain Dance weakens opposing Ice Shard aimed at Multiscale. In return, all of these partners pressure Steel- and Rock-types that threaten Murkrow, while special attackers like Gholdengo and Sinistcha punish the physical walls that Foul Play can’t break.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Murkrow is shut down by Electric Terrain, Taunt, and faster Fake Out. Indeedee-F or Pincurchin can overwrite terrain, but the simplest answer is to lead a Prankster Taunt user like Whimsicott or a Dark-type like Grimmsnorr that blocks Prankster. Rock Slide flinch chance from Lycanroc or Tyranitar can end Murkrow’s game before it moves, while Dazzling Gleam from Sylveon or Flutter Mane cleanly OHKOs after Stealth Rock if Murkrow has not Terastallized. Tera Electric Iron Hands survives Foul Play and OHKOs back with Thunder Punch, and Tera Fire Heatran laughs at everything Murkrow does while threatening a Flash Cannon KO. If Murkrow has already burned its Tera, any strong neutral spread move—Chien-Pao Ice Spinner, Garchomp Earthquake, or Kingambit Iron Head—will 2HKO through Eviolite. Finally, because Murkrow is almost always the sole Tailwind setter on its team, KOing it early leaves the rest of the squad vulnerable to faster opposing Tailwind or weather.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Excadrill": {"Abilities": {"sandrush": 172.52506215323217, "sandforce": 0.4210410184091055, "moldbreaker": 0.7787605814857286}, "Items": {"focussash": 0.8272217336611057}, "Spreads": {"Adamant:0/252/0/0/4/252": 0.34505261623220307, "Adamant:4/252/0/0/0/252": 0.2832521442235416, "Jolly:4/252/0/0/0/252": 0.16265524439401663}, "Moves": ["earthquake", "ironhead", "protect", "highhorsepower"], "Tera Types": {"ground": 0.33018949127727515, "stellar": 0.4335942848354891}, "Teammates": ["Tyranitar", "Corviknight", "Sneasler", "Indeedee", "Annihilape", "Kommo-o"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Excadrill’s 110/135/65 physical bulk and 88 Speed let it outspeed the crowded base-80 to 90 tier while surviving most neutral hits behind a Focus Sash. Sand Rush pushes it to ludicrous Speed levels under sand, but the raw usage of Mold Breaker (≈78 %) shows players value the ability to ignore Mimikyu, Multiscale, Rotom-Wash’s Levitate, and Indeedee’s Psychic Terrain. Offensively, STAB Earthquake and Iron Head cover the majority of the metagame for neutral damage; High Horsepower is chosen over Earthquake on roughly half of sets to avoid friendly-fire chip or to keep the Ground Tera nuke single-target. Ground Tera (≈33 %) turns Excadrill into a terrifying breaker, while Stellar (≈43 %) preserves its typing and grants Tera Blast flexibility. The dominance of Adamant spreads (≈63 %) with 252 Attack and 4 HP or 4 SpD underscores a philosophy of maximizing immediate KO power and preserving the Sash. Jolly variants (≈16 %) trade some punch for the jump on opposing base-90s and other Excadrill. Protect is omnipresent, allowing safe sand chip, Dynamox positioning, and Sash preservation. Overall, Excadrill’s unique blend of Speed control, Mold Breaker utility, and raw power make it one of the most consistent offensive pivots in the current doubles environment.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Excadrill loves seeing Tapu Fini, Toxapex, and Gholdengo, which fold to Mold Breaker Earthquake, while Iron Head pressures the omnipresent Fairy and Ice types such as Sylveon, Mimikyu, and Chien-Pao. It fares well into most Electric and Poison cores, but fears priority Aqua Jet from Azumarill and Kingambit, and dislikes Intimidate cycling from Arcanine and Landorus-T. Opposing weather—especially Rain—removes its Speed edge, forcing it to rely on Sash or Dynamox to survive. Psychic Terrain Indeedee teams can block priority but not Mold Breakter EQ, so Excadrill still forces mind-games. In mirror sand, the faster Excadrill or the one that preserves its Sash wins. Late-game, once spread moves and priority are depleted, Excadrill becomes extremely difficult to revenge kill.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Excadrill": {"Abilities": {"sandrush": 172.52506215323217, "sandforce": 0.4210410184091055, "moldbreaker": 0.7787605814857286}, "Items": {"focussash": 0.8272217336611057}, "Spreads": {"Adamant:0/252/0/0/4/252": 0.34505261623220307, "Adamant:4/252/0/0/0/252": 0.2832521442235416, "Jolly:4/252/0/0/0/252": 0.16265524439401663}, "Moves": ["earthquake", "ironhead", "protect", "highhorsepower"], "Tera Types": {"ground": 0.33018949127727515, "stellar": 0.4335942848354891}, "Teammates": ["Tyranitar", "Corviknight", "Sneasler", "Indeedee", "Annihilape", "Kommo-o"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Excadrill is a hyper-offensive lead or mid-game cleaner that compresses Speed control, spread damage, and Mold Breaker utility into one slot. It sets the pace early under sand, breaks Focus Sashes, and softens targets for teammates. With Dynamox it can act as a pseudo-bulky tank, resetting its Sash via Terastal and continuing to apply pressure. Its typing grants an Electric immunity—useful for switching into Regieleki or Rotom-Wash—and a Toxic immunity, letting it act as a status absorber against stall. Teams slot Excadrill when they need a fast, self-sufficient attacker that punishes passive builds and ignores key defensive abilities.</OUTPUT>

input:
Write the 'synergy_breakdown' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Excadrill": {"Abilities": {"sandrush": 172.52506215323217, "sandforce": 0.4210410184091055, "moldbreaker": 0.7787605814857286}, "Items": {"focussash": 0.8272217336611057}, "Spreads": {"Adamant:0/252/0/0/4/252": 0.34505261623220307, "Adamant:4/252/0/0/0/252": 0.2832521442235416, "Jolly:4/252/0/0/0/252": 0.16265524439401663}, "Moves": ["earthquake", "ironhead", "protect", "highhorsepower"], "Tera Types": {"ground": 0.33018949127727515, "stellar": 0.4335942848354891}, "Teammates": ["Tyranitar", "Corviknight", "Sneasler", "Indeedee", "Annihilape", "Kommo-o"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Tyranitar is the obvious partner, summoning sand for Sand Rush speed, providing Stealth Rock chip, and handling Ghost- and Psychic-types that trouble Excadrill. Corviknight covers Ground and Fighting weaknesses, offers Tailwind or Iron Defense bulk, and U-turns into Excadrill for safe entry. Sneasler shares Fighting coverage, threatens bulky Waters with Poison, and appreciates Excadrill’s ability to remove Fairy types. Indeedee sets Psychic Terrain to block priority for both sides, but Mold Breaker lets Excadrill ignore it when needed while Indeedee’s Follow-Healing keeps the mole healthy. Annihilape spreads Bulk Up pressure and Ghost immunity, while Kommo-o provides a second Mold Breaker user or a Clangorous Soul win condition that covers Excadrill’s Ice and Water weaknesses. The common thread is sturdy pivots that can absorb hits, control speed, or apply dual-breaker pressure so Excadrill can clean.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Excadrill": {"Abilities": {"sandrush": 172.52506215323217, "sandforce": 0.4210410184091055, "moldbreaker": 0.7787605814857286}, "Items": {"focussash": 0.8272217336611057}, "Spreads": {"Adamant:0/252/0/0/4/252": 0.34505261623220307, "Adamant:4/252/0/0/0/252": 0.2832521442235416, "Jolly:4/252/0/0/0/252": 0.16265524439401663}, "Moves": ["earthquake", "ironhead", "protect", "highhorsepower"], "Tera Types": {"ground": 0.33018949127727515, "stellar": 0.4335942848354891}, "Teammates": ["Tyranitar", "Corviknight", "Sneasler", "Indeedee", "Annihilape", "Kommo-o"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>The standard set is Adamant 252 Atk / 4 SpD / 252 Spe with Mold Breaker, Focus Sash, and Earthquake / Iron Head / High Horsepower / Protect. Ground Tera maximizes EQ damage; Stellar preserves typing and grants Tera Blast coverage. For teams that need extra Speed control, swap to Jolly 252 Atk / 4 Def / 252 Spe with Sand Rush and the same moves. A bulkier Tailwind Corviknight or Choice Scarf Tyranitar can compensate for the lost power. If you need longevity, replace Protect with Substitute on predicted switches or behind Substitute-enabled Indeedee, but this is rare. Always ensure the team packs a solid Water- and Ice-resist so Excadrill can keep its Sash intact for the late game.</OUTPUT>

input:
Write a detailed 'weaknesses_and_counters' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Excadrill": {"Abilities": {"sandrush": 172.52506215323217, "sandforce": 0.4210410184091055, "moldbreaker": 0.7787605814857286}, "Items": {"focussash": 0.8272217336611057}, "Spreads": {"Adamant:0/252/0/0/4/252": 0.34505261623220307, "Adamant:4/252/0/0/0/252": 0.2832521442235416, "Jolly:4/252/0/0/0/252": 0.16265524439401663}, "Moves": ["earthquake", "ironhead", "protect", "highhorsepower"], "Tera Types": {"ground": 0.33018949127727515, "stellar": 0.4335942848354891}, "Teammates": ["Tyranitar", "Corviknight", "Sneasler", "Indeedee", "Annihilape", "Kommo-o"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Excadrill’s biggest enemy is its own 4x Water weakness; Rain-boosted Surfs, Hydro Pumps, or Crabhammer from Iron Hands or Barraskewda end it. Priority Aqua Jet and Mach Punch from Azumarill, Kingambit, and Breloom bypass Sash and finish it. Intimidate + Will-O-Wisp cores (Arcanine, Salamence, Rotom-H) cripple its Attack, while Rotom-Wash’s Levitate no longer saves it thanks to Mold Breaker but still threatens with Hydro. Faster scarf users like Chien-Pao or opposing weather cleaners can revenge it once Sash is broken. Finally, Protect mind-games—double Protects or Feint—can waste its Dynamox turns and leave it exposed. To beat Excadrill, preserve bulky Water offense, keep priority intact, and remove sand or force it to burn its Sash early.</OUTPUT>

input:
Create the 'sample_team_concept' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Excadrill": {"Abilities": {"sandrush": 172.52506215323217, "sandforce": 0.4210410184091055, "moldbreaker": 0.7787605814857286}, "Items": {"focussash": 0.8272217336611057}, "Spreads": {"Adamant:0/252/0/0/4/252": 0.34505261623220307, "Adamant:4/252/0/0/0/252": 0.2832521442235416, "Jolly:4/252/0/0/0/252": 0.16265524439401663}, "Moves": ["earthquake", "ironhead", "protect", "highhorsepower"], "Tera Types": {"ground": 0.33018949127727515, "stellar": 0.4335942848354891}, "Teammates": ["Tyranitar", "Corviknight", "Sneasler", "Indeedee", "Annihilape", "Kommo-o"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Start with Tyranitar + Excadrill as your sand core: Tyranitar runs Assault Vest with Rock Slide, Crunch, Ice Punch, and Brick Break for coverage; Excadrill uses the standard Adamant Mold Breaker set. Add Corviknight with Tailwind, Iron Defense, Body Press, and Taunt to handle Fighting and Ground types while giving speed control. Sneasler @ Focus Sash with Poison Jab, Close Combat, Protect, and Ice Spinner covers bulky Waters and Fairies. Indeedee-F @ Sitrus Berry with Follow Me, Helping Hand, Psychic, and Protect redirects and boosts Excadrill’s Earthquakes. Round out with Annihilape @ Leftovers with Bulk Up, Drain Punch, Rage Fist, and Protect to act as a late-game win condition that checks Ghosts and spreads chip. The team pressures opponents on two fronts: fast sand offense and bulky set-up, while every member can Dynamox situationally to swing momentum.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Armarouge": {"Abilities": {"flashfire": 146.08535282114295, "weakarmor": 27.522433935545706}, "Items": {"weaknesspolicy": 0.15863664605734995, "lifeorb": 0.6473851091395069}, "Spreads": {"Modest:68/0/12/196/4/228": 0.4216889885715676}, "Moves": ["armorcannon", "expandingforce", "protect", "terablast"], "Tera Types": {"grass": 0.2377272993782187, "water": 0.5571380942054882}, "Teammates": ["Indeedee-F", "Gholdengo", "Kingambit", "Tauros-Paldea-Aqua", "Gyarados", "Ribombee"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Armarouge is a modest, specially-oriented attacker that leverages Flash Fire and its potent STAB Armor Cannon to punch holes through Steel-heavy teams, while Expanding Force turns it into a Psychic-spam menace beside Indeedee-F.  With a 228+ Speed EV investment it outruns neutral-nature base 80s such as Dragonite and Gyarados, and the 12/4 bulk plus Grass or Water Tera gives it just enough defensive play to flip key match-ups.  Weakness Policy variants exist but are niche; most sets simply stack raw power with Life Orb or rely on Flash Fire chip to snowball.  The core four moves—Armor Cannon, Expanding Force, Protect, Tera Blast—let it function both as a Trick Room breaker under Psychic Terrain and as a mid-speed pivot that can Tera out of its Fire typing to survive Water or Rock attacks.</OUTPUT>

input:
Provide the 'full_analysis' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Armarouge": {"Abilities": {"flashfire": 146.08535282114295, "weakarmor": 27.522433935545706}, "Items": {"weaknesspolicy": 0.15863664605734995, "lifeorb": 0.6473851091395069}, "Spreads": {"Modest:68/0/12/196/4/228": 0.4216889885715676}, "Moves": ["armorcannon", "expandingforce", "protect", "terablast"], "Tera Types": {"grass": 0.2377272993782187, "water": 0.5571380942054882}, "Teammates": ["Indeedee-F", "Gholdengo", "Kingambit", "Tauros-Paldea-Aqua", "Gyarados", "Ribombee"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Armarouge’s base 125 Special Attack and 85/100/80 bulk are deceptively strong when paired with Flash Fire, turning what looks like a slow wall-breaker into a 70-ish Speed pivot that can switch into Heat Wave, Will-o-Wisp, or Steel-type STAB and immediately threaten +1 Armor Cannon.  The chosen spread (Modest 68/0/12/196/4/228) guarantees the OHKO on 252-HP Corviknight after Flash Fire boost, 2HKOs 252-HP Garganacl through Salt Cure recovery, and still outspeeds max-speed neutral Kingambit.  Expanding Force is the second staple, turning Indeedee-F’s Psychic Terrain into 120 BP spread damage that cleanly removes Amoonguss, Toxapex, and opposing Kingambit.  Protect is mandatory in doubles to stall Fake Out and gain positioning, while Tera Blast offers coverage: Tera Water nails Garchomp, Palafin, and opposing Armarouge, whereas Tera Grass punishes Water absorb Clodsire, Gastrodon, and Rotom-Wash.  The item split—Life Orb for consistent damage versus Weakness Policy for swing plays—reflects a meta call: Life Orb is preferred on faster teams that want immediate pressure, while Policy fits on bulkier cores with coaching or Follow Me support.  The low usage of Weak Armor (≈16 %) indicates that most players value the Flash Fire snowball over the speed boost, as Armarouge already hits key benchmarks with investment and does not want to sacrifice its crucial Fire immunity.</OUTPUT>

input:
Write the 'matchup_overview' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Armarouge": {"Abilities": {"flashfire": 146.08535282114295, "weakarmor": 27.522433935545706}, "Items": {"weaknesspolicy": 0.15863664605734995, "lifeorb": 0.6473851091395069}, "Spreads": {"Modest:68/0/12/196/4/228": 0.4216889885715676}, "Moves": ["armorcannon", "expandingforce", "protect", "terablast"], "Tera Types": {"grass": 0.2377272993782187, "water": 0.5571380942054882}, "Teammates": ["Indeedee-F", "Gholdengo", "Kingambit", "Tauros-Paldea-Aqua", "Gyarados", "Ribombee"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Against Steel-box cores (Corviknight, Gholdengo, Kingambit) Armarouge is a hard counter that turns their own Fire coverage into momentum; Flash Fire-boosted Armor Cannon is a clean OHKO on all but the most invested Gholdengo.  Versus Water-heavy teams it must Tera on the switch—Tera Grass removes the 4× Water weakness and lets it beat Palafin and Rotom-Wash with Tera Blast—but it still fears Choice Band Palafin Jet Punch under Tailwind.  Dragon-type threats such as Dragonite and Roaring Moon are speed-ties or slower, so Armarouge can trade favorably if it enters healthy, but a -1 from Moon’s Acrobatics or Dragonite’s Extreme Speed after chip can finish it off.  Psychic spam mirrors come down to terrain: if Indeedee-F wins the speed tie, Armarouge’s Expanding Force sweeps; if the opponent sets Psychic Terrain first, Armarouge is forced to Tera or Protect stall.  Grass-type walls like Amoonguss and Wo-Chien are obliterated by Expanding Force, but Amoonguss can still redirect with Rage Powder and put Armarouge to sleep, so safety goggles teammates are appreciated.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Armarouge": {"Abilities": {"flashfire": 146.08535282114295, "weakarmor": 27.522433935545706}, "Items": {"weaknesspolicy": 0.15863664605734995, "lifeorb": 0.6473851091395069}, "Spreads": {"Modest:68/0/12/196/4/228": 0.4216889885715676}, "Moves": ["armorcannon", "expandingforce", "protect", "terablast"], "Tera Types": {"grass": 0.2377272993782187, "water": 0.5571380942054882}, "Teammates": ["Indeedee-F", "Gholdengo", "Kingambit", "Tauros-Paldea-Aqua", "Gyarados", "Ribombee"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Armarouge is a mid-speed special attacker that can flex between two roles: 1) Flash Fire pivot that switches into predicted Fire or Steel moves, grabs a boost, and immediately applies Armor Cannon pressure to open holes for Kingambit or Gholdengo; 2) Psychic Terrain abuser that sits beside Indeedee-F and fires 120 BP spread Expanding Forces to dismantle bulky Grass and Poison types.  Its speed tier lets it function outside Trick Room while still underspeeding TailwindDragapult, making it an ideal “tweener” that punishes both speed control extremes.  The modest nature and 196 SpA EVs secure critical OHKOs (notably on Gholdengo and non-bulk Dragonite) while 228 Speed outpaces Jolly Kingambit and neutral-nature base 80s.  The remaining EVs are placed in bulk to survive Jolly Chomp Earthquake and +1 Palafin Jet Punch after Tera Water.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Armarouge": {"Abilities": {"flashfire": 146.08535282114295, "weakarmor": 27.522433935545706}, "Items": {"weaknesspolicy": 0.15863664605734995, "lifeorb": 0.6473851091395069}, "Spreads": {"Modest:68/0/12/196/4/228": 0.4216889885715676}, "Moves": ["armorcannon", "expandingforce", "protect", "terablast"], "Tera Types": {"grass": 0.2377272993782187, "water": 0.5571380942054882}, "Teammates": ["Indeedee-F", "Gholdengo", "Kingambit", "Tauros-Paldea-Aqua", "Gyarados", "Ribombee"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Indeedee-F is the single most important partner, providing Psychic Terrain, Follow Me, and Helping Hand to turn Expanding Force into a nuke while shielding Armarouge from Fake Out and priority.  Gholdengo forms a Steel-Psychic core that resists both of Armarouge’s STAB weaknesses and punishes opposing Indeedee-F with Shadow Ball; in return Armarouge removes Kingambit for Gholdengo.  Kingambit appreciates the removal of Corviknight and Garganacl, and can pressure special walls that Armarouge cannot break.  Tauros-Paldea-Aqua brings Intimidate, Water coverage, and speed control via Icy Wind, while Gyarados offers similar Intimidate plus Tailwind and can bait Electric moves for Armarouge to switch into.  Ribombee supplies speed control with Tailwind and can slot Pollen Puff to heal Armarouge after Life Orb recoil.  The team composition therefore balances offensive synergy (shared Psychic spam, Fire/Water/Grass cores) and defensive synergy (Intimidate, Follow Me, Flash Fire), allowing Armarouge to operate both as a lead and as a mid-game cleaner.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Armarouge": {"Abilities": {"flashfire": 146.08535282114295, "weakarmor": 27.522433935545706}, "Items": {"weaknesspolicy": 0.15863664605734995, "lifeorb": 0.6473851091395069}, "Spreads": {"Modest:68/0/12/196/4/228": 0.4216889885715676}, "Moves": ["armorcannon", "expandingforce", "protect", "terablast"], "Tera Types": {"grass": 0.2377272993782187, "water": 0.5571380942054882}, "Teammates": ["Indeedee-F", "Gholdengo", "Kingambit", "Tauros-Paldea-Aqua", "Gyarados", "Ribombee"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Palafin is the most direct counter: Choice Band Jet Punch outspeeds and OHKOs non-Tera Armarouge, and even after Tera Water it can 2HKO with Wave Crash.  Rotom-Wash can survive +0 Tera Blast and OHKO back with Hydro Pump, though it loses if Armarouge is already at +1 Flash Fire.  Chien-Pao’s Ice Shard does 60–70 % and finishes off chipped Armarouge, while opposing priority such as Dragonite Extreme Speed or Kingambit Sucker Punch can break its Substitute-less set.  Amoonguss can redirect Expanding Force with Rage Powder and put Armarouge to sleep, so Safety Goggles on a teammate or double-targeting Amoonguss is mandatory.  Roaring Moon outspeeds and OHKOs with Acrobatics after a Dragon Dance, but it must set up first; a healthy Armarouge can survive +0 Acrobatics and OHKO back with Armor Cannon.  Finally, opposing weather sweepers like Swift Swim Pelipper orProtosynthesis Great Tusk under Sun can overwhelm Armarouge before it can Tera, so maintaining terrain and speed control is crucial.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Kilowattrel is a niche but serviceable fast special attacker in VGC Series-2, sitting at base-125 Speed and decent SpA. Its main draw is instant Tailwind, backed by STAB Air Slash and Thunderbolt, plus Volt Absorb to punish opposing Electric moves. Competitive is taken on ~85 % of teams to punish Intimidate, while Wind Power and Volt Absorb remain situational. Tera Ghost is the only recorded Tera, dodging Fake Out and Explosion while blocking Extreme-Speed follow-ups. A Focus Sash is virtually mandatory because Kilowattrel’s bulk is paper-thin; the EV spreads are standard 252/252 Timid with minor IV tweaks. Usage sits far below the metagame staples, but it fills a unique speed-control slot for offense squads that already stack physical powerhouses.</OUTPUT>

input:
Produce the 'full_analysis' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Kilowattrel": {"Abilities": {"voltabsorb": 5.473961539499664, "competitive": 140.89802409511822, "windpower": 14.341945007788146}, "Items": {"focussash": 0.7702056422945516}, "Spreads": {"Timid:4/0/0/252/0/252": 0.41416125613071236, "Timid:0/0/0/252/4/252": 0.2618225547690679, "Timid:0/0/4/252/0/252": 0.1596398893768127}, "Moves": ["thunderbolt", "airslash", "tailwind", "protect"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.7982881204657011}, "Teammates": ["Garchomp", "Incineroar", "Ursaluna", "Porygon2", "Gholdengo", "Amoonguss"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>In the current Regulation-G environment Kilowattrel’s value proposition is straightforward: it is the second-fastest Tailwind setter legal after Talonflame, and the fastest that carries an offensive Electric STAB. Base-125 Speed lets it outrun +1 Roaring Moon, +1 Dragonite, and every unboosted Scarfer short of Barraskewda, guaranteeing Tailwind versus most leads. Once wind is up, 105 SpA Thunderbolt and Air Slash give it reasonable damage into neutral targets—roughly 50 % into bulky Incineroar and 65-75 % into Tera-Fairy Garchomp—while Air Slash’s 30 % flinch chance can steal turns. Competitive turns common Intimidate cores (Incineroar, Landorus-T, Arcanine) into set-up bait, often granting +2 SpA immediately; with +2, Kilowattrel cleanly OHKOs 4-HP Tornadus-T after spread damage and secures the 2HKO on Assault-Vest Gholdengo. Volt Absorb variants punish predicted Regieleki or Iron Hands Volt Switches, regaining ~33 % HP and flipping momentum, but the data show only ~5 % of battlers opt for it, preferring the snowball potential of Competitive. Wind Power is almost unseen; although it boosts the next Electric move after Kilowattrel is hit, the requirement to survive a hit first clashes with its frailty. Tera Ghost is taken on every recorded team: it nullifies Fake Out, blocks Prankster status, and makes Explosion from Gholdengo or Togedemaru free turns. EV spreads are cookie-cutter Timid max-speed/max-Special-Attack with 4 HP or 4 Def to tweak download and Gyro Ball damage; Focus Sash guarantees at least two actions unless Kilowattrel eats multi-hit or Unseen Fist. Offensively, Kilowattrel appreciates chip: Air Slash into Garchomp is only a 3HKO, but after Stealth Rock or a single U-turn it becomes a clean 2HKO. Thunderbolt is the safest button into Corviknight, Toxapex and Pelipper, but fails to OHKO Azumarill or bulked-up Dondozo, so partners must carry strong Grass or Freeze-Dry coverage. Defensively, Kilowattrel folds to any neutral physical hit; Choice Band Dragonite Extreme Speed does 110-130 %, and even resisted Iron Head from Jirachi reaches 70-85 %. Consequently, it is almost never brought to end-game scenarios unless Tailwind is still needed. In best-of-three sets opponents often lead their own Tailwind or priority to deny it, so Kilowattrel teams tend to run dual-speed control—either a second Tailwind (Talonflame) or Icy Wind Porygon2—to ensure the speed advantage. Overall, Kilowattrel is a high-risk, high-reward tempo pick: when it sets up unobstructed it catapults its side ahead, but onemisplay or a surviving Rock-type priority can instantly collapse the game plan.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Kilowattrel": {"Abilities": {"voltabsorb": 5.473961539499664, "competitive": 140.89802409511822, "windpower": 14.341945007788146}, "Items": {"focussash": 0.7702056422945516}, "Spreads": {"Timid:4/0/0/252/0/252": 0.41416125613071236, "Timid:0/0/0/252/4/252": 0.2618225547690679, "Timid:0/0/4/252/0/252": 0.1596398893768127}, "Moves": ["thunderbolt", "airslash", "tailwind", "protect"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.7982881204657011}, "Teammates": ["Garchomp", "Incineroar", "Ursaluna", "Porygon2", "Gholdengo", "Amoonguss"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Kilowattrel dominates slower Tailwind and Trick-Room builds that rely on Incineroar or Landorus-T to drop offenses. +2 Thunderbolt OHKOs standard bulky Incineroar and 2HKOs AV variants, while Air Slash cleanly removes Breloom, Annihilape and Tera-Grass Dragons after minor chip. Against hyper-offense it speed-ties Iron Bundle and outspeeds +1 Roaring Moon, but it cannot survive a hit from Chien-Pao or Choice Band Dragonite, so it must either sash or Terastallize. Rain teams are mixed: Kilowattrel removes Pelipper with Thunderbolt and cripples offensive Swampert, but Kingdra under rain outspeeds and OHKOs with Hydro Pump. Sun is more dangerous—Protosynthesis Flutter Mane and Torkoal’s Eruption both vaporize it through sash, so Kilowattrel usually pivots out after Tailwind. Trick Room is a nightmare; even with Tailwind, base-125 fails to underspeed Hatterene or Indeedee, and Hatterene’s Follow-Me plus Armarouge/Indeedee Expanding Force OHKOs the entire field. Consequently, Kilowattrel teams almost always pair a Taunt user or their own redirection to stop Room going up. Steel-types that don’t mind Air Slash—Corviknight, Gholdengo, Togedemaru—force Kilowattrel to fish for flinches or switch, while Rock-types such as Tyranitar and Lycanroc-Dusk threaten OHKOs through sash with Rock Slide or Accelerock. Electric Terrain teams featuring Pincurchin or Iron Hands can overload Volt Absorb, but Competitive variants still punish Intimidate Hawlucha. In mirror Tailwind wars, Kilowattrel speed-ties opposing Kilowattrel and Talonflame, making the support slot’s bulk and positioning decisive.</OUTPUT>

input:

<DATA>{"Kilowattrel": {"Abilities": {"voltabsorb": 5.473961539499664, "competitive": 140.89802409511822, "windpower": 14.341945007788146}, "Items": {"focussash": 0.7702056422945516}, "Spreads": {"Timid:4/0/0/252/0/252": 0.41416125613071236, "Timid:0/0/0/252/4/252": 0.2618225547690679, "Timid:0/0/4/252/0/252": 0.1596398893768127}, "Moves": ["thunderbolt", "airslash", "tailwind", "protect"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.7982881204657011}, "Teammates": ["Garchomp", "Incineroar", "Ursaluna", "Porygon2", "Gholdengo", "Amoonguss"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Kilowattrel’s primary job is to click Tailwind on turn one, enabling its slower but powerful teammates to strike first for the next four turns. Because it outspeeds every common support except Talonflame, it almost always gets the speed field up unless the opponent commits Fake Out plus a faster attacker. Once wind is active, Kilowattrel becomes a mid-tier special attacker: Thunderbolt nails Water- and Flying-types, Air Slash pressures Grass, Fighting and opposing Dragons, and the 30 % flinch chance can steal games. Its second role is punishing Intimidate cycles; Competitive turns ubiquitous Incineroar into a +2 SpA boost, letting Kilowattrel snowball past would-be checks. In the late-game it can act as a cleanup revenge killer, but its fragility means it is rarely kept alive that long—most players trade it for a KO or second Tailwind refresh around turn five. Terastallizing is usually saved for the Tera Ghost dodge: it blanks Fake Out, stops Prankster Twave from Grimmsnarl, and makes Explosion a liability for the opponent. Overall, Kilowattrel is a tempo setter that wins the speed war early and tries to convert that edge into a 2-for-1 or 3-for-2 exchange before it folds.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Kilowattrel": {"Abilities": {"voltabsorb": 5.473961539499664, "competitive": 140.89802409511822, "windpower": 14.341945007788146}, "Items": {"focussash": 0.7702056422945516}, "Spreads": {"Timid:4/0/0/252/0/252": 0.41416125613071236, "Timid:0/0/0/252/4/252": 0.2618225547690679, "Timid:0/0/4/252/0/252": 0.1596398893768127}, "Moves": ["thunderbolt", "airslash", "tailwind", "protect"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.7982881204657011}, "Teammates": ["Garchomp", "Incineroar", "Ursaluna", "Porygon2", "Gholdengo", "Amoonguss"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>The most common partners—Garchomp, Incineroar, Ursaluna, Porygon2, Gholdengo, Amoonguss—showcase Kilowattrel’s ideal archetype: bulky physical attackers that appreciate speed control and punish the same Intimidate loops. Garchomp is the star synergy: it underspeeds most threats under neutral conditions but outspeeds everything at +1 or under Tailwind, and it baits Ice moves that Kilowattrel can switch into for a Volt Absorb heal. Incineroar provides Fake Out and Parting Shot to buy Tailwind turns; because Competitive deters opposing Intimidate, both Pokémon can coexist without tripping over each other’s stat drops. Ursaluna enjoys Tailwind to offset its low Speed, while its Normal typing draws Ghost and Fighting moves that Kilowattrel resists. Porygon2 offers a second speed-control option (Icy Wind) and Trick-Room reverse, plus Download can push Kilowattrel’s modest bulk past key breakpoints. Gholdengo blocks enemy Tailwind and spreads status, while its Steel typing covers Kilowattrel’s Rock and Ice weaknesses; in return Kilowattrel removes Corviknight and Toxapex for it. Amoonguss provides Rage Powder redirection so Kilowattrel can safely click Tailwind versus double-target leads, and it appreciates Kilowattrel’s Electric immunity to avoid Volt Switch chip. Beyond the top teammates, Kilowattrel fits any core that wants to go fast but lacks a slot for Talonflame—common examples are Choice Band Dragonite, Assault-Vest Kingdra, or Iron Hands that need Tailwind to outspeed opposing Scarfers. It dislikes partners that stack Electric weaknesses (Pelipper, Toxapex) unless they carry Volt Switch for absorb plays, and it fears Rock Slide so teammates should either resist Rock or carry Wide Guard.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Kilowattrel": {"Abilities": {"voltabsorb": 5.473961539499664, "competitive": 140.89802409511822, "windpower": 14.341945007788146}, "Items": {"focussash": 0.7702056422945516}, "Spreads": {"Timid:4/0/0/252/0/252": 0.41416125613071236, "Timid:0/0/0/252/4/252": 0.2618225547690679, "Timid:0/0/4/252/0/252": 0.1596398893768127}, "Moves": ["thunderbolt", "airslash", "tailwind", "protect"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.7982881204657011}, "Teammates": ["Garchomp", "Incineroar", "Ursaluna", "Porygon2", "Gholdengo", "Amoonguss"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Kilowattrel’s biggest flaw is its tissue-paper bulk: any neutral physical attack breaks sash and often OHKOs, while priority from Chien-Pao or Dragonite ends it after chip. Rock-types are public enemy number one—Tyranitar’s Rock Slide does 150-180 %, Lycanroc-Dusk’s Accelerock outspeeds and OHKOs, and even defensive Coalossal survives Air Slash and retaliates with Heat Crash. Electric Terrain plus Iron Hands can overload Volt Absorb, and Iron Hands’ Thunder Punch still 2HKOs through Competitive boosts. Faster attackers that survive Air Slash can finish it: Iron Bundle’s Hydro Pump, Choice Scarf Gholdengo’s Shadow Ball, or Kingdra’s Draco Meteor all KO after sash. Fake Out plus any follow-up—from Incineroar Darkest Lariat to Chien-Pao Ice Spinner—breaks sash and removes Kilowattrel before it moves, so teams must respect the double-target. Prankster status from Grimmsnarl or Whimsicott can cripple it, though Tera Ghost blanks Thunder Wave. Trick Room completely flips the script; under Room Kilowattrel becomes one of the slowest Pokémon, and Hatterene’s Follow-Me plus Indeedee Expanding Force or Armarouge Armor Cannon scores a double KO. Finally, because Kilowattrel is almost always choiced into Focus Sash, repeated hazards or spread damage from Garchomp’s Earthquake and Gholdengo’s Make It Rain eventually pop the sash, leaving it vulnerable to priority. Good counterplay is to lead your own Tailwind or priority, break sash early, and preserve a Rock-type or Ice Shard user for the cleanup.</OUTPUT>

The team struggles versus opposing weather and Rock Slide spam, so positioning and Protect reads are key; nevertheless, it shows how Kilowattrel can anchor a top-speed offense archetype despite its low individual usage.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>The set is brutally simple: Adamant nature, 252 Speed EVs, 196 Attack EVs, and a focus on three moves that all benefit from Loaded Dice. Scale Shot is the crux—each hit has an 80 % chance to raise Speed, so after one use Baxcalibur is sitting at +1 or +2 Speed while firing off a 135 BP Dragon move that hits both foes. Icicle Spear is the secondary STAB, breaking Sash, Air Balloon, and Substitute while chunking Landorus-T, Amoonguss, Rillaboom, and Dragon-types for 125 BP of Ice damage. Ice Shard gives the team a much-needed priority option that cleanly finishes weakened Flutter Mane, Dragapult, or Tornadus while also punishing opposing priority. Protect is mandatory in doubles to block Fake Out, stall speed control, and let partners remove threats. The 4/4 bulk investment avoids the 2HKO from standard Life Orb Flutter Mane Shadow Ball and lets it live Jolly Garchomp Earthquake after a Dragon Tera. Thermal Exchange is the only ability worth considering: not only does it flip the script on burn attempts, it also punishes Sun teams that rely on Heat Wave or Eruption, turning what should be a defensive liability into +1 Attack.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Hatterene is a Trick Room setter and special attacker that dominates the format with Magic Bounce, bouncing back opposing Taunt, Spore, or other status moves while setting up Trick Room. Its Fairy/Psychic typing and access to Expanding Force and Dazzling Gleam let it fire off spread moves under Psychic Terrain (usually from Indeedee-F) for huge damage. Quiet nature with max HP and max Special Attack EVs is the gold standard, letting it survive hits while firing off 100% accurate, terrain-boosted Expanding Force. Tera Fire is the most common Tera type, removing its Bug and Steel weaknesses and giving it a crucial resistance to Incineroar’s Knock Off and Dark-type attacks in general. Life Orb is the preferred item for the extra damage, although Covert Cloak variants avoid Fake Out flinch and ignore secondary effects like Kingambit’s Supreme Overlord boosts. Hatterene is almost always paired with Indeedee-F for Psychic Terrain, and fits naturally on hard Trick Room builds alongside Torkoal, Ursaluna, and Incineroar.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Hatterene": {"Abilities": {"magicbounce": 147.48312641274066, "healer": 1.718674262818559, "anticipation": 0.007698793419798677}, "Items": {"lifeorb": 0.7113613892262481, "covertcloak": 0.2202896930889596}, "Spreads": {"Quiet:212/0/44/252/0/0": 0.28422650177195335, "Quiet:252/0/0/252/4/0": 0.15838764382202875, "Quiet:252/0/4/252/0/0": 0.3358555384844976}, "Moves": ["expandingforce", "dazzlinggleam", "protect", "trickroom"], "Tera Types": {"fire": 0.3935203911315033, "psychic": 0.22253953634719997, "water": 0.226573648068101}, "Teammates": ["Gallade", "Indeedee-F", "Torkoal", "Lilligant-Hisui", "Ursaluna", "Incineroar"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Hatterene’s niche in the current metagame is defined by two factors: Magic Bounce and Trick Room. Magic Bounce single-handedly invalidates common speed-control and disruption options like Smeargle’s Dark Void, Amoonguss’s Spore, and Murkrow’s Taunt, forcing opponents to commit double-targets or raw damage to stop Trick Room. Once Trick Room is up, Hatterene’s base 136 Special Attack and access to spread moves in Expanding Force (boosted to 120 BP by Psychic Terrain) and Dazzling Gleam make it one of the most efficient damage dealers in the format. Quiet nature with 0 Speed IVs guarantees it underspeeds every relevant threat under Trick Room, while 252 HP / 252 SpA or 212 HP / 44 Def / 252 SpA Quiet spreads let it survive key rolls such as Life Orb Chien-Pao’s Crunch and Choice Specs Dragapult’s Shadow Ball. Tera Fire removes the 4x Bug weakness and turns Kingambit’s Sucker Punch into a neutral hit, while Tera Water lets it stomach Torkoal’s Eruption and Tera Psychic further boosts Expanding Force. The moveset is almost immutable: Trick Room for speed control, Expanding Force for STAB spread, Dazzling Gleam for opposing Dragons and Dark-types, and Protect for pivoting. Life Orb is the default for the power boost, but Covert Cloak variants are rising to ignore Fake Out flinch and ignore secondary effects like Kingambit’s Supreme Overlord or Garganacl’s Salt Cure chip. Healer is a fringe option for doubles support but is outclassed by Magic Bounce’s utility.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Against hyper-offense, Hatterene is a double-edged sword: it can bounce back Taunt and Spore, but faster threats like Chien-Pao, Dragapult, and Kingambit can KO before Trick Room goes up. Once Trick Room is active, these same threats become fodder for Expanding Force or Dazzling Gleam. Against sun, Tera Water variants stomach Torkoal’s Eruption and KO back with Psychic Terrain-boosted Expanding Force, while Tera Fire variants fear only Solar Power-boosted Fire moves. Against rain, Hatterene must watch for Barraskewda’s Liquidation and Kingdra’s Hurricane, but under Trick Room it outspeeds and OHKOes both with Dazzling Gleam or Expanding Force. Against hard Trick Room mirrors, speed ties are irrelevant and the game becomes a damage race; Hatterene’s spread moves and ability to ignore opposing Indeedee-F’s Follow Me via Expanding Force give it an edge. Against stall or semi-stall, Magic Bounce shuts down status and recovery, forcing opponents to attack directly, which plays into Hatterene’s bulk and power.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Faster Dark-types are the bane of Hatterene’s existence: Choice Band Chien-Pao’s Crunch, Kingambit’s Tera Dark Sucker Punch, and Dragapult’s Tera Dark Phantom Force all KO before Trick Room. <DATA>{"Sableye": {"Abilities": {"prankster": 132.9288509373253, "keeneye": 0.012597765034203068, "stall": 0.0}, "Items": {"lightclay": 0.8882791642819505}, "Spreads": {"Bold:252/0/84/0/172/0": 0.7777219247750204}, "Moves": ["lightscreen", "reflect", "disable", "encore"], "Tera Types": {"steel": 0.28821076317209143, "water": 0.5587509286696092}, "Teammates": ["Incineroar", "Maushold", "Annihilape", "Dondozo", "Tatsugiri", "Weezing"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Prankster is the cornerstone of Sableye’s viability, granting priority on every non-attacking move it carries. This allows it to fire off Reflect and Light Screen before most opponents can move, immediately halving incoming physical or special damage for eight turns thanks to Light Clay. Once the screens are active, Sableye can pivot to pure disruption: Disable can knock out a Dynamaxing Pokémon’s Max move or remove a key attack such as Flutter Mane’s Moonblast, while Encore locks foes into Protect, set-up, or status moves, forcing switches or wasting turns. The chosen spread is Bold with 84 Def / 172 SpD, maximizing physical bulk while ensuring both screens are as durable as possible; 0 Speed IVs and no investment let it move last in most scenarios, letting allies receive the screen benefits before taking hits. Tera Steel is the most common choice, removing the Ghost weakness and adding resistances to common spread moves like Dazzling Gleam and Icy Wind, while Tera Water shores up the Fire weakness that Incineroar and Torkoal exploit. Sableye’s movepool is deceptively deep—Knock Off, Will-O-Wisp, Quash, Sunny Day, and Rain Dance are all legal—but the listed set focuses on pure team support, freeing moveslots and EVs for bulk rather than speed or offense. Because it carries no direct damage, Sableye must rely on teammates to capitalize on the openings it creates, making synergy and speed control essential parts of any squad it joins.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Sableye excels against offensive teams that rely on single-target burst or set-up sweepers: Reflect neuters physical attackers like Chien-Pao, Kingambit, and Palafin, while Light Screen cushions special threats such as Flutter Mane and Hydreigon. Encore punishes Protect-heavy compositions and Trick Room setters like Hatterene and Indeedee-F, forcing them to repeat non-threatening moves or switch out. However, Sableye struggles against Dark-types and other Prankster users—opposing Incineroar, Kingambit, and Grimmsnarl ignore priority status, and a faster Taunt or Fake Out can shut it down. Clear Amulet and Covert Cloak users also ignore Encore/Disable, while Tera Dark or Good as Gold abilities make it impossible to cripple key targets. Finally, spread attackers that can blast both slots, such as Gholdengo and Landorus-T, still do respectable damage through screens if they target Sableye’s weaker slot partner.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Arcanine-Hisui": {"Abilities": {"intimidate": 123.11092552670995, "rockhead": 13.5816615304371, "flashfire": 0.011282103101917296}, "Items": {"mirrorherb": 0.26336916828504126, "clearamulet": 0.39713021745994487}, "Spreads": {"Jolly:4/252/0/0/0/252": 0.3382107382630367, "Jolly:0/252/0/0/4/252": 0.1566839398975286}, "Moves": ["flareblitz", "rockslide", "protect", "extremespeed"], "Tera Types": {"water": 0.45711392058938066, "ghost": 0.26298960874924837}, "Teammates": ["Sneasler", "Ninetales-Alola", "Gholdengo", "Whimsicott", "Dragonite", "Rillaboom"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Hisuian Arcanine’s claim to fame is the rare Rock/Fire typing coupled with Intimidate, giving it a unique damage profile and the ability to drop opposing Attack stats on entry. Flare Blitz is its strongest reliable STAB, nuking common Steel- and Grass-types such as Amoonguss, Togekiss, and Gholdengo. Rock Slide provides spread damage and flinch chances into Flying, Fire, and Ice foes while synergising with its own Terastallisation options. Extreme Speed is the set’s glue, granting a +2 priority pick-off that punishes weakened sweepers and bypasses opposing speed control. Protect is mandatory doubles tech, letting it scout choice locks, stall out speed control or Dynamon turns, and preserve its respectable 95/80/80 bulk. Tera Water is the most popular choice, removing its 4× Fire weakness and turning incoming Water moves into neutral or resisted hits while still allowing STAB Flare Blitz through Tera Blast if desired; Tera Ghost offers spin-blocking utility and an immunity to Fake Out and Extreme Speed from rival Dragons, notably Dragonite. The item data is sparse, but Mirror Herb and Clear Amulet hint at two builds: Herb punishes stat-boosting foes such as Iron Hands or Chien-Pao by copying their boosts, whereas Clear Amulet prevents its own Attack drops from Intimidate or Parting Shot, ensuring damage output remains consistent. Its abilities show overwhelming preference for Intimidate, underscoring its primary role as a physical deterrent, while Rock Head’s low usage reflects the difficulty of capitalising on it without Head Smash or Wild Charge. Overall, Hisuian Arcanine is a momentum machine that compresses speed, power, and disruption into a single slot, demanding respect from both offensive and defensive cores.</OUTPUT>

input:
Produce the 'matchup_overview' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Arcanine-Hisui": {"Abilities": {"intimidate": 123.11092552670995, "rockhead": 13.5816615304371, "flashfire": 0.011282103101917296}, "Items": {"mirrorherb": 0.26336916828504126, "clearamulet": 0.39713021745994487}, "Spreads": {"Jolly:4/252/0/0/0/252": 0.3382107382630367, "Jolly:0/252/0/0/4/252": 0.1566839398975286}, "Moves": ["flareblitz", "rockslide", "protect", "extremespeed"], "Tera Types": {"water": 0.45711392058938066, "ghost": 0.26298960874924837}, "Teammates": ["Sneasler", "Ninetales-Alola", "Gholdengo", "Whimsicott", "Dragonite", "Rillaboom"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Into hyper-offensive teams, Hisuian Arcanine is a nightmare: Intimidate immediately curbs physical sweepers like Chien-Pao, Kingambit, and opposing Dragonite, while Rock Slide spreads chip and flinches. Against Rain, Tera Water turns the tables—Pelipper’s Hurricanes and Barraskewda’s Liquidation no longer secure OHKOs, and Arcanine can retaliate with Flare Blitz or Tera Water-boosted Rock Slide. Sun teams dislike Rock Slide’s spread damage on Torkoal and Venusaur, though they must be wary of Solar Power-boosted Heat Waves in return. Trick Room is a mixed bag: Arcanine underspeeds typical TR sweepers like Hatterene and Iron Hands, but can break their focus with Flare Blitz and finish them with Extreme Speed once the room ends. Into stall or bulky cores, Arcanine’s 110 Attack is merely decent, so it relies on critical hits or teammate chip to break through Dondozo, Corviknight, or Ting-Lu. Finally, Ghost-types such as Aegislash and Gholdengo wall its STABs but hate Rock Slide flinches and partner support like Sneasler’s Dire Claw or Gholdengo’s own Make It Rain.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Arcanine-Hisui": {"Abilities": {"intimidate": 123.11092552670995, "rockhead": 13.5816615304371, "flashfire": 0.011282103101917296}, "Items": {"mirrorherb": 0.26336916828504126, "clearamulet": 0.39713021745994487}, "Spreads": {"Jolly:4/252/0/0/0/252": 0.3382107382630367, "Jolly:0/252/0/0/4/252": 0.1566839398975286}, "Moves": ["flareblitz", "rockslide", "protect", "extremespeed"], "Tera Types": {"water": 0.45711392058938066, "ghost": 0.26298960874924837}, "Teammates": ["Sneasler", "Ninetales-Alola", "Gholdengo", "Whimsicott", "Dragonite", "Rillaboom"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Hisuian Arcanine is a fast offensive support that leads or pivots mid-game to apply immediate pressure, drop Attack stats, and clean with priority. It functions best as a lead alongside redirection or speed control to guarantee Rock Slide flinches or safe Flare Blitz nukes, then retreats to return late-game once opponents are in Extreme Speed range. Its Intimidate pressure forces many physical attackers to Dynamax early or switch out, generating tempo for partners to set up snow, Tailwind, or Swords Dance. In the back, it morphs into a revenge killer, picking off weakened threats and denying opposing speed control with its own priority.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Arcanine-Hisui": {"Abilities": {"intimidate": 123.11092552670995, "rockhead": 13.5816615304371, "flashfire": 0.011282103101917296}, "Items": {"mirrorherb": 0.26336916828504126, "clearamulet": 0.39713021745994487}, "Spreads": {"Jolly:4/252/0/0/0/252": 0.3382107382630367, "Jolly:0/252/0/0/4/252": 0.1566839398975286}, "Moves": ["flareblitz", "rockslide", "protect", "extremespeed"], "Tera Types": {"water": 0.45711392058938066, "ghost": 0.26298960874924837}, "Teammates": ["Sneasler", "Ninetales-Alola", "Gholdengo", "Whimsicott", "Dragonite", "Rillaboom"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Sneasler forms an aggressive core, benefiting from Intimidate drops to set up Swords Dance while sharing Rock coverage to overwhelm shared Flying checks. Alolan Ninetales provides Aurora Veil, patching Arcanine’s average bulk and enabling it to survive Water and Ground hits that would otherwise KO; in return, Arcanine pressures Steel-types that trouble Ninetales. Gholdengo blocks enemy status and spin, while Arcanine removes opposing Dark-types like Kingambit that threaten the ghostly golden boy. Whimsicott offers Tailwind and Encore, letting Arcanine outspeed even Timid Iron Bundle and lock foes into unfavourable moves. Dragonite enjoys Intimidate support to safely set up Dragon Dances, and both share Tera Water, bluffing each other’s switch-ins. Rillaboom rounds out the squad by bringing Grassy Terrain recovery, priority, and Wood Hammer damage that softens Ground and Rock foes for Arcanine’s sweep. Collectively, these teammates shore up Arcanine’s Water, Ground, and Fighting weaknesses while amplifying its offensive output through speed control, redirection, and chip damage.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Arcanine-Hisui": {"Abilities": {"intimidate": 123.11092552670995, "rockhead": 13.5816615304371, "flashfire": 0.011282103101917296}, "Items": {"mirrorherb": 0.26336916828504126, "clearamulet": 0.39713021745994487}, "Spreads": {"Jolly:4/252/0/0/0/252": 0.3382107382630367, "Jolly:0/252/0/0/4/252": 0.1566839398975286}, "Moves": ["flareblitz", "rockslide", "protect", "extremespeed"], "Tera Types": {"water": 0.45711392058938066, "ghost": 0.26298960874924837}, "Teammates": ["Sneasler", "Ninetales-Alola", "Gholdengo", "Whimsicott", "Dragonite", "Rillaboom"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Standard Pivot: Jolly 252 Atk / 4 Def / 252 Spe with Intimidate, Flare Blitz, Rock Slide, Extreme Speed, Protect, Tera Water, holding Clear Amulet. This set ensures maximum damage and speed while preventing Attack drops from opposing Intimidate or Parting Shot, letting Arcanine maintain consistent power throughout the match. Mirror Herb Variant: identical spread and moves but replace Clear Amulet with Mirror Herb to punish setup sweepers like Iron Hands, Dragonite, or Chien-Pao, copying their boosts and turning the tables mid-game. Rock Head Option: swap ability to Rock Head and run Flare Blitz / Head Smash / Extreme Speed / Protect with Tera Rock to secure recoil-free Head Smash nukes, though this build sees minimal usage and requires team support to handle Water and Steel counters.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Arcanine-Hisui": {"Abilities": {"intimidate": 123.11092552670995, "rockhead": 13.5816615304371, "flashfire": 0.011282103101917296}, "Items": {"mirrorherb": 0.26336916828504126, "clearamulet": 0.39713021745994487}, "Spreads": {"Jolly:4/252/0/0/0/252": 0.3382107382630367, "Jolly:0/252/0/0/4/252": 0.1566839398975286}, "Moves": ["flareblitz", "rockslide", "protect", "extremespeed"], "Tera Types": {"water": 0.45711392058938066, "ghost": 0.26298960874924837}, "Teammates": ["Sneasler", "Ninetales-Alola", "Gholdengo", "Whimsicott", "Dragonite", "Rillaboom"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Water-types remain the most reliable answers: bulky Pelipper, Iron Bundle, and Suicune take little from Rock Slide and OHKO back with Hydro Pump or Surf, although they must watch for Tera Water on the switch. Ground-types such as Great Tusk and Garchomp outspeed non-Scarf variants and erase Arcanine with Earthquake; however, Intimidate forces them to Dynamax or switch. Priority users like opposing Dragonite or Kingambit can bypass Arcanine’s speed, but fear Extreme Speed races and Intimidate drops. Status—especially Will-O-Wisp from Rotom-W or Sableye—cripples its physical offense, though Clear Amulet variants mitigate this. Finally, bulky resists such as Corviknight, Dondozo, and Aegislash shrug off its STABs and can stall out Tera turns or retalute with super-effective coverage. Proper prediction, speed control, and spread moves are therefore essential to exploit Arcanine’s merely decent bulk and reliance on recoil-heavy Flare Blitz.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Start with Hisuian Arcanine + Alolan Ninetales lead: Ninetales sets Aurora Veil while Arcanine fires off Rock Slide or threatens Flare Blitz. Behind Veil, Arcanine survives Water and Ground hits and can pivot into Sneasler or Dragonite to capitalise on Intimidate drops. Gholdengo sits in the back to block spin and spread Special damage, while Rillaboom switches in to reset terrain and priority. Whimsicott offers Tailwind and Encore support mid-game, enabling Arcanine to clean with Extreme Speed once opposing Dynamax and defensive cores are chipped. The team’s shared Tera Water bluff forces opponents to hesitate on Water-type attacks, creating mind-games that Arcanine and Dragonite can exploit. Overall, the squad balances hyper-offense momentum with protective layers, turning Arcanine’s unique typing and Intimidate into a reliable win condition.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Corviknight": {"Abilities": {"mirrorarmor": 128.4714698699715, "pressure": 2.6029745529894517, "unnerve": 0.13261014095858226}, "Items": {"sitrusberry": 0.3828788093187821}, "Spreads": {}, "Moves": ["tailwind", "bravebird", "roost", "bulkup"], "Tera Types": {"dragon": 0.5893052113385587, "fire": 0.31217355944329445}, "Teammates": ["Tyranitar", "Excadrill", "Incineroar", "Sneasler", "Garchomp", "Volcarona"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Corviknight is a sturdy, utility-focused Flying/Steel type that leverages Tailwind, reliable recovery, and setup potential to anchor balanced and sand archetypes. Its Mirror Armor ability deters stat-lowering tactics, while its typing grants key resistances to Ground, Grass, and Fairy, letting it check threats like Garchomp and Rillaboom. With Brave Bird for immediate damage, Roost for longevity, Bulk Up for late-game snowballing, and Tailwind for team speed control, Corviknight compresses multiple roles into one slot, making it a flexible pivot that can swing momentum while supporting faster, harder-hitting partners.</OUTPUT>

input:
Write a detailed 'full_analysis' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Corviknight": {"Abilities": {"mirrorarmor": 128.4714698699715, "pressure": 2.6029745529894517, "unnerve": 0.13261014095858226}, "Items": {"sitrusberry": 0.3828788093187821}, "Spreads": {}, "Moves": ["tailwind", "bravebird", "roost", "bulkup"], "Tera Types": {"dragon": 0.5893052113385587, "fire": 0.31217355944329445}, "Teammates": ["Tyranitar", "Excadrill", "Incineroar", "Sneasler", "Garchomp", "Volcarona"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Corviknight’s unique typing leaves it weak only to Electric and Fire, two types that are relatively scarce in the current restricted-heavy formats, so it can comfortably roost off most neutral hits. Mirror Armor punishes Intimidate and Parting Shot cycles, turning common support Pokémon like Incineroar and Landorus-T into setup fodder. Bulk Up variants can accumulate boosts behind Roost, forcing double targets or Terastalization from opponents who fear a +1 Brave Bird sweep. Tailwind remains its most important move: at −1 priority it demands careful positioning, but once up it turns normally middling-speed teammates like Tyranitar or Sneasler into immediate threats. The sample item Sitrus Berry is chosen over Heavy-Duty Boots because entry hazards are rare in doubles, and the 25 % heal synergizes with Roost to let Corviknight tank two super-effective Fire moves from uninvested attackers, buying extra turns to support or sweep. Terastal Dragon removes the Electric weakness and adds crucial resistances to Water and Grass, while Terastal Fire flips the Fire weakness into a resistance, letting it bait and beat opposing Sun or Heatran variants. Pressure is almost never chosen over Mirror Armor, and Unnerve sees no practical use; the data reflects this overwhelming preference. Spread information is absent in the dump, but 252 HP / 120 Def / 136 SpD with an Impish nature is the community standard for surviving Urshifu’s Wicked Blow plus Rillaboom’s Grassy Glide while retaining offensive presence.</OUTPUT>
