<DATA>{"Corviknight": {"Abilities": {"mirrorarmor": 128.4714698699715, "pressure": 2.6029745529894517, "unnerve": 0.13261014095858226}, "Items": {"sitrusberry": 0.3828788093187821}, "Spreads": {}, "Moves": ["tailwind", "bravebird", "roost", "bulkup"], "Tera Types": {"dragon": 0.5893052113385587, "fire": 0.31217355944329445}, "Teammates": ["Tyranitar", "Excadrill", "Incineroar", "Sneasler", "Garchomp", "Volcarona"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Corviknight dominates slower, setup-reliant teams that rely on Intimidate or stat-drops, but struggles against fast Electric or Fire attackers such as Regieleki, Zapdos, Charizard-Y, or sun-boosted Torkoal. It walls Garchomp, Landorus-T, and most non-Choice Band Rillaboom, but must Terastal or switch out against opposing Heatran, Rotom-Wash, or Zapdos-Galar. Bulk Up variants can out-stall fatter builds lacking immediate Fire coverage, while Tailwind variants flip the speed war against Rain or Sand that otherwise outspeed the rest of the squad. In restricteds formats, it can soft-check Calyrex-Ice and Shadow Rider with Tailwind up, but cannot stomach +2 Expanding Force or Astral Barrage without Terastal and a partner’s Follow Me. Overall it performs best when the opponent’s Electric and Fire threats are accounted for in the builder, letting it act as a mid-game pivot and late-game cleaner.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Corviknight is primarily a bulky support pivot that compresses Tailwind setter, Intimidate deterrent, and win-condition into one slot. It leads when the opponent lacks immediate Electric/Fire pressure, sets Tailwind, then either U-turns out or begins Bulk Up stacking depending on the foe’s response. Mid-game it uses Roost to maintain health for Brave Bird recoil and repeated switches, while Mirror Armor punishes opposing Parting Shot and Snarl cycles. Late-game, after Fire-types are eliminated, it can serve as a solo cleaner with +1 or +2 Brave Bird, outspeeding everything under Tailwind. Its role is therefore flexible: support first, tank second, and win-condition third, adapting to the flow of each match rather than locking into a single game plan.</OUTPUT>

Excadrill gains the same speed benefit under Tailwind and can eliminate opposing Electric-types for Corviknight. Incineroar forms a classic Intimidate core, softening physical attackers so Corviknight can roost more freely, while Mirror Armor punishes opposing Incineroar’s Intimidate. Sneasler and Garchomp are mid-speed powerhouses that become terrifying under Tailwind, and both lure Fairy and Ice moves that Corviknight can stomach. Volcarona offers a special win-condition and appreciates Corviknight’s ability to remove Stealth Rock in singles formats, though in doubles it mainly benefits from Tailwind to fire off fast Heat Waves. The shared Fire weakness is mitigated by Terastal Dragon or by simply eliminating opposing Fire-types early with Excadrill or Tyranitar’s Rock coverage.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Tauros-Paldea-Aqua": {"Abilities": {"intimidate": 126.31145266328997, "angerpoint": 0.04553910706695963, "cudchew": 1.5425383192990694e-11}, "Items": {"mirrorherb": 0.8629710160586865}, "Spreads": {"Jolly:4/252/0/0/0/252": 0.51900693995311}, "Moves": ["wavecrash", "aquajet", "closecombat", "protect"], "Tera Types": {"water": 0.2750404871086968, "grass": 0.43326541944600466}, "Teammates": ["Kingambit", "Gholdengo", "Rillaboom", "Archaludon", "Dragonite", "Pelipper"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>The data show that virtually every serious Tauros-Aqua set runs Intimidate (≈100 % usage), underscoring its primary identity as a pivot that softens physical attackers on switch-in. Wave Crash is the STAB of choice, offering a 120 BP Water nuke that 2HKOes most neutral targets and cleanly OHKOes common threats like Torkoal, Lava-Torko variants, and offensive Heatran under sun, while the recoil forces it to operate in burst windows. Aqua Jet supplies essential priority, turning Tauros into a respectable cleaner that out-paces standard speed tiers of 81–95 after chip, and punishes faster but frail threats such as Flutter Mane and Iron Valiant once they are knocked into range. Close Combat rounds the coverage, smacking Ferrothorn, Kingambit, and opposing Tauros formes for heavy damage and preventing it from becoming deadweight against Grass- or opposing Water-type cores. Protect is mandatory in doubles to stall out speed control turns, scout choice locks, and leverage Intimidate multiple times. Tera usage is split between Water (≈28 %) to power up Wave Crash and flip Grass match-ups, and Grass (≈43 %) to bait opposing Water, Electric, and Grass moves while removing the Electric weakness and giving it a better lane versus Amoonguss and Rillaboom. The item data are sparse, but Mirror Herb appears as a tech to copy opposing stat boosts, punishing Calm Mind/Dragon Dance setups that otherwise set up on Tauros. Overall, Tauros-Aqua’s niche is defined by immediate burst, speed control mitigation, and pivot utility rather than sustained presence.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Hisuian Lilligant carves a unique niche in VGC as a Chlorophyll abuser that can outspeed and dismantle bulky cores with a surprise Close Combat while still offering valuable support via After You and Sleep Powder. With a 115 base Speed that doubles under sun, it naturally outpaces the entire unboosted metagame, while access to Solar Blade gives it a 120 BP Grass STAB that needs no charge in sunlight. The most successful spreads run Jolly with maximum Attack and Speed investment, holding Focus Sash to guarantee at least one turn of action against faster threats or priority. Tera Ghost is the dominant choice, turning the usual Fighting-type counterplay on its head by rendering Lilligant immune to Fake Out and Extreme Speed while still letting it fire off unresisted coverage. Though frail, its ability to compress speed control, sleep, and a high-power Fighting move onto a single slot makes it a terrifying sun-based cleaner that can single-handedly rip through teams if given a free switch.</OUTPUT>

input:
Write a detailed 'full_analysis' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Lilligant-Hisui": {"Abilities": {"chlorophyll": 115.06328574651785, "hustle": 0.5354431003324742, "leafguard": 0.004010567449964364}, "Items": {"focussash": 0.9178827996386567}, "Spreads": {"Jolly:4/252/0/0/0/252": 0.45597350369054857, "Jolly:0/252/4/0/0/252": 0.16084247802873636}, "Moves": ["afteryou", "closecombat", "sleeppowder", "solarblade"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.7520902132457161}, "Teammates": ["Indeedee-F", "Hatterene", "Torkoal", "Gallade", "Ursaluna", "Farigiraf"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Hisuian Lilligant’s stat-line is deceptively potent: 105 Attack and 115 Speed place it in the same offensive tier as Choice Scarf Garchomp, but with Chlorophyll it becomes faster than +1 Roaring Moon under sun. Solar Blade is the headline STAB, offering 120 BP with no charge turn in sunlight, cleanly OHKOing bulky Waters like Toxapex and Rotom-W after minimal chip. Close Combat is the tech that separates it from other Chlorophyll sweepers, nailing Heatran, Gholdengo, and Tyranitar for super-effective damage while preventing Steel-types from walling it. After You turns Lilligant into a pseudo-speed control piece, letting slower partners like Ursaluna or Torkoal move immediately in Trick Room mirrors or against opposing weather. Sleep Powder remains one of the best tempo moves in doubles, crippling would-be counters such as Corviknight or Dragonite on the switch. Focus Sash is almost mandatory because Lilligant’s 70/75/75 bulk is paper-thin; the item guarantees a move against faster scarfers or priority spam. Tera Ghost is preferred on 75 % of teams, removing its Fighting weakness and granting immunity to Fake Out and Extreme Speed, the two most common ways to pick off Chlorophyll sweepers. Chlorophyll usage sits at 99.5 %, dwarfing Hustle and Leaf Guard, proving that the draw of doubling Speed in sun is the only realistic reason to use Hisuian Lilligant over other Grass-types.</OUTPUT>

input:
Create the 'matchup_overview' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Lilligant-Hisui": {"Abilities": {"chlorophyll": 115.06328574651785, "hustle": 0.5354431003324742, "leafguard": 0.004010567449964364}, "Items": {"focussash": 0.9178827996386567}, "Spreads": {"Jolly:4/252/0/0/0/252": 0.45597350369054857, "Jolly:0/252/4/0/0/252": 0.16084247802873636}, "Moves": ["afteryou", "closecombat", "sleeppowder", "solarblade"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.7520902132457161}, "Teammates": ["Indeedee-F", "Hatterene", "Torkoal", "Gallade", "Ursaluna", "Farigiraf"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Under sun, Lilligant wins the speed tie against every unboosted threat and even outspeeds +1 Dragonite, making it a nightmare for balance and bulky offense. Solar Blade + Close Combat yields perfect neutral coverage barring Aegislash and the rare Tera Fairy Corviknight, so traditional checks like Corviknight and Skarmory must fear Sleep Powder or a Tera Ghost-boosted Solar Blade. Against rain, Lilligant still outspeeds Swift Swim Kingdra and OHKOes with Solar Blade, but it must watch for Choice Specs Hurricane; Focus Sash guarantees it can trade. Trick Room is problematic because Lilligant’s Speed becomes irrelevant, so it relies on After You to let partners move first or simply fires off Sleep Powder to buy turns. Priority users like Kingambit and Dragonite are answered by Tera Ghost, which flips the Fake Out and Extreme Speed match-ups. Opposing sun mirrors come down to who keeps weather up; Lilligant can click Sleep Powder on enemy Torkoal or Venusaur to seize tempo. Overall, Lilligant’s match-up spread is polarized: it steamrolls slower, non-priority teams but folds to Trick Room or faster weather if sun is lost.</OUTPUT>

It compresses three roles: Chlorophyll sweeper, sleep inducer, and emergency speed control via After You. In the early game it fires off Sleep Powder to cripple counters or sets sun with Torkoal, then in the mid-game it cleans weakened teams with Solar Blade and Close Combat. After You lets it serve as a “speed swap,” allowing slower but powerful partners like Ursaluna or Choice Specs Torkoal to move immediately against faster foes or in Trick Room. Because it demands sun to function, Lilligant is never a standalone threat; instead it is the spearhead of a weather-based offense that seeks to trade efficiently, keep sun active, and finish games before opposing weather or Room goes up.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Indeedee-F and Farigiraf are natural partners, providing Follow Me / Psychic Terrain to block priority and let Lilligant set up or fire off attacks safely. Torkoal is mandatory for sun, offering Stealth Rock and Lava Plume chip that softens targets for Lilligant’s Solar Blade. Hatterene forms a potent anti-Room core: it deters Rocks and can OHKO Gholdengo with Mystical Fire, while Lilligant removes Tyranitar and Heatran that trouble Hatterene. Gallade shares a Fighting-type synergy, pressuring Steel- and Dark-types that resist Grass, while Lilligant removes Slowbro and Toxapex for Gallade. Ursaluna is perhaps the most explosive teammate: After You lets the bear move immediately, firing off Choice Band-boosted Earthquakes or Headlong Rushes before the opponent can react. Together these Pokémon form a hyper-offensive sun core that trades aggressively, keeps hazards off, and ends games before opposing weather or Trick Room can stabilize.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Lilligant-Hisui": {"Abilities": {"chlorophyll": 115.06328574651785, "hustle": 0.5354431003324742, "leafguard": 0.004010567449964364}, "Items": {"focussash": 0.9178827996386567}, "Spreads": {"Jolly:4/252/0/0/0/252": 0.45597350369054857, "Jolly:0/252/4/0/0/252": 0.16084247802873636}, "Moves": ["afteryou", "closecombat", "sleeppowder", "solarblade"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.7520902132457161}, "Teammates": ["Indeedee-F", "Hatterene", "Torkoal", "Gallade", "Ursaluna", "Farigiraf"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Trick Room is the single biggest counter: under Room, Lilligant’s 115 Speed becomes a liability, and its frailty means it often dies before moving. Priority users that can hit through Ghost—namely Shadow Sneak Kingambit and Sucker Punch Meowscarada—can pick off Lilligant even after Tera. Faster weather, especially Choice Specs Hurricane Kingdra in rain, can OHKO through Sash if sun is lost. Corviknight with Tera Fairy avoids the 2HKO from +2 Solar Blade and can retalify with Iron Head or set up Tailwind. Aegislash is one of the only Pokémon that naturally resists both STAB and Close Combat, though it must watch for Sleep Powder on the switch. Finally, because Lilligant relies on Focus Sash, any form of residual damage—Stealth Rock, Sand, or Burns—breaks Sash and leaves it vulnerable to faster scarfers. Keeping sun active and hazards off is therefore non-negotiable; if Torkoal dies or rain goes up, Lilligant’s threat level plummets.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Hydreigon": {"Abilities": {"levitate": 104.44927483050945}, "Items": {"safetygoggles": 0.25781211811808485, "lifeorb": 0.2085363811107098, "covertcloak": 0.15918720482782248}, "Spreads": {"Timid:0/0/0/252/4/252": 0.16572238987605903}, "Moves": ["dracometeor", "snarl", "protect", "darkpulse"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.4698042223214163, "fire": 0.17874746542420109}, "Teammates": ["Sneasler", "Amoonguss", "Incineroar", "Gholdengo", "Ursaluna", "Porygon2"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Hydreigon is a fast, specially offensive Levitate user that thrives in the current format as a pivoting special attacker and speed-control enabler. With near-exclusive use of Levitate, it ignores Spikes and Earthquake spam, letting it act as a soft check to Landorus-T and Lando-I while firing off STAB Draco Meteor and Dark Pulse. Safety Goggles variants ignore Amoonguss Rage Powder and Spore, letting it pick off or cripple the mushroom cleanly, whereas Life Orb boosts its already solid damage output and Covert Cloak blanks incoming Snarls, Icy Winds and Fake Tears. Tera Ghost removes its Fighting weakness, blocks Extreme Speed and gives it a Ghost STAMP on its own Draco, while Tera Fire flips the Ice and Fairy match-ups and punitshes Steel-type switches. Timid 252/252 is the only serious spread, guaranteeing it outspeeds the crowded base-100 scarf tier and slower Dragons while still hitting like a truck after a Draco drop. It fits most comfortably on balance and BO structures that appreciate a pivot that can both dish and spread Snarl chip, and its most common partners—Sneasler, Amoonguss, Incineroar, Gholdengo, Ursaluna and Porygon2—form a sturdy core that covers every offensive type and every speed tier in the metagame.</OUTPUT>

input:
Draft the 'full_analysis' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Hydreigon": {"Abilities": {"levitate": 104.44927483050945}, "Items": {"safetygoggles": 0.25781211811808485, "lifeorb": 0.2085363811107098, "covertcloak": 0.15918720482782248}, "Spreads": {"Timid:0/0/0/252/4/252": 0.16572238987605903}, "Moves": ["dracometeor", "snarl", "protect", "darkpulse"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.4698042223214163, "fire": 0.17874746542420109}, "Teammates": ["Sneasler", "Amoonguss", "Incineroar", "Gholdengo", "Ursaluna", "Porygon2"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Hydreigon’s main draw is the combination of high special attack, workable speed tier and Levitate, which together let it act as both a breaker and a pivot. Draco Meteor is still the strongest spammable Dragon move in the tier; after a drop it still 2HKOes most neutral targets and cleanly OHKOes frailer offensive Pokémon such as Chi-Yu, Iron Moth and opposing Hydreigon. Dark Pulse provides perfect neutral coverage alongside Draco, flinches and breaks Psychic Terrain, and is crucial for hitting Aegislash, Gholdengo and Indeedee-F for super-effective damage. Snarl is what pushes Hydreigon from a simple attacker into a support pivot: dropping both opponents’ special attack by one stage turns many 2HKOs into 3HKOs, protects frail partners such as Sneasler from taking lethal special hits, and gives the team pseudo-“intimidate” versus special attackers. Protect is mandatory doubles glue, letting it scout choice locks, stall out Tailwind or Trick Room turns, and recover a little health with Leftovers-style items. Safety Goggles is the most common item because Amoonguss is on roughly every third team: ignoring Rage Powder and Spore means Hydreigon can click Draco or Snarl into the mushroom without fear, forcing the opponent to either double-target the dragon or risk losing their redirector. Life Orb is still popular for the immediate power it adds, turning many 2HKOs into OHKOs (notably OHKOing 0 HP Gholdengo with Dark Pulse after rocks). Covert Cloak is a tech that has risen in usage alongside the popularity of Snarl Mirror matches, Icy Wind spam and Fake Tears: by ignoring secondary effects it essentially gives Hydreigon a free pass to ignore speed control and special drops, letting it keep its offensive pressure throughout longer games. Tera Ghost is the most common because it removes the only 4× weakness (Fighting) and turns the dragon into a spinblocker that also dodes Extreme Speed from Dragonite and opposing Ursaluna. Tera Fire is the second most common, flipping the Fairy and Ice match-ups and roasting Kingambit, Corviknight and Gholdengo on the switch. Timid 252/252 is the only relevant EV spread: it outspeeds Jolly Chien-Pao, scarf Garchomp and Modest Iron Moth while guaranteeing the OHKO on 0 HP Gholdengo with Dark Pulse after Stealth Rock. No bulk investment is run because the dragon’s bulk is merely average and its role is to hit first and hit hard; any bulk investment causes it to miss key KOs and speed-ties it cannot afford to lose.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Hydreigon": {"Abilities": {"levitate": 104.44927483050945}, "Items": {"safetygoggles": 0.25781211811808485, "lifeorb": 0.2085363811107098, "covertcloak": 0.15918720482782248}, "Spreads": {"Timid:0/0/0/252/4/252": 0.16572238987605903}, "Moves": ["dracometeor", "snarl", "protect", "darkpulse"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.4698042223214163, "fire": 0.17874746542420109}, "Teammates": ["Sneasler", "Amoonguss", "Incineroar", "Gholdengo", "Ursaluna", "Porygon2"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Hydreigon is naturally checked by faster Fairy-types, notably Iron Valiant, Choice Scarf Sylveon and Choice Specs Indeedee-F, all of which outspeed and OHKO with Moonblast or Dazzling Gleam. bulky Fairies such as Clefable and Azumarill can stomach a Draco and retaliate, though they dislike Snarl chip. Ice-types such as Chien-Pao and Choice Scarf Galarian-Darmanitan outspeed and KO, but both dislike switching into Draco or Dark Pulse. Steel-types such as Kingambit and Corviknight can tank hits and either set up or U-turn out, though both lose to Tera Fire variants. Faster Dragons such as Dragapult and Roaring Moon outspeed and KO, but neither enjoys switching into Draco Meteor. Priority users such as Bisharp and Kingambit can pick off a chipped Hydreigon with Sucker Punch, but this is unreliable if the dragon has a substitute or protects. Finally, any form of speed control—Tailwind, Trick Room or Icy Wind—immediately flips the match-up, turning Hydreigon from a threat into a liability if it cannot KO the setter. Conversely, Hydreigon pressures most slower special attackers, bulky Waters and Steels, and any team that relies on Amoonguss or Indeedee-F for redirection. It also acts as a soft check to Landorus-T and Garchomp, ignoring Earthquake and threatening back with Draco or Ice-less coverage.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Hydreigon is a fast special attacker and pivot that doubles as speed-control deterrent and anti-redirect. It comes in early to mid-game to fire off powerful Draco Meteors, spread Snarls and wear down checks for its teammates. Once the opposing Fairy or Ice-type is removed or chipped, it can clean late-game with Dark Pulse flinches or a second Draco. Its Levitate ability lets it act as a Ground-immune pivot, bringing in frail partners such as Sneasler or Gholdengo safely versus Landorus-T or Garchomp. Safety Goggles variants are the team’s primary answer to Amoonguss, ignoring Spore and Rage Powder while either OHKOing the mushroom or forcing it to switch. Snarl drops let it support bulkier set-up sweepers such as Ursaluna or Kingambit by neutering opposing special attackers. Tera Ghost turns it into a spinblocker and Extreme Speed absorber for teams that rely on hazards or priority, while Tera Fire gives it a mid-game wallbreaking angle versus Steel and Grass teams. In short, Hydreigon is a Swiss-army knife that compresses the roles of special breaker, pivot, anti-redirect and speed-control check into one slot.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Hydreigon fits best on balance and bulky-offense cores that appreciate a fast special attacker that can also pivot and spread chip. Sneasler is its most common partner: the poison ape baits in Psychic- and Fairy-types for Hydreigon to exploit, while Hydreigon removes Amoonguss and Flying-types that bother Sneasler. Amoonguss itself is another staple teammate: the mushroom provides redirection and status, while Hydreigon removes opposing Gholdengo and Tornadus-T that threaten Amoonguss. Incineroar forms a classic Dark-Fire-Grass core, providing Intimidate, Parting Shot and Fake Out to give Hydreigon free switch-ins and to soften physical threats. Gholdengo blocks hazards and spreads status, while Hydreigon removes opposing Steels and Ghosts that trouble the golden magnet. Ursaluna appreciates Snarl chip and the removal of Corviknight and Toxapex, while Hydreigon appreciates Ursaluna’s ability to break past special walls such as Blissey and Ting-Lu. Finally, Porygon2 provides Trick Room control and Ice Beam coverage, while Hydreigon removes Fighting-types that threaten the duck and provides a fast mode outside Trick Room. Together these Pokémon form a sturdy core that covers every offensive type and every speed tier, letting the pilot choose between fast pressure or slow bulk depending on the opponent.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Magmar carves a unique niche in VGC as an unevolved Eviolite support, leveraging its respectable bulk after the boost to spam Follow Me, disrupt with Taunt, and spread burn chip via Flame Body. Its Fire-typing grants invaluable resists to common Fairy and Steel moves while letting it throw out STAB Heat Waves, making it a glue pivot that can both protect allies and contribute damage. The data shows players overwhelmingly prefer Vital Spirit (82.6 %) to ignore sleep from Amoonguss, Tapu, and Lilligant, and almost every set runs the same four moves—Follow Me, Heat Wave, Protect, Taunt—indicating a very rigid but effective support role. Tera Ghost is the only meaningful Tera choice, turning Magmar into a Normal- and Fighting-immune slot that still keeps its Fire STAB and can dodge Fake Out, letting it stick on the field longer to redirect.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Magmar": {"Abilities": {"flamebody": 5.2206517350860375, "vitalspirit": 82.57178775449528}, "Items": {"eviolite": 0.9997137598310797}, "Spreads": {"Bold:244/0/212/4/4/44": 0.30235378956200964}, "Moves": ["followme", "heatwave", "protect", "taunt"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.6876397424595694}, "Teammates": ["Dragapult", "Ninetales-Alola", "Sneasler", "Kingambit", "Basculegion", "Rillaboom"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Eviolite Magmar sits in a sweet spot of 65 / 57 / 85 defenses that become 65 / 85 / 127 after the item, letting it survive most unboosted super-effective hits with proper HP investment. Follow Me is the star of the set: redirecting Draco Meteors, Behemoth Blades, and Glide damage away from frail sweepers such as Dragapult or Basculegion while simultaneously fishing for Flame Body burns on contact attackers. Heat Wave supplies consistent spread damage, chipping Sash users and breaking Focus Sashes on the likes of Indeedee or Tornadus while still dealing meaningful neutral damage to common Steel and Grass threats. Taunt shuts down Trick Room, Tailwind, and recovery, giving Magmar game against hard-room squads and stall cores. Protect is mandatory for stalling speed-control turns, scouting Choice locks, and keeping Magmar healthy enough to redirect again. Vital Spirit is the ability of choice because the current metagame is saturated with Spore and Lovely Kiss, and being able to switch into Amoonguss Rage Powder without fear is a huge swing. The listed spread (Bold 244 HP / 212 Def / 44 Spe) bumps physical bulk while outspeeding neutral-nature base 70s such as Breloom and uninvested Tapu Fini, letting Magmar Taunt before they move. Tera Ghost removes the Fighting weakness, blocks Fake Out and Extreme Speed, and makes Magmar immune to Explosion and Self-Destruct, which are seeing a resurgence on Regieleki and Azelf leads. In best-of-three, opponents must guess whether Magmar will Tera to stick around or keep its original typing to preserve Fire resistances, giving the Magmar player a layer of mid-series flexibility.</OUTPUT>

It also pressures Steel-heavy teams—Zacian, Kingambit, Gholdengo—because Heat Wave ignores Intimidate and breaks Sturdy/Focus Sash. Against Trick Room, Taunt plus Follow Me lets Magmar stall turns while stopping setters like Hatterene or Porygon2. Conversely, spread-rockers such as Landorus-T and Tyranitar threaten OHKOs with Earthquake and Rock Slide, and faster Taunt users like Tornadus or Meowscarada can silence Magmar before it moves. Water-types—especially Tailwind Kyogre or Palafin—can tank Heat Waves and retaliate with double-target surges, so Magmar needs a partner that can KO or neuter them quickly. Finally, Mold Breaker Dragapult ignores Flame Body, and strong special attackers such as Flutter Mane or Iron Bundle can 2HKO through Eviolite if Magmar does not Terastallize.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Gyarados’s biggest draw is the combination of Intimidate and Dragon Dance, compressing team support and win condition into one slot. Intimidate immediately weakens the plethora of physical attackers in the format—Great Tusk, Kingambit, Chien-Pao, opposing Gyarados—buying free turns to set up or allow partners to position. After a Dragon Dance, its respectable 81/100 offenses translate into 358 Attack and 284 Speed, outspeeding +1 252 Roaring Moon and KOing bulk-neutral targets with +1 Tera Dragon Scale Shot. Waterfall remains the reliable STAB choice, 2HKOing most Incineroar and Garganacl variants while flinching slower walls. Taunt is invaluable speed control insurance, preventing Trick Room from Indeedee-F/Armarouge or Tailwind from Corviknight/Talonflame, and shutting down Recover spam from Dondozo or Toxapex. Protect is non-negotiable in doubles, letting Gyarados dodge Fake Out, stall Dynamax turns, or enable ally spread moves. The chosen item, Loaded Dice, guarantees five hits on Scale Shot, turning it into a 120 BP Dragon move that breaks Substitute, Focus Sash, and Sturdy while raising Speed—essentially a Dragon Dance in move form. Tera Dragon synergizes perfectly: it removes the 4× Electric weakness, turns Ferrothorn’s Power Whip into a resisted hit, and flips Kingambit’s Sucker Punch from super-effective to resisted. With Scald for burn pressure, Icy Wind for speed control, Recover for longevity, and Protect for stalling, it fits best on slower, bulk-leaning teams that appreciate passive chip and speed control. <DATA>{"Milotic": {"Abilities": {"competitive": 85.1373639330936, "marvelscale": 1.295122845668919, "cutecharm": 0.04416067243522043}, "Items": {"safetygoggles": 0.15954063797277154, "leftovers": 0.5511803256686435}, "Spreads": {"Calm:252/0/92/4/68/92": 0.34295101995181576}, "Moves": ["scald", "protect", "recover", "icywind"], "Tera Types": {"dragon": 0.17940131715751897, "grass": 0.4176254962271234, "poison": 0.3535693306075453}, "Teammates": ["Tyranitar", "Gholdengo", "Rillaboom", "Incineroar", "Sneasler", "Dragonite"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Milotic’s stat-line and movepool push it toward a defensive support role rather than an offensive one. Base 95/79/125 bulk (HP/Def/SpD) is excellent for a Water-type, and when paired with 252 Calm investment plus 68 SpD EVs it comfortably lives most super-effective special hits, even when Terastallized into a defensive typing. Competitive punishes Intimidate users such as Incineroar, Landorus-T, and Arcanine, turning their signature abilities into +2 SpA boosts that make Scald and Icy Wind considerably more threatening. Recover + Protect is the gold-standard for stalling turns, gaining Leftovers recovery, weather chip, or poison damage while scouting choice-locked foes. Icy Wind provides speed control without relying on speed-tiers, letting slower partners such as Tyranitar or Gholdengo move before key threats on the following turn. Safety Goggles variants ignore Amoonguss and Breloom spores, while Leftovers variants accumulate incremental recovery that, with Recover, can outlast Dynamons and Terastallized attackers. Tera Grass flips the Electric and Grass matchups, Tera Poison removes Fairy and Grass weaknesses while giving Toxic-immunity, and Tera Dragon provides a neutral defensive profile that only fears Dragon and Fairy, both of which Milotic can play around with burns and speed control. The listed teammates suggest a balanced or semi-room archetype: Tyranitar sets sand and breaks Flying-types, Gholdengo blocks status and spreads hazard chip, Rillaboom provides priority Grassy Glide and heals Milotic via Grassy Terrain, Incineroar forms a double-Intimidate deterrent alongside Milotic, Sneasler enjoys Icy Wind speed control to land Dire Claw shenanigans, and Dragonite benefits from Milotic’s ability to remove Ice-type pressure with Scald burns and Tera Grass.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Milotic is solid into physical attackers that rely on Intimidate, notably Incineroar, Landorus-T, and Arcanine, turning their primary form of pressure into set-up fodder. Against Rain, Scald burns and Tera Grass neuter offensive Swampert, Barraskewda, and Ludicolo, though it must watch for Thunder or Freeze-Dry from Tornadus or Pelipper. Sun teams are trickier: Venusaur’s Sludge Bomb and Torkoal’s Eruption can 2HKO even bulky Milotic, so Tera Poison or timely Terastallization plus Icy Wind support is required. Trick Room variants that pack Stakataka, Hatterene, or Indeedee-F can ignore Milotic’s speed control, forcing it to Recover-stall turns or rely on partner redirection. Electric Terrain teams carrying Pincurchin or Iron Thorns threaten with Thunder or Wild Charge; Tera Grass removes the Water weakness but still demands caution versus Iron Thorns’ Quake. Fairy-types like Flutter Mane, Sylveon, and Iron Valiant can dent Milotic with Moonblast or Spirit Break, yet they dislike burns and the subsequent speed drops from Icy Wind. Overall, Milotic is a soft check to many physical and Water-weak threats but must Terastallize or receive partner support to handle strong special attackers or super-effective coverage.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>With Neutralizing Gas active 85 % of the time, Galarian Weezing single-handedly invalidates many metagame staples: Incineroar’s Intimidate, Rage Powder users, Grim Neigh, Quark Drive, and even opposing weather or Surge abilities all vanish the moment it hits the field. Its modest 116 HP / 116 SpD spread with 196 EVs in Special Attack guarantees that it OHKOes standard +1 Dragapult with Strange Steam while always surviving Life Orb Garchomp’s Tera-Fire Tera Blast or Choice Specs Kilowattrel’s Tera-Hurricane. Protect is mandatory on a Pokémon that draws so much aggression, and Sludge Bomb gives it a second STAB that cleanly knocks out opposing Fairy-weak threats such as Iron Bundle or Azumarill. The 76 Speed EVs creep uninvested base 100s like Togekiss and Sylveon, ensuring it fires off its spread attack before going down. Tera choices are matchup-dependent: Water removes its Fire weakness and flips the script on Heatran and Torkoal, Fire lets it absorb Will-o-Wisp and sun-boosted Heat Waves while punishing Steel-types, and Ghost grants it a crucial immunity to Fake Out and Extreme Speed, letting it serve as an emergency stop to Dragonite and opposing priority sweepers.</OUTPUT>

Versus Trick Room, it shuts down Indeedee’s Psychic Terrain and Hatterene’s Magic Bounce, allowing your own Taunt or Spore users to function. Against Dragapult or opposing Fairy-spam, its double STAB spread moves apply immediate pressure, and because Neutralizing Gas stops Clear Body it can drop the ghost’s Special Defense with Strange Steam’s confusion chance.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Blaziken": {"Abilities": {"speedboost": 82.32496866050606, "blaze": 0.3522233645198068}, "Items": {"focussash": 0.9499774367810839}, "Spreads": {"Timid:0/0/0/252/4/252": 0.29476891134183725, "Timid:4/0/0/252/0/252": 0.15334159968024438, "Modest:0/0/0/252/4/252": 0.2941468939811691}, "Moves": ["protect", "heatwave", "aurasphere", "coaching"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.17175828197848214, "fire": 0.5681791297138146, "stellar": 0.21671798993465347}, "Teammates": ["Rillaboom", "Kingambit", "Electabuzz", "Dragapult", "Dondozo", "Ninetales-Alola"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Blaziken’s claim to fame in VGC 2024 is the combination of Speed Boost and a 110 base-power spread Heat Wave that becomes a 156 BP STAB nuke under Tera Fire. After a single Protect it reaches +1, outspeeding the entire unboosted metagame, and at +2 it outpaces even +1 Chien-Pao or Choice Scarf Dragapult. Modest and Timid 252/252 spreads are equally common, trading immediate OHKO thresholds (Modest Tera Fire Heat Wave cleanly OHKOs 252 HP Gholdengo and 252 HP Kingambit) for the Timid speed tier that always wins the mirror. Aura Sphere gives perfect neutral coverage alongside Fire, nailing Heatran, Kingambit and Tyranitar while ignoring Wide Guard. Coaching is the surprise tech that turns Blaziken into a dual-role piece: after a Protect speed boost it can click Coaching on the predicted switch, instantly granting +1 Atk/+1 Def to partners such as Rillaboom or Kingambit, enabling them to pick up KOs they otherwise could not (e.g., +1 Kingambit Sucker Punch OHKOes 252 HP 4 Def Indeedee-F). Focus Sash is mandatory because 80/80 physical bulk and 70 special bulk mean any neutral STAB or super-effective hit breaks it; nevertheless, Sash guarantees at least one Speed Boost cycle and prevents priority revenge kills from Shadow Sneak, Aqua Jet or Sucker Punch. Tera Ghost is the third-most common option, letting Blaziken block Fake Out, Extreme Speed and Shadow Sneak while maintaining offensive Fire-type power, whereas Tera Stellar is taken for pure neutral coverage and the 1.2× boost to both STABs when Coaching is not needed. The data show almost no Blaze usage, confirming that Speed Boost is the sole reason to justify Blaziken over other Fire-types like Torkoal or Chi-Yu.</OUTPUT>

It struggles into hard Trick Room (Hatterene+Indeedee-F or Mimikyu setters) because it cannot afford to Protect in front of a turn-one Room, and Follow Me+Storm Drain Tatsugiri+Shellos completely blanks Heat Wave while setting up. Rain teams with Pelipper and Barraskeweda force Blaziken to Tera Ghost or risk a 100% OHKO from Rain-boosted Liquidation. Tailwind from Talonflame or Murkrow lets opposing attackers outspeed even +2 Blaziken, so it must either slot its own Tailwind partner or run Wide Guard support to block opposing Hurricanes and Rock Slides. Priority from Kingambit or Dragonite can break Sash before a second Speed Boost, so Blaziken appreciates Psychic Terrain or a Follow Me user to buy the extra turn.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Smeargle": {"Abilities": {"moody": 66.43973586153614, "owntempo": 3.0908120246783524, "technician": 3.1768340965196846}, "Items": {"focussash": 0.8727100697139817}, "Spreads": {"Timid:236/0/20/0/0/252": 0.28198162841364505}, "Moves": ["spore", "followme", "spikyshield", "decorate"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.7931796075777103}, "Teammates": ["Rillaboom", "Incineroar", "Gholdengo", "Whimsicott", "Kommo-o", "Arcanine-Hisui"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Smeargle’s niche in VGC 2024 lies in its unrivaled movepool and the ability to turn Moody’s RNG into game-winning momentum. Moody repeatedly boosts and drops stats at the end of every turn; with Evasion raises, Smeargle can become virtually untouchable, while stacking Speed or Special Attack boosts turns it into an unexpected win condition via Stored Power or a decorated ally. Spore remains the only 100% accurate sleep in the format, instantly removing a threat for 1–3 turns and forcing the opponent to play 2-v-1 or switch, both of which generate tempo. Follow Me redirects single-target attacks, protecting frail sweepers like Gholdengo or Kommo-o while they set up or attack. Spiky Shield punishes contact moves and stalls Dynamax turns, and Decorate provides the single largest attack boost in the game, turning physical or special attackers into unstoppable forces. The chosen spread outspeeds max-speed base 100s (e.g., Jolly Garchomp) while allocating 20 EVs in bulk to survive modest spread moves. Focus Sash guarantees survival of any one hit, ensuring Spore or Follow Me goes off. Tera Ghost is preferred to block Fake Out, Extreme Speed, and Mach Punch, preserving sash and allowing Smeargle to continue supporting. Despite 20 base stats across the board, Smeargle’s presence warps the game: opponents must carry Safety Goggles or priority Taunt to bypass Spore, and they often overcommit to double-targeting Smeargle, freeing its partner to set up. Moody’s randomness can backfire—drops in the wrong stat or early wake rolls—but the upside of snowballing evasion and speed is so high that many players accept the variance. Overall, Smeargle is a high-risk, high-reward support that compresses sleep, redirection, stat passing, and stalling into one slot, enabling hyper-offense and balance alike.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Smeargle": {"Abilities": {"moody": 66.43973586153614, "owntempo": 3.0908120246783524, "technician": 3.1768340965196846}, "Items": {"focussash": 0.8727100697139817}, "Spreads": {"Timid:236/0/20/0/0/252": 0.28198162841364505}, "Moves": ["spore", "followme", "spikyshield", "decorate"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.7931796075777103}, "Teammates": ["Rillaboom", "Incineroar", "Gholdengo", "Whimsicott", "Kommo-o", "Arcanine-Hisui"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Smeargle excels against setup or slow teams that rely on single-target damage: Follow Me neuters Urshifu-Rapid-Strike, Chien-Pao, and Kingambit, while Spore disables bulky walls like Amoonguss, Toxapex, or Dondozo. Moody snowballing becomes problematic for opponents lacking Haze or Clear Smog, as evasion boosts render Choice-locked attackers useless. Against hyper-offense, Smeargle must get off a quick Spore or redirect to avoid being doubled into sash range; faster Taunt users like Whimsicott or Grimmsnarl can shut it down, and Safety Goggles holders such as Iron Hands or Gholdengo ignore sleep. Terrain wars matter: Rillaboom’s Grassy Terrain halves Spore’s accuracy, so Smeargle prefers to pair with Rillaboom itself or overwrite terrain with Incineroar’s Sunny Day or Whimsicott’s priority Sunny Day. Ghost-typing helps versus Fighting and Normal spam, but Dark-types like Chien-Pao and Kingambit threaten with Sucker Punch or Knock Off, making prediction crucial. In tailwind matchups, Smeargle can underspeed to ensure Spore lands after tailwind fades, or use Follow Me to protect its own tailwind setter. Overall, Smeargle wins the war of attrition but loses to immediate pressure, status-blocking items, or critical hits through sash.</OUTPUT>

Triple Axel gives it a wide neutral coverage, and Protean lets it flip its typing on demand to dodge super-effective hits or gain resistances. Despite a shallow movepool and average offenses, 123 base Speed places it above the crowded 110–120 tier, letting it outrun Gholdengo, Dragapult, and most Lando-T. Its usage sits at a modest ~9 %, but the raw utility of guaranteed criticals and item removal keeps it on the radar for offensive cores that need a speedy Grass breaker.</OUTPUT>

input:
Write the 'full_analysis' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Meowscarada": {"Abilities": {"protean": 9.472554673197823, "overgrow": 63.10497979025583}, "Items": {"focussash": 0.7795504405267443}, "Spreads": {"Jolly:4/252/0/0/0/252": 0.1758555130867061, "Jolly:0/252/0/0/4/252": 0.47116811034984724}, "Moves": ["flowertrick", "knockoff", "protect", "tripleaxel"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.2571914773460648, "grass": 0.20018681784161932, "stellar": 0.28468332237046734}, "Teammates": ["Dragapult", "Incineroar", "Primarina", "Annihilape", "Ursaluna-Bloodmoon", "Weezing-Galar"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Meowscarada’s offensive niche is defined by Flower Trick: 70 BP, perfect accuracy, and a guaranteed critical hit, meaning it effectively attacks with 105 BP that ignores opposing Intimidate, Defense boosts, and screens. This alone makes it one of the most reliable answers to Amoonguss, Garganacl, and bulky Water-types like Toxapex and Rotom-Wash in formats where they appear. Knock Off is standard for item disruption and 97.5 BP against anything still holding an item, while Triple Axel (120 BP effective after three hits) punishes common Grass resists such as Corviknight, Togekiss, and Dragonite. Protect is almost mandatory on a Pokémon that invites double-targeting because of its paper-thin bulk. Protean is chosen on roughly 9 % of teams, letting Meowscarada become a pure Grass, Dark, or Ice type at will to flip matchups—turning into an Ice-type to survive a Draco Meteor from Dragapult, or into a Dark-type to dodge Ghost STAB. Overgrow, the ability picked two-thirds of the time, is a safety net that boosts Grass power when HP falls below a third, occasionally clinching KOs with Flower Trick when Protean has already been burned. The terrain-agnostic nature of its moves means it performs equally under Psychic Terrain, Grassy Terrain, or in Trick Room (though it hates the latter). EV spreads are almost always 252 Atk / 252 Spe Jolly; a handful drop four EVs into HP or Defense to survive specific rolls, but the difference is marginal. Focus Sash is the only item shown, underscoring how desperately it needs a one-time cushion to set up or attack twice. Tera choices are split: Tera Ghost removes Ghost weaknesses and grants perfect neutral coverage alongside Trick + Knock, Tera Grass boosts Flower Trick to nuclear levels under Overgrow, and Tera Stellar provides a one-time nuke option while keeping Protean flexibility. The absence of bulkier spreads or support items suggests Meowscarada is viewed almost exclusively as a hit-and-run attacker rather than a pivot.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Meowscarada": {"Abilities": {"protean": 9.472554673197823, "overgrow": 63.10497979025583}, "Items": {"focussash": 0.7795504405267443}, "Spreads": {"Jolly:4/252/0/0/0/252": 0.1758555130867061, "Jolly:0/252/0/0/4/252": 0.47116811034984724}, "Moves": ["flowertrick", "knockoff", "protect", "tripleaxel"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.2571914773460648, "grass": 0.20018681784161932, "stellar": 0.28468332237046734}, "Teammates": ["Dragapult", "Incineroar", "Primarina", "Annihilape", "Ursaluna-Bloodmoon", "Weezing-Galar"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Meowscarada’s speed tier lets it revenge-kill or trade with the majority of the metagame that sits at 110–120 base Speed, including Garchomp, Gholdengo, and opposing Dragapult. Flower Trick cleanly 2HKOes most bulky Waters and even 3HKOs max-defense Toxapex after Leftovers, while Knock Off cripples switch-ins like Corviknight and Rotom. Triple Axel flips the script on Flying-types that expect a Grass lock, doing 70–85 % to standard Togekiss and Yache Dragonite. Against offense, Meowscarada’s fragility is its downfall: any priority—especially Sucker Punch from Kingambit or First Impression from opposing Meowscarada—ends it after Sash is gone. It also folds to any status, particularly burn from Rotom-W or paralysis from Thunder Wave Togekiss. Trick Room teams render it useless, and Tailwind teams that boost slower powerhouses like Ursaluna-Bloodmoon can overpower it before it moves. Defensively, it resists Ground, Water, Electric, Grass, and Dark, but its dual weaknesses to Flying, Poison, Bug, Fire, Ice, and Fairy mean it struggles to switch in safely. In practice Meowscarada is brought in after a KO or via a slow U-turn/Volt Switch, fires off one or two attacks, and either retreats or faints.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Salamence’s greatest asset is the combination of Intimidate and Tailwind, compressing two of the most valuable forms of team support into one slot. After Intimidate, physical attackers such as Koraidon, Chien-Pao, or opposing Bloodmoon Ursaluna lose crucial KOs, while Tailwind flips the speed order for four turns, enabling slower powerhouses like Ursaluna-Bloodmoon, Gholdengo, or Tyranitar to move first. Draco Meteor remains a 130 BP nuke that removes Lugia, Kyogre, or opposing Dragons after chip, and Dual Wingbeat is a multi-hit spread move that cleanly knocks out Grass-types like Rillaboom or Amoonguss while circumventing Focus Sash. Protect is mandatory in doubles to stall Fake Out, dodge Zacian’s Behemoth Blade, or gain positioning. The given EV spread—Adamant 4/252/0/0/0/252—maximises Attack and Speed to ensure it OHKOes Calyrex Shadow with Tera Flying-boosted Dual Wingbeat and outspeeds +1 neutral-nature base 90s after Tailwind. Life Orb gives it the extra damage to secure 2HKOs on bulky restricted Pokémon, while Choice Scarf variants trade power for the ability to surprise opposing weather or speed-control teams. Tera Steel is the safest option, removing the 4× Ice weakness and granting a crucial Toxic immunity, but Tera Fire punts back Sun-boosted Fire moves and Tera Flying turns Dual Wingbeat into a nuclear spread option. Moxie sets exist but are rare; they require multiple KOs to snowball and are harder to pilot in the restricted-heavy format.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Salamence enjoys excellent matchups against Ground-weak or physically offensive cores. It walls Groudon’s Precipice Blades, forces Garchomp to Tera to avoid the OHKO from Draco Meteor, and shrugs off Iron Hands’ Fake Out + Close Combat thanks to Intimidate. Against Sun, it outspeeds and KOes Torkoal with Dual Wingbeat and can Tera Fire to take Overheat. Into Kyogre, it must beware Ice Beam but can Tailwind on the switch and dent the whale with Draco Meteor. Zacian remains problematic: without Intimidate drops, +1 Behemoth Blade cleanly OHKOes through Tera Steel, so positioning and Protect stalling are critical. Ice-type restricted Pokémon—Calyrex-Ice, Kyurem-White, or Chien-Pao—force mind-games: Tera Steel is mandatory to survive, but even then a Tera Ice Glacial Lance or Icicle Spear can still 2HKO. Trick-room semi-room squads that pack Mimikyu or Armarouge can ignore Tailwind and punish Salamence’s middling bulk, while faster Taunt users like Whimsicott or Iron Bundle prevent Tailwind entirely.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Salamence is a hybrid speed-control and offensive pivot. In team preview it is brought whenever the opponent leans on physical attackers or when your own win condition requires faster turns. Turn-one it either clicks Tailwind to enable slower breakers, or immediately threatens with Draco Meteor/Dual Wingbeat to remove problematic Grass or Dragon types. Mid-game it cycles in and out to re-apply Intimidate, using Protect to scout choice locks and preserve HP. Late-game, if Intimidate has sufficiently crippled the opposing board, Salamence can Tera and sweep with Dual Wingbeat, though its Attack stat is merely above-average rather than elite. Because it compresses Tailwind and Intimidate, it frees the second support slot for a screen setter or Fake Out user, allowing more flexible team structures.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>The most frequent partners—Rillaboom, Ursaluna-Bloodmoon, Annihilape, Alolan-Ninetales, Gholdengo and Tyranitar—form a balanced core that appreciates speed control and hates physical pressure. Rillaboom provides Grassy Terrain recovery and strong priority, while Salamence’s Tailwind lets it outpace opposing weather. Ursaluna-Bloodmoon’s enormous Special Attack but middling Speed becomes devastating under Tailwind, and Intimidate patches its poor physical bulk. Annihilape shares a Fighting resistance and can spread Bulk Up boosts while Salamence keeps physical attackers at bay. Alolan-Ninetales sets Aurora Veil and brings Snow, turning Salamence’s Ice weakness into a manageable 2× and giving it a pseudo-bulk boost. Gholdengo blocks opposing Tailwind and enjoys Intimidate support to survive Ground and Dark moves. Finally, Tyranitar’s Sand boosts its Special Defense, and the pair can alternate Intimidate and Sand chip to wear down foes. Tera synergy is notable: Salamence can Tera Steel to cover Tyranitar’s Fairy weakness, while Tyranitar can Tera Dark to remove Ghost-type counters for Gholdengo.</OUTPUT>

Add Ursaluna-Bloodmoon as the restricted powerhouse that appreciates Tailwind and Intimidate. Tera plans are equally flexible: Salamence Tera Steel to wall Ice, Tyranitar Tera Dark to remove Ghosts, and Ursaluna Tera Fairy to resist Dragon and Dark. Bring this squad when you expect a lot of Groudon, Koraidon, or Iron Hands and want a single Pokémon to handle speed control, physical pressure, and spread damage all at once.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Dusclops": {"Abilities": {"frisk": 41.55591641649848, "pressure": 22.17139953377184}, "Items": {"eviolite": 0.9997330527110887}, "Spreads": {"Sassy:252/0/4/0/252/0": 0.3824434964869738, "Sassy:244/0/188/0/76/0": 0.25313092723104363}, "Moves": ["painsplit", "trickroom", "willowisp", "nightshade"], "Tera Types": {"dark": 0.3262669367660753, "grass": 0.6391435460370974}, "Teammates": ["Ursaluna", "Torkoal", "Tyranitar", "Ursaluna-Bloodmoon", "Sneasler", "Annihilape"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Dusclops’s niche is unrivaled: a ghost that is immune to Fake Out, resists common spread moves like Earthquake, and reaches 30/130/130 bulk after Eviolite. This lets it stomach +2 Crunch from Chien-Pao, Life Orb Flutter Mane Moonblast, and even Choice Band Palafin Jet Punch, always firing Trick Room in return. Night Shade provides guaranteed 100 HP damage to anything not named Chansey, Pain Split turns 50/50 HP wars into guaranteed recovery versus bulky foes, and Will-O-Wisp neuters physical set-up sweepers like Kingambit, Chien-Pao, and opposing Ursaluna. The two showcased EV spreads highlight two philosophies: 252/4/252 maximises special bulk while still avoiding 2HKOs from key special attackers, whereas 244/188/76 hits a jump point in defence, guaranteeing survival against Life Orb Earthquake from Great Tusk and allowing Dusclops to stay on the field longer to click support moves. Tera Grass is preferred to remove the water weakness and tank Surfs from partners, but Tera Dark is rising in usage to dodge Rage Fist boosts from Annihilape and gain a crucial Ghost/Dark defensive profile versus opposing ghost types. With 99.9% of sets holding Eviolite, deviation is practically nonexistent; the item is simply too valuable to forgo.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Dusclops": {"Abilities": {"frisk": 41.55591641649848, "pressure": 22.17139953377184}, "Items": {"eviolite": 0.9997330527110887}, "Spreads": {"Sassy:252/0/4/0/252/0": 0.3824434964869738, "Sassy:244/0/188/0/76/0": 0.25313092723104363}, "Moves": ["painsplit", "trickroom", "willowisp", "nightshade"], "Tera Types": {"dark": 0.3262669367660753, "grass": 0.6391435460370974}, "Teammates": ["Ursaluna", "Torkoal", "Tyranitar", "Ursaluna-Bloodmoon", "Sneasler", "Annihilape"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Dusclops is at its best versus hyper-offensive teams reliant on speed and priority: Flutter Mane, Iron Bundle, Chien-Pao, and Kingambit all struggle to OHKO it, allowing room to go up and the slower backline to reverse pressure. Against other Trick Room teams it becomes a 50/50 speed-tie of who sets last, but Will-O-Wisp and Night Shade give it an edge in the war of attrition. Stall and bulky Tail-Room squads can overwhelm it with Taunt users like Murkrow or status spreaders such as Amoonguss, but even then Dusclops can Tera out of Spore vulnerability and click Pain Split to stay healthy. Sun and Rain can dent it with boosted Surfs and Overheats, yet Tera Grass patches the water weakness and sun-boosted Heat Wave from Torkoal is a common partner move that opponents must respect. In short, Dusclops dictates pace versus fast teams and becomes a walling nuisance versus slower ones, but it loathes Taunt, critical hits and strong dark-type STAB that can muscle past its Eviolite.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Dusclops": {"Abilities": {"frisk": 41.55591641649848, "pressure": 22.17139953377184}, "Items": {"eviolite": 0.9997330527110887}, "Spreads": {"Sassy:252/0/4/0/252/0": 0.3824434964869738, "Sassy:244/0/188/0/76/0": 0.25313092723104363}, "Moves": ["painsplit", "trickroom", "willowisp", "nightshade"], "Tera Types": {"dark": 0.3262669367660753, "grass": 0.6391435460370974}, "Teammates": ["Ursaluna", "Torkoal", "Tyranitar", "Ursaluna-Bloodmoon", "Sneasler", "Annihilape"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Dusclops is a pure support Pokémon whose only win condition is ensuring Trick Room goes up and remains active long enough for its teammates to dismantle the opponent. It leads in over 90% of games, immediately threatening room or a burn, and in the mid-game it pivots in repeatedly to reset room, absorb hits, and spread status. Its ghost typing lets it block Rapid Spin and ignore Fake Out, making it the premier partner for slow, hard-hitting titans that despise flinches. Offensively it contributes fixed 100 HP chunks via Night Shade and uses Pain Split to punish high-HP walls like Dondozo and Toxapex, turning its own lower HP into a resource. Max special bulk is favoured because most physical attackers fear Will-O-Wisp, but the physically defensive spread exists specifically to check Great Tusk, Kingambit and opposing Ursaluna under room. Tera is used reactively: Grass to flip water match-ups, Dark to dodge Rage Fist and ghost-targeting moves, and occasionally Normal to become immune to ghost attacks that threaten its slot. Throughout the match Dusclops is less a Pokémon and more a 50-HP-per-turn button that says “your strategy now plays in Trick Room.”</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Dusclops": {"Abilities": {"frisk": 41.55591641649848, "pressure": 22.17139953377184}, "Items": {"eviolite": 0.9997330527110887}, "Spreads": {"Sassy:252/0/4/0/252/0": 0.3824434964869738, "Sassy:244/0/188/0/76/0": 0.25313092723104363}, "Moves": ["painsplit", "trickroom", "willowisp", "nightshade"], "Tera Types": {"dark": 0.3262669367660753, "grass": 0.6391435460370974}, "Teammates": ["Ursaluna", "Torkoal", "Tyranitar", "Ursaluna-Bloodmoon", "Sneasler", "Annihilape"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Dusclops’s teammates are almost exclusively slow powerhouses that appreciate room and can cover its inability to hit dark or normal types for meaningful damage. Ursaluna and Bloodmoon Ursaluna form the core: both operate perfectly under room, break through every common wall, and appreciate burns on fighting types that threaten them. Torkoal provides sun-removed Eruption spam and removes water weakness for Dusclops with Tera Grass; in return Dusclops beats water absorb Gastrodon and Toxapex that trouble sun. Tyranitar offers a sand backbone, special bulk, and lures fighting moves that Dusclops can switch into; Will-O-Wisp neutles Iron Hands and Lucario that trouble TTar. Sneasler appreciates room for Dire Claw shenanigans and can beat Taunt users with Unburden pops, while Annihilape shares ghost/dark resists, stacks Rage Fist, and forms an impenetrable burn core with Dusclops. These cores are so standard that opponents often lead Taunt + dark type to stop room, meaning Dusclops itself needs ally redirection (Indeedee-F) or follow-me users like Togekiss to guarantee room versus anti-room techs. The synergy is simple: Dusclops sets room, allies murder everything, and Pain Split plus Eviolite ensure it can do so up to three times a game.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Dusclops": {"Abilities": {"frisk": 41.55591641649848, "pressure": 22.17139953377184}, "Items": {"eviolite": 0.9997330527110887}, "Spreads": {"Sassy:252/0/4/0/252/0": 0.3824434964869738, "Sassy:244/0/188/0/76/0": 0.25313092723104363}, "Moves": ["painsplit", "trickroom", "willowisp", "nightshade"], "Tera Types": {"dark": 0.3262669367660753, "grass": 0.6391435460370974}, "Teammates": ["Ursaluna", "Torkoal", "Tyranitar", "Ursaluna-Bloodmoon", "Sneasler", "Annihilape"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>The surest way to beat Dusclops is to deny Trick Room: Taunt from Murkrow, Whimsicott or Grimmsnarl stops room outright, forcing it to burn or Night Shade while faster attackers pile on damage. Strong dark-type STAB from Choice Band Kingambit, Chien-Pao or Tyranitar can 2HKO through Eviolite, especially if they avoid burn. Critical hits bypass bulk investment and happen more than you expect; a crit Crunch or Knock Off usually spells the end. Status in general cripples it: Toxic from Amoonguss or Toxapex puts it on a timer, and without leftovers Pain Split can only stall so long. Opposing ghost types like Aegislash and opposing Dusclops can turn room into a coin flip, and if they carry Imprison they block Trick Room entirely. Finally, multi-hit moves such as Population Bomb from Maushold or Baxcalibur Icicle Crash through potential Rocky Helmet chip can KO before Pain Split recovers. If room is already up, strong spread attackers like Chi-Yu or Palafin can overwhelm its teammates faster than Dusclops can reset, so preventing the second room is just as important as stopping the first.</OUTPUT>

Dusclops leads with Indeedee-F; Follow Me redirects Taunt or dark-type attacks while Psychic Terrain blocks priority, guaranteeing room. Torkoal clicks Eruption under sun or Heat Wave in neutral weather to nuke fast threats, while both Ursaluna forms clean late-game. Kingambit occupies the last slot as a secondary Trick Room attacker that can also function outside room if the opponent denies it, and provides Sucker Punch insurance versus faster threats once room ends. EV spreads are standard: Dusclops uses the special bulky spread, Torkoal runs 252 HP / 252 SpA Quiet with Charcoal, both Ursaluna run Brave with 252 HP / 252 Atk and Assault Vests for bulk, Indeedee-F runs Bold with 252 HP / 252 Def and a Focus Sash, and Kingambit runs Brave 252 HP / 252 Atk with Life Orb. The team’s game plan is simple: lead Dusclops + Indeedee, set room, pivot into the appropriate Ursaluna or Torkoal depending on resists, and bulldoze through everything with 150 BP STABs before the opponent can adapt.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Delphox": {"Abilities": {"magician": 8.035127169800171, "blaze": 53.810112914183854}, "Items": {"lifeorb": 0.6698289965878479}, "Spreads": {"Timid:4/0/0/252/0/252": 0.15381589423661626, "Timid:0/0/0/252/4/252": 0.15797487110441305, "Timid:4/0/4/252/4/244": 0.43245119555791883}, "Moves": ["expandingforce", "protect", "heatwave", "terablast"], "Tera Types": {"fairy": 0.22410542321497898, "fire": 0.16670108766081812, "fighting": 0.3122283495726784}, "Teammates": ["Indeedee-F", "Sneasler", "Tyranitar", "Lycanroc", "Murkrow", "Sinistcha"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>The fox enters Series 2 with one clear mission: spam terrain-boosted Expanding Force. 312228 Tera Fighting and 224105 Tera Fairy indicate players want to flip the script on Dark-type answers or gain a crucial Dragon immunity, while 166701 still opt for STAB-boosted Fire Tera Blasts for extra oomph on Heat Wave. Timid 252/252 spreads dominate, underscoring that Delphox wants to outspeed and OHKO rather than trade. Life Orb is the lone listed item, meaning every attack is a potential nuke but every self-damage chip matters. The 53% Blaze preference over the 8% Magician shows players value the emergency power spike more than item theft gimmicks, although Magician can steal a Tera Shell or Booster Energy on prediction. Protect rounds out the set, mandatory for doubles play and for letting Indeedee-F set terrain safely. Usage sits low because it competes with faster or bulkier psychics like Indeedee itself or the Tapus, but Delphox differentiates via mixed Fire coverage and Tera flexibility.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Delphox obliterates slower Grass, Steel and Fighting cores (Amoonguss, Kingambit, Iron Hands) with Expanding Force or Heat Wave, and Tera Fairy variants now beat Roaring Moon and Dragapult one-on-one. It struggles vs. priority users outside terrain (Chien-Pao’s Ice Shard, Dragonite’s ES) and outright folds to any strong Dark or Rock move; Tyranitar is simultaneously a common teammate and a nightmare opponent because sand breaks Focus Sash and special bulk lets TTar tank a hit. Wide Guard Aegislash and Dondozo blunt its spread game, while faster threats like Iron Bundle or opposing Scarfers force Protect mind-games.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Garganacl": {"Abilities": {"purifyingsalt": 54.50795467398372, "sturdy": 0.06194584661649877, "clearbody": 0.029056202552405153}, "Items": {"marangaberry": 0.28757374826748755, "leftovers": 0.3547677082106156, "sitrusberry": 0.23713775616849808}, "Spreads": {"Careful:252/0/20/0/236/0": 0.16003814492123583, "Careful:196/0/76/0/236/0": 0.16691577059982235}, "Moves": ["saltcure", "recover", "wideguard", "protect"], "Tera Types": {"flying": 0.3110019731105927, "ghost": 0.1924130004816902, "water": 0.15571987213007984, "poison": 0.2587734723368864}, "Teammates": ["Dondozo", "Incineroar", "Ninetales-Alola", "Gholdengo", "Volcarona", "Rillaboom"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Garganacl is a premier defensive pivot in VGC 2024, leveraging its signature move Salt Cure and Purifying Salt to blanket-check physical attackers while spreading residual damage. With a 54% usage of Purifying Salt, it ignores status and halves incoming Ghost- and Dragon-type damage, letting it sit on threats like Chien-Pao, Dragonite, and Gholdengo. Maranga Berry (29% usage) and Leftovers (35% usage) are the dominant items, both paired with Careful nature and 236 SpD EVs to maximize special bulk while still surviving key physical rolls. Its moveset is almost fixed—Salt Cure, Recover, Wide Guard, Protect—turning it into an unkillable tank that chips both foes, blocks spread moves, and outlasts most neutral targets. Tera Flying (31%) and Tera Poison (26%) are the most common shifts, giving it key immunities to Ground or Fighting while preserving its Rock-typing STAB on Salt Cure. Garganacl’s presence forces opposing teams to play aggressively or pack strong Water/Ground/Steel breakers, making it the glue of many balance and hard-stall cores.</OUTPUT>

input:
Write a detailed 'full_analysis' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Garganacl": {"Abilities": {"purifyingsalt": 54.50795467398372, "sturdy": 0.06194584661649877, "clearbody": 0.029056202552405153}, "Items": {"marangaberry": 0.28757374826748755, "leftovers": 0.3547677082106156, "sitrusberry": 0.23713775616849808}, "Spreads": {"Careful:252/0/20/0/236/0": 0.16003814492123583, "Careful:196/0/76/0/236/0": 0.16691577059982235}, "Moves": ["saltcure", "recover", "wideguard", "protect"], "Tera Types": {"flying": 0.3110019731105927, "ghost": 0.1924130004816902, "water": 0.15571987213007984, "poison": 0.2587734723368864}, "Teammates": ["Dondozo", "Incineroar", "Ninetales-Alola", "Gholdengo", "Volcarona", "Rillaboom"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Garganacl’s niche is unrivaled: it is the only Rock-type with access to both Recover and a passive damage move that ignores Protect. Salt Cure’s 1/8 max-HP drain against non-Steel targets is effectively a guaranteed KO timer—after two hits most offensive Pokémon are in range of any follow-up attack. Purifying Salt’s status immunity removes the traditional Rock-type fear of Scald burns or Spore, while the 50% damage reduction from Ghost and Dragon attacks lets it hard-wall Flutter Mane, specs Dragapult, and even boosted Baxcalibur. The chosen EV spreads illustrate two philosophies: the 252 HP / 20 Def / 236 SpD Careful spread reaches 211/169/200 bulk, surviving Modest Life-Orb Gholdengo Make-It-Rain plus Follow-Me chip, while the 196/76 variant shifts 20 EVs into Defense to guarantee surviving Jolly Chien-Pao Icicle Crash into Sacred Sword. Wide Guard is the secret sauce: it blanks Flutter Mane’s Dazzling Gleam, Kingambit’s Behemoth Blade, and both versions of Landorus’s Earth Power, giving teammates free turns to set up or retaliate. Recover + Protect lets Garganacl win 1v1 endgames against most non-boosted attackers, and because Salt Cure hits through Protect, it punishes passive play. Tera choices are reactive: Flying removes its Ground weakness and allows it to switch into Great Tusk Headlong Rush or Landorus-T Earthquake, while Tera Poison flips the Fighting weakness into a resistance and neutralizes Rillaboom’s Grassy Glide. Water (15%) is a middle-ground that keeps neutrality to Ground but adds a crucial resistance to Fire, useful versus Heatran and Sun teams. The dominance of berry items—Maranga raises SpD after taking a special hit, Leftoids provide constant recovery—means Garganacl is never dead weight even if ignored, because every turn it stays on field the Salt Cure clock ticks. Opponents must either double-target it (risking Wide Guard), over-kill with super-effective moves, or remove it with raw power before it gets two Salt Cures off. Garganacl therefore dictates tempo: it forces switches, reveals Tera types early, and depletes opposing Dynamons while your own sweepers set up behind Wide Guard.</OUTPUT>

input:
Create the 'matchup_overview' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Garganacl": {"Abilities": {"purifyingsalt": 54.50795467398372, "sturdy": 0.06194584661649877, "clearbody": 0.029056202552405153}, "Items": {"marangaberry": 0.28757374826748755, "leftovers": 0.3547677082106156, "sitrusberry": 0.23713775616849808}, "Spreads": {"Careful:252/0/20/0/236/0": 0.16003814492123583, "Careful:196/0/76/0/236/0": 0.16691577059982235}, "Moves": ["saltcure", "recover", "wideguard", "protect"], "Tera Types": {"flying": 0.3110019731105927, "ghost": 0.1924130004816902, "water": 0.15571987213007984, "poison": 0.2587734723368864}, "Teammates": ["Dondozo", "Incineroar", "Ninetales-Alola", "Gholdengo", "Volcarona", "Rillaboom"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Against offense, Garganacl is a hard wall: it survives Chien-Pao’s Sacred Sword and 2HKOes back with Salt Cure while healing stall. It blanks Choice-specs Dragapult, survives +1 Dragonite Tera Normal Extreme Speed, and lives Flutter Mane Shadow Ball into Follow-Me. Balance teams struggle more because they rely on residual damage—Garganacl’s Recover and status immunity negate Toxic, Burns, and Leech Seed, so their win conditions must break it with raw power. Stall mirrors become Salt Cure wars where the player with more PP wins; however, Tera Poison Gargancl beats opposing Tera Flying variants by resisting Salt Cure and removing Flying’s Ground immunity. Rain teams are the worst matchup: specs Pelipper Hurricane and specs Palafin Jet Punch both 2HKO, and Wide Guard does not block Jet Punch. Sun fares better because Tera Water Gargancl tanks Torkoal Eruption and OHKOes back with Salt Cure, but Tera Fire Charizard still forces a 50-50 Protect gamble. Trick Room teams packing Tera Fighting Iron Hands or Tera Ground Tyranitar can muscle past, but must commit Dynamax or Tera to guarantee the KO. In summary, Garganacl autowins against most physical and ghostly special attackers, goes even with balanced cores, and must be respected by rain or strong Fighting/Ground breakers.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Garganacl": {"Abilities": {"purifyingsalt": 54.50795467398372, "sturdy": 0.06194584661649877, "clearbody": 0.029056202552405153}, "Items": {"marangaberry": 0.28757374826748755, "leftovers": 0.3547677082106156, "sitrusberry": 0.23713775616849808}, "Spreads": {"Careful:252/0/20/0/236/0": 0.16003814492123583, "Careful:196/0/76/0/236/0": 0.16691577059982235}, "Moves": ["saltcure", "recover", "wideguard", "protect"], "Tera Types": {"flying": 0.3110019731105927, "ghost": 0.1924130004816902, "water": 0.15571987213007984, "poison": 0.2587734723368864}, "Teammates": ["Dondozo", "Incineroar", "Ninetales-Alola", "Gholdengo", "Volcarona", "Rillaboom"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Garganacl is a defensive pivot, win-condition, and anti-meta glue. It switches into every common physical attacker—Chien-Pao, Dragonite, Kingambit, Gholdengo—and begins the Salt Cure timer while healing off any chip. Wide Guard turns it into a team player, denying spread moves that would otherwise pressure frail partners like Volcarona or Alolan-Ninetales. Because it is immune to status and carries Protect, it is the preferred Dynamax target in stalemates: Max Rockfall sets sand that chips foes and activates its own Rock-type STAB boost, while Max Guard preserves Wide Guard effects. In endgames, Recover plus Protect allows it to PP-stall choice-locked moves and slowly Salt-Cure the last opposing Pokémon to death. Its mere presence forces opponents to conserve their Tera and Dynamax to break it, giving your own sweepers freer set-up windows.</OUTPUT>

Write a detailed 'synergy_breakdown' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Garganacl": {"Abilities": {"purifyingsalt": 54.50795467398372, "sturdy": 0.06194584661649877, "clearbody": 0.029056202552405153}, "Items": {"marangaberry": 0.28757374826748755, "leftovers": 0.3547677082106156, "sitrusberry": 0.23713775616849808}, "Spreads": {"Careful:252/0/20/0/236/0": 0.16003814492123583, "Careful:196/0/76/0/236/0": 0.16691577059982235}, "Moves": ["saltcure", "recover", "wideguard", "protect"], "Tera Types": {"flying": 0.3110019731105927, "ghost": 0.1924130004816902, "water": 0.15571987213007984, "poison": 0.2587734723368864}, "Teammates": ["Dondozo", "Incineroar", "Ninetales-Alola", "Gholdengo", "Volcarona", "Rillaboom"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Dondozo is the most synergistic partner: Garganacl covers Dondozo’s Fairy and Dragon weaknesses, while Dondozo ignores Salt Cure chip thanks to Water-typing. Together they form a double-Wide-Guard core that blanks Flutter Mane and Landorus, and both can stall out Dynamax turns. Incineroar provides Intimidate, Fake Out, and Parting Shot to bring Garganacl in safely; in return Garganacl absorbs Ghost and Dragon moves aimed at Incineroar. Alolan-Ninetales sets Aurora Veil, halving the damage Garganacl takes on switch-in and giving it more turns to Salt Cure. Gholdengo blocks opposing status and Rapid-Spin, preserving hazards that wear down Steel-types who would otherwise ignore Salt Cure. Volcarona appreciates Wide Guard protection while it Quiver-Dances, and once Volcarona is at +1 Garganacl can pivot to absorb Water and Rock moves. Rillaboom breaks opposing Water-types with Grassy Glide and provides Grassy Terrain that slightly offsets Salt Cure chip on allies while boosting Garganacl’s own Leftovers recovery. The common denominator is that all teammates either bring Garganacl in safely or benefit from the free turns Wide Guard and Salt Cure generate.</OUTPUT>

This spread survives Modest Gholdengo Make-It-Rain plus Follow-Me chip and raises SpD after taking any special move, letting it beat specs Flutter Mane one-on-one. <DATA>{"Garganacl": {"Abilities": {"purifyingsalt": 54.50795467398372, "sturdy": 0.06194584661649877, "clearbody": 0.029056202552405153}, "Items": {"marangaberry": 0.28757374826748755, "leftovers": 0.3547677082106156, "sitrusberry": 0.23713775616849808}, "Spreads": {"Careful:252/0/20/0/236/0": 0.16003814492123583, "Careful:196/0/76/0/236/0": 0.16691577059982235}, "Moves": ["saltcure", "recover", "wideguard", "protect"], "Tera Types": {"flying": 0.3110019731105927, "ghost": 0.1924130004816902, "water": 0.15571987213007984, "poison": 0.2587734723368864}, "Teammates": ["Dondozo", "Incineroar", "Ninetales-Alola", "Gholdengo", "Volcarona", "Rillaboom"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Strong special Water- and Grass-types are the most reliable answers: specs Pelipper Hurricane, specs Palafin Jet Punch, and Life-Orb Rillaboom Wood Hammer all 2HKO through berry recovery. Tera Fighting Iron Hands under Trick Room cleanly OHKOes with Close Combat, while Tera Ground Landorus-T or Great Tusk can break Tera Flying variants with Earthquake or Headlong Rush. Status from Magic-Bounce users like Hatterene or from Mold-Breaker users can bypass Purifying Salt, but most teams instead rely on raw damage. Encore users such as Murkrow or Ditto can lock Garganacl into Protect or Recover and use the free turns to set up, though they must watch for Wide Guard. Finally, Perish-Trap teams ignore Salt Cure timers and can force Garganacl out before it achieves anything. In general, if you can OHKO or force a 2HKO through Protect while avoiding Wide Guard, you beat Garganacl; otherwise the Salt Cure clock will eventually overwhelm you.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Garganacl": {"Abilities": {"purifyingsalt": 54.50795467398372, "sturdy": 0.06194584661649877, "clearbody": 0.029056202552405153}, "Items": {"marangaberry": 0.28757374826748755, "leftovers": 0.3547677082106156, "sitrusberry": 0.23713775616849808}, "Spreads": {"Careful:252/0/20/0/236/0": 0.16003814492123583, "Careful:196/0/76/0/236/0": 0.16691577059982235}, "Moves": ["saltcure", "recover", "wideguard", "protect"], "Tera Types": {"flying": 0.3110019731105927, "ghost": 0.1924130004816902, "water": 0.15571987213007984, "poison": 0.2587734723368864}, "Teammates": ["Dondozo", "Incineroar", "Ninetales-Alola", "Gholdengo", "Volcarona", "Rillaboom"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Begin with the Dondozo + Garganacl core: Dondozo @ Leftovers, Unaware, 252 HP / 156 Def / 100 SpD Careful, Order Up / Body Press / Rest / Sleep Talk; Garganacl @ Maranga Berry, Purifying Salt, Careful 252/20/236, Salt Cure / Recover / Wide Guard / Protect, Tera Flying. Add Incineroar @ Figy Berry, Intimidate, 252 HP / 76 Atk / 180 Def Adamant, Fake Out / Parting Shot / Flare Blitz / Taunt for pivot support. Include Choice-specs Gholdengo to block spin and apply offensive pressure. Round out with Alolan-Ninetales @ Light Clay, 252 HP / 252 Def Timid, Aurora Veil / Freeze-Dry / Moonblast / Protect, and Life-Orb Volcarona @ 252 SpA / 4 SpD / 252 Modest, Quiver Dance / Heat Wave / Giga Drain / Protect. The game plan is lead Incineroar + Ninetales: Fake Out plus Veil turn one, Parting Shot into Garganacl on predicted Ghost or Dragon move, then cycle Wide Guard and Salt Cure while Dondozo or Volcarona set up behind Veil. The team blankets every offensive archetype—Sun, Rain, Trick Room, Hyper-offense—because Garganacl and Dondozo wall physical threats while Veil plus Intimidate neuters special attackers, and Gholdengo plus Volcarona provide the offensive ceiling to close games.</OUTPUT>
