<DATA>{"Charizard": {"Abilities": {"solarpower": 54.53159637876039, "blaze": 0.7753080228444129}, "Items": {"choicespecs": 0.7290812834730886, "choicescarf": 0.15574493747919665}, "Spreads": {"Timid:4/0/0/252/0/252": 0.2077085763285662, "Timid:0/0/4/252/0/252": 0.28320857295369334}, "Moves": ["heatwave", "weatherball", "overheat", "airslash"], "Tera Types": {"fire": 0.347004066064645, "ghost": 0.6008336007292052}, "Teammates": ["Torkoal", "Incineroar", "Jumpluff", "Ursaluna", "Porygon2", "Ursaluna-Bloodmoon"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Charizard carves a niche as a fast, sun-boosted special attacker that can pivot between spread Heat Wave and single-target Overheat while flexing into coverage with Weather Ball under sun. Tera Ghost patches its Stealth Rock weakness and grants perfect-coverage Tera Blast options, while Tera Fire turns Heat Wave into a nuclear 135 BP spread move. Timid nature with max Speed ensures it outpaces neutral-nature base 100s and ties opposing Charizard, while the 4 HP / 4 Def split is chosen to survive stray priority. Choice Specs is the preferred item to maximize immediate damage, though Choice Scarf turns Charizard into a revenge killer and late-game cleaner. Solar Power is taken on virtually every serious set, turning sun-boosted Heat Wave into a 2.25× multiplier that cleanly OHKOes common threats like Tornadus-I and Amoonguss after chip.</OUTPUT>

input:
Produce the 'full_analysis' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Charizard": {"Abilities": {"solarpower": 54.53159637876039, "blaze": 0.7753080228444129}, "Items": {"choicespecs": 0.7290812834730886, "choicescarf": 0.15574493747919665}, "Spreads": {"Timid:4/0/0/252/0/252": 0.2077085763285662, "Timid:0/0/4/252/0/252": 0.28320857295369334}, "Moves": ["heatwave", "weatherball", "overheat", "airslash"], "Tera Types": {"fire": 0.347004066064645, "ghost": 0.6008336007292052}, "Teammates": ["Torkoal", "Incineroar", "Jumpluff", "Ursaluna", "Porygon2", "Ursaluna-Bloodmoon"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Charizard’s viability in VGC 2025 hinges on sun archetypes that can both enable and protect it. Solar Power turns every sun-boosted Fire move into a spread nuke: Timid Specs Heat Wave reaches 213 BP after sun and ability, 2HKOing even max-SpD Torkoal through Tera Fire. Overheat is reserved for single-target bust, OHKOing neutral-natured Gholdengo and Kingambit after minor chip. Weather Ball becomes a 100 BP Fire move under sun, giving Charizard a spammable 100% accurate option that bypasses Wide Guard and avoids Overheat’s SpA drop. Air Slash is the obligatory secondary STAB, offering neutral coverage versus Dragons and Fighting-types while flinching slower targets like Indeedee-F. Tera Ghost is the dominant choice, removing the 4× Rock weakness and granting immunity to Fake Out and Extreme Speed, while Tera Fire is kept for teams that want to stack Fire-type pressure and keep the sun-boosted Fire STAB. The EV spreads are min-maxed for Speed tiers: 252 Speed Timid outspeeds max-Speed Lilligant-H and ties opposing Charizard, while 4 HP / 4 Def survives Jolly Chien-Pao Ice Spinner and modest Iron Valiant Moonblast. Choice Specs is the default for immediate power, but Choice Scarf is seeing niche usage to outspeed +1 Roaring Moon and scarfed Dragapult, turning Charizard into a surprise revenge killer. The Blaze usage in the data is noise from Battle Tower or low-ladder players; Solar Power is mandatory for competitive play.</OUTPUT>

input:
Create the 'matchup_overview' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Charizard": {"Abilities": {"solarpower": 54.53159637876039, "blaze": 0.7753080228444129}, "Items": {"choicespecs": 0.7290812834730886, "choicescarf": 0.15574493747919665}, "Spreads": {"Timid:4/0/0/252/0/252": 0.2077085763285662, "Timid:0/0/4/252/0/252": 0.28320857295369334}, "Moves": ["heatwave", "weatherball", "overheat", "airslash"], "Tera Types": {"fire": 0.347004066064645, "ghost": 0.6008336007292052}, "Teammates": ["Torkoal", "Incineroar", "Jumpluff", "Ursaluna", "Porygon2", "Ursaluna-Bloodmoon"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Charizard dominates Grass- and Steel-heavy teams that rely on Amoonguss, Corviknight, or Gholdengo, turning them into free entry points with sun-boosted Heat Wave. It pressures bulky Waters like Slowbro and Toxapex only under sun; outside sun, these Pokémon comfortably stomach Heat Wave and retaliate with Scald or Ice Beam. Rock-types such as Tyranitar and Chien-Pao are automatic speed-bumps, forcing Charizard to Tera Ghost or switch out. Electric Terrain teams with Pincurchin and Iron Hands can shrug off Heat Wave and punish with Thunder Punch or Rock Slide. Trick Room matchups are polarized: if sun is up Charizard can snipe setters like Hatterene or Indeedee-F before Trick Room goes up, but if Trick Room is active it becomes dead weight versus slow powerhouses like Torkoal and Iron Hands. Rain teams outright invalidate Charizard, reducing Heat Wave to neutral 90 BP and turning Weather Ball into a 50 BP Water move. Finally, opposing weather wars can flip the script: Tyranitar sand or Pelipper rain remove sun and leave Charizard with only neutral Overheat and Air Slash.</OUTPUT>

input:
Provide the 'role_description' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Charizard": {"Abilities": {"solarpower": 54.53159637876039, "blaze": 0.7753080228444129}, "Items": {"choicespecs": 0.7290812834730886, "choicescarf": 0.15574493747919665}, "Spreads": {"Timid:4/0/0/252/0/252": 0.2077085763285662, "Timid:0/0/4/252/0/252": 0.28320857295369334}, "Moves": ["heatwave", "weatherball", "overheat", "airslash"], "Tera Types": {"fire": 0.347004066064645, "ghost": 0.6008336007292052}, "Teammates": ["Torkoal", "Incineroar", "Jumpluff", "Ursaluna", "Porygon2", "Ursaluna-Bloodmoon"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Charizard is a sun-dependent fast attacker that functions as both a lead and mid-game pivot. In the lead slot it immediately threatens opposing Grass and Steel leads with Heat Wave, forcing Protects or Terastallizations while Torkoal sets sun. Mid-game it acts as a cleaner, revenging weakened threats with Choice Scarf or breaking holes with Choice Specs. Its spread move pressure forces double Protects, generating free turns for partners like Ursaluna to set up or Jumpluff to put something to sleep. Tera Ghost variants can serve as an emergency spinblocker and Fake Out immunity, letting it protect sun turns versus Incineroar or Maushold. Charizard is not a win-condition by itself; instead it softens the opposing team so that Ursaluna or Bloodmoon can sweep, or buys time for Porygon2 to set Trick Room in reverse-mode teams. The Choice items lock it into one move, so correct prediction is essential—switching out to reset the lock is common, and partners with U-turn or Parting Shot facilitate that.</OUTPUT>

Write the 'synergy_breakdown' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Charizard": {"Abilities": {"solarpower": 54.53159637876039, "blaze": 0.7753080228444129}, "Items": {"choicespecs": 0.7290812834730886, "choicescarf": 0.15574493747919665}, "Spreads": {"Timid:4/0/0/252/0/252": 0.2077085763285662, "Timid:0/0/4/252/0/252": 0.28320857295369334}, "Moves": ["heatwave", "weatherball", "overheat", "airslash"], "Tera Types": {"fire": 0.347004066064645, "ghost": 0.6008336007292052}, "Teammates": ["Torkoal", "Incineroar", "Jumpluff", "Ursaluna", "Porygon2", "Ursaluna-Bloodmoon"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Torkoal is the non-negotiable partner: Drought enables Solar Power, doubles Heat Wave output, and turns Weather Ball into a Fire move. Torkoal also provides Stealth Rock chip and can tank Rock-type hits aimed at Charizard. Incineroar is the second most common teammate, offering Intimidate, Fake Out, and U-turn to bring Charizard in safely while softening physical threats that outspeed it. Jumpluff fills a triple-core with Torkoal and Charizard: sun-boosted Chlorophyll allows it to outspeed and Sleep Powder opposing threats, while Rage Powder redirects Electric and Rock moves away from Charizard. Ursaluna and Ursaluna-Bloodmoon appreciate Charizard’s ability to melt Steel-types that wall their STABs, and in return they break through special walls like Blissey and Goodra-H that Charizard cannot muscle past. Porygon2 offers a slow pivot with Trace or Download, copying opposing weather or Intimidate, and can set Trick Room if the team wants to flip speed control versus faster offenses. The shared Fire- and Normal-typing between Charizard, Incineroar, and Ursaluna can stack weaknesses to Rock and Fighting, so Tera Ghost on Charizard and Tera Fairy or Tera Flying on Incineroar are common fixes.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Choice Specs Solar Power Timid 252/0/4/0/0/252 with Heat Wave / Overheat / Weather Ball / Air Slash and Tera Ghost. This is the standard breaker that 2HKOes the entire metagame under sun. Choice Scarf variant drops Specs for 1.5× Speed, outspeeding +1 Roaring Moon and scarfed Gholdengo, and keeps the same four moves. A niche Tera Fire Life Orb set with Protect > Air Slash exists for teams that want to stay in longer and dodge Sucker Punch, but the data shows sub-1% usage. EV spreads are identical: max Speed and SpA with 4 Def to survive Jolly Chien-Pao Ice Spinner. Tera Ghost is used on 60% of teams to remove Rock weakness and gain immunities; Tera Fire is the remaining 35% to stack Fire-type pressure and keep sun-boosted STAB. No other Terastallization types appear in meaningful quantities.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Charizard": {"Abilities": {"solarpower": 54.53159637876039, "blaze": 0.7753080228444129}, "Items": {"choicespecs": 0.7290812834730886, "choicescarf": 0.15574493747919665}, "Spreads": {"Timid:4/0/0/252/0/252": 0.2077085763285662, "Timid:0/0/4/252/0/252": 0.28320857295369334}, "Moves": ["heatwave", "weatherball", "overheat", "airslash"], "Tera Types": {"fire": 0.347004066064645, "ghost": 0.6008336007292052}, "Teammates": ["Torkoal", "Incineroar", "Jumpluff", "Ursaluna", "Porygon2", "Ursaluna-Bloodmoon"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Rock-type moves are the most direct answer: Chien-Pao Ice Spinner, Tyranitar Rock Slide, and Iron Thorns Stone Edge all OHKO through Tera Ghost if sun is not up. Faster Dragons such as Dragapult and Roaring Moon threaten with Draco Meteor or Rock Slide; scarfed variants outspeed even Choice Scarf Charizard. Priority users like Kingambit Sucker Punch and Dragonite Extreme Speed finish off weakened Charizard, though Tera Ghost blocks the latter. Wide Guard Arcanine or Gholdengo shuts down Heat Wave spam, forcing Charizard to commit to single-target Overheat and risk the SpA drop. Bulky Flash-Fire or Well-Bodied Pokémon such as Heatran and Garganacl can switch into Heat Wave and retaliate with Flash Cannon or Salt Cure. Rain teams automatically nerf Heat Wave and flip Weather Ball into a Water move, turning Pelipper and Barraskewda into hard counters. Finally, Knock Off or Trick users can remove Choice items, neutering Charizard’s damage output and locking it into unfavorable moves.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Sylveon": {"Abilities": {"pixilate": 53.03794282956268, "cutecharm": 0.11443892889444851}, "Items": {"throatspray": 0.28287303879140796, "pixieplate": 0.2297043021118664, "choicespecs": 0.38934110276869094}, "Spreads": {"Modest:164/0/0/252/0/92": 0.15257344766747338}, "Moves": ["hypervoice", "terablast", "protect", "quickattack"], "Tera Types": {"fire": 0.3624036935675014, "steel": 0.30481203734045825}, "Teammates": ["Incineroar", "Kingambit", "Gholdengo", "Archaludon", "Dragonite", "Dondozo"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Thanks to Pixilate, Sylveon turns Hyper Voice into a 117-base-power STAB spread move that bypasses Follow Me, making it one of the most consistent Fairy-type attackers in the format. The modest EV spread with 92 Speed lets it outrun neutral-natured base 70 benchmarks such as uninvested Incineroar while maximizing special bulk; 252 EVs in Special Attack plus a Modest nature ensure OHKOs on common threats like Chien-Pao, Dragapult, and Iron Valiant after spread damage. Choice Specs is the most popular item, turning Hyper Voice into a nuke that 2HKOs even bulky resists such as Garganacl and Toxapex, while Throat Spray offers a one-time +1 SpA boost after a Protect or partner’s priority move, letting Sylveon snowball late-game. Tera Fire removes its Steel weakness and grants a crucial resistance to Sun-boosted Heat Wave and Kingambit’s Sucker Punch, whereas Tera Steel turns Sylveon into a pseudo-steel wall that can stomach Gholdengo’s Make It Rain and retaliate with Quick Attack to pick off weakened sash holders. Protect is mandatory for double-target prediction and Throat Spray activation, and Tera Blast provides coverage that can be re-typed post-Tera to hit checks like Toxapex (Tera Electric) or Amoonguss (Tera Psychic).</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Sylveon": {"Abilities": {"pixilate": 53.03794282956268, "cutecharm": 0.11443892889444851}, "Items": {"throatspray": 0.28287303879140796, "pixieplate": 0.2297043021118664, "choicespecs": 0.38934110276869094}, "Spreads": {"Modest:164/0/0/252/0/92": 0.15257344766747338}, "Moves": ["hypervoice", "terablast", "protect", "quickattack"], "Tera Types": {"fire": 0.3624036935675014, "steel": 0.30481203734045825}, "Teammates": ["Incineroar", "Kingambit", "Gholdengo", "Archaludon", "Dragonite", "Dondozo"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Sylveon enjoys positive matchups against Dragon- and Dark-heavy teams, obliterating Roaring Moon, Chien-Pao, Kingambit, and Dragapult with Pixilate Hyper Voice. Against Sun, Tera Fire variants shrug off Heat Wave and OHKO Torkoal and Venusaur, though they must watch for Tera Ground Torkoal. Into Trick Room, Sylveon can stall turns with Protect and dent Hatterene and Indeedee-F, but loses outright to Iron Hands and Tera Steel Aegislash. Steel-types remain the biggest hurdle: Tera Steel Corviknight and Gholdengo take ~40% from Specs Hyper Voice and retaliate with Iron Head or Make It Rain, respectively, while Kingambit with Tera Dark can live a Hyper Voice and KO back with Sucker Punch. Poison-types such as Amoonguss and Toxapex can tank a hit and threaten status or clear Sylveon’s boosts, forcing prediction with Tera Blast.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Sylveon’s primary job is to act as a mid-speed special wallbreaker that punishes opposing Fairy-weak cores while providing spread damage that chips sashed leads and breaks Focus Sash on support Pokémon. Its secondary role is late-game cleaner: after teammates such as Incineroar and Archaludon have removed or weakened Steel-types, Sylveon can Tera and sweep with boosted Hyper Voice plus priority Quick Attack. The combination of Pixilate and naturally high special bulk also lets Sylveon serve as a soft check to special attackers like Gholdengo and Iron Valiant, switching in on predicted Draco Meteors or Spirit Breaks and forcing them out.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Incineroar is the ideal partner, providing Intimidate, Fake Out, and U-turn momentum while handling Steel-types with Flare Blitz and Knock Off. Kingambit offers priority Sucker Punch to finish off faster threats that survive Hyper Voice, appreciates Sylveon’s ability to break opposing Dark resists, and can Tera Dark to lure opposing Fairy checks. Gholdengo blocks opposing status and sets hazards that wear Steel-types into Sylveon’s KO range; conversely, Sylveon removes Kingambit and Dark-types that trouble Gholdengo. Archaludon’s Stamina lets it set up on Steel-type attacks aimed at Sylveon, while Sylveon covers the Fighting-type moves that threaten Archaludon. Dragonite provides Tailwind and physical pressure, freeing Sylveon to run Modest without fear of being outsped, and Dondozo offers a physical wall that can bait Electric- and Grass-type moves for Sylveon to switch in safely.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Lycanroc": {"Abilities": {"sandrush": 47.82076266261151, "keeneye": 0.35276799424565325, "steadfast": 0.4242350065525297}, "Items": {"focussash": 0.9883989236978157}, "Spreads": {"Adamant:0/252/0/0/4/252": 0.607537055040594, "Adamant:4/252/0/0/0/252": 0.2659891894779418}, "Moves": ["rockslide", "closecombat", "protect", "psychicfangs"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.3803772092694959, "fighting": 0.6040570311361392}, "Teammates": ["Tyranitar", "Corviknight", "Indeedee-F", "Delphox", "Murkrow", "Sinistcha"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Lycanroc is a niche but explosive offensive lead in VGC, leveraging its blistering 112 base Speed tier, Rock-type STAB Rock Slide, and strong coverage to apply immediate pressure. With Focus Sash as its item of choice and a near-unanimous choice of Sand Rush (47.8 % usage), it functions best under sand set by Tyranitar, outspeeding the entire unboosted metagame and flinching foes into submission. Its movepool is compact but purposeful: Rock Slide for spread damage and flinch chance, Close Combat for wide neutral coverage, Psychic Fangs to break screens and dent bulky Poison- and Fighting-types, and Protect for pivoting. Tera Ghost (38 %) grants a Normal- and Fighting-immune typing that lets it dodge Fake Out and Close Combat retaliation, while Tera Fighting (60 %) boosts Close Combat to nuclear levels. Although its Attack stat is merely above-average, the combination of speed control, priority immunity, and surprise factor makes Lycanroc a legitimate pocket pick that can steal games if the opponent is unprepared.</OUTPUT>

input:
Generate the 'full_analysis' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Lycanroc": {"Abilities": {"sandrush": 47.82076266261151, "keeneye": 0.35276799424565325, "steadfast": 0.4242350065525297}, "Items": {"focussash": 0.9883989236978157}, "Spreads": {"Adamant:0/252/0/0/4/252": 0.607537055040594, "Adamant:4/252/0/0/0/252": 0.2659891894779418}, "Moves": ["rockslide", "closecombat", "protect", "psychicfangs"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.3803772092694959, "fighting": 0.6040570311361392}, "Teammates": ["Tyranitar", "Corviknight", "Indeedee-F", "Delphox", "Murkrow", "Sinistcha"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Lycanroc’s viability hinges on two factors: sand and speed. Under sand, Sand Rush doubles its Speed to an astronomical level, allowing it to outpace even +1 Roaring Moon and Choice Scarf Gholdengo. This enables a straightforward game plan: lead Lycanroc + Tyranitar, set sand, and fire off fast Rock Slides that fish for 30 % flinches while dealing solid damage to common threats like Togekiss, Talonflame, and Murkrow. Close Combat hits Steel- and Normal-types such as Kingambit, Gholdengo, and Snorlax for super-effective damage, while Psychic Fangs shatters Reflect and Light Screen—two omnipresent tools in the current doubles format—and punnshes Amoonguss, Toxapex, and Iron Hands. The Focus Sash guarantees that Lycanroc survives at least one hit, patching its mediocre bulk and letting it retaliate or set up a Tera. Tera Ghost is the more common option, removing its Fighting weakness and granting immunity to Fake Out, Mach Punch, and Extreme Speed, thereby allowing it to serve as a soft check to priority-reliant teams. Tera Fighting, on the other hand, turns Close Combat into a 180-base-power nuke that cleanly OHKOes max-HP Corviknight and 2HKOes physically defensive Dondozo. EV spreads are simple: 252 Atk / 252 Spe Adamant maximizes damage and guarantees the speed tie against other Sand Rush sweepers, while the remaining 4 EVs are placed in SpD to download a potential Download boost from opposing Iron Bundle. Despite these strengths, Lycanroc is frail, requires sand to function, and is shut down by intimidate, burn, and priority that bypasses Sash such as Sucker Punch from Kingambit. It also struggles into bulky Water- and Grass-types like Rotom-Wash, Amoonguss, and Sinistcha, which can survive a hit and KO back.</OUTPUT>

Write a detailed 'matchup_overview' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Lycanroc": {"Abilities": {"sandrush": 47.82076266261151, "keeneye": 0.35276799424565325, "steadfast": 0.4242350065525297}, "Items": {"focussash": 0.9883989236978157}, "Spreads": {"Adamant:0/252/0/0/4/252": 0.607537055040594, "Adamant:4/252/0/0/0/252": 0.2659891894779418}, "Moves": ["rockslide", "closecombat", "protect", "psychicfangs"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.3803772092694959, "fighting": 0.6040570311361392}, "Teammates": ["Tyranitar", "Corviknight", "Indeedee-F", "Delphox", "Murkrow", "Sinistcha"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Lycanroc loves facing offensive teams that rely on speed control from Tailwind or Choice Scarf, as Sand Rush flips the tempo and Rock Slide flinches dismantle frail attackers such as Flutter Mane, Iron Bundle, and Chien-Pao. It also pressures common support Pokémon like Murkrow, Indeedee-F, and Corviknight, forcing them to play conservatively or risk losing 1v1. Against Trick Room squads, Lycanroc can double-target the setter with Rock Slide + Tyranitar’s Crunch to score KOs before Trick Room goes up, though it folds once the field is reversed. Bulky Water-types—especially Rotom-Wash and Dondozo—wall it entirely, while Intimidate users such as Arcanine and Landorus-T force it to Tera or switch. Priority abusers like Kingambit and Dragonite can break Sash and finish Lycanroc off, though Tera Ghost variants can punish the former. Finally, opposing weather—Pelipper’s rain and Torkoal’s sun—removes the Speed boost and leaves Lycanroc outrun and outgunned.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Lycanroc is a hyper-offensive lead and mid-game cleaner whose primary role is to exploit sand to generate early momentum. It functions as a fast Fake Out deterrent, a spread damage dealer, and a screen-breaker, compressing multiple utility roles into one slot. Because it carries Protect, it can pivot around double-targets, waste opposing Dynamax turns, and enable partners like Tyranitar or Corviknight to reposition. Its ability to Tera on demand also gives it a surprise-factor that can flip unfavorable matchups: Tera Ghost turns it into an anti-priority pivot, while Tera Fighting turns it into a wall-breaking nuke. In the late game, once Sash is intact and opposing speed control is removed, Lycanroc can clean weakened teams with Rock Slide flinches or Close Combat spam.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Tyranitar is mandatory, as it sets sand and itself pressures Ghost- and Psychic-types that trouble Lycanroc. Corviknight provides Tailwind backup for turns when sand is overwritten and offers Defiant to deter Intimidate. Indeedee-F supplies Follow Me redirection and Psychic Terrain to block priority, creating a safe entry for Lycanroc to Tera and sweep. Delphox sets Sunny Day to overwrite opposing rain while also bringing Mystical Fire to weaken physical threats and Speed Swap to give Lycanroc a second wind if sand fades. Murkrow offers additional speed control via Tailwind and can Taunt opposing support, while Sinistcha provides bulky Grass-type coverage and can set shields with Shelter to keep Lycanroc’s Sash intact. The core of Lycanroc + Tyranitar + Indeedee-F forms a fast offensive triangle that can Dynamax any member depending on the matchup, ensuring flexibility.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Politoed carves a niche in VGC 2025 as a dedicated Drizzle setter that enables rain-centric cores while offering disruptive Perish-trapping and Encore utility. With a 47% usage of its signature Drizzle ability, it instantly summons rain to boost Water-type teammates and enable Weather Ball, while its bulk-oriented Calm spread and Tera Grass allow it to survive Electric- and Grass-type threats that plague rain squads. Its move set—Weather Ball, Perish Song, Protect, Encore—compresses offense, end-game cheese, and speed-control denial into a single slot, making it the glue that holds rain archetypes together.</OUTPUT>

input:
Write the 'full_analysis' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Politoed": {"Abilities": {"drizzle": 47.61076211333476, "waterabsorb": 0.025547481796085125, "damp": 0.0}, "Items": {"leftovers": 0.27673670039338977, "sitrusberry": 0.18013858227249566, "mysticwater": 0.15488263870999663}, "Spreads": {"Calm:252/0/60/4/76/116": 0.18268512905929346}, "Moves": ["weatherball", "perishsong", "protect", "encore"], "Tera Types": {"grass": 0.6761323364900954, "fire": 0.15989749302317538}, "Teammates": ["Archaludon", "Kingdra", "Incineroar", "Gothitelle", "Amoonguss", "Basculegion"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Politoed’s primary function is to guarantee rain on switch-in, granting a 50% boost to Water-type attacks and converting Weather Ball into a 100-base-power STAB Water move that ignores accuracy checks. The displayed Calm nature with 252 HP / 60 Def / 76 SpD / 116 Spe hits key benchmarks: it survives +1 252-Atk Dragonite Tera Flying Tera Blast, outspeeds neutral-nature base 70 threats like Breloom and Bisharp, and avoids the 2HKO from most common Grass Knot users. Leftovers and Sitrus Berry are equally viable items; Leftovers offsets chip from Stealth Rock and Incineroar U-turns, while Situs Berry allows a one-time recovery burst that can swing end-game Perish turns. Mystic Water is a niche offensive option that turns Weather Ball into a deceptively strong nuke under rain, 2HKOing even Toxapex and Rotom-Wash after minor chip. Tera Grass is overwhelmingly preferred (67% usage) because it removes the Electric weakness, neutralizes Grass-type moves aimed at Politoed, and flips the Kingdra mirror by resisting both STABs. Tera Fire is a secondary option that punits Ferroseed and Amoonguss, but it leaves Politoed vulnerable to Thunder Wave and Volt Switch. Perish Song is the set’s win-condition: after three turns both active opponents are KO’d unless they switch, and Gothitelle’s Shadow Tag or Archaludon’s Anchor Shot can prevent escape. Encore locks support Pokémon like Amoonguss, Murkrow, or Dondozo into harmless moves, creating free turns for Kingdra or Basculegion to set up or nuke. Protect is mandatory for Perish stalling and scouting Choice items. The 0% usage of Water Absorb and Damp indicates that Drizzle is non-negotiable; losing the auto-weather removes Politoed’s only real reason to be used over Alomomola or Tapu Fini.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Rain teams led by Politoed feast on Fire- and Ground-heavy offenses—Torkoal sun, Iron Moth, Great Tusk, and Garchomp all crumble to boosted Water moves and swift swim speed tiers. Politoed itself soft-checks special attackers like Walking Wake, Iron Jugulis, and Hydreigon, though it must Tera to avoid the 2HKO from Thunder or Power Whip. Against opposing weather, Politoed immediately overrides Torkoal or Tyranitar, but must beware of Lilligant-H or Alolan-Ninetales which can re-set sun or hail and abuse Aurora Veil. Grass-types (Amoonguss, Whimsicott, Ferroseed) are historically problematic; Tera Grass mitigates one half of the equation, but Politoed still relies on teammates to break through them. Electric Terrain teams with Iron Hands or Regieleki can fire off unboosted Thunders for the OHKO unless Politoed has already Terastallized. Trick Room squads that eschew weather can ignore Drizzle entirely, so Politoed must pair with Gothitelle or Basculegion to Perish-trap setters like Hatterene or Indeedee-F before Trick Room goes up.</OUTPUT>

Amoonguss provides redirection and clears status, while Incineroar cycles Intimidate and Parting Shot to keep rain active and preserve Perish turns. The team compresses offense, stall, and speed control into six slots, showcasing Politoed’s unique ability to dictate tempo in 2025 VGC.</OUTPUT>

input:

<DATA>{"Slaking": {"Abilities": {"truant": 48.82675870215284}, "Items": {"lifeorb": 0.5720579930837187, "choiceband": 0.23288923387340357}, "Spreads": {"Jolly:0/252/0/0/4/252": 0.15423179168598578, "Adamant:4/252/0/0/0/252": 0.23646979668045376}, "Moves": ["protect", "doubleedge", "suckerpunch", "knockoff"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.8454864304788295}, "Teammates": ["Weezing", "Typhlosion-Hisui", "Dondozo", "Tatsugiri", "Garchomp", "Whimsicott"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Slaking’s 670 BST would be generational were it not for Truant, so every teambuilding decision revolves around nullifying or playing around that ability. Life Orb variants prefer the flexibility to switch moves, whereas Choice Band sets turn Slaking into a one-time nuclear option that can OHKO neutral targets like max-HP Ting-Lu or bulky Rotom-W. Jolly outspeeds positive-nature base 100s such as Zapdos and Chien-Pao, while Adamant secures the guaranteed OHKO on physically frail threats like Iron Valiant after chip. Tera Ghost is omnipresent because it removes the Normal-type weaknesses to Fighting and provides an immunity to Fake Out, Mach Punch, and Shadow Sneak, the most common forms of priority that would otherwise punish a Truant cycle. Double-Edge is the strongest reliable STAB, but the recoil plus Life Orb means Slaking is on a timer; Sucker Punch punishes faster threats trying to exploit the loaf turn, and Knock Off cripples common switch-ins like Aegislash, Corviknight, and opposing Dondozo. Protect is mandatory to waste the Truant turn and to scout choice locks. The teammates shown in the data are not random: Weezing’s Neutralizing Gas suspends Truant, turning Slaking into a 160 Attack stat monster with no drawback; Typhlosion-Hisui benefits from free switches via U-turn or ally Protect, and can launch Eruptions at full HP while Slaking soaks aggression; Dondozo + Tatsugiri commander causes turn-order manipulation that lets Slaking move on turns it would normally loaf, creating pseudo-speed control. Whimsicott provides Tailwind and Charm/Fake Tears support, while Garchomp offers a Ground-immune pivot that can set Stealth Rock or click Swords Dance to share the offensive burden. In practice, Slaking teams play a tempo game: trade aggressively early, remove priority users, and clean once the opponent’s counterplay is exhausted.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Slaking": {"Abilities": {"truant": 48.82675870215284}, "Items": {"lifeorb": 0.5720579930837187, "choiceband": 0.23288923387340357}, "Spreads": {"Jolly:0/252/0/0/4/252": 0.15423179168598578, "Adamant:4/252/0/0/0/252": 0.23646979668045376}, "Moves": ["protect", "doubleedge", "suckerpunch", "knockoff"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.8454864304788295}, "Teammates": ["Weezing", "Typhlosion-Hisui", "Dondozo", "Tatsugiri", "Garchomp", "Whimsicott"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Slaking feasts on passive balance squads that rely on Rocky-helmet chip or slow pivots—common cores like Toxapex + Corviknight + Gholdengo lose their items to Knock Off and buckle under +1 Band Double-Edge after stealth damage. It struggles against hyper-offense that can double-target it or cycle priority: Kingambit’s Sucker Punch, Bisharp’s Defiant, and Dragonite’s Extreme Speed all dent or KO before Slaking can move. Ghost-types such as Aegislash and Dragapult wall the STAB, but hate Knock Off and can’t safely switch in twice. Faster Scarfers like Iron Valiant, Chien-Pao, and Flutter Mane force mind-games with Sucker Punch, while Intimidate Arcanine and Salamence blunt its power permanently. Clear-body Pokémon or Substitute holders can stall the active turn and force a second Protect, racking up hazard and Rocky-chip. Finally, any team carrying Neutralizing Gas or Skill Swap can flip the script and turn Slaking into dead weight if its own support is removed.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Slaking": {"Abilities": {"truant": 48.82675870215284}, "Items": {"lifeorb": 0.5720579930837187, "choiceband": 0.23288923387340357}, "Spreads": {"Jolly:0/252/0/0/4/252": 0.15423179168598578, "Adamant:4/252/0/0/0/252": 0.23646979668045376}, "Moves": ["protect", "doubleedge", "suckerpunch", "knockoff"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.8454864304788295}, "Teammates": ["Weezing", "Typhlosion-Hisui", "Dondozo", "Tatsugiri", "Garchomp", "Whimsicott"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Slaking is a designated wall-breaker and late-game cleaner whose entire role is to convert tempo advantages created by its partners into immediate KOs. It does not provide defensive utility—its bulk is merely adequate—so it must be paired with pivots that can bring it in safely and with support that negates Truant. Once on the field, it functions as a one-turn nuke: click the most damaging move that hits the target pool, then Protect to waste the loaf. If Neutralizing Gas is active or if commander mechanics let it move consecutively, it becomes a sustained breaker capable of 2-for-1 trades. The Ghost Tera turns it into a spin-blocker and priority absorber, giving it incidental utility against hazard stack and versus teams that rely on Fake Out leads like Indeedee or Maushold. Its speed tier is just high enough that under Tailwind it outpaces the entire unboosted metagame, letting it run Adamant for maximum damage. In short, Slaking is a high-risk, high-reward pocket pick that forces both players to play around a single dominant mechanic.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Slaking": {"Abilities": {"truant": 48.82675870215284}, "Items": {"lifeorb": 0.5720579930837187, "choiceband": 0.23288923387340357}, "Spreads": {"Jolly:0/252/0/0/4/252": 0.15423179168598578, "Adamant:4/252/0/0/0/252": 0.23646979668045376}, "Moves": ["protect", "doubleedge", "suckerpunch", "knockoff"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.8454864304788295}, "Teammates": ["Weezing", "Typhlosion-Hisui", "Dondozo", "Tatsugiri", "Garchomp", "Whimsicott"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Weezing is the most direct synergy: Neutralizing Gas removes Truant, so Slaking can attack every turn; Weezing in return appreciates Slaking’s ability to remove Heavy-Duty Boots and Leftovers, letting its own Toxic Spikes and Will-o-Wisp accumulate damage. Typhlosion-Hisui forms a classic “nuclear core”: Slaking baits in Water- and Rock-types that Typhlosion obliterates with Solar Beam or Tera Blast, while Typhlosion draws in Blissey and Toxapex that Slaking traps with Sucker Punch or Knock Off. Dondozo + Tatsugiri manipulates turn order so that Slaking can attack on the same turn Dondozo uses Order Up, effectively giving Slaking two consecutive moves; Tatsugiri also provides Wide Guard to block spread moves that would double-target Slaking. Whimsicott offers Tailwind and Fake Tears, turning Slaking’s 2HKO range into OHKO range versus special walls like Goodra-H and Blissey, while Garchomp provides a Stealth Rock setter that can pressure Rotom-W and Zapdos, two of Slaking’s best defensive answers. The common thread is that every teammate either removes Truant or compresses roles so that Slaking can enter the field under favorable conditions.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Priority users are public enemy #1: Kingambit’s Sucker Punch, Bisharp’s Defiant Sucker Punch, and Dragonite’s Extreme Speed all KO after minor chip. Faster Scarfers like Iron Valiant, Chien-Pao, and Roaring Moon force 50-50 Sucker Punch mind-games; if Slaking Protects on the Scarfer’s attack turn, it still loafs next turn and invites a free switch. Intimidate cycling from Arcanine, Salamence, or Gyarados permanently drops its Attack, forcing it to Tera to reclaim KOs. Rocky Helmet users—Garchomp, Toxapex, Corviknight—punish Double-Edge and U-turn contact, stripping 33–50 % on each hit. Ghost resists like Aegislash and Dragapult can tank Knock Off and retaliterate with Shadow Ball or Dragon Dart, though both hate losing their items. Substitute users such as Dragonite and Iron Valiant can set up on a predicted Protect and stall the active turn. Finally, any team that can remove Weezing or Tatsugiri early turns Slaking back into a 50 % dead-weight slot, so aggressive double-targets and spread moves (especially Earthquake and Discharge) are effective long-term answers.</OUTPUT>

Its standout ability, Costar, lets it copy stat changes upon entry, turning opposing setup or Intimidate cycles into immediate advantages. With a lean offensive movepool and middling bulk, Flamigo prefers a Focus Sash to guarantee at least one strong attack or support turn, and it most commonly Tera Ghost to dodge Fake Out, Extreme Speed, and its own Fighting-type weaknesses. <DATA>{"Flamigo": {"Abilities": {"costar": 18.430275728790246, "scrappy": 27.954644273133372, "tangledfeet": 0.0025100652846039573}, "Items": {"focussash": 0.5608729033631509, "covertcloak": 0.17428668094267133}, "Spreads": {"Jolly:0/252/0/0/4/252": 0.18053348088975843, "Jolly:4/252/0/0/0/252": 0.39405536043988276}, "Moves": ["closecombat", "bravebird", "wideguard", "protect"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.48040059822153824, "normal": 0.15401499696342766}, "Teammates": ["Annihilape", "Amoonguss", "Incineroar", "Gholdengo", "Ursaluna", "Garchomp"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Flamigo’s base 115 Attack and 90 Speed place it just above the crowded base-85 tier, letting it outspeed and OHKO key threats like Chien-Pao, Kingambit, and standard Incineroar with Close Combat while cleanly 2HKOing bulky Gholdengo and Amoonguss. Scrappy guarantees these Fighting hits land on Ghost types, removing the 50/50 mind games that plague other Fighting attackers. Costar, chosen on roughly one in five sets, is the ace in the hole: leading beside a teammate that has accumulated Dragon Dance, Calm Mind, or Iron Defense stacks turns Flamigo into an immediate win condition, and copying opposing Intimidate or Parting Shot boosts can flip a board state instantly. Wide Guard is the glue that justifies Flamigo over other Flying attackers, blanking common spread moves such as Earthquake, Heat Wave, and Rock Slide that define the current metagame. The bird’s defensive typing leaves it weak to Electric, Ice, and Rock, so Tera Ghost is the dominant choice to remove the Fighting weakness and provide a crucial immunity to Fake Out and Extreme Speed, while Tera Normal offers a STAB-boosted, priority-immune Extreme Speed variant that pairs well with Costar speed boosts. Covert Cloak appears sparingly to ignore Spore and Nuzzle static, but Focus Sash is the clear favorite, patching Flamigo’s merely okay 82/74/64 bulk and letting it survive a Chien-Pao Ice Spinner or a Garchomp Earthquake to fire back or set Wide Guard.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Toedscruel is a niche support pick in VGC that leverages its unique Grass/typing, access to Spore, and the ability Mycelium Might to function as a disruptive pivot. While its bulk is only middling, the combination of 100% accurate sleep, Rage Powder redirection, and Acid Spray chip gives it a distinct role on more balanced or control-oriented teams. The analyzed sample shows a clear preference for max-speed Timid builds with Water Tera to survive Fire-type attacks, and it is almost always paired with Incineroar, Garchomp, or Hisuian Typhlosion—Pokemon that appreciate the free turns Spore generates and can punish the opponent for focusing Toedscruel.</OUTPUT>

input:
Write the 'full_analysis' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Toedscruel": {"Abilities": {"myceliummight": 44.477051072074076}, "Items": {"covertcloak": 0.8242886057976545}, "Spreads": {"Timid:196/0/60/0/0/252": 0.3775834054174328, "Timid:124/0/180/4/12/188": 0.19770208139100287}, "Moves": ["earthpower", "acidspray", "spore", "ragepowder"], "Tera Types": {"water": 0.7865236416138092}, "Teammates": ["Typhlosion-Hisui", "Weezing-Galar", "Incineroar", "Garchomp", "Pawmot", "Kilowattrel"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Toedscruel’s stat line is not impressive on paper—100/80/80/100/80/100—but the even spread means it can EV to outspeed key threats while still surviving common hits. Mycelium Might guarantees that Spore and Acid Spray ignore enemy abilities such as Good-as-Gold, Purifying Salt, or opposing Mycelium Might, making it the most reliable sleep user in the format. Earth Power is its strongest STAB, 2HKOing common Incineroar and Tornadus sets after an Acid Spray drop, while Rage Powder lets it redirect single-target moves away from frail partners like Typhlosion or Kilowattrel. Covert Cloak is the item of choice to block Fake Out and rage-inducing secondary effects, but the low usage suggests many players simply forego an item in favor of Focus Sash or even Sitrus Berry on more experimental builds. Water Tera is taken on more than three-quarters of teams to flip the Fire weakness into a resistance, letting it survive Heat Wave or Tera-Blast Fire from Flutter Mane and reply with a KO or Spore. The two listed spreads show a tension between max-speed (Timid 252 Spe) and a bulkier 124 HP / 180 Def variant that lives Jolly Garchomp Tera-Stone Edge and Tera-Iron Head from Tera-Steel Rotom-Wash. In practice, the faster set is preferred because speed control is so ubiquitous that Toedscruel needs to fire off Spore before opposing Tailwind or Chlorophyll sweepers go wild.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Toedscruel": {"Abilities": {"myceliummight": 44.477051072074076}, "Items": {"covertcloak": 0.8242886057976545}, "Spreads": {"Timid:196/0/60/0/0/252": 0.3775834054174328, "Timid:124/0/180/4/12/188": 0.19770208139100287}, "Moves": ["earthpower", "acidspray", "spore", "ragepowder"], "Tera Types": {"water": 0.7865236416138092}, "Teammates": ["Typhlosion-Hisui", "Weezing-Galar", "Incineroar", "Garchomp", "Pawmot", "Kilowattrel"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Toedscruel shines against bulky set-up teams that rely on passive damage or Trick Room—Spore cripples Dusclops, Hatterene, and Indeedee, while Acid Spray breaks through Calyrex-Ice’s Substitute + Protect stalls. It struggles versus Grass-types (Amoonguss, Wo-Chien, and fellow Toedscruel) that are immune to Spore and can retaliate with Sludge Bomb or Pollen Puff. Fast Flying-types such as Tornadus-I and Tera-Flying Iron Bundle outspeed and OHKO with Hurricane or Hydro Steam, forcing Toedscruel to either Tera or switch. Sun teams are a mixed bag: Torkoal’s Eruption is scary, but if Toedscruel survives the first hit it can Spore the setter and buy two free turns. Against Rain, Water-tera gives it a crucial resistance to Fire, but the lack of recovery means repeated Hydro Pumps still wear it down. In the mirror, speed ties decide everything; the analyzed cohort shows almost every Toedscruel is Timid max-speed, so winning the coin-flip is paramount.</OUTPUT>

It is brought to teams that want to force 2-vs-1 scenarios via sleep, spread special defense drops for its special-attack partners, and provide emergency redirection. Because it is neither a hyper-offensive threat nor a pure wall, it fits best on balanced cores that already carry Incineroar or Garchomp—Pokemon that can take advantage of the free turns Spore generates without needing additional set-up. Its ability to ignore priority-padded Fake Out and ignore abilities also makes it a reliable lead against Indeedee/Armarouge or Follow-Me Togekiss structures.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Toedscruel": {"Abilities": {"myceliummight": 44.477051072074076}, "Items": {"covertcloak": 0.8242886057976545}, "Spreads": {"Timid:196/0/60/0/0/252": 0.3775834054174328, "Timid:124/0/180/4/12/188": 0.19770208139100287}, "Moves": ["earthpower", "acidspray", "spore", "ragepowder"], "Tera Types": {"water": 0.7865236416138092}, "Teammates": ["Typhlosion-Hisui", "Weezing-Galar", "Incineroar", "Garchomp", "Pawmot", "Kilowattrel"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Incineroar is the most common partner, providing Intimidate, Parting Shot, and a Fire-typing that covers Toedscruel’s Ice and Bug weaknesses while appreciating sleep support against Water- and Rock-types that threaten it. Garchomp forms a classic “FWG” core, resisting Fire and Electric for Toedscruel while benefiting from Acid Spray drops to secure KOs with Tera-Dragon Earthquake. Hisuian Typhlosion loves free switch-ins created by Spore, and can chain Eruptions unimpeded once enemy Fire resists are slept. Weezing-Galar covers the Fairy weakness, provides Neutralizing Gas to disable opposing Mycelium Might or Purifying Salt, and can set Toxic Spikes to further pressure bulky waters. Pawmot gives the squad a Revival Blessing win-condition, but more importantly its Electric typing deters Flying-types from spamming Hurricane into Toedscruel. Kilowattrel is the fastest Tailwind setter that also threatens opposing Water-types with Thunderbolt, forming a clean “Spore -> Tailwind -> double-target” opener against slower teams.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Grass-types are the hard counter: Amoonguss and Wo-Chien absorb Spore and can either clear status with Clear Smog or retaliate with super-effective Sludge Bombs. Safety Goggles on Indeedee, Torkoal, or Iron Hands completely negate Toedscruel’s primary value, forcing it to rely on weak Earth Powers. Fast Flying-types—Tornadus, Iron Bundle, and Kilowattrel—outspeed and OHKO with Hurricane or Ice Beam before it can move unless Toedscruel Terastallizes. Priority users such as Dragonite Extreme Speed or Kingambit Sucker Punch can finish it off after chip, and because Toedscruel rarely runs Protect, it is vulnerable to double-targets. Finally, sun-boosted Eruption from Torkoal or Chi-Yu’s Tera-Fire attacks do upwards of 80% even through Water Tera, so sun matchup requires careful positioning or immediate sleep on the setter.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Jumpluff is a dedicated sun-setting support Pokémon whose sole purpose is to enable Chlorophyll sweepers by firing off fast Tailwind and Sleep Powder under harsh sunlight; its blistering base 110 Speed combined with Chlorophyll doubles its Speed in sun, letting it move before almost any unboosted threat while Covert Cloak keeps it safe from Fake Out and Rage Powder punishes spread attackers. <DATA>{"Jumpluff": {"Abilities": {"chlorophyll": 44.605060988286986, "infiltrator": 0.060994896266694576, "leafguard": 0.06865470455287509}, "Items": {"covertcloak": 0.8864784898173954}, "Spreads": {"Timid:244/0/44/0/0/220": 0.15559845299719902}, "Moves": ["tailwind", "sleeppowder", "ragepowder", "sunnyday"], "Tera Types": {"water": 0.6099204728838064}, "Teammates": ["Ursaluna", "Torkoal", "Charizard", "Incineroar", "Porygon2", "Typhlosion-Hisui"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Jumpluff’s competitive niche is almost entirely defined by Chlorophyll and its unique support move-pool: Tailwind for speed control, Sleep Powder for crippling counters, Rage Powder to redirect spread moves away from frail sun sweepers, and Sunny Day to reset weather or start sun without Torkoal.  Base 110 Speed already places it ahead of common support like Murkrow and Cyclizar, and under sun it becomes the fastest support Pokémon in the format bar Regieleki.  Covert Cloak is the only item used because it blocks Fake Out, icy-wind speed drops, and Nuzzle paralysis—disruptions that would otherwise stop Jumpluff from firing off its one crucial move.  Tera Water is the dominant Tera type, removing the Fire weakness that sun teams inherently invite and turning Jumpluff into a soft check to sun mirror Heat Wave and Torkoal’s Eruption.  EVs are poured into Speed and bulk: 244 HP gives a Life Orb number, 44 Def guarantees it survives -1 Palafin Jet Punch, and 220 Spe with Timid reaches 197 (394 in sun), outspeeding +1 Roaring Moon and scarf Meowscarada.  The complete absence of attacking moves shows Jumpluff accepts zero offensive responsibility—it is a pure enabler that wins games by letting partners like Ursaluna, Charizard, and Typhlosion-Hisui move first and hit twice as hard under sun.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Against rain Jumpluff is naturally oppressed—Pelipper’s rain cancels sun, and Kingdra or Barraskewda outspeed and KO.  Versus Trick Room it fares better: it can Sunny Day on the turn Trick Room is set, then Sleep Powder the setter or Tailwind so its own sweepers can function during Trick Room turns.  Against other weatherless speed control mirrors it shines; Murkrow and Cyclizar are out-sped and put to sleep, while Cyclizar cannot break Covert Cloak with Snarl.  Into Incineroar and other Fake Out users Cloak lets Jumpluff ignore the flinch and immediately respond with Tailwind or Sleep Powder.  Amoonguss is problematic because Spore ignores Cloak, but Jumpluff can Tera Water to tank Sludge Bomb and retaliate by putting Amoonguss to sleep first.  Overall Jumpluff wins match-ups where sun is up and loses those where opposing weather or priority paralysis is established.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Palafin dominates neutral matchups thanks to its spammable Water STAB and priority, but struggles against bulky Grass- and Dragon-types. Amoonguss walls every move except Tera Blast Ice and can Spore it through Misty Terrain if Tera Grass is unavailable. Rillaboom, both ally and enemy, outslows and OHKOs with Grassy Glide while shrugging off Jet Punch through Grassy Terrain recovery. Dragapult and Archaludon resist Water and retaliate with Draco Meteor or Stomping Tantrum respectively; however, both drop to +1 Tera Water Wave Crash after prior chip. Electric Terrain teams featuring Iron Hands or Iron Thorns can stomach a hit and KO back with Thunder Punch, but must beware the 30% flinch from Jet Punch. Rain teams love Palafin because it breaks opposing weather setters, yet opposing Pelipper can muddy the speed order and let Swampert outspeed and KO. Against Trick Room, Palafin functions as a late-game cleaner once the mode ends, but is dead weight inside it unless it carries Scarf to underspeed and flip turn out. Tera Fairy Dragapult and Tera Grass Kingambit are emerging techs to bait and beat Palafin one-on-one. Overall, Palafin dictates the tempo of most games: if it enters safely, something faints; if it is denied transformation or terrain, it becomes setup fodder.</OUTPUT>

Mid-game it fires off Jet Punch to pick off weakened threats, deny speed control, and punish Fake Out users. Palafin’s role is therefore not to tank hits, but to guarantee that every turn it takes results in an advantageous HP trade or a free switch for a teammate.</OUTPUT>

In short, if you can prevent the flip turn, survive the first hit, or exploit its predictability, Palafin becomes manageable.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>In the current Regulation G metagame Weavile occupies a unique speed tier that outpaces the entire Paradox quartet, Ogerpon, and both Landorus-T and Enamorus while still OHKOing or 2HKOing most of the tier’s support cores.  Ice Spinner is preferred over Icicle Crash for its perfect accuracy and its ability to remove Psychic Terrain and grassy terrain on the switch, neutering Indeedee/Armarouge redirection and weakening opposing Grassy Glide or Horn Leech recovery.  Knock Off is the second most spammable move in doubles and lets Weavile cripple common switch-ins such as Corviknight, Tornadus, and opposing Sashed leads.  Ice Shard gives the team a much-needed priority option that cleanly picks off weakened Flutter Mane, Dragapult, and opposing Weavile.  Protect is mandatory for double-target mind-games and to guarantee the Focus Sash is not broken before Weavile can act.  Terastallizing into Ghost is the consensus best choice: it flips the script on Fighting-type counters, blocks Extreme Speed and Mach Punch, and grants a crucial Fake Out immunity that lets Weavile protect its partner or secure a second attack.  Pressure is the default ability because Pickpocket is too inconsistent in doubles, but the difference is marginal.  EV spreads are almost always 4 HP / 252 Atk / 252 Spe Jolly to maximize damage and speed while the remaining 4 EVs are dumped into HP; the Focus Sash guarantees at least one full-power attack or a safe Tailwind/Parting Shot from a teammate.  Weavile’s offensive typing is simultaneously its greatest strength and its Achilles heel: Ice/Dark is unresisted against the majority of the tier, but it also leaves Weavile weak to every common form of priority and every relevant spread move.  Consequently, Weavile is almost never the win-condition itself; instead it functions as a high-tempo pivot that trades one-for-one or removes items so that bulkier teammates such as Ursaluna-Bloodmoon, Archaludon, or Annihililape can sweep later.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Weavile dominates offensive teams that rely on speed control from Choice Scarf or Tailwind, since it naturally outspeeds the entire unboosted metagame and picks off frail threats with Ice Shard.  It crushes Psychic-spam cores built around Indeedee + Armarouge or Indeedee + Gholdengo because Ice Spinner strips terrain and Knock Off removes the Assault Vest or Sitrus Berry that these teams rely on for longevity.  Against weather, Weavile threatens Pelipper and Torkoal for heavy damage and can remove Damp Rock/Heat Rock to shorten weather turns, though it must watch for Scald burns or Heat Wave flinches.  Stall and balance squads that carry bulky Fighting-types—Annihilape, Iron Hands, or Hariyama—are the hardest counters, as they can stomach a Knock Off and OHKO back with Mach Punch or Close Combat.  Corviknight and Togekiss completely wall Weavile and can set up Tailwind or Bulldoze speed control in its face, while Rotom-Wash and Rotom-Heat can burn it or simply Volt Switch out.  Priority users such as Dragonite with Extreme Speed or Kingambit with Sucker Punch also force mind-games that often end in Weavile’s demise if the Sash is already broken.  Finally, because Weavile is almost always choiced into Ghost, any opposing Dark-type that can survive a hit—Tyranitar, Kingambit, or opposing Weavile—will force it out or trade unfavorably.</OUTPUT>

Its low bulk means it rarely survives beyond two turns, so every move must count: Knock Off is used liberally, Ice Spinner is aimed at terrain setters, and Ice Shard is saved for the fastest or most threatening opposing Pokémon.  In short, Weavile is a high-speed, high-risk trade piece that buys momentum and item control for bulkier, slower teammates.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Gothitelle": {"Abilities": {"shadowtag": 36.393439607521024, "competitive": 0.310197199460256, "frisk": 0.2200409292795107}, "Items": {"sitrusberry": 0.7389499120756127}, "Spreads": {"Bold:252/0/196/0/60/0": 0.24559411174825957}, "Moves": ["fakeout", "protect", "psychic", "trickroom"], "Tera Types": {"water": 0.41523090221885606, "dark": 0.32460745874132346}, "Teammates": ["Incineroar", "Archaludon", "Politoed", "Amoonguss", "Primarina", "Gholdengo"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Gothitelle is a premier support Pokémon in VGC thanks almost entirely to Shadow Tag, letting it imprison opposing switch-ins and set up Trick Room for slower, bulkier teams. With a single dominant item (Sitrus Berry) and a standard support move triad of Fake Out, Protect, Psychic and Trick Room, it is a one-set wonder that compresses speed control, chip damage, and trap-stall duties into one slot. Bold 196 Def / 60 SpD investment lets it survive common physical and special hits, while Water and Dark Tera types give clutch one-time resistances against Fire- and Fighting-type onslaughts. It is almost never seen without Incineroar and Archaludon, forming the backbone of a bulky Trick Room core that pressures offense and balances alike.</OUTPUT>

input:
Write the 'full_analysis' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Gothitelle": {"Abilities": {"shadowtag": 36.393439607521024, "competitive": 0.310197199460256, "frisk": 0.2200409292795107}, "Items": {"sitrusberry": 0.7389499120756127}, "Spreads": {"Bold:252/0/196/0/60/0": 0.24559411174825957}, "Moves": ["fakeout", "protect", "psychic", "trickroom"], "Tera Types": {"water": 0.41523090221885606, "dark": 0.32460745874132346}, "Teammates": ["Incineroar", "Archaludon", "Politoed", "Amoonguss", "Primarina", "Gholdengo"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Shadow Tag is the engine that drives Gothitelle’s viability; by denying the opponent the ability to switch, Gothitelle can safely click Trick Room against faster teams or stall out Dynamax turns against restricted legends. Fake Out adds immediate tempo, forcing 50-50 protect reads and letting partners such as Archalodon or Primarina set up or fire off spread moves unhindered. Protect is mandatory for scouting choice-locked attackers and gaining extra Leftovers-style recovery with Sitrus Berry. Psychic is the obligatory STAB, 2HKOing Amoonguss and Toxapex while avoiding the collateral damage of Psyshock onto physical walls. The EV spread is optimized to survive -1 Life Orb Chien-Pao Ice Spinner, Choice Band Palafin Jet Punch, and modest Gholdengo Make It Rain, while the 60 SpD guarantees that it is never OHKOed by Specs Toxapex Sludge Bomb after Sitrus recovery. Tera Water flips the script on Incineroar’s Flare Blitz and Tera Dark dodges Ghost-type Judgment from opposing Gholdengo. Gothitelle’s low usage stats outside of Shadow Tag (Competitive and Frisk combine for under 0.6 %) underscore how irreplaceable the trapping ability is; without it, Gothitelle would be outclassed by Indeedee or Alcremie.</OUTPUT>

Produce the 'matchup_overview' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Gothitelle": {"Abilities": {"shadowtag": 36.393439607521024, "competitive": 0.310197199460256, "frisk": 0.2200409292795107}, "Items": {"sitrusberry": 0.7389499120756127}, "Spreads": {"Bold:252/0/196/0/60/0": 0.24559411174825957}, "Moves": ["fakeout", "protect", "psychic", "trickroom"], "Tera Types": {"water": 0.41523090221885606, "dark": 0.32460745874132346}, "Teammates": ["Incineroar", "Archaludon", "Politoed", "Amoonguss", "Primarina", "Gholdengo"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Against hyper-offense, Gothitelle is a hard counter: Shadow Tag prevents opponents from rotating to a faster sweeper after a KO, allowing Trick Room to go up unimpeded and turning threats like Chien-Pao and Iron Bundle into dead weight. Balance teams that rely on pivoting with U-turn or Volt Switch crumble because their momentum is nullified, while Gothitelle can Protect stall into favorable end-games. Stall is more nuanced—Gothitelle can’t break through Toxapex or Dondozo alone, but it can imprison their recovery turns and let partners such as Archaludon or Specs Primarina overwhelm them. Rain is tricky; Pelipper can’t switch out, but Kingdra under rain still outspeeds and OHKOes with Hydro Pump, so Gothitelle must Tera Water or rely on Politoed’s rain canceling. Sun is similarly dangerous—Torkoal can’t escape, but Tera Fire Eruption still melts Gothitelle unless it Tera Waters on the predicted switch. Ghost-types like Aegislash and Gholdengo fear Shadow Tag less because they can KO Gothitelle first, making Tera Dark a key mid-game option to survive Shadow Ball.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Gothitelle": {"Abilities": {"shadowtag": 36.393439607521024, "competitive": 0.310197199460256, "frisk": 0.2200409292795107}, "Items": {"sitrusberry": 0.7389499120756127}, "Spreads": {"Bold:252/0/196/0/60/0": 0.24559411174825957}, "Moves": ["fakeout", "protect", "psychic", "trickroom"], "Tera Types": {"water": 0.41523090221885606, "dark": 0.32460745874132346}, "Teammates": ["Incineroar", "Archaludon", "Politoed", "Amoonguss", "Primarina", "Gholdengo"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Gothitelle is a dedicated lead and mid-game trap-stall support. In the lead slot it pairs with Fake Out users or redirection to guarantee Trick Room, while in the mid-game it can come in after a KO, trap a choice-locked attacker, and Protect stall until the Dynamax ends. Its low offensive stats mean it is never the win condition; instead, it creates win conditions by removing the opponent’s ability to revenge kill or pivot. Shadow Tag also enables last-turn trapping in best-of-three timer stall strategies, a niche that has clinched many regional top-cuts. Gothitelle’s speed tier—base 65—lets it underspeed most offensive threats under Trick Room while still outspeeding dedicated room sweepers like Stakataka and Torkoal, ensuring it can fire off a final Fake Out or Psychic before fainting.</OUTPUT>

Write the 'synergy_breakdown' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Gothitelle": {"Abilities": {"shadowtag": 36.393439607521024, "competitive": 0.310197199460256, "frisk": 0.2200409292795107}, "Items": {"sitrusberry": 0.7389499120756127}, "Spreads": {"Bold:252/0/196/0/60/0": 0.24559411174825957}, "Moves": ["fakeout", "protect", "psychic", "trickroom"], "Tera Types": {"water": 0.41523090221885606, "dark": 0.32460745874132346}, "Teammates": ["Incineroar", "Archaludon", "Politoed", "Amoonguss", "Primarina", "Gholdengo"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Incineroar is the ideal partner: Intimidate plus Fake Out from both Pokémon forms a double disruption core that neutilizes physical attackers, while Parting Shot gives Gothitelle safe re-entry to reset Trick Room. Archaludon appreciates the removal of faster Water- and Ground-types; with Gothitelle trapping and stalling, Archaludon can set up Steel Beam or spam Electro Shot without fear of Rotom-Wash or Iron Hands switching in. Politoed provides additional Fake Out and rain to weaken Fire-type attacks versus Gothitelle, while Gothitelle traps and removes opposing weather setters. Amoonguss offers redirection and status, letting Gothitelle set Trick Room even against double-target pressure, and in return Gothitelle traps and removes Amoonguss’s checks like Toxapex and Gholdengo. Primarina and Gholdengo are the primary special attackers that benefit from Trick Room; both can OHKO the Dark- and Steel-types that trouble Gothitelle, while Gothitelle traps their faster checks such as Meowscarada and Chien-Pao.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Gothitelle @ Sitrus Berry  Ability: Shadow Tag  Level: 50  EVs: 252 HP / 196 Def / 60 SpD  Bold Nature  IVs: 0 Atk / 0 Spe  - Fake Out  - Protect  - Psychic  - Trick Room  Tera Type: Water / Dark  Alternate spread: 252 HP / 140 Def / 116 SpD Calm if special attackers like Specs Gholdengo are more prevalent. Tera Water is the default for Fire-type coverage; Tera Dark is chosen when Ghost-type STAB or Dark-type allies like Incineroar demand the resistance. No speed EVs ensure underspeeding inside Trick Room while minimizing Foul Play and confusion damage. Psychic > Psyshock because the extra power secures the 2HKO on Amoonguss and Toxapex; dropping Fake Out for Ally Switch is a gimmick that sacrifices too much tempo. Sitrus Berry is non-negotiable—Colbur or Chilan berries do not provide the same longevity against spread damage and double-targets.</OUTPUT>

input:
Produce the 'weaknesses_and_counters' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Gothitelle": {"Abilities": {"shadowtag": 36.393439607521024, "competitive": 0.310197199460256, "frisk": 0.2200409292795107}, "Items": {"sitrusberry": 0.7389499120756127}, "Spreads": {"Bold:252/0/196/0/60/0": 0.24559411174825957}, "Moves": ["fakeout", "protect", "psychic", "trickroom"], "Tera Types": {"water": 0.41523090221885606, "dark": 0.32460745874132346}, "Teammates": ["Incineroar", "Archaludon", "Politoed", "Amoonguss", "Primarina", "Gholdengo"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Dark-types are public enemy number one: Choice Band Chien-Pao and Kingambit both OHKO with Sucker Punch or Kowtow before Gothitelle can Tera, so Gothitelle must either Tera Dark on the switch or rely on Incineroar’s Intimidate. Ghost-types like Aegislash and Gholdengo can KO first with Shadow Ball or Make It Rain, forcing Gothitelle to Protect stall or Tera Dark. Bug-types are rare but devastating—Scizor’s Bug Bite removes Sitrus and OHKOes, while Volcarona can Quiver Dance on the trapped Gothitelle. Multi-hit attackers such as Breloom or Maushold bypass Sitrus recovery and break through. Taunt completely shuts Gothitelle down, so Mental Herb variants of Toxapex and Corviknight can prevent Trick Room; however, Gothitelle can simply Protect stall until Taunt fades. Finally, Dynamax ignores Shadow Tag, so a Max Airstream or Max Quake can KO Gothitelle before it can reset the room.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Gothitelle": {"Abilities": {"shadowtag": 36.393439607521024, "competitive": 0.310197199460256, "frisk": 0.2200409292795107}, "Items": {"sitrusberry": 0.7389499120756127}, "Spreads": {"Bold:252/0/196/0/60/0": 0.24559411174825957}, "Moves": ["fakeout", "protect", "psychic", "trickroom"], "Tera Types": {"water": 0.41523090221885606, "dark": 0.32460745874132346}, "Teammates": ["Incineroar", "Archaludon", "Politoed", "Amoonguss", "Primarina", "Gholdengo"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Trick Room Balance: Gothitelle + Incineroar + Archaludon + Politoed + Amoonguss + Primarina. Lead Gothitelle + Incineroar to Fake Out and Intimidate, set Trick Room, then pivot into Archaludon or Primarina under redirection from Amoonguss. Politoed provides rain to soften Fire-type hits and additional Fake Out pressure. The team is weak to opposing Gholdengo, so Tera Dark on Gothitelle and Specs Primarina are mandatory. EV spreads maximize bulk while ensuring Archaludon and Primarina outspeed base 100s under Trick Room. The sixth slot can be flexed to Gholdengo for hazard stacking or Toxapex for additional Toxic stalling, but the core six provide a proven regional-winning balance that abuses Shadow Tag to remove fast threats and let the slow powerhouses sweep.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Clefable": {"Abilities": {"unaware": 28.458382205753473, "magicguard": 7.285977065991342, "cutecharm": 0.1891304812657585}, "Items": {"sitrusberry": 0.46311259771561153, "safetygoggles": 0.3943379459897608}, "Spreads": {"Bold:252/0/212/0/44/0": 0.1974420955012298, "Calm:252/0/116/60/76/4": 0.271363263616915}, "Moves": ["lifedew", "followme", "moonblast", "protect"], "Tera Types": {"water": 0.5578535677937019, "poison": 0.1946577877794638}, "Teammates": ["Incineroar", "Rillaboom", "Volcarona", "Gholdengo", "Baxcalibur", "Electrode-Hisui"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Clefable carves a unique niche in VGC 2024 as a bulky Fairy-type support, leaning on Follow Me and Life Dew to redirect and heal while Moonblast threatens Dragons and Dark-types. Unaware is the dominant ability (appearing on roughly 80% of sampled teams), letting it ignore opposing stat boosts and check setup sweepers such as Volcarona or Iron Hands. Its EV spreads prioritize physical or mixed bulk—Bold with 212 Def or Calm with 76 SpD—so it can survive a wide array of super-effective hits and continue supporting allies. Tera Water is the most common Tera type, granting a crucial Fire resistance and removing the Fairy-type’s Steel weakness for a turn, while Tera Poison punges Grass and provides Toxic-immunity. Itemization is light, with Sitrus Berry and Safety Goggles both hovering under 0.5% usage, meaning Clefable is usually slotting in as a low-investment glue rather than a win-condition. It appears almost exclusively alongside Incineroar and Rillaboom, two pivots that appreciate Clefable’s redirection and cleric support, while Volcarona, Gholdengo, Baxcalibur, and Hisuian Electrode round out cores that value safe setup or speed control.</OUTPUT>

input:
Provide the 'full_analysis' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Clefable": {"Abilities": {"unaware": 28.458382205753473, "magicguard": 7.285977065991342, "cutecharm": 0.1891304812657585}, "Items": {"sitrusberry": 0.46311259771561153, "safetygoggles": 0.3943379459897608}, "Spreads": {"Bold:252/0/212/0/44/0": 0.1974420955012298, "Calm:252/0/116/60/76/4": 0.271363263616915}, "Moves": ["lifedew", "followme", "moonblast", "protect"], "Tera Types": {"water": 0.5578535677937019, "poison": 0.1946577877794638}, "Teammates": ["Incineroar", "Rillaboom", "Volcarona", "Gholdengo", "Baxcalibur", "Electrode-Hisui"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Clefable’s value in the current Regulation G metagame stems from its rare combination of Follow Me, Life Dew, and Unaware in a single slot. Follow Me remains one of the few redirection options that does not require a turn of setup, allowing partners to click boosting moves like Dragon Dance or Quiver Dance, fire off powerful spread attacks, or set terrain/weather with impunity. Life Dew then patches the 25% HP cost of repeated redirects, creating a sustainable pivot that can sit on the field for multiple turns. Unaware is the keystone: with 252/212 Bold it avoids the OHKO from +1 Chien-Pao Ice Spinner, survives Flutter Mane Moonblast, and lives Life Orb Kingambit Iron Head, all while ignoring Swords Dance or Bulk Up boosts. Calm variants with 76 SpD are tuned to stomach Specs Dragapult Shadow Ball and +2 Volcarona Heat Wave, making Clefable one of the few reliable stopgaps to late-game cleaners. Offensively, Moonblast is spammable and 2HKOes most Dragons, Dark-types, and Fighting-types, forcing switches that buy more redirection turns. Protect is mandatory for stalling Fake Out, Tera activations, and allied spread damage. Tera Water flips the script on Fire-type counters—turning a 2× weakness into a resistance—so even Sun-boosted Eruption from Torkoal fails to KO, while Tera Poison punishes Grass-types like Amoonguss or Rillaboom that expect to chip Clefable with Clear Smog or Wood Hammer. The low item usage indicates that Clefable is rarely the team’s win-condition; instead it is a low-maintenance support piece that operates without heavy EV or item investment, freeing resources for bulkier attackers or setup sweepers.</OUTPUT>

input:
Produce the 'matchup_overview' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Clefable": {"Abilities": {"unaware": 28.458382205753473, "magicguard": 7.285977065991342, "cutecharm": 0.1891304812657585}, "Items": {"sitrusberry": 0.46311259771561153, "safetygoggles": 0.3943379459897608}, "Spreads": {"Bold:252/0/212/0/44/0": 0.1974420955012298, "Calm:252/0/116/60/76/4": 0.271363263616915}, "Moves": ["lifedew", "followme", "moonblast", "protect"], "Tera Types": {"water": 0.5578535677937019, "poison": 0.1946577877794638}, "Teammates": ["Incineroar", "Rillaboom", "Volcarona", "Gholdengo", "Baxcalibur", "Electrode-Hisui"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Clefable’s matchups are defined by its ability to nullify setup and provide consistent redirection. Against hyper-offense it is a hard counter: Unaware ignores Dragon Dance Baxcalibur, Swords Dance Kingambit, and Bulk Up Iron Hands, while Follow Me buys a free turn for its own partner to retaliate or set up. Into Sun or Rain, Tera Water lets it survive Torkoal Eruption or Specs Pelipper Hurricane and continue healing allies. Versus Trick Room, Clefable can redirect Hatterene or Indeedee to prevent terrain or allow its own side to set TR, then Life Dew stall the four turns. Against Grass-spam cores (Rillaboom + Amoonguss) Tera Poison removes the Grass weakness and blocks Spore, turning Clefable into an emergency status absorber. Steel-types remain the biggest obstacle: Tera Steel Gholdengo is immune to poison, resists Moonblast, and can 2HKO with Make It Rain; likewise Tera Kingambit with Iron Head pressures Clefable even through Tera. Poison-types like Tera Amoonguss or Glimmora can also outlast Moonblast and threaten with Sludge Bomb. Finally, double-targeting or spread damage (Earthquake, Rock Slide) can overwhelm Clefable’s recovery, especially if Safety Goggles is not equipped to ignore Spore or Rage Powder.</OUTPUT>

input:
Create the 'role_description' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Clefable": {"Abilities": {"unaware": 28.458382205753473, "magicguard": 7.285977065991342, "cutecharm": 0.1891304812657585}, "Items": {"sitrusberry": 0.46311259771561153, "safetygoggles": 0.3943379459897608}, "Spreads": {"Bold:252/0/212/0/44/0": 0.1974420955012298, "Calm:252/0/116/60/76/4": 0.271363263616915}, "Moves": ["lifedew", "followme", "moonblast", "protect"], "Tera Types": {"water": 0.5578535677937019, "poison": 0.1946577877794638}, "Teammates": ["Incineroar", "Rillaboom", "Volcarona", "Gholdengo", "Baxcalibur", "Electrode-Hisui"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Clefable is a pure support pivot whose job is to sit on the field, redirect single-target attacks, neutralize opposing stat boosts with Unaware, and provide team-wide healing. It is not a damage dealer—Moonblast is primarily deterrent—but rather a momentum gatekeeper that enables setup or protects fragile attackers. Because its EV spreads are tuned to survive specific benchmarks rather than outspeed threats, Clefable almost always moves last, using Protect and Life Dew to waste opposing dynamax turns or stall out weather/terrain. In the early game it leads beside fast attackers or setup sweepers to guarantee safe setup; in the late game it becomes a clerical wall that can repeatedly Life Dew while the partner cleans. Tera is used reactively: Tera Water when opposing Fire-type dynamax is revealed, Tera Poison when Grass or Toxic status is imminent. Because it carries no speed control of its own, Clefable relies on teammates to provide Tailwind, Trick Room, or Electrode’s Speed Swap.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Clefable": {"Abilities": {"unaware": 28.458382205753473, "magicguard": 7.285977065991342, "cutecharm": 0.1891304812657585}, "Items": {"sitrusberry": 0.46311259771561153, "safetygoggles": 0.3943379459897608}, "Spreads": {"Bold:252/0/212/0/44/0": 0.1974420955012298, "Calm:252/0/116/60/76/4": 0.271363263616915}, "Moves": ["lifedew", "followme", "moonblast", "protect"], "Tera Types": {"water": 0.5578535677937019, "poison": 0.1946577877794638}, "Teammates": ["Incineroar", "Rillaboom", "Volcarona", "Gholdengo", "Baxcalibur", "Electrode-Hisui"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Incineroar is the perfect partner: Intimidate plus Parting Shot softens physical attackers that might 2HKO Clefable, while Clefable redirects away from Incineroar’s 4× Fighting weakness. Rillaboom forms a Grassy Terrain core that passively heals Clefable and weakens Earthquake, allowing Calm spreads to forgo extra Defense for more SpD. Volcarona appreciates Follow Me to buy a Quiver Dance, then sweeps behind Clefable’s Life Dew support. Gholdengo benefits from redirection while it sets up Make It Rain or Steel Beam, and Clefable’s Tera Poison removes the Ghost-type’s Dark weakness. Baxcalibur can safely Dragon Dance while Clefable redirects Ice-type moves, then Glaive Rush cleans. Hisuian Electrode provides Speed Swap to let Clefable move first for clutch Life Dew or Follow Me, while Clefable removes the Bug weakness Electrode faces from Kingambit. In general, Clefable fits on balanced or bulky-offense teams that need one slot to solve both setup protection and opposing booster checks.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>The two proven spreads are: 1) Bold 252 HP / 212 Def / 44 SpD with Unaware, Tera Water, and Sitrus Berry—this survives +1 Chien-Pao Ice Spinner, Jolly Iron Head from Kingambit, and Timid Flutter Mane Moonblast, while outslowing most threats to guarantee last-slot Life Dew. 2) Calm 252 HP / 116 Def / 76 SpD / 4 Spe with Unaware, Tera Poison, and Safety Goggles—this lives Specs Dragapult Shadow Ball, +2 Volcarona Heat Wave in Sun, and ignores Amoonguss Spore. input:
Provide the 'weaknesses_and_counters' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Clefable": {"Abilities": {"unaware": 28.458382205753473, "magicguard": 7.285977065991342, "cutecharm": 0.1891304812657585}, "Items": {"sitrusberry": 0.46311259771561153, "safetygoggles": 0.3943379459897608}, "Spreads": {"Bold:252/0/212/0/44/0": 0.1974420955012298, "Calm:252/0/116/60/76/4": 0.271363263616915}, "Moves": ["lifedew", "followme", "moonblast", "protect"], "Tera Types": {"water": 0.5578535677937019, "poison": 0.1946577877794638}, "Teammates": ["Incineroar", "Rillaboom", "Volcarona", "Gholdengo", "Baxcalibur", "Electrode-Hisui"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Steel-types that can stomach Moonblast are the clearest answers: Tera Steel Gholdengo, Tera Kingambit, and Tera Iron Hands all threaten the 2HKO with super-effective Steel moves while resisting Fairy. Strong spread attackers like Tera Earthquake Landorus-T or Tera Rock Slide Tyranitar can bypass Follow Me and overwhelm Clefable’s recovery. Status—especially Toxic from Glimmora or Toxapex—cripples Clefable’s long-game, since Life Dew cannot outpace repeated poison damage. Taunt users such as Murkrow or Grimmsnarl shut off Life Dew and Follow Me, forcing Clefable into passive Moonblast loops. Finally, double-targeting or dynamax burst damage can KO before Tera or Sitrus activate; for example, Specs Kyogre Water Spout + Calyrex-Shadow Astral Barrage cleanly OHKOes even the bulky Calm spread. To beat Clefable, bring at least one Steel-type attacker, pack spread or multi-target moves, and apply constant offensive pressure so it cannot afford to click Life Dew.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Clefable": {"Abilities": {"unaware": 28.458382205753473, "magicguard": 7.285977065991342, "cutecharm": 0.1891304812657585}, "Items": {"sitrusberry": 0.46311259771561153, "safetygoggles": 0.3943379459897608}, "Spreads": {"Bold:252/0/212/0/44/0": 0.1974420955012298, "Calm:252/0/116/60/76/4": 0.271363263616915}, "Moves": ["lifedew", "followme", "moonblast", "protect"], "Tera Types": {"water": 0.5578535677937019, "poison": 0.1946577877794638}, "Teammates": ["Incineroar", "Rillaboom", "Volcarona", "Gholdengo", "Baxcalibur", "Electrode-Hisui"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Start with the classic Fire-Water-Grass core: Incineroar @ Assault Vest + Rillaboom @ Miracle Seed + Clefable @ Sitrus Berry. Add Volcarona @ Focus Sash as the setup win-condition that benefits from Clefable redirection. Round out with Gholdengo @ Choice Specs for Steel-type offense and Hisuian Electrode @ Light Clay for Speed Swap + Screens. Incineroar and Rillaboom provide pivoting and terrain, Clefable redirects and heals, Volcarona sweeps after a Quiver Dance, Gholdengo breaks opposing Steel-types, and Electrode ensures speed control. The team has a clear game plan: lead Clefable + Volcarona vs offense to guarantee setup, or Clefable + Incineroar vs physical attackers to cycle Intimidate + Parting Shot. Tera Water on Clefable covers Sun, Tera Poison covers Grass, while the rest of the team can flex Tera types for coverage. EV spreads are standard: 252 HP on Clefable, 252 Atk on Rillaboom, 252 SpA on Gholdengo, 252 Spe on Electrode, mixed bulk on Incineroar, and 252 HP / 252 SpA on Volcarona with Quiver Dance. The result is a balanced, low-maintenance team that abuses Clefable’s support to enable multiple win-conditions.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Pawmot": {"Abilities": {"naturalcure": 17.897918440610507, "voltabsorb": 16.45221782235503, "ironfist": 1.890713619960059}, "Items": {"focussash": 0.8650159025387338}, "Spreads": {"Jolly:0/252/0/0/4/252": 0.4242323807454522, "Jolly:4/252/0/0/0/252": 0.19101938975171284, "Jolly:0/252/4/0/0/252": 0.2818517199262227}, "Moves": ["doubleshock", "closecombat", "fakeout", "protect"], "Tera Types": {"electric": 0.9523808009687763}, "Teammates": ["Weezing-Galar", "Toedscruel", "Garchomp", "Typhlosion-Hisui", "Gholdengo", "Dondozo"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Pawmot’s stat line is min-maxed for aggression: base 115 Attack and 110 Speed give it the jump on Garchomp, Lando-T, and most bulky pivots, while its frail 70 / 70 / 60 bulk means it cannot trade for long. Double Shock is the headline move—an Electric-type Explosion that removes the user’s Electric typing after use. This self-typing removal is double-edged: on the one hand it robs Pawmot of STAB, but on the other it turns incoming Electric or Ground moves neutral, letting you dodge predicted T-bolts or Earthquakes after the nuke. Close Combat provides perfect neutral coverage alongside Double Shock, smashing Steels that resist Electric and Stealth Rock setters like Gholdengo. Fake Out is invaluable for speed control and free chip, while Protect preserves Focus Sash and lets Pawmot wait out Tailwind turns. Natural Cure is the most used ability because status—especially Twave from Rotom or WoW from Arcanine—otherwise cripples its sweep; a single switch cures it. Volt Absorb is situationally better on teams that bait opposing Electric moves, turning Pawmot into a soft check to Zapdos or Iron Hands. Iron Fist is niche but technically boosts Drain Punch (which the data do not show) or Thunder Punch; the usage implies players value the raw power of Double Shock over marginal fist boosts. Tera Electric is near-universal: it nullifies the Double Shock drawback, keeps STAB, and gives Pawmot a one-time 140 BP nuke that can OHKO neutral targets like Tornadus or bulky Gholdengo after chip. EV spreads are almost always 252 Atk / 252 Spe Jolly to maximize speed ties; the occasional 4 HP or 4 Def are optimization noise rather than bulk benchmarks.</OUTPUT>
