<DATA>{"Pawmot": {"Abilities": {"naturalcure": 17.897918440610507, "voltabsorb": 16.45221782235503, "ironfist": 1.890713619960059}, "Items": {"focussash": 0.8650159025387338}, "Spreads": {"Jolly:0/252/0/0/4/252": 0.4242323807454522, "Jolly:4/252/0/0/0/252": 0.19101938975171284, "Jolly:0/252/4/0/0/252": 0.2818517199262227}, "Moves": ["doubleshock", "closecombat", "fakeout", "protect"], "Tera Types": {"electric": 0.9523808009687763}, "Teammates": ["Weezing-Galar", "Toedscruel", "Garchomp", "Typhlosion-Hisui", "Gholdengo", "Dondozo"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Pawmot’s Electric-Fighting coverage only misses Toxapex, Slowbro, and a handful of bulky Fairies, so its matchups hinge on whether it can outspeed and OHKO before it is revenged. It crushes Water-centric cores—Pelipper, Rotom-W, and Dondozo all fold to Double Shock, while Azumarill and Iron Hands drop to Close Combat. Against Grass types it is neutral at best: Amoonguss survives Double Shock after Sitrus and retaliates with Spore, but Natural Cure versions can switch out and return. Dragon-types like Garchomp and Dragapult are natural speed-tie nightmares; Pawmot needs Tera Electric or prior chip to guarantee the KO. Steel-types such as Corviknight and Gholdengo fear Close Combat but can tank one and KO back with Body Press or Make It Rain. Priority users—Kingambit’s Sucker Punch, Dragonite’s Extremespeed—bypass its speed and break Sash, so Pawmot must Protect or remove these first. Terrain wars matter: Psychic Terrain stops Fake Out, Grassy Terrain weakens Double Shock, and Electric Terrain boosts it. Opposing Tailwind or Trick Room flips the script entirely, turning Pawmot from predator to paper.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Pawmot’s 70 / 70 / 60 bulk and self-inflicted Double Shock drop make it notoriously easy to revenge. Priority in Sucker Punch, Aqua Jet, or Extremespeed breaks Focus Sash and KOes. Bulky Fairies—Azumarill, Sylveon, Clefable—resist both STABs and retaliate with Moonblast or Aqua Jet. Amoonguss survives Double Shock after Sitrus and Spores, though Natural Cure variants can reset. Physically bulky Steels such as Corviknight and Skarmory tank Close Combat and KO back with Body Press or Brave Bird. Ground-types that can take one Close Combat—Lando-T, Garchomp, Excadrill—force mind-games: Pawmot must Tera to guarantee the OHKO, and if it teras early it loses end-game power. Trick Room turns Pawmot’s speed into a liability, letting slow powerhouses like Iron Hands or Kingambit move first. Finally, status outside of Natural Cure variants sticks—Burn neuters Double Shock, Paralysis kills speed, and Poison plus Life Orb recoil can stack with Double Shock chip to guarantee a KO on the following turn.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Gardevoir": {"Abilities": {"telepathy": 26.07921566758602, "trace": 3.2837481516419844, "synchronize": 2.419871882937946}, "Items": {"choicescarf": 0.5629211332651964}, "Spreads": {"Modest:0/0/0/252/4/252": 0.17892478861187613}, "Moves": ["mysticalfire", "dazzlinggleam", "moonblast", "expandingforce"], "Tera Types": {"fairy": 0.2317288663408964, "psychic": 0.3012740001083322}, "Teammates": ["Indeedee-F", "Sneasler", "Garchomp", "Tyranitar", "Incineroar", "Excadrill"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Gardevoir carves a niche in VGC as a fast, specially offensive Fairy/Psychic attacker that abuses spread moves and terrain-boosted Expanding Force. While its bulk is only average, its access to both Dazzling Gleam and the terrain-dependant Expanding Force lets it apply immediate dual-STAB pressure to the field, and Mystical Fire grants it valuable Fire-type coverage against Steel targets that otherwise wall it. Choice Scarf is the only item of note in the data, pointing toward a hit-and-run pivot set that aims to outspeed and KO threats before they can retaliate; the Modest 252/252 spread maximises damage output while preserving a sliver of special bulk. Telepathy is the dominant ability, preventing friendly spread damage and allowing Gardevoir to slot comfortably next to partners such as Indeedee-F or Incineroar that rely on their own spread moves. Trace and Synchronize appear at far lower rates, suggesting they are niche or simply inferior options on most teams. Tera Fairy is the most common Tera type, amplifying STAB Dazzling Gleam and Moonblast while giving Gardevoir a Dragon immunity; Tera Psychic is close behind, boosting Expanding Force to nuke levels under Psychic Terrain. The teammate list is a who’s-who of terrain abusers and pivots—Indeedee-F sets Psychic Terrain for Expanding Force, Sneasler and Garchomp supply physical speed control and Ground-type pressure, Tyranitar and Incineroar offer Fake Out and Intimidate support, and Excadrill brings Steel-type offense and sand speed control—indicating that Gardevoir is usually fielded on balanced offensive squads that appreciate fast special pressure and terrain synergy.</OUTPUT>

input:
Write the 'full_analysis' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Gardevoir": {"Abilities": {"telepathy": 26.07921566758602, "trace": 3.2837481516419844, "synchronize": 2.419871882937946}, "Items": {"choicescarf": 0.5629211332651964}, "Spreads": {"Modest:0/0/0/252/4/252": 0.17892478861187613}, "Moves": ["mysticalfire", "dazzlinggleam", "moonblast", "expandingforce"], "Tera Types": {"fairy": 0.2317288663408964, "psychic": 0.3012740001083322}, "Teammates": ["Indeedee-F", "Sneasler", "Garchomp", "Tyranitar", "Incineroar", "Excadrill"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Gardevoir’s offensive typing is simultaneously its greatest strength and its most exploitable weakness. Fairy/Psychic is historically awkward: resisted by Steel and other Psychics, yet unresisted by Dragon, Dark, and Fighting cores that populate the metagame. The data show Gardevoir running four attacks and a Choice Scarf, underscoring a philosophy of ‘kill something immediately or pivot out’. Mystical Fire is the glue that holds the set together, 2HKOing common Steel-type switches such as Corviknight, Gholdengo, and Kingambit while dropping their Attack stat. Dazzling Gleam is the go-to spread move, punishing Dragon- and Dark-type duos and preserving damage when the opponent fields two targets. Moonblast is the single-target nuke, offering a 30 % chance to drop Special Attack and giving Gardevoir a reliable finishing move that doesn’t rely on positioning. Expanding Force is the most interesting inclusion: under Psychic Terrain it becomes a 120-base-power spread move that cleanly OHKOs neutral targets such as Rotom-Wash, Amoonguss, and opposing Indeedee-F, turning Gardevoir into a legitimate terrain sweeper. The Choice Scarf guarantees it outpaces the unboosted metagame, letting it revenge kill threats like +1 Dragonite, Booster Energy Iron Valiant, and opposing Choice-locked attackers. Telepathy is the optimal ability because Gardevoir is almost always paired with Indeedee-F or Incineroar; both allies spam spread moves, and Telepathy prevents the self-inflicted chip that would otherwise cripple Gardevoir over a long game. EV spreads are straightforward: Modest nature maximises damage, 252 Speed with Scarf hits 364, outspeeding everything up to +1 base 100s, and 4 EVs are dropped into Special Defence to survive a modest roll from Specs Dragapult Shadow Ball. Tera Fairy is preferred when the team needs a Dragon immunity and a stronger Fairy STAB to muscle past bulky Dark-types such as Kingambit and Ting-Lu; Tera Psychic is chosen when the squad is built around Psychic Terrain and Gardevoir is expected to nuke entire teams with Expanding Force. In practice the two Tera types are interchangeable depending on the rest of the roster, but the data tilt slightly toward Psychic because Expanding Force’s raw power is the biggest differentiator Gardevoir brings to the table compared to other Fairy-type special attackers like Sylveon or Scream Tail.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Gardevoir": {"Abilities": {"telepathy": 26.07921566758602, "trace": 3.2837481516419844, "synchronize": 2.419871882937946}, "Items": {"choicescarf": 0.5629211332651964}, "Spreads": {"Modest:0/0/0/252/4/252": 0.17892478861187613}, "Moves": ["mysticalfire", "dazzlinggleam", "moonblast", "expandingforce"], "Tera Types": {"fairy": 0.2317288663408964, "psychic": 0.3012740001083322}, "Teammates": ["Indeedee-F", "Sneasler", "Garchomp", "Tyranitar", "Incineroar", "Excadrill"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Gardevoir’s matchup spread is polarised. Against Dragon, Dark, and Fighting archetypes it is an outright menace: Choice Scarf Expanding Force under terrain OHKOs common threats such as Dragapult, Roaring Moon, Kingambit, and Iron Valiant, while Dazzling Gleam cleanly 2HKOs bulky Fighting-types like Annihilape and Arcanine. Steel-type cores are the primary roadblock; without Mystical Fire Gardevoir fails to break Corviknight, Gholdengo, or Tinkaton, and even with the fire coverage it must predict correctly because a misprediction leaves it locked into an ineffective move. Psychic-type mirrors are awkward because opposing Indeedee-F sets Terrain first, nullifying Gardevoir’s Expanding Force boost and forcing it to rely on Moonblast. Ghost-types such as Aegislash and bulky Gholdengo can stomach a Mystical Fire and retalify with powerful Steel-type or Ghost-type moves. Priority users—especially Shadow Sneak Aegislash and Sucker Punch Kingambit—can finish off a chipped Gardevoir before it moves, so maintaining healthy HP is crucial. Finally, Tailwind or Chlorophyll sweepers that can outspeed even Scarf Gardevoir (such as Tailwind Zapdos or Sun-based Venusaur) force the player to either Tera Fairy for bulk or switch out and reset positioning. In short, Gardevoir dominates mid-speed, offense-oriented teams but struggles against sturdy Steel cores and faster speed-control archetypes.</OUTPUT>

It is brought to games to immediately remove or heavily dent Dragon, Dark, and Fighting threats while providing consistent spread chip with Dazzling Gleam. Its presence forces the opponent to keep their Steel-type healthy and to play carefully around Psychic Terrain, lest Expanding Force rip through back-to-back targets. Because it is locked into one move, Gardevoir is rarely the long-term win condition; instead it trades itself for one or two KO’s, softens the enemy for a teammate sweep, or punches holes early so that cleaners such as Sneasler or Garchomp can finish the game. Telepathy means it can sit on the field next to Indeedee-F or Incineroar without taking friendly fire, making it a low-maintenance offensive pivot that fits on balanced and hyper-offense structures alike.</OUTPUT>

Sneasler appreciates Gardevoir’s ability to OHKO bulky Psychic- and Fairy-types that wall it, while Gardevoir in turn benefits from Sneasler’s Poison-type coverage for opposing Fairies and its ability to pressure Steel-types with Close Combat. Garchomp forms a classic speed-control core: Gardevoir removes Dragons and Fairies that trouble Garchomp, and Garchomp handles opposing Steel-types with Earthquake while providing a secondary Scarf or Tailwind option. Tyranitar supplies Fake Out and special bulk with Assault Vest, can remove opposing Indeedee-F with Crunch to reclaim Terrain, and summons sand to chip bulkier teams. Incineroar offers Intimidate, Parting Shot, and Fake Out, creating safe switch-ins for Gardevoir and weakening physical attackers that could otherwise KO it. Excadrill rounds out the squad by providing Steel-type offense, a Ground immunity, and sand-rush speed control that covers Gardevoir’s offensive gaps. Together these teammates form a balanced offensive shell that manipulates Terrain, controls speed, and breaks down shared checks so that Gardevoir can fulfil its hit-and-run role efficiently.</OUTPUT>

No alternate items or spreads appear in the data, indicating that Choice Scarf is the only viable competitive item at present.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Gardevoir": {"Abilities": {"telepathy": 26.07921566758602, "trace": 3.2837481516419844, "synchronize": 2.419871882937946}, "Items": {"choicescarf": 0.5629211332651964}, "Spreads": {"Modest:0/0/0/252/4/252": 0.17892478861187613}, "Moves": ["mysticalfire", "dazzlinggleam", "moonblast", "expandingforce"], "Tera Types": {"fairy": 0.2317288663408964, "psychic": 0.3012740001083322}, "Teammates": ["Indeedee-F", "Sneasler", "Garchomp", "Tyranitar", "Incineroar", "Excadrill"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Steel-types that can survive Mystical Fire are the hard counters: Assault Vest Gholdengo, Corviknight, and Tinkaton can all stomach the hit and retalify with powerful Steel-type or Flying-type moves. Priority in the form of Shadow Sneak Aegislash or Sucker Punch Kingambit bypasses Gardevoir’s Speed and finishes it off after chip. Faster speed control—Tailwind Zapdos, Chlorophyll Venusaur, or Booster Energy Iron Valiant—outspeeds even Scarf Gardevoir and OHKOs back. Psychic Terrain can be overwritten by opposing Indeedee-F or by switching in a Grass-type under Grassy Glide, nullifying Expanding Force’s power. Finally, because Gardevoir is Choice-locked, correct prediction is essential; a mispredict into a Steel-type or a Protect can leave it setup fodder for threats such as Dragonite or Kingambit. To mitigate these weaknesses, keep Gardevoir healthy, pair it with redirection or Intimidate support, and preserve Terrain control through the rest of the team.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Gardevoir": {"Abilities": {"telepathy": 26.07921566758602, "trace": 3.2837481516419844, "synchronize": 2.419871882937946}, "Items": {"choicescarf": 0.5629211332651964}, "Spreads": {"Modest:0/0/0/252/4/252": 0.17892478861187613}, "Moves": ["mysticalfire", "dazzlinggleam", "moonblast", "expandingforce"], "Tera Types": {"fairy": 0.2317288663408964, "psychic": 0.3012740001083322}, "Teammates": ["Indeedee-F", "Sneasler", "Garchomp", "Tyranitar", "Incineroar", "Excadrill"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>A proven archetype is Psychic Terrain Hyper-Offense: lead Indeedee-F + Gardevoir to set Terrain and immediately fire off Expanding Force, bringing Sneasler or Garchomp in the back to clean. Indeedee-F runs Psychic Seed, Follow Me, Protect, and Expanding Force to redirect and maintain Terrain. Gardevoir holds Choice Scarf and functions as described. Sneasler runs Poison Touch, Close Combat, Dire Claw, and Protect to break Fairies and punish physical switches. Garchomp carries Lum Berry or Choice Scarf, Earthquake, Dragon Claw, and Protect to handle opposing Steel-types and provide secondary speed control. Incineroar supplies Fake Out, Parting Shot, Flare Blitz, and Taunt to soften physical attackers and create safe pivots. Excadrill rounds out the squad with Sand Rush, Iron Head, Rock Slide, and Protect to punish opposing Fairies and give a sand mode if Tyranitar is brought instead of Incineroar. The team’s game plan is simple: establish Terrain early, delete one or two threats with Gardevoir, then clean with the appropriate offensive teammate while maintaining momentum through Fake Out and pivoting moves.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Gastrodon is a bulky, disruptive Water/Ground pivot that abuses Storm Drain to blank opposing water attacks while spreading Yawn pressure and firing off strong, super-effective Earth Powers; with 68/68/78 bulk augmented by Sitrus or Leftovers, it sits in front of Rain, Rotom-Wash and Ogre-style teams, flips momentum with a free +1 Sp.Atk, and forces double-targets or switches with the constant threat of sleep.</OUTPUT>

input:
Provide the 'full_analysis' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Gastrodon": {"Abilities": {"stormdrain": 30.84035758527181, "stickyhold": 0.19655238383948903, "sandforce": 0.0015445281772714092}, "Items": {"leftovers": 0.4875874430413261, "sitrusberry": 0.3023694805085012}, "Spreads": {"Sassy:252/0/116/0/140/0": 0.1789390000250339}, "Moves": ["protect", "earthpower", "yawn", "icebeam"], "Tera Types": {"fire": 0.43672659183595836, "poison": 0.21198995157111072}, "Teammates": ["Tyranitar", "Incineroar", "Sinistcha", "Rillaboom", "Sneasler", "Kingambit"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Storm Drain is the only ability worth considering—turning every Water-type attack into a free Special Attack boost makes Gastrodon a natural anti-metagame piece in a format saturated with Kyogre, Palafin, Rotom-Wash and Kingdra. Sitrus berry is preferred on more fast-paced teams to guarantee it lives two big hits (notably Life-Orb Flutter Mane Moonblast or Choice-band Dragonite Tera-Normal Extreme-Speed) and still fire off a second Yawn or Ice Beam, whereas Leftovers is better on bulkier structures that aim to trade long-term. EV spread is a standard Sassy 252 HP / 116 Def / 140 Sp.Def: the extra special bulk lets it survive Specs Tatsugiri Hyper-Drill, +2 Kingambit Tera-Flying Tera-Blade or Life-Orb Chi-Yu Overheat while still checking physical threats such as Kingambit, Gholdengo and Zacian after Intimidate. Moves are mandatory: Protect for scouting and Leftovers/Sitrus recovery, Earth Power as the spammable STAB that OHKOes Tatsugiri, Heatran and Iron Moth, Yawn to force switches, deny setup and win end-games, and Ice Beam to nail the omnipresent Dragons (especially Tera-Dragon Koraidon and Tera-Flying Dragonite) as well as Rillaboom and Breloom. Tera-Fire removes the Grass weakness and turns Ferrothorn, Amoonguss and opposing Rillaboom into set-up fodder, while Tera-Poison grants a crucial Toxic-immunity and a better matchup into Fairy-spam teams (Sylveon, Hatterene, opposing Sinistcha). Gastrodon fits equally on hard Trick-Room, semi-room and balance shells because its low speed lets it operate under Trick-Room while still being usable outside.</OUTPUT>

input:

<DATA>{"Gastrodon": {"Abilities": {"stormdrain": 30.84035758527181, "stickyhold": 0.19655238383948903, "sandforce": 0.0015445281772714092}, "Items": {"leftovers": 0.4875874430413261, "sitrusberry": 0.3023694805085012}, "Spreads": {"Sassy:252/0/116/0/140/0": 0.1789390000250339}, "Moves": ["protect", "earthpower", "yawn", "icebeam"], "Tera Types": {"fire": 0.43672659183595836, "poison": 0.21198995157111072}, "Teammates": ["Tyranitar", "Incineroar", "Sinistcha", "Rillaboom", "Sneasler", "Kingambit"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Against Rain (Kyogre, Pelipper, Palafin) Gastrodon is a hard counter: Storm Drain absorbs Surfs, Muddy Waters and Jet-Punches, while Earth Power OHKOes Pelipper and 2HKOes max-HP Kyogre. Versus Sun (Koraidon + Iron Moth) it switches into Overheat, gains the boost and threatens back with Earth Power; Tera-Fire variants win the 1v1 even after a Tera-Grass Koraidon Tera-Blade. Against Psy-spam (Indeedee + Armarouge or Hatterene) it can eat a Specs Expanding Force, Yawn the setter and stall the terrain turns. Grass-types are the obvious bane: Rillaboom’s Wood Hammer is a clean OHKO even without Grassy Terrain, Amoonguss can Spore through Storm Drain, and Ferrothorn sets hazards freely; however, all of them dislike a Tera-Fire Ice Beam or Overheat from teammates. Setup sweepers that carry Sub (Dragonite, Kingambit, Bloodmoon) can dodge Yawn, but cannot safely set up in front of a +1 Earth Power.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Gastrodon": {"Abilities": {"stormdrain": 30.84035758527181, "stickyhold": 0.19655238383948903, "sandforce": 0.0015445281772714092}, "Items": {"leftovers": 0.4875874430413261, "sitrusberry": 0.3023694805085012}, "Spreads": {"Sassy:252/0/116/0/140/0": 0.1789390000250339}, "Moves": ["protect", "earthpower", "yawn", "icebeam"], "Tera Types": {"fire": 0.43672659183595836, "poison": 0.21198995157111072}, "Teammates": ["Tyranitar", "Incineroar", "Sinistcha", "Rillaboom", "Sneasler", "Kingambit"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Gastrodon’s primary job is to act as a special-bulky pivot that flips momentum against Water-type attacks while blanking common spread moves like Muddy Water, Surging Strikes and Jet Punch. In game-plan terms it is both a defensive answer (checking Kyogre, Rotom-Wash, Palafin, Iron Bundle) and an offensive enabler: every Storm Drain trigger is a +1 Sp.Atk, turning its modest 92 base into a legitimate threat that 2HKOes most neutral targets. Yawn gives it a secondary win-condition—by putting a target to sleep it either removes a piece for three turns or forces a switch that can be exploited by attackers such as Kingambit, Sneasler or Rillaboom. Because it is slow, Gastrodon is equally happy playing under Trick-Room or outside it, making it an excellent flexible glue for BO and semi-room squads.</OUTPUT>

Sinistcha covers the Grass weakness with Heat-Wave and benefits from Yawn forcing switches to get Poltergeist off safely. Rillaboom is superficially redundant but in practice forms a FWG (Fire-Water-Grass) defensive core: Rillaboom handles opposing Gastrodon and Rotom-Wash while Gastrodon covers the Fire and Flying weaknesses Rilla invites. Sneasler enjoys Yawn putting foes to sleep, giving it free setup with Swords-Dance or free Dire-Claw fishing; Kingambit similarly loves forced switches to grab a Defiant boost or set up Swords-Dance. In return Gastrodon appreciates Kingambit’s Dark-typing to take Psychic and Ghost moves.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Hard Trick-Room build: Porygon2 (setter), Gastrodon (Storm-Drain), Tyranitar (sand + rocker), Hatterene (secondary setter + attacker), Kingambit (win-con), Incineroar (Intimidate pivot). The team compresses defensive roles—Gastrodon covers Water, Fire and Electric while providing Yawn pressure, Tyranitar and Incineroar form a Dark-Intimidate core, and the two setters guarantee room goes up versus both fast and slow teams.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Scizor is a premier physical pivot in VGC, leveraging Technician-boosted Bullet Punch and a Choice Band to pick off faster threats while maintaining momentum with U-turn. Its near-universal Tera Fire usage patches up its crippling Fire weakness, letting it survive otherwise lethal hits and retaliate. input:
Create the 'full_analysis' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Scizor": {"Abilities": {"technician": 29.781369353526134, "swarm": 0.022358596866405567, "lightmetal": 6.201798838212369e-05}, "Items": {"choiceband": 0.8927795800863461}, "Spreads": {"Adamant:252/252/0/0/4/0": 0.2710387946828398, "Adamant:164/252/4/0/4/84": 0.5715990012746569}, "Moves": ["closecombat", "bulletpunch", "uturn", "knockoff"], "Tera Types": {"fire": 0.5996220698368598, "psychic": 0.235320582223795}, "Teammates": ["Ursaluna-Bloodmoon", "Kingambit", "Dragonite", "Annihilape", "Tatsugiri", "Dondozo"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Scizor’s niche in VGC 2025 rests on three pillars: priority, power, and pivoting. Technician Bullet Punch becomes a 90 BP STAB move once Band-boosted, out-damaging unboosted Jolly Dragonite’s Extreme Speed and cleanly KOing frail or chipped threats like Flutter Mane, opposing Scizor, and low-health Kingambit. U-turn guarantees that Scizor can retain offensive tempo, generating favorable switch-ins for teammates such as Ursaluna-Bloodmoon or Annihilape that appreciate softened checks. Close Combat covers the Steel-resistant Dark and Normal types that otherwise wall its STAB, notably 2HKOing max HP Kingambit through Protect while guaranteeing the KO on standard Incineroar. Knock Off rounds the set by removing critical items—Leftovers from Dondozo, Sitrus from support Togekiss, or opposing Bands—crippling would-be counters for the remainder of the match. Tera Fire is the linchpin of the set: it flips the Fire-type matchup, letting Scizor survive Heat Wave from Torkoal or a Sun-boosted Eruption and retaliate, while simultaneously removing its Ice-type weakness, allowing it to live Blizzard from Kyurem or Ice Spinner from Chien-Pao. Psychic Tera represents a smaller but notable cohort that instead aims to tank Fighting-type moves from Annihilape and Iron Valiant while still resisting Bullet Punch mirror exchanges. EV spreads cluster around two philosophies: maximum power and creep speed. The classic 252/252 Adamant spread offers the highest immediate damage, while the 164/84 spread creeps Modest Torkoal and uninvested base 70s, letting Scizor U-turn first on key threats. Both keep bulk investment minimal, reflecting Scizor’s role as a hit-and-run attacker rather than a wall.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Scizor": {"Abilities": {"technician": 29.781369353526134, "swarm": 0.022358596866405567, "lightmetal": 6.201798838212369e-05}, "Items": {"choiceband": 0.8927795800863461}, "Spreads": {"Adamant:252/252/0/0/4/0": 0.2710387946828398, "Adamant:164/252/4/0/4/84": 0.5715990012746569}, "Moves": ["closecombat", "bulletpunch", "uturn", "knockoff"], "Tera Types": {"fire": 0.5996220698368598, "psychic": 0.235320582223795}, "Teammates": ["Ursaluna-Bloodmoon", "Kingambit", "Dragonite", "Annihilape", "Tatsugiri", "Dondozo"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Scizor dominates against Fairy, Ice, and Rock teams, dismantling the ubiquitous Flutter Mene, Chien-Pao, and Tyranitar cores. It pressures Trick Room modes by picking off frail setters like Hatterene before they move and 2HKOing bulkier ones like Porygon2. Into Sun, Tera Fire variants flip the script on Torkoal and Chi-Yu, removing their primary check. Conversely, Scizor struggles into Intimidate cycles—especially Incineroar and Arcanine—which force it to cycle U-turn, lowering its immediate breaking potential. Rain cores with Pelipper and Iron Bundle outspeed and KO with Hydro Pump, while Rotom-Wash resists everything Scizor does and burns it with Will-O-Wisp. Electric Terrain teams featuring Iron Hands can stomach a Bullet Punch and retaliate with Fake Out plus Drain Punch, chipping Scizor into KO range for partners. Finally, opposing Kingambit can survive a Close Combat and KO back with Sacred Sword if Swords Dance has been set up, making positioning and Protect reads vital.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Scizor": {"Abilities": {"technician": 29.781369353526134, "swarm": 0.022358596866405567, "lightmetal": 6.201798838212369e-05}, "Items": {"choiceband": 0.8927795800863461}, "Spreads": {"Adamant:252/252/0/0/4/0": 0.2710387946828398, "Adamant:164/252/4/0/4/84": 0.5715990012746569}, "Moves": ["closecombat", "bulletpunch", "uturn", "knockoff"], "Tera Types": {"fire": 0.5996220698368598, "psychic": 0.235320582223795}, "Teammates": ["Ursaluna-Bloodmoon", "Kingambit", "Dragonite", "Annihilape", "Tatsugiri", "Dondozo"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Intimidate cycles from Incineroar and Arcanine force Scizor to U-turn, dropping its immediate damage and allowing free switches. Rotom-Wash resists Bullet Punch, burns with Will-O-Wisp, and OHKOs with Overheat. Rain-boosted Hydro Pump from Iron Bundle or Pelipper outspeeds and KOes before Tera Fire can be declared. Iron Hands under Electric Terrain survives Bullet Punch and retaliates with Fake Out plus Drain Punch, wearing Scizor down. Opposing Kingambit can survive Close Combat at full health and KO back with Sacred Sword if it has chipped Scizor or obtained a Swords Dance boost. Fire-type coverage from Chi-Yu or Torkoal still threatens pre-Tera Scizor, forcing early Tera commitment and opening it to other weaknesses. Finally, Protect stalling can waste Band-locked turns, so mixed attackers like Hydreigon can Protect on predicted Bullet Punch and punish the switch-in with Draco Meteor or Fire Blast.</OUTPUT>

input:
Write a detailed 'sample_team_concept' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Scizor": {"Abilities": {"technician": 29.781369353526134, "swarm": 0.022358596866405567, "lightmetal": 6.201798838212369e-05}, "Items": {"choiceband": 0.8927795800863461}, "Spreads": {"Adamant:252/252/0/0/4/0": 0.2710387946828398, "Adamant:164/252/4/0/4/84": 0.5715990012746569}, "Moves": ["closecombat", "bulletpunch", "uturn", "knockoff"], "Tera Types": {"fire": 0.5996220698368598, "psychic": 0.235320582223795}, "Teammates": ["Ursaluna-Bloodmoon", "Kingambit", "Dragonite", "Annihilape", "Tatsugiri", "Dondozo"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Scizor / Ursaluna-Bloodmoon / Kingambit / Rotom-Wash / Togekiss / Amoonguss. Scizor and Bloodmoon form the core offensive duo, with Scizor luring Incineroar and Rotom-Wash for Bloodmoon to sweep. Kingambit provides a second priority user and punishes Intimidate cycling with Supreme Overlord stacks. Rotom-Wash offers speed control via Electroweb and removes opposing Fire-types with Thunderbolt, while Togekiss supplies Follow Me and Tailwind to enable Scizor to pick off faster threats. Amoonguss completes the defensive core with Rage Powder and Spore, redirecting Electric- and Fire-type moves aimed at Scizor while spreading sleep to buy setup turns for Kingambit or Bloodmoon. The team balances hyper-offense and support, using Scizor’s pivoting to create 2v1 windows and Bloodmoon’s raw power to close games once checks are eliminated.</OUTPUT>

input:
Create the 'full_analysis' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Metagross": {"Abilities": {"clearbody": 29.6725478715309, "lightmetal": 1.2435444187053335e-05}, "Items": {"assaultvest": 0.6272330877774206}, "Spreads": {"Adamant:252/116/36/0/100/4": 0.18310549684409103, "Adamant:252/124/4/0/52/76": 0.15015731601190516}, "Moves": ["psychicfangs", "bulletpunch", "stompingtantrum", "heavyslam"], "Tera Types": {"water": 0.5300037811677188}, "Teammates": ["Ninetales-Alola", "Sinistcha", "Dragonite", "Blaziken", "Dondozo", "Tatsugiri"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>The supplied data show that almost every successful ladder Metagross is running Assault Vest with an Adamant nature and heavily customised bulk: the two most common spreads (252 HP / 116 Atk / 36 Def / 100 SpD / 4 Spe and 252 HP / 124 Atk / 4 Def / 52 SpD / 76 Spe) both max HP and invest the remaining EVs to survive key hits—most notably Moonblast from Flutter Mane and Heat Wave from Chi-Yu—while keeping Attack as high as possible. Clear Body is chosen on virtually every team to ignore opposing Intimidate, Icy Wind and Electroweb drops, preserving Metagross’s immediate power. The moveset is locked into four attacks: Psychic Fangs for reliable STAB and screen-breaking, Bullet Punch for priority that bypasses speed control, Stomping Tantrum to nail Gholdengo, Kingambit and opposing Tera Electric targets, and Heavy Slam to abuse its 550 kg weight for massive Fairy and Ice damage. Water Tera appears on roughly 53% of teams, flipping the 4× Fire weakness into a resisted hit and letting Metagross survive Heat Wave or Tera Fire Heat Crash long enough to retaliate. With Assault Vest plus natural bulk, Metagross becomes a slow but almost unbreakable pivot that forces double-targets or burns enemy dynamax while its partner sets up speed control or offensive pressure.</OUTPUT>

input:
Produce the 'matchup_overview' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Metagross": {"Abilities": {"clearbody": 29.6725478715309, "lightmetal": 1.2435444187053335e-05}, "Items": {"assaultvest": 0.6272330877774206}, "Spreads": {"Adamant:252/116/36/0/100/4": 0.18310549684409103, "Adamant:252/124/4/0/52/76": 0.15015731601190516}, "Moves": ["psychicfangs", "bulletpunch", "stompingtantrum", "heavyslam"], "Tera Types": {"water": 0.5300037811677188}, "Teammates": ["Ninetales-Alola", "Sinistcha", "Dragonite", "Blaziken", "Dondozo", "Tatsugiri"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Metagross loves facing Fairy-heavy teams (Sylveon, Azumarill, Scream Tail) and Dragon-spam cores (Dragonite, Baxcalibur, Garchomp) that cannot break its AV bulk and crumble to Heavy Slam or Tera Water Iron Head. It goes roughly even with other Steel-types—loses to Tera Fire Kingambit one-on-one but beats Gholdengo and most Corviknight sets—while disliking strong special Fire attackers (Chi-Yu, Sunny-day Charizard, Torkoal Eruption) that can still 2HKO through Vest. Ghost match-ups are mixed: it can’t touch Aegislash without Stomping Tantrum chip, but AV lets it live Shadow Ball and retaliate. Overall it functions as a mid-speed tank that dictates the tempo by forcing opponents to commit double attacks or burn Tera to remove it.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Metagross is a bulky offensive pivot and Fairy-check that occupies the “slow but unkillable” slot on balance or hard-room squads. With Assault Vest it switches into special attackers, survives the 2HKO, and fires off 130+ BP Heavy Slams or super-effective coverage. Clear Body ensures its Attack stat can’t be debuffed, making it an ideal dynamax target that keeps pressure even when intimidated. Bullet Punch gives the team a much-needed priority finisher, while Psychic Fangs breaks Aurora Veil and Reflect so partners can clean. It rarely dynamaxes itself unless the opposing board is weak to Steel spread moves; instead it soaks damage, removes items with Psychic Fangs, and lets faster or setup-oriented teammates sweep.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Metagross": {"Abilities": {"clearbody": 29.6725478715309, "lightmetal": 1.2435444187053335e-05}, "Items": {"assaultvest": 0.6272330877774206}, "Spreads": {"Adamant:252/116/36/0/100/4": 0.18310549684409103, "Adamant:252/124/4/0/52/76": 0.15015731601190516}, "Moves": ["psychicfangs", "bulletpunch", "stompingtantrum", "heavyslam"], "Tera Types": {"water": 0.5300037811677188}, "Teammates": ["Ninetales-Alola", "Sinistcha", "Dragonite", "Blaziken", "Dondozo", "Tatsugiri"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Ninetales-Alola is by far its most common partner: Aurora Veil halves the already modest damage Metagross takes, letting it comfortably live Fire moves and start breaking enemies. Sinistcha provides burn immunity with Purifying Salt, redirection via Ally Switch, and additional chip with Matcha Gotcha, while appreciating Steel-type removal for opposing Fairies. Dragonite offers speed control with Thunder Wave or Extreme Speed clean-up after Metagross weakens targets, and both share Water Tera synergy. Blaziken covers the Fire and Steel problems for Metagross while gaining safe switches on predicted Earthquakes, and the pair can alternate dynamax depending on the match-up. Dondozo + Tatsugiri form a second bulky win-condition: Metagross baits Electric and Grass moves that Dondozo can soak, while Tatsugiri’s Commander boost turns Metagross into a slow but terrifying offensive threat under Trick Room. In short, Metagross fits cores that either veil and speed-control for it, or that stack multiple bulky win-conditions to exhaust enemy resources.</OUTPUT>

input:
Produce the 'weaknesses_and_counters' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Metagross": {"Abilities": {"clearbody": 29.6725478715309, "lightmetal": 1.2435444187053335e-05}, "Items": {"assaultvest": 0.6272330877774206}, "Spreads": {"Adamant:252/116/36/0/100/4": 0.18310549684409103, "Adamant:252/124/4/0/52/76": 0.15015731601190516}, "Moves": ["psychicfangs", "bulletpunch", "stompingtantrum", "heavyslam"], "Tera Types": {"water": 0.5300037811677188}, "Teammates": ["Ninetales-Alola", "Sinistcha", "Dragonite", "Blaziken", "Dondozo", "Tatsugiri"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Strong special Fire attackers remain the most consistent answers: Chi-Yu under sun, Torkoal Eruption, or Tera Fire Hydreigon Draco Meteor into Heat Wave all break the Vest threshold. Ghosts that can avoid Heavy Slam (Aegislash, Gholdengo with Air Balloon) force Metagross to rely on prediction or partner chip. Ground-types with speed control—Lando-T Scarf or Great Tusk under Tailwind—can KO with Earthquake before Metagross moves. Clear Body ignores Intimidate, but Will-o-Wisp or Thunder Wave cripple it; therefore status absorbers like Clodsire or Toxapex partners can stall it out. Finally, because it is locked into four attacks, Protect spam and redirection (Amoonguss, Indeedee-F) waste its turns and let opponents set up or reposition. If Metagross has already burned its Tera, neutral Fire moves become 2HKOs again, so keeping Tera in pocket is mandatory against sun or Fire-heavy teams.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Gengar": {"Abilities": {"cursedbody": 28.850985835741565}, "Items": {"focussash": 0.8993054831483615}, "Spreads": {"Timid:4/0/0/252/0/252": 0.4192572426523635, "Timid:0/0/0/252/4/252": 0.3469643606613136}, "Moves": ["shadowball", "icywind", "protect", "sludgebomb"], "Tera Types": {"stellar": 0.4979949539361306, "dark": 0.17615402751526532}, "Teammates": ["Annihilape", "Incineroar", "Archaludon", "Rillaboom", "Gholdengo", "Dragonite"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Gengar is a blazing-fast special attacker that leverages its stellar Tera type and wide movepool to act as a disruptive glass cannon. With Timid nature and maximum Speed investment, it naturally outspeeds the crowded base-100 tier and below, while Cursed Body gives it a 30% chance to disable an incoming contact move, punishing opponents for targeting it. The dominant Stellar Tera type turns Shadow Ball into a spammable, neutral-damage nuke that ignores resistances, letting Gengar muscle past would-be walls. Icy Wind provides crucial speed-control support, and Sludge Bomb nails Flutter Mane and other Fairies for an easy OHKO. A Focus Sash is the only item worth considering, guaranteeing that Gengar survives at least one hit so it can trade or cripple a faster threat. Its most common partners—Annihilape, Incineroar, Archaludon, Rillaboom, Gholdengo, and Dragonite—form a balanced core that covers every defensive type and brings redirection, terrain, weather, and priority to support Gengar’s hit-and-run style.</OUTPUT>

input:
Create the 'full_analysis' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Gengar": {"Abilities": {"cursedbody": 28.850985835741565}, "Items": {"focussash": 0.8993054831483615}, "Spreads": {"Timid:4/0/0/252/0/252": 0.4192572426523635, "Timid:0/0/0/252/4/252": 0.3469643606613136}, "Moves": ["shadowball", "icywind", "protect", "sludgebomb"], "Tera Types": {"stellar": 0.4979949539361306, "dark": 0.17615402751526532}, "Teammates": ["Annihilape", "Incineroar", "Archaludon", "Rillaboom", "Gholdengo", "Dragonite"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Gengar’s place in the current VGC meta is defined by two factors: its unmatched base 110 Speed tier and the newly available Stellar Tera type. Timid and fully invested, it outpaces the likes of Ogerpon-Wellspring, Landorus-T, and Iron Crown while still hitting hard with 130 base Special Attack. Stellar Tera removes Shadow Ball’s immunities and resistances, meaning Gengar no longer needs prediction to break Normal- or Dark-types; it simply clicks Shadow Ball for neutral damage and often a KO after Tera. Cursed Body is a low-roll but high-impact ability: disabling a Sacred Sword from Annihilape or a Sucker Punch from Kingambit can swing entire games. The chosen moveset is lean and effective: Shadow Ball is the primary STAB, Sludge Bomb nails opposing Fairies and Grass-types, Icy Wind provides both chip damage and a one-stage speed debuff that allows slower teammates to move first next turn, and Protect is mandatory in doubles to stall Fake Out, dodge Zacian’s Behemoth Blade, or preserve the Focus Sash for a second turn. EV spreads are straightforward: 252 Speed and 252 Special Attack maximize offenses, with the last 4 HP or Defense to slightly optimize bulk; either spread achieves the same key stat breakpoints, so the choice is largely cosmetic. Tera Dark is an occasional alternative to Stellar, granting an immunity to opposing Shadow Balls and Prankster status, but the sheer versatility of ignoring resistances keeps Stellar firmly in the lead. With only one item—Focus Sash—appearing in the data, it is clear that Gengar’s success hinges on living exactly one hit and retaliating for a KO or massive chip before going down.</OUTPUT>

input:
Write the 'matchup_overview' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Gengar": {"Abilities": {"cursedbody": 28.850985835741565}, "Items": {"focussash": 0.8993054831483615}, "Spreads": {"Timid:4/0/0/252/0/252": 0.4192572426523635, "Timid:0/0/0/252/4/252": 0.3469643606613136}, "Moves": ["shadowball", "icywind", "protect", "sludgebomb"], "Tera Types": {"stellar": 0.4979949539361306, "dark": 0.17615402751526532}, "Teammates": ["Annihilape", "Incineroar", "Archaludon", "Rillaboom", "Gholdengo", "Dragonite"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Gengar excels against slower, bulkier teams that rely on setup or Trick Room, as it can fire off Icy Winds or STAB moves before most threats move. It pressures Flutter Mane, Indeedee-F, and Rillaboom with Sludge Bomb, while Shadow Ball dents neutral targets like Gholdengo and Archaludon for 40–60%. Against offense, Gengar’s Speed lets it trade favorably with Iron Boulder, Iron Crown, and opposing Gholdengo, but it must watch for priority: Kingambit’s Sucker Punch, Dragonite’s Extreme Speed, and Rillaboom’s Grassy Glide all break the sash and KO. Stellar Tera turns many 2HKOs into OHKOs, notably against bulky Rotom-Wash and support Incineroar, but Gengar still falls short of KOing dedicated special walls like Assault Vest Slowking-Galar or Clodsire without prior chip. In the mirror, speed ties are everything; the faster Gengar wins with Shadow Ball, while the slower one has to Protect and rely on ally support. Psychic Terrain from Indeedee stops priority, but Gengar can simply target Indeedee first with Shadow Ball. Overall, Gengar’s matchups are polarized: it dominates anything slower and frailer, but crumbles to faster scarfers, priority, or spread moves that break the sash before it can act.</OUTPUT>

Write a detailed 'role_description' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Gengar": {"Abilities": {"cursedbody": 28.850985835741565}, "Items": {"focussash": 0.8993054831483615}, "Spreads": {"Timid:4/0/0/252/0/252": 0.4192572426523635, "Timid:0/0/0/252/4/252": 0.3469643606613136}, "Moves": ["shadowball", "icywind", "protect", "sludgebomb"], "Tera Types": {"stellar": 0.4979949539361306, "dark": 0.17615402751526532}, "Teammates": ["Annihilape", "Incineroar", "Archaludon", "Rillaboom", "Gholdengo", "Dragonite"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Gengar is a lead, pivot, and late-game cleaner rolled into one. In the lead slot it threatens immediate damage and speed control, forcing opponents to decide whether to target Gengar—risking a Cursed Body proc and a wasted move—or its partner, allowing Gengar to fire off Icy Winds or spread poison. Mid-game it acts as a pivot: Protect plus the sash lets it scout choice-locked attackers, absorb a hit, and switch out to a more appropriate teammate. In the endgame, once priority users and opposing speed control are eliminated, Gengar can Tera and sweep with boosted Shadow Balls that ignore resistances. Its low bulk means it rarely survives more than two turns, so every action must either secure a KO, cripple speed, or disable a move via Cursed Body; anything else is a wasted turn. The Focus Sash guarantees that Gengar gets at least one meaningful action, making it one of the most reliable one-for-one traders in the format.</OUTPUT>

Produce the 'synergy_breakdown' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Gengar": {"Abilities": {"cursedbody": 28.850985835741565}, "Items": {"focussash": 0.8993054831483615}, "Spreads": {"Timid:4/0/0/252/0/252": 0.4192572426523635, "Timid:0/0/0/252/4/252": 0.3469643606613136}, "Moves": ["shadowball", "icywind", "protect", "sludgebomb"], "Tera Types": {"stellar": 0.4979949539361306, "dark": 0.17615402751526532}, "Teammates": ["Annihilape", "Incineroar", "Archaludon", "Rillaboom", "Gholdengo", "Dragonite"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Annihilape provides redirection via Rage Fist setup and absorbs status for Gengar, while Gengar’s Icy Wind lets Annihilape outspeed and KO faster threats. Incineroar offers Intimidate and Parting Shot, creating safe switches for Gengar and weakening physical attackers that might break its sash. Archaludon’s Sturdy and massive special bulk let it tank hits aimed at Gengar, while Gengar removes opposing Ground- and Fighting-types that trouble Archaludon. Rillaboom sets Grassy Terrain, weakening Earthquake and restoring sash-broken HP at the end of turn, and its Grassy Glide picks off faster threats that Gengar can’t finish. Gholdengo blocks opposing status and spinblocking, while Gengar removes opposing Ghost- and Dark-types that trouble it. Dragonite provides priority Extreme Speed to finish off sash-broken targets after Gengar’s initial hit, and its bulk lets it tank special hits that would KO Gengar. Together these teammates form a balanced offensive core with speed control, redirection, priority, and terrain, ensuring Gengar always has an avenue to enter the field and claim a KO or two.</OUTPUT>

Tera type should almost always be Stellar; the ability to ignore resistances turns Shadow Ball into a neutral 120 BP attack that nothing wants to switch into. An alternate spread of 0 HP / 0 Atk / 0 Def / 252 SpA / 4 SpD / 252 Timid is functionally identical, trading one point of HP for one point of special defense—either is fine. <DATA>{"Gengar": {"Abilities": {"cursedbody": 28.850985835741565}, "Items": {"focussash": 0.8993054831483615}, "Spreads": {"Timid:4/0/0/252/0/252": 0.4192572426523635, "Timid:0/0/0/252/4/252": 0.3469643606613136}, "Moves": ["shadowball", "icywind", "protect", "sludgebomb"], "Tera Types": {"stellar": 0.4979949539361306, "dark": 0.17615402751526532}, "Teammates": ["Annihilape", "Incineroar", "Archaludon", "Rillaboom", "Gholdengo", "Dragonite"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Gengar’s greatest enemy is priority: Kingambit’s Sucker Punch, Dragonite’s Extreme Speed, and Rillaboom’s Grassy Glide all break the sash and KO. Faster scarfers like Iron Valiant, Chien-Pao, and opposing Gengar can outspeed and OHKO with neutral moves. Bulky Assault Vest users such as Slowking-Galar, Clodsire, and Kingambit can tank a Shadow Ball and retaliate. Wide Guard shuts down Icy Wind and Sludge Bomb, forcing Gengar to target single foes and limiting its spread damage. Psychic Terrain from Indeedee stops priority, but Indeedee itself is cleanly OHKOed by Shadow Ball, so terrain is only a temporary answer. Finally, any multi-hit move—Population Bomb, Bullet Seed, or Rock Blast—breaks the sash and secures the KO. To counter Gengar, bring a faster threat or a bulky AV pivot, preserve priority until after the sash is broken, and keep your own speed control up so Gengar can’t run away with Icy Wind.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Chandelure": {"Abilities": {"flamebody": 0.33295107876840796, "infiltrator": 0.5766418585528963, "flashfire": 26.273218393872092}, "Items": {"choicespecs": 0.29013161788940484, "focussash": 0.2381162696020365, "lifeorb": 0.1627333225656073}, "Spreads": {"Quiet:252/0/140/116/0/0": 0.16160890826830288, "Modest:132/0/4/116/4/252": 0.1992491486749515}, "Moves": ["heatwave", "shadowball", "trickroom", "protect"], "Tera Types": {"grass": 0.6155499597698191}, "Teammates": ["Ribombee", "Ursaluna-Bloodmoon", "Electabuzz", "Dragonite", "Rillaboom", "Archaludon"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Chandelure is a specialized Trick Room setter and offensive pivot that leverages its unique Ghost/Fire typing and sky-high Special Attack to pressure common Steel and Psychic cores while enabling slower breakers.  Choice Specs and Life Orb variants are both viable, but the dominant spread opts for Quiet nature with 140 HP / 116 Def EVs to survive key physical rolls and guarantee Trick Room versus faster threats.  Grass Tera is ubiquitous (≈62 %), flipping the Water match-up and giving Chandelure a one-time defensive pivoting option.  Its main partners—Ribombee, Ursaluna-Bloodmoon, and Rillaboom—form a cohesive “slow-mode” core that can toggle between speed control modes and immediately punish opposing Trick Room or Tailwind attempts.  Infiltrator is the preferred ability (≈58 %) to ignore Aurora Veil and Substitute, while Flame Body is a niche option to fish for burns on contact moves.  Despite middling bulk and a weakness to ubiquitous Rock- and Water-type coverage, Chandelure’s role compression as both speed control and immediate offensive threat makes it a staple on semi-room squads in current Regulation formats.</OUTPUT>

input:
Write a detailed 'full_analysis' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Chandelure": {"Abilities": {"flamebody": 0.33295107876840796, "infiltrator": 0.5766418585528963, "flashfire": 26.273218393872092}, "Items": {"choicespecs": 0.29013161788940484, "focussash": 0.2381162696020365, "lifeorb": 0.1627333225656073}, "Spreads": {"Quiet:252/0/140/116/0/0": 0.16160890826830288, "Modest:132/0/4/116/4/252": 0.1992491486749515}, "Moves": ["heatwave", "shadowball", "trickroom", "protect"], "Tera Types": {"grass": 0.6155499597698191}, "Teammates": ["Ribombee", "Ursaluna-Bloodmoon", "Electabuzz", "Dragonite", "Rillaboom", "Archaludon"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Chandelure’s stat line and movepool push it toward a hybrid role: it is simultaneously the fastest viable Trick Room setter (base 80) and one of the strongest special attackers available in Regulation D.  Heat Wave and Shadow Ball give perfect neutral coverage against the tier’s premier Fairy, Steel, and Psychic tanks, while Trick Room flips the tempo versus hyper-offensive archetypes built around Dragapult, Iron Valiant, or Choice Scarf Gholdengo.  The Quiet 252/140/116 spread survives Jolly Chien-Pao Crunch 100 % of the time and guarantees Trick Room against Timid Iron Bundle outside of Tailwind.  Modest 252 Speed with 132/4/116/4 is an off-speed variant designed to outrun neutral-nature base 70s (e.g., Breloom, Bisharp) under Tailwind while still maximizing power.  Choice Specs turns Chandelure into an immediate nuke, 2HKOing even bulky Tera-Water Arcanine with Heat Wave, whereas Life Orb grants the freedom to switch moves and bluff sets.  Grass Tera is not merely defensive: after Terastallizing, Chandelure avoids the 2HKO from standard Rotom-Wash Hydro Pump and OHKOes back with Overheat, creating a devastating mid-game pivoting opportunity.  Infiltrator invalidates Skeledirge’s Torch Song substitutes and screens stacks, giving Chandelure unique utility versus stall and semi-stall.  The combination of Ghost neutrality to Fighting and Fire neutrality to Fairy means Chandelure can safely switch into Great Tusk and Azumarill once, making it one of the few setters that does not require a dedicated pivot to enter the field.  However, its dependence on accuracy (Heat Wave 90 %, Shadow Ball 100 %) and vulnerability to Sucker Punch, First Impression, and Aqua Jet require careful positioning and often a Protect slot, limiting it to four-move-slot syndrome and forcing teams to dedicate a slot to hazard removal or dual-screen support.</OUTPUT>

input:
Write a detailed 'matchup_overview' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Chandelure": {"Abilities": {"flamebody": 0.33295107876840796, "infiltrator": 0.5766418585528963, "flashfire": 26.273218393872092}, "Items": {"choicespecs": 0.29013161788940484, "focussash": 0.2381162696020365, "lifeorb": 0.1627333225656073}, "Spreads": {"Quiet:252/0/140/116/0/0": 0.16160890826830288, "Modest:132/0/4/116/4/252": 0.1992491486749515}, "Moves": ["heatwave", "shadowball", "trickroom", "protect"], "Tera Types": {"grass": 0.6155499597698191}, "Teammates": ["Ribombee", "Ursaluna-Bloodmoon", "Electabuzz", "Dragonite", "Rillaboom", "Archaludon"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Versus hyper-offense, Chandelure is a primary speed-control button: it underspeeds Flutter Mane, Iron Valiant, and Chien-Pao outside of Tailwind, enabling partners such as Ursaluna-Bloodmoon and Bloodmoon itself to sweep.  Against balance, Trick Room invalidates common Choice Scarf users like Garchomp and Gholdengo, while Specs Heat Wave pressures Corviknight and Toxapex alike.  Grass Tera single-handedly flips the Rotom-Wash, Pelipper, and Swampert match-ups from losing to favorable, although it must Terastallize early to do so.  Stall teams that rely on Substitute + Protect cycles (Skeledirge, Gliscor) are broken by Infiltrator Shadow Ball, but Chandelure still dislikes Toxic and passive burn, so cleric support from Ribombee (Pollen Puff + Speed Swap) or Dragonite (Heal Bell) is common.  Rain teams present the worst overall scenario: Choice Specs Hurricane from Pelipter cleanly OHKOes even bulky spreads, and Swift Swim Barraskewda outspeeds and KOes before Trick Room can be set.  Consequently, most Chandelure teams pack Rillaboom to pressure Pelipper with Glide and to provide Grassy Terrain chip to offset Rain-boosted Surfs.  Sun is more manageable because Chandelure underspeeds Torkoal and can reverse the field speed, but Tera Fire Eruption still deals 70–80 % and requires Protect prediction.  In mirror Trick Room games, Chandelure’s speed tier becomes a liability because opposing Hatterene and Indeedee-F can set terrain and Room first; Ribombee’s Speed Swap or Fake Out support is therefore mandatory.</OUTPUT>

input:
Write a detailed 'role_description' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Chandelure": {"Abilities": {"flamebody": 0.33295107876840796, "infiltrator": 0.5766418585528963, "flashfire": 26.273218393872092}, "Items": {"choicespecs": 0.29013161788940484, "focussash": 0.2381162696020365, "lifeorb": 0.1627333225656073}, "Spreads": {"Quiet:252/0/140/116/0/0": 0.16160890826830288, "Modest:132/0/4/116/4/252": 0.1992491486749515}, "Moves": ["heatwave", "shadowball", "trickroom", "protect"], "Tera Types": {"grass": 0.6155499597698191}, "Teammates": ["Ribombee", "Ursaluna-Bloodmoon", "Electabuzz", "Dragonite", "Rillaboom", "Archaludon"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Chandelure is first and foremost a tempo setter that compresses three jobs into one slot: Trick Room initiation, immediate special wallbreaking, and mid-game Tera pivot.  Unlike Hatterene, it does not supply its own terrain, but its higher Speed and access to Protect let it function as a lead or back-line cleaner depending on the opponent’s structure.  Offensively, it targets the tier’s most common defensive cores: Corviknight + Gholdengo, Toxapex + Kingambit, and Amoonguss + Iron Hands.  Specs Heat Wave + Shadow Ball is only shy of the OHKO on max-HP Gholdengo, but after Stealth Rock or one round of Life Orb chip the KO is guaranteed.  On the defensive side, Chandelure’s Ghost typing grants an immunity to Fake Out and Rapid Spin, making it an ideal blocker versus Great Tusk and Iron Treads that attempt to clear hazards.  Its Fire typing also punishes U-turn from Corviknight and Mandibuzz with Flame Body procs, indirectly preserving Trick Room turns for slower partners.  Because it underspeeds base 85s, Chandelure can serve as a “slow” mode attacker even when Trick Room is not active, picking off weakened threats with Shadow Ball or spreading Burns with Will-O-Wisp (though Will-O-Wisp is rare in current usage).  Finally, the threat of Terastallizing into Grass forces opponents to respect potential defensive swaps, giving Chandelure teams an intangible positioning advantage that can be leveraged into double-switch momentum.</OUTPUT>

input:
Write a detailed 'synergy_breakdown' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Chandelure": {"Abilities": {"flamebody": 0.33295107876840796, "infiltrator": 0.5766418585528963, "flashfire": 26.273218393872092}, "Items": {"choicespecs": 0.29013161788940484, "focussash": 0.2381162696020365, "lifeorb": 0.1627333225656073}, "Spreads": {"Quiet:252/0/140/116/0/0": 0.16160890826830288, "Modest:132/0/4/116/4/252": 0.1992491486749515}, "Moves": ["heatwave", "shadowball", "trickroom", "protect"], "Tera Types": {"grass": 0.6155499597698191}, "Teammates": ["Ribombee", "Ursaluna-Bloodmoon", "Electabuzz", "Dragonite", "Rillaboom", "Archaludon"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Ribombee is the most frequent partner (≈22 % co-usage) and forms a self-contained speed-control package: Ribombee sets Tailwind versus faster teams and Speed Swaps to Chandelure versus slower ones, ensuring optimal positioning regardless of tempo.  Ribombee also supplies Pollen Puff healing and Sticky Web, the latter enabling Chandelure to underspeed neutral-nature base 70s without Quiet.  Ursaluna-Bloodmoon is the premier Trick Room abuser: it appreciates Ghost/Fire coverage luring in and weakening Corviknight and Skarmory, while Chandelure appreciates Bloodmoon’s ability to break past special walls like Blissey and Clodsire.  Rillaboom provides Grassy Glide priority to finish off weakened Water-types that survive Heat Wave, and Grassy Terrain slightly offsets Life Orb recoil.  Rillaboom also pressures opposing Water-types that force early Tera from Chandelure, preserving Tera for end-game sweeps.  Dragonite supplies Heal Bell to cure burns and toxic that would otherwise cripple Chandelure, while Multiscale guarantees a safe switch-in versus Choice-locked Ground or Ice moves.  Archaludon is a newer addition that gives the team a second Trick Room setter and a powerful Steel/Dragon STAB to punish Fairy-types that wall Chandelure; Stamina also lets Archaludon snowball after a Flame Body burn.  Finally, Electabuzz is an unexpected offensive pivot that baits Ground-type moves for Chandelure to switch in safely, while Discharge spreads paralysis that makes Trick Room easier to set later.  The overarching synergy is a dual-speed-control core that can toggle between Tailwind, Trick Room, and neutral speed while maintaining constant offensive pressure.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Chandelure": {"Abilities": {"flamebody": 0.33295107876840796, "infiltrator": 0.5766418585528963, "flashfire": 26.273218393872092}, "Items": {"choicespecs": 0.29013161788940484, "focussash": 0.2381162696020365, "lifeorb": 0.1627333225656073}, "Spreads": {"Quiet:252/0/140/116/0/0": 0.16160890826830288, "Modest:132/0/4/116/4/252": 0.1992491486749515}, "Moves": ["heatwave", "shadowball", "trickroom", "protect"], "Tera Types": {"grass": 0.6155499597698191}, "Teammates": ["Ribombee", "Ursaluna-Bloodmoon", "Electabuzz", "Dragonite", "Rillaboom", "Archaludon"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Chandelure’s most exploitable flaw is its fragility on the physical side: even with 140 Def EVs it is cleanly OHKOed by Choice Band Chien-Pao Ice Spinner and 2HKOed by Great Tusk Headlong Rush.  Any form of passive damage—Stealth Rock, Life Orb, burn or poison—quickly pushes it into KO range.  Water-type coverage remains the single best answer: Specs Pelipper Hydro Pump in Rain and Choice Specs Iron Bundle Hydro Steam both OHKO before Tera, forcing Chandelure to Terastallize early and reveal Grass, after which Kingambit or Gholdengo can safely switch in.  Sucker Punch users such as Kingambit and Ting-Lu bypass Trick Room speed and KO after minor chip; Protect mind-games are mandatory but unreliable.  Faster Substitute users like Hydrapple and Gliscor can stall out Trick Room turns, although Infiltrator Shadow Ball breaks most substitutes.  Priority Tailwind from Corviknight or Kilowattrel can re-flip speed even after Room is set, leaving Chandelure and its slow partners exposed.  Finally, status—especially Toxic from Toxapex or burn from Rotom-Wash—cripples Chandelure’s longevity and forces it to Protect stall, wasting precious Trick Room turns.  Teams that pack dual priority (e.g., First Impression + Sucker Punch) or that can set both hazards and weather generally give Chandelure the most trouble.</OUTPUT>

Chandelure @ Life Orb – Trick Room / Heat Wave / Shadow Ball / Protect – Quiet 252/140/116, Infiltrator Tera Grass.  Ursaluna-Bloodmoon @ Choice Band – Blood Moon / Earthquake / Stone Edge / Protect – Brave 252/252/4.  Rillaboom @ Assault Vest – Grassy Glide / Wood Hammer / Knock Off / U-turn – Adamant 252/252/4. The team operates in two gears: versus fast offense, Ribombee sets Sticky Web and Tailwind while Chandelure cleans early; versus balance or semi-room, Chandelure and Archaludon alternate Trick Room turns while Bloodmoon and Rillaboom break cores.  Dragonite provides cleric support and a secondary pivot into Ground and Ice moves, while Archaludon gives a second Steel resist and end-game sweep potential with Stamina boosts. The structure is self-sufficient in speed control and can toggle between offense and defense depending on the opponent’s lead, making it a reliable top-cut choice for current Regulation D best-of-three formats.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Arcanine": {"Abilities": {"intimidate": 26.02393861614701, "justified": 0.9558132392494763, "flashfire": 0.004196145526708606}, "Items": {"sitrusberry": 0.5439144495132346}, "Spreads": {"Jolly:252/68/4/0/4/180": 0.40639400872593556}, "Moves": ["flareblitz", "protect", "extremespeed", "willowisp"], "Tera Types": {"grass": 0.7012691473378471}, "Teammates": ["Gholdengo", "Maushold", "Archaludon", "Ursaluna-Bloodmoon", "Dondozo", "Ribombee"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Intimidate remains the overwhelmingly preferred ability, appearing on 96 % of sampled Arcanine and immediately tilting physical exchanges in your favor by dropping the foe’s Attack one stage on switch-in. Flare Blitz is the obligatory high-damage STAB, nuking frail Steel and Grass types such as Amoonguss and Iron Bundle, while Extreme Speed gives the team a desperately needed +2 priority option to finish off Focus Sash holders and low-health Dynamax targets. Will-O-Wisp is the set’s heart and soul, punishing contact attackers like Chien-Pao, Kingambit, and opposing Arcanine and turning many 2-for-2 exchanges into 2-for-1s by crippling whatever stays on the field. Protect is mandatory doubles tech, scouting choice-locked Dragapult or Urshifu-Rapid-Strike and gaining extra Leftovers-style recovery via Sitrus Berry. Tera Grass is taken on 70 % of sets because it flips the Water matchup: Tera Grass Arcanine resives Rain-boosted Surfs from Pelipper or Palafin and converts them into 25 % healing, while still retaining neutrality to Rock and Ground that plague Fire types. The chosen EV spread lives Jolly Iron Valiant Life Orb Close Combat, outspeeds Adamant Breloom, and guarantees the OHKO on 0 HP Gholdengo with Flare Blitz after burn or chip. Justified variants exist but are niche, mostly appearing on Beat Up teams that stack Kingambit or Cobalion; Flash Fire is virtually unseen.</OUTPUT>

It pressures Sun teams by underspeeding Torkoal and OHKOing Venusaur with Flare Blitz, yet it also dismantles Rain’s physical attackers, burning Palafin and gaining free healing off Water moves post-Tera. Into Trick Room it acts as a fast nuisance, KOing Indeedee-F and Hatterene before they set up or at least forcing Protect and burn damage. Against PsySpam or Gholdengo offense, Arcanine can trade favorably, eating a Make It Rain and retaliating for the KO. It struggles versus special attackers that ignore Intimidate—Choice Specs Dragapult, Iron Moth, and Hydro Pump Iron Bundle can all OHKO before it moves—and versus Ground spam from Lando-T or Great Tusk that can punish the Tera Grass lock with Earthquake.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Malamar carves a small but meaningful niche in VGC as a Contrary Superpower sweeper that can also flip the field’s speed dynamics with Trick Room. Its near-exclusive use of Contrary lets it snowball Attack and Defense in a single move, turning Superpower into a scaling nuke that punishes passive play. While its stats are middling and its Speed tier poor, the combination of Knock Off utility, Topsy-Turvy disruption, and flexible Tera options (Steel for survival, Water for Fire-type pivots) makes it a surprisingly dangerous setup piece on bulky offense or full-room squads. The data show it almost always runs max Attack Adamant with Safety Goggles or Leftovers, underscoring its role as a slow, self-buffing win-condition that wants to ignore enemy weather and status while it accumulates boosts.</OUTPUT>

input:
Write a detailed 'full_analysis' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Malamar": {"Abilities": {"contrary": 26.007029941575404, "suctioncups": 0.0, "infiltrator": 0.0010144381732314356}, "Items": {"leftovers": 0.15507020422113096, "safetygoggles": 0.40817996194002737, "sitrusberry": 0.2533941915360631}, "Spreads": {"Adamant:252/252/0/0/4/0": 0.3872609326140106}, "Moves": ["superpower", "knockoff", "trickroom", "topsyturvy"], "Tera Types": {"steel": 0.45587140867911, "water": 0.16310425076025542}, "Teammates": ["Archaludon", "Indeedee-F", "Torkoal", "Lilligant-Hisui", "Hatterene", "Gallade"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Contrary is the engine that justifies Malamar’s inclusion: every Superpower becomes a bulkier, harder-hitting threat that outpaces most unboosted neutral targets after one use and becomes genuinely oppressive after two. Knock Off provides invaluable item control against common VGC staples like Sitrus, Eject Pack, or Covert Cloak, while Topsy-Turvy flips the script on opposing Dragon Dancers, Iron Defense users, or Calm Mind sweepers. Trick Room is the final piece, letting Malamar function as both abuser and setter: it underspeeds the entire unboosted metagame, so moving first under its own Room turns Superpower into a 120 BP STAB that simultaneously raises its two most important stats. The chosen Tera types reinforce two distinct gameplans: Steel removes the pesky Fairy weakness, adds a Flash Fire-style neutrality to Heat Wave, and provides a crucial Toxic immunity, whereas Water punishes Sun teams by flipping the Fire matchup and granting a handy resistance to common spread moves like Heat Wave and Rock Slide. Safety Goggles is the most popular item because it guarantees Malamar can set up on Amoonguss or rage-powder users, while Leftovers offers slow, incremental recovery that synergizes with the Defense boosts. The 252/252/4 spread maximizes immediate damage output and bulk, ensuring OHKOs on frailer threats like Flutter Mane or Chi-Yu after a single boost while surviving -1 neutral attacks such as Dragon Pulse from bulky Dialga. Overall, Malamar is not a splashable Pokémon, but on the right structure it becomes a multi-lane threat that can win games outright if given a single free turn.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Malamar loves facing bulky setup cores that rely on stat changes—Dondozo, Garganacl, Iron Hands, and Armarouge all struggle to break +2/+2 Malamar before falling to boosted Superpowers. It also pressures Sun and Sand teams that lean on special attackers; after a Contrary raise, even neutral targets like Torkoal or Tyranitar risk the 2HKO. Conversely, Malamar hates fast Fairy or Bug-type pressure: Flutter Mane, Iron Valiant, and Chien-Pao all outspeed and OHKO before it can boost, while Choice Band First Impression from opposing Gallade or Lokix deletes it from full. Priority users such as Dragonite with Extreme Speed or Kingambit with Sucker Punch can pick off a weakened Malamar unless it has already accumulated Defense boosts. Finally, Unaware users like Skeledirge ignore Contrary shenanigans, forcing Malamar to rely on raw damage or ally support to break through.</OUTPUT>

In the early game it functions as a Knock Off bot and Topsy-Turvy safety valve, removing items and neutralizing opposing setup. Mid-game it looks for a free turn—via a Protect, a KO pivot, or a rage-powder ally—to click Superpower and begin snowballing. Once at +2/+2 it becomes the team’s cleaner, breaking holes in the opponent’s defensive core while simultaneously growing harder to KO. The inclusion of Trick Room also lets Malamar serve as emergency speed control for its own team, flipping the tempo against faster offenses and enabling slower partners like Archaludon or Hatterene to operate at peak efficiency. In short, Malamar is a hybrid setup sweeper and field controller that demands answers the moment it enters play.</OUTPUT>

Indeedee-F provides Follow Me and Psychic Terrain, giving Malamar the free turns it craves while blocking priority revenge kills. Torkoal and Lilligant-Hisui form a classic SunRoom core that can either set Sun for fast Lilligant or Room for slow Malamar, forcing opponents to guess the mode turn one. Hatterene offers another Trick Room setter that blocks opposing status with Magic Bounce, stacking mental pressure alongside Malamar’s Topsy-Turvy. Finally, Gallade shares overlapping Fighting coverage, can self-proc Weakness Policy with Tera Flying, and lures Fairy-types that Malamar loves to eliminate. Together these teammates create a dual-speed archetype that can toggle between Sun, Tailwind, and Trick Room, ensuring Malamar always has the tempo it needs to boost.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Kingdra": {"Abilities": {"swiftswim": 23.461169824679327, "sniper": 2.329896536955951, "damp": 1.1090488812925958e-05}, "Items": {"lifeorb": 0.7817316713702687}, "Spreads": {"Modest:4/0/0/252/0/252": 0.37248315409315685}, "Moves": ["protect", "dracometeor", "weatherball", "muddywater"], "Tera Types": {"stellar": 0.5734302066487553, "water": 0.33145825063876816}, "Teammates": ["Archaludon", "Politoed", "Incineroar", "Gothitelle", "Amoonguss", "Pelipper"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Kingdra’s niche in VGC 2025 is defined by its unique typing and Swift Swim: the only Water/Dragon in the format, it resists Fire- and Water-type moves that plague other rain attackers while retaining a coveted Dragon STAB that hits Rotom-W, Dragapult, and other rain staples for super-effective damage. Modest Life Orb is the only spread shown, maximizing Special Attack and Speed to guarantee KOs on common threats such as 4 HP Tornadus, offensive Landorus-T, and non-Dynamax Rotom-W after Stealth Rock or a single Helping Hand boost. Draco Meteor is the nuke that breaks through bulky Grass-types like Amoonguss after chip, while Muddy Water provides spread damage with a 30% accuracy debuff that can swing follow-up turns. Weather Ball becomes a 100 BP Water move under rain, giving Kingdra a single-target nuke that bypasses the spread damage reduction and OHKOes threats such as Incineroar and Chien-Pao after Stealth Rock. Protect is mandatory for doubles, allowing Kingdra to dodge Fake Out, buy rain turns, and enable its partner to eliminate counters. Tera Stellar is preferred because it removes the Dragon-typing’s Fairy and Ice weaknesses for the turn, neutralizes Draco Meteor’s Special Attack drop, and turns Tera Blast into a 120 BP move that hits neutrally across the board, letting Kingdra clean late-game even after it has dropped its main nuke. Tera Water is an alternative that boosts Muddy Water and Weather Ball to absurd levels, securing OHKOs on max HP Gastrodon and Assault Vest Slowking, but it leaves Kingdra vulnerable to the same Ice- and Fairy-type moves it hoped to dodge. The usage data shows virtually no deviation from the Modest 252/252 spread, indicating that speed-tieing opposing Kingdra and other Swift Swim sweepers is paramount, and the power drop from Timid is noticeable in key damage rolls.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Kingdra": {"Abilities": {"swiftswim": 23.461169824679327, "sniper": 2.329896536955951, "damp": 1.1090488812925958e-05}, "Items": {"lifeorb": 0.7817316713702687}, "Spreads": {"Modest:4/0/0/252/0/252": 0.37248315409315685}, "Moves": ["protect", "dracometeor", "weatherball", "muddywater"], "Tera Types": {"stellar": 0.5734302066487553, "water": 0.33145825063876816}, "Teammates": ["Archaludon", "Politoed", "Incineroar", "Gothitelle", "Amoonguss", "Pelipper"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Rain mirrors are skill-based: faster rain or a speed-tie roll decides who commands the tempo, so Kingdra teams pack priority and speed control such as Pelipper Tailwind or Amoonguss spore pressure. Against sun, Kingdra outspeeds and OHKOes most Chlorophyll sweepers with Muddy Water, but must watch for Torkoal’s Eruption and Venusaur’s Sludge Bomb; Tera Stellar helps survive a Sludge Bomb and retaliate. Versus sand, Kingdra cleanly beats Excadrill outside of Dynamax and 2HKOes most Tyranitar variants, though it fears Ice Punch or a Tera Ice move. Against Trick Room, Kingdra is naturally faster, but must double-target common setters like Hatterene or Indeedee-F to prevent room going up; Gothitelle is a listed teammate specifically to Shadow Tag block retreat and allow Kingdra to position safely. Fairy-type cores featuring Sylveon, Clefairy, or Primarina are problematic: +1 Sylveon Hyper Voice in terrain or Helping Hand Pixilate-boosted Hyper Beam OHKO Kingdra, so Incineroar and Amoonguss are used to Intimidate and redirect, respectively. Ice-types such as Chien-Pao and Iron Bundle outspeed under rain if they hold Choice Scarf, so Kingdra teams carry their own priority (Gothitelle Sucker Punch, Incineroar Fake Out) to pick them off before they strike.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Kingdra": {"Abilities": {"swiftswim": 23.461169824679327, "sniper": 2.329896536955951, "damp": 1.1090488812925958e-05}, "Items": {"lifeorb": 0.7817316713702687}, "Spreads": {"Modest:4/0/0/252/0/252": 0.37248315409315685}, "Moves": ["protect", "dracometeor", "weatherball", "muddywater"], "Tera Types": {"stellar": 0.5734302066487553, "water": 0.33145825063876816}, "Teammates": ["Archaludon", "Politoed", "Incineroar", "Gothitelle", "Amoonguss", "Pelipper"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Kingdra despises priority and faster attackers that ignore Swift Swim. Choice Scarf Chien-Pao’s Triple Axel or Ice Spinner OHKO even if Kingdra is at full health. Sylveon under Psychic Terrain or with Helping Hand Hyper Voice does the same. Amoonguss with Clear Smog removes Kingdra’s Swift Swim speed and Special Attack boosts from Max Flutterby or Max Ooze, turning it into dead weight. Wide Guard users such as Aegislash, Entei, or opposing Starmie block both Muddy Water and Weather Ball, forcing Kingdra to rely on Draco Meteor and its subsequent drop. Bulky Grass-types—especially Toxapex-Gmax Venusaur cores—can stomach a Draco Meteor and retalivate with Sludge Bomb or G-Max Vine Lash chip. Tera Fairy Dragapult is a soft check, living a Draco Meteor and OHKOing back with Tera Fairy Draco Meteor or Tera Blast Fairy. Finally, opposing weather setters such as Tyranitar or Torkoal can reset the weather on the switch, neutering Swift Swim and leaving Kingdra outsped by the entire metagame.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Umbreon is a premier support Pokémon in VGC, leveraging its immense natural bulk and disruptive movepool to anchor defensive cores. With FoulPlay and Snarl it simultaneously chips and neuters physical and special attackers, while Yawn and Taunt lock opponents into sleep or deny their utility. Inner Focus is the dominant ability, chosen 22.4% of the time to ignore flinches from Fake Out and Rock Slide, and the most successful spreads are Calm or Bold with heavy HP/Defense investment. Tera Ghost, Flying, or Water grant key immunities or resistances that let Umbreon pivot through match-ups, and it is almost always paired with Eeveelution or weather teammates that appreciate its slow, methodical pace.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Umbreon": {"Abilities": {"innerfocus": 22.389269555676943, "synchronize": 2.0281821924720926}, "Items": {"sitrusberry": 0.6226099604828911, "safetygoggles": 0.24655371243180854}, "Spreads": {"Calm:252/0/100/0/156/0": 0.23925263828000748, "Bold:252/0/252/0/4/0": 0.23373981993939646, "Bold:252/0/132/4/84/36": 0.2340836608976912}, "Moves": ["foulplay", "snarl", "yawn", "taunt"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.24614709849856467, "flying": 0.23392083245166143, "water": 0.23996859707477125}, "Teammates": ["Archaludon", "Pelipper", "Ursaluna-Bloodmoon", "Sylveon", "Espeon", "Vaporeon"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Umbreon's base stats translate to 95/110/130 bulk, meaning that even uninvested it survives powerful Z-moves and max-dynamax attacks. The chosen spreads reflect two philosophies: Calm 252/0/100/0/156/0 maximises special bulk to stomach Flutter Mane Moonblasts and Iron Bundle Hydro Pumps, while Bold 252/0/252/0/4/0 shores up the defense side to live Choice Band Chien-Pao Icicle Crash. A hybrid Bold 252/0/132/4/84/36 creeps four Speed to out-slow opposing support Torkoal and Amoonguss, letting Umbreon fire a Taunt or Yawn before they move. FoulPlay is the cornerstone attack: it scales off the target's Attack stat, letting Umbreon punish physical set-up sweepers like Kingambit and Dragonite without investing EVs in its own offenses. Snarl provides immediate special damage reduction, turning 2HKOs into 3HKOs against partners such as Chi-Yu and Iron Moth. Yawn forces switches or secures sleep, creating free turns for partners such as Archaludon to set up Electro Shot or for Pelipper to re-set rain. Taunt shuts down Trick Room, Tailwind, and opposing recovery, making Umbreon a universal answer to stall and speed control archetypes. Item-wise, Sitrus Berry is the most common (0.62%), giving 25% recovery that in tandem with Protect and Leftovers-like residual healing lets Umbreon stick on the field for 8-10 turns; Safety Goggles (0.25%) is a tech to ignore Rage Powder and Spore, particularly useful when paired with its own Amoonguss or when facing Venusaur. Tera Ghost is the most popular choice (24.6%), removing Normal- and Fighting-type weaknesses and granting an immunity to Fake Out and Extreme Speed, while Tera Flying and Tera Water respectively grant Ground immunity and a Rain-boosted Water resistance, synergising with Pelipper rain teams. In dynamax formats, Umbreon rarely maxes itself but can use Max Darkness to drop both opponents' SpD, amplifying teammates' special damage output.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Umbreon": {"Abilities": {"innerfocus": 22.389269555676943, "synchronize": 2.0281821924720926}, "Items": {"sitrusberry": 0.6226099604828911, "safetygoggles": 0.24655371243180854}, "Spreads": {"Calm:252/0/100/0/156/0": 0.23925263828000748, "Bold:252/0/252/0/4/0": 0.23373981993939646, "Bold:252/0/132/4/84/36": 0.2340836608976912}, "Moves": ["foulplay", "snarl", "yawn", "taunt"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.24614709849856467, "flying": 0.23392083245166143, "water": 0.23996859707477125}, "Teammates": ["Archaludon", "Pelipper", "Ursaluna-Bloodmoon", "Sylveon", "Espeon", "Vaporeon"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Umbreon excels against balanced and hyper-offensive squads that rely on single-target burst; Snarl plus Intimidate support can reduce a Chien-Pao's Icicle Crash to ~25% damage. It struggles against faster Substitute users like Iron Valiant and Meowscarada that can block Yawn, and against Fairy-types such as Sylveon and Flutter Mane that resist FoulPlay and threaten with super-effective Moonblast. Steel-types like Gholdengo and Kingambit are neutral to FoulPlay, but their slower speed tiers mean they still dislike Yawn and Taunt. Rain teams containing Pelipper and Ursaluna-Bloodmoon appreciate Umbreon's ability to tank Grass-type moves aimed at Pelipper and phaze opposing set-up with Yawn, while sun teams can find Umbreon passive if they cannot keep Snarl pressure up. Trick Room match-ups are split: Umbreon can Taunt the setter, but if Trick Room goes up its low Speed becomes a liability unless it Terastallizes into Ghost to avoid Fighting-type attacks. Shadow Ball spam from Indeedee and Hatterene can 2HKO, so Tera Ghost is pivotal to flip those numbers.</OUTPUT>
