<DATA>{"Umbreon": {"Abilities": {"innerfocus": 22.389269555676943, "synchronize": 2.0281821924720926}, "Items": {"sitrusberry": 0.6226099604828911, "safetygoggles": 0.24655371243180854}, "Spreads": {"Calm:252/0/100/0/156/0": 0.23925263828000748, "Bold:252/0/252/0/4/0": 0.23373981993939646, "Bold:252/0/132/4/84/36": 0.2340836608976912}, "Moves": ["foulplay", "snarl", "yawn", "taunt"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.24614709849856467, "flying": 0.23392083245166143, "water": 0.23996859707477125}, "Teammates": ["Archaludon", "Pelipper", "Ursaluna-Bloodmoon", "Sylveon", "Espeon", "Vaporeon"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Umbreon's primary role is a support anchor that controls the tempo of the game through constant chip and status. It is not a win-condition; instead, it creates a 5v4 or 5v3 by forcing double targets, sleep, or switches, allowing its typically offensive partners to sweep mid- to late-game. Its EV spreads are optimised to survive specific calcs rather than to KO back, so it fits best on mid-range or hard-TR squads that value incremental advantage over speed. Because it is slower than most support Pokémon, Umbreon can serve as a pseudo-Trick Room setter by Yawning key threats, then either Protecting or pivoting out to reset field positioning. The prevalence of Inner Focus over Synchronize indicates a metagame preference for ignoring flinch over punishing status, highlighting Umbreon's role as a Fake Out absorber for frail sweepers like Bloodmoon Ursaluna.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Archaludon is the most common partner, appreciating Umbreon's ability to tank Ground- and Fighting-type moves while Archaludon sets up Electro Shot; in return, Archaludon pressures Fairy-types that trouble Umbreon. Pelipper provides Rain, reducing Fire-type damage on Umbreon and enabling Hurricane spam that benefits from Snarl's SpD drops. Ursaluna-Bloodmoon enjoys Yawn support to buy turns for Blood Moon and benefits from Umbreon baiting Ghost-type moves that it can switch in on. Sylveon forms an Eeveelution core, covering the Fairy-type weakness and providing Hyper Voice spread damage while Umbreon handles Steel-types with FoulPlay. Espeon gives fast screens and can bounce back Taunt, while Vaporeon passes Wish to extend Umbreon's longevity even further. In general, Umbreon fits best on teams that contain one bulky pivot and one fast offensive mode, letting it choose whether to play slow or pivot into speed control.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Umbreon is helpless against strong Fairy-type special attackers; Choice Specs Sylveon and Flutter Mane OHKO with Hyper Voice or Moonblast unless Umbreon Terastallizes into Steel or Poison, which then removes its valuable Ghost/Flying/Water defensive utility. output: <OUTPUT>Electrode-Hisui is a niche but surprisingly disruptive support Pokémon in VGC, leveraging its blistering base 150 Speed to fire off the fastest Electroweb in the format, enabling its slower partners to move first while shaving 25 % off both enemies’ Speed tiers. While its offensive stats are unimpressive, its movepool (Bullet Seed, Taunt, Protect, and Electroweb) and the threat of Aftermath chip give it a unique role as a speed-control pivot that can break Sash, pressure Substitute users, and deny Trick Room or Tailwind with nearly guaranteed Taunt speed ties. The most successful sets run Timid 252 Spe to outrun even Choice Scarf Dragapult, with the remaining EVs usually dropped into bulk or a little SpA to guarantee certain Bullet Seed damage rolls. Tera Ghost is the only Tera type worth noting, turning its Normal immunity into a Ghost resist and letting it dodge Fake Out and Extreme Speed while still keeping Aftermath online. On rain or bulky-offense frameworks, Electrode-Hisui compresses speed control and anti-setup utility into one slot, freeing the second support slot for a win-condition like Archaludon or Gholdengo.</OUTPUT>

input:
Provide the 'full_analysis' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Electrode-Hisui": {"Abilities": {"aftermath": 12.150104880856922, "soundproof": 3.60826142600212, "static": 8.918230285281988}, "Items": {"loadeddice": 0.4752744738765469, "focussash": 0.45305118671483774}, "Spreads": {"Timid:4/0/0/252/0/252": 0.45836936803027056, "Timid:236/0/4/12/4/252": 0.27065330188734854}, "Moves": ["bulletseed", "taunt", "electroweb", "protect"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.9063024774372473}, "Teammates": ["Archaludon", "Pelipper", "Gholdengo", "Annihilape", "Baxcalibur", "Clefable"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Electrode-Hisui’s claim to fame is its unmatched Speed tier; at base 150 it outspeeds the entire unboosted metagame and most Scarfers, ensuring Electroweb or Taunt lands before almost any opposing move. Electroweb is the centerpiece: a spread move that simultaneously damages and lowers Speed, letting slower breakers such as Baxcalibur or Annihilape move before would-be threats like Iron Valiant or opposing weather sweepers. Bullet Seed provides a multi-hit attack that breaks Focus Sash, Sturdy, and Substitute while also dealing solid damage to bulky Waters and Gastrodon; Loaded Dice is occasionally slotted to raise the hit rate to five, though Focus Sash is still the preferred item to guarantee at least one disruption turn versus faster Fake Out leads. Taunt shuts down Trick Room, Tailwind, Grimmsnarl screens, and Amoongus spores, while Protect is mandatory for double-target mind-games and Aftermath activation. Aftermath itself is deceptely potent: many players will target Electrode with a physical move expecting an easy KO, only to lose 25 % of their health and jeopardize end-game calcs. The EV spreads are straightforward: max Speed Timid is non-negotiable; the remaining EVs are typically invested in bulk (236 HP / 4 Def / 4 SpD) to survive Jolly Chien-Pao Ice Spinner or Specs Dragapult Shadow Ball, though some opt for 12 SpA to ensure Bullet Seed always 2HKOes 252/0 Gastrodon through Sitrus. Tera Ghost is almost exclusive because it flips Fake Out match-ups, dodges Rapid Spin, and grants a crucial immunity to opposing Normal-type Extreme Speed attempts while preserving Aftermath chip. Overall, Electrode-Hisui functions as a high-tempo support that compresses speed control, anti-hazard, and anti-setup into the fastest package available, allowing its teammates to operate at their preferred tempo.</OUTPUT>

input:
Write the 'matchup_overview' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Electrode-Hisui": {"Abilities": {"aftermath": 12.150104880856922, "soundproof": 3.60826142600212, "static": 8.918230285281988}, "Items": {"loadeddice": 0.4752744738765469, "focussash": 0.45305118671483774}, "Spreads": {"Timid:4/0/0/252/0/252": 0.45836936803027056, "Timid:236/0/4/12/4/252": 0.27065330188734854}, "Moves": ["bulletseed", "taunt", "electroweb", "protect"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.9063024774372473}, "Teammates": ["Archaludon", "Pelipper", "Gholdengo", "Annihilape", "Baxcalibur", "Clefable"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Electrode-Hisui loves facing bulky offense and balanced teams that rely on speed control or setup: it Taunts Grimmsnarl before it can screen, drops Speed on Iron Valiant and Chien-Pao so its partner can KO first, and punishes physical attackers with Aftermath. Against hard Trick Room teams, turn-one Taunt plus Electroweb damage often prevents the room from ever going up, while Bullet Seed cleanly removes Hatterene’s Focus Sash. Rain teams appreciate Electrode because it outruns and weakens Swift Swim sweepers like Kingdra and Barraskewda for Pelipper and Archaludon to finish. Conversely, Electrode struggles versus hyper-offensive teams that carry priority or spread special firepower: Chien-Pao’s Ice Shard or Bisharp’s Sucker Punch KO before Aftermath triggers, while Specs Dragapult or Iron Moth simply OHKO with special moves. Priority Tailwind or Booster Energy Speed ties can also leave Electrode moving second, reducing its disruption value. Finally, Ghost-resistant or multi-hit-immune Pokémon such as Corviknight, Gholdengo, or Air-Balloon Garchomp can shrug off Bullet Seed and retaliate.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Lucario is a hyper-offensive glass cannon that almost always carries Focus Sash and runs either full Jolly or full Adamant EVs, aiming to outspeed or overpower foes with STAB Close Combat, priority Extreme Speed, and coverage Meteor Mash. Tera Normal is the most common pick to boost Extreme Speed to terrifying levels, while Tera Stellar is gaining traction as a neutral power-up for all its moves. Inner Focus is the dominant ability, preventing flinch hax and letting it safely lead against Fake Out users. <DATA>{"Lucario": {"Abilities": {"innerfocus": 22.860470701058684, "justified": 0.16966991486601257, "steadfast": 0.42073976213215875}, "Items": {"focussash": 0.8980887965330412}, "Spreads": {"Adamant:0/252/0/0/4/252": 0.2283726581511085, "Jolly:0/252/0/0/4/252": 0.5250242657975358}, "Moves": ["closecombat", "extremespeed", "meteormash", "detect"], "Tera Types": {"normal": 0.25865013159057965, "stellar": 0.643135359990975}, "Teammates": ["Garchomp", "Tyranitar", "Incineroar", "Talonflame", "Gholdengo", "Sinistcha"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>With 90/115/90 offenses and 70/70/80 bulk, Lucario is the quintessential high-risk, high-reward attacker: it hits incredibly hard but folds to almost any neutral hit. The usage data show a near-universal Focus Sash (≈90 %), underscoring that it must survive one hit to function. Jolly 252/252 is the most popular spread (≈52 %), letting it outspeed positive-nature base 110s such as Garchomp and Meowscarada, while Adamant 252/252 (≈23 %) trades that speed for immediate wall-breaking power. Close Combat is mandatory: a STAB 120 BP move coming off base 115 Attack is a guaranteed OHKO on most neutral targets that don’t resist it. Extreme Speed provides invaluable +2 priority, cleaning weakened boards and punishing opposing speed control. Meteor Mash offers a 90 BP Steel move that nails Fairies such as Sylveon and Hatterene while giving a 20 % chance to boost Attack, further snowballing games. Inner Focus is taken on virtually every set because flinches are the easiest way to waste its sash; Steadfast and Justified are fringe options that rarely outperform it. Tera Normal is the most common Tera type (≈26 %), turning Extreme Speed into a 120 BP STAB priority move capable of sniping even bulky resists after chip, while Tera Stellar (≈64 %) boosts every move by 1.2× without locking Lucario into a single type, preserving coverage options. The Pokémon fits naturally onto offensive cores that appreciate a fast, self-sufficient breaker that does not require setup turns.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Lucario loves to face slower, offensive teams that lack bulky resists to Fighting and Steel. It OHKOes common threats like Kingambit, Tyranitar, Gholdengo, and Garchomp with the appropriate move and can pick off faster but frail attackers such as Meowscarada and Iron Valiant with Extreme Speed after chip. It struggles against Intimidate cycles—Incineroar and Arcanine can halve its Attack and break its sash with Snarl or Flare Blitz—and against bulky Fairy-types like Sylveon and Wellspring that survive Meteor Mash and retalivate with Hyper Voice or Mystical Water. Priority users such as Dragonite and Breloom can bypass its sash with multi-hit or priority moves, while Follow Me + Trick Room teams can set up in its face if it fails to secure the double KO turn one. Ghost-types like Aegislash and Dragapult are immune to Extreme Speed and can tank a Close Combat, forcing Lucario to Tera Normal or switch out.</OUTPUT>

Garchomp provides Ground immunity, spreads Rocky Helmet chip, and lures in Fairies for Lucario to delete. Incineroar cycles Intimidate and Parting Shot, creating safe switch-ins and softening physical walls that Lucario dislikes. Talonflame brings Tailwind for speed control and can pivot with U-turn, letting Lucario re-enter safely. Gholdengo blocks opposing status and spreads Special offense, pressuring physically bulky answers like Corviknight and Slowbro. Sinistcha rounds out the core with passive chip via matcha, stacking damage that puts targets into Extreme Speed KO range. Together, these teammates form a fast, disruptive offense archetype that keeps up constant pressure and denies the opponent any safe turns.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Braviary-Hisui": {"Abilities": {"tintedlens": 22.1437787830113, "sheerforce": 0.8283155843426424, "keeneye": 0.04445680534448482}, "Items": {"lifeorb": 0.5102275219456661, "twistedspoon": 0.21913038077687383, "choicescarf": 0.21170050448812738}, "Spreads": {"Quiet:100/156/0/252/0/0": 0.42379719948060773, "Timid:4/0/0/252/0/252": 0.19209583097722074, "Timid:0/0/0/252/4/252": 0.17483175302828183}, "Moves": ["expandingforce", "dazzlinggleam", "protect", "esperwing"], "Tera Types": {"psychic": 0.9409969891873518}, "Teammates": ["Poliwrath", "Pelipper", "Indeedee-F", "Annihilape", "Sneasler", "Ursaluna"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Although base 80 Speed and a mediocre special movepool leave it outclassed on paper, Braviary-Hisui’s unique combination of Tinted Lens, Psychic-typing and access to Expanding Force allows it to function as a terrain-based wallbreaker that ignores the usual Flying-, Steel- and Dark-type resists that plague Psychic attackers.  Life Orb is the preferred item: the 30 % recoil is offset by the raw power boost it provides to neutral Expanding Force, which effectively hits every non-immune target for at least neutral damage.  Twisted Spoon is a lower-damage, no-recoil alternative that still secures key OHKOs under terrain, while Choice Scarf turns Braviary into a surprise speed-control option that outspeeds +1 Kingambit and Chien-Pao.  The Quiet nature spread (100/156/0/252/0/0) is the most common, maximizing special attack while letting Braviary underspeed its own Indeedee-F so terrain is already active when it attacks; Timid variants trade immediate power for the ability to outspeed base 100 threats such as Garchomp and Chien-Pao.  Tera Psychic is essentially mandatory, pushing Expanding Force to a 156 BP spread move after STAB and terrain, and giving Braviary a one-time nuke that can erase bulky resists like Corviknight and Aegislash.  Protect is kept on every set to allow positioning around Fake Out and to let speed-controlling partners such as Poliwrath or Pelipper set rain or swap in safely.  Esper Wing is the preferred coverage, offering a 100 % crit chance in Tailwind or versus burned targets and rounding out the set with a reliable single-target option.</OUTPUT>

output: <OUTPUT>Braviary-Hisui excels versus balance and bulky offense cores that rely on traditional Psychic resists—Corviknight, Kingambit, Gholdengo, Amoonguss—because Tinted Lens turns their resisted Expanding Force into neutral damage, effectively removing their safe switch-ins.  It struggles versus faster offensive teams that can KO before terrain is active or that carry priority in the form of Sucker Punch or Aqua Jet; Chien-Pao, Basculegion and Palafin can all pick off a chipped Braviary before it moves. Rain teams featuring Pelipper mitigate Braviary’s Fire-type weakness and let it run Hurricane over Esper Wing, but this is rare in practice.  Trick Room is a double-edged sword: Braviary underspeeds many threats under Trick Room, but the terrain setter must still move first, so follow-me or Fake Out support is required to guarantee terrain.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Braviary-Hisui": {"Abilities": {"tintedlens": 22.1437787830113, "sheerforce": 0.8283155843426424, "keeneye": 0.04445680534448482}, "Items": {"lifeorb": 0.5102275219456661, "twistedspoon": 0.21913038077687383, "choicescarf": 0.21170050448812738}, "Spreads": {"Quiet:100/156/0/252/0/0": 0.42379719948060773, "Timid:4/0/0/252/0/252": 0.19209583097722074, "Timid:0/0/0/252/4/252": 0.17483175302828183}, "Moves": ["expandingforce", "dazzlinggleam", "protect", "esperwing"], "Tera Types": {"psychic": 0.9409969891873518}, "Teammates": ["Poliwrath", "Pelipper", "Indeedee-F", "Annihilape", "Sneasler", "Ursaluna"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Indeedee-F is the non-negotiable partner, providing both Psychic Terrain and Follow-Me to let Braviary fire off un-interrupted Expanding Forces; the two form the core of the team and are almost always brought together.  Poliwrath offers rain-boosted Water STAB to dent Steel-types that still live Expanding Force, while Pelipper sets rain to weaken Fire-type moves aimed at Braviary and gives Braviary a 100 % accurate Hurricane option.  Annihilape and Sneasler give the team physical pressure, removing special walls like Blissey and Ting-Lu that can stall out terrain turns, and both appreciate Braviary’s ability to nuke Corviknight and Toxapex.  Ursaluna provides a slow pivot that can absorb status and retaliate with Guts-boosted Facade, freeing Braviary from having to Tera early to survive burns.  In general the team wants at least one redirector (Indeedee-F) and one speed-control option—either rain + Swift Swim or Tailwind from Pelipper or a teammate like Talonflame—to let Braviary attack before it is KO’d.</OUTPUT>

input:
Write a detailed 'recommended_sets' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Braviary-Hisui": {"Abilities": {"tintedlens": 22.1437787830113, "sheerforce": 0.8283155843426424, "keeneye": 0.04445680534448482}, "Items": {"lifeorb": 0.5102275219456661, "twistedspoon": 0.21913038077687383, "choicescarf": 0.21170050448812738}, "Spreads": {"Quiet:100/156/0/252/0/0": 0.42379719948060773, "Timid:4/0/0/252/0/252": 0.19209583097722074, "Timid:0/0/0/252/4/252": 0.17483175302828183}, "Moves": ["expandingforce", "dazzlinggleam", "protect", "esperwing"], "Tera Types": {"psychic": 0.9409969891873518}, "Teammates": ["Poliwrath", "Pelipper", "Indeedee-F", "Annihilape", "Sneasler", "Ursaluna"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Standard Terrain Breaker: Life Orb, Tinted Lens, Tera Psychic, Quiet 100/156/0/252/0/0 — Expanding Force / Dazzling Gleam / Protect / Esper Wing.  This set maximizes spread damage while keeping Braviary slower than Indeedee-F for guaranteed terrain.  Scarf Cleaner: Choice Scarf, Tinted Lens, Tera Psychic, Timid 4/0/0/252/0/252 — Expanding Force / Dazzling Gleam / Esper Wing / Protect.  Outspeeds +1 Kingambit and Chien-Pao, turning Braviary into a late-game cleaner once resists are chipped.  Spoon Pivot: Twisted Spoon, Tinted Lens, Tera Psychic, Quiet 0/0/0/252/4/252 — Expanding Force / Dazzling Gleam / Protect / Esper Wing.  For teams that require longevity over raw power, trades Life Orb recoil for a still-relevant 20 % boost and lets Braviary act as a pivot throughout the match.</OUTPUT>

input:
Generate the 'weaknesses_and_counters' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Braviary-Hisui": {"Abilities": {"tintedlens": 22.1437787830113, "sheerforce": 0.8283155843426424, "keeneye": 0.04445680534448482}, "Items": {"lifeorb": 0.5102275219456661, "twistedspoon": 0.21913038077687383, "choicescarf": 0.21170050448812738}, "Spreads": {"Quiet:100/156/0/252/0/0": 0.42379719948060773, "Timid:4/0/0/252/0/252": 0.19209583097722074, "Timid:0/0/0/252/4/252": 0.17483175302828183}, "Moves": ["expandingforce", "dazzlinggleam", "protect", "esperwing"], "Tera Types": {"psychic": 0.9409969891873518}, "Teammates": ["Poliwrath", "Pelipper", "Indeedee-F", "Annihilape", "Sneasler", "Ursaluna"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Priority users that ignore terrain—Basculegion’s Aqua Jet, Chien-Pao’s Sucker Punch, Kingambit’s Sucker Punch—can KO Braviary before it moves if it has taken any chip from Life Orb or spread damage.  Faster Choice Scarf users such as Gholdengo, Iron Valiant and Chien-Pao naturally outspeed even Timid Braviary and OHKO with their respective STABs.  Opposing terrain—especially Grassy Terrain from Rillaboom—halves Expanding Force’s power and removes its spread property, neutering Braviary’s main niche.  Wide Guard users like Aegislash and Arcanine completely blank Expanding Force and force Braviary into the weaker Esper Wing, while bulky resists that can survive one hit—Toxapex, Garganacl, Corviknight—can retaliate with status or setup.  Finally, because Braviary is reliant on Indeedee-F for terrain, double-targeting Indeedee-F on turn one leaves Braviary with a mere 90 BP single-target move and easy setup fodder for the opponent.</OUTPUT>

input:
Write a detailed 'sample_team_concept' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Braviary-Hisui": {"Abilities": {"tintedlens": 22.1437787830113, "sheerforce": 0.8283155843426424, "keeneye": 0.04445680534448482}, "Items": {"lifeorb": 0.5102275219456661, "twistedspoon": 0.21913038077687383, "choicescarf": 0.21170050448812738}, "Spreads": {"Quiet:100/156/0/252/0/0": 0.42379719948060773, "Timid:4/0/0/252/0/252": 0.19209583097722074, "Timid:0/0/0/252/4/252": 0.17483175302828183}, "Moves": ["expandingforce", "dazzlinggleam", "protect", "esperwing"], "Tera Types": {"psychic": 0.9409969891873518}, "Teammates": ["Poliwrath", "Pelipper", "Indeedee-F", "Annihilape", "Sneasler", "Ursaluna"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Indeedee-F @ Focus Sash — Psychic / Follow Me / Helping Hand / Protect — 252 HP / 252 Def / 4 SpD Bold.  Braviary-Hisui @ Life Orb — set above.  Poliwrath @ Choice Band — Waterfall / Close Combat / Ice Punch / Protect — 252 HP / 252 Atk Adamant under Pelipper rain.  Pelipper @ Damp Rock — Rain Dance / Hurricane / Tailwind / Protect — 252 HP / 252 SpA Modest.  Annihilape @ Leftovers — Rage Fist / Drain Punch / Bulk Up / Protect — 252 HP / 252 Atk Impish.  Sneasler @ Focus Sash — Dire Claw / Gunk Shot / Sucker Punch / Protect — 252 Atk / 252 Spe Jolly.  The idea is to lead Indeedee + Braviary in most matchups, fire off terrain-boosted Expanding Forces, then pivot to rain or Tailwind depending on the opponent’s composition.  Poliwrath and Annihilape handle special walls, Sneasler provides speed control and status, and Pelipper gives rain to nerf Fire moves while letting Braviary run accurate Hurricanes if needed.</OUTPUT>

input:
Write the 'short_summary' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Mamoswine": {"Abilities": {"oblivious": 19.9480645217077, "thickfat": 0.8799436146352873, "snowcloak": 0.2477842185426729}, "Items": {"focussash": 0.7162974165796374}, "Spreads": {"Adamant:0/252/0/0/4/252": 0.46347383676921294, "Adamant:4/252/0/0/0/252": 0.16228588684179157, "Jolly:0/252/0/0/4/252": 0.1766245816161146}, "Moves": ["earthquake", "iceshard", "iciclecrash", "protect"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.3399656910947974, "ground": 0.4867664265918878}, "Teammates": ["Ninetales-Alola", "Sneasler", "Incineroar", "Garganacl", "Talonflame", "Salamence"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Mamoswine is a hyper-offensive Ice/Ground breaker that leverages its dual STAB and Ice Shard priority to rip through common Dragon, Flying, and Steel cores in VGC. With Focus Sash guaranteeing at least one attack, it functions as both a lead and a mid-game cleaner, compressing speed control and raw power into a single slot. Its ability spread shows a clear preference for Oblivious to block Intimidate and Taunt, while Tera Ghost lets it dodge Fake Out and Extreme Speed and Tera Ground turns Earthquake into a nuke that ignores Raging Bolt’s Assault Vest and Togekiss’s Babiri Berry.</OUTPUT>

input:
Create the 'full_analysis' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Mamoswine": {"Abilities": {"oblivious": 19.9480645217077, "thickfat": 0.8799436146352873, "snowcloak": 0.2477842185426729}, "Items": {"focussash": 0.7162974165796374}, "Spreads": {"Adamant:0/252/0/0/4/252": 0.46347383676921294, "Adamant:4/252/0/0/0/252": 0.16228588684179157, "Jolly:0/252/0/0/4/252": 0.1766245816161146}, "Moves": ["earthquake", "iceshard", "iciclecrash", "protect"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.3399656910947974, "ground": 0.4867664265918878}, "Teammates": ["Ninetales-Alola", "Sneasler", "Incineroar", "Garganacl", "Talonflame", "Salamence"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Mamoswine’s value in the current format stems from its unique ability to OHKO the tier’s most ubiquitous threats—Torkoal, Landorus-T, and the rising Garchomp—while carrying Ice Shard to pick off faster Dragons and weakened Tailwind sweepers. 252 Atk Adamant is the dominant spread, maximizing the damage on Earthquake and Icicle Crash; the 4 EVs in SpD guarantee that uninvested Sylveon Hyper Voice never breaks Sash, while the remaining 252 in Spe lets it outrun uninvested base 70s such as Breloom and Bisharp. Focus Sash is near-mandatory: it turns Mamoswine into a guaranteed two-for-one trade piece that can tank a hit from Iron Boulder or Chien-Pao and retaliate for the KO. Tera Ghost is preferred on more offensive structures because it invalidates opposing priority and allows Mamoswine to stay on the field against Indeedee’s Follow Me or Kingambit’s Sucker Punch, while Tera Ground is chosen on teams that want to nuke through Rotom-W and Gholdengo without fearing Wide Guard. Thick Fat is theoretically useful to survive Heat Wave and Moonblast, but usage stats show players overwhelmingly favor Oblivious to preserve Attack stage against Incineroar and Landorus-T, two of the most common intimidators in the format.</OUTPUT>

input:
Draft the 'matchup_overview' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Mamoswine": {"Abilities": {"oblivious": 19.9480645217077, "thickfat": 0.8799436146352873, "snowcloak": 0.2477842185426729}, "Items": {"focussash": 0.7162974165796374}, "Spreads": {"Adamant:0/252/0/0/4/252": 0.46347383676921294, "Adamant:4/252/0/0/0/252": 0.16228588684179157, "Jolly:0/252/0/0/4/252": 0.1766245816161146}, "Moves": ["earthquake", "iceshard", "iciclecrash", "protect"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.3399656910947974, "ground": 0.4867664265918878}, "Teammates": ["Ninetales-Alola", "Sneasler", "Incineroar", "Garganacl", "Talonflame", "Salamence"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Mamoswine bullies Sun, Sand, and Dragon-centric archetypes, ripping through Torkoal, Lilligant, Garchomp, and Salamence with STAB moves that are either super-effective or boosted by tera. Against Rain it trades evenly: it OHKOs Pelipper with Icicle Crash but must respect Barraskewda’s Liquidation and Iron Bundle’s Freeze-Dry. Into Trick Room it functions as a hard stop to Mimikyu and Rhyperior, though it hates Dusclops’ Bulldoze speed control and Hatterene’s Mystical Fire. Versus hyper-offense, Ice Shard picks off weakened Flutter Mane, Chien-Pao, and Dragonite, but it folds to priority from Bisharp and Kingambit if Sash is broken. Into stall or bulky Balance cores—Garganacl, Corviknight, Dondozo—it struggles to break through without Tera Ground, and must rely on teammates to wear down or trap these walls.</OUTPUT>

input:
Write a detailed 'role_description' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Mamoswine": {"Abilities": {"oblivious": 19.9480645217077, "thickfat": 0.8799436146352873, "snowcloak": 0.2477842185426729}, "Items": {"focussash": 0.7162974165796374}, "Spreads": {"Adamant:0/252/0/0/4/252": 0.46347383676921294, "Adamant:4/252/0/0/0/252": 0.16228588684179157, "Jolly:0/252/0/0/4/252": 0.1766245816161146}, "Moves": ["earthquake", "iceshard", "iciclecrash", "protect"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.3399656910947974, "ground": 0.4867664265918878}, "Teammates": ["Ninetales-Alola", "Sneasler", "Incineroar", "Garganacl", "Talonflame", "Salamence"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Mamoswine is a lead or mid-game wallbreaker that compresses speed control and priority into one slot. It is typically brought in Game-1 to immediately pressure the opponent’s terrain or weather setter, force a Tera early, or trade one-for-one with a restricted legendary. After Sash is consumed it pivots to a cleanup role, using Ice Shard to finish off faster threats once spread damage or Intimidate support has been applied. Because it both benefits from and provides spread damage, it fits equally on hyper-offense teams that aim to end games by turn-5 and on balance squads that need a reliable answer to Garchomp and Landorus-T without dedicating two slots to Ice and Ground coverage.</OUTPUT>

input:
Write a detailed 'synergy_breakdown' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Mamoswine": {"Abilities": {"oblivious": 19.9480645217077, "thickfat": 0.8799436146352873, "snowcloak": 0.2477842185426729}, "Items": {"focussash": 0.7162974165796374}, "Spreads": {"Adamant:0/252/0/0/4/252": 0.46347383676921294, "Adamant:4/252/0/0/0/252": 0.16228588684179157, "Jolly:0/252/0/0/4/252": 0.1766245816161146}, "Moves": ["earthquake", "iceshard", "iciclecrash", "protect"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.3399656910947974, "ground": 0.4867664265918878}, "Teammates": ["Ninetales-Alola", "Sneasler", "Incineroar", "Garganacl", "Talonflame", "Salamence"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Alolan-Ninetales is the most common partner, providing Aurora Veil to guarantee Mamoswine survives two hits even after Sash is broken, while Mamoswine in return removes opposing Torkoal and Heatran that threaten the hail core. Sneasler forms a brutal offensive core: both share Earthquake immunity and Sneasler’s Poison Jab covers Fairy-types that wall Mamoswine, while Icicle Crash deletes Landorus-T for Sneasler. Incineroar is the classic pivot: Intimidate and Parting Shot create setup chances, and Mamoswine punishes the Fire-types that roast Incineroar. Garganacl shores up the matchup into Fairy and Water teams by soaking Moonblast and Surf, while Mamoswine removes opposing Steel-types that block Salt Cure. Talonflame supplies Tailwind and Quick Guard so Mamoswine can forego speed EVs and run bulk, and Salamence provides a second Ground-immune Intimidate cycle that lets Mamoswine stay on the field longer.</OUTPUT>

<DATA>{"Mamoswine": {"Abilities": {"oblivious": 19.9480645217077, "thickfat": 0.8799436146352873, "snowcloak": 0.2477842185426729}, "Items": {"focussash": 0.7162974165796374}, "Spreads": {"Adamant:0/252/0/0/4/252": 0.46347383676921294, "Adamant:4/252/0/0/0/252": 0.16228588684179157, "Jolly:0/252/0/0/4/252": 0.1766245816161146}, "Moves": ["earthquake", "iceshard", "iciclecrash", "protect"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.3399656910947974, "ground": 0.4867664265918878}, "Teammates": ["Ninetales-Alola", "Sneasler", "Incineroar", "Garganacl", "Talonflame", "Salamence"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Standard Lead: Mamoswine @ Focus Sash, Ability: Oblivious, Level 50, EVs: 252 Atk / 4 SpD / 252 Spe, Adamant Nature – Earthquake – Ice Shard – Icicle Crash – Protect. Tera Type: Ghost. This set guarantees a fast, powerful opener that can trade with virtually any restricted legendary or Paradox threat. Alternative Tailwind Cleaner: Mamoswine @ Focus Sash, Ability: Oblivious, Level 50, EVs: 252 Atk / 4 Def / 252 Spe, Jolly Nature – Earthquake – Ice Shard – Icicle Crash – Tera Blast (Ground). Tera Type: Ground. Jolly lets you outrun positive-natured base 100s such as Salamence and Victini under Tailwind, while Tera Blast Ground becomes a 150 BP spread move that ignores Wide Guard and hits Rotom-W and Gholdengo for neutral damage.</OUTPUT>

input:
Create the 'weaknesses_and_counters' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Mamoswine": {"Abilities": {"oblivious": 19.9480645217077, "thickfat": 0.8799436146352873, "snowcloak": 0.2477842185426729}, "Items": {"focussash": 0.7162974165796374}, "Spreads": {"Adamant:0/252/0/0/4/252": 0.46347383676921294, "Adamant:4/252/0/0/0/252": 0.16228588684179157, "Jolly:0/252/0/0/4/252": 0.1766245816161146}, "Moves": ["earthquake", "iceshard", "iciclecrash", "protect"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.3399656910947974, "ground": 0.4867664265918878}, "Teammates": ["Ninetales-Alola", "Sneasler", "Incineroar", "Garganacl", "Talonflame", "Salamence"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Priority and spread damage are the easiest ways to break Mamoswine: Fake Out from Meowscarada or Iron Hands followed by any multi-target move will consume Sash, after which any faster attacker can finish it off. Water-types with priority—Iron Bundle’s Freeze-Dry, Barraskewda’s Liquidation—OHKO through Sash if Rain is up. Intimidate cycles from Landorus-T and Incineroar force Mamoswine to Tera or switch, and because it is almost always choice-locked into a spread move, Wide Guard from Tapu Fini or Aegislash completely blanks it. Bulky resists such as Rotom-W, Corviknight, and Dondozo can stomach even a Tera-boosted Earthquake and recover or set up in its face. Finally, status—especially burn from Heat Wave or Will-O-Wisp—renders Mamoswine useless, as it has no recovery outside of ally Pollen Puff or Veil-boosted healing.</OUTPUT>

Write the 'sample_team_concept' section using only the data given.

<DATA>{"Mamoswine": {"Abilities": {"oblivious": 19.9480645217077, "thickfat": 0.8799436146352873, "snowcloak": 0.2477842185426729}, "Items": {"focussash": 0.7162974165796374}, "Spreads": {"Adamant:0/252/0/0/4/252": 0.46347383676921294, "Adamant:4/252/0/0/0/252": 0.16228588684179157, "Jolly:0/252/0/0/4/252": 0.1766245816161146}, "Moves": ["earthquake", "iceshard", "iciclecrash", "protect"], "Tera Types": {"ghost": 0.3399656910947974, "ground": 0.4867664265918878}, "Teammates": ["Ninetales-Alola", "Sneasler", "Incineroar", "Garganacl", "Talonflame", "Salamence"]}}</DATA>
output: <OUTPUT>Aurora Veil Hyper-Offense: Alolan-Ninetales (Veil + Snow Warning), Mamoswine (Sash), Sneasler (Poison Gem), Incineroar (Assault Vest), Garganacl (Leftovers), Talonflame (Sharp Beak). Lead Ninetales + Mamoswine: Veil turn-1, Blizzard + Earthquake spread damage. Behind Veil, Mamoswine survives two hits and can trade with any restricted. Sneasler cleans late-game under Veil, Incineroar pivots and removes Intimidate, Garganacl walls Fairies and Waters, and Talonflame provides Tailwind and Quick Guard to let Mamoswine run Adamant without fearing opposing priority. The team aims to end games by turn-6 while maintaining enough defensive backbone to outlast opposing Tailwind or Trick Room.</OUTPUT>
